title: GORBACHEV GAINS, EXPERTS IN U.S. SAY
description: American experts on the Soviet Union said today's shake-up in the Kremlin dramatically strengthened the hand of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, without giving him a complete triumph over his opponents.

title: London Transit Passes Are Worth Imitating
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents; Two Proteins Stimulate Production of Cartilage
description: The Collagen Corporation, a biotechnology company in Palo Alto, Calif., received patents this week on two proteins that stimulate the body to produce cartilage.

title: Sanofi's U.S. Unit To Add Kallestad
description: Sanofi Inc. said it was acquiring Kallestad Diagnostics, based in Austin, Tex., for $72 million from Erbamont N.V., a Netherland Antilles company with headquarters in Stamford, Conn. Sanofi, the New York-based subsidiary of the French drug company Sanofi S.A., said it expects Kallestad to work closely with Diagnostics Pasteur, Sanofi's joint venture with Pasteur Institute, the French research center.

title: Article 925388 -- No Title
description: Though still large by any count, the amount of new capital that American corporations raised on Wall Street has shrunk by nearly $24 billion so far this year. That represents a 10.3 percent decline, to $205.7 billion, compared with $229.2 billion for the same nine-month period last year, according to IDD Information Services, which tracks new issues.

title: Coping With Selling Your Car
description: Fall is new-car time, and a shopper faces many decisions, not the least of which is whether to trade the old one in or sell it privately. It's less trouble to let the dealer take your car and apply its worth to the price of a new one. But it's important to know when to trade and how to get a fair price if you sell it yourself.

title: Delchamps Rejects Latest A.&P. Bid
description: Delchamps Inc., a regional supermarket chain in the South, rejected the latest unsolicited overture from the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company because the takeover would not be good for it. A.&P. offered to bid as much as $30 a share, Delchamps said, but the $210 million deal was ''not in the company's best interest.'' A.&P. has made offers in the past. After the announcement, shares of Delchamps dropped $2.375, to $23.50, on the over-the-counter market. James Wood, chairman and chief executive at A.&P., the nation's fourth-largest supermarket chain, said he had been disappointed by the response. Delchamps operates 101 supermarkets in Alabama, Florida, Mississippi and Louisiana.

title: Corrections
description: A cast listing on Sept. 23 with a theater review of the Young Playwrights Festival misidentified the group presenting the festival. It is the Foundation of the Dramatists Guild; Nancy Quinn is the producing director.

title: Graf Adds Gold to Her Grand '88 Record
description: When she arrived in Seoul more than two weeks ago, an Olympic gold medal appeared out of reach for Steffi Graf. The pursuit of the Grand Slam had taken its toll, the mental and physical exhaustion having drained her of her customary resolve, eliminating the bounce in her step as she moves at that familiar, no-nonsense pace around a court. Perhaps she was trying to accomplish too much in one year, after all.

title: Leading Indicators Improve
description: The Government's chief economic predictor climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in August and also did slightly better in June and July than previously thought, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Review/Music; Yo-Yo Ma In Dvorak Cello Piece
description: Those who heard Yo-Yo Ma play the Dvorak Cello Concerto with the Boston Symphony at Tanglewood a few months ago would have found an interesting comparison in Thursday's New York Philharmonic performance at Avery Fisher Hall. The performance at Tanglewood had the same deeply moving impulses but without the hurtling, breakneck enthusiasm that on Thursday almost extinguished the music with its passion. So strong is Mr. Ma's technique and so genuine his feelings that we never experience vulgarity. If there is excess - and here I believe there was - the listener is still charmed by a musician with so much sincerity to give.

title: College Football; Duke (4-0) Offering Plenty to Celebrate
description: This is a year to celebrate football at Duke: the 100th anniversary of the first intercollegiate game in North Carolina, in which Trinity College beat North Carolina, 16-0. And it is the 50th anniversary of the Iron Dukes, a team that was undefeated, untied and unscored upon in the 1938 regular season but lost to Southern California, 7-3, in the Rose Bowl.

title: A Plea: Say It Ain't So, Ben
description: A crowd gathered outside Ben Johnson's house today as it has every day since the athlete returned from Seoul, South Korea, on Tuesday. Many of those gathered here are sustained by the hope that Canada's fallen athletic idol will somehow explain his drug-testing disaster in Seoul in a way that will make it possible for the nation to believe in him again.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-6, 28

title: Bengals Undecided
description: The Cincinnati Bengals had not decided yesterday on the roster status of Daryl Smith and Emanuel King, who have just returned from a 30-day suspension by the National Football League for substance abuse. Smith, a cornerback, and King, a linebacker, practiced with the team Thursday, but King hurt his lower back, suffering a muscle pull or a spasm. A decision on the pair's status for the game tomorrow against the Los Angeles Raiders will not be made until today, according to Mike Brown, the assistant general manager. (AP)

title: Quayle Gives Up Chance to Study For Bentsen Debate to Discuss It
description: Dan Quayle did not want to do his homework.

title: Beijing Strengthens Centralized Control Of Fitful Economy
description: After moving steadily away from traditional socialism for the last decade, China will strengthen centralized control of the country's economy, Prime Minister Li Peng declared today.

title: Parking Rules
description: The annual Pulaski Day Parade will begin at noon tomorrow at 26th Street and Fifth Avenue, marching north to 52d Street, then east to Third Avenue. Because of the Jewish holidays of Shemini Atzereth and Simhath Torah, which conclude the harvest festival of Succoth, alternate-side parking will be suspended in New York City on Monday and Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Korean Arts Seek to Share Olympic Spotlight
description: Kim Myong Hwan, master of the Korean narrative opera known as pansori, strives to preserve an ancient art. Suh Se Ok, one of South Korea's foremost contemporary painters, seeks to make the old new, reinterpreting the traditional discipline of calligraphy in modern abstract paintings.

title: Italy's Proposed Budget
description: The Italian Cabinet has approved a proposed 1989 budget that would put the deficit at 117.25 trillion lire, or $83.7 billion. The plan, which Parliament must approve, was adopted late Thursday.

title: Ford Heirs Fight, and Entertain, in Seeking Estate
description: So determined was Henry Ford 2d to exert influence from the grave that he left instructions on what emotions his friends and family should feel at his funeral.

title: 3.6% Inflation in Europe
description: Inflation in the European Community stood at 3.6 percent in August, unchanged from a year ago but up slightly from July, a report released today said. The community's statistical agency, Eurostat, said the consumer price index rose 3.4 percent in July. It said the average inflation rate for the first six months of the year was 2.6 percent.

title: In Wisconsin's North Woods Towns, The '88 Campaign Is Hardly Remote
description: The candidates spend almost all of their time in the cities, but Presidential elections are won and lost in the villages and hamlets of America as well as its metropolises.

title: Seoul Youths Hurl Firebombs Into U.S. Army Headquarters
description: Protesters hurled firebombs into an American Army station today in a mounting anti-American campaign, the American and South Korean authorities said. No damage was reported. The attack followed an outburst of anti-United States sentiment spurred by incidents involving American athletes and the news media during the Summer Olympics. The Games, which began Sept. 17, end Sunday.

title: A New Party Structure In the Soviet Union
description: The personnel shake-up in the Soviet Communist Party yesterday was accompanied by a revamping of the party structure. Six Central Committee commissions were created, all headed by secretaries of the Central Committee, to supplant 22 departments as the party's main administrative apparatus. Political power continues to be centered in the Central Committee and the Politburo, where all important decisions are made. Communist Party Congress

title: California Sues to Force Tobacco Warnings
description: The State Attorney General today sued 25 manufacturers and eight retailers of noncigarette tobacco products in an effort to force compliance with a state law requiring warnings to consumers whenever they are exposed to cancer-causing chemicals.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in Weekend yesterday about the Hell's Kitchen Park Art Show in the Clinton area of Manhattan gave an incorrect location. The show takes place tomorrow on 10th Avenue between 47th and 48th Streets.

title: Don't Privatize Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Walker Status Uncertain
description: The playing status of Wesley Walker of the Jets, who caught four touchdown passes in the last two games, was termed questionable yesterday for the game tomorrow against the Kansas City Chiefs at Giants Stadium.

title: Wynton Marsalis
description: Wynton Marsalis, the trumpeter, is leading a quintet tonight and tomorrow at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: From Cassavetes, a Theater Tempest
description: ''Opening Night'' could be described as John Cassavetes' version of ''All About Eve'' if Mr. Cassavetes were the sort to be strongly influenced by the work of other film makers, which he most certainly is not. Like the characters who ramble amiably through this sprawling, funny, emotionally raw 1978 film -which has a style that's of a piece with the director's other long films of the 1970's, among them ''Minnie and Moskowitz'' (1971), ''A Woman Under the Influence'' (1974) and ''The Killing of a Chinese Bookie'' (1976) - Mr. Cassavetes displays a remarkably free-spirited point of view.

title: An Aging Gromyko Takes Last Bow
description: Public life ends for Andrei Andreyevich Gromyko this weekend, 49 years after it began.

title: No Tomorrows for Yankees
description: The race finally ended for the Yankees tonight. They could have kept themselves alive for another day, but instead they bowed quietly from contention in the American League East on a night when the Boston Red Sox lost again but won the division title.

title: Glassblowing Display
description: A Greek glassblower, Thomas Halvatzis, will discuss and demonstrate his craft at the Hellenic Cultural Center of the Greek Archdiocese, 27-09 Crescent Street, in Astoria, Queens, on at 5 P.M. tomorrow. Admission is free. The program is in Greek and English. Information: (718) 626-7896 or (718) 204-0108.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In the name of liberation from male 'domination,' women must not appropriate to themselves male characteristics contrary to their own feminine originality.'' - Pope John Paul II. [ 6:2. ]

title: What to Do With Old Items
description: If you have a worn-out appliance that may contain PCB's, you should take these precautions:

title: SHAKE-UP VIEWED AS GIVING GORBACHEV STRONGER HAND
description: In a major Kremlin shake-up that appears to strengthen the position of Mikhail S. Gorbachev as party leader, the Communist Party Central Committee dismissed three veteran members of the Politburo today.

title: Patents; An Implant To Correct Child's Bite
description: AN orthodontist in Livingston, N.J., has developed a removable dental implant that can correct a child's overbite or underbite without the need for wire braces and plastic bands.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 10.

title: Olympic Highlights
description: TENNIS: Steffi Graf of West Germany, who won the Grand Slam, took the gold medal in the women's singles, beating Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina, 6-3, 6-3. TRACK AND FIELD: The United States won the men's 1,600 and the women's 400 relays. The men equaled the world record of 2:56.16. Evelyn Ashford overtook Marlies Gohr of East Germany in the final 100 meters to give the United States the gold medal in the 400. Paula Ivan of Rumania won the women's 1,500. BOXING: Ray Mercer was one of two Americans to win gold medals. He knocked out Hyun Man Baik of South Korea at 2:16 of the first round in the heavyweight final. Articles begin on page 47.

title: Disdain and Praise For Vatican Letter
description: Prominent American Catholic women were divided today in their initial reaction to the Vatican document on their role.

title: New Texas Savings Rescue
description: Six more deeply troubled savings institutions in Texas were rescued late today in two transactions that the Federal Home Loan Bank Board estimated would require $2.5 billion in Federal assistance in the next decade.

title: 3 Networks Agree to Run Condom Ads in AIDS Fight
description: The three major television networks have agreed to broadcast a public-service advertising campaign that promotes the use of condoms to prevent the spread of acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: Shortening Links In the Retail Chain
description: It started as a concept about four years ago, an attempt to stem the flow of apparel imports. It exists today in its infancy, with a handful of retailers, clothing manufacturers and fabric and fiber producers participating. And in five more years, consumers across the nation may reap the benefits of this revolution in the way apparel and general merchandise are made available for sale.

title: Miss Martineau Wed To John Landreth Jr.
description: At St. Mary Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church in Beverly, Mass., Jeanne Lisa Martineau, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roland William Martineau of Beverly, was married yesterday to John Thompson Landreth Jr., a son of Mr. Landreth of Fallbrook, Calif., and Betty Wright Landreth of New York. The Rev. Richard G. Johnson performed the ceremony.

title: Japan's Surplus for August
description: Japan's current-account surplus, the main measure of its trade in goods and services, continued to drop in August on heavy spending by Japanese tourists abroad, the Government announced today.

title: Jury, Citing Mother's Condition, Absolves Her in 2 Babies' Deaths
description: A former pediatric nurse who admitted suffocating two of her newborn babies and trying to kill the third was absolved yesterday by a jury, which said that her actions were a result of a mental disease or defect.

title: Storm Victims Fault Mexico's Aid Effort
description: When a luxury apartment building collapsed here earlier this week, killing five people, the residents of this industrial center of three million shuddered. Just as Hurricane Gilbert was receding into memory, it had once again struck a blow at a city struggling to recuperate from the storm's disastrous passage across northeastern Mexico two weeks ago.

title: Spring Bulbs: Time Is Now
description: Although there were reminders to send in mail orders for bulbs, many gardeners dallied. Now, it may be too late to order by mail, since most brokers forward their orders to the Netherlands, and the bulbs are then shipped directly to the gardener. Other brokers fill bulb orders from their own warehouses, and they report that supplies are getting low.

title: Red Sox Lose, 4-2, But Win Division
description: The Boston Red Sox backed into the American League East championship tonight when the Milwaukee Brewers were eliminated by the Oakland Athletics, 7-1.

title: Excerpts From John Paul II's Apostolic Letter 'On the Dignity of Women'
description: Following are excerpts from ''Mulieris Dignitatem'' (''On the Dignity of Women''), an apostolic letter issued yesterday by Pope John Paul II, as issued in English by the Vatican:

title: Your Money; How Charities Can Help Donors
description: CHARITY can begin at home - in fact, with the home. An individual can realize both economic and tax benefits by donating a home or other assets while continuing to enjoy their use. Neal Myerberg, chief executive officer for endowments and bequests of the U.J.A.-Federation, calls this strategy ''donor-centered giving.''

title: Gibraltar Killings of 3 in I.R.A. Ruled Lawful
description: A jury decided today that British commandos acted within the law when they shot and killed three unarmed Irish Republican Army guerrillas in this British colony last March.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Official Convicted
description: A State Representative who is president of the Alabama National Association for the Advancement of Colored People was convicted of extortion today for taking $10,000 in exchange for trying to obtain the early release of a convicted murderer from prison.

title: KEY RATES
2d Round for Iran and Iraq; Peace Talks Resume at U.N.
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar opened a second round of peace negotiations between Iran and Iraq today, presenting a new package of proposals to the two countries' Foreign Ministers, United Nations officials said.

title: Judge Rebuffs U.S. for Blocking Convoy of Aid to Nicaragua
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that the United States Customs Service should not have stopped a convoy of veterans trying to take food, medication and motor vehicles to Nicaragua last June.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Ex-Rutgers Player Enters Guilty Plea
description: A former star football player for Rutgers University has pleaded guilty to charges of death by automobile and admitted that he was intoxicated behind the wheel before a crash that caused the death of a teammate and injured another passenger.

title: About New York; Pull the Cord If You've Heard This One, Now...
description: The doors were closing on the IRT Broadway express when the short, frayed man in the stained blue T-shirt rushed in and began shouting at the passengers. For a tense instant it seemed that yet another crazy person was claiming the attention of strangers, so some on the uptown train buried themselves in newpapers or stared fixedly at ads for hemorrhoid relief.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: Formica Told Of Bid Proposal
description: The Formica Corporation, a leading manufacturer and distributor of decorative surfacing products, said yesterday that it had received a letter from Malcolm I. Glazer, a Rochester investor, that he was prepared to make a $20-a-share bid to acquire the shares of Formica that he does not already own. The purchase price would be $201 million. Formica, which is based in

title: Daisy Systems Seeks Cadnetix
description: The Daisy Systems Corporation began a tender offer at $8 a share in cash to acquire control of the Cadnetix Corporation. Daisy, a maker of computer-aided engineering systems, based in Mountain View, Calif., already holds 7.6 percent of Cadnetix, a Boulder. Colo., company that makes similar systems. Daisy's offer is for 11.7 million shares, which would give it 51 percent of Cadnetix.

title: Indicted Haitian Colonel Is Ousted
description: An army colonel indicted in the United States on drug charges was retired late tonight, the state-run television reported. The unexpected removal of the officer, Col. Jean-Claude Paul, came after several days of speculation that he might become the armed forces chief in Haiti's new military regime.

title: Leo Schloss, Educator And Accountant, 74
description: Leo Schloss, an educator and accountant, died Wednesday at University Hospital in Stony Brook, L.I., after a long illness. He was 74 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: The War on Dirty Water
description: House committees have wisely adopted the proposal by the Governors of New York and New Jersey that fines for ocean sludge dumping after 1993 go into an environmental project trust fund. The measure warrants approval by the House and by Senate conferees.

title: In Vietnam, the Birth of the Credibility Gap
description: LEAD: Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, did not succeed in silencing Lieut.

title: Pilots Accused Of Lying to U.S. In Applications
description: Twenty-seven pilots, including at least two who fly large airliners, were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Florida yesterday on charges of denying past drug- or alcohol-related convictions in applying for pilot medical certificates.

title: The Breath of the Black Dragon in Russia and China
description: Just a year ago, I inspected the scene of the great Black Dragon forest fire, which broke out in May 1987 along the Amur River, the boundary between eastern Siberia and Chinese Manchuria. As I walked in the world left by the fire -every tree, every bush, tuft of grass turned to black - I felt I was walking in a prehistoric forest of a long dead planet.

title: Close-Up: Wrestling
description: An Olympic Original Wrestling was a major part of the ancient Olympic Games, with competitors oiling their bodies and wrestling on sand. It has evolved into two disciplines: Greco-Roman and freestyle. In Greco-Roman, wrestlers cannot use holds below the waist or use their legs for holds; freestyle allows most standard techniques. Matches consist of two three-minute rounds and are decided by either pinning an opponents shoulders to the mat; by gaining a 12-point lead, or by scoring more points. The Scoring System 1 PointFor a takedown (taking an opponent to the mat and controling him) or a reversal (moving from a bottom position to an uppermost position and applying control. 2 PointsFor holding an opponent's shoulder at less than a 90-degree angle to the mat or executing a lift and throw for a near fall. 3 PointsFor taking an opponent immediatley to his back. 4 PointsFor a grand amplitude (sending an opponent, with feet flying, onto his back. 5 PointsFor a grander amplitude (a more impressive grand amplitude). Keep an Eye on . . . Bruce Baumgartner, U.S.; Kaszlo Klauz, Hungary, in the 130-kilogram freestyle.

title: Health Officials Order Shutdown Of Gay Cinema
description: New York City yesterday closed an East Side cinema that caters to homosexuals, accusing the establishment of flagrantly violating state and city regulations against unsafe sexual activities and of operating an AIDS-virus breeding ground for profit.

title: '84 Winner In Marathon
description: Carlos Lopes of Portugal, who won the 1984 gold medal in an Olympic-record time of 2 hours 9 minutes 21 seconds, will defend his title in the men's marathon on Sunday afternoon. (The marathon will begin at midnight Saturday Eastern daylight time.) Students, upset that police have refused to release one of their leaders, have threatened to disrupt the race. But security officials say that the runners will not be impeded.

title: BRIEFS
description: * All Nippon Airways Co., Tokyo, bought the San Francisco Meridien Hotel for about $100 million from Tag-Arcon-Pioneer Ltd.

title: Trauma of Miscarriage
description: To the Editor:

title: New Members of Politburo
description: Vadim A. Medvedev

title: Israeli Troops and Settler Fire on Arabs, Killing 2
description: Two Palestinians were killed today as Israeli troops and a Jewish settler opened fire on stone-throwing youths in Hebron, in the West Bank, Palestinians said.

title: Some Treasury Bond Yields Dip Below 9%
description: Some Treasury bond yields fell below 9 percent yesterday as oil prices fell to their lowest level in more than two years.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the growing volume of submissions, however, we regret that we can no longer return articles unless they are accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope.

title: AFGHAN SAYS PACT ON WAR IS IGNORED
description: The Afghan Foreign Minister today accused Pakistan and the United States of violating or failing to carry out the Geneva accords on the Afghan war.

title: Mary Hall Oxholm, Lobbyist, 86
description: Mary Hall Oxholm, a former trustee of the Maternity Center Association in Manhattan, died of heart failure Wednesday at the Valley Care Nursing Home in Sewickley, Pa. She was 86 years old and lived in Gibsonia, Pa.

title: Nets Guard Banned for Drugs
description: Duane Eddy Washington, who was hoping to win a spot in the backcourt with the Nets, was banned by the National Basketball Association yesterday after having tested positive for cocaine use.

title: Lincoln Hudson, 72, Advertising Executive
description: Lincoln Theodore Hudson, a former advertising executive, died of an undisclosed illness Monday at Jackson Park Hospital and Medical Center in Chicago. He was 72 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: U.S. Vows to Take Contras Off Honduras's Hands
description: President Reagan has assured Honduras that the United States ''accepts responsibility'' for thousands of Nicaraguan guerrillas living in Honduran camps, and American officials are considering admitting some of them to the United States as refugees, Administration officials said today.

title: BRIDGE
description: Many American tournaments now prohibit smoking. But at some tournaments in Europe, it is compulsory - in the evenings. This is a traditional demand for the use of ''le smoking,'' the dinner jacket, and the call for decorum was heard at the Staten Bank Pairs Tournament, an all-expert event, played in the Hague in late January.

title: An Inner Circle of 100 or So Carried Out A-Bombing of Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: Bentsen, Before Teachers, Seeks Support 'for Future of Schools'
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen urged teachers and parents today to support the Democratic national candidates because ''the future of our schools is on the line on Nov. 8.''

title: The Politburo: Another Shake-Up
description: The Soviet Communist Party shake-up yesterday removed some familiar names from the ruling Politburo and added new ones. Here is the current Politburo line-up, including full, voting members and candidate (nonvoting) members, as well as the members who were removed yesterday. The Government functions of some members may change today after a session of the Supreme Soviet, the legislative body. * Came to office, or was promoted after Mr. Gorbachev came to power in 1985. ** Named yesterday Full members Mikhail S. Gorbachev, party leader * Viktor M. Chebrikov, K.G.B. chief; party secretary and head of party commission on legal policy * Yegor K. Ligachev, party secretary and head of commission on agriculture ** Vadim A. Medvedev, party secretary and head of commission on ideology * Viktor P. Nikonov, party secretary * Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, Prime Minister Vladimir V. Shcherbitsky, Ukrainian party leader * Eduard A. Shevardnadze, Foreign Minister * Nikolai N. Sylunkov, party secretary and head of commission on social and economic policy Vitaly I. Vorotnikov, Premier of Russian Republic * Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, party secretary and head of commission on international affairs * Lev N. Zaikov, Moscow party leader Candidate members ** Aleksandra P. Biryukova, former party secretary ** Anatoly I. Lukyanov, former party secretary * Yuri D. Maslyukov, director of State Planning Commission (Gosplan) * Georgi P. Razumovsky, party secretary and head of commission on party building and personnel * Yuri F. Solovyev, Leningrad party leader * Nikolai V. Talyzin, First Deputy Prime Minister ** Aleksandr V. Vlasov, Interior Minister * Dmitri T. Yazov, Defense Minister Who's out Andrei A. Gromyko, President Mikhail S. Solomentsev, former Party Control Commission chief Pyotr N. Demichev, first Vice President (Candidate member) Vladimir I. Dolgikh, former national party secretary for industry (Candidate member)

title: Joaquin Roces Is Dead; Aquino Backer Was 75
description: Joaquin Roces, a prominent newspaper publisher who persuaded Corazon C. Aquino to run for President, died today of complications from cancer, his doctor announced. He was 75 years old.

title: POPE, DEFENDING WOMEN'S DIGNITY, SETS NARROW ROLE
description: Pope John Paul II today issued a major document on the status of women that forcefully defends their dignity but narrowly defines their role in the Roman Catholic Church and in secular society.

title: Patents; Snake Venom Is Said To Curb Some Cancers
description: Venom from the Western diamondback rattlesnake may prove useful in the war on cancer.

title: 'Well Paid' Hardly Describes Airline Employees
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Sluman Takes Charge: Jeff Sluman shot a 3-under-par 67 yesterday to hold off Leonard Thompson for a 2-shot lead after the second round of the $400,000 Southern Open in Columbus, Ga. Sluman, who captured the PGA championship six weeks ago, shot an opening-round 63 and was at 130. Thompson matched the 63 yesterday with a string of eight birdies for a 132 after a first-round 69. Lance Ten Broeck, Mike Hulbert and Dan Forsman were another stroke back at 133.(AP) Yancey Shares Lead: Bert Yancey, a rookie on the Senior Tour, broke 70 for the first time this year and tied for the first-round lead yesterday in the $300,000 Seniors Challenge in Roswell, Ga. Yancey, who qualified for the tour when he passed his 50th birthday in August, shot a four-under-par 68 that included 32 on the back nine. He shared the lead with Dick Hendrickson and George Lanning.(AP) TENNIS Wilander Gains Semifinals: Top-seeded Mats Wilander of Sweden advanced to the semifinals of the $123,400 Sicilian Championships by beating unseeded Claudio Panatta of Italy, 4-6, 6-2, 6-3, yesterday in Palermo, Italy. Also gaining semifinal berths were third-seeded Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina and fourth-seeded Thomas Muster of Austria. Perez-Roldan defeated a countryman, Horacio de la Pena, 6-4, 7-6. Muster eliminated Thierry Tulasne of France, 6-4, 6-4.(AP) Wilkison Scores Upset: Unseeded Tim Wilkison upset fifth-seeded David Pate, 2-6, 7-6, 6-3, yesterday and gained a quarterfinal berth in the $425,000 Transamerica Open in San Francisco. Other players advancing were Danie Visser, a South African who lives in Palm Desert, Calif., and Johan Kriek, a South African who lives in Naples, Fla. Visser defeated Richard Matuszewski of Hopewell Junction, N.Y., 6-1, 7-6. Matuszewski, a qualifier, had upset top-seeded Aaron Krickstein, of Grosse Point, Mich., in the first round. Kriek beat Jim Grabb of Tucson, Ariz., 6-1, 6-2.(AP) HOCKEY Whalers Beat Rangers: Brennan Turcotte, a rookie center, scored all three Ranger goals in a 5-3 loss to the Hartford Whalers last night at Madison Square Garden. Turcotte scored all his goals against Mike Liut after the Whalers took a 1-0 lead on Sylvain Cote's first of two goals. Cote broke a 3-3 tie with his second goal against Mike Richter after goals by John Anderson and Joel Quenneville early in the third period. Cote's winner came with 1:28 left before Brent Peterson's empty-net goal gave the Whalers their fourth victory (4-3-1) in the exhibition season and put the Rangers' record at 4-4-1. The teams will meet again tomorrow night in Hartford. Nordiques Rout Islanders: Michel Goulet scored two power-play goals in the third period as the Quebec Nordiques beat the Islanders, 8-3, Thursday night in Quebec City. Goulet scored on a slap shot from the left face-off circle only five seconds after Bryan Trottier was sent off for high-sticking early in the third period. Goulet got his second goal on a wrist shot from the slot. Peter Stastny scored twice for Quebec in the second period, once on a breakaway and then on a deflection after a wrist shot by Jari Gronstrand. Ken Morrow, Greg Gilbert and Rich Kromm scored for the Islanders. Mario Gosselin made 32 saves for Quebec, and the Islander goaltender, Billy Smith, stopped 20 shots. The loss left both teams with 3-5 exhibition records.(AP)

title: Ted Tiller Dies at 75; Actor and Playwright
description: Ted Tiller, an actor, director, playwright and producer, died of complications resulting from brain surgery Sept. 24 at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 75 years old.

title: How Ordinary Details Can Suddenly Derail a Life
description: These Things Happen By Marian Thurm 173 pages. Poseidon Press. $15.95.

title: Inflation Rises in Brazil
description: Brazil's monthly inflation rate increased again in September, according to official figures released Thursday. The Brazilian Geography and Statistics Institute said the consumer price index rose by 24 percent in September, on a base month of March 1986.

title: Falcons to Stay
description: Rankin Smith, owner of the Atlanta Falcons, said today that he would keep the team in Atlanta and try to build a new open-air stadium by 1991. Smith told a news conference he was uncertain whether a proposed domed stadium could be built before the team's lease with Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium expires after the 1990 season.

title: Busy Racing Weekend
description: New York's most promising 2-year-old colts and fillies will run in separate Grade I races that highlight a busy weekend of stakes action.

title: Miles Smeeton, Conservationist, 83
description: Miles Smeeton, a yachtsman and conservationist, died of a stroke Wednesday in Calgary, Alberta. He was 83 years old and lived in the Calgary area.

title: Russian-English High School Is Closed Because of Back Taxes
description: St. Sergius High School, a small Manhattan secondary school that trained its students in the values and culture of pre-revolutionary Russia, was closed by Federal agents Thursday for failure to pay almost $90,000 in back taxes.

title: Stocks Mixed as Dow Falls by 6.40
description: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday after a late wave of selling reversed a broad advance.

title: Christie Can Keep Medal
description: Linford Christie, a sprinter from Britain who tested positive for a banned substance after he finished fourth in the 200 meters, will be allowed to stay in the Olympics and keep a silver medal won in an earlier race, Olympic officials said today.

title: Highs and Lows For U.S. Squad
description: The United States team won an Olympic gold medal Friday in a track and field event it did not expect to win. It lost a chance for a gold medal in an event it was sure it would win.

title: Drexel Files an Appeal To Oust Judge in Case
description: Going over the head of a Federal judge, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. yesterday filed an appeal seeking to remove the judge from a broad securities fraud action brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Education page on Sept. 21 about the teaching of liberal arts studies misstated curriculum changes at Duke University. The faculty voted to increase the overall number of credits needed for graduation. It did not add more books and courses on non-Western European thought to the core liberal arts curriculum.

title: USG to Get $400 Million For Masonite
description: As part of a sweeping restructuring, the USG Corporation today agreed to sell the Masonite Corporation to the International Paper Company for about $400 million in cash.

title: Changes Big and Small Aid Flight, Experts Say
description: As is suggested by the impressive flight of the space shuttle Discovery so far, America's winged spaceship and its vast complex of supporting facilities have undergone improvements that have left them stronger and better tested than ever before, space experts said today.

title: Two Gold Medals and One Silver for U.S. Relays
description: American sprinters and Kenyan distance runners turned the last full day of Olympic track and field into a celebration.

title: Martha E. Combs Wed To Steven E. Wheeler
description: Martha E. Combs, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore H. Combs of Marblehead, Mass., and North Conway, N.H., was married yesterday to Steven E. Wheeler, a son of June B. Wheeler of Richmond and Floyd E. Wheeler of Remlik, Va. Henry M. Kidder Jr., a justice of the peace of Oyster Bay, L.I., performed the ceremony at the Creek Club in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL NATIONAL BASKETBALL ASSOCIATION - Suspended Duane Washington, guard, of the Nets for two years for violating the substance-abuse agreement. GOLDEN STATE (NBA) - Signed Joseph Hutt, Biola College, and John Starks, guards. KNICKS (NBA) - Signed Rod Strickland, guard, to a multiyear contract. FOOTBALL SAN FRANCISCO (NFC) - Announced the retirement of Wes Chandler, wide receiver. TAMPA BAY (NFC) - Placed Ervin Randle, linebacker, on injured reserve. Signed Ray Isom, defensive back. HOCKEY EDMONTON (NHL) - Signed Reed Larson, defenseman. COLLEGES FAIRLEIGH DICKINSON - Named Hallie Cohen assistant athletic director; Tom Bonerbo sports-information director and women's basketball coach; Wayne Braxton lacrosse coach, assistant football coach and director of athletic facilities, and Glenn Gottshalk defensive line coach. PACE - Named Jim Morgan assistant women's basketball coach.

title: Judge Permits DNA Evidence
description: A Queens judge ruled yesterday that prosecutors may present DNA-matching evidence to the jury in a sexual-assault case, the first time such evidence linking a defendant with a crime is to be used in New York State.

title: PAKISTAN GUNMEN KILL AT LEAST 60
description: At least 60 people were killed and 150 were wounded today when gunmen opened fire on crowds in Hyderabad, a city in southern Pakistan, doctors and witnesses said.

title: Teacher Rejects Calls to Testify In Attack Case
description: A New York City teacher refused to testify yesterday at a disciplinary hearing against a student accused of beating him, and officials at the Board of Education and the teachers union are worried that efforts to control school violence may have suffered a setback.

title: Who Would Try to Teach in New York City?
description: To the Editor:

title: North and 2 Others Lose Bid to Overturn Iran-Contra Charges
description: A Federal appeals court today refused to dismiss the conspiracy indictments against Oliver L. North, John M. Poindexter and Albert Hakim, three of the defendants in the Iran-contra case.

title: Ex-Developer Convicted of Fraud
description: A former millionaire and developer has been found guilty of defrauding banks in an attempt to get loans to keep his failing company afloat.

title: INSIDE
description: Resettling the Contras

title: Despite Some Trouble, Shuttle Is Doing 'Great'
description: Flight controllers said today that the space shuttle Discovery was performing well, despite two pesky equipment malfunctions, as the astronauts spent their first full day in orbit operating scientific experiments, checking out all systems and enjoying the views of the Earth below.

title: Film Festival; An Avant-Garde Clash Of Two Kinds of Laws
description: In Warren Sonbert's ''Honor and Obey,'' soldiers march in formation, a tiger stalks through the snow, religious processions wind through streets, and palm trees wave in a tropical breeze. As brightly colored images of authority figures blend into scenes of cocktail parties, this 22-minute silent film flows along with the grace of a musical score built on complex tensions hidden among the notes. ''Whose authority will you obey?'' the film seems to ask, as it deftly avoids simple-minded juxtapositions. Instead, we see a melange of images so full of geography - Notre Dame Cathedral, the Sydney Opera House, Fifth Avenue - that the work mocks the idea of any specific setting. Sooner or later, social and natural laws meet and probably clash, Mr. Sonbert suggests, but in this scenario of discrete images all is apparent harmony.

title: Soviet Player Sought
description: Stan Kasten, the president of the Atlanta Hawks, is in Seoul, South Korea, attempting to sign one of the stars of the gold medal men's basketball team from the Soviet Union.

title: Dukakis Tailors Speech To Fit Texans' Interests
description: On a crisp fall day when the pungent air on the Isom farm rang with Texas oratory, the Governor of Massachusetts rolled up the sleeves of his blue button-down shirt for the kind of campaigning his supporters say he must use to catch up with Vice President Bush in this pivotal state.

title: Review/Theater; Flesh vs. Spirit in a Play by Claudel
description: Paul Claudel entered the French diplomatic service in 1890 and almost immediately began to write poetry and plays, the entire body of which dwelt on religious or, more specifically, Roman Catholic themes, and the central thread of which was the emptiness of a life that is devoid of spirituality. By the time of his death in 1955, Claudel was an Immortal in the Academie Francaise and was regarded as one of the leading Catholic writers of his time.

title: Corrections
description: The TV Notes column on Thursday referred incorrectly to the scheduling of the next debate between the Presidential candidates. The date has not been determined; it is expected to be Oct. 13 or 14.

title: Youth Testifies Emotionally On Role in Fatal Stabbing
description: A 17-year-old youth, testifying in his own defense at his murder trial in Queens yesterday, broke down in tears as he described events leading to the fatal stabbing of another youth in a confrontation between two groups of teen-agers.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Backs Eastern on Layoffs of 4,000
description: Eastern Airlines won another victory yesterday in its fight to cut its work force and operations when a Federal appeals court upheld its right to lay off 4,000 employees.

title: Leiter Left Unprotected
description: Ken Leiter, the 27-year-old defenseman who appeared in 51 games for the Islanders last season, was the most prominent player left unprotected by the three metropolitan area National Hockey League teams for the waiver draft Monday.

title: Third World Debt Won't Wait
description: The third world debt crisis is six years old. The debt has grown by 50 percent. Many of the debtor nations are in desperate shape; none are out of the woods. And contrary to everyone's best interests, more capital flows from debtors to the industrial world than the other way around. Increasingly, this distress threatens struggling democracies. The problem cries out for solution.

title: Real Welfare Reform, at Last
description: Barbara Harris, a high school dropout and divorced mother, has been on welfare since 1982. She fits perfectly the profile of the long-term welfare recipient. But as a participant in an education program for welfare mothers, she also embodies the hopes of welfare's reformers. ''I have two girls,'' she says. ''I want to be able to say, I bought this, I bought that. I can take care of myself.''

title: Patents; Translating Words With Multiple Meanings
description: Sharp Kabushiki Kaisha, the Japanese parent company of the Sharp Electronics Corporation, has designed a language-translation machine that helps sort out the nuances of words with multiple meanings.

title: Appliances No One Wants
description: When Mary G. Smith moved into her home in Darby Township near Philadelphia in May, she discovered that the previous owner had left an air-conditioner in the garage.

title: Doubling-Up by Tenants Costing New York Millions
description: The New York City Housing Authority has run up $62 million in operating deficits in the last three years, and housing officials say that one of the prime causes of the shortfalls - overcrowding - is also one of the key reasons why they have not sought additional Federal aid to cover the debts.

title: Balance Is the Eastern Look
description: The East has several strong teams this season in Division I-A, and Boston College and Pitt are among them. They meet at noon today in the Boston College's Alumni Stadium.

title: Shielded From Demonstrations, Bush Assails Dukakis on Crime
description: Vice President Bush blitzed the Northeast corridor today, hammering Michael S. Dukakis on crime while his campaign aides played an intense game of keep away with anti-Bush demonstrators.

title: U.S. Denies Violating Panama Canal Treaty
description: The Reagan Administration today disputed a Panamanian charge that a shipment of weapons to American military forces in Latin America constituted a violation of the Panama Canal Treaties.

title: Mercer Stops South Korean
description: It is one of boxing's oldest lines. Asked how he will avert a possible hometown decision, a boxer will hold up his fists and say, ''These are my judges.'' And today Ray Mercer's fists were the judges in a first-round knockout of Hyun Man Baik of South Korea, thereby defusing any chance of a home-nation influence on the Olympic heavyweight gold medal.

title: Congress Meets Spending Bill Deadline
description: With precisely one minute to spare before a midnight deadline, Congress accomplished late Friday what it has been unable to do for more than a decade, complete all 13 annual spending bills before the start of the new fiscal year.

title: Review/Jazz; A Quintet That Crosses Category Lines
description: Ever unpredictable, Muhal Richard Abrams turned to synthesizer from his usual instrument, the piano, for half of his concert Thursday night at Greenwich House. As the prime mover in the Association for the Advancement of Creative Music, formed in Chicago in the 1960's, Mr. Abrams spurred a generation of jazz musicians to forge eclectic styles that drew on history but weren't captives of the past. His own music has a restless intelligence, probing various idioms but never getting typecast.

title: JUDGE FINDS F.B.I. IS DISCRIMINATORY
description: A Federal district judge in Texas found today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had discriminated against Hispanic agents in promotions and working conditions and that the bureau's internal procedure for dealing with discrimination complaints was ''bankrupt.''

title: Oil Price Off On Fears of More Supply
description: Oil prices dropped sharply yesterday as traders reacted to the prospect of continuing overproduction by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, especially Saudi Arabia.

title: Stieb Loses Gem Again
description: Dave Stieb lost a no-hit bid with two out in the ninth inning for the second consecutive start, finishing with another one-hitter tonight as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Baltimore Orioles, 4-0.

title: Kitty Dukakis Urging All-Out War on AIDS
description: Kitty Dukakis said today that AIDS was ''one of the greatest struggles of our century,'' but she also said the deadly affliction presented an opportunity to ''demonstrate to the world the compassion and resourcefulness that is the true American character.''

title: Poaching in Kenya Destabilizes Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: American Wrestlers Lose Two Matches and One Protest
description: Mark Schultz of the United States, the world champion and 1984 Olympic gold medal winner, lost two matches and his chance of winning a freestyle wrestling medal today.

title: Last Jump Goes Ritter's Way
description: Red Oak is a small town in Texas, 30 miles south of Dallas. When Louise Ritter grew up there, it had only 1,000 residents, and she says she knew all of them.

title: 7 Companies Settle Toxic Dumping Lawsuit
description: Seven companies have agreed to pay a total of $12.5 million to New York City to settle a lawsuit involving the dumping of hazardous industrial and chemical wastes at five city landfills.

title: From Dacron To Men's Pants
description: The Du Pont Company is a leader in the Quick Response approach. The company's director of business development for fibers, Peter N. Buttenhoff, offers this example:

title: Famous Hotels in Inter-Continental Chain
description: While President Francois Mitterrand of France chatted over coffee with Gov. Michael S. Dukakis at the Inter-Continental Hotel in Manhattan on Thursday, an elusive Japanese billionaire took a quick look around the lobby, proclaimed it ''very nice,'' slipped out the hotel door - and left town.

title: Koch Plan Would Tax Illegal Drugs
description: In an unusual move against drug-traffickers, the Koch administration said yesterday that it would seek a law requiring people possessing illegal drugs to buy city-issued tax stamps.

title: Review/Cabaret; Campy Female Impersonations by Charles Pierce
description: Ranging from the high drama of B. D. Wong's performance in ''M. Butterfly'' to the goofy comic antics of Monty Python, from Jim Bailey's eerily accurate re-creations of legendary stars to the Ridiculous Theatrical Company's stylized gender-bending, female impersonation has almost as many genres as the theater itself. None are more enduring than the sort of campy-smutty drag act in which a bewigged and flashily gowned male performer offers dragon-lady caricatures of show-business legends.

title: Patents; A Method to Detect Some Forms of Cancer
description: A. Arthur Gottlieb, founder of Imreg Inc. in New Orleans, won patent approval for a method of detecting leukemia, Hodgkin's disease and other cancers affecting lymph cells.

title: Article 923888 -- No Title
description: Because the ''multiple sufferings'' of a physically abused young girl had particularly touched welfare officials, the New York City Board of Estimate yesterday approved spending $156,000 to send her to a rehabilitation school in New Hampshire.

title: Doctors Go on Strike at a Financially Troubled Bronx Clinic
description: Doctors at a financially troubled South Bronx clinic rejected a final contract offer yesterday and went on strike, leaving the clinic to be run by temporary replacements.

title: Cone Tops Cards For 20th Victory
description: David Cone, who began the season looking for work in the Mets' bullpen, ended it last night by pitching himself into the baseball record books.

title: Coffee Pact Is Seen as Near
description: The two-week conference of the 74-nation International Coffee Organization is approaching an agreement here on 1989 export quotas, the chief Brazilian negotiator, Jorio Dauster, said today.

title: Review/Dance; A Roland Petit Ballet to Satie's Music
description: Roland Petit played a major role in the rebirth of French ballet after World War II, and it was natural that he be represented in the three-week dance festival here devoted to four centuries of dance in France.

title: A Perestroika Generation
description: Today's sweeping changes in the Kremlin give Mikhail S. Gorbachev's leadership a fresh sense of momentum at a time when his domestic programs have been flagging badly, when public discontent about the anemic economy is rising, and when troops patrol restive Soviet republics.

title: Sports of The Times; The Many Faces of America
description: ''All right, gang, let's get it together for the closing ceremony tomorrow. First you put your left foot out, then your right. It's called marching. Please don't carry ''Hi, Mom'' banners and NBC signs. You can't begin to know how childish that looked in the opening ceremony.''

title: Severe Accidents at Nuclear Plant Were Kept Secret Up to 31 Years
description: The Savannah River Plant in South Carolina, an enormous Government complex that produces fuel for the nation's nuclear weapons, has experienced a number of serious reactor accidents that have been kept secret from the public for as long as 31 years, two Congressional committees disclosed today.

title: Unrealistic Hopes In Ratings Game
description: HERE was the scene across the United States yesterday: It's Friday morning, and people are rubbing their eyes, steeling themselves for the final workday of the week. Perhaps a brisk wake-up from a little early-morning television? Turn it on and . . . yes, it's . . . water polo. Not only that, there's also, hold on now, rhythmic gymnastics. Energized, America went to work. Viewers might have forgotten that these obscure sports are as much a part of the Olympic Games as track and field and basketball. And the reason is that we really haven't seen the Summer Games plainly for 12 years.

title: French Watercolors In Lenox Hill Benefit
description: ''Velins du Roi,'' an exhibition of watercolors from the collections of Louis XIV, Napoleon and others, will open with a benefit for a community organization from 6 to 9 P.M. Tuesday at the W. Graham Arader 3d Gallery, 29 East 72d Street.

title: August Home Sales Up 0.1%; Three-Month Pace Strong
description: Sales of new single-family homes, bolstered by a surge in the Middle West, rose slightly in August to continue the strongest sales pace since early 1987.

title: Japanese Purchase Of Inter-Continental Set for $2.27 Billion
description: In one of Japan's largest purchases of an American company, the Seibu Saison Group, a retailing giant that is one of the country's most aggressive conglomerates, acquired the luxury Inter-Continental Hotel chain today for $2.27 billion.

title: Motion in Noriega Case Does Not Refer to Bush
description: Court papers seeking to dismiss a drug indictment against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian leader, do not include references to Vice President Bush or his Presidential campaign, as prosecutors had feared they would.

title: Joachim Prinz, Leader in Protests For Civil-Rights Causes, Dies at 86
description: Dr. Joachim Prinz, a former president of the American Jewish Congress and a leader in civil-rights causes, died of a heart attack yesterday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J. He was 86 years old and lived in Brookside, N.J.

title: THE GAMES AT A GLANCE
description: Track and Field Evelyn Ashford, in what could well have been her farewell appearance, said took the baton with 100 meters left and said goodbye to her competition. Ashford, after an awkward handoff from Florence Griffth Joyner, brought home the gold for the U.S. with an inspired anchor leg in the women's 400-meter dash. For Griffth Joyner, it was her third gold medal of the Games. The men, meanwhile, had trouble passing the baton, thereby leaving themselves with the messy matter of placing the blame. The American men's 400-meter relay team, the favorite for the gold medal, was disqualified from competition Friday after officials ruled it had passed the baton out of the zone in a heat. The incident was the latest bit of trouble for a team already amply beset by controversy. Internal disputes had left the team without cohesion or comaraderie. ''I think it was doomed from the start,'' said Russ Rogers, the team's coach. It certainly was after 300 meters Friday when Calvin Smith and Lee McNeill failed to complete their pass. The Kenyans continued to run with such grace and without the slightest trace of a grimace that it all appeared effortless. Simply walking from these Games, though, may be another matter. They have got a lot of gold to haul back home. Peter Rono of Kenya won the men's 1,500 meters and his countryman, John Ngugi, minutes later captured the 5,000 meters to finish a day when Kenyans took three gold medals in distance events. Julius Kariuki earlier won the 3,000-meter steeplechase. Paul Ereng of Kenya got everything started for Kenya when he won the 800 meter at the beginning of the week. Paula Ivan of Rumania set an Olympic record when she won the women's 1,500 meters in 3 minutes 53.96 seconds. Boxing Ray Mercer stood on the top level of the medal platform and took a bite of his gold medal, testing its authenticity. In a traditional ceremony, it was a symbolic moment, one that captured in many ways the identity of the entire American team. As unorthodox as they were unheralded, they are a brash and loose collection of fighters who are not above having a little fun during the biggest moments of their lives. And they are - like the medal Mercer put between his teeth - for real. Mercer stopped Baik Hun Han of South Korea in the the final of the heavyweight division. Kennedy McKinney of the United States took a gold in the 119-pound class, gaining a 5-0 decision over Alexandar Hristov of Bulgaria. Michael Carbajal lost a tough decision at 106 pounds and had to settle for the silver. Three more American boxers were scheduled to fight for gold today. Tennis When Steffi Graf and Gabriela Sabatini both qualified for the final in women's singles, people joked that Seoul had merely turned out to be like any other stop on the women's tour. And the match turned out to be like most others between the two. Graf, who earlier this month completed the Grand Slam, completed he bid for the gold medal in straight sets, 6-3, 6-3.

title: Chip Maker Cuts Back: 'The Boom Is Over'
description: In another signal that demand may be softening for computers and semiconductors, Advanced Micro Devices Inc. said today that it anticipated flat sales for its semiconductors in the coming quarters and would lay off 1,400 workers.

title: Fishing for the Ones That Got Away
description: Amid the tumultuous growth sweeping across this island, Bobo Wang is the kind of entrepreneur that the Government is hoping will become a symbol of the new Taiwan.

title: Letter: On Human Rights; In Turkey, Democracy Is a Fact
description: To the Editor:

title: Board Delays Vote On S.I. Navy Port
description: The New York City Board of Estimate agreed to a Koch administration request early yesterday and postponed indefinitely a vote on the city's plan for handling a possible nuclear accident at the Navy port being built on Staten Island.

title: Turning On the Heat
description: The key to a trouble-free start-up of heating equipment is maintenance. This is work for the experts, and homeowners who schedule annual checkups of their oil furnaces have the right idea. The service should include a check of burner, nozzles, contact points, filters and automatic controls. Gas burners are easier to maintain; a homeowner can change filters annually, though professional cleaning of the furnace and venting will eventually be needed.

title: Homeless Families Create a Community
description: When Albert Dempsky learned his family was to be moved from a welfare motel in Willingboro where it had lived for two years to the grounds of a state psychiatric hospital here, he said he would sleep in the woods before he would go.

title: Rose Re-signs
description: Pete Rose, who was criticized by the team's owner, Marge Schott, as Cincinnati headed toward its fourth consecutive second-place finish, signed a two-year contract yesterday to continue as manager of the Reds.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: BIRD-EYES. By Madelyn Arnold. (Seal Press, Paper, $8.95.) Despite its title, this novel is nothing so comfortable as a bird's-eye view of its setting - women's D ward of the Eastern Central State Hospital, an institution whose location is deliberately vague. Instead, the reader is placed right behind the eyes of a 16-year-old named Latisha as she watches the ghoulish parade of arbitrarily cruel nurses and doctors as well as patients who shriek and stare beneath the relentless glare of the fluorescent lights.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: IF ONLY WE COULD DRIVE LIKE THIS FOREVER. By Elisabeth Harvor. (Penguin, Paper, $6.95.) What Elisabeth Harvor's second book of stories lacks in invention, it makes up for in perseverance. All but one of the tales (six short stories, one novella) focus on youngish, middle-class Canadian women who are currently - or will imminently or eventually be - divorced mothers.

title: Floods Destroying Island Way of Life
description: ONCE, before the devastating floodwaters came, it was an island renowned for its quiet serenity: a dozen clapboard summer cottages dotted its two-and-a-half-acre expanse. Ducks roamed its Pompton River shoreline, and residents fished from their yards. But times change, say residents here, just like the tidewaters, and there came a chance to move.

title: The Day the Nation's Cash Pipeline Almost Ran Dry
description: LAST Oct. 20, a day after the nation's financial markets collapsed, Goldman, Sachs & Company and Kidder, Peabody & Company found themselves short of cash by a total of more than $1.5 billion, according to people close to the firms.

title: BOOZE AND MUSES
description: Westbrook Pegler dropped into Harry's New York Bar in Paris one afternoon in 1936 and decided that the joint's best days were over. ''The old saloon,'' he wrote, ''smells of dead cigars, beer and the past.'' Peg had a way with words, but it seems not to have occurred to him that at Harry's they sold the past and booze was just a sideline.

title: Italy 'Snipers' In Legislature May Now Fall
description: Everybody here calls them the snipers. They are several dozen members of Parliament from the governing coalition who publicly pledge allegiance to the Government but who in reality are busily trying to ambush it to settle personal or factional scores.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our home is covered with aluminum siding in a blue-gray color. Last Halloween, children threw eggs against one corner, leaving a stain. There are also some white stains from bird droppings. The rains have lightened these stains considerably, but I have been reluctant to scrub the siding, as I have heard this might strip it down to the bare metal. Is it all right to use a hose and some mild cleaner to try and remove these stains, or will this tend to strip off the finish?

title: Louganis Wins Award for Spirit
description: Greg Louganis, who defended his Olympic title in the men's 10-meter platform and 3-meter springboard diving events in the Seoul Games, was named today as the winner of the United States Olympic Committee spirit award.

title: Arson Blamed in Dallas Fire That Was Fatal to 5 Children
description: The fire that killed five children in a house whose back doors and windows were blocked by burglar bars was deliberately set, fire officials say.

title: Omaha, Debate Site, to Aid Homeless
description: Shelter has been offered to several hundred homeless people during the Vice-Presidential debate here next week, but city officials denied that the idea was to push homeless people out of sight.

title: A Public School Seeks Equality in Uniformity
description: A NEW uniform requirement to take effect in a New Haven public school tomorrow promises to quell arguments and fistfights among students over who has the designer T-shirts or the most expensive brand-name sneakers.

title: Examining Pop Music in the Greater Sociological Context
description: In a cozy, neo-Gothic seminar room overlooking the Yale College campus, with sunlight streaming through the leaded-glass windows, Robert Walser of the University of Minnesota was delivering a paper to a gathering of colleagues. Bearded, bespectacled, dressed in tweed jacket and bluejeans, he could almost have been a liberal-arts Everyman as he discussed ''coherent systems of signification'' and ''specific affective experiences.'' Almost. Because he had an electric guitar slung over his shoulder, plugged in to an amplifier, and the topic of his paper was ''Bon Jovi's Alloy: Discursive Fusion in Top 40,'' a close textual and musical analysis of Bon Jovi's ''Livin' on a Prayer,'' with live examples. ''The song constructs a transcendent new context for Tommy and Gina,'' Mr. Walser said, referring to the song's characters. ''And for us.'' Chapters Worldwide

title: Tough Choices to Make for Power Without Pollution
description: SENATOR Timothy E. Wirth quotes the old Mark Twain line and takes it seriously: ''Everybody talks about the weather but nobody does anything about it.''

title: Sergeant Is Shot During Kidnapping Investigation
description: A police sergeant was shot and wounded yesterday when he stopped a car in Queens during a kidnapping investigation, the authorities said.

title: Loved Ones
description: GATES OF HEAVEN Produced, directed and edited by Errol Morris. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 85 minutes. $79.95.

title: POSTINGS: Hotel in Transition; Nurses' Station
description: Irving Schatz scored a real estate coup three years ago when WNET/Channel 13 paid him $15 million to buy its offices and studios on the lower nine floors of the Henry Hudson Hotel. Mr. Schatz scored again in August when St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center agreed to lease the remaining portion of the 26-story building. But the most recent success has saddened him, he said. St. Luke's 40-year lease of 500 rooms comes with an option to buy. If exercised, it would mean the end of Mr. Schatz's 20-year stewardship of the West 57th Street behemoth.

title:
GARDENING;
Flavor of Apples Takes Time to Mature
description: LEAD: FALL and apples seem to have been made for each other. What could be more pleasant than a stroll through the woods under a bright blue sky on a chilly October day while munching on a spicy apple and enjoying the brilliant colors of fall foliage?

title: RUNNING AWAY
description: THE TRAGEDY OF APRIL SAVINO'S abbreviated life is that when she finally found a home it was among the homeless - on the benches and in the bleak recesses of Grand Central Terminal. There, at last, she felt needed and even, by the strange code of the streets, respected.

title: Playland Cites Rise in Visitors
description: LEAD: DESPITE the continuing investigation into charges of financial and administrative mismanagement at Playland, this season the county-owned amusement park in Rye recorded its highest attendance since 1982.

title: CHOSEN AND GIVEN
description: Robin Marantz Henig's article ''Chosen and Given'' (Body and Mind, Sept. 11) dismays adoptive parents like ourselves because it makes adoption sound fatally flawed, or, at least, statistically risky. It stigmatizes without offering much in the way of helpful suggestions, and adopted children already suffer enough from prejudices about adoption. JOHN AND RANDI FOREMAN Millbrook, N.Y.

title: Ethnic Rioting in Karachi Kills 46 and Injures 50
description: Ethnic riots erupted today in Pakistan's largest city, Karachi, in reaction to a massacre Friday in nearby Hyderabad. Forty-six were killed in today's riots and 50 were injured. The reported death toll in the two days of clashes was at least 208.

title: Testing The Odds And Gravity
description: A composer writing his first opera is like a parachutist stepping out of a plane for the first time. Even if the thing opens, survival still hangs by a few threads. All the leaper prays for at the moment is the chance - maybe - to try again. With his ''Rasputin,'' which was given its world premiere the other night by the New York City Opera, Jay Reise took just such a step into the unknown and, though the landing was bumpy, the 38-year-old composer may take solace in the realization that successful first operas are about as common as jumpers who survive when the chute fails.

title: Austrian Beds
description: To the Editor: Twelve hours before discovering ''How to Sleep in an Austrian Bed'' I had been reading the following:

title: THE ALPHA ZULU
description: AN APPETITE FOR POWER Buthelezi's Inkatha and South Africa. By Gerhard Mare and Georgina Hamilton. Illustrated. 261 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. $35.

title: DATA BANK: October 2, 1988
On Guard Against the Inedible
description: LEAD: LAST week was fairly quiet at the state's Food Chemistry Laboratory here, where scientists investigate the disturbing and sometimes dangerous debris that can find its way into foods.

title: Miss Gray Wed to L. J. Buck
description: Elizabeth Christian Gray, a daughter of Mrs. Thomas Owen Moore Jr. of Winston-Salem, N.C., and the late Bowman Gray 3d, was married yesterday to Leonard Jerome Buck, the son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Austin Buck of Bernardsville, N.J. The Rev. Dudley Colhoun and the Rev. Harold Barrett, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Winston-Salem.

title: Government in the Soviet Union: Gorbachev's Proposal for Change
description: THE CURRENT STRUCTURE Supreme Soviet of the U.S.S.R.

title: Teaching as a Therapeutic Activity
description: THERE was nothing subtle about the pain. It started in the middle of my chest and made its unsettling way up into my neck, momentarily forming a knot before moving into my face. There, the pain just below my eyes reminded me of the pain I got as a kid when I ate lemon ice too fast.

title: Winning the Future
description: 'The progress of the European Community is one of the promising world trends. By creating a community of 12 European democracies, we won a victory over national egoism, power-political thinking and prejudice. It is the greatest and finest victory in the history of Europe. It has not cost one single human life, yet it is winning us the future.' - Hans-Dietrich Genscher, Foreign Minister of West Germany, addressing the United Nations General Assembly.

title: 12-Hospital Study Cites Preventable Deaths
description: As many as one-quarter of the deaths of patients being treated for heart ailments, stroke and pneumonia in 12 hospitals could have been prevented, but doctors committed a variety of errors, a new study indicates, Doctors improperly treated patients complaining of chest pain, prescribed the wrong kind of antibiotics for pneumonia and misdiagnosed stroke, according to the study published today in The Annals of Internal Medicine. The study, conducted by the Rand Corporation, a research organization, was based on a review of 182 patients who died in 1985 at hospitals owned by American Medical International of Beverly Hills, Calif., a chain of 115 hospitals in the United States and abroad.

title: A Sampling of Autumn Lectures
description: LEAD: AS the days grow shorter and summer's preoccupation with outdoor activity fades, many Westchester residents are ready to turn their energy to more cerebral pursuits. The crisp days of autumn may inspire us to explore again some topic last tackled in college, or investigate subjects that hold the promise of avocational pleasure.

title: Julianna Witkowski Marries William M. Brewster
description: Julianna Susan Witkowski, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon J. Witkowski of Detroit, was married yesterday to William Mark Brewster, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rodney L. Brewster of Seattle. The Rev. Arthur McGovern performed the ceremony at St. Paul's on the Lake Roman Catholic Church in Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich.

title: When Shuttle Is Visible
description: The space shuttle Discovery will be visible in some parts of the United States as it moves across the sky in the rest of its four-day flight. Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said the craft would appear as a fast-moving point of bright light. Because the shuttle's path is south of the United States, the shuttle will not be visible from northern cities. Here is a list of cities for which NASA has calculated sighting possibilities, including the sighting day, the time, duration, elevation in degrees above the horizon (90 degrees is straight overhead), direction of travel and local time: AUSTIN, Tex. - Monday, 6:41 A.M.; 3 minutes; 13 degrees; from south to southeast. HONOLULU - Sunday, 6:59 A.M.; 6 minutes; 64 degrees; west southwest to east northeast. HOUSTON - Monday, 6:41 A.M.; 4 minutes; 16 degrees; south southwest to east southeast. MIAMI - Monday, 6:08 A.M.; 3 minutes; 19 degrees; south southwest to east southeast. NEw ORLEANS - Sunday, 6:30 A.M.; 2 minutes; 11 degrees; south to southeast. ORLANDO, Fla. - Monday, 6:09 A.M.; 2 minutes; 12 degrees; south to southeast. SAN ANTONIO - Monday, 6:40 A.M.; 3 minutes; 15 degrees; south southwest to east southeast. SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. - Monday, 6:13 A.M.; 2 minutes; 11 degrees; south to southeast. ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. - Monday, 6:08 A.M.; 2 minutes; 12 degrees; south to southeast. TAMPA, Fla. - Monday, 6:08 A.M.; 2 minutes; 12 degrees; south to southeast. WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. - Monday, 6:08 A.M.; 3 minutes; 17 degrees; south to east southeast.

title: 2 Bribery Inquiries Examine Newark School System
description: Federal and Essex County prosecutors are investigating allegations that some school officials here sold administrative jobs, officials familiar with the inquiries said.

title: This Year's Top Female Athlete Is . . .
description: For 1987 and most of 1988, Jackie Joyner-Kersee has been honored by sports groups round the world as the world's greatest female athlete. Then, last month, a West German teen-ager captured the elusive tennis achievement won only by four previous legends. When Steffi Graf won the Grand Slam, many thought it only logical to wait until the conclusion of the Olympics to crown this year's female athlete of the year. This had nothing to do with the outcome of the women's tennis in Seoul; the incomplete field lessens that accomplishment. The debate would begin if Joyner-Kersee won both the heptathlon and the long jump. Joyner-Kersee has swept that difficult double, so let the debate begin.

title: DIVIDED AGAINST HER FATHER
description: LEAD: MY FATHER'S HOUSE A Memoir of Incest and of Healing. By Sylvia Fraser. 254 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $17.95.

title: Headliners; Speaking of Ethics
description: As independent prosecutor in the case of the former White House aide Michael K. Deaver, Whitney North Seymour Jr. says he has developed ''strong views on how to achieve a higher standard of ethics in govenrment.''

title: POSTINGS: Rockland Conversion; Market Upswing
description: When Unity Capital purchased Hillcrest Point for $10 million in 1984, the Long Island developer considered the decision as only a corporate milestone - its first foray into Rockland County. It had no big plans; the 16-acre garden apartment complex on Route 45 in Spring Valley, company officials thought, should remain a rental.

title: THE WORLD: Anti-U.S. Feelings; Amid Glamor of the Games, Korea Sees Warts on an Ally
description: WHILE the world has been watching South Korea during the Olympic Games, Koreans have been staring back - alternately riveted, charmed and disgusted by the encounter.

title: IN THE HEART OF THE HEARTLAND
description: LEAD: SHINE HAWK By Charlie Smith. 367 pp. New York: Paris Review Editions/ British American Publishing. $17.95.

title: Flannery O'Connor's Works
description: To the Editor:

title: Red Sox Happy; Stieb Heartbroken
description: Rich Gedman, the catcher for the Red Sox, sat in the empty, but still cramped clubhouse in Cleveland Friday night, soaking his aching right shoulder and listening for the update from Oakland. A couple of hundred miles away, Dave Stieb, the pitcher for the Blue Jays, lay awake in his bed in Toronto, his mind throbbing with painful memory.

title: L.B.J.'S HOMESPUN GROUSING
description: Richard Goodwin's article seems to suggest that Mr. Johnson was merely engaging in hortatory ventilation in conversations with junior aides, a manipulative device that Mr. Goodwin seems not to have recognized. The President's observation that a face-to-face meeting with Ho Chi Minh ''could work things out'' explodes the author's observation of paranoia. THOMAS H. BAER ] Los Angeles

title: 60's Revue Staged in Bridgeport
description: BY restoring a misguided Broadway musical to its beginnings as a pop concert, the Downtown Cabaret Theater in Bridgeport has come up with one of its most appropriately placed and crowd-pleasing entertainments. It may well be providing a lesson on how to salvage an unsuccessful show.

title: Clubs Reply to a Daring Move
description: It was a daring move for so young a club. With little more than a sailing season behind it, the Manhattan Yacht Club issued a challenge to yacht clubs around the world for a regatta in New York Harbor this fall.

title: CANADA ELECTIONS CALLED FOR NOV. 21
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney sought the dissolution of Parliament today and scheduled a general election for Nov. 21.

title: THE REGION - Pro & Con: Landlords, Tenants and Rent Control; Should Any Low-Income Housing Be Left in Private Hands?
description: WHEN New York City landlords lobby for rent increases from the city's Rent Guidelines Board, they often argue that low-income tenants do not pay enough each month to meet basic operating costs. Tenants in turn usually tell the board, which sets maximum increases for rent-stabilized apartments, that landlords are earning enough - and if they aren't, perhaps they should leave the business.

title: Honk if You Want a Bumper Sticker
description: Ever feel helplessly nostalgic describing to someone much younger the rhyming Burma Shave signs that once lined the roadways? A report by William Schmidt of The Times produces much the same feeling. It said that political buttons and bumper stickers are outre, things of the past. The Bush and Dukakis campaigns are producing them by the bushel, but nobody seems to be buttoning lapels or stickering bumpers.

title: Correction
description: An article on Sept. 11 described the work of the artist Balcomb Greene incorrectly. He paints in a realistic style.

title:
DINING OUT;
Touch of Manhattan in Mount Kisco
description: LEAD: THE look at Mount Kisco's Brownstone Cafe is definitely Manhattan. Occupying the lower level of a three-story brownstone, the neat, floor-through restaurant ends in a small garden hidden within a palisade fence and banks of rhododendrons. Inside, bright floral pictures continue the garden theme and glow dramatically against dark-green walls.

title: Melissa Morgan, an Editor, Married to Benedict Chant
description: Melissa Jo Morgan, the daughter of Judith Barnes of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Anthony Ian Morgan of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to Benedict Guy Chant, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Chant of Braishfield, Hampshire, England. Frederick E. Schulman, a retired town justice of New Castle, N.Y., officiated at the home of the bride's father and stepmother, Mercedes Lopez-Morgan.

title: America by Rail
description: To the Editor: In their two-part sequence, ''Across America by Rail'' (Travel, July 24), neither Nancy M. Debevoise nor William Borders touched on the key point: that a major upgading of rail passenger facilities is desperately needed.

title: Dukakis Vows a Vast Coastal Sanctuary
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis stepped up the battle for the environmentalist vote in this critical state today by promising its residents that he would ban offshore drilling along two-thirds of the California coast.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Corpus Christi
description: Most Texans pride themselves on having casual attitudes and life styles (or at least pretending to), and the people of Corpus Christi are no exception: They act surprised - maybe even disappointed - if you imply you're not here to enjoy yourself.

title: THE GODDESS IN TENNESSEE
description: Bruce Weber writes that a full-size replica of the Parthenon was constructed, ''for some reason,'' in Nashville, in 1897, as part of the city's centennial celebration (Works in Progress: ''The Goddess in Tennessee,'' Aug. 28). I am happy to be able to supply the reason. A friend living in Nashville told me that, in those days, Nashville was known as ''the Athens of the South.'' This was because Vanderbilt University and other institutions of higher learning were situated there.
