Because the Parthenon was the jewel of the Athenian Acropolis, it was fitting that a replica be erected in the Athens of the South. ROBERT L. MANNING Lafayette, Ga.

title: Giants and Taylor Brace for Redskins
description: There probably never should have been any doubts that Lawrence Taylor would play in today's game against the Redskins in Washington.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Henderson, Nev.;
2-Decade Delay About to End
description: LEAD: A 2,200-ACRE planned community originally proposed in this small municipality 13 miles southeast of Las Vegas in the mid-60's is expected to get under way shortly.

title: Gloria Gaines Has Wedding
description: Gloria Ryan Gaines, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Gaines of Lexington, Ky., was married there yesterday to Craig Robert Callen, a son of Helen M. Callen of Peabody, Mass., and Robert H. Callen of North Providence, R.I. The Rev. Daniel J. Noll, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Holy Spirit Parish Newman Center at the University of Kentucky.

title: The Subliminal Message of the Bush Campaign; Not 'Second Victim'
description: To the Editor:

title: Marcel Ophuls on Barbie: Reopening Wounds of War
description: If things had gone according to plan, the architecture of Marcel Ophuls's film about the Nazi war criminal Klaus Barbie would have been similar to ''The Sorrow and the Pity'' - the French director's classic exploration of the universe of collaboration and resistance in German-occupied Clermont-Ferrand. The setting of the Barbie film would have been Lyons at the time of the Gestapo chief's trial for crimes against humanity, with flashbacks to Barbie's chilling career as a torturer and nemesis of the French resistance during the war, tipster for American counterintelligence in postwar Germany and, later, a shady businessman and security adviser to South American dictators.

title:
GARDENING;
Flavor of Apples Takes Time to Mature
description: LEAD: FALL and apples seem to have been made for each other. What could be more pleasant than a stroll through the woods under a bright blue sky on a chilly October day while munching on a spicy apple and enjoying the brilliant colors of fall foliage?

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Locals; Wagner Routs Montclair
description: Doug Kovar and Terry Underwood, the 1-2 offensive punch of Wagner, accounted for five touchdowns as the Seahawks crushed previously undefeated Montclair State, 51-21, yesterday in the 10th annual Pride Bowl before 13,000 at Schools Stadium, Newark.

title: Snarling Ex-Sooners
description: Sometimes emotions can outstrip intelligence and that may have been the case last week when Tony Casillas, a defensive lineman for the Atlanta Falcons, said he wished he could be on offense for just one play in today's game against the Seattle Seahawks so he could challenge his former Oklahoma teammate, Brian Bosworth, the Seahawks' acclaimed linebacker.

title: POSTINGS: Low Rent on the Fringe; The Option Play
description: On one side of 96th Street is the 1,484-unit Normandie Court, where one-bedroom rents start at $1,295 a month. But when the apartment building rising across the street at 1865 Second Avenue opens in December, rents for its 18 two-bedroom units will be about $350.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
Mapping the Future in Light of the Past
description: LEAD: IN ancient Rome, the deity Janus presided over endings and beginnings, one of his two faces peering into the past, the other into the future.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our home is covered with aluminum siding in a blue-gray color. Last Halloween, children threw eggs against one corner, leaving a stain. There are also some white stains from bird droppings. The rains have lightened these stains considerably, but I have been reluctant to scrub the siding, as I have heard this might strip it down to the bare metal. Is it all right to use a hose and some mild cleaner to try and remove these stains, or will this tend to strip off the finish?

title: The Subliminal Message of the Bush Campaign; The Point Spread
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Weisenstein Becomes a Bride
description: At st. James Episcopal Church in New York, Kristina Ellen Weisensteinm the daughter of Mrs. Philip J. Wojak of Webster Groves, Mo., and Hugh L. Weisenstein of St. Louis, was married yesterday to Waddell Waters Stillman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Gordon B. Stillman of New York and Wrightsville Beach, N.C.

title: New Role for OPEC: Small Fish in a Big Pond
description: THE energy crisis of the 1970's, with its long gasoline lines and the frantic race to buy crude oil at any price, is dead. A new world of energy has emerged, one in which oil is more easily supplanted by other sources of energy, including natural gas, coal and, despite the accidents at Chernobyl and Three Mile Island, nuclear power.

title: Drug-Proof U.S. Borders May Be An Impossible Dream
description: IN the words of Senator Phil Gramm, a conservative Republican from Texas, ''We could assign the armed forces full-time to nothing but drug interdiction and probably not double the street price.''

title: Arbitrator Who Freed Gibson May Be the Dodgers' M.V.P.
description: If Fred Claire is the National League executive of the year, Tommy Lasorda the National League manager of the year and Kirk Gibson the league's most valuable player, another award has to be created. It would go to Tom Roberts, who is really the most valuable player of the year as far as the Los Angeles Dodgers are concerned.

title: TALKING: Relocation; Handling Disparities In Housing
description: ONCE upon a time, Americans could move from one part of the country to another and find only marginal differences in rental costs or house prices.

title:
GARDENING;
To the Rescue If Frost Threatens
description: LEAD: THE first killing frost emphatically finishes most of the vegetable garden. It's about time!

title: Austrian Beds
description: To the Editor: Oscar Millard's ''How to Sleep in an Austrian Bed'' (Travel, July 24) covers more sleeping couches than those in Austria. I had a similar experience in Munich at a five-star hotel where the staff responded to every request except that of providing me with a topsheet instead of a Tuchent.

title: WHO HIRED THE ASSASSIN?
description: ALL THE RIGHT ENEMIES The Life and Murder of Carlo Tresca. By Dorothy Gallagher. Illustrated. 321 pp. New Brunswick, N.J.: Rutgers University Press. $24.95.

title: Yanks' Loss Is Their 75th
description: The race was really over a week ago, perhaps even two weeks ago, but it did not officially end for the Yankees until Friday night. They had kept their hopes and their chins up beyond reality, even though they knew the chase would probably end soon.

title: HEROIC RESISTANCE
description: PRAISES & DISPRAISES Poetry and Politics, the 20th Century. By Terrence Des Pres. 246 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Bills Turning On the Juice Again
description: Remember when O. J. Simpson dashed through the Rich Stadium snow and when Jack Kemp and Joe Ferguson tossed those winning bombs for the Buffalo Bills? Remember when rumpled Lou Saban and hard-nosed Chuck Knox would clutch their caps on the sidelines and when Bills fans - with football the only pro game in town - had so much to cheer?

title: Time Warp on the Gulf
description: THE OLD GALVESTON CLUB EXISTS IN AN amiable time warp in the rear of a downtown building that houses a dreary newsstand and video game arcade. The generally uncategorizable decor ranges from nautical flags to a golden Buddha rescued from a gambling joint.

title: POSTINGS: Danbury Project; Zigzagged Offices
description: When a national business magazine selected Danbury, Conn., this year as the best place to live in America, residential developers were expected to come running. But one of the most active builders there spent 1988 erecting not homes but a $20 million office building near the conference-center hotel it finished in 1981.

title: Walton Keeping Things Simple
description: Joe Walton has been so concerned about not overloading his young Jets with too many plays that he admits he did not push them to try to get a big early start.

title: 'Holy Secrets'
description: PHYSICIANS AND PRIESTS have long been the keepers of secrets. On graduation from medical school, doctors take the oath of Hippocrates, promising: ''Whatsoever I shall see or hear in the course of my profession . . . if it be what should not be published abroad, I will never divulge, holding such things to be holy secrets.'' Soon these new doctors find themselves entrusted with intimate details that a patient may have been unwilling to share with anyone else. In that trust may lie the secret to the patient's cure. Still, on occasion, the trust is broken - the doctor may, for ethical or legal reasons, reveal confidential information. And that occasion presents a dilemma.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: South/Southwest; Alabama Rallies For 31-27 Victory
description: Richard Fain scored the only touchdown today on a 32-yard interception return to lead a defense that shut down the Louisiana State quarterback, Tommy Hodson, in Florida's 19-6 Southeastern Conference victory.

title: Truong Chinh Dies in Hanoi at 80; Was in Ho Chi Minh's Inner Circle
description: Truong Chinh, one of the last of the original group of militant Communist revolutionaries who governed Vietnam over the last 35 years, died at his home in Hanoi on Friday, according to the Vietnam News Agency. He was 80 years old.

title: Highlighting 3 American Composers
description: SUMMER at the Charles Ives Center for the Arts in Danbury officially ended seven weeks ago, but the site comes alive again for a three-part coda that includes some of the most imaginative programming of late.

title: Anger and Praise Follow Pope's Letter on Women
description: In the United States, first reactions to Pope John Paul II's letter ''On the Dignity of Women,'' issued Friday in Rome, were mixed, and there was immediate speculation about the impact of the papal document on the pastoral letter on women's issues now being drafted by the American bishops.

title: 'Olympus' Offers Old-Style Fun
description: WITH big-time musical theaters subsisting on spectacles and secondary theaters relegated to replicating each other's retreads, along comes ''Olympus on My Mind.'' Here is just the sort of breezy and brainy divertissement that could serve as a restorative for jaded musical-comedy aficionados.

title: Changing the Styles As the Styles Change
description: DRESSING mannequins may look like child's play, but Susan McIntyre and Lisa Wagner know better. As employees in the ''visual merchandising'' department of Saks Fifth Avenue in White Plains, it is their job to keep the store's lifelike models au courant and enticing to customers. When the outfits they have assembled are sold right off the display figures - as frequently happens - it is a tribute to the women's savvy and sense of style.

title: Ideas Wanted for the Census
description: Marketing students in colleges and universities are to devise ways to promote participation in the 1990 census in a contest sponsored by the American Marketing Association. The Census Bureau is asking for ideas on appealing to ethnic groups that have sometimes balked at being counted. Three hundred and fifty-two college chapters of the marketing association have been invited to compete. Winners are to receive $2,000.

title: Dying Maple Leaves Roots
description: AS soon as I opened the door and saw him, a burly, blond, sunburned young man who carried his hat in his hands and kept his eyes downcast to avoid the questioning look in mine, I knew he had come to deliver bad news.

title: The Market, After the Fall
description: The Business Section today looks closely at the financial markets and the economy on an important anniversary. These are some of the topics:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/PEOPLES OF THE WORLD
description: GREEK MYTHS: GODS, HEROES AND MONSTERS Their Sources, Their Stories and Their Meanings. By Ellen Switzer and Costas. Photographs by Costas. 208 pp. New York: A Jean Karl Book/Atheneum.

title: Emancipation Age: Should It Rise to 18?
description: LEAD: THE inconsistencies defy explanation. In New York State, 16-year-olds cannot buy alcoholic beverages, work without a permit for more than 20 hours a week, obtain a senior driver's license, get married or join the military without parental approval.

title: IN THE HEART OF THE HEARTLAND
description: LEAD: TRACKS By Louise Erdrich. 226 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $18.95.

title: MISHEARD WORDS
description: The term ''homeboy'' is an old and common feature of American black vernacular. Originally, it referred specifically to a male from the speaker's hometown and tended to be used in conversation between two men not living in their hometown. Thus, when two Austinites are living in New York, one says of the other, ''He's my homeboy,'' and greets him, perhaps, by saying, ''What's happening homes?'' W. JACKSON READING Orono, Me. ]

title: Another Milestone for Mets
description: Three days before the playoff for the National League pennant, the Mets passed a couple of modest milestones yesterday and even passed 3 million at the gate at Shea Stadium for the second straight year.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 2, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 THE DARK TOWER: The Gunslinger, by Stephen King. (Plume/NAL, $10.95.) Volume One of a series about a young man's pursuit of an evil force. 2 9 FALLEN HEARTS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.95.) The scandals and horrors of her past return to haunt a bride in a backwoods town. 3 12 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 4 4 THE FIVE BELLS AND BLADEBONE, by Martha Grimes. (Dell, $4.50.) Two Scotland Yard men track down a murderer. 5 * 5 TEAM YANKEE, by Harold Coyle. (Berkley, $4.95.) The exploits of an American tank company in Europe - during World War III. 6 2 MURDER IN THE CIA, by Margaret Truman. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A C.I.A. operative investigates the suspicious death of a literary agent on her way to Budapest. 7 4 LEGACY, by James A. Michener. (Fawcett, $4.95.) The inside story of William Casey's years at the helm of the C.I.A., 1981 to 1987. 2 19 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions in treating serious illness. 3 16 THE POWER OF MYTH, by Joseph Campbell with Bill Moyers. (Doubleday, $19.95.) How mythology illuminates life's stages, from birth to coming-of-age to marriage to aging and death. 4 4 IT'S ALL IN THE PLAYING, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $4.95.) Cartoons about a boy, his toy tiger and his parents. 3 8 FEELING GOOD, by David D. Burns. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) The ninth collection of ''Far Side'' cartoons. 5 18 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) How to solve your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: HAITIANS FEAR VIOLENCE AFTER COLONEL'S OUSTER
description: Haiti's most powerful unit commander, Col. Jean-Claude Paul, was dismissed late Friday night, raising fears of new violence in the troubled country.

title:
AMERICAN ISLANDS: PUERTO RICO;
Fireflies and Frog Songs
description: LEAD: I GOT TO PUERTO RICO 495 YEARS after Columbus. If he had few advance notions about the Arawak island of Borinquen, I did. I've been resident in Nueva York long enough to have got an impression of Puerto Rico as a thoroughly urban tropical place.

title: Varying Standards on Steroid Use
description: THE desire to enhance athletic performance is one of man's oldest pursuits, traceable, perhaps, to that point in time when speed, strength and agility became recreational pursuits rather than survival techniques.

title: Dollar's Domain
description: To the Editor:

title: Rail Trips With Intrigue On the Itinerary
description: LEAD: WHEN I was little, on nights when the moon was full or nearly full, casting a bluish-white oblong of light onto the wall beside my bed, I used to lie awake imagining I was in the sleeping berth of a train. I would pretend that I had been asleep as the train shot through the countryside, then had waked as it pulled into the station, where

title: More Towns Name Historians
description: NEARLY half of Connecticut's cities and towns have appointed municipal historians, and many others are considering it, one year after a law went into effect authorizing the position.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/PEOPLES OF THE WORLD
description: LEAD: THE MYTHOLOGY OF SOUTH AMERICA By John Bierhorst. Illustrated. 269 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $15.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Miles to Go
description: To the Editor:

title: Mustache Mania; Or, Many a Slip Between Nose and Lip
description: A FRIEND of long standing looked at me one day recently and suggested I grow a mustache. ''A mustache?'' I said. ''What in the world for?'' ''It'll make your nose smaller,'' he said. The subject of noses is a sensitive one for me, so I quickly and wittily retorted, ''Oh yeah?''

title: New Club for Wall Streeters Necessitates U-B There or B#2
description: LEAD: A club called B#2 has opened in lower Manhattan. That is pronounced ''be square,'' and the thing everyone loves to point out is its automatic teller machine.

title: Let's Go Back to the True Olympic Spirit; Why No Soccer on TV?
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Appears to Be Losing Struggle for Control of Senate
description: As the election campaigns across the country this fall have heated up, Republican chances of regaining control of the Senate seem to have become more remote.

title: Custom-Made Shoes in Hong Kong
description: TO the Duchess's declaration that ''a woman can never be too thin or too rich,'' I might add, ''or have too many shoes.'' Political implications aside, to women of a certain age, shoes are the ultimate sign of class. After all, we do say ''well-heeled,'' not ''well-hatted'' or ''well-gloved.'' A trip to Hong Kong can change all that - and, if you're both persistent and lucky, maybe get you the first pair of shoes that really fit since your neighborhood shoe man last looked at your feet in that X-ray machine.

title: Downtown, They Take Rock Seriously
description: The new-music composers Elliott Sharp, John Zorn, Wayne Horvitz, Hank Roberts and George Cartwright (who leads the group Curlew) are radically different from each other, but they do have a few things in common. They are all members of the Downtown School, if only because they perform in the same places, to the same audiences. They have played with each other, and they're roughly the same age: mid- to late 30's. And they all draw on popular music for their compositions.

title: Al Holbert, Racing Driver, 41
description: Al Holbert, whose 63 victories ranked him first among International Motor Sports Association drivers, was killed when his twin-engine airplane crashed shortly after takeoff from a Columbus airport Friday night, officials said. He was 41 years old.

title: When America Starts to Tinker
description: THE American genius, who invents at his kitchen table or in a corporate laboratory, is losing ground to innovators from abroad. Last year, United States residents were granted only 54 percent of the patents issued the Patent and Trademark Office, according to Government statistics.

title: Reviews/Music; The Accent Is on Youth At Samuel Zyman Concert
description: As young composers go, Samuel Zyman seems to have luck, and a good deal more, on his side. He was born in Mexico City and began his studies there, but came to New York in 1981 to work with Stanley Wolfe, Roger Sessions and David Diamond at the Juilliard School. Now he is on the Juilliard faculty and has amassed an impressive number of awards and commissions, as well as a recording of his works on the new Antilles/New Directions label, with a second installment due early next year.

title: New York Sued Over Rent Program for Elderly Poor
description: Thousands of elderly tenants in New York City have been forced to sacrifice food, clothing and medical services to pay for unnecessary rent increases because the city has failed to notify them of a program intended to freeze rents for the elderly poor, a law suit filed by the Legal Aid Society has charged.

title: Satellite Threat Is Seen at End
description: The nuclear core of an errant Soviet space satellite has broken free into an orbit in outer space and will pose no radiation threat anywhere on earth, the West German Government said today.

title: Correction
description: A review of a poster exhibition, ''Persuasive Images,'' on Sept. 18 gave an incorrect closing date. The show, at the Lehman College Art Gallery in the Bronx, closes on Oct. 26.

title: CATHARINE MCCORMACK WED
description: Catharine Mary McCormack, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Michael McCormack of New York, was married yesterday to Robert McDonald Totman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Totman of Phoenix. The Rev. Michael Quinlan officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York. Mrs. Totman is a foreign exchange trader and her husband a credit analyst at the Sumitomo Bank in New York. The bride's father is a corporate vice president of Drexel Burnham Lambert. Mr. Totman's father is the European marketing manager for Loral Defense Systems in Phoenix.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Appointment With Death Starring Peter Ustinov, Lauren Bacall, Carrie Fisher, John Gielgud, Piper Laurie, Hayley Mills, Jenny Seagrove, David Soul, Nicholas Guest, Valerie Richards. Directed by Michael Winner. 1988. Warner Home Video. 102 minutes. $89.95. Closed captioned. Rated PG, though it contains little to disturb children.

title: Remembering A Tokyo Boy With a Future
description: At the beginning of an English class in Tokyo shortly after the end of World War II, Elizabeth Gray Vining asked her Japanese pupils what they wanted to be in later life.

title: A Healthy Vacuum
description: FOR nearly 30 years, Calvin Parks, a garage mechanic, had the hazardous job of cleaning out asbestos grit from brake drums. It was a job so dangerous that his partner, who performed the same tasks, died from asbestosis in 1982.

title: Jacqueline Moore Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of of Jacqueline Kent Moore, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Koelle Moore of London and Cove Neck, L.I., to Christopher Wren Watson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Deering Watson of Gibson Island, Md., and East Hampton, L.I., took place yesterday at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Gary P. Fertig performed the ceremony.

title:
TWO RARE OPERS TO OPEN SEASON;
A Tour and a Debut
description: LEAD: IT has long been a policy of Alfredo Silipigni, general director and principal conductor of the New Jersey State Opera, to present (along with the more traditional fare) some works that, chances are, most operagoers have not come across before. The company will open its 23d season next Sunday at 6 P.M.

title: Banned Nepal Opposition Hopes for Revival
description: In a bare, brick building off a bustling thoroughfare in the Nepalese capital, Krishna Prasad Hattarai, president of the major opposition party banned nearly 30 years ago, spoke of the hopes of groups seeking multi-party democracy.

title: BOND PLAN CALLED WEAK ON BRIDGES
description: The emotional and political trauma caused this spring by the closing of the Williamsburg Bridge because of structural defects is being used to persuade voters to approve the $3 billion transportation bond issue on the New York State ballot next month.

title: In Chile, Unofficial Polls Show 'No' Taking Lead Over Pinochet
description: To the Editor:

title: The Difficult Degas: A Mystery Still
description: Until a year or two ago there could not possibly have been a Degas exhibition like the one that opens to the public at the Metropolitan Museum on Oct. 11 and has been seen in a slightly different form at the Grand Palais in Paris and the new National Gallery of Canada in Ottawa. Without multinational good will on the grand scale, and without the close cooperation that is now standard form between museums in France and the United States, the show would never have made it out of dreamland. It is an indispensable show. Contrary to what is often supposed, Edgar Degas is one of the least known and least well understood of the great European painters. Many of his finest achievements are in museums in remote places or in private collections to which access is not always easy. Often they are too fragile to be on regular exhibition. In his work, as in his life, Degas was the most complex, as well as the most private of men, and there are great paintings in the present show that have resisted elucidation for more than 100 years and continue to do so. The easy Degas, who spawned his undemanding dancing girls by the dozens, is familiar to everyone who tours the dealers' galleries and the auction rooms. But the Degas who really matters is the difficult Degas who went his own way for more than half a century and still defies us to keep up with him.

title: Easy Goer Captures Cowdin
description: Anyone who had seen him run knew he was something special, but it took a stakes victory yesterday to make it official: Easy Goer is the best 2-year-old in the country and might turn out to be a great one.

title: New York Businesses Turn to Elderly to Fill Jobs
description: ''Seventy-one: Oh, my God,'' Ardath Cifuni exclaimed when asked her age.

title: U.S. Ties AIDS to Soaring Pneumonia Deaths
description: AIDS is believed responsible for an increase in pneumonia deaths among young adults in New York and, possibly, other cities.

title: Irony Is Back, And It's No More Mr. Nice Guy
description: Late 1980's rock is overrun with professional nice guys. Like politicians on the stump, they're busy demonstrating their idealism, their empathy with the common folk, their good intentions, their sincerity. While a little responsibility on the part of people with mass-media exposure doesn't hurt, some mainstream rockers - Steve Winwood, George Michael, Def Leppard, Huey Lewis and dozens of others -have grown so protective of their images that they won't touch iffy, ambivalent or dangerous subjects and emotions.

title: ELAINE POCHTAR IS MARRIED TO JAMES CRANE SWEENEY
description: Elaine Nancy Pochtar, a vice president of Morgan Stanley & Company, and James Crane Sweeney, a vice president of Shearson Lehman Hutton, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York by the Rev. Harry Boyle.

title: Stuck in Second
description: If baseball history repeats, and in Cincinnati it has demonstrated an uncanny recent ability to do just that, it would seem a fairly safe bet that the Reds will be coming in second in the National League West for the next couple of years. After all, in four full seasons under Pete Rose the Reds have never finished anywhere else, and since Rose has just signed a contrtact extension that will keep him in place for two more seasons, there is not much reason to expect a change.

title: Question Of the Week; Which Is The Better Team, '86 Mets, Or '88 Mets?
description: They will not win 108 games in 1988. They have played without the leadoff success of Dykstra-Backman, and without the '86 seasons of both Gooden and Carter. There was no Keith Hernandez with his Gold Glove and ballet-like grace at first base for far too many games.

title: What to Do When the Taxman Goofs
description: EVERY tax professional has at least one horror story to tell about Internal Revenue Service foul-ups. Jo Carole Klepack, a tax manager with the New York accounting firm of Siegal, Rich, Pachtman & Company, recalls the case of a client who diligently paid his estimated taxes each quarter. But the I.R.S. failed to credit one payment to the proper quarter - even though the information was noted on the check - and it issued a notice of tax due.

title: Debate Renewed on Barriers to Lawyers
description: DEBATE over New Jersey restrictions on out-of-state lawyers has accelerated since the recent passage of similar limits by New York State.

title:
INVESTING;
Strategies That Worked in a Rocky Year
description: LEAD: NERVES of steel, cash on hand and calm, emotionless execution were the ingredients needed for investors to take best advantage of the values available after the 22.6 percent stock crash last Oct. 19, analysts say in retrospect.

title: Miss Vogel, an Accountant, Marries Joseph W. Mullins
description: Kathleen L. Vogel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. O. Martin Vogel of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Joseph W. Mullins, the son of Marie J. Mullins of New Rochelle, and Christopher J. Mullins of Palm Beach Shores, Fla., were married yesterday. Justice William R. Crosbie of the Village of Tarrytown, N.Y., performed the ceremony at Tappan Hill Restaurant in Tarrytown.

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;
REPORT FROM MILAN
description: LEAD: Even though the streets of Milan are now filled with women in midthigh skirts, designers have decided that for summer 1989, the moment has come for women to wear long lengths again.

title: A Moment of Beauty Amid the Chaos
description: ONE morning as I went outside to take a shower there was a soft, warm rain falling. If I had been patient I could have soaped up and let the gentle rain do the rinsing. But the workmen were to arrive at 7 A.M. and I didn't want them to catch me dancing through the rain drops in my own backyard.

title: BASEBALL'S RENAISSANCE MAN
description: I attended many Dodger games at Ebbetts Field as a child, and I share Bart Giamatti's thoughts about the game bringing back nostalgic memories. Your article also brought to mind nostalgic memories of my favorite professor at Mount Holyoke College in 1954, teaching ''Dante's Inferno'' at an 8 A.M. class - Bart Giamatti's father! OLIVE REICH Shelter Island Heights, L.I.

title: Returning to Revlon's Glory Days
description: A WOMAN strides into a department store and weaves her way to the cosmetics area. She dodges a man in a tuxedo spraying perfume into the air. She passes a salesman in a lab coat clutching a jar of cream, and another waving a compact of multicolored eyeshadows. Never mind the ladylike clouds of pink powder and floral fragrance, this woman has entered a war zone.

title: Headliners; Speaking of Virtue
description: Some historians say that when the Rev. Junipero Serra was setting up Franciscan missions along the Pacific coast in the 18th century, the Indians he encountered considered him no saint. After its own investigation, the Vatican differs. Last week, Pope John Paul II beatified Father Serra, bringing the missionary one step from sainthood. The Pope praised Father Serra, two of whose missions became the cities of San Francisco and San Diego, as ''a shining example of Christian virtue.'' Several historians say that Father Serra's Franciscans used Indians in forced labor and flogged them if they disputed Church teachings or attempted to escape. A Vatican spokesman disagreed, saying, ''No one is beatified if there is a shadow of a doubt about their virtue.''

title: Hungary
description: To the Editor: I am just back from a delightful holiday in Hungary where the American tourists get a real welcome. As Western Europe is very expensive, beautiful Budapest with its museums, attractive and interesting architecture, exciting excursions and its lovely opera house (best tickets $5) is a revelation.

title: Shoreham Concern Isn't a Phobia
description: ''Nuclear Phobia Over Shoreham'' [ Opinion, Aug. 21 ] , the writer not only ignores a number of near meltdowns in American commercial reactors over the years, but also ignores the whole body of epidemiological evidence in the scientific literature on the health effects of low-level radiation.

title: THE ESTONIANS SAY, LET US BE ESTONIAN
description: While Mikhail S. Gorbachev was busy in Moscow shaking up the high command of his social revolution, the residents of the tiny republic of Estonia today advanced the front line.

title: Film Festival; 2 Views Of Sexual Fantasies
description: When do businessmen do the tango? More often than you might think, according to ''Ray's Male Heterosexual Dance Hall,'' a wickedly deadpan short film by Bryan Gordon. Mr. Gordon has the novel idea of letting a bevy of dark-suited executives meet at lunchtime in a dance club (with ticker tape over the bar) to run through their paces, which are choreographed to songs like ''Begin the Beguine.''

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE PLEDGE. By Howard Fast. (Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) Although Howard Fast's latest novel addresses the political and moral upheaval of the McCarthy era, the manner in which he goes about it is so formulaic, dated and undemanding that the real way to read the book is to picture John Payne and Maureen O'Hara in the film version.

title: Court Backs Fanelli on Oath of Office
description: SHORTLY after County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke suspended his Probation Director, Marino J. Fanelli, last May - the first department head to be removed in his administration - Mr. O'Rourke announced that a legal technicality made the filing of charges unnecessary.

title: D. D. WOLFF WEDS LUCINDA M. GATCH
description: At the Episcopal Chapel of St. James the Fisherman in Wellfleet, Mass., yesterday, Lucinda McCormick Gatch, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Milton McCormick Gatch Jr. of New York and Wellfleet, was married to David Daniel Wolff, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Edwin Wolff of Cokato, Minn.

title: Question Of the Week; Which Is The Better Team, '86 Mets, Or '88 Mets?
description: I think the 1986 Mets were better. They had more action, they won more games and lost fewer games. I am not too sure the Mets will go to the World Series this time. Let's see. ANGEL EUGIEO Brewster, N.Y.

title: Elizabeth O'Neill Wed To Robert A. Wright
description: Elizabeth Blanck O'Neill and Robert Alan Wright were married yesterday at the New Canaan, Conn., home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry O'Neill. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr., a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: A.C.L.U. Boasts Wide Portfolio of Cases, but Conservatives See Partisanship
description: The American Civil Liberties Union is known for supporting unpopular causes, but George Bush's recent attacks on the group have touched off heated debate over whether the A.C.L.U. itself is an unpopular cause ''out in deep left field,'' as the Republican Presidential candidate portrays it, or a respected American institution defending the nation's basic civil liberties.

title: Apology Due From Anderson
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Bridgeport Law School to Add 5 Lecture Halls
description: THE largest law school in the state, the Bridgeport University School of Law, has started a $7.5 million expansion.

title: Make Steffi Play Lefty
description: The most awesome thing about this Miss Steffi Graf is not that she is 19 years old and has already won the Grand Slam Plus One. That's history. Oh, no. The real scary thing about this Miss Graf is that she roared through the final match of the Summer Games, not just a kid having a fine time at the Olympics but also a superb technician adding a level to her game.

title: MAN AGAINST HIS BRAIN
description: MEMORIES OF AMNESIA By Lawrence Shainberg. 219 pp. New York. Paris Review Editions/ British American Publishing. $16.95.

title: Washington Gains and Houston Loses Population
description: Florida and Texas have a total of 9 of the nation's fastest-growing metropolitan areas, but the only change in the top 10 was that the Washington, D.C., region edged ahead of economically distressed Houston.

title: Closing the Gap Between the Brain and the Mind
description: Flipping from station to station by remote control, inveterate television watchers can tell almost instantly when they have chanced upon an educational science show. It is hardly even necessary to glance at the channel indicator. Earnest people in white coats sit in book-lined studies gesturing meaningfully. Chart recorders with twitching needles spew out paper marked with inscrutable zigzag lines. In the background, a voice, often British, narrates in a deadpan style the amazing wonders unfolding on the screen.

title: Bernstein's Mahler: In Tune With Genius
description: There have always been conductors who championed the music of Gustav Mahler, starting with Gustav Mahler. From Bruno Walter to Otto Klemperer to Dimitri Mitropoulos, Jascha Horenstein and others, Mahler the composer never lacked eloquent advocates.

title: BASEBALL'S RENAISSANCE MAN
description: In addition to giving us a fine portrait of a very fine man, Charles Siebert's article on Bart Giamatti gave us a wonderful quote from Pete Rose (''Baseball's Renaissance Man,'' Sept. 4). Pete's compliment for Bart Giamatti: ''He's an intellectual from Yale, but he's very intelligent.''

title: DABBLING IN LOVE - NOT THE NICE KIND
description: THE ASSIGNATION By Joyce Carol Oates. 192 pp. New York: The Ecco Press. $16.95.

title: Lilco Getting Out of the Street-Lighting Business
description: LEAD: SLOWLY and almost unnoticed by most residents, the Long Island Lighting Company has been getting out of the street-lighting business. During the last 15 years, the utility has sold about 95 percent of its street lights to 55 Long Island municipalities.

title: Autumn Diversions on Ile de Re
description: Although it's barely a speck on the map of France, I think of the Ile de Re as France's kind and gentle, quiet island. A flat, irregular stretch of land bathed in an ever-bright haze, this tiny, tidy Atlantic island off the coast of La Rochelle is the epitome of ''douce France,'' all that is calm, quiet, welcoming about this eternally attractive nation.

title: NANCY FRIEDMAN ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter H. Neuhaus of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Neuhaus's daughter Nancy Ellen Friedman to Dr. Barry Scot Horowitz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan H. Horowitz of Hartsdale, N.Y. Ms. Friedman, a daughter also of the late Marvin D. Friedman, is a diamond buyer for Macy's New York. Her fiance is a resident in internal medicine at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. The couple plan to marry Nov. 5.

title: Dr. Judith Fine to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Ingram Fine of Bayside, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Judith Susan Fine to Dr. David C. Preston, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Channing Preston of Lyndhurst, Ohio. Dr. Fine, an intern in medicine at University Hospital in Boston, graduated from the Tufts University School of Medicine. Her fiance, who is the chief resident in neurology at the New England Medical Center in Boston, received an M.D. degree from Case Western Reserve University.

title: Mrs. Thatcher's Britain
description: There have been some important and probably lasting changes in British society since Margaret Thatcher was first elected as Britain's first woman Prime Minister in 1979. While it is a good deal less than the ''revolution'' she proclaims, it is rather more than just another swing of the pendulum between left and right.

title: Something New At Morristown Fair
description: OCCASIONALLY there is something new, not just under the sun but also under the roof of a craft fair. Take, for example, a suit of armor for a mouse. Intricately wrought despite its tongue-in-cheek theme, that ultimate in trappings will be found in a booth full of works by Canadian artists, a special feature at the Morristown CraftMarket opening here Friday night.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Ivy League; Cornell Overwhelmed by Lehigh, 27-14
description: Mark McGowan of Lehigh ran for a 67-yard touchdown and threw two fourth-quarter scoring passes to lift Lehigh to a 27-14 victory over Cornell today.

title: Flannery O'Connor's Works
description: To the Editor:

title: Family Afflicted by AIDS Finds a Better Life
description: Garfield the Cat, a stuffed toy incarnating the comic strip character, was just about all the Rays were able to retrieve from the ashes after an arsonist burned their home to the ground.

title: Scrambled Eggs And Cross-Purposes
description: TEN YEARS AGO MY mother and father split up. In the uneasy truce that has followed, my father's Sunday morning visits have become a ritual. I scramble some eggs. The kids play in their pajamas. My wife dresses for Mass. Retired now, he is youthful-appearing since he gave up the chemotherapy. But he walks and speaks with a look only those who have had the cancer cut out of them can possess. The surgeon said there was a 75 percent chance the cancer would return in the next five years. If my father gets by that, he's cured. He's into his fourth year, but being a fatalist by nature, he talks loosely of when he will ''check out.'' We don't dwell on the possibility, but maybe it accounts for the edgy overtones that accompany our conversations.

title: TV's Coverage Of Conference
description: The Cable News Network plans live coverage of the astronauts' news conferences from space, tentatively scheduled for 8:57 A.M. Eastern daylight time. ABC News, CBS News and NBC News will report on the news conference in their regular news broadcasts.

title: The Compact Disk at 5: Music by the Numbers
description: The compact disk is so much a staple of modern musical life that we are astonished to think how young it is. It was only five years ago that the CD made its American debut.

title: Antidote for Auto Theft
description: An innovative, inexpensive New York City program promises genuine relief for the epidemic of automobile thefts in American cities.

title: Spain's Chief Criticized on U.S. Defense Pact
description: When he was a leftist student leader and later head of the Socialist opposition, Felipe Gonzalez was against nuclear weapons, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and a defense treaty with the United States signed in 1953 by Gen. Francisco Franco.

title: Cubans Meet U.N. Group
description: About 1,500 Cubans requested meetings with a United Nations human rights delegation during its visit to Cuba, many of them complaining that they were barred from leaving the country, an official said Friday. The delegation returned from Cuba this week after a 10-day visit.

title: A Late Blooming Shrub for Ornamental Use
description: DON'T be lured by mild, sunny weather; move house plants indoors; exceptions are Christmas cactuses, which remain outdoors until light frosts to set flower buds. Continue transplanting evergreens, conifers and perennials. Bulb planting also goes on this month and continues to the early days of next month. Rose of Sharon

title: Chairs That Suggest Mondrians Come to Life
description: Gerrit Rietveld's ''Red-Blue'' chair, the first object made in the De Stijl palette, looks today as it did when the design was new 70 years ago - like a three-dimensional Mondrian. A rare early example of the Dutch architect's chair, its stained surfaces faded and worn, it is one of many surprises to be seen in ''Gerrit Rietveld: A Centenary Exhibition,'' opening tomorrow at the Barry Friedman gallery, 1117 Madison Avenue (at 84th Street).

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/PEOPLES OF THE WORLD
description: THE MOST BEAUTIFUL PLACE IN THE WORLD By Ann Cameron. Illustrated by Thomas B. Allen. 57 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $10.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: STREETSCAPES: The Old Squibb Building; 'Restoration' Is Adding Color To Original All-White Design
description: ALTHOUGH the 1930 Squibb building at Grand Army Plaza was built to the architect's original design, renovations meant to make up for what had mistakenly been thought to be cutbacks brought on by the crash of '29 are still being carried out.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: The Sound of a Slogan ''NOTHING in life is simple,'' said George E. Fey, president of the Long Island Tourism and Convention Commission. The search for a new Long Island slogan started out that way. Long Island needed a slogan. The Commission held a contest. They picked a winner in August from the 7500 entries submitted. And now Long Island's new slogan, ''From Sound to Sea, the Place to Be'' is in use. Right?

title: Managua Jails 2 Economists, Stirring Fears
description: The Government's right to keep economic data secret is at the heart of a legal case that has sent shock waves through Nicaragua's white-collar sector.

title: WALL STREET STOLE MY HUSBAND
description: CRAZY IN LOVE By Luanne Rice. 307 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: Pavarotti Tickets on Sale
description: Tickets for Pavarotti Plus, a concert by Luciano Pavarotti and guests on Jan. 9 at Lincoln Center, go on sale today at the Avery Fisher Hall box office. Guest artists will include June Anderson, Shirley Verrett, Sherrill Milnes, Ruggero Raimondi, Kallen Esperian, Eduardo Ayas and Thomas Hampson. Anton Guadagno will conduct. Tickets, at $75 and $50, are available at the box office or through Center Charge, 874-6770.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Antrim, N.H.;
Scouts' Pullout Worries Town
description: LEAD: THE decision by the Boy Scouts of America to sell the little-used Camp Sachem here has upset many in this town of 2,500 residents in south-central New Hampshire, who are suspicious of development.

title: THE REAL CHARLES DICKENS, OR THE OLD ANIMOSITY SHOP
description: In his life Charles Dickens was like the rest of us, but maybe more so: another poor and wonderful soul attempting to deal with his and the world's pain and confusion in the best way he knew how. There is a large Dickens constituency, part of which has a vested interest in idealizing the great novelist. In the academic world, more articles are published on Dickens than on anyone other than Shakespeare. Each August the California Dickens Project at the Santa Cruz campus of the University of California brings together hundreds of Dickens scholars, graduate students and high school teachers to immerse themselves for 10 days in the world of Dickens. There, and at other Dickens conferences each year in America and England, the ''Inimitable,'' as he was the first to call himself, is celebrated in various ways, ranging from esoteric papers to general toasts of appreciation. The American Dickens Society and the international Dickens Fellowship flourish, with readings and discussion groups around the world, from Singapore to Kansas City. Never was a bard so well appreciated and celebrated. He continues to be widely considered the greatest novelist in the English literary tradition, and the best loved.

title: Recommendations On Tax Changes
description: An Opinion page article by State Senator C. Louis Bassano (''Fiscal Blueprint: Burden's Not New,'' Aug. 21) criticized the final report of the New Jersey State and Local Expenditure and Revenue Policy Commission. Like much of the rhetoric surrounding the report, Senator Bassano's article reflects an inaccurate or incomplete perception of the recommendations. I would like to take this opportunity to clarify a few of the issues for my colleague.

title: Sharon Chu Wed To N. M. Kreutter
description: Sharon Fong Chu, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sherwood C. Chu of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Norman Michael Kreutter, a son of Maj. Dale T. Kreutter, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Kreutter of Fayetteville, Ga. The Rev. Horst Gutsche performed the ceremony at the Zion Evangelical Lutheran Church in Brooklyn Heights.

title: No. 3 in a Growing-Up-Jewish Trilogy
description: DURING the last few seasons, the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst has been presenting Israel Horovitz's trilogy about growing up Jewish in Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Tennis; Tennis Returns to Good Reviews
description: From Philippe Chatrier's perspective, the experiment was a success. But that is to be expected. Chatrier is the president of the International Tennis Federation, whose dream it was to see the sport regain medal status in the Olympics Games after a 64-year absence. For the past two weeks, spectators watched some of the top players in the world compete for gold instead of prize money.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
In Mercer, Growth Shifts to I-95 Environs
description: LEAD: WHILE the open fields along Route 1 in Mercer County continue to give way to new homes and commercial buildings, growth pressures are steering development five miles west to the available land around Interstate 95, which is considered the region's next boom area.

title: From the Heartland: Nudity, Lemurs And Picasso
description: After visiting America some years ago, James Monahan, a British dance critic, wrote how amazed he was by the way Americans seemed ''addicted to congregations and to worrying, in congregation, a subject to death - or to life.''

title: Michelle DeMuth Weds W. W. Gay
description: At the Reformed Church of Bronxville, N.Y., Michelle Denise DeMuth, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Dennis L. DeMuth of Ida, Mich., was married yesterday to William Wingate Gay, a son of William K. Gay of Mahwah, N.J., and Mrs. E. Virgil Conway of Bronxville. The Rev. Dr. Robert W. Bedingfield performed the ceremony.

title: Jack Ruby's Timing
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSH IS DISPUTED ON U.S.-NORIEGA TIE
description: Stansfield Turner, President Carter's intelligence chief, said today that the Central Intelligence Agency cut off its payments to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama in the Carter Administration and resumed them after the Reagan Administration took office in 1981.

title: '89 Drought Feared as a World Catastrophe
description: Another drought in 1989 would be catastrophic for the world's food supply and cause a scramble by needy countries for dwindling grain supplies, an economist said today.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Indianapolis; Solo No More Next to a Canal
description: RODNEY HALL is growing lonely next to the narrow canal that skirts the western edge of downtown Indianapolis.

title: Amputee Is Discharged As an Air Force Cadet
description: A cadet who lost part of a leg in a traffic accident has lost his effort to stay in the Air Force Academy in spite of his contesting a Pentagon rule calling for discharge in the event of such an injury.

title: Debt Distortions
description: To the Editor:

title: The Outlook for the Competitive Senate Races: From Delaware to California; INCUMBENCY NOT ALWAYS AN EDGE
description: This is the outlook for the competitive Senate races this year:

title: SUSAN KOESTER WEDS
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Peace in New York, Susan Deirdre Koester, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Koester of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to James Lawrence Kennedy, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert L. Kennedy of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. The Rev. William J. Sweeney performed the ceremony. The bride is an associate at the New York law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell. Mr. Kennedy is an account marketing representative in Harrison, N.Y., at the Rolm systems division of the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: A Small Town's Big Party
description: LEAD: IT takes more than lush green valleys, winding country roads and handsome old clapboarded homes to make a town special. One of the state's smallest towns, Warren, settled in 1737 and situated in the rolling hills of northwestern Connecticut, has all that. But it is the people - some 1,170 of them at last count - who are the fabric of the community.

title:
TWO RARE OPERAS TO OPEN SEASON;
Dance Enlivens 'Villi'
description: LEAD: LOVE, betrayal and revenge constitute the key elements in Puccini's one-act opera, ''Le Villi,'' which will open the 23d season of the New Jersey State Opera next Sunday at the New Brunswick Cultural Center. While ballet functions as a stepchild in many operas, providing an interlude that has little to do with furthering the narrative line, the dance sections of ''Le

title: Commercializing Space
description: When the space shuttle Discovery and its crew were lofted into orbit last Thursday, it ended America's 32 month hiatus from manned spaceflight. On the same day that the Discovery was launched, the United States and 11 other nations signed a pact to build a space station capable of supporting scientific and commercial endeavors and a sustained human presence. With the shuttle in orbit, will business soon follow? Peter E. Glaser Vice president, Arthur D. Little.

title: Tudor Suffers Hip Spasm
description: The status of John Tudor, scheduled to pitch Game 2 of the National League Championship Series against the Mets here next Wednesday night, remained in doubt today after he suffered a muscle spasm in his right hip with one out in the second inning Friday night against San Francisco. Tudor had to leave the game, which the Dodgers won, 6-4.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; What Did You Think Of the Seoul Olympics?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Treasured Islands
description: THERE ARE MAGIC MOUNTAINS AND happy valleys, haunted woodlands and enchanted rivers, but no natural feature on the map is more enticing than an island. You have only to think of the names - Capri, Grand Canary, Bali, St. Lucia, the Hebrides, the Cyclades. . . . You have only to think of the islands of myth and fiction, from the Fortunate Isles to King Arthur's Avalon, from ''Treasure Island'' to ''South Pacific.''

title: A Word on the Meaning Of the Word 'Chai'
description: I was surprised to learn from Amelia B. Winkler's article [ ''A Return to the Past on Rosh ha-Shanah,'' Westchester Opinion, Sept. 11 ] that the Hebrew word chai means ''good luck'' with a numerical value of 18. (The Hebrew letters have numerical equivalents that form the basis for a mystical understanding of the meanings of the various words.) In fact, chai means ''life.'' The translation of ''good luck'' would be ''mazal tov,'' with a value of 94. I'll bet that most congregations would prefer that kind of contribution by far. DANIEL S. ROSEN Mount Vernon

title: Matthew Troy Describes a Politician's Temptations
description: Going to prison ''did not make me a better person, and it didn't make me a more moralistic man,'' the former New York City politician told a law class at Pace University. ''What it did was to make me a little bit scared about practicing law and a bit more careful about how I handle my clients.''

title: Judge Says Rockefeller Estate Isn't Liable in Attica Lawsuit
description: Inmates at the Attica Correctional Facility have no claim against the estate of former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller for the deaths that occurred during a violent prison uprising in 1971, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: Lennon? A Film Joins the Fray
description: ''We were out to create a balanced portrait of John Lennon, not an idealized vision of St. John of Liverpool,'' says the director Andrew Solt of his documentary, ''Imagine: John Lennon,'' which opens Friday. ''John Lennon had an edge to him, and we show that, along with many other facets of his personality that were captured on film over the years. Lately, it has been suggested that we as a generation have been duped - that Lennon's life was just one incredible public relations scam. That has become an underlying question. Our film leaves it to the audience to decide who the real John Lennon was.''

title: Let's Go Back to the True Olympic Spirit
description: To the Editor:

title: Draft Treaty Seeks to Take the Profit Out of Drugs
description: The United States and more than 100 other countries have negotiated a treaty that would dramatically increase international cooperation in the effort to curb narcotics trafficking.

title: BEST SELLERS: October 2, 1988
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 9 THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan races to the rescue of America's highest-ranking secret agent in the Soviet Union. 2 5 2 BREATHING LESSONS, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $18.95.) The many facets of a 28-year marriage are revealed during a drive to a friend's funeral. 3 2 8 TILL WE MEET AGAIN, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $19.95.) The exploits of a woman and her two daughters from pre-World War I Paris to present-day Los Angeles. 4 3 14 ALASKA, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $22.50.) The history of the 49th state told in fictional form. 5 4 4 SPOCK'S WORLD, by Diane Duane. (Pocket, $16.95.) An emergency meeting of the planet Vulcan's ruling council exposes its secret history and that of the Enterprise's Commander Spock. 6 10 4 THE SILENCE OF THE LAMBS, by Thomas Harris. (St. Martin's, $18.95.) A young woman F.B.I. trainee on the trail of a serial killer. 7 7 10 DOCTORS, by Erich Segal. (Bantam, $19.95.) The life stories of five members of Harvard Medical School's class of 1962. 8 6 48 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 9 * 9 7 SHINING THROUGH, by Susan Isaacs. (Harper & Row, $18.95.) The progress of a Queens woman from Wall Street secretary to wife of her boss to spy in Nazi Germany. 10 11 33 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 11 * 12 24 LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $18.95.) A Colombian poet's perdurable love for a woman is tested by life's changing conditions. 12 8 13 TO BE THE BEST, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The Harte department store dynasty, founded by ''a woman of substance,'' undergoes emotional and financial strains. 13 1 KOKO, by Peter Straub. (Dutton, $19.95.) Three Vietnam veterans on the trail of a friend who may be responsible for a series of murders committed throughout Asia. 14 13 6 DEMON LORD OF KARANDA, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $18.95.) The battle for control of a continent continues in the fantasy saga ''The Malloreon.'' 15 14 3 THE AVIATORS, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $18.95.) A volume in the ''Brotherhood of War'' series set in Vietnam. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 24 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A British scientist's review of efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 2 4 4 THE LIVES OF JOHN LENNON, by Albert Goldman. (Morrow, $22.95.) The rock-and-roll star as legend and as human being. 3 2 5 THE BOZ, by Brian Bosworth with Rick Reilly. (Doubleday, $17.95.) The life and controversial opinions of the Seattle Seahawks football player. 4 3 6 THE RAGMAN'S SON, by Kirk Douglas. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) The actor recalls his life as poor immigrant's son, waiter, steel mill worker, haberdashery salesman, film star, father and man. 5 5 11 THE DUCHESS OF WINDSOR, by Charles Higham. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.) The life of the woman from Baltimore who married King Edward VIII. 6 6 12 GENERATION OF SWINE, by Hunter S. Thompson. (Summit, $18.95.) Commentary on the current decade. 7 7 5 TRANSFORMATION, by Whitley Strieber. (Beech Tree/Morrow, $18.95.) The author of ''Communion'' tells of more confrontations with ''intelligent nonhumans.'' 8 1 PRESS ON! by Chuck Yeager and Charles Leerhsen. (Bantam, $17.95.) The legendary pilot on flying, the outdoors and his West Virgina roots. 9 8 42 TRUMP, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. 10 1 THEY WENT THATAWAY, by Malcolm Forbes. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) How the famous (and the infamous) met their end. 11 9 16 TALKING STRAIGHT, by Lee Iacocca with Sonny Kleinfield. (Bantam, $21.95.) More experiences and opinions of the Chrysler chairman. 12 10 8 SENATORIAL PRIVILEGE, by Leo Damore. (Regnery Gateway, $19.95.) A reporter's reassessment of the 1969 accident on Chappaquiddick Island. 13 11 46 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $19.95.) The author discusses ways for companies to survive in today's and tomorrow's turbulent world. 13 1 ONE SIZE DOESN'T FIT ALL, by John Madden with Dave Anderson. (Villard, $16.95.) Observations on football and a host of other subjects by the television commentator and former coach. 15 12 9 ALMOST GOLDEN, by Gwenda Blair. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The career of the television anchorwoman Jessica Savitch and the ways of newscasting during the past two decades. 16 * 13 16 RIDING THE IRON ROOSTER, by Paul Theroux. (Putnam, $21.95.) A yearlong journey by train through China. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 65 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 2 4 4 ALL YOU CAN DO IS ALL YOU CAN DO, BUT ALL YOU CAN DO IS ENOUGH! by A. L. Williams. (Nelson, $14.95.) The philosophy of a highly successful entrepreneur who deals in life insurance and investments. 3 2 157 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $16.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 4 3 26 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 5 5 44 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) The Second College Edition of a standard work, updated in 1982. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) A BRIGHT SHINING LIE: John Paul Vann and America in Vietnam, by Neil Sheehan. (Random House, $24.95.) This ambitious 861-page monument to the disillusion of Vietnam is both the story of the war and the story of an American hero who proved as complex, ambiguous and disappointing as the war itself. THE FACTS: A Novelist's Autobiography, by Philip Roth. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.95.) Mr. Roth's simple subtitle fronts for a combined short novel, apologia, confession, nostalgia exercise, self-explication and several other modes and entities. NELLY'S VERSION, by Eva Figes. (Pantheon, Paper, $8.95.) A woman who has lost her identity to masculine conventions finds clarity through amnesia and dual personality in this shrewdly executed feminist satire (first published in Britain in 1977). THE SYKAOS PAPERS, by E. P. Thompson. (Pantheon, $19.95.) An alien explorer (Sykaos is Earth in his language) and a female anthropologist combine in many ways in this rich, tricky, ultimately despairing novel by the distinguished British historian. THE AGES OF GAIA: A Biography of Our Living Earth, by James Lovelock. (Norton, $16.95.) Whether the earth is a single organism or not, Mr. Lovelock's illuminating arguments for his thesis should inspire respect and admiration for this clever planet. UNSENT LETTERS: Irreverent Notes From a Literary Life, by Malcolm Bradbury. (Viking, $16.95.) Memoirs masquerading as satiric essays, witty always, labored sometimes, by Britain's prime novelist of academe's deep and dreadful groves. WE ARE NOT AFRAID: The Story of Goodman, Schwerner, and Chaney and the Civil Rights Campaign for Mississippi, by Seth Cagin and Philip Dray. (Macmillan, $22.50.) A detailed recounting of the murders of three civil rights workers in 1964 by an appalling conspiracy of Klansmen and police officers. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: AND THE BAND PLAYED ON: Politics, People, and the AIDS Epidemic, by Randy Shilts. (Penguin, $12.95.) ''AIDS did not just happen to America,'' Randy Shilts writes in his chronicle of the pandemic. ''It was allowed to happen.'' And, he concludes, the Reagan Administration, public health officials, the communications media and the leadership of the gay community all share the blame. Last year, The Times's Christopher Lehmann- Haupt called the book ''a heroic work of journalism.'' ROCK SPRINGS, by Richard Ford. (Vintage, $6.95.) Sick of pretending that it is really possible to change his aimless life, a character in the story ''Rock Springs'' is momentarily astonished to find himself stranded in a motel parking lot, looking for another car to steal. The other pieces in Richard Ford's collection are also about marginal men and women (even some marginal children), drifters whose lives have a way of jumping the track. ''The finest of [ these stories ] achieve luminous moments, moments with potential to change how the reader sees and thinks,'' our reviewer, John Wideman, said last year. ARMED AND DANGEROUS: The Rise of the Survivalist Right, by James Coates. (Noonday/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $8.95.) The paranoid fanatics who belong to The Order, Posse Comitatus and the other anti-Semitic groups in James Coates's book call the Federal Government ''ZOG,'' for Zionist Occupational Government, and they stockpile weapons in preparation for a revolution that they are certain is ordained by God. This is ''an excellent piece of work,'' Wayne King said here last year, ''both a good read and a chilling warning.'' WEAVEWORLD, by Clive Barker. (Pocket, $4.95.) The Fugue is a universe woven entirely in a carpet, where a people called the Seerkind hide from their enemies in the outside world. Last year, our reviewer, John Calvin Batchelor, said Clive Barker has created ''a fantastic romance of magic and promise that is at once popular fiction and utopian conjuring.'' FREEDOM SONG: A Personal Story of the 1960s Civil Rights Movement, by Mary King. (Quill/Morrow, $12.95.) In the early 1960's, the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, or ''Snick,'' attracted many of the youngest and most militant of the civil rights workers who interrupted college and career to fight racism in the South. Mary King's chronicle of the movement ''will stand as a monument to that wondrous time,'' Susan Brownmiller said in The Times last year. TEMPTING FATE, by Laurie Alberts. (Washington Square/Pocket, $6.95.) When this first novel about a band of misfits in an Alaskan fishing village was published last year, our reviewer, Deborah Kirk, said it ''ably evokes a climate and style of life that few will ever know, much less imagine. [ It ] is a perceptive work of adventure fiction.'' SECRECY AND POWER: The Life of J. Edgar Hoover, by Richard Gid Powers. (Free Press/Macmillan, $12.95.) In 1924, J. Edgar Hoover replaced the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who had fallen because of the Teapot Dome affair. Almost half a century later, during the Watergate scandal, he died in office. Last year our reviewer, Norval Morris, called this ''the best biography of Hoover so far.'' THE OXFORD GAMBIT, by Joseph Hone. (Collier/ Macmillan, $4.95.) A Soviet mole has burrowed deep within the labyrinth of British intelligence. In 1980, Peter Andrews said here that Joseph Hone's novel ''gives us a view of the world of espionage as a self-contained universe, intricate and deadly, following its own baroque rules.'' IDOLS OF PERVERSITY: Fantasies of Feminine Evil in Fin-de-Siecle Culture, by Bram Dijkstra. (Oxford, $14.95.) In the 19th century, when women began to rebel against their roles as baby-makers, men waged psychological warfare with misogynist art and literature. Last year, our reviewer, Alessandra Comini, called Bram Dijkstra's book ''an ensemble of acrid evidence that will titillate the sadomasochistic set and sadden champions of human rights. . . . Readers may be able to put Mr. Dijkstra's persuasive book down, but they will not be able to forget its message, so applicable to the end of our century - that ideological dualisms, whether about sex or race, are also deadly.'' THE POWER OF SILENCE: Further Lessons of Don Juan, by Carlos Castaneda. (Pocket, $4.95.) In the eighth installment of Carlos Castaneda's tales of the Yaqui sorcerer, the narrator ascends to ever higher planes of consciousness. ''His relationship with his teacher seems more egalitarian than in previous books, and the character of Don Juan appears more modern and less macho,'' Margot Adler said here this year. FIRST LINES: Poems Written in Youth, From Herbert to Heaney. Edited by Jon Stallworthy. (Oxford, $7.95.) To better understand the development of poetic sensibility, Jon Stallworthy collected verse written by great poets when they were young. ''Many of the poems . . . are moving, over and above their literary value, as reminders of the exaltations and uncertainties of growing up,'' John Gross said in The Times in 1987. A CASE OF LONE STAR, by Kinky Friedman. (Berkley, $3.50.) Country western singers are being murdered in a Manhattan nightspot, and our hero, a musician turned detective named Kinky (named after the musician turned author Kinky Friedman) manages to catch the killer. ''It's all very refreshing, this un-self-conscious meld of author and not so fictional character,'' Newgate Callendar said in The Book Review last year.

title: Under the Coral Sea
description: THERE IS AN ISLAND IN OUR MINDS. IT IS made of fairy tales, cartoons, adventure stories, sea chanteys, pirate lore, ''The Tempest,''

title: B. J. KILCOYNE WED TO MS. LIVINGSTON
description: The marriage of Martha Evarts Tracy Livingston, the daughter of Mrs. W. Putnam Livingston of Keene, N.H., and the late Mr. Livingston, to Brian Joseph Kilcoyne, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Kilcoyne of North Andover, Mass., took place yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Jaffrey Center, N.H. The Rev. Allen A. Tinker, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Nelson Howard 3d, performed the ceremony.

title: Key Excerpts From Speech By President
description: Following are excerpts from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's acceptance speech on his election as state Presdient today, as translated by Reuters from the official Russian text issued by Tass:

title: Ellen Zachos Married To a Record Producer
description: Ellen Zachos, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kimon S. Zachos of Manchester, N.H., and A. T. Michael MacDonald, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur T. MacDonald of Portsmouth, N.H., were married yesterday in Manchester. The Rev. David G. Phreaner, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Currier Gallery of Art.

title: Creating Penthouses From Air Rights
description: FROM Park Avenue through Chelsea to Greenwich Village, perspicacious Manhattan developers are coming up with innovative ways to create expensive new space out of thin air by adding floors atop existing buildings and selling the resulting penthouses for millions.

title: NEW COURT TERM MAY SHOW EXTENT OF REAGAN'S INFLUENCE
description: The Supreme Court returns from a three-month recess on Monday to open a new term that is likely to provide the measure of President Reagan's success in his eight-year attempt to shift the Court in a more conservative direction.

title: Give 'Em Hell, Mike
description: Given George Bush's natural advantages, as the designated heir of a highly popular President in prosperous times, he has a surprisingly narrow lead in this campaign. The election is still there to be won by Michael Dukakis.

title: Abenakis' Chief Pursues Cause Through Conflict
description: The Abenaki Tribal Council is housed in the old railroad station on the outskirts of this town five miles south of the Canadian border. The station is run down and too small to accommodate the tribal chief's vision of an Abenaki nation.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our home is covered with aluminum siding in a blue-gray color. Last Halloween, children threw eggs against one corner, leaving a stain. There are also some white stains from bird droppings. The rains have lightened these stains considerably, but I have been reluctant to scrub the siding, as I have heard this might strip it down to the bare metal. Is it all right to use a hose and some mild cleaner to try and remove these stains, or will this tend to strip off the finish?

title: Joanne Smyrk Married To John Nolan Andrea
description: St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Joanne Smyrk, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Rodney Smyrk of Manhasset, to John Nolan Andrea, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Andrea Jr., of Old Brookville, L.I. The Rev. Edward Doherty performed the ceremony.

title: Virginia Smith Wed To Douglas J. Ellison
description: Virginia Loving Smith, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Calton Smith Jr. of Charlotte, N.C., was married there yesterday to Douglas James Ellison, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Henry Ellison Jr. of Simsbury, Conn. The Rev. Henry N. Parsley Jr. performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Marybeth Dorman Weds Thomas David Jacobson
description: Marybeth Dorman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Dorman of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to Thomas David Jacobson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Jacobson of Westfield, N.J. The Rev. Kenneth White performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Bethel Park, Pa.

title: Throngs March to Anti-Pinochet Rally
description: Opponents of Gen. Augusto Pinochet concluded their campaign to defeat him in Wednesday's presidential plebiscite with a huge rally today that brought people from the farthest corners of the country.

title: Reviews/Dance; Anita Feldman Designs Tap Abstractions
description: Anita Feldman employs traditional tap steps in untraditional ways by choreographing tap dances that -though they lack specific subject matter - are so varied in mood and rich in dynamic shadings that they could be called abstract paintings in motion. She displayed some fine tap abstractions Thursday night when her company, Anita Feldman Tap, performed in the auditorium of the Whitney Museum of American Art at Equitable Center.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: East; Penn State's Sacca Wins in First Start
description: Tony Sacca, the first true freshman to start at quarterback in Joe Paterno's 23 seasons as coach, threw for two touchdowns tonight as Penn State routed Temple, 45-9.

title: THE FLOATING ADULTERERS
description: THE CHINESE WESTERN Short Fiction From Today's China. Translated by Zhu Hong. 224 pp. New York: Available Press/ Ballantine Books. Paper, $5.95.

title: The Art of Navajo Sand Paintings
description: METICULOUSLY the old Navajo brushes the flat ground, then begins to spread the layer of sand that in another time and another place would have been the way to make a sick man well, the means to put the universe in balance.

title: No Headline
description: Dr. Katherine Lucy Swan, a fellow in rheumatology at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, and Dr. Geoffrey Steven Ginsburg, a fellow in cardiology at Beth Israel Hospital and Children's Hospital in Boston, were married yesterday at the Bel Age Hotel in West Hollywood, Calif. The Rev. Dr. John Lloyd Ogilvie, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: INSIDE
description: Smoking Ban for Officers

title: Asbestos: Two Troubling Aspects
description: THOUSANDS of buildings in New Jersey are contaminated with asbestos, and most of them will undergo remediation in the coming years. The remediation process could be hazardous to health, but the abatement contractor's insurance policy may not be worth the paper on which it's printed.

title: Giant Neon Eagle To Soar Once More
description: LEAD: GOING home to the nest for a while can be more than restful; sometimes it can inspire a new outlook on life. So might attest the Anheuser-Busch neon eagle in Newark.

title: DATA UPDATE: October 2, 1988
Columbia Shows Signs, but Not Enough
description: Columbia's record losing streak moved to 44 and counting today. A loss in each of the seven games left this season and the Lions will have more consecutive football defeats than any college football team in history - major, medium or small college.

title: Miles to Go
description: To the Editor:

title: Jonathan Winthrop, an Architect, Wed To Sydney Cheston, a Student, in Maine
description: Sydney Cheston, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Morris Cheston of Philadelphia and Somesville, Me., and Jonathan Winthrop, a son of Angela F. Winthrop of Hamilton, Mass., and the late Frederic Winthrop, were married yesterday in Northeast Harbor, Me. The Rev. F. Goldthwaite Sherrill performed the ceremony at St. Mary's by-the-Sea Episcopal Church.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Too Many Duchesses for Gide When Proust first submitted ''Remembrance of Things Past'' to the Nouvelle Revue Francaise, it was read and rejected by Andre Gide, who is supposed to have said of the manuscripts ''They're full of duchesses, not at all our style.'' Here we see two of the other editors having second thoughts. This is from ''Gaston Gallimard: A Half-Century of French Publishing'' by Pierre Assouline (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich).

title: Lillian Hellman's Temperament
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: VISITORS who want to see Francie Berger, Keith Fetridge and Karsten Kristensen must first share a waiting room with a six-foot hippopotamus that carries a surfboard. Then they are escorted to a room where another hippo stands by the window, ''Betsy Ross'' sits with the Stars and Stripes draped over her lap, Mr. Fetridge and Mrs. Berger are playing with plastic bricks, and Mr. Kristensen - who also pays with the toy bricks - drops by regularly to see how everyone is doing.

title: Ranger Fan Knows the Score
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Gorbachev's Shake-Up: Logical and Apparently Urgent
description: The shakeup in the Soviet leadership this week, although unexpected in its timing and breadth, represents a logical step in Mikhail S. Gorbachev's effort to restructure the political system and flows from the other initiatives he has taken to reshape the country since assuming power in March 1985.

title: In Praise of Follies: Britain and Ireland
description: IT IS SAFE TO SAY THAT BRITAIN AND IRELAND contain what must be the known world's greatest assemblage of follies - those eccentric and generally useless temples, grottoes and castles built, often at great cost, to satisfy the whim of the builder. The sorts of construction, in other words, that provoke the beholder to utter the good old Anglo-Saxon cries of ''Coo!'' or ''Cor!''

title: Reviews/Dance; Kevin Jeff's Choreography In a Benefit Performance
description: The Jubilation Dance Company had a good reason to celebrate when it offered a benefit performance Friday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. This season it will embark upon its second international and fourth American tour. No wonder Jubilation was jubilant.

title: Round and Round in Circles the New Issues Go
