description: THE United States Postal Service is issuing a particularly attractive set of four stamps this weekend to recall the golden days of carrousels. The 25-cent stamps, in blocks of four, are part of the popular folk art series.

title: Parole Action Could Close Landmark Murder Case
description: Sometime early next month, New York State prisoner 66A0003 will ask the Parole Board to write the final chapter in the Wylie-Hoffert murder case - a landmark legal saga that was pivotal in abolishing the state's death penalty and in restricting police interrogations throughout the country.

title: New Drive to Save Old Current Events
description: LEAD: FOR Lynne Newell and Barry Woods, very old news is very good news. For instance, the discovery in someone's attic of a very old but well-preserved Connecticut newspaper is the kind of thing that makes their day.

title: Testing the Limits
description: RICHARD III Starring Laurence Olivier (in photo), Cedrick Hardwicke, Ralph Richardson, John Gielgud, Claire Bloom. Produced and directed by Laurence Olivier. 1955. 155 minutes. Janus Classic Collection. Nelson Entertainment. $19.98

title: State Laboratories Quietly Tackling Threats to Health
description: LEAD: LESS than a day after syringes and blood vials began washing up on New Jersey beaches last summer, the state's Public Health and Environmental Laboratories here confirmed what many had feared: some of the blood showed evidence of exposure to the AIDS virus. Even so, the experts said, there was no danger of contracting the disease from the grisly tide because time and cold ocean temperatures would have killed any AIDS virus.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: HARD CANDY. By Barbara Condos. (Morrow, $20.95.) As Barbara Condos, the real-life model for Damon Runyon's Little Miss Marker, tells her life story, she was no Marie Antoinette but has led a life that makes for diverting and sometimes engaging reading. Daughter of the well-known fight promoter Hymie Caplin, the bright and beautiful Babsie ran with a glamorous and wealthy crowd.

title: Boxing Ends in Controversy
description: After two weeks of controversy, turmoil and hostility in a cauldron called the Chamshil Students' Gymnasium, it probably would have been too much to expect the boxing competition to end with the Olympic spirit prevailing. So what might otherwise have been considered a good showing by an inexperienced team from the United States was forgotten today in another round of protest, which included allegations of possible bribery.

title: Miss Murphy Marries John Cannizzaro
description: St. John's Episcopal Church in Little Silver, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Rachel Elizabeth Murphy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Bradford Murphy of Little Silver and Harwichport, Mass., to John Anthony Cannizzaro, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Cannizzaro of South Plainfield, N.J. The Rev. Mark Van Sant performed the ceremony.

title: Fishing for a Cooler Idea
description: TRUE to the adage that necessity is the mother of invention, Dennis Calton came upon his product because he was fed up. A stream fisherman, the 30-year-old had a habit of putting his hand-held lunch cooler aside as he worked his way casting upstream - only to watch it go the way of the fish. ''I got tired of losing my six-pack,'' he said.

title: Accord on 3-Year Pact Is Announced at Deere
description: Negotiators for Deere & Company and the United Automobile Workers reached a tentative agreement today on a three-year contract affecting more than 13,400 workers, company and union spokesmen said.

title: The Full Life Can be Full of Values Too
description: ''Full Life, Empty Values'' by Linda Gass [ Opinion, Aug. 21 ] correctly points out that a successful economic system must also be compatible with a value system. Her desire to have our value system ''teach our children to be the best, not just have the best'' is commendable. However, her outrage at ''what it is our generation is teaching its children'' is myopic.

title: Postscripts for the Next President
description: ''A BRIEFING for the Next President,'' a series of columns in the Business Forum, featured articles by Lester C. Thurow (Aug. 21) and Robert L. Heilbroner (Sept. 4). The articles prompted an unusually strong response from readers concerned about keeping America competitive. Some of their comments follow:

title: New Keepers for Lighthouses
description: LEAD: TWO years ago, a member of the Norwalk Seaport Association saw a real-estate advertisement. The Sheffield Island lighthouse, which had been owned by the same family since the Coast Guard decommissioned it in 1914, was for sale.

title: Where Ancient Peoples Thrived
description: NORTHERN ARIZONA is so vast and rocky and windswept that first-time visitors sometimes wonder how the ancient peoples of the Southwest came to live there. At sunset, or during one of the region's violent thunderstorms, the light may be extraordinary, incandescent gold pouring through purple clouds, and the expanse of space is sublime. But as you drive across the starkly beautiful land, stopping at 600- and 700-year-old pueblos built on treeless mesas and outcroppings of rock, watching the rain evaporate before it hits the ground, you can't help thinking that whatever the esthetic and metaphysical advantages, at times it must have been a hellish place to live.

title: Canada's Misty Isles
description: LEAD: THE MISTY, MYSTERIOUS CHARLOTTES. Here there be neither snow nor ice but interesting characters in abundance.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE QUEUE. By Vladimir Sorokin. Translated by Sally Laird. (Readers International, Cloth, $16.95; Paper, $8.95.) This short, absurdist tale by a Soviet book designer, which originally appeared in France in 1985, is set in a monumental Moscow queue. There is a dreamlike illogic about a queue - its assurance that nonproductivity (industry's) begets more nonproductivity (the people's) - that seems to hold an appeal for satirists.

title: June C. Palumbo Weds J. M. Meyer
description: The marriage of June Carolyn Palumbo, a personnel recruiter at the New York advertising agency of McCann-Erickson, to James Martin Meyer, a management supervisor and a senior vice president at Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton, a New York advertising agency, took place yesterday in New York. The Rev. Damian A. O'Connell performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church.

title: It's Now or Never on Shoreham
description: IF Long Islanders want Shoreham to close, and I believe that the overwhelming majority does; if Long Islanders want the lowest utility rates possible, and I know the overwhelming majority does; then there can be no argument. Our settlement is not only the best way to go; it's the only way to go. First Shoreham. The settlement closes Shoreham once and for all, now and forever. It ends the Shoreham nightmare: years of divisiveness, uncertainty and tens of millions of dollars in lawyers' fees, which have benefitted no one, except possibly the lawyers.

title: Joanne Trout Is Bride Of Craig Michael Cutler
description: The marriage of Joanne Elizabeth Trout, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Trout of Old Greenwich, Conn., to Craig Michael Cutler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Cutler of Wilmington, Del., took place yesterday at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Avery Manchester performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: A CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sept. 25 misstated Alfred Faiella's job title. He is executive director of the Newark Economic Development Corporation.

title: New Chairman of the K.G.B.: Vladimir Aleksandrovich Kryuchkov
description: Has been a deputy director of the K.G.B., or Committee on State Security since 1978 . . . Vaulted over the head of two more senior deputies in appointment today to replace Viktor M. Chebrikov . . . Is also an army general . . . Joined the K.G.B. in 1967 when Yuri V. Andropov, who later served as Soviet leader, was head of the secret police and intelligence agency . . . Appointed deputy chairman in 1978 by Mr. Andropov . . . Elected to party Central Committee in 1986 . . . Apparently viewed with favor by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, although ties between the two men are not visible in the public record of their careers . . . Is said to be the man who has supervised the handling of Edward Lee Howard, the C.I.A. agent who defected several years ago . . . Before joining the K.G.B., worked in the party apparatus in Moscow from 1959 to 1967 . . . Trained as a lawyer, served as a public prosecutor before working for the party . . . Born in 1924.

title: Life Among Motown's Machiavellis
description: TEN years ago last summer, I resigned as an editor at Fortune magazine and moved to Detroit to join the public affairs staff of the Ford Motor Company. My job: to help communicate company positions on regulatory issues.

title: Catherine Ziehm Weds
description: Catherine S. Ziehm, a daughter of Frederick G. Ziehm of Albany and the late Ruth Hickey Ziehm, was married yesterday to Mark Warkala, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Warkala of Point Pleasant, N.J. The Rev. John Halborg performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York. The bride is a securities analyst at McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei in New York. Mr. Warkala is a financial analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: Cristina Ryan, Editor, Weds Andrew Wilson
description: Cristina Ryan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Ryan of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married at the Lotos Club in New York yesterday to Andrew Wilson, the son of William S. Wilson 3d and Ann Wilson, both of New York. Justice Harold Silverman of State Supreme Court in the Bronx performed the ceremony.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Soccer; Soviets Top Brazil For First Gold Since '56
description: The Soviet Union won its first Olympic gold medal in soccer since 1956 tonight in the Olympic Stadium, beating Brazil in overtime, 2-1. Afterward the team's coach proclaimed Soviet soccer ready to join the sport's international elite.

title: Reviews/Music; Sheryl Woods Sings Rosina in ''Barbiere'
description: The beginnings of Friday's ''Barbiere di Siviglia'' at the New York City Opera did not promise great things: tired orchestral intonation in the overture, a wan Almaviva, serious dislocations between stage and pit. It was Rosina's appearance that cheered things up immeasurably.

title: Octoberfest Fare in East Patchogue
description: AUTUMN's nippy nights and hearty German food are a perfect pair. Both are available now at East Patchogue's Pine Grove Inn, where they've been serving skyscraper-size portions of German fare since 1910. October also brings the added bonus of German music and Octoberfest gaiety.

title: Driven wild in Sicily
description: AFTER MORE THAN 20 YEARS OF marriage, I still have an urge to get away with my wife to a beautiful subtropical island. But as we sat stranded on the Autostrada del Sole, I wondered whether Sicily was a wise choice. We could already see the island's thorny spine on the far side of the Straits of Messina, but a phalanx of cars seven miles long stood between us and the ferry port. We had set off from Rome early in the week to avoid traveling on a national holiday, but throngs of Italians had had the same idea and were, as they say, making il ponte -bridging the gap between the weekend and the holiday by skipping a few days of work.

title: Anne Cameron Married on L.I.
description: The marriage of Anne Hamilton Cameron, a daughter of Mrs. Richard R. Dailey of New York and Lyme, Conn., and William A. Cameron of New York and East Hampton, L.I., to Terrence Patrick Cunningham took place yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton. The bridegroom is a son of Col. and Mrs. James J. Cunningham of Lancaster, Pa., and Rock Hall, Md. The Rev. Francis B. Creamer Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Sodium: The Lights of Choice
description: LEAD: AS a result of the Long Island Lighting Company's phasing out its street-lighting operations, 55 Long Island municipalities have had to determine whether they will keep their older incandescent and mercury vapor street lights or upgrade to a more efficient system.

title: A Divided Electorate Ponders Which Israel Is the Right One
description: With critically important parliamentary elections only 30 days away, Israel seems evenly divided on what kind of a country it should be: an assertively nationalistic and unyielding nation of the right, or a more conciliatory and traditionally liberal state of the left.

title: THE PROMISE THAT FAILED
description: The artificial-heart project is one example of what is wrong with our health-care system. An effective health-care system requires macro-thinking about all the environmental, emotional and social factors involved. However, the medical world, with our compliance, is run by the micro-minded, looking in the wrong direction for the wrong answers. We are running up enormous emotional and financial expenditures as we try to save 10 with draconian transplants and chemotherapies, while we lose 10,000 to the damaging life styles and pollutants that should be the primary focus of our concern. LORETTA HIRSCH Washington

title: Leaders and Experts Join in Child Care Drive
description: Organized child care, it has long been argued, is beneficial to children, to working parents and to families. But more and more, organized child care is also being considered essential to a healthy economy.

title: How Title Insurance Comes to the Rescue
description: WHEN a next-door neighbor staked out an area to build an addition to his home, a couple in lower Westchester believed the stakes were on their property line. So they contacted their title insurance company, which entered the dispute and provided $5,000 for legal costs. The result was that the stakes were moved. When a real-estate lawyer in Carmel was convicted of stealing $791,000 in closing funds from clients, the homeowners with adequate title insurance were assured of compensation for their losses.

title: A Look Beyond Summerfare
description: LEAD: SURPRISE over the cancellation of Pepsico Summerfare has given way to speculation, as members of Westchester's arts community begin assessing the effect of the festival's demise on the county's cultural future.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: New Rochelle Events New Rochelle continues its tricentennial celebration with three events this week. An exhibition at the public library, ''The Restoration of an Old City,'' traces the 20th-century history of La Rochelle in southern France, revealing some parallels with its Westchester counterpart. Prepared by Daniel Pesche, a La Rochelle architect, the collection of photographs, postcards and three-dimensional models describes a period of deterioration between the World Wars and the recent program of renewal in which the city's architectural and cultural heritage was restored. It will be on view until Oct. 12.

title: NEW MAN AT K.G.B.
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev consolidated his leadership of the Soviet Union today by taking over the presidency of the country to match his role as head of the Communist Party.

title: Suzanne Stroble Weds Douglas Richard Sitter
description: The wedding of Suzanne Louise Stroble, the daughter of Charles R. Stroble of Greenwich, Conn., and Mrs. Henry L. Coon of Bronxville, N.Y., to Douglas Richard Sitter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Sitter of Bronxville, took place yesterday in Washington. Msgr. J. Joshua Mundell performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Epiphany.

title: Store Ceiling Yields 3 Boys
description: Three boys lived for nine days inside the suspended ceiling of a department store until the manager checked to see why the burglar alarm had been ringing off and on for days. Two of the boys, both 13 years old, left home Sept. 19 and set up camp in the Zayre store.

title: MISHEARD WORDS
description: Jack Rosenthal's column on misheard words (On Language, ''Misheard, Misread, Misspoken,'' Aug. 28) reminded me of a peculiar theological notion from my own childhood. I thought God's first name was Howard. I got that from the Lord's Prayer: . . . Howard be Thy name. DAVID MCCRAW West Park, N.Y.

title: Martha Graham Dances With the Future
description: Martha Graham sits in an airy mirrored studio on East 63d Street in Manhattan,immaculately made up, her skinned-back hair crowned by a wide floppy black chiffon bow that flares out over her pointed ears and somehow looks like Cleopatra's coiffure. She wears Mary Janes on her famous feet and chunks of turquoise around her neck. Only the hunch of her back and arthritic knobs on the hands she habitually sheathes in gloves betray her age. She is 94. She is gazing at a young woman, Terese Capucilli, as sinuous and strong as a whip, dancing the lead with Donlin Foreman in Miss Graham's 1940 work, ''Letter to the World,'' an homage to Emily Dickinson's poetry and soul.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Basking Ridge $262,000 43 Decker Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 37-year-old Cape Cod; family room, den, deck, 2 fireplaces; taxes $3,254. Budd Lake $189,000 18 Falcon Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 46-year-old Cape Cod; den, hardwood floors, fireplace, full basement; taxes $2,680. Maplewood $152,000 16 Brown Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 38-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, eat-in kitchen, porch, den; taxes $2,749. Millburn $213,500 71 Myrtle Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 42-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,954. Randolph $156,000 157 Franklin Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 85-year-old Victorian; patio, hardwood floors, new kitchen; taxes $1,881. South Orange $320,000 372 Hartford Road 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 27-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage, deck; taxes $6,828. OTHER AREAS North Tarrytown, N.Y. $280,000 139 Hunter Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 61-year-old Tudor; fireplace, sunroom, porch, walk to station; taxes $4,460. Somers, Conn. $235,000 160 Rosehaven Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 6-year-old Cape Cod; skylights, woodstove, 1 acre; taxes $1,900. East Patchogue, L.I. $138,000 64 Lyman Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old ranch; dining room, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $2,200.

title:
ART;
Powerful Imagery Evoked in Lipton Retrospect
description: LEAD: THE exhibition surveying the career of the late sculptor Seymour Lipton, on view through next Sunday in the 10th-floor gallery of the Axinn Library at Hofstra University in Hempstead, offers a small but representative selection of his works.

title: Elsa Margaret Kellstrom Weds Dwight Stocker 3d
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Morristown, N.J., Elsa Margaret Kellstrom, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arne A. Kellstrom of Singapore, was married yesterday to Dwight Lathrop Stocker 3d, a son of Mrs. Thomas Webb of London and the late Mr. Stocker Jr. The Rev. Phillip Dana Wilson performed the ceremony.

title: THE NATION: Change of Command; A New NASA Guides Space Program Into the Post-Challenger Era
description: THE agency responsible for launching the space shuttle Discovery last week has new leadership and a new organization since it was shaken to its roots by the explosion of the Challenger in 1986.

title: ARMY CRUSHES BUCKNELL
description: Army, which failed to complete a pass in beating Northwestern a week ago, completed 4 of 5 passes today against another team without a victory, Bucknell. But, as was the case against Northwestern, the Cadets needn't have bothered going to the air in view of their awesome running game.

title: 'La Cage' In All Its Splendor
description: YES, the Paper Mill Playhouse is doing ''La Cage aux Folles'' justice, totally. This is a splendiferous production of a splendiferous musical - and that's not all there is to that.

title: Out of a Clear Blue Sky, a 'Love Affair' of Collecting
description: THE exhibition ''A Love Affair'' comes to the Montclair Art Museum much as love comes to individuals - out of a clear blue sky. A selection of 72 works, it was culled from a collection five times the size that a New Jersey couple have been amassing - unbeknownst to the art world - for the last half century.

title: Fordham's New Theologian: a Flair for Diplomacy
description: When Avery Dulles took up his duties last month as the first occupant of the Prof. Laurence J. McGinley Chair in Religion and Society at Fordham University, he came bearing a reputation as one of the nation's most eminent theologians.

title: Nancy Ware Marries D. C. Shepard in Iowa
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in Sioux City, Iowa, Nancy Melissa Ware, an associate with the Philadelphia law firm of Schnader, Harrison, Segal & Lewis, was married yesterday to David Chauncey Shepard, a management consultant for Touche Ross in San Francisco. The Rev. William F. Skinner performed the ceremony.

title: The Tangled Case Of Artists' Agent
description: HE WAS described once in a magazine profile as one of the world's most successful agents for fashion photographers, with receipts estimated at $12 million a year. In January he was portrayed in a news article as an ''agent who left by night,'' reputedly leaving in his wake a mountain of debt, unpaid fees to artists and no forwarding address.

title: Karl Weintz and Teryn L. Bevan Exchange Vows
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., Teryn Leigh Bevan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Bevan 2d of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Karl Frederick Weintz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Frederick Weintz Jr. of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Jack Bishop performed the ceremony.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Montpelier, Vt.;
Timberland Sale Lights No Fires
description: LEAD: IT was billed as the Great North Country Land Auction, a huge sale that was to be closely watched for its effect on land prices and development trends in northern New England.

title: A Pair of Shows for a Pair of Trendy Twins
description: To someone outside the orbit of SoHo, reputations in contemporary art can seem based as much on manipulation as on merit. There is a widely held but seldom-voiced suspicion that a cabal of New York dealers, curators and critics periodically conspires to put certain names on the artistic map regardless of the ultimate merit of the work involved. Even within the contemporary scene, one can find skeptics who believe that the ''hot'' artists of any given moment are merely a creation of the marketplace, propelled to public attention by that calculated, artificial and blatant form of stimulation known as hype.

title: Miss Stafford Weds Doctor
description: Carolyn Anne Stafford, an associate at the Boston law firm of Hill & Barlow, and Dr. Eric H. Stein, a resident in head and neck surgery at the Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary, were married yesterday at the Hilton Hotel in Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Barbara Jenkins, a Presbyterian minister, and Rabbi Charles Davidson performed the ceremony.

title: Social Events; Aid for Many Needs
description: Graham Returns

title: Starting Sundays With Klaus Column
description: Reading the Long Island Section of The Sunday Times used to be O.K; it was nice reading about local events in Nassau and out in the Hamptons. Nice, but not fun and exciting.

title: Melissa Fogelman Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Fogelman of North Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melissa Beth Fogelman, to Eric Steven Redleaf, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Redleaf of Dellwood, Minn. Miss Fogelman is a second-year medical student at Washington University in St. Louis, where her fiance, an engineer with Emerson Electric in St. Louis, is studying for an M.B.A. degree.

title: U.S. Studying Safety of Workers On Top-Secret Jet Fighter Project
description: Federal health inspectors and Pentagon investigators have begun a joint inquiry into assertions by Lockheed Corporation workers that they are endangered by chemicals used in making the top-secret Stealth fighter.

title: Pinelands Debate, Then and Now
description: HIS law office rises 36 stories above the sophisticated spaces of Rockefeller Center, but when Franklin E. Parker checks his wristwatch he is reminded of New Jersey's wildest spot. The timepiece's face carries a drawing of a pine cone and a cluster of pine needles, symbols of the vast New Jersey Pine Barrens, which Mr. Parker helped protect for nine years as the first and, until last May, only chairman of the New Jersey Pinelands Commission.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Castles and Dreams
description: LEAD: Years ago, when he was a boy growing up in New Rochelle, Stephen P. Tenore used to play around two old stone castles at Glen Island, imagining that they were fortresses for brave knights or brash pirates.

title: Crossing Obstacles for 'Delancey'
description: IF it isn't one obstacle, it's another for the film maker Joan Micklin Silver, who has a knack for sidestepping them. ''I just keep on keepin' on, peddling scripts,'' as she put it. And those scripts, according to the description of her husband, Raphael Silver, are ''about real people and real relationships, with warmth and humor; not the obvious stuff that'll sell.''

title: Auto Insurance: Another Aspect
description: Representative Jim Courter's Aug. 14 Opinion page article, ''Auto Insurance: A Better Way,'' focuses on the Joint Underwriting Association's mega-buck deficit and argues for fairness for corporate behemoths and a still heavier club of enforcement against the owners of 400,000 uninsured vehicles who disobey the law.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our home is covered with aluminum siding in a blue-gray color. Last Halloween, children threw eggs against one corner, leaving a stain. There are also some white stains from bird droppings. The rains have lightened these stains considerably, but I have been reluctant to scrub the siding, as I have heard this might strip it down to the bare metal. Is it all right to use a hose and some mild cleaner to try and remove these stains, or will this tend to strip off the finish?

title: One Year After, the Market Lives but Matters Less
description: ON October 19, 1987, the New York stock market crashed, sending markets around the world into a dizzying downward spiral. Even before anyone could add up all the losses, forecasts of global recession and worse filled the air.

title:
THEATER;
The Man Behind The Scenes at The Ensemble
description: LEAD: Frank Gilroy, the Pulitzer prize-winning author of ''The Subject Was Roses,'' was the first author to give Curt Dempster a new play to direct, back in 1968. The only place to give it a hearing then was the Actors Studio, where Mr. Dempster was a member of the Directors Unit.

title: Maine Shellfish Deaths
description: The mud flats of Maquoit Bay are off-limits to clam diggers pending results of tests to determine the cause of mass deaths of quahogs, razor clams, mussels, periwinkles, marine worms and soft-shell clams. Some officials suspect a toxic algae. The shellfish harvest is worth about $1.5 million a year.

title: ALL SPENDING BILLS COMPLETED ON TIME
description: President Reagan today signed the last of 13 spending bills for the new Federal fiscal year and praised Congress for completing its work on time.

title: SIGMUND THE CONQUEROR
description: FREUD IN EXILE Psychoanalysis and Its Vicissitudes. Edited by Edward Timms and Naomi Segal. Illustrated. 310 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $32.50.

title: Three in Haiti Force Way Onto Airliner and Are Seized in New York
description: Three armed security guards at the international airport in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, forced their way aboard an American Airlines passenger jet bound for New York City yesterday afternoon, airline officials said. The men were arrested on arrival at John F. Kennedy International Airport at about 8:10 P.M.

title: Two New Museums Offer a Contrast: British Brashness vs. American Reserve
description: New York and London have just acquired a pair of major new cultural institutions, covering much the same fields of interest. Early last month Mayor Koch cut the inaugural ribbon at the American Museum of the Moving Image. A few days later, some 3,000 miles away, the Museum of the Moving Image was formally opened by Prince Charles.

title: The Search for a Lighter Laptop
description: LAPTOP computers are great in theory but disappointing in real life. If you want power, you get weight. If you want less weight, you sacrifice power. But recent advances in technology may change that lamentable equation.

title: In Search of a Star Amid Glitter and Kitsch
description: A portent perhaps. The new television season, in disarray because of the recent writers strike, is getting under way with a Liberace race. Both ABC and CBS have been struggling to finish movie biographies of the flamboyant entertainer who died of AIDS in February 1987. Each network claims initial ignorance of the other's plans. One ABC executive - Allen Sabinson, vice president in charge of motion pictures - admits, however, that the realization that two films were being made on the same subject has been ''painful, unpleasant, annoying and aggravating.'' Welcome, folks, to television land.

title: TAKING THE PULSE ONE YEAR LATER
description: THE crashes of 1987 and 1929 bore an eerie resemblance to each other. For more than three years before both market plunges, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose mightily. And for months after, they followed similar down drafts.

title: ORDER AND CHAOS
description: The crisp facade of Villa Zapu forms an imposing barrier as it cuts across a high ridge of land on the western edge of the Napa Valley. The house, pool and tower-guesthouse form the heart of Anna and Thomas Lundstrom's 130-acre home and winery.

title: RANDI M. BUZIN IS WED TO MITCHELL J. SOLOMON
description: Randi Meryl Buzin, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herman H. Buzin of Massapequa, L.I., was married there last night to Mitchell Jay Solomon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Max M. Solomon of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. Rabbi Sanford Jarashow performed the ceremony at Temple Judea.

title: The Building Wars: News From the Front
description: ANOTHER secret invasion has been launched, not in the jungles of Southeast Asia or Central America, nor in the mountains of Afghanistan. It one waged not by contras, terrorists, or ommunists. I'm referring to the raid by American developers on Connecticut's leafy backyard.

title: The English Find a Revolution on Their Own Shores
description: APART from Dover sole and fish and chips, Great Britain has not been famous for its seafood. One would never think it was an island surrounded by waters teeming with fish to judge by the standard stocked in many of its shops: frozen plaice fillets and codfish sticks (aptly named fish fingers).

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKSBookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Roundup; Yugoslavia Gets Gold in Water Polo
description: It was a repeat of the water polo championship matchup in the 1984 Games. It was a repeat of the outcome, too.

title: Question Of the Week; Which Is The Better Team, '86 Mets, Or '88 Mets?
description: Alas, the answer to the question at hand can be drawn from the tragic history of Romeo and Juliet. The one came too soon, the other too late. Me thinks however that it would be a sweet, sweet union indeed if The Mook '86 at the plate could meet The Doc '88 on the mound (well, this only works if the '88 team wins all the beans too). LOUIS ALTMAN South Fallsburg, N.Y.

title: Caroline Brodnitz Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ernest W. Brodnitz of Harding Township, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Caroline Francoise Brodnitz to Michael Joseph McNally, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph McNally of Denville, N.J. Miss Brodnitz is a vice president of marketing with Mastercard International in New York. Her fiance is a partner and founder of Quadrant Technologies in Englewood Cliffs, N.J. A February wedding is planned.

title: Parking Rules
description: The annual Pulaski Day Parade will begin at noon today at 26th Street and Fifth Avenue, marching north to 52d Street, then east to Third Avenue. Because of the Jewish holidays of Shemini Atzereth and Simhath Torah, which conclude the harvest festival of Succoth, alternate-side parking will be suspended in New York City tomorrow and Tuesday.

title: COMPASS AND MAP ARE HUNTER'S FRIENDS
description: Unless you know the country you are going to hunt this fall and winter like the back of your hand, now is the time to obtain the relevant maps and to make sure that you haven't mislaid your compass.

title: Shading Sun Glare A Healthy Vacuum
description: GREGORY F. AINSWORTH has come up with a solution for page glare, an irritant that bedevils book-reading sun-worshipers.

title: Strait of Magellan
description: To the Editor: In response to the question in the July 17 Q &A column regarding cruises through the Strait of Magellan, I would like to advise you that Sun Line has a cruise on that itinerary.

title: Police and Fire Depts. Face Massachusetts Smoking Ban
description: Massachusetts has become the first state to prohibit newly hired police officers and firefighters from smoking on or off the job.

title: Budapest As a City Of Museums
description: BUDAPEST is a city of museums. Some brim with archeological treasures, others with monumental sculptures, paintings from all parts of Europe, beguiling examples of folklore, fabulous arts and crafts collections, and galleries of exhibits that portray the social, economic and agrarian history of Hungary.

title: Daredevils for the Environment
description: LEAD: ON A GRAY MORNING last spring, the Greenpeace boat Beluga, a 78-foot converted fireboat, circled slowly near the junction of the Saguenay and St. Lawrence rivers in Quebec. Those of us on board - a dozen or so media representatives plus a few young Greenpeace staff members and a Greenpeace video cameraman - stared up at the face of a riverside cliff where two climbers on ropes battled to open a large banner that billowed and snapped above them in the wind.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Baltimore;
Rouse Expands Grip on Harbor
description: LEAD: THE prospective sale of McCormick & Company's real estate holdings on the Baltimore waterfront to a joint venture led by the Rouse Company will give Rouse nearly total ownership of property fronting the Inner Harbor.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Cashing Checks Free in Paris

title: Reviews/Music; William Blaine, a Pianist
description: William Blaine, a pianist who is an artist in residence at Northeast Missouri State University, played a roof-rattling concert at Weill Recital Hall on Friday evening. The performance certainly had its points of interest, and in each of the works he played, Mr. Blaine offered a few unusual interpretive twists. But at times the scope of his ideas outstripped his technical abilities. And while there were no disasters, there were a few cliffhangers, and more than a few inaccuracies.

title: Princeton Drives to 2-0 in Ivy
description: Princeton's drive for its first Ivy League football championship since 1969 cleared an important barrier today. The Tigers beat Brown, 31-27, for the first time in five years and they did it the hard way, by coming from behind in the second half against a sound opponent.

title: Dr. Henry Ilian Wed To Linda Joan Freitag
description: Linda Joan Freitag, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Freitag of Larchmont, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Henry Robert Ilian, the son of Sara Ilian of New York and the late Simon Ilian. Rabbi Gary Bretton-Granatoor performed the ceremony at the Columbia University Faculty House.

title: 80'S ART WITH A PASSPORT TO WEST GERMANY
description: With the Carnegie International and the Whitney Biennial on this art season's horizon, two Boston museums have got the jump on showing us what the newest art of our time might look like. ''American Art of the Late 1980's,'' organized by three curators from the Boston Museum of Fine Arts and the Institute of Contemporary Art, includes the efforts of 26 artists and artist teams and brings together some of the best work being made today. This is a young show, with the majority of those included being born after 1950, and in many ways it is a good one with several innovative features.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE CREW, HALFWAY IN ITS FLIGHT, DOES SCIENTIFIC TESTS
description: The astronauts of the space shuttle Discovery cruised around and around the world today, conducting scientific experiments, reading a youth's letter in a telecast and rehearsing procedures for their return to the Earth on Monday.

title: Three Homeless Seized In Helms Office Protest
description: Three homeless protesters served a homemade ''eviction notice'' on the office of Senator Jesse Helms Friday, removed the furniture from his outer office and then were led off in handcuffs.

title:
DINING OUT;
Inventive Dishes in Maplewood
description: LEAD: ONE of my sternest critics asserts that I prefer small restaurants to large ones. While this is not exactly true, I do confess that I feel like an explorer when I first visit a small unknown restaurant. The hope that this one will be worth the trek into the hinterlands and that the now unknown chef will be the next culinary star is a strong incentive to continue, even though past experience has shown that some small restaurants are so awful they are virtually unreviewable.

title: Sports of The Times; Green to Gold, Now Green Again
description: Once green amateurs, they're Olympic boxing champions now. Ray Mercer, Andrew Maynard, Kennedy McKinney. They hope to turn their gold medals into million-dollar contracts. But in turning pro, they'll soon be green again.

title: Mobutu Agrees to Visit South Africa
description: President P. W. Botha of South Africa was given a red-carpet, brass-band welcome today on his first visit to black Africa's second-most-populous nation.

title: The Many Kinds Of Human Abilities
description: Poor Christine Meding! (''Readung My Way to Success,'' Opinion page, Sept. 4). She has graduated from high school woefully ignorant, in spite of her reading and high S.A.T. scores. She doesn't seem to realize that her linguistic ability is only one of many kinds of human abilities - artistic, mathematical, physical, organizational, entrepreneurial, spatial, interpersonal, mechanical - to name a few.

title: Willie Chan, the Nabob of Hong Kong Cinema
description: Willie Chan, who may be Hong Kong's hottest movie agent, breezed into New York from Vancouver last week to help open the Hong Kong Film Festival at the Asia Society, and breezed right out again to Toronto, demonstrating the out-of-suitcase life style that is the stamp of his trade.

title: Sign of Growth For the Future
description: A sign of growth in the months ahead came in a Government report showing that its chief forecasting gauge rose four-tenths of 1 percent in August. Some analysts interpreted the report as a signal that another dose of higher interest rates from the Federal Reserve might be needed. But others were cautious about drawing such sharp conclusions from a single month's figures. In July the index dropped six-tenths of 1 percent after soaring 1.5 percent in June. The index in August was pushed higher by a drop in average weekly claims for state unemployment benefits and higher orders from manufactured consumer goods.

title: Freeport Police to Fight Prostitution
description: LEAD: FREEPORT officials say that prostitution in some sections of the village is becoming ''more visible and blatant,'' and so to discourage customers and to penalize the streetwalkers with less loss of police time, the village will enact its own prostitution law.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Historic Pillars Take New Form

title: Warm Feelings as Olympics End
description: The Games of the XXIV Olympiad approached their end today amid feelings of warmth, satisfaction, appreciation and relief on the part of the organizers, hosts and participants.

title: 'It's Been A Cycle of Abuse and Neglect'
description: IN autumn, the eyes of most people turn to the woods, where the blazing scarlet of red maple leaves mixes with the golden yellows of beech and the purples of oak. At this time of year, people see only beauty, but professional foresters, like Stephen H. Broderick of the University of Connecticut's Cooperative Extension Service, see some of the problems.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is no need for a long-winded policy speech.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ 1:5. ]

title: CANADIANS DECLINE TO LET WOODS BURN
description: While officials in the United States are beset by controversy over the fires that have destroyed more than two million acres of forest in the Western states, including large parts of Yellowstone National Park, the officials who run Canada's national parks say this country lost less acreage to fire this summer than it did in decades.

title: THE FED'S PLUMBER: E. Gerald Corrigan; A Crisis Manager Takes on the Mechanics of the Market
description: WHEN the declines in stock prices reached alarming proportions last October, the first phone calls by bankers and securities dealers were to E. Gerald Corrigan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bellport $157,000 80 Circuit Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 22-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, deck; taxes $2,300. Bay Shore $485,000 32 Maple Avenue 8-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 86-year-old Victorian; 1 waterfront acre with bulkheading, 3-car garage; taxes $5,700. East Patchogue $138,000 64 Lyman Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old ranch; dining room, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $2,200. Oakdale $134,000 136 Matthews Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 29-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement, laundry room, 1-car garage; taxes $3,300. Smithtown $335,000 6 Teapot Lane 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 30-year-old farm ranch; basement, attic, 2-car garage, 1.1 acres; taxes $4,700. Stony Brook $213,000 6 Silverspruce Lane 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 22-year-old farm ranch; family room, portico, on cul-de-sac, 0.5 acres; taxes $3,700. OTHER SALES North Tarrytown, N.Y. $280,000 139 Hunter Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 61-year-old Tudor; fireplace, sunroom, porch, walk to station; taxes $4,460. Somers, Conn. $235,000 160 Rosehaven Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 6-year-old Cape Cod; skylights, woodstove, 1 acre; taxes $1,900. Maplewood, N.J. $152,000 16 Brown Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 38-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, eat-in kitchen, porch, den; taxes $2,749.

title: Quayle, in Difference With Bush, Urges Tougher Tack in Arms Talks
description: Senator Dan Quayle today outlined a basic difference with the Reagan Administration and Vice President Bush over strategic arms negotiations, saying their pace should be slowed and demands on the Soviet Union should be increased.

title: FOCUS: Broward County, Fla.; A 10,000-Acre City Is Growing in the Everglades
description: AROUND Broward County they call it Muck Mountain - 40 feet of oozing black dirt scraped off the surface of the Everglades so that neat new houses could be built. It is a manmade mountain and from its peak, one of the highest points in this low-lying plain, it is possible in a few seconds to understand the forces that brought it into being.

title: Anne H. Clothier, Winston Haydon, Exchange Vows
description: The marriage of Anne Hopkins Clothier, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Clothier Jr. of Haverford, Pa., and Burgoyne Island, Nova Scotia, to Richard Winston Haydon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rogers Kenneth Haydon of Itta Bena, Miss., took place yesterday in Wayne, Pa. The Rev. Stephen K. Jacobson performed the ceremony in the chapel at St. David's Episcopal Church.

title: DAVID SILVER WED TO AMELIA WOOD
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York, Amelia Sheridan Wood, a daughter of Donald J. Wood of Wayland, Mass., and Mrs. Brian R. Fernandez of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday to David Richard Silver, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Silver of New York. The Rev. Dr. William Johnson of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine and the father of the best man, performed the ceremony.

title: A Case of Deja Vu And Its Aftermath
description: TWO situations arose in quick succession in the final of the Expo team championship in Brisbane, Australia, on Sept. 9. After three days of Swiss qualifying play, a touring American group spearheaded by the world champions Lew Stansby and Chip Martel were opposed by four Australians plus the globe-trotting Pakistani star Zia Mahmood.

title: MISHEARD WORDS
description: There is indeed a word for a phrase that is misheard.

title: An Apples Revival West of the Cascades
description: MOST of us think of an apple as sharp and crisp, with sweet-tart juice and a gentle perfume. But that fruit is too often only a memory, since the apples in supermarkets these days require a shift of expectation. More often than not, they are pulpy and flavorless.

title: The Mental Health Sieve
description: Only Jorge Delgado knew what demons drove him to defile St. Patrick's Cathedral with murderous violence. But his recent rampage, in which he killed an elderly usher and was himself shot down by police, resulted all too predictably from chronic mental health care mismanagement.

title: Concessions After the Preliminary Fumble
description: MOST slashing mating attacks, no matter how imaginative or cunning, would never have had a chance to occur without some preliminary fumbling on the part of the opponent.

title: Go Slow, Even on Son of Star Wars
description: Lieut. Gen. James Abrahamson resigned last week as head of the Star Wars program because deployment of a comprehensive space-based missile shield by the late 1990's is an idea whose time has passed. That, however, prompts new pressure to build a smaller system that seems more plausible than President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative. Yet it would be nearly as questionable, and potentially as destabilizing to the nuclear balance.

title: Correction
description: A diagram last Sunday with an article about retinal cell transplants in rats labeled layers of the retina incorrectly. The layer next to the outer layer, or sclera, is the choroid. Next to that is a layer of retinal pigment epithelial cells, then a layer of photoreceptor cells.

title: CANONIZED AND ANALYZED
description: LEAD: MEMORIES AND HALLUCINATIONS A Memoir. By D. M. Thomas. 195 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: The Attack of the Beeping Intruder
description: Bleep. Bleep. There you are in the midst of a busy workday, waiting for an important message from the West Coast. Suddenly the facsimile machine pulses into action, chirping and buzzing, ejecting a printed page 30 seconds later.

title: Central Islip Area to Get a Facelift
description: LEAD: THE blighted Carleton Park neighborhood of Central Islip will soon get a much-needed facelift.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FIDDLING AROUND What's in a name? Not that much if you're a devotee of traditional music. So what used to be the Fiddlers Convention has become the Long Island Fiddle and Folk Music Festival this year, meaning that today's proceedings are officially open to those who not only fiddle around, so to speak, but also enjoy or make music with banjos, guitars, mandolins and the like.

title: L.B.J.'S HOMESPUN GROUSING
description: I run into the views attributed to Lyndon Johnson all the time - among working-class people and small businessmen, especially in the Midwest, where I grew up. Mr. Goodwin is overintellectualizing. These views can be exceptionally strong when Americans have not undergone a certain level or style of acculturation through education, foreign residence or other countering influences. Perhaps that was the problem - a person locked into provincial fears of liberals, Harvard etc., became President. KARL W. RYAVEC Amherst, Mass.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE EQUALITY TRAP. By Mary Ann Mason. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Women today suffer more economic hardship than their mothers, despite, and in many cases because of, the women's movement. Acting as unwitting handmaidens to the demands of a changing economy, feminists have helped to accelerate the feminization of poverty, says Mary Ann Mason, a lawyer specializing in family law, in ''The Equality Trap.

title: Ritual Pallor Amid Change In the Kremlin
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said it best today as he stood at the huge mahogany lectern emblazoned with a laurel wreath and a hammer and sickle: ''There is no need for a long-winded policy speech.'' The session of the Supreme Soviet that confirmed the Communist Party General Secretary as President was about power, not policy.

title: THE SMACK OF FIRM GOVERNMENT
description: MRS. THATCHER'S REVOLUTION The Ending of the Socialist Era By Peter Jenkins. Illustrated. 417 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $25. THATCHER By Kenneth Harris. Illustrated. 248 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $19.95

title: Let's Go Back to the True Olympic Spirit; Chats and Commercials
description: To the Editor:

title: Clapboard Controversy: Paint or Siding for a 1770 Church
description: A PLAN to cover one of the oldest meetinghouses in the state with vinyl siding rather than to repaint it has touched off a furor in eastern Connecticut.

title: Two Sides of Tyson: Fighter Battles Himself
description: In June 1987, Mike Tyson encountered an acquaintance he had not seen for some time. When she asked how he was, he said simply, ''I'm in love,'' referring to his relationship with the actress Robin Givens. And he blushed.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''This bill represents protectionism at its worst.'' - President Reagan, after he vetoed the textile measure.

title: Haunted Hopes for . . . for What Now?
description: It seems to me that most people live baseball lives informed by one spectacular or calamitous season early in their experience, in my case, age 11, 1949. By that time I was articulate and sure-footed on the subject, having haunted libraries to read about the baseball that had preceded my consciousness of the game. Having attached myself to the Red Sox - an unobserved barnacle on the bottom of their boat - I had witnessed the 1948 playoff loss to Cleveland through pre-adolescent tears behind a closed and locked door. ''Leave me alone!'' I yelled at my father's concerned voice in the hallway.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Barr Takes Lead on Course Record: Dave Barr, charging from 10 shots behind, tied the Green Island Country Club course record yesterday with a nine-under-par 61 to take a 1-shot lead after three rounds of the $400,000 Southern Open tournament. Barr, even-par after 36 holes, overtook the second-round leader, Jeff Sluman, with a round that included nine birdies and finished at 201. Sluman, the P.G.A. champion, stumbled to a 74 and 204 total over the par-70, 6,791-yard course in Columbus, Ga. Mike Hulbert, Lance Ten Broeck and Dan Forsman trailed Barr by one after rounds of 69. Barr's round included birdie putts of 35, 20, 15 and 10 feet. He had a par-saving 23-footer on the 16th hole. (AP) Inkster and McGeorge Share Lead: Juli Inkster and Missie McGeorge each shot 3-under-par 69's yesterday to share the lead after two rounds of the $300,000 L.P.G.A. San Jose Classic. Both were at 6-under-par 138 on the 6,370-yard course at the Almaden Golf and Country Club in San Jose Calif. Missie Berteotti had a 71 for a two-day total of 139. (AP) Charles Takes Lead in Senior Challenge: Bob Charles of New Zealand birdied the final hole to take a one-stroke lead yesterday after two rounds of the $300,000 Senior Challenge at Roswell, Ga. Charles, who leads the Senior PGA Tour in money-winnings, completed his three-under-par 69 with a 3-foot birdie putt. That gave him a 139 total, five under par, for two rounds over the Horseshoe Bend Country Club course. Dick Hendrickson and Bert Yancey, who shared the first-round lead, each had a last-hole birdie, matched par 72 and were tied with Harold Henning at 140. (AP) Strange Shares Lead in Japan: Curtis Strange of the United States shot a two-under-par 70 yesterday to share the lead at seven-under-par 209 after the third day in the $680,000 Tokai Classic in Tokyo, Strange scored birdies on the 12th and 13th holes and an eagle on the 15th after bogeying the 10th and 11th. Tied with Strange in first place were two Australians, Brian Jones and Graham Marsh, the second-round leader, and Yoshitaka Yamamoto of Japan. They were trailed by another Japanese, Yutaka Hagawa, who had a six-under-par total of 210.(AP) Horse Racing Corwyn Bay Wins: Corwyn Bay won the first Cartier Million, the world's richest horse race for 2-year-olds, yesterday at Phoenix Park in Dublin. Ridden by Stephen Crane, the Irish colt weaved through the field of 20 racing along the seven-furlong flat course to make a late run on the inside rail. The victory by Corwyn Bay netted $850,000 for the horse's owner, Tommy Stack. The favorite, Miss Demure of England, ridden by Willie Carson, nosed out French Pretender for second place and $340,000 for her owner, Robert Armstrong.(AP) Tennis Wilander and Carlsson Advance to Final: Top-seeded Mats Wilander easily defeated Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina, and Kent Carlsson, seeded No. 2, edged Thomas Muster of Austria, yesterday, to move into the final of the $123,400 Sicilian Championship at Palermo. Wilander downed Perez-Roldan, 6-2, 6-2, and Carlsson stopped the fourth-seeded Muster, 7-6, 7-5.(AP) Chang Makes His First Grand Prix Final: Sixteen-year-old Michael Chang moved into his first Grand Prix final yesterday by defeating Danie Visser, 7-5, 6-4, in the $415,000 Transamerica tournament in San Francisco. The unseeded Chang, who turned pro in February, is ranked 36th in the world. The left-handed Visser used his serve effectively and attacked Chang's at every opportunity. Visser also used drop shots and lobs well to gain a set point against Chang at 5-4. But Chang cut down on his errors and unleashed a flurry of passing shots and winning volleys to take the first set. The only service break of the second set came in the ninth game when Visser failed to handle Chang's powerful service returns.(AP) Soccer Newcastle Upsets Liverpool: A late goal on a penalty kick by the Brazilian star Mirandinha gave Newcastle United a 2-1 victory at champion Liverpool yesterday on a day of upsets in the English First Division. With the first-place team, Norwich, losing by 3-1 at home to Charlton Athletic, the results meant that Millwall, which is playing in the First Division for the first time, took over the top spot on a 3-2 home victory over Queens Park Rangers. In other upsets, Wimbledon downed Everton, 2-1, at home, and Middlesbrough won, 4-3, at Coventry City.(AP) Dog Show Random Request Is Best in Upset: A wire fox terrier, Ch. Randam Request, owned by the Wishing Wells Kennels and Don Brouillette of Wrentham, Mass., was gaited by Bobby Fisher to top honors yesterday at the Golden Anniversary Show of the Suffolk County Kennel Club on the grounds of Hofstra University, in Hempstead, L.I. The 19-month-old bitch never had taken a best, while all six of the other finalists had been top winners and among them they had a total of 60 major awards.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE VIEW FROM WITHIN: Jazz Writings, 1948-1987. By Orrin Keepnews. (Oxford University, $19.95.) Since the early 1950's Orrin Keepnews has been among the most prolific producers of jazz recordings, and almost as prolific a producer of program notes and articles too. This selection of writings includes entertaining, even valuable pieces about Jelly Roll Morton, Art Tatum and Charlie Parker as well as ''Inside the Recording Booth,'' which is probably the best description yet written of how a jazz recording is produced.

title: 20 YEARS AFTER A MASSACRE, MEXICO STILL SEEKS HEALING FOR TIS WOUNDS
description: On Oct. 2, 1968, the Mexican Army and security police fired on students and other unarmed protesters at Tlatelolco plaza here. When the shooting stopped, dozens of people were dead, more than a thousand had been wounded, and the Mexican political system had suffered a blow from which it still has not recovered.

title: More Suburbs Accepting Middle-Income Housing
description: A growing number of communities across the region are approving moderate-income housing projects as more residents discover that high prices are barring their own children and parents from living nearby.

title: Exploring Argentina's Deepest South
description: USHUAIA, Argentina, on the south coast of Tierra del Fuego, is about as far south as a tourist can comfortably go in the Americas. It faces the Beagle Channel, named for the ship that brought Charles Darwin on his 1832 exploration of local wildlife. Penguins, sea lions and rare sea birds still abound. On desolate Navarino Island, across the channel, is a small Chilean naval installation, Puerto Williams. Antarctica is just 700 miles of iceberg-chocked ocean away.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: AMERICAN PLAYWRIGHT A centennial celebration of the birth of Maxwell Anderson, the noted American playwright, will open today in Stamford with an exhibition at the Ferguson Library and a buffet dinner and performance at the Landmark Club.

title: Sound Pollution: The Wrong Villain
description: Your issue of Sept. 4 featured an article about the pollution of Long Island Sound [ ''An Effort to Ban Discharges From Boats'' ] and the efforts oflocal leaders to establish a zero pollution factor.

title: House Panel Approves Lobbying Restrictions
description: A bill that would for the first time restrict lobbying by former Presidents and former members of Congress has cleared the House Judiciary Committee.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: The Square Feet Numbers Game; How Much of What Is Paid For Is Usable Space?
description: ONE of the more rapacious tricks that Manhattan landlords found irresistible earlier this decade - sleight-of-hand inflation of floor space - no longer dupes most tenants shopping around for office quarters.

title: On Sephardic Service In the County
description: I would like to correct some misinformation in the article ''A Sephardic Temple Greets the New Year'' [ Sept. 11 ] .

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: CAROL ANDERSON TABER;
A Voice for Working Women
description: LEAD: CAROL ANDERSON TABER, 43 years old, of Ho-Ho-Kus is the publisher of Working Woman magazine, which is based in New York City. Since she became publisher in 1979, the magazine has had a 60-fold growth in revenue and a nearly 10-fold growth in circulation to 900,000, from 97,000.

title:
MUSIC;
How to Succeed at Success
description: LEAD: Common wisdom holds that Itzhak Perlman is at the top of his profession, and, despite occasional complaints from music critics, few musicians would argue with that assumption. But the 43-year-old violinist seems bothered by the idea that he may indeed be at the top of his trade. ''It's really not very healthy to think about it,'' he says.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title: Battling Subway Crime, Both Real and Perceived
description: In the New York City subway system, where dark passageways and steel bars can create the aura of menace even in the best of times, the transit police are battling a real increase in serious crime as well as the public's exaggerated perception of crime that threatens to erode ridership and confidence in the system.

title: NONFICTION NONFICTION
description: THE BOZ: Confessions of a Modern Anti-Hero. By Brian Bosworth with Rick Reilly. (Doubleday, $17.95.) For someone so young, 23 years old, Brian Bosworth - The Boz - has picked up an awful lot of wisdom. He's an expert, for instance, on the generation gap: ''Adults are so screwed up. There's no pleasing them. They don't know what they want. Except two things: (1) they don't want you being any different than anybody else on the block; and (2) they want to yell at you.'' Mr. Bosworth, the linebacker for the Seattle Seahawks, is as differnt as they come - witness his Boz earring and Boz hair style. And why bother raising your voice when you can wreak sanctioned havoc, which brings us to the Boz's two goals on the football field: getting into fights and hitting people on the head. Thoughtfully, Mr. Bosworth provides detailed instructions. ''There are some surefire tricks. Like, if the guy is down, take his helmet and bang it a bunch of times against the ground. Or maybe stick your finger in his earhole and jam it around.'' For pearls of wisdom like these, Mr. Bosworth has reaped the scorn of ''adults,'' the adulation of ''kids'' and an $11-million contract. Written with the aid of Rick Reilly, a Sports Illustrated writer, the book takes the form of a long, sometimes rambling monologue. Nevertheless, amid the sophomoric rantings of someone so privileged due to his athletic prowess that he practically owned Norman, Okla., where he attended Oklahoma University, there is the occasional insight into college and pro sports, including drug use, recruitment and the coaching ability of Barry Switzer. In the end, Mr. Bosworth admits that what he does - play football for a living - ''isn't a real job,'' but then, ''The Boz'' isn't a real book.

title: What Does It Take To Make a Landmark?
description: Call the city and suburban Homes a block of tenements and it does not seem like a natural candidate for landmark status. Call it utopian housing, however, and it begins to look a lot better. And utopian housing is precisely what this is - since this sprawling series of structures, which runs along the south side of 79th Street from York Avenue to the East River, is one of the most ambitious attempts in the history of New York to create viable housing for the poor. Together with its neighboring complex, the Cherokee Apartments, the City and Suburban Homes stands as perhaps our greatest legacy from a critical moment in both the architectural and social history of the city - a monument to the moment when a solution to the city's housing problems actually seemed possible.

title: Youthful Memories of a Superhighway
description: WHEN the Connecticut Turnpike was built in the mid-50's to decimate the driving time between Boston and New York, we were teen- agers, and we were thrilled.

title:
AMERICAN ISLANDS: CATALINA;
Sailing on To Avalon
description: LEAD: CATALINA IS AN ISLAND SHAPED LIKE A fat sleeping dog, its head joined to it by its narrow Isthmus. It is 22 miles long, 24 miles off the southern California coast and set squarely against the prevailing wind, so that the lee side is protected, indented with dozens of coves with sandy bottoms and transparent emerald water.

title: Hospitals Uniting to Attract Nurses
description: THE advertisements - offering a ''fantastic salary,'' a ''challenging position'' and the chance to ''work hours you want'' - are constant and sound an increasingly desperate note. But hospital administrators say the nursing shortage in Westchester is getting worse.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Of Conferences, Books and Auctions
description: LEAD: THE American Numismatic Society will hold its fifth annual Coinage of the Americas conference Oct. 29 and 30 at the society's museum in New York City. The theme will be ''The Coinage of the Viceroyalty of Peru and Its Successor States.'' More than a dozen prominent scholars will deliver research papers.

title:
GARDENING;
Flavor of Apples Takes Time to Mature
description: LEAD: FALL and apples seem to have been made for each other. What could be more pleasant than a stroll through the woods under a bright blue sky on a chilly October day while munching on a spicy apple and enjoying the brilliant colors of fall foliage?

title: Rites of Passage
description: THOUGH rodeos, chicken scratch dances and beauty pageants may be encountered by visitors to any of Arizona's 20 Indian reservations, a few genuine ceremonials and rituals remain. In these rituals tourists can discover the authentic expression of an indigenous culture. Many of the ceremonials among Indian tribes have endured despite hostility and suppression throughout the centuries, and these vividly colorful and startling vestiges of once-thriving cultures have, to many Indian elders, become the only way to preserve an embattled culture. ''Any kind of tribal dances or customs were discouraged not only by missionaries but also by the government,'' says Urban Giff, a Pima Indian on the Gila River Reservation. ''We have only now begun to recognize their cultural values and pass them on to our children.''

title: After the Hurricane: What to Do
description: ''HAPPY to be out alive'' is a typical response of vacationers who got out of the resort areas of Mexico - Cancun and Cozumel - and Jamaica and Grand Cayman Island after Hurricane Gilbert hit two weeks ago. With 400 people dead or missing, mostly in Mexico, and damage estimates at $10 billion in the century's most powerful hurricane, those who got safely home have good reason to be relieved. When they were asked about replacing lost vacations, most said that for the moment they were resting.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Sept. 16 MANHATTAN Carnegie Hill $541,737 1140 Fifth Avenue (95th St.) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,400-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, windowed kitchen, maid's room; maintenance $890, 30% tax-deductible (Broker: Edward Lee Cave) Greenwich Village $360,000 30 Fifth Avenue (10th St.) 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining alcove, windowed kitchen; maintenance $718, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Kanelba & Robilotti) Greenwich Village $2.14 million 6 St. Luke's Place 4-story, single-family town house; dining room, large kitchen, library, study, terrace, garden, 8 fireplaces, 27- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $8,350 (Broker: William B. May) Upper East Side $975,000 4 East 88th Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,900-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, maid's room and bath, fireplace, Central Park view; maintenance $1,228, 28% tax-deductible (Broker: Sotheby's International Realty) Washington Heights $150,000 116 Pinehurst Avenue (Hudson View Gardens) 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; dining room, large walk-in closet, partial Hudson River view; maintenance $606, includes gas and electricity, 20% tax-deductible (Broker: C-Uptown Realty) West Side $782,000 91 Central Park West (70th St.) 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, manned elevator, dining room, large kitchen, fireplace; maintenance $995, 38% tax-deductible (Broker: Corcoran Group) BRONX Baychester $132,000 4415 Grace Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, detached stucco house; dining room, finished basement, detached 1-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $900 (Broker: J.A.V. Realty) Morris Park $188,500 1949 Howe Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, detached, brick house; dining room, large kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,080 (Broker: Tryax Realty) BROOKLYN Brooklyn College Area $74,500 657 East 26th Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,100-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; dining area, remodeled kitchen, high-ceilings; maintenance $345, 53% tax-deductible (Broker: Dwork & Korn) Park Slope $190,000 302 13th Street 3-family, 4-story, detached, frame house; 2 bedrooms, large kitchen in lower duplex; 1 bedroom in others; 1 bath, den in each; basement, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,050 (Broker: John P. Barry Realty) QUEENS Bayside $240,000 48-21 210th Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached colonial; dining room, large kitchen, den, finished basement, 2-car garage, 40- by 175-ft. lot; taxes $900 (Broker: Century 21/Weber & Rose) Forest Hills $90,000 99-45 67th Road (Berkley) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 700-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; large, windowed kitchen, hardwood floors; maintenance $239, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Kraham Realty) STATEN ISLAND Light House Hill $250,000 293 Edinboro Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, detached ranch; dining room, fireplace, finished basement, 50- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,200 (Broker: Otto Vitale Real Estate) Westerleigh $210,000 40 Egbert Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, detached, colonial: dining room, large kitchen, parlor room, fireplace, enclosed front porch, detached, 1-car garage, 62- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $709 (Broker: George K. Wonica)

title: Are Automatics Truly Foolproof?
description: WHEN I was an infant, I expected my parents to take care of things like food and shelter. I assumed that they always had everything under perfect control. Only later, when I was forced to provide for myself, did I find out that life isn't always as neat as it seems.

title: L.B.J.'S HOMESPUN GROUSING
description: Richard N. Goodwin's article ''The War Within'' (Aug. 21), laced with the private political utterances of a beleaguered President Lyndon B. Johnson, purports to document L.B.J.'s descent into clinical paranoia in midsummer 1965. However, Mr. Johnson's outbursts denote no thought disorder, merely his homespun grousing that the limousine liberals were croaking arrant pacifism while he ordered what was plainly needed to win the Vietnam War. WILLIAM STEINSMITH, M.D. San Francisco

title: A FEW MORE PLOWSHARES, COMRADES
description: THE OTHER SIDE OF ARMS CONTROL Soviet Objectives in the Gorbachev Era. By Alan B. Sherr. 325 pp. Boston: Unwin Hyman. Cloth, $49.95. Paper, $17.95.

title: THE PROMISE THAT FAILED
description: The failure of the artificial heart was inevitable the moment the first patient developed a post-operative complication that should have been anticipated prior to the operation (''The Promise That Failed,'' by Ralph Brauer, Aug. 28). The problem was not infection. The heart is only a portion of the vascular tree and functions by pumping blood to supply oxygen to the cells and to remove carbon dioxide and other metabolic wastes. It is rare for the heart solely to be affected by a disease process. This may occur in rheumatic heart disease and inflammation of heart muscle in the young, but heart disease in the elderly is invariably a manifestation of a widespread circulatory problem that affects the heart vessels as well as the heart muscle. This was the situation with the first patient treated with a permanently implanted artificial heart.

title: SOCIAL CHANGE 101
description: SAIGON, ILLINOIS By Paul Hoover. pp. New York: Vintage Books. Paper, $6.95.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: 'Clones' Sell Poorly; Detroit's New Goal: Models That Differ Not Only in Name
description: DETROIT automakers have introduced little that is truly new in recent new-car seasons, but this year the story is slightly different. Although they are introducing no brand-new car models, they have succeeded in differentiating between the ones they are showing.

title: The Sophisticated Traveler/Magazine/Part 2
description: Treasured islands, from Hawaii to Venice to the Nile and the Coral Sea.

title: Vacancy Report
description: To the Editor:

title: Q and A
description: Claim on Co-op

title: Shoreham Ruling By S.E.C. Is Awaited
description: LEAD: COMPELLING evidence that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission is moving rapidly toward licensing the Shoreham nuclear-power plant shifted attention last week to proceedings involving another Federal agency.

title: Creating a New Jersey Heirloom (First, Get the Wool)
description: ON trips west and north - to New England, the Ohio Valey, West Virginia - my husband and I saw many examples of local traditional craftwork: baskets, pottery, woven cloth. All wrought, the creators are quick and proud to point out, from local materials, native clay or stone or vine, trees or grasses.

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Track and Field; Pride and Frustration for the Americans
description: The United States won the gold medal in the men's 1,600-meter relay today and the silver medal in the women's 1,600-meter relay. Florence Griffith Joyner added a gold and a silver medal to her two previous golds.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: MILITARY RE-ENACTMENT More than 200 soldiers of the 3d and 22d New Jersey Regiments, re-enactment groups, will clash next weekend in River Edge as the Bergen County Historical Society continues to mark the 125th anniversary of the Civil War.

title: A Diverse Selection of New Englanders
description: THERE is something humorous about a collection of curators titling a group show, ''New England Now,'' only to admit in the catalogue that they could not find anything specifically ''New English'' about the artists they had chosen. Undismayed by this, the curators fall back on diversity as the common factor - as if anyone would knowingly assemble a group of look alikes.

title: Kalikow Complex Up for Landmarking
description: THE New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission will hear testimony Thursday for and against landmark designation for City and Suburban Homes, a 14-building complex of turn-of-the-century tenements on Manhattan's Upper East Side.

title: On the Mesas of the Hopis
description: IN the dusty plaza of a Hopi Indian village, the flat pueblo rooftops begin to fill with people. Others gather below, leaning against the wall or sitting on benches and straight-backed chairs brought outside for the occasion. The Hopi patiently wait. Dark-eyed children, dressed in their Sunday best, chase each other like puppies at play. Far over the distant mountains, dark thunderheads appear, emitting low rumbles, but carrying no real promise of rain.

title: A Retarded Son Accepts Himself
description: MY second son, Christopher, was born with a handicap - he learns things very slowly. Today, more than 35 years later, he would be called ''learning disabled'' and there would be many programs to help him. But at that time we had to find our own answers and help.

title: A Look at the Lessons Learned
description: When the stock market collapsed on Oct. 19, dire predictions were made about the ability of the nation's economy to rebound from such a cataclysmic event. Yet, 12 months later, according to many experts, the economy and the financial markets are sound. The Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, talked to 11 experts about what they have learned since the stock market fell. NATHAN GANTSCHER, President and chief operating officer, Oppenheimer & Company.

title: Bonsai Amid the Loblolly
description: LEAD: ON opening day of the new horticulture display at Champion International in Stamford, Yuji Yoshimura, a grower of bonsai, and an author and lecturer, put the finishing touches on a Japanese exhibition garden, misted it and stood back to survey its overall effect.

title: INSPECTIONS FIND AIRLINE PROBLEMS
description: A Federal inspection of 35 commuter airlines has produced nearly a dozen cases of falsified records and problems with maintenance and operations.

title:
AMERICAN ISLANDS: HAWAII;
Blowing Hot and Cold
description: LEAD: IN A STEAMY TORMENT OF YOUTH, THE ISLAND of Hawaii has been displaying its growing pains almost steadily for close to six years. Surprising visitors to Hawaii Volcanoes National Park with occasional fiery outbursts, Kilauea's erupting side vents send streams of hot lava coursing seven miles to the sea.

title: The Subliminal Message of the Bush Campaign; Nuclear Freeze
description: To the Editor:

title: CHOSEN AND GIVEN
description: I do not dispute Ms. Henig's findings that many adopted children have social and behavioral problems, but it seems clear to me that the psychological burden of abandonment, of which she speaks, will diminish once society stops viewing adoption as a negative experience. Instead of focusing so heavily on the issues of separation and abandonment, Ms. Henig might have discussed the unique beauty of uniting a child with parents who have endured far more than nine months to get him. BROOKS BARTON New York, N.Y.

title: Administration Faulted on Homeless Aid Program
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that the Reagan Administration is defying a Congressional mandate to release underused Federal property as housing for the nation's homeless.

title: Miss Vogelpohl Marries in Texas
description: Elisabeth Anne Vogelpohl, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Elmer B. Vogelpohl Jr. of Galveston, Tex., was married there yesterday to Arthur Lindeman Jacobson Jr., a son of Mr. Jacobson of La Quinta, Calif., and Mrs. Edward Strauss of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. John Donovan performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal church.

title: An Heir to Land - But Where?
description: OUT of the blue, Woonsocket, R.I., learned that it had fallen heir to a parcel of land that might be worth up to $500,000. But there was a hitch.

title: Olympic Highlights
description: TRACK AND FIELD: Matching a world record set in 1968, the United States men's 1,600-meter relay team won comfortably. But the women's 400 team needed a blazing anchor leg by Evelyn Ashford to beat East Germany to the wire. TENNIS: Steffi Graf of West Germany gilded her Grand Slam year by winning in singles. The American team of Ken Flach and Robert Seguso won gold in doubles. BOXING: Ray Mercer, heavyweight, and Kennedy McKinney, bantamweight, won gold medals. Another American, Michael Carbajal, lost a decision and earned silver. WATER POLO: In a rematch of the 1984 final, Yugoslavia defended its title by beating the United States, 9-7. Articles, section 8.

title: Symbolic Presidency Proves Better Than None in Lebanon
description: THE Middle East, the Lebanese factional leader was saying, ''lives always with its history; we are obsessed with history.'' He might have added that in his country, history has been overtaken by guns and demography, outside maneuvering and internal dissent to produce a present in which tolerance and hope have become strangers. Last week, they seemed more alien than ever.

title: Photo Project Battles Mortality
description: LEAD: IN 1985, deeply moved by two dramas about AIDS, Robert Giard, the photographer, began a series of portraits of gay writers.

title: Grappling With the Problem Of School Prayer
description: ''DARK as the night that covers me, black as a pit from pole to pole, I thank whatever gods may be for my unconquerable soul.''

title: An Assembly Race Suddenly Changes
description: UNTIL just more than a week ago, Paul H. Chrystal Jr. of Eastchester, a Democrat, was a relatively solitary figure in his campaign to oust Gordon W. Burrows as the 23-year Assemblyman from the 84th District. Mr. Chrystal was attracting few volunteers and little money.

title: Maverick Violinist
description: LEAD: NO LESS A JUDGE THAN THE PRE-EMINENT conductor Herbert von Karajan calls Gidon Kremer ''the greatest violinist in the world,'' whereas the romantically inclined violinist Shlomo Mintz, a contemporary of Kremer's, says he is ''definitely not my ideal.''

title: A New Center to Keep New York's Finest Fit
description: In its continuing effort to chart the physical well-being of its officers, the New York City Police Department has developed a cardiovascular-fitness center, complete with nutritionists, cholesterol charts, weight machines and trained instructors who also happen to be police officers.

title: Maplewood Theater Stirs Memories
