description: The interesting article on the Maplewood Theater's present state was especially evocative to me (''A Movie Theater's Bit of Drama,'' Sept. 4). It brought back memories of the time, circa 1940, when the theater was a hotbed of fine plays enacted by famous stars.

title: CHOSEN AND GIVEN
description: Ms. Henig quotes Dr. David Brodzinsky's statement that ''the majority of them [ adoptees ] do very well in life.'' However, his message is quickly buried beneath an avalanche of assertions implying that adoptees are at high risk for a multitude of emotional behavioral and learning problems.

title: 'Glory Days' Over, Apple Farms Turn to Peaches
description: NEW JERSEY'S wholesale apple industry, battered by heavy competition and the loss of farmland, is in the midst of a sharp decline. What was once a $14-million-a-year industry has dropped in value by more than 30 percent in recent years, growers and state agricultural officials say.

title: Johnson Breaks His Silence
description: Ben Johnson has broken his silence on the events that led to his being stripped of his Olympic 100-meter victory, telling The Toronto Sun in an article published today that ''I have never knowingly taken illegal drugs, nor have had illegal drugs administered to me.''

title: Credit Cards
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's article on credit card problems (Practical Traveler, Aug. 7) was very informative. I would like to add a piece of advice that my husband and I have found helpful. He applied for a MasterCard in his name and I applied for a Visa card in my name. He carries the MasterCard and I carry the Visa. If his wallet is stolen, we have my Visa; the reverse is true if my purse is stolen, having the MasterCard as backup.

title: J. C. Bastis Weds Laurie Bruckner
description: At the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. Paul in Hempstead, L.I., Laurie Anne Bruckner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Bruckner of Upper Brookville, L.I., Vero Beach, Fla., and New York was married yesterday to Jason Christopher Bastis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Christos G. Bastis of New York and Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Basil Gregory and the Rev. Nicholas J. Magoulias, Greek Orthodox priests, and Bishop Robert C. Witcher of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, officiated.

title: WHAT HAPPENED AT THE MALL
description: IN THE HEART OF THE WHOLE WORLD By John Rolfe Gardiner. 239 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: Melissa Moreno Wed to J. L. Seiler 3d
description: Melissa Wilcox Moreno, a daughter of Judith Wilson Moreno of Philadelphia and Cape May, N.J., and Vito Nicholas Moreno of King of Prussia, Pa., was married yesterday to Joseph Leidich Seiler 3d, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Seiler Jr. of Millington and Ocean City, N.J.

title: Headliners; Speaking of Silence
description: The grand jury before which Tawana Brawley has refused to testify apparently has found no evidence of a crime against the New York teen-ager, The New York Times reported last week. In a case that for many has come to symbolize racism in the criminal justice system, Miss Brawley, who is black, said she was abducted and raped last fall by six white men, one of whom wore a badge. She then refused to speak with investigators, saying a cover-up was likely. While the grand jury was not expected to criticize Miss Brawley, investigators in the case believe she fabricated the rape story to avoid being punished for staying out late, The Times said. Miss Brawley denied this, saying she still feared a cover-up.

title: Comforting Rituals For a New Season
description: WINTER is coming. I can feel it hanging on the cold breeze that sweeps through my bedroom window and wakes me to the steel-gray day that lies outside.

title: Plea by Leon Spinks
description: Leon Spinks, the former world heavyweight boxing champion, pleaded no contest Friday in Rochester Hills, Mich., to a charge of driving while impaired stemming from his arrest in April.

title: Smoking Laws Leave Workers Under a Cloud
description: LEAD: AS Nassau and Suffolk Counties play catchup with each other's no-smoking laws, more and more people are getting caught in the middle.

title: Judge Censured for Rudeness To Woman in Massachusetts
description: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court has censured a judge for rudeness to a woman who sought court protection from her husband, but the high court allowed the judge to remain on the bench. The decision was criticized by the woman's family.

title: Volunteering? No WayAm I Ever Doing That Again
description: WITH the onset of the school year, a malady will overcome many healthy, intelligent women. Homebound women, not participants in the outside workforce and with school-age children, are most susceptible to the syndrome. Among the symptoms of this affliction are the inability to say the word ''no'' and a hand that involuntarily raises itself in response to a call for chairwomen, committee members or other types of volunteer positions.

title: Support Group Helps Smokers Fight Addiction
description: THE white-haired woman sat nervously in the first row. All too soon, it was her turn to speak. ''My name is Rose,'' she said, ''and I'm a nicotine addict.'' ''I can't brag tonight, I've been kind of bad,'' Rose continued, her lips forming a nervous half smile. ''I keep saying, 'I hate you, cigarettes,' but I smoked today.

title: Richard Stern Marries Susan O. Amerling on L.I.
description: Susan Oppenheimer Amerling, the daughter of Ernest Oppenheimer of the Bronx and the late Fanny Oppenheimer, was married last evening to Richard B. H. Stern, the son of Marion Haas Stern of New York and the late David I. Stern. Cantor Debra Stein-Davidson performed the ceremony on the beach in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Q and A
description: Guadeloupe

title: Setting Sail in Pants That Billow
description: WHAT'S new this week on the fashion marquee? It's Pantasia, a full-length feature with a cast of thousands of yards of material and, to keep you on the edge of your seat, several surprise endings.

title: Mexican Letter: Fighting Words, Poisoned Pens
description: In Latin America, politics and literature not only converge, they often collide, and at the moment, the din from the nastiest clash in recent years is echoing throughout the region. What began in June with a long polemic in a Mexican literary magazine has grown into a transcontinental argument about the relationship between history and the novel and between revolution and democracy - all of it enlivened by harsh personal insults, accusations of back-stabbing campaigns aimed at winning the Nobel Prize in Literature and even the spectacle of Nicaragua's top cop passing literary judgment on some of Latin America's leading intellectuals.

title: To Play in Asia, Moscow Has to Pay
description: General Secretary Mikhail S. Gorbachev has updated his 1986 speech on Asia with new proposals to make Moscow a full-fledged participant in the region's political and economic affairs. And his impending meeting with the Chinese foreign minister, widely interpreted as a precursor to a summit meting, only underscores his determination.

title: Science Fiction
description: THE TOYNBEE CONVECTOR (Knopf, $17.95) is Ray Bradbury's first book of new fiction since his collected stories appeared in 1980. Mr. Bradbury published his first short story in 1941, when he was 21 years old. In the two decades that followed, he created a body of work - including ''The Martian Chronicles,'' ''The Illustrated Man'' and ''Fahrenheit 451'' - that made him the best-known science fiction writer in the world. Since then, sad to say, his work has shown a steady decline in force and freshness.

title: A French Restaurant Turns Italian
description: USUALLY when restaurants are not doing well, they go out of business. La Plume in Bethel has tried a different approach: it changed its name to Pappagallo's and its cuisine from formal French to informal Italian. What remains the same is the cast of characters - the chef and owners - and the locale - an 1850 Victorian frame house.

title: Susan McClellan Becomes the Wife Of Linsday Valk
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Michael the Archangel in Greenwich, Conn., Susan Jane McClellan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Wells McClellan of Greenwich, was married yesterday to Garry Lindsay Valk, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Garry Valk of Cutchoque, L.I. Msgr. Thomas Guinan performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Charles C. Smith, a Congregational minister.

title: Ms. Munson Has Wedding on L.I.
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Palmer Munson, an associate at the New York law firm of White & Case, to Robert Louis von Stade, a residential real-estate broker with William B. May & Company in New York, took place yesterday at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony.

title: PLAIN AND FANCY
description: Casseroles may have been unfashionable during the last 10 years, but these one-dish meals have always meant robust, sensual pleasure to me. Though absent from trendy restaurants, one-dish meals did not vanish from family dinners and buffet tables. Their ease of preparation alone should assure eternal popularity. Increasingly, however, casseroles are being served by some of the country's more creative chefs. This is not really surprising, given the current fascination with nostalgic, earthy fare.

title: Reviews/Music; Clarinetist's Idiomatic Approach
description: Roger Salander's evening at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday brought us a side of clarinet playing we rarely hear. His program was different yet substantial - anchored by Weber's great Duo Concertant for Clarinet and Piano but offering elsewhere substantial pieces by Saint-Saens, Milhaud and Krenek and also music by two less-known Viennese composers, Erich Eder de Lastra and Alfred Uhl.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: A NATURAL STATE. By Stephen Harrigan. (Texas Monthly Press, $14.95.) Natural history, or at least the best of it, results from the collision of two worlds - the mind of man and the realities of nature. When such collisions occur, as they do in the writings of Edward Abbey or Annie Dillard or Barry Lopez, they leave us with journeys into the natural world that make a difference, that last.

title: Welfare Bill's Radical Goals Would Take Years
description: If its proponents are right, the welfare bill that passed Congress Friday will create a historic change in the lives of millions of poor people in America and in the way in which the rest of society views them.

title: Hirohito's Bleeding Worsens And Relatives Rush to Side
description: Emperor Hirohito's internal bleeding suddenly worsened today, causing his blood pressure to plummet and his relatives to come rushing to his bedside.

title: PERSPECTIVES: New Condos in Flatbush; Tapping the Market in Central Brooklyn
description: THE heart of the old town of Flatbush is the intersection of Church and Flatbush Avenues, says Irving Choban with the authority of his office, the presidency of the Flatbush Historical Society. The town had spread out three miles from that center by 1892, when it merged into the city of Brooklyn. Its 1798 Dutch Reformed Church still stands - on the site of the original church, built in 1654 - as does its 1876 town hall, now a school.

title: REAGAN ON REAGAN: 'SAME MAN I WAS'
description: In a brief departure from partisan activities, President Reagan said today that although world events had changed dramatically, he had not.

title: Beyond Materialism, Toward Diversity
description: I am not a friend of nor do I know Mrs. Gass. However, I felt it was expedient that Mr. Marcus take off his Porsche-labeled sunglasses and look at life as it really is on Long Island. As a woman living in a similar environment, I felt I had to defend Mrs. Gass and the rather unrealistic, angry tone in which Mr. Marcus replied to Mrs. Gass's commentary.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: CARNOVSKY'S RETREAT. By Larry Duberstein. (Permanent Press, $18.95.) It would be easy to mistake this novel from the author of ''The Marriage Hearse'' for a slight but entertaining bit of local color, a guileless evocation of voice (earthy, Jewish) and place (working-class, horse-playing, New York).

title: COMES THE COUNTERREVOLUTION
description: BABY BOOMERS By Paul C. Light. 319 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $19.95.

title: Smuggling Snakes For High Profit
description: THE Federal charge against 43-year-old Agremiro Espana was smuggling. Drugs? No, boa constrictors - 700 of them.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Montpelier, Vt.;
Timberland Sale Lights No Fires
description: LEAD: IT was billed as the Great North Country Land Auction, a huge sale that was to be closely watched for its effect on land prices and development trends in northern New England.

title: A Car That Floats on Air
description: AMONG those who were elated by the convention was Ernst Knolle, whose bullet-shaped magnetically suspended car received three tentative offers from investors and two offers from Hollywood producers. ''It's the simplest thing you can imagine,'' said the 63-year San Franciscan, a retired mechanical engineer who has worked 20 years on it. It's called the Knolle Magnetrans: a streamlined, two-passenger prototype that can go up to 200 M.P.H. on a battery-powered motor.

title: Concord Jews Celebrate a Renovation
description: On a recent Friday Jay Rosenfield, president of the temple here, found himself in a tense situation. The electricians and carpenters were getting ready to leave, the rug man was on his way out, but the man installing the front door wasn't quite finished when the bar mitzvah party arrived.

title: A High-Tech Bus Terminal
description: IF there is a cutting edge to the tour-bus business, Domenico Tours says it is in Bayonne, at the company's new airport-like bus station, Port Quintstar.

title: PUTTING THE WORLD ON HOLD
description: SOLITUDE A Return to the Self. By Anthony Storr. 216 pp. New York: The Free Press. $17.95.

title: Afloat on the Ancient Nile
description: IT IS BEST TO APPROACH ASWAN BY WAY OF the desert, for in this journey between two worlds -one savage and one tranquil, one barren and one beneficent - it is possible to understand why it was that Aswan became a legendary place. The desert is a fearful thing, an abode of death, but as the airplane swoops over its endless blankness of sand, there is suddenly a glimpse of green banks, of palm trees and vegetation, and then of water. This is Aswan.

title: Donna Loves Sneaks
description: EVERYBODY wears sneakers. For walking. For sports. For comfort. What's left to be said about sneakers? Simply that they're fashionable.

title: Japan Clings to a Vague, Historic Reverence
description: IN the opening days of Emperor Hirohito's reign in 1926, a Japanese newspaper, The Tokyo Nichinichi, printed an exclusive report from the Imperial Palace: The new Emperor's era would be named Kobun, connoting ''light of civilization.'' The Palace was enraged and, perhaps to prove the paper wrong, named the era Showa, or ''enlightened peace.'' Under a shower of criticism, the editors resigned. Last week the same paper, since renamed the Mainichi Shimbun, tripped up again. Its English language edition mistakenly published an editorial lamenting Hirohito's death. Within hours, the editor in chief of the Mainichi was stripped of his title and another senior editor was dismissed.

title: Board Overrides O'Rourke's Veto, Blocking a Consulting Contract
description: LEAD: FOR the first time in recent memory, Westchester's Board of Legislators last week overrode a County Executive's veto, blocking a controversial consulting contract and setting the stage for a possible lawsuit.

title: All Aboard for Upper Egypt
description: IN THE MID-1800'S, WHEN JOURNEYING UP THE Nile had just become the rage, a French traveler, M. Ampere, described the typical tour of Egypt as ''a donkey ride and a boat trip interspersed with ruins.'' The itinerary hasn't changed much in a century, but the means and speed of travel have. Buses have replaced donkeys and flights have replaced boat trips, except, perhaps, for the scenic cruise from Luxor to Aswan. Indeed, what the traveler used to see at leisure from the deck of a sailboat over a period of weeks, the average tourist now crams into a few days. As a result, he sees little of rural Egypt, where about half the population of 54 million still lives and toils. And he encounters few ordinary Egyptians, except for those trying to sell him something.

title: Kerri L. Martin To Wed Nov. 6
description: The engagement of Kerri Lucille Martin to Richard Allan Bartlett has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Jack Martin of Chattanooga, Tenn. Mr. Bartlett is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Bartlett of Tuscaloosa, Ala.

title: Sparta Journal; Country Living, but at What Price?
description: FRONT yards of field grass and yarrow at 18 of the 61 houses in the new Sussex Mills residential development here convey the obvious: the spacious homes - built on speculation - are for sale.

title: Quayle to Speak First In Debate Wednesday
description: Senator Dan Quayle, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, will receive the first question and give the first closing statement in his debate Wednesday night with his Democratic opponent, Senator Lloyd Bentsen.

title: Grants Offered for Plans That Reduce Pollution
description: The Citizen's Committee for New York City is offering $5,000 awards to 10 neighborhood organizations that come up with projects to reduce air, noise or water pollution, curb toxic waste hazards or promote recycling and energy conservation.

title: Law Protects Art from Owners
description: SEVERAL years ago, a mural by the painter Michael Borders, ''The Genesis of the Capital City,'' was removed from a public building in Hartford and cut up for billboards. When the artist found out about it, there was nothing he could do, because it was no longer his property.

title: Excerpts From Quayle Interview on Arms
description: The following are excerpts from an interview today with Senator Dan Quayle:

title: The Subliminal Message of the Bush Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: Gadgetry To Foil Thieves
description: BRICKTON KRISTY has taken auto gadgetry to new heights and designed a sophisticated door-locking system that he believes should foil most car thieves.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/PEOPLES OF THE WORLD
description: PAINTING FACES By Suzanne Haldane. Illustrated. 32 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $12.95.

title: Correction
description: Because of a transmission error, a front-page art review in the Arts and Leisure section today about Degas renders a word incorrectly. The affected sentence, on page 16, should read, ''I for one do not believe that the celebrated 'Interior,' now in the Philadelphia Museum, has anything to do with any of the French novels of the day.''

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Epic County Films
description: LEAD: Edwin Thanhouser, one of the film makers who put New Rochelle on the map as a movie capital of the East during the early 1900's, was headed to a location with a camera crew when they happened to spot a burning building:

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: DECORATIVE ARTS

title: Joseph F. Kern, Publisher, 73
description: Joseph F. Kern, publisher of Popular Mechanics magazine for 17 years until his retirement in 1980, died of heart failure Friday at his home in Garden City, L.I. He was 73 years old.

title: FICTION
description: HOUSE OF HEROES: And Other Stories. By Mary La Chapelle. (Crown, $18.95.) ''It's like birch bark, rough and smooth at the same time.'' The simile refers to a character's voice, but it's an equally apt description of the stories in Mary La Chapelle's first collection. In ''House of Heroes: And Other Stories,'' she chooses rough-hewn subjects - a mime and a giant who struggle with nonconformity, a boy who finds a dead body. But Ms. La Chapelle's writing and insights are smooth and elegant, a respite for readers bored with minimalist fiction and self-indulgent heroes. The recipient of the 1986 PEN/Nelson Algren Fiction Award, Ms. La Chapelle produces work that is traditional yet unexpected, analyzing small-town life in the Great Lakes region with compassion and a sharp eye for the odd detail. Her special turf is the inner territory that lies between sanity and insanity - and the ways people who find themselves on either side view those on the other. The title story, for example, is about a woman who works in a halfway house for disturbed boys. In ''Faith,'' a mentally ill teen-ager attaches herself to a psychologist. And in ''The Meadow Bell,'' one of the most beautifully realized stories, a man floats between past and present, reason and madness, as he seeks to impress an outsider who, it turns out, is trying equally hard to impress him. The control and restraint that Ms. La Chapelle shows in this story is enviable as she deftly avoids the ''sentimentality close at hand . . . like an embarrassing pet waiting at the door.'' Here and elsewhere, her heroes are of the everyday sort - misunderstood, struggling, maybe even crazy. But she makes us care about them, and believe that they would care about us.

title: In Defense Of Carl Lewis
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
Flavor of Apples Takes Time to Mature
description: LEAD: FALL and apples seem to have been made for each other. What could be more pleasant than a stroll through the woods under a bright blue sky on a chilly October day while munching on a spicy apple and enjoying the brilliant colors of fall foliage?

title: Mother's Work
description: WHAT DO WE call a woman who manages the household finances, bears the babies and educates the preschool children, does the shopping and cooks the meals, organizes family social functions and serves as confidante, lover and constructive critic to her husband?

title: THE SEOUL OLYMPICS: Equestrian; Frenchman Captures Gold in Show Jumping
description: With smart riding and a little luck, Pierre Durand of France and his flashy black jumper Jappeloup won the individual show jumping gold medal in the Olympic Stadium here today.

title: The Wit and Wisdom of Elliot Erwitt
description: LEAD: He's been taking photographs for more than 40 years, ever since he was a teen-ager growing up in Hollywood and bought his first camera. In the ensuing years, Elliott Erwitt became a photojournalist, commercial photographer and film maker, whose assignments have taken him all over the world.

title: WHO OWNS THE LAND?
description: As two of the attorneys litigating the constitutionality of the White Earth Land Settlement Act on behalf of the Indians of White Earth, we were pleased that you chose to cover the efforts of the Chippewas to regain their land (''Who Owns the Land?'' by Louise Erdrich and Michael Dorris, Sept. 4). However, we believe certain important facts were omitted from the article, and we cannot agree with the authors' conclusions that ''the state [ of Minnesota ] is liberal, sensitive'' and that there are no ''evil geniuses.''

title: A Vanished Townsman Leaves Only Questions
description: Peter H. Burr was a popular figure in this seaside community. He was a teacher, Boy Scout leader and a member of the town's governing board. In July, he disappeared amid reports that he sexually molested a 16-year-old boy.

title: Multi-Theaters: Popularity Breeds Problems
description: THE first evening shows at the Commack Multiplex Theater start shortly after 7 on Friday nights but by 6:30, the cars are beginning to filter into the large parking lot, their passengers trying to beat the rush to buy tickets for one of the multiplex's 13 movies.

title: In Brazil, It's Lonely in the Avant-Garde
description: Whether Gerald Thomas's principal objective when he returned here from New York four years ago was to introduce a new genre of theater, to upset the local cultural establishment or simply to gain fame, the Anglo-Brazilian stage director can fairly claim - and frequently does - to have achieved all three.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE ENVIRONMENTAL OBSERVATORY;
When the Earth Moves, Scientists Are There
description: LEAD: BURIED somewhere in the woods of Westchester Community College, in a spot deliberately undisclosed, is a little machine that records the movements of the earth. The seismometer, as it is known, is just six inches high, but it senses vibrations from many miles away. A few weeks ago, it picked up an earthquake in Kentucky and a disturbance believed to have originated in the Aleutian

title: Police Work Inspires a Novel
description: LEAD: DEAD bodies in varying degrees of mutilation turn up all over the fictional Nassau County town of Seaport - in hotel rooms, in housing projects, on sidewalks and in factories.

title: THE WORLD: A Voice From Warsaw; 'So Now in Recent Days, We Have an Opposition'
description: WE'RE sitting with my wife in our kitchen at the round table. Round tables are very fashionable in Poland these days. At such tables, our press, television and politicians tell us, it's easier to reach compromises.

title: Clinton Grad Sees 490 'Big' Games
description: Bernie Sherman was there again Friday when DeWitt Clinton won its third game of the high school football season, a 13-6 decision over New Dorp.

title: Joachim Blunck And Miss Hughes Exchange Vows
description: Mary Larkin Hughes, a daughter of Eileen L. Hughes of New York and the late Emmet John Hughes, was married yesterday to Joachim Blunck, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Karl-Werner Blunck of Oakland, N.J. Edward J. Hannabury, a town justice of Shelter Island, L.I., officiated there at the Shorewood Estate.

title: Parks as Paupers
description: The summer was a banner season for news concerning the national parks, particularly with the fire in Yellowstone ravaging one-half of that massive and glorious natural preserve. There was, however, a park story that didn't make headlines even though it is probably more significant than the ones that did. This year, the Administration's total parks budget comes up hundreds of millions of dollars short of what is minimally necessary to keep our parks safe and sound.

title: Pocantico Preserve Gains Acceptance
description: LEAD: WITH much fervor and some dismay, the Rockefeller State Park Preserve was dedicated on the blustery morning of May 1, 1986, by Governor Cuomo, local Scouts and other dignitaries.

title: Getting Smart by Sitting Down
description: BILLED as the ''Edison of Japan'' because he holds the world record of 2,360 patents, Yoshiro NakaMats created a sensation by showing up with his invention, which he told a disbelieving audience can heighten intelligence and even extend life.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Second Homes Aimed at Modest Budgets
description: LEAD: THE rapid rise of land prices in the Hamptons is placing many houses rising in traditional resort locations out of the reach of buyers on modest budgets. But developers have begun building in areas that are not so traditional, and where land costs are much lower. They are targeting those who want a reasonably priced weekend retreat near beaches and are not overly concerned with having a prestige address.

title: THE GAMES AT A GLANCE
description: Track and Field For the American men's 1,600-meter relay team, there wasn't anyone to run against after barely 400 meters. So they ran against time and history and raced them both to a draw. The team of Danny Everett, Steve Lewis, Kevin Robinzine and Butch Reynolds sprinted all but alone to the gold medal, equaling the 1968 world record of 2 minutes 56.16 seconds. Boxing Controversy, which had been like a third man in the ring throughout this competition, struck regularly again on the final day. Roy Jones of the United States, who scored at will and with authority, lost an inexplicable 3-2 decision to Park Si Hun of South Korea at 156 pounds. Jones, a promising 19-year-old fighter from Pensacola, Fla., was so disillusioned by the decision that he said he might never fight again. Later, Riddick Bowe, the superheavyweight from Brooklyn, saw his fight stopped early in the second round after taking his second mandatory eight count. He merely shook his head at the referee's surprising decision and walked away in dismay. The day was not a complete loss to controversy, though. Andrew Maynard scored a 5-0 decision over Nourmagomed Chanavazov of the Soviet Union at 178-pounds to win a gold medal. Water Polo Terry Schroeder, the captain of the American team, remained in the water after the final game was over. He didn't want to leave the pool because he didn't want to acknowledge what had just happened in it. No matter how long he stayed, though, Schroeder, a chiropractor, couldn't make the dull ache go away. The United States, which had finished second to Yugoslavia in Los Angeles in 1984, watched a 5-2 halftime lead wash away as Yugoslavia rallied for a 9-7 victory. Soccer After 32 years, 104 minutes didn't seem an unreasonable amount of time to wait for the gold medal. The Soviet Union, which hadn't won the gold in this sport since 1956, defeated Brazil, 2-1, in overtime. The game, which was supposed to feature a clash of styles between the flamboyant Brazilians and the disciplined Russians, wound up a demonstration of mutual inertia for the first half. But the teams traded goals in the second half and then the Soviet Union won it on Yuri Savichev's goal in the 104th minute of play.

title: THE REGION: The Comptroller and His Backers; Regan Raises Funds, an Inquiry Raises Questions
description: LIKE illicit lovers, politicians and their fund-raisers are passionate in private but prudent, indeed prissy, in public.

title: Question Of the Week; Which Is The Better Team, '86 Mets, Or '88 Mets?
description: I'm sure that most of the letters will discuss Mitchell vs. McReynolds, Orosco vs. Myers and the like. In my mind, as long as Mookie plays every day and Darryl keeps acting like a mensch (as he has all season) the Mets will win it all.

title:
INVESTING;
Ethics and Top Returns, Too
description: LEAD: WHEN it comes to stock picking, some investors prefer to let their conscience be their guide. As manager of the $10 million Parnassus Fund, based in San Francisco, Jerome L. Dodson puts companies to the test of social responsibility before investing in them.

title: DETERMINED TO BE HEARD
description: THEY ARE THE POWERFUL and the powerless, the popular and the scorned. A guild of stubborn optimists who test the limits of the system for the rest of us, they take their grievances, as they were taught they could in America, as far as you can go: to the United States Supreme Court.

title: Review/Opera; Gruberova and Araiza in Met 'Lucia'
description: You never can be sure what was done in the distant past, and the Metropolitan Opera itself is making no claims, but Friday night's performance was almost certainly the closest thing to an unabridged ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' ever given by the company.

title:
DANCE;
Crowded Calendar, Tough Choices
description: LEAD: CLASSICAL ballet companies, folk and ethnic ensembles, two troupes that offer a combination of ballet and jazz, and modern dance crowd this month's calendar, posing some difficult choices for aficionados. With more than 15 performances scheduled in the state's central and northern regions alone, the dance landscape appears lush and fertile.

title: Lorraine Simonton and John S. B. Oler, Both Bankers, Are Wed in New York
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York, Lorraine Simonton, a daughter of Mrs. Bennet Stocum Simonton of Rye, N.Y., and Salvatore Frustaci of Ardmore, Pa., was married yesterday to John Scott Brooks Oler, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Clarke Kimberly Oler of Pasadena, Calif. The bridegroom's father, associate rector of All Saints Episcopal Church in Pasadena and former rector of the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in New York, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Hugh Hildesley.

title: Alone With Venice in Winter
description: I DON'T KNOW IF RALPH WALDO EMERSON EVER COMMENTED ON Venice, but in that city in mid-January I'm reminded of his once writing that the part of the church service he liked best was the silence before the preaching begins. That is Venice in the winter. The sun seems never to rise, but to remain low and diffused in the sky, as if shining through a window of milky glass or alabaster, and the shadows are as long as church aisles. And the silence, that silence intensified by the sound of water lapping against stone, is one whose significance seems deeper than anything anybody can say, even the most inspired preacher. You don't want the service to begin, you don't want anyone to speak.

title: DISSIDENT ATTACKS SOVIET SPORTS SYSTEM
description: Twenty-eight years after he bent his thick weight lifter's neck to receive the Olympic gold medal, Yuri Vlasov watches the Summer Olympic Games with rage and longing, longing for what he thinks sports might be, and rage at what he thinks they are in the Soviet Union.

title: Ms. Hatcher Wed To Andrew Roth
description: Julia A. Hatcher, a daughter of Mrs. Frederick Gipson and Charles Hatcher of Toledo, Ohio, was married last evening to Andrew D. Roth, a son of Rosalind Wells of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi John Rosove performed the ceremony at the Washington Hebrew Congregation.

title: Aikman Connects Again for U.C.L.A.
description: Troy Aikman passed 48 yards to Reggie Moore for a touchdown with 1 minute 28 seconds left in the game today to give U.C.L.A. a 24-17 victory over Washington in both team's Pacific-10 Conference opener.

title: Sealing Double-Hung Windows
description: DOUBLE-HUNG windows, so named because they have two vertically sliding sashes, are difficult to seal against drafts. Even well-made models eventually develop gaps between the sashes and frame, allowing air to pass between them.

title: Thrift May Leave
description: Three years after he took over a financiallystrapped loser and turned it into a money-making contender, Syd Thrift, the general manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates, may be on the verge of getting his reward. According to the club president, Carl Barger, there is a ''distinct possibility'' that Thrift will be dismissed this week.

title: Question Of the Week; Which Is The Better Team, '86 Mets, Or '88 Mets?
description: The 1988 edition of the Mets is superior. This year's pitching was more consistent and at times overpowering. It certainly had to compensate for poor hitting. Yes, in 1986 they ran away with the division, however this year they had to overcome a crippling injury to Hernandez, blend in a weak hitting rookie shortstop, Elster, and deal with the sudden lack of offense from Carter. The most amazing feat of all was and is their ability to turn it on and off when necessary. They let the Pirates get close, but then won the right games at the right times. Just look at how they're finishing the season. GARY M. LEON East Brunswick, N.J.

title: Emelin's Guest Artist Series Opening
description: THE Emelin Theater's guest artist series will bring several notable chamber ensembles and soloists to the county this season. The Ridge String Quartet, for example, which will play later in the season, is one of the top young groups in the country, and there is no gainsaying the reputations of the pianist Rudolf Firkusny, the cellist Nathaniel Rosen and the Buswell-Parnas-Luvisi Trio, all of whom will be visiting performers.

title:
ART;
Artists Imprint Their MemoriesOn Photographs From the Past
description: LEAD: AT a certain point in one's viewing of ''Imprinted Memories'' at the Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson, the realization dawns that we are all artists in this genre. Whenever an adult flips through his family album, the memory interprets rather than repeats past events. Yardena Youner, the curator of this exhibition, has chosen 15 photographers who formally manipulate photographs from the past, the artist's past mostly; many of the resulting narratives are novel and engrossing.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Midwest; Notre Dame (4-0) Rolls, 42-14
description: Tony Rice rushed for two touchdowns and passed for another to lead Notre Dame to a 42-14 rout of Stanford tonight. Rice completed 11 of 14 passes for 129 yards and rushed for 107 yards.

title: Weighing Imagery In a Campaign Made for Television
description: FOR better and for worse, television has come of age in this Presidential election. No longer is the tube some dark, new force distorting the process through which voters select their Presidents. In the new electronic democracy, television is the force that shapes the process through which voters select their Presidents. Walter Mondale's complaint that he lost in 1984 because he was bad on television is not likely to be heard again from a candidate for national office.

title: East and West Get Down to Basics in Arms Negotiations
description: WHOEVER wins in November, the next Administration will find itself involved in one of the most complex negotiations on arms reduction ever attempted. Arms control officials say that by the end of this year, the 16 nations in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the 7 members of the Warsaw Pact will be ready to commence talks limiting conventional weapons in all of Europe.

title: Flannery O'Connor's Works
description: To the Editor:

title: Rutgers Swamps Cincinnati
description: The emotional impact of last week's triumph over Penn State was still fresh for Rutgers in its game against Cincinnati this afternoon. Playing with a high degree of enthusiasm, the Scarlet Knights dominated the Bearcats when it counted and registered a 38-9 triumph.

title: Pursuing the Past in Deerfield
description: LEAD: IN Deerfield, Mass., a haunting in the sunlight seems plausible. The shouts of young voices - at field hockey in the meadow or sports practice behind the academy - are as commonplace as the songs of birds. But might those high, thin cries be those of children long since gone, their voices still cradled in the air?

title: CHOSEN AND GIVEN
description: I am getting tired of a nation of ''walking wounded'': every complaint gives rise to a new field of psychology and a resulting rash of support groups.

title: Views and Conflicts On Recycling Issue
description: In the article ''Legislators Adopt Recycling Program'' [ Sept. 11 ] , County Executive O'Rourke refers to the plan as ''a model for the State of New York and maybe the whole country.'' I consider the plan a model of deception.

title: Flannery O'Connor's Works
description: To the Editor:

title: Lafayette Gains 3d Victory in a Row  P.S.A.L.
description: Lafayette, a school that won only twice last season, has become one of the powers in the Brooklyn A Division of the Public Schools Athletic League this season. Led by Chris App, its first-year coach, and Craig Harris, its senior fullback, the Chiefs improved their record to 3-0 yesterday with a 21-6 victory over a Brooklyn rival, Sheepshead Bay.

title: IRONY TO THE RESCUE
description: THE HIDDEN READER Stendhal, Balzac, Hugo, Baudelaire, Flaubert. By Victor Brombert. 226 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $27.50.

title: A Tale of Two Trees
description: THIS is a tale of two trees, one that we lost and one that we saved.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
ASBESTOS: TWO TROUBLING ASPECTS
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S school asbestos program is one of the best in the country. It requires state-of-the-art procedures for removing asbestos and monitoring the work.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: GANADO RED. By Susan Lowell. (Milkweed Editions, Paper, $9.95.) Predominantly set in the rough beauty of the Southwest, the novella and eight stories in ''Ganado Red'' show how deeply geography and culture can color the psyche and how alien we can feel in unfamiliar environments. They also show how easily the arrival of love, illness or malevolence can rattle the fragile foundations of our world.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
FICTION
description: LEAD: After the Civil War, corrupt politicians of the Gilded Age were appalled by a newfangled device that was actually able to cost them elections - the chromolithograph cartoon. In an age without television or movies, in which most magazines and newspapers consisted of columns of solid text and cost made illustrated books parlor-insulation for the rich, a powerfully drawn, color-lithographed political cartoon priced for the general pocket could mightily shape public opinion.

title: FILM VIEW
description: In the first half hour of ''Patty Hearst,'' as the blindfolded heiress is systematically berated by one shrill Symbionese Liberation Army member after another, the film tries to convey what Miss Hearst's nightmarish experience must have been like. That it isn't truly able to capture this, either then or later, can be explained only partially by the film's assumption that, as far as Miss Hearst's thought processes were concerned, there was nobody home.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $355,000 70 Fuller Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 21-year-old split level; country kitchen, brick fireplace, walk to shopping; taxes $5,335. North Tarrytown, N.Y. $280,000 139 Hunter Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 61-year-old Tudor; fireplace, sunroom, porch, walk to station; taxes $4,460. Peekskill, N.Y. $280,000 1715 Maple Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 88-year-old colonial; fieldstone fireplace, family room, patio, 1.3 acres; taxes $4,365. Newington, Conn. $155,000 145 Superior Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod, new boiler, zoned heat, 1-car garage, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,383. Plainville, Conn. $153,000 66 Roberts Street Extension 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 34-year-old Cape Cod; family room, woodstove, large deck; taxes $1,375. Somers, Conn. $235,000 160 Rosehaven Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 6-year-old Cape Cod; skylights, woodstove, 1 acre; taxes $1,900. OTHER AREAS Bellport, L.I. $157,000 80 Circuit Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 22-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, deck; taxes $2,300. East Patchogue, L.I. $138,000 64 Lyman Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old ranch; dining room, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $2,200. Maplewood, N.J. $152,000 16 Brown Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 38-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, eat-in kitchen, porch, den; taxes $2,749.

title: Oman Official Says Iran Wants Hostages Released
description: A consensus is emerging among Iran's political leadership that Western hostages held by Iranian-backed groups in Lebanon should be released, according to Oman's Foreign Minister, Youssef bin al-Alawi.

title: An Artful Guide To Bali's Crafts
description: FOR CENTURIES, SPICE traders did their best to avoid the small island of Bali, lying just off the easternmost tip of Java. The warriors were fierce and, besides, there was little to export except coconuts and copra - certainly nothing to fight over. Even the Dutch colonizers maintained only a small outpost here.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Old Saybrook
description: LEAD: AT Saybrook Point, where the Connecticut River meets Long Island Sound, fishermen cast their lines, families stroll along the waterfront and sail and power boats come and go.

title: Next Time
description: STAGING THE OLYMPICS IS, OF course, an Olympian feat in itself, and today, as the burden is lifted from the city of Seoul, it is building on the shoulders of Barcelona, host-to-be of the 1992 summer games, the first-ever Spanish Olympics. The city is erecting a complex of stadiums and other facilities - known as La Anilla Olimpica, or the Olympic Ring - that overlooks the Mediterranean from a plateau on Montjuic Mountain.

title: Parade Held for General as Balloting Nears
description: Thousands of cars and trucks rolled through Santiago today in a parade of support for Gen. Augusto Pinochet, three days before Chileans vote on extending his presidency.

title: Book Publishers Try New Kinds of Promotions
description: A week from today, Delacorte Press will begin shipping to bookstores more than 90,000 hardcover copies of ''Killing Time in St. Cloud,'' a novel set in that Minnesota city. To stimulate sales, the publisher is sponsoring a contest in which the winner can choose a trip to St. Cloud, worth $5,000 including expenses, or $5,000 in cash.

title: Reviews/Television; Marrying for Murder, Not for Love
description: Easing into the new season with a slew of made-for-television movies, CBS is clearly determined to stick with tired old tactics. At 9 tonight, ''Unholy Matrimony'' opens with the familiar label ''based on a true story.'' Then, buried in the final credits, is the almost subliminal proviso: ''However, some names, locations, events, dates and characters have been changed or fictionalized.''

title: Review/Fortepiano; Instrument as Co-recitalist
description: We are still at the stage in the old-instrument movement where attending a Malcolm Bilson recital means going to hear an instrument as well as an instrumentalist. The properties of Mr. Bilson's fortepiano - modeled after Mozart's own and used to play four Mozart sonatas at the Miller Theater at Columbia University Saturday night - are now familiar to many. But perhaps they do bear repeating: lighter tone, more fragile staying power but also varied color and a readiness to reveal inner detail.

title: Food Mergers Worry Some Officials
description: Fierce competition among supermarket companies has prompted a wave of mergers, making a once highly fragmented business more concentrated. In some major cities, as much as 39 percent of all grocery-store business is controlled by a single chain.

title: U.S. Scientists Discount Findings in French AIDS Treatment Study
description: An unproved AIDS drug has been reported to have some temporary benefit by French scientists, but the results have been discounted by American experts and called inconclusive by the company that makes the drug.

title: People
description: * Brian Hurley has been promoted to senior partner at Tatham-Laird & Kudner Advertising, Chicago.

title: THOMAS A. WEST WEDS EVE STRAUSS, A STUDENT
description: Eve Meredith Strauss, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Strauss of New York, and Thomas Alexander West, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David A. West of Blue Bell, Pa., were married yesterday. Acting Justice Frederic S. Berman of New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Burden Mansion in New York.

title: More Fighting Brings Hunger to Sudan
description: Increased fighting in the Sudanese civil war, which international relief workers say threatens two million people with starvation, has resulted in a sudden Government setback.

title: Premier of Bavaria Remains Seriously Ill After a Collapse
description: Franz Josef Strauss, the conservative Premier of Bavaria and one of the last of the politicians who helped found West Germany, was reported in critical condition today after collapsing during a deer hunt.

title: Tight Race Seen in Patrick Division
description: PATRICK DIVISION

title: Campaign Trail; Campaign Courtesy: Bush Calls on Bishop
description: Quietly but persistently, Vice President Bush has gone out of his way in recent weeks to court leading Roman Catholic clergymen in the Northeast and Midwest. The purpose is perfectly straightforward: Mr. Bush is seeking to appeal to Catholic voters, in part because of his opposition to abortion. Governor Dukakis has not met as many Catholic leaders as Mr. Bush; his support for a woman's right to choose an abortion is contrary to Roman Catholic teaching.

title: Drug Dealer Dies 10 Hours After Torching
description: A man described by the New York City police as a drug dealer died yesterday morning, 10 hours after he was doused with a flammable liquid and set afire across the street from Madison Square Garden.

title: Once Rarely Explored, the Holocaust Gains Momentum as a School Topic
description: The Holocaust, which was once too painful and bewildering to deal with in schools, has become a growing subject in American classrooms.

title: College Football; Backs Right in the Running
description: So far this season, quarterbacks are getting most of the attention in the run for the Heisman Trophy.

title: Priest Killed in 4-Car Collision
description: A priest who headed a New Jersey Catholic school died yesterday after being thrown from his car during a four-vehicle collision in midtown Manhattan, the police said.

title: Yankees End Up in Fifth Place
description: THE prediction Don Mattingly offered last January came from nowhere, like a pop fly that is gathered in by a powerful wind and blown suddenly into the bleacher seats. It was simply not expected.

title: The General and the Sergeant: Confreres in Haiti
description: Since the coup in Haiti two weeks ago, the new President, Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, and Sgt. Joseph Hebreux have been sharing an office in the presidential palace, jointly greeting visitors and attending meetings.

title: KAREN O'TOOLE AND PAUL GROMER MARRY
description: At St. David's Episcopal Church in South Yarmouth, Mass., Karen Doran O'Toole, the daughter of the late Mrs. Wilfred Ernest Schofield of South Yarmouth and the late Col. Lawrence Aloysius O'Toole Jr., U.S.A.F., was married yesterday to Paul Wolfgang Gromer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Joseph Gromer Jr., of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Sherrill Smith performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Christopher Schiavone, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Pipe Bomb Kills Child in Texas
description: A pipe bomb exploded in a residential neighborhood last night, killing an 8-year-old boy and injuring five other children, the authorities said. Capt. Roy Knight of the Fire Department said the children found the device along a curb in front of a home near a light-industrial area on the city's south side. Investigators recovered fragments of the bomb, but Captain Knight said he did not know how it was made. Three of the children were in serious condition, hospital officials said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13 News analysis: Soviet leadership changes in the last two days underscore a paradox: the more Mikhail S. Gorbachev tries to disperse power in an attempt to expand democracy, the more he must concentrate it in his own hands. Page A1

title: Chiefs Rally to Tie Jets
description: The Jets didn't lose today. In a solemn locker room, they just looked as if they did.

title: A Sport in Turmoil From Start to End
description: ''Peace, Harmony, Progress,'' the motto of the Games of the XXIVth Olympiad, was left battered at the end of the 429-bout boxing tournament.

title: Reproducing Charlie Parker's Art With Modern Technology of 'Bird'
description: ''Bird,'' Clint Eastwood's film tribute to the legendary saxophonist Charlie Parker, starts out with a high-voltage scene. Parker, played by Forest Whitaker, is hunched over his saxophone, unreeling gorgeously tense lines to a club audience. The rhythm section is right there with him; the music is riveting, intensely creative.

title: U.S. Is Successful Despite Low Status
description: All that talk about the demise of track and field in the United States is just that: talk.

title: Literacy Is Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Frost Prevails: David Frost of South Africa, a nine-time runner-up in four years on the PGA Tour, earned his first victory yesterday by knocking in a five-foot birdie putt on the first playoff hole to capture the Southern Open at Columbus, Ga. Frost caught Bob Tway with a six-foot birdie putt on the final hole of regulation play, then won when he birdied and Tway two-putted from 10 feet.(AP) Charles Is Winner: Bob Charles was declared the winner when steady rains washed out the scheduled final round of the Senior Challenge tournament at Roswell, Ga. Charles led through two rounds of the scheduled 54-hole event, and won with a total of 139, five under par.(AP) Victory for Guadagnino: Kathy Baker Guadagnino shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday for a total of 207 to beat Cathy Marino by a stroke in the San Jose Classic. (AP) AUTO RACING Prost Wins Easily: Alain Prost of France drove his turbocharged McLaren-Honda to an easy victory yesterday in the Spanish Grand Prix at Jerez de la Frontera. Prost led from the start and completed the 72 laps of the 2.62-mile Spanish circuit 26 seconds ahead of the second-place finisher, Nigel Mansell of Britain, who drove a normally aspirated Williams-Judd.(AP) ROAD RACING < Atlanta Women Wins: Gordon Bakoulis-Bloch of the Atlanta Track Club led a field of 1,656 to win the New York Road Runners Club's women's four-mile run in 22 minutes 2 seconds at Central Park yesterday. Mia Mahedy, who finished second, led the Warren Street Athletic Club to the team title.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * Spain is forecasting 5 percent inflation by the end of 1988, overshooting a 3 percent target, but economic growth is also set to outpace previous forecasts, Finance Minister Carlos Solchaga said. At a news conference on Saturday to unveil full details of the Government's 1989 budget plans, he said the Government was committed to bringing inflation down to 3 percent by the end of 1989.

title: Pakistan Court Ends Zia Ban on Party Candidates
description: Overturning a decree issued by the late President, Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, the Supreme Court ruled today that candidates in next month's election may run under the banner of any political party.

title: Metro Datelines; Long-Term Shelters In Plan for Homeless
description: City officials have unveiled a $15 million plan to help the homeless that calls for the creation of 12 neighborhood residences that would provide long-term shelter and support with the aim of helping the homeless finally break out of poverty.

title: Takeover Stocks at Top In 3d Quarter
description: Takeover stocks continued their dominance as the best and, in some cases, the worst performers during the third quarter. But if those names are omitted, the three months just ended are likely to be quickly forgotten by investors.

title: Governor Dukakis Is Toying With Defense, and America
description: LEAD: Anyone of voting age knows enough about the world to take for granted that when he listens to campaign oratory what he will get is a characteristically and intentionally debased form of discourse. Thus, the Presidential debate should not in any way have disappointed normal expectations.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Rescuer Is Confident On Savings Bailout
description: LEAD: Clifford J. Grum, president and chief executive of Temple-Inland Inc., the Texas holding company that led the investor group that agreed to invest $128 million in a federally assisted bailout last week, sees the savings institutions as natural adjuncts to the company's $3.4 billion mortgage banking business.

title: Review/Opera; A Debut in 'Giulio Cesare'
description: Barbara Kilduff, a soprano, was scheduled to sing her first Cleopatra in the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Handel's ''Giulio Cesare'' on Oct. 19. But because Kathleen Battle was indisposed on Saturday evening, Ms. Kilduff stepped into the role a couple of weeks earlier than expected.

title: New Hampshire Trips Itself
description: Among the lowlights and highlights of college football in the East on Saturday were the bumbling of an overconfident New Hampshire team, the emergence of Princeton as a potential Ivy title contender, the redemption of a Boston College quarterback, Mike Power, once booed by his own fans, and another triumph for a Lafayette team not sure how good it can be.

title: In the South, Dukakis Faces an Uphill Climb
description: The scene in Charlotte, N.C., on Friday would have swelled the heart of Walter F. Mondale, who sometimes seemed the loneliest Democrat around when he headed south in 1984 and sought the embrace of his party's elected officials.

title: Now, the City's Country Jail Is Crowded
description: The fresh air, mild and damp as it wafts over the St. Lawrence Seaway from Canada, immediately impresses prisoners when they arrive here for an extended stay at New York City's newest jail.

title: Officers Resign At Bank Leumi
description: The chairman and seven board members of Bank Leumi, one of Israel's leading commercial banks, have resigned after public outrage over huge sums awarded to 25 senior bank executives, the bank said Friday.

title: Seven Years Without Directing, And Billy Wilder Is Feeling Itchy
description: If Billy Wilder could hide the fact that he is 82 years old, he would. Hollywood pays homage to old age but doesn't appreciate it.

title: Mastercard And Visa: Rival Donors
description: THE never-ending marketing rivalry between the big bank credit cards is not just over fees and perquisites. It is over ''causes,'' too.

title: DU PONT ASSERTS IT FULLY DISCLOSED REACTOR PROBLEMS
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said today that it had fully disclosed information about a number of serious accidents at the Savannah River Plant, a Government complex that produces fuel for nuclear weapons.

title: Fannie Mae Set to Price $500 Million Issue
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, starting with today's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills.

title: Metro Datelines; 10 Held in Protest By Gay Catholics
description: Ten demonstrators were arrested yesterday after they laid down in Fifth Avenue outside St. Patrick's Cathedral to protest John Cardinal O'Connor's stance on homosexuality.

title: MARY C. JURKASH MARRIES DANIEL BERICK, A LAWYER
description: At the Bond Chapel on the University of Chicago campus, Mary Carol Jurkash, the manager of professional services at the New York law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, was married yesterday to Daniel G. Berick, an associate at the New York law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan. The Rev. John Sanaghan, a Roman Catholic priest, and Cantor Sidney Medintz officiated.

title: Harvard Research Plan Advances Public Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Letter: On Phone Service; Price Caps Plan Still a Wrong Number
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising for Hasbro Doll Seeks to Dethrone Barbie
description: The doll wars will begin to heat up today with new advertising by Hasbro Inc., even though the start of the frantic Christmas shopping season is still eight weeks away.

title: Hirohito Survives Blood Loss
description: Emperor Hirohito of Japan is still suffering from internal bleeding, but has weathered the latest crisis in his two-week fight for life, palace officials reported today. They said the 87-year-old monarch lost a small amount of blood today and received another transfusion this morning. On Saturday, the Emperor suffered a sudden loss of blood and a sharp drop in his blood pressure.

title: First Monday, Second Tuesday
description: Obedient to the law, the Supreme Court reconvenes today, the first Monday in October. Even more than usual, a sense of imminent change attends the high court's new term. As of the second Tuesday in November, America will have chosen a new President and many people expect new Justices and legal changes soon thereafter.

title: Campaign Trail; Ohio Gives Bentsen A Sparring Partner
description: He's youthful! He's photogenic! He's Dennis E. Eckart. And the Democratic Congressman from Ohio is portraying Sen. Dan Quayle in Senator Lloyd Bentsen's preparation for the Vice Presidential debate.

title: Tunes for Tax Man Say Pay as You Owe
description: The Internal Revenue Service has reported a rare case of rendering unto it what is Caesar's - in this case, Irving Caesar's. The 93-year-old songwriter - ''Tea for Two,'' ''Swanee,'' ''Just a Gigolo,'' ''I Want to Be Happy,'' ''Crazy Rhythm,'' ''Is It True What They Say About Dixie'' and more than 1,000 other lyrics - wants to give the I.R.S. the copyrights to two of his songs for children.

title: Bridge
description: Players from Long Island dominated the final standings Saturday in New York's Grand National Pairs Championship. In play at the Penta Hotel, at 33d Street and Seventh Avenue, these three pairs earned a trip to Reno for the finals in March: First - Mel Colchamiro, Long Beach, L.I., and Leigh Steinberg, Port Washington, L.I.; second, Ronald Cohen, Woodmere, L.I., and Alan Miller, Manhattan; third, Frank and Diana Schuld, Glen Head, L.I. Play was in conjunction with the Greater New York Bridge Association's Senior Regional Championships. These were the winners: Startified Pairs Flight A - Lee Vines and Bob Geiger, both of Manhattan. Flight B - Bill Albin, Manhattan, and Steve Gula, Wilmington, Del. Flight C - Dorothy Helphand and Cecile Rothaus, both of Manhattan. Open Pairs - Gerald Tatz, Middletown, N.Y., and Sera Shea, Monroe, N.Y. These were the sectional winners: Mixed Pairs - Ann Raymond and Adam Wildovsky, both of Manhattan. Unmixed Pairs - John Solodar and Seymour Reich, both of Manhattan. Open Pairs - Linda Ewen, Jamaica, Queens, and Suzanne Goldstein, Roslyn Heights, L.I.; also, Leslie Trutt, Patchogue, L.I., and Ken Moss, Hauppaugue, L.I. 99er Pairs - Pearl and Seymour Ehrlich, Paramus, N.J. 49er Pairs - Donald Lane and Ronald Korda, Scarsdale, N.Y.; also, Carla Feltman and Frank Jewett, both of Manhattan.

title: Edmonton Will Be Difficult to Dethrone
description: SMYTHE DIVISION

title: Business and the Law; Bid to Drop Judge Renews Old Fight
description: THE upcoming confrontation between a Federal judge in Manhattan and a leading New York trial lawyer in the securities fraud case of Drexel Burnham Lambert will not be the first for the two men. More than a decade ago, Judge Milton Pollack and Arthur L. Liman locked horns in a bitter lawsuit involving complex securities issues.

title: Injured Gibson Improving
description: As Kirk Gibson walked slowly, very slowly, through the entrance to the Los Angeles Dodger clubhouse, Mickey Hatcher, his teammate, looked up and smiled. ''Hey, Walter Brennan,'' Hatcher said. The good news for the Dodgers was that as slowly as Gibson was moving, he could see progress. He played six innings Friday, after missing five of the previous six games, and aggravated a muscle injury in his left leg.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In the last 35 years, the Dodgers - in Brooklyn and Los Angeles - have had only two managers, Walter Alston (1954-76) and Tom Lasorda. During that span, which major league team has had the next fewest number of managers?

title: Metro Matters; For Parks Chief, Offbeat Charm Is His Signature
description: Everyone has a favorite Henry Stern story.

title: Canada Faces National Vote On U.S. Trade
description: When Prime Minister Brian Mulroney called a general election on Saturday, he presented Canadians with a choice that all three parties have said is the most important that voters here have faced this century.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Rebel Mine Kills Guatemalan
description: One officer died and seven were wounded when a mine planted by guerrillas went off in northern Guatemala, the army said today. The incident happened Saturday near San Juan, 315 miles north of the capital in the Peten region, the announcement said.

title: Soviets Urge Nations to Provide a U.N. Army
description: The Soviet Union has suggested that countries routinely earmark some of their armed forces for United Nations peacekeeping duties, effectively giving the United Nations an army of its own.

title: Haiti Seems Less Than Perturbed By Ouster of a Powerful Colonel
description: At the mustard-colored headquarters where Col. Jean-Claude Paul had reigned until this weekend as Haiti's most powerful troop commander, the soldiers today were quietly accepting his forced retirement.

title: Allied Closing 5 Stores
description: The Allied Stores Corporation said it would close five Stern's department stores: in Philadelphia, King of Prussia, Langhorne and Media, Pa., and Moorestown, N.J. The department store chain will continue to operate 24 units. It said closing is expected in about 30 days on agreements with the landlords on termination of store leases of all but the Philadelphia store, which the Campeau Corporation, parent of Allied, owns.

title: Campaign Trail; A Beloved Mug Shot For the Bush Forces
description: ''I've Seen Elvis in the Flesh!'' ''Statue of Elvis Found on Mars!'' ''Kablaam! Body Builder Explodes as He Was Pumping Iron Too Fast!''

title: High Hopes Ride on Quayle Debate Performance
description: The Vice-Presidential debate Wednesday is Senator Dan Quayle's moment in political history, when he can overcome, or confirm, the public's unease about him as a candidate, a possible Vice President and a potential President, analysts in both parties agree.

title: A Soviet Paradox; Concentration of Power by Gorbachev Seems at Odds With Democracy Push
description: The dramatic leadership changes that Mikhail S. Gorbachev engineered in the last two days underscored a central paradox of his program to reshape the Soviet Union: the more he tries to disperse power, the more he finds it necessary to concentrate power in his own hands.

title: Campaign Trail; A Bandana Is More Than a Neckerchief
description: The press corps traveling with Governor Dukakis got an object lesson the other day in the old saying that all politics is local. After a stop at a farm in West Texas reporters were delighted to discover that each of them had been given a bright red or blue cowboy bandana, and many of them promptly tied them around their necks.

title: Harvard Research Plan Advances Public Health; Working Partnership
description: To the Editor:

title: Shuttle Return On TV Today
description: The ABC, CBS, NBC and Cable News networks plan live coverage of the shuttle landing, scheduled for 12:37 P.M. today, Eastern daylight time, at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. All four networks plan to begin live coverage about half an hour before the landing and to stay with the shuttle until shortly after it touches down.

title: No Mistaking Tylor's Return
description: On the third play of the game today, the Giants' defender crashed into the Washington Redskins backfield and sacked the quarterback, causing a fumble and setting up the Giants' first score. Lawrence Taylor was back. ''He's a great football player,'' said the Redskins' young quarterback, Mark Rypien, the object of Taylor's attentions throughout the game at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium. ''For the most part, our guys did a good job containing him, but he won a few times, too.''

title: Italy's Proposed Budget
description: The Italian Cabinet has approved a proposed 1989 budget that would put the deficit at 117.25 trillion lire, or $83.7 billion. The plan, which Parliament must approve, was adopted late Thursday. It includes cutbacks in some health-care and cultural programs as well as in the national railroad.

title: >Review/Opera; Capobianco's 'Rigoletto'
description: ''Rigoletto'' at the New York State Theater on Saturday afternoon did not offer a very promising environment for the young singers who took on its leading roles for the first time with the company. The Tito Capobianco production, new this year, is an embarrassment, the kind of show that brings ''traditional'' opera into severe disrepute. And the musical conditions were all too indicative of the City Opera's chronic under-rehearsal. The conductor, Elio Boncompagni, showed good presence of mind on the dozen or so occasions when ensemble between pit and stage became seriously unglued, but an ounce of prevention is worth several pounds of such cures.

title: Foreign Stocks Lower Over All in Third Quarter
description: Foreign stock markets, on the whole, declined again in the third quarter of this year, but many of those that were down from April through June rebounded in the last three months. A similar reversal befell many second-quarter winners.

title: Harper In TV Film On Network She Sued
description: Two weeks after her courtoom victory in a trial in which she heard herself accused of unprofessional, unstable conduct, Valerie Harper is starring in a two-hour movie at 9 P.M. Monday for NBC, one of the parties she sued for breach of contract when she was dismissed from the comedy series ''Valerie.''

title: Undone by Ballpoint
description: 1. Book of Hours Those calligraphic pitfalls required by state law, ''Push-pulls and ovals'' at a clip, Showed fictive citizens the way to write and draw. Ten-inch Palmer letters rode White cards around the blackboard top. Our Bayeux, its sloping figures flowed. One fat fifth-grader with no breasts Twice licked the dip-pen tip. We lusted for fair penmanship Sweating at our palimpsests. 2. Keys of the Kingdom The spindle fattens with our words Stamped on inky ribbon by the plunging keys, One finger at a time, no chords. Margin release! Carriage return! Wild words, while the space bar frees A multigraphic logos we must learn. This is absolution by machine, Curing scriptural disease With a font of a b c's That leave purest equal spaces in between. 3. The Last Word In the beginning was the word Made not of flesh but bytes Processed from menus with the print deferred. Is it eros still or disk drive that governs the unseen? The cursor seeks and finds and rights: At last! a memory friendly users now can clean. Academe is full again of missionary zeal, For salvation by formatting, rubouts and deletes; So green be your screen until your last rites, Down at your terminal, a silent daisy wheel.

title: Two Bombs in Holiday Bread Wound 3 Girls in Jerusalem
description: Two bombs hidden in loaves of Jewish holiday bread exploded in Jerusalem today and slightly wounded three young girls, the police said.

title: Who Participates In What, and Where
description: THE National Sporting Goods Association has released its Sports Participation Index, a state-by-state analysis of participation in 33 sports, from aerobics to water-skiing. Not only does the survey show the top five participant sports in each state for 1987, it also shows how participation levels in each of the 33 sports stack up in the 11 most populated states.

title: DR. GARY TANNENBAUM WEDS DR. MARY BRITTIS
description: The marriage of Dr. Mary Ellen Brittis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas J. Brittis of Yonkers and East Hampton, L.I., to Dr. Gary Alan Tannenbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Tannenbaum of Scarsdale, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Caramoor estate in Katonah, N.Y. Rabbi Albert Sturmer and the Rev. Dr. Melvin A. Hawthorne, chaplain at the Church Center for the United Nations, performed the ceremony.

title: Orthotics Work for the Whole Body
description: IN 1984, Isabele Carmichael of New York, a top road racer, qualified for the first Olympic marathon trial for women. Later that year she developed recurring tightness in her right leg that caused her foot to grow numb. Forced to cut her high-level training to mere jogging, she desperately sought a medical solution to her problem.

title: Cardinals Hand Rams First Defeat
description: Neil Lomax threw for 342 yards and two touchdowns today as the Phoenix Cardinals ended the conference's last undefeated run by beating the Los Angeles Rams, 41-27.

title: Soviet Bank For Projects
description: A new Soviet bank has been created to finance high-risk scientific and engineering projects, the newspaper Pravda said last week.

title: South Koreans Feel Triumphant as the Games End
description: South Korea, which came into the Olympics hoping for six gold medals but fearful that it might fall short, emerged from the Games in triumph both as host and competitor. It placed sixth in the overall medal standing with 33 and fourth in the gold-medal standing with 12.

title: INSIDE
description: Lessons of the Holocaust Many schools are not only teaching it as history but exploring it in terms of modern-day prejudice. Page A16. Pinochet's Risky Course Chile decides Wednesday on the rule of the man that one backer calls a ''very peculiar dictator.'' Page. A10.

title: Review/Film; At Work and Home, a Difficult Life
description: ''Jacob,'' Mircea Daneliuc's new Rumanian film, is about a gold miner whose life is very difficult, in the mines and out.

title: Reviews/Television; What Teen-Agers Do Not Know
description: The ignorance of America's high school students is the subject of tonight's episode in ABC's ''Burning Questions'' series. The one-hour documentary, which can be seen at 8 P.M. on Channel 7, offers no new answers to the title question, ''America's Kids: Why They Flunk,'' but lays on the appalling evidence in the form of test results and interviews.

title: The Matron Stakes To Some Romance
description: The Matron Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday was among the most boring Grade I stakes races ever run, but it did settle an important question: Some Romance is the best 2-year-old filly in New York.

title: Books of The Times; Love in the Mind's Interior and in the Wilderness
description: Of Such Small Differences By Joanne Greenberg 262 pages. Henry Holt & Company. $18.95. Private Woods By Sandra Crockett Moore 302 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $18.95.

title: Men's Volleyball; U.S. Repeats Gold-Medal Performance
description: Is America ready for a new America's Team? As Karch Kiraly of the gold-medal volleyball team noted this afternoon, the Dallas Cowboys are not exactly claiming the title these days.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The economy grew in September at the slowest pace in six months, the nation's purchasing managers said in their monthly report, adding that industrial production increased at a respectable rate and that orders for exports rose. Many economists and Government officials have been hoping for signs of slower overall growth, out of fear that the economy may overheat. [ Page D1. ] More stocks fell than rose in the third quarter, and volume declined even further. Shares in companies that were takeover targets continued to be active, however, as 9 of the Big Board's top 10 gainers were involved in takeover actions. [ D1. ] COMPANIES California's challenge to the merger of two big grocery chains comes partly in reaction to an increasingly concentrated supermarket industry. Analysts note that mergers like the one between American Stores and Lucky are encouraged by the highly competitive nature of the industry, in which the most efficient operators thrive. [ D1. ] The doll wars are heating up. A volley of advertising will begin today to promote Maxie, a new fashion doll by Hasbro. The nation's leading toy company has fallen far behind No. 2 Mattel, creator of the Barbie doll, in the $400 million fashion-doll market. [ D1. ] Maxwell said its rival knew the terms of its bid for Macmillan. The British company said that the auction was unfair because the rival bidder, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts, had been told by a Macmillan official that its offer was 50 cents higher than Maxwell's. Both bids have since been raised. [ D3. ] Du Pont denied that it covered up information about accidents at a plant that produces fuel for nuclear weapons. [ A1. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT Many foreign stock markets declined again in the third quarter, but several that had previously dropped gained in the most recent period. The West German, Italian and Austrian markets had a burst of growth, while those in Canada, Singapore/Malaysia and Hong Kong slipped. Japan's market was essentially flat. [ D6. ] A private American investor has turned to black Africa, countering a decline in investment there. Kim A. Barkan is building a plant in Congo to make telephone poles from eucalyptus trees. [ D6. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS Publishers are increasingly relying on giveaways to draw attention to new books. These range from rebates, video cassettes and free books to jewelry, vacations and cruises. [ D10. ] The price-per-subscriber has soared in cable-TV acquisitions, and most analysts say the increases will probably stick. [ D10. ] The Christian Science Monitor's publisher is starting a news program on cable television in a broad effort to expand its reach. It has also begun publishing a general-interest news monthly. [ D10. ] A new generation of critics has begun to judge advertising. In the five years that the genre has existed, ad criticism has been a source of interest and controversy. Ad Scene. [ D10. ] Visa and Mastercard's rivalry extends even to charity. Mastercard is intensifying its charity marketing program, while Visa plans to continue contributions for the Olympics. Advertising. [ D11. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The credit markets are awaiting an employment report for September. Analysts hope those numbers, due Friday, will provide a sign of whether August's performance was a temporary lull or the beginning of a period of slow growth. Credit Markets. [ D1. ] An anticipated confrontation in Federal court may echo a clash in the 1970's between District Judge Milton Pollack and Arthur L. Liman, a New York trial lawyer. Mr. Liman is representing Drexel Burnham Lambert, which is seeking Judge Pollack's removal from a complex securities case. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] Analysts are wary of software companies' stock. They cite repeated delays in the introduction of new products and uncertainties about how well the systems will be received. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: U.S. Sees Stable Relations Despite Kremlin Shake-Up
description: American officials said today that they did not expect any major changes in Soviet policy toward the United States as a result of the shake-up in the Kremlin leadership over the last two days.

title: No Lightweight in Class
description: At 115 pounds, James Martin may have been the lightest athlete ever red-shirted at a major university. But the Penn State wrestling coach, Rich Lorenzo, felt that Martin, a three-time Pennsylvania state high school champion in weight divisions ranging from 98 to 105 pounds, was too light to compete in the lightest collegiate division, which is 118 pounds, when he arrived at University Park, Pa., in 1984.

title: Christian Science Publisher Expands Into TV and a Magazine
description: In a broad effort to expand its historically modest reach, the organization that publishes The Christian Science Monitor is spending more than $100 million on a new evening news program for cable television and a new general-interest news monthly, both of them called ''World Monitor.'' The name says a great deal about the growing ambition of the newspaper, which has been published in Boston by the Christian Science Publishing Society since 1908 and has been losing money ever since.

title: Generoso P. Pope Jr. Dead at 61; The National Enquirer's Publisher
description: Generoso P. Pope Jr., the millionaire owner and publisher of The National Enquirer, suffered a heart attack yesterday at his home in West Palm Beach, Fla., and was pronounced dead on arrival at the J.F.K. Medical Center in Atlantis, Fla. He was 61 years old.

title: Philadelphia Shelters Turn Out the Homeless
description: About 20 private shelters evicted at least 1,000 homeless people when contract negotiations with the city ended without an agreement, officials said today.

title: Hopes Rise for the Release of Hostages in Lebanon
description: Hopes for the release of foreign hostages in Lebanon rose today as the spiritual leader of a pro-Iranian group believed to be behind the kidnappings said a solution was in sight. The kidnappers themselves promised to free one of their captives.

title: Civilian Handguns Are Crime Stoppers
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.
