title: Welcome, President Gorbachev!
description: As the people of Israel, Pakistan and the U.S. prepare to go to the polls next month, the people of the Soviet Union were treated to an election Communist-style: at the shortest meeting of the Central Committee in 70 years, Mikhail Gorbachev added the presidency to his powers.

title: Review/Dance; Mixed Bill by Nureyev And 7 of His Friends
description: Over the years, Rudolf Nureyev has often toured with a small troupe called Rudolf Nureyev and Friends. Composed of dancers from various companies and performing works in several choreographic idioms, these ensembles have had considerable success. On Saturday night, Mr. Nureyev brought his newest group of dancing friends - seven members of American Ballet Theater - to Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, at Lehman College in the Bronx. But their program was only intermittently effective.

title: Blacks in U.S. Are Lobbied By Angolans
description: Increasingly skilled in the arts of political tourism, Angola's left-wing Government unveiled its deluxe package tour recently for a group of black American churchmen.

title: Kamsa Hamnida, Ben Johnson
description: SHORTLY before the Olympics began, a large wall clock in The Associated Press office here fell to the floor. Ever since, its hour, minute and sweep-second hands have turned counter-clockwise, as if these Olympics were going back in time. And in a way, they did.

title: JOHN CATSIMATIDIS WED TO MARGO VONDERSAAR
description: At the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York, Margo Vondersaar and John A. Catsimatidis were married yesterday by Archbishop Iakovos, primate of the Greek Orthodox Church in North and South America.

title: Rangers End Preseason With Victory
description: The Rangers closed their exhibition season with a 4-2 triumph over the Whalers tonight, and the performance prompted Coach Michel Bergeron to say the club was ready for its regular-season opener on Thursday.

title: Chrysler Sets Price Rise
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced that the price of its 1989 models would increase an average 2.3 percent, the same figure as the tentative price rise it announced in August. The increase by Chrysler, for the fourth straight year, is the lowest of the United States auto makers. The General Motors Corporation said in August that it was increasing prices by an average 2.9 percent based on comparably equipped models. The Ford Motor Company said Sept. 12 that prices of its 1989 cars and trucks would increase 2.6 percent.

title: End of Tradition
description: When Carl Braun, Butch van Breda Kolff and Bud Palmer were the 1947 Knick heroes, New York defeated the Providence Steamrollers, 89-75, in a game that began a longstanding tradition: the Christmas Day game at Madison Square Garden.

title: Muriel Snowden, 72, Pioneer in Integration
description: Muriel Snowden, co-founder of the non-profit Freedom House that pushed for integration and self-help in Boston's predominantly black Roxbury section, died of cancer at her home Friday. She was 72 years old.

title: How Did the Dodgers Do It?
description: THEY began hearing the question some time after Memorial Day, when the Los Angeles Dodgers took hold of first place in the West Division of the National League and refused to let go. How have they done this?

title: HONORS THE 7 LOST
description: In a solemn tribute televised from orbit, the astronauts aboard the space shuttle Discovery paid homage today to the crew of the ill-fated Challenger, saying, ''We have resumed the journey that we promised to continue for you.''

title: U.S. Has No Strategy at All for War on Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Candidate Is Culprit in 1-Vote Loss
description: Herbert Connolly lost the primary election for a nomination to the Massachusetts Governor's Council by just one vote: his own.

title: Metro Datelines; Telephone Workers Get Discounted Rate
description: Top officials, employees and retirees of Southern New England Telephone Company receive local telephone service for free or at a 50 percent discount under a rate-benefit policy worth about $4 million annually.

title: Time Lowers Guarantee To Hold Back Ad Costs
description: Despite rising publishing costs, Time magazine announced Friday that it would maintain its current national page costs through 1989 by reducing its circulation rate base guarantee to 4.3 million, from 4.6 million.

title: Gretzky Shifts Spotlight to L.A.
description: They are calling it sacrilege in Edmonton, where Wayne Gretzky was regarded as a national monument on ice skates. But the unprecedented trade that sent the world's greatest hockey player to its most improbable marketplace has been heralded as nothing less than revolutionary by the rest of the image-conscious National Hockey League.

title: Hong Kong Journal; Where Wall-to-Wall Means People
description: The tiny park is hard and gray and uninviting - concrete benches sitting on concrete pavement. The only green is a little strip of grass with a few wispy trees, and these are fenced off from the public.

title: Veterans From 2 Armies and 2 Wars Finding Shared Wounds in Moscow
description: The table was covered with food and bottles of drink, and the men were sitting around it, talking of their soldier days. Silverware clattered and glasses tapped in fraternity, until one of the the men recalled how eerie the nights were. And in the sudden silence, they all remembered.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Construction Spending Aug. Factory Orders Aug. Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Unemployment Rate Sept. Consumer Borrowing Aug.

title: Bears Demolish Disjointed Bills, 24-3
description: Sixty-one seconds remained in the third quarter when the Buffalo Bills were at the Chicago Bears' 14-yard line. It was fourth-and-1.

title: Metro Datelines; City Schools Restate Policy on Religion
description: Parochial schools are still permitted to use the athletic fields, auditoriums and other facilities of New York City public schools as long as they are not being used for religious purposes, a spokesman for the Board of Education said yesterday.

title: Lawyer Back in Buyouts With Bid for Fischbach
description: Andrew N. Heine, a New York lawyer who has participated in leveraged buyouts off and on since the 1960's, is back on the scene with an offer to buy the Fischbach Corporation, whose chairman is Victor Posner, the financier.

title: State by State; Liberals in Madison See Little Choice
description: This is one place, even in the age of Ronald Reagan, where the ''L-word'' is not a dirty word.

title: Coming of Age in Raritan: A Sense of Loss
description: Suzette Dalton, a 16-year-old from Texas, misses Corpus Christi's warm beaches on the Gulf of Mexico. Kit Mischler, her new 16-year-old friend from Georgia, misses Atlanta's shopping malls.

title: A New Breed of TV Critic Asks: to Zap or Not to Zap?
description: GENE SISKEL and Roger Ebert are not yet quaking in their armchairs, but a new generation of critics is joining them on the television tube, in this case to judge the most pervasive contemporary cultural form - advertising.

title: Campaign Finance; In Election Spending, Watch Ceiling and Use a Loophole
description: Federal limits on spending by Presidential campaigns have become the political version of the 55-mile-per-hour speed limit: They're there, but they don't matter much.

title: Doubt, Hope At the Finish
description: Questionable decisions in the ring and the possible physical dangers of competition have prompted executives of the International Olympic Committee to review whether boxing should continue in the Olympics.

title: Chief of a DDB Ad Office Will Head Porsche in U.S.
description: The president and chief executive of Porsche A.G.'s North American operations will be Brian Bowler, a British-born advertising executive.

title: Twice Right on Trade
description: President Reagan struck two mighty blows for consumers the other day when he vetoed a bill to throttle imports of textiles and clothing, and then, minutes later, signed another to expand trade with Canada. An effort by misguided House Democrats to override the veto this week is a further extension of pure political mischief.

title: Medal Winners of the 1988 Seoul Olympics  Final Medal Standings
Murder Conviction Is Upset by One Word
description: The 1972 murder conviction of a Rochester man was reversed by a state appellate court because the trial judge repeatedly substituted the word ''and'' for ''or'' while instructing the jury about the insanity defense.

title: Review/Music; A Violinist of South India
description: The World Music Institute opened its new season on Friday with an extraordinary concert of music from south India. M. S. Gopalkrishnan, one of India's leading violinists, and Guruvayur Dorai, a mrdangam drummer, were joined by a small electronic instrument that produced calm drone tones to back their fevered improvisations.

title: Maxwell Says Rival Knew of Bid
description: In another twist in the battle for Macmillan, Maxwell Communications said yesterday that papers filed in Washington confirmed that during the auction process a rival bidder knew the terms of one of its recent offers.

title: STEVEN BLISS WED TO JUDITH SACKS
description: Judith Abby Sacks, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David G. Sacks of Larchmont, N.Y., and Longboat Key, Fla., was married yesterday to Steven Jeffrey Bliss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin B. Bliss of Yonkers. Rabbis Abraham Klausner and Leonard Poller officiated at the Beach Point Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Bright Vermont Foliage Masks Concern for Trees
description: The buses and campers and the neon no-vacancy signs are a sure indication that the fall foliage season has arrived in Vermont.

title: Analysts See Good Reasons For Price Rise in Cable Deals
description: The price-per-subscriber paid in cable television acquisitions has soared over the past two years, and most analysts agree that the big increases will stick and prices may even go higher.

title: Thucydides Knew
description: To the Editor:

title: Piniella's Return Unlikely
description: Lou Piniella, unable to bring the Yankees a division title in his second attempt as manager, may be on his way out again. A dismissal is reportedly imminent, as is the choice of Dallas Green as Piniella's successor.

title: Outdoors: On the Sugar River in Search of Trout
description: MY wooden wading staff vibrated in the waist-deep water as I made my way across the rapids above the head of a big pool on the Sugar River. I had been daydreaming about getting here for the previous three days, and I reminded myself that there was no need to rush, that five hours of fly fishing lay ahead of me before nightfall.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Jewish holidays of Shemini Atzereth and Simhath Torah, which conclude the harvest festival of Succoth, alternate-side parking are suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Home Products Corp., New York, a manufacturer and marketer of medicines, foods and household products, elected Frank A. Bennack Jr., president and chief executive of Hearst Corp., to its board.

title: Shoreham on a Seesaw: The Art of Shifting Blame for Nuclear Plant's Fate
description: In the three months since Governor Cuomo announced a historic agreement to abandon the Shoreham nuclear power plant, he has retreated from his original position that the State Legislature must approve a bill describing the deal as ''in the public interest.''

title: Army Drops Colt as M16 Rifle Maker
description: The Army has dropped Colt Industries Inc. as the manufacturer of America's standard infantry weapon, the M16 rifle, according to a published report. The move could affect employment at strike-plagued Colt plants in Connecticut.

title: U.S. and Soviet Officials Uniting To Discourage Athletes' Drug Use
description: An Olympics tainted by a drug scandal ended today with the sports officials of the United States and the Soviet Union agreeing to work together against drug use among athletes.

title: Detroit Catholics Vow to Fight Closings
description: The Roman Catholic Church announced a plan to close more than a third of Detroit's 112 Catholic churches, and stunned and saddened parishioners attending Mass today vowed to fight the move.

title: Mr. Gorbachev's Surprise
description: Mikhail Gorbachev's economic reforms were failing dismally, nationalist protests were growing and conservative critics carping. But instead of succumbing, the Soviet leader called last week on his capacity for dramatic surprise. He summoned the state and party leadership, drastically rearranged it and emerged stronger than ever.

title: CARRIE BORETZ WEDS
description: Carrie Boretz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Boretz of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday at the Lotos Club in New York to Edward Nicholas Keating, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward Keating of New Canaan, Conn. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony. The bride, a freelance photojournalist who will keep her name professionally, graduated from Washington University in St. Louis. Mr. Keating, a freelance photographer, attended Columbia University.

title: League Leaders
Campaign Trail; Bentsen's Eyes Glaze (Briefly) in Carolina
description: It's getting to be the time on the campaign trail when the cities and the states and the tarmacs and the Hyatts run together.

title: Audit of Fire Department Shows Inspection Positions Left Vacant
description: Most of New York City's standpipes and sprinkler systems, which protect about 16,700 commercial and residential buildings, have not been inspected in more than five years, according to an audit released yesterday by Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin.

title: Tag Sale, As a Show Of Shows, Is a Hit
description: Despite the esoterica on sale, yesterday in Lincoln Center could have been Dec. 23 at Bloomingdale's. The brand names were Ziegfeld, not Kamali, and Sondheim, not de la Renta, but the stock (as in summer) moved just as fast.

title: Bengals (5-0) Rout the Raiders
description: Boomer Esiason picked apart a revamped Los Angeles secondary today, passing for 332 yards and three touchdowns as the Cincinnati Bengals, the National Football League's only unbeaten team, rolled to a 45-21 victory over the Raiders.

title: Sport Imitates Art
description: When the International Olympic Committee stripped Ben Johnson of his gold medal in the 100-meter dash at the Seoul Olympics because of anabolic steroid use, the controversial body-building drug received front-page attention in newspapers around the world. And that may prove to be good news for Disney Educational Productions.

title: Pretoria Chief, Ending Zaire Visit, Presses Diplomacy in Black Africa
description: South Africa, exploiting the good will generated in the region by its promise to grant independence to Namibia, is intensifying a diplomatic campaign to develop more normal relations with the rest of Africa.

title: TV Notes
description: Out of South Africa

title: Market Place; Software Stocks Under Pressure
description: WITH rapid growth and high profit margins, the stocks of the Big Three personal computer software companies have typically traded at a healthy premium to the market. But delays in core products from the Ashton-Tate Corporation and the Lotus Development Corporation and a drop in fourth-quarter operating margins at the Microsoft Corporation have recently put pressure on these stocks. Analysts say the group should now be approached with caution.

title: Baseball; Lanier Dismissed as Astros' Manager
description: Hal Lanier was dismissed as manager of the Houston Astros today after a disappointing season that ended with the team losing 13 of its final 17 games.

title: Interco Describes Its Plan
description: Interco Inc. yesterday released details of a financial restructuring approved last month to thwart a takeover attempt.

title: Oakland Journal; In a Gym, They're All Contenders
description: Sweat pouring from his brow, John Raymond delivers a series of staccato jabs to the speed bag hanging in King Boxing Gym, on one of this city's meanest streets. Thump-a-ta, thumpa-a-ta, thump-a-ta. ''I come here,'' the lawyer glowers, ''when I'm in the mood.''

title: Police Theorize Sight of Gun Led to Shooting of Officer
description: The shooting by a half-dozen police officers in Queens on Saturday, in which a sergeant and two unarmed kidnapping suspects were wounded, might have started when an officer thought one of the suspects had a gun, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Latin Military Still Seems to Stress The Role of Fighting Communism
description: Even with democracy now in place in most Latin American countries, the region's military forces still appear to view their principal role as that of combating Communism, according to secret resolutions adopted at the most recent Conference of American Armies.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Calendar Shuffle
description: What do the Supreme Court Justices know about the Presidential election that the rest of us don't?

title: Purchasers Find Drop In Growth
description: The nation's economy grew in September at the slowest pace in six months, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in a monthly report that is scheduled to be released today.

title: Hershey Decides to Shift Its Cadbury Accounts
description: The Hershey Chocolate Company, Hershey, Pa., has decided to shift its recently acquired Cadbury U.S.A. business from Wells, Rich, Greene/ New York, to its two agencies of record, DDB Needham/New York and Ogilvy & Mather. The entire budget is estimated at more than $30 million. Sources said DDB Needham's share falls somewhere between $15 million and $20 million, with Ogilvy & Mather's adding up to some $12 million.

title: Washington Talk: Congress; Welfare Overhaul: Right Timing for a War Dance
description: It was the best of bills, it was the worst of bills. It was a bill everybody wanted, it was a bill nobody wanted. It was a bill that evoked boldness, it was a bill that evoked fear.

title: Bipartisan Caucus Calls for a Shift in Favor of Conventional Forces
description: The next President should increase spending for non-nuclear weapons and meet military budget restrictions by canceling new weapons rather than reducing training for conventional forces, a bipartisan group of legislators has recommended.

title: Sir Sacheverell Sitwell Dies at 90, Last of Trio of Literary Eccentrics
description: Sir Sacheverell Sitwell, the poet, art critic and last of the Sitwell trio of literary siblings, died Saturday at his home, Weston Hall, 50 miles north of London, said his son, Francis Sitwell.

title: Toads Invade Florida Complex
description: A black horde of tiny toads invaded a retirement complex Saturday, literally blocking doors. The toads began moving in Friday. ''The whole yard looks like it's moving,'' said Donna Abshier, assistant administrator of the Forest Glen Lodge. ''They just completely cover everything. It's unreal.'' Bob Steiger, agricultural extension agent for Pasco County, said the infant toads were a byproduct of flooding in parts of the area.

title: North Carolina Tops Soccer Mark
description: Wendy Gebauer, Ava Hyatt and Shannon Higgins scored goals as North Carolina's women's soccer team defeated William and Mary, 3-1, Saturday in Williamsburg, Va., and set a National Collegiate Athletic Association record with its 58th consecutive game without a defeat.

title: Museums Feel the Pinch of Tax Law Changes
description: When museum officials get together these days, their talk is as likely to turn to taxes as to art. Phrases like ''unrelated business income,'' ''alternative minimum tax'' and ''disincentives'' roll smoothly off their tongues as they worry over the latest rulings of a Congress and an Internal Revenue Service that many of them perceive as hostile to nonprofit institutions.

title: Fitness; Running a Marathon A Day for the Elderly
description: RUNNING with Sam Freeman is rather ordinary: a gentle five-mile-per-hour pace, slow enough to chat and step easily out of the way of oncoming traffic along the Jefferson Davis Highway here should a driver hug the shoulder of the road too tightly.

title: Abuses Up in Salvador, Rights Group Says
description: A human rights group gave details today of what it called a dramatic increase in political killings and other abuses in El Salvador and accused the United States of ignoring Government violations.

title: Hussein Postpones Elections For a Promised Parliament
description: King Hussein of Jordan postponed parliamentary elections today, three months after dissolving a Parliament in which half the seats were held by representatives of the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

title: Rickel Moves Account To Harvey Herman
description: Rickel Home Improvement Center, South Plainfield, N.J., has moved its business to Harvey Herman Associates from the Venet Companies, Union, N.J. The budget is $4 million.

title: Death Toll in India After Heavy Floods Is Reported at 1,000
description: The death toll from floods that have submerged many areas in India's northwest was nearing 1,000 today, according to reports from the region. Hundreds of thousands of residents in four states have been evacuated to higher ground.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Gracious Response
description: While the tone was decorous at the White House last week, with official statements lauding the 1988 winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, disappointment pervaded 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: Account
description: * Melvin Simon Associates, Indianapolis, a shopping center manager, to Pagano Schenck & Kay, Providence, R.I.

title: El Salvador, U.S.A.
description: Last week, I escorted my little boy to his first day at kindergarden. On the bulletin board was a tree filled with apples, on which were written the names of all the children in the class. Esteban, Mia, Rafael, Melina . . . I began to count, and discovered that almost half of the children in this Washington public school's entering class were Hispanic, and most of those were Salvadoran.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Today, up here where the blue sky turns to black, we can say at long last to Dick, Mike, Judy, to Ron and El, and to Christa and Greg: Dear friends, we have resumed the journey that we promised to continue for you. Dear friends, your loss has meant that we could confidently begin anew. Dear friends, your spirit and your dreams are still alive in our heart.'' - The crew of Discovery. [ A1:6. ]

title: Brodsky and Paz at PEN
description: Joseph Brodsky and Octavio Paz will appear tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. at the CUNY Graduate Center Auditorium, 33 West 42d Street, in an event sponsored by the PEN American Center. Mr. Brodsky and Mr. Paz will engage in a discussion, then Mr. Paz will read a selection of his poems in Spanish and Eliot Weinberger will read the English translations. The event is free and open to the public.

title: Bordin of Italy in Late Surge Gains Gold
description: With about a mile remaining today in the men's marathon, the last of the 237 events in the Seoul Olympics, Gelindo Bordin of Italy felt his strength slipping away. ''I thought it was over,'' he said. Lucky for him, the two runners just ahead were having the same thoughts.

title: U.S. Investor in Congo Defies Trend in Africa
description: Across black Africa, American investment is declining. But at a eucalyptus plantation here, Kim A. Barkan is going against the trend with a fully American-equipped factory due to start production in November.

title: British Growth Is Expected to Slow
description: Britain's economic growth is expected to slow to 2.1 percent in 1989 from 3.6 percent this year, according to a British Treasury survey published Friday.

title: Finding The Sweet Spot In Golf
description: FOR the golfer who has everything and wants more, there's a new gadget, the Check Go, for finding the sweet spot on a golf ball.

title: At Cathedral, a Blessing for Algae
description: After a summer of polluted beaches, soaring temperatures and devastating drought, it was time to get back to basics. And so, at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday, there was a special blessing for the algae.

title: Rate Moves Hinging On Jobless Data
description: With Treasury bond yields around 9 percent, investors and traders have found a balance between the risk of higher interest rates if the economy continues to expand rapidly and the chance of lower interest rates if oil prices fall and put a lid on inflation.

title: IC's Rail Spinoff Ruling
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission ruled that IC Industries' proposed spinoff of its Illinois Central Railroad Company was not within its jurisdiction. A spokesman for IC Industries, a Chicago-based consumer products company, said that the ruling cleared the way for a spinoff of the railroad, but an I.C.C. spokesman declined to confirm or deny that interpretation.

title: Maxwell Gets French Stake
description: Robert Maxwell, the British publisher, said he had bought just under 5 percent of Bouygues, the giant construction group based in France, in a bid to fend off a hostile takeover of the company's privately owned French television channel TF1.

title: It Used to Be Sedition; Now It's on Estonian TV
description: Mart Niklus was not a hard man to spot in the crowd of go-to-meeting suits and studiously civic-minded faces.

title: 20 Are Trapped in a Broken Roller Coaster
description: A roller-coaster ride screeched to a halt in the middle of a loop at a fair here, trapping 20 people upside down 50 feet in the air for more than an hour Saturday.

title: Harvard Research Plan Advances Public Health; Like a Newspaper
description: To the Editor:

title: Pinochet, a 'Very Peculiar Dictator,' Faces Voters
description: After 15 years of authoritarian rule, Gen. Augusto Pinochet is - to all appearances - about to risk his grip on power.

title: Quayle Derided for His Comment on Arms
description: A top aide to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis asserted today that Senator Dan Quayle ''sounds dangerous'' in disagreeing with the Reagan Administration by saying that strategic arms talks with the Soviet Union should be linked to Soviet concessions on non-nuclear arms.

title: Mets Finish Up With a Flourish
description: The Mets rang down the curtain with flourishes and home runs yesterday when they completed a three-game sweep of the St. Louis Cardinals and headed for Los Angeles with 100 victories, a record attendance and a shot at their second National League pennant in three years.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 3, 1988: MONDAY Carolina Freight Nevada Pwr Central Vt Public Service Oxford Indus TUESDAY Blessings Corp Southwest Gas Corp Pacific Enterprises WEDNESDAY General Dynamics Murphy Oil Corp Houston Industries Southwestern Energy THURSDAY Amax Inc Rite Aid Corp Birmingham Steel Corp Sierra Pacific Resources General Public Utils Sun Co Orange & Rockland Utils Zayre Corp Puget Sound Pwr & Lt FRIDAY Hannaford Bros U S West Inc Travelers Corp

title: Hollywood Entices the Japanese
description: Flush with cash and eager to learn about the entertainment industry, the Japanese are starting to invest in Hollywood.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Renaissance Women
description: Among the many women's groups with headquarters in the capital is one called Renaissance Women, with 3,000 members across the country and overseas.

title: L.I. Village Cuts Frills In Schools
description: For public-school children in this Nassau County village, there are no buses this year. There are no new library books. There are only a few after-school sports, and students have to pay to play for a team. In short, there are no frills.

title: K.G.B.'s New Chief: 'Spymaster' Up From Ranks
description: When the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, came to Washington last December for the summit meeting with President Reagan, American experts were startled that his traveling party included Vladimir Aleksandrovich Kryuchkov, a K.G.B. official who directs overseas spying.

title: U.S. Car Gain In Japan Seen
description: The head of the Japanese Automobile Importers Association said Friday that the group expected sales of American cars in Japan to increase greatly in the next five years. but he warned that the cars still faced important market obstacles.

title: Taylor Helps Giants Hold Off Redskins
description: During the last few days, several people have wondered whether the impact of Lawrence Taylor's return was being exaggerated. They wondered whether one player could make that great a difference in a sport where the whole was supposedly greater than the individual parts.

title: Botha Promises to Press Initiative For Southern Africa Cooperation
description: President P. W. Botha tonight pledged South Africa's active support for an initiative to bring together the leaders of southern Africa's black-ruled countries.

title: Fashion; Patterns
description: So many men's fragrances have been introduced this year that it can't be just a coincidence. There is something in the air, and it isn't just after-shave.

title: Japanese Re-Think Their Hirohito Obsession
description: In the midst of a national vigil for their ailing Emperor, Japanese are beginning to ask themselves just how much his illness should shadow their lives.

title: N.F.L. Notebook; McMahon Puts Bite in Bears
description: David Tate had just leaped, landed and twisted his way through the Buffalo Bills' offensive team with his first interception as a Chicago Bear. The Bears were already belting the Bills, 17-3, and now a few minutes before the half, thanks to Tate, the exuberant rookie free safety from Colorado, Chicago had the ball at its 42-yard line.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Plan Helps Risky Film To Succeed
description: OVER the weekend, Thomas Pollock, chairman of the MCA Motion Picture Group, received some good news. The new release of MCA's Universal Pictures studio, ''Gorillas in the Mist,'' which was in its second week, was doing very well.

title: Sensormatic Electronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Careers; Refreshing Literature For M.B.A.'s
description: HUMANITIES courses have not played a large role until recently in master of business administration programs.

title: Gorbachev Changes Leaders in Russian Republic
description: The leadership of the Russian Republic, the largest of the 15 principal components of the Soviet Union, was shuffled today at the direction of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: Soft Defense Worries Parcells
description: In the wake of an inspirational victory over the Washington Redskins on Sunday, the Giants find themselves with a 3-2 record and a 3-0 mark in the Eastern Division of the National Conference.

title: Review/Art; Medieval Illuminated Manuscripts In Exhibition at Getty Museum
description: It would still be a little while before Gutenberg's printing press stole literary primacy from illuminated manuscripts, but during the 15th and 16th centuries in cities like Ghent and Bruges, artists of the first rank continued to lavish attention on hand-bound books. Under commission from such culturally enlightened nobles as the Burgundian duke Philip the Good, his son Charles the Bold and Emperor Rudolf II of Vienna, a school of Flemish illumination flourished. Its considerable accomplishments can be seen in a handsome exhibition at the J. Paul Getty Museum here through Oct. 16.

title: City of Tokyo Sets U.S. Offer
description: The City of Tokyo is offering in the United States debt market $175 million of 9 1/4 percent guaranteed bonds due in 1998 at a price of 99 7/8 to yield 9.269 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Sonic Boom Above, Crowd's Roar Below
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 3 - Dazzled by shock waves that sent ripples across the clouds, about 430,000 people whooped, whistled and wept today as they welcomed the space shuttle Discovery on a dry lakebed here in the California desert.

title: Rosenblatt Considers Leaving Judicial Post
description: Amid widespread speculation that he was being forced out of office, New York State's Chief Administrative Judge, Albert M. Rosenblatt, said yesterday that he was considering leaving his post.

title: DISCOVERY LANDS SMOOTHLY AFTER TRIAL MISSION IN SPACE HAILED AS 'STUNNING SUCCESS'
description: The space shuttle Discovery returned to earth today, swooping out of the blue sky, safe and triumphant, to conclude a four-day mission that seemed to go a long way toward restoring confidence in the reliability of the winged, reusable vehicles and reviving the nation's space program.

title: From Goldwater, Without Soft Soap, to . . .
description: Barry Goldwater seldom minced words in more than 30 years in Washington, and he is no more circumspect in retirement.

title: Review/Opera; 'Ballad of Baby Doe' Returns, With Faith Esham
description: ''The Ballad of Baby Doe'' more than holds its own in the tiny repertory of repeatable American operas, and the latest revival by the New York City Opera on Sunday evening gave ample demonstration of the reasons why. They begin with sturdy operatic dramaturgy. The tale is told in short, pointed scenes; everything is as simple and direct as it is in, say, ''Pagliacci,'' and the characters are archetypes: the powerful self-made man, his unsympathetic wife, the sweet young thing who takes her place.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Agent Acquisition Co., Washington, said it had acquired Atlas Van Lines Inc. of Evansville, Ind. from Wesray Capital Corp. for about $124 million.

title: Sands Regent reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Talk With Piniella Put Off by Yankees
description: Lou Piniella, who expected to learn of his dismissal or his rehiring as Yankee manager today in Florida, instead was told by a club official yesterday that the meeting had been postponed indefinitely by George Steinbrenner, the team's principal owner.

title: Kiley Stresses Chance To Push Transit Goals
description: With the end of the United States Government's 30-year Interstate highway construction program looming in 1991 and the growing problems of traffic congestion and air quality in cities around the country, advocates for mass transit have been presented with a ''convergence'' of opportunities to influence new national transportation policy into the next century, the head of the nation's largest transit system said today.

title: School Bombing 30 Years Ago Helped Town Heal Wounds
description: Thirty years ago, Pat Johnson recalls, the windows rattled, rousing her from sleep. When she and her family ventured out into the cool fog they saw a fire a mile away downtown.

title: Bush Welcomes Shuttle's Crew, As an Official
description: When the five astronauts dropped to Earth today, Vice President Bush was waiting for them at the bottom of the shuttle ramp.

title: Hammer View On China Deal
description: The American industrialist Armand Hammer said this weekend that he remained optimistic about a giant coal project in Shanxi Province in northern China, despite technical problems that have slashed output and set off a dispute with the Chinese Government.

title: A Playoff Veteran Goes Round Again
description: He calls it a new season, not simply the resumption of the long and winding campaign that finally finished last Sunday. Don Baylor does not allow himself to connect the regular season to the playoffs, and then to the World Series, perhaps because he knows that his body - closing in on its fourth decade and struck by more than 250 errant pitches in 17 seasons - could not tolerate the notion of playing from April to October without a small respite.

title: Quadlogic Controls Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Barry Blau & Partners Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue represent fees and production revenue. Corrected from Thursday's, Sept. 29, editions.

title: Shareholders Vote Nov. 4 On Shoreham
description: The fight over Governor Cuomo's plan to abandon the Shoreham nuclear power plant moved a step closer to conclusion today as Shoreham's owner, the Long Island Lighting Company, scheduled a shareholder vote on the plan for Nov. 4.

title: Supreme Court Refuses Role In New Haven Mall Dispute
description: The city of New Haven lost another round today in the continuing dispute over the proposed construction of a controversial shopping mall when the Supreme Court refused to become involved in the matter.

title: Congressman Asks For an Indictment To Defend Himself
description: A Georgia Congressman demanded on the House floor today that he be indicted immediately so he could answer allegations of his possible connection with a money-laundering scheme.

title: N.A.S.D. Agrees on Circuit Breakers
description: In a move that clears the way for the adoption of coordinated halts in trading when markets are volatile, the National Association of Securities Dealers said yesterday that it would agree to cooperate with a plan proposed by the New York Stock Exchange and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: Mayor of Yonkers Attacks Council for Resistance
description: Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko today asked the Federal judge in the Yonkers housing-desegregation case to remove the City Council from the process of selecting sites for low-income housing.

title: Ransburg Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $3,250,000 (a reserve for losses on disposals), for both periods. c-Net loss d-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $15,703,000 (which included a reserve for loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $13,750,000) and $21,109,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; the quarter also included an extraordinary charge of $160,000; the 9 months also included an extraordinary credit of $109,000. The latest quarter's net from continuing operations included an $800,000 reserve related to the costs of an operation's disposal.

title: Sports People; Winning Gamble
description: Byron Scott took a gamble last year and it paid off. The 27-year-old guard signed a five-year contract with the Los Angeles Lakers yesterday that is believed to be worth more than $5 million. Before last season, Scott signed a one-year contract, hoping his bargaining power would be increased this year. The five-year veteran responded with the best season of his career, leading the National Basketball Association champions in scoring with a 21.7-point average.(AP)

title: TDA Industries Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After losses on disposal from discontinued operations of $8,000 for the latest year and $136,006 for 1987.

title: Fashion: By Design; The Button as Focal Point
description: A button's function is to fasten things. This season, however, buttons are the stuff of fashionable decoration as well.

title: Perot Sues G.M. Subsidiary
description: Ross Perot, the Dallas computer entrepreneur, has charged his former company, Electronic Data Systems, and its parent, the General Motors Corporation, with unlawful efforts to drive his new company out of business.

title: Chicago Faces a Glut Of High-Priced Hotels
description: Chicago, famous for its bracing winds off Lake Michigan and stylish high-rise office buildings, will soon learn whether it has what it takes to support a horde of $200-a-night hotels.

title: GULF PEACE TALKS ADVANCING SLOWLY
description: The Foreign Ministers of Iran and Iraq are making slow progress in talks here on a permanent peace settlement, diplomats and United Nations officials said today.

title: Stake in USG Cut
description: Desert Partners L.P., the Midland, Tex., investment partnership, has lowered its stake in the USG Corporation to 5.7 percent, from 9.4 percent, it said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Desert Partners, which earlier this year made a bid for control of the wallboard manufacturer based in Chicago, sold two million common shares on Friday for $7.50 each. The group now owns 3.1 million shares of USG.

title: Kean Order Halts New Construction on Jersey Coast
description: Governor Kean moved today to control development along New Jersey's coastline by requiring all new construction, even of a single-family house, to be approved by the State Department of Environmental Protection.

title: BEIRUT KIDNAPPERS RELEASE A HOSTAGE AFTER 20 MONTHS
description: Kidnappers in Lebanon today released an Indian citizen after more than 20 months of captivity.

title: New Goal: 3d World Debt Reduction
description: A consensus has developed among many countries that ways should be sought to reduce, and not simply restructure, the third world's staggering $1.2 trillion debt.

title: All-State Properties Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
A Giant Glass Weed Has Sprung Up in Queens
description: To the Editor:

title: Los Angeles Journal; Hope Wins When the Homeless Run
description: Ernie Garcia was hot, sweaty and tired after a five-kilometer training run on Saturday. But his grin seemed wider than the running track and his happiness had little to do with the fact that he had finished the tree-lined course far ahead of his friends.

title: Don't Let Union Sq. Fall Back Into Neglect
description: To the Editor:

title: Literacy Project in Kentucky Wins $100,000 Prize
description: To hear Sharon Darling and Jeanne Heberle tell it, their $100,000 prize-winning literacy project was born on the highway between Louisville and Frankfort, Ky.

title: Farm Workers Fault Lack of Enforcement Of Sanitation Rules
description: Federal rules issued a year ago requiring minimal amenities for farm workers, including toilets and fresh drinking water, are being widely and flagrantly ignored, legal groups representing the workers say.

title: FPA Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $4,020,000 and $5,526,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a gain of $5,700,000 from an accounting change. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $447,000 for the quarter and $1,432,000 for the year.

title: Paradyne Expects To Report a Loss
description: The Paradyne Corporation, which makes data communications equipment, said it would lose money in the current quarter because it was taking $32 million in special charges, mostly for restructuring its product line. Paradyne said it was withdrawing from producing some switching systems, some messenger display terminals and certain peripheral products, effective Nov. 1.

title:
Market Place;
Analysts Wary On Big Oil Stocks
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the price of crude oil has been dropping lately, the major oil stocks are holding up surprisingly well.

title: Bolstering an Alliance
description: One of the rituals of the Atlantic alliance is the official expression of gratitude to the United States for holding a protective military arm over Western Europe for four decades at the expense of European taxpayers.

title: 'Not Yet Time' to Free Americans
description: In the hours before the release of an Indian hostage here today, the man believed to be the mentor of the shadowy pro-Iranian group known as the Party of God said it was ''not yet the right time for the American hostages to be freed.''

title: Executives Are Shifted at Book-of-the-Month Club
description: Lawrence M. Crutcher, the president of Book-of-the-Month Club and a vice president of its corporate parent, Time Inc., will became chairman of the club at the end of the year. He will succeed Al Silverman, who has headed the club since 1984.

title: Stocks Fall Broadly as Dow Declines 7.65
description: Stock prices fell broadly but moderately yesterday, extending Friday's drop as trading volume declined.

title: Tyson in Domestic Dispute
description: Mike Tyson's troubles continue.

title: Court to Weigh Validity Of State Antitrust Laws
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether states can offer greater protection than Federal antitrust law provides to purchasers who may have been indirectly injured as the result of a price-fixing conspiracy among manufacturers.

title: RULING ON SEX BIAS CURBS EMPLOYERS
description: Employers may not dismiss women or refuse to hire them because of suspicions that their exposure to chemicals or radiation on the job may some day cause reproductive or fetal damage, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14, D29 A hostage in Lebanon was released after more than 20 months of captivity, the State Department confirmed. The hostage is Mithileshwar Singh, a citizen of India and a resident of the United States. Page A1

title: Grand Met Bids to Buy Pillsbury
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the large British conglomerate, has offered to buy the Pillsbury Company for $60 a share in cash, or a total of $5.12 billion.

title: Government Agrees to Relaxation Of Auto Mileage Standard for '89
description: Acceding to requests by the two largest American auto makers, the Department of Transportation announced today that it would lower the fuel economy requirement for 1989 cars from 27.5 miles a gallon to 26.5 miles a gallon.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Jewish holiday of Simhath Torah, which concludes the harvest festival of Succoth, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: About New York; From a Business Of Numbers, A Gift of Words
description: The title of the piece has the ring of a high-school writing class, one of those hardy theme topics that gently float you back to the blackboard afternoons of early fall, to the composition teacher who thought ''My Summer Vacation'' was the very crucible of inspiration.

title: National League Pennant Playoff
description: Can the Dodgers do what they have not been able to do all season: score against Mets' pitchers? All about who the players are, what their numbers are and what might happen. Articles begin on page B9. >

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Tuesday about contributions to the Republican Party misstated the source of a $120,000 donation. It was Trammell Crow, the Dallas real-estate developer, not the Trammell Crow Company.

title: Conversion Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: N.H.L. Preview; Devils Have No Time to Rest on Laurels
description: The Devils transformed their image from that of losers to winners last season by making the playoffs for the first time and falling only a game short of reaching the Stanley Cup finals.

title: New Drug Law: The Senate's Duty; The House Offers Only Empty Promises
description: Two summers ago, America discovered crack and overdosed on oratory. The result, that election year, was a hasty bill that promised new initiatives and new billions for the war on drugs. They were empty promises. By early 1987, Reagan budgeteers were cutting back on the billions; many of the initiatives died for lack of follow-through.

title: SMUGGLER AGREES TO RUN AIDS HOME
description: A Federal district judge with a tough reputation has tentatively agreed to let a man who helped import 11 tons of marijuana run a hospice for AIDS patients instead of serving a maximum 15-year prison sentence.

title: Saudis Agree to Observe Pact On Spread of Nuclear Arms
description: The Saudi Foreign Minister declared today that his country would adhere to the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.

title: Banks Catch Mets Fever
description: On the eve of the National League playoffs, Mets fever has spread to the financial industry. Yesterday the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation announced a Mets-linked Mastercard. Besides getting a credit card that sports the Mets' logotype, card holders will be eligible for sweepstakes prizes that include a trip to the Mets' spring training and the use of a Shea Stadium box. National Westminster Bank

title: Grace K. Baruch, Researcher and Author, 52
description: Dr. Grace K. Baruch, associate director of the Wellesley Center for Research on Women, died yesterday of cancer at her home in Newton Center, Mass. She was 52 years old.

title: Raiders Suffer Serious Injuries
description: The running back Marcus Allen and the tight end Todd Christensen of the Los Angeles Raiders suffered serious injuries in the game against Cincinnati on Sunday.

title: Sports People; Leyva Elevated
description: As expected, Nick Leyva, a St. Louis Cardinal coach for the last five seasons, was named yesterday as manager of the Philadelphia Phillies. Leyva replaces Lee Elia, who was dismissed Sept. 23.

title: Scientists Give Wishbone New Twist
description: EVERYONE knows the purpose of a bird's wishbone -two people pull it apart while each makes a wish; the one who ends up with the larger piece will see the wish come true. But scientists have long wondered what the wishbone's role was in birds.

title: 15-Year-Old Boy Is Indicted As Adult in Synagogue Fire
description: A 15-year-old boy who was arrested in the arson of a Brooklyn synagogue in which five Torah scrolls were destroyed has been indicted by a grand jury and will be tried as an adult in State Supreme Court, instead of Family Court where the possible punishment is less severe.

title: Computer Line Grows
description: In a significant expansion of its product line, Silicon Graphics Inc. will introduce new computers Tuesday that will bring new machines to both ends of Silicon Graphics' current product line, which dominates the market for work stations offering interactive three-dimensional graphics.

title: Illinois Man Arrested Twice In a Mistaken Identity Case
description: A school bus driver who was mistakenly jailed twice and accused of being a Navy deserter may be at the end of his military troubles, after the authorities caught the man they believe used his identity to enlist and then disappear.

title: Commtron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Seoul Leader Says He Is Willing to Visit the North
description: In another effort to defuse tensions with North Korea, President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea said today that he would be willing to travel to North Korea to meet with Kim Il Sung, the North Korean leader.

title: Lincoln Center and Actors Reach Pact
description: Lincoln Center Theater and Actors' Equity Association reached tentative agreement yesterday on a contract for Lincoln Center's staging of its season at the Lyceum Theater.

title: Drug Emporium Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
DNA Pioneer to Tackle Biggest Gene Project Ever
description: DR. James D. Watson, who is about to assume a key role in the largest biological research project ever contemplated, sees that effort as the redemption of a longstanding bargain between scientists and other citizens.

title: Compuflight Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Business and Health; New Drugs Stress The Cost Savings
description: THE Ciba Pharmaceutical Company is expected to introduce a drug today that could eliminate the need for gall-bladder surgery in more than 300,000 Americans each year. Besides arming themselves with data about the drug's medical effectiveness, many of the company's salespeople will also carry a computer program to help medical-care providers calculate how many dollars they can save by using the new drug instead of the surgery.

title: Mormon Sees Growth of Evil
description: The president of the Mormon Church, Ezra Taft Benson, said Sunday that he believes evil forces are growing in influence worldwide, but that the forces of good ultimately will prevail. In remarks at the concluding session of the 158th semiannual general conference of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, Mr. Benson said that ''not many years hence'' Jesus will return to vanquish all evil.

title: Energy Dept. Says It Kept Mishaps at Nuclear Weapon Plant Secret
description: The Department of Energy said today that it was responsible, along with its predecessor, the Atomic Energy Commission, for keeping secret from the public a number of serious reactor accidents that occurred over a 28-year period at the Savannah River Plant in South Carolina.

title: Let a Hundred Sports Bloom
description: South Korea deserves Olympian honors for staging a glorious global spectacular - the first trouble-free summer Olympics since 1964. More athletes from more countries competed in more events than ever before. But these superlatives raise yet another question: Is the Olympics getting to be too much of a good thing? Too many events, not enough focus?

title: Chess
description: Stuart Rachels, an 18-year-old national master from Birmingham, Ala., has won the 1988 United States Junior Invitational Championship, held at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst from July 26 to Aug. 4.

title: David E. Satterfield 3d, Former House Member, 67
description: David E. Satterfield 3d, a conservative Democrat who represented Virginia's Third District in the House of Representatives, died of congestive heart failure Friday at the College of Virginia Hospitals in Richmond.

title: Ramon Durano Dies; Marcos Backer Was 82
description: Ramon Durano, a former congressman, business leader and one of the country's most colorful politicians, died today of cancer, his family said. He was 82 years old. Mr. Durano virtually owned Danao, a city of 60,000 people north of Cebu. Many Danao residents were born in Mr. Durano's hospital, worked in his factories, retired to his home for the elderly, and were buried in his cemetery.

title: Tec Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
A Lack of Appeal
description: Officials of the Justice Department officials say it might not appeal a judge's finding that one of its agencies, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, discriminates against Hispanic employees.

title: Bush on Trial, Too
description: When the two Vice-Presidential candidates take on each other in televised debate tomorrow, George Bush will be as much on trial as either of them.

title: Dukakis Says Standard of Living Is Deteriorating
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, embarking today on what aides called a pivotal phase of his effort to overtake Vice President Bush, mixed an appeal to black voters with a warning that American children are in danger of being ''unable to enjoy the same standard of living as their parents.''

title: Review/Television; The Day The Earth Moved
description: As a source of relatively cheap programming, the independent documentary is becoming ever more prominent on the schedule of the financially strapped public-television system. The range is considerable, with programs going from sometimes politically ''sensitive'' subjects on ''Nonfiction Television'' to the contemporary arts on ''Alive From Off Center.'' Tonight at 10 o'clock on Channel 13, there is the debut of still another umbrella series, encompassing a variety of documentaries within the confines of a sketchy theme.

title: Comet Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the figures include the results of operations of Video Library Inc., and Video Excitement of America Inc. from Jan. 1 and full-year results for Comet Enterprises.

title: Chile Waits, In Silence, For a Verdict
description: THERE'S a kind of un-election campaign going on in Chile that may become the textbook case of how to get a dictator to go quietly.

title: A Composer's Son Remembers Life With Father, Through Fiction
description: In ''Waiting Weeping,'' the wrenching final story of Jonathan Schwartz's new book, ''The Man Who Knew Cary Grant,'' Norman Savitt, an ailing songwriter, and his journalist son, Jesse, attend the father's 84th birthday party at Sardi's. For an exhilarating moment, Norman Savitt seems to shed 30 years as he performs many of the pop standards he has written, accompanying himself on an upright piano and singing in a voice reminiscent of Fred Astaire's.

title: Estonia Ferment: Soviet Role Model or Exception?
description: With the christening on Sunday of an independent movement for political and economic autonomy, the republic of Estonia became the mecca for aspiring democrats throughout the Soviet Union. From the neighboring Baltic republics of Latvia and Lithuania, from the more distant republics of Armenia, Byelorussia, the Ukraine, Moldavia and Kazakhstan, from the Russian cities of Moscow, Leningrad and Kuibyshev, leaders of like-minded movements sat here in the Lenin Palace of Culture and applauded as 3,000 delegates of the Popular Front of Estonia formally launched their campaign.

title: How Mets and Dodgers Stack Up
description: Mets Catchers (Average, home runs, runs batted in) 8 Gary Carter (.242, 11, 46) The Kid, at 34, endured some dry spells in his 14th season, even after punishing himself into hard shape last winter. He even went three months and 225 times at bat before he hit the 300th home run of his career. 2 Mackey Sasser (.285, 1, 17) Left-handed hitter who arrived in spring training in trade from Pittsburgh, and made impression with hard-nosed style. Good contact hitter, line-drive type, but scatters his throws. 33 Barry Lyons (.231, 0, 11) Reserve catcher for last two seasons, and dependable. Right-handed hitter with some power. Infielders (Pos., avg., h.r., r.b.i.) 17 Keith Hernandez (1b, .276, 11, 55) Now 34 and still playing it safe with right hamstring muscle, which was torn four months ago, so he has lost a step. But he is still leader of the team. Hit .341 against Dodgers. 6 Wally Backman(2b, .303, 0, 17) Lost job as left-handed half of platoon at second base because he lost 70 points in batting average last year. Started hitting in May and won his job back in August. 9 Gregg Jefferies (3b, .321, 6, 17) Arrived from minor leagues late in August, and blazed through one month with .323 average and six home runs. Will play second or third, and others will be shifted to make room. 20 Howard Johnson (3b/ss, .230, 24, 68) Hit .371 against Dodgers and will move to shortstop when Mets want big bats in lineup. 21 Kevin Elster (ss, .214, 9, 37) Rookie shortstop with fine glove and style on defense, and good double-play man, but he may be replaced for offense. Outfielders (Pos., avg., h.r., r.b.i.) 22 Kevin McReynolds (lf, .288, 27, 99) Steadiest Met. Hit around .290 all season, second to Strawberry in home runs, led league with 18 assists from outfield, stole 21 bases in 21 attempts. 1 Mookie Wilson (cf, .296, 8, 41) Sulked as No. 2 to Lenny Dykstra and asked to be traded. Then got shot at playing in August when Dykstra slumped, and got hot. 4 Lenny Dykstra (cf, .270, 8, 33) Seemed solid in center, but yielded job six weeks ago. Against Dodgers, batted only .143 this season. 18 Darryl Strawberry (rf, .269, 39, 101) The big man who carried the offense for first couple of months, then lost consistency in midsummer, but turned on power and speed in September. Starting Pitchers (Record, e.r.a.) 16 Dwight Gooden (18-9, 3.19) Complained of shoulder pain in August, and lost three of final four, but heads into playoff with strength and numbers. Likes to pitch in Dodger Stadium, and thrives against the Dodgers. 44 David Cone (20-3, 2.22) Came out of bullpen when Rick Aguilera hurt elbow in early May, and blazed way to sixth best winning percentage in baseball history for 20-game winners. Won last eight; hasn't lost since Aug. 17. 12 Ron Darling (17-9, 3.25) Completed seven games, pitched four shutouts, seemed less cerebral and more physical in approach. 50 Sid Fernandez (12-10, 3.03) Often brilliant with low hits and high strikeouts, right knee buckled twice in second half under the stress of 230 pounds. Relievers (Record, e.r.a., saves) 48 Randy Myers (7-3, 1.72, 26) New left-handed tiger of bullpen who replaced Jesse Orosco. Had a hand in 32 victories, striking out one per inning. 42 Roger McDowell (5-5, 2.63, 16) His sinkerball stopped sinking for spells this season. He was recently smacked for 23 hits in 11 innings. For groundouts, he's still the man. 15 Rick Aguilera (0-4, 6.93, 0) One of the front five in rotation until he suffered inflamed elbow and later underwent arthroscopic surgery. Pitched only 23 innings. 26 Terry Leach (7-2, 2.54, 3) When Mets needed a sound arm last year, he won 10 games in a row. When they needed long or short relief this year, he won seven more. Unflappable right-hander with underhand delivery. 27 Bob McClure (2-3, 5.40, 3) Left-hander with World Series experience with Milwaukee. Reserves (Pos., avg., h.r., r.b.i.) 11 Tim Teufel (2b, .234, 4, 31) Stopped hitting and opened door for Backman's return in August. Right-handed hitter, likely to start against most left-handers. 29 Dave Magadan (1b, .277, 1, 35) Hit .300 in every minor league and in National League until he wilted under strain of not playing this year. Left-handed line-drive hitter who has problems on defense. 13 Lee Mazzilli (1b/of, .147, 0, 12) Veteran switch-hitter subsided as role player this year, with only 114 times at bat and 17 hits. Manager 5 Davey Johnson At 45, he's had five consecutive winning seasons and a winning percentage of .600, finishing in second place three times and in first place twice. Still commanding figure among players, favors offensive lineup with hit-and-run attack and speed on bases, and loves the long ball. Looks for tactical edge with right-left switches and bold decisions. Dodgers Catchers (Average, home runs, runs batted in) 14 Mike Scioscia (.257, 3, 35) Solid No. 1 catcher who may be the best in guarding home plate against runners great and small. Left-handed hitter who may give way to Rick Dempsey against left-handers. 56 Rick Dempsey (.251, 7, 30) Tough 39-year-old veteran of Yankees and Baltimore Orioles. For last six weeks, Tommy Lasorda has been platooning them. Hit .273 against Mets. Infielders (Position, avg., h.r., r.b.i.) 22 Franklin Stubbs (1b,.223,8,34) Left-handed hitter platoons with Tracy Woodson. Hit seven home runs, all against right-handed pitchers. 3 Steve Sax (2b, .277, 5, 57) Doesn't turn the double play, but he can hit and run. Stole 42 bases, by far the most on the team, and he's the main threat to Mets' poor defense against base-stealers. 33 Jeff Hamilton (3b, .236, 6, 33) Spent six weeks on disabled list after he ran into tarpaulin in San Francisco and pulled rib ligaments in upper chest. Returned Sept. 5 and hit .300 down homestretch. 7 Alfredo Griffin (ss, .199, 1, 27) Hit only .167 against Mets, who put him out of action May 21 when Gooden fastball broke finger. 21 Tracy Woodson (1b, .249, 3, 15) Can play third, but Hamilton has pre-empted move there. May start against left-handers. Outfielders (Pos., avg., h.r., r.b.i.) 23 Kirk Gibson (lf, .290, 25, 76) Signed as free agent from Detroit last winter, and he's the key to Dodgers' offensive success. Mets struck him out 19 times in 36 times at bat. Has sore hamstring. 31 John Shelby (cf, .263, 10, 64) Switch-hitter who batted .300 against Mets. Hits in No. 5 spot behind Gibson and Mike Marshall, but has struck out 124 times, the most on the team. 5 Mike Marshall (rf, .277, 20, 82) The cleanup man, right-handed hitter with power and leads club in knocking in runs. Hit .192 against Mets. Starting Pitchers (Record, e.r.a.) 55 Orel Hershiser (23-8, 2.26) The main man, right-hander with snapping stuff, 23-game winner who ended season in record blaze of 59 straight shutout innings over his last six games. 30 John Tudor (10-8, 2.32) Traded to the Dodgers this summer for Pedro Guerrero, and replaced Fernando Valenzuela as chief left-hander. 54 Tim Leary (17-11, 2.91) Onetime star prospect of the Mets who injured his right shoulder in first start in 1981. Seems flat lately. 49 Tim Belcher (12-6, 2.91) Has found steady work with Dodgers and will probably start fourth game. Spent time in bullpen and thrived. Relievers (Record, e.r.a., saves) 50 Jay Howell (5-3, 2.08, 21) Has surpassed Orosco as stopper of bullpen. Right-hander hasn't allowed a run in last 18 games. 26 Alejandro Pe na (6-7, 1.91, 12) Missed all of 1985 and part of 1986 after shoulder surgery, but has made effective comeback as middle relief man. Used 58 times this year. 47 Jesse Orosco (3-2, 2.72, 9) Former stopper for Mets and winning pitcher in three of their four victories in 1986 playoff. Switched to set-up duty for Jay Howell this year. 51 Brian Holton (7-3, 1.70) Effective right-hander who pitched 58 times for Dodgers last year and 44 times this year and gave up less than two runs every nine innings. 29 Ricky Horton (1-1, 5.00) Left-handed relief pitcher who used to trouble the Mets when he was with the St. Louis Cardinals. But he hasn't troubled anybody since the Dodgers acquired him in a trade late in August. Reserves (Pos., avg., h.r., r.b.i.) 9 Mickey Hatcher (1b, .293, 1, 25) He and Danny Heep are the main pinch-hitters, and Hatcher is by far the more accomplished: 11 for 36 this year with eight runs batted in as pinch-hitter. 12 Danny Heep (of, .242, 0, 11) Another former Met, left-handed batter who got only four hits in 43 times up this year. 37 Mike Davis (of, .196, 2, 17) Signed as free agent from Oakland, where he hit 22 home runs. 27 Mike Sharperson (inf, .271, 0, 4) Plays anywhere in the infield. Turns faster double play than Sax at second. 36 Jose Gonzalez (.083, 0, 0) Added to playoff team yesterday when Fernando Valenzuela was droppped. He is a good defensive outfielder and an exceptionally speedy runner, but he got into only 37 games and the Mets will see him mainly as a pinch-runner. Manager 2 Tommy Lasorda The family extrovert and gourmet, completing his 39th year in Dodger system and 12th as manager. Led Dodgers to dramatic turnaround after finishing fourth last year, 16 games below .500. Still the evangelist, headed for sixth playoff and possibly fourth World Series.

title: Baby's Sex and Divorce
description: Couples who have sons are more likely to stay married than couples who have daughters, according to a study by sociologists at the University of Pennsylvania. While, in general, couples who have children are less likely to divorce than are those who do not, having a son reduces the risk of divorce, on average, 9 percent more than does having a daughter.

title: Books of The Times; Barbara Tuchman's Telling of a Nation's Birth
description: The First Salute By Barbara W. Tuchman 347 pages. Illustrated. Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day yesterday listing current interest rates misstated the prime rate and the discount rate. The prime rate, which banks charge on loans to large corporations, is 10 percent. The discount rate, which the Federal Reserve charges on loans to depository institutions, is 6 1/2 percent.

title: J. Ralph Corbett, Manufacturer, 91
description: J. Ralph Corbett, founder the NuTone Company, a maker of home door chimes, died today at a retirement community. He was 91 years old.

title: Grist Mill Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Sikes Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Scherer Studies Its Options
description: The R. P. Scherer Corporation will consider selling the company, a course of action that had been advocated by dissident shareholders during a bitter dispute with management. In a statement issued late

title: Campaign Trail; Stand-in for Quayle Discusses His Role
description: The phone rings. ''This is Dennis Eckart, also known as Dan Quayle,'' Dennis Eckart tells a reporter, chortling.

title: Audiovox Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Koch Proposes More Civilians At Police Dept.
description: Mayor Koch, forced to cut city services to finance his planned anti-drug drive, proposed yesterday to make the trims less severe by hiring 618 civilians for the Police Department, instead of uniformed officers, an action that would have cost several million dollars more.

title: Charles R. Jonas, Former House Member, 83
description: Charles Raper Jonas, a North Carolina Republican who served in the House of Representatives from 1952 to 1972, died of congestive heart failure Friday at his home in Lincolnton, Md. He was 83 years old. Mr. Jonas, a member of the House Appropriations Committee, was active in efforts to curb growth in government and to achieve a balanced Federal budget. He was a graduate of the University of North Carolina, where he also earned a law degree.

title: Film Festival; '36 Fillette,' a Story Of Hunger for Wisdom
description: Films about the sexual initiation of adolescent girls have a way of becoming almost as coy as their heroines. Certainly that's the case with Catherine Breillat's ''36 Fillette,'' a film that devotes inordinate attention to stop-and-go sexual maneuvers and slow, heavy breathing. These and other related details are sure to make ''36 Fillette'' popular with art lovers of a certain stripe.

title: Paine Webber Sees Gain On Sale of Car-Rental Unit
description: The Paine Webber Group Inc. said yesterday that it expects to report a third-quarter pretax gain of $46 million, reflecting the sale of its stake in National Car Rental System Inc. to the Fidelco Capital Group of Millburn, N.J.

title: Kinnock Thwarts New Effort By British Labor Party's Left
description: The leader of Britain's opposition Labor Party, Neil Kinnock, who earlier crushed a left-wing attempt to unseat him, today defeated an attempt to block a policy review that opens the way to more cooperation with private enterprise. Mr. Kinnock began the party's annual conference here Sunday night by putting down a challenge for the leadership by the longtime hero of the Labor left, Tony Benn.

title: Soviet Troops Filling In For Armenian Strikers
description: Uniformed troops of the Soviet Interior Ministry have begun to substitute for the striking civilian workforce of a disputed southern territory that has been the focus of more than seven months of volatile confrontations, the press agency Tass reported tonight.

title: Texas Air Accord Seen With S.A.S.
description: Scandinavian Airlines System and the Texas Air Corporation are expected to announce an agreement to coordinate their schedules in order to offer customers the shortest times between their major destinations, sources close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Candidates and Media At Odds Over Message
description: While the attention of most Americans was focused Thursday on the space shuttle Discovery's climb into orbit, two other infrequent events went almost unnoticed: Both Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis held news conferences.

title: F.T.C. to Oppose McKesson's Bid
description: The McKesson Corporation, the nation's largest wholesaler of drugs and toiletries, said the Federal Trade Commission would seek a court order blocking McKesson from buying the Alco Health Services Corporation, another large drug wholesaler. The F.T.C. also voted to try to stop McKesson's acquisition of the Northwestern Drug Company, based in Auburn, Wash. The commission said later in a statement that each of the proposed acquisitions could substantially reduce competition in wholesale prescription drug distribution.

title: Oil Prices Continue to Fall Amid the Discord in OPEC
description: Oil prices continued their precipitous decline yesterday, with prices of some key Middle East crudes falling below $10 a barrel.

title: Shoreham Plan Advances
description: The fight over Governor Cuomo's plan to abandon the Shoreham nuclear plant moved a step closer to conclusion yesterday. Page B1.

title: We Can Have an Ethics Bill and the Constitution
description: To the Editor:

title: Owners of Delchamps Resist 3d Bid by A.&P.
description: The people at Delchamps, a Southern grocery chain coveted by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, refer to the A.&P.'s latest bid as the third annual offer. ''It comes along with Halloween,'' Alfred F. Delchamps Jr., chairman and chief executive, said yesterday.

title: Review/Television; A Flight From the Soviet System
description: Vladimir and Masha Slepak first applied for an exit visa from the Soviet Union in 1969 and were turned down on the ground that Mr. Slepak's work as a television researcher had entrusted him with state secrets. The only secret he had learned, Mr. Slepak replied, was that Soviet television was far behind developments in the West.

title: Fairchild Attracts Carlyle's Interest
description: A unit of the Carlyle Group L.P. has purchased almost 10 percent of Fairchild Industries' common stock for about $16.8 million, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Carlyle Group, a private merchant banking and investment firm based in Washington, stated in the filing that it was exploring the possibility of acquiring all of the outstanding common stock of Fairchild in a friendly transaction.

title: Notes and Bonds Rise Modestly
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose modestly yesterday, as lower oil prices continued to make investors and speculators wonder whether the inflation rate may be lower than previously expected.

title: Four Are Accused Of Killing Producer In Soured Film Deal
description: Four people have been charged with murder in the slaying five years ago of Roy Radin, the New York producer who the authorities say was involved in a soured deal to finance the movie ''The Cotton Club.''

title: Foe of Pinochet Warns of Attempts to Hinder Vote
description: As workers cleaned up the political leaflets that covered Santiago like snow this morning, an opposition leader warned that agents of Gen. Augusto Pinochet were looking for a way to interfere with the plebiscite on Wednesday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's an absolute, stunning success.'' - Rear Adm. Richard H. Truly, head of the shuttle program. [ A1:6. ]

title: Remy Starts Bid for Piper
description: The cognac maker Remy Martin began a bid for a controlling stake in Piper-Heidsieck, one of the last family-owned French champagne concerns.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Broadcast Exhibit
description: The Museum of Broadcasting has decided to spotlight Young & Rubicam in its first major retrospective on the advertising industry. The three-month exhibit, opening Friday, will include more than 500 radio and TV spots created by the agency over the last 60 years. Among the museum pieces will be ads from the early days of radio featuring Burns and Allen for Grape-Nuts cereal and Jack Benny for Jell-O gelatin; the most contemporary ones will include Bill Cosby as spokesman for Jell-O and ''Peanuts'' cartoon characters promoting Metropolitan Life. The museum, at 1 E. 53d Street in New York City, is open Tuesday to Saturday from noon until 5 P.M. and Thursday until 8 P.M.

title: A Family is Disappointed
description: The release today of Mithileshwar Singh in Lebanon represented dashed hopes for the family of another hostage, Alann Steen. They had waited listening to television and radio in their homes in Santa Cruz, south of here, as early reports indicated that Mr. Steen was the one to be freed.

title: Golden Nugget to Purchase Atlantic City Hotel
description: Golden Nugget Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the troubled 500-room Claridge Casino Hotel in Atlantic City for $110 million, subject to approval by New Jersey regulators.

title: Chemical Week Purchased
description: A British publisher of commodity newsletters and several American investors have purchased Chemical Week magazine; a related publication, Industrial Chemist, and two affiliated press services, it was announced yesterday.

title: Eurotunnel Cost Revision
description: Eurotunnel, the consortium set up to build a 31-mile rail tunnel linking Britain and France, said today that the project would cost about $500 million more than previously forecast but that its May 1993 completion date remained unchanged.

title: Barn Owls Prosper in the Suburbs, But Land Development Is a Threat
description: BARN owls are alive and apparently thriving in suburban New Jersey, a 15-year study has revealed. But their future, like that of most birds of prey, is threatened by human endeavors that destroy their nesting sites, hunting grounds and food supply.

title: Travel-Fraud Warnings Given
description: Consumers in New York State receive an average of three postal cards per week for fraudulent travel schemes, the executive director of the state's Consumer Protection Board said yesterday.

title: Reeds Jewelers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income Revenue represents total revenue.

title: New Olympic Drug Test Foiled Sprinter
description: Ben Johnson, the Canadian sprinter who was stripped of his Olympic gold medal for taking a steroid drug, was caught by a new, extremely sensitive test never before used in the Olympics.

title: Community Psychiatric Ceners Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Sports People; Knicks Get Assistant
description: Ralph Willard, a former basketball player at Holy Cross, was named yesterday as an assistant to Rick Pitino, the Knicks' coach. Willard will specialize in coordinating videotape studies, and aid in scouting (AP)

title: 2 Inchcape Acquisitions
description: The international trading group Inchcape P.L.C. said today that it had bought two United States testing and inspection companies for a total of $:12.5 million ($21.2 million). The London-based multi-industry group said it had acquired ETL Testing Laboratories Inc., which tests electrical consumer goods and components, and PKB Scania Companies, a commodity inspection concern.

title: Hostage Release Could Play Role in the Campaign
description: The sudden release of a hostage held in Lebanon for nearly 20 months has interjected into the 1988 campaign the possibility of an ''October surprise'' that could sway the outcome of the Presidential race.

title: For Film Trivia Buffs
description: WHAT was Gower Gulch? Where did Gable and

title: House Passes Bill Allowing Challenges to V.A.
description: The House of Representatives today unanimously approved a bill giving veterans who dispute decisions on benefits the limited right to challenge the agency in a special appeals court, with the assistance of lawyers.

title: Sports People; Allison Goes Home
description: The stock-car driver Bobby Allison, cleared to go home from a Birmingham, Ala., hospital today, envisions a return to racing after a long course of rehabilitation from injuries suffered in a crash June 19.

title: Bankers Trust Names Chief Financial Officer
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation has established a chief financial officer's post and reached into the securities industry to fill it, naming William C. Jennings from Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: Thompson Medical Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The latest quarter included a provision of $2 million that was established to reserve for the receivable due from Revco D.S. Inc., which filed for bankruptcy protection in July 1988.

title: Sports People; New Friend
description: Teresa Weatherspoon of Pineland, Tex., who won a gold medal with the United States women's basketball team at the Olympic Games, brought plenty of souvenirs with her on her return from Seoul last Friday.
