But she left a couple of them with a new fan and friend she made at the Seattle-Tacoma International Airport.

title: My Life With Andrei
description: This morning I woke up with a deep sense of nostalgia. I was stunned when I suddenly realized who I was being nostalgic about. Andrei Gromyko! Mr. Gromyko and I go back a long time together, although I wonder sometimes if he knows a thing about it. But oh, what we went through together, the walkouts from the U.N. -he leading, me following - the daily clash of minds between two men doomed to be political adversaries but, withal, civilized in social encounter, never forgetting to bow to each other at diplomatic soirees.

title: General Automation Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $97,000 and $769,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income and includes extraordinary credits of $682,000 for the quarter and $1,086,000 for the year. The company said it has made substantial year-end writeoffs totaling about $8 million, including a writeoff of $3.8 million on the sale of assets and technology of its parallel computers subsidiary, writeoffs of about $1.9 million attributable to reorganization of the company by its new management and $1 million relating to the settlement of lawsuits.

title: Random House Reorganizes And Picks Crown Executive
description: Bruce Harris, formerly the director of publishing of the Crown Publishing Group, was appointed yesterday to the new and highly visible position of director of publishing for the Random House trade group.

title: Sports People; Green Arraigned
description: Mitch Green, the heavyweight boxer, was arraigned yesterday in Criminal Court in Queens on charges of driving while impaired and driving without a license. He was released in his own recognizance.

title: Sir Alec Issigonis, 81; Designer of Minicar And Morris Minor
description: Sir Alec Issigonis, who designed the popular, boxy ''Mini'' cars and the practically invincible Morris Minor, died Sunday at his home in Birmingham. He was 81 years old and had suffered from Parkinson's disease.

title: Card Test at Sears
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company plans to test acceptance of Mastercard, Visa and American Express credit cards at some of its stores in addition to its Sears and Discover cards. The tests will involve 12 department stores and 6 paint and hardware stores. Except for two earlier tests in 1979 and 1980, Sears has not accepted either of the major bank cards or the American Express card. The test will take place in stores in Richmond, starting this week.

title: Texas Law Seems Mixed Blessing to Bentsen
description: The special state law written to protect Senator Lyndon B. Johnson in 1960 does not seem to be doing Senator Lloyd Bentsen much good in his campaign for the Vice Presidency in 1988.

title: Panel Backs Gene Transplant For Cancer Treatment Test
description: An influential advisory committee recommended today that the Government for the first time approve the transplanting of foreign genes into human patients.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Greetings Corp., Cleveland, a maker of greeting cards, promoted Edward Fruchtenbaum and James R. Van Arsdale to senior vice presidents, of marketing and operations, respectively.

title: KEY RATES
Margerie Lowry, 83, Actress and a Writer
description: Margerie Bonner Lowry, an actress and a writer, and the widow of the writer Malcolm Lowry, died in a Los Angeles nursing home last Wednesday. She was 83 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Siddall Gets Account
description: Kettler & Scott, a diversified building and land development company in Northern Virginia, has called on Siddall, Matus & Coughter of Richmond as its agency. The budget comes to nearly $5 million. The agency, noted for its real estate and land development marketing, plans to develop marketing programs for its client's latest developments: Sully Station, Virginia Run, Wellington and Cascades.

title: Prelate Attacks Condom Ads
description: Archbishop John F. Whealon today criticized a state advertising campaign that encourages sexually active adults to use condoms in an effort to prevent AIDS.

title: The Talk of Rye; A 'Village' That Has History, Charm, Money and Pressures
description: On the historic Boston Post Road here is a piece of real estate that seems to embody all the qualities of this six-square-mile city: old, verdant, valuable and threatened.

title: California Educators Assert Lottery Has Failed to Pay Off for the Schools
description: The California lottery has created many big winners, but the public school system has yet to hit the jackpot.

title: Military Contractor Has Westland Link
description: A British manufacturer of armored military vehicles bought a 22.02 percent stake in Britain's Westland helicopter company for $:47.8 million, or $80.8 million in cash. The company, GKN, bought the holding in Westland Group P.L.C. from Italy's Fiat Motor Group and Hanson P.L.C., of Britain.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Intron, a Schering Corp. brand of interferon alfa-2b to treat hairy cell leukemia and venereal warts, to Robert A. Becker, a health-care member of the WCRS Group.

title: Canada Southern Petroleum Ltd reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $104,000. c-Net income and includes tax credits of $143,000. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: Satellite Information Systems Co reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: THE PLAYOFFS: Mets Confident Going Into Playoff With Dodgers; First Hurdle Is Hershiser
description: The Mets streaked into town today after winning 29 of their last 36 games and were installed as solid favorites over the crippled Los Angeles Dodgers to win their second National League pennant in three years.

title: 5.1% Kuwait Stake In Midland Bank
description: The Kuwait Investment Office, the London-based investment arm of the Kuwaiti Government, said it holds a 5.1 percent stake in Midland Bank P.L.C. In a statement filed with London's Stock Exchange, the Kuwait Investment Office, which also holds a stake of about 20 percent in the British Petroleum Company, said it had bought 1.5 million Midland shares on Friday. That lifted its holding to 28.04 million shares, or above 5 percent, requiring it to divulge the stake.

title: Infotechnology Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: Thousands Seek Haven After Flooding in India
description: As waters receded steadily today in India's northwest, thousands of people fled flood-damaged villages for shelter in relief camps, said an official in Punjab, the worst hit of four Indian states.

title: Taiwan's U.S. Purchases
description: Taiwan will buy $532 million worth of American wheat, cotton and industrial goods this month, the Taipei Government said today. It will buy 480,000 metric tons of wheat, worth $98.8 million, and 200,000 bales of cotton, worth $44 million.

title: Construction Spending Down 0.6%
description: Construction spending fell six-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Government said today. Economists said the lackluster performance was a result of rising interest rates and previous overbuilding in many regions.

title: Gunman Wounds Child at School
description: A gunman in a camouflage outfit opened fire on a third-grade gym class at a playground today, seriously wounding a girl before fleeing, the authorities said.

title: Andersen Beats Clock and Cowboys
description: Morten Andersen kicked a 49-yard field goal as time ran out tonight to give New Orleans a 20-17 victory over Dallas and end a 17-year drought for the Saints against the Cowboys.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Kobs & Draft Advertising has moved its offices to 633 Third Avenue.

title: Myerson Trial's Opening Statements to Start
description: The Federal judge in the Bess Myerson case held a closed conference yesterday with the prosecutors and defense lawyers, then announced that the trial's opening statements would begin on schedule this morning.

title: Ethnic Strife Prompts 2 to Quit Yugoslav Politburo
description: The shock waves of ethnic conflict between Serbs and Albanians in southern Yugoslavia reached the top of the Communist leadership last week when two Politburo members resigned.

title: ICN Biomedicals Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $259,000 for the quarter and $506,000 for the 9 months. c-After an extraordinary credit of $39,000 for the quarter and 9 months. The latest quarter's pre-tax income included a writeoff of $130,000 in connection with consolidation of facilities.

title: North Stars Claim Leiter
description: The Islander defenseman Ken Leiter was claimed by the Minnesota North Stars yesterday in the fourth round of the waiver draft, but he said that he informed Bill Torrey, the Islanders' general manager, last Wednesday that he had decided to retire.

title: Last Chance for Voters
description: New Yorkers who put off focusing on the Presidential campaign until after the end of the World Series risk a rude shock - disenfranchisement for the Nov. 8 election. The deadline for voter registration in New York State is next week. To protect their right to vote, unregistered New Yorkers must move quickly. Mail registration forms must be returned to the Board of Elections no later than Oct. 11, a week from today. In New York City, local polling places will be open for registration from 1 to 9 P.M. on Oct. 13 and 15.

title: As Chile Prepares to Vote, U.S. Envoy Is Praised
description: Among the items hanging in the office of Harry G. Barnes Jr. is a newspaper cartoon that shows him knocking in vain on the doors of Chile's fortress-like presidential palace.

title: Women Need to Know Risks of Hysterectomy
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Accuses 4 Of High Profits In Fake Dali Art
description: Four people were charged yesterday with operating a Manhattan gallery that sold more than 1,000 fake Salvador Dali lithographs for $3.4 million.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Boy, 17, Is Guilty of Manslaughter in Stabbing
description: After deliberating less than four hours, a jury yesterday found a 17-year-old boy guilty of first-degree manslaughter in the stabbing death of a 16-year-old boy in a confrontation between two groups of teen-agers in Queens last year.

title: Blowup in the Family
description: Edward Teller, the 80-year-old physicist, disclosed that he was ''angry'' at the hydrogen bomb of which he is widely renowned as ''the father.'' Speaking yesterday at the American Enterprise Institute, Mr. Teller said: ''All these years I never received a Father's Day card.''

title: Studios Struck by Teamsters
description: The drivers who haul stars, equipment and props for television and movie producers went on strike today. The strike marks the second time this year the entertainment industry has been strained by a labor dispute.

title: Church's Fried Chicken Inc reports earnings for 12wks to Sept 4
For Red Sox Fans, Hope Springs Eternal
description: LEAD: They've got me hooked again.

title: INSIDE
description: Change in Debate Sponsor The League of Women Voters withdrew from the next Presidential debate. The commission that sponsored the first one took over. Page D31. U.S. Envoy Influences Vote The United States Ambassador is credited with helping to make possible the relatively free campaign environment in Chile. Page A6. Franz Josef Strauss Dies Franz Josef Strauss, who influenced West German politics from his stronghold in Bavaria, is dead at the age of 73. Page D27.

title: THE PLAYOFFS: Mets Confident Going Into Playoff With Dodgers; Lasorda Wipes Slate Clean On Offense
description: When Tommy Lasorda was asked what the Dodgers would have to do to beat the Mets, he answered with the typically trite reply of a baseball manager. ''Score more runs,'' the Los Angeles manager said.

title: Celcor Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,478,000 for the latest year and $638,000 for the year-earlier period. The company said the net from discontinued operations in both periods included gains recognized on sales of discontinued operations.

title: Hershiser Steals Center of Stage
description: Your attention, please. The role of Met nemesis in the National League Championship Series, originated by Mike Scott in 1986, will be played this year by Orel Hershiser.

title: Man Held in Plot to Kill Wife
description: A 54-year-old man was arrested Sunday for possession of a pipe bomb, which the police said he planned to use against his estranged wife. The police said the man, Charles Hill, had placed an advertisement in The Irish Voice seeking a person to perform a ''confidential assignment.'' A police informant answered the ad. Mr. Hill then arranged for the murder of his wife, Mary Sutherland Hill, who lives in Glasgow, the police said.

title: Louis Fried, Executive And Philanthropist, 94
description: Louis Fried, a former president of the National Shoe Stores chain and a philanthropist, died of heart failure yesterday at his home in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 94 years old.

title: Campaign Trail; Whee! the Children Talk to Big Michael
description: Governor Dukakis visited Hartford yesterday for an ''informal'' session with fourth-grade and sixth-grade students at the Alfred E. Barr Elementary School.

title: New Egg-Implanting Technique Avoids Surgery
description: DOCTORS in Australia have developed a new technique for implanting fertilized eggs in women's fallopian tubes. They hope the technique will improve the success rate of in vitro fertilization, without surgery.

title: Franz Josef Strauss Is Dead at 73; Conservative Led Bavarian State
description: Franz Josef Strauss, the butcher's son who helped shape the West German state and exercised a caustic and often contentious influence over its politics from his stronghold in Bavaria, died today. He was 73 years old.

title: Hospital Staffing Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Compromise Drug Plan in Senate Includes Death-Penalty Provision
description: A bipartisan group of Senators today introduced the Senate's offering in the election-year war on drugs: a compromise package that includes language permitting a death penalty for convicted drug traffickers or individuals involved in drug-related killings.

title: Pinpointing the Pathway of Smell
description: MOLECULAR biologists have begun to crack one of nature's most complicated mysteries: how humans and other animals manage to distinguish thousands of different odor molecules and interpret them as smells.

title: Cintas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Bridge
description: There was considerable bridge activity around the New York metropolitan region over the weekend.

title: WORKERS IN BURMA RETURNING TO JOBS
description: Tens of thousands of Burmese Government workers returned to work today, heeding an ultimatum by the Burmese military to end weeks of strikes in support of political change.

title: Libya and Chad Restore Ties and Vow to Settle Dispute Peacefully
description: Libya and Chad announced today that they would restore diplomatic ties and seek a peaceful settlement of a 15-year conflict over a strip of uranium-rich territory annexed by Libya in 1973.

title: New Faces of 1988
description: Tourneau, the watch store, has ingeniously married old, as in antique or classic, to old, as in used or cheaper. In Sunday's New York Times Magazine, it advertised ''pre-owned'' watches, with luxe names like Cartier, Patek Philippe and Rolex, displayed against distressed wood and leather-bound books.

title: Fashion; A Many-Splendored Spring: Dressing for Every Mood
description: Italian designers obviously prefer to be known as benevolent fashion leaders, not despots. So in the spring and summer showings that began on Sunday, there is almost an embarrassment of riches: clothes for women to wear to work and to play, in cities and at vacation resorts. There is no single dominant note, like the mini of recent memory. Skirts are all lengths, from above the knee to near the ankles, and overshadowing them both are pants.

title: Sports People; Parrish Traded
description: Hiring a new manager was not the full extent of Lee Thomas's business yesterday. He also traded Lance Parrish, a catcher who had been a vast disappointent for the last two seasons. Parrish, 32, went to the California Angels for David Holdridge, a minor league pitcher.

title: Lothar Wolff, Film Producer, Is Dead at 79
description: Lothar Wolff, a film producer, died of prostate cancer Sunday at Rosary Hill Home in Hawthorne, N.Y. He was 79 years old and lived in New York City and Sharon, Conn.

title: Nippon Mining Unit Appoints a Chairman
description: Gould Inc., which was recently acquired by the Nippon Mining Company, announced yesterday that it had named C. David Ferguson chairman and chief executive.

title: A Complex Olympic Collage
description: NBC took America to another part of the world as well as to the Olympics, and that was the strength and the weakness of 179 1/2 hours of coverage.

title: Knight-Ridder Plans to Sell 8 TV Stations to Cut Debt
description: In a move to reduce its debt of nearly $1 billion and to focus on its cable television and electronic information services, Knight-Ridder Inc. announced yesterday that it would sell its eight network-affiliated television stations.

title: Slim Laptop Is Appealing At 4.4 Pounds
description: A NEW 4.4-pound laptop was introduced yesterday by NEC Home Electronics.

title: Q&A
description: Q.How do nuclear submarines get their oxygen supply when they stay submerged for weeks and months at a time? A.The crew of a submerged submarine can get oxygen from three sources: the air the submarine carries with it, air it takes in through a snorkel when it is just below the surface, and seawater, according to Lieut. Brian Cullin, a public relations officer.

title: New Drug Law: The Senate's Duty; Trashing the Constitution Won't Help
description: The House drug bill would weaken the exclusionary rule, which bars the use of illegally seized evidence in criminal trials. It is up to the Senate to defend the Constitution.

title: Corrections#NOF#
description: Because of an editing error, a table in Business Day on Saturday about leading underwriters on Wall Street and the amount of capital they raised for American companies this year misstated the source of the information. It was IDD Information Services.

title: Autoclave Engineers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a gain from the sale of real estate of $554,000. Year-ago results are restated to reflect the reversal of a gain of $266,000 from the sale of an investment. The company said share earnings and shares outstanding used to compute share earnings for year-ago quarter have been adjusted to give effect to the 10 percent stock dividend issued on May 16, 1988.

title: Personal Computer Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chiron Research Unit
description: The Chiron Corporation, a biotechnology company based in Emeryville, Calif., said today that it had formed an affiliated company, Mimesys Inc., to research and develop the next generation of biotech drugs. The unit will be involved with an expanded joint development agreement with Johnson & Johnson and the Warner-Lambert Company. A Chiron spokesman said the venture would try to attract prominent scientists by offering a 20 percent stake to employees.

title: Quneitra Journal; A Blasted Place Where a Vengeful Spirit Thrives
description: Lieut. Khaled al-Natur, a Syrian Army officer, lowered his Soviet-made binoculars and gestured beyond his country's borders.

title: Group Lifts Stake In American Hoist
description: An investment group led by Frank J. A. Cilluffo has increased its stake in the American Hoist and Derrick Company to 9 percent, from 5 percent, by buying 250,000 shares on a day when its stock price dipped to $9.50 a share, the group said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: High Court Move Aids Manville
description: More than six years after one of the most controversial corporate bankruptcy filings ever, the United States Supreme Court yesterday cleared the way for the Manville Corporation of Denver to emerge from Chapter 11.

title: Bergen Brunswig Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a $124,000 loss on discontinued operations and a $1,999,000 after-tax gain on disposition of discontinued operations. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $442,000 and $2,041,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: McDonnell Douglas Wins Swiss Contract
description: Switzerland's military chief today awarded the McDonnell Douglas Corporation a $1.8 billion contract to build 34 F/A-18 Hornets for the Swiss armed forces, whose fleet consists of 30-year-old French-made Mirage fighters.

title: Bicycle Polo Pedals Toward Centennial
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Apartheid Arouses Anger
description: To a hushed audience, the Rev. Allan Hendrickse described in detail how his father's ''beautiful home'' had been knocked down brick by brick when their old neighborhood in Uitenhage was declared legal for whites only.

title: Drought-Stricken Farmers Applying for Aid
description: Farmers began signing up for payments today under a $3.9 billion benefits package to aid victims of the summer drought.

title: Johnson May Give Up His Track Career
description: Ben Johnson, denying that he knowingly used steroids, said that he planned to get even with those responsible for his disqualification as the Olympic 100-meter champion.

title: Walton Stands By His Costly Decision
description: ''Oh, my nerves,'' is what Coach Joe Walton had to say about Sunday's game.

title: NEW HAITIAN CHIEF SEEMS ENTRENCHED
description: After a tense weekend, Haiti was quiet today, and Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, the new President, appeared in control of all major units in the military.

title: Comprehensive Care Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said its earnings declined about $1 million in the latest first quarter because of decreased earnings in its contract operations.

title: Women Need to Know Risks of Hysterectomy; Smoking in Pregnancy
description: To the Editor:

title: Americans Love Noise
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaign Trail; No Time for a Spin After No. 2 Debate
description: All those Highly Informed television reporters are torn with grief. All those eager campaign analysts, all those expert columnists covering the political campaigns, all those political consultants who appear with Bryant and Ted and Peter and Tom - all are deeply distressed.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * A. David Jones, a senior vice president at BBDO, Detroit, has been promoted to senior management representative.

title: U.S. Gain in Computer Speed Race
description: After several years of trailing Japan, the United States may be pulling ahead again in the supercomputer speed race.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Review/Music; Boston Trio, With Rarities
description: The violinist Daniel Stepner, the gambist Laura Jeppesen and the harpsichordist John Gibbons perform individually with several American and European period instrument bands, and are among the most highly regarded of this country's early music players. Hearing them together as the Boston Museum Trio is always a treat, not only because of the caliber of their playing, but also because they frequently turn up with a few rarely heard gems.

title: Zoo Mistreatment Charged As Elephant Attacks Doctor
description: A zoo advocacy group is calling for an investigation into the cause of puncture wounds on the head and face of an elephant that injured a veterinarian who was trying to treat the wounds.

title: National Healthcare Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a charge of about $2.4 million for losses on the disposal of facilities. c-Included a charge of about $700,000 for losses on the disposal of facilities for the quarter; the year included a tax benefit of $2 million.

title: CSX Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $6,000,000 for the quarter and $9,000,000 for the 9 months, and the 9 months also included a $180,000,000 gain on the sale of discontinued operations. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $12,000,000 and $45,000,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9 months also included a $294,000,000 loss due to an accounting change. The latest 9 months also included pretax charges of $778,000,000 relating to labor separation payments and certain litigation claims. Year-ago results are restated for an accounting change and for classification of the company's energy segment as discontinued operations.

title: Campaign Trail; Yankee Ingenuity, Campaign '88 Style
description: There was Vice President Bush (on a nonpolitical trip, of course) welcoming the crew of the space shuttle Discovery after it landed here yesterday.

title: Ode to Whatshisname
description: In World War II the Library of Congress awarded a poetry prize to Ezra Pound, whose Fascist sympathies were well known, and Congress reacted by barring the library from giving out any new prizes.

title: Review/Theater; Recalling the Kosher Salt of the Earth
description: ''The Grandma Plays'' is a kitchen-sink comedy that provides no sustenance either for its actresses or for the audience. Ostensibly the chronicle of pivotal moments in the life of a Brooklyn woman named Pearl Berman, the Todd Graff play is instead a trio of flimsy character sketches.

title: Supreme Court Refuses To Lift Execution Stay
description: The United States Supreme Court refused today to lift a Federal appeals court order blocking the execution of a convicted murderer who wanted all appeals dropped.

title: American Nursery Products reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Dr Pepper/7-Up Financing To Pay Off Prudential Loan
description: The Dr Pepper/Seven-Up Companies are offering $422.3 million of notes and common stock purchase warrants through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Capital Funding.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ford Account To Thompson
description: The Ford Motor Company has called on J. Walter Thompson Worldwide to take on additional advertising for New Zealand and Australia. The budget is an estimated $25 million.

title: Mysterious Particles May Upset Theories on Radiation From Space
description: RADIATION that seems to violate current theories about the energy and matter in space are striking the earth, scientists from several research installations have concluded.

title: Finance Dept. Aide Quits Amid Reports On Tax Reductions
description: A deputy finance commissioner, whose job included making judgments on tax assessments, has resigned, city officials said yesterday.

title: Dukakis Seeking Extradition Of Escapee From California
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis wants a prison escapee returned to Massachusetts to serve out his murder sentence even though the man lived a model life in Los Angeles for 14 years, it was disclosed in court today.

title: Shaklee Holds 23% Of Garden Supplier
description: The Shaklee Corporation bought a 23 percent stake in Smith & Hawken, a privately held company that sells deluxe home gardening supplies through the mail. The companies said they would cooperate on marketing their product lines to their combined customer base. Financial terms were not announced.

title: Proxmire Makes 11th-Hour Effort for a Bank Bill
description: In a last-ditch effort to save legislation that would overhaul the nation's banking laws, Senator William Proxmire proposed a new approach today to circumvent a bitter dispute between two committee chairmen in the House.

title: THE PLAYOFFS: Sports of The Times; On the Day Before the Dodgers, Butterflies for Jefferies
description: ''YOU nervous, Doc?''

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: On Horse Racing; Staging a Pro Tour For Thoroughbreds
description: Golf, tennis and bowling all have their professional tours, long strings of major events that wind across the country and through the calendar. Fans keep close count of the leaders in tour victories, an imperfect but useful way to measure consistency and achievement.

title: Factories' Orders Show A 3.1% Rise
description: Orders for manufactured goods surged 3.1 percent in August, the Government said today, indicating that the economy is continuing to grow at a robust pace.

title: Cheyenne Software Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Revenue for the latest year included the company's F.A. Computer Technologies Inc. unit. The prior year results are reclassified to conform to current year presentation.

title: Inco to Make Special Payout
description: Inco Ltd., the world's biggest nickel producer, today announced a huge recapitalization under which it will pay out $1 billion to stockholders as a special dividend before the end of the year.

title: Green Asks Businesses for Ideas to Help Schools
description: New York City's Schools Chancellor, Dr. Richard R. Green, looking outside the education field for ideas on reforming the vast education bureaucracy, has asked New York's business community to recommend improvements in the system's personnel policies.

title: Review/Pop; Prince Mixes Erotic and Religious Messages
description: Prince, who played a sold-out concert at Madison Square Garden on Sunday night, projects one of the most confusing, enigmatic images in pop music, mixing erotic love with religion, irony and humor with seriousness. It is these contradictions that separate him from straightforward, bland mainstream performers and ultimately make him more interesting than they are.

title: Business Cards Tomorrow reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said its shareholders voted to change the company's name to American Franchise Group Inc.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Restrictions on Religious Displays to Be Weighed
description: The Supreme Court today added several important church-state cases to the docket for its new term, agreeing to revisit the sensitive question of what limits the Constitution places on the official observance of religious holidays.

title: Hamengku Buwono IX, 78, Indonesia Sultan
description: Sultan Dorodjatun Hamengku Buwono IX, who held several high Government posts in Indonesia, including the vice presidency, after independence from the Netherlands after World War II, died at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington on Sunday. He was 78 years old and lived in Jogjakarta, Indonesia.

title: Farmer Brothers Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and year included the writeoff of $3.2 million of assets as a result of an accounting change.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Sept. 19 misidentified a company that creates advertising inserts for newspapers. It is Valassis Direct Response of New York City.

title: Women Voters' League Drops Backing of Debate
description: The League of Women Voters today withdrew its sponsorship of next week's debate between Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, but the Presidential nominees' campaigns reached an agreement that would allow the debate to proceed in Los Angeles as scheduled.

title: Judge Designates Alternative Site for Yonkers Housing
description: The Federal judge in the Yonkers housing-discrimination suit bypassed a defiant City Council yesterday and designated an alternative to a church-owned site for housing for the poor.

title: Middlemen, Not Dairy Farmers, Make the Milk More Expensive
description: To the Editor:

title: Agency's Biggest Find Is Constant Controversy
description: A trivia quiz: What is the third-largest source of Federal revenue, after the Internal Revenue Service and the Customs Service?

title: At the Nation's Table
description: GIULIANO Hazan, the 29-year-old son of the doyenne of classic Italian cooking, Marcella Hazan, is following in his mother's footsteps. Last week was the official opening of Giuliano Hazan's Gastronomia, a takeout shop for Italian cuisine on the East Side of Providence.

title: Review/Theater; Exploring Politics, Love And the Politics of Love
description: The pleasant surprise in the Equity Library Theater's revival of ''The Male Animal'' is the fun it manages to eke out of the 1940 politico-romantic comedy, whose politics are transparent and whose romance is opaque. It was a period when playwrights used cocktails to inspire their heroes to speak slurred truth. Yet in this case the spirit of the writers, James Thurber and Elliot Nugent, manages to slip through the plot's contrivances in the form of smart cracks and cartoon characters that bring out smiles amid the yawns.

title: Harvey Wellman, Ex-Diplomat, Dies at 71
description: Harvey R. Wellman, a United States diplomat and member of the Foreign Service for 32 years, died of a heart attack Sept. 27 at Middlesex Memorial Hospital in Middletown, Conn. He was 71 years old and lived in Old Saybrook, Conn.

title: Hungarian Exuberance
description: The Kodaly Ensemble Hungarian Dance Theater made its New York debut Sunday night at the Fashion Institute of Technology. It was a terrific evening of boisterous dancing and high spirits combined with serious thought.

title: Eating Well
description: AMERICANS are eating out more than they ever have, or perhaps, to be precise, they are eating more food cooked by strangers than cooked by their spouses, their parents or themselves. Whether they eat their meals in restaurants, fast-food places or school or office cafeterias, or buy from takeouts or prepared-food counters at the supermarket, fewer people are eating meals made at home.

title: Alec Issigonis Dies; Auto Designer, 81, Introduced the Mini
description: Sir Alec Issigonis, who designed the popular, boxy ''Mini'' cars and the practically indestructible Morris Minor, died Sunday at his home in Birmingham. He was 81 years old and had suffered from Parkinson's disease.

title: Hooray for Moscow
description: There is a good feeling these days at the headquarters here of the Motion Picture Association of America because of agreements concluded last week in Moscow with the Soviet Ministry of Cinematography enlarging the Soviet market for American films and filmmakers. Jack Valenti, chairman of the association, said he had been trying for such agreements for more than two decades.

title: Just Call Him El Presidente
description: When Gen. Augusto Pinochet came to power in the military coup 15 years ago it thrust on the Chilean scene a last name not very common here and pronounced a variety of ways ever since.

title: At Historic Vineyard, A Historic Harvest
description: AFTER a 181-year interval between vintages, Monticello has joined the avant-garde of Virginia wine making. Some might say the rear guard, but let's not quibble.

title: Honduran Seeks U.N. Patrol To Evict Neighbors' Rebels
description: The Foreign Minister of Honduras today proposed an international peacekeeping force that would evacuate Nicaraguan and Salvadoran rebels from Honduran territory and patrol the borders to keep them out.

title: No Runaround For McReynolds
description: Their precious opportunities had passed so quickly through eight scoreless innings that as Kevin McReynolds approached home plate in the ninth inning, he knew there could be no other way but the direct approach.

title: Pole Under Scrutiny for U.S. Trip
description: A Polish prosecutor has begun investigating Solidarity's national spokesman because he appeared last month before a Congressional committee in Washington.

title: Manville's Shares Climb, Baffling Analysts
description: Common stock of the Manville Corporation rose sharply in heavy trading yesterday, closing at $2.875, up $1.125. Analysts were baffled at the move, saying that investors may not understand the extent of the stock dilution that will occur as part of the company's reorganization plan as it comes out of bankruptcy.

title: Kenneth J. Thornhill, 61, Financial Adviser
description: Kenneth J. Thornhill, a financial consultant and former member of the Data General Corporation's board of directors, died Saturday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla. His wife said he probably died of a heart attack. He was 61 years old.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Angolan President Predicts an Agreement Soon for the Withdrawal of Cuban Forces
description: Angola's President predicted today that an agreement would soon be reached on the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola and independence for Namibia.

title: How Mr. Regan Could Clear the Air
description: In a tense appearance before the New York State Commission on Government Integrity, State Comptroller Edward Regan faced new evidence that he traded state business for campaign contributions. His answers strained credulity; he needs to do much more to reassure the public.

title: Venezuela Refining Aim
description: Venezuela is close to concluding a deal for new refining operations in the United States, Juan Chacin, president of Petroleos de Venezuela S.A., said today. ''Currently, we have about 450,000-barrels-a-day refining capacity outside Venezuela,'' he told an investment seminar at the National Press Club. ''Our objective is to increase it to 700,000 barrels a day.'' He declined to elaborate on the possible acquisition. Petroleos de Venezuela, the country's national oil company, already owns 50 percent of the Citgo Petroleum Corporation and the Champlin Refining Company.

title: Soviet Railway Blast Kills 4 and Injures 280
description: Rail cars filled with explosives crashed into a coal train in the central Russian Republic today, causing an explosion that killed 4 people and injured 280, Soviet reports said.

title: Prime Computer Chief Leaving After 7 Years
description: Prime Computer Inc. said yesterday that its president and chief executive, Joe M. Henson, would step down and be succeeded by Anthony Craig after a transition period of several months.

title: Pillsbury Moves Fast To Defend Against Bid
description: As Wall Street was furiously bidding up the stock of the Pillsbury Company today in response to a surprise takeover bid, the company moved to defend itself.

title: Lebanon's Christian Forces Tighten Hold on East Beirut
description: Lebanon's main Christian militia tightened its grip on East Beirut today after taking control of fighters loyal to former President Amin Gemayel.

title: Pinochet Foes, Bolstered by Polls, Hope to Oust Him in Vote Today
description: Chileans will vote Wednesday in a plebiscite in which opponents of Gen. Augusto Pinochet think they are going to end a military government at the ballot box.

title: Gorbachev's Coup: Sign of Weakness
description: LEAD: The only sure conclusion we can draw from the upheaval in the Soviet Union is that it is dangerous for members of the Politburo to go on vacation. After General Secretary Mikhail S. Gorbachev returned from vacation in mid-September, he ran into a firestorm of criticism for his failure to do anything about the deterioration in food supplies and the growing unrest in places like Armenia and the Baltic states.

title: The Shoreham Paradox; While Closer Than Ever to Getting License, A-Plant Has Lost Much of Its Value to Lilco
description: The Long Island Lighting Company has coveted an operating license for its Shoreham Nuclear Power Station for 20 years, but as it nears its goal the utility is showing ambivalence, simultaneously seeking permission to open Shoreham while patiently awaiting approval of an agreement to abandon it.

title: Review/Concert; Bychkov and the Buffalo
description: Semyon Bychkov, who is now 36 years old, emerged as one of the most promising conductors of his generation a few years ago, and the scope of his international career is manifest both in his series of recordings with the Berlin Philharmonic and his appointment as director of the Orchestre de Paris, starting next season.

title: Two Groups to Dance In a Memorial Tribute
description: The world premiere of a dance by Saeko Ichinohe and an appearance by the Workshop Ensemble of the Dance Theater of Harlem will be part of a memorial tribute to Hector Tello, a choreographer and soloist with Miss Ichinohe's company, at 6 P.M. on Oct. 11 at the Japan Society, 333 East 74th Street. Mr. Tello died last year.

title: Short Coattails Affect Tactics in Jersey Race
description: When Gov. Michael S. Dukakis went to Jersey City to address a rally last week, Senator Bill Bradley was at his side. But Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, who is in the midst of a tough re-election campaign, passed up the chance to be seen with the Democratic nominee for President.

title: A Network For Women Whose Work Is at Home
description: In an age of agonizing choices for women, particularly for those who decide to stay home with their children, naming a newsletter dedicated to helping them was surprisingly easy.

title: 2 Ways Art Gives Shape To Political Horrors
description: ''Nothing is impossible with a camera, my boy!'' Samuel Fuller bellows at his interviewer in ''Faulkenau, the Impossible.'' The director's voice is still full of bravado at the age of 76. With his lined face and flowing white hair, even smoking a cigar he looks like an aged avenging angel swooping down from the screen to rage against war. Leon Golub, on the other hand, is a slight, bald man of 66. He talks without a trace of pretension about power, politics and art, and often chuckles at mundane details as he goes about his work - painting huge canvases that freeze political assassins, torturers and mercenaries.

title: Irate Yugoslavs March on Parliament
description: About 5,000 workers from two machine-tool factories on the outskirts of Belgrade marched on Parliament today to protest low wages.

title: President Is Chosen For Battery Park City
description: David Emil, deputy commissioner of the state's Department of Social Services, will become the next president of the Battery Park City Authority, Governor Cuomo announced yesterday.

title: 400 Are Arrested in Atlanta Abortion Protests
description: Four hundred people who oppose abortion were arrested at abortion clinics here today in the largest in a series of demonstrations that began at the time of the Democratic National Convention here in July.

title: White House Policy Makers Keep an Eye on the Election
description: Lee M. Thomas, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has been highly visible in recent weeks: warning of the dangers of radon gas, announcing a strategy for dealing with the nation's garbage crisis, proposing a total ban on chemicals that are destroying the earth's ozone shield.

title: Corrections
description: The Business People column on Monday misstated the value of F.A.C.

title: Market Place; Friendly Suitors And Pillsbury
description: WALL STREET professionals speculated yesterday that the Pillsbury Company might seek a friendly suitor to defend itself against a $5.23 billion takeover bid from Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British food and beverage giant. Most speculation centered on a foreign buyer, not so much because of the weak dollar but because of United States accounting rules that would make most acquiring American companies look less profitable.

title: Colleges Offer Forum To Foreign Dissidents
description: Bard College and seven other liberal arts colleges have formed a consortium to give one-year fellowships to dissidents from countries throughout the world.

title: Canadian Unit Adds Fruehauf
description: The Varity Corporation, a Canadian farm and industrial equipment maker, has signed a letter of intent to acquire the vehicle parts concern Fruehauf Corporation in a stock swap, the two companies said today. No total value was announced. Under the proposed merger, Varity would acquire all the outstanding shares of Fruehauf's class A and class B common stock in exchange for about two shares each of Varity common stock. Fruehauf had said in late August that Varity was considering buying the company.

title: Minister and Archivist Are Back on the Boards
description: By JENNIFER DUNNING

title: Books of The Times; A Comedy of Contemporary Manners and Effluvia
description: This Is Your Life By Meg Wolitzer 263 pages. Crown Publishers. $17.95.

title: Newly Revealed Michelangelo to Be Shown
description: A drawing attributed to Michelangelo has been revealed by conservators at the Uffizi Museum in Florence, and will go on view on Sunday at the National Gallery here as part of an exhibition of drawings by the artist.

title: Directors Make Bid For Virgin Group
description: The directors of the Virgin Group P.L.C. have offered to buy the 37 percent of the British music and entertainment group that they do not own for about $2.37 a share, the same price the shares were floated at in November 1986. The offer values the company at $:248 million, or about $420.7 million.

title: A Club for All
description: To The Living Section:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: Lawmaker Asks Quick Action
description: A Georgia Congressman demanded on the House floor Monday that he be indicted immediately so that he could answer allegations of his possible connection with a money-laundering scheme.

title: From California, Words of Advice
description: With some glee, Republican sources have leaked a private Democratic document that is faintly embarrassing and somewhat informative about the California Democratic Congressional delegation.

title: The Islanders' Egos Are Still Hurting
description: The Islanders, who won their division title last season and followed with a hasty first-round playoff exit, have moved into the new season at the same pace they left the old one: at a limp.

title: Bentsen Faces Dual Job In TV Debate Tonight
description: When Lloyd Millard Bentsen Jr. walks on the stage of the Civic Auditorium Wednesday night to debate, he will be carrying an invisible portfolio of political responsibility as detailed and heavy as any Vice-Presidential candidate in many years.

title: Controlling the News
description: The Pentagon's chief spokesman, J. Daniel Howard, the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs, appears to have won an internal struggle for control of the department's daily compendium of news clips, which ranks among the most influential publications in the Government.

title: President Of Rollins Resigns in Board Rift
description: Darrell E. Trent, the president and chief executive of Rollins Environmental Systems Inc., announced his resignation yesterday in a letter contending that the board's executive committee had frustrated his attempts to manage the company.

title: Physicians Agree Tyson Isn't Manic-Depressive
description: Mike Tyson received a second opinion on his psychiatric state yesterday, and according to Dr. Abraham L. Halpern, the fighter is not a manic-depressive.

title: Third World Debt Plan Is Defended by Japan
description: The decision by Japan to promote its own proposal to help Latin American debtors stems from the danger that creditor banks and debtor nations might abandon the American approach to the problem, a senior finance ministry official said today.

title: Oxford Journal; Reluctant Scholars at the School of Hard Knocks
description: Matthew Arnold, professor of poetry here from 1857 to 1867, described it as ''that sweet city with her dreaming spires.'' But here and at every other British university, the ivory tower is tumbling down.

title: Thomas J. Kelly, 65; Won Medal of Honor
description: Thomas J. Kelly, a recipient of the Medal of Honor and president of the Congressional Medal of Honor Society from 1964 to 1969, died of a heart attack Sunday at Shore Memorial Hospital in Somers Point, N.J. He was 65 years old and lived in Margate, N.J.

title: California Chain Curbs Tobacco Sales
description: The largest supermarket chain in Southern California today ordered all cigars and pipe and chewing tobacco removed from its shelves because the tobacco companies that make the products had declined to place consumer warning labels on them.

title: Reagan Stands Firm But Won't Get to Fly
description: Ronald Reagan might have persuaded Congress to build a new Air Force One, but he's going to miss the distinction of being the first President to fly in it.

title: New Conflict in Macmillan Bidding
description: The board of Macmillan Inc. did not know that the company's management had told Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company of a rival bid by the Maxwell Communications Corporation during the auction process on Monday evening, according to papers filed in Delaware Chancery Court.

title: Enlisting the Gipper To Win One for Bush
description: With the Presidential race in its final weeks, and the contest turning into a horse race, the Bush campaign is turning to - who else? - the Gipper to step up his campaigning among so-called Reagan Democrats.

title: Politburo Demands Plan for Agriculture
description: Meeting for the first time since last week's leadership shake-up, the Politburo today ordered an overhaul of Soviet agriculture and approved creation of a new party journal and a new Government newspaper.

title: Knee Surgery for Turner
description: Odessa Turner, the Giants' second-year wide receiver, underwent arthroscopic surgery yesterday to remove a bone chip from his left knee. The surgery was performed by Dr. Russell Warren at the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan.

title: Time to Look at What We've Done to Nicaragua; Civilians Targeted
description: To the Editor:

title: ABC Offers 'Open-Ended' Campaign Forum
description: ABC News said tonight that it had invited the two Presidential candidates to participate in ''an open-ended discussion'' of the issues on a network broadcast that might be several hours long.

title: Secret U.S. Policy Against Terrorists Reported
description: A former Government official said tonight that President Reagan signed a secret intelligence order three years ago giving intelligence officers broad latitude for aggressive action against terrorists, including violence in some cases if the action was taken in ''good faith.''

title: Officer Shoots Man Outside His Home
description: A Bronx man was shot in the stomach by a police officer last night after the man pointed what the police said appeared to be a rifle at him.

title: About New York; Fall Classics: Orange and Blue Is All the Rage
description: If there really is a time for every purpose under heaven, then this is a time for blue margaritas with orange twists. A time to give away New York Film Festival tickets, steal home and curl up by the television set.

title: Sun Holders Back Splitting Company
description: Stockholders of the Sun Company, the nation's 10th-largest oil company, approved a restructuring that spins off its $4.2 billion domestic gas exploration and production unit into a separate operation and cuts 1,300 jobs. The new structure retains the petroleum refining and marketing operations in a slimmed-down business.

title: Savings Units' Sale Expedited
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it would offer 10 insolvent thrift institutions for sale on an expedited basis so that bids can be approved within 35 days of their receipt.

title: Dukakis Cites Kennedy And Names Nixon, Too
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, who has been cloaking himself in the mystique of John F. Kennedy for months, summoned Kennedy's memory to this college town north of Chicago today to draw a parallel between Vice President Bush and the 1960 Republican nominee, Richard M. Nixon.

title: Legislative Problems Seen in '89
description: WHEN John O'Toole assumes the presidency of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, he will have his hands full. ''It will be our toughest year ever in Washington and in the state capitals,'' Mr. O'Toole said in a telephone interview yesterday.

title: Ticketron Account To Warner, Bicking
description: Ticketron, a division of the Control Data Corporation, has appointed Warner, Bicking & Fenwick to handle the seven-figure budget for its Ticketron and Teletron services. Previously handling the account was Serino, Coyne & Nappi.

title: Johnson Repeats Denial on Steroids
description: Ben Johnson appeared at a tightly controlled news conference in a Toronto hotel today, and, reading a brief statement that had been drafted with his lawyer, renewed his denial that he had ever knowingly taken performance-enhancing drugs.

title: How It Happened; At Last, The Tide Turns for Carter
description: In the first inning Gary Carter couldn't overcome the jump Steve Sax got against Dwight Gooden and in the third inning he couldn't overcome his own lack of speed.

title: The Three People on Trial
description: Bess Myerson: 64 years old. Grew up in a working-class home in the Bronx. Won Miss America title in 1945, and later appeared on television on ''The Big Payoff'' and ''I've Got a Secret.'' Went to graduate school and worked for a time as a journalist. Served as Mayor John V. Lindsay's Consumer Affairs Commissioner. Befriended Representative Edward I. Koch, and in his 1977 mayoral compaign, she was his frequent companion, helping dispel rumors that the unmarried candidate had anything to hide about his personal life. Mr. Koch later named Ms. Myerson as his Cultural Affairs Commissioner. Married and divorced twice. Hortense W. Gabel: 75. First gained prominence more than 30 years ago by accusing politicians of abusing their offices to enrich themselves and real-estate developers. Named to fill an unexpired term on the State Supreme Court by Gov. Hugh L. Carey in 1975. Selection was widely lauded as a sign that lawyers could be named to the trial court even when they were not toeing the political line. Named judge of the year in 1986 by the National Association of Women Judges, an organization she helped found in 1979. Grew up in the Bronx. Married to Dr. Milton Gabel, whom she met in 1944 when he was an Army dentist. Carl A. Capasso: 43. President of Nanco Contracting Corporation, which has obtained more than $150 million from New York City since 1978 for sewerage, pollution and street paving work. Pleaded guilty to tax-evasion charges in January 1987 and was sentenced to four years in prison and fined $500,000. His former wife, Nancy, charged that Ms. Myerson had broken up the marriage. Current trial charges that Ms. Myerson had a ''secret understanding'' with Justice Gabel to help Mr. Capasso in his divorce case. Under that agreement, the prosecution contends, Mrs. Gabel reduced Mr. Capasso's support payments to his estranged wife and two children after Ms. Myerson gave the judge's daughter, Sukhreet, a job on her staff.

title: Former Spy Chief Talks for Dukakis
description: Much like A.T.&T., the Dukakis campaign is telling reporters to pick up the phone and touch someone - in this case Adm. Stansfield Turner.

title: Time to Look at What We've Done to Nicaragua; It's in Bookstores
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Simple Wisdom From the Oracle of the Mets
description: BASEBALL is a cerebral game, certainly, one that in order to succeed takes much quarrying of the nooks and crannies of the noodle. And if there is a baseball player quicker to be contemplative, a ballplayer more ready to be ruminative, a player more eager to excavate the labyrinths of the brain than Keith Hernandez of the Mets, he doesn't come to mind.

title: Sheldon I. Kramer Executive, 51
description: Sheldon I. Kramer, the chief executive of Research Publications Inc., died of lung cancer Saturday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Quayle Getting His Big Chance To Clear Doubts
description: As a top official in Vice President Bush's campaign discussed Senator Dan Quayle recently, he struggled to explain several gaffes by the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, such as Mr. Quayle's declaration that he ''did not live in this century.''

title: Congress Deadlocks Again On Revising Clean Air Act
description: The last hope for Congressional action this year to overhaul the 1977 Clean Air Act disappeared today when the Senate's leading spokesman on environmental issues announced that he had abandoned months of negotiations with utility, environmental and union lobbyists on a compromise bill.

title: Sabonis Indecisive
description: Arvidas Sabonis, the 7-foot-4-inch Soviet center who was instrumental in his country's gold medal in basketball at the Seoul Olympic Games, will probably not join the Portland Trail Blazers of the National Basketball Association this season, Bucky Buckwalter, a vice president of the team, said. After watching the basketball competition at Seoul, South Korea, Buckwalter returned to Portland to report that the Soviets do not want to jeopardize Sabonis's future eligibility for Olympic competition, pending a vote by the Federation of International Basketball Associations in April. The federation is expected to allow professionals to be eligible for play in the Olympics.(AP)

title: Court Backs Media General
description: A stockholder's lawsuit against Media General Inc. involving the newspaper company's two-tiered stock structure was dismissed on Monday by a Federal judge. United States District Judge

title: Corrections
description: The ''At the Movies'' column in Weekend on Friday misidentified the actress co-starring with Fred Ward in ''Miami Blues.'' She is Jennifer Jason Leigh.

title: Georgetown Redefines Alumni Role
description: When does an alumni association best serve its alma mater: when it is part of the university's administration or when it is independent?

title: Ted Chin Wins Chronicle Job
description: Ted Chin & Company has been called on by Chronicle Publications, a division of the Prentice Hall Trade division of Simon & Schuster, to handle advertising for its two historical coffee-table books, ''Chronicle of the 20th Century,'' and the forthcoming ''Chronicle of America.'' The budget is $2 million. The client formerly used Hill & Knowlton, its public relations agency, for any trade and consumer advertising it did. The stepped-up consumer campaign will consist of TV, magazine and newspaper ads, scheduled to appear around Thanksgiving.

title: Book Notes
description: A Chinese Penguin

title: Review/Violin; Familiar Pieces, Familiarly
description: Victor Tretyakov, a one-time Tchaikovsky competition gold medalist, gave a recital of familiar works in familiar fashion at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon. Mr. Tretyakov possesses most of the emblematic virtues of today's preferred violinists: a muscular bowing arm that rarely tires, intonation that - with the help of liberal vibrato - is almost never off, a soberly energetic approach to music making that leads him not into bad taste.

title: Barneys to Build a Chain Of 100 Stores Nationally
description: Barneys New York said yesterday that it planned to build a national chain of up to 100 apparel stores, beginning with three new stores in the East.

title: Thrift Dismissed
description: Syd Thrift, who knew better than than anyone else - and was prone to boast of it - that his personal wheeling and dealing transformed the Pittsburgh Pirates from a last-place franchise near bankruptcy into a profitable contender in the National League East, was dismissed yesterday as general manager in a unanimous vote of the Pirates' 16-member board of directors. According to board members, Thrift's egotism knew few bounds and his reluctance to share credit with anyone else for the Pirates' resurgence galled most of his fellow executives. . . . Jimy Williams, who drew fire because of his fueding with the outfielder George Bell during the season, was rehired yesterday by the Toronto Blue Jays, who finished tied for third in the American League East. (AP)

title: Disabled Girl Wins Millions For Damage Suffered at Birth
description: An 8-year-old girl who is blind and suffers from brain damage and cerebral palsy was awarded more than $7 million in damages yesterday when a jury in Manhattan found that a city hospital was negligent during her birth.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Spy Satellite Reactor Now in a Safe Orbit, Its Trackers Report
description: Western officials are continuing to track the orbit of a nuclear reactor that once powered a Soviet spy satellite but have confirmed reports that there is no longer a danger of radioactive debris falling to earth.

title: Turkey Inflation Spurts
description: Turkey reported today that its inflation rate soared to an annual rate of 81.8 percent in September, prompting calls by bankers for action to bring it under control. The State Statistics Institute said retail prices rose 4.8 percent last month, after an increase of 3.4 percent in August.

title: I.B.M. Introduces Updated Program
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a new version of its DB2 mainframe database management program designed to allow information to be stored in many locations rather than on a central computer. But I.B.M. said the program would not be available for another year. The software will permit access to information stored on mainframe, mid-range and personal computers. DB2 will cost $108,000 to $223,550, the company said.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Clabir Corp. said it was in default on its 14 1/2 percent subordinated debentures due 2004, after not making a $1.02 million semiannual interest payment due Sept. 1. While it has sufficent funds to make the payment, it was unable to negotiate a satisfactory waiver with its banks of their rights under a provision of their credit agreement. Common Stock

title: Bias Ruling Curbs Employers
description: Employers may not dismiss women or refuse to hire them because of suspicion that their exposure to chemicals or radiation on the job may some day cause reproductive or fetal damage, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said Monday.

title: Bridge
description: Pride and sorrow are inspired by a new book, the ''1987 World Championships,'' which records the competition in Jamaica in which a United States team scored a double victory.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Advanced Semiconductor MaterialsInternational, the Netherlands, said it had sold its 50 percent stake in ASM Lithography N.V. to Philips N.V. Terms were not disclosed.

title: 2 Seeking Missing G.I.'s Are Seized in Laos
description: The police in Laos have seized two Americans who said they planned to distribute dollars stamped with a reward offer for any American military personnel held captive in Indochina.

title: Canseco Facing High Expectations
description: This is the sound of Jose Canseco's power:

title: For Red Sox Fans, Caution Amid Zeal
description: Sure, the city is excited about the Boston Red Sox.

title: For Japanese, A Book Drops A War Lesson
description: A textbook publisher has deleted a lesson describing Japanese brutality in World War II after protests from ruling party politicians.

title: Ripken Sr. to Return
description: Cal Ripken Sr., who was dropped as manager of the Baltimore Orioles on April 12 and was succeeded by Frank Robinson, will return in 1989 as the third-base coach. One day after dismissing four coaches and placing two pitchers - Don Aase and Doug Sisk - on waivers after a final record of 54-107, the worst in the franchise's history in Baltimore, the Orioles announced that the new coaching staff would consist of Elrod Hendricks, the lone holdover, plus Ripken Sr., Tom McCraw, Al Jackson and Johnny Oates. Dismissed yesterday were Terry Crowley, Herm Starrette, John Hart and Minnie Mendoza.(AP)

title: Calls to 150 Planes Disrupted as Rains Flood Phone Center
description: A regional air traffic control center covering an area stretching from Denver to Indianapolis lost contact with about 150 planes for 27 minutes when water flooded a communications center last week, officials of the Federal Aviation Administration say.

title: School District Study Finds That Bigger Is Not Better
description: Despite decades of school district mergers around the country, students perform better in smaller districts, a new study says.

title: Ex-Hostage Says Three Still Held Are 'O.K.'
description: An Indian citizen freed after more than 20 months of captivity in Lebanon said today that three Americans held with him were ''O.K.''

title: A Vote to End Asset Agency
description: The House Banking Committee voted, 42 to 8, today to abolish the much-criticized Federal agency created to manage and dispose of the assets of insolvent savings institutions.

title: Carl Reich, Hematologist, 88
description: Dr. Carl Reich, a physician and hematologist, died of heart failure Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Movement Is Seen in Southern Africa Talks
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that negotiations on the conflicts in Angola and Namibia were ''nearing success.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alfin Inc., a manufacturer of fragrances, appointed Martin D. Goldberg senior vice president, finance and operations, replacing Kenneth H. Landis, who resigned.

title: New Vending Machines to Elevate Snacking
description: The computer is moving into vending machines, and snacking in the workplace is going to become a more sophisticated affair.

title: McKesson-Alco Agreement Ended
description: The McKesson Corporation, the nation's largest wholesaler of drugs and toiletries, and the Alco Health Services Corporation said they had terminated their $500 million merger agreement because of Federal opposition. The Federal Trade Commission had authorized its staff to seek a court order to bar McKesson's purchase of Alco, based in Valley Forge, Pa., the nation's third-largest independent drug wholesaler.

title: Corrections
description: The Patents column in Business Day on Saturday misstated the uses of a removable orthodontic device.

title: Legal Gain By Suitor Of Irving
description: The Bank of New York Corporation yesterday won an important legal victory that dramatically improved its chances of acquiring the Irving Bank Corporation.

title: Stocks Continue Retreat as Dow Falls 3.20
description: The stock market yesterday repeated its moderately lower performance of Monday, although volume accelerated.

title: Program at Singer Nearly Completed
description: The Singer Company said it had ''essentially completed its divestiture program'' with the closing of the sale of its Kearfott Guidance and Navigation division to the Astronautics Corporation of America. Singer, based in Stamford, Conn., has sold 8 of its 12 operating units for a total of $1.94 billion, slightly more than what its chairman, Paul A. Bilzerian, paid last February to buy control of the military contractor.

title: Entire Dump Panel Resigns in a Protest
description: A panel named by Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke has resigned, saying he had ignored its recommendations on closing the Croton dump and had not kept the panel informed. A spokesman for Mr. O'Rourke, Jim Keller, said the panel tended toward secrecy and would not be replaced because its job was essentially complete.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Ciccarelli Signs
description: Dino Ciccarelli, who had been holding out for 24 days, agreed yesterday to a contract with the Minnesota North Stars, just three days before the team was to have begun assessing him $1,000 daily as a penalty. Ciccarelli gave his verbal approval to a contract negotiated during a four-hour meeting that included his agent, Ron Salcer; Jack Ferreira, the general manager, and Dean Lombardi, the assistant general manager. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed, but speculation in printed reports estimated it to be for a four-year pact with a salary of at least $300,000 a year, plus incentive bonuses.(AP)

title: Little Brother Watches
description: The tables are being turned on who is watching whom. When computers and satellites came into use, big governments got powerful new tools for keeping track of their citizens and each other. But the information explosion can work both ways.

title: Fryeburg Journal; A Fair That Still Caters to Farmers
description: Throughout New England, agriculture as a way of life has been fading, a casualty both of development pressure and the increasing difficulty of doing business in the 1980's.

title: Fleisher Finds a New Career
description: Larry Fleisher, who guided the National Basketball Players Association to the strongest position of any of the major sports unions, during his 27 years as its general counsel, will become a corporate vice president in charge of basketball operations for the International Management Group. I.M.G. is a worldwide organization that represents athletes in many sports.

title: Soviets Drop a Demand Blocking Arms Talks
description: The Soviet Union has withdrawn a demand that has held up new East-West talks on cutting conventional arms, Administration officials said today.

title: Review/Television; Building Bridges in Vienna '38
description: If you are not passionately interested in what the Vice-Presidential candidates have to say in their debate this evening, and if you have access to the pay-cable Disney Channel, consider watching ''A Friendship in Vienna'' at 9 o'clock. Going back 50 years to the Vienna of 1938 - the Vienna of an impending German occupation, the Anschluss - the film tells the story of an intense friendship between two young schoolgirls, one Jewish and the other Roman Catholic. Like ''The Diary of Anne Frank,'' a far more powerful predecessor, ''A Friendship in Vienna'' provides a glimpse of enormous tragedy through the eyes of participants at the edges of ordinary life.

title: Palestinian Is Reported Shot By a Suspected Collaborator
description: A Palestinian accused of collaborating with the Israeli authorities shot and seriously wounded another Arab in the occupied West Bank today, Arab hospital officials and witnesses said.

title: Three Posts at Justice Filled
description: The Senate voted today to confirm nominees for three top Justice Department posts. In voice votes, the Senate approved Harold G. Christensen as deputy attorney general; Frank Keating as associate attorney general, and Edward S. G. Dennis Jr., as an assistant attorney general in charge of the criminal division.

title: Postal Fraud Case Charges
description: Two top executives of Recognition Equipment Inc., a manufacturer of information processing equipment that has been under investigation for two and a half years by the United States Attorney's office in connection with a Postal Service bribery scheme, are expected to be indicted by Federal grand juries in Washington this week, the company said on Monday.

title: Botha's Black Africa Diplomacy Is Rebuffed by Zambian President
description: President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia, former chairman of a group of South Africa's black-governed neighbors, today rebuffed President P. W. Botha's recent efforts to widen diplomatic ccontacts in the region.

title: Reviews/Dance; Experiment and History At the Lyons Festival
description: The International Dance Biennale, which ends on Thursday, has spent more than three weeks here acting as a showcase for ''Four Centuries of Dance in France,'' the theme chosen for this year's festival by its director, Guy Darmet.

title: Poll Finds Increased Support For Nation's Space Program
description: Public support for the nation's space program has increased, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: 2 Companies Begin Silicon Chip Effort
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation and SGS-Thomson Microelectronics jointly entered the market for silicon chips for use in advanced telecommunications systems. The chips introduced under a technology agreement are to be used in telecommunications systems that are known as Integrated Services Digital Networks.

title: Ex-Delegate for Samoa Faces Prison Term
description: American Samoa's former delegate to Congress was sentenced to a prison term of 5 to 15 months today for participating in a payroll-padding scheme that prosecutors say earned him $39,000.

title: Moscow Asked to Review Solzhenitsyn Exile
description: The Union of Film Makers said today that it has asked the Government to review the legality of the 1974 deportation of Alexander Solzhenitsyn. Mr. Solzhenitsyn, the author and Nobel laureate, was deported and stripped of his Soviet citizenship after the publication in the West of ''The Gulag Archipelago,'' which documented political repression and life in Soviet prison camps.

title: The New York Times/CBS News Poll; The Vice-Presidential Candidates: Voters' Views Before the Debate
Wine Talk
description: ''I REALLY envy the French,'' the young woman said. ''All anyone has to do is just mention French wines and everyone assumes it's great. Most people don't even know about us.''

title: Boy, 6, Takes Car And Drives 5 Miles
description: A 6-year-old took his grandmother's Chrysler and drove five miles through two states in a rainstorm until being overtaken by a chiropractor who chased him. ''The kid was driving pretty doggone good,'' said the chiropractor, Lawrence Forgacs.

title: Economic Scene; Airline Fares: Problems Persist
description: ST. LOUIS travelers can fly on any airline they want - as long as it's Trans World Airlines.

title: The Bentsen-Quayle Question
description: All the advance sarcasm makes tonight's Vice-Presidential debate sound like a trivial TV game show. Can Dan Quayle walk and chew gum at the same time? Can Lloyd Bentsen keep America from falling asleep by 8:35? The wisecrackers miss the point, and so do the analysts waiting eagerly to pronounce a winner and a loser.

title: Strawberry Looks West
description: Darryl Strawberry was quoted today as saying he had decided ''it's time to go home'' and intended to leave the Mets when his contract ended after the 1990 season and would try to sign as a free agent with the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Hope Reborn in Haiti
description: Thanks largely to their own persistence, Haitians now have their best chance at real democracy in more than three decades. Cynical outsiders claimed Haiti was too poor and too-long misgoverned for there to be any realistic chance of that. But Haiti's democrats - strengthened by the refusal of countries like the U.S. to assist the military regime - never gave up. Now Washington can begin to think about resuming aid.

title: Hearty Food Without Skimping On Technique
description: PAULA WOLFERT knows that some people, even food people, are saying that cooking is done for. All over. Kaput. But she refuses to believe it. And she is so enthusiastic, so excitable, so passionate, that it does seem that if only she could talk to everyone, in person, well, there would be a rush to kitchen stoves and voluptuous, aromatic meals would begin appearing.

title: Pentagon Keeps Silent On Stealth Plane Details
description: The Pentagon, turning a poorly kept secret into a public relations fumble, refused today to discuss details about its Stealth fighter, even after a draft press release on the plane had leaked to a newspaper and a Republican Senator had scheduled a news conference on the subject.

title: Myerson Trial Gets Account Of Conspiracy
description: A prosecutor's opening statement portrayed Bess Myerson yesterday as a glamorous and greedy public official who took part in a corrupt conspiracy to fix her companion's divorce case.

title: Dr. Harold Brown, 86, Parasitology Professor
description: Dr. Harold W. Brown, a professor emeritus of parasitology at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, died of a heart attack Monday at St. John's Riverside Hospital in Yonkers. He was 86 years old and lived in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: From Argentina, How 6 Polish Jews Hid From the Nazis
description: ''Debajo del Mundo'' (''Under the World'') exists in dangerous artistic territory. The film is based on a true story, of Polish Jews who in 1942 escaped to a makeshift hovel dug underground in the woods. For the next two years the family of six moved from one squalid catacomb to another. This subject comes so loaded with emotional power that one dishonest scene could send the film careening into cheapened sentiment, manipulation or self-righteousness. But the exceptional achievement of ''Debajo del Mundo'' is to display the ugly truth - these hunted people could not take eating or breathing for granted - with a brutal honesty that is enhanced, not evaded, by gracefully composed visual images.

title: Many Minority Teachers Plan to Quit, Poll Finds
description: Despite a noticeable improvement in their salaries and morale in recent years, a substantial number of teachers plan to quit teaching within five years, especially young teachers and black and Hispanic teachers, according to a new national survey.

title: As the Object of Slurs, WASP's Are Latecomers
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Jeffrey Avison has been named vice president, marketing, at Wilkinson Sword USA, Atlanta.

title: INSIDE
description: Cleopatra's Other Side

title: Trial in Air Crash Resumes
description: A Federal trial over a 1985 Delta Air Lines crash that killed 137 people resumed Monday after being in recess since August. At stake in the nonjury trial before Federal District Judge David O. Belew Jr. are more than $100 million in claims from survivors and relatives of victims. Delta wants the Government to pay part of the claims and the cost of replacing the jet destroyed in the crash at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport. If Judge Belew rules that the Government should share blame, a trial will determine how much it should pay.

title: Private Hospitals Planning Staff Cuts
description: Rising wages, high capital costs and low Medicaid reimbursement rates have forced some private, nonprofit hospitals in New York City to seek ways to slash their payrolls, administrators and health experts say.

title: Caution on Trade Offer
description: The European Community gave a cautious response today to a United States offer to discuss short-term measures on world agriculture reform. A spokeswoman for the European Commission, acting for the European Community, said that, while the community welcomed any effort to undertake short-term reforms in agriculture, the American offer would have to be studied to ''see what the U.S. position means.'' The offer, seen as an apparent effort to unblock the current impasse in the Uruguay Round of trade liberalization talks, was made at a meeting of trade ministers in Pakistan.

title: J. Ralph Corbett, 91; Executive Aided Arts
description: J. Ralph Corbett, a a patron of the arts who was founder of the Nutone Company, manufacturer of electrical door chimes, died Monday at a Cincinnati nursing home after a long illness. He was 91 years old and lived in Cincinnati.

title: NBC Worker Buyout Seen
