description: Continuing a cost-reduction drive that has already eliminated hundreds of jobs, NBC will offer a buyout plan to 140 employees as an enticement to leave the company, network executives said yesterday.

title: 135 Lands Violate Human Rights, Amnesty International Declares
description: Amnesty International asserted today that 135 nations committed human rights abuses in the last year, ranging from the jailing of draft resisters in Western Europe to the massacre of unarmed civilians in Iraq and the Sudan.

title: G.E. Sets Plans To Invest in Spain
description: The General Electric Company plans to invest $1.7 billion over 10 to 15 years in a new silicon and plastics plant to be built at Cartagena, in southeastern Spain. Ignacio Trillo, the chairman of G.E.'s Spanish subsidiary, said the Spanish Government would subsidize 30 percent of the value of the investment and would provide a free 1,680-acre site for the new factory.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''God willing, the warrior Iranian people will maintain their revolutionary and sacred rancor and anger in their hearts and use their oppressor-burning flames against the criminal Soviet Union and the world-devouring United States and their surrogates.'' - Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. [ A1:1. ]

title: Britain Acts to Force Kuwait To Lower Holdings in B.P.
description: The British Government today ordered the Kuwait Investment Office to cut its holdings in the British Petroleum Company by more than half.

title: Lessons
description: When it comes to the humanities, American colleges and universities seem to be shooting themselves in the foot.

title: Princeton/Newport Asset Freeze Backed
description: A Federal district judge said yesterday that the Government may freeze the assets of a New Jersey investment partnership even though the firm has not been charged with wrongdoing.

title: 'Massachusetts Miracle' - or Mirage?
description: LEAD: I have never been a believer in the Massachusetts Miracle.But last month, Gov. Michael

title: 'Poor Seoul,' Los Angeles Says Smugly
description: The Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, never quite achieved orbit. We just never got caught up in them, neither the South Koreans, who stayed away from their own Games, nor the television audience in this country. I even heard curmudgeonly grumbles from people during the two Olympic weeks, an impatient ''when is this finally going to be over?''

title: Food Notes
description: Dean & DeLuca Moves

title: On Keeping Kosher
description: To The Living Section:

title: EX-NUCLEAR AIDES DENY BEING TOLD OF PLANT MISHAPS
description: Top officials of the defunct Atomic Energy Commission said today that they were never informed of serious reactor accidents at the Savannah River Plant. They suggested that the incidents had been kept secret by local managers because of national security concerns about publicizing America's problems producing atomic weapons.

title: Afghan Rebel Attack Kills 5
description: Guerrillas fighting the Soviet-backed Government in Afghanistan shelled the eastern town of Gardez, killing five people and wounding four, the official Kabul Radio said today. The radio, monitored in Islamabad, Pakistan, said 31 houses and 11 shops were damaged in the attack Monday on Gardez, the capital of Paktia Province, which shares a border with Pakistan.

title: Hot Dog an Immigrant
description: To the Editor:

title: Sun-Times Strike Vote
description: The editorial staff at The Chicago Sun-Times voted Monday to authorize a strike after the newspaper's management proposed to cut salaries by 10 percent.

title: Classic Confrontation For Quayle at Penn
description: ''Quayle, Quayle, Quayle.''

title: Time to Look at What We've Done to Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: California's Anti-AIDS Quackery
description: LEAD: Two Novembers ago, by a margin of better than 2 to 1, California voters said no to an AIDS initiative proposed by the political extremist Lyndon LaRouche. Proposition 64 called for testing - and, according to some, quarantining - the estimated quarter of a million Californians with the virus.

title: The Pop Life
description: The Political Browne

title: A Virginian's Boston Barbecue
description: CHRIS SCHLESINGER is the first to admit that he does not have the best barbecue in the Boston area. The atmosphere of his brand new takeout place is not grungy enough to qualify, even if the food is authentic.

title: Robert L. Yeager, 81, Pulmonary Specialist
description: Dr. Robert L. Yeager, a specialist in the treatment of pulmonary diseases and the head of the health center bearing his name in Pomona, N.Y., died of spine and bone cancer at Summit Park Hospital in Pomona. He was 81 years old and lived in Pomona.

title: About Real Estate; South Bronx Retail Project Finally Moves Ahead
description: Nearly 15 years after Mayor Abraham Beame ceremoniously turned the earth on a vacant city-owned lot at 156th Street and Third Avenue in the South Bronx to signal a commitment to the development of a supermarket and shopping center in the troubled area, the site remains nothing more than two acres of dirt.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The House upheld President Reagan's veto of import limits on textiles, apparel and shoes. The 272-to-152 vote fell 11 short of an override. Vice President Bush and Senator Dan Quayle have opposed the bill. The Democratic Presidential candidate, Michael S. Dukakis, has not taken a public position on the measure, but his running mate, Lloyd Bentsen, supports it. [ Page A1. ] A roll call of the House vote. [ B5. ] Auto makers had their third-best year ever. Strong late-September sales resulted in total model-year deliveries of 15.6 million vehicles. Sales of imported vehicles fell 7.5 percent. [ D1. ] The Government may freeze Princeton/Newport's assets, even though the firm has not been charged, a Federal judge said. [ D7. ] COMPANIES Kohlberg, Kravis raised its bid for Kroger to $64 a share, or about $5.03 billion. The Haft family had offered $55 a share. [ D1. ] Pillsbury moved to defend itself after receiving a surprise hostile takeover offer from Grand Metropolitan. The food company said it had sued Grand Met, a British conglomerate, in 13 states, accusing it of violating state liquor laws. Pillsbury's stock jumped $18, to $57, in response to the $60-a-share offer. [ D1. ] Bank of New York won a legal victory that dramatically improves its chances of acquiring Irving Bank. [ D1. ] Continental and S.A.S. agreed to link flights. The move will bring many more international arrivals to Newark airport. [ B1. ] Macmillan's board did not know that the company's management had told Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts of a rival bid by Maxwell Communications, according to court papers. [ D21. ] Barneys New York plans to build a national chain of up to 100 stores, concentrating on high-quality women's clothing. [ D4. ] Analysts were baffled by a jump in Manville's stock price, saying that investors may not realize how much the stock will be diluted under a reorganization plan. [ D5. ] LTV plans to auction its bar-steel division. Analysts said the operations might sell for up to $250 million. [ D4. ] A consumer group will resume a boycott of Nestle and American Home Products over the promotion of infant formula. [ D2. ] NBC will offer buyouts to 140 technicians as an enticement to leave the company. [ D21. ] MARKETS The oil markets reacted calmly to a Saudi warning that it would not allow other producers to increase output and encroach on its market share. [ D1. ] The dollar was mixed, as were gold prices. Gold rose to $398.10 an ounce on the Comex, up 60 cents. [ D16. ] Stocks dipped again as volume rose. The Dow Jones industrials dropped 3.20 points, to 2,102.06. [ D10. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed. [ D19. ] TECHNOLOGY Kodak will introduce a new, sharper color film aimed at photo enthusiasts. Analysts were quick to praise the film. [ D1. ] The computer is moving into vending machines, bringing sophistication to on-the-job snacking. [ D9. ] INTERNATIONAL Kuwait was ordered to reduce its stake in British Petroleum. Britain's Monopolies and Mergers Commission said the 21.68 percent holding might be contrary to the public interest. [ D8. ] Japan responded to criticism of its foreign debt plan. [ D2. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Pillsbury may have to seek a friendly suitor to defend itself against Grand Met. Market Place. [ D10. ] Several actions could be taken to spur competition among airlines in hub cities. Peter Passell. Economic Scene. [ D2. ]

title: Mets Bring Hershiser's Streak to a Crashing Halt
description: In one dramatic burst of three runs in the ninth inning tonight, the Mets not only ended Orel Hershiser's extraordinary streak of shutout pitching after 67 innings but roared on to upset the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3-2, in the opening game of the playoff for the National League pennant.

title: Bra Burnings, Gray Hair, Other Illusions
description: To the Editor:

title: Saudi Threat To Raise Oil Output
description: In its toughest statement about oil policy in years, Saudi Arabia has warned Iran, Iraq and other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to restrain their oil production or face financial ruin.

title: Fallon McElligott Wins Minnetonka Unit's Job
description: Fragrance Marketing Group, a subsidiary of the Minnetonka Corp., Minnetonka, Minn., has named Fallon McElligott, Minneapolis, to look after its Foltene hair care and Claire Burke home fragrance product lines. The combined billings for both products, formerly handled in-house, came to about $4.75 million last year. A new budget has not been disclosed. A new consumer and trade print campaign for Foltene, a line of therapeutic products for thinning hair, is scheduled to begin in March; with print advertising for Claire Burke to begin later in 1989.

title: How Boston and Oakland Compare
description: RED SOX Catchers(Average, home runs, runs batted in) 10Rich Gedman(.231, 9, 39) Once a solid offensive player with good power but has slipped noticeably in last two seasons. Still, has strong arm behind plate and will keep Canseco honest on bases. 6Rick Cerone(.269, 3, 27) Picked up after his release by Yankees in April and made significant contributions with bat. Infielders(Pos., avg., h.r., r.b.i) 38Todd Benzinger(1b, .254, 13, 70) A switch-hitter who will probably face only right-handers. Defense is so-so. 25Larry Parrish(1b, .217, 14, 52) Late acquisition after he was released by Texas Rangers. Will share duties with Benzinger at first. 17Marty Barrett(2b, .283, 1, 65) Teams don't notice he's there until he beats them, and he has that ability. Will bat second in order behind Boggs and can move runners over exceptionally well. 26Wade Boggs(3b, .366, 5, 58) Best hitter in game. Won his fourth straight batting title and collected at least 200 hits for sixth consecutive season. 3Jody Reed(ss, .293, 1, 28) Benefited most when Joe Morgan took over as manager. Moved into starting spot and produced enough to become legitimate rookie-of-year candidate. Superb offensive player, but his defense sometimes can hurt. Outfielders(Pos., avg., h.r., r.b.i.) 39Mike Greenwell(lf, .325, 22, 119) Had Canseco not had his big year, Greenwell would surely be league's most valuable player. Defense can be spotty, even scary. 12Ellis Burks(cf, .294, 18, 92) Considered superb athlete with average arm, although he covers ground well in Fenway. Led Boston with 25 stolen bases and hit almost .500 with bases loaded. 24Dwight Evans(rf, .293, 21, 111) Although he turns 37 next month, is still among most productive players in league with 55 homers and 234 r.b.i. in last two seasons. Knows nuances of Fenway. Designated Hitter(Avg., h.r., r.b.i.) 14Jim Rice(.264, 15, 72) His bat has slowed and his power has diminished, but he remains dangerous. Starting Pitchers(Record, e.r.a.) 47Bruce Hurst(18-6, 3.66) Why is he starting Game 1? He was 13-2 at Fenway this season and had 11-2 record after Red Sox losses. Lost his only start against A's this season. 21Roger Clemens(18-12, 2.93) Struggled at times because of injuries. Worked 264 innings and led league with 291 strikeouts. When he's on, his fastball is unhittable. 52Mike Boddicker(13-15, 3.39) Came to Boston in late July trade and finished with 7-3 record, solidfying Red Sox staff. 44Wes Gardner(8-6, 3.50) Former Met who blossomed into starter. Could start if Red Sox are ahead after first three games. Relievers(Record, e.r.a., saves) 48Lee Smith(4-5, 2.80, 29) His acquisition by Red Sox last winter was organization's key move. Although he struggled at times, was still formidable in late innings. 46Bob Stanley(6-4, 3.19, 5) Has come back a long way from last season, when he lost 15 games and had no saves. 15Dennis Lamp(7-6, 3.48, 0) Spent part of August on disabled list with muscle strain in right elbow. 41Mike Smithson(9-6, 5.97, 0) Started 18 games at end of season, but usually gives up the big one: allowed 25 home runs, tops among Boston pitchers. Reserves(Pos., avg., h.r., r.b.i.) 7Spike Owen(ss, .249, 5, 18) Lost his job to Reed at the All-Star break. Played in just 89 games but hit .429 in 1986 playoffs. 11Ed Romero(.240, 0, 5) Veteran who can help when he's called on, although it probably won't happen in post-season. 16Kevin Romine(.192, 1, 6) Isn't likely to play, unless it's as pinch-runner. Manager 35Joe Morgan Took over during break for All-Star Game when John McNamara was dismissed. Made number of changes that took effect and turned Red Sox around. Club was 46-31 in his tenure after 12-0 start. ATHLETICS Catchers(Average, home runs, runs batted in) 6Terry Steinbach(.265, 9, 51) He was the unlikely m.v.p. of this year's All-Star Game, but his home run production dropped from 16 to 9. 4Ron Hassey(.257, 7, 45) He returned from knee surgery and was surprisingly able to platoon with Steinbach. 11Matt Sinatro(.333, 0, 5) He played in only 10 games and batted 9 times for the A's. Infielders(Pos., avg., h.r., r.b.i.) 25Mark McGwire(1b, .260, 32, 99) He was a home-run hitting sensation as 1987 rookie of the year, but he couldn't match his 1987 output of 49 home runs and 118 r.b.i. Nevertheless, he's a charter member of the team's Big Bashers. 9Mike Gallego(2b, .209, 2, 20) He played second, short and third and batted more times than he had collectively in playing parts of three seasons. His success, though, did not surpass his previous efforts. 7Walter Weiss(ss, .250, 3, 39) A's traded Alfredo Griffin to make room for the rookie, and he responded by handling the job capably all season. 4Carney Lansford(3b, .279, 7, 57) Early in June, he was hitting .402, but his average dropped more precipitously than the stock market a year ago. Outfielders(Pos, avg., h.r., r.b.i.) 33Jose Canseco(rf, .307, 42, 124) First player to hit 40 home runs and steal 40 bases. Led the league in r.b.i. and home runs. 42Dave Henderson(cf, .304, 24, 94) With fourth team in the past three years, he responded with the best season of his career. 2Tony Phillips(lf, .203, 2, 17) He has played three infield positions as well as platooning in left field, but has hit poorly all season. Designated Hitters(Avg., h.r., r.b.i.) 39Dave Parker(.257, 12, 55) A torn thumb ligament undermined his contribution, forcing him to miss seven weeks in July and August. 12Don Baylor(.220, 7, 34) He is four victories away from playing in the World Series for the third successive season with three different teams. Starting Pitchers(Record, e.r.a.) 34Dave Stewart(21-12, 3.23) He is the only pitcher in the majors to have 20-victory seasons in 1987 and 1988. 35Bob Welch(17-9, 3.64) He established a career high for victories, but won only twice in last five weeks. 14Storm Davis(16-7, 3.70) A flop with San Diego last year, he regained the effectiveness that once earned him comparisons with Jim Palmer. 29Curt Young(11-8, 4.14) Only left-hander in starting rotation. He had arm trouble in July and August, but after his return, he gained six victories in seven decisions. Relief Pitchers(Record, e.r.a., saves) 43Dennis Eckersley(4-2, 2.35, 45) Becoming a reliever last season after 12 years as a starter, he has developed into the league's premier closer. 40Rick Honeycutt(3-2, 3.50, 7) Whatever else he does, he will be remembered for being caught in 1980 with a thumbtack taped to his finger. 54Todd Burns(8-2, 3.16, 1) A rookie, he became the fifth starter early in July, but is expected to be used in relief. 51Eric Plunk(7-2, 3.00, 5) He, too, has gone from starter to reliever. 19Gene Nelson(9-6, 3.06, 3) Has finally become a good long reliever and had his most effective performance this season. 32Greg Cadaret(5-2, 2.89, 3) A left-hander, he was the team's second-busiest reliever, appearing in only two fewer games than Eckersley. Reserves(Pos., avg, h.r., r.b.i.) 28Stan Javier(of/1b, .257, 2, 35) Son of the former major leaguer Julian Javier. He was successful on 20 of 21 stolen-base attempts. 22Luis Polonia(lf, .292, 2, 27) A switch-hitter. He is not talented defensively, although he has improved. Manager 10Tony LaRussa In his ninth season as a major league manager, his third with Oakland, he led his team to his best record ever (104-57). The Chicago White Sox won the American League West title under him in 1983 with 99 victories.

title: Emerson Electric Elects
description: The Emerson Electric Company said today that it had elected James F. Hardymon, a 27-year veteran of the company, to be its new president. Mr. Hardymon, who had been vice chairman, will retain his responsibilities as chief operating officer. Mr. Hardymon, 53 years old, joined Emerson's Browning Manufacturing division in 1961. He became executive vice president in 1983 and was elected to the board of directors and named vice chairman in 1987.

title: Dow Chemical Names Anderson & Lembke
description: The Dow Chemical Company, Midland, Mich., has chosen Anderson & Lembke, Stamford, Conn., to handle three divisions of its newly organized plastics group. The business-to-business and corporate ad budget exceeds $5 million.

title: In Milan, Flamboyance Takes Back Seat
description: The spring and summer clothes introduced here this week are neither aggressively masculine nor flamboyantly feminine. It is not a time for stormy fashion messages.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: I HAVE a lot of fun experimenting with variations on classic recipes. Take, for example, veal Pojarski. The standard recipe calls for cutting up veal and blending it with butter, seasonings and bread soaked in milk, then sauteeing it in clarified butter.

title: 10 Die and Dozens Missing As Storm Hits City in France
description: A rainstorm that hit this southern city has killed at least 10 people and dozens more are missing, rescue workers said today.

title: Opinion Is Sought in Drexel Case
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan yesterday asked that the Securities and Exchange Commission give its opinion about conflict of interest charges leveled against a judge in the securities fraud case against Drexel Burnham Lambert.

title: Time to Look at What We've Done to Nicaragua; Right to Know
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY RATES
Buyout Bid For Kroger Increased
description: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, a specialist in leveraged buyouts, said yesterday that it had raised its bid for the Kroger Company, the nation's second-largest operator of supermarkets, to $64 a share, or about $5.03 billion.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: MUCH to his mother's dismay, Karl Beckley, the chef and owner of the Green Lake Grill in Seattle, has come to the conclusion that he is adopted. ''Karl thinks he's an Elvis love child,'' said Mr. Beckley's brother Keith. ''He's threatening to write a book.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Steffi Graff, the winner of the tennis Grand Slam and an Olympic gold medal, is among the first to qualify for the $1 million Virginia Slims Championships Nov. 14-20 at Madison Square Garden. Also qualifying for the 16-woman field were Martina Navratilova, Chris Evert and Gabriela Sabatini. . . . The New York Road Runners Club announced yesterday that Sebastian Coe and Steve Ovett of Britain will compete in the seventh annual Mercedes Mile on Fifth Avenue on Oct. 15. . . . Cale Yarborough, the only stock car driver to win three straight Winston Cup titles, said he would retire at the end of the season. . . . Randy Lanier, 1986 Indianapolis 500 rookie of the year, was found guilty by a Federal jury yesterday of running a multimillion-dollar drug-smuggling operation. . . . Roy Jones Jr., the boxer who lost the gold medal in the most controversial match of the Summer Olympics, will turn pro, according his father, Roy Jones Sr., a former professional boxer. ''I know that for a fact,'' the senior Jones said. ''My son won't fight amateur again.''(AP)

title: Obsolete Bases, Modernized Benefits
description: With the Congressional session waning fast, lawmakers find two worthy bills tantalizingly close to passage.

title: American League; Hurst To Open Against Stewart
description: The ground ball that rolled through Bill Buckner's legs two autumns ago has not faded from memory. Red Sox fans can still see it - every painful moment of it -and now, they suddenly see redemption.

title: House Upholds Textile-Bill Veto By Close Margin
description: In a major victory for the Administration, the House today upheld President Reagan's veto of legislation setting limits on imports of textiles, apparel and shoes.

title: Sergei A. Losev, 61; The Director of Tass, Dies in Soviet Union
description: Sergei A. Losev, general director of the official Soviet press agency Tass, died suddenly at age 61, the agency announced here today.

title: IRAN WILL NOT RELY ON U.S. OR SOVIETS, KHOMEINI DECLARES
description: In a statement on Iran's postwar policies, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini has called on the Iranian people to rebuild the country without relying on either the Soviet Union or the United States.

title: LTV Plans to Auction Its Bar-Steel Division
description: The LTV Corporation said today that it planned to auction its bar-steel division, a profitable operation with nine plants that produce about 10 percent of the company's annual steel output, or about 1.2 million tons.

title: For Busy Traders, Lunch Is a Moveable Feast
description: LEAD: SHORTLY after noon, Ronald Howard, a deliveryman, wheeled an insulated food cabinet the size of two refrigerators onto the over-the-counter trading floor of Shearson Lehman Hutton.

title: Color Is Sharper In New Film Line Offered by Kodak
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it would soon market a line of film that offers the finest grain, sharpness and color of any film it has produced.

title: Microwave Cooking
description: FEW of us find time any more - if we ever did - to put food up for the winter, but the microwave oven can bring home-canned treats back into our lives, quickly and well.

title: A Better-Than-Expected '88 For Sales of U.S. Vehicles
description: Strong auto sales in late September closed the 1988 model year on a solid note. Americans bought 15.6 million vehicles in the year, making it the third-best year ever.

title: Lawyers for Davis Expected to Start Defense Today
description: The defense is expected to begin its case today after a dramatic conclusion this week to more than two months of testimony by prosecution witnesses in the trial of Larry Davis in the attempted murder of nine police officers.

title: Micron Stake Agreement Set
description: Amstrad P.L.C., a leading British manufacturer of personal computers, has agreed to pay $75 million for 9.8 percent of Micron Technology Inc., a maker of computer memory chips based in Boise, Idaho.

title: Friendly Skies
description: Somewhere over Nebraska, Representative Norman Mineta emerged from the cockpit of a DC-10 last Saturday, on a United Air Lines flight from Washington to San Francisco.

title: LATEST POLL FINDS DUKAKIS IS CLOSING THE GAP WITH BUSH
description: Michael S. Dukakis, helped by traditional Democrats and by widespread public skepticism about Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana, is closing in on Vice President Bush, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Boycott of Nestle to Resume
description: A consumer group said today that it would resume a boycott of Nestle S.A. because of its promotion of infant formula. The boycott would also be extended to the American Home Products Corporation.

title: Accord at Marriott
description: Three airline companies in the Persian Gulf have signed an agreement with the Marriott Corporation to buy 50 percent of its catering service at Heathrow Airport in London. The new company, the Marriott-GCC Inflight Catering Service Company, will build a new kitchen at Heathrow to provide food according to Moslem rules. Marriott, which has about 100 airport outlets worldwide, caters to nine airlines at Heathrow, and officials hope the Islamic kitchen will attract Moslem carriers.

title: Health Insurance Is Offered By County to All Residents
description: One million residents and workers in an affluent county near the nation's capital are now eligible to obtain insurance that will cover up to $1 million of the costs of catastrophic illnesses under a plan initiated by the county.

title: Citicorp Sale Of Paper Mixed
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday at Citicorp's regular weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

title: Fannie May Is Offering Debt Of $500 Million Due in 1993
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association is offering, through various securities dealers, $500 million of indexed sinking-fund debentures due in 1993 at a price of par.

title: Space Shuttle Now Faces Stiff Test
description: The space shuttle Discovery came through the rigors of launching and flight in excellent shape, officials reported today, but getting it ready to fly again on schedule will be a severe test critical to future space operations.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: NEW Mexicans love their chili.

title: 2 Princeton Clubs to Get New Sex-Bias Hearings
description: An appeals court ruled today that two all-male eating clubs at Princeton University did not get a fair hearing when they were found guilty of discriminating against women by the State Division on Civil Rights in 1987, and ordered the case reopened.

title: Hilton Offering 10-Year Notes
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation is offering $100 million of 9 3/4 percent notes due in 1998 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: PTL Reports Deal of $115 Million for Assets
description: A month after Jim Bakker failed in efforts to return to its helm, the PTL ministry announced today that it had negotiated a sale of its assets for $115 million to a Canadian businessman.

title: Acquisition in Korea For the Ogilvy Group
description: Ogilvy Group Inc. has set up a South Korean branch by buying a 30 percent stake in Korad, one of the country's largest ad agencies, with $100 million in billings. The price was not disclosed.

title: Exiled Iranian President Connects Both Candidates to Hostage Talks
description: Former President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr of Iran said today that representatives of both American Presidential candidates have been to Iran for talks and that an aide to Vice President Bush conducted secret negotiations on the release of Americans held hostage in Lebanon.

title: Florida Picks Senate Nominee
description: Representative Kenneth (Buddy) MacKay today captured the Democratic Senate nomination over Florida's Insurance Commissioner, Bill Gunter, in the runoff of their heated contest. Mr. MacKay will oppose the Republican candidate, Representative Connie Mack 3d, in November.

title: KENYA THREATENS TO CURB CHURCHES
description: The Secretary General of Kenya's sole political party has warned that Parliament may abolish the constitutional guarantee of freedom of worship.

title: Cone's Brilliance Puts Luster on Trade
description: ''I hear the Mets are calling it 'the steal of the century,' '' said John Schuerholz, the general manager of the Kansas City Royals, who made the deal. ''Well, considering how it's turned out so far, I suppose that's a fair assessment.''

title: At the Nation's Table
description: FOR those who shy away from Cajun food because they find it too hot, a visit to La Trouvaille comes as a delightfully mild surprise.

title: Facing Up to School Phobia and Dealing With It
description: For some youngsters, just showing up in school is a striking achievement.

title: House Extends Job Bias Protection To Its Own Workers, With Limits
description: The House of Representatives today extended the same protection against job discrimination to its own employees that most American workers received 24 years ago, but with a few major exceptions.

title: DETROIT CATHOLICS WARY ON CLOSINGS
description: With 43 of the Roman Catholic churches here designated by the archdiocese for closing, people at some of those churches were planning resistance today while a group of black clergy were saying the consolidation could provide added resources to help the city's majority black population.

title: 2 Bushes on the Stump: One Tough, the Other Gentle
description: First, there was the harsh George Bush, who slashed his Democratic opponent on such issues as the Pledge of Allegiance and the American Civil Liberties Union. Then there was the gentle George Bush, the candidate who talked about the romance of space exploration and the tragedy of a two-tiered America where the well-heeled often ignore the poor.

title: Memorial to the Slave Trade Planned for Senegal
description: A memorial to the slave trade and an adjoining conference center are to be erected in the West African nation of Senegal at a cost of $500 million, Senegalese officials here say.

title: Natasha Richardson, on Portraying Patty Hearst
description: She is abducted at gunpoint, she is beaten, she is harangued by murderous ideologists. She is blindfolded, bound, imprisoned in a closet, and threatened with execution. She is confined until she is too weak to stand, forced to make tape-recordings praising her captors, and then she is raped.

title: U.S. Notes and Bonds Mark Time
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed yesterday, although some dealers reported that trading was a bit more brisk than in recent sessions.

title: Ozzie Smith Sued
description: Agents who negotiated a contract for the St. Louis Cardinals shortstop, Ozzie Smith, one of the highest-paid baseball players, filed a Federal lawsuit yesterday charging that he owes them more than $300,000 in commissions.

title: In Newark, Airport to Go International
description: Newark International Airport is poised to become a major international-arrivals port under an alliance announced yesterday by the Texas Air Corporation and the Scandinavian Airlines System.

title: Lone Star Tastes
description: Chateau Pecos, anyone?

title: Leander Perez Jr. Is Dead at 68
description: Leander Perez Jr., a former District Attorney who lost his father's legacy of power in Plaquemines Parish in fights with his brother, died of a heart attack today. He was 68 years old.

title: Tablets Found in Baby Food
description: Two white tablets, turned in by a Long Island woman who said they had been found in a jar of baby food, were being tested today at a police laboratory, but investigators said there was no evidence of widespread tampering.

title: Chase Expects Loan Losses
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said today that it expected nonperforming loans in Argentina to reduce its third-quarter after-tax earnings by about $18 million.

title: A Bush Man Slips Behind Enemy Lines
description: Into this enemy heartland rode Ron Kaufman, Northeast political director of the Bush campaign, early yesterday morning. He looked up and saw hundreds of potential voters standing, shivering, in line at the Boston Garden waiting to buy Celtics tickets. It was the first day tickets for individual games were on sale.

title: Nissan Expects Flat U.S. Sales
description: The Nissan Motor Corporation said it expected American sales of its cars and trucks to be flat in the 1989 model year, despite its plans to introduce four new or restyled models. Company executives acknowledged that Nissan's name recognition among buyers is still lower than recognition of the automaker's old Datsun name, which was dropped six years ago.

title: The Dukakis Inaugural
description: My countrymen:

title: 2 Put on Leave At Sunstrand
description: The Sundstrand Corporation placed two officers on administrative leave and reassigned a third today, as Government investigations continued into reported company overcharges on military contracts.

title: Anatomy of a Takeover
description: Tracking the Bank of New York's hostile takeover bid for control of Irving Bank Corp.: Sept. 25, 1987: Bank of New York makes an unsolicited $1.4 billion cash-stock bid for Irving. Oct. 9: Irving's board rejects the bid, and activates the company's ''poison pill'' anti-takeover defense. Nov. 20: Bank of New York lowers its offer to $1.2 billion, reflecting the Oct. 19 stock market crash. Feb. 25, 1988: Bank of New York's takeover proposal gets approval from the Federal Reserve and New York State Banking Boards. April 18: Banca Commerciale Italiana offers to buy 51 percent of Irving as part of a major financial restructuring by Irving that it values at $1.1 billion to $1.2 billion. The two revise the proposed deal several times in the following weeks, raising its estimated value to $1.4 billion. May 6: Irving's shareholders re-elect Irving's directors, although Bank of New York challenges the proxy results in court. July 6: A New York State court strikes down a provision of Irving's poison pill. Irving says it will appeal. Aug. 19: The Fed rules that the Italian Government agency that owns most of Banca Commerciale has to supply financial information in the Irving bid. Aug. 29: Banca Commerciale withdraws its bid. Oct. 4: The New York State Supreme Court's Appellate Division upholds the lower court ruling that struck down a part of Irving's poison pill. Oct. 5: Irving announces its chairman now supports a revised $1.5 billion merger proposal by Bank of New York.

title: Dr. George Hatem Is Dead at 78; Leader in Public Health in China
description: Dr. George Hatem, who under the name Ma Haide became an almost legendary figure in China for his public health efforts, died on Sunday in a Beijing hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: Winn-Dixie Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 21
Reviews/Music; Estonian's Christian Mass
description: Trinity College has discovered for American ears Vitaly Gewicksmann, a 64-year-old Estonian composer whose Christian Mass ''Duodecim Cantica'' was sung by the Citysingers of Hartford at Trinity's chapel Sunday afternoon. It is not surprising that Mr. Gewicksmann's liturgical format has found no favor in a country where atheism is national policy. This apparently has a particular resonance for a small Episcopal school operating in a country founded on religious freedom. At any rate, the score of ''Duodecim Cantica,'' which was withdrawn from a performance in Moscow eight years ago, found its way through intermediaries to Hartford, and presumably because of the effects of glasnost Mr. Gewicksmann himself was present on Sunday.

title: The Boston at Carnegie
description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Seiji Ozawa, is to begin a series of concerts at Carnegie Hall next Wednesday at 8 P.M. with a performance of Mahler's Ninth Symphony. The concert is to be repeated next Thursday, also at 8 P.M. A Brahms program is also scheduled by the orchestra at Carnegie Hall on March 1 and 2, with Maurizio Pollini as the piano soloist.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My 18-year-old house has aluminum siding that I would like to paint. I know the siding should be washed first, but is power-washing by machine required, or can I just scrub by hand? Also, what kind of paint should I use, and is a special undercoat required? A.As long as you get most of the dust and dirt off, it does not matter what method is used to clean the siding. Scrubbing by hand with a detergent is usually adequate. Most good-quality exterior latex house paints are suitable for use on aluminum siding; just be sure you check the label before you buy. Most do not require a separate undercoat, but again you should read the directions on the label to make certain. Q. The previous owner of my house put plastic sheets on the inside of the windows during winter. They were held up with a double-stick tape, and now there is sticky glue as well as pieces of the tape left on the wood frames. We have tried bleach, alcohol and scraping, but nothing has worked. Other than stripping everything off with remover, what can we do? A. A solvent that usually works on sticky residue is rubber-cement thinner, sold in art-supply and stationery stores. Heating the area with a hair dryer also helps, especially if you rub it with a coarse rag while it is still soft.

title: Sports People; Hopson Injured
description: Training camp does not open until tomorrow, but little has changed for the Nets. Their players combined for almost 600 missed games over the last two National Basketball Association seasons with injuries and drug problems. Yesterday, they learned that Dennis Hopson, their top 1987 draft choice and the third player selected over all, was injured last Thursday in a pickup game and would miss the entire camp with a severely spained right ankle. An injury to the same ankle kept the 6-foot-5-inch guard out of 14 games last season.

title: A's Win With a Little Power and a Lot of Pitching
description: The afternoon was like a series of snapshots, each of them frozen within the walls of Fenway Park: the home run that Jose Canseco lifted over the Green Monster; the run-scoring single that Dave Henderson, a former Red Sox hero, lined in the eighth; the diving grab at short by Walt Weiss to save a run.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertsing; People
description: * Gerard Starybrat has joined Kallir, Philips, Ross as senior vice presidentaccount group supervisor.

title: AIR TRAFFIC ERRORS LEAD F.A.A. TO CUT FLIGHTS AT CHICAGO
description: Worried by a new series of mistakes by air traffic controllers in Chicago, the Federal Aviation Administration has cut peak-hour landings at the city's two main airports.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Foote, Cone Subsidiary Buys Shop in Australia
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Pty. Ltd., the Australian subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, has acquired Forbes Macfie Hansen Pty. Ltd., which is based in Sydney. The purchase price was not disclosed. The merged entity will be called Foote, Cone & Belding and have combined billings of $80 million. Foote, Cone's client roster includes Colgate-Palmolive, the Australian Guarantee Corpo-ration and the Kimberly-Clark Corporation. The newly acquired agency will bring aboard accounts such as Best Foods, Toycorp and the Australian Consolidated Press.

title: Excerpts From Aide's Memo
description: Following are excerpts from a memorandum by Frederick B. Christensen, a senior supervisor with E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, upon his early retirement, dated July 29, 1981. The memorandum was written on stationery with a letterhead ''du Pont, Inter-office Memorandum.'' The name of the person to whom it was addressed has been deleted in the copy in the Department of Energy Public Documents Collection.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; A Third Centennial
description: This weekend will mark a monumental but little-heralded anniversary in the nation's capitol.

title: Wright Formally Denies Breach on Nicaragua
description: House Speaker Jim Wright today issued a formal denial of accusations that he violated the chamber's rules when he discussed a C.I.A. covert operation in Nicaragua aimed at undermining the Sandinista Government.

title: Hipotronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
Tears and Triumph as Holocaust Is Recalled
description: President Reagan unveiled the cornerstone today for a new museum dedicated to studying and remembering the Holocaust, and he had harsh words for the treatment of Jews by the United Nations and the Soviet Union.

title: Time Flies In a Stylish Fashion
description: RON FLEEGER is a New York product and interior designer with a quirky mission.

title: Quayle as President?
description: A man I know, a deeply committed Republican, has just been seriously ill with Legionnaire's disease. At one point he was near death. As he began to recover, he told his brother that he was going to vote for Michael Dukakis.

title: C.I.A. Near Settlement of Lawsuit By Subjects of Mind-Control Tests
description: The Central Intelligence Agency appears to be close to settling a lawsuit filed by nine Canadians who sought compensation after discovering they had been unwitting subjects in mind-control experiments, some involving LSD.

title: Q-Med Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income and the 9 months included an extraordinary credit of $551,700.

title: House Passes Bill on Disclosure of Foreign Stakes in U.S.
description: Despite contentions that it was catering to election-year fears, the House passed a controversial bill today that would require major foreign investors to report their United States holdings to the Government.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Chilean election described a decision involving a public-opinion poll incorrectly in some copies. Opposition leaders and a research organization, the Center for Public Studies, were said to have endorsed a decision against releasing a survey showing Gen. Augusto Pinochet far behind on the eve of the vote.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WITH the onset of cool weather, drafts around windows, doors and other openings in buildings become more noticeable. Besides being uncomfortable, drafts indicate that household air is passing to the outside, taking with it expensive heat.

title: Tyco Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The results of Atcor Inc. have been included since the date of its acquisition on Aug. 10, 1987.

title: Health: Psychology; Aggression in Children Can Mean Problems Later
description: It is the extremely aggressive child, rather than the anxious or depressed one, who is most likely to have emotional troubles later in life, new studies are showing. The findings contradict prevailing wisdom in child development, which holds that anxiety is the most basic source of emotional difficulties.

title: S.E.C. Seeks To Stay With Drexel Judge
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that a Federal district judge presiding over the broad securities fraud action against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. should continue to hear the case because no conflict of interest exists.

title: Metro Datelines; Regan Aide Invokes Fifth Amendment
description: Joseph Palumbo, whose fund-raising memorandums to State Comptroller Edward V. Regan and others were the subject of State Government Integrity Commission hearings last month, invoked the Fifth Amendment yesterday rather than testify today to the commission.

title: Review/Theater; Is Cannibalism Justified?
description: Even though it features just a single actor on the stage, Barry Collins's drama ''Judgment'' calls itself a two-character play. That is because the two-hour monologue delivered without intermission by Andrei Vukhov, a fictional Soviet Army officer describing his imprisonment in a monastery cell during World War II, is offered to the audience as testimony to be judged.

title: Justices Weigh Sentencing and Racial Hiring
description: Three days into its new term, the Supreme Court grappled today with two of the most significant constitutional controversies on its docket: the validity of government-sponsored affirmative action programs and the new Federal criminal sentencing system.

title: Trump Deal For Shuttle Called Near
description: Donald J. Trump, the Manhattan real estate developer, said yesterday that he was close to an agreement to buy the Eastern Airlines shuttle between New York, Boston and Washington. An executive close to the negotiations said he would pay more than $300 million in cash.

title: In Indochina, New Appeals For Missing
description: The two predominant American responses to the emotionally charged issue of the 2,393 American servicemen still unaccounted for in the Vietnam War were on display this week, creating a drama of the living and the dead.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Augusto Pinochet lost a referendum in Chile called to extend his term as President by eight years, the Interior Ministry announced. Page A1

title: Will We Understand Haiti at Last?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fruehauf Deal At $770 Million
description: The Varity Corporation's proposed acquisition of the Fruehauf Corporation would involve a stock swap worth about $70 million and the assumption of more than $700 million in debt, a Fruehauf executive said today.

title: Digital-Tandy Venture Seen
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation is expected to announce Thursday that it will resell personal computers made by the Tandy Corporation, industry officials said.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Friday listing United Nations peacekeeping forces around the world omitted two members of the Iran-Iraq Military Observer Group. Peru and Uruguay are also members.

title: INSIDE
description: Mets Lose and A's Win The Dodgers chased the Mets' 20-game winner David Cone with five runs in the first two innings and won, 6-3, in Los Angeles, tying the National League playoff at 1-1. Oakland got baseball's best hitter, Wade Boggs, to strike out in two key situations, beating the Red Sox, 2-1, in Boston in the opener of the American League series. Page B27. Accord on Military Bases House and Senate negotiators agreed on legislation that will clear the way for closing about two dozen obsolete military bases in the U.S. Page A19. Scholarship Formula Fails New York is abandoning a new scholarship formula meant to help girls because it encouraged schools to inflate grade-point averages. Page B1.

title: State by State; To Win in Illinois, Avoid Backyard Fights in Chicago
description: They do it their own way in the Windy City.

title: Milan's Muted Palette Has Flashes of Color
description: With two days of showings to go, the parade of pleasant spring and summer fashions continues inexorably here. Every designer has his or her own vision of how women will want to look for warm weather, but there are common themes.

title: HEALTH: Nutrition; Diet Higher in Fat May Help Adult Diabetics, Study Shows
description: A new study suggests that the diet usually recommended for patients with the most common form of adult diabetes may be less effective in protecting health than a diet that allows greater consumption of unsaturated fats.

title: Notes and Bonds Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes were little changed yesterday, despite another big drop in oil prices. Dealers said that trading remained very sluggish.

title: Mother Details Officer's Threat To Kill Davis
description: The mother of Larry Davis testified yesterday that a police officer had threatened to kill him several weeks before a shootout in 1986 between him and the police.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: WALKING alone at night last week in the city. I know the drill. My eyes meet the eyes of passing men only for a moment, then move into some empty middle distance that is meant to convey the message: not approachable. I have been doing this for many years, since I finally became grown up enough to understand that even in one glance, even between strangers, even on the street, something passes between men and women over which you must maintain control. Unless, of course, you are in a position to do something about it, which I, married, with children, am most assuredly not. So I don my touch-me-not look.

title: Review/Music; An Evening of Drums
description: Art and commerce met in a quirky way on Monday evening at Marymount Manhattan Theater when members of Gageego, an avant-garde ensemble, joined forces with the Percussion Group and several independent drummers to present a collection of 17 snare drum pieces published under the title ''The Noble Snare.''

title: Nordstrom's Fashion Chain Will Expand to Jersey in '90
description: Nordstrom Inc., the highly regarded West Coast fashion chain, will enter the metropolitan New York market in the spring of 1990 with a large store in the Menlo Park Mall in Edison, N.J.

title: NEAR DESTRUCTION OF REACTOR CITED
description: A foreman's error almost turned a leak of reactor coolant at the Savannah River Plant into a catastrophe that would have destroyed the reactor, according to a memorandum written by a former engineer there.

title: Test Vaccine Prevents Pregnancy in Guinea Pigs
description: Scientists have produced an experimental contraceptive vaccine that prevents pregnancy in guinea pigs.

title: Hold That Revolving Door
description: There's still time for the 100th Congress to demonstrate that it cares about ethics in government. A bill imposing reasonable cooling-off periods on ''revolving door'' lobbying by former senators and representatives might pass the House today. This measure could then be quickly reconciled with a tougher ethics bill that has passed the Senate.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Brooke Yachts International, Lowestoft, England, to TBWA Advertising,Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

title: Metro Matters; For Welfare, A Chance to Fix A Bruised Image
description: At 8:15 yesterday morning, fully 15 minutes before the building opened to the public, more than two dozen people were squeezed into the outer lobby of 12 West 14th Street. Another dozen or so had spilled onto the sidewalk.

title: Review/Television; Will Power vs. Disease
description: The television movie ''Leap of Faith,'' on NBC at 9 o'clock tonight, sets out to tackle a subject of some controversy: fighting disease with what the medical establishment generally considers questionable therapies. But then, in typical prime-time fashion, the movie hesitates and waffles, ending up with a postscript telling viewers there is little or no evidence that these ''adjunct'' techniques are effective.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Boatmen's Bankshares Inc. Names a Chief Executive
description: LEAD: Three years after becoming the president of Boatmen's Bankshares Inc., a mid-size bank holding company based in St. Louis, Andrew B. Craig 3d is scheduled to become chief executive.

title: Image Retailing Group Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
Review/Dance; Graham, Troupe and Friends
description: There is Martha Graham the dramatist and there is Martha Graham the poet. There is, of course, only one Martha Graham but among her various aspects, these were the two that came to the fore when the Martha Graham Dance Company opened a three-week season on Tuesday night.

title: An Unstoppable Export Machine
description: To the consternation of the United States and its other trading partners, West Germany is demonstrating that its export machine is virtually unstoppable. Even a 42 percent rise of the mark against the dollar over the last three years has not dethroned the country as the world's No. 1 exporter.

title: Chile: The Pinochet Years
description: Sept. 11, 1973: The armed forces, led by Gen. Augusto Pinochet, overthrow the Socialist-Communist coalition Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens. Mr. Allende dies of bullet wounds; his doctor says he committed suicide, but family members and many supporters later say he was killed. Hundreds of leftists are killed or disappear after being arrested; tens of thousands are imprisoned or sent into exile. June 20, 1974: General Pinochet becomes supreme chief of the nation, retaining his post as president of the military junta. April 5, 1976: U.S. suspends arms sales to Chile, citing human rights violations. Sept. 26, 1976: Mr. Allende's Foreign Minister, Orlando Letelier, and an American friend are killed by a car bomb in Washington. The United States later blames the Chilean secret police. July 9, 1977: General Pinochet outlines a political program calling for the military to remain in power at least 11 more years. Jan. 4, 1978: General Pinochet calls a referendum to seek support; he wins, but opposition leaders charge fraud. July 24, 1978: General Pinochet dismisses the air force commander, Gen. Gustavo Leigh, who had advocated a gradual withdrawal of the armed forces from power. Sept. 11, 1980: General Pinochet wins support in a referendum for a constitution providing for transition to a restricted democracy and confirming his presidency until 1989. The opposition claims fraud. March 11, 1981: General Pinochet is sworn in as President under the new Constitution. May 11, 1983: Fed by a deep economic crisis, protests against military rule break out. Aug. 25, 1985: Eleven political parties, backed by the Catholic Church, sign an accord calling for a transition to democracy. The Government rejects call for talks. Sept. 7, 1986: A leftist guerrilla group, the Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front, ambushes a presidential motorcade.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''It's not that they're not sympathetic, it's simply that they will take America backwards.

title: Landmark Status for a Lost Cause?
description: New York City's Landmarks Preservation Commission meets today to consider whether it ought to landmark good intentions. That's all that might justify landmark status for the buildings (see photo) known as City and Suburban homes.

title: Bridge
description: The eyes of the bridge world are about to turn to Venice, where the eighth World Team Olympiad begins Saturday. At the local level this weekend, there is activity in New Jersey and Westchester.

title: Metro Datelines; Official Faults Project Near Grucci Factory
description: The Brookhaven Town Supervisor ordered the planning board yesterday to reconsider its approval of a 795-unit condominium project half a mile from the Grucci fireworks factory.

title: Qed Exploration Inc reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Included a $2,682,241 non-cash writedown of its oil and gas properties. c-Net income

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Broader Base Sought By Scanner Executive
description: LEAD: Jerome Swartz started his career as a research engineer, specializing in matters as arcane as the propagation of laser light and as practical as touch-activated elevator switches. ''I'm a technologist; my Ph.D.'s in the laser area,'' he said earlier this week in a telephone interview from his office in Bohemia, L.I.

title: Southern Co reports earnings for 12mo Aug 31
White House May Soon Seek Release of Arms for Contras
description: The White House is considering asking Congress to release soon $16.5 million in stockpiled weapons to the Nicaraguan rebels, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: THE young man was about to graduate first in his class in medical school. He rushed over to his father, who had worked all his life in the garment district in Manhattan.

title: The Global Strategy at Grand Met
description: The fast-paced deal-making in recent days by Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. represents the last crucial steps in an aggressive corporate overhaul intended to turn the British conglomerate into one of the world's leading food and drink companies.

title: Crime: Old Whine, Old Bottles
description: LEAD: The issues in this campaign have been lost in a smokescreen of polls, polemics and platitudes. Neither Vice President Bush nor Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, for example, has offered a credible crime and law enforcement program that would improve public safety, cut public costs or attempt to reform the criminal justice system.

title: Mixing Styles With Ease
description: MARK HAMPTON, the New York interior decorator, announced in March that Hickory Chair, the North Carolina manufacturer of traditional furniture, would produce the Mark Hampton Collection of about 30 pieces. Some would be inspired by furniture in Mr. Hampton's Manhattan apartment and Southampton, L.I., home, and others would simply be pieces he believes are easy to live with.

title: Japanese Airline To Buy Boeing Jets
description: All Nippon Airways, Japan's second-largest airline, said it would buy six of the Boeing Company's 747-400 jumbo jets at a total cost of $720 million. The airline said the 370-seat aircraft had been chosen because it was fuel efficient and could fly farther than current models. All Nippon said the planes would be used on its Tokyo-Washington and Tokyo-London routes.

title: Henry V. Leonard Jr., Executive, 64
description: Henry V. Leonard Jr., executive vice president of the General Motors Overseas Corporation and general manager of its Japanese branch, died of a heart attack Friday in Norwich, England, while on a business trip. He was 64 years old and lived in Tokyo.

title: Olympic Ratings May Be Ill Omen for Networks
description: The NBC network's poor ratings for the Summer Olympic Games may signal long-term misery for the television industry, say advertising executives who analyze viewer habits and buy commercial time.

title: DCNY Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Concert; Carnegie Still Seeks Old Sound
description: In the words of the legendary aphorist Yogi Berra, it looks like deja vu all over again. With its efforts to rectify the acoustical imbalances that resulted from an extensive remodeling, Carnegie Hall would appear to be headed down the same rocky road as Avery Fisher (originally Philharmonic) Hall. The parallel is not exact, fortunately: Carnegie's problems are slight compared with those that plagued the Lincoln Center building for many years. But when one considers Carnegie's pre-remodeling reputation as one of the world's acoustical marvels, its changed sound had to set off alarms and send the experts back to the drawing board.

title: N.H.L. Preview; Rangers Relying on Defense
description: After his brief emergency stay in the hospital last spring, Michel Bergeron was told by his doctors that he could either do without cigarettes and coffee or he could do without his gallbladder. Last Sunday, Bergeron sat in his office with a cigarette in one hand, coffee in the other and a smile across his face.

title: Market Place; Global Funds Draw Bond Fans
description: BONDS of the New South Wales Treasury or the South Australian Finance Authority may sound obscure to United States investors, but those are exactly the kinds of issues that make up the portfolios of a fast-growing group of mutual funds.

title: Takeover Stocks Climb; Dow Advances by 4.45
description: A new wave of takeover fever swept Wall Street yesterday. But while rumors pushed many stocks sharply higher, the market managed only a small gain over all.

title: A Way to Save Paper, From Posters to Charts
description: ''ANYTHING that's paper can be laminated,'' said Richard Canin, the product manager of the Idesco Corporation of Manhattan. And laminated products can be used in the home in numerous ways, said Andrew Schonzeit, president of the company.

title: Save RICO From 'Reform'
description: RICO, the 1970 Racketeer Influenced Corrupt Organizations law, gave organized crime's victims a way to sue for civil redress. The idea was to motivate an army of victims to bring individual lawsuits, with the promise of triple damages. The law has turned out to work better for people with complaints about consumer and conventional business fraud. That has prompted businesses to lobby Congress for relief. These ''reformers'' would reduce most damage awards to actual money losses, carve out new exemptions for securities and commodities frauds and make these changes retroactive, invalidating suits now in the courts.

title: Banco Popular de Puerto Rico reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Robert W. Iversen, Professor, 68
description: Robert W. Iversen, a retired professor of public administration at the Maxwell School of Syracuse University, died of stomach cancer Sept. 28 at his home in Syracuse. He was 68 years old.

title: Morehouse Industries Inc reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
Harvey Wellman, 71; Retired U.S. Diplomat
description: Harvey R. Wellman, a United States diplomat and member of the Foreign Service for 32 years, died of a heart attack Sept. 27 at Middlesex Memorial Hospital in Middletown, Conn. He was 71 years old and lived in Old Saybrook, Conn.

title: Hometown Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said despite charging off $100,000 in non-recurring merger expenses during the second quarter and deferral of about $128,000 in loan origination fee income.

title: U.S. Official Denies Rumors Of Secret Talks on Hostages
description: The State Department's top counterterrorism official today dismissed new rumors that the United States is secretly negotiating the release of hostages in Lebanon. He asserted that a host of private American citizens are falsely claiming to represent the Government in hostage deals overseas.

title: Thor Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BRIEFS
description: * Banner Industries, Cleveland, a manufacturer of mechanical components and chemical products, said it had agreed to sell its Chemrex Inc. unit to SKW Trostberg A.G., a West German company, and expected to realize a gain of $40 million before taxes, or $25 million after taxes.

title: MSI Data Offers Deal to Telxon
description: The MSI Data Corporation, a maker of portable computers, said it would accept an immediate $20 million cash payment from the Telxon Corporation to settle all MSI claims in pending patent infringement and tender offer lawsuits. MSI and Telxon have filed a series of claims and counterclaims against each other since 1985, charging each other with infringement of patents and unfair competition. The companies make portable data collection systems for use in retail sales and factory inventories.

title: Queens Woman, 85, Shot Twice in Robbery
description: An 85-year-old Queens woman was shot twice in the chest yesterday as she struggled with a robber outside the apartment building where she lives.

title: Koch Blocked On Shelters, 3 Officials Say
description: Three borough presidents said yesterday that a lawsuit they had filed challenging the Koch administration's plan to build 11 shelters for the homeless had succeeded, but the law secretary for the judge hearing the case said the decision had not yet been signed.

title: Bank Board Lifts Rescue Cost to $45 Billion
description: Bringing its estimate more into line with those of its critics, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it would cost $45 billion to $50 billion to shut or merge the nation's 500 insolvent savings institutions.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - WORKING GROUP ON RIGHTS OF MIGRANT WORKERS - 11 A.M. and 3 P.M. DECOLONIZATION COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Ken Donahue yesterday resigned as defensive coach at Tennessee (0-5). The Volunteers have given up more 36.6 points and 491.6 yards a game during their worst start ever. Donahue, 63, has been an assistant coach for 37 seasons, including 21 at Alabama with Paul (Bear) Bryant. . . . A day after he completed his 30-day suspension for violation of the National Football League's substance-abuse policy, Calvin Thomas of the Chicago Bears was traded yesterday to the Denver Broncos for an undisclosed, conditional 1989 draft choice. The choice will depend on the running back's performance with the Broncos. . . . Doug Flutie, the third-string quarterback for New England, was named the American Football Conference's offensive player of the week after rallying the Patriots to a 21-17 victory over Indianapolis Sunday. He also was named the starter for Sunday's game against Green Bay . . . Phil and Steve Mahre, the twins who were the gold and silver medalists in the slalom at the 1984 Winter Olympics, said it was ''90 to 95 percent certain'' they will reach an agreement to ski competitively for the first time in five years by joining the Unites States pro ski tour next year. . . . The Chicago White Sox have excercised their option on Jerry Reuss and will keep the 39-year-old left-hander who had a 13-9 record this season. . . . The California Angels have given Butch Wynegar, cather, his unconditional release. . . . Mary Slaney, who finished eighth in the women's 1,500 and 10th in the 3,000 at the Seoul Olympics, has entered the Mercedes Mike on Fifth Avenue Oct. 15.

title: Healthvest SBI reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Regina Chief Sounds Optimistic Note
description: The besieged Regina Company has resolved many of the product-quality problems that plagued it last spring and summer, its new chairman said yesterday.

title: Fatal Ignorance
description: To be ignorant about AIDS prevention is to court death. But while countless television ads tell how to dull a headache and sweeten bad breath, those counseling how to avoid this tragic disease are rare. NBC and ABC have run a few ads advocating condom use; CBS hasn't run any.

title: GBC Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ohio Pollution Control Bonds
description: The Ohio Water Development Authority and the Ohio Air Quality Development Authority are tentatively offering a total of $50.7 million in tax-exempt collateralized pollution control revenue bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Review/Piano; Haefliger Plays Copland
description: Andreas Haefliger began his debut recital at the 92d Street Y on Saturday night with a bold and uncompromising statement of Aaron Copland's hard-hitting ''Piano Variations'' and followed it with thoughtful Beethoven and Schumann that placed him firmly in the Germanic tradition of committed intellectual interpretation of the classics.

title: Film Festival; A Dickens Tale in Modern Portugal
description: Of all the films in this year's New York Film Festival, surely ''Hard Times'' is the most peculiar. Joao Botelho's version of the 1854 Charles Dickens novel has been translated into Portuguese and filmed in contemporary settings, but these are actually the least eccentric things about it. Mr. Botelho's other modifications of his material are much more puzzling, and more self-defeating as well.

title: International Lease Finance Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a $3,731,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Review/Dance; The Slovak State Folk Ensemble
description: The Slovak State Folk Ensemble brought virtuoso folk dancing to the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts on Sunday afternoon. It was a program of nonstop merriment.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Don't Call Him Judge
description: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist is not known for standing unduly on ceremony; despite his exalted station in life, he retains a distinctly unstuffy manner.

title: Sports People; Pacers, Smits Agree
description: Rik Smits, the second player selected in the draft last June, has agreed in principle to a four-year contract with the Indiana Pacers that will reportedly pay the 7-4 former Marist College center $1.3 million a year.'' . . . Ron Grinker, the agent for Danny Manning of Kansas, the first player selected in the draft, said his client would not report to the Los Angeles Clipper camp tomorrow because both sides are far apart in their contract negotiations. ''It's not a matter of a few thousand dollars or a few thousand dollars apart,'' said Grinker. ''We're probably millions apart and that is frightening because that means one of us is dramatically incorrect.'' . . . The Boston Celtics announced that Dirk Minnifield, their free-agent guard, had entered a drug-rehabilitation center. The club also said it would not re-sign Minnifield, who was signed last Dec. 17 as a free agent, five weeks after he was waived by the Golden State Warriors.

title: Getty Plans Bid For Clark Oil
description: The Getty Petroleum Corporation said it would submit a bid for the bankrupt Clark Oil and Refining Corporation, a leading discount gasoline marketer in the Midwest. The company said its bid for Clark and other assets of the Apex Oil Company would top the $650 million offered by the Horsham Corporation. Getty said its proposal would be filed in the Federal Bankruptcy Court in St. Louis by late Monday. Horsham, meanwhile, promised a battle for the company.

title: IPM Technology Inc reports earnings for
description: b-After a loss of $58,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $710,000. The company said figures for 1987 were restated to reflect the company's discontinued operations.

title: How Emergency Aid Goes Astray in Burma
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Men Attack the Daughter Of John Wayne and a Friend
description: A financier and a daughter of the actor John Wayne were tied up and beaten in a daytime attack by two men on Monday, and the police said that no clear motive for the attack had been determined.

title: Carnival Cruise Lines Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Lack of Federal Rules Cited In Growing Medical Wastes
description: A lack of Federal regulation and inconsistent practices in handling medical wastes bear a major responsibility for the syringes, surgical byproducts and other potentially infectious medical garbage that have surfaced on beaches and at dump sites around the country, a Congressional study group reported today.

title: BENTSEN AND QUAYLE ATTACK ON QUESTION OF COMPETENCE TO SERVE IN THE PRESIDENCY
description: Senators Dan Quayle of Indiana and Lloyd Bentsen of Texas clashed angrily last night during a Vice-Presidential debate in which each insisted that he could handle the burdens of the Presidency.

title: Sports People; Canadian Inquiry
description: The Canadian Government yesterday appointed a senior judge to head a judicial inquiry into the use of drugs in Canadian sports, with the focus on the events leading to the disqualification of Ben Johnson after his victory in the 100-meter run at the Seoul Olympic Games. In appointing Charles W. Dubin, associate chief justice of the Supreme Court of Ontario, the Government chose one of the widest forms of inquiry available under Canada's parliamentary system. Justice Dubin will have the power to subpoena witnesses and to question them under oath. Among those expected to be called are Johnson, who has denied knowingly taking the anabolic steroids that were found in his urine after the race.

title: Bush and Dukakis Praise Running Mates
description: Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis expressed pride tonight in their running mates' performances, and each asserted that his party's candidate had won the Omaha debate.

title: Helen of Troy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Husky's Oil Discovery
description: Husky Oil Ltd. said Tuesday that the consortium it heads had made a potentially large oil discovery off the coast of Newfoundland. Husky Oil, in which the Nova Corporation of Alberta and the Hong Kong financier Li Ka-Shing each holds a 43 percent interest, said its Whiterose E-09 well on the Grand Banks had found ''a possible accumulation of 200 million to 300 million barrels'' of recoverable oil. Natural gas was also found.

title: Hungary Liberalizes Law
description: A new law to liberalize Hungary's economy in a way that the Justice Minister said might smack of capitalism to some people won unanimous assent today in Parliament.

title: ABC Wants Debate With a Difference
description: George Bush's aides say he is committed to two debates and no more.

title: 'Star Wars' Was Rejected in the 1960's; MX Increases the Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Obstetricians Report a Crisis
description: Burdened by frequent lawsuits and heavy insurance costs, obstetricians in New York State are increasingly abandoning their practices, leading to overcrowding in public maternity clinics and reducing specialized care in rural areas, according to obstetricians and a recent study of their specialty.

title: The Deficit Dodgers
description: Michael Dukakis and George Bush both must campaign in the shadow of the gigantic Reagan budget deficits. Each has plenty of ideas for new priorities or programs; each knows how hard it will be to find money for them; each has shrunk from proposals that would raise taxes or increase Federal spending. And each has found a different way to dodge the deficit.

title: Cherry Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Sports People; Plunkett Honored
description: Jim Plunkett, the 1970 Heisman Trophy winner and the Most Valuable Player in the Super Bowl of 1981 when he led the Oakland Raiders to a victory, was named yesterday as winner of the first Ernie Davis Award. The award honors the all-America running back from Syracuse who died of leukemia 16 months after winning the 1961 Heisman Trophy.

title: Planters Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The bank said the latest quarter included a pre-tax gain of about 4 cents a share from the sale of its Ashboro office.

title: Where Designers Go to See What's In
description: MORE than 25,000 designers, architects and dealers are expected to gather in New York this week for Designer's Saturday, a four-day event that began yesterday and will introduce some of the newest designs for home and office.

title: For School Nurses, New Challenges
description: LEAD: THE image of the school nurse as someone who gives eye and ear tests, reviews health forms and dispenses Band-Aids is a thing of the past. Today, along with routine childhood illnesses, school nurses deal with such critical problems as AIDS, drug use, teen-age pregnancy and suicide, eating disorders and child abuse.

title: Talking Deals; BellSouth's Move Into Eurobonds
description: LIKE a growing number of American companies, BellSouth has taken its first plunge into the Eurodollar bond market, saving hundreds of thousands of dollars. More important for its new international strategy, the company has made a splash that will help its name abroad.

title: Chronic Failures at Nuclear Plant Are Disclosed by the Energy Dept.
description: The Department of Energy said today that chronic equipment failure and poor operating procedures caused nuclear reactors at the Savannah River Plant to shut down unexpectedly 9 to 12 times a year for nearly two decades, a rate twice that of the civilian nuclear power industry.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON BASE CLOSINGS
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed today on legislation that will clear the way for closing about two dozen obsolete military bases, a process so politically sensitive that Congress has prevented the Pentagon from shutting down any major bases since 1977.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Lobbies; Homosexual Groups and the Politics of AIDS
description: The issue of homosexuality remains distasteful to many in Congress, as demonstrated by the overwhelming vote in the House on Tuesday permitting members to refuse to hire anyone whose life style they decide is unacceptable, a framework interpreted as including men and women who are gay.

title: Eisig Silberschlag, 85, Hebrew College Chief
description: Dr. Eisig Silberschlag, a former president of Hebrew College of Boston, died last Friday at St. David's Hospital in Austin, Tex. He was 85 years old and lived in Austin, where he was a professor of Judaic studies at the University of Texas.

title: 'Star Wars' Was Rejected in the 1960's
description: To the Editor:

title: Eckersley Victor In Classic Battle
description: With the fans' stomping threatening to shatter the towering wall in left, with baseball's leading batter, Wade Boggs, facing him in the ninth inning and the winning run on base, Dennis Eckersley of the Athletics was worried about negative vibrations.

title: Epsilon Data Management Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: New Owners in N.F.L.
description: The sales of the New England Patriots and Seattle Seahawks were approved unanimously today at a special meeting of National Football League owners. The transactions were approved pending the reception of documents by the league office within 10 days. N.F.L. officials said they anticipated no problems with either sale.

title: Results Plus
description: Golf New Yorkers win: An eight-member team of New York Professional Golf Association players won bragging rights in the metropolitan area yesterday when it defeated its New Jersey counterpart, 18-15, in the fifth annual Dodge Challenge Cup at the Rockaway River Country Club in Denville, N.J. The match of the best club professionals from each state ends the 1988 golf season.

title: Serene Spot For Shirt Shopping
description: THE new Comme des Garcons Shirt shop at 454 West Broadway, between Houston and Prince Streets in SoHo, is a striking example of a perfectly done minimalist interior.

title: Lucien Ballard, Cinematographer
description: Lucien Ballard, a cinematographer whose sensuous images contributed to the heyday of the black-and-white film as well as the era of the three-dimensional color spectacular, died Saturday at Eisenhower Medical Center in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 84 years old and had been injured in an auto accident. In a career that spanned nearly 50 years, Mr. Ballard worked on more than 100 films with directors as disparate as Josef von Sternberg, Henry Hathaway, Raoul Walsh, Sam Peckinpah and Stanley Kubrick.

title: Bold Prediction From Dukakis
description: Just hours before the Bentsen-Quayle debate, Mr. Dukakis began a news conference yesterday with a rare confession of anxiety.

title: Price War Fears Send Oil Tumbling
description: Oil prices fell sharply again yesterday, as the lack of an agreement among leading exporters to curtail production increased fears of a price war.

title: Petition Filed Opposing Offer to Buy Gold Fields
description: A petition was filed today to block the acquisition of strategic American minerals by a giant South African company, under legislation that authorizes the President to block foreign takeovers that endanger national security.

title: Copyright Bill Advances
description: The Senate today took a major step toward United States participation in the Bern Treaty to expand copyright protection to Americans who create artistic works and intellectual property.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Designers (and Friends) Hold Gala to Help AIDS Charities
description: LAST night's gala sponsored by Metropolitan Home magazine transformed the cavernous 26th Street Armory on Lexington Avenue into a designer dreamscape, complete with tented galleries, tables set with votive candles and scenes of downtown Zanzibar from an opera stage set by the artist David Hockney.
