The $350-a-plate affair, sold out for several weeks, benefited the Design Industries Foundation for AIDS (Diffa) and brought together an illustrious group of artists, entertainers and leading interior designers.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sept. 21 about a speech on health care by Michael S. Dukakis misidentified the principal author of the speech. He was David Kusnet, not Theodore C. Sorensen.

title: Lillian Vernon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: b-Net income The company terminated its S Corporation tax status in August, 1987. Accordingly, no provision for income taxes was made for the year-ago second quarter and 6 months. A pro forma tax provision was computed for comparative purposes.

title: Haitians' Suit Alleges Bias In U.S. Immigration Policy
description: A suit filed last week in Federal court asserts that thousands of Haitian refugees seeking asylum here have been denied residency because of discrimination by the Immigration and Naturalization Service in the last decade.

title: Learning to See Beyond the Guilt
description: THE first step toward resolving feelings of competitiveness with parents involves wading through complex emotions. These feelings are particularly acute when the child succeeds at something the parents would like to have accomplished themselves.

title: American Airlines
description: The AMR Corporation said it would spend about $50 million to develop San Jose, Calif., as an important West Coast hub for American Airlines. The company said the first phase of the hub would open on Dec. 2, with 86 jet and commuter flights a day to 19 cities. When the hub is fully developed by 1991, American and the American Eagle commuter airline will operate 175 flights a day to 52 cities from San Jose. About 2,300 jobs are expected to be created at the hub.

title: Dodgers Batter Cone Early and Tie Mets in Playoff
description: David Cone started the evening with a red face and the feeling that ''the Dodgers are out to get me,'' and he was right.

title: Prosecutor Is Dropping Charge Against Rowan
description: The prosecution announced today that it would drop a charge of weapon possession against the syndicated columnist Carl T. Rowan, whose trial last week ended in a hung jury.

title: Jobless Dip in Germany
description: The number of jobless West Germans dropped by 70,000, to 2.1 million, in September, and the Government said today that the 3.2 percent decline proved the success of its efforts to promote economic growth. The Federal Statistics Office said that seasonally unadjusted unemployment fell to 8.1 percent of the work force in September from 8.5 percent in August.

title: Israel Bans Kahane Party From Election
description: The Central Election Commission today banned Rabbi Meir Kahane's party from parliamentary elections next month on the grounds that it is racist and undemocratic.

title: National League Notebook; Strawberry Stirs Controversy
description: As Alan Hendricks, a players' agent, testified in Collusion III today, an executive on one side of the conspiracy cases wondered if Darryl Strawberry had created Collusion IV.

title: Fire at Merv Griffin's House
description: Fire damaged a $1.75 million house under construction for the producer-entrepreneur Merv Griffin, and fire officials estimated damage at $1 million. The fire occurred Tuesday in the P.G.A. West Country Club development near Palm Springs, said Tim Spann, a spokesman for the Riverside County Fire Department. The house was 80 percent complete ''and a little more than half of it was destroyed,'' said Capt. Brenda Seabert. The cause of the fire has not been determined.

title: Hovnanian Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a $2,583,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Patent Plan in Europe
description: The European Community Commission proposed patent legislation today to protect biotechnology inventions in the 12-nation trade bloc. National patent laws differ so much that ''lack of legal certainty and lack of sufficient protection is commonplace in the community,'' the commission said. Scientists in the community are at a disadvantage compared with their colleagues in the United States and Japan, where laws offer ''considerably more protection through patentability than is available in Europe,'' the commission said.

title: Lois Burnham Wilson, a Founder Of Al-Anon Groups, Is Dead at 97
description: Lois Burnham Wilson, a founder of the Al-Anon Family Groups, whose members are relatives and friends of alcoholics, died yesterday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. Mrs. Wilson, widely known as Lois W., was 97 years old and was a longtime resident of Bedford Hills, N.Y.

title: Studies Find Abortion Is Common In All Race and Economic Groups
description: Two nationwide surveys indicate that young, poor, black unmarried women are most likely to have abortions, but that the operation is common among women of all racial and economic groups, even among women who belong to religious groups that oppose abortions. They show that nearly 3 of every 100 American women 15 to 44 years old had an abortion last year, a figure that has remained constant for a decade.

title: Man Held as Priest's Killer, and Freed
description: Hours after the police arrested a suspect in the slaying of a Bronx priest, the 28-year-old man was released late Tuesday night after the Bronx District Attorney declined to prosecute him.

title: Judge Seals Verdict as Trial In Suit Against Klan Ends
description: A Federal jury returned a verdict today in a civil rights lawsuit against 10 present and former members of the Ku Klux Klan, but the judge immediately ordered the verdict sealed.

title: Sudbury Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
Review/Television; Life After Divorce, in the 'Taxi' Spirit
description: John Lacey, a New York teacher married for 10 years, comes home to find a ''Dear John'' letter with the news that his wife has run off with his best friend. ''Must have thrown you for a loop,'' says his nasty brother-in-law, sneering. ''And with your best friend yet!'' At the urging of his sister, John decides to visit a singles support group in a community center in Rego Park, Queens. The brother-in-law is puzzled, wondering aloud, ''Why would he want to hang around with a bunch of other pathetic losers?''

title: Alco Seeks Ways To Increase Value
description: The Alco Health Services Corporation said it was studying new ways to increase shareholder value after its agreement to be acquired by the McKesson Corporation was called off. McKesson, the country's largest drug wholesaler, had agreed to buy Alco for $508 million, after a management-led group had offered $440 million for it.

title: Woodland Hills Journal; Where Bingo Itself Is a Hot Number
description: Debbie Tate celebrated her 18th birthday in this Los Angeles community Saturday night. She played bingo.

title: Sergei A. Losev, 61, The Director of Tass And Party Delegate
description: Sergei A. Losev, general director of the official Soviet press agency Tass, died suddenly on Monday, the agency announced here Tuesday. He was 61 years old.

title: TV Notes
description: News at Noon

title: Drug Helps Children With AIDS, Researchers Say
description: Children with AIDS improve dramatically when given the drug azidothymidine, or AZT, regaining lost intelligence, speech and the ability to walk, a study has found.

title: REGIME CONCEDES
description: Opponents of President Augusto Pinochet defeated him in the plebiscite Wednesday in which he sought the voters' approval to extend his term as President by eight years.

title: Europe-China Pact Seen
description: A top European Community official said today that China and Europe were likely to reach an accord on Chinese textile exports at talks next month. Willy de Clercq, the community's Commissioner for External Relations and Trade, said he expected an agreement to be reached in Brussels on replacing a four-year textile pact that will expire at the end of this year.

title: How It Happened; Balk Began Cone's Downfall
description: In his last 14 starts of the season, David Cone gave up a total of five runs in the first two innings. Hitting against Cone in the second game of the National League pennant playoff tonight, the Los Angeles Dodgers battered him for five runs in the first two innings.

title: U.S. Asking Soviets To Let World Court Settle Some Disputes
description: The Reagan Administration has proposed that the United States and the Soviet Union let the World Court arbitrate specific disputes between them and agree in advance to accept the Court's verdict, a senior Administration official said today.

title: Atlanta Mall Rules Organ Grinder Obsolete
description: Sam Ketcham seems more puzzled than hurt when he talks about being ousted from Lenox Square, the stylish Atlanta shopping mall where he had performed as an organ grinder with a monkey for three decades.

title: New York State Returns to National Tests for Scholarships
description: A new formula for using high-school grades as a basis for awarding $40 million in college scholarships has been abandoned because it encouraged schools to inflate students' grades, New York State officials said yesterday.

title: A Professor Is the First Witness in Myerson's Trial
description: Testimony in the Bess Myerson trial began yesterday with the prosecution presenting a law professor who told the jury about divorce procedures in New York State.

title: The Planetary Heat Wave Is Real
description: To the Editor:

title: Film Festival; The 'Butcher of Lyons' Is Himself Picked Apart
description: Marcel Ophuls's ''Hotel Terminus: The Life and Times of Klaus Barbie'' begins with a deceptive sense of restraint and calm. In the opening sequence, a friend of Mr. Barbie's recalls a New Year's Eve party at which the former Gestapo officer took offense at some disrespectful remarks made about Hitler. The friend was amused that Mr. Barbie still might find some subjects not funny.

title: New York City Inspectors Have Plenty of Pride
description: To the Editor:

title: Cummins Expects Loss
description: The Cummins Engine Company said on Tuesday that it expected to report a third-quarter net loss significantly greater than its $6.3 million loss a year earlier. Cummins said the factors contributing to the poor results included price discounting of its engines because of stiff competition in the heavy-truck market, higher costs of new engine models and difficulty in meeting orders during a company restructuring.

title: Yields Post A Slight Rise
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose only slightly in the week that ended yesterday.

title: Is That Dan Quayle In a Purple Haze?
description: Is Dan Quayle a child of the 60's? A former flower child? A secret hippie?

title: Budget Panel Meets Openly
description: A consultant to the National Economic Commission estimated today that the Government could save as much as $95 billion over five years by reducing cost-of-living adjustments, or COLA's, for entitlement programs other than Social Security.

title: SL Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income The latest fourth quarter included the previously reported charge of about $5.8 million in connection with a restructuring. The results are adjusted for a 6 percent stock dividend distributed in November 1987.

title: Metro Datelines; Executive Is Accused Of Embezzlement
description: A New York insurance executive was indicted by a Manhattan grand jury on charges of embezzling $1.8 million over four years, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, announced yesterday.

title: Riesenberg Is Filling the Gaps
description: Less than six days into training camp this summer, Doug Riesenberg, the Giants' second-year offensive tackle, decided that his watchwords for the season would be ''low key.''

title: Benefit Art Show
description: About 30 pieces of art, some by noted entertainers, will be on view through Oct. 30 at the 101 Wooster Gallery, 101 Wooster Street. The exhibition is a benefit for Shelter Aid, a referral organization that helps victims of domestic violence. Among the artists represented in the show are Gina Lollobrigida and Tony Bennett. Other works come from the collections of Steve Martin, Anthony Quinn and Suzanne Vega. Hours are noon to 6 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays; admission by donation. Information: 219-2790.

title: Flash of Lightning Ignites A Long-Becalmed Debate
description: The debate had been under way for the better part of an hour, swaying back and forth with nothing in particular standing out.

title: Transactions
description: TUESDAY Baseball

title: Transcript of the Debate on TV Between Bentsen and Quayle
description: Participants in the Debate CANDIDATES: Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat, and Dan Quayle, Republican. MODERATOR: Judy Woodruff, ''MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour,'' PBS. PANELISTS: Tom Brokaw, anchor and managing editor, NBC Nightly News; Jon Margolis, Washington correspondent, The Chicago Tribune; Brit Hume, national correspondent, ABC News.

title: Frederick R. Lack, 93, Retired Executive, Dies
description: Frederick R. Lack, vice president in charge of radio and specialty products for Western Electric before his retirement in 1958, died of a heart attack Tuesday at the Southport Manor Nursing Home in Southport, Conn. He was 93 years old.

title: Sinking-Fund Debentures Are Offered by James River
description: The James River Corporation is offering $250 million of 10 3/4 percent sinking-fund debentures due in 2018 at a price of par through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company. At pricing, the yield spread was about 174 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

title: Royal Admiral Sold To a Big Stockholder
description: A bid to merge two of the nation's largest cruise lines was thwarted today when a Norwegian partner in Royal Admiral Cruises Ltd. bought 70 percent of the company's stock for $561 million, heading off a similar offer by Carnival Cruise Lines Inc.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Southern Travel Is Now Called Travel South
description: Southern Travel magazine has changed its named to Travel South. The Southern Progress Corporation, a subsidiary of Time Inc. that publishes Southern Living, had bought Southern Travel in September 1987 from The New York Times Magazine Group. Its circulation is 200,000.

title: Judge Criticizes Pretoria for Thwarting the Courts
description: A liberal South African judge has voiced criticism of the country's white political leaders for usurping the power of the judiciary and has called for a major effort to protect the rule of law.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Agency's Job: Explaining Californians
description: BOZELL, JACOBS, KENYON & ECKHARDT'S branch office here has been working with the Chrysler Corporation for several years to study that most fascinating and perplexing of creatures, the Californian. Chrysler and the agency wanted to know what makes Californians tick in order to sell more cars within the state and eventually elsewhere, since what is hot in La Jolla will one day find its way to Peoria.

title: KEY RATES
Salant Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
description: b-Included charges of $2,848,000 for the quarter and $4,848,000 for the 9 months from the amortization of fees related to the financing of the acquisition of Manhattan Industries, which was completed in August. c-Net income d-Included extraordinary tax credits of $1,532,000 for the quarter and $1,831,000 for the 9 months. The figures included the results of operations of Manhattan Industries, commencing May 1, 1988.

title: Crazy Eddie Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: b-Includes a one-time gain of $48,226,000 from a debt swap offer for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss and includes income tax benefits of about $7.9 million for the quarter and about $10.2 million for the 6 months.

title: Review/City Opera; Debuts in 'Magic Flute'
description: There were four newcomers in the New York City Opera's production of Mozart's ''Magic Flute'' at the New York State Theater on Tuesday evening. One of them, Sandra Moon, made her company debut as Pamina, and as it turned out, she was by far the best singer in the cast.

title: The Yearning Of Refugees: Angola Unity
description: Seated in a traditional thatched-roof palaver hut, Bravo da Rosa and other Angolan refugees talked recently about Angola's civil war with a frankness rarely heard on the other side of Angola's border, 15 miles from here.

title: Insurers Reap Windfall In Hospital Repayments
description: To the Editor:

title: Clarence Carnes, 61; Tried to Flee Alcatraz
description: Clarence Carnes, the only inmate not killed or executed after a 1946 escape attempt from Alcatraz, died Monday at the Medical Center for Federal Prisoners. He was 61 years old.

title: WQXR Commentary
description: Radio station WQXR, 96.3 FM and 1560 AM, is to begin a five-week series of commentary on the Presidential election today, featuring columnists of The New York Times. The series will include 90-second analyses and vignettes by A. M. Rosenthal, Russell Baker, Anthony Lewis, Tom Wicker and Flora Lewis, broadcast periodically every day through Nov. 9.

title: Dukakis Sees Campaign Progress
description: Michael S. Dukakis, bullish from the latest round of polls, asserted today that his campaign had made ''substantial progress'' in recent days and predicted ''five long, tough and aggressive weeks'' before Election Day.

title: Esiason Provides Test for Gastineau
description: The Jets reassembled at their training site today and turned their attention to the Cincinnati Bengals and Boomer Esiason, the National Football League's top-ranked passer.

title: Health; Personal Health
description: Is it such a good idea to be drinking eight or more glasses a day of the water that comes out of your tap? Samuel Coleridge's line from ''The Rhyme of the Ancient Mariner'' - ''Water, water everywhere, Nor any drop to drink'' - could characterize a growing number of American communities, where the drinking water has been tainted by pollutants.

title: With Charter, Brazil Closes Military Era
description: After almost 20 months of intense bargaining and frequent squabbles, Brazil's Congress today put into effect a new Constitution, hailed here as a crucial step in the country's transition from dictatorship to democracy.

title: Mattingly Trade Denied
description: The first of what will likely become a winter filled with trade rumors involving Don Mattingly surfaced this week but was quickly denied by the Yankees.

title: Bethlehem Steel Bid
description: United States Bankruptcy Judge Warren Bentz on Tuesday signed an order accepting the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's $20 million cash bid for a modern, idled rail mill that Federal lenders seized from the financially troubled Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation. Bethlehem officials have said they will operate the Westmoreland County mill in conjunction with Bethlehem's rail mill in Steelton. But it is not clear when the Monessen plant might be reactivated. Wheeling-Pittsburgh closed it because of slack demand for transportation rail.

title: Review/Theater; Chicago's Steppenwolf Group Adapts 'The Grapes of Wrath'
description: The question raised at first by the Steppenwolf Theater Company's epic-sized stage adaptation of ''The Grapes of Wrath'' is a simple one. Why?

title: United Illuminating Issue Is Offered
description: The United Illuminating Company yesterday began offering $150 million of 10 1/2 percent debentures due 1995 at a price of 99.875, to yield 10.524 percent, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & company.

title: 35 Years of Innovative L.I. Houses
description: PEOPLE who missed ''Long Island Modern:

title: Green Seeking to Require Recitation of the Pledge
description: The New York City Schools Chancellor told the Board of Education yesterday that he believed it was important for all public schools in the city to begin the day with a recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance.

title: Harry R. Mancher, 70, U.J.A. Treasurer, Dies
description: Harry R. Mancher, the president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies from 1977 to 1980 and a longtime treasurer of the United Jewish Appeal-Federation, died of a brain tumor yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Digital Communications Asociates reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: Briefs
description: Debt

title: Fighting Apathy, The Chicago Way
description: So they're bored in Chicago with the Presidential race.

title: 6 Months Into Budget Cuts, Albany Agencies Feel Toll
description: The Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities has eliminated 230 positions. The Division of Substance Abuse Services has closed its laboratory in Brooklyn. And the Department of Agriculture and Markets has laid off its inspector of large-capacity truck scales.

title: Key Soviet Aide Recommending Freer Economy
description: The Kremlin's new chief ideologist, moving quickly to set the tone for the restructured Soviet leadership, has called for more radical experiments with market economics and rejected the idea of a world struggle against the West.

title: Bush, in Colorado, Offers Plan Of Investing 'in Our Children'
description: Vice President Bush said again today that he wants to help the poor through inspirational leadership rather than with costly Federal programs. But he promised to use some Federal dollars for a plan to help disadvantaged children.

title: Oil and Varnish: An Easy-to-Use Finish
description: LEAD: A homemade mixture of varnish and oil is a finish I was introduced to in England, when, in the 1950's, I helped a neighbor restore his wood-paneled station wagon.

title: Cambodian Rejects Vietnam Plea
description: A leader of the coalition fighting the Vietnamese-backed Government of Cambodia today rejected Vietnamese demands that the Khmer Rouge be ejected from the coalition before Vietnam withdraws its troops from the country.

title: Poll Gives Bush Rising Lead Over Dukakis
description: Vice President Bush pulled further ahead of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis in a new poll released tonight by ABC News and The Washington Post.

title: Books of The Times; Football as Show Business, Football as Statistics
description: Monday Night Mayhem The Inside Story of ABC's Monday Night Football By Marc Gunther and Bill Carter Illustrated. 384 pages. Beech Tree Books/William Morrow. $18.95. The Hidden Game of Football By Bob Carroll, Pete Palmer and John Thorn 415 pages. Warner Books. $18.95.

title: Public Clinics Crowded and Short on Staff
description: Like many of the women waiting to be seen by an obstetrician at the maternity clinic at 21 Old Broadway, Belen Ramirez has learned patience.

title: Review/Theater; A Religious Gamble
description: An unworldly monk from a Puerto Rican monastery gets a fast big-city education in ''Padre Gomez y Santa Cecilia'' by Gloria Gonzalez at the Repertorio Espanol theater and, when his superiors threaten to punish him for what he has learned, he has a few things to teach them.

title: THE PLAYOFFS: American League Notebook; Canseco Bat Quiets Serenade
description: In 1986, they serenaded Darryl Strawberry, the Mets' outfielder, with a persistent sing-song chant during the World Series: ''Dar-ryl, Dar-ryl.'' Today, the fans at Fenway Park made Jose Canseco their target.

title: Robert Buchakian, Retailer, 52
description: Robert Buchakian, a retailer who founded the Treasure Island stores, died of a brain tumor Tuesday at his home in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 52 years old.

title: Hockney to Zuni: A Show House With a Difference
description: SHOW houses, where interior decorators use their talents to benefit a charitable cause, seem to be coming along with ever-increasing frequency.

title: The Mysterious and Lovely Lablab Vine
description: THE outset of all gardeners' careers is marked by an uneasy excitement. Every plant is new, unknown and nameless.

title: Ford Credit Notes To Yield 8.981%
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company, a unit of the Ford Motor Company, is offering $200 million of 8 7/8 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.725, to yield 8.981 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: A PARADE IN EGYPT MARKS '73 FIGHTING
description: Egypt today held its first full-scale military parade marking the 1973 war with Israel since President Anwar el-Sadat was assassinated in a similar parade seven years ago.

title: U.S. Visit by Mali Leader Reflects Better Ties
description: When the President of Mali goes to dinner at the White House on Thursday night, he will be only the second leader of a black African nation honored by the Reagan Administration with the pomp and glitter of a state visit.

title: Events: Walking Tour and Lecture Series
description: Borderline Walk, Brooklyn Historical Society, 128 Pierrepont Street, at Clinton Street, Brooklyn Heights; 718-624-0890.

title: Metro Datelines; Queensboro Ramp Reopened to Traffic
description: The ramp from the upper roadway of the Queensboro Bridge at 60th Street between First and Second Avenues reopened yesterday, one year after being closed for reconstruction.

title: Radon Scare - Where's the Proof?
description: Before people rush to have radon levels in their homes reduced, as Federal officials advise, they might ask themselves whether such advice is premature. Long-term exposure to high concentrations of the gas might well increase a person's chances of contracting lung cancer. But the 4 picocurie per liter of air ''action level'' urged by the Environmental Protection Agency and the Public Health Service seems low. Other countries - for example, Canada and Finland - do not recommend remedies unless levels are more than five times greater.

title: Farm Credit Bank Delays Bond Sale
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation said yesterday that it would not be offering bonds for Oct. 20 delivery because of the limited need of the farm credit system and its borrowers for medium- and long-term type financing.

title: Kenyan Said to Order End to Church Dispute
description: President Daniel arap Moi has ordered officials of the governing party and clergymen to end a dispute, and he promised that the Government will not curtail freedom of worship, newspapers reported today.

title: U.S. Sees No Sign of New Hostage Release
description: As an Indian freed by his Lebanese captors arrived at an American military hospital here, State Department officials said today that they had no indication that any American hostages might be released soon.

title: Boxing Notebook; Tyson's Mother-in-Law: Compassionate or Overly Ambitious?
description: Olga Rosario, who has worked for Ruth Roper's New York-based computers systems business for the last eight years, thinks that Roper is being miscast as the villain in the troubles of Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion.

title: After Yearlong Battle, Irving Yields to Bank of New York
description: After a year of fierce resistance and skirmishing, the management of the Irving Bank Corporation said yesterday that it would recommend that its board agree to merge with the Bank of New York Company.

title: THE PLAYOFFS:
description: Sports of The Times ; A Quail And a Phoenix

title: Memo Tells of Near Disaster
description: An accident in 1965 at the Savannah River reactor in South Carolina was a near catastrophe, according to an engineer's memorandum. Page A23.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Biotherapeutics Inc., Franklin, Tenn., a medical laboratory, appointed three executives to fill jointly the new office of chairman until a permanent management structure is formed. Named were Dr. Robert Oldham, scientific director; Dr. William West, medical director, and Paul T. Agee, chief operating officer.

title: Kenneth W. O'Neil, 72, Bomb-Squad Chief
description: Kenneth W. O'Neil, a retired New York City police lieutenant who headed the department's bomb squad for 18 years, died, apparently of a heart attack, on Monday at the Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center in Hanover, N.H. He was 72 years old and lived in Bristol, N.H.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; No Debate Abroad
description: In addition to the American audience for the televised exchange last night between the Republicans' Dan Quayle and the Democrats' Lloyd Bentsen, there might have been a global audience of 10 million or more for the debate.

title: S.E.C. Names Administrator
description: Richard D. Marshall, a lawyer with Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, has been named the associate regional administrator of the New York office of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: The House Where Gentleman Jim Lived
description: RON and JoAnn Bellistri live in a house in Bayside, Queens, that stops traffic.

title: Robert C. Urban, Executive, 68
description: Robert C. Urban, a former chief executive officer of the American Safety Razor Division of Philip Morris Inc., died of complications yesterday after brain surgery at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 68 years old and lived in Summit, N.J.

title: U.S. Order on Anti-Terror Strikes Is Disclosed
description: President Reagan signed an intelligence order in 1985 that gave the Central Intelligence Agency broader legal protections when it makes pre-emptive strikes against terrorists, according to former Government officials.

title: Amsterdam Journal; Welcome Mat Gone, Flower Children Go Straight
description: In the 1970's, this capital of canals, bicycles and quaintly tinkling streetcars was also a mecca for Western Europe's unruly, irreverent and off-beat - an oasis of drug-laced social experimentation that thrived in a mellow aura of Dutch tolerance.

title: Reviews/Music; Dmitriy Cogan, A Pianist, In Recital Debut
description: Dmitriy Cogan, a young pianist of more than usual dexterity and confidence, made his local solo debut at Weill Recital Hall Monday evening. Mr. Cogan, who comes to New York from Moscow by way of San Francisco, has been studying at Juilliard and has been heard before as the partner of the violinist Alexander Markov. On his own, he tackled six major works and had no appreciable problems with them.

title: Free at Last: a Haven for Horses in the Black Hills
description: Born free, then captured by lasso and caged in pens, some 150 wild horses have been released to gallop along the rocky ridges and steep canyons of the Black Hills, safe from the rope and the rifle.

title: Arbor Drugs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Whistle-Blower Bill Planned
description: Governor Cuomo said today that he would propose legislation next year to extend ''whistle blower'' job protection to those government employees who go to news organizations with their information.

title: Rubicon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
When Inspiration Strikes Twice
description: A. Graves Lounge chair, by Michael Graves for SunarHauserman, was introduced in 1981. B. Round Chair, by David Ebert for Modern Mode, was introduced in 1988.

title: Study Says Piers in Hudson Don't Damage Environment
description: A 26-month study for the Public Development Commission has found that ''platforming'' - constructing large piers for buildings in the Hudson River near the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center - is not environmentally harmful.

title: Ford Introduces New Taurus Model
description: The Ford Motor Company introduced a ''super high output'' version of its popular Taurus model that it said would compete with such luxury imports as BMW and Volkswagen's Audi. The Taurus SHO, which is scheduled to be in dealer showrooms on Dec. 26, will have a base price of $19,700. Ford plans to produce 20,000 Taurus SHO's during the 1989 model year.

title: Loss in Game 1 Doesn't Faze Sox
description: Joe Morgan leaned back in his chair, with his usual post-game beer in front of him. For the manager of a team that had just lost the first game of the American League playoff, he looked relaxed.

title: Erring Official Quits
description: The National Football League instant-replay official who was suspended for two games by Commissioner Pete Rozelle after making a crucial mistake in a game between the Giants and the Dallas Cowboys Sept. 18 has resigned. ''No one forced me to retire,'' said Armen Terzian, a field judge for 21 years. ''The league didn't talk retirement at all. Just two weeks' suspension. I felt when I took the heat off everybody by saying it was my mistake, I sure didn't want to be treated like a little kid and be suspended.'' The play occurred when Darryl Clack of Dallas lost Raul Allegre's opening kickoff in the sun and the ball bounced off his shoulder at the 2-yard line and into the end zone. When Clack was tackled by Mark Collins of the Giants while attempting to run the ball out of the end zone, the referee incorrectly ruled it a safety for the Giants, who won by that 2-point margin, 12-10. Since it was a muff and not a fumble, the officials should have called a touchback which would have given Dallas possession at its 20. At halftime, Terzian admitted that he as replay judge he had erred in not ordering a review of the play.(AP)

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Fulbright on Yakovlev
description: J. W. Fulbright, the former Senator from Arkansas who more than 40 years ago proposed legislation that established the Fulbright Program of exchanges between foreign and American scholars, was in fine fettle at a recent Washington luncheon party.

title: Environmental Study Urges Limiting Rise in Cabs to 400
description: New York City's already bad air and traffic can withstand only a small fraction of the 1,800 new taxicabs authorized by the city last year, an environmental study has concluded.

title: Dense-Pac Microsystems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-Includes a net business interruption insurance claim of $165,000. Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 1-for-2 reverse stock split effective July 13, 1988.

title: Layoffs at Kroger In Defensive Move
description: The Kroger Company said that it was laying off about 300 employees at its headquarters here in a corporate restructuring it is undertaking while fighting two takeover offers. Most of those being laid off have been notified and will leave their jobs Friday, a company spokesman, Paul Bernish, said. Kroger, the nation's largest supermarket operator, said the job reductions would save the company at least $13 million a year.

title: U.N. Talks on Cyprus Peace Settlement Hit Snags
description: A new round of peace talks aimed at ending the division of Cyprus into Greek and Turkish areas by June has run into serious difficulties, according to diplomats and officials involved in the talks.

title: No Oscar, No Knockout
description: George Bush's speech writer, Peggy Noonan, turned to a colleague after the Bentsen-Quayle ''debate'' and gleefully declared: ''It's over. We won the election!'' She's a political professional and may well have been right.

title: Darling and Tudor Meet in a Tie Breaker
description: The National League playoff, tied at one game apiece, switches venues to New York tonight from Los Angeles, the land of fantasy where Kareem Abdul-Jabbar does TV interviews on the grass as Magic Johnson watches from the box seats and the first balls are thrown out by left-handed legends named Sandy Koufax and Fernando Valenzuela.

title: Laborites: The Ideals Still Divide
description: The British Labor Party goes to war with itself every fall at its annual conference in Blackpool, but this year its leader, Neil Kinnock, hardly managed to fight his way to a draw with his own left wing and the big labor unions.

title: Cay M. Andersen, 75, Episcopal Lay Figure
description: Cay M. Andersen, a faith healer and co-founder of the Community of Jesus, a residential religious community based in Orleans, Mass., died of heart failure in her sleep on Wednesday at her home in Orleans. She was 75 years old.

title: Call Those Theaters Anything but Populist
description: To the Editor:

title: Renewal of Wetlands Begins at Queens Bay
description: A city-owned wetland at the edge of Jamaica Bay in Queens - which has attracted abandoned cars and dumped garbage as well as hundreds of species of migrating birds - will be cleaned up and maintained as part of a renewed city effort to preserve ecologically significant sites, according to New York City officials.

title: Topics of The Times; Children in Politics: II
description: An adviser to the Vice President calls Mr. Bush's new children's plan ''holistic.'' ''Opportunistic'' might be more like it. This is not to say that the Bush proposal doesn't have good things in it -only that it seems more like a hastily cobbled-together attempt to steal some thunder from the Democrats than a well-made plan to give poor children a fair chance.

title: Happy With Result, Quayle Says
description: Senator Dan Quayle, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, took his campaign back on the road today, asserting that he had ''showed 'em'' in Wednesday night's debate with Senator Lloyd Bentsen. He charged that Mr. Bentsen had taken a ''cheap shot'' at him.

title: Horizon Healthcare Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $68,000 and a tax credit of $199,000.

title: Chase Offering Preferred Stock
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation yesterday offered 5.6 million shares of $25-a-share perpetual preferred stock through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

Results include the discontinued operations of Confections Inc.; the company's 58 percent interest was sold in July 1988.

title: L.S.U. to Test Auburn Passer
description: After playing two years as the backup quarterback to Jeff Burger at Auburn, Reggie Slack has blossomed into one of the nation's leading passers as the Tigers have gone undefeated through four games.

title: CATHERINE E. ROSS WED TO DAVID ALAN GLASER
description: Catherine Elizabeth Ross and David Alan Glaser were married last evening at Temple Emanu-El in New York by Rabbi Ronald Sobel. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold S. Ross of New York and Bondville, Vt. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Glaser of Freehold, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: A list of Olympic medal winners in SportsMonday this week misidentified a silver medalist in women's tennis doubles and gave her home country incorrectly. She is Jana Novotna; she and her partner, Helena Sukova, are from Czechoslovakia, not the Soviet Union.

title: Washington Talk: Foreign Affairs; Voice of America Has Some Wondrous Plans
description: First there was the telephone call from Minsk, followed by a telephone call from Pinsk. It was a Tuesday morning call-in show from the Soviet Union, just another day at the Voice of America.

title: Mariners Drop Snyder
description: Jim Snyder, who took over as manager of the Seattle Mariners when Dick Williams was dismissed June 6, will not be retained. Instead, a statement issued by the Mariners yesterday said a new manager for the team would be sought from outside the club. ''Jim came in under difficult circumstances and did a job for us,'' said Woody Woodward, vice president of baseball operations. ''He's a good baseball man, and we hope to keep him in our organization.'' Snyder was offered a scouting position with the Mariners, who finished last in the American League West with a 68-93 record, including 45-60 under Snyder. He said he was very disappointed. The Mariners also said that the third-base coach, Bill Plummer, had been offered a job next season, but that the pitching coach, Billy Connors; the batting coach, Frank Howard, and the first-base coach, Howie Bedell, would not be returning. (AP)

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bob Probert, the forward who was suspended by the Detroit Red Wings during training camp for disciplinary reasons, has checked into a drug-alcohol rehabilitation center in California, according to his agent, Pat Duscharme. ''I think it is an accumulative effect,'' Duscharme said. ''We've been working on this since the beginning of last season. He's been confronted by management often.'' . . . Jack Trudeau, who was the Indianapolis Colts' starting quarterback when he suffered damage to cartilage in his left knee Sept. 19, is considering whether to give up the remainder of the season and have immediate reconstructive surgery on the knee or try to finish out the schedule. (AP)

title: LEBANESE AT U.N. ON 2-EDGED SWORD
description: With rival governments both claiming power in Beirut, Lebanese diplomats at the United Nations say they are trying to pursue business as usual ''in the name of the Lebanese state.''

description: * Datakey Inc., Minneapolis, a producer of microelectronic devices for electronic security and process control systems, appointed James E. Donaghy a director.

title: Judge Critical of Prosecution Over Iran-Contra Indictment
description: A Federal district judge today rebuked the prosecution in the Iran-contra affair for having a suspect indicted in Washington for crimes that are alleged to have taken place in another jurisdiction.

title: A Widower Meets the Neighbors in 'Empty Nest'
description: Let's hear it for the widowers living in Florida. The Paul Junger Witt-Tony Thomas-Susan Harris production team, which brought forth ''The Golden Girls,'' is now giving the very successful quartet of women a new neighbor. The neighbor, a widower named Harry Weston, is played by Richard Mulligan, once a star of the Witt-Thomas-Harris series ''Soap.'' He is a pediatrician and the central character in ''Empty Nest,'' the sitcom making its debut on NBC tomorrow night at 9:30 - which, as it happens, is the slot immediately following ''The Golden Girls.'' The crossover potential for characters and storylines is, needless to say, enormous.

title: Polls: The Fog Rolls In
description: LEAD: Shrewd observers of the political scene have concluded that the Presidential race will be decided only in the last three days of the campaign. If they are right - and I think they are - then all polls before that time must be dismissed as giving no valid indication of the final result.

title: Wisconsin Toy Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Concerts Organized On Themes
description: Anyone checking out the musical Zeitgeist of New York City has three major clues from which to form an opinion this weekend. The World Music Institute and Hunter College are presenting a symposium, including concerts, titled ''Immigrant Music in New York City.'' The Caribbean Cultural Center is starting its 10th anniversary season with ''Drumscussion,'' the first of a month's worth of concerts, featuring three of the greatest New Orleans drummers - Vernel Fournier, Earl Palmer and Ed Blackwell - along with Daniel Ponce of Cuba and Babatunde Olatunji of Nigeria. And at Symphony Space, Izulu Dance Theater and Music will be putting on a two-part concert of South African sounds, featuring lush Zulu choral singing and umbaqanga, the electric, urban music.

title: Lady Macbeth a Celt
description: To the Editor:

title: photo of John LennonReview/Film; 'Imagine: John Lennon,' Portrait of a Generation
description: There's a scene in the documentary ''Imagine: John Lennon'' that finds Lennon face to face with one of his most persistent fans. This dazed-looking young man has been caught trespassing on the grounds of the Lennons' estate in Ascot, England, and is now awestruck to be in the presence of his hero. So he wants to talk about Beatles songs. He thinks that when Lennon sang the line ''Boy, you're gonna carry that weight/Carry that weight a long time,'' he himself was the ''Boy'' the singer had in mind.

title: State by State; Quayle and Debate Rate Low on Illinois Campus
description: At the Republican National Convention, Vice President Bush said he had chosen Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana as his running mate because he would appeal to young people and to Midwesterners.

title: New York's Fall Foliage: Where It Is and How to Go
description: Getting there - anywhere north of New York City - is more than half the pleasure these October weekends when the spectacular display of fall foliage is reaching its colorful peak.

title: Tokyo Stocks Off for 5th Day
description: Stock prices fell today as mounting concern over Emperor Hirohito's health sent investors to the sidelines. The Nikkei index dropped by 233.15 points, or 0.85 percent, to 27,172.34. It declined by 95.53 points on Wednesday.

description: The Mighty Brooklyn Skyways will sing gospel music Sunday at 3:30 P.M. at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (475-51230). Tickets are $10.

description: David Melman, a third-year law student, recalls with a certain fascination how one young associate described the ritual at her law firm's recruitment lunches.

title: BRAWLEY MADE UP STORY OF ASSAULT, GRAND JURY FINDS
description: Concluding a seven-month investigation, a New York State grand jury reported an avalanche of evidence yesterday that Tawana Brawley had fabricated her tale of abduction and sexual assault in the hands of a gang of racist white men last year.

title: Advocates Share Strategies And Support for Homeless
description: For Sara Ehmer and other members of her Unitarian church in Rockland County, helping the homeless has always seemed a lonely job. Today Ms. Ehmer, who is a member of her church's social concerns committee, discovered she had company. Lots of company.

title: Abrams Calls for Inquiries On Brawley Lawyers' Role
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams yesterday asked judicial disciplinary panels to investigate the ''conduct and statements'' of the two lawyers who represented Tawana Brawley, the 16-year-old black girl who a grand jury said falsely contended she was the victim of a racially motivated attack.

title: Precision Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest quarter and year included charges of $1,026,000 to cover restructuring costs and projected losses on completion of certain contracts and inventory components.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Try and Try Again
description: It's ''wait till next year'' time on Capitol Hill. With only a few days left in the current session of Congress, members are still introducing bills, but with the realization that they are unlikely to attract the full attention of the lawmakers, who are intent on leaving town. The object of the exercise, they say, is to get a jump on the next session, which begins in January.

title: U.S. Says 'Butt Out' To Those Tampering With Hostage Talks
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that private American citizens were misrepresenting themselves as official spokesmen for the United States Government in trying to arrange hostage deals with Iran, and he said they should ''just butt out.''

description: New York City, acknowledging that many welfare recipients have unfairly been stripped of benefits, will no longer cut off those who fail to answer questionnaires they receive as often as nine times a year.

title: Six-Race Regatta In New York Harbor
description: The first annual International Yacht Club Challenge will be held in New York Harbor today through Sunday, presented by the Manhattan Yacht Club, 207 Front Street. The six-race regatta will feature 20 international yacht clubs sailing identical J-24's.

title: Teams Setting Sail In Hudson Regatta
description: It isn't the America's Cup, but it's as close as anyone can come to an international regatta without spending a lot of money.

title: San Francisco Museum Chooses Swiss Architect
description: The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art has announced that the Swiss architect Mario Botta will design its new building. The $70 million, 175,000-square-foot structure, which is to be built in the Yerba Buena Gardens complex, a development in downtown San Francisco, will double the museum's current exhibition space. It is scheduled to open in 1993. The museum will retain its rights to the War Memorial Veterans Building, where its collection of 20th-century art has been housed since 1935. Museum officials have not decided whether the old Beaux-Arts structure will be used for exhibitions after the new building opens.

title: Metro-Puck Comics Has Wider Audience
description: The recently merged Metro-Puck Comic Network has stretched its audience reach in comics sections of Sunday newspapers across the country by combining the Metro Comics and Puck-the-Comic weekly networks.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report on Tuesday in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page misidentified Gunter Diehl. He is the former West German Ambassador to India and to Japan, not to the United States.

description: Surprised and embittered by a sudden takeover offer, the chairman and chief executive of the Pillsbury Company gave a strong indication today that the Minneapolis-based food-and-restaurant giant would fight, even though analysts are calling the bid more than generous.

title: A.&P. Tender Offer For Delchamps
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, spurned by the management of Delchamps Inc., has taken its $210 million offer for the supermarket company directly to its shareholders. Michael J. Rourke, A.&P.'s vice president of communications, said A.&P. decided Wednesday to begin a $30-a-share tender offer after three unsuccessful attempts in three years to convince Delchamps executives that a merger was in the best interest of shareholders. Delchamps stock closed at $27.125 a share today, up 12.5 cents, in over-the-counter trading.

title: Islanders Tie After 4-1 Lead
description: Goals by Gary Suter, Colin Patterson and Joe Nieuwendyk in a 3-minute-34-second span of the third period overcame a 4-1 Islander lead and gained a 4-4 tie for the Calgary Flames in their season opener tonight.

description: The Digital Equipment Corporation announced an agreement with the Tandy Corporaiton to develop a new line of personal computers to be sold under the Digital label.

title: 6 Savings Executives Held Liable in Maryland
description: A Maryland jury yesterday found that six officers and directors of a now-bankrupt savings institution had breached their fiduciary duties and awarded the Maryland Deposit Insurance Fund $112 million in damages.

title: Weak Quarter for Money Managers
description: LEAD: Mutual fund investors and corporate pension funds shared the same investment fate in the third quarter. On average, their professional money managers failed once again, as they have for most of the decade, even to match the performance of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, according to figures released separately by two research firms yesterday.

title: Muller Jordan Weiss Buys Kelley-Swofford
description: Muller Jordan Weiss has acquired Kelley-Swofford, a $3 million agency in Coral Gables, Fla., whose specialty is travel and tourism. The amount was not disclosed.

title: All Plaintiffs in Suit Against Klan To Be Polled on Staying in Case
description: A Federal judge here said today that he would not unseal a verdict against 10 present and former members of the Ku Klux Klan until more than 50 people who filed the lawsuit had been asked if they wished to remain plaintiffs.

title: Sports of The Times; Return From The Mixed Zone
description: AT the Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, we had to do our interviews in the Mixed Zone, a halfway house between security fences, beseeching athletes to stop and talk to us. We never got to meet the thwarted table-tennis lovers, Ahn Jae Hyung of South Korea and Jiao Zhimin of China, to question them about their discreet four-year courtship whose flame burns even after the Olympic flame has been extinguished.

title: Salvador Leftist to Run For President in March
description: Guillermo Ungo, the elder statesman of El Salvador's political left, will run for President in March, the first leftist to run in an election since civil war broke out nearly a decade ago, his coalition party said today.

Micro Bio-Medics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Tyson Seeks Site Change
description: Mike Tyson doesn't want to fight Frank Bruno in London, and said as much yesterday to Donald Trump.

title: KIM SEIBEL WEDS RANDALL WALTUCH
description: Kim J. Seibel, the daughter of Monroe Seibel and Joy Grayson, both of New York, and Randall E. Waltuch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norton D. Waltuch of Englewood, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla., were married last evening in New York. The ceremony at the Helmsley Palace Hotel was performed by Rabbi Jack Bemporad, assisted by Cantor Nathan Benjamin.

title: Editors' Note
description: The Bridge column on Sept. 6 discussed South Africa's political acceptability in international competitions. The column noted a World Bridge Federation agreement to encourage multiracial play in South Africa and added, ''The organization there is multiracial, with most of the players either Indian or Jewish.''

title: TV Week Network
description: NBC has agreed to commit more than $1 million in advertising to TV Week Network, a joint venture that began recently between Tribune Media Services and Western States Associates. As a result, NBC has become the charter account for the new clearinghouse, which gives advertisers the chance to reach TV Sunday newspaper supplements in 28 markets.

title: Oil Price Is Little Changed: Stability Is Seen as Tenuous
description: Oil prices were little changed yesterday, although analysts said the stability was tenuous.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: A New Fusion Steve Coleman and Five Elements, the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Whether it's jazz or funk or pop - or all of the above in a choppy, shifty amalgam of odd-meter riffs and sidelong solos - Steve Coleman's music is searching for a new kind of fusion that gives musicians something to explore while they lay down a groove. At recent Five Elements dates, Mr. Coleman's compositions have been more innovative than the band's improvisations, but the gap is closing. Tomorrow and Sunday at 9 and 11 P.M.; tickets are $8. Farmer's Fluegelhorn

title: Columbia Pictures Entertainent Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $4,629,000 and $7,875,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Comparable figures are not applicable, since the company changed its fiscal year when it was formed on Dec. 17, 1987, by the combination of Tri-Star Pictures Inc. and the entertainment business sector of Coca-Cola Co. The company said for the second quarter ended Sept. 30, 1987, it had net of $15,835,000, or 21 cents a share, on revenue of $330.3 million; for the 6-month period, the company had final net of $23.8 million, or 24 cents a share, after a $5,912,000 gain on an accounting change, and revenue was $528,707,000.

title: Increasingly, Bad Habits Are Labeled Addicitons
description: These days almost anyone might have an addiction. If it isn't to drugs or alcohol, it's to food, cigarettes, exercise, relationships, sex, shopping, work or even video games. Habits that were once called neuroses, compulsions - or just plain weaknesses - are now described as addictions.

title: People
description: * John F. Trzuskowski has joined Zwiren & Partners, Chicago, as managing partner/creative director.

title: A's Grab 2-0 Lead by Edging Red Sox in the Ninth
description: They have played two games and beaten Boston's two best pitchers, and now they are going home. The Oakland Athletics, who won 104 games during the regular season and sailed into the post-season with extraordinary momentum, crushed the hearts of the faithful at Fenway Park tonight. And now, they are heading west.

title: Summit Health Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Results for the latest year include a $17.1 million pretax loss provision on the closure and sale of unprofitable operations.

title: About Real Estate; Suburbs Reach Hudson Valley Town
description: As suburban sprawl reaches farther and farther into the Hudson Valley, it is beginning to affect some of the smallest farming towns in Orange, Ulster and Dutchess Counties, traditionally known for apple orchards, vineyards and wooded hillsides.

title: Victors' 'First Among Equals' Seeks a Peaceful Transition
description: The political groups that united to campaign for President Augusto Pinochet's defeat in Wednesday's plebiscite had a number of erudite spokesmen but no overwhelming personality. To the extent that there was a visible leader, it was Patricio Aylwin, the smiling, genial president of the Christian Democratic Party, the country's largest party.

title: Steinberg Loses Motion To Exclude Statements
description: Joel B. Steinberg lost his attempt yesterday to exclude from his trial statements he gave to the police before his arrest in the death of Lisa Steinberg.

title: Spraying Begins for Fruit Fly
description: Three helicopters sprayed pesticide tonight over the city's west side and parts of Beverly Hills in an attempt to destroy an infestation of the Mediterranean fruit fly. Forty-seven flies have been found in yards since Sept. 26, a serious infestation that if allowed to spread could threaten fruits and vegetables that are a major part of California's $15.5 billion-a-year farm economy. The pesticide Malathion also was being sprayed over Culver City and West Hollywood.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12 Gen. Pinochet will accept rejection of an extension of his term as President, after 15 years of tough military rule in Chile. Virtually complete unofficial returns showed that the general lost his bid for a new eight-year term. Page A1

title: American President Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 16
description: The company said the latest quarter included pretax income of $23,300,000 from the previously announced sale of a 1,000-acre parcel of land.

title: Mercedes Forecast
description: Mercedes-Benz of North America Inc. projected slower United States sales growth over the next several years, noting greater competition from Japanese and European companies. The company also said it had raised prices for 1989 models an average of 1.7 percent over 1988 prices. The subsidiary of the West German-based Daimler-Benz A.G., said Mercedes-Benz forecasts American sales of 80,000 to 83,000 cars in the 1989, compared with 80,000 in 1988.

title: N.F.L. Matchups; Broncos Hoping To Get Untracked
description: Dan Reeves was mulling over his game plan yesterday for Sunday's contest against San Francisco and was reminded that his Denver Broncos had three consecutive victories against the 49ers.

description: b-Net income

description: The results in U.S. dollars for 1988 and 1987 have been converted from Netherlands guilders at NLG 2.1220 equals U.S. $1.00.

title: Lincoln Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said all share earnings and shares outstanding figures are fully diluted and are adjusted to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend distributed in May 1987 and June 1988.

title: New TV Spots For Pizza Chain
description: A loudmouthed, wildly dressed radio announcer called Spooner Wiggins has become the fast-talking spokesman for Godfather's Pizza. The figure was created by Buckley/ DeCerchio, the fledgling agency run by Tom DeCerchio, 28 years old, and Bryan Buckley, 25. The total ad budget is $6 million.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Touched by War

title: Icahn Talks On Eastern Reported
description: Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines, has held some general talks about a possible takeover of Eastern Airlines with the head of the machinists' union at Eastern, people familiar with the talks said yesterday.

title: Troubled Cone Stops the Press
description: David Cone, distraught over the controversy that flared over his remarks as a newspaper commentator on the National League playoff, has relinquished his literary career to focus on his baseball career.

title: Robinson Wants Ball
description: David Robinson would like to get out of the Navy and begin earning some of the $26 million he will be paid by the San Antonio Spurs. According to his father, Ambrose, the 7-1 Robinson will seek an early release from the two years he has left on his Navy commitment. Robinson, who was on leave to play for the United States Olympic team, has returned to his civil engineering job at Kings Bay, Ga. . . . The Nets, in need of guards after losing Dennis Hopson, whose sprained ankle will keep him out of training camp, signed Frank Johnson. He played the last seven seasons with the Washington Bullets. The 29-year-old Johnson, a 6-foot-3-inch free agent, could be an asset as a playmaker if he can stay healthy. Johnson has had three stress fractures in his left foot. . . . The Spurs have signed Alvin Robertson, their All-Star guard, to a seven-year contract, five of which are guaranteed, that will pay him a reported $950,000 a year. . . . Nine of the N.B.A.'s 25 first-round picks, including Danny Manning of the Los Angeles Clippers, the first player selected, remain unsigned.

title: P. B. Wald, 57, Official Of Liberty Foundation
description: Palmer Bernard Wald, the vice president of the Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation, died Wednesday in St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 57 years old and lived on the Upper West Side.

title: Staff Builders Inc (NY)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Paine Webber Settles Charges
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has reached a settlement with Paine Webber Inc. over complaints that the investment company had mishandled the account of a Roman Catholic charity that lost millions of dollars.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Drexel Burnham Lambert was denied its motion to disqualify the judge hearing the securities fraud case against the firm, four executives and others. The decision does not end the legal struggle over Federal District Judge Milton Pollack but was nonetheless seen as a victory for the Government. [ D1. ] Coniston Partners proposed a friendly merger with TW Services, the operator of Hardee's fast-food stores and Denny's family-style restaurants, for $28 a share. Coniston recently paid an average of $19.80 to buy 19.1 percent of TW. [ D1. ] Pillsbury's chairman indicated that the company would fight to remain independent, resisting a $60-a-share, $5.23 billion bid by Grand Metropolitan. He faces an uphill battle on Wall Street, as most of Pillsbury's stock is said to be held by arbitragers. [ D1. ] The nation's retailers showed modest gains in September. Several retailers recorded sales increases of 3 percent or less - meaning they continued to lose ground to inflation. [ D1. ] A Maryland jury found that six officers and directors of a bankrupt Maryland savings institution breached their fiduciary duties and awarded $112 million to the state insurance agency. [ D2. ] Recognition Equipment and two top executives were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Washington on charges of conspiring to defraud the United States Postal Service. [ D2. ] Carl C. Icahn has discussed a takeover of Eastern Airlines with the machinists' union at Eastern, people familiar with the talks said, adding that the talks were in an exploratory phase. [ D4. ] The Hospital Corporation of America said it would reject a leveraged buyout bid for about $47 a share, or $3.3 billion. [ D4. ] Chrysler and Fiat announced a 50-50 venture to distribute Alfa Romeo cars in the United States and Canada. [ D4. ] The Cooper Companies signed a letter of intent to sell its surgical ophthalmic products business to Alcon Laboratories Inc., a subsidiary of Nestle, for about $325 million. [ D4. ] MARKETS

description: Something about filling in seems to appeal to Stephen Baker.

title: William P. Connors, Photographer, 59
description: William P. Connors, a fashion photographer, died of cancer Sept. 29 at his home in the Coconut Grove area of Miami. He was 59 years old.

title: Note and Bond Prices Sluggish
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved sluggishly in a very narrow range for the fourth consecutive session yesterday, as market participants nervously awaited this morning's report on September employment.

title: Devils Lose, Rangers Tie in Openers; Rangers 2, Blackhawks 2
description: The Rangers played an essentially solid defensive game tonight, but their fears about an inability to score goals were largely realized as they scrapped to a 2-2 draw with the Chicago Blackhawks in the season opener for both teams.

title: First American Health Conepts Inc reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: 2 Lawyers Say Police Searched The Davis Home
description: The trial of Larry Davis was disrupted yesterday when the defense said that police officers had entered Mary Davis's home with guns drawn shortly after she had finished testifying Wednesday as a witness for her son.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Lobbying for Nurses
description: Partly because of a letter written to every member of the House of Representatives by last year's Miss America, Kaye Lani Rae Rafko of Michigan, the House has approved a measure intended to ease the shortage of nurses by allowing foreign nurses to stay in the United States even though their visas have expired or are about to.

title: Dining Out Guide: Late-Night Places
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Cafe Luxembourg

title: Luther Medical Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Senate Panel Faults Aide on Role in Bork Hearings
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee has found that a committee aide acted inappropriately when she discouraged a witness from testifying last year in behalf of the nomination of Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court, which was ultimately rejected by the Senate.

title: Allen O. Felix, 72, Ex-Stock Exchange Aide
description: Dr. Allen O. Felix, retired director of educational services for the New York Stock Exchange, died of myeloma on Tuesday at his home in Paramus, N.J. He was 72 years old. Dr. Felix held a bachelor's degree in mathematics from the University of Colorado and a doctorate in education from Teachers College of Columbia University, where he taught for five years before joining the Stock Exchange in 1955. He was its first educational services director, working with college and high-school students and teachers to help them understand the stock market. He retired in 1985. He was a Denver native and served in the Navy during World War II, rising to the rank of lieutenant commander.

title: Harvard Knitwear Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
Psychiatrist's View of Tyson
description: Dr. Abraham L. Halpern, the psychiatrist who said Mike Tyson was not a manic-depressive after examining him Tuesday, said yesterday that he had based his opinion on a 30-minute clinical interview and an hour of observing Tyson with his boxing manager and friends.

title: Scientist Assails a U.S. Nuclear Verification Plan
description: A senior scientist at a Federal weapons laboratory told Congress today that the Reagan Administration's plan for verifying limits on nuclear testing was too stringent and could interfere with the program to develop new nuclear devices.

title: The Bentsen-Quayle Whatever
description: It was not a debate. It was not even a good news conference. It was a staged, manipulated, choreographed performance, stilted and artificial. At the end the most important question remained unanswered.

title: Murder in the Cathedral Reflects Failed Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Up by 1.24 in Dull Day As Investors Await Job Data
description: Stocks gained a bit yesterday but many investors stayed away from the market, awaiting the nation's September unemployment figures, which will be released today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Big Lead for Rizzo: Patti Rizzo started with three straight birdies and finished with three more on the way to a seven-under-par 65 and a four-stroke lead yesterday after the first round of the Takara Invitational in Hinocho, Japan. ''I had my best putting in my life today,'' Rizzo said. ''It's first time I've had nine birdies in one round.''(AP) Kite Is Fifth: Masashi Ozaki shot a bogey-free 67 yesterday and took the opening-round lead in the Japan Open in Sayama. Tom Kite, who shot a 72, was tied with Toshimitsu Izawa for fifth place and David Ishii of Honolulu was in a group at 73.(AP) Two Share Lead: Dave Hill and Lou Graham matched two-under-par 68's and shared the first-round lead yesterday in the Vantage Championship in Clemmons, N.C. Hill scored three of his five birdies in putts of 20, 30 and 45 feet. Graham is the 1975 United States Open champion and a rookie among golfers over 50. (AP) Brooks Moves Up: Mark Brooks shot an eight-under-par 64 yesterday and joined Bobby Clampett and Tom Purtzer as first-round leaders in the $400,000 Gatlin Brothers Southwest Golf Classic in Abilene, Tex. ''I waited until the wind started blowing to get going,'' said Brooks, a former University of Texas All-American from Fort Worth. Brooks was 1 over par through three holes, then birdied five of the next six holes and eagled the seventh by holing a sand wedge from 97 yards out.(AP)

title: Boston Curator Named
description: Kathy Halbreich has been named to head the new department of contemporary art at the Museum of Fine Arts here, the museum's director, Alan Shestack, announced last week. Ms. Halbreich, whose appointment is effective Nov. 28, is currently curator of an international exhibition on art of the 1980's for the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington, scheduled to open in January 1990.

title: Campaign Trail; Tsongas Cites Views On Capital Gains Tax
description: Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas says he does not miss politics, Presidential or local. But the 47-year-old Boston lawyer, who decided not to seek re-election to the Senate after being told in October 1983 that that he had nodular lymphoma, a mild cancer of the lymph nodes, remains involved in the Dukakis campaign. And Mr. Tsongas is disturbed that Vice President Bush keeps using his name.

title: Employee Rights Bill Introduced in Senate
description: Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, has introduced a bill that would extend to Senate employees protection against job discrimination based on race, sex, age or handicaps. A similar bill was approved this week in the House of Representatives.

title: Valley Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Pitching and Bench Deliver for Dodgers
description: Deep in the Dodger psyche, in a place that is not shared with the dozens of people asking questions about the National League Championship Series against the Mets, an important question had to be answered in the affirmative Wednesday night.

title: Reform Effort In Hungary
description: Hungary's lawmakers resumed debate today on tax laws that are among reforms intended to move the country toward a market-oriented economy. On Wednesday, members of

title: Concept 90 Marketing Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Chrysler to Distribute Alfa Romeos in U.S.
description: A joint venture to distribute Alfa Romeo cars in the United States and Canada was announced today by the Chrysler Corporation and the Italian auto maker Fiat S.p.A., which owns Alfa Romeo.

title: Addenda
description: * Alzed Communications, a division of Alzed Enterprises Ltd., Pittsburgh, a communications industry executive search and placement firm whose specialty is advertising positions, has opened a New York office.

title: Jacqueline Friend, 72, Psychology Professor
description: Jacqueline Friend, a psychology professor and the New York State coordinator of pre-retirement planning for the American Association of Retired Persons, died of cancer Wednesday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. She was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Highest-Paid Piston
description: The Detroit Pistons made Isiah Thomas the highest-paid player in club history yesterday, agreeing to a contract that will pay the 6-foot-1-inch guard a reported $16 million over the next eight years. Thomas had been trying for months to restructure a contract that called for him to make $750,000 this season. General Manager Jack McCloskey said there never was any question that Thomas deserved a raise. The problem was finding a way to give Thomas the money he wanted while remaining within the league salary cap of $7.232 million. How was it done? ''Voodo economics,'' Thomas said, laughing. . . . Andrew Toney, the Philadelphia 76ers' guard, failed to report to training camp, and General Manager John Nash said Toney's agent, Bob Wright, told him the eight-year veteran was experiencing pain in his feet and ''indicated Andrew is on the brink of retirement and will formalize a statement next week.'' (AP)

title: Public School Students To Receive Uniforms
description: In the belief that dressing the city's public school children in uniforms might improve discipline, Mayor Koch said yesterday that he had persuaded a manufacturer to donate enough clothes for a pilot project in a city school.

title: George Bush's Candidate
description: When he asked Senator Dan Quayle what Mr. Quayle would do if he suddenly became President, Tom Brokaw observed that the question could not simply be brushed aside as hypothetical. ''It is, sir, after all, the reason why we are here tonight.'' Mr. Brokaw got it right. Wednesday night's debate between the two Vice-Presidential candidates was not a debate. Nor was it an examination of Dan Quayle's or Senator Lloyd Bentsen's qualifications for the Vice Presidency. It was an examination of their fitness to be President, and a test of the judgment of the two men who chose them.

title: Nu Horizons Electronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31

BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Dow Chemical Names Essex Unit's President
description: LEAD: The Dow Chemical Company yesterday named William S. Stavropoulos, a group vice president, to the additional posts of president and chief executive of the Essex Chemical Corporation, which it acquired last month for about $366 million.

title: British Steel To Be Sold
description: The British Government said today that it would sell the state-owned British Steel Company to the public next month at a price to be disclosed later.

title: Market Place; Maxicare Faces Tough Comeback
description: INVESTORS and bondholders counting on a miracle cure from the new management of the troubled Maxicare Health Plans Inc. will have to settle for a more old-fashioned remedy.

title: FOES URGING RECONCILIATION
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet spoke to the nation tonight and accepted his defeat in Wednesday's plebiscite on an extension of his term in office.

title: Zenith Relinquishes Stockholders List
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation agreed to hand over a list of its stockholders to a group of dissidents and said the group's attempt to wage a proxy fight against Zenith management would not trigger the company's takeover defense.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CLEVELAND (AL) - Named Dom Chiti roving minor league pitching coach.

title: Show Your A.C.L.U. Card With Pride, Governor
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Geoffrey Household, 87, Novelist Who Wrote Suspense Works, Dies
description: Geoffrey Household, one of the British authors who helped to develop the suspense story into an art form, died Tuesday. He was 87 years old and lived near Banbury, 65 miles from London.

title: Shultz Diary: U.N. Visitors All Day Long
description: When Secretary of State George P. Shultz meets foreign ministers in his suite at the United Nations Plaza Hotel, he often greets them by saying, ''Welcome to my dentist's office.''

title: Hardman-Cook Quintet
description: Bill Hardman on trumpet and Junior Cook on saxophone will lead a quintet tonight and tomorrow at Birdland, 2745 Broadway, at 105th Street (749-2228). Music begins at 9 P.M.; there is a $5 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Review/Art; The Cosmopolitanism of 19th-Century Poland
description: ''Nineteenth-Century Polish Painting'' at the National Academy of Design is a great deal of fun, even if some of the best things in it are not by Poles and do not date from the 19th century. Neither of these facts need inconvenience the visitor. The exhibition as a whole is animated by the cosmopolitan spirit that was very much alive in Poland during the reign of King Stanislaus Augustus and continued unabated when Poland was wiped off the map of Europe in 1795. Gifted foreigners were welcome in Poland, and gifted or good-looking Poles of both sexes were welcome throughout Europe - above all, perhaps, in Paris.

title: Algiers Imposes Emergency After Protest
description: The Government imposed a state of emergency and a curfew today after three days of violent protests against high prices and unemployment.

title: Film Festival; In a City Where Life Is Just Barely Possible
description: Krishna, a small, spindly legged 10-year-old country boy, is kicked out of the house by his mother and told not to return until he has 500 rupees to pay for a bicycle he has ruined. Krishna drifts to the nearest big city where, without effort, he is absorbed into Bombay's proliferating population of homeless street kids.

title: At the Bar
description: As 6-year-old Lisa Steinberg was beaten and subsequently died last year, her West 10th St. neighbors were too powerless or too indifferent to act. Nor had most of them ever spoken up on the many previous occasions when violence rocked the apartment of her purported parents, Joel Steinberg and Hedda Nussbaum.

title: Trust Amer Service Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Blasius Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $325,000. c-Includes a gain of $87,000 from the repurchase of notes.

title: Devils Lose, Rangers Tie in Openers; Flyers 4, Devils 1
description: The National Hockey League's new rule on high-sticking and an inspired performance by Ron Hextall in goal were the chief elements in the Devils' 4-1 loss to the Flyers in their opener tonight.

title: Abrams and Grand Jury Propose Changes in Laws
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams proposed changes in state law yesterday that he said would make it possible to prosecute people who harbor such fugitives as Glenda Brawley.

title: Indictments In Postal Fraud Case
description: Recognition Equipment Inc., an information processing company in Irving, Tex., and two top executives were indicted today by a Federal grand jury in Washington on charges of conspiring to defraud the United States Postal Service.

title: An Officer Is Indicted In Shooting of Youth
description: A 28-year-old New York City police officer was indicted yesterday on charges that he shot a 15-year-old Brooklyn boy in the leg after the youth surrendered.

title: Restaurants
description: Eze
