title: Review/Music; Itzhak Perlman in Recital
description: For luxury of tone and visceral musicality, there is probably no more talented violinist in the world than Itzhak Perlman. Also no violinist more successful. Success at its worst, however, operates in inverse proportion: an ever-growing number of fans demanding to hear an ever-shrinking repertory of comforting favorites.

title: When a Bargain Fur Is No Bargain
description: Fur discounts this season have started before the first frost, and advertisements promise mink coats for as little as $1,499. What kind of mink can you get at that price?

title: Palestinians Report 4 Killed By Israeli Troops in Nablus
description: Four Palestinians were shot and killed today by Israeli soldiers trying to quash rioting that broke out during the funeral of an Arab killed in the West Bank city of Nablus, Palestinians said.

title: Corrections
description: The About New York column on Tuesday, about the revival of a literary magazine at Walton High School in the Bronx, misattributed ''Lollipop Kiss,'' a poem in the magazine. The poem was submitted by a student, Deneen Fripp, who says she was credited as the author through a misunderstanding. It was written by Dorothy E. King, who published it in the April 1987 issue of Essence magazine.

title: Green Replaces Piniella As Manager of Yankees
description: George Steinbrenner, as expected, changed managers yesterday for the 16th time in his 16 years as the Yankees' principal owner. Steinbrenner dismissed Lou Piniella for the second time in 355 days and replaced him with Dallas Green, a former major league pitcher, manager, general manager and club president. Green received a two-year contract.

title: Mercedes-Benz to Offer Used-Car Warranties
description: Mercedes-Benz of North America is testing a program to guarantee the quality of its used cars in an effort to increase their resale prices.

title: Accept Soviet Offer Of Bases' Trade-Off
description: To the Editor:

title: Life Sentence in Hostage Case
description: Clutching a Bible and wiping his eyes, James L. Harvey was sentenced Friday to life in prison plus 20 years for taking 110 people hostage at a church school in Tuscaloosa for 12 hours on Feb. 2. Mr. Harvey, 43 years old, had pleaded guilty at the encouragement of his sisters, cutting short a trial in which he had maintained that, in his actions at the school, he was exercising his right to bear arms and was making a statement for the nation's homeless, poor and illiterate.

title: Regular Size Lighters Being Recalled by Bic
description: Bic is recalling its new, regular size fixed-flame cigarette lighters because some of them may fail to extinguish, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said today.

title: Radio City Without Radio: WNBC Is Gone
description: With voices from its past - Jack Benny, Bob Hope, Lowell Thomas, George Burns and Gracie Allen, among others - and a hectic sort of wake at its offices at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, WNBC-AM broadcast for the last time yesterday, ending 66 years of history.

title: Gen. Louis Buehl, 56, No. 3 in Marine Corps
description: Lieut. Gen. Louis H. Buehl 3d, Chief of Staff of the Marine Corps, died at Bethesda Naval Medical Center on Wednesday after suffering a stroke, the Pentagon said Thursday. He was 56 years old, General Buehl had held the No. 3 post in the Marine Corps since October 1987. He was outranked by the the Commandant and the Assistant Commandant.

title: Consumer Credit Increased By $5.44 Billion in August
description: American consumers borrowed $5.44 billion more than they paid off in August, as auto loans and credit card debt grew rapidly, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: Patents; Severed Nerves Attached By Electric Current
description: A group of scientists received patent approval this week for a method of using electric current to repair severed nerves. The method has been tested in small animals, and the inventors hope to obtain Federal approval for human tests within a year.

title: Confusion for Philadelphia Homeless
description: At the privately owned shelter for the homeless where she lived with her two infant children, Brownzella Bell was preparing a breakfast bottle for her 3-month-old when she learned that her family would have to be out by 10 A.M.

title: Unemployment: The Biggest States
description: Civilian unemployment. Figures are seasonally adjusted.

title: Post-Gretzky Oilers Top Islanders, 5-1
description: Jimmy Carson, the key player obtained by Edmonton from Los Angeles in the trade that sent Wayne Gretzky to the Kings, scored two goals, and Jari Kurri had three assists tonight as the Oilers opened their season with a 5-1 victory over the Islanders.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-5 Early resignation of Chile's leader, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, was demanded by a jubilant crowd in Santiago. But the general showed no sign of resigning before the Constitution requires. Page 1 News analysis: After Chile's vote to end Gen. Augusto Pinochet's rule, it may face a more difficult task: sorting through many political options and at least two dozen political parties to find the next President. 4 The crisis in Yugoslavia is now being debated in the streets. Along with the worsening economic problems, and growing ethnic tension has come the rise of a Serbian nationalist leader, Slobodan Milosevic. 1 Burma's political struggle has ended its initial phase of protest in faiure, the result of a military crackdown. But many diplomats say long-term change through multiparty elections remains possible.

title: Car Careens Onto Sidewalk And Kills 5 Wisconsin Girls
description: A /peeding car struck a utility pole tonight and careened into five girls on a sidewalk, killing all of them, the authorities said.

title: Judge Allows Seven Shelters; Surprises Foes
description: Less than 48 hours after three borough presidents claimed they had won a lawsuit to block the Koch administration's plan to build 11 shelters for the homeless, a Brooklyn judge ruled yesterday that the city could proceed with seven of them and rejected the borough leaders' most sweeping legal argument.

title: Uniforms: Schools Like Idea
description: Thomas Nardone, an assistant principal at P.S. 126 was quick to call the Board of Education yesterday to ask that his school be selected for a pilot project to put public school students in uniform.

title: NEAR 14-YEAR LOW
description: The nation's unemployment rate fell two-tenths of a point in September, to 5.3 percent, the Labor Department reported today. At the same time the slowdown in creating new jobs continued, easing fear that the economy would expand too rapidly.

title: Rummaging in Broadcasting's Attic
description: Nostalgia reigns at the Smithsonian's National Portrait Gallery where a new exhibition, ''On the Air: Pioneers of American Broadcasting,'' opened today.

title: Budget Rental Studies Sale
description: The Budget Rent a Car Corporation, the nation's third-largest car rental concern, said today that it had hired financial advisers to explore ways of raising the value of the company, which might include its possible sale.

title: Patents; Improving Time-Release Medication
description: Hans Lowey, a pioneer in time-release drugs during the 1950's, won patent approval this week for his seventh improvement in the field. ''I have the feeling I have contributed something,'' said Mr. Lowey, 81 years old, as he reflected on his career.

title: Jaruzelski Encounters His Complaining People
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski took his case, Gorbachev style, directly to the Polish people this week, and was swamped with bitter complaints.

title: Yale University Buys Renaissance Archive
description: An enormous trove of Italian Renaissance and later manuscripts and documents, forming the archive of the prominent Spinelli banking family of Florence over a period of 500 years, has been bought for an undisclosed sum by Yale University, its officials have announced.

title: Shoreham License Recommendation Is Overturned
description: A Federal licensing board's recommendation that the Shoreham nuclear plant receive a full-power operating license was overturned yesterday by an appeals panel of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: Water Supplies In Ground Held Generally Safe
description: The nation's vast stores of underground water are generally still of good quality, but contamination is being discovered with increasing frequency, according to a report issued today by the United States Geological Survey.

title: Review/Theater; 'Dinner at 8,' 30's Fare, Is Served Up Anew
description: George Cukor's movie adaptation of ''Dinner at Eight'' was a paradigm of the all-star films that tumbled out of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in the 1930's. Top studio stars (including John and Lionel Barrymore, Marie Dressler and Jean Harlow) turned it into one of the glossiest and most popular of Hollywood movies.

title: Police Clear Officers in Shooting of Sergeant
description: None of the police officers involved in the accidental shooting of a sergeant last Saturday during the arrest of three suspects in a kidnapping will be disciplined, the police said yesterday.

title: David Finkle, Investor, 86
description: David Finkle, a private investor, died Tuesday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla., after a long illness. He was 86 years old.

title: Tax Accord By ARCO
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said today that it had agreed to pay $172.3 million to the Alaska Department of Revenue, which will substantially resolve a 10-year tax dispute over oil and gas production income from the company's Prudhoe Bay and Cook Inlet operations.

title: Prokofiev's Piano Sonatas
description: Barbara Nissman will play the nine piano sonatas of Sergei Prokofiev and several of the composer's short works in three Wednesday concerts this season at Alice Tully Hall. The first program will be at 8 P.M. Oct. 19; the others will be on Nov. 16 and Feb. 1, both at 8 P.M. The nine sonatas, composed between 1907 and 1947, provide a chronicle of artistic growth. Tickets - $12 for each concert or $30 for all three - are available at the box office or through Center Charge: 874-6770.

title: Ruling on Challenger Tape to be Reconsidered
description: A Federal appeals court has agreed to reconsider its decision ordering the space agency to release the audio tape recording of seven astronauts' last moments before they died in the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger in 1986.

title: Irving Signs Merger Deal, Ending Fight
description: The Irving Bank Corporation's board yesteday signed an agreement to merge with the Bank of New York, ending a yearlong struggle to avoid the unwanted takeover. The merger agreement raises the curtain on a new, more private struggle within Bank of New York to wring more profits from the enlarged company.

title: New York and New Jersey Jobless Rates Decline
description: Unemployment rates in New York and New Jersey declined slightly in September, and New York's average unemployment rate for the first nine months of this year was lower than the rate in the same period last year, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Flight Delays on the Rise in Chicago
description: Like other passengers on United Airlines Flight 558 from Lincoln, Neb., Keith Cook hit the ground running the other night, briefcase flapping and coat flying as he raced for the television monitors showing information on connecting flights.

title: Is There a Doctor In the Cabin?
description: ON March 27 Prof. Ben Bagdikian was flying home to San Francisco from New York with his wife, Marlene. The United Airlines flight was about two hours from its destination when he experienced something he said was rare for him, intense heartburn. He attributed it to the carrot cake, but in 20 minutes the pain did not get any better. Professor Bagdikian then became the central figure in an anxious drama that air passengers sometimes witness without ever learning how the captain made the decision to divert or not to divert the flight.

title:
DINING OUT;
Tastes of Thailand in Scarsdale
description: LEAD: Diners who found Bangkok 54 a disappointment in its opening weeks last March might want to have another look. The kitchen and service have reached an efficient stride, and all the dishes listed on the lenghy menu are now available.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Poll Planned on Accessory Apartments
description: LEAD: A TELEPHONE poll to be conducted this month by the Coalition on Affordable Rental Housing will seek a clearer picture of how Long Island residents feel about accessory apartments in neighborhoods of single-family homes.

title: THE PLAYOFFS: How It Happened; Sticky Situation for Dodger Reliever
description: In an action unprecedented in post-season baseball play, Jay Howell, the Los Angeles Dodgers' No. 1 relief pitcher, was ejected from the third game of the National League pennant playoff yesterday for having pine tar on his glove.

title: Let's Keep Our Expectations In Fair Territory
description: WHY do our sports heroes disappoint us so? Since Watergate, Vietnam, Gary Hart and Iranscam, it's hard for politicians to surprise and disappoint us with their sins. But when the news breaks that Lawrence Taylor (or Dwight Gooden or Keith Hernandez) is messing with drugs, that Mike Tyson is terrorizing his wife, that Ben Johnson's speed has been boosted illegally, then it's a knife right into our expectations. ''Say it ain't so. . . .'' and then fill in the blank with the name of one of your favorite stars.

title: Amusement Park: A Casino's Gamble
description: A DECADE after the first casino opened here, the casino scene has added something totally different - a two-acre, $19 million indoor amusement park with a four-story Ferris wheel, a roller coaster and a fun house.

title: Musical 'Drood' Enlists the Audience
description: THE intensity and passion in the writings of Charles Dickens make his work especially suitable to the stage.

title: Review/Jazz; Dick Katz and Michael Moore Pool Talents
description: The pianist Dick Katz is a fixture on the New York jazz scene, playing with big bands - the American Jazz Orchestra, Loren Schoenberg's orchestra - and in small groups. On Thursday night he played at Zinno with the bassist Michael Moore; duets allow a pianist to strech out, and Mr. Katz took full advantage of his opportunity.

title: Steeples And Schnapps In Westphalia
description: IN the south Munsterland town of Werne, the towering Gothic steeple of the large, light-filled Hallenkirche was restored last year. When it was time for the reinstallation of the cross and the five-foot-high cock on top of it, the priest blessed them. Music blared while the whole town watched as workmen climbed the narrow steeple to put the top-heavy cock back and remove the scaffolding.

title: A Scribe's Outfitters in London
description: PETER WOOLF, a pen enthusiast who deals in both new and old writing implements, uncapped a handsome fountain pen and doodled with a little piece of history. His pen, a gold-capped Parker 51, was one of the midcentury's most popular models before it was discontinued in the 1960's. General Eisenhower used an early Parker 51 to sign documents marking the end of World War II. And these days, restored Parker 51's, priced from $145, are the fastest selling item at Penfriend, Mr. Woolf's well-stocked shop in the Bush House Arcade on the Strand in London. ''Handwriting is one of the few crafts we can all use to express ourselves all of our lives,'' he said, signing his name with a flourish. ''And the Parker 51 was a wonderful pen.'' Fountain pens are enjoying new popularity on both sides of the Atlantic, burnished by nostalgia, renewed appreciation of their appearance and what one fan terms a reaction against the computerized world. Most of the surviving fountain pen makers, including Parker, Sheaffer and Waterman, have brought out stylish remakes of their earlier models; Mont Blanc never stopped producing its thick black Masterpiece of the 1920's. Sales of vintage pens restored to mint condition, like the Parker Duofold or the Conway Stewart Dinkie, have also boomed in recent years, with prices for the rarest soaring past $3,000.

title: Pavarotti Is Finding New Horizons
description: With all the superstar glitter that usually attends Luciano Pavarotti's activities - and overshadows what truly matters about him -it is reassuring to note that he takes his art seriously enough to extend the borders of his familiar repertory. The tenor is now heard in a pair of new recordings of Bellini's ''Norma'' and Mozart's ''Idomeneo,'' and, although surrounded by pre-eminent singers, it is his contribution that proves to be the strongest asset of both sets.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-25

title: Fears and Opportunism Aborted Shoreham
description: Ross Fleisig's ''Nuclear Phobia Over Shoreham'' [ Opinion, Aug. 21 ] is both informative and welcome, because I am convinced numerous people do favor use of the completed power station to end Nassau and Suffolk energy problems.

title: Canada's Future
description: 'Ours is above all an agenda of confidence for Canada.' - Brian Mulroney, Prime Minister of Canada, calling a general election in which the primary issue is a free-trade agreement that the Conservative Government has negotiated with the United States.

title: Review/Music; Adaptation of Medieval 'Romance of the Rose'
description: A pleasing and sometimes beautiful entertainment based on ''The Romance of the Rose'' opened on Friday night at the Mannes College of Music (150 West 85th Street). It is billed as a 15th-century music drama, which is not quite right, but Paul C. Echols's instincts for imaginative dramatic presentation of pre-Renaissance music are often right indeed. Further performances are to be heard tonight, Friday, Saturday and next Sunday.

title: Senate Backs Infectious-Waste-Disposal Bill
description: Legislation to combat midnight dumping of medical wastes has won Senate approval and now goes back to the House for further action.

title: SMALL IS DEADLY
description: AT DEATH'S DOOR By Robert Barnard. 200 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $15.95. OPEN SEASON By Archer Mayor. 319 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $18.95.

title: Indiana Overpowers Ohio State by 41-7
description: Anthony Thompson scored four times in the first half, setting Indiana game, season and career scoring records in leading the Hoosiers to a 41-7 Big Ten Conference rout of Ohio State today.

title: SCHOLARS DISCUSS BLACK STRUGGLES
description: At the first Pan-African conference, held in London in 1900, the issues of black empowerment and South Africa led the agenda. For the black scholars who gathered this weekend in Manhattan, little has changed.

title: Barking Teacher Captivates Class
description: SHE goes to school every day, wearing a blue and yellow backpack. But she is unlike any of her classmates at the Stanley T. Williams Elementary School in North Branford.

title: WHO'S THE MOLE?
description: THE NINTH CIRCLE By N. J. Crisp. 271 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: FICTION
description: WONDERFUL YEARS, WONDERFUL YEARS. By George V. Higgins. (Holt, $19.95.) George V. Higgins's ''Wonderful Years, Wonderful Years'' is the latest in his chronicles of low, middle and upscale criminal life in and around Boston. Let it be said straight away that he has one of the best ears for the spoken word of any writer of fiction since Ring Lardner. This permits him to bring off a very difficult task: he advances his plot action and character development almost entirely through dialogue. In the hands of anyone less skilled, this verbal volleyball of direct and indirect quotations would likely be a disaster. A former Federal prosecutor, Mr. Higgins knows the intricacies of law enforcement and the gray world inhabited by business people who operate on the thinnest of ethical and legal ice. This very readable, often hilarious book concerns a public-works contractor, his loopy wife, his chauffeur and the chauffeur's present and former girlfriends, a whole fog bank of lawyers, both pleasant and nasty, and assorted minor characters. The plot is complex, and at its core are a couple of politically ambitious Federal prosecutors who are eager to further their careers by hanging the contractor out to dry, preferably in some dark lockup. Mr. Higgins's expertise does not stop with law enforcement. He also has a convincing knowledge of mental illness and, wonder of wonders, manages in an essentially comic novel to introduce with empathy and understanding the terror of the threat of AIDS as it suddenly descends on some unsuspecting individuals.

title: Headliners; Telling His Side
description: Representative Pat Swindall would like to make a campaign swing through a Federal courtroom. Mr. Swindall, a Georgia Republican who is locked in a tight re-election battle, last week took the floor of the House to demand that Federal authorities indict him immediately so he could answer allegations of his involvement in a money-laundering scheme. Mr. Swindall has testified before a grand jury and although he has not been charged, press reports about the case have hurt his campaign.

title: THE CONSERVATIVE WORD
description: COLUMN RIGHT Conservative Journalists in the Service of Nationalism. By David Burner and Thomas R. West. 115 pp. New York: New York University Press.

title: FROESE HOLDS OFF THRID-PERIOD FLURRY
description: Momentum, like most anything else one might lose on a frozen surface, is difficult to retrieve. The Rangers, who had it for two periods, flopped and floundered and grasped and grappled in pursuit of it in the third period. They never recovered it, but somehow - good fortune and fine goaltending had a lot to do with it - they managed to cling to their lead and hang on for a 4-2 victory over the Blues tonight.

title: THE NATION: The Politics of Protectionism; When Running for President, It's Hard to Be Free on Trade
description: WHEN Senator John F. Kennedy and Vice President Richard M. Nixon were contesting the White House in 1960, Mr. Kennedy listened sympathetically to domestic textile producers' pleas for protection against cotton apparel from Japan.

title: Prospects; Airlines of the World, Unite
description: The Texas Air Corporation and Scandinavian Airlines Systems last week announced an alliance between the two companies that would link their schedules and flights around the world. In the agreement, S.A.S. also has the right to purchase up to 10 percent of Texas Air within the next six months. Texas Air, which lost $255.9 million in the second quarter of 1988 and has developed a reputation for poor service, will receive $50 million from S.A.S. and benefit from that airline's reputation for high quality. Will we see a proliferation of international airline alliances? Daniel M. Kasper Director of the transportation group at Harbridge House.

title: How the Brain Works: Meeting of the Minds Seeks New Insight
description: SINCE science is a product of brains interacting with brains, understanding how a person's three pounds of gray matter perceives and theorizes about the world is perhaps the most basic question of all. In the last few years, new methods of brain scanning, genetic manipulation, computer modeling and other techniques have led many neuroscientists to predict that they are finally on the verge of linking psychology and biology and developing theories of the mind. This optimism was clear late last month at a conference in Cambridge, Mass., sponsored by Nature, the British science journal, and audaciously titled ''How the Brain Works.''

title: Football Faces a 100-Yard Loss
description: LEAD: For football fans, the thud of colliding shoulder pads is the sweet music of autumn. But few realize that silent stadiums and fields are a distinct possibility in the next 10years. Two events reflect why football may be an endangered American sport.

title: Film Festival; Social Realist Fable of 1930's China
description: ''Red Sorghum,'' Zhang Yimou's new Chinese film, begins very prettily, and with something of the ho-ho-ho joviality exhibited by the members of the chorus in a stock production of ''The Student Prince.''

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Mashpee, Mass.;
Optimism On Cape Cod
description: LEAD: A RELATIVELY slow home-sales market on Cape Cod has not discouraged the builders of two large developments here. One is Windchime, a $45 million, 170-unit condominium project with clubhouse and tennis courts and abutting a 300-acre public preserve.

title: Jan M. Decker Marries Christopher S. McCormick
description: Jan Marie Decker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin D. Decker of West Redding, Conn., was married last evening to Christopher Sawbridge McCormick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert McCormick of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Richard M. Cromie performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Fort Lauderdale.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Many of the double-hung windows in my house need to have the putty replaced around the outside. Since each window has 12 panes, I thought of using a caulking gun to speed the job, but my dealer says that only glazing compound should be used. Someone suggested using silicone caulking. Do you know if this can be used instead of glazing compound around each pane?

title: Setting Sail For Discovery
description: MY list was a mile long. The cleaners, soon as it opens. A fast trip to the grocery. Wrap and mail the dress my college sophomore needs for a dance. Feed the cats. Fill the car with gas. Catch the 9:19 and be in the office for a 10:30 A.M. meeting.

title: Reagan's Legions of Nominees Put His Own Stamp on the Judiciary
description: ALL summer, 29 of President Reagan's nominations to the Federal bench languished in the Senate, and the Democratic majority made no secret of their motives. They wanted to keep as many judicial slots open as possible, in the hope that a newly-elected President Dukakis would fill them with his own choices next year.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Chips May Fall, But Don't Bet on It

title: Of Debt and Dirt
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Has 4 Months to Improve Sewage Plan
description: New York City has been given four months to decrease the volume of sewage flowing into its Wards Island treatment plant or face a state moratorium on new sewer hookups in the Bronx and Upper East Side neighborhoods served by the plant, city and state officials said yesterday.

title: Mary Dunn Shafter Is Wed
description: At St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn., Mary Dunn Shafter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Shafter of New Canaan, Conn., and Peru, Vt., was married yesterday to James Thomas Sullivan. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Sullivan of Bristol and Old Saybrook, Conn. The Rev. Joseph A. Burke, a Jesuit priest, performed the ceremony.

title: The Newest Condos Try to Replicate Prewar Quality
description: BUILDERS of Manhattan condominiums are rolling a new word off their tongues these days as readily as ''luxury,'' the reigning favorite.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Westport Seminar to Study Affordability
description: IN spite of Connecticut's vigorous economic health and 3.2 percent unemployment rate, its once-booming housing industry continues to languish.

title: African Sculptures at Yale
description: THE first exposure of ''Evocative Images'' took place two years ago at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. There, the show numbered 84 works of African art lent by the University Museum of the University of Pennsylvania and it celebrated that museum's centenary.

title:
ART;
Southampton Show Offers Local Talent
description: LEAD: AMONG the several East End galleries consistently showing talent from the area year round, the Benton Gallery in Southampton has a reputation for showing an ambitious range and quantity of work.

title: BEHIND BARBED WIRE
description: Following the devastation of our Pacific fleet at Pearl Harbor, the Pacific Coast was hysterical over an invasion threat, to a degree that is almost impossible to understand 47 years later. Japanese troops did invade the Aleutian Islands; a Japanese balloon bomb did land in Oregon; a few shells were lobbed onto the California coast.

title: Israelis Find Polio Virus in Sewage of 4 More Cities
description: Active polio viruses have been discovered in sewage and a water purification plant in four more Israeli cities, bringing the total number of infected areas to nine, Israel Radio said today.

title: On Dodgers' Ex-Turf, It's Go Mets!
description: Few signs of Ebbets Field remain in the neighborhood, apart from the fabled stadium's name that adorns a large public housing complex and many small shops on Bedford Avenue, but memories of the old Dodgers, our Dodgers, persist.

title: Vilma Bornemann Wed To Demetrios Caraley
description: Vilma Mairo Bornemann, dean of studies at Barnard College, and Demetrios Caraley, the Janet H. Robb Professor of the Social Sciences and chairman of the department of political science at Barnard, were married yesterday at the nondenominational St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University. The Rev. William F. Starr officiated.

title: Compromise Can End West Bank Occupation
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO CHEERS FOR $5 OIL
description: As the price for crude oil slid below $10 a barrel in the spot market last week and OPEC officials warned that it could sink to $5, an uneasy sense of deja vu pervaded the world. The sharp decline stirred memories of the price plunge that occurred in 1986, sending economic shock waves through oil-producing regions, including the American Southwest.

title: AMERASIAN INFLUX EXPECTED BY U.S.
description: The number of Amerasian children and family members coming from Vietnam to live in the United States is expected to expand from the current level of 200 to 300 monthly to 1,000 as a result of recent United States-Vietnam discussions, State Department officials directing the resettlement effort say.

title: State Acts to Bar Coastal Projects
description: LEAD: AFTER seven years of hearings, revisions and red tape, the state's Department of Environmental Conservation is carrying out what it contends is a tough set of regulations to restrict development in coastal areas endangered by erosion.

title: Amy Engelhard Plans To Wed Glenn Firester
description: Amy Engelhard and Glenn Michael Firester plan to be married March 19, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Engelhard of Woodmere, L.I., and New York have announced. Mr. Firester is the son of Phillip Firester of Princeton, N.J., and Phyliss Tarlow of Woodbury, L.I.

title: Gold Divides Dakotans as River Did
description: Here in Deadwood Gulch, where Wild Bill Hickok drew eights and aces, along with a bullet, people still talk about the good old days, when gold mining was booming and the brothels were operating freely and openly.

title:
GARDENING;
Leaves: A Phenonemon and a Resource
description: LEAD: LEAVES are the food manufacturing organs of plants. Most leaves are some shade of green, the green color coming from the chlorophyl in the leaf cells.

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY;
FOR REFERENCE: THE BEST AND THE BLOODIEST
description: LEAD: Reference A CATALOGUE OF CRIME. By Jacques Barzun and Wendell Hertig Taylor. 831 pp. (Harper & Row, 1971.) Two old friends - the first a cultural historian, the second a scientist - share their opinions and differences in 3,476 entries on detection, mystery, espionage, true crime, Sherlockiana and the supernatural.

title: Californian With AIDS Seeks A Law for Broader Disclosure
description: On the day Paul Gann learned he had AIDS, five years after a blood transfusion, he considered leaving his wife of 56 years, his children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren and isolating himself in a desert cabin.

title: Question of the Week; What Did You Think Of the Seoul Olympics?
description: After a few days of watching the Olympics, my 7-year-old daughter said, ''I wish the games were on Channel 13 so there would be no advertising.''

title: A Vote For Graf
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY: IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: WHEN THE CAT'S AWAY. By Kinky Friedman. (Beech Tree/Morrow, $16.95.) Kinky Friedman, a songwriter and performer turned novelist, brings to crime fiction something that no other writer can offer: himself. The hero of ''When the Cat's Away,'' as was the case in the two previous entries in this series, is none other than Kinky Friedman.

title: London Promoter Firm on Tyson Site
description: Mike Tyson's training for his heavyweight title defense against Frank Bruno Dec. 17 is expected to be delayed as the champion meets this week with his attorney, Howard Weitzman, and prepares to respond to a divorce petition filed Friday by Tyson's wife, Robin Givens, in Los Angeles. A hearing is scheduled for Oct. 27.

title: Jennifer Weksler, Architect, Weds
description: At the Philadelphia Art Alliance, Jennifer Lee Weksler, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Marc E. Weksler of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday to Christopher David Keller, a son of Robert A. Keller 3d of Atlanta and Helen Praeger Young of Beijing.

title: Review/Rock; The Serious and the Goofy By John Hiatt and His Band
description: John Hiatt, who played a brilliant set at the Bottom Line on Thursday, does everything right. Though he can be an intensely personal songwriter, Mr. Hiatt mitigates seriousness with a goofy, self-aware persona on stage. And though he and his tight, all-Louisiana band - Sonny Landreth on guitar, Dave Ransom on bass and Ken Blevins on drums - effectively bang out basic rock-and-roll, he often parodies the average rock performer's rote posturing. Rock, in his hands, is alive.

title: Of Manville, Morals and Mortality
description: Last Monday, the United States Supreme Court cleared the way for the Manville Corporation to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Zambia Detains 9 as Rumors Of Coup Plot Fill the Capital
description: Zambian officials have detained nine people for subversive activities. Western diplomats said the detentions revealed the Government's growing sensitivity to potential political opposition ahead of the parliamentary and presidential elections on Oct. 26.

title:
ART;
Dramatic Neuberger Show Of Artist-Illustrated Books
description: LEAD: EXHIBITIONS of artist-illustrated books too often seem like a trip to the library; the pleasures they offer are for the specialist, because the books are displayed in a hothouse atmosphere. Though there is plenty of protective glass at the Neuberger Museum here, where ''Bonnard to Kiefer: 20th-Century Artist-Illustrated Books from the Bareiss Collection at the Toledo Museum of Art'' is on view through Jan.

title: PERIOD PIECE
description: WITHNAIL AND I Starring Richard E. Grant, Paul McGann, Richard Griffiths, Ralph Brown, Michael Elphick, Daragh O'Mallery, Michael Wardle, Una Brandon-Jones, Noel Johnson, Irene Sutcliffe. Directed by Bruce Robinson. 1987. Media Home Entertainment. 107 minutes. $79.95. Rated R.

title: THE HARD RIDE OF WILLY T.
description: IT'S A SCORCHING SATURDAY AFTERNOON IN DETROIT, the temperature in the 90's. On the streets surrounding the city's downtown Renaissance Center, 50,000 sweltering fans strain against the fencing as only a few feet away two race cars scream by at upwards of 150 miles per hour. Nearing the finish, the Escort Trans-Am has been a remarkable race.

title: Sicilian Mafia, After Crackdown, Revives With a Wave of Killings
description: The Sicilian Mafia is on the offensive again. Having survived a judicial crackdown, resurgent criminal families are conducting a campaign of terror against the state while striking underworld rivals in a series of daylight killings.

title: Undefeated Irish Avert an Upset
description: Notre Dame, which had lost three straight times to Pitt, narrowly avoided another such upset today to keep the Irish undefeated with five victories.

title: Why Botha and Mobutu Might Find Friendship Expedient
description: THE state-controlled newspaper here has yet to publish the most startling image of southern Africa last week: Zaire's President, Mobutu Sese Seko, stepping forward to greet his guest, South Africa's President, Pieter W. Botha.

title: Correction
description: A front-page picture caption last Sunday about Mikhail S. Gorbachev's succeeding Andrei A. Gromyko as the Soviet President described a Politburo vote incorrectly in some editions. The members were shown voting to accept Mr. Gromyko's retirement. In a later vote, the Politburo elected Mr. Gorbachev President.

title: Shelby Calvert Marries Thomas Morss
description: At King's Chapel in Boston yesterday evening, Shelby Lynn Calvert, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald D. Calvert of Huntsville, Ala., and Thomas Wentworth Morss, a son of Everett Morss of Beverly Farms, Mass., and Mary Shiverick Morss of Beverly, Mass., were married. The revised Angelican wedding ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles R. Forman.

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY;
DID A CRAZED COMMUTER DO IT?
description: LEAD: SOMETHING IN THE AIR By Emma Lathen. 270 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: Pope, Visiting France, Calls for a United Europe
description: As he began a four-day visit to France, Pope John Paul II today called for a united Europe that would bring together the people of West and East.

title: THE GIRL WHO STOPPED FEELING NOTHING
description: A DEADLY SILENCE The Ordeal of Cheryl Pierson: A Case of Incest and Murder. By Dena Kleiman. Illustrated. 305 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $19.95.

title: Pollution? Many Varieties of Fish Are Safe to Eat
description: THE problems of ocean pollution were brought close to home - right to the beaches - this summer. As a result, consumers have been asking questions about the fish and shellfish on sale in retail shops and restaurants. Is it safe to eat? At a time when consumption of fish is on the increase, largely for health reasons, should one stop eating it, also for health reasons?

title: The Stay-At-Home Path to Fitness
description: THE flow of people to health clubs and gymnasiums in pursuit of physical fitness has developed a side stream. More and more are staying home to train, with the help of professional instructors. The state representative for the International Dance/Exercise Association, Mikki Williams of Westport, said at-home training was a booming industry, growing at a rate of 15 to 20 percent a year, especially in Fairfield and New Haven Counties.

title: Eagle Rookie Tight End Not a Follower
description: Keith Jackson has an irresistible penchant for going against the grain. When someone asks why, the Philadelphia Eagles' rookie tight end just shrugs and says he's been that way for as long as he can remember.

title: Anti-Semitic Letter in Suffolk Race Draws Apology
description: The Conservative Party chairman of Suffolk County apologized Friday for an unsigned letter sent to some party members that urged the defeat of two candidates for judgeships because they are Jewish.

title: College and Career: Parental Reactions
description: I was delighted to read the two articles describing parents' reaction to their children going to college and those who have just graduated from college [ Opinion, Aug. 28 ] . They both captured two pieces of the puzzle, with one looking on college as a preparation for life and the other as a preparation for a job.

title: The Race for Congress; 'Almost Incumbent' in Vermont Is Favorite in Senate Contest
description: Representative James M. Jeffords, a Republican running for the Senate in Vermont, voted against legislation restricting smoking on commercial airline flights.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Elizabeth $110,000 625 Meadow Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, den, formal dining room; taxes $2,400. Maplewood $170,000 6 Rynda Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; screened porch, fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $3,358. Pompton Plains $137,000 32 Winding Way 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 48-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, full basement, near shopping; taxes $1,959. Randolph $405,000 6 Echo Ridge Road 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 14-year-old colonial; pool, deck, c/a, fireplace; taxes $4,894. Wanaque $135,000 19 Park Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 43-year-old Cape Cod; family room, full basement, eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,944. Wayne $359,000 52 Sleepy Hollow Drive 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 16-year-old colonial; fireplace, 2-car garage, eat-in kitchen; taxes $4,059. OTHER AREAS Westbrook, Conn. $168,500 164 Fawn Hill Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 15-year-old raised ranch; deck, family room with fireplace, 0.33 acre; taxes $1,129. Chappaqua, N.Y. $535,000 2 Bradley Farms 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; fireplace, jalousied porch, pool, 1.7 acres; taxes $6,162. Hicksville, L.I. $198,000 5 Winding Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 40- year-old Cape Cod; new kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,200.

title: PASSIONS OF THE OFFSHORE IRISH
description: LEAD: THE SILENCE IN THE GARDEN By William Trevor. 204 pp. New York: Viking.

title: A Yiddishist With a Passion
description: LEAD: AARON KRAMER believes that ''poems translated without zeal are stillborn.''

title: Writers Honor a Long-Dead Peer
description: Forty-six years after he was shot dead by a Nazi storm trooper, Bruno Schulz, a Polish Jew who left behind only two short volumes of nostalgic, sensual prose and some drawings, is being honored with tributes that include film showings, poetry readings, the awarding of a new literary prize in his name, an exhibition of his pen-and-ink sketches and the publication of his letters in English translation.

title: Conference Center Plan Dropped for Lasdon Site
description: LEAD: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke has abandoned plans to put a conference center on a portion of Lasdon Park and instead will give Northern Westchester residents a chance to determine how the 180acre former estate should be used.

title: Property Tax Vs. Sales Tax: Debate Is On
description: LEAD: UNTIL the stock market crashed last October, officials in Nassau and Suffolk could bank on surging sales-tax revenues to help finance rising county budgets.

title: How to Think Like a Baroque Choreographer
description: Dances do not exist in isolation. They possess a theatrical context, and they may express ideas of their time. Anyone who doubts this should ponder the productions of Catherine Turocy.

title: BAD DAYS AT 'BIG DRY'
description: I was deeply moved by John L. Moore's account of the Montana drought, ''Bad Days at 'Big Dry' '' (Aug. 14). The drought of 1988, for some reason, has spared the desert where I live. Here in New Mexico, we had a cool, wet summer, and the suffering of the rest of the country has not seemed real to me.

title: Newcomer Facing Powerful Incumbent
description: LEAD: A POLITICAL newcomer is challenging an incumbent from one of Connecticut's most powerful political families in the First Congressional District, which includes Hartford and 17 suburban towns.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Deer Park
description: WHEN Gerald and Rosaline Dunn went house hunting on Long Island 19 years ago, they looked for a neighborhood that was affordable, that had low taxes and that was a good place to raise a family.

title: Duck Conservation Plan Limits Hunting Season
description: A sharply curtailed hunting season for ducks went into effect today in New York and the rest of the Northeast as part of a continent-wide effort to overcome a dramatic decline in the duck population of North America.

title: 'Madame Sousatzka' Strikes a Chord
description: Films about musicians? Plenty, ever since Harry Baur played Beethoven in the 1930's. Through films have paraded Chopin, Liszt, Schumann, Clara Schumann, Brahms, Berlioz, Tchaikovsky, Delius, Wagner, Mahler, you name it. Most of those films has one thing in common. They were awful.

title: Stafford's Practice
description: To the Editor:

title: Michele Elliman Marries James J. Fee
description: Michele Sperry Elliman, a daughter of Judith Beavers of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Lawrence M. Elliman of St. Helena, Calif., was married yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York to James Joseph Fee, a son of Mrs. James J. Fee Jr. of Garden City, L.I., and the late Mr. Fee. The Rev. J. Seymour Flynn performed the ceremony.

title: Euterpe Dukakis Assails Bush
description: Euterpe Dukakis, the mother of the Democratic Presidential candidate, accused George Bush and the Republican Party today of spreading false information about her brothers.

title: CHILE JOURNALISTS REPORT AN ATTACK
description: Foreign and Chilean journalists said today that riot police intentionally attacked more than 20 of them Friday night while they were trying to cover an anti-Government demonstration.

title: Correction
description: An obituary of Serge Jaroff was published in error yesterday. A memorial service is to be held today at 4 P.M. at Protection of the Holy Virgin Cathedral, 59 East Second Street, for Mr. Jaroff, who died in 1985.

title: A City Reclaims Its Celebrated Son n
description: DURING this week and next weekend, the playwright Eugene O'Neill is being honored in New London - a city where he was known for much of his life (1888-1953), but not always honored.

title: THE FATE OF TWO NATIONS
description: AN OCEAN APART The Relationship Between Britain and America in the Twentieth Century. By David Dimbleby and David Reynolds. Illustrated. 415 pp. New York: Random House. $24.95.

title: The Class Reunion: I Want to Go, and Yet I Don't
description: THE 50th reunion of my high school class (Rahway, 1938) is coming up this week and, although I've sent the committee in charge a check for $30, thus signifying my intentions to be on hand, I think I'm in a quandary.

title: BEYOND THE BOMB: TURMOIL IN THE LABS
description: THE BOOM TIMES of the Reagan era have ended for the elite scientists who practice the secret art of designing and testing new kinds of nuclear arms. At America's rival centers for nuclear research - the 7,800-person Los Alamos National Laboratory, high in the mountains of New Mexico, and the 8,000-person Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, set amid the grassy hills of northern California - the atmosphere is of ferment and soul-searching. By their own admission, the high priests of the atomic brotherhood have reached a turning point, some would call it an identity crisis, as they try to fathom their future.

title: Watergate Figure Leads Ethics Panel
description: Jeb Stuart Magruder, who pleaded guilty to conspiring to obstruct justice in a Watergate case and spent seven months in prison for his crimes, is now heading a commission on ethics and values in the capital of Ohio.

title: Huntington Fair Housing Before Court
description: THE United States Supreme Court is expected to announce on Tuesday whether it will hear an appeal from the Town of Huntington in a case that could pressure communities across the country to revise their zoning laws to allow the construction of more low-income housing.

title: But Washington Holds the Key
description: The ambitious undertaking of the European Community to remove the many internal barriers to the unimpeded movement of goods, services, people and capital has begun to seep into the public consciousness. In the offing is a vastly different Europe, one consisting of a single market of 320 million people, the culmination of a 30-year effort to achieve a real Common Market. This development promises to achieve the most significant change in the European landscape since the conclusion of World War II.

title: Why Summerfare Summers Will End So Soon
description: The Pepsico Summerfare will die next summer, 10 years after it began. The festival has been a cold shower in the July heat - asking summer dozers to wake up, think and feel, even if the feelings are uncomfortable and the thoughts a little jarring.

title: THE HAVES, THE HAVE-NOTS AND THE HAVE-SOMEWHATS
description: THE GREAT DIVIDE Second Thoughts on the American Dream. By Studs Terkel. 439 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $18.95.

title: The Homeless for Whom Housing Is Not Enough
description: THEY are a shadow people, possibly the most vexing of New York City's forgotten and lost: the growing numbers of homeless people who are addicted to drugs.

title: THE REGION: After the Grand Jury; What Happened to Tawana Brawley's Case - And to Attitudes About Race and Justice
description: WITH a grand jury's report that Tawana Brawley was not kidnapped, raped and abused by a gang of white men last year, the New York State authorities closed the book Thursday on a tortuous and divisive investigation. In seven months, the grand jury said, it had found no evidence to support accusations by the teen-ager and by her family's advisers, but did find witnesses' accounts and forensic evidence that contradicted them. Attorney General Robert Abrams strongly criticized the conduct of Miss Brawley's lawyers, Alton H. Maddox Jr. and C. Vernon Mason, who said they would go on using protests, confrontation and noncooperation to dramatize their contention that the legal system is biased.

title: BLINDED BY IDEALISM
description: BROKEN ALLIANCE The Turbulent Times Between Blacks and Jews in America. By Jonathan Kaufman. 311 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $19.95.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Bennington, Vt.;
Condo Blends Old and New
description: LEAD: A 130-YEAR-OLD house is the centerpiece of a 42-unit condominium project now under way in this southwestern Vermont town of 16,000 residents, which, despite the presence of the country's most expensive college, remains steadfastly blue-collar.

title: Knicks to Use Oakley as Top Rebounder
description: Charles Oakley pushed several Knicks in gray shirts out of the way, bulled his way to the basket, snapped up the defensive rebound and tossed the outlet pass to Gerald Wilkins, who went flying to the basket.

title: Abigail Disney, Ph.D Candidate, Weds Pierre Norman Hauser 2d at Columbia
description: Abigail Edna Disney and Pierre Norman Hauser 2d were married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University. The Rev. Janet Fechner-Pelletier, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Special Today; The Good Health Magazine/Magazine, Part 2
description: Special reports today include: * Revolutionary heart treatment: stopping attacks before damage is done. * Exploding the myth about teen-age gloom. * Facing your own mortality.

title: First, We Must Recognize Problems of Children; Problem Is Global
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW WE WERE IS HOW WE REALLY ARE
description: THE PROUD DECADES America in War and Peace, 1941-1960. By John Patrick Diggins. Illustrated. 381 pp. New York: W .W. Norton & Company. $19.95.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Wigwam Wiggler With grace and aplomb, Frank Jones, the Islip Town Supervisor, crawled into his wigwam. ''The problem may be getting him out,'' said one of the two Islip officials standing nearby. Not to worry.

title:
GARDENING;
Leaves: A Phenonemon and a Resource
description: LEAD: LEAVES are the food manufacturing organs of plants. Most leaves are some shade of green, the green color coming from the chlorophyl in the leaf cells.

title: Jamie Sue Gangel Marries Daniel Silva in Washington
description: Jamie Sue Gangel, a network television correspondent for NBC News, and Daniel Silva, a writer and producer for CNN, both in Washington, were married there yesterday at the Mayflower Hotel. Judge Stanley S. Harris of Federal District Court in Washington officiated.

title: THE CAREFREE LIFE
description: KITTY An Autobiography. By Kitty Carlisle Hart. Illustrated. 263 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

title: Belgium's Answer to Quiche: Pungent Cheese Tarts
description: OLD cheese, old recipe, old Belgian town. Fermented cheese is the pungent main ingredient used in tarte al djote, which was concocted about 950 years ago in Nivelles, in southern Brabant Wallonia.

title: YUGOSLAV POLICE FIGHT OFF A SIEGE IN PROVINCIAL CITY
description: Riot policemen using truncheons and cattle prods today broke up a crowd that had besieged the Parliament building of the republic of Montenegro, in southern Yugoslavia, since Friday.

title:
INVESTING;
Why Bad News Is More Reliable
description: LEAD: Not everyone who sells short is a hedger. There are still some old-time speculators around who just hope to make a killing. And they have their defenders, like Martin E. Zweig, an investment adviser.

title: Wiffle Ball is Getting Serious
description: STANDING on what usually is second base in a Little League game, the batter digs in while the pitcher, his back to the regular home plate, fires in his pitch from the mound, about 33 feet away. It is a pitch that would make Phil Niekro and Hoyt Wilhelm, two of baseball's greatest knuckleball pitchers, green with envy.

title: Terry A. Hastings And C. C. Powers Wed in California
description: Terry Anne Hastings, a daughter of Margery Maude Hastings of Palos Verdes Estates, Calif., and the late Glenn A. Hastings, was married yesterday to Christopher Cother Powers, a son of Helen W. Powers of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Francis C. Powers of New York and Honolulu at the nondenominational Neighborhood Church in Palos Verdes Estates. The Rev. Karl Johnson, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony.

title: Castle Is Inventor's Vision of the Past
description: John Hays Hammond Jr. was a prolific inventor with hundreds of patents, but his most enduring creation may have been his home, a medieval-style castle and museum overlooking the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Of Cash, Crystals and Consumerism
description: ''New Age'' often conjures up the unlikely - from an awareness of past lives to reinterpretation of the energy inherent in crystals. But despite a persistent image of hucksterism, business is discovering that the New Age movement is a growing and affluent consumer market.

title: Tory, Tory, Hallelujah!
description: There's nothing like naked, undisguised anger to get the creative juices flowing. In this day and age, it's far more effective than love.

title: IS THIS TICKET FOR GAME 3?
description: It had the potential for disaster, the prospect of a violent clash involving more than 100,000 frustrated ticket-holders trying to fight their way into a baseball stadium with room for only half of them.

title: Jumping Ship?
description: HE got a four-year college education at the taxpayers' expense, and as part of the bargain David Robinson was expected to spend two years serving his country as a naval officer. That's something the 7-foot-1-inch Annapolis graduate said he would be glad to do, but Robinson voiced those sentiments before he returned from temporary assignment in Seoul, South Korea, with the United States Olympic basketball team and returned to duty at his base in Kings Bay, Ga.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FOODS FOR FESTIVALS There are festivals of all kinds, of course, and this is the week of the Food Festival, when particular delicacies get special treatment from fund-raising groups. So today, to help the Greenlawn Centerport Historical Association do its good deeds, have a pickle, or two or three, straight or in relishes.

title: Green Eyes, Red Rage, Shameful Longings
description: IN the same way I invariably spell surprise suprise, never remember if commas go inside or outside quotation marks (inside!) and unconsciously make the same wrong left turn instead of right when visiting friends in New Jersey, I'm never sure of whether I'm feeling jealous or envious of Raquel Welch's body and Christie Brinkley's hair.

title: Grape Pickers Find Extra Cash And a Change of Pace in the Vineyard
description: LEAD: WHEN Janice Jones decided she needed money recently, she did not return to the sort of secretarial work she had done years ago. Instead, she began picking grapes.

title: BY FITNESS OBSESSED
description: I ONCE MET AN ULTRAMARATHONER who said he fights boredom on his runs by overtaking anyone ahead of him, no matter how painful the task. At the time, I thought such behavior a bit odd, perhaps more an obsession with fitness than a tactic for achieving it. A few months later, I was working out on a rowing machine and found myself losing badly in a silent race with a man next to me. When he finally left, I sneaked a look at the meter on his machine to see just how far he had rowed. Before I knew it I was sitting back down and rowing furiously to match his distance - and add another three miles.

title: Kenya Moves to Stop Poaching of Elephants
description: The Kenyan Wildlife Ministry has dismissed 10 game wardens and rangers and suspended 33 others in a campaign to stop elephant poaching, newspapers here reported late this week.

title:
ART;
From the Beginning, Books Showed the Way
description: LEAD: There is a manuscript i find especially appealing in the exhibition ''A Sign and a Witness: 2,000 Years of Hebrew Books and Illuminated Manuscripts'' opening on Saturday (through Jan. 14) at the New York Public Library. It's not the oldest, the rarest, or the most beautiful manuscript to be shown in the exhibition, although it is old, rare and beautiful enough.

title: First, We Must Recognize Problems of Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Dropping Like Flies
description: THERE is $700,000 up for grabs, but you had to go all the way to Australia to get a piece of it, and for some ailing top tennis professionals, the Australian Indoor Open, which started in Brisbane yesterday, was apparently not worth the trip. First, Ivan Lendl bowed out citing injury, and joined the native son, Pat Cash, on the ailment list. Now John McEnroe has withdrawn, citing an unspecified medical condition and leaving the tournament with no major drawing card except for Tim Mayotte, who became the No. 1-seeded entrant by default.

title: CORRECTION
description: A restaurant review on Sept. 11 about the Water's Edge in Cape May gave the area code incorrectly. The restaurant's number is (609) 884-1717.

title: An Inexpensive Idea for Collectors
description: COLLECTORS seeking distinctive aspects of the plethora of recent United States stamps have become enamored of plate-number coils.

title: Congress Agrees to Ban Ocean Dumping by 1991
description: The House and Senate agreed Friday to ban ocean dumping of sewage sludge after 1991, concluding a 10-year legislative effort meant to stop sewage authorities in New York and New Jersey from disposing of their treated waste in the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Two Major Series Open This Month
description: TWO major series get under way this month as the Grande Band of New York opens the Sleepy Hollow Concerts in Tarrytown and the Westchester Symphony begins its season at the State University of New York at Purchase.

title: Perspectives of the Air: Jeweled Island on a Silver Sea
description: AS the improbable-looking two-propped plane rattled its way toward Boston, I looked through the hazed plastic windows. The topography below brought to mind Churchill's description that ''We are an island race.''

title: Hofstra Rolls To 5-0
description: Ken Bonkowski, a senior quarterback, threw three touchdown passes to lead undefeated Hofstra (5-0) to a 34-11 rout over Gettysburg (3-2) at Musselman Stadium in Gettysburg, Pa., yesterday.

title: State Is Consulted On Radon Program
description: NEW JERSEY is at the center of a whirl of information swapping among states grappling with setting up radon control programs.

title: A Surprising Chance for Democracy in Haiti
description: WHEN Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril assumed power in Haiti three weeks ago, American officials said there was no reason to expect him to show more respect for democratic principles than his predecessor, who came to power in a military coup in June.

title: The Big New Pitch for Old Ads
description: The year is 1931. Millions of Americans are without work, President Hoover is powerless to stem the darkening Depression - and the country is suddenly beset by the dread specter of ''toilet tissue illness.''

title: Finding Love Among the Ruins
description: IF HE LEAVES ONE more dirty coffee cup lying under the bed, I think I'm going to lose my mind,'' says my friend Monica. She and Jack have been married only a couple of months, but she tells me that the honeymoon is over. ''I'm married to the slob,'' she laments.

title: Headliners; Offending All Sides
description: When he lived in New York and was active as the founder of the Jewish Defense League, Rabbi Meir Kahane espoused views that many found offensive. Four years ago he emigrated to Israel, where his views have also been found repugnant. Last week, members of the Central Elections Commission, saying Mr. Kahane's Kach party had a racist and ''Nazi-like ideology,'' banned the party from participating in parliamentary elections next month. Among the bills that Mr. Kahane introduced - unsuccessfully - as Kach's only member of Parliament was one that would have prohibited sexual relations between Jews and Arabs. A Kach spokesman said banning the party had been ''a political decision'' and that it would be appealed to the Supreme Court.

title: GULF TALKS STALL OVER A WATERWAY
description: Iran and Iraq remain seriously divided over the future of a strategic waterway, according to United Nations officials and diplomats close to the latest round of negotiations, which ended here earlier this week.

title: Liberia Finds 10 Guilty of Plot Against Doe
description: A jury has found a former presidential candidate and nine other people guilty of plotting to overthrow the Government and kill President Samuel K. Doe.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: San Diego;
A Vested Right For 315 Units
description: LEAD: THE Worthing Western Corporation, based in Newport Beach, Calif., has begun building a 315-unit complex in Rancho Bernardo, a quiet residential inland neighborhood about 25 minutes north of San Diego's downtown. It will be the first Southern California project for its parent, Worthing Corporation of

title: Debate May Yet Prove Larger Than a Tempest In the No. 2 Spot
description: IF Lloyd Bentsen won the 1988 Vice-Presidential debate here this week, as the opening rounds of local and national polls suggested, did that improve the November prospects of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis?

title: Review/Music; Contemporary Pieces By Composers League
description: Little that was heard at the League of Composers/International Society of Contemporary Music program in Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday evening served to dispel the gloom that now enshrouds academic composition.

title: Lewis, in Tokyo, Speaks on Johnson
description: Carl Lewis, the Olympic 100-meter gold-medal winner, said today that the detection of Ben Johnson's use of a banned drug was a ''blessing'' for sports. Evidence of steroid use cost Johnson, a Canadian sprinter, the gold medal in the 100.

title: POSTINGS: Carroll Gardens Conversion; The 55-Unit Mill
description: Since the turn of the century, a jute factory has stood at 376 President Street, between Bond and Hoyt Streets, in a brownstone neighborhood of Brooklyn that in the last two decades has come to be known as Carroll Gardens. The gentrifying area has a historic district, and the factory, in recent years used for furniture making, lies just outside it.

title: U.S. Challenges Claims on Toothpaste and Mouthwash Labels
description: The Food and Drug Administration has asked six toothpaste and mouthwash manufacturers to remove from labels assertions that the products prevent gum disease and plaque buildup, spokesmen for the Federal agency said today.

title:
GARDENING;
One Solution to Leafy Problems
description: LEAD: AT this time of the year, falling tree leaves are an enormous problem. Gardeners can do their bit to lessen the burden on trash collectors and municipal dumps by tilling leaves into the soil, using them as mulch or composting them.

title: Lynch Is 3d in Cross-Country
description: Although she failed to defend her Eastern States Cross Country Championships in the chilly rain at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday, Nnenna Lynch did not blame the weather for her third-place finish.

title: State Lags In Permits On Waste
description: MORE than 1,400 companies that make up most of the commercial solid-waste and hazardous-waste haulers in New Jersey are operating without proper state permits and some are transporting and disposing of the wastes illegally, state law-enforcement and environmental officials said last week.

title: A Brash Young Quarterback Sparks the Bengals
description: There are undoubtedly times when Boomer Esiason kicks back and dreams of slapping home the winning score - in a hockey game.

title: Los Angeles
description: To the Editor: Robert W. Stock's article ''In Los Angeles, Lights! Action! Tourists!'' (Travel, July 31) was quite timely for my family, as we were departing for Los Angeles the following day.

title: Question of the Week; What Did You Think Of the Seoul Olympics?
description: The overemphasis on winning a gold medal is very disturbing. Why are the spectacular athletes who qualified to be Olympians, but did not win medals, passed by? Why do the victorious silver and bronze medalists appear to have to almost apologize for not winning the gold?

title:
FOCUS: Mill Run, Pa.;
Owners of Wright Homes Consider a Conservancy
description: LEAD: CONCERNED that the Frank Lloyd Wright legacy may be nibbled away by collectors buying bits and pieces, a consortium of owners and curators of Wright homes is looking at the possibility of establishing a Wright conservancy.

title: FICTION
description: THE TELLING OF LIES. By Timothy Findley. (Delta, Paper, $7.95.) As he demonstrated some 20 years ago in ''The Last of the Crazy People,'' the Canadian novelist Timothy Findley is an expert at using a crime story as the nucleus of a serious book. In ''The Telling of Lies,'' the initial crime involves the murder of an odious pharmaceutical magnate. The novel's atmospheric setting is an old hotel on the coast of Maine, an establishment that is soon to be turned into a hideous condo development. Mr. Findley's vividly drawn narrator, an elderly hotel resident named Vanessa Van Horne, finds herself becoming a reluctant detective as she confronts an ominous conspiracy. Her only weapons are her aristocratic manners and her expertise, learned in a World War II Japanese prison camp, in ''the subversive uses of charm.'' This is very much a novel of charm and manners, if of a rather chilly sort. It is also a full-fledged thriller, replete with mad doctors, sinister C.I.A. operatives and spectacular brainwashing techniques. Mr. Findley's delicate balancing act is reinforced by the perceptions of his heroine, who, as a landscape architect, sees all manner of intricate symmetries in her story; for example, her experiences in prison, presented in harrowing flashbacks, anticipate her confrontation with her own Government and its collective ''layers of lying.'' For both conventional mystery fans and seekers after unconventional storytelling, this novel offers tart and original pleasures.

title: Opposition to Airport Plan Sharpens
description: LEAD: HAVING aired their views at a public hearing last Tuesday night, opponents of the plan for a new terminal at the County Airport say they may soon seek their day in court unless the county is receptive to their requests.

title: DIETING REASSESSED
description: LOSING WEIGHT HAS NEVER been easy, and recent research has helped explain why. Two important studies have reported that the tendency to be overweight is to a large extent inherited - tied, inextricably, to one's genes, planted in the body, with no apparent compassion or sense of fairness, by one's own ancestors. The news could hardly have been heartening for the 65 million Americans who try an estimated 30,000 diet regimens each year. Moreover, other recent studies have found that certain common patterns of dieting not only make it harder to lose weight but also pose serious health dangers of their own.

title: BYE-BYE MY PRIVATE EYE
description: Fiction, in some respects, is even more crime-ridden than life. Consider the not-uncommon life situation in which two people have been married for some time only to find they have grown out of compatibility, let alone passion. When this happens they can, with society's understanding nod, obtain a divorce and each go on with his or her individual life. There will doubtless be scars and readjustments, but very rarely does either party suffer a murder indictment.

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY: IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: KOKO. By Peter Straub. (Dutton, $19.95.) It's been 14 years since Michael Poole's scarring experiences in Vietnam. Now a pediatrician, he's in Washington for the dedication of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial along with thousands of other veterans, including three survivors of his platoon: Harry (Beans) Beevers, an unemployed lawyer whom they once called the world's worst lieutenant; Tina Pumo, who owns a New York restaurant called Saigon; and ''wild little'' Conor Linklater.

title: New York Is Seen Nearing Its Debt Limit
description: Thirteen years after New York City's fiscal crisis, a new financial squeeze is developing: the city, raising billions of dollars to repair its deteriorating public works, is in danger of borrowing more than it can afford to repay, the Koch administration says.

title:
INVESTING;
Why Pension Funds Will Sell Short
description: LEAD: A recent ruling by the Internal Revenue Service has raised the possibility that pension funds may soon begin selling stocks short, a speculative tactic that some pension fund managers argue can be used to reduce their risks.

title: Sharon K. Faath and Michael Fremer Are Married
description: Sharon Keyes Faath, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Faath Jr. of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Alan Fremer, the son of Samuel Fremer of North Miami Beach, Fla., and the late Florence H. Fremer, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis R. Coleman, friends of the couple, in Allendale, N.J.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Amsterdam
description: Off-season Amsterdam returns from a summer of backpacking tourists to the place that Albert Camus called ''a dream of gold and smoke.'' Mist lies on the black water of the old canals, foghorns sound in the snowy harbor, the bars fill with gin drinkers, footfalls echo in the empty museums. The best Amsterdam has to offer is on foot: walks along the canals to see the human-scale buildings, the museums where Rembrandt and Vermeer and Van Gogh shine forth, cafes where a book and a drink can make an evening, the odd corners where the past wafts back.

title: Selling A Home: Hard Work If You Can Get It
description: WHEN my wife and I decided to sell our home, we did not realize the time and energy involved. It seemed simple; you list it and sell it. The first step was to find a broker. We decided to list with an agency near our home.

title: Food Rule Challenged By Pupils
description: When he was in the third grade, Andy Gauvin decided he wanted to be President of the United States. Now a sixth-grader, he has had his first look at how government works.

title: Review/Recital; An Iconoclastic Pianist Opens Beethoven Series
description: Andrew Rangell is a 40-year-old pianist who has been living quietly in New England and operating with his own chosen repertory along the fringes of the music business. Mr. Rangell has not had any real professional management until recently, and listening to him play the first of seven Beethoven recitals at the 92d Street Y Thursday night, one quickly concluded that he is hardly a consensus candidate for success in the world of musical politics.

title: Court Supports Housing Group on Winterizing Colonial Cottages
description: A COURT decision in a zoning dispute has cleared the way for a nonprofit housing group in northern Westchester to winterize two summer cottages to provide year-round housing for eight low-income elderly residents of Cortlandt.

title: POSTINGS: How to Upgrade; Reinvesting In the Bronx
description: One would be hard-pressed to name a place that has suffered more than the Bronx from the ills of urban decay. But the wounds left by decades of decline in some neighborhoods are begining to heal with the return of private investment.

title: Boston Case Raises Questions on Misuse of Affirmative Action
description: Philip and Paul Malone are fair-haired, fair-complexioned identical twins who worked for the Boston Fire Department for 10 years. Last month both were dismissed when a state agency ruled that they had lied on their job applications: They had contended they were black. The finding has sent shock waves through the city government, touching off charges that employees of other agencies may have misused plans designed to remedy past discrimination against black and Hispanic workers.

title: Angola's Army Retakes Towns Held by Rebels
description: Since South Africa's troop pullout from Angola a few weeks ago, Angola's military has recaptured a string of rebel towns, including the birthplace of Jonas Savimbi, the rebel leader.

title: Taking of Shellfish Is Banned In South End of Puget Sound
description: Shellfishing has been banned in southern Puget Sound because of poisoning by a naturally occurring organism. Shellfish from the area are being pulled from store shelves in Washington, Oregon, Alaska, Hawaii, Pennsylvania, Maine and New York, officials say.

title: THE LEGACY OF DR. KOOP
description: ONE FATEFUL EVENING last spring Frances Epstein, a dressmaker in Riverdale, N.Y., lit a cigarette, flicked on her TV and found herself face to face with C. Everett Koop, Surgeon General of the United States. Dressed in a dark blue military uniform, bearded, huge, unsmiling, looking for the life of him like a vengeful biblical patriarch, the 71-year-old top doctor of the nation looked directly at Frances Epstein in Riverdale and asked, ''Why do people continue to smoke despite the known health hazards?''

title: Donna Davidson Becomes a Bride
description: The Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Donna Lee Davidson, the daughter of Alan R. Davidson of Longboat Key, Fla., and Mrs. William C. McPherson 3d of Rye, and Key Largo, Fla., to Richard Robert Lovely, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas D. Lovely of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. Michael Pakenham performed the ceremony.

title: Review/Recital; Violin-Piano Duet Bill
description: Place often has a way of setting the musical tone of an evening. Thus Weill Recital Hall - newly elegant and with its acoustical rough edges now smoothed over - seemed to frame and contain Friday's evening of violin and piano music to the proper scale. The music was the Beethoven Sonata in A from Op. 30, Schubert's B-minor Rondo Brilliant and an early Richard Strauss piece, the Sonata in E Flat from his 24th year.

title: A SISTER'S NEED
description: Like Margaret Moorman, I needed to move 3,000 miles to escape the enormous pain and sense of responsibility that I felt growing up with a schizophrenic sister two years younger than myself (''A Sister's Need,'' Sept. 11).

title: Poll Finds Lautenberg Keeps Lead Over Dawkins in Race
description: With only a month left before Election Day, Senator Frank Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, is leading his Republican rival, Pete Dawkins, by 20 points, according to a poll by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University.

title:
MUSIC;
20th-Century Works Stand Out
description: LEAD: ONE glance at the 1988-89 concert season in New Jersey will reveal that this is a season unlike any previous one. The season, which is just under way, is impressive in the depth and scope of works and staggering in the number of performances.

title: BEHIND BARBED WIRE
description: John Hersey attempts to chronicle the relocation of Japanese subjects (issei) and Japanese-American citizens (nisei) following the sneak attack by Japan on Pearl Harbor.

title: Susanne L. Smith Is Wed to Peter Spencer Morgan
description: At Grace Episcopal Church in New York, Susanne Lois Smith, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Leslie C. Smith of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter Spencer Morgan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Perry Morgan Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and Northhaven, Me. Bishop John S. Spong, the Episcopal Bishop of Newark, and the Rev. Harold E. Barrett, the rector of Grace Church, performed the ceremony.

title: HOW TO LOWER YOUR CHOLESTEROL
description: CHOLESTEROL IS A SOFT, waxy substance made in the liver that is essential to the body, but if too much circulates in the blood it can build up as plaque on artery walls, increasing the risk of heart disease and stroke.

title: A Valley for All Seasons
description: THE VALTELLINA, a ribbon of green between two Alpine ranges, stretches about 60 miles east of the northern tip of Lake Como. The peaks that tower behind its slopes are among Europe's tallest. Rising up from the valley floor are ancient vineyards, first laid out by Ligurians and Etruscans. Once part of the Roman province of Rhaetia, the Valtellina continues to produce the wines celebrated by Vergil, Pliny and Strabo, and much appreciated by Caesar Augustus. The vines, terraced above the Adda River in a 25-mile strip between Ardenno and Tirano, require a goat's sure-footedness and a mule's back to tend and harvest - labors still accomplished by villagers working with funnel-shaped baskets strapped to their backs.

title: Holly Harder Has Wedding
description: Holly Harris Harder, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry U. Harder of Greenwich, Conn., and Saranac Inn, N.Y., was married in Saranac Inn yesterday to Bruce Catlin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Catlin of Woodstock, Vt., and Sabael, N.Y. The Rev. Charles W. Sheerin performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK:Mashpee, Mass.;
Optimism On Cape Cod
description: LEAD: A RELATIVELY slow home-sales market on Cape Cod has not discouraged the builders of two large developments here. One is Windchime, a $45 million, 170-unit condominium project with clubhouse and tennis courts and abutting a 300-acre public preserve.

title: Henry Wicke 3d Wed To Brenda L. Murphy
description: The marriage of Brenda Lee Murphy, a daughter of Janet Lee Murphy of Lancaster, Pa., and Martin J. Murphy of Newport, R.I., to Henry Albion Wicke 3d, the son of Mr. Wicke Jr. of Brooklyn and Mrs. Lawrence Hock of Clarence, N.Y., took place yesterday in Lancaster. The Rev. James Lyons performed the ceremony at the Sacred Heart of Jesus Roman Catholic Church.

title: Hospital Rates Stir New Furor
description: LEAD: CONTENDING that the State Commissioner of Health has unfairly maligned them, New Jersey hospitals last week fought to salvage their request for a $150 million, across-the-board increase in the rates they charge patients.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Marlow, N.H.;
Old Inn Cast In a New Role
description: LEAD: A THRIVING mail-order computer accessories company is reshaping the future of an old country inn in this quiet rural town of 542 people in the southwestern Monadnock region.

title: After a Long Battle, Irving Will Merge
description: Irving Bank ended its yearlong struggle to avoid the grasp of the Bank of New York and agreed to a $1.5 billion merger.
