The merger marks the first time a United States bank has been acquired in a hostile takeover. The deal creates the nation's 12th-largest banking institution, with assets of $42 billion. Irving's decision to yield came one day after a New York court decided that a key component of the bank's anti-takeover defense was invalid. While shareholders and arbitragers stand to gain from the decision, the undisputed winner in the battle is Bank of New York's chairman, J. Carter Bacot. He has been insisting that the two institutions, by joining together, would be in a better position to compete in a changing industry. *

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY: IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: BITTER BLOOD: A True Story of Southern Family Pride, Madness, and Multiple Murder. By Jerry Bledsoe. (Dutton, $19.95.) When a wealthy mother and daughter were gunned down gangland-style at their Louisville, Ky., home in 1984 with no obvious motive, a detective predicted, ''That family has a dark cloud in it somewhere.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bayport $162,000 79 Stephen Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 23-year-old ranch; breakfast room, den, patio, family room, pool; taxes $2,800. Hauppauge $200,000 18 Wenwood Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 20- year-old ranch; basement, decks, 0.5 acre, 1-car garage; taxes $2,700. Hicksville $198,000 5 Winding Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 40- year-old Cape Cod; new kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,200. Plainview $245,000 65 Sylvia Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 35-year-old split level; dining room, den, basement; taxes $4,500. St. James $242,000 40 Hillside Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; den, skylights, 2-car garage, 0.5 acres; taxes $3,900. Syosset $199,900 49 Candy Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 37-year- old ranch; eat-in kitchen, new windows, aluminum siding; taxes $2,900. OTHER AREAS Elizabeth, N.J $110,000 625 Meadow Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, den, formal dining room; taxes $2,400. Westbrook, Conn. $168,500 164 Fawn Hill Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 15-year-old raised ranch; deck, family room with fireplace, 0.33 acre; taxes $1,129. Chappaqua, N.Y. $535,000 2 Bradley Farms 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; fireplace, jalousied porch, pool, 1.7 acres; taxes $6,162.

title: Park Passes
description: To the Editor: The July 17 Practical Traveler referred to a ''Golden Eagle Passport, which is free. It lets you and anyone in the auto with you, or your family, if you are on a bus, into any national park free. It is available only in person from a national park.''

title: Of Swallows And Martins
description: Although I enjoyed reading Pete Dunne's article on Aug. 28 (''In the Natural State''), I was surprised that he didn't mention purple martins. These birds are fabulous insecticides and are also part of the swallow family, which he so lovingly described.

title: WHAT FATHER SAID
description: THE LETTER LEFT TO ME By Joseph McElroy. 152 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title:
The Curtains Part on Murder Most British;
One of Le Carre's Spies Is Missing
description: LEAD: The theme of John Le Carre's novel ''A Perfect Spy,'' is treachery, political and personal. Magnus Pym, a senior British Intelligence officer - that is to say, one of our top spies - is missing without leave from the Embassy in Vienna. Is he a traitor?

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY: IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE WHALE'S FOOTPRINTS. By Rick Boyer. (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) Many of fiction's detectives pursue sleuthing as a sideline to other careers or avocations. Rick Boyer's Doc Adams has one of the more unusual jobs in crime fiction: here is an oral surgeon who uses his training to rescue good guys, drug pesky attack dogs and even determine the cause of death in murder cases.

title: PTL Buyer Is Open to Talks About Bakkers' Use of Assets
description: Stephen J. Mernick, the Canadian developer who bought the assets of the PTL ministry this week, said today that he is keeping all options open about their future use.

title: Review/Pop; Songs of Love by Vandross and Baker
description: Two of pop's most luxurious voices were on display Wednesday at Madison Square Garden, where the national tour featuring Luther Vandross and Anita Baker started a four-night engagement. It's a perfect pairing. Mr. Vandross and Ms. Baker are gifted singers and love-song specialists; each has sold millions of albums of plushly produced ballads, sultry mood music for consenting adults.

title: Age of Garage Doors Is at Issue in 2 Deaths
description: Two children in suburban Minneapolis were killed by power-operated garage doors in separate accidents on the same day last week, and the authorities say the devices were probably too old to meet current safety standards.

title: Revising the Harlem Renaissance
description: LEAD: IN the decade before 1929, black artists, writers and musicians brought an artistic energy to Harlem that made it the center of black culture. Langston Hughes's first poem was published, Marian Anderson began her concert career and Bessie Smith made her first recordings.

title: NONFICTION
description: ONE TOUGH COP: The Bo Dietl Story. By Bo Dietl and Ken Gross. (Pocket, $3.95.) In 15 years with the New York City Police Department, Bo Dietl made more than 1,400 felony arrests; the average officer makes 180 in the same time span. Nicholas Pileggi, the author of ''Wiseguy,'' says in an introduction that Mr. Dietl ''tells us more about our impotence in fighting crime than all the doctoral theses being studied by desk-bound cops.'' Mr. Dietl's shield has some tarnished edges, however. He admits to drinking on duty, brawling off duty, accepting graft, feuding with civil rights activists and maintaining ties with Mafia bosses. He made arrests without probable cause. To flush out a murder suspect, he threatened to burn down a house and kill all its occupants. Mr. Dietl's 62 medals and commendations were matched by repeated charges of insubordination and brutality. The department stalled on promoting him to detective, exiled him to Brooklyn and, finally, processed his resignation in record time. Half of ''One Tough Cop'' transcribes Mr. Dietl's own words, mercilessly uncut and studded with obscenities. The rest is told by Ken Gross, a reporter for People magazine, and some parts may have got better in the telling.

title: Brawley Again Denies Faking Story of Abduction and Rape
description: For the second time in two weeks, Tawana Brawley yesterday denied publicly that she had made up her story of abduction and sexual abuse at the hands of a white racist gang last year. But she again refused to give details or answer questions about the incident.

title: JAMMU HAS PLANS FOR ST. LOUIS
description: THE TWENTY-SEVENTH CITY By Jonathan Franzen. 517 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95.

title: THE MYTH ABOUT TEEN-AGERS
description: A FATHER I KNOW TELLS of one unsettling moment when he was sure he would never understand the teen-age mind. The mind in question was that of his own teen-ager, a 15-year-old blonde possessed of considerable charm and an aggressive reticence. The pivotal moment was this effort at conversation:

title: Debt and Dirt
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Angrily Insisting He Fully Backs Quayle
description: Vice President Bush was walking back up the steps of his home after receiving the endorsement of the head of a police organization when someone called out a question about Senator Dan Quayle's much-debated performance as his running mate.

title: THE DEFENSE PLEADED NAGGING
description: DEATH OF A ''JEWISH AMERICAN PRINCESS'' The True Story of a Victim on Trial. By Shirley Frondorf. Illustrated. 281 pp. New York: Villard Books. $18.95.

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY;
PRIZZI FOR PRESIDENT
description: LEAD: PRIZZI'S GLORY By Richard Condon. 273 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $17.95.

title: New Construction Stretches Miracle Mile
description: LEAD: THE North Shore's Miracle Mile, once a short retail strip on Northern Boulevard in Manhasset, now extends five miles, from Great Neck on the west to Greenvale on the east, with stores aimed at affluent shoppers.

title: Suit Over Plumbing Won by Homeowners
description: Nearly 100 owners of homes with leaky pipes have been awarded a total of some $7 million in damages from the four companies that made and installed the plumbing, ending a trial that produced a 4,465-page verdict.

title: Sports of The Times; Pine Tar Is Not a Cheater's Tool
description: Under baseball law, pine tar in a pitcher's glove is illegal because it's a ''foreign substance.'' No argument there. But to most baseball people, pine tar is not considered to be a cheater's tool.

title: Amputee Prepares for Sports Media in Seoul
description: FINISHING ninth in a mini-triathlon field of 160 is an outstanding accomplishment. For Jim Henry of Windham, that is an amazing feat.

title: Two House Races Drawing Notice
description: ALTHOUGH they are being run in the shadows of Presidential and United States Senate races, two of New Jersey's 14 Congressional contests are attracting attention outside their district borders.

title: ROBUST FOOD FOR THE FALL
description: ON A CLEAR, CRISP AUTUMN day, it's hard to resist the urge to be outdoors, whether for a bracing run along the beach, a hike in the woods or a long walk in the city. These invigorating activities, combined with the tonic effect of brisk fall weather, are guaranteed to bring you home ravenous for a warm, robust meal.

title: Where Did All the Animals Go?
description: THE lawn in our backyard resembles an unkempt head of hair. Its owners eschew expensive styles, unpronounceable chemicals and trendy designs. Instead, we give it a basic, no-nonsense cut once a week. The grass is abundant and healthy, but it is far from the immaculate turf that graces the fairways of golf courses or the front yards of yuppie homes. We take care of our grass the old-fashioned way. We cut it. As rarely as possible.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Master Store Leases in Co-ops; Buildings and Investors Profit in Retail-Space Deals
description: IRVING SUTTON has trouble finding storefront buildings to buy in New York City these days, so, like a small but growing number of other real estate investors, he is buying control of retail space in co-op apartment buildings.

title: P.S.A.L.: Lafayette (4-0) Tops Midwood
description: Responding to its toughest challenge of the season, Lafayette beat Midwood, 7-3, yesterday in the mud, and became the team to beat in the 10-school Brooklyn A Division of the Public Schools Athletic League. The game, which matched the two undefeated teams in the division, was decided by a fumble.

title: Caroline M. Kirby Wed To Scribner Van Ingen
description: Caroline Mary Kirby, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Edgar George Kirby of Greenwich, Conn., and Joseph Scribner Van Ingen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Terrell Van Ingen Jr. of Greenwich, were married yesterday. The Rev. Richard Van Wely performed the ceremony at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: Athletics Bombard Red Sox
description: By the sixth inning, the chant had already started. They were calling for a sweep, and now the Oakland Athletics can give it to them.

title: Review/Theater; 'Sharon Shashanovah,' A Play Within a Play
description: The mirrors and puppets that occupy the stage of the 47th Street Theater for ''The Legend of Sharon Shashanovah'' signal the theatergoer that yet another exercise in the merging of reality and illusion and all that may be in store. As the puppets are replaced by actors, however, hope arises that the playwright, A. F. Horn, intends a takeoff on such standard theatrical intentions and pretensions.

title: AN EMPTINESS IN THE OVAL OFFICE
description: LANDSLIDE The Unmaking of the President, 1984-1988. By Jane Mayer and Doyle McManus. Illustrated. 468 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $21.95.

title: Producer Scouts State for TV Series
description: WHEN Thomas McGowan, a moviemaker from Malibu, Calif., decided to make a television series about old New England legends, he decided to return to his boyhood roots in Connecticut.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: THE WORLD'S BIGGEST MARKET;
How Companies Can Keep Europe Open
description: LEAD: After a decade as the center of global trade attention, Japan has suddenly taken a back seat to the 12-nation European Community. As realization of a true European common market approaches, ''Europe 1992'' has become the new buzz phrase in Washington and other trade capitals.

title: Beware: CD's Sonic Boom Can Demolish a Speaker
description: That glittering cymbal crash, that luminous orchestral burst, all caught in digital splendor - that's the thrilling payoff of digital sound. But for loudspeakers, such climactic musical moments hold unprecedented peril. Unless the speaker's vital parts can absorb the high signal levels encountered on CD's, these surges of energy are turned into heat that may literally cook the speaker to death.

title: Ohio State Won't Forfeit
description: Ohio State has decided not to forfeit its 26-9 victory over Syracuse after being advised that there was no existing N.C.A.A. rule requiring it to do so, Syracuse officials announced today.

title: Sherilyn Adie Marries
description: Sherilyn Ann Adie, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Adie of Sykesville, Md., and Ocean Beach, L.I., and David Brian Robinson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Robinson of Ephrata, Pa., were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Ellicott City, Md., by the Rev. Joseph P. Burroughs.

title: Asterisk Needed
description: OLYMPIC officials and international track authorities have made their decision. But the editors of the Guinness Book of Records are their own authority and they are deciding whether to recognize Ben Johnson's 100-meter Olympic time of 9.79 seconds as a world record.

title: Question of the Week; What Did You Think Of the Seoul Olympics?
description: Jingoism is a worthy sentiment but was done to death during the Olympics. As a visitor from England I would have appreciated one chance to have been proud of my athletes, cheered on their successes and shed my own tear during the playing of our national anthem. It was not to be. SHIRLEY PARDON New York

title: Israeli TV Political Ads Lowering the Low Road
description: Nissim Zvilli leaned forward with chin in hand, a bemused smile across his face as he looked directly into the televison camera.

title: NONFICTION
description: CORPORATE CRIME AND VIOLENCE: Big Business Power and the Abuse of the Public Trust. By Russell Mokhiber. (Sierra Club, $25.) In Russell Mokhiber's compelling chronicle of corporate negligence, the criminals are white-collar executives and the victims are the rest of us. Mr. Mokhiber, the editor of the Washington-based newsletter Corporate Crime Reporter, points out that the largest robbery in United States history totaled $5.4 million, whereas the far larger cost to the American public resulting from the manufacture of faulty goods, monopolistic practices and a host of other corporate law violations has been estimated by a Senate subcommittee to be between $174 billion and $231 billion annually. Yet few corporate executives have had to face tough penalties for such abuses as the marketing of the fatally flawed Ford Pinto or the shirking of responsibility for the environmental disaster at the Love Canal, the onetime waste dump for Hooker Chemical. These and other case histories make ''Corporate Crime and Violence'' grimly urgent reading, as one company after another is shown to have valued short-term economic profits far above human lives, community safety or the long-term health of the environment. A passionate if sometimes strident advocate of legal reform, Mr. Mokhiber outlines a 50-point ''law-and-order program to curb corporate crime'' and calls for a grass-roots alliance of victims of corporate crime to challenge ''an inequitable justice system that consistently treats street thuggery as a criminal activity and corporate thuggery as business as usual.''

title: Plainfield's Role In Enterprise Zone
description: I noted with great interest and appreciation the Aug. 28 article regarding Plainfield's effective use of the Urban Enterprise Zone legislation (''With State's Help, Plainfield Rebounds''). This letter is to correct some inaccuracies and contribute some historical perspective.

title: Sara E. Robertson Is Bride of Dr. Stephen Phillips
description: The wedding of Sara Elizabeth Robertson, the daughter of Mrs. Wood Lyda of Bellevue, Wash., and Earl E. Robertson Jr. of Kansas City, Mo., to Dr. Stephen Gregory Phillips, a son of Mrs. William J. Wallace of Seattle and the late Robert L. Phillips, took place yesterday at the Plymouth Congregational Church in Seattle. The Rev. Joseph C. Williamson performed the ceremony.

title: Stutterers Seek Help for Problem
description: LEAD: WHEN he was growing up, David Bell of Hartsdale ate a lot of chocolate ice cream.

title: 'Paul Robeson' to Close
description: ''Paul Robeson,'' a drama by Phillip Hayes Dean about the life of the black actor and singer, will close after the matinee today at the John Golden Theater, 245 West 45th Street. The play, directed by Harold Scott and starring Avery Brooks, will have run for five previews and 11 regular performances.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Many of the double-hung windows in my house need to have the putty replaced around the outside. Since each window has 12 panes, I thought of using a caulking gun to speed the job, but my dealer says that only glazing compound should be used. Someone suggested using silicone caulking. Do you know if this can be used instead of glazing compound around each pane?

title: Variety in Hispanic Works
description: IT'S no good, this lip service to minorities by way of less than satisfactory art exhibitions. A current example is the show that is part of a package at the Paterson Museum honoring Hispanic people - one of the city's largest and most recent infusions of new blood. It consists of 22 artists born in North, Central and South America, the Caribbean and Spain itself.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: O'NEILL CENTENNIAL

title: Folk Art Makes Space for the Doodle
description: Penmanship flourished in 19th-century America, producing thousands of disciplined doodlers. Many who mastered the swirled lines and swept curves of Spencerian script went on to adapt their cursive skills to drawing. Some of the florid images that resulted are among the drawings on view in ''They Worked in Ink,'' an exhibition and sale at Hirschl & Adler Folk, 851 Madison Avenue, through Saturday.

title: Meredith Young Weds in Virginia
description: At the Rock Spring Congregational Church in McLean, Va., Meredith Coe Young, the daughter of Capt. Alfred A. Young, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Young of McLean, was married yesterday to Matthew Anatole Baratz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton S. Baratz of Locust Grove, Va. The Rev. Richard L. Dodds performed the ceremony.

title: Rock, Born in the U.S.S.R.
description: The Poles have an outspoken ambivalence about their Soviet big brothers even at the best of times, and it was not the best of times when the Moscow rock band Zvuki Mu played Warsaw in May. Demonstrators were marching in the streets, and students had shut down the university in sympathy with striking miners and shipyard workers. As Zvuki Mu took the stage, recalls Sasha Lipninsky, the band's bass player, there were cries of ''Soviets go home!'' from the restless crowd of Polish punks in black leather and spiked hair.

title: Shoe Firms Taken to Task
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Sentiment, History Fade But a Fir Still Stands
description: THE drone of a bulldozer, leveling all that once was, sounds like a mourner. Clouds of dust rise from the rubble in seeming protest, reaching for the sun, or maybe heaven.

title: W.G. Roche Wed To Lisa Connors
description: Lisa Mary Connors, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Joseph Connors of Plandome, L.I., was married yesterday to William Gilbert Roche, a son of Maurice William Roche of Stamford, Conn., and the late Dolores Roche. The Rev. Ronald G. Connors, Bishop Coadjutor of San Juan de la Maguana in the Dominican Republic, and a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary in Manhasset, L.I.

title: Yale Trounced By Army, 33-18
description: On a field soaked by rain, Mike Mayweather ran for 155 yards and Ben Barnett for 92 as Army rolled over Yale, 33-18, before 17,898 fans at the Yale Bowl today.

title: THE REVOLUTION IN HEART TRANSFORMATION
description: HE AWOKE SHORTLY AFTER midnight, a 60-year-old man who had always been in good health even though he smoked and was overweight. But now he had a crushing, breath-robbing pain in his chest. He felt nauseated and broke into a cold sweat. Both he and his wife recognized the signs. She called an ambulance, and 30 minutes later he was in the emergency room of Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. His blood pressure was dropping and his electrocardiogram warned that a major heart attack was almost certainly developing. Normally, if he was lucky enough to survive it, a special coronary care team would have to watch over his life for days to keep him from slipping over the edge. Even if they succeeded, his heart might well be severely and permanently damaged. That was the expectation, but for this patient there was a crucial difference. Within five minutes of his arrival at the hospital, doctors had inserted a tube in a vein in his arm and begun infusion of a drug called tissue plasminogen activator, or t-PA. Thirty minutes after the infusion began, the man's pain disappeared completely. And tests later indicated that the attack had been halted -with little heart damage.

title: Debris Is Cleaned From Maine Coastal Areas
description: Maine's beaches are a bit cleaner today thanks to the efforts of about 1,200 people who collected 13,000 pounds of garbage that had been dumped at 60 coastal locations.

title: Sudan Halts Locust Spraying, Blaming Ethiopian Air Raids
description: The Sudan says it has stopped trying to control a locust plague along the Ethiopian border because of Ethiopian air attacks.

title: School Vans Are Target of Bill
description: LEAD: WITH the end of summer, motorists once again share the road with students on their way to school. But now the traditional large yellow school buses are sharing the road with smaller buses and vans.

title: Zukerman and Neikrug
description: The violinist and violist Pinchas Zukerman and the pianist Marc Neikrug are to perform the complete Violin and Viola Sonatas by Brahms, on Oct. 25 at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. The program is to include the Scherzo in C minor and the Sonata in G, both for violin and piano, and the Sonata in F minor for viola and piano. Information: 247-7800.

title: SELLING ADVENTURES TO THE PAST: PYRAMIDS AND PERU
description: As those intrigued by New Age philosophies accumulate leisure time and spending money, they are dabbling in spiritual healing, rebirthing, past-life regression therapy and traveling around the world. This has created tourist hot spots in such places as Machu Picchu, the ancient Incan city in the mountains of Peru, and the holy city of Lhasa in Tibet.

title: Sills to Be Feted
description: Bevery Sills, the general director of the New York City Opera, is to be honored as a ''Friend of the Arts'' by the Town Hall Foundation next Sunday at 7 P.M. at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. Festivities are to begin with a concert of ''Songs of the American Musical Theater'' sung by Earl Wrightson and Lois Hunt. A dinner and award presentation will follow. Tickets to the concert, dinner and award presentation are $125. Information: 997-1003.

title: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER Paying More Attention to Furniture
description: A lovely 100-year-old desk and a 4-year-old personal computer do not go together very well. The desk was designed for pen and paper, blotter and inkwell, not desktop computers, keyboards, laser printers, facsimile phones and mice. The matching chair was designed to provide support for brief periods, not for the eight hours a day that most office workers spend at their desks. Computers make special demands on the human body, demands all too often aggravated by the wrong furniture. The right furniture can lead to better organization, better accessibility, higher productivity and better health.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: ALICE IN LA-LA LAND, by Robert Campbell. (Pocket Books, $3.95.) Since Raymond Chandler wrote about the underside of Los Angeles, parts of the city have become even sleazier, and Robert Campbell has seized upon the worst of them for this sequel to ''In La-La Land We Trust.'' Last year, The Times's John Gross said this story about a loathsome talk show host with a psychopathic streak seemed excessively brutal. But ''Mr. Campbell confirms that he is a master of the hard-boiled Chandleresque manner.'' A SOUTHERN FAMILY, by Gail Godwin. (Avon, $4.95.) The night before he dies violently, Theo Quick tells his sister Clare that he wishes he were a character in one of her novels - unlike in life, tragedy in literature remains under some rational authorial control. ''After reading a Godwin novel,'' Beverly Lowry said in these pages last year, ''you find yourself going to the library to check out the book one of her characters has been reading, you ask the record store for her music, you cook her food. And so the experience continues, like good music, well beyond the last page. . . . Her books all give evidence of a supple intelligence working on the page. In this one she's in full bloom and at her mindful best.'' MOTHERS IN THE FATHERLAND: Women, the Family, and Nazi Politics, by Claudia Koonz. (St. Martin's, $14.95.) Convinced of the need to nurture German souls for the seeds of Nazism, women played a disturbingly important role in the rise of the Third Reich, Claudia Koonz argues. ''She has written a book of great historical and moral importance,'' Robert Jay Lifton said here earlier this year. ''It invites further probing of an extremely difficult issue - that of gender responses to situations of potential and actual evil.'' Basic Books has republished THE ITALIANS AND THE HOLOCAUST: Persecution, Rescue, and Survival by Susan Zuccotti ($9.95). Unlike in Germany and other countries, 85 percent of Italy's Jews survived World War II. ''A book on this subject had been long overdue, and Susan Zuccotti has risen to it with erudition and compassion,'' Raleigh Trevelyan wrote here last year. WITH OR WITHOUT: And Other Stories, by Charles Dickinson. (Collier/Macmillan, $7.95.) The men in these stories live detached, circumscribed lives in small towns. ''They arouse our empathy,'' Richard Perry said here last year. ''We move among them as among a room of accident victims, wondering if any will recover, and who or what is responsible.'' INWARD BOUND: Of Matter and Forces in the Physical World, by Abraham Pais. (Oxford University, $17.95.) Written by the author of ''Subtle Is the Lord,'' a biography of Einstein, this history of particle physics is ''illuminated by [ Abraham ] Pais's felicitous style,'' one reviewer said in 1986. He ''writes with lucidity and avoids frills but also shows an acute aesthetic sense and a fine sense of humor.'' TIME WITH CHILDREN, by Elizabeth Tallent. (Collier/Macmillan, $7.95.) Matrimony sounds like a fine idea to the characters in Elizabeth Tallent's short stories. Once bound, however, they find they are, at heart, emotional kleptomaniacs, stealing affection wherever they can. Last year, The Times's Michiko Kakutani called this ''a finely crafted volume that reattests to her poise and eloquence as a writer.'' THE MAKING OF ''THE AFRICAN QUEEN'': Or, How I Went to Africa With Bogart, Bacall and Huston and Almost Lost My Mind, by Katharine Hepburn. (Plume/ New American Library, $8.95.) Katharine Hepburn's memoir of life in the jungle ''is as spirited, appealing and shrewdly elusive as its author,'' Caryn James said here in 1987. ''This is the Hepburn we know: the woman who leaves 'Betty Bogart' behind to fix the crew's lunch while she tracks elephants.'' The same publisher has also reprinted the memoirs of Lee Strasberg, who was artistic director of the Actors Studio. Last year, our reviewer, Stephen Aaron, said A DREAM OF PASSION: The Development of the Method ($8.95), edited by Evangeline Morphos and published posthumously, describes ''in clear language devoid of jargon'' an acting technique that has been criticized as solipsistic and emotional, yet has produced performers of the caliber and appeal of Al Pacino and Joanne Woodward. THE MIND AND BODY SHOP, by Frank Parkin. (Laurel/Dell, $4.95.) A philosophy professor at a troubled British university, where a corporate flag flies above the library and coin-operated turnstiles have been installed in the lecture halls, seizes upon a plan to use sex to sell students on the pleasures of the mind. In 1987, our reviewer, Elizabeth Hawes, complained that the novel was too chipper. But she said Frank Parkin's ''eye and tongue are sharp, and his every sentence supplies a striking distortion, or projection, of reality.'' ACCIDENTAL MILLIONAIRE: The Rise and Fall of Steve Jobs at Apple Computer, by Lee Butcher. (Paragon, $9.95.) Steven Jobs, the countercultural folk hero who is a co-founder of Apple Computer, is little more than an image crafted by Regis McKenna, a Bay Area publicist who helped create the Silicon Valley legend, according to Lee Butcher. He has written ''a crisp, provocative book,'' John Taylor said here last year. ''It reduces Mr. Jobs to human proportions and makes him infinitely more interesting, if much less likable.'' AGENTS OF INNOCENCE, by David Ignatius. (Avon, $4.50.) In this novel of espionage in the Middle East, a C.I.A. agent is cast as a sensitive, principled, intellectual man. ''What emerges is a richly drawn psychological portrait,'' Jules Koslow said here last year. ''It is the skillfully drawn characters as much as the plot and subplot machinations that the reader will remember.''

title: Miss Rozelle Has Wedding
description: Anne Marie Rozelle, the daughter of Pete Rozelle of Harrison, N.Y., and Jane M. Coupe of San Clemente, Calif., was married yesterday to Douglas K. Bratton, the son of Iris K. Bratton of Concord, N.C., and the late Carl H. Bratton. Judge William R. Johnston of the Town of Harrison performed the ceremony at the Mashomack Club in Pine Plains, N.Y.

title: County Weighs Highway Bond
description: LEAD: WITH Election Day a month away, government officials and others in Westchester are choosing sides over the $3 billion state transportation bond issue that will appear on the ballot.

title: Permanent Olympic Site, Greece Perhaps, Would Improve Games
description: To the Editor:

title: Coping With the Costs
description: The United States dollar, after two years of behaving like a punctured balloon, has actually gained a bit in value against the major European currencies this year. But what should be good news for American travelers in Europe - an increase in the value of the dollar of roughly 10 percent since the beginning of 1988 - has not worked its way into lower prices for dollar spenders because of inflation in the booming European travel business.

title: THE WORLD: Western Europe; Soviet Bloc's Neighbors Seek a Grip On Unrest
description: WESTERN European governments have long nourished deep sympathy for Eastern Europeans living under Communist rule. But this feeling has often been overlaid by a guilty sense that little could be - or perhaps even should be -done to tinker with a division of the continent that has coincided with more than four decades of peace. Now, as Mikhail S. Gorbachev consolidates his grip on power within the Soviet Union, it is becoming evident that the stakes in Eastern Europe have risen for everyone. Ferment in Hungary, Poland and Yugoslavia and the potential for upheavals in Czechoslovakia, Rumania and possibly East Germany have policy-makers in Paris, London and Bonn crossing their fingers and praying for peaceful, evolutionary change.

title: BRUINS TRIUMPH, 6-2
description: Boston scored on three of its first five shots, and the defensman Ray Boruque had four assists, three in the first period, as the Boston Bruins defeated the Hartfdord Whalers, 6-2 tonight.

title: A Final Wish is Not Honored
description: LAST month, my mother passed away. She was 69 years old. The last few years, her health had been rapidly deteriorating. She signed a ''living will'' and her one wish was never to be put on a life support system. Unfortunately, that wish was not granted.

title: Playing the Party Circuit
description: When Hiroshi Watanabe became president of the Sanwa Bank on June 29, he thought he should meet some of his clients. So Mr. Watanabe's staff scheduled 29 lavish parties for more than 10,000 guests at luxury hotels across Japan.

title: Seeking the Vision to See Beyond Discovery
description: THE Discovery had just landed, and Rear Adm. Richard H. Truly was pleased with the achievement. The former astronaut, who was brought back to NASA after the Challenger disaster 32 months ago to revive the shaken program, is widely credited with the successful return of Americans to space. ''The nation,'' he said in this moment of elation, ''is going to have the shuttle as the backbone of its space program well into the next century.''

title: Confusion on Bush Panelist
description: The Rev. Florian M. Galdau, one of six members said to have resigned from Vice President Bush's ethnic coalition last month, now says he never did so.

title:
GARDENING;
Leaves: A Phenonemon and a Resource
description: LEAD: LEAVES are the food manufacturing organs of plants. Most leaves are some shade of green, the green color coming from the chlorophyl in the leaf cells.

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY;
STRANGE DOINGS IN YUPPIE HEAVEN
description: LEAD: A QUESTION OF MURDER By Eric Wright. 200 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $15.95.

title: Bonna L. Horovitz Is Wed To Joel Steven Finkelstein
description: Bonna Lynn Horovitz and Joel Steven Finkelstein, both lawyers, were married yesterday evening at the Princeton (N.J.) Jewish Center by Rabbi Melvin J. Glazer and Cantor Robert Friedman.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
When Films Were Movies and Heroines Were Blond
description: LEAD: IN the gloomy autumn night, a car pulls up to a building, screeches to a halt and three passengers leap out. Is it a robbery? Is it a riot? No, it's a movie. The driver calls out the words his wife has been waiting to hear - ''I'll park; you get the tickets'' - and then speeds off into the night (or, more specifically, to a parking spot about 17 miles from the multiplex theater).

title: Suzanne Falter Marries
description: Suzanne Virginia Falter, the daughter of Mrs. John Paul Jones of Lafayette Hill, Pa., and the late John Falter, was married yesterday in Central Park to Raymond Lawrence Barns, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Barns. The Rev. Mary Alice Brown of the Unity Church of Teaneck, N.J., officiated. The bride, a graduate of the Springside School and Wellesley College, is freelance writer. Mr. Barns, a graduate of Syracuse University, is a freelance photographer.

title: LUSH LASHES
description: When Tammy Faye Bakker faced the world with mascaraed tears sliding down her cheeks, it was humiliation by cosmetics. Not long after that, a clear mascara appeared on the drugstore shelves. A coincidence? Perhaps. But the market was ripe for a mascara that didn't leave black raccoonlike rings under the eyes, that didn't stream off in the rain or a flood of tears and that didn't need to be sandblasted off at night.

title: Woodbury Project Opposed
description: CONCERNS over traffic congestion, air quality, esthetics and safety in Woodbury have prompted various efforts during the last few years to block commercial development on the few remaining open spaces within the community.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Shoot to Kill Starring Sidney Poitier, Tom Berenger, Kirstie Alley, Clancy Brown, Richard Masur, Andrew Robinson, Kevin Scannell, Frederick Coffin. Directed by Roger Spottiswoode. 1988. Touchstone Home Video. 109 Minutes. $89.95. Closed captioned. Rated R.

title: The Evolution of Eurospeak
description: WHEN Albert Bloch, a character in Marcel Proust's ''Remembrance of Things Past'' dislikes the music of the gypsy band in a posh seaside hotel, he says, ''Tell the laift to make them stop.'' The novel's narrator wryly notes that his parvenu friend Bloch thinks the letter i in English is always pronounced as in life, but he omits to add that the correct French expression for elevator attendant is not laift but liftier, although many people would say lift.

title: 100,000 Hold Rally in Latvia
description: More than 100,000 Latvians rallied in Riga, the Latvian capital, in support of the nationalist Latvian People's Front, the official Tass press agency said today. The People's Front, which has 130,000 members, opened a conference today, and a Latvian native said speakers at the meeting criticized the management of the republic's farming and industry. The front has Moscow's favor because it supports economic restructuring.

title: Sheryl WuDunn Wed to Reporter
description: Sheryl WuDunn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David WuDunn of New York, was married yesterday to Nicholas D. Kristof, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ladis K. D. Kristof of Yamhill, Ore. The Rev. David Anderson performed the ceremony at St. Cloud Presbyterian Church in West Orange, N.J.

title: NONFICTION
description: MASQUERADE: A True Story of Seduction, Compulsion, and Murder. By Lowell Cauffiel. (Doubleday, $18.95.) W. Alan Canty, a psychologist, was a pillar of his community in suburban Detroit, quiet and circumspect in his dealings with patients, a loving husband and a devoted son. Then Dr. Canty turned up dead, his head crushed by blows from a Louisville Slugger, his body dismembered by a kitchen knife and the pieces scattered. His story is told in ''Masquerade,'' Lowell Cauffiel's excellent account of one man's flirtation with a twilight zone of his own making and the subsequent police investigation of his death. Dr. Canty led a double life, one that led him to liaisons with a young prostitute, Dawn Spens, in Detroit's grim Cass Corridor section. Dr. Canty quickly became Spens' regular customer, a genuine sugar daddy who gave her clothes, cars and other gifts until the money ran out. It ended on July 13, 1985, when he was murdered by her pimp, John (Lucky) Fry. Mr. Cauffiel, a former Detroit journalist, conveys a sense of a man's loss of control and helpless spiraling into disaster throughout his highly readable narrative. The book's characterizations and style are lucid and polished, he has obviously done the requisite research, and the bite-size chapters are almost cinematic in their movement. ''Masquerade'' names names, convincingly relating a factual tale of murder - and another, more speculative tale, one whose fabric is woven of the less distinct, unpredictable threads of the mind.

title: Head Trauma
description: AS HIS ROOM FILLED WITH the clutter of a normal 17-year-old, so did his mind. I examined him one or two weekends a month when I covered my colleagues' patients on the head-trauma and spinal-cord-injury wards at a California rehabilitation center. That weekend his eyes were fixed downward. Moist oxygen puffed into the tracheostomy tube in his neck, and, whenever his lungs began to fill with fluid and choke him or a nurse turned him to prevent bedsores, his spastic legs and arms shot out straight. On a cork board beside the suction machine and intravenous tubes, his mother had pinned the picture of her muscular son standing beside his girlfriend and surfboard at the beach.

title: Women's Hotel
description: To the Editor:

title: Singer Wins G.O.P.'s Assembly Contest
description: IT took something of an uprising in Republican ranks last week, but Cecile Singer, who has run Assemblyman Gordon W. Burrows's Westchester office for two decades, was selected to replace him as the Republican candidate for his 84th Assembly District seat.

title: Burma's Opposition Appears to Falter
description: Diplomats and others familiar with events in Burma say a phase of the struggle for political change there has ended with the failure of a broad but loosely organized democratic opposition to divide the military and sweep the authorities from power.

title: THE LAUREATE OF BLACK AMERICA
description: LEAD: THE LIFE OF LANGSTON HUGHES Volume II, 1941-1967: I Dream a World. By Arnold Rampersad. Illustrated. 512 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95

title: U.S. Political Mail Explained
description: A staff member of the Federal Trade Commission, in trouble over some politically oriented letters he mailed, has told a House subcommittee that he was doing what he thought was expected.

title: WAQUIOT WINS THE GOLD CUP
description: Waquoit splashed to a 15-length victory in the $1,063,000 Jockey Club Gold Cup yesterday on a Belmont Park track so sloppy that two Kentucky Derby winners were scratched from the card.

title: Q and A
description: Primary Residence

title: Question of the Week: Next Week; Once and For All, What About The D.H. in The Series?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Home Care for the Elderly Cut Back
description: TWO years ago, New York State officials recognized the problems faced by frail older adults squeezed between hospitals that could not keep them and nursing homes that would not take them.

title: Taking a Short Break Abroad
description: These days a remark about going to the country for the weekend could well prompt the question: Which country?

title: Racing on Long Island Sound
description: Long Island Sound has a reputation for light winds in summer. But in the fall, the breeze picks up and provides a more kindly environment for sailboat racing.

title: Q and A
description: Williamsburg

title: Scott Suhr Wed To Sally Bromage
description: At Grace Episcopal Church in Madison, N.J., yesterday, Sally Van Dusen Bromage, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Bromage of Florham Park, N.J., and Scott Montgomery Suhr, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Suhr of Marietta, Ga., were married. The Rev. Robert W. Ihloff performed the ceremony.

title: Algerian Troops Again Fire on Protesters in Capital
description: Troops opened fire on a crowd outside a mosque in eastern Algiers today and used tear gas in the center of the city to disperse youths shouting slogans against President Chadli Benjedid.

title: L.S.U. Surprises Auburn, 7-6
description: Tommy Hodson capped a 75-yard drive with a fourth-down, 11-yard touchdown pass to the tailback Eddie Fuller with 1 minute 41 seconds to play tonight, and David Browndyke kicked the extra point that gave Louisiana State a stunning 7-6 victory over Auburn.

title: BEST SELLERS: October 9, 1988
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 10 THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan races to the rescue of America's highest-ranking secret agent in the Soviet Union. 2 2 3 BREATHING LESSONS, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $18.95.) The many facets of a 28-year marriage are revealed during a drive to a friend's funeral. 3 3 9 TILL WE MEET AGAIN, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $19.95.) The exploits of a woman and her two daughters from pre-World War I Paris to present-day Los Angeles. 4 4 15 ALASKA, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $22.50.) The history of the 49th state told in fictional form. 5 5 5 SPOCK'S WORLD, by Diane Duane. (Pocket, $16.95.) An emergency meeting of the planet Vulcan's ruling council exposes its secret history and that of the Enterprise's Commander Spock. 6 6 5 THE SILENCE OF THE LAMBS, by Thomas Harris. (St. Martin's, $18.95.) A young woman F.B.I. trainee pursues a serial killer. 7 10 34 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 8 8 49 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 9 13 2 KOKO, by Peter Straub. (Dutton, $19.95.) Three Vietnam veterans on the trail of a friend who may be responsible for a series of murders committed throughout Asia. 10 11 25 LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $18.95.) A Colombian poet's perdurable love for a woman is tested by life's changing conditions. 11 1 PRIME TIME, by Joan Collins. (Linden/Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Five actresses compete for a glamorous role in Hollywood. 12 1 TRACKS, by Louise Erdrich. (Holt, $18.95.) The mysterious life of Fleur Pillager, a Chippewa woman with the powers of a shaman. 13 * 15 4 THE AVIATORS, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $18.95.) A volume in the ''Brotherhood of War'' series set in Vietnam. 14 14 7 DEMON LORD OF KARANDA, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $18.95.) The battle for control of a continent continues in the fantasy saga ''The Malloreon.'' 15 7 11 DOCTORS, by Erich Segal. (Bantam, $19.95.) The life stories of five members of Harvard Medical School's class of 1962. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 25 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A British scientist's review of efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 2 2 5 THE LIVES OF JOHN LENNON, by Albert Goldman. (Morrow, $22.95.) The rock-and-roll star as legend and as human being. 3 3 6 THE BOZ, by Brian Bosworth with Rick Reilly. (Doubleday, $17.95.) The life and controversial opinions of the Seattle Seahawks football player. 4 4 7 THE RAGMAN'S SON, by Kirk Douglas. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) The actor recalls his life as poor immigrant's son, waiter, steel mill worker, haberdashery salesman, film star, father and man. 5 1 LANDSLIDE, by Jane Mayer and Doyle McManus. (Houghton Mifflin, $21.95.) Two Washington reporters on ''the unmaking of the President, 1984-1988.'' 6 5 12 THE DUCHESS OF WINDSOR, by Charles Higham. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.) The life of the woman from Baltimore who married King Edward VIII. 7 7 6 TRANSFORMATION, by Whitley Strieber. (Beech Tree/Morrow, $18.95.) The author of ''Communion'' tells of more confrontations with ''intelligent nonhumans.'' 8 6 13 GENERATION OF SWINE, by Hunter S. Thompson. (Summit, $18.95.) Commentary on the current decade. 9 8 2 PRESS ON! by Chuck Yeager and Charles Leerhsen. (Bantam, $17.95.) The legendary pilot on flying, the outdoors and his West Virginia roots. 10 10 2 THEY WENT THAT-A-WAY . . ., by Malcolm Forbes with Jeff Bloch. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) How the famous (and the infamous) met their end. 11 9 43 TRUMP, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. 12 12 9 SENATORIAL PRIVILEGE, by Leo Damore. (Regnery Gateway, $19.95.) A reporter's reassessment of the 1969 accident on Chappaquiddick Island. 13 11 17 TALKING STRAIGHT, by Lee Iacocca with Sonny Kleinfield. (Bantam, $21.95.) More experiences and opinions of the Chrysler chairman. 14 * 13 47 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $19.95.) The author discusses ways for companies to survive in today's and tomorrow's turbulent world. 15 34 THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS, by Paul Kennedy. (Random House, $24.95.) How economic and military forces affected the fortunes of great nations in the past 500 years. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 66 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 2 2 5 ALL YOU CAN DO IS ALL YOU CAN DO, BUT ALL YOU CAN DO IS ENOUGH! by A. L. Williams. (Nelson, $14.95.) The philosophy of a highly successful entrepreneur who deals in life insurance and investments. 3 4 27 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 4 3 158 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $16.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 5 5 45 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) The Second College Edition of a standard work, updated in 1982. AND BEAR IN MIND SHINE HAWK, by Charlie Smith. (Paris Review/British American, $17.95.) Themes of elusive trugth, of longings and questings that have no end, pervade this rich and lyrical novel; its narrator flashes back and forth between his life as an artist in New York and his brother's death an dburial in rural Georgia. ALL THE RIGHT ENEMIES: The Life and Murder of Carlo Tresca, by Dorothy Gallagher. (Rutgers University, $24.95.) The career of the intransigent anarchist (1879-1943) and charismatic agitator, murdered in New York at the probable behest of Fascisti. MEMORIES OF AMNESIA, by Lawrence Shainberg. (Paris Review/British American, $16.95.) In this bold tussle with the ultimate metafictional self-swallowing, Mr. Shainberg's protagonist, a brain surgeon, operates on his own brain and reports on the deterioration of his own consciousness. THE OTHER SIDE OF ARMS CONTROL: Soviet Objectives in the Grobachev Era, by Alan B. Sherr. (Unwin Hyman, Cloth, $49.95; Paper, $17.95.) A thorough analysis of the opportunities and problems behind Mr. Gorbachev's accessibility to arms reduction. THE ASSIGNATIN, by Joyce Carol Oates. (Ecco, $16.95.) A collection of brief fictional pieces, incarnating with Ms. Oates's habitual intensity the proposition that this is a dangerous world and love doesn't help, though no one, alas, can do without it. MRS. THATCHER'S REVOLUTION: The Ending of the Socialist Era, by Peter Jenkins. (Harvard University, $25.) A distinguished British hournalist argues that the Prime Minister's very real achievements were enabled by trends not of her making. IN THE HEART OF THE WHOLE WORLD, by John Rolfe Gardiner. (Knopf, $17.95.) An accomplished, convincing novel about a teacher obsessed first with a student, whom he makes pregnant, then with his unacknowledgeable daughter. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Stafford's Promise
description: To the Editor:

title: 'You Have to Believe in the Students'
description: FOR many poor youths, education is their exodus from a dismal environment. Over the last two decades, urban education has begun to deteriorate as inner-city schools nationwide are plagued by crime, low financing and parental apathy.

title: HERE COMES MOTHER, LIKE THE STATUE OF LIBERTY
description: When he was a boy, Robert Stone said in the Paris Review's latest volume of ''Writers at Work,'' he and his mother used to go on the road together, like Kerouac characters. ''My mother and I would take off on some migration to where things were going to be better.'' Once they spent two nights sleeping on a roof. ''It was wild,'' Mr. Stone said. ''It was useful. On the one hand, it gave me a fear of chaos, and on the other hand, it was a romance with the world and bus stations and things like that.''

title: Review/Concert; New-Music Tribute To an Oboist
description: North/South Consonance, a chamber ensemble that specializes in music by contemporary American and Latin American composers, dedicated its Thursday evening program at Merkin Concert Hall to the memory of Josef Marx, an oboist who devoted himself to new music.

title: HIGH POINT
description: Traditional furniture has always been the bread and butter of the Southern Furniture Market in High Point, N.C., and this fall is no exception. ''It's going to be an especially conservative market,'' says Carl Levine, senior vice president of home furnishings at Bloomingdale's. ''Business has been poor ever since the stock crash on Oct. 19. Neither customers nor manufacturers are taking risks, therefore traditional designs are selling far better than modern ones.''

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''There have been many managements in the past who have taken the same rationale as Pillsbury and ultimately couldn't produce on it. It turned out to be a mistake for shareholders.'' Barry Ziegler, Tucker, Anthony & R. L. Day, on Pillsbury's decision to fight Grand Met's takeover bid.

title: Rap Plus Reggae - A Compelling Synthesis
description: The title track of Don Baron's ''Young, Gifted and Black'' (Uni 4; all three formats) starts off with a brittle rap beat. The words ''We're talking 'bout'' are repeated like percussion licks. Mr. Baron enters, repeating a syllable, imitating rap's scratching technique. He starts singing ''I'm young, gifted and black,'' in a Jamaican accent, and charges into a section of reggae toasting - the Jamaican version of rapping - all over a dense rap collage.

title: FICTION
description: A VOID IN HEARTS. By William G. Tapply. (Scribners, $16.95.) If you're a fan of Spenser's Boston beat and first-person narration, but your tolerance for catalogues of laps, reps, exquisite manly repasts and wardrobe details has flagged, give William G. Tapply's Brady Coyne a try. A Copley Square lawyer who, with refreshing misgivings, occasionally deserts trusts for freelance detection, Coyne is neither knight-errant nor cool professional. When a seedy private investigator is crushed by a hit-and-run driver, the ''accident'' adds up to murder. Coyne turns investigator, and throughout ''A Void in Hearts'' his wry account of his own fears, false confidence, confusion and bad guesses lends considerable charm to action that proceeds rapidly from modest initial incidents to dramatic and deadly confrontations. If the plot's surprises depend in part on their outlandishness, well, that's entertainment. Coyne sees himself as ''an anachronism, a country boy''; gazing through the window of his office, he reflects that ''many people find elevated views of cities at night beautiful. I'm a moon and stars man, myself.'' Romantic notions don't inform the state of Coyne's affections, however, or his ethical judgments. ''I loved it,'' he exults, when two icily amoral characters glide away unprosecuted from, at the very least, appropriating a suitcaseful of mob money. This seventh Brady Coyne mystery details the hero's equivocal relations with his ex-wife, Gloria, and throws in a casual affair. Skepticism is Coyne's strength, but uncommited ambivalence hollows him out. ''A Void in Hearts'' takes its title from a bridge term, but there's something important missing in Brady too.

title: Taking His Cuts
description: ONE of the Mets' most promising minor league managers has decided to abandon baseball for the meat business. Tucker Ashford, the 33-year-old manager of the club's Texas League farm club in Jackson, Miss., submitted his resignation last week.

title: Dodging Politics, a Doctor Aids the Salvadoran Poor
description: Picking her way through a political minefield, Dr. Vicky Guzman de Luna is bringing health care for the first time to thousands of impoverished peasants.

title: Wolfe and Tolstoy
description: To the Editor:

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY: IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE UNICORN'S SECRET: Murder in the Age of Aquarius. By Steven Levy. (Prentice Hall, $18.95.) Nearly everybody who lived in Philadelphia in the 1960's knew of Ira Einhorn, the pony-tailed, Santa-bearded (and -bellied) hippie who ruled the town's counterculture. Arguably visionary, indisputably charismatic, he was able to gather up not only the disaffected but also the news media and a remarkable assemblage of corporate moguls, and to hold them in his thrall for more than a decade.

title: Eiffel Tower Workers on Strike
description: The 70 employees at the Eiffel Tower went on strike today for higher pay, preventing tourists from entering. The employees, who make $4.55 an hour, want a raise of about 31 cents.

title: Boat People Beaten in Hong Kong, Report Finds
description: An independent report has concluded that after a protest in a Vietnamese detention center, guards there used ''unnecessary force'' against some boat people, kicking and beating them as they squatted in the camp yard with their heads down and their hands behind their necks.

title: Indian Brings U.S. Technology Back Home
description: Satyen Gangrao Pitroda, a businessman who renounced his American citizenship to return to his native India and work as Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's scientific adviser, has become known as the country's Mr. Technology.

title: Seeking a Law To Fight Obesity
description: REPRESENTATIVE Gary L. Ackerman weighed 286 pounds when he decided action was needed:

title: PRESCHOOL STAFF DEMAND PENSIONS
description: Frustrated in their attempts to gain a pension and higher salaries from the Koch administration, Head Start employees have turned to street protests to press their demands.

title: Question of the Week; What Did You Think Of the Seoul Olympics?
description: I feel the gains of the Olympics far outweigh the bad and the ugly aspects. The greatest benefit is the chance to see the rigors and the wonders of the lesser-known sports, to appreciate the dedication of time, energy and finances that so many athletes put into endeavors that they know will never repay them in anything but their own satisfaction.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE WESTCHESTER ART WORKSHOP;
With an Eye on the 21st Century, Safety Comes First
description: LEAD: TO hear Wayne Kartzinel tell it, the Westchester Art Workshop has moved from the cellar to the ''21st century.''

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Knicks at Purchase
description: LEAD: The State University of New York at Purchase may have a reputation for focusing primarily on the arts, but the school will see some professional sports action tonight and through the basketball season.

title: Does Bottle Policy Need Revamping?
description: Congratulations to Deborah O'Keefe for addressing the bottle and can recycling issue [ ''Bottle Law: When Can Becomes Can't,'' Opinion Page, Sept. 18 ] . It is a subject about which I have been writing in my head for months. Mrs. O'Keefe has covered most of the major frustrations of the process, but I would like to expand on the subject further. Machines that crunch up bottles and cans always seem to be out of coins when I try to return them before or after work. The store manager will then give me a reason why the time is not right for reloading machines.

title: Turkey
description: To the Editor: Regarding the advice for a woman traveling alone in Turkey (Q & A, Aug. 14), may I add a couple of items from my own experience?

title: Libraries Defining Policies on Young
description: LEAD: CHILDREN and public libraries naturally go together for reading, for doing homework and for storytelling times, but libraries emphasize that they are not day-care centers.

title: Karl G. Seelaus 3d Weds Miss Bosee
description: At the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn., Barbara de Valengin Bosee, the daughter of J. Kennard Bosee of New York and Phyllis Torrey Bosee of Old Greenwich, was married yesterday to Karl Gustav Seelaus 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Karl G. Seelaus of Jupiter Island, Fla. The Rev. Dale M. Greene performed the ceremony.

title: Mercedes Sosa: A Voice of Hope
description: When Mercedes Sosa sings of the pain of exile, the fear of political persecution or the joy of witnessing democracy restored, as she has done on five continents for more than 30 years, she is not parroting someone else's words. Above all, she is recounting her own experience and that of millions of Latin Americans to whom she is the voice of hope and justice.

title: Top Earner in South Korea: Owner of Tear Gas Company
description: A woman who heads a tear gas company earned more money than anybody else in South Korea last year, the result of a surge in violent protests, tax officials said today.

title: L.A. LAWLESS
description: FEAR OF THE DARK By Gar Anthony Haywood. 185 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press.

title: Sarah Chazen Marries
description: Sarah Ellen Chazen, an administrative assistant at Young & Rubicam, the advertising agency, and Martin David Levin, a financial consultant for Shearson Lehman Hutton, were married yesterday evening at the Tammy Brook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J. Rabbi Stephen A. Klein officiated. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Chazen of Hackensack, N.J., and Alfred Levine of Smoke Rise, N.J., and Barbara Downey of Boca Raton, Fla.

title: BEHIND BARBED WIRE
description: Painful as it was to be reminded again of my three-year incarceration, I am grateful to John Hersey for writing ''Behind Barbed Wire'' (Sept. 11) with such clarity and eloquence.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
A Hazard Filtered Out
description: LEAD: A catch-basin filtration system of water collection, said to be the only one of its kind in the country, has been installed in a house in Kent to replace a well that was contaminated with arsenic. The system is used in various forms throughout the Caribbean but fell out of favor years ago in America when large aqueducts were built, according to Rudolfo Hafner, a contractor with the Federal Environmental Protection Agency who helped install it at the Gypsy Trail Road home of Norman and Alicia

title: U.S. Embassy Vehicle Is Hit By Gunfire in San Salvador
description: An American Embassy security vehicle was hit by gunfire on Friday, but there were no casualties, an embassy spokesman said today. Two Salvadoran security men were in the car at the time of the attack. No Americans were involved, the spokesman said.

title: Top Recruit Feels Pressure
description: Peter Fortay worries about his son, Bryan. He worries when Bryan is told by men twice his age that he's a better high school quarterback than John Elway was. He worries when college coaches guarantee Bryan a starting position as a freshman. He worries when Bryan is mentioned as a 1992 Heisman Trophy candidate.

title: Workers Heed Call of the Vine
description: LEAD: THELMA BRITT, stooping beneath a net designed to discourage birds, clipped bunches of dark red pinot noir grapes and placed them in a plastic crate as her husband, Glen, stood on the other side of the vine doing the same thing.

title: Deidra D. Dain Becomes a Bride
description: Deidra Depew Dain, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry P. Dain 3d of Garrison, N.Y., and Michael Scott Sottosanti, the son of Joseph Sottosanti of Luray, Va., and the late Jacqueline Clague Sottosanti, were married yesterday at St. Philip's Episcopal Church-in-the-Highlands in Garrison.

title: Christopher Patusky to Wed Lerzan Kizilay in September
description: Dr. and Mrs. Dogan Kizilay of South Orange, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter Lerzan Suzanne Kizilay to Christopher Patusky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Patusky of Stamford, Conn. The couple plan to marry next September.

title: Season Marked By New Plays
description: A WOMAN plans to create a new room in her basement, until her long-lost, apocalypse-fearing husband returns, intent on turning it into a bomb shelter.

title: INSIDE
description: Tables Turn in Estonia

title: Brasher Paintings of American Birds in Storrs Exhibit
description: REX BRASHER was an ornothologist and an artist who combined his two passions in a collection of 874 paintings of North American birds. Fifty paintings from the collection, which was purchased by Connecticut in 1960, are on exhibit through Oct. 24 at the Connecticut State Museum of Natural History in Storrs.

title: Businessmen Friendly to a Tax Rise
description: Leaders of the largest American companies, who gathered here today for the semi-annual meeting of the Business Council, generally support the candidacy of Vice President Bush. But in their support for strong measures to reduce the Federal budget deficit, they are counting on a bipartisan commission whose probable recommendations the Vice President has sharply disavowed.

title: Vernon Township Journal; Questions Linger After Zoning Settlement
description: FOR four years, Heidi Hyland has given her best efforts to opposing a zoning variance that permitted expansion of facilities for satellite communications at an earth station in her residential neighborhood here.

title: About Cars; Peugeot's 405 Europe's No. 1
description: One thing about the Long Island Expressway: as the world's longest parking lot, it does provide time for comment.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The question before the house - The Metropolitan Opera House, that is - sounds simple enough: does George Frideric Handel belong in this company's repertory? Of course, but in what shape or form? As you suspected, the answers are neither simple nor unchallengeable. This season's production of ''Giulio Cesare,'' which turned into a personal triumph for its Cleopatra, Kathleen Battle, represented one approach, admittedly difficult to follow because there are not many Kathleen Battles around. Handel's dramatic values were not ignored, but the main emphasis here was - properly - on vocal bravado, specifically the technically taxing but enchanting outpouring of florid sound that is identified in operatic shorthand as bel canto.

title: Inexpensive and Intriguing Thai
description: IF you are in the mood for Thai ood, head for Bangkok Jansom in Bridgeport, the latest in the upsurge of Connecticut restaurants featuring the spicy cuisine of Thailand.

title: On Campus, the Millenium
description: Game after game, season after season, they lost.

title: A Few Common Backyard Problems Are Solved
description: KEEP up with planting, especially evergreens; tamp the earth gently afterward with your feet to be sure roots contact soil; water in well. Start leaf raking so grass is not smothered, particularly on new lawns that have been seeded or sodded. Continue planting bulbs, especially smaller ones. Postpone pruning of shade trees until late winter. House plants, particularly tropical foliage plants, should be indoors. Caution on taking white flies indoors on plants such as gerberas; discard plants and buy new ones next summer. QUESTIONS/ANSWERS GRAPEVINES

title: Judge Bars Stating A.C.L.U.'s Role at Trial
description: A judge in a freedom-of-the-press case has barred any mention of a lawyer's membership in the American Civil Liberties Union in front of the jury because of the criticism that the organization has received in the Presidential campaign.

title: New Jersey Q & A:Robert R. Herb; Running Bergen County's Jail
description: HIS is a jail repeatedly criticized by the state for its continued violence and overcrowding, where the prison population has nearly peaked at 1,000 in a facility originally designed to hold 395.

title: THE BRIGHT SIDE OF BAD HEALTH
description: THOUGHTS OF GOOD HEALTH ALMOST made me hit a jogger as I was bowling along in my pollution-driven compact, savoring the bouquet exuded by the burning leaf of my panatela as it wafted across the parkway. I had deftly engergized the power steering to miss, narrowly, collision with a bicycle. Joggers, cyclists, couples munching organic greenery on the sward - devotion to good health, I mused, that's what life has come to.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
'Snow and Sand' Medal Honors the Animals
description: LEAD: THE Society of Medalists pays tribute to animals with its latest medal ''Snow and Sand.'' The obverse of the 5-ounce bronze medal depicts a team of dogs pulling a sled and Eskimo through the Arctic snow. The reverse shows camels with one of them bearing an Arab rider.

title: Christine M. Morrissey Weds Peter S. Duncan
description: Christine Marie Morrissey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Morrissey of Briarcliff, N.Y., was married yesterday to Peter Stuart Duncan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Peter A. Duncan of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. James Quinn, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Marymount Chapel in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Strange Day On the Fields Of New York
description: On the day Columbia won a football game for the first time in five years, a pitcher was ejected from a major league baseball playoff game for the first time for having a foreign substance on his glove.

title: Miss Giroux Weds David A. DeNunzio
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York, Jocelyne Antoinette Giroux, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Claude Andre Giroux of New York, was married yesterday to David Ames DeNunzio, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Dwight DeNunzio of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Kenneth France-Kelly performed the ceremony.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: AT CENTURY'S TURN

title: DOUBTING THE PROPHET
description: A GATHERING OF SAINTS A True Story of Money, Murder and Deceit. By Robert Lindsey. Illustrated. 397 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95. THE MORMON MURDERS A True Story of Greed, Forgery, Deceit, and Death. By Steven Naifeh and Gregory White Smith. Illustrated. 458 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $19.95.

title: Laura R. Walker Is Married
description: Laura Ruth Walker and Albert Lewis Wells Jr. were married yesterday at the Riverside Church in New York by the Rev. Dr. Eugene E. Laubach, a Methodist minister. The bride, who will retain her name, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Walker of Elmsford, N.Y. Her husband is a son of Mrs. Albert Lewis Wells of El Cajon, Calif., and the late Mr. Wells.

title: Debatemanship
description: THE LATIN ROOT for the word >debate is the same as that for >battle: >battuere, ''to beat,'' as in whacking your opponent over the head.

title: BENTSEN KEEPS UP ATTACK ON QUAYLE
description: Charging that the Republicans were trying to ''run away'' from Senator Dan Quayle since last week's Vice-Presidential debate, Senator Lloyd Bentsen predicted today that the Democratic campaign would focused on him ''more and more'' in coming weeks.

title: Saving the Ocean: Here's What We Can Do
description: FOR years, the ocean has been sending warning signals. Yielding to disease brought on by ocean pollution, hundreds of dolphins washed ashore last spring. Medical waste fouled beaches, warding off vacationers. That Jersey Shore communities have suffered severe economic losses this year is only the most immediate consequence of our disrespect for the ocean.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Many of the double-hung windows in my house need to have the putty replaced around the outside. Since each window has 12 panes, I thought of using a caulking gun to speed the job, but my dealer says that only glazing compound should be used. Someone suggested using silicone caulking. Do you know if this can be used instead of glazing compound around each pane?

title: On Capturing Nature's Gorgeous Fall Glow
description: IN many parts of the country, leaves are falling, underbrush is thinning out and sunlight, when it appears, is giving nature a gorgeous glow. You don't even have to be a photographer to enjoy it.

title: Protecting Your Eyes
description: IT WAS THE TOP OF THE ninth with two outs at a Babe Ruth League regional championship near Albany. The batter hit a line drive, which took a bounce and struck 11-year-old second baseman Justin Metacarpa in his right eye, knocking him to the ground. By the time he arrived at the emergency room of a nearby hospital, the right side of his face had swollen to twice its normal size and his vision was blurred. The doctors thought Justin had a detached retina, and said he might eventually lose the sight in his right eye.

title: 15 Years for Biting Guard
description: A prisoner carrying the AIDS virus received a 15-year prison sentence Friday for biting a guard who later tested negative for the disease. Judge Henry W. Blizzard of state Circuit Court also sentenced the prisoner, Adam Brock, to 10 years for assaulting guards with a padlock. The additional sentences were added to the prisoner's 13-year sentence for robbery. Prosecutors said they will pursue attempted murder charges against any other inmate with the virus for acquired immune deficiency syndrome who bites a guard.

title: Flair for the Grand Gesture: Celebrating a Magazine
description: In every decade there is a review of literature and art that could have come out at no other time, so neatly is it buttoned into the spirit of the age. This was true before 1900 of The Yellow Book in London and of La Revue Blanche in Paris. It was true of the Blue Rider Almanac in Munich in 1911 and of Blast in London in 1914-15. As run by Scofield Thayer in this country in the 1920's, The Dial had just that character.

title: Motherhood Should Be an Olympic Event
description: AS a mother home with a newborn, I have had some time between feedings, mountains of laundry and endless bouts of burping to observe quite a bit of the spectacle call the Olympics.

title: Dukakis Sees Heated 30 Days In Fight With a 'Bankrupt' Foe
description: Michael S. Dukakis begins the final month of his campaign for the White House with an icy anger against Vice President Bush and a trace of wistful longing for the more civil, relatively issue-oriented politics of the primaries.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: MARVIN KITMAN'S ''I Am a VCR'' (Random House, New York, $17.95) is an autobiography ''because somebody,'' the author writes, ''had to write it, and it might as well be me.''

title: U.S. Athletes Weren't Wrong
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Question of the Week; What Did You Think Of the Seoul Olympics?
description: As a 14-year-old viewing my first Olympics, I was very disappointed. Sure, it had some moments but when I think of the Seoul Games, I will think of Ben Johnson's disqualification, the Alexandar Hristov bout, and the boxer Roy Jones being robbed of a gold medal in favor of a local hero. In my opinion, these Olympics were nothing short of a disgrace. TONY YOSELOFF East Brunswick, N.J.

title: Prehung Interior Doors
description: AMATEURS are sometimes discouraged from performing certain remodeling projects because of the prospect of having to replace or install doors.

title: NO GORE, PLEASE - THEY'RE BRITISH
description: The novels of P. D. James and Lawrence Block represent two of the most durable strains of crime writing. Ms. James, whose last book, ''A Taste for Death,'' was a best seller both in her native England and in America, is frequently compared to Agatha Christie for her mastery of the traditional British form known as the ''polite mystery,'' in observance of its gentlemanly police detectives, civilized social settings and ratiocinative plots. The Edgar Award-winning Mr. Block has written more than 30 crime novels, including ''When the Sacred Ginmill Closes,'' the most recent entry in a series that features an alcoholic New York private eye. His realistic style, terse dialogue, action-filled plots and morally pragmatic heroes identify his novels as specimens of the American-made hard-boiled school of detective fiction.

title: Of Quayle, Hipocrysy and Paths of Honor
description: THE questions now being asked about Senator Dan Quayle's successful evasion of the draft arouse vivid memories in me of that turbulent period.

title: Agency Fines Pool Company
description: The Environmental Protection Agency says it has fined a pool supply company more than $100,000 for failing to notify agencies of a chlorine fire that routed 25,000 people from homes and businesses in June.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
General Hooker Lane?
description: LEAD: CECILY TRUETT LANCIT and her husband, Larry, natives of South Carolina, are up in arms over a Northern Civil War general in what is shaping up as the Skirmish of Chappaqua.

title: Westchester Q&A: Madeleine Gutman; Making Arts and Culture Work in Greenburgh
description: WHILE a number of municipalities in the county have developed means of directly supporting community arts programs, few local government-sponsored agencies have been as active for as long as the Town of Greenburgh Arts and Culture Committee.

title: HER MISTAKES WERE BEAUTS
description: MARIE ANTOINETTE By Joan Haslip. Illustrated. 306 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $19.95.

title: Question of the Week; What Did You Think Of the Seoul Olympics?
description: Had I been at the Games, I would have cheered for the equestrians and the fencers. What I saw on TV were glimpses of riders falling off their mounts, and a scrap of fencing presented as musical comedy.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Fairfield, Conn. $171,000 371 Greenfield Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 82-year-old antique farmhouse; updated kitchen and baths, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,035. Glastonbury, Conn. $334,000 91 Olde Wood Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old Colonial antique reproduction; brick terrace, 0.5 acre; taxes $2,997. Westbrook, Conn. $168,500 164 Fawn Hill Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 15-year-old raised ranch; deck, family room with fireplace, 0.33 acre; taxes $1,129. Chappaqua, N.Y. $535,000 2 Bradley Farms 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; fireplace, jalousied porch, pool, 1.7 acres; taxes $6,162. Mohegan Lake, N.Y. $224,000 2901 Sherman Court 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 15-year-old raised ranch; family room, deck, patio, pond; taxes $4,135. Peekskill, N.Y. $214,500 6 Udell Court 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 20-year-old raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, family room, deck; taxes $4,239. OTHER AREAS Maplewood, N.J. $170,000 6 Rynda Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; screened porch, fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $3,358. Pompton Plains, N.J. $137,000 32 Winding Way 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 48-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, full basement, near shopping; taxes $1,959. Plainview $245,000 65 Sylvia Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 35-year-old split level; dining room, den, basement; taxes $4,500.

title: Campaigning, Very Quietly, In New York
description: Somewhere out there, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts and Vice President Bush are fighting for the Presidency of the United States. But with four weeks to go before Election Day, politicians are starting to refer to the Presidential campaign in New York State as the campaign that isn't.

title: Rebounding From Scandal, Ex-Official Will Lead Bonn's 3d Party
description: Otto Lambsdorff, the eloquent and abrasive former Economics Minister who left the Cabinet four years ago in a political-payoff scandal, concluded a triumphant comeback today by winning election as chairman of the Free Democratic Party, the small but influential liberal member of the West German governing coalition.

title: Herbert Nass Engaged To Jodi Ann Grossman
description: Jodi Ann Grossman and Herbert Evan Nass, a son of Edna K. Nass of New York and the late Samuel Nass, plan to marry in April, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Michael L. Grossman of New York have announced.

title: Underground Fire Is Put Out
description: An underground coal fire discovered here last month was extinguished Friday after firefighters poured water and a synthetic foam into holes bored into the earth, Fire Chief Tim Baden said.
