The fire, which threatened an area of about 30 homes in this town of 5,000 people, was discovered Sept. 30 when children playing on a hillside poked sticks into the ground and saw that the sticks were on fire when they pulled them out.

title: Cameras Go Into Court Looking for Drama
description: To the Editor:

title: Owners of Wright Homes Consider a Conservancy
description: LEAD: CONCERNED that the Frank Lloyd Wright legacy may be nibbled away by collectors buying bits and pieces, a consortium of owners and curators of Wright homes is looking at the possibility of establishing a Wright conservancy.

title: Army to Study if Black Heroes Were Denied
description: The Army will review records of black World War I heroes to determine whether any were denied high honors because of their race.

title: PANEL IS CRITICAL OF NUCLEAR AGENCY
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has come under intense Congressional fire over a proposed regulation that would mandate random drug testing for workers in atomic plants but leave safeguards against alcohol abuse to ''the prudent judgment of each utility.''

title: First, We Must Recognize Problems of Children; A Staggering Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: HITTING THE AIR WAVES AND THE BEST SELLERS LIST
description: Once largely the fodder of kitchen table presses and self-publishing, the New Age is being embraced as a money maker by the communications industry.

title: Paying Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: Columbia Wins! That's Right, Wins!
description: The end came for Columbia yesterday. The 44-game losing streak and the five years of no-win situations became history in the wake of a 16-13 triumph over Princeton that spread championship-like joy throughout Lawrence A. Wien Stadium at Baker Field.

title: Corrections
description: The bidding is rendered incorrectly for the displayed hand in the Bridge column on page 77 today. The correct sequence of bidding is: [ diagram ]

title: An Answer To Jails Is Reading
description: TEN years ago, I worked as an education coordinator for the New York State Division for Youth in Mount Vernon and Yonkers. Now I find myself wondering why Westchester hasn't picked up on an obvious alternative to incarceration - the Sentenced to Read Program, which is simply teaching learning-disabled young adults to read. This is already being used in other states as well as in the Bronx.

title: Homicidal Passion As National Pastime
description: This is the week when mystery lovers brew their tea at extra strength in pleasurable anticipation of the 34 hours of recreational murder and mischief promised by PBS for its ninth season of ''Mystery!'' Designed to have those teacups rattling in their saucers is the season opener from Anglia Television, ''Cause Celebre,'' a two-part dramatization of a sensational crime that occurred between the wars in a small resort town, but which scandalized the whole of England at the time. (In the New York metropolitan area it will be seen Thuraday night at 10 on Channel 31 and Saturday night at 9 on Channel 13.) The drama, which was adapted by Ken Taylor from a Terence Rattigan stage play, parts the parlor curtains on the 1935 murder of Francis Rattenbury, a respectable architect from the strait-laced seaside town of Bournemouth who was bludgeoned to death in his home by his chauffeur. This impressionable 18-year-old ''country lad'' had been having an affair with his 60-year-old employer's much younger wife, Alma, an affectionate and romantic creature who was made to stand trial with her lover, although no one, not even the prosecution for the Crown, seriously suspected her of having committed the crime for which she offered a clumsy confession.

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY: IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: TART, WITH A SILKEN FINISH. By Peter Barthelme. (St. Martin's, $13.95.) The wasted Beaumont, head of a one-man advertising agency, a man with a penchant for social drinking, attractive secretarial help and mild self-reflection, stumbles on a document in a client's office. The client is a bank, the bank is in Houston, the document is incriminating - and so the feckless ad man becomes a target.

title: PERSPECTIVES: The J-51 Changes; Abatements Broaden for Co-ops and Condos
description: THE conversion of her rental building in Riverdale to a cooperative five years ago seemed unfair to Beatrice Strom, a retired high-school teacher. ''I objected philosophically because it was imposed,'' she said.

title: No Evidence of Poison Is Found on Candy
description: Federal officials have been unable to confirm a New Jersey prosecutor's report that white powder found on a piece of candy was the poisonous substance strychnine.

title: Despite Rent Rise, ''Trend'' is Dismissed
description: LEAD: HIGHER rents went into effect last weekend for 57,250 apartments in 18 Westchester communities, but housing officials cautioned against interpreting the increases as the beginning of a trend.

title: Big Night Nears for Season Openers
description: THE ides of October are coming, and with them a barrage of season openers. Among the orchestras that will begin their seasons on Saturday are the Greenwich, Ridgefield, Stamford and Waterbury Symphonies.

title: Sisters Give Town $1 Million
description: Two frugal sisters who never took part in municipal affairs and never let on how much money they had saved have surprised the city by leaving it a $1 million trust fund.

title: Chileans Send a Warning to Latin America's Generals
description: THE Chilean people's rejection of Gen. Augusto Pinochet's bid for a further eight years in power last week brought huge sighs of relief as well as cheers of delight from the many Latin American countries that are themselves struggling to consolidate new democracies.

title: Walkout at Electric Boat Ends on Its 100th Day
description: Electric Boat and union negotiators reached a tentative contract agreement today on the 100th day of a walkout by 10,000 submarine-builders.

title: Review/Dance; Love Is Pitted Against Evil in Works by Martha Graham
description: The program presented by the Martha Graham Dance Company on Thursday at City Center did not include any Graham classics, though ''Clytemnestra,'' which certainly qualifies as a major work, was danced in excerpt. What stood out was the vividly personal, strong performing of a number of Miss Graham's dancers.

title: Political Notes; Bid for Senate Lacks Money For Television
description: After only one week of television advertising, Robert R. McMillan, the Republican who is trying to unseat Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, is so short of money that he is off the air except for some limited advertising on cable stations.

title: Behind Geneva's Reclusive Facade
description: GENEVA, the city Voltaire called ''proud, noble, wealthy and sly,'' is difficult to get to know. Behind a seemingly impregnable fortress of luxury hotels and international organizations, the Genevese see little reason to flaunt their accomplishments. Under Calvin, they developed a Protestantism that spread throughout the globe and made Geneva the intellectual center of Protestant Europe. One of the city's more troublesome native sons, Jean Jacques Rousseau, breathed life into a Romantic philosophy and a political creed that remain controversial 200 years later. And the Genevese long ago evolved a rational, prosperous civic life where art and science flourished. But why parade such things? The French statesman Talleyrand is said to have remarked that there were five continents: Europe, Asia, America, Africa - and Geneva. The Genevese are nothing if not self-sufficient.

title: Bizarre Game Turns the Mets' Way
description: It was cold. It was rainy. It was slippery. It was tingling. It was totally bizarre.

title: Performances at Branch of Whitney Museum
description: A performance on Nov. 2 at 7:30 P.M. by Amina Claudine Myers and David Peaston, composers and musicians, will begin a free five-part series of events at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, 120 Park Avenue, at 42d Street.

title: Long Beach Wary Of Theater Plan
description: LEAD: PLANS by a Manhattan-based developer, M.G.B. Equities, to convert the now-vacant Laurel Theater in Long Beach into a United Artists ''fiveplex'' - a building housing five theaters - is generating much controversy among residents of the seaside community.

title:
GARDENING;
Leaves: A Phenonemon and a Resource
description: LEAD: LEAVES are the food manufacturing organs of plants. Most leaves are some shade of green, the green color coming from the chlorophyl in the leaf cells.

title: 42 Sightseers Are Killed In Chinese Plane Crash
description: A plane carrying workers being rewarded for recent good performances crashed into a hotel in Shanxi Province on Friday, killing 42 of the 46 people on board, an official daily said today.

title: NANCY DREW GETS REAL
description: Nancy Drew - the prim teen-age detective with golden curly hair and proper dresses - always got her man. The new Nancy Drew - the modish sleuth with lush blond hair and designer jeans - still gets her man, but now she eyes high school boys as well as criminals. Nancy Drew a flirt? Not exactly, but since the remade Nancy appeared two years ago, she has lost her Victorian moorings; now she asks boys for dates, she displays a jealous streak and she has discovered kissing.

title: On Those Historic Confrontations
description: SHOULD there be a four-game tiebreak match to determine a champion of the Soviet Union for 1988? The two players who tied for first place in the tournament, which ended in Moscow in mid-August, are Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov. These two have already contested -in their four title matches plus tournaments - 130 games.

title: Roadway Expansion: Highway to Debt
description: Your article (Roadway Expansion Awaits Bond Issue, Sept. 25) liberally quotes proponents of this wasteful borrowing scheme, but contains nary a line about the considerable opposition it faces.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I find this city the same as before, the same dead, massacred people on the streets.'' - Judge Pietro Grasso of Palermo, Sicily, on renewal of Mafia violence. [ 1:4. ]

title: Review/Rock; Old and New By Jackson Browne
description: In ''Anything Can Happen,'' the most memorable of several new songs Jackson Browne performed at the Beacon Theater on Wednesday evening, the Los Angeles-based singer and songwriter reflects: Anything can happen in a world so full of fear Dreams are whispered in the dead of night And people disappear.

title: POSTINGS: Tracking the Medians; Houses Get Bigger
description: What went down has come up. The size and lavishness of single- family homes, which shrank considerably between 1978 and 1982, are on the rise, with sizes and prices having set records in 1987.

title: Review/Recital; An Organist From Italy
description: Mario Duella, an organist from Italy, made his United States debut in a brief but varied recital at the Church of St. John the Evangelist on Wednesday evening. He is an alert and colorful player, not one to let an opportunity for a registrational change slip past him.

title: Idle Ordinance On Prostitution
description: IT has been called by its sponsor ''the toughest ordinance in the land'' against prostitution.

title: Estonians Find Little to Like in Russian 'Migrants'
description: In the Estonian university city of Tartu, the authorities were told recently, the medical emergency service sometimes refuses to send an ambulance if the caller asks for help in Russian rather than Estonian.

title: Daniel Polsky Is Wed To Carrie G. Fishman
description: Carrie G. Fishman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Monte Fishman of Bronxville, N.Y., was married last evening to Daniel S. Polsky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Polsky of Floral Park, L.I. Rabbi Richard S. Chapin officiated at the Park Lane Hotel in New York.

title: TALKING: Contracts; Getting Out Of a Deal On a Home
description: ALTHOUGH a contract to buy a home usually lets a buyer withdraw without penalty if there is a recognized difficulty - a structural fault, say, or failure to get financing - occasions do arise when a buyer may need to back out for other reasons.

title: Question of the Week; What Did You Think Of the Seoul Olympics?
description: As athletic performance increasingly translates into greater dollars, avarice becomes a greater motivation factor. The most blatant example surfaced when the reverse effect applied. In the case of Ben Johnson, we saw the potential loss of millions of dollars (because of drugs) to this athlete splashed across the television screen and newspapers and very little mention of its effect on sport.

title: Tritium's Role in Powering a Bomb
description: Tritium, a radioactive form of hydrogen, is a vital and perishable ingredient of nuclear bombs. Unlike plutonium, which lasts for tens of thousands of years, tritium transforms itself into a form of helium at a rate of about 5.5 percent a year. Therefore, it must be replaced periodically. A few grams of tritium inside a bomb help to produce a more efficient chain reaction - the same destructive energy from less fuel. This translates into smaller, lighter warheads. How it is manufactured

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Cleveland; Conglomerate Coming Back
description: AFTER more than a year of talks with city and state officials, Figgie International Inc. has announced it intends to move its headquarters back to this area after six years in Richmond, Va., in exchange for the right to develop 3.5 million square feet of commercial space on 630 acres of city-owned property in the eastern suburbs.

title: A War on the U.S. War on Abortion
description: THE Reagan Administration's strong anti-abortion policy has produced little change in the United States, but it has given rise to an impassioned debate about its effect on the third world.

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: THE coming Presidential election is being touted as important: a contest that will determine whether Reaganism can survive Reagan or whether the Democrats can recapture the White House after losing four of the last five elections. But as crucial elections go, this one doesn't hold a patch on the Presidential contest of 1864.

title: Behind the Rosy Numbers Lurks Decline
description: Current economic news creates the illusion of a healthy economy. The unemployment rate is at a 14-year low. The trade deficit is shrinking. The widely anticipated recession has not materialized, and inflation remains moderate.

title: U.S. ORDERS HALT ON COYOTE POISON
description: The Environmental Protection Agency says it is banning the manufacture of a compound used to kill coyotes, a move expected to anger ranchers and state officials in the West.

title: Syracuse Offense Flattens Rutgers
description: Scott Erney, the Rutgers quarterback, had well-earned credentials. Todd Philcox, his Syracuse counterpart, was a role-player, a senior with promise. But Philcox, aided by a stronger supporting cast, emerged as the hero today in a marvelous quarterbacks' game at the Carrier Dome before a capacity crowd of 48,798.

title: Headliners; Seeing Both Sides
description: Like every other artist, Michelangelo went back to the drawing board on occasion. And so he did with ''Cleopatra,'' the conservators at the Uffizi Museum in Florence have discovered. It had long been known that something was on the other side of the drawing Cleopatra, but nobody could tell what it was because it had been hidden behind a backing that was glued on sometime in the 19th century. Over the summer, conservators removed the backing while preparing the drawing for an exhibition marking the 500th anniversary of the artists' birth. What they discovered was a second, sketchy version of Cleopatra in a markedly different mood - some said she looked horrified - from the one on the other side. In any case, both sides of Cleopatra go on display beginning today at the National Gallery in Washington.

title: Bringing Dormant Assets Back to Life
description: Billions of dollars' worth of dormant assets lay unclaimed or are overlooked around the country, a treasure trove that experts say is growing at the rate of $1 billion a year.

title: Skillful Bidding In a Tournament
description: A group of American bridge players found some surprises when they visited Australia and New Zealand in August and September. Most of the clubs have large premises, owned and managed by members who believe that tea, coffee, wine and sandwiches are an indispensable part of an evening of bridge.

title: Syria and Iran Alerted U.S. to Hostage Release
description: Administration officials said today that both Syria and Iran sent a series of messages before the release of an Indian hostage in Lebanon suggesting that American hostages would be freed.

title:
DANCE;
Ballet Plans Gala Starring Nureyev
description: LEAD: TAKE the name Rudolf Nureyev, link it with the Princeton Ballet in a joint performance next Sunday at the State Theater in New Brunswick, arrange a gala post-performance champagne supper, and, unlike Shakespeare's Juliet, you'll never ask: ''What's in a name?''

title: THE ROMANCE OF A LOAF OF BREAD
description: EVEN THE SOUND OF IT ASTONISHES. A loaf of bread straight from the oven, when it is turned out of the pan and tapped on the bottom with a knuckle, has the ring of life to it. Beneath the hardness of the crust lies the hollowness of a million cells. The ear judges and strains to name what it hears. A click? Too inanimate. A tunk? Too dull. A tock? Not resonant enough. The mind intervenes: the sound is the culinary equivalent of a rap on the back of a violin.

title: LIFE SENTENCE IN HOSTAGE CASE
description: Clutching a Bible and wiping his eyes, James L. Harvey was sentenced Friday to life in prison plus 20 years for taking 110 people hastage at a church school in Tuscaloosa for 12 hours on Feb. 2. Mr. Harvey, 43 years old, had pleaded guilty at the encouragement of his sisters, cuttng short a trial in which he had maintained that, in his actions at the school, he was exercising his right to bear arms and was making a statement for the nation's homeless, poor and illiterate.

title: Question of the Week; What Did You Think Of the Seoul Olympics?
description: Ben Johnson's bout with performance-enhancing drugs made me suspect of the other athletes. For me, as the wife of Cliff Bertrand, a former Olympian in the 200 meters and N.Y.U. track coach, the Olympics have always epitomized love for country, dignity, pride and Spartan proclivities. Of course, Greg Louganis, the spunky Phoebe Mills and many others afforded me the mesmerizing spectacle that has characterized these Games. But in the recesses of my mind, I felt that the Olympics had lost some of its pristine appeal and unadulterated charm, and that our children would not know of the Olympics as we did. PHOEBE BERTRAND Baldwin, L.I.

title: Meredith Birdsall Becomes a Bride
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J., Meredith Kilburn Birdsall, a daughter of Virginia O. Birdsall of Waterford, Conn., and Richard D. Birdsall of New London, Conn., was married yesterday to Kevin Richard Cunningham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Cunningham of Jaffrey Center, N.H.

title: Why a Stronger Gorbachev Might Not Be Strong Enough
description: RUSSIA has always loved the man on horseback. Peter westernized, Lenin revolutionized, Stalin industrialized, each moving the country from one historical stage to the next by sheer, personal and often ruthless power.

title: One-Inning Workout Provides Boost for Cone
description: After all the pratfalls and problems in Shea Stadium yesterday, the Mets not only took the lead in the National League playoff but also restored David Cone to some of the rank he earned this season when he won 20 games and lost only 3.

title: Breaking the Rules To Make a Corner An Urban Event
description: Maybe the best test of a good architect is his or her ability to break the rules and get away with it. The triumphant example of this right now in New York is the skyscraper nearing completion on the northwest corner of 57th Street and Lexington Avenue, known as 135 East 57th Street. In an age when architects, planners and critics alike have been saying that the first law of urban design is Always Hold the Street Line - which means put your building right out at the sidewalk instead of behind one of those dreary concrete plazas - this new tower is set back, far back, from the corner. Moreover, it isn't even set back evenly - it curves, in a concave shape, making its facade look like no other building in New York.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: EYEING THE EAGLE The American bald eagle as fine art, political symbol and collectible is to be celebrated with more than 150 items on exhibition in ''The American Eagle: Spirit and Symbol 1782-1882,'' at the Katonah Gallery today through Dec. 31.

title: Aikman Leads U.C.L.A., 38-21
description: Troy Aikman passed for 288 yards and 4 touchdowns as U.C.L.A. struggled to a 38-21 victory over Oregon State tonight in a Pacific-10 Conference game.

title: Claire Altschuler Weds Cornelius Marx
description: The wedding of Claire Morse Altschuler, a daughter of Mrs. Jerome Zimmerman of Atlanta and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Arthur Altschuler, to Cornelius Harris Marx, the son of Albert Marx of Los Angeles and the late Joan H. Blum, took place last evening at the Plaza in New York.

title: Birth of a Retail Brainchild on North Shore
description: People who lived on the North Shore before World War II nostalgically recall the birth of the Miracle Mile. It originated in the 1940's as a cluster of small shops adjacent to Lord & Taylor's first branch store, situated on the south side of Northern Boulevard just east of Shelter Rock Road.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Furious Itch of Novelty

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: FRIDAY Baseball

title: Margaret Greer, Consultant, Wed To S. B. Carr Jr.
description: At the Washington Episcopal Cathedral, Margaret Weyerhaeuser Greer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Greer Jr. of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Samuel Baldwin Carr Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carr of Milton, Mass. Canon Charles S. Martin performed the ceremony.

title: Friendly Help On Capitol Hill
description: A PORTION of United States aid to Jamaica was reported being blocked in Congress in March because of a property dispute between the Jamaican Government and a friend of Representative Charles Wilson of Texas.

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY: IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: WARLORDS OF CRIME: Chinese Secret Societies - The New Mafia. By Gerald L. Posner. (McGraw-Hill, $18.95.) Gerald Posner has written a terrifying account of the Triads, the Chinese secret societies that now dominate the world heroin trade. He traces their history from the Buddhist monk-led resistance to the Manchu Dynasty, through their involvement in politics as legitimate supporters of Sun Yat-Sen, to the formation of massive criminal organizations so powerful that the Japanese absorbed and accommodated them during the days of occupation.

title: KEEP SILLINESS LEGAL
description: DAVE BARRY'S GREATEST HITS By Dave Barry. 287 pp. New York: Crown Publishers.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: KEYS, wallet, neat little cosmetics bag, handkerchief or tissue, and perhaps a small pen and miniature appointment book. That's it. Is anything else needed in a handbag?

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 9, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 3 THE DARK TOWER: The Gunslinger, by Stephen King. (Plume/NAL, $10.95.) Volume One of a series about a young man's pursuit of an evil force. 2 3 MURDER IN THE CIA, by Margaret Truman. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A C.I.A. operative investigates the suspicious death of a literary agent on her way to Budapest. 3 1 HEAVEN CENT, by Piers Anthony. (Avon, $4.50.) A young prince's search for a missing sorcerer. 4 13 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 5 * 5 THE FIVE BELLS AND BLADEBONE, by Martha Grimes. (Dell, $4.50.) The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: STREETSCAPES: The High Bridge Water Tower; Fire-Damaged Landmark To Get $900,000 Repairs
description: SINCE 1872, the High Bridge Water Tower, on the Manhattan cliffs at 174th Street, has dominated the Harlem River Valley. But the granite landmark has been a civic embarrassment - visible from several major highways - since its peaked roof caved in after a fire in 1984.

title: IT'S ART BUT IS IT PHOTOGRAPHY?
description: IN APRIL 1986, THE STARN TWINS, PHOTOGRAPHY's newest and youngest celebrities, had their first show in New York, at the Stux Gallery in SoHo. Identical twin brothers, Doug and Mike Starn were just 24 years old and completely unknown in New York. They lived, worked and exhibited in Boston, never a city from which to launch a modern or post-modern art career. Then, in the third week of the show, the art critic Gary Indiana published a brief notice about their work in the weekly events section of The Village Voice. It read: ''I hate to regress into review chat, but run, don't walk, don't miss it: it's brilliant.'' Indiana followed up a week later with a lengthy review that called the show ''a meticulously ordered, thorough-going assault on photographic conventions, thematically unified and visually thrilling.''

title: Family Leave for Employees Is Debated
description: LEAD: A BILL that would bring fundamental changes to the workplace by requiring employers to provide unpaid leave and job security for New Jersey workers who want time off for family responsibilities has provoked a debate between business groups and family advocates.

title: HOMEWARD BOUND
description: Growing up on the destitute side of a tiny town in Arizona spoiled me. All the neighbors were Mexican, and they knew a million ways to get the richest flavors from the poorest foods. I learned early on that my mother's cookies could be swapped for pumpkin empanadas, and that her Spam sandwiches were better traded for spicy beef tamales. Happiness back then was a warm buttered tortilla from the back of the wood stove next door. Bliss was a spoonful of refried beans to roll up inside. Mobility, eastward, deprived me of some of the best food of my life. The farther I got from Arizona, the harder it was to get a good Mexican meal. Back before nachos went national, in fact, it was tough finding any edibles with a Mexican accent. Living in Lincoln, Neb., I learned to be grateful for canned chili; in Louisville, Ky., I was elated to find even frozen enchilada dinners.

title: Motivate the Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: On Making Recycling Work in Westchester
description: Back in February, Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke submitted a token comprehensive recycling plan to the state Department of Environmental Conservation in order to meet its requirements so that the county's request to increase the tons burned at the Charles Point incinerator from 657,000 tons to 740,000 tons would be considered.

title: Reactor Shutdown Could Impede Nuclear Deterrent, Officials Say
description: Nuclear reactors at the Savannah River Plant in South Carolina, shut down since August for safety reasons, may be out of service so long that the United States will be unable to maintain all its nuclear weapons in a state of readiness, Administration officials said today.

title: BIGOTS AND BASHERS
description: THE BIG NOWHERE By James Ellroy. 406 pp. New York: The Mysterious Press. $17.95. BLUE BELLE By Andrew Vachss. 340 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: U.S. Plans Electric Power to Drive New Warships
description: The Chief of Naval Operations, Adm. Carlisle A. H. Trost, has directed that all American warships designed in the future be equipped with electrical propulsion systems that will be critical elements in what the Navy is calling a revolution at sea.

title: Body of Adm. Byrd's Son, 68, Found in Empty Warehouse
description: Richard E. Byrd Jr., who lived his life in the shadow of his father, the admiral and Arctic explorer, was found dead last week in the darkness of an abandoned warehouse in Baltimore, his emaciated body clad in dirt-blackened clothes and one scuffed shoe, the police there said yesterday.

title: NOT EVERY AGE HAS ITS PLEASURES
description: THE SWIMMING-POOL LIBRARY By Alan Hollinghurst. 288 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: Michael Karpen Wed To Jeri Sue Bitterman
description: Jeri Sue Bitterman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard M. Bitterman of Parsippany, N.J., and Michael Alan Karpen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray H. Karpen of Passaic, N.J., were married last evening at Congregation Beth Shalom in Lawrence, L.I., by Rabbi Kenneth D. Poplack.

title: Anderson Is Wrong
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Open Space Preservation Benefits Landowners Too
description: THE recent article ''Housing or Space? Dispute Ensues'' was helpful in focusing on issues that have arisen in the effort to preserve ecologically sensitive open space in the southeastern corner of Brookhaven Town.

title: FACING YOUR OWN MORTALITY
description: ANNA ENGQUIST HAD JUST turned 80. Four hundred friends and relatives gathered at a ''This Is Your Life, Anna'' party at Elim Evangelical Lutheran Church in Scandia, Minn., to celebrate her indomitable spirit and dedication to the community. Barely a week after this glorious event Anna learned she had ovarian cancer and would need major surgery. She was told that the surgery would be risky because of various medical problems, including high blood pressure, 80 or so extra pounds and a heart condition. Anny spent the week before the operation getting her affairs in order - lining up caretakers for her pets, checking on her will and bank accounts. She also had prescient conversations with close friends and relatives, telling them in different ways how much they meant to her and how much she had enjoyed her life. The day before she went into the hospital, she left a long note on the kitchen table about bills coming due, repairs needed on the house and where all of her important papers could be found. Anna was prepared to die. Her surgeon wavered between concern over her seemingly fatalistic attitude - he feared she might give up too easily - and admiration for her calmness. As she was being wheeled into surgery, she gave voice to her thoughts: ''I'm in God's hands.''

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Courtyard Of the Louvre Debuts, Again

title: Miss Mintz Weds Lawyer in Boston
description: Naomi Mintz, a senior account executive for Ketchum Public Relations, and Daniel Abraham Lowenthal 3d, an associate in the law firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts, both in New York, were married last evening in Boston. Rabbi Irwin M. Blank, an uncle of the bride, officiated at the Lafayette Hotel.

title: Big Parties, Big Causes
description: Brooklyn Expansion

title: HEY, COACH - GO FOR IT!
description: THE HIDDEN GAME OF FOOTBALL By Bob Carroll, Pete Palmer and John Thorn. 415 pp. New York: Warner Books. $18.95.

title: The Crime Of Losing
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Question of the Week; What Did You Think Of the Seoul Olympics?
description: The tension is over! The Czechoslovakian women's volleyball team was an emotional drain topped only by the Costa Rican archery team. I couldn't take watching the South Koreans in table tennis, either. I've taped it so I can watch it after I've calmed down. Wow! E. K. MILLER Rye, N.Y.

title: Convicts Find Joy in Giving
description: DENNIS STEO says he spent his youth as a ''stickup man.'' Now, Mr. Steo, a convicted murderer who has been imprisoned for 17 years, spends his days soliciting donations and addressing cards to make life more meaningful for New Jersey's elderly and disabled.

title: DATA BANK: October 9, 1988
U.S. Is Urged to Halt Sale of Rifles to Guatemala
description: A group of senators and House members responsible for overseeing foreign aid programs are urging the State Department to halt a $13.8 million sale of American arms to Guatemala, contending that the sale represents a significant and troubling shift in United States policy.

title: Claudia Zinnen Weds
description: The wedding of Claudia Jane Zinnen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert O. Zinnen of Longmeadow, Mass., to Kurt William Roeloffs Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Roeloffs of Patchogue, L.I., took place yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Longmeadow. Deacon David G. Caron performed the ceremony. The bride, a graduate of Smith College, is studying for an M.B.A. degree at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. The bridegroom, a project manager at the Wilmington, Del., office of the Trammell Crow Company, real-estate developers, graduated from Columbia College and received an M.B.A. degree at the Wharton School.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Skills Testing Is Not The Answer
description: LEAD: THE headline talks of more difficult New Jersey high school skills testing. The Legislature wants an 11th- grade academic basic skill level by 1995. My head spins around and around.

title: The Rarest of Them All
description: Autumn hues prevail in jewelry made by Kris Perry from Baiting Hollow, L.I. She gathers fossils and sets them in silver to make pendants, bracelets and other items.

title: PRAGUE WAITS FOR A THAW
description: Mark A. Uhlig's article ''Prague Waits for a Thaw'' (Sept. 4) is unduly pessimistic. It dwells excessively on the ossified leadership and ignores changes from below.

title: Bolivia Dismisses 5 Officers In a Drug Smuggling Scheme
description: The armed forces has dismissed a general and four other officers for allowing cocaine worth $10 million to be smuggled out of Bolivia, the military high command said today. The discharges came one day after officials announced the discovery and destruction of a jungle cocaine laboratory that produced tens of millions of dollars in drugs.

title: THE DISC JOCKEYS
description: ON THE PLAYING FIELDS OF St. John's Seminary in Boston, the sounds of the softball players ''Second base, second base!'' ''Hold up! Hold up!'' are loud and clear. There are other sounds, equally crisp, equally urgent, but a lot quieter: ''Lead, lead,'' ''Up, up, up!'' They are the sounds of Ultimate Frisbee players, with far less breath to waste, running nonstop, diving, ricocheting, tearing up the turf.

title: CHECKS AND BALANCES
description: No sooner had trend-conscious men begun replacing their white dress shirts with a slightly racier model - say a three-quarter-inch awning stripe in a jolting shade of green - than shirt makers felt pressed to come up with something more novel. To hear manufacturers tell it, in dress shirts this season, checks are the new stripes.

title: Larry Kramer's Update on the War at Home
description: ''I don't consider myself a playwright or a novelist but a writer who tries to find the best form to get the message out,'' declared Larry Kramer, who brought the boiling-hot politics of the AIDS crisis to the theatrical mainstream with his 1985 play ''The Normal Heart.'' ''I write out of anger, and of course for anyone who's gay now there's a lot to be angry about.''

title: Plan to Raze Chernobyl Is Criticized by Pravda
description: Pravda reported today that officials are planning to demolish the town of Chernobyl, near the site of the nuclear accident in 1986, but the newspaper criticized the plan and said people should be allowed to gradually return to their homes.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about an agreement by President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire to visit South Africa misstated the history of such visits by black African national leaders. Mr. Mobutu's would not be the first; President Hastings Kamuzu Banda of

title: FORGET ANGST, CRIME IS ENOUGH
description: THE VEILED ONE By Ruth Rendell. 278 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $17.95.

title: A Commitment to Causes
description: ''He was a glorious figure,'' says his biographer, Eric Gordon. ''More than anyone, he defined American words set to American music.'' As the 25th anniversary of Marc Blitzstein's untimely death approaches, renewed interest in the composer appears to be developing. Born in 1905 and killed 59 years later in a barroom fight on Martinique, Blitzstein was an elder contemporary of the American composers Harold Shapero, David Diamond and Leonard Bernstein, fervently committed to serving social and political causes through his music.

title: Jets' Defense Is Up for Review
description: Pass-rushing, run-stopping, and fumble-causing: the New York Jets' defense?

title: Parade Today
description: The United Hispanic-American parade starts at 12:30 P.M. at 44th Street and Fifth Avenue, marches north to 72d Street, then east to Third Avenue. Holiday Tomorrow Columbus Day is observed tomorrow. NEW YORK Parade: Starts at 11:30 A.M. at Fifth Avenue and 44th Street, moving north to 86th Street, then east to Third Avenue. Parking: Alternate-side parking rules suspended. Sanitation: Tomorrow's collections will be made Tuesday. Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail only. Banks: Closed. Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Subways, buses and commuter trains on weekday schedule. Schools: Closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail only. Banks: Closed. Transportation: N.J. Transit on weekday schedule. Schools: Many closed. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on weekday schedule.

title: Apryl Miller Weds
description: Apryl Nanette Miller, a fashion-design major at the Fashion Institute of Technology, and Steven Gary Schulman, an associate in the New York law firm of Milberg Weiss Bershad Specthrie & Lerach, were married yesterday evening at the Carlyle in New York. Rabbi David M. Posner officiated. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Marshall E. Miller of Kent, Wash., and Selma Schulman of Gloversville, N.Y., and the late Jacob Schulman. The previous marriage of the bride, who will retain her name, ended in divorce, as did that of the bridegroom.

title: Blue Cross to Increase Its Rates in New Jersey
description: Individual subscribers of Blue Cross-Blue Shield in New Jersey will soon face a 22.2 percent increase in insurance rates, which state officials hope will reduce the company's growing deficit.

title: MARYLAND GUN BAN IS HOTLY DEBATED
description: The campaign in Maryland over a proposal to repeal a gun law in the November elections has become so heated that each side seems to be spending almost as much energy attacking its opponent's tactics as attacking its position.

title: HOW TO FIND A PSYCHIC OR A RIGHT BRAIN ADVISER
description: Last year, Dave's Down To Earth Rock Shop moved to a new location in Evanston, Ill., nearly tripling in size to 2,000 square feet and adding a mineral museum in the basement. One reason: an explosion in interest in the metaphysical uses of crystal - for healing and for yielding positive energy.

title: Arabs Report 2 Killed In West Bank Protest
description: Parts of the occupied West Bank were paralyzed today by a strike to protest the killing of four Palestinians by Israeli troops. Arab and hospital reports said two more Palestinians died after clashes with soldiers.

title: Constraints on Growth Explored
description: IS New Jersey taking business away from New York? Certainly, said the former Governor of New Jersey, Brendan T. Byrne, who saw the Meadowlands complex and the casinos of Atlantic City rise during his eight-year term.

title: 'Lion in Winter': Mid-Life Crisis
description: LONG ISLAND STAGE has opened its 14th season with ''The Lion in Winter,'' James Goldman's comedy-drama of life among the Plantagenets during the Middle Ages.

title: Vary the Experts
description: To the Editor:

title: Daniel Katz Wed To Miss Marshall
description: Katharine Delano Marshall, a daughter of Patricia T. Marshall of New York and Allerton D. Marshall, also of New York, and Daniel Blake Katz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Katz of Roeland Park, Kan., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed at Bay House, the Orient, L.I., home of Nina H. Frost and her husband, Timothy T. Frost, friends of the couple. Mrs. Frost's father, U.S. District Court Judge Charles S. Haight Jr. of the Southern District Court of New York, officiated.

title: Cynthia J. Kelly Is Bride Of Russell R. Haines 3d
description: Cynthia Jean Kelly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred F. Kelly of Middletown, N.J., and Russell R. Haines 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Haines of Brielle, N.J., were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert E. Bell Jr. performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Red Bank, N.J.

title: Highlights of the Season
description: The opening of a new Jewish museum in Frankfurt, a Henry Moore show at the Royal Academy of Arts in London, a month of photography in Paris and a music festival in the Austrian capital are among the cultural highlights in Europe this fall and winter. The following roundup is based on information from New York Times bureaus in London, Paris, Rome, Bonn and Madrid and on information gathered in New York. Dollar figures are approximate. Telephone numbers are local to the city in which the event takes place unless otherwise indicated; numbers in parentheses are area codes. BRITAIN

title: Wolfe and Tolstoy
description: To the Editor:

title: Workshop on Selling Abroad
description: WHEN it comes to doing business abroad, many small- and medium-size-business owners do not know how to negotiate in a different, sometimes difficult foreign environment.

title: Street Fashion; When Style Knows No Season
description: The coatdress, a big success last summer, has lost none of its momentum with the arrival of the cooler days of fall.

title: Explosions Kill Four At Ammunition Plant
description: Four workers were killed Friday when a fire and explosions destroyed an ammunition manufacturing company.

title: A Dream for Elderly Gone Sour
description: LEAD: BACK in 1974, the Rev. William Coleman dreamed of what he called ''a continuum of care'' for the aged on the North Fork.

title: Season of Liberty
description: The cause of political liberty has suddenly flamed up in the world. From Chile to Burma, people are demanding their rights: a share in their government, freedom of speech, protection against official oppression and brutality.

title: Bass Verite: The Poetics Of Fishing
description: It's not often that one sees a completely new art form develop. There was jazz. And now we have the fishing shows. As has to be expected with anything truly new, the initial reaction has been muted. Nowhere is this truer than among those attuned to the performing arts. Perhaps in Atlanta sophisticated and urbane people discuss plastic worms and crank baits, but in New York all the talk is about Jimmy Levine's pacing of the third act of ''Siegfried'' and what the next British musical will be. And this is at the meetings of Trout Unlimited - God knows what people talk about at the opera.

title: Revolutionary Luxury
description: ONCE AN AMERICAN-OWNED REsort with expansive gardens, a luxurious pool and cabanas, the Hotel Nacional in Havana, from its construction in the 1920's until the late 50's, served a clientele of film stars like Johnny Weissmuller, gangsters like Al Capone and other self-indulgent, wealthy travelers. (The photo at right was taken in 1951.) Currently, its guests are mostly from Eastern Europe. One might say that over the last three decades the hotel has suffered from capitalist neglect. Now in the midst of an ambitious renovation, it is the picture of elegance in waiting.

title: In Pops Uncle
description: SHADOW OF A DOUBT Starring Joseph Cotten and Teresa Wright (in photo). Directed byAlfred Hitchcock. MCA Home Video. 108 minutes. $29.95. Not rated.

title: JERSEY PREPARING PLAN ON HOMELESS
description: New Jersey is preparing a program intended to get all homeless families out of welfare hotels and motels within three years, says Drew Altman, the state's Commissioner of Human Services.

title:
ART;
>'Dissidents' on Exhibition
description: LEAD: THE City of Glen Cove is currently hosting two noteworthy group exhibitions: ''New Discoveries,'' at the Discovery Gallery, 12 and 16 Village Square, and ''The Decorative Dissidents,'' at the Sabbeth Art Gallery of the Wunsch Arts Center, 1 Forest Avenue.

title: THE FIREBRAND GRITS HER TEETH
description: BLOOD SHOT By Sara Paretsky. 328 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $17.95.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Yachting

title: Does Piniella Still Work for Yanks?
description: The announcement was a mere formality, a matter of making official what had been known for weeks. Lou Piniella was gone, the era of Dallas Green had arrived. Another year, another Yankee manager for George Steinbrenner.

title: Campaign Aims at Growth on the Cape
description: In handbills and posters, environmentalists are urging voters to ''just say yes'' to two resolutions on the Nov. 8 ballot to rein in development on Cape Cod.

title: Darien Theater Offers Fresh 'Guys and Dolls'
description: AT the Darien Dinner Theater, there is a spanking new musical fable about a gambler for whom the stakes are never too high (he is called Sky); Sarah Brown, the Salvation Army lass he takes to Havana (on a bet), and another gambler (Nathan Detroit) who has been engaged for 14 years to a nightclub singer (Miss Adelaide), who sneezes a lot.

title: The Next Generation of Poison; An Issue for the No-Issue Campaign
description: America's air is mostly breathable. Its rivers don't catch fire anymore. Raw sewage usually ends up in treatment plants, not the nearest river basin. That much has been accomplished by the environmental laws of the early 1970's. Yet the campaign is only half won because tighter controls have been offset by the extra pollution from economic growth. Worse, society now confronts a new generation of environmental dangers, more insidious, far-reaching and intractable than the old.

title: A Playwright Muses on the Artist's Calling
description: Richard Foreman has always been generous in discussing his work - a body of plays that, over the years since he founded the Ontological-Hysteric Theater in 1968, has moved and perplexed audiences both here and abroad.

title: Sri Lanka Arises as Issue in Indian State Vote
description: India's deepening involvement in the politics and civil strife of Sri Lanka is developing into a major issue in Tamil Nadu state elections scheduled to be held before the end of January, politicians from all parties in southern Indian say.

title: Florida Judge Given Rare Public Reprimand for Indiscretions
description: The Florida Supreme Court, for only the second time in its history, has publicly reprimanded a judge, rebuking him for 14 judicial indiscretions that included waving a gun from the bench.

title: Special Today; Mystery Reading/Book Review, Section 7
description: A special section on mysteries, true crime and thrillers. * Civilized-British vs. hard-boiled-American. * The best and the bloodiest - reference books for the criminally inclined.

title: Penn State Trounces Cincinnati By 35-9
description: Tony Sacca, the first freshman to start at quarterback in Joe Paterno's 23 years as coach, passed for two touchdowns today and Michael Timpson returned a punt 64 yards as Penn State (4-1) trounced Cincinnati, 35-9.

title:
DINING OUT;
Delicious Options on Italian Menu
description: LEAD: FROM the outside, Per Forza! could be Basking Ridge's corner luncheonette. In fact, that's what it once was, before becoming a convivial little Italian restaurant a year ago. Inside, the storefront has been spruced up with Art Deco sconces, architectural details and fresh flowers on the snug, white-clothed tables.

title: TALKS ON NAMIBIA STALL ON TROOPS
description: More than a dozen officials from Angola, Cuba and South Africa met with an American mediator in Manhattan yesterday in a major effort to negotiate a regional peace settlement for southern Africa. But they apparently failed to agree on a timetable for withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola.

title: Winfield V. M. Henry Wed To Elizabeth Fay, Teacher
description: Elizabeth Walsingham Fay, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald L. Fay of Nashville, and Winfield Vans Murray Henry, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clement Sulivane Henry Jr. of New York and Edgartown, Mass., were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. William T. Bryant Jr. and the Rev. Dr. Perry H. Biddle Jr. performed the ceremony in the Stanford Chapel of the First Presbyterian Church in Nashville.

title: A Hungarian Looks Back
description: Janos Kadar is an old Communist. For 32 years, from the time the Soviet army was putting down the Hungarian revolution in 1956 until last May, he was the leader of his party and his country. Since he joined in 1931, at the age of 19, he has seen the system evolve, through Stalinism, war, violent upheaval, and now an effort at far-reaching reform, rejecting much that used to be articles of his faith.

title: A 'House' Divided, Again
description: The outlook in the last month of the election is that the Republicans will retain the Presidency, the Democrats will control both houses of Congress and the country will face four more years of divided Government.

title: Postal Service Bars Texas Concern From Contracts
description: The Postal Service said Friday that it had suspended a Texas concern from bidding on contracts pending the outcome of a case in which the concern and two of its top executives are charged with attempting to rig postal contracts.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: VETERANS' BENEFIT Salute to Vietnam Veterans, a benefit concert Saturday at 7:30 P.M. in the Meadowlands Arena, will bring together seven of the top male singers of the 1960's.

title: POSTINGS: Views With Music; Ft. Lee Condo
description: Yet another high-rise apartment house is coming to the Palisades, this one on the site of the old Palisades Amusement Park, in Fort Lee, N.J., south of the George Washington Bridge.

title: Miss George Wed To Parker Mauck
description: Alexandria Pinkerton George and Parker Gilbert Mauck were married yesterday in Bedford, N.Y., at the home of Ann Pinkerton, the bride's cousin. The Rev. Hugh Magee performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: POP VIEW
description: Keith Richards's first solo album, ''Talk Is Cheap,'' sounds loose, sloppy, thrown-together, unfinished. That's why I like it - it's a relief to hear a musician open the lid on canned music.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Now the Rights Groups Take On Aquino
description: International human-rights groups whose criticism helped fuel opposition to Ferdinand E. Marcos three years ago are now taking to task his successor, President Corazon C. Aquino, for allowing many abuses to continue.

title: A SISTER'S NEED
description: Margaret Moorman's article does those of us with bipolar disorder no favor. Mood disorders are treated very successfully with lithium.

title: Motown Mentality
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan Backs House Drug Bill
description: President Reagan warned Congress today that ''time is fast running out'' and pressed the Senate to approve a House version of anti-drug legislation before it adjourns.

title: In Crestwood, a Harvest of Honey
description: LEAD: NORMAN BANTZ stood in the basement of his home here and held aloft a honeycomb just taken from one of the 30 honeybee hives he keeps in his yard.

title: Ruth H. Bunche, 82, Widow of Statesman
description: Ruth Harris Bunche, a former teacher and the widow of Ralph J. Bunche, the Nobel Peace Prize Laureate and former Under Secretary General at the United Nations, died of pancreatic cancer yesterday at her home in Kew Gardens, Queens. She was 82 years old.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended Sept. 24 MANHATTAN Carnegie Hill $880,000 16 East 96th Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; dining room, 2 fireplaces, Central Park view; maintenance $1,250, 48% tax-deductible (Broker: Corcoran Group) Chelsea $980,000 340 West 22d Street 4-story, 3-family town house; 3 bedrooms, 2 1/2 baths, dining area, south garden in owner's duplex, 3 bedrooms, 3 baths, skylights in second duplex; 1 bedroom, 1 bath in third unit; 1 fireplace in each; full basement, 21-by-98-ft. lot; taxes $8,500 (Broker: Kingman Associates) Greenwich Village $337,500 302 West 12th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 950-sq.-ft. prewar condo; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, large kitchen, Hudson River view; common charge $374, taxes $1,980 (Broker: Ambrose Mar-Elia) Murray Hill $155,000 220 Madison Avenue (37th St.) (John Murray House) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 775-sq.-ft. in 1941 co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining El, windowed kitchen; maintenance $756, 70% tax-deductible (Broker: Penthouse Properties) Upper East Side $120,000 174 East 74th Street 500-sq.-ft. postwar studio co-op; 24-hr. doorman, separate dressing area, remodeled kitchen; maintenance $367, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Arthur P. Wonica)

title: MEMO TO THE NEXT PRESIDENT
description: LEAD: NO PRESIDENTIAL candidate in recent memory has been elected by discussing harsh economic realities and making voters uncomfortable. That being the case, contenders for the White House are careful to stick to broad statements of intentions and ideological posturing. Sometimes the ideological differences are profound enough to grab the voters' attention, but more often there is a blurring of distinctions as the two candidates try to capture the middle ground -holding out the promise of vigorous economic growth, jobs, low inflation, moderate interest rates.

title: AN AWARD HONORS TECHNICAL PROWESS
description: The nearest thing to an Oscar or an Emmy in home electronics is the Grand Prix awarded each year to outstanding models by Audio-Video International, a leading trade journal. In the past, these prizes were restricted to sound equipment. This year, for the first time, video has been included, and the winners have just been announced.

title: Sports of The Times; Mike Boddicker And His Fosh Ball
description: When Wade Boggs arrived here with the Red Sox for the third game of the American League Championship Series, he was asked if he was suffering jet lag. ''Not jet lag,'' he said, ''bat lag.'' After all, the major leagues' leading hitter was batting just .143, as the A's had gone ahead by 2-0 in the four-of-seven-game series.

title: Making a Living in Traveling in Style
description: THE family car, the rented compact, the tour bus - those common means of trip-taking are not the means that Larry and Mary Kellough recommend. The Kelloughs encourage traveling in style, driving with dignity, in a classic Rolls-Royce or Bentley.

title: A Race That Offers Some Clear Choices
description: WHEN voters in Connecticut's Second District make their choices for United States Representative on Nov. 8, they will not be able to say the race was too short to get to know the candidates.

title: High Costs Cited for AIDS 'Boarder Babies'
description: Children infected with the AIDS virus are running up hospital bills of more than $90,000 each, often because they have nowhere else to go, new studies in New York and Connecticut indicate.

title: First, We Must Recognize Problems of Children; Punish the Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: Notebook; Stieb's 1-Hitters Rare Indeed
description: Dave Stieb's pair of one-hitters in his last two starts of the season represented one of the more intriguing feats of the year. They also helped mark an appropriate end to a season that belonged to the pitchers.

title:
LONG ISLAND INTERVIEW: JOHN HOHENBERG;
Charting the Changes in American Journalism
description: LEAD: PROF. JOHN HOHENBERG of Long Island and Tennessee has been teaching journalism to college students for 40 years. His teaching career at the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism and, among other places, at the University of Tennessee as recently as last year, followed 25 years as a newspaper reporter on the West Coast and in New York,

title: GIJON CAPER: PICKING THE WORLD'S BEST MYSTERY
description: ''Writers are the least qualified to judge literary prizes,'' the French novelist Didier Daeninck told me last June, as we sampled stuffed olives and calamares aboard Al Andaluz, the opulent Victorian flagship of the Spanish rail line. ''They are too jealous.''

title: A SISTER'S NEED
description: Margaret Moorman's poignant description of the devastation wreaked upon patients and their families by severe depressive disorders is compelling.

title: Excerpts From the Interview With Dukakis
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Michael S. Dukakis, conducted by The New York Times Friday evening in Asheville, N.C.:

title: Rabbi in U.N. Delegation Seeks 'Human Dignity'
description: When President Reagan addressed the opening of the United Nations General Assembly on Sept. 26, one of the seats of the United States delegation was empty. It belonged to a new member of the delegation, its only rabbi, who was unable to attend because the President's address coincided with the first day of the Jewish harvest festival of Succoth.

title:
CRIME/MYSTERY: IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: CORNELL WOOLRICH: First You Dream, Then You Die. By Francis M. Nevins Jr. (Mysterious Press, $19.95.) Inside this fat, 613-page biography of the suspense writer Cornell Woolrich (a k a William Irish, a k a George Hopley) is an anorexic book struggling to get out. Written in breathless, fanzine style, ''Cornell Woolrich'' is stuffed with plot summaries of what seems to be every pulp magazine story and novel Woolrich ever wrote, as well as the many radio, television and movie adaptations of his work (which include Hitchcock's ''Rear Window'' and Truffaut's ''Mississippi Mermaid'').

title: WHEN TO CHALLENGE THE THERAPIST -- AND WHY
description: FR ANYONE UNDERGOING PSYCHOTHERAPY, the question is inevitable. Is it working? When symptoms linger, or problems that seemed gone reappear, or doubts arise about the therapist, it's natural to wonder. Is it time to switch therapists? Or is the treatment, in fact, working to the extent it can? And is the pain that persists essentially what everyone must suffer from time to time?

title: A.N.C. Leaders Meet Indians
description: Leaders of the African National Congress are meeting with representatives of South Africa's large Indian minority to discuss ways of ending apartheid, organizers said today. Spokesmen for the Natal Indian Congress and the Transvaal Indian Congress, the two main groups meeting here, said the talks would explore the Indian minority's role in apartheid. The A.N.C., based in Zambia, is trying to hold talks with a range of South African groups.

title: Judith Place Has a Bridal
description: The wedding of Judith Gauntlett Place, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Bassett Moore Place of San Francisco and Portola Valley, Calif., to Harold Dean McMillan Jr., a son of Rachel Mitzmacher of Woodside, Queens, and Mr. McMillan of Astoria, Ill., took place yesterday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Lithgow, N.Y. The Revs. Brewster Beach and Richardson W. Schell performed the ceremony.

title: LIABILITY LITIGATOR: Michael Ciresi; WINNING WITH HARD WORK AND HISTRIONICS
description: It was a classic performance by Michael Ciresi. Armed with stacks of previously undisclosed company documents, a sharp instinct for the holes in his opponent's case, and an even sharper tongue for opposing witnesses, the 42-year-old attorney persuaded a St. Paul jury last month that G. D. Searle & Company had intentionally misled his client about the safety of its Copper-7 intrauterine birth control device.

title: Ann Leary, a Nurse, Weds John J. Finnegan, Engineer
description: At St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church in Mount Kisco, N.Y., Ann C. Leary, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund J. Leary of Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday to John J. Finnegan, a son of Theresa Finnegan of Brooklyn and the late Michael Finnegan. Msgr. Robert O'Connell officiated, assisted by the Rev. Robert Romano and the Rev. Patrick Guilfoyle, a cousin of the bride.

title: Billy Daniels, Who Sang in Nightclubs, Dies at 73
description: Billy Daniels, the veteran nightclub performer, actor and big-band singer who rose to fame with his recording of ''That Old Black Magic,'' died of stomach cancer Friday at the Kenneth Norris Jr. Cancer Hospital and Research Institute at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles. He was 73 years old and lived in Hollywood Hills, Calif.

title: Mark Herr Wed To Miss Putman
description: At the Nassau Presbyterian Church in Princeton, N.J., Rachel Clinton Putman was married yesterday to Mark Sherwood Herr. The Rev. Cynthia R. Jarvis performed the ceremony.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Builders Look to Energy-Saving Features
description: LEAD: DEVELOPERS eager to spur sales in a slow market are working hand in hand with a major utility these days to implement energy-conservation programs.

title: 2d Man Arrested In Priest Killing
description: A second man was charged yesterday in the slaying of an Albanian priest three days after the police released another suspect because the Bronx District Attorney said there was not enough evidence to prosecute him.

title: ALBERT UPLIFTS ANYTHING
description: LEAD: THE FLOATPLANE NOTEBOOKS By Clyde Edgerton. 265 pp. North Carolina: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. $16.95.

title:
OUTDOORS;
Appalachian Trail a Resource
description: LEAD: THE idea for the Appalachian Trail was suggested by Benton MacKaye, a forester from Massachusetts. A confirmed wanderer in the wilds, he visualized a foot path through the wilderness, a quiet sanctuary for people from our vast urban areas. The plan was proposed in an article ''The Appalachian Trail: An Experiment in Regional Planning'' in The Journal of the American Institute of

title: Miss Clendenin, Richard Kolosky Exchange Vows
description: Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Chapel in Queens Village, Queens, was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Christine Ann Clendenin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael C. Clendenin of New York, to Richard John Kolosky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald R. Kolosky of Peekskill, N.Y. The Rev. Peter V. Kain peformed the ceremony.

title: War Ace Still Bears Witness To History
description: LEAD: WHAT amazes A. Raymond Brooks the most about aviation history is that he has been alive to witness it.

title: A Jewel in a Tarnished Showcase
description: CHEZ NOELLE is a great Gaullic gustatory outpost in a modest, mundane section of Port Washington better known for auto-body shops and lumberyards. A trip to this unlikely neighborhood reveals one of Long Island's finest restaurants.

title: Shelagh M. McCann Weds David Saunders in Texas
description: Shelagh Marian McCann, the daughter of Annes McCann-Baker of Austin, Tex., and C. Howard McCann of Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, was married in Austin last evening to David Charles Saunders, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Saunders of Manhasset, L.I. The Rev. Armistead Powell performed the ceremony at All Saints Episcopal Church.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Many of the double-hung windows in my house need to have the putty replaced around the outside. Since each window has 12 panes, I thought of using a caulking gun to speed the job, but my dealer says that only glazing compound should be used. Someone suggested using silicone caulking. Do you know if this can be used instead of glazing compound around each pane?

title: DATA UPDATE: October 9 1988
DODGERS TRY TO PICK UP THE PIECES
description: Had the events of the past five days been just slightly different, the inhabitants of the visiting clubhouse at Shea Stadium yesterday could have been one game from a pennant with a 3-0 lead in the National League Championship Series.

title: Students, Urging Change, Mock Polish Party
description: Friday was Policeman's Day in Poland, a day when the Interior Minister congratulates the forces and when the Polish leader thanks representatives of the party's finest, in sparkling uniforms, for their service in protecting Communism.

title: Two Nations Transformed In Aftermath Of Gulf War
description: IN the new political atmosphere being shaped by the cease-fire in the Iran-Iraq war, issues that appeared irrelevant only weeks ago have suddenly become urgent policy matters for Teheran and Baghdad. Both countries are grappling with the need to reorient their economies, demobilize huge armies, forge new relationships with other countries and define new roles for themselves in the region.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Politics; Hostage Situation Has Both Campaigns Uneasy
description: When word reached the capital last week that an American hostage was about to be released in Lebanon, the White House was gripped by both excitement and apprehension.

title: Residents Cheer After Guard Is Slain At Housing Project
description: Residents of a crime-ridden public housing project cheered when the body of a security guard was carried to an ambulance after he died in a hail of bullets.

title: 300 Protest as North Speaks in California
description: About 300 people turned out to jeer Oliver L. North, the former National Security Council aide, while he urged more than 1,000 Christian business leaders to fight the ''alien and godless philosophy'' of Communism.

title: Canada Jobless Rate Off
description: Canada's unemployment rate dropped to 7.8 percent in September from 8 percent a month earlier, the Government agency Statistics Canada said Friday. The report can be helpful to the Conservative Government in the Nov. 21 election. The total number of unemployed in the labor force dropped by 21,000, to 1,048,000, during the month.

title: TUNE IN TO GET UP FOR THE SLOPES
description: With a nip of fall in the air, skiers are beginning to get edgy about tuning up for the winter. These days, when videotapes are being created on practically every subject, it comes as no surprise that both tuning the body and tuning the skis can be learned from a television screen. There is some advantage to having the expert right there in the living room, but more important, watching a video is an easy and relaxing way to learn, especially when skiing sequences are interspersed between the how-to information. What follows is a cursory look at what some of these tapes offer. Official Workout And Training Program

title: Indiana Democrats Count on a Bayh
description: In this conservative, Republican-dominated state, the Democrats are banging on the door of the Indiana governor's mansion after 20 years of being kept out.

title: Spotlight at Apple Shifts to a Rising Star
description: Apple Computer Inc. said on Friday that Delbert W. Yocam, president of its education and Pacific divisions, had said he will resign from his operational duties in November 1989.

title: Tourism Has Indeed Returned to Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Matters; A Clear Pledge: Instilling Values In First Grade
description: On weekday mornings across the country, the most saluted man in America, William Safire once wrote, is Richard Stans. But Friday morning Marilyn Meyer's 17 first graders at P.S. 142 placed their hands over their hearts and clearly enunciated their Pledge of Allegiance to the flag and to the republic, not for Richard Stans, but ''for which it stands.'' They even pronounced ''indivisible'' correctly.

title: Boston Loses Playoff; Candidates Set a Date
description: The American League playoff ended yesterday, with Oakland's victory over Boston, and officials from both Presidential campaigns said the early completion of the series cleared the way for a Thursday debate between Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis.

title: To Forgive, Divine
description: ''Everybody is entitled to make a mistake,'' said Senator Howard Metzenbaum, referring to an excess of zeal on the part of one of his staffers. What a refreshing statement; in this election year, what a humane idea.

title: Chilean Burden: A Legacy of Terror
description: As Chile moves toward its expected democratic transition in the coming months, a major hurdle will be how to deal with the thousands of deaths, disappearances and reports of torture linked to the regime of Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

title: Review/Television; Debate About U.S.'s Nuclear Arsenal
description: As the Presidential candidates argue over which nuclear weapons to keep and which to cut, the complexities of nuclear policy tend to be simplified for point-scoring purposes. So tonight's showing of ''To What End?'' comes as a timely analysis of the choices that will face the next President. The illuminating documentary can be seen on Channel 13 at 10 P.M.

title: Japanese Lift Purchases of U.S. Property
description: Confounding almost the entire investment community, the Japanese have continued to pour billions of dollars into United States real estate in 1988, a new study reported today.

title: Deng's Daughter Peruses the Art of Manhattan
description: On her first trip to SoHo the other day, Deng Lin, a Chinese artist who is accomplished in the brush-and-ink tradition that has flourished in her country for more than a thousand years, circled warily around a huge and complex Frank Stella wall piece at the Leo Castelli Gallery on Greene Street. She paused meditatively in front of a simpler floor piece by Ellsworth Kelly, composed of two flat semicircular planes. And she looked with a certain fascination at a pair of massive steel plates by Richard Serra, standing upright in precarious tension.

title: Late Games
description: The fourth game of the National League playoff between the Mets and the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Islanders-Los Angeles Kings hockey game began too late to be included in this edition.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct.10, 1988: MONDAY La-Z-Boy Chair Co PS Group Phillips Petroleum Xerox Corp TUESDAY CBI Industries Chesapeake Corp Diversified Energies ITT Corp Procter & Gamble Reliance Group Hldgs SL Industries TECO Energy Inc Weyerhaeuser Co WEDNESDAY AAR Corp Bard (C.R.) Hillenbrand Indus Pacificorp Super Valu Stores Tokheim Corp Walgreen Co Woolworth (F.W.) Co THURSDAY Colgate-PalmoliveKeycorp Ford MotorNECO Enterprises Hartmarx CorpWisconsin Public Serv Keycorp NECO Enterprises Wisconsin Public Serv FRIDAY Dreyfus Corp Federal SignalPPG Indus NY State El & Gas

title: Washington Bank Head Faces Board Challenge
description: A highly visible board fight is shaping up in Washington involving Luther H. Hodges Jr., the chairman and chief executive of the Washington Bancorporation, as three directors challenge his leadership.

title: Swiss Gain Big Stake on Wall St. In Deal That Could Offer a Model
description: After more than six months of intense negotiations, the First Boston Corporation, one of Wall Street's largest securities firms, and its London-based sister company, Financiere Credit Suisse-First Boston, agreed yesterday to merge.

title: Dodgers Pitcher Suspended for 3 Days
description: In a decision that could have a major impact on the National League championship playoff, the president of the league yesterday imposed a three-day suspension on Jay Howell of the Los Angeles Dodgers for having pine tar on his glove in Saturday's game against the Mets.

title: Construction Delays Due at Holland Tunnel
description: People who drive through the Holland Tunnel to jobs in New York City can expect a longer morning trip starting tomorrow, when one lane of eastbound traffic approaching the entrance will be closed so a tollbooth rehabilitation project can begin.

title: Rich and Famous Adding Kings Games to Life Style
description: Outside Chasen's, where imposing men work to keep the great unwashed outside the entrance to the restaurant, the sign attached to the awning, beneath silver and black balloons, says ''Private Party.'' There are those who would suggest that the Los Angeles Kings have been holding private parties for more than two decades as one of the least accepted franchises in the National Hockey League, but now, suddenly, people are actually trying to talk their way in.

title: When Fishing Is an Indoor Sport
description: As the fishing season winds down, the armchair angler tends to gear up. Books and videos on fishing offer a winter's worth of immersion in the sport. But it takes a fishing trip south, or a parlor game, to take the pastime out of solitary confinement.

title: Next Inc. Produces a Gala (And Also a New Computer)
description: At last, it's here, the event the computer world has been waiting for.

title: Chilean Victors Calm Economic Fears
description: As soon as it was apparent that Gen. Augusto Pinochet had been refused eight more years in power in a plebiscite last Wednesday, Chilean opposition groups quickly reassured businessmen that many of his economic policies would be maintained once democracy returns here.

title: No More F.B.I. 'Taco Circuit'
description: If there was an auspicious aspect to a Federal judge's finding that the F.B.I. had discriminated against Hispanic agents, it was the response from the F.B.I. Director, William B. Sessions: ''During my tenure as Director, approximately one-half of the agents currently in the F.B.I. will be eligible to retire. This enhances opportunities for minorities and women desiring to become special agents.'' That means a chance to change the culture of this agency, which has made progress in ending old policies of minority exclusion, but still hasn't mastered the art of inclusion.

title: Sports World Specials; No Place Like Home
description: For more than 25 years, Lehigh football coaches from Bill Leckonby to Hank Small, the incumbent, took prospective recruits over South Mountain to a landscaped bowl surrounded by corn fields. They pointed and said, ''That's where our new stadium will be.''

title: Topics of The Times; Books Before Uniforms
description: Mayor Edward Koch has persuaded a local clothing manufacturer to donate 400 uniforms for New York City schoolchildren, ''with the thought that it might help in the learning process to have that kind of discipline.''

title: MGM/UA Names 3 Merrill Lynch Bankers to Top Posts
description: The MGM/UA Communications Company said yesterday that it would name three investment bankers from Merrill Lynch Capital Markets to top positions at the motion picture and television studio.

title: Many Black Monday Cases Unheard
description: A recent survey of investor sentiment about the nation's stock and options markets has found that a year after the market crash, small investors who lost money or had complaints continue to be frustrated by the market.

title: Fugitive Planner Arrested
description: A financial planner who disappeared with $25 million and left notes of apology for his former clients was arrested as a fugitive Saturday in Japan after being expelled from Taiwan, Federal Bureau of Investigation agents said.

title: Miriam Mahdaviani Wed
description: Miriam Eva Mahdaviani, a dancer with the New York City Ballet and a choreographer, was married yesterday to Eric Jay Goldstone, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sheldon B. Goldstone of Scranton, Pa., and Naples, Fla. Rabbi Simon H. Shoop and Cantor Joseph Handlin performed the ceremony at Federal Hall in New York. The bride, who attended Barnard College, is a daughter of Roberta Balsam Mahdaviani of Forest Hills, Queens. The bridegroom is a portfolio manager at A. C. Israel Enterprises in White Plains.

title: Billy Daniels, Who Rose to Fame On 'Old Black Magic,' Dies at 73
description: Billy Daniels, the veteran nightclub performer, actor and big-band singer who rose to fame with his recording of ''That Old Black Magic,'' died of stomach cancer Friday at the Kenneth Norris Jr. Cancer Hospital and Research Institute at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles. He was 73 years old and lived in Hollywood Hills, Calif.

title: Wilson Foods 'Poison Pill'
description: A Delaware Chancery Court has denied an effort by the Doskocil Companies to invalidate a ''poison pill'' takeover defense of the Wilson Foods Corporation.

title: Topics of The Times; A Sanctuary for Mustangs
description: About 150 wild mustangs received a wonderful gift last week: free run of an 8,300-acre, privately owned preserve in the Black Hills of South Dakota. The horses - roughly one-third of 1 per cent of the wild mustangs roaming Western lands - were too old for adoption under a Government resettlement program. They faced a mean, confined life in pens in Nebraska or the possibility of being illicitly slaughtered for dog food.

title: For Decency in the Fields
description: What farm workers first asked of the Federal Government in 1972 seemed modest enough: drinking water and toilet facilities in the workplace. But 15 years later, these minimum standards are not yet assured, even after a Federal appeals court ruling that the Labor Department had improperly failed to protect field hands from communicable diseases and heat stress.

title: Control Defeats the Conga Line in Sky
description: It began so innocently aboard Governor Dukakis's campaign charter.

title: Anne Geary, Lawyer, Weds Charles Joseph
description: Anne Morris Geary and Charles Stephen Joseph, both lawyers in New York, were married yesterday at the lighthouse on the Haig Point Plantation, Daufuskie Island, S.C. The Rev. John M. van Dyke, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony, assisted by Dr. Alvin Lieberman, an uncle of the bridegroom.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Improved Relationship
description: Six years ago, American Jewish groups raised a ''Where was George?'' question, not about Vice President Bush, but about George P. Shultz, who was President Reagan's choice to become Secretary of State succeeding Alexander M. Haig Jr. Their answer, voiced with some disquiet, was that Mr. Shultz had been president of the huge Bechtel Corporation, which was doing billions of dollars worth of construction in Saudi Arabia and hence perceived as hostile to Israel.

title: Worker Protection Endorsed
description: Legislation to provide better protection for Government employees who report waste or fraud in their agencies won Senate approval on Saturday and was sent to President Reagan.

title: Polish Bid to Broaden Regime Falters
description: The new Polish Prime Minister's effort to attract people into the Government from outside the Communist realm is faltering, undermined by the prospect of discussions here this month between the Government and the opposition.

title: Amid Cheers, Aiming to Close In on a Dream
description: The Athletics looked ahead to the World Series next week.

title: Man Stabbed at Stony Brook College Party
description: A 20-year-old man was slightly wounded when he was slashed during a dispute in front of a fraternity house on the campus of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, L.I., yesterday, the police said.

title: The Hairy-Chested Democrats Club
description: LEAD: We might have known.
