Just as the most conservative American President in half a century, negotiating with the most flexible Soviet General Secretary in history, has begun to build a political consensus for large reductions in nuclear arms, along come members of the Hairy-Chested Democrats Club to reassert their ''expertise'' and ''toughness'' by undermining the nascent consensus.

title: A's Sweep Red Sox and Win Pennant
description: The post-game celebration was brief. The Oakland Athletics gathered together on the infield grass late today, hugged and smiled and waved joyously, and then retreated to the security of their clubhouse, where they popped corks and sprayed one another obligingly with champagne. They were done, but they were not done. ''We're two-thirds of the way there,'' Don Baylor said after the shouting and the toasting had finally died down. ''The champagne gets a little sweeter tasting at each level. We're in the middle of that right now.''

title: Frank W. Emig, A.F.L.-C.I.O Official, 62
description: Frank W. Emig, director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s department of community services since 1985, died Saturday of cancer. He was 62 years old. As director of community services for the federation, Mr. Emig headed representatives in 188 cities in 37 states responsible for coordinating blood drives, food banks and other charities, according to Rex Hardesty, a federation spokesman.

title: Base Closings: Everyone Wins
description: Four years ago, the Grace Commission on government waste pointed out that the Pentagon was still operating a 121-year-old base that had been scheduled for closing in 1964, in 1970, in 1978 and again in 1979. Now the days of obsolete bases appear to be truly numbered, thanks to a pending bill that represents a triumph of national interest over parochial obstructionism.

title: Market Place; Election Forecast For Investors
description: A MONTH before the Presidential election, the markets and investors are pondering the impact of the outcome. There are all kinds of guides, from past performances to policies of the contenders. But that does not mean they have the answer.

title: Dean Burk, 84, Chemist for Cancer Institute
description: Dean Burk, a retired chief chemist at the National Cancer Institute, died of cancer Thursday at the home of his daughter in Washington. He was 84.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Tracy-Locke Deal
description: Tracy-Locke, Dallas, the subsidiary of Omnicom Group that is celebrating its 75th anniversary this year, has agreed in principle to buy Stern/ Monroe, a $25 million Dallas-based shop, for an undisclosed amount. Lawrence N. Sterne, principal of the Stern/Monroe agency, will become chairman/corporate development when the agency consolidation is done.

title: Leslie E. Halprin Marries Joseph Heyison, a Lawyer
description: Leslie Eileen Halprin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Halprin of New Haven, was married last evening at Congregation B'nai Jacob in Woodbridge, Conn., to Joseph Avery Heyison, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack R. Heyison of Oil City, Pa. Rabbi Michael Menitoff and Cantor Joseph Konigsberg officiated.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Guide of the Long Island Weekly yesterday gave an incorrect telephone number for the Oyster Festival next Saturday and Sunday in Oyster Bay. The correct number for information is (516)-624-8082.

title: Sharon Polansky Weds J. I. Herbst
description: Sharon Honey Polansky, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Polansky of Plainview, L.I., and Jeffrey Ira Herbst, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Herbst of Peekskill, N.Y., were married yesterday morning at the Mountain Lakes House in Princeton, N.J., by Rabbi Lauren Levy.

title: Tax Watch; 4th-Quarter Plans To Reduce Taxes
description: IN the final quarter of the year, the thoughts of many investors turn to taxes and how to avoid them. While the Tax Reform Act of 1986 did its best to dash hopes of avoidance, there are still techniques available to soften the tax bite.

title: Convict's Victim Makes an Ad
description: Clifford Barnes is making a radio commercial - to the delight of George Bush and the concern of Michael Dukakis.

title: Books of The Times; Kazin Views What the Writer's Eye Has Seen
description: A Writer's America Landscape in Literature By Alfred Kazin Illustrated. 240 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: 3 More Palestinians Die In Occupied Territories
description: Israeli soldiers swept through at least 30 villages in the West Bank today, and two Palestinians were killed in clashes with troops during a general strike, an Israeli Army spokesman said.

title: Today, 52d Ain't Got That Swing
description: When they talked about the Duke yesterday on 52d Street, they were evoking not a Presidential candidate, but a jazz great.

title: Sir Egerton Richardson, Jamaican Diplomat, 76
description: Sir Egerton Richardson, Jamaica's first representative to the United Nations and its former Ambassador to Washington, died at his home on Saturday night, the authorities said today. He was 76 years old. The cause of Sir Egerton's death was not known, but he had reportedly been ailing for more than a year.

title: Review/Art; The Drawings of Michelangelo: The First Flowerings of Genius
description: No one can be sure just what disappeared when Michelangelo set ablaze perhaps hundreds of his own drawings not long before his death. As an old man deeply concerned with his place in history, the artist apparently determined that posterity should not possess the false starts and reconsiderations these preparatory drawings represented. He wished for the completed paintings, sculptures and architectural designs to appear effortlessly conceived.

title: A Pianistic Paradox
description: It took only a few bars of ''Hommage a Rameau'' to hear that Steven Silverman is a pianist of taste and sensitivity. Listening to him play at Weill Recital Hall late Saturday afternoon, one admired the natural purity of Debussy's precise rhythmic writing and the warm chordal textures with their careful separation of colors.

title: Donna Etkins Marries Micah Kroloff, Lawyer
description: At the Beacon (N.Y.) Hebrew Alliance yesterday, Donna S. Etkins, the daughter of Lillian Etkins of Beacon and the late Abraham Etkins, was married to Micah N. Kroloff, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Charles A. Kroloff of Westfield, N.J. The bridegroom's father officiated, assisted by Cantor Martha T. Novick.

title: ON YOUR OWN: Fitness; High Cholesterol Found in Children
description: Asobering statistic is emerging from a program in Michigan to increase physical fitness among children. A University of Michigan group is finding that one-fourth of the school children it tests have elevated cholesterol levels.

title: U.S. CRIME LEVELS SHOW RISE IN 1987
description: The nation's crime levels rose 1.8 percent last year, the Government reported today, ending a five-year decline that the Reagan Administration had attributed partly to vigorous law enforcement and tougher treatment of criminals.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Wednesday misidentified the first international advertising agency to become a minority owner of a South Korean agency. Backer Spielvogel Bates paid $40 million in April for a minority share of Diamond Advertising of Seoul.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Omnicom to Issue Debt
description: Morgan Stanley & Co. will raise $75 million in convertible subordinated debentures for Omnicom Group Inc. Proceeds of the offering will be used to reduce Omnicom's borrowings under its commercial paper program and short-term domestic bank line of credit, and the remainder, if any, will be used for general purposes, including acquisitions.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis

title: Pentagon Needs Separate Procurement Board
description: To the Editor:

title: Horse Racing; 2 Grass Horses Are on Rise
description: New leaders of the nation's grass horses and sprinters may have been crowned yesterday at Belmont Park when Sunshine Forever scored an easy victory in the $600,000 Turf Classic and Mining whipped Gulch in the $223,200 Vosburgh Stakes.

title: Rates May Ease in the Near Term
description: The bond market's mood has brightened considerably over the past few months, as more and more signs of a moderation in economic growth and inflation have appeared.

title: Initial 'Cosby' Reruns Didn't Meet Projections
description: Despite a high-powered publicity campaign, reruns of ''The Cosby Show'' - the most expensive repeats ever telecast - fell short of expectations in their first week.

title: Fatal Shootings of Young People on the Rise in Florida
description: Hunched over slightly, Aaron Miller steadies his .22-caliber pistol and fires, blowing pea-size holes in a target's black bull's-eye. The 10-year-old is probably as good a shot as any at a popular suburban shooting range.

title: Chicago Blacks Split on Mayoral Candidates
description: Delegates to a meeting intended to unite Chicago's black community behind one mayoral candidate have cast most of their votes for two contenders.

title: On the Road Again, With a Passion
description: After nearly a decade of fuel shortage fears, Government regulation and functional but generally unexciting new cars, Americans' passion for the automobile, high speed and the open road is being rekindled this fall with a fervor that excites drivers, delights car makers and frightens safety experts.

title: Stock Fraud In 10 Nations
description: Investigators from the United States and nine other nations will meet in Washington on Monday to coordinate inquiries into an extensive international stock swindle, Swiss judicial sources said Friday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Ralph Frank Jr. has joined Mendelsohn/Zien Advertising, Los Angeles in the newly created post of vice chairman.

title: The Race for Congress; Liewberman Fights Uphill For Senate
description: Most mornings, shortly after sunrise, Joe Lieberman, Democratic candidate for Senate, runs three or four miles through the suburban Westville section of town, where he has lived for the past 20 years. Sometimes, his wife, Hadassah, joins him. Sometimes, as the couple jogs along the quiet tree-lined streets, they push a baby carriage carrying their 6-month-old daughter, Hana.

title: Under Little-Noticed New Provision, U.S. Must Find Options to Atom Tests
description: The Federal agency that designs and makes nuclear arms must try to develop ways to insure the reliability of the weapons without explosive testing, according to a provision in the annual military budget measure that President Reagan recently signed into law.

title: Stuart M. Cobert and Marcy Engel, Lawyers, Wed
description: Marcy Engel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Engel of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stuart Martin Cobert, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Cobert of Upper Montclair, N.J. Rabbi Amiel Wohl performed the ceremony at the Hampshire Country Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Cheryl Pierson Weds Accomplice
description: Cheryl Pierson, the Long Island teen-ager who hired a classmate to kill her father after saying he had sexually abused her for years, yesterday married her longtime boyfriend, Robert Cuccio. Mr. Cuccio was also convicted in the case for giving a payoff to the killer.

title: Review/Television; A Life in, and Out of, an Institution
description: ''Winnie'' is a puzzle. The made-for-television movie on NBC at 9 this evening gives Meredith Baxter Birney (''Family Ties'') an opportunity to act up a storm in the title role of a moderately retarded woman institutionalized for some 30 years. We root for Winnie as she struggles to prove that she can make it on her own but, while protecting its veneer of heartwarming uplift, the film, based on a true story, ends up demonstrating precisely the opposite.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; A Voice in Europe
description: There is a plan for 330 million West Europeans to be free, by 1992, to reside and do business anywhere in the 12 countries of the European Community.

title: Dr. Frank Gollan, 78; Isolated the Polio Virus
description: Dr. Frank Gollan, a polio victim who isolated the virus of the disease and was instrumental in inventing the first heart-lung machine, died last week with his wife, Alice, at their home in what their son said appeared to be a double suicide. He was 78, and his wife 81. ''My father made various allusions to suicide,'' said Andy Gollan. He said he believed his father and stepmother each took an overdose of pills Wednesday night.

title: A Pollution Garden Grows So Ozone Can Run Amok
description: ''Become an Ozone Damage Detective,'' beckons a sign at the entrance to the Air Pollution Garden, an exhibit at the Institute of Ecosystem Studies in this Dutchess County village.

title: Corporate Penalty Plan Stirs Debate
description: A proposal that outlines how corpo-rations should be punished for committing crimes is fueling a debate in government and academic circles. A draft of the proposal, written by the staff of a Federal agency, will receive its first public airing tomorrow at a hearing in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about New York City's capital spending and borrowing incorrectly stated the level of debt repayment in six years. It will be $3.8 billion in 1994.

title: Venice Journal; Repair of Old Canals Divides Eclectic Community
description: Founded at the turn of the century as a canal-graced center of artistic and intellectual ferment, Venice today seethes with questions like these:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; First Event of '92 Summer Games: Bidding
description: AS a network television show, the Olympic Games had a startlingly off year in 1988, losing money for both ABC, which carried the Winter Games in Calgary, and for NBC, which just concluded its presentation of the Summer Games in Seoul. The audience shortfalls would seem to pose serious doubt as to the event's value as a sure-fire network hit and the networks' willingness to pay rich prices for future Olympics.

title: Review/Dance; Classical Drama From Martha Graham Troupe
description: It was Martha Graham who developed the idea of nonlinear drama in dance. As a result, even once-experimental film directors such as Jean-Luc Godard looked old-fashioned by the 1960's to those familiar with Miss Graham's great gift for telling a story without ''telling'' it.

title: Nominees Wage Intensified War Of Attack Ads
description: Here are a few questions a weekend television watcher was likely to encounter:

title: Hundreds Said to Starve Each Day In War Areas of Southern Sudan
description: Hundreds of people are dying of hunger every day in areas of the southern Sudan where a guerrilla war has uprooted thousands, relief workers and a Sudanese official say.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''These events are creating a political situation in the country that, if it continues, could lead to extraordinary conditions.'' - President Raif Dizdarevic of Yugoslavia. [ A1:6. ]

title: Raise the Age for Boys To Enter First Grade
description: To the Editor:

title: Crafty Bengals Topple Jets, 36-19
description: The Bengals, overcoming an early 9-0 deficit produced on turnovers, showed they were for real today as Boomer Esiason led them to a 36-19 trouncing of the Jets.

title: Stephanie Present Is Wed tO Dr. Michael Podolak
description: Stephanie Danielle Present and Dr. Michael Joseph Podolak were married yesterday at Tavern on the Green in New York by Rabbi Martin J. Zion.

title: Away From Home, Dial a Candidate
description: Benson Ginsburg, a CBS News cameraman covering the Presidential campaign, has a telephone answering machine, but the message on it is hardly the usual, ''I'm not in right now, so please leave your name and number.''

title: Outdoors: Sea Ducks at Sunrise
description: Oct. 1 was sultry, more suitable for swimming than participating in the opening day of the state's sea duck hunting season, but Dixon Merkt of Lyme, Conn., and I had made plans for the excursion more than a month earlier.

title: A Long Celebration After a Long Wait
description: They tore down the goal posts, they caused the police to reroute traffic near their campus and they celebrated deep into the night. The Columbia faithful acted just like college football fans do after an impressive victory, which is notable since they have not had any practice in the past five years.

title: Hungary Sets the Pace For East Bloc Change
description: When Hungary abolished private enterprise after World War II, a symbol of Communism's triumph over capitalism was the conversion of the huge stock market, a Beaux-Arts pile of granite in downtown Budapest, into television studios.

title: Bush Joins Parade In the Chicago Area To Woo Ethnic Vote
description: Vice President Bush today pledged to ''never forget'' the lack of freedom in Eastern Europe as he continued his effort to attract ethnic voters.

title: Israelis Revolutionize Hair Removal Industry
description: For the 350 families of this collective community in the Upper Galilee, the outlook is bright. Officials of their kibbutz-owned factory are confident that worldwide sales of the Epilady hair remover, which the factory began making two years ago, will double, to $60 million.

title: L.S.U. Quarterback Surprises Auburn
description: After two humiliating weeks that included being benched by his coach, Mike Archer, L.S.U.'s outstanding junior quarterback, Tommy Hodson, returned to full-fledged hero status Saturday night.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; U.S. News Rate Base
description: U.S. News & World Report will raise its rate base 100,000 to 2,150,000, a 5 percent increase, beginning Jan. 1. The weekly magazine had posted its highest circulation, 2.36 million, in its 55-year history, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations statement of the first half of 1988.

title: Reservations About Quayle Linger, Worrying Some Republican Leaders
description: Senator Dan Quayle appears to be a threat to George Bush's chances of winning the Presidency next month, despite Mr. Bush's early successes in undermining Michael S. Dukakis's image.

title: Contract at Deere Easily Wins Union Ratification
description: Blue-collar workers at Deere & Company factories in five states overwhelmingly ratified a new contract with their first general pay increase since 1981, United Auto Workers officials said today.

title: TOLL IS PUT AT 200 IN ALGERIAN RIOTS
description: Six days of rioting have left 200 Algerians dead by unofficial estimates and the Government of President Chadli Benjedid divided and under siege.

title: David Mamet Lends a Hand To Homeless Vietnam Veterans
description: Ken Smith, a 36-year-old paramedic and former combat infantryman in Vietnam, had never heard of David Mamet. ''Didn't know him from a hole in the ground,'' he said.

title: Treasury Offers Bills and Notes This Week
description: Treasury financings this week begin with tomorrow's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills, which was postponed today because of Columbus Day. On Wednesday the Treasury will auction $6.75 billion of new seven-year notes.

title: Corrections
description: The About New York column on July 30, about restoration of a mural at the Church of the Ascension in Manhattan, described the winning bid incorrectly. Holly Hotchner was the winning bidder and the project director; Robert Sawchuck was a co-conservator with her.

title: Naples Journal; Is It Over Then? City Closes Its Heart to the Car
description: Italy's romance with the automobile, a frenzied and abiding passion that has withstood the rigors of decades, is turning to heartache.

title: The Press Corps Strikes Back
description: Only four weeks to go, and the pressures within the Bush campaign are plainly intensifying.

title: Of Barbecue and Bellwethers: In Missouri, the Race Is Too Close to Call
description: Scott Gedstad, a restaurant owner, decided to vote for Vice President Bush as soon as the Democrats nominated Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, whom he dislikes because ''he's too much a Government giveaway man, too much a socialist.''

title: Challenge By Saudis To OPEC
description: Saudi Arabia called on other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries this weekend to reduce their oil production to the agreed-upon levels and said it was not responsible for the fall in oil prices, now at their lowest levels in two years.

title: As Giants Keep Scraping By Morris Looks for Better Days
description: With the exception of a stretch here and a stretch there, the Giants have not played very well through their first five games.

title: The Coleman Stove
description: To the Editor:

title: Thomas to Make Pro Debut on Ice
description: In her 15 years as an amateur figure skater, Debi Thomas left behind many vivid memories. She was the first black star in a sport traditionally dominated by white athletes, and her unusual blend of strength and grace captivated audiences and won national and world championships.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: Latvians Establish a Movement to Seek Sovereignty
description: Alarmed at having become a minority within their own borders, Latvians created an independent political organization this weekend to demand sovereignty in governing their republic.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Eastman Kodak Co., Rochester, appointed Earnest W. Deavenport Jr. president of the Eastman Chemicals division, Kingsport, Tenn.

title: Reviews/Music; A 'Carmen' With Verismo Overtones
description: Bizet's ''Carmen'' has gone through a lot of alien country on its way through history to the present. It has picked up bad habits along the way. The opera's brutality and realism are a particular source of stylistic confusion, being identified - and falsely I think - with those of an intervening verismo school. Especially guilty are the singers and directors who have made their bread and butter in the latter repertory.

title: Eva Sambi Colin Is Bride Of John Usdan, Executive
description: Eva Sambi Colin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Colin of Roslyn Estates, L.I., was married at the Pierre last evening to John Lemberg Usdan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel H. Usdan of New York. Rabbis Lee Friedlander and David Lincoln officiated, assisted by Cantor David Lefkowitz.

title: Try Campaigning in 750 Languages
description: LEAD: Picture a national election with 12 major political parties instead of two and a jumble of 1,800 candidates vying for 109 seats in national government. Then imagine trying to conduct the campaign in 750 different languages, with no national television or Dan Rather to sort it out, and you have the elements of the wild and lively politics of Papua New

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1988
description: Companies

title: Don't Even Think of Stealing This Radio!
description: Christopher Conquest's first car stereo was a portable boom box that he kept in the back seat. It was stolen in 1980. He bought a new car and had a stereo radio and cassette tape player installed. That unit was stolen last year. He had a third unit installed. It was stolen several months ago.

title: New Chief From the Old School
description: LEAD: For months after he was dismissed last October as president and general manager of the Chicago Cubs, Dallas Green, the 54-year-old new manager of the Yankees, thought about his baseball future. Bitterness, hurt and anger swirled through him. The dismissal came as a surprise and was a first for him in a 33-year baseball career.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addenda
description: * MacUser, a monthly magazine providing business Macintosh users with comparative product reviews, will increase its circulation 22 percent to 280,000, from 230,000, and its rate base will go up 24 percent with the February issue.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Account
description: * New York Republican State Committee/Victory '88 to Lubicom for print advertising for Vice President Bush's presidential election campaign and the Republican ticket in New York.

title: Packers Finally Win One
description: Brent Fullwood ran for three second-half touchdowns and Green Bay intercepted five passes today as the Packers routed the New England Patriots, 45-3, for their first victory of the season.

title: 6 Killed in Accident in Kansas
description: A fiery head-on collision of a car and a pickup truck killed six people, five of them members of one family, and injured a seventh person, investigators from the Kansas Highway Patrol said today.

title: E.P.A. Blows Up a Hazard That Had Become a Symbol
description: Skeptical and bemused, but mostly cooperative, about a third of this city's 8,000 residents evacuated their homes today as the Federal Government safely destroyed a 20-year-old container of potentially lethal chemicals that had threatened the center of town.

title: Abigail R. Ostow, Psychiatrist, Is Wed
description: Dr. Abigail Ruth Ostow, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Mortimer Ostow of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Arthur Gershon Telegen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Telegen of Milton, Mass., were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents. Rabbis Morton Leifman and Shlomo Balter performed the ceremony.

title: Supreme Court to Hear Case on Bandshell Noise
description: New Yorkers who visit Central Park for its natural serenity and those who go there for rousing rock performances will do battle by proxy next February, when the United States Supreme Court hears a dispute over city rules that regulate amplified music at the park's bandshell.

title: Columbus Day Closings
description: Most Federal Government offices as well as the Federal Reserve and the United States government bond market will be closed today in observance of Columbus Day. Most banks will also be closed, although the nation's stock and commodity markets and most businesses will be open. All Canadian stock markets and bond markets will be closed in observance of Canada's Thanksgiving holiday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Publisher Relishes Task At Elle
description: ANN SUTHERLAND FUCHS is not merely happy about her new job as publisher of Elle. On Friday, her second day on the job, she was ectastic. ''Some people were born to save the world,'' Mrs. Fuchs said. ''I was born to be publisher of Elle. It is like utopia to me.''

title: Valerie Miller Marries
description: Valerie Ann Miller and Jonathan David Galef were married yesterday at the Harmonie Club in New York by Rabbi David Posner. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Miller of Armonk, N.Y., is the creative services coordinator for L'Oreal Fragrance and Cosmetics in New York. Mr. Galef, president of Pegasus Computer Systems in New York, is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Bennett G. Galef of New York.

title: Next's Computer to Offer Package of Technologies
description: Despite the great secrecy surrounding the Next Inc. computer, many of its basic features have already become known. But there are still expected to be some surprises.

title: In Zaire, AIDS Awareness vs. Prevention
description: The gates of a presidential complex here are about to swing open for what health officials call the condom conference.

title: Horace Kramer, 70, Consultant
description: Horace Z. Kramer, a prominent Nassau County Democrat, tax expert and political consultant, died of congenital heart disease Saturday at his home in Woodmere, L.I. He was 70 years old.

title: Coffee, Tea or Video? Airlines Testing Small TV's
description: Northwest Airlines, looking for a better way to occupy fidgety passengers on long international flights, has begun testing a miniature television mounted in front of passengers. Two other airlines are also planning to use the three-inch color screens.

title: Schooners Transport Sailors Into Another Era
description: For the modern sailor, to step aboard today's traditional schooner is to enter the sailing world of the 18th century.

title: Bronco Interception Helps Top 49ers
description: Crisp winds were blustering through Candlestick Park today at nearly 35 miles an hour, and the Denver Broncos and San Francisco 49ers played a sort of hodgepodge football game that seemed to sweep the crowd of 61,711 off its feet.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * Australia's 28,000 coal miners voted Friday to accept restructuring plans that industry officials say could increase production as much as 10 percent. Mining companies, suffering from low world prices and rising shipping costs, want to introduce measures that include increasing shifts to eight hours, from seven, and extending the weekly operation of mines to six days, from five.

title: Giamatti Hangs 'Em
description: What Jay Howell should have said was:

title: Redskins Roll Past Cowboys
description: Mark Rypien threw three touchdown passes and ran for one score today to lead the Washington Redskins to a 35-17 victory over the error-prone Dallas Cowboys.

title: Foul Play Ruled Out In Infant Girl's Death
description: A preliminary autopsy has shown that a 6-month-old girl died of complications from her premature birth, not from child abuse or a dog attack, according to the Monroe County Medical Examiner.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; CEBA Awards Presentation
description: This year's CEBA awards for excellence in communications to black audiences will be presented Oct. 20 at the New York Hilton.

title: Columbus Day
description: NEW YORK Parade: Starts at 11:30 A.M. at Fifth Avenue and 44th Street, moving north to 86th Street, then east to Third Avenue. Parking: Alternate-side parking rules suspended. Sanitation: Today's collections will be made tomorrow. Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail only. Main post office at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue open. Banks and schools: Closed. Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Subways, buses, Metro-North and Long Island Rail Road on regular weekday schedule. Libraries: Closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail only. Banks: Closed. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular weekday schedule. Schools: Many closed. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail only. Banks and schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven Line on regular weekday schedule.

title: AIDS Spurs Soviet-U.S. Cooperation
description: All morning long, Kathleen Eglin had been practicing to greet Dr. Valentin I. Pokrovsky, the Soviet Union's leading AIDS expert. When he stepped off the elevator, she was waiting.

title: Electric Boat Workers Deal With Anger and an Offer
description: The pickets were conspicuously absent today here on Thames Street outside the Electric Boat submarine shipyard, where about 9,000 machinists, mechanics and other tradesmen had been on strike for the last 14 weeks. Many of them were meeting in union halls, living rooms and coffee shops, learning the details of a four-year contract their leaders tentatively agreed to late Saturday. Many of them were angry.

title: Some in Westchester Care Enough to Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: This year's record winning streak at Fenway Park, which helped the Boston Red Sox win their division title, revived memories of the late-season streak by the Chicago Cubs in 1935 that helped them win the National League pennant. How many of those 21 Cub victories in a row were at Wrigley Field?

title: Review/Television; 20 Years of '60 Minutes'
description: Considering the profits and prestige the program has brought to CBS, ''60 Minutes'' is being given a surprisingly chintzy 20th-anniversary party. Here is a clip festival on the cheap. It runs for two hours, but not even on the same night. The first half, covering 1968 to 1978, can be seen tonight at 8. The rest, from 1978 to the present, is scheduled for next Monday.

title: YUGOSLAV LEADER ISSUES A WARNING ON NATION'S CRISIS
description: President Raif Dizdarevic, in a television address to the nation, warned tonight that the crisis in Yugoslavia might lead to ''extraordinary conditions.''

title: Deborah Lynne Donaldson Wed to William C. Gourd
description: The Asbury United Methodist Church in Tuckahoe, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Deborah Lynne Donaldson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert John Donaldson of Bronxville, N.Y., to William Courtney Gourd, a son of Josephine Stanley Gourd of Ridgefield, Conn., and the late Michael Gourd. The Rev. Clayton Z. Miller performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. Climate Limits Use of Energy Cogeneration
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth A. Schwartz and David W. Hinden Wed
description: Elizabeth Ann Schwartz, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Schwartz of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to David William Hinden, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hinden of Hartsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Alexander Shapiro officiated at the Four Seasons in New York.

title: Unions Wary of Icahn on Eastern
description: About three years ago, Carl C. Icahn triumphantly donned a T.W.A. pilot's jacket and danced around his office, jubilantly proclaiming: ''I own an airline. I own an airline.''

title: Disney World Is Cited For Polluting Creek
description: Walt Disney World could face thousands of dollars in fines for polluting a creek with treated sewage, according to officials of the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: TV NOTES
description: A 12th Anniversary

title: 4 NATIONS AGREE ON CUBAN PULLOUT FROM ANGOLA WAR
description: Officials from Angola, Cuba, South Africa and the United States agreed yesterday that all Cuban troops should be withdrawn from Angola within 24 to 30 months, American officials said.

title: Bridge; American teams win two opening rounds at World Team Olympiad.
description: Both United States teams won their first- and second-round matches when the World Team Olympiad began here today.

title: Nancy Kislin Marries R. P. Flaum, a Lawyer
description: At Anshe Emeth Memorial Temple in New Brunswick, N.J., Nancy Jill Kislin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kislin of North Brunswick, N.J., and Richard Paul Flaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Flaum of Boca Raton, Fla., were married yesterday by Rabbi Bennett F. Miller.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Spanish Agency Bought
description: Publicis-FCB, a new European alliance between Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, Chicago, and Publicis S.A., Paris, has increased its stronghold in Spain to almost $90 million in billings by buying Arge, one of the country's leading agency networks. Terms were not disclosed. The newly added $45 million Madrid-based shop will operate under the same name and leadership. Publicis-FCB's Spanish-holdings already include FCB/Madrid, Publicis/Madrid and Moline y Publicis/Barcelona.

title: Living at Home, 28, And not Neurotic
description: LEAD: Imagine a presumptuous stranger telling you that he understands people like you very well. You reply, ''Excuse me, sir, do I know you?''

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chief of Lear Seating Sees The Other Side of a Buyout
description: LEAD: Leading a management group to buy out a company can give an executive an exciting sense of independence, but Kenneth L. Way points out that some personal financial stress is involved, at least while the venture gets under way.

title: Sundstrom Lifts Devils
description: Patrik Sundstrom scored two power-play goals in the third period Saturday night as the Devils rallied to defeat the Quebec Nordiques, 5-3.

title: 36 Sinhalese Villagers Are Slain in Sri Lanka
description: At least 36 Sinhalese villagers were massacred in northern Sri Lanka on Sunday night, a military spokesman said today, and the killings were attributed to Tamil separatists.

title: INSIDE
description: Nuclear Tests Discouraged

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Projects in Third World Create Growing Market
description: Although the market for exports to cash-strapped developing countries has fallen strikingly in the past decade, third-world projects financed by the international development banks have created a booming market for an array of products.

title: Lasorda Displays Irritation on Howell
description: Tommy Lasorda, the Los Angeles Dodgers' manager, stopped short of igniting a dispute with Dave Johnson, the Mets' manager, last night, but he left the clear impression that he didn't think too highly of the way Johnson questioned Jay Howell's glove in the third game of the National League pennant playoff.

title: Boy, 14, Is Arrested In a Student's Death
description: A 14-year-old Edison High School student has been arrested in connection with the stabbing death of a 17-year-old student near the school's main gate after a dance, the police said yesterday.

title: Trinity Wasn't Church of Revolutionaries
description: To the Editor:

title: Candidate Apologizes for Remark
description: A Democratic candidate for the Senate says he did not intend to offend anyone when he said that ''polacks, spiks, wops and the Irish'' were welcome in the Democratic Party.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; On Their Own
description: Normally, liberal Democrats in Congress can count on the endorsement of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to help win re-election. In practical terms, that means volunteers to assist in a wide range of activities, including distributing pamphlets and leaflets, registering voters and getting out the vote on election day. It also helps in fund raising.

title: New Rangers Line Goes Right to Work
description: The rewards may not yet qualify as a jackpot, but the inspired combination Michel Bergeron began playing in the third period of last Thursday's game against the Chicago Blackhawks has paid some handsome dividends.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; A Fresh Fish Starts With a Clean Sidewalk
description: The workday starts at about 1:30 A.M. at Terry's Fish and Seafood, with a steam-cleaning of the sidewalk outside the storefront at Northern Boulevard and 86th Street in the Jackson Heights section of Queens.

title: Big Traders' Caution Remakes the Market
description: A year ago institutional money managers would have snapped up shares of a blue-chip growth company if, in the absence of negative news, it dipped by as much as a quarter of a point. But one afternoon recently, with these big players decidedly more cautious, the stock of the Warner-Lambert Company slid by a point and a half on sell orders that totaled less than 5,000 shares.

title: Ex-Vermont Educator Guilty
description: George Sleeman, a former Bennington superintendent of schools, has been convicted on nine charges of embezzlement and perjury. A Vermont District Court jury deliberated three hours before returning guilty verdicts Saturday.

title: Navy Warns of New Soviet Torpedo
description: New Soviet torpedoes, armed with conventional warheads, have become so explosive that one hit could put a large American aircraft carrier out of action, according to a United States Navy assessment.

title: Publishers Seek a New York Address
description: When the Boston book publisher David R. Godine inaugurates its New York office this morning, Jessica Benson will not have much worry about being late for work. ''I'll be working from my apartment the first six months to a year,'' said Ms. Benson, the sole employee in Godine's new office. ''After that we may rent space with an existing publisher.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Bank Leumi Account To Partners & Shevack
description: The Bank Leumi Trust Company has assigned its advertising to Partners & Shevack, a Mickelberry Corporation subsidiary. The budget is $1.3 million and represents the charter account for the renamed agency.

title: Recipe Fortifies Breast Milk for Premature Babies
description: Scientists have developed a recipe for fortifying mother's milk that improves the odds of survival for tiny premature infants, the Agriculture Department has reported.

title: Truck Hits School Bus; 16 Students Are Hurt
description: A tractor-trailer truck struck the rear of a school bus today, injuring 16 students and the bus driver as the vehicles tumbled down an embankment, the authorities said.

title: Consolidated Papers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gtech Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-Includes a $974,000 gain from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,100,000 for the quarter and $1,807,000 for the 6 months.

title: Braintree Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Pre-tax gains on sales of loans and investments during the first 9 months of 1988 were $85,000, compared to $476,000 for the same period in 1987.

title: Driver and 2 Officers Hurt in Cruiser Crash
description: Two police officers and a civilian were injured yesterday when a police car crashed with a car at Morris Avenue and 166th Street, the police said. It was the third time in less than a month that a civilian was injured in an accident involving a patrol car.

title: Frisch's Restaurants Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 18
First Commercial Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Builder Casts His Swine Before Town
description: The day after local officials snubbed Bill Auble's proposal last April to build apartments and a shopping center on farmland that borders this tiny upstate village, something curious happened. A hog farm suddenly appeared on Mr. Auble's land, just off the main north-south route into the village.

title: Digging for Key to Freed Slaves' Lives
description: Archeologists are sifting through the remnants here of the largest known community of freed slaves in Westchester County. The finds so far - from the stone foundation of a house built in the 1850's - have included shards of ceramic pottery, a 1902 coin, a brass button of a uniform from the New York Central-Harlem River Railroad and the bones of goats and cows.

title: For a Chief of State, No Wrinkles, Please
description: In its bid for acceptance as a world fashion power, the British fashion industry has an effective champion in Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

title: SRI LANKA CAPITAL IS AN ARMED CAMP
description: Hours after the massacre on Sunday of more than 40 ethnic Sinhalese villagers, apparently by Tamil guerrillas, Sri Lanka's capital was under heavy military guard today as Sinhalese militants called a nationwide strike.

title: SPI Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Elvis Presley Joins the Fads At Book Fair In Frankfurt
description: Nobody could remember whether Elvis Presley came to the Frankfurt Book Fair the last time he was in the area 30 years ago. But he was sure there last week, his sideburns gleaming and his crooked smile flashing - and no Army uniform this time.

title: NASA Says Seals Worked
description: Inspection has turned up no damage to the O rings that sealed the joints in one of the shuttle Discovery's solid-fuel booster rockets, NASA reported today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AM International, Chicago, a supplier of graphics-industry products, said its president and chief operating officer, Jerry O. Williams, had resigned and that the chief executive, Merle H. Banta, had assumed the responsibilities.

title: Interchange Financial Servces reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Conston Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-Net income

title: Adolph E. Meyer, Historian, 90
description: Adolph E. Meyer, professor emeritus of educational history at New York University, died of pnuemonia Sept. 30 at his home in Champaign, Ill. He was 90 years old.

title: Treaty Bans Sea Burning Of Toxic Wastes
description: Nations that have signed an international treaty designed to protect the marine environment voted last week to prohibit the practice of incinerating toxic wastes at sea.

title: On Horse Racing; Memorable Season For Phipps Stable
description: The D. Wayne Lukas stable is snakebit these days, and the snake doing the biting wears black silks and a cherry-red cap.

title: Reviews/Dance; At Home in the Ordinary
description: Deborah Hay made simplicity eloquent in ''The Man Who Grew Common in Wisdom,'' the solo she presented Friday night at the Warren Street Performance Loft.

title: Prague Symphony
description: Jiri Belohavek is to conduct the Prague Symphony Orchestra in a program of Czechoslovak music at Carnegie Hall on Oct. 19 at 8 P.M. Steven Mayer, a pianist, will join the orchestra to perform Dvorak's Piano Concerto in G minor. Dvorak's Symphony No. 8 in G major and Smetana's ''Moldau'' will complete the program. Tickets range from $25 to $13. Information: 247-7800.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a chart in Business Day on Friday about Sears, Roebuck & Company's profits misstated the contributions of two divisions. Allstate contributed 52.2 percent of profits; the merchandise group contributed 42.7 percent.

title: Intel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
EXILE OF POL POT IS SEEN AS KEY TO CAMBODIA PACT
description: Nations involved in diplomatic efforts to end the war in Cambodia agree that several leaders of the Khmer Rouge should be sent into exile in China as part of any settlement, Asian officials and diplomats here say.

title: Campaign Trail; Quayle Gets Even With Questioners
description: Senator Dan Quayle, who rides in a curtained-off portion of his Boeing 727, ''the Hoosier Pride,'' shies away from reporters. But the 41-year-old Indiana Senator is plainly handling the generally rough treatment with some aplomb.

title: Communications Transmision Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: How It Happened; A Few Extra Swings, Then 3 Dodgers Connect
description: Steve Sax ran out to the batting cage, taking his bat with him but leaving his uniform shirt in his locker. ''You got to wear your shirt,'' Manny Mota, a Los Angeles Dodgers coach, told him. ''The people are starting to come in.'' Sax, wearing a gray T-shirt, argued briefly, then raced to the clubhouse and returned a minute later, the gray uniform shirt partly buttoned but hanging over his pants.

title: Mayor Sees City's (and His) Renewal
description: The voice on the evening newscasts sounded tough. The New Jersey State senator was saying that he was introducing a bill that would sanction the death penalty for drug dealers who have a record of narcotics offenses and who are convicted of selling to a pregnant woman or juvenile.

title: Drexel Judge Suspects Firm Acted Improperly for Defense
description: In his strongest response yet to charges that he has violated conflict-of-interest laws, the Federal judge hearing the securities-fraud action against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. yesterday suggested that a New York law firm representing a major defendant had acted improperly in the case.

title: Athens Court Votes to Send Bombing Suspect to the U.S.
description: A Greek court ordered today that a Palestinian accused by the United States Government of bombing an American passenger plane be extradited to the United States.

title: Talking Business; with Grove of Intel; Using Diversity In a Downturn
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator, the book-to-bill ratio, is expected to drop for the fifth straight month when it is released this week. It might even fall below 1, which would be the lowest value since 1986. The ratio compares orders with shipments, and a level below 1 indicates that fewer new products are being ordered than are being shipped. This means that business is likely to fall.

title: Dukakis, in Levittown, Offers a Plan To Help Young Families Buy Homes
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, saying it was time to ''redeem the promise'' of home ownership for young Americans, proposed a program today for first-time home buyers that would allow the use of Individual Retirement Accounts as down payments.

title: DMI Furniture Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
Abbott Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said its improved earnings were due to productivity improvement, higher volume, and a better product mix, as well as a weaker U.S. dollar and lower tax rate.

title: Micron Products reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company said its 1988 results include $13,180,000 in sales of Numedco Inc., acquired in February and non- recurring acquisition costs of $166,000.

title: FASHION: By Design; Sensible Shoes Go Chic
description: To downtown dressers, the ''cop on the beat'' shoe is not new. For several years, sprightly young women have been finishing off their all-black outfits with chubby-toed, thick-soled, black leather shoes much like the ones worn by police officers.

title: Congress to Adjourn by Week's End
description: A little later than Congressional leaders had hoped but with more decorum than anybody on Capitol Hill expected, the 100th Congress is wrapping up its business, aiming for adjournment by the end of the week.

title: Fur Vault Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
Nikko Securities Names President of Unit in U.S.
description: The Nikko Securities Company said yesterday that it had appointed Hideo Suzuki, a 28-year employee of the company, as president and chief operating officer of its United States subsidiary.

title: Critic's Notebook; They Sing, They Dance, They're Utterly Different
description: When Prince started a two-night stand at Madison Square Garden on Oct. 2, and Michael Jackson arrived at the New Jersey Meadowlands the next day for his first of three shows, it shaped up as a trans-Hudson battle of the bands.

title: Coca-Cola Promotes Marketing Executive
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it had named Ira C. Herbert, executive vice president and corporate marketing director, president of Coca-Cola USA, in an apparent effort to strengthen its marketing.

title: Sanmark-Stardust Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: General Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an $858,000,000 gain from an accounting change. Year-ago results are restated.

title: Magna International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a gain equal to about 5 cents a share from the sale of real estate and certain investments. c-Included special gains on the sale of real estate, a subsidiary and certain investments equal to 48 cents a share. d-Included a gain equal to about 30 cents a share from the sale of real estate and investments. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Drop in Oil Prices Threatens Mexican Plan
description: The sharp decline in oil prices could jeopardize the Mexican Government's austerity program, which has succeeded in slowing the rate of inflation in this economically troubled country.

title: Belgian Coalition Gets A Lift in Local Voting
description: The Government of Prime Minister Wilfried Martens, which has tried to move Belgium toward a federal system separating French-speaking and Flemish-speaking interests, appears to have emerged unscathed in nationwide municipal elections.

title: Review/Music; Tangled Love and Hate
description: Musical Theater Works was founded in 1983 to give composers a public forum for their works in progress. The company's first production of the season, ''Passionate Extremes,'' a hybrid chamber opera and musical comedy, is running through next Sunday at the Theater at St. Peter's Lutheran Church (Lexington Avenue at 54th Street). Heard on Saturday afternoon, the work made for a diverting hour and a half; but its work-in-progress designation should be taken seriously.

title: Plasti-Line Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
In London, 60's Panache Returns
description: Among the many current trends in British fashion is a resurgence of the ethnic or hippie dressing of the 1960's, considered a romantic period by today's young people, who were infants at the time. Retailers - who have been exploring the 300 fashion houses exhibiting at Olympia, the convention center in the Kensington section, and attending the 19 formal fashion shows -find that hippie looks have replaced the conservative or yuppie looks prevalent just six months ago.

title: Sports People; Colts' Woes Grow
description: Jack Trudeau, the Indianapolis Colt quarterback who was injured three weeks ago, underwent reconstructive knee surgery yesterday and will be out for the rest of the season. Trudeau, who won the starting job over the veteran Gary Hogeboom a week before the injury, suffered ligament and cartilage damage in a 23-17 loss at Cleveland. The rookie Chris Chandler, who started the next three games, suffered a bruised breastbone in the second quarter of Sunday's 34-23 loss at Buffalo. Hogeboom re-placed him and completed 15 of 32 pass attempts for 202 yards but was intercepted twice. It was uncertain whether Chandler would play against Tampa Bay this weekend. (AP)

title: QUAYLE ANSWERS SUCCESSION QUERY
description: Senator Dan Quayle, arguing all the while that the question was ''inappropriate,'' today outlined what he would do if he had to assume the duties of President in an emergency.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They do a whole bunch of talking but they don't give you any answers on the big problems.

title: Corporate Securities Group reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Amerford International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Sage Drilling Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included charges of about $986,000 for the write down of assets to be sold and about $340,000 for additional depreciation on rig equipment.

title: Eagles Beat Sputtering Giants
description: The Giants, who had played poorly but managed to win three of their first five games this season, played poorly and paid for it tonight. The Giants' defense gave up 24 points, allowed yet another quarterback to post All-Pro numbers, including an 80-yard bomb at the end of the game, and lost a 24-13 decision to the Eagles at Veterans Stadium.

title: Bold Plans for Curing Sick Housing
description: Less than four months into his new job, Vincent Lane, the head of the Chicago Housing Authority, has set an audacious course for himself: he wants to turn a giant public housing system that is overwhelmed by gangs, crime and corruption into a laboratory for innovation.

title: The Prosecution Adds Nussbaum To Witness List
description: Hedda Nussbaum is expected to be named today as a possible prosecution witness against Joel B. Steinberg in the beating death of Lisa Steinberg, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Catalogue Unit Takes Buyout Bid
description: In a move to head off an unwanted takeover bid, the Best Products Company, one of the nation's biggest catalogue showroom chains, said yesterday that it had accepted an offer of $27.50 a share, or $685 million, from Adler & Shaykin, a Manhattan investment firm specializing in management buyouts.

title: 2D NUCLEAR PLANT IS ORDERED CLOSED BY ENERGY DEPT.
description: Facing the latest safety problems at the nation's nuclear weapon plants, the Department of Energy has shut down plutonium processing at the Rocky Flats Plant near Boulder, Colo.

title: Bush's Attack on Crime Appeals to the Emotions
description: A hush came over the crowd in Roman Hall here today when Vice President Bush singled out Helen Lanza midway through his latest speech against crime.

title: No Help for Journalists
description: Most Washingtonians eventually become accustomed to the ways of the Federal bureaucracy, but now and then something occurs that leaves even the most experienced rolling their eyes to the heavens.

title: Sports People; DeLoach Drops Out
description: Joe DeLoach, who won the 200-meter dash at the Olympics, said yesterday that would not compete for the rest of the school year at the University of Houston while deciding on his future. ''The best thing for me to do is sit and wait,'' said DeLoach, a native of Bay City, Tex. ''I'll red-shirt this year and make a decision later.'' DeLoach beat out his close friend, Carl Lewis, to win the gold medal. ''After the Olympic Games, it's hard to get focused again,'' said Tom Tellez, the Houston track coach. ''The best thing for Joe is to red-shirt and take time to make up his grades and see if anything is there for him like endorsements. I think he needs to kick back and relax.'' (AP)

title: Attwoods PLC reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: Results are in U.S. dollars; the dollar amounts were translated from sterling at the rate of one pound equals $1.766 for the 1988 period and for the 1987 period at the rate of one pound equals $1.53. Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipts (ADR); each ADR respresents 5 ordinary shares.

title: Rocky Mountain Chocolate Factory Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Paper Maker Cites Diversity
description: Although the International Paper Company has made its presence felt in just about every aspect of the paper manufacturing business, the $7.7 billion company has kept a low profile on the ad front.

title: Cutting Trash Down to Size
description: Each year Americans throw away 16 billion disposable diapers, 1.6 billion pens and 2 billion razors. That's just part of an annual 1,300 pounds of household waste per person. Yet acceptable places to dump the garbage are fast disappearing because of tighter environmental standards and opposition from local communities.

title: Met Fans Squeezed in Parking Lot Shutout at Shea
description: The man who oversees parking at Shea Stadium is the first to admit that traffic before and after Met games is an ordeal. That is why he tries to be the first to arrive, at 6 A.M.

title: Joint U.S.-Vietnamese Teams Find Remains of Americans
description: Joint United States-Vietnamese search teams found the remains of a number of American servicemen missing from the Indochina war during a 10-day search ending today, an official United States statement said.

title: Jets Determined To Hone Technique
description: Coach Joe Walton today put his team back on the hook he had allowed them to escape from on Sunday.

title: Palestinians Are Said to Agree On Need to Declare a State
description: Palestinian leaders have agreed to recommend declaring a Palestinian state, officials of the Palestine Liberation Organization said today, but the timing of a special meeting to issue the statement remains uncertain.

title: For Jefferies, Times Get a Little Tough
description: As Gregg Jefferies energized the Mets in the last month of their season, the rookie's sudden prominence created the sense that his talent and motivation had come together to merge with the right time and place.

title: Townsend Scudder, 88, Teacher and Author
description: Townsend Scudder 3d, an educator and author, died of heart failure Friday at the health center at Pomperaug Woods, a retirement community in Southbury, Conn. He was 88 years old and lived at Pomperaug Woods.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Latvians Extending a Hand to Outsiders, Just a Bit
description: Sergei Yegorenok was something of a rarity at this weekend's inaugural congress of the Latvian Popular Front.

title: Sunwest Financial Services reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Results Plus
description: Horse Racing Victory for a Long Shot: High Browser, the longest shot in a field of 10, dueled with Miss Unnameable before winning by a length yesterday in the Athenia Handicap at Belmont Park. The winner, a 3-year-old Tom Rolfe filly trained by Mack Miller, paid $27.40 for $2 to win and ran the mile and three-eighths under Pat Day in 2:18 3/5. Also, weights were released for the Meadowlands Cup Friday. Alysheba was assigned 127 pounds, 4 more than Bet Twice. Other likely starters are Cryptoclearance at 119, Brian's Time at 117, Simply Majestic at 116 and Pleasant Virginian at 114. Golf Lyle Edges Faldo: Sandy Lyle of Scotland sank a 20-foot putt on the 35th hole yesterday to beat Nick Faldo of England, 2 and 1, and win the World Matchplay championship in Wentworth, England. Lyle finished with four straight birdies.(AP) Yachting Knickerbocker Cup to Perry: Dave Perry of Milford, Conn., won the Knickerbocker Cup match-racing series on Long Island Sound yesterday. Ten skippers competed, each sailing with a crew of five on a J-35.

title: City National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes non-recurring income of $599,000, or 2 cents a share and $855,000, or $1.37 a share for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes non-recurring income of $3,357,000, or 14 cents a share for the quarter and $5,362,000, or 22 cents a share for the 9 months. The company said the latest year non-recurring income reflects sales of the South El Monte Branch Property, leveraged lease assets and Instant Teller earnout proceeds. The prior year non-recurring income reflects sale of Instant Teller, payroll proceeding and leveraged leases. The company also said the share earnings results reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 15 and a 20 percent stock dividend payable Oct. 17.

title: Studies Unmask Origins of Brutal Migraines
description: MIGRAINE headache, long mired in popular myths and medical misconceptions, is at last yielding its miserable secrets to neurologists who study the cellular and chemical functions of the brain.

title: Patterns
description: Caution's the Word

title: Campaign Trail; Rather's Role A Matter of Debate
description: The news has sent shock waves through the corridors of CBS. Dan is - angry. Dan Rather is - very upset.

title: First Boston Merger Brings Sense of Relief
description: Within First Boston Inc. yesterday there was a sense of relief that the long-awaited deal with the firm's London-based affiliate, Financiere Credit Suisse-First Boston, was finally announced. Some called it a year late, because of the turmoil and setbacks the firm has been through in the past year.

title: Intervoice Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Fewer Failures Of Banks Seen
description: The number of United States commercial bank failures is expected to decline by about 25 percent in 1989 after reaching a record this year, the head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation says. The F.D.I.C. chairman, L. William Seidman, told a news conference at the American Bankers Association's annual convention Sunday that by the end of 1988 as many as 250 banks will have failed or needed Federal assistance to stay afloat. Last year a record 184

title: Bank of New Hampshire Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquistion of Suncook Bank, which has been accounted for on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: Chile Victors Now Plan For a Presidential Vote
description: Victorious opposition forces, trying to remain united after defeating Gen. Augusto Pinochet in the plebiscite last week, have begun the search for their own presidential candidate.

title: Fumes From Toxic Chemical Spill Injure 22 at Electrical Company
description: Twenty-two workers at an electrical company were stricken by fumes from a spilled chemical today, most of them after an evacuation order was ended and they re-entered the building, officials said.

title: Thomas S. Farrell, College President, 76
description: Brother Thomas S. Farrell, founding president of Walsh College, died of a stroke Saturday. He was 76 years old.

title: Deere Workers in Five States Ratify a Three-Year Contract
description: Blue-collar workers at Deere & Company factories in five states overwhelmingly ratified a new contract with their first general pay increase since 1981, United Auto Workers officials said Sunday.

title: New Ozone Threat: Scientists Fear Layer Is Eroding at North Pole
description: EVEN as they ponder the implications of the vast hole that opens each year in the protective ozone layer over Antarctica, a major international team of scientists are now focusing new attention to the Arctic, where experts fear the ozone layer may also be developing worrisome gaps.

title: Bangladeshi Asks for Help on Controlling Floods
description: In an appeal to the General Assembly, the Foreign Minister of Bangladesh said today that a permanent solution to the country's annual flood disasters must be reached through regional cooperation with international support.

title: Robins Case Trustees Said To Be Split
description: The court-appointed examiner in the A. H. Robins bankruptcy case has filed a report indicating that the trustees are deeply divided over many issues critical to the disbursement of a $2.4 billion trust fund for victims of a birth-control device made by Robins.

title: Medusa Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $3,453,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The results are pro forma and are for periods when Medusa was a subsidiary of the Crane Co.

title: Sports People; Tyson Confers
description: Mike Tyson was still at the Orwell, Ohio, farm of his promoter, Don King, yesterday, conferring with his attorney, Howard Weitzman, about the divorce suit filed Friday by the fighter's wife, Robin Givens. A source close to Tyson said that one legal approach being considered is to seek an annulment of the marriage to preclude Givens from gaining a share of the couple's property. Sources say that Tyson married Givens after his mother-in-law, Ruth Roper, told Tyson's late co-manager, Jim Jacobs, that Givens was three and a half months pregnant. Friends of Tyson's have questioned whether Givens was ever pregnant, and that issue may become a basis for seeking an annulment. Tyson was expected to be back in New York this week. On Thursday, Tyson, along with King and the fighter's manager, Bill Cayton, and Seth Abraham of Home Box Office will meet with Jarvis Astaire and Mickey Duff, who are co-promoting Tyson's mandatory defense against Frank Bruno in London. Tyson wants to change the site of the Dec. 17 bout to the United States. The meeting is an effort to determine whether Astaire and Duff can be persuaded to agree to the shift.

title: Rite Aid to Sell Super Rite Stake
description: The Rite Aid Corporation said it had decided to sell its 46.8 percent stake in Super Rite Foods Inc., and Super Rite Foods, in turn, reported that an investor group would make an offer to acquire all of the grocery company's common shares. The investor group includes Super Rite's chairman, Alex Grass, and other members of management.

title: A Jet in Trouble Dumps Its Fuel, Dousing Queens
description: The pilot of a jetliner with engine trouble jettisoned some of its fuel over Queens yesterday, showering some residents of Far Rockaway with kerosene before landing the plane at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Athletics Spread Success Around
description: The final moments of the celebration were almost done. The players were allowing themselves final sips of champagne, the manager was recalling a summer full of memories for the surrounding news media, and the general manager, dressed in faded blue jeans, tennis shoes and a shirt opened at the collar, was telling a couple of reporters how the whole thing had finally come together.

title: New School Unveils Its Restored Orozco Murals
description: New York City has added another gem to its long list of artistic treasures, one that it almost let slip away. This latest addition is not new, but it is newly restored: a cycle of five frescoes that the Mexican muralist Jose Clemente Orozco painted at the New School for Social Research on West 12th Street over 50 years ago.

title: Cooking and Spelling Chilli (as in Illinois)
description: To the Editor:

title: Columbus Day Closings
description: The Federal Reserve and the Treasury bond market were closed yesterday for Columbus Day. Most banks were also closed, although the nation's stock and commodity markets were open. In Japan and Canada, all financial markets were closed for national holidays.

title: Review/Music; New York Chamber Symphony Opens Season
description: Gerard Schwarz put together a nicely rounded, all-American program for his New York Chamber Symphony's season opener at the 92d Street Y Saturday night: Aaron Copland's ''Appalachian Spring'' Suite, a new work by Ned Rorem and a concert version of Leonard Bernstein's ''Trouble in Tahiti.'' But because the birth of his daughter kept Mr. Schwarz in Seattle, where he leads another orchestra, David Zinman (whose own Baltimore Symphony is on strike) was recruited to stand in for him.

title: Immucor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $106,695.

title: What Roe v. Wade Said
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors Test New Plastics for Artificial Lenses and Corneas
description: NEW plastic materials that do not repel water will soon enhance the long-term prospects of patients who need artificial lenses or corneas, scientists have reported.

title: Dara Lyn Meyers Becomes a Bride
description: Dara Lyn Meyers, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Burt R. Meyers of White Plains and West Yarmouth, Mass., was married yesterday to Evan Moses Kingsley, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Ralph P. Kingsley of North Miami Beach, Fla., and Lenox, Mass. The bridegroom's father and Rabbi Harvey Tattelbaum performed the ceremony at Bet Am Shalom Synagogue in White Plains.

title: Sara Lee to Expand Hosiery Holdings
description: The Sara Lee Corporation, the leader in the United States hosiery market with its Hanes and L'eggs brands, received permission to purchase a controlling stake in France's most popular hosiery maker, Dim S.A. The French Finance Minister, Pierre Beregovoy, said he had given Dim's parent, Societe Bic, approval to sell a 31 percent stake in the stocking maker to Sara Lee for $47.6 million, after a nine-month delay while he pondered terms of the deal.

title: KEY RATES
Ms. Solomon Wed To J. I. Griffin 4th
description: The wedding of Joan Lynna Solomon, the daughter of Mr. and Richard A. Solomon of Chevy Chase, Md., to James Isaac Griffin 4th, a son of Mr. Griffin 3d of Dallas and the late Davyne S. Griffin, took place yesterday at the Audubon Society in Chevy Chase. The Rev. Thomas Kryder Reid, an Episcopal priest, and Rabbi Robert Brenner performed the ceremony.

title: Lebanon, With 2 'Governments,' Faced With Deepening Stalemate
description: Lebanon's warring factions are at a standoff, still locked in a constitutional dispute that threatens partition and more violence.

title: Long Night for the Mets
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers put their pine-tar problems behind them Sunday night, outlasted the Mets in a struggle that raged for four and a half hours, and finally nailed them in the 12th inning on a home run by Kirk Gibson.

title: Bustle of Life in Sea Ice
description: IN a discovery that could lead to a better understanding of the fragile polar ecosystem, scientists have found a surprising concentration of tiny plants and animals thriving in the pores of the sea ice that forms each winter and surrounds the Antarctic continent, the National Science Foundation announced yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Meldrum & Fewsmith Gets Card Business
description: American Greetings, the 82-year-old Cleveland-based greeting card company, has called on a nearby agency, Meldrum & Fewsmith, to handle its retail trade programs. A seven-figure budget will be aimed at 90,000 stores and distributors. The agency, whose specialty is retail and business advertising, already has such clients as Libbey Glass and Mr. Coffee.

title: Kllm Transport Services reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 2
description: b-Includes a $103,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Ravenswood Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Vigilant Children Are the Heroes As Salmon Make a Comeback
description: NEARLY 3,000 miles of creeks, streams and rivers course through Snohomish County, a booming suburban area north of Seattle, but students at the Jackson Elementary School here are concerned about only one small stretch of water.

title: The Manipulators
description: This campaign is getting real exciting. Only about a month to go, and still nobody knows whether the American people will choose Lee Atwater or John Sasso.

title: Corrections#YES#
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about alternatives to the explosive testing of nuclear weapons misstated the number of tests for reliability that occur at the nuclear test site in Nevada. They are carried out occasionally, making up a small fraction of the two dozen or so explosive tests performed for all purposes each year.

title: Hallwood Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $578,000 and an extraordinary tax benefit of $1,442,000 from a tax loss carryforward for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes extraordinary tax benefits from tax loss carryforward of $1,348,000 for the quarter and $6,911,000 for the year.

title: Perjury Case Raises Legal Eyebrows
description: The case against a prominent Manhattan negligence lawyer accused of suborning perjury has added to a debate in legal circles over whether courtrooms are appropriate settings for sting operations, particularly if the tactic involves fake court documents.

description: Imagine a once-serviceable red brick public school now boarded up and dilapidated. Then imagine, on the same two-acre site, small clusters of single-family town houses, neat lawns, shrubs and flowers.

title: A Time to Get Mad
description: No doubt fired up by the North Carolina barbecue he was eating during the interview, Michael Dukakis told Robin Toner of The New York Times that he finally was ready to slug it out with a ''bankrupt'' opponent who was relying on ''disgraceful'' tactics. It's about time.

title: Twin Dies; Twin Is Charged
description: A 19-year-old man was charged with driving while impaired after his car spun out of control early today and hit a utility pole, killing his twin brother, who was the only passenger. The man, Craig Voogt of Melville, who suffered head injuries, also was charged with speeding after the accident, which left Keith Voogt dead.

title: Spearhead Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Holiday Slows Bond Activity
description: Activity in the Treasury bond market was virtually nonexistent yesterday, with the United States market closed for Columbus Day. Japanese financial markets were also closed.

Trial Set in Robbery Of Wells Fargo in '83
description: After more than three years of arguments, motions and other twists, a Federal trial is set to begin today for five people accused in the 1983 robbery of $7.1 million from a Wells Fargo depot.

description: OCTOBER is Computer Learning Month, and throughout the country efforts are under way to increase the public's understanding of how computers can be used more effectively in schools, at home and at work.

description: What color do you drink?

title: Book Award Nominees
description: Peter Gay, Don DeLillo and J. F. Powers are among the 10 authors nominated for the 1988 National Book Awards. The nominations were announced yesterday by Barbara Prete, the executive director of the sponsoring organization, National Book Awards Inc.

title: South Africa Opens Segregated Local Voting
description: South Africans of all races began voting today in segregated nationwide elections for local councils despite a boycott call by anti-apartheid leaders in defiance of emergency regulations.

title: Fetal-Tissue Panel Reached No Decision on Abortion Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: State by State; From Jersey to Missouri, Voters Are Fed Up
description: The American public is fed up with the Presidential candidates and the way they're running their campaigns.

title: Campaign Trail; Dukakis Gives Aides The Cold Shoulder
description: Poised for the second and final Presidential debate on Thursday, the staffs of both candidates are nervously trying to shape the television styles of Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis. Clearly Mr. Bush has to lower his voice, stop the abrupt hand gestures and refrain from the kind of comments he made in a television interview last year on how his father used to discipline him.

title: 2 Killed in Factory Explosion
description: At least two people were killed and seven injured when a carbon dioxide tank exploded today at a plant that makes airplane and rocket parts.

title: Foreign Agents Said to Have Entered Bomb Labs
description: Congressional investigators have found evidence that visitors from the Soviet bloc and other countries, including suspected intelligence agents, have routinely been allowed access to the Energy Department's nuclear weapons laboratories.

title: Saudis' Plan On Oil Output Raises Prices
description: Oil prices rebounded in world trading yesterday after Saudi Arabia reiterated that it would cut its production if others did the same.
