Buick or Olds? G.M. Wants It Clear
description: ''This is not your father's Oldsmobile,'' blares the voice in a television commercial proclaiming a new generation of cars from the oldest division of the General Motors Corporation.

title: G-R-I Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Sports People; 'Not Dead Yet'
description: Wisconsin football fans, some of whom are frustrated over the 0-5 start of Coach Don Morton's team, saw him in a coffinlike box if they tuned into his television show over the weekend. At the start of the show, Morton's head popped out of a pine box that had been lined with felt. On the lid was a sign that read, ''We might be down, but we're not dead yet.'' The segment, which was filmed Thursday, started out with the camera panning a graveyard and stopping at individual tombstones marking the opponent and score in each of Wisconsin's first four losses to Western Michigan, Northern Illinois, Miami and Michigan. ''I suggested the idea to him and he jumped at it,'' said the show's host, Van Stoutt of WISC-TV in Madison. ''Lately, he's been surrounded by a lot of negativism and so he wanted to do something different.'' Saturday, the Badgers lost their fifth game, 31-6, to Iowa at Iowa City.

title: International Research & Development Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
S.E.C. Inquiries Scrutinized
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has failed to investigate most reports of suspicious foreign trading of United States securities, despite a growing number of illegal trades originating from abroad, a House panel said today.

title: Evans Incorporated reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
Psychologist's Expert Testimony Called Unscientific
description: PSYCHOLOGISTS and psychiatrists who testify as experts in court are themselves on trial, after a fashion.

title: Accounts of Jailed Planner
description: A receiver for the fugitive financial planner arrested in Tokyo last week said today that he had moved to identify and freeze accounts held or controlled by the suspect in two countries, and might have located a third account.

title: Falcon Player Dies at Age 29
description: LEAD: A member of the Atlanta Falcons suffered a seizure and died early today, and authorities said that cocaine was the probable cause of his death.

title: U.S. Defense Aide Calls on Allies To Spend More to Deter the Soviets
description: A senior Defense Department official said today that the Soviet military remained a strong threat despite Moscow's re-examination of domestic policies, and the official called on the allies of the United States to take a bigger share of the West's defense burden.

title: Getty Offers To Buy Apex Division
description: The Getty Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it had offered to buy the Clark Oil and Refining Corporation and some other assets of the Apex Oil Company for $553.5 million in cash.

title: Tenneco Selling Its Oil Company For $7.3 Billion
description: Wrapping up the most extensive auction of properties ever by an American corporation, Tenneco Inc. said today that it expected to receive $7.3 billion in cash from buyers of its oil and gas properties.

title: Ruth Tendler, Administrator, 62
description: Ruth Tendler, assistant director of the Lincoln Institute for Psychotherapy, died of lung cancer Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: b-Net loss

description: * Carlton Communications P.L.C., London, said it had completed the acquisition of Technicolor Holdings Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Deceit Wins the Day
description: CORRUPTION is a nasty game. I liked it. You play the part of Derek

title: Yugoslavia Unglued: How Unrest Grew
description: Under Tito, Yugoslavia was synonymous with tough leadership. But it has been like a rudderless ship for the last eight years, with a series of crises that have raised serious questions about its direction.

title: Leaving It to Charity And Knitting Needles
description: To the Editor:

title: Biin to Display New Computers
description: Biin, a joint venture between the Intel Corporation and Siemens A.G., will introduce today two computer systems intended for specialized fault-tolerant applications where high security is desired. These computers are widely used in such applications as banking, electronic funds transfer and airline reservation systems.

title: Acronyms at Large
description: In the Pentagon's office of acronyms the latest word in unconventional warfare is LIC, or Low Intensity Conflict. LIC, pronounced ''lick,'' is an umbrella concept covering everything from guerrilla and anti-guerrilla operations to welldigging and road building in poor countries to help prevent farmers from succumbing to communism. It also covers shows of force, such as the dispatching of light infantry and paratroop battalions to Honduras last March.

title: Aboil in the Balkans
description: Yugoslavia has long been a maverick among the nations of Eastern Europe. Dominated for decades by a man who took orders from no one, it resisted Stalin's iron grip and remained steadfastly nonaligned. Now, goaded by an ambitious politician named Slobodan Milosevic, it's torn by turmoil that seems remarkably like the ethnic rivalries erupting in parts of Mikhail Gorbachev's empire from Armenia to the Baltic. But this Balkan crisis is as worrisome for the West as it is for the East.

title: Maine Paper Mill Workers End Bitter 16-Month Strike
description: One of the most bitter strikes of the 1980's ended today when members of the paper workers union decided to break off their 16-month-old walkout against the International Paper Company.

title: Help for the F.B.I.
description: ''F.B.I. Confirms Amazing Powers of Psychic,'' said the headline on this week's front page of The National Enquirer.

title: Minorco's Plan For Newmont
description: The Minerals and Resources Corporation, which is attempting a takeover of Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. of Britain, said today that it would sell Gold Fields' 49.3 percent stake in the Newmont Mining Corporation if its bid succeeds. Newmont owns the biggest

title: Multiple Choice Flunks Out
description: LEAD: Many things have been urged upon the beleaguered public schools: install computers, reduce class size, pay teachers better and respect them more and give them bodyguards, reform teacher training, restore the principal's authority, purge the bureaucracy and reduce paperwork, lengthen the school year, increase homework, stick to the basics, stop ''social promotion,'' kill social studies and bring back history, and (the latest plan) pay kids not to drop out or play truant.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Plans Vote Drive
description: The N.A.A.C.P. National Board is planning a nationwide voter drive linked to the 25th anniversary of the murder of Medgar Evers, a Mississippi civil rights leader.

title: Telerate Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is 56 percent owned by Dow Jones & Co.

title: Brawley to Get Muslim Name
description: Tawana Brawley has expressed a desire to become a Muslim and will receive a new Muslim name next Feb. 26 at a dedication of a Nation of Islam mosque here, an official of the religious group said today.

title: Michael Anthony Jewelers Inc. reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income Fiscal 1988 results include the sales of MAJ Manufacturing Co. and Enca Industries Ltd., units whose stock or operating assets were acquired July 1 and Sept. 10, 1987, respectively. The company said the loss is the result of lower gross margins. increased costs and expenses, and the writeoff of obsolete inventories and doubtful accounts receivable.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 The exile of Khmer Rouge leaders, including Pol Pot, is a necessary part of a settlement of the war in Cambodia, involved nations, including China, Vietnam and the United States, agreed. Page A1

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Stores Asked To Place Ads All Week
description: FOR years, American retailers have concentrated their advertising on end-of-the-week shoppers.

title: A Friend in Pennsylvania
description: The state whose blue-orange motor vehicle license plates say, ''You've got a friend in Pennsylvania'' could be thinking these days of the Democratic-run Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: Market Place; Delta a Favorite In Airline Stocks
description: MANY companies believe they must continually report strong quarterly and annual earnings to please investors and analysts, but Wall Street has been willing to tolerate exceptions when it is convinced that a payoff will be even greater later on. Delta Air Lines is one such exception, analysts say.

title: Paper Tigers of TV Criticism
description: LEAD: I heard someone on a radio talk show recently ticking off the most important inventions since the beginning of time.

title: Driver Cited in Hayride Crash
description: A tractor driver was arrested for public intoxication after 11 teen-agers were injured when a hayride wagon overturned late Saturday. The wagon overturned as it was going down a steep road in Eagle Creek Park, the authorities said. Many of the 40 passengers were affiliated with the Fellowship of Christian Athletes at Speedway High School. The driver, John R. Pourchot, 34 years old, was released on his own recognizance.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Wednesday about bidding to acquire Macmillan Inc. misstated a description in court papers about a telephone conversation between Michael Tokarz of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company and two Macmillan executives, Edward P. Evans and William F. Reilly. Mr. Tokarz's deposition says he told his lawyers, who were in his office at the time, that the call ''would look bad on the record.'' The remark was not made to Mr. Evans.

title: Howell's Penalty Reduced to 2 Days
description: In what basically was a compromise, A. Bartlett Giamatti, the National League president, yesterday cut Jay Howell's suspension by one day, meaning he will be eligible to pitch tonight in the sixth game of the National League playoff in Los Angeles.

title: Sports People; Surgery for Dravecky
description: Dave Dravecky, the San Francisco Giant pitcher, has undergone successful surgery to remove a cancerous tumor in his throwing arm, the Giants said yesterday. The 32-year-old left-hander underwent an eight-hour operation at the Cleveland Clinic on Friday. He will remain in the hospital for the next few days. Dr. George Muschler, who performed the surgery, reported that there was no apparent nerve damage, according to the Giants. Dravecky, a native of Youngstown, will remain in Ohio over the winter. The team said that the pitcher expects to report for spring training. (AP)

title: Reviews/Dance; Dakin of Graham Group Takes 3 Roles in a Night
description: Even a major dancer in a great company does not usually appear in a leading role in three highly demanding works on a program, but Christine Dakin accomplished this unexpected feat superbly with the Martha Graham Dance Company on Saturday night.

title: Grand Met Seeking End to Court Order
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British conglomerate attempting to take over the Pillsbury Company, will ask a Federal court in Detroit Tuesday to quash a restraining order that is preventing Grand Met from buying Pillsbury shares.

title: F.D.A. Pressed to Approve More AIDS Drugs
description: Advocates for AIDS patients, dissatisfied with the progress of developing and approving new treatments for the disease, are continuing to put pressure on the Food and Drug Administration through meetings with Government officials and demonstrations.

title: Cubans at Home in New Land at Last
description: Carlos M. Castaneda, the Cuban-born editor of El Nuevo Dia, one of Puerto Rico's principal newspapers, was in a somber mood, at odds with the alluring backdrop of cloudless sky, emerald sea and verdant hills.

title: Cattle Prices Are Increasing
description: Cattle prices are being pushed higher this fall by hefty demand and smaller supplies, but analysts at the Agriculture Department say consumers may not see much further effect at retail beef counters.

title: Europe-Latin Accord
description: The European Community signed an agreement in Paris today with the Inter-American Development Bank to encourage growth of private European investment in Latin America, a community statement said. The agreement lays the foundations for the I.A.D.B. and the 12-nation community to promote investment and set up joint ventures between Western European concerns and small and medium-size companies in Latin America.

title: Reviews/Dance; Changes a Baby Brings
description: Melanie Slater set up small archetypal worlds in three dances performed on Saturday night at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: Resorts Stock Drops on Move by Griffin
description: The deal between Merv Griffin and Donald J. Trump to split up Resorts International Inc. showed signs of unraveling yesterday as Mr. Griffin withdrew his pending tender offer for Resorts stock and asserted that he now had the right to cancel the deal entirely.

title: Amazon Settlers Turn Forests To Ash in Name of Progress
description: The fires that have raged around this frontier town for the last three months have once more pushed back the jungle and turned forests into black and sapless land. But the mood of Redencao is anything but mournful.

title: Dow Jones & Company Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 12
description: The company said share earnings for the 9-month would have been $1.12 vs $1.27 excluding nonrecurring gains on sales of investments in both years.

title: U.S. Bank Sues Israeli Enterprise
description: The Finance Ministry, the Bank of Israel and private bankers today held emergency talks with the top management of Koor, Israel's largest industrial concern, after the Bankers Trust Company filed a lawsuit demanding the company's liquidation.

title: Consumers Accepting 4% Inflation
description: According to many economists, the inflation rate has remained at 4 percent to 5 percent for so long now that people are becoming accustomed to it.

title: Village Super Market Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Sale by Goodrich
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company, based in Akron, Ohio, reached an agreement to sell its Engineered Rubber Products unit to a management group from its aerospace division. Terms were not disclosed. The unit designs and produces such textile-reinforced specialty products as inflatable life rafts, helicopter emergency flotation systems and inflatable tanks for fluid storage. The group buying the unit includes Oscar J. Mifsud, general manager of B. F. Goodrich Aerospace's De-Icing System unit; David B. Smith, general manager of Engineered Rubber Products, and Patrick Ryan, controller of De-Icing Systems.

title: Knicks vs. Nets: Already?
description: The Knicks and Nets will open the exhibition season tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, and Eddie Lee Wilkins will continue his quest to become the backup center to Patrick Ewing.

title: Neti Technologies reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: The company said 1988 revenues were entirely from its computer timesharing and software licensing operations. Revenue in 1987 resulted primarily from the company's computer hardware sales and leasing operations, which were sold May 31, 1987.

title: Walking a Tightrope On Intelligence Issues
description: With an off-the-cuff retort to a provocative question, Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, has rekindled one of Washington's longest running and most acrimonious debates - about what role Congress should have in overseeing American intelligence operations.

title: River Forest Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: An article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about the political implications of efforts to free American hostages in Lebanon gave an incorrect date in some copies for the release of David P. Jacobsen. It occurred on Nov. 2, 1986.

title: Advanced Micro Devices Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: b-Net loss The 1987 quarter and 9 months results have been restated to reflect an accounting change. Year-ago periods include a pre-tax charge of $40,985,000 associated with the merger of Advanced Micro Devices and Monolithic Memories Inc.

title: Mets Lose to Dodgers and Go From Dream to Crisis
description: Less than 12 hours after they had blown a lead in the ninth inning and a game in the 12th, the Mets returned to Shea Stadium yesterday and might have blown a pennant.

title: Sterling Capital Corp reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: Samuel Adams, Ex-C.I.A. Officer And Libel Case Figure, Dies at 54
description: Samuel A. Adams, a former Central Intelligence Agency analyst who was a co-defendant in Gen. William C. Westmoreland's libel suit against CBS, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Strafford, Vt. He was 54 years old.

title: Dow Jones Net Falls by 13%
description: Revenues and income from The Wall Street Journal and other printed publications owned by Dow Jones & Company declined sharply in the third quarter, overshadowing strong gains in electronic publishing at Telerate Inc., a partly owned subsidiary, and in other news and information services segments.

title: Assix International Inc. reports earnings for Year to June 30
Skolniks Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The 1988 shares outstanding include 800,000 units of the company's initial public offering in April.

title: 'Jewish Journalism'
description: ''A People in Print: Jewish Journalism in America,'' is to open at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street, at noon Thursday. The exhibition, which runs through Feb. 23, examines the role of the Jewish press and the personalities who shaped it. In addition to more than 300 drawings, paintings, periodicals, photographs and related artifacts, the exhibition also features two video presentations and letters from Presidents Jefferson and Madison. Information: 860-1888.

title: Books of The Times; Centenary for Author of an Indubitable Classic
description: Anita Loos A Biography By Gary Carey Illustrated. 331 pages. Alfred A.Knopf. $24.95.

title: Washington Bancorporation reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: First National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jesse A. Spilka Weds Susan Rachel Brophy
description: Susan Rachel Brophy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira N. Brophy of New York, was married yesterday to Jesse Adam Spilka, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Spilka of New York. Rabbi Martin Zion officiated at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens.

title: O'Brien Energy Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago first quarter results is adjusted to reflect O'Brien Energy Systems' June 1988 acquisition of three British companies.

title: Campaign Trail; One Job Bentsen Isn't Seeking Now
description: It began so perfectly for Lloyd Bentsen over the weekend.

title: Blaze in Chicago Leaves 3 Dead
description: A fire swept through the top two floors of an apartment building today, killing three people and seriously injuring five others, two of them young children, an official of the Fire Department said.

title: As Strife Persists, Algerian Asks for Time
description: President Chadli Benjedid of Algeria pleaded tonight for more time to institute programs to solve the nation's political crisis.

title: Token Plot: To Catch A Suspect
description: A swindle in which criminals jam subway turnstiles and retrieve deposited tokens is rising in New York City. In this series of photographs, taken with a hidden camera tripped by remote control at the 116th Street and Broadway station on IRT No. 1 line, a suspect is shown as he tampers with a turnstile and is eventually arrested by the transit police.

title: U. of Chicago Maintains Its Intellectual Vigor
description: To the Editor:

title: Superheroes' Battleground: Prime Time
description: Bang! Pow! Crunch! Thunk! Iron Man, She-Hulk and Daredevil are coming to prime-time television.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * San Francisco Marriott, a 1,500-room hotel opening in October 1989, to Rosenthal, Greene & Campbell, Bethesda, Md.

title: N.F.L. Notebook; Craig Sets the Pace For Running Backs
description: The way Roger Craig sees it, his body should be like a finely tuned automobile. Like rolling into a body shop for oil changes and new filters, Craig three times a week visits a chiropractor and twice a week has a massage. He is 6 feet and 212 pounds, having lost 13 pounds since last season.

title: Bankers Seek to Avoid A Role in Savings Crisis
description: Bankers are growing increasingly concerned that they will be asked to help pay for bailing out their ailing cousins in the savings and loan industry.

title: Roatan Journal; On Scorned Isles, They'd Have Victoria Whipped
description: It is often said that this forgotten sliver of Honduras is striving to be forever England.

title: Afghan Rebel Attacks Are Reported to Go On
description: Moslem guerrillas fired rockets into the Afghan capital on Sunday night, killing five or six people, an official of the Soviet-allied Government said today. The official said he did not know how many people were wounded in the attack and could not provide further details.

title: First National Bancorporation reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Griffin to Buy Stations
description: The entertainer Merv Griffin agreed Friday to pay $34 million for four radio stations of the Federal Communications Corporation. The stations are WHJJ-AM and WHJY-FM in Providence, R.I., along with WVEZ-AM and FM in Louisville, Ky. The operations represent the entire broadcast holdings of Federal Communications, based in Providence, whose principal owner is Robert Fish. Mr. Griffin already owns four radio stations.

title: Serara T. Ketlogetswe, Botswana's Ambassador, 68
description: Serara T. Ketlogetswe, Botswana's Ambassador to the United States, has died at a hospital in the capital, Gaborone, the southern African nation's press agency reported today. He was 68 years old.

title: American Recreation Centers reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 24
description: b-Net income

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why do cats like catnip? A.The active substance of catnip, Nepeta cataria, is a chemical called nepetalactone that sets off in the cat's brain the behavioral patterns usually connected with a variety of pleasurable or exciting things, according to research by Dr. Benjamin L. Hart, an animal behavior expert at the University of California at Davis.

title: Rangers Shut Out; First Time Since '86
description: There was a light show done in their honor before the game, replete with spotlights and lasers. The memory the Rangers took away from the evening, though, was undoubtedly that of the light show conducted at their expense in the third period. Red light after red light went on behind their goal, leaving them to slink off in the glare of a 5-0 loss to the Devils.

title: Electrosound Group Incorporated reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $59,000. The latest quarter included an after-tax charge of $1,779,000 relating to the company's pro rata share of losses at Memory-Tech, its 40 percent owned compact disc manufacturing joint venture with Mitsubishi Corp.

title: Laszlo Berger, 86, Analyst on Wall Street
description: Laszlo Berger, a Wall Street analyst and investment broker for more than 50 years, died, apparently of a heart attack, on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86 years old.

title: Hostage Charge Against Indian Protester Dropped
description: A judge today dismissed Federal hostage-taking charges against a militant Indian, Timothy Jacobs, but said he would leave it to a jury to decide whether a second defendant was guilty.

title: THE PLAYOFFS: Sports of The Times; 'JH' Inspired Gibson's Home Runs
description: IF the Dodgers win the National League pennant, the Mets' biggest mistake will not have been whatever runners they left on base or whatever bad pitches they threw. Their biggest mistake will have been demanding the search of Jay Howell's glove. Howell was using pine tar in order to get a better grip on the ball. But because of Howell's suspension, the Dodgers got a 3-2 grip on this tumultuous four-of-seven-game playoff that resumes in Los Angeles tonight.

title: Luby's Cafeterias Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a $474,000 after-tax gain from the sale of land.

title: Gelman Sciences Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $100,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: Review/Theater; Some Merry Pranksters From the 18th Century
description: If there is any moral to be drawn from Oliver Goldsmith's venerable 1772 comedy, ''She Stoops to Conquer,'' it is that sooner or later what goes around comes around, to use contemporary parlance. In the case of ''She Stoops to Conquer,'' the repercussions that its merry pranksters bring on themselves through practical jokes that rebound and romantic machinations that run awry come swiftly and sweetly home to roost.

title: Americus Journal; Town Goes Public To Resurrect Cafe
description: Down at Americus's principal intersection, the one with the red blinking light, a modest sign peering dimly through a window identifies the Breckinridge County Cafe.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. SPECIAL COMMITTEE AGAINST APARTHEID - 10 A.M.

title: John Pirie, 81, a Retired Airline Executive
description: John Charles Pirie, a lawyer and retired airline executive, died of cancer Wednesday at the Meridian Nursing Home in Annapolis, Md. He was 81 years old and lived in Annapolis.

title: Profit Increases 23% at G.E.
description: The General Electric Company said today that its net earnings rose in the third quarter by 23 percent, to $815 million, or 90 cents a share, from $661 million, or 73 cents a share, in the corresponding period last year.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Philips Official Returns To Head American Unit
description: LEAD: Einar Kloster, a former executive vice president of the North American Philips Corporation, will return as president of the company on Jan. 1.

title: Less Lead in Rivers
description: A decline in lead contamination in major American rivers has been found at two-thirds of 300 sites studied from 1974 to 1985, scientists at the United States Geological Survey have reported.

title: Old Fashion Foods Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-Included a gain of $203,000 from a retroactive change in income tax accounting.

title: First Victory For Islanders
description: Tomas Jonsson scored on a screened slapshot from the blue line five minutes into the third period tonight to lift the Islanders to a 3-2 victory over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: VLSI Technology Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
Research Yields Clues to Drug Resistance in Cancer Therapy
description: RECENT research advances hold the promise of overcoming one of the most serious problems in cancer treatment: the tendency for tumors in some patients to become resistant to chemotherapy.

title: U.S. Panel Proposes Steps to Cut Safety Lapses at O'Hare Airport
description: Eighty measures to improve operations at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago, including higher pay and other incentives to attract experienced air-traffic controllers, have been proposed by a Government team that studied the nation's busiest airport.

title: Stocks Close Mixed as Dow Climbs 8.71
description: The stock market ended mixed yesterday in slow Columbus Day trading, but the Dow Jones industrial average managed on a small gain to reach a new high since the market tumbled last Oct. 19.

title: Hidden Victim In Brawley Case Is Civil Rights
description: Since graduating from Radcliffe in 1971 and Columbia Law in 1975, Suzanne Lynn has devoted her legal career to civil rights. In 1986, Ms. Lynn, who is black, was named chief of the state Attorney General's civil rights bureau, supervising six lawyers.

title: CHESS
description: If you put three grandmasters into a small, double-round competition, it would be a reasonably safe bet that they would take the top places. And that is what happened in the Baden-Baden, West Germany, International Tournament in July: Vitaly Tseshkovsky of the Soviet Union won first prize with a 10-4 score; Dusan Rajkovic of Yugoslavia and Mihai Suba of Rumania shared second place at 8 1/2-5 1/2.

title: Don't Sentimentalize Hirohito's Wartime Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Group Hails Corporate Aid On Housing
description: A nonprofit group overseeing the creation of 1,000 apartments for low-income families in New York City has raised more than 30 percent of the total cost - $25 million -from corporate investors, officials of the group say.

title: Structural Dynamics Reearch reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nominees Set to Meet Thursday For Debate
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and Vice President Bush will meet in their second debate Thursday at 9 P.M., Eastern daylight time, at the Pauley Pavilion of The University of California at Los Angeles, the campaigns said today.

title: INSIDE
description: Dodgers Lead Series, 3 to 2 The Dodgers beat the Mets, 7-4, to gain an edge in the National League playoff. Jay Howell's suspension was reduced, making the Dodger pitcher eligible for tonight's game. Page D27.

title: Bridge
description: Play in the World Championships was slightly delayed here today when astonished players were faced with old deals they had encountered yesterday. This organizational glitch was quickly repaired.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Careers; New Concept On Research In Colorado
description: MORE than two dozen Coloradans with doctoral degrees in technical fields descended on New York last week to promote their state as a high-tech research center. The group, representing a consortium called the Colorado Alliance of Research Universities, later flew to Washington to sell its ideas there.

title: Czech Premier Quits Over Policy Rift
description: Czechoslovakia's Prime Minister resigned today after 18 years in office, apparently because of differences with the new party leader.

title: Cypress Semiconductor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $27,000 and $1,886,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Intel Acquires a Technology
description: The Intel Corporation has purchased a promising new interactive video technology from the General Electric Company and plans to make chips incorporating the technology, industry sources said today.

title: Review/Theater; At Hartford, Mark Lamos's Vision Of 'A Midsummer Night's Dream'
description: ''Pyramus and Thisby,'' the play-within-the-play performed by Bottom and his fellow workmen, usually provides a hilarious finale to ''A Midsummer Night's Dream.'' That is most pointedly not the case in Mark Lamos's production of Shakespeare's comedy at the Hartford Stage. ''Pyramus'' caps Mr. Lamos's ''Dream'' the way an episode of ''Masterpiece Theater'' might follow a movie by Fellini, or a Bach cantata might conclude a pop concert by David Bowie. It's definitely a cue to stop dreaming, sit up and attend to Culture.

title: A Bipartisan Fear Of Full Employment
description: LEAD: Former President Gerald Ford laid it on the line about unemployment at the Republican Convention, but his candor and insight have gone unnoticed.

title: The Proof of the Pudding: Two Sample Recipes
description: A Better Burrito A 4-course Mexican meal in a single tortilla (Adapted from ''KidsCooking: A Very Slightly Messy Manual'' by the editors of Klutz Press, 1987) Preparation time:

title: Review/Opera; 2 Rareties in New Jersey
description: The careers of Puccini and Mascagni are describable in purely musical terms - the first as a long crescendo, the second as a sudden, brilliant sforzando dissipating into nothing. Mascagni's ''Zanetto,'' for example, has been virtually lost in the wake of his earlier ''Cavalleria Rusticana,'' the work that made him rich and famous but overshadowed the rest of his life. ''Le Villi,'' on the other hand, is Puccini's first opera. It exudes success and confidence of more to come.

title: A Long Way From Beads and Fathers of the 20's
description: When Adelaide Hall reminisces about ''Blackbirds of 1928,'' the hit Broadway revue that made her a star 60 years ago, the image of herself that she conjures is a far cry from the international grande dame of cabaret that she has long since become.

title: Knogo Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Year-ago earnings are restated.

title: Charlotte Charles Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Alex Gottlieb, 81, Dies; TV and Film Producer
description: Alex Gottlieb, who produced more than 50 television shows and Hollywood movies during his four-decade career, died of a cerebral hemorrhage in Los Angeles on Sunday. He was 81 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: New Credit for Soviet Union West German bankers will provide a $1.6 billion line of credit for Moscow, which wants to improve its food and consumer goods industries. Page D1. Cubans Detain Cup Yacht A Cuban gunboat forced a ship carrying the 132-foot New Zealand, which failed in its bid for the America's Cup, into a Cuban port. Page A27. Anti-Greenhouse Greenery A Connecticut utility, concerned that its new coal-fired complex will add to global warming, will plant 52 million trees in Guatemala. Page A14. Ulster Politician Jeers Pope The Rev. Ian Paisley, the Protestant official from Northern Ireland, called Pope John Paul II ''the Antichrist'' as the pontiff spoke in France. Page A3.

title: Macmillan Has Deficit
description: Macmillan Inc. reported yesterday that it had a loss of $1.7 million in the third quarter, compared with a profit of $43.3 million, or $1.52 a share, in the similar quarter a year earlier. Sales rose 5.7 percent, to $340.7 million, from $322.2 million a year earlier.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. GENERAL COMMITTEE - 9:30 A.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. DECOLONIZATION COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. PLEDGING CONFERENCE FOR HUMANITARIAN AND ECONOMIC ASSISTANCE TO AFGHANISTAN - 10 A.M.

title: Exchange's New Hours
description: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange announced on Monday that in January it will open trading in foreign currency options and futures three and a half hours earlier than its present 8 A.M. start in an effort to increase trading with European investors. In September 1987, the exchange became the first to open night trading in foreign currency options. With the new morning hours, the exchange will be open for foreign currency options trading from 4:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. and from 7 P.M. to 11 P.M.

title: Technology Marketing Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $74,716 and $210,292 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and the quarter is after an extraordinary charge of $7,124.

title: ENERGY SECRETARY VOWS FAST ACTION ON ARMS REACTOR
description: Energy Secretary John S. Herrington said today that he had appointed a special team to correct safety failures at the Savannah River Plant and to put a reactor that produces vital nuclear weapon material back into operation in January.

title: East Flatbush Casts Wary Eye On AIDS Babies
description: At this moment in world history, is there anything more soul-wrenching than babies with AIDS? For them, things start bad and, one way or another, just keep getting worse.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Rule on Press Liability in Identifying Rape Victim
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the First Amendment shields the press from liability for publishing information that, while accurate, nonetheless invades someone's privacy or damages a reputation.

title: About Education
description: Elizabeth Jensen, who teaches American history to a class of 11th graders, has written on the blackboard: ''Resolved: The British Government possesses the legitimate authority to tax the American colonies.'' Having defined the debate, she sits in a corner with pencil and notebook and listens as rebels and loyalists re-enact the history that ultimately led to the Declaration of Independence.

title: Student Loan Marketing Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Founding Foodies Sell Silver Palate
description: THESE days shoppers assume that stores will carry exotic salad dressings, thick preserves and mustards with complex flavors. They also take it for granted that they can run out at 7 P.M. and grab a great meal to take home to eat in front of the television. Ten years ago, however, such offerings were relatively rare - except at the Silver Palate.

title: Truvel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: 'Goo-Goos' Glom Onto Issues, Again
description: LEAD: The goo-goos, as the forces of good government were once called with more affection than respect, are agitating again. They are vocalizing their quadrennial complaint - that the Presidential candidates are failing to address the issues. The League of Women Voters has stamped off the platform refusing to be party to ''hoodwinking'' the electorate by sponsoring a debate that will, presumably, skip around the issues.

title: Chemfix Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Ralph Gampell, 71, Court Administrator
description: Dr. Ralph Gampell, a physician and lawyer who was former chief administrator of the court system in California, died of cancer Oct. 3 at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 71 years old.

title: How a Fake Office Created a Real Office
description: Fans of a certain age remember when play-by-play radio broadcasts of a baseball game were actually created in a studio far from the ball park. Imaginative announcers relied on brief messages sent over telegraph lines. To heighten reality, recordings of crowd noises were played - cheers, for example, when the latest wire message announced a home run.

title: What to Know About Related Foods
description: THERE are many hidden hazards for people with allergies, said Dr. Sami L. Bahna, chairman of the department of allergy and immunology at the Cleveland Clinic Foundation. He suggested a number of potentially perilous situations. Even when labeling is available, foods to which people are highly allergic appear under unfamiliar names.

title: Lions Sign Witkowski
description: John Witkowski, former Columbia quarterback, has signed with the Detroit Lions as a backup to Rusty Hilger. Witkowski, 26 years old, played three games for the Lions during the 1984-85 season. Hilger moved into the No. 1 spot after Chuck Long suffered a partial ligament tear in his left knee. Hilger was signed last week as a free agent after backup Eric Hipple broke his ankle two weeks ago. (AP)

title: New Bond Funds Are Being Offered
description: FALLING interest rates are the friends of bond investors, but to realize the benefit of rising bond prices at times when rates fall, investors must pay close attention to the kinds of issues they own.

title: Half-Ton of Cocaine Is Seized in Queens
description: Police officers seized about 1,000 pounds of cocaine from a house in Little Neck, Queens, on Monday night, bringing to 14,000 pounds the amount of the drug seized in New York City over the last four months, officials said yesterday.

title: Not Only Tourists Are Victims of Cabbies
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is no military solution to what we are facing. It is mainly a political problem.'' - Maj. Gen. Amram Mitzna, Israel's military commander in the West Bank. [ A6:3. ]

title: Banponce Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Candidates Focus on the U.S. Role in World Economy; 'Make America No. 1' Is Message of Dukakis
description: Michael S. Dukakis stepped up his appeal to national economic self-interest today, saying it was time for a ''second Declaration of Independence'' from trade deficits, from Federal debt and from ''an over-reliance'' on foreign capital.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: Stones Confidential ''I think of our differences as a family squabble,'' Keith Richards said the other day about his strained relationship with Mick Jagger. ''If I shout and scream at him, it's because no one else has the guts to do it or else they're paid not to do it. At the same time I'd hope Mick realizes that I'm a friend who is just trying to bring him into line and do what needs to be done. Though rock-and-roll is over 30 years old, no one has really tried to make it grow up. And a reunited Rolling Stones would be in a better position than anyone to explore what is still uncharted territory.''

title: Jury Screening Starts In Steinberg Trial
description: Forty-six potential jurors were selected and 152 others were excused yesterday as the judge and both sides in the trial of Joel B. Steinberg began what promises to be a nearly monthlong search for a jury.

title: Bonita G. Wrather, 65, an Actress and Executive
description: Bonita Granville Wrather, a child film star of the 1930's and a longtime executive in the Wrather Corporation, a complex of oil, entertainment and real estate businesses founded by her husband, Jack Wrather, died of cancer yesterday at St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 65 years old and had homes in Holmby Hills, Calif., and London.

title: Mets Win, 5-1, For a Showdown
description: The New York Mets defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5-1, to tie the National League Championship Series at three games each. The seventh and deciding game is scheduled for tonight in Los Angeles with the Dodgers' Orel Hershiser to pitch against the Mets' Ron Darling. Articles, page A27

title: Campaign Trail; Rather Is Bearer Of Unexpected News
description: Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts arrived in Los Angeles yesterday for their second and final debate Thursday night, only to find out that they had been upstaged by Dan Rather.

title: White as a Beet: Growers and Chefs Find a New Palette
description: LEAD: HARICOTS VERTS from New Jersey; arugula from Tivoli, N.Y.; baby white asparagus from Hart, Mich.; petits pois and mesclun from the Catskills, and radicchio rosso (red chicory) from Santa Cruz, Calif. European favorites are now at home in the United States, along with an array of fruits and vegetables recently considered fare for only a select few markets and restaurants.

title: Armenians Astir: Write-In Candidate Wins 78%
description: The Communist Party of Armenia has proclaimed ''election-rigging'' in the case of a biophysicist who ran a write-in candidacy for public office and won more votes than the party's hand-picked nominee.

title: Six Are Killed in Crash Of an Air Force Tanker
description: An Air Force tanker plane crashed this afternoon at Wurtsmith Air Force Base, killing 6 people and injuring 10 others.

title: Standard Shares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Moderate Economist Named Czech Premier
description: Apparently trying to forge greater unity within its leadership, the Czechoslovak Communist Party appointed a moderate economist as Prime Minister today and announced a shuffling within the party.

title: Amserv Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Spaniards Study English (Not the King's) in U.S.
description: Berta M. Villamayor, a 16-year-old student from Madrid, told a visitor what she learned in her English course at the Duence International School here last summer.

title: Some Israelis Sense a Futility In Steps to Quell Arab Revolt
description: Amira Shamrukh, a 44-year-old Palestinian mother with 14 children, spent another day in an Israeli military court today, trying to keep another of her sons out of jail for stone-throwing.

title: Valcom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
A Most Ferocious Math Problem Tamed
description: By piecing together the output of hundreds of computers on three continents, a team of mathematicians succeeded yesterday in solving a monster computational problem that had defied all previous efforts. The achievement is likely to force cryptographers to reassess the future application of some codes used by governments and banks.

title: Griffin's Bid for Resorts Backed by Jersey Panel
description: Merv Griffin yesterday received the approval of the New Jersey Casino Control Commission to take over Resorts International Inc. and said he intended to complete the deal in which he and Donald J. Trump will divide up the casino company.

title: First Maryland Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Fiscal 1987 share figures have been restated to reflect a 6-for-5 stock split effected in the form of a 20 percent stock dividend distributed in March 1988.

title: Teaching Children To Cook By the Book
description: IF food is comforting to children, cookbooks tailored for them represent a wealth of reassurance. When done well, they encourage children to build the most basic skills. And they offer something more: stolen moments with a busy parent.

title: Digital Warranty
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation effectively raised its prices by 6 percent to 9 percent on most products by eliminating a free one-year warranty program. A Digital spokesman said customers would be advised to purchase a ''standard warranty,'' which adds about 6 percent to 9 percent to equipment costs. Free service would still be available to customers who bring their computers to Digital centers for servicing, he said.

title: Teachers Strike in Arkansas
description: Teachers in the state's second-largest school district walked off the job today after the school board rejected a mediation committee's recommendation that they be given a 3 percent raise. Classes for 21,000 students in the Pulaski County Special School District were canceled. The district covers all the schools in the county in which Little Rock is situated, except the Little Rock and North Little Rock schools.

title: U S Sprint Seen Turning a Corner
description: After years of bitter customer complaints, dismissed managers, shifting ownership and huge losses, U S Sprint finally seems ready to turn the corner.

title: Review/Music; Of the Stage and Screen
description: Dennis Russell Davies and the American Composers Orchestra addressed themselves to concert-hall byproducts of the American musical theater tradition Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

title: Suntrust Banks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Economist Sees Hope for Continued Texas Upturn
description: Despite the recent fall in oil prices, Texas is likely to continue to build on its fledgling economic recovery over the coming year, a leading Texas economist said here today.

title: Oh, for A 'Normal Country'
description: Ask Vitaly Korotich, who edits the politically lively Soviet magazine Ogonyok, what he wants, what he is fighting for so hard. He gives a shy smile and says, ''I'm tired of labels. I want a normal country.''

title: Review/Architecture; Winter Garden At Battery Park City
description: The Winter Garden at Battery Park City in lower Manhattan, a 120-foot-high room of steel and glass overlooking the Hudson River, opens formally to the public on Friday. It is perhaps the grandest public space built in New York since Grand Central Terminal, and it is surely the most eagerly awaited: it was finished more than a year ago but has been kept under wraps, in part to allow the 16 45-foot-tall palm trees that have been planted under its glass roof a chance to acclimatize themselves to New York's uncertain sunlight.

title: Co-op Space For Artists In Brooklyn
description: ARTISTS priced out of the market for lofts in Manhattan have long sought refuge from high rents by taking space in the city's other boroughs. But in the last few years some of them have found that the push to revitalize industrial neighborhoods close to Manhattan has also pushed up the prices of loft space there, too.

title: The Editorial Notebook; From the Outside: Yonkers II
description: ''I love the flowers,'' says William Coram, pointing to the bright autumn blossoms alongside his brown-shingled dwelling in Greenburgh, N.Y. ''I have them blooming all summer long.''

title: Candidates Focus on the U.S. Role in World Economy; Bush Says Rival Wants To Exploit U.S. Fears
description: Vice President Bush offered a stinging rebuke to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's warnings about foreign investment today, calling his language ''protectionist demagoguery'' designed to exploit a fear of foreigners and frighten the American public.

title: Boxing Notebook; King Is Back in Tyson Camp
description: For a good part of the summer, and into the fall, Don King was feeling like the odd man out in the Mike Tyson industry.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Drexel Judge Assails Defense Tactic
description: In response to a call to disqualify himself from presiding over the Drexel Burnham Lambert securities fraud case, a Federal judge suggested yesterday that several prominent defense lawyers might have violated ethical rules.

title: Eateries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a $35,000 charge from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. Prior year periods are restated to reflect a change in accounting for restaurant startup costs.

title: Vivigen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $51,100 and $170,700 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Roots of Western Tradition Lie in the East
description: To the Editor:

title: Elmer (Mousey) Alexander, Drummer, 66
description: Elmer (Mousey) Alexander, a veteran drummer who performed with some of the nation's major orchestras, died of heart and kidney failure Sunday in South Seminole Community Hospital in Longwood, Fla. He was 66 years old and lived in Longwood.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Mini-Series Covering Ad Business
description: FINALLY, after television mini-series on police officers, doctors and lawyers, there will be one on the advertising business.

title: MacMillan Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest quarter includes non- recurring charges of $29,400,000, from a disposal of inventory resulting from MacMillan's decision to close its Scribner Laidlaw Elementary School business, and $39,700,000, from expenses related to tender offers for the company and a proposed restructuring. All share earnings figures assume full dilution.

title: Reagan Vows to Support Sihanouk's Forces
description: President Reagan told Prince Norodom Sihanouk today that the Administration regards him as a pivotal leader in a future Cambodian government and that it will increase aid to the non-Communist Cambodian opposition, Administration officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of Monday's New York lottery numbers published yesterday gave an incorrect number for the New York Numbers. The winning number was 801.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ST. LOUIS (NL) - Named Jim Riggleman third-base coach. BASKETBALL HOUSTON (NBA) - Traded Jim Petersen and Rodney McCray, forwards, to Sacramento for Otis Thorpe, forward. INDIANA (NBA) - Released Herbert Crook and Jarvis Basnight, forwards, and Troy Lewis, guard. PHOENIX (NBA) - Named Mark Grabow strength and conditioning coach during training camp and Scotty Robertson consultant. FOOTBALL DETROIT (NFC) - Signed John Witkowski, quarterback. INDIANAPOLIS (AFC) - Signed Bob Gagliano, quarterback. HOCKEY BUFFALO (NHL) - Sent Brad Miller, defenseman, to Rochester of the American Hockey League. HARTFORD (NHL) - Assigned Richard Brodeur, goaltender, to Binghamton of the American Hockey League.

title: Lance Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
Arminius N. Hayne, Musician, 102,
description: Arminius N. Hayne, a musician who was believed to have been the oldest member of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, died of heart disease last Thursday in Brooklyn Hospital. He was 102 years old and lived in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn.

title: Review/Television; Inner Voyage in 9 Parts
description: ''The Mind'' is not the kind of series you snuggle into with a bowl of popcorn. This is television demanding that you sit up straight, pay attention and perhaps even take notes. This is - to use that unfashionable label -educational television. And public television, bless it, is the only broadcasting entity around these days willing to tackle such a project. The nine-part series begins tonight at 8 on Channel 21 and at 9 on Channel 13.

title: From the Phantom, With Love
description: LEAD: Dear New York:

title: Army Civilian Admits He Passed Weapons Data to South Africans
description: A former Army weapons analyst pleaded guilty today to espionage charges after confessing that he had passed classified military information to Washington-based South African diplomats.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: A Chef Turns Publisher Daniel Boulud, the executive chef of Le Cirque, has started a monthly newsletter with his wife, Michele. The attractive publication, ''Easy Cooking With Great Chefs,'' has some very sensible features, including a column with buying and cooking tips for seasonal produce, fish and other food. There are also low-calorie menus with recipes, a pasta of the month and an interview series called ''Grilling the Chef.''

title: Echlin Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
State Dept. Does What It Can on Two Americans Jailed in Liberia
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Only Tourists Are Victims of Cabbies
description: To the Editor:

title: Ulster Protestant Interrupts Pope, Yelling 'Antichrist!'
description: Pope John Paul II was interrupted at the beginning of a speech to the European Parliament today by the Rev. Ian Paisley, the Northern Ireland Protestant politician, who noisily denounced him as ''the Antichrist.''

title: Octel Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $241,000 tax credit. The company said its improved performance was due to success in selling its voice processing products.

title: EX-HOSTAGE FACES MARINE DISCHARGE
description: A marine who spent 444 days as a hostage at the United States Embassy in Iran says he is being forced out of the Marine Corps because of emotional problems stemming from his captivity.

title: CPC International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a special gain of $126 million, or $1.53 a share, resulting from the company's restructuring. Year-ago third quarter and 9-month sales includes operations divested in 1987.

title: First Virginia Banks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BB&T Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Chandler and Marlowe Are the Toast of a Party
description: Philip Marlowe might have described it as ''a lot of Hollywood swells trying to feel good about themselves supporting literature,'' said Roger Simon, president of the American chapter of the International Association of Crime Writers.

title: Shearson Offering $200 Million Issue
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton entered the debt market yesterday with a public offering of $200 million in 9 7/8 percent senior subordinated notes, due in 2000, at a price of par.

title: Chapparal Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter and 9-months earnings include $367,000 recovered by the company in a lawsuit.

title: New P.I.P. Accord
description: Postal Instant Press Inc. agreed to a revised merger agreement with Golder, Thoma & Cressey, a Chicago leveraged buyout concern, that lowers the acquisition price to $15.50 a share, or about $61 million, from $17.41, or $69 million. The Los Angeles-based company agreed to the new terms because debt financing was unavailable on terms that were comparable to the original financing commitment.

title: 10,000 Polish Students Urge Legalization of Association
description: About 10,000 students at universities in major Polish cities held rallies today to demand legalization of the outlawed Independent Students Association.

title: Cone Overcomes The Early Pressure
description: In the right-field bullpen at Dodger Stadium, just minutes before the game of his professional life, David Cone continued to receive unsolicited opinions on his brief journalism career. The opinions were as unfavorable as they were loud.

title: Northwest Airlines Is Sued by Singer
description: The Singer Company said it had sued Northwest Airlines Inc. for interfering with the sale of Link-Miles, its international flight-simulation business, to Thomson-CSF, a French electronics group. The lawsuit, which seeks at least $75 million, was filed in United States District Court in Minneapolis, where Northwest has sued Singer and Paul A. Bilzerian, its chairman, for $25 million. The suit contended that Mr. Bilzerian's takeover of Singer delayed the delivery of simulators that were crucial to the carrier's Pacific routes.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Interpublic Group Unit Adds Fahlgren & Swink
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies said yesterday that its Lintas New York Inc. subsidiary had acquired Fahlgren & Swink, an agency with offices in the South and Midwest, for an undisclosed exchange of stock.

title: Hycor Biomedical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Henrietta Jacobson, A Yiddish Actress, 82
description: Henrietta Jacobson, a longtime star of the Yiddish theater in New York, died of heart failure Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: IP Timberlands Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest third quarter results include a $14.6 million gain from the sale of 42 million acres of Timberland.

title: Note and Bond Prices Ease a Bit
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds eased slightly in light trading yesterday.

title: At Harvard, Guidelines On Speech and Dissent
description: Lawyers and philosophers have been wrestling with the question of how to define free speech for at least 200 years. Now Harvard Law School has weighed in.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: Tenneco Inc. said today that it would receive more than $6.4 billion in cash after taxes and expenses from the auction of most of its oil and gas businesses.

title: Quayle, Loosening Style, Takes Grip on Campaign
description: After more than six weeks of avoiding press conferences and impromptu campaign speeches, Senator Dan Quayle has changed his style, loosening it to the point that he now takes questions from reporters and exchanges quips with his audiences.

title: WINE TALK
description: ST. GREGORY OSTIENSE came to northern Spain in the year 1039, commanded by Pope Benedict IX, to rid the land of a plague of locusts. Five years later, exhausted by his labors -which seem to have been successful - the saint died here in Logrono, today the center of the bustling Rioja wine district.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR Diary:

title: NBC Widens Authority Of Program Executive
description: NBC yesterday greatly expanded the creative and administrative authority of Brandon Tartikoff, the programming executive who brought the network from last place nine years ago to first place last season.

title: Bandag Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lukens Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: Share earnings results reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in the latest third quarter.

title: Israelis Go to Bankers Trust To Halt Liquidation Attempt
description: A delegation of Israeli bankers and industrialists is scheduled to meet with officials of the Bankers Trust Company this morning at the bank's headquarters on Park Avenue to block an effort to liquidate that country's largest industrial concern.

title: Chairman Is Retiring From Jordan Marsh
description: The Allied Stores Corporation said yesterday that Elliot J. Stone, chairman of the company's Jordan Marsh department stores for six years, will retire, effective Jan. 1.

title: High School Is Offering A Multilingual Future
description: In Los Angeles, a city ever more aware of hard-charging competition from the nations bordering the Pacific, the question about education is no longer simply, ''Why can't Johnny and Jane read?''

title: The Smoking Law Revisited: Room Enough for Everyone
description: SIX months ago, a significant number of New York's restaurateurs were ready to tear their hair out as the city's new smoking law went into effect.

title: Review/Dance; The Enactment of a Ritual
description: Too many cooks might have spoiled the broth in ''Shifted Hearts,'' a new duet by Gabrielle Lansner and Lissy Trachtenberg that was performed on Friday evening at the Dia Art Foundation. Set to a musical collage by Guy Yarden, the dance was a matter of white gauzy hangings, long trains of white material and long-winded wafting and manipulation of the material to no apparent purpose. The choreographers, both skillful and attractive performers, seemed at times to be enacting a ritual, but if so it was a private one.

title: Where Summer Subtly Slips Into Fall
description: ''Fall is definitely here,'' my husband said the other morning, returning from the front yard with the newspapers. How did he know? ''Because the car seats are damp,'' he said. ''I guess it's time to put the top up.''

title: Shamrock Appeal To Workers on Bid
description: Shamrock Holdings Inc., rebuffed in its $2.4 billion bid for the Polaroid Corporation, plans to appeal to the company's employees, who are major stockholders. Polaroid, based in Cambridge, Mass., has rejected a request by Shamrock to meet with its workers.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Penguins 8, Capitals 7: Mario Lemieux scored his first three goals of the season, two of them short-handed, to lead Pittsburgh to victory over Washington in Pittsburgh last night. Mike Ridley of the Capitals scored four goals. Lemieux, who was held to one assist by the Capitals in the season opener Friday night, also had two assists. Ridley's best career game raised his season goal total to five, the most in the league.

title: Hugh Algernon Percy, Duke of Northumberland, 74
description: Hugh Algernon Percy, the 10th Duke of Northumberland, died today, a family spokeswoman said. He was 74 years old.

title: U.S. to Pay $750,000 In Suit on LSD Testing
description: The Justice Department announced today that it had settled a lawsuit by nine Canadians who charged that the C.I.A. made them the subjects of mind-control experiments involving drugs.

title: Dukakis Plan Improves College Loan Program; Every Option Is Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Better Screening Of Older Drivers Urged in Report
description: A Federal study of elderly motorists today called for better screening to identify impaired drivers but concluded there was no justification to restrict driving solely on the basis of age.

title: A Chase and Gunfire In Suspect's Capture
description: A suspected car thief was captured after leading police on a 10-mile chase through two towns, ramming a stolen car into a police cruiser, then firing at an officer as the suspect tried to run away, the police said.

title: U.S. Officials Concede Lapses In Security at Weapon Labs
description: Energy Department officials today conceded that there had been security lapses involving foreign visitors to the United States' nuclear weapons laboratories. But they maintained that there was no firm indication that classified information had been disclosed as a result.

title: Robeson Industries Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
New York Area Retail Sales Off
description: New York City retail sales continued to languish in September, with average declines from September 1987 of 1.1 percent in the city and six-tenths of 1 percent in the metropolitan area, several leading retailers reported in a monthly spot check.

title: Review/Film; Holocaust With a Twist
description: Among the starving inmates of a Nazi concentration camp, there is one well-fed and well-muscled man. An accident of fate has placed him in this peculiarly mortifying position. Before the war, both he and the camp's commandant were boxers, and the commandant is now feeling frustrated and alone. So the commandant (Manfred Krug) earmarks this prisoner, Jan Kominek (Stefan Kvietik), as his own personal plaything. Kominek is given special rations, training privileges and anything else that will leave him ready to take a beating in the ring.

title: For PC's, the Mouse Will Reign
description: In the world of the personal computer, the mouse is about to become king.

title: Housing Issue By Massachusetts
description: The Massachusetts Housing Finance Agency is offering $94.56 million of tax-exempt residential housing revenue bonds, with a maximum yield of about 8.185 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; J. Walter Thompson In Management Shifts
description: A new management group has been appointed for the Asia Pacific region by the J. Walter Thompson Company, said Burton J. Manning, the agency's chairman and chief executive officer. The move is in line with a policy of decentralizing management similar to a shift in the company's European region last month. J. Walter Thompson, a unit of WPP Group, is a $3.4 billion, multinational agency with 184 offices in 37 countries. A three-man team replaces Donald Thompson, 52 years old, who is retiring this year after 26 years with the company. He has been area director of the Asia Pacific region for seven years. Lee Preschel continues as chairman of Latin America/Asia Pacific, and the new group reports to him.

title: Passport Travel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said that effective Sept. 30 it sold one of the two branch offices it acquired in March. It said the office which was sold accounted for about $4,000,000 in sales for the March through August period, including $1,980,000 in its third quarter.

title: Baby Is Shot to Death
description: A 13-month-old Brooklyn boy was fatally shot last night when a revolver held by his 21-year-old uncle accidentally discharged, the police said. The child, Lorenzo Burton, of 765 Lincoln Avenue, East New York, was shot one in the face. The boy's uncle, who was not immediately identified, was being questioned early today. The baby and his uncle lived in the same apartment.

title: John Denver Canceled
description: Because of scheduling conflicts, concerts by the singer John Denver at Radio City Music Hall, scheduled for tonight and Thursday night, have been canceled. Ticket refunds are available at the Radio City Hall box office.

title: EASTERN SHUTTLE LIKELY TO BE SOLD TO TRUMP TODAY
description: The Texas Air Corporation will announce today that it has sold the Eastern Airlines shuttle to Donald J. Trump, the New York real estate developer, for more than $300 million, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Lessons
description: If anyone has any doubts that boys are different from girls, just ask a college registrar. Girls get better grades than boys in high school and go on to college in greater numbers. But boys get higher scores on standardized tests - a matter of some economic significance since tests scores are used to award thousands of competitive academic scholarships.

title: Florence E. Wall, 95, Authority on Cosmetics
description: Florence E. Wall, an authority on cosmetics, died Oct. 2 at the Carolton Chronic and Convalescent Hospital in Fairfield, Conn., after a long illness. She was 95 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Acadian Farmers Rediscover a Staple
description: FOR the first time in four generations, the Bouchard family of Fort Kent, Me., will not harvest potatoes this year. As the harvest begins in Aroostook County, it seems strange and a little disconcerting to Albin and Rita Bouchard, who were born and raised in this potato-growing country at the northern tip of the state. They are descendants of French colonists, many of whom were expelled by the British from their Acadian homeland in 1755.

title: Debaters In Jersey Turn Angry
description: Meeting in their first debate, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg and the Republican challenger, Pete Dawkins, attacked each another tonight with what seemed to be intense anger, involving emotions that have been simmering during months of bitter campaigning.

title: Sonoco Products reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: In addition to increased sales, the company said third-quarter profit was aided by the cost savings resulting from the consolidation of the acquisition of Boise Cascade Corp's consumer packaging division.

title: Dukakis Plan Improves College Loan Program; About That Interest
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Fall Victim to Big Plays Again
description: It seems that after each Giant game this season, certain plays have been singled out as the difference between victory and defeat.

title: After the Victory, Lions Raise Sights
description: ''We'll play them one at a time'' was all that Larry McElreavy, Columbia's football coach, would say last Sunday about the rest of the Lions' season. What he left unmentioned was that Columbia has a chance to win the Ivy League football championship this season.

title: Gibson Bunt Is Puzzling Move
description: Kirk Gibson made a remarkably rapid return to the Los Angeles Dodgers' lineup tonight, but no sooner did he appear in it than he made a remarkably eyebrow-raising play.

title: New Trend on Campus: Nonstop Public Reading
description: At 3:29 A.M., the elm-lined plaza fronting Princeton University's Firestone Library is dark, cold and crowded. Students huddled in ski jackets and under quilts listen intently as Ronald Extract, flashlight in hand, bends over a makeshift lectern to read page after page of Thomas Pynchon's novel ''Gravity's Rainbow.''

title: Cadet Who Became Ill in Police Training Hospitalized Again
description: One of several cadets stricken by a kidney ailment in police training last month re-entered the hospital today with intestinal bleeding, officials said.

title: Metro-North Police Division Is Demoralized, Report Says
description: The Metro-North police unit is a demoralized, chaotic agency in the midst of a crisis of goals, leadership and management, an independent report released yesterday said.

title: Green Tree Acceptance Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $7,212,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Rockingham Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company converted to public ownership July 31, 1987.

title: First Lady Calls Bushes To Offer Her Support
description: Nancy Reagan has called Vice President Bush and his wife, Barbara, to say she is ''very supportive'' of Mr. Bush's Presidential campaign and to deny reports that she is loath to turn the White House over to them, the President's chief spokesman said today.

title: Mortgage Bonds From Connecticut
description: The Connecticut State Housing Finance Authority is offering $195 million of housing mortgage revenue bonds through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton.

title: The 100th Congress's Sour Ending; A Flawed Approach to College Aid
description: Imagine a college aid plan that generously rewards parents who save, yet costs the taxpayers nothing. Sound too good to be true? Alas, it is. But under pre-election pressure to deliver the bacon without the calories, the Senate chose to believe what it heard and voted, 94 to 0, to attach Senator Edward Kennedy's education Savings Bond proposal to the catch-all ''technical corrections'' tax bill.

title: Burke's Shutout a Milestone
description: Sean Burke has played only 33 games for the Devils and he is already their career leader in shutouts.

title: Darling Vs. Hershiser
description: The National League pennant comes down to one game in Los Angeles tonight involving two starting pitchers who have won a total of 40 games this season but have failed to win or lose a game in the league championship series.

title: Realty South Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Study Says 53,000 Got Prison Furloughs in '87, and Few Did Harm
description: With Vice President Bush pounding Gov. Michael S. Dukakis almost daily on the issue of furloughs for prisoners, a new study has found that such a temporary release from custody was granted to almost 10 percent of the Federal and state inmate population last year.

title: Kohlberg, Kravis Withdraws Kroger Bid
description: Ending speculation that it might pursue a hositile takeover bid, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company today withdrew its unsolicited $5.03 billion bid for the Kroger Company. The giant supermarket company had rejected the bid from the leveraged buyout firm as inadequate four days ago.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The drunken-driving manslaughter trial of Bruce Kimball, the diver whose car killed two teen-age boys and injured six other people when it veered into a crowd Aug. 1 in Brandon, Fla., has been postponed until Dec. 12 at the request of defense lawyers. Kimball, who has been free on $10,000 bond, failed to make the United States Olympic diving team; he won a silver medal in platform diving in 1984 at Los Angeles. . . . Kim Gallagher, the 1984 Olympic silver medalist and the 1988 Olympic bronze medalist in the 800-meter run, has entered the Mercedes Mile race on Fifth Avenue Saturday. The only American woman to run faster than Gallagher at 800 meters is Mary Slaney. . . . Dale Ellis, a free agent who was an unhappy member of the Seattle SuperSonics last season, has signed a six-year contract with the club. . . . Rex Chapman, the Charlotte Hornets' top draft choice, has signed a multiyear contract with the team. (AP)

title: Other Side Assisted Judge's Daughter, Myerson Witness Testifies
description: A witness disclosed under cross-examination yesterday that a divorce lawyer for the estranged wife of Bess Myerson's companion had helped obtain an apartment for the daughter of Justice Hortense W. Gabel.

title: Cascade International reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Long Delays In Gathering Data
description: IT is nearly the middle of October and no one knows yet what happened to the economy in September. Only one major Government statistic has appeared so far, reporting that unemployment fell slightly last month (good news, perhaps), but fewer new jobs were created than in previous months (bad news, maybe).

title: Bridge
description: European teams continue to do well in the World Team Olympiad, with strong performances by Sweden, Austria and Italy in both events, and Greece scoring surprisingly well in the open event.

title: American Bank of Connecticut reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Police Add Computer To Arsenal
description: The 67th Precinct station house in Brooklyn could have been conjured up by a Hollywood director, from the telephones ringing off the hook to the gruff but kindly sergeant presiding over the hubbub from behind his high-altitude wooden desk. Below him, uniformed officers, some herding handcuffed suspects, thread their way past bewildered-looking complainants. Somewhere a radio is playing country music.

title: Gold Fields' Suit Warns on Oppenheimer Control
description: The hostile $4.9 billion bid by the Oppenheimer mining group of South Africa for Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. would create a monopoly in the world gold market and illegally restrain trade in the United States, according to an antitrust suit filed today by Gold Fields and companies associated with it in the United States.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Israeli measures have not worked to quell Palestinian uprisings in the occupied territories. As the disorders enter the 11th month, some in the military concede that the tough measures may add to the violence in the short run. Page A1

title: Review/Television; Facing Breast Cancer and One's Own Mortality
description: The 99 women and 1 man who agreed to be interviewed and to share their feelings on ''Destined to Live: 100 Roads to Recovery,'' an NBC special that will be shown at 10 o'clock tonight, have all had a glimpse of their own mortality. All have had breast cancer and have searched their souls for strength to go on. The message of this moving and emotional film is that they have won the battle. ''You cannot stay afraid all of your life,'' said Vonetta McGee of ''Cagney and Lacey,'' one of the breast cancer survivors interviewed in the film.

title: Electric Boat Workers Vote 4-Year Contract
description: Submarine builders at Electric Boat voted today to accept a new four-year contract, ending a 103-day walkout without achieving most of their demands. The vote was 3,752 to 1,822. ''I'm glad it's over,'' said Joseph Messier, president of the 10,200-member Metal Trades Council. Mr. Messier said the contract is unpopular with many members because it is almost identical to one rejected by union negotiators in August.

title: An Old Custom, Funeral Cakes
description: SPECIAL occasions of every sort feature food and funerals are no exception. In many cultures, there are foods that are customarily served after a funeral.

title: Gibson Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Interco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $11,943,000 for the quarter and $11,831,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $9,065,000 and $8,512,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Mosinee Paper Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest 9-month includes a one-time after-tax charge of $671,100 for the reconfiguration and restructuring of Sorg Paper Co., a subsidiary.

title: Putting the Books to the Test: A Professional Offers an Assessment
description: AS someone who takes food seriously, as an art, profession and pleasure, I judge a children's cookbook by these criteria:

title: The 400 Richest? Oh, No, Not for This
description: The Nouvelle Restraint, also known as the Nouvelle Austerity, rides again on the charity circuit. Or at least it did last night in the Plaza Hotel's Grand Ballroom, where 400 benefactors of the Literacy Volunteers of New York City showed up minus black tie to dance and dine on veal pot pie and ice cream snowballs.

title: Knicks Down Nets; Ewing Is Sidelined
description: The exhibition season is always a time for experimentation and it was no different tonight as the Knicks defeated the Nets, 112-102, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. It was the first of 95 National Basketball Association exhibition games.

title: Dr. B. Frank Polk Is Dead at 46; Expert on Epidemiology and AIDS
