description: Dr. B. Frank Polk, a leader in AIDS research who was a professor of epidemiology at the Johns Hopkins School of Public Health in Baltimore, died of a brain tumor yesterday at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He was 46 years old.

title: Samuel Morrell, Wine Merchant, 90
description: Samuel Morrell, founder of Morrell & Company, the Wine Emporium Ltd., died of a heart attack Sunday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: LSI Logic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Recalling Vietnam: Building Bridges on a Stage
description: Some came with old peace symbols from the 1960's affixed to their coats. Some came in full dress military uniform with Medals of Honor tied around their throats with powder-blue ribbons.

title: Algeria's Misfortune: 'One Quick Blow' From Oil
description: Thousands of young Algerians have thrown rocks and firebombs and clashed with the police over the last week to protest economic conditions that economists and diplomats say have been deteriorating for years.

title: 180 More Wild Horses Found Dead in Nevada
description: A ground search in central Nevada by the Bureau of Land Management has found 180 more wild horses slaughtered, bringing to 450 the total believed to have been shot to death bureau officials said today.

title: Bercor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-After a gain of $80,000 from a change in accounting principle.

title: Cyberoptics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Wayland Flowers Dies; Ventriloquist Was 48
description: Wayland Flowers, a ventriloquist who brought life to a cackling, off-color puppet named Madame, died on Tuesday, five weeks after collapsing on stage. He was 48 years old.

title: Political Memo; Analyzing the Electoral Vote: Does G.O.P. Have a 'Lock'?
description: Around this time every four years, Republicans begin speaking about ''the lock,'' and when they recite the words there is usually a gleam of knowing confidence in their eyes.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about a jury verdict against officers and directors of a Maryland savings and loan misidentified a California mortgage insurer in some references. It should have been identified throughout as the TMIC Insurance Company Inc. Although TMIC was formerly called the Ticor Mortgage Insurance Company, TMIC's parent, known by the one word Ticor, is not a mortgage insurer and is not directly involved.

title: Newmil Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A School Lunch Update
description: The Agriculture Department has a new school cafeteria cookbook that includes recipes, labor-saving tips and a little pizazz for the pinto bean.

title: Ursula Nordstrom, 78, a Nurturer Of Authors for Children, Is Dead
description: Ursula Nordstrom, the former publisher and editor in chief of juvenile books at Harper & Row, and an innovative force in children's book publishing, died of ovarian cancer yesterday at the New Milford (Conn.) Hospital. She was 78 years old and lived in Bridgewater, Conn.

title: Bonn Sets Credit Line For Soviets
description: West German bankers have completed arrangements for the largest Western credit line ever to the Soviet Union - a package worth $1.6 billion to help Moscow modernize its food and consumer goods industries.

title: No Sinking Feeling For the Dodgers
description: After producing nearly as many errors as hits, after leaving the victory champagne on ice and trudging back to the clubhouse, the Los Angeles Dodgers did not duck or hide tonight. No moaning, no groaning.

title: Reagan Due to Rule on U.S. Indictment of Marcos
description: Faced with conflicting recommendations from his advisers, President Reagan is due to decide whether to approve the indictment of Ferdinand E. Marcos, the former ruler of the Philippines, before the Presidential election, senior Administration officials said today.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Puerto Rico Infrastructure Financing Authority is tentatively offering $323.1 million of special tax revenue bonds through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: For Bush on the Campaign Trail, The Style Is First Sour, Then Sweet
description: At one moment, Vice President Bush sneers bellicose Clint Eastwood lines and calls his Democratic opponent's record ''immoral'' and ''insensitive.'' At another moment, he spins literate, compassionate visions of how he would gently but firmly lead the country.

title: Clerics in South Africa Urge Boycott of Segregated Vote
description: Leading South African churchmen, theologians and academics defied the nation's emergency laws today, calling for a boycott of segregated local elections nationwide.

title: Tyson Foods Bids For Holly Farms
description: Tyson Foods Inc., the nation's largest poultry processor, announced today that it had proposed to buy the Holly Farms Corporation for more than $1 billion. Holly Farms is a diversified food company with about 50 percent of its sales in chicken.

title: Joyce Purnick Is Appointed To the Times Editorial Board
description: Joyce Purnick, urban affairs correspondent of The New York Times, will join the newspaper's editorial board on Jan. 1. Her appointment was announced yesterday by Jack Rosenthal, editorial page editor of The Times.

title: KEY RATES
Prosecutor Vows to Sue 3 Advisers to Brawley
description: The Dutchess County prosecutor who was cleared last week by a grand jury of involvement in the Tawana Brawley case, said yesterday that he would go ahead with his planned slander suit against Miss Brawley and her advisers.

title: Westinghouse Electric Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bogus Perfume Is Charged
description: Police in Southern California have cracked a counterfeit perfume operation, seizing hundreds of thousands of phony bottles of such brand-name scents as Giorgio, Chanel, Poison and Joy, the San Bernardino, Calif., sheriff's department said.

title: Campaign Trail; Republican Flattered By the Other Side
description: With absolute delight, Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi told Mr. Dukakis yesterday, ''I think Joe Biden once said that imitation is the sincerest form of flattery.''

title: Ford Vans Recalled for Defect
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it was recalling about 103,000 Aerostar minivans and Bronco II and Ranger SuperCab trucks from the 1986 model year because of a defect in the underseat wiring. In addition to the Aerostar recall, Ford said it is recalling about 64,000 model year 1988 F-150, F-250 and F-350 pickup and other light trucks equipped with optional sliding rear windows, which may have been improperly tempered, Ford said.

title: For a Chicago 'Baseball Joint,' Extra Innings
description: Babe Ruth drank here - between innings, if the legend is true - and Bill Veeck threw his wooden leg across a stool and rhapsodized here for hours. And future baseball greats, it now appears, will get a chance to become part of the lore at McCuddy's saloon.

title: Senate Passes Tax Package That Includes 'Bill of Rights'
description: The Senate passed a package of miscellaneous tax provisions late tonight that include increases, cuts and a first-ever ''bill of rights'' to strengthen the hand of taxpayers involved in disputes with the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Lilco Makes Gains in Bid for a Permit
description: The Long Island Lighting Company today scored technical and political victories in its long struggle to win a commercial operating license for its Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Fanning the Flames of Conservatives
description: At the White House, in the twilight of the Reagan Presidency, departures of such high-profile figures as Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and Education Secretary William J. Bennett have tempered the fires of the Administration's conservative voices, except for one.

title: Lyons Transforms Role on Jet Defense
description: The thing that Marty Lyons is probably best remembered for in the last two years when it comes to the Bills' Jim Kelly is creating a new penalty in pro football: ''Giving him the business.''

title: Video Superstores of America Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $433,231 from an accounting change. c-Net loss

title: EATING WELL
description: IN February 1986, a Brown University student died after eating just two spoonfuls of chili in a Providence, R.I., restaurant. The chili contained peanuts, a food to which the student, Kate Brodsky, was severely allergic.

title: Futures Broker Cited for Fraud
description: GNP Commodities Inc., a Chicago-based futures brokerage that the Nomura Securities Company of Japan is in talks to purchase, has been charged with fraud, regulators said today.

title: A Conciliatory Tone Enters Albany Talks Over Shoreham Deal
description: Although Governor Cuomo and members of the State Legislature continue to oppose each other over the settlement to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant, both sides have recently adopted a more conciliatory tone that makes acceptance of the basic settlement appear increasingly likely.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on the Fashion page yesterday about Margaret Thatcher's interest in fashion referred incorrectly to her position. She is the head of government in Britain; Queen Elizabeth is the head of state.

title: Senator Says F.B.I. Pursued Anderson
description: A State Senator who is under indictment on mail and bank fraud charges said yesterday that two F.B.I. agents asked him to ''set up Warren Anderson,'' the Senate majority leader.

title: Book Notes
description: Books on TV ''Bookmark,'' a national weekly television series about books and authors, will be aired by PBS starting in January. Lewis H. Lapham, editor of Harper's magazine, will be the host of the 26-part series, which is being underwritten by the Bell Atlantic Corporation.

title: United Telecommunications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $7,333,000. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,691,000 and $5,396,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Year-ago 9-month includes a charge of $108.5 million in the second quarter from the writedown of assets.

title: Congressional Study Says Job Bias Cases Are Poorly Handled
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission failed to properly investigate as many as 82 percent of the claims of job discrimination it closed in a three-month period last year, the General Accounting Office reported today.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Mcorp Chief's Mission: To Keep Texan Control
description: LEAD: Although Gene H. Bishop, chairman and chief executive of Mcorp, lost the gamble that his Dallas-based banking group could outlast Texas's economic woes without Federal assistance, he remains a man with a mission.

title: 8 Are Hurt When Tanker Hits Car and Flips, Spilling Fuel
description: Eight persons were injured last night, none seriously, after a tanker truck carrying 3,000 gallons of gasoline collided with a car, overturned and caught fire in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Grenoble Journal; The Alps Won't Do; Mayor's Ambition Is Taller
description: Although locked in by steep mountains, Grenoble has always prided itself on being a few iconoclastic jumps ahead of the rest of France. It rebelled against Louis XVI one year before the revolution of 1789; it stoutly resisted the occupying Nazis when much of the country wavered or collaborated.

title: Dollar Declines Against Yen And Ends Flat Versus Mark
description: The dollar fell against the yen yesterday, reflecting a downward sentiment that has been overtaking the foreign exchange market since the vigorous summer rally peaked last month.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Carson Pirie Scott & Co., Chicago, the department store chain, elected as a director James A. Perkins, increasing the board to 12 members.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 12 ,1988
description: Companies

title: International Paper Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Edward Chodorov, 84, Playwright And Writer and Producer of Films
description: Edward Chodorov, a Broadway playwright and the author or producer of some 50 motion pictures, died on Sunday after a brief illness at his home in New York City. He was 84 years old.

title: Santucci Office Accused of Bias In Racer's Death
description: A Queens man went on trial yesterday on a charge that he had committed manslaughter by pouring oil onto a street to discourage drag racers, causing one racer to die when his car skidded into a tree.

title: Shunned Deal Maker
description: According to some in Washington's sizable circle of Middle East experts, a familiar figure has been feverishly pacing the sidelines in recent bouts of speculation over the release of Americans held hostage in Lebanon.

title: Meese's Final Slap
description: Look for Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to overturn or severely restrict an order signed by his predecessor, Edwin Meese 3d, that would have resulted in the appointment of special prosecutors to investigate members of Congress. An announcement of Mr. Thornburgh's action could come as early as next week.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Hawley Martin Halts Ford & Westbrook Bid
description: Hawley Martin Partners said yesterday its planned acquisition of Ford & Westbrook would not take place because ''the financial condition of Ford & Westbrook was not what had been originally anticipated.'' Both agencies had agreed in principle to merge late in August.

title: The Seam of Their Faces
description: CAME morning yesterday and the sun here reflected off the hills and the haze and the crawling cars on the swelling freeways. It was a day like most days in this City of Angels and 24 Dodgers. There was no rain and no prognostication of rain. This meant that the two major events in this country at this time - one annual, the other quadrennial - would not have to alter plans.

title: Judge Cuts Sentence in Corruption Case
description: A Federal judge yesterday reduced the prison sentence of Richard L. Rubin, once described as a ''power broker'' for the late Donald R. Manes, despite a prosecutor's assertion that Mr. Rubin, who is supposed to be cooperating with investigators, may not have told what he knows about political corruption.

title: Books of The Times; Obsessions With Money and Sex Bring Trouble
description: Are You Listening Rabbi Low By J. P. Donleavy 405 pages. Atlantic Monthly Press. $18.95.

title: Reaching the Peak
description: The subject of Howard Nemerov's first talk as the nation's Poet Laureate, given at the Library of Congress last week, was ''Poetry and Nonsense.''

title: Next P.L.C. to Sell Stores to Ratners
description: Next P.L.C., a British fashion retailer, agreed to sell 433 jewelry stores in Britain to the Ratners Group P.L.C. for about $232 million. The sale follows last year's bidding war between Next and Ratners for the Combined English Stores Group P.L.C., a retail chain that included the Salisburys and Zales jewelry stores. Next ultimately won the battle, paying about $:338 million, or about $581 million.

title: Ozawa Cancels
description: Because of the death of his wife's mother in Japan, Seiji Ozawa, music director of the Boston Symphony, will not be leading the orchestra's concerts at Carnegie Hall tonight and tomorrow night. David Zinman, music director of the Baltimore Symphony, will conduct. The program, which has been altered, will be the Chopin Piano Concerto No. 1, with Stanislav Bunin, a Soviet pianist, making his North American debut, and the Mahler Symphony No. 1.

title: Bentsen Says Bush Plays Politics With Crime
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen today accused Vice President Bush of ''playing politics with the tragedies of crime'' to win advantage in the Presidential campaign.

title: Dow Loses 2.49 Points; Trading Is Listless
description: LEAD: Stock prices pulled back in listless trading yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average, which on Monday edged up to its highest level since last October's market crash, fell 2.49 points to close at 2,156.47. The loss snapped a four-session winning streak for the blue-chip indicator.

title: Signed, Then Traded
description: In what was apparently a prearranged deal, the Sacramento Kings signed Otis Thorpe yesterday, then traded him to the Houston Rockets for two forwards, Rodney McCray and Jim Petersen. The 6-foot-11-inch Thorpe, the most coveted of the off-season restricted free agents, was one of five National Basketball Association players to average more than 20 points and 10 rebounds a game last season. Don Chaney, the Rockets' new coach, said, ''We wanted a player that would fit in with our philosophy of the running game and can also be a post-up player.'' In four seasons with the Rockets, McCray averaged 12.9 points and 6.6 rebounds. The 6-10 Petersen, injured much of last season, averaged 8.9 points in 69 games. (AP)

title: Athletics' Pitchers Are Forming a Batting Rotation
description: Two days after winning the American League pennant by completing an emphatic four-game sweep of Boston, the Oakland Athletics routinely returned to business today. They stretched, they hit, they talked continually into a crowd of notepads, microphones and television cameras. They also allowed their pitchers to grab bats and finally begin taking batting practice.

title: Review/Jazz; A Mixed Bag of 3 Bands
description: Last Friday's Superband concert at Town Hall, featuring three bands and an immense amount of talent, was a standard jazz spectacle. As in many of these shiny events - the stage was littered with odd, 70's-styled constructions of chrome and fabric, and there was a meager light show casting fragments of lights on stage - the music fought hard to escape the packaging.

title: Jay Journal; Paper Mill Strike Ends, But the Anger Remains
description: The pickets have left the mill.

title: Cup Yacht Detained by Cuba
description: New Zealand, the 132-foot sloop that failed in her challenge for the America's Cup last month, is now in a Cuban port after a gunboat intercepted a ship carrying the yacht from San Diego to New York.

title: India Opposition Parties Join In a Coalition to Oust Gandhi
description: A new opposition party was born in India today, the amalgamation of four often-squabbling groups whose leaders say they believe that in unity they can end the Nehru-Gandhi political dynasty.

title: U.S. Aides Express Concern Over Yugoslav Crisis
description: There was a moment, last Friday, when violent demonstrations in two regional capitals in Yugoslavia made United States policy makers apprehensive that the Communist leaders of that Balkan country were losing control.

title: S.E.C. Aide Assails Plan on Punishing Companies
description: Gary Lynch, the enforcement director of the Securities and Exchange Commission, yesterday voiced sharp criticism of proposed new Federal rules for punishing companies that violate criminal laws.

title: On a Safer Track
description: After weathering four years as director of the Interior Department's beleaguered Minerals Management Service, William D. Bettenberg has apparently had enough. Effective Oct. 23, he will take a secondary position at the agency, which has been the focus of Congressional investigations and press reports of alleged mismanagement.

title: PENTAGON LAXNESS ON CONTACTS SEEN
description: Congressional investigators say that when Melvyn R. Paisley was Assistant Navy Secretary he repeatedly met with officials of the Boeing Company, his former employer, although he had told the Navy he would not deal with the company.

title: U.S. Utility Planting 52 Million Trees
description: Concerned that its new coal-burning power plant in Connecticut will add to the trend toward a warming of the atmosphere around the globe, an electric utility has come up with an unusual response: it will pay to have trees planted in Guatemala.

title: Fab Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,800,000 from a change in accounting principle.

title: Dukakis Plan Improves College Loan Program
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman, 47, Dies in Car Crash
description: A 47-year-old woman was killed last night when a car and a truck collided at the intersection of Caton and McDonald Avenues in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn, the police said. The woman, Eva Romero, of 564 East 2d Street, Brooklyn, was in a car driven by Herman Rivera, 25, of 165 Park Hill Avenue on Staten Island. He was charged with driving while intoxicated.

title: Now, Make Peace Within Angola
description: Patient American diplomacy is now paying off in southern Africa. A further round of talks has brought new progress toward a peace agreement that would secure both Namibian independence and the withdrawal of Cuban forces from Angola. Details of Cuba's withdrawal schedule remain to be worked out. Yet the atmosphere is encouraging, and the Nov. 1 target for beginning the Namibian independence process could still be met.

title: Ditmar Loses Lawsuit
description: Art Ditmar, the former Yankee pitcher who was mistakenly identified in a beer commercial as having given up Bill Mazeroski's World Series-winning home run for the Pittsburgh Pirates in 1960, lost a bid to revive his lawsuit yesterday in Washington. United States District Court Judge Alice M. Batchelder, citing a lack of jurisdiction, let stand a ruling that wrongly being branded a ''gopher ball'' pitcher generally is not a serious enough matter to sustain a libel lawsuit. Ditmar, who retired as a major leaguer in 1962 and became a recreation director in Brook Park, Ohio, sued the beer company and the advertising agency for misidentifying him for throwing a pitch delivered by a teammate, Ralph Terry. In the original broadcast, Chuck Thompson, the announcer, incorrectly said Mazeroski hit Ditmar's pitch, and the original broadcast was aired in the commercial. Ditmar said the commercial held him up to ''undeserved ridicule, humiliation and contempt.'' He said it might have cost him appearance money for playing in baseball old-timers' games and charity golf tournaments. But Judge Batchelder ruled that Ditmar failed to provide more than speculation that the commercial had caused him any financial harm. (AP)

title: Algeria to Lift State of Emergency As Unrest Ebbs in Riot-Torn Cities
description: A state of emergency that included the use of the military will be lifted Wednesday morning, the Government announced tonight. Officials also said a 10 P.M.-to-6 A.M. curfew would be lifted.

title: Ryan's Family Steak Houses reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
Goddard Students Take Over Building
description: A group of Goddard College students occupied the school's administration building for nearly two days, but by late this afternoon most had left and the remaining protesters had narrowed a 26-item list of demands to two.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Raytheon Campaign
description: A new, multimedia campaign for the Raytheon Company by Della Femina, McNamee WCRS, a unit of WCRS Group, will break on national television Saturday and in national print Monday. Continuing the theme ''Quality starts with fundamentals,'' the new campaign has billings of about $8 million, or approximately the same as the previous campaign, also by Della Femina.

title: First Federal Savings PR reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $69,000 for the quarter and $200,000 for the 9 months.

title: Toyota Is Considering Another Plant in U.S.
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation is near a decision on building another assembly plant in the United States, one that would be used to produce light trucks, a senior Toyota official said today.

title: Lomas & Nettleton Mortgage Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Opera; Peter Sellars's Particular View of 'Tannhauser'
description: A serio-comic opera might well be composed about the rise and fall of a sexually prone, spiritually supine television evangelist in the 1980's. If so, Peter Sellars, with his talent for exploring the sleazy side of modern culture, would be an ideal choice as director. But, with no such contemporary opera at hand, he was forced to spend his energies on Wagner's ''Tannhauser,'' which takes place in 13th-century Thuringia. On Monday evening, Mr. Sellars struggled vainly to overcome that unfortunate circumstance in a new production for Lyric Opera of Chicago.

title: Bank Is Charged by U.S. With Money-Laundering
description: The Federal Government charged today that an international bank holding company had conspired with cocaine dealers to launder millions of dollars in illegal drug money in a network that reached from the United States to Europe to the Medellin drug cartel in Colombia.

title: Aspiring Congressmen Tough Out Jersey Races
description: In the three Congressional districts in New Jersey's southern counties, voters rarely reject an incumbent. This year challengers are having an even tougher time because of the competition for voter interest from the Presidential and United States Senate contests.

title: Serbs Spar With Slovenians, Adding to Yugoslav Tensions
description: Serbian Communist leaders replied angrily today to charges of Serbian nationalism made by Slovenian Communist leaders, as political tension rose in Yugoslavia before an important session of the Communist Party's Central Committee on Monday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Borden Inc. said it had acquired two plastic packaging manufacturers, Macaple S.A. of France, and Pelapack Plastics Pty. Ltd. of Australia. The company also said it had undertaken a $22 million expansion of its Texas packaging film plant. Terms of the acquisitions were not disclosed.

title: Rite Aid Head Taking Advantage of the Market
description: Sentiment might be expected to play a role in the latest investment move by Alexander Grass, chairman and chief executive of the Rite Aid Corporation.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about shutdowns of nuclear reactors at the Savannah River nuclear weapon production plant misstated the date that the Boston Edison Company shut its Pilgrim Reactor in Plymouth, Mass.

title: Johnson Is Charged
description: Ben Johnson, the Olympic sprinter who was disqualified for steroid use after winning the 100-meter run, was charged with assault and dangerous use of a weapon yesterday in Toronto. The charge came five days after a driver said a man pointed a handgun at him from a Porsche later identified as belonging to Johnson. The police later found a starter's pistol in Johnson's car. Johnson said he was driving his car at the time of the incident, but denied pointing a gun at another driver. Johnson is to appear in provincial court Oct. 25 on the charges, Sgt. Pat Tallon said. . . . Linford Christie, the sprinter who survived a drug test ordeal at the Olympics, said he deserved an apology from track and field authorities over the way he was treated at Seoul, South Korea. Christie, who received two silver medals at the Games, tested positively after the 200-meter final but was later cleared of any drug abuse. (AP)

title: Campaign Trail; A Nervous Wife Presses Her Issues
description: One person who will, most certainly, be at the debate is Kitty Dukakis, the wife of the Democratic nominee.

title: The 100th Congress's Sour Ending; 'Corrections' Worse Than the Errors
description: No tradition is more sacred to the final days of a Congress than loading up one last bill with irrelevant amendments that wouldn't stand a chance of enactment on their own. This year it's the so-called ''tax corrections'' bill. Originally intended only to rectify technical errors and unintended windfalls in the 1986 tax reform, it's now shaping up as the Christmas Tree Act of 1988.

title: Goodrich-Michelin
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company is negotiating the sale of its aircraft tire operations to the French tire maker Michelin for undisclosed terms. The companies said their talks included an agreement for aircraft wheel, brake and tire assembly operations, and a license for Michelin to use the Goodrich name and other trademarks relating to aircraft tires.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ASIAN cuisine has had a profound effect on Western cuisine in recent years. My own cooking repertoire incorporates many techniques and seasonings that were unheard of in classic French and American cuisine just 10 years ago. Our ideas about food textures and seasoning - pairing sweet and sour, hot and sweet, and so on -have evolved greatly with exposure to Eastern cooking.

title: Price Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Turnstile Thieves Get Revolving-Door Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: The Darker Side Of the 'Baby Blues'
description: ANN GREEN smothered her firstborn in 1980 and her second baby two years later, but the deaths were not considered suspicious until she tried to kill her third child.

title: Cone Stars as Mets Battle Their Way Into Game 7
description: With all of their oldtime talent for survival, the Mets drew back from the brink tonight when they defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5-1, and forced the playoff for the National League pennant into the seventh and deciding game.

title: Police Treat Youth's Death as Bias Case
description: A black Staten Island teen-ager died after being hit by a car Friday night, and the police said yesterday that he might have been chased to his death by a group of whites angered during an argument that began outside a bar several blocks away.

title: Shailer L. Bass, 82; Headed Dow Corning
description: Shailer L. Bass, a former board chairman and chief executive officer of the Dow Corning Corporation, died Sunday at Provincial House, a nursing home in Midland, after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: Brazil Acts to Slow Destruction of Amazon Forest
description: Faced with growing warnings from scientists and the threat of losing international funds, President Jose Sarney today announced a series of steps aimed at slowing the rapid destruction of the Amazon rain forest.

title: Pretoria Fire Hits Anti-Apartheid Catholic Office
description: A fire gutted two floors of a Roman Catholic office in Pretoria early today in what appeared to be a new wave of attacks against anti-apartheid organizations.

title: Alexander's Announces Another Sale of a Store
description: Alexander's Inc., the New York retailer that is more than 50 percent owned by the real estate developers Donald J. Trump and Interstate Properties, yesterday announced the sale of a second store within a week.

title: Giant Defense Is Falling Flat
description: Darryl Rogers, the coach of the Detroit Lions, made an interesting observation this afternoon when someone asked his impressions of the Giants.

title: No Warming Trend, Dukakis Aides Insist
description: No, no, no, no, the Dukakis aides say. There is no master plan to warm up the Massachusetts Governor, whose performance in the first debate was considered skilled but rather chilly by many reviewers.

title: Mixed Week For Yields
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money-market accounts and money-market mutual funds were mixed for the week ended yesterday.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Article 087688 -- No Title
description: Donald J. Trump, the real estate developer, agreed to buy the Eastern Airlines shuttle yesterday for $365 million in cash and said he would rename it after himself and turn it into a ''diamond.''

title: There's No Debate: The Format Works
description: LEAD: It's become almost compulsory these days to bemoan the format of national campaign debates. You know the patter -and you'll certainly hear it tonight - ''Why, it's not a real debate at all, but a joint press conference where intrusive journalists pose disconnected questions and the rigid time limits guarantee little more than canned recitations of carefully packaged positions.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air Wis Services Inc., Appleton, Wis., said it would not meet with Cove Capital Associates Inc., to discuss Cove's offer to acquire Air Wis for $16.36 a share.

title: Peruvian General Ousted
description: A Peruvian general was removed as commander of an important military region and retired for spreading rumors that the armed forces were plotting to oust President Alan Garcia, a senior military spokesman said today. He said the general, Victor Raul Silva Tuesta, was called to a special meeting of the army chiefs of staff on Saturday and relieved of his command of the First Military Region, which covers some of Peru's prosperous northern provinces.

title: An Arduous Hunt for the Missing in Vietnam
description: At low tide, the beach seems to extend all the way to the submerged wreckage of an American bomber shot down 20 years ago in a raid on this industrial port.

title: An Unasked Question, an Insufficient Answer in the Debates
description: To the Editor:

title: Laclede Steel Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said in the latest quarter and 9-month periods charges for excess of market price over grant price on its stock appreciation rights plans reduced net income by $35,000 and $1,379,000, respectively. The company also said in the year- ago quarter and 9-month periods charges for accruals to the company's wage and salary restoration of reduced net earnings by $84,000 and $420,000, respectively, and the 9 months also include a charge for costs of a special early retirement incentive for hourly employees reduced net earnings by $517,000. Share earnings results do not reflect a 3-for-2 stock split taking effect Oct. 21. Adjusted share earnings amounts after the split are $1.26, vs year-ago 22 cents a share for the quarter, and $3.28, vs year-ago 76 cents a share for the 9 months.

title: Sports People; Tyson's Hand Problem
description: Mike Tyson still has hand problems. His right hand, which he fractured in an August street fight with Mitch Green, was placed in a cast again Monday by Dr. Richard Rhodes. a physician in Orwell, Ohio. Rhodes said the August injury to the third metacarpal had not healed properly. ''The reason it hadn't healed,'' said Rhodes, ''was that Mike had taken the cast off on his own before he should have.'' Rhodes said Tyson appeared in his office Monday complaining that the knuckle on the hand was still swollen and sore. A source close to Tyson said that Tyson hurt the hand while hitting a heavy bag. ''We'll leave the cast on for two or three weeks and then take new X-rays,'' said Rhodes. (AP)

title: Joel Oppenheimer, 58, A Columnist and Poet
description: Joel Oppenheimer, a poet, newspaper columnist and college professor, died of lung cancer last Tuesday at his home in Henniker, N.H. He was 58 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the New York City Police Department's use of computers misidentified the commander of the 67th Precinct in Brooklyn. He is Capt. John J. Sullivan. A picture with the article was published in error. It showed the computer room at Police Headquarters, into which the precinct's computer is connected.

title: Bankworcester Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ford Taps Taiwan
description: The Ford Motor Company began exporting its Mercury Sable to Taiwan, making it the first car Ford has exported to that country. The Sable was selected to tap into the demand for larger cars in Taiwan, where most vehicles are compacts and subcompacts, Bob Day, a Ford spokesman, said. He said Ford is ''quite optimistic'' about its sales in Taiwan for 1989. ''We certainly feel we'll be able to sell in the thousands, rather than the hundreds,'' he said.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. title: Washington Talk: Government Consultants; Paying Physicists to Write Christmas Greetings
description: It should be no surprise to find a company called R&D Associates doing technical studies for the Government on ways to verify limits on underground tests of nuclear weapons. But should the company also be paid to write Christmas messages?

title: Plane Too Near Reagan Flight
description: Air Force One, with President Reagan aboard, and a 50-passenger regional airliner passed illegally close to each other yesterday about 50 miles southwest of New York, apparently because of an error by an air traffic controller, according to Government officials.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the dedication of the Lawrence A. Wien Center for Dance and Theater in Manhattan misidentified the woman next to Mayor Koch. She was Enid Morse, a daughter of Mr. Wien; Mrs. Peter Malkin is her sister.

title: TV Notes
description: Dr. Bellows Is Called

title: New Hope for Poverty Law
description: The Legal Services Corporation, created by Congress in 1974 to provide legal representation for the poor, has survived eight murderous assaults by the Reagan Administration. President Reagan has repeatedly asked Congress to ''zero out'' funding and abolish the program.

title: Health: Alcoholism; Drinking Problems Rise Among Young Women
description: Specialists say that a growing number of single, well-educated young women are seeking treatment for alcoholism, and that they are at greater risk of developing chronic alcohol-related diseases earlier than their male counterparts.

title: Two Polls Show Bush Is Ahead of Dukakis
description: Two new ABC News/Washington POst Polls released last night showed Vice President Bush with an overwhelming advantage over Michael S. Dukakis in the battle for the Electoral College but a modest lead for the popular vote.

title: Merrill to Revamp Pensions
description: Merrill Lynch & Company has decided to recapture capital from its pension fund, a move that will add about $200 million to its earnings in the third quarter, people close to the company said yesterday.

title: US Trust Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; World Color To Print Life
description: World Color Press Inc., one of the leading magazine and commercial printers, has signed a multiyear contract with Time Inc. to print Life magazine starting in January, 1989.

title: Mr. Bush Adopts Youth Service
description: Give Presidential candidate George Bush credit for taking up the colors of youth service, a cause that has waited too long for a champion.

title: LSI Logic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Music; Percussion in 3 Modes
description: Saturday night's concert at Aaron Davis Hall, at City College - the first event of a month's worth of events sponsored by the Caribbean Cultural Center - resounded with the sounds of drums. Three different groups, Babatunde Olatunji and his Drums of Passion, a trio of drummers from New Orleans and the Cuban percussionist Daniel Ponce, all lighted the stage in different ways.

title: Argonaut Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Latest third quarter results reflect a loss of $600,000 and the 9 months reflect a gain of $29.8 million both from the sale of investments. Year-ago third quarter and 9-month results reflect gains of $18 million and $29.4 million, respectively.

title: Africans at the U.N. Express Skepticism on Pretoria Moves
description: African foreign ministry officials warned today that a South African withdrawal from Namibia and renewed diplomatic contacts between South Africa and black African nations would not restore stability to southern Africa or improve Pretoria's standing on the continent.

title: Amcast Industrial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a pre-tax restructuring charge of $4.2 million for both the quarter and year.

title: Riggs National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago 9 months included $32 million in loan-loss provisions for loans to lesser developed countries.

title: Architect's Statements Writ Small
description: THE flock of architect-designed products continues unabated. The latest entries are from Louis Vuitton, which is introducing a series of watches and pens designed by the Italian architect Gae Aulenti.

title: MILITARY SUPPLIER FINED $115 MILLION ON FRAUD CHARGES
description: In what the Justice Department described as the largest fraud settlement in history, an Illinois aerospace company agreed today to pay fines and penalties totaling $115 million as it acknowledged a conspiracy to overcharge the Government on military contracts.

title: Cubans Release Cup Yacht
description: The Cuban Government yesterday released the ship that was transporting New Zealand, the unsuccessful America's Cup challenger, from San Diego to New York. The release came a day after the ship was ordered into a Cuban port by a gunboat.

title: Sports People; McCallum Traded
description: The San Diego Chargers acquired Napoleon McCallum, a running back, from the Los Angeles Raiders yesterday, completing a July transaction in which the Chargers sent Jim Lachey, a tackle, to the Raiders for John Clay, a tackle, and a draft pick to be named later. McCallum, 25 years old, a graduate of the Naval Academy, was picked in the fourth round of the 1986 draft after setting the Division I-A collegiate all-purpose yardage record of 7,122. He is fulfilling his five-year military obligation as a lieutenant junior grade assigned to a naval vessel. In 1986 he was able to play part time for the Raiders when he was stationed aboard a ship harbored at Long Beach, Calif. He is due to complete his service obligation in 1990. . . . David Robinson has petitioned the Navy, through Lee Fentress, his agent, for release from active duty before his two-year commitment is scheduled to end on May 17 so that he may join the San Antonio Spurs for the National Basketball Association season. Lieut. Ken Ross, a Navy spokesman, confirmed yesterday that the letter to William L. Ball 3d, the Secretary of the Navy, was re-ceived last Friday. Ball will appar-ently not act on the request until the 7-foot-1-inch Naval Academy gradu-ate makes the request himself, rather than through his agent.

title: Southeast Banking Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Last year's earnings were negatively impacted by an $85 million special provision for credit losses ($77 million net of tax credits) relating to loans to lesser developed countries.

title: Summit Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sports People; Hornets Sign Chapman
description: Rex Chapman, who was the top draft choice of the Charlotte Hornets of the National Basketball Association after scoring 1,073 points in his first two seasons at the University of Kentucky, signed a four-year contract yesterday worth $2.6 million after weeks of stalled negotiations.

title: Talking Deals; The Rich Auction For Tenneco Oil
description: DALLAS

title: Sports People; 49ers Settle
description: The San Francisco 49ers have agreed to pay the former defensive lineman Charles Krueger more than $1 million after being found liable for fraudulently failing to reveal the severity of his crippling knee injury, it was reported yesterday. The tentative settlement would dismiss the National Football League team's appeal of a judge's ruling ordering the 49ers to pay Krueger $2.36 million. ''We're disappointed, but if both sides are unhappy with the settlement then it's probably fair,'' said Krueger's lawyer, Clark Leslie. He confirmed general terms of the settlement reported yesterday by The Recorder, a legal newspaper. Krueger, now 48 years old, a mainstay of the 49ers' line from 1958 to 1973, ruptured a ligament in his left knee in 1963 and underwent surgery. A state appeals court ruled in February 1987 that the team never told him that a ligament was missing from his knee and failed to advise him of the risk he was running by playing in severe pain for the rest of his career. (AP)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 The U.S. will airlift food to the Sudan, breaking a deadlock between the Government and foreign donors of relief for Sudanese famine victims. The 10-day airlift will ferry wheat into the town of Abyei. Page A1

title: Judge in Case of Child Abuse Dismisses Some of Charges
description: The judge in the long trial of two people accused of sexually abusing children at the McMartin Pre-School dismissed more than a quarter of the charges today because three child witnesses refused to testify for the prosecution.

title: E.P.A. IS CHANGING HOW IT REGULATES PESTICIDES IN FOOD
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it was changing its rules on pesticide residues in foods in a way intended to reduce the overall threat of cancer to consumers.

title: An Unasked Question, an Insufficient Answer in the Debates; Bush Likable?
description: To the Editor:

title: How Laundering Is Said to Work
description: This is an example of one way money was laundered in the BCCI case, according to Federal officials. Step 1: Drug dealers in such cities as New York, Detroit, Philadelphia or Chicago contact undercover agents, who are posing as experts on money laundering, and tell them they have a pickup of one million dollars. Agents then pick up the money in cash and deposit it in a non-BCCI bank account in the desired city. Step 2: The agents, who are the depositors, ask the bank to wire the money to an account at BCCI in Tampa that had been set up for the operation. Step 3: The money is transferred by wire through a non-BCCI New York bank to BCCI headquarters in Luxembourg. Step 4: From there, the money is wired to BCCI in London, where it is placed in a certificate of deposit. Step 5: The certificate of deposit is used as the basis to generate a loan in the Bahamas to a phony corporation set up by the drug dealers. The money is wired from the phony corporation back into the undercover account in Tampa. Step 6: Money from Tampa is transferred by wire to the BCCI branch in Uruguay. Step 7: From Uruguay, the money is transferred as cash into Colombia.

title: Voters in the Two Camps: Where They Stand on the Issues
Gateway Communications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Ruling for Disney
description: A Los Angeles Superior Court judge today ruled in favor of the Walt Disney Company in permitting the entertainment conglomerate to use the MGM/ UA name and the company's lion logotype on a Florida studio tour that is expected to open next year. The MGM/ UA Communications Company, a unit of the Tracinda Corporation, which is controlled by Kirk Kerkorian, had filed a lawsuit against Disney in May for reportedly violating a 1985 agreement that permitted Disney to use its name, props and film clips for the studio complex and products but barred use of the name on hotels. Since the agreement, MGM/UA, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., underwent a management change.

title: Asset Agency Survives Vote
description: The House today refused to abolish the Federal agency that was created to manage and sell off assets of insolvent savings institutions.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; WPP Is Realigning Some Top Executives
description: WPP Group is realigning some of its top management in an effort to better coordinate its diverse holdings and strengthen itself in certain geographic areas, the company said.

title: European Bloc's Budget
description: The European Community Budget Commissioner, Henning Christophersen, said today that the 1989 draft budget would be some 2 billion European Currency Units, or $2.26 billion, less than projections. He said the revised budget would be presented in early November to the European Parliament, whose approval is needed, and to the decision-making European Community Council.

title: An Unasked Question, an Insufficient Answer in the Debates; Blank Bumpers
description: To the Editor:

title: 60th St. Water-Main Break Floods Subway
description: More than five million gallons of water burst through Broadway early yesterday from a 90-year-old high-pressure water main near Columbus Circle and immediately headed for the subway. The cascade flooded tunnels all the way to Queens with up to nine feet of water and affected virtually every subway line for the morning rush hour.

title: At Youth's Wake, Questions of Bias
description: As a wake and funeral were held yesterday for Derek Antonio Tyrus, two of his friends said their last memory of the black youth was of him running down Tompkins Avenue in Staten Island on a rainy evening and away from an angry white man, who demanded to know what black people were doing in the neighborhood.

title: Jarred by Riots, Algeria Proposes a Vote
description: Responding to economic and political unrest that culminated in a week of riots, President Chadli Benjedid tonight announced a three-point plan that could sharply reduce the ruling party's hold on power.

title: Caribbean Nations Say Drugs Imperil Stability
description: Caribbean area nations, which have long served as drug trafficking transit points, expressed concern at the United Nations this week about increasing threats to their stability from drug use and crime.

title: Sports People; Clearly, an Overdose
description: David Croudip, an Atlanta Falcons defensive back, ingested a fatal does of cocaine in one dose just hours before his death, according to a Georgia Crime Laboratory report released yesterday. The report, released to the office of Dr. Joesph L. Burton, Medical Examiner of several metropolitan Atlanta counties, said that Croudip's death Monday was definitely caused by an overdose of cocaine. Dean Browning, an assistant Medical Examiner, said the quantity found indicated the drug had been taken in one dose, and not over a period of time. Croudip died early Monday after he was taken to a suburban Atlanta hospital after he suffered seizures at his home. He was 29 years old. Earlier this week, Burton said lab tests indicated that cocaine was in Croudip's body. (AP)

title: Lawyer May Be Forced to Identify Client
description: The police know many facts about the hit-and-run death of Mark Baltes, whose body was dragged 60 feet when he was struck by a white Buick after midnight on March 9, 1986.

title: STRIKES CHALLENGE NEW PARIS PREMIER
description: A wave of strikes is posing one of the toughest challenges yet for France's Prime Minister of four months, Michel Rocard.

title: Treasury Prices Continue to Slide
description: Treasury note and bond prices weakened in light, nervous trading yesterday, pushed lower by a further drop in the dollar, falling oil prices and the increased prospect that new 30-year Treasury bonds would be sold in November.

title: Soviet Baseball Taking Its First Steps
description: The players of the D. I. Mendeleyev Institute of Chemical Technology baseball team, which opened a three-game tour of the United States with a game against Johns Hopkins University here this afternoon, have no nickname. A publicist searching for something suggested Mets, but so far the team has been simply called The Men. To little avail. Johns Hopkins trounced them today, a 16-0 no-hitter, at Homewood Field. In three games this spring in the Soviet Union, the Hopkins Blue Jays beat the Mendeleyevs by scores of 15-1, 15-2, and 20-3. But anyone looking for the Bad News Bears in this first-ever Soviet baseball team to visit the United States would have missed what was taking place right before their eyes.

title: Health; Personal Health
description: Even doctors who treat hundreds of people suffering from migraines find it difficult to fully describe the sickening, throbbing pain associated with the often incapacitating attacks.

title: Fine Homes International LP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago 9-month figures are not directly comparable because the company was wholly owned by Merrill Lynch & Co. through June 24, 1987. Share earnings represent limited partnership units.

title: Off the Beaten Path: Homes Flourish In Unusual Spaces
description: LEAD: FOR three artists living and working along the southern New England coast, the area's architectural heritage held little appeal.

title: Dodgers Win It as Hershiser Shuts Out Mets
description: Six months after they set out to ''dominate'' the National League, the Mets took the final tumble tonight to the Dodgers. Tommy Lasorda's ''team of destiny'' swept past them and won the National League pennant with yet another classic of shutout pitching by Orel Hershiser.

title: Century Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PARENT & CHILD
description: ''I NAGGED him,'' recalled Helene Berinsky, a book designer in Manhattan whose teen-age son was overweight. ''I watched what he ate and died inside every time he ate an extra cookie.''

title: Designers' Saturday: Chairs, Beds, Tables, Tired Feet
description: TOTING their shopping bags, a legion of design professionals - some 25,000, all told - descended upon New York last week for the annual four-day shop-till-you-drop marathon known as Designers' Saturday. For the event more than 300 manufacturers introduced new furniture designs for home and office in showrooms around the city. Dennis Miller Associates on West 21st Street presented the six-piece Clipper collection that the architect Alan Buchsbaum designed with Mark Litalien before Mr. Buchsbaum's death last year. Created originally for Mr. Buchsbaum's witty updating of the 1950's Catskills palace, the Nevele in Ellenville, N.Y., the overstuffed lounge chair (far right, about $2,500) has been scaled down for residences. (The furniture is available through architects and designers.) At the International Design Center in Long Island City, Queens, the visitors also admired new showrooms. The airy, stripped-down Vecta showroom, designed by Morphosis, a Los Angeles concern, displayed chairs behind narrow peepholes in a wall of rusted steel. Other chairs were suspended in midair over pools of water.

title: Trump Shuttle Head Delighted With Post
description: Bruce R. Nobles takes perhaps a special delight in being chosen to head the East Coast air shuttle operation purchased yesterday by Donald J. Trump from the Texas Air Corporation. It was only a few years ago that Mr. Nobles was president and chief operating officer of the Pan Am shuttle, a subsidiary of the Pan American Corporation.

title: Jersey Car Insurer Fees 'Pulled Out of Air' in '84
description: The fees and commissions that automobile insurance companies were allowed to collect for servicing New Jersey's Joint Underwriting Association when it began in 1984 were ''literally pulled out of the air,'' a member of a state study panel said today.

title: Corrections#YES#
description: An article in Business Day on Monday misstated the trading volume for a recent decline in the price of the stock of the Warner-Lambert Company. The stock fell $1.50, as 15,000 shares were traded.

title: Cremona in Texas? Professor Says His Violins Can Rival Stradivari's
description: Could it be that the ravishingly warm and woody brilliance of a well-played Stradivarius results not so much from the craftsmanship of Antonio Stradivari - by common consent the world's greatest violin maker - but from his phenomenally lucky choice of wood and varnish? And that the real credit for that hauntingly beautiful sound belongs to a bunch of microbes?

title: Defendant in Murder of an Officer Describes Queens Scene on Tape
description: One of four young men charged with the execution-style murder of a Queens police officer was heard yesterday on a videotape played in court graphically describing the slaying.

title: Using Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Court Allows Vote On Official Language
description: A Federal appeals court today bolstered Colorado's effort to place on the Nov. 8 ballot a constitutional amendment declaring English to be the state's official language.

description: Year-ago 9-month results are pro forma, representing the combined partnership and predecessor operations.

title: Dissension Faces India Party Just Hours After Formation
description: Within hours of its formation Tuesday, the People's Party, a new opposition grouping in India, faced dissension within its ranks about its name and platform.

title: Sinking Dollar Is Erasing Summer's Gains
description: The dollar fell sharply against the yen, the West German mark and other currencies yesterday, continuing a decline that has erased much of the gain from a summer rally.

title: Metro Matters; Taxpayers' Tale: Fighting to Fix A $20,000 Error
description: Jonathan L. Halperin and Michelle Copeland are doctors, which means their financial plight isn't likely to generate automatic sympathy.

The company also said share earnings for the prior year periods are restated due to the reduction of capital stock to be issued as the result of the expiration on Nov. 30, 1987 of the rights of all security holders of the debtor and, with certain exceptions, other claimants against the debtor to participate in the Plan of Reorganization.

title: As Nominees Shun Tax Issue, U.S. Panel Quietly Ponders It
description: Conventional wisdom about the 1988 Presidential race holds that after the new President, whoever that may be, takes office he will swallow his campaign oratory and ask Congress for a major increase in taxes, cuts in Social Security benefits and other brutal swipes at the Federal budget to reduce the deficit.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Spy Who Got Away
description: In the ''Where Are They Now?'' department, Edward Lee Howard, the man the Central Intelligence Agency trained for clandestine work in Moscow who then told the K.G.B. all he knew, says he has a bit of fresh information on Vitaly Yurchenko, the Russian who betrayed his secret three years ago.

title: Accord Possible On Redskin Park
description: Mayor Marion Barry said today that he would consider letting Jack Kent Cooke, the owner of the Redskins, build a parking lot for a new football stadium on 36 acres of the city's historic Langston Golf Course if a new 18-hole course is created that satisfies the golfers.

title: Review/Dance; Graham's 'Phaedra' and 'Errand Into the Maze'
description: According to Greek mythology, Pasiphae, wife of Minos, the king of Crete, was seduced by a bull and gave birth to the Minotaur, half man, half beast.

title: Couple Get Life for a Murder
description: An 18-year-old man and a 15-year-old girl pleaded guilty to murdering the girl's mother and were sentenced to life imprisonment yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. The man, Mario Garcia, got 15 years to life, and the girl, Andrea Williams, got 7 years to life. They admitted killing the mother, Adriennne Lomax, 44, with a machete and a knife because of her opposition to the couple's romance.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Big and Little Spenders
description: Representative Philip M. Crane, an Illinois Republican, is the taxpayer's best friend in the House, while Representatives John P. Murtha of Pennsylvania and Charles Wilson of Texas, both Democrats, are the most profligate with public funds, according to the National Taxpayers Union.

title: First Wachovia Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gateway Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Television; Scaling the Peaks of Adventure
description: Among the adventures celebrated on ''The Explorers: A Century of Discovery,'' tonight's National Geographic Society special, are Robert E. Peary's journey to the North Pole and Richard E. Byrd's flight to the South Pole; William Beebe's descent into the ocean in his bathysphere and Jacques Cousteau's visits with deep sea life; Jane Goodall's and Dian Fossey's investigations into the ways of chimpanzees and mountain gorillas; Edmund Hillary's and Jim Whittaker's climbs of Mount Everest; the opening of the tomb of Tutankhamun and the spotting of the wreck of the Titanic, and more.

description: Desperados Latin Drug Lords, U.S. Lawmen, and the War America Can't Win By Elaine Shannon Illustrated. 499 pages. Viking. $21.95.

title: Review/Music; Percussive Flute in 'Salsa Meets Jazz'
description: The flute may seem the least percussive of instruments. But in the Cuban music that gave rise to salsa, percussion is everywhere, and the flute punctuates songs with quick, sharp riffs and whistles. At the same time, it can send melody lines whizzing through the rhythm like the shuttle of a high-speed loom.

title: University Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Fiscal 1988 included a $299,000 investment banking fee for the pending sale of the bank. Fiscal 1987 included $4.6 million in loan loss and real estate owned reserves.

title: Walesa Says He Will Demand That Solidarity Be Legalized
description: Lech Walesa told a United States diplomat today that he would insist in negotiations with Communist authorities that the Solidarity labor movement be made legal again.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cell Technology Inc., Boulder, Colo., a biotechnology company specializing in immunotherapy, appointed its president and chief executive officer, W. Terrance Schreiber, to the additional post of chairman.
