title: Cardinal Blocked In Bid for Interco
description: A Federal appeals court Tuesday blocked a hostile $2.66 billion takeover bid for Interco Inc. just hours before the tender offer was scheduled to close. In ruling against the Cardinal Acquisition Corporation of Washington, the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit did not specify what judges would hear the suit filed by Interco, which argues Cardinal's bid was illegal. The ruling freezes the bid until a further decision is made.

title: Panel Warns Of Increase In AIDS Cases
description: Warning that 11,000 New Yorkers will have AIDS in 1991 and that up to 100,000 more will be suffering from related illnesses, the New York City AIDS planning agency is calling for a major overhaul and rapid expansion of medical and social services.

title: Tactics That Do and Don't Work
description: ''THE No. 1 mistake parents make when they have overweight kids is focusing only on their child's weight,'' said Dr. Kathie Jacobson, a psychologist at the Teen Age Medical Service in Minneapolis. ''There's a message that 'I don't love you the way you are. You'll have to change for me to love you.' ''

title: Stuttgart Orchestra To Give Two Concerts
description: Sir Neville Marriner will lead the Stuttgart Radio Symphony Orchestra in a concert at Avery Fisher Hall next Wednesday at 8 P.M., playing Haydn's Symphony No. 96 (''Miracle''), Beethoven's Symphony No. 2 and Elgar's ''Enigma'' Variations. Tickets are $23, $17 and $12. Information: 874-6770.

title: Legal Setback Is Seen for Pillsbury
description: In what could prove to be a setback for the Pillsbury Company, a Minnesota state judge is expected to rule Thursday that neither Pillsbury nor the British conglomerate trying to acquire it, Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., can take any action in their takeover battle before Oct. 27.

title: U.S. and Soviets Plan Joint Research Of Medical Problems
description: The United States and the Soviet Union plan to sign an agreement Thursday for joint research on AIDS, drug abuse and other medical areas.

title: CB&T Bancshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $4,460,000 after-tax gain on sale of the company's Georgia Co. subsidiary and an after-tax special loan loss provision of $3 million. The per share figures reflected a 3-for-2 stock split paid earlier this month.

title: Senate, in Effort to Save Drug Bill, Agrees to Consider 3 Amendments
description: The Senate today reached broad agreement on limiting the amendments that can be offered to major legislation to fight drug use.

title: The Northern Strategy
description: The great mystery of the 1988 campaign is this: What caused the Great Midsummer Turnaround?

title: In Midwest Hotels, Choose Igloos or Pharaoh's Tomb
description: FROM the outside, the Burnsville Royale Hotel looks like any other example of 1960's interstate-exit motel architecture: a flat roofed, two-story building surrounded by an asphalt parking lot.

title: E-Z-EM Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
Farmers' Agency In Stock Offering
description: The Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation, known as Farmer Mac, said yesterday that it intended to raise its initial financing of approximately $20 million through a common stock offering, probably during the week of Nov. 14.

title: Award Changes a Designer's Life
description: When Rifat Ozbek received the British Fashion Council's Designer of the Year Award from Margaret Thatcher at 10 Downing Street at the start of Fashion Week here, the Prime Minister asked him to make an acceptance speech. After a whispered consultation, she returned to the microphone. ''He says he just wants to say thank you,'' she reported.

title: Report Finds Region's Economy Is Booming
description: A year after ''Black Monday'' on Wall Street, the economy of the New York metropolitan region is bustling, with unemployment dropping and retail sales climbing, according to a report released yesterday by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Mayotte Defeats Drewett: Tim Mayotte of Boston beat Brad Drewett of Australia, 6-2, 6-4, yesterday to advance to the second round of the Australian Indoor championships at the Sydney Entertainment Center. Mayotte, seeded first in the 32-player tournament and the winner of the silver medal at the Seoul Olympics, won the Brisbane Indoor tournament last Sunday. In other second-round matches, second-seeded Andres Gomez of Ecuador beat a wild-card entry, Brett Custer, 6-4, 7-6, and Glenn Michibata of Canada downed John Fitzgerald, 6-4, 7-6. Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia, who was seeded fifth, beat Broderick Dyke, 6-3, 7-6, and Shuzo Matsuoka of Japan stopped Mark Kratzmann, 6-1, 7-6.(AP) Hockey Blues 4, Maple Leafs 2: Consecutive third-period goals by Brett Hull and Gino Cavallini gave St. Louis the victory at Toronto last night. Greg Paslawski and Todd Ewen also scored for St. Louis. Derek Laxdal and Gary Leeman scored for Toronto. Toronto had a 36-22 shots advantage but the work of the Blues' goaltender Greg Millen kept the score close. Leeman tied the score 2-2 at 13 minutes 26 seconds of the third period. Leeman passed to Ed Olczyk 20 feet from Millen, then dashed to the net to take a return pass and tip the puck under the cross bar. Hull gave the Blues the lead again when he slapped a low drive past Wregget at 4:40. Some digging by Bullard set up Cavallini's goal at 9:05 of the third. Bullard lugged the puck around the Leaf net, finally dumping it out front where Cavallini, parked at the crease despite being manhandled by Curran and Darren Veitch, shoved it past Wregget.(AP) Nordiques 6, Canadiens 5: Walt Poddubny scored twice, including the game-winning goal midway through the second period, as Quebec won at Montreal. The Nordiques, who had lost six straight regular-season games to Montreal dating back to last season, also had goals by Gaetan Duchesne, Paul Gillis, Joe Sakic, the 19-year-old rookie, and Peter Stastny. The Canadiens were held to only two shots at the Quebec goaltender, Bob Mason, in the third period. Mason, making his first start against Montreal in a Nordiques uniform, made 27 saves. The Canadiens, who trailed, 4-1, at one point in the opening period, finally made it 4-4 on Smith's second goal, at 2:13 of the middle period. But Peter Stastny whipped in a cross-ice pass by his brother Anton on the power play about four minutes later to restore Quebec's lead. Then, in an embarrassing turn for the Montreal defensemen, Chris Chelios and Craig Ludwig, the Nordiques moved ahead, 6-4, at 11:44. The Nordiques were about to be called for icing but neither defenseman made a move to touch the puck. It was left for Duchesne, whose shot was stopped by the goaltender Brian Hayward, but Poddubny scored on the rebound. (AP) Blackhawks 10, Jets 1: Denis Savard tied a club mark with a pair of short-handed goals and added three assists and Rick Vaive scored his fifth career hat trick as the Blackhawks won in Chicago for their first victory of the season. After having allowed the most goals this season (17), the Blackhawks scored four first-period goals, including three in just 1 minute 42 seconds to gain their first victory after two losses and a tie. The Chicago goalie, Darren Pang, who was replaced last Saturday after allowing five goals, was named to start in goal when Jimmy Waite came down with the flu. Pang stopped 35 shots as Winnipeg misfired on 11 of 12 power play opportunities.(AP) Sabres 8, Penguins 5: Dave Andreychuk, playing in his first game of the season, scored three goals and assisted on two others for Buffalo. The Sabres, trailing, 2-0, after the first period, came back with five goals in the second period to take a commanding lead. Andreychuk had been sidelined with a knee injury from the preseason. (AP)

title: F.B.I. ENDS INQUIRY ON BABY SWITCHING
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has closed its monthlong inquiry into charges of a 1978 baby swap at a rural hospital, having found no evidence that Federal laws were broken.

title: Relaxed Bush Camp Is Set for the Debate
description: Barbara Bush wore a Michael Dukakis mask.

title: Health; Military Testing for AIDS Is Found to Be Highly Accurate
description: The military program to test for evidence of the AIDS virus has been extremely accurate, misidentifying individuals as infected far less often than many critics had predicted, according to a new report.

title: Public Mistrust Curbs Soviet Nuclear Power Efforts
description: From Lithuania to Armenia, in the press and in the streets, the Soviet nuclear power industry is suffering from a phenomenon that used to be unimportant here: a mistrustful public.

title: A Corrupted Process
description: By talking with hundreds of voters, R. W. Apple Jr. of The New York Times has confirmed what we feel: Americans are disgusted with this election campaign. They are fed up with the mud-slinging and the failure to talk about the real issues facing the country.

title: INSIDE
description: Trump's Deal for Shuttle

title: Liberty National Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Federal National Mortgage Assn (FNMA) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Darling Bemoans the Missed Chances
description: The cruel truth that Ron Darling had to face tonight went beyond the fact that he was the losing pitcher in the seventh game of the National League Championship Series.

title: Alexander & Baldwin Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a credit of $18,269,000 representing cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Is 11-Year-Old a Genius, or Just Bright? Either Way, He's a Troubled Child
description: Agustin Eastwood De Mello likes to tell the story of how his son, Adragon, at 7 weeks of age, looked up at him and said hello. Other signs of Adragon's precocity followed, the father says. He could read and write at the age of 2. At 5 he joined Mensa and at 8 he enrolled in a community college near this seaside town, about 80 miles south of San Francisco.

title: New Hampshire Arrests Ex-Firefighter in Arson
description: A former volunteer firefighter was arrested today on suspicion of setting 16 of the blazes that have terrified this town since May, prompting residents to sleep in shifts and patrol the streets at night.

title: Haight-Ashbury Journal; Love and Hate Linger In Ex-Hippie District
description: It has been 21 years since the ''summer of love,'' when hippies walked the streets of the Haight-Ashbury District wearing flowers in their hair and pink and white buttons bearing the message ''Pooh loves you.''

title: Robin Kinkead, Journalist, 82
description: Robin Kinkead, a New York Times correspondent in Moscow in the early 1930's and later the first bureau chief in the Soviet capital for Reuters, died of emphysema on Tuesday at his home in Sacramento, Calif. He was 82 years old.

title: Rangers Put On Another Dismal Show
description: The demotions were made before the game. That, in a sense, was an advantage for Michel Bergeron, for had the coach of the Rangers waited until after his team played the Whalers last night, he might have never been able to reach a decision. There were, after all, an awful lot of new candidates to choose from.

title: Noriega Political Payments Reported by Indicted Banker
description: The international bank that was indicted on Tuesday for laundering money for drug dealers maintained an account for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega that made payments to Panamanian politicans, according to Senate testimony released today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Fires, deforestation, huge agricultural projects, gold mines and predatory development are destroying our flora and fauna. We must contain the predatory actions of man.'' - President Jose Sarney of Brazil. [ A6:1. ]

title: THE PLAYOFFS: How It Happened; For Mets, as Difficult as 1-2-3
description: Throughout history, empires and civilizations crumbled because their defenses collapsed. Tonight, in the civilized city of Los Angeles, the baseball empire the Mets have been building for five years crumbled because their defense collapsed.

title: Arrow Bank Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Editorial Notebook; Blacks and Tawana Brawley
description: It seemed obvious, long before a grand jury said so, that there was no substance to Tawana Brawley's story of gang rape by white law enforcement officers. Still, even after the grand jury reported last week, many blacks reacted with skepticism that bordered on denial of the panel's findings.

title: Burdick of North Dakota Runs Against G.O.P. and Age Issue
description: State Representative Earl Strinden, the 56-year-old challenger for the Senate seat held by 80-year-old Quentin N. Burdick, says he would rather not raise the ''age issue.''

title: Keystone Consolidated Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and includes a $197,000 tax credit.

title: Barnett Banks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mountain Apparitions By New Mexico Architect
description: ''LANDSCAPE APPARITIONS,'' drawings, sketches and photographs by Antoine Predock, an architect in Albuquerque, N.M., is at the John Nichols Gallery through Nov. 26. Above is a model of the American Heritage Center in Laramie, Wyo., conceived by Mr. Predock as an ''archival mountain in Marlboro Country.'' The works show Mr. Predock's interest in geological and Southwestern architectural forms, and gives clues to the germination of his ideas. The gallery, at 83 Grand Street, at Greene Street, is open Tuesday through Saturday, noon to 6 P.M.; 212-226-1243.

title: Affiliated Banc Corporation of Wyoming reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results for the latest periods reflected the effect of new accounting rules deferring fee income. The year-ago per share earnings are restated to reflect the effect of outstanding stock options.

title: In Boston, a Wasteland Is Now an Oasis
description: ''IT was devastated,'' said Tony Pangaro, an architect and urban planner, describing the Southwest Corridor when he took on the job of development coordinator. ''The houses were barely able to hold themselves up. There were clearings that looked like Berlin after the war.''

title: Hafts Seek Approval For Stake in Walgreen
description: The Haft family, the corporate raiders who have frequently gone after companies but have rarely taken them over, are now seeking clearance to buy $15 million or more worth of stock in the Walgreen Company, the nation's largest drugstore company said today.

title: Grain Pact Is Expected
description: Negotiators from the United States and the Soviet Union are expected this week to extend a multibillion-dollar accord under which the Soviet Union buys American grain, trade sources said today.

title: Boeing Jumbo Jet Deliveries Delayed
description: Deliveries of some of the Boeing Company's new 747-400 jumbo jets will be delayed by a month or so, Boeing Commercial Airplanes said. Dean D. Thornton, president of the Boeing operating company, said that of the 161 747-400's ordered by 21 customers, 20 planes would be delivered an average of one month past the agreed-upon date.

title: The Candidates and the Bomb Alarm
description: America's capacity to build nuclear weapons is disintegrating. Worried military planners contemplate cannibalizing their components. Worried members of Congress discover that the capacity to build them safely has eroded. And what is the response?

title: Sports of The Times; Johnson Looks to '89 With the Mets
description: IN the hours before the Dodgers won the National League pennant last night, Davey Johnson spoke openly for the first time of his desire to return as the Mets' manager next season.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: OUTDOOR equipment like patio and picnic furniture, barbecue grills, play items and tools will last longer and be more quickly available in the spring if it is cleaned, repaired and thoughtfully stored in the fall.

title: Mondale Rules Out the Idea Of Heading U. of Minnesota
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale said today that he had declined an invitation to be interviewed for the post of president of the University of Minnesota, a decision that disappointed his top supporter for the job, Gov. Rudy Perpich.

title: Indiana National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago 9 months included an after-tax provision of $15,180,000 for foreign loans.

title: Hitler Jokes No Bar to Funds
description: The University of North Dakota says it will accept a $5 million endowment from a Las Vegas hotel owner who threw parties for his employees on or near Adolf Hitler's birthday. The university said it had concluded the parties were meant only as a joke.

title: Tragedy, Comedy, Farce. Then Verdicts
description: Courtroom dramas have always made good plays. But this fall, the tables have turned and it is in the courtrooms on Centre Street and off Foley Square - not Broadway - where some of the city's best theater can be found.

title: William Allan, Labor Reporter, 81
description: William Allan, a labor reporter who was jailed as a Communist in the 1950's, died of a heart attack Monday at Kaiser Hospital in Oakland, Calif. He was 81 years old and lived in Oakland.

title: Justices Seem Unswayed by Civil Rights Debate They Sought
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on one of the major questions facing the Justices this term: whether to overturn its own 1976 landmark decision giving minorities the right to use a Reconstruction civil rights law to sue for private acts of racial discrimination.

title: Bard President Adds Chief Executive Title
description: Without ever attending medical school or putting in long hours as a resident, George T. Maloney has a good knowledge of what ails hospital patients and how to treat them.

title: These Mets Fans Weren't at Cheers
description: Like many bars and restaurants in the city, P. J. Clarke's on Third Avenue and 55th Street became very quiet last night around 9 o'clock. Mets fans hadn't even finished their first drink, and their team was already behind, 6-0.

title: Do I Look Like a Criminal?
description: LEAD: Every week, millions of television viewers are riveted to two popular docudramas - Fox Television's ''America's Most Wanted'' and NBC's ''Unsolved Mysteries.'' These programs show reenactments of crimes and then ask for information that might lead police to the criminals or suspects who were featured.

title: First Union Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dow Falls by 30.23 on Trade Deficit Fears
description: LEAD: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday amid growing concern about the nation's trade situation. The Commerce Department will report today on the trade deficit for August.

title: Bridge
description: Both American teams gained ground in the qualifying pools of the World Team Olympiad here today.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Meese's New Career
description: If you thought you had heard the last of Edwin Meese 3d, who resigned as Attorney General last summer, think again: He is starting a career on the lecture circuit today with an address to the Economic Club of Colorado in Denver.

title: Chip Indicator Posts a Decline
description: The Semiconductor Industry Association's leading indicator dropped to its lowest point in nearly two years today, as chip makers based in the United States, Europe and Japan reported an increase in shipments but a decline in orders.

title: Georgia-Pacific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago 9-month includes pretax gain of $66,000,000 from liquidation of investments.

title: CBS Posts 16.3% Gain in Net And Raises Dividend to $1.10
description: CBS Inc. yesterday raised its divi-dend while reporting a 16.3 percent increase in its third-quarter net income from the period a year earlier.

title: Studies Of Light, Weight And Glass
description: Glass offers the fascinating paradox of being simultaneously transparent while also being the medium of optical illusion. Glass sculpture that seems obvious in its form, clear in its imagery and firm in its colors may suddenly change when viewed from a different angle, revealing interior shifts that seem to have swum up from another dimension. The newest work of Mark Peiser is a model of just such magic.

title: Adtec Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Teacher, in Reversal, To Testify on Assault
description: A George Washington High School teacher who had declined to testify against a student charged with assaulting him has changed his mind, officials of the United Federation of Teachers said yesterday.

title: New Delhi Journal; Fantasy or Blasphemy? A Book Is a Burning Issue
description: The banning by Indian officials of a book they apparently had not read, on the advice of Moslem leaders who also had not seen it, has opened a debate troubling to many here about the political limits of free expression and the shallowness of religious peace in India.

title: NO VOTE EXPECTED ON CONTRAS' ARMS
description: The Administration and Congressional Republicans have agreed that there is little point in seeking a vote on rearming the Nicaraguan rebels before Congress adjourns, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, said today.

title: Refinishing Porcelain On Sinks and Tubs
description: ONE solution to improving your bathroom's appearance is to hire professionals who specialize in refinishing porcelain - including bathtubs, sinks, toilets and tile.

title: Central Park Has Phone Link to Police
description: A new telephone system in Central Park was dedicated yesterday, and city officials said it should help make the park safer.

title: Judge Orders Yonkers Parties Back to Court
description: The Federal judge in the Yonkers housing discrimination suit today ordered the parties in the dispute into court on Monday to explain why he should not designate an alternative to a site owned by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York for public housing.

title: Capitalizing on Penchant For French Furnishings
description: FOLLOWING the American penchant for things French, Grange, a French home furnishings manufacturer, opens its first retail store in the United States today at 831 Madison Avenue (69th Street).

title: Lindberg Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Year-ago 9-month includes a pretax charge of $5,677,000 with related tax benefits of $2,415,000 in connection with restructuring.

title: From State Dept., A Stand-In for Bush
description: The State Department says it is perfectly legal, but Abraham D. Sofaer, the department's legal adviser, and a former Federal judge, is in the midst of a quiet controversy anyway. Mr. Sofaer is appearing Monday in New York City as a representative for Mr. Bush, a somewhat unusual move for a legal official.

title: Ecology & Environment reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
First Boston Profits Up 2.2%
description: First Boston Inc. reported yesterday that earnings in the third quarter edged up 2.2 percent on a gain in revenues of 1.4 percent.

title: A's Not Finished With Their Work
description: One look at the dark, fiery eyes of Tony LaRussa or a view of the Oakland Athletics' workouts is enough to wipe out any notion the American League champions are settling into smugness before the World Series.

title: President Calls G.O.P. a Party For Democrats
description: President Reagan, campaigning through industrial regions of the Northeast, urged conservative Democrats today to ''come home'' this fall and vote Republican.

title: Health: Fetal Testing; New Tests to Provide Safer Screening for Down's Syndrome
description: Researchers say a set of three blood tests has proved highly successful in identifying women who are likely to be carrying fetuses with Down's syndrome, the leading inherited cause of mental retardation.

title: An Unasked Question, an Insufficient Answer in the Debates; Homeless Need More
description: To the Editor:

title: First Financial Management Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Getty Museum to Sell 8 Ancient Manuscripts
description: The J. Paul Getty Museum is selling eight ancient manuscripts, six of which date from before A.D. 900, at Sotheby's in London on Dec. 6, the auction house announced yesterday. Most of the manuscripts are Carolingian and all were acquired in 1983 as part of the Ludwig collection of 144 books.

title: Hershiser Passes Final Exam
description: From the beginning, back when he first signed with the Los Angeles Dodgers as the 17th selection in the 1979 free-agent draft, even back during those minor league dog days in Clinton, Iowa, and San Antonio and Albuquerque before he joined the Dodgers for good in 1983, Orel Hershiser had long been tabbed as a student of the game.

title: Gilbert Miller Haas, Investment Adviser, 76
description: Gilbert Miller Haas, an investment adviser and economic consultant, died of liver cancer Oct. 7 at his home in Key West, Fla. He was 76 years old.

title: New Plague For London: Graffiti Tags
description: Would you believe graffiti on the London subways? The London Underground would like you not to, and will spend $1.7 million this year trying to remove it as fast as it is sprayed on.

title: Southern National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
German Firm Is Rescued
description: One of West Germany's leading raw material and fuel trading firms was rescued today by the nation's largest bank after huge losses brought on by the recent oil price slide.

title: Israelis Blow Up Homes of Arabs
description: Israeli soldiers blew up four Palestinian homes and sealed five others today in reprisal for the killing of Arabs who had collaborated with Israel. Palestinians hurled a grenade at a troop bus but missed.

title: Soviets Promise Aid to Help Rebuild Afghanistan
description: The Soviet Union announced today that it would send food and other aid worth about 400 million rubles to Afghanistan, where its armed forces have been fighting for eight years.

title: CBS Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $866.6 million and a loss of $100,000 on extinguishment of debt. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $25.7 million and $85.9 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; a gain on the disposal of discountinued operations of $1.7 million and a charge of $200,000 from extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and 9 months. Year-ago results are restated for the disposal of the company's recorded music operations. In the latest 9 months the gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $866.6 million is based on financial information submitted by Sony Corp. and does not give effect to adjustments which may result from closing-date balance sheet contractual procedures.

title: Geordie Graham, 88, a Dancer With Denishawn Company, Dies
description: Georgia Graham Sargeant, a former leading dancer in the Denishawn company in the 1920's and a sister of Martha Graham, the modern-dance pioneer, died Tuesday in Tucson. She was 88 years old and had lived in Tucson for the last 10 years.

title: Former Church Janitor Admits Abducting Pair
description: A deaf former church janitor pleaded guilty today to charges of kidnapping and molesting two girls, keeping one in a dirt crawl space under the church's altar for as long as six weeks.

title: Noriega Political Payments Reported by Indicted Banker; U.S. Trap Is Described
description: By JEFFREY SCHMALZ

title: Shuttle's Value to Trump Tied to Profitability, Not Atlantic City Connection
description: In the 1990's of Donald J. Trump's dreams, a gambler will fly to Atlantic City on a Trump plane, place his wagers at a Trump casino and then move on to New York, also on a Trump plane, where he will stay in a Trump hotel and shop at Trump Tower.

title: Quayle, Free of Handlers, Is Going With His Instincts
description: For the first time since the early days of the campaign, Senator Dan Quayle seems to be his own candidate, doing things his way, going with the instincts he developed on his own in a dozen years in public life. He is suddenly spontaneous, available, confident, natural.

title: Peoples Bancorp of Worceser reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Why Cave Dwellers Could Forgo Dentists
description: To the Editor:

title: Sudan, Racked by Famine, Agrees To $100 Million U.S. Food Airlift
description: The Sudan has agreed to let the United States start a 10-day airlift of food to the famine-afflicted southern region, breaking an impasse between the Government and foreign aid donors.

title: Gordon Jewelry Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations $1,576,501 and $12,782,036 for the quarter and year, respectively. The loss for fiscal 1988 includes a pretax provision of $33,660,666 for asset writeoff and contingencies related to the bankruptcy of a debtor. The year-ago loss from continuing operations includes a pretax provision of $15 million for inventory valuation allowance.

title: Stumbling Through New York's Freedom of Information Thicket
description: To the Editor:

title: Myerson Trial Hears Judge's Daughter
description: Sukhreet Gabel testified yesterday that Bess Myerson offered her a job in the New York City Cultural Affairs Department a week or two after they met at a dinner party in June 1983.

title: First National Cincinnati Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After gains from accounting changes of $3,066,000 for the latest period and $4,297,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Q&A
description: Q. We are having a problem with mold and mildew on our bathroom ceiling. In the past we cleaned those areas with water and bleach, then painted with a latex paint. We also installed a small ceiling exhaust fan to get rid of steam when using the shower. Still, our problem with mold persists. Can you suggest a solution? A. When washing off the mildew, use one part bleach to four parts water, but mop this over the entire ceiling, not just the spots where mildew is visible. Let the solution dry on the surface, then rinse off with lots of water. When you repaint, use a paint that has extra mildewcide added, or add it yourself (many paint stores sell mildewcide or can order it for you).

title: Review/Opera; 'Trovatore' Cast Shifts At the Met
description: Saturday evening's ''Trovatore'' at the Metropolitan Opera served to introduce Dolora Zajick, an Oregonian mezzo-soprano new to the company, in the hard-to-cast role of the gypsy Azucena. It was immediately apparent that she will be a useful addition to the roster, and one looks forward to her appearances as Amneris in ''Aida'' next season.

title: F.T.C. Approves Kroger Store Sale
description: The Kroger Company received Government approval to sell 24 Florida Choice supermarkets and 24 liquor stores to Kash N' Karry for $55 million. The sale to Kash N' Karry - a supermarket operator based in Tampa, Fla., that Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen Ltd. has agreed to buy from Lucky Stores Inc. - is expected to be completed by Friday. The move, approved by the Federal Trade Commission, is part of Kroger's $4.6 billion restructuring plan designed to fend off two unwanted suitors.

title: House Passes Bill Aimed at Lobbying in Congress
description: The House of Representatives today approved a bill that would strengthen existing laws against lobbying by former high-level employees of the executive branch. The legislation, for the first time, would also place restrictions on lobbying by former members of Congress and former Congressional aides.

title: Entronics reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Market Place; Wall St. Studying Posner Holdings
description: WALL STREET analysts have long felt that trouble spells opportunity. And one of the next big opportunities, they say, will be the companies dominated by Victor Posner, the 69-year-old Miami industrialist.

title: First Federal of Michigan reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $952,000, or 9 cents a share, from the early retirement of debt for the quarter; the 9 months is after an extraordinary gain of $972,000. c-Included a gain of $3,010,000, or 27 cents a share, from the early retirement of debt for the quarter; the 9 months is after an extraordinary gain of $4,737,000.

title: KEY RATES
2 More Prison Barges Considered
description: Plans for two new prison barges, expected to house as many as 1,200 city inmates, are being considered by the New York City Board of Estimate.

title: Joyce Brown Makes Plea Deal in Drug Case
description: Joyce Brown, who successfully fought involuntary hospitalization last winter under Mayor Koch's drive to treat mentally ill homeless people, was conditionally discharged yesterday from Criminal Court in Manhattan after pleading guilty to a reduced charge of disorderly conduct in a drug-possession case.

title: Third Fire in 2 Years at Los Angeles Library
description: A fire broke out Tuesday in the basement of the downtown Central Library, where hundreds of thousands of books were destroyed in two 1986 blazes that were attributed to arson.

title: Astrosystems Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
First Boston Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Congress Agrees on Closing Bases But Leaves the Choices to a Panel
description: Torn between concern about the Federal deficit and fear of harm to states' economies, Congress today approved and sent to President Reagan a bill that gives a Pentagon-appointed commission the power to decide which obsolete military bases should be closed.

title: Carteret Savings Mortgage Notes
description: The Carteret Savings Bank is offering $85 million worth of mortgage-backed medium-term notes that are due in 1993 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Sobs in Court Over Horror Of Hijacking
description: One after another, the witnesses take their place at the table in the center of the brightly lit courtroom to wrest from time and trauma the memories of the terrible death of Robert Dean Stethem.

title: PARIS AND MOSCOW FORGING NEW TIES
description: After three days of talks, the Foreign Ministers of France and the Soviet Union today announced a thawing of relations between the two nations and said negotiations on cutting conventional forces in Europe would start by the end of the year.

title: College Football; The End Will Be a Factor as Penn State and Syracuse Meet
description: One of the East's traditional rivalries will have its 66th and next-to-last game Saturday night when Penn State (4-1) and Syracuse (4-1) meet at Beaver Stadium. Unfortunately for all concerned, including the fans, the rivalry is going to end abruptly in 1989 at Syracuse with much bad feeling between the schools.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Sports Magazine From ESPN
description: ESPN, the cable-television sports programming network, is getting into the publishing business with an advertiser-supported magazine called TV Sports.

title: Cherokee Group reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: The company said non-recurring expenses relating to the proposed acquisition of the company by Green Acquisition Co. reduced latest quarter net earnings by 3 cents a share.

title: The Return of a Computer Star
description: Steven P. Jobs is back. The personal computer industry's boy wonder, who founded Apple Computer when he was 21 years old, today introduced the new machine on which he hopes to once again ascend to the top of the computer world. And the machine drew some rave reviews.

title: 5 Television Channels Will Carry the Debate
description: The debate in Los Angeles tonight between Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis will begin at 9 o'clock, Eastern daylight time, and will be broadcast by five television networks: ABC, CBS, NBC, CNN and C-Span.

title: Campaigns Extend Battle to the Sea
description: Laughter reigned in Miami, too, as the Bush and Dukakis forces clashed by sea. The results were ambiguous.

title: Officials Cancel Bluebonnet Bowl
description: The board of directors of the financially strapped Bluebonnet Bowl voted Tuesday to cancel this year's game, scheduled for Dec. 31, and to try to begin again in 1989.

title: Ski Resorts Ready For Coming Season
description: FOR the fifth year in a row, ski resorts in the Northeast have made major investments in lifts and snowmaking equipment. Resort operators said new and replacement lift expenditures came to more than $21.5 million this year, new snowmaking capability cost $6.6 million and upgrading of current snowmaking equipment totaled $6.4 million.

title: Hilton Hotels Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Dance; Carolinians and Music Both Swirl
description: The music swirled. So did the dancers Tuesday night when the North Carolina Dance Theater opened a week's engagement at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street.

title: Top Officers Are Shifted In Emhart Revamping
description: The Emhart Corporation, a maker of industrial machinery, electronic components and consumer products, yesterday announced a reorganization of its operating units into three sectors corresponding to its three worldwide markets.

title: Koch Gets New Chef With a Flair for Sole
description: Mayor Koch began another chapter yesterday in his love affair with food: He hired a new chef, a 29-year-old who has worked in Manhattan at the Berkshire Place Hotel and Le Perigord-Park restaurant and has degrees from the New York Institute of Technology and the Culinary Institute of America.

title: Climate Improves for U.S.-Soviet Pacific Talks
description: To the Editor:

title: Ken Murray, 85, Vaudeville Star Who Later Recorded Hollywood
description: Actor and comedian Ken Murray, who spent more than a quarter century in vaudeville and in films, died yesterday in Burbank, Calif. He was 85 years old and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: Neworld Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Concert; Robert White's Lyric Tenor
description: Robert White is a singer of taste, subtle artistry and lovely tone whose gifts are consistently thwarted when he appears with orchestra. The much-recorded lyric tenor sang Monday evening with the New York City Symphony in Alice Tully Hall, and in certain soft phrases of Britten's song cycle ''Les Illuminations,'' for instance the rapturous ''Je danse,'' he was wonderful. But far too much of the time he just couldn't be heard clearly enough for any enjoyment.

title: Weicker and Lieberman Clash in Strident Debate
description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman sparred here today over each other's past support for tax increases, the politics of the columnist William F. Buckley Jr. and the legacy of the late Governor Ella T. Grasso in a contentious debate marked most, perhaps, by Mr. Lieberman's persistent attacks on the three-term Senator's attendance record.

title: Review/Theater; Exhuming Kafka, by Way of Brazil
description: In his previous work in New York, Gerald Thomas offered his own idiosyncratic interpretations of Samuel Beckett. Recently, in Brazil, he has been acting as author as well as director. In ''A Process,'' which opened a three-play repertory of his work last weekend at La Mama (and which will be repeated Oct. 27), Mr. Thomas takes off from Kafka's ''Trial'' and moves into unprofitable dramatic territory.

title: First City Bancorp of Texas Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The banking company was recapitalized in a $1.5 billion federally assisted rescue in April; thus, comparable results are not available. The 5-month period was from April 20 to Sept. 30.

title: State by State; Bush Has a Slight Lead in Arkansas
description: A rational man or woman would have ample reason to conclude that this state, a conservative bastion in a conservative region, will give Vice President Bush a healthy margin over Gov. Michael S. Dukakis next month. Glance around Pine Bluff, for instance. This is a place that proudly named its main traffic artery the Martha Mitchell Expressway after a favorite daughter, the garrulous wife of John N. Mitchell, the former Attorney General who went to jail for his role in the Watergate scandals. It is a place whose newspaper editor, Paul Greenberg of The Commercial, has become a noted small-town spokesman for conservatism.

title: Ballet Appointment
description: W. McNeil Lowry, former vice president of the division of the humanities and arts of the Ford Foundation, has been named president of the board of the San Francisco Ballet. Announcing the appointment Tuesday, Helgi Tomasson, artistic director of the company, described Mr. Lowry as ''one of the leaders in preserving and promoting American dance across the country and around the world.'' Mr. Lowry served with the Ford Foundation from 1953 to 1975. Since then he has become known as a commentator on the arts.

title: ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes gains from repurchase of long-term debt and an accounting change of $5,228,000 for the quarter and $11,292,000 for the 9 months. c-After gains from repurchase of long-term debt and an accounting change of $2,092,000 for the quarter and $3,543,000 for the 9 months. Year-ago quarter and 9-month results are adjusted for accounting change.

title: Bank of New England Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Holly Expected to Fight Tyson Offer
description: The battle of America's chicken suppliers has only just begun, analysts say. Tyson Foods Inc.'s $920 million bid for the Holly Farms Corporation would give Tyson a chance to expand as the nation's chicken processing superpower, but a fight is likely.

title: Crash That Kills Man Traps Widow 8 Days
description: A 77-year-old woman who survived a car crash spent eight days trapped in a ravine near her dead husband before being discovered by hikers, the authorities said today.

title: Calendar: Folk Art, Tours and Fall Fairs
description: From East to West, Sponsored by the Museum of American Folk Art; 212-481-3080.

title: Peary Notes Said to Imply He Failed to Reach Pole
description: New evidence based on navigational notes by Robert E. Peary indicates that the Arctic explorer fell short of his goal and deliberately faked his claim in 1909 that he was the first person to reach the North Pole, according to an analysis by a Baltimore astronomer and historian.

title: Attaching Felt Requires a Steady Hand
description: LEAD: At one time the use of felt (or green baize, a similar cloth) to cover the working surfaces of furniture was confined to the lining of cutlery drawers and the tops of card tables. There was the familiar Queen Anne style card-playing table, with scooped-out corner wells for chips or gold guineas: better tables were covered in baize, a more expensive, woven product, while felt, whose fibers are matted or pressed together, was used on cheaper models.

title: O'Neill Centenary: Celebrating the Master
description: This Sunday is the 100th anniversary of the birth of the American playwright who wrote ''In the Zone,'' ''Ile,'' ''The Rope,'' ''Where the Cross Is Made,'' ''Diff'rent,'' ''The Straw,'' ''The First Man,'' ''The Fountain'' and ''Welded.''

title: Trump City Site May Be Sold, Developer Says
description: In a deal that might seal the fate of one of New York City's largest tracts of prime real estate, Donald J. Trump, the developer, casino operator and corporate financier, has been negotiating the sale of 76 acres along the Hudson River on the Upper West Side.

title: Review/Television; 'Durrell in Russia': The Travels of 2 Naturalists
description: Last spring, the Arts & Entertainment cable network carried a charming mini-series called ''My Family and Other Animals,'' based on Gerald Durrell's best-selling account of his somewhat eccentric boyhood. In addition to being the brother of Lawrence, the novelist, Mr. Durrell is an internationally renowned naturalist.

title: Notes Totaling $500 Million Are Issued by Pennsylvania
description: Pennsylvania entered the debt market yesterday with a $500 million issue of tax-anticipation notes that were bid for by various securities dealers.

title: Baseball Notebook; Myers Joins Elite Of Relief Pitchers
description: When the season began, Randy Myers said he was the setup man for Roger McDowell in the Mets' bullpen scheme. Throughout the season, Myers said he was the setup man for McDowell. If one were to ask him today, Myers would say he was the setup man for McDowell.

title: Computer Data Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, an article in some editions yesterday about a debate between Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey and his Republican challenger, Pete Dawkins, misidentified a Rutgers University professor of political science. He is Gerald R. Pomper. The article also misidentified a company run by Mr. Lautenberg. It is ADP.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: JUSTICE Harry Blackmun of the Supreme Court says there is a ''distinct possibility'' that Roe v. Wade, which insured a woman's right to have an abortion, will be reversed this term. During the Presidential debate, George Bush says his credo is adoption, not abortion. Michael Dukakis wonders aloud whether the Vice President would brand a woman a criminal for having an abortion.

title: Newmil Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Poll Shows U.S. Voter Optimism Is Helping Bush in the Campaign
description: Voters are increasingly optimistic about the state of the nation and satisfied with President Reagan's performance, and they continue to be wary of government programs, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Rietveld, an Esthetic Wellspring
description: GERRIT RIETVELD'S Mondrian-like ''Red-Blue'' chair is no longer the only one of his designs that looks familiar. In a new exhibition, ''Gerrit Rietveld:

title: Big Surplus On Trade In Germany
description: Surging exports helped West Germany's trade surplus in August keep up a record-breaking pace, statistics released today showed.

title: U.S. Bills Chile in Killing of Letelier
description: The Reagan Administration has demanded that the Government of Chile pay $12 million in compensation for the killing of Orlando Letelier, the Chilean exile leader assassinated here in 1976, but Chile recently rejected the request, Administration officials said today.

title: For New and Old Independent Films, An Archive and Exhibition Center
description: If there is a patron saint of independent film making, Jonas Mekas is the man. After more than three decades of making, exhibiting, reviewing, collecting and preserving avant-garde movies, the 65-year-old Lithuanian-born director of Anthology Film Archives realized a longstanding dream yesterday, when the new home for his archives opened on the Lower East Side.

title: Vatican Moves To End a Protest By Jersey Nuns
description: The Vatican has assigned a special delegate to help resolve a dispute between five cloistered Carmelite nuns and their mother superior over modernizing their austere way of life in a monastery in Morris Township.

title: 2 Plead Not Guilty in Killing
description: Two men charged with the 1983 murder of a New York producer who was trying to finance a movie, ''The Cotton Club,'' pleaded not guilty Tuesday in Municipal Court. The defendants, William Molony Mentzer and Alex Lamota Marti, are accused of shooting to death the producer, Roy Radin.

title: American Mobile Systems reports earnings for Year to June 30
Corrections
description: A listing on Synday in the Long Island Weekly gave an incorrect day for the season premiere of the Long Island Philharmonic. The concert is Saturday at 8:30 P.M. at Hauppauge High School.

title: Review/Film; 'Madame Sousatzka,' Or, Life Through Music
description: Madame Irina Sousatzka (Shirley MacLaine) is a magnificent relic, the kind of creature who can be found only in the memories of her most devoted students, or else on the movie screen. A woman like this would be at a disadvantage in the real world, but Madame barely acknowledges the real world at all. She lives solely for music, surrounded by photographs of great pianists and educating a hand-picked group of prodigies, to whom she gives homemade cookies and imparts her own brand of wisdom. ''I teach not only how to play the piano, but how to live,'' says she.

title: Walbro Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $22,000 and $195,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; the 9 months also include a gain of $440,000 from a change in accounting. Share earnings for the year-ago periods were restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in August 1988.

description: The company said the year-ago 9-month includes a net gain of $9,802,000 from the sale of Hygeia Sciences Inc. common stock and an after-tax loss of $7,123,000 on the sale of two wholly owned subsidiaries.

title:
About Real Estate;
A Plan to Give a New Feel To an Old Gimbels Site
description: LEAD: The closing of the Gimbels East de-partment store in December 1986 went largely unlamented by the neighborhood's residents. From the start, the giant retailer and its boxy 12-story building, which occupied almost half the block north of 86th Street between Lexington and Park Avenues, were viewed as out of character with the area.

title: Russell Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Levine, Huntley Wins An Eveready Account
description: The Eveready Battery Company of St. Louis has called on Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver to introduce Lithium-plus, a new AA-sized battery scheduled to go on sale early next year. The budget has been estimated as high as $15 million.

title: Poland Names New Officials to Bolster Economy
description: After failing to bring people outside the Communist realm into his Government, Poland's new Prime Minister today presented a new team of ministers to tackle the country's economic problems.

description: The Government lost a two-and-a-half-year battle today to stop three London newspapers from publishing excerpts from a former intelligence agent's memoirs.

title: Pentagon in Favor of Starting Reactors of Energy Agency
description: A prolonged delay in restarting nuclear weapon reactors could jeopardize national security, Pentagon officials said Wednesday. They expressed relief at an announcement by the Energy Department that it planned to resume production of tritium early next year.

title: How to Turn Oxford Into a Moneymaker
description: To the Editor:

title: From 'Balzac of Egypt,' Energy and Nuance
description: Critics sometimes call Naguib Mahfouz the Balzac of Egypt because of the way his works express the pulsating energy of city life and because of their psychologically nuanced characters and broad social concern.

title: Our Towns; He Offers Trash To Town, but Is It Grateful? Nooo!
description: Many fear garbage. Not Dennis Greenwald, supervisor of this Catskills town of 10,000. He's looking for tons of high-quality, out-of-town garbage. ''Two years I was going to conferences, everyone was saying, 'Garbage, garbage.' No one knew what to do with it.'' Mr. Greenwald thought, ''I'll take your money; bring it to Mamakating!'' It's a rural town with plenty of land.

title: Ethics Panel Plans Hearings And Pressure in Last Weeks
description: Five months before it is due to go out of business, the New York State Government Integrity Commission still has ambitious plans for holding more public hearings, publicizing at least two more areas of potential corruption and active lobbying of the Governor and legislative leaders for laws that would make commission proposals into realities.

Mahfouz: Clarity Is Good, But So Is Ambiguity
description: Naguib Mahfouz attributed his winning the Nobel Prize today to hard work, good luck and a French translation of his trilogy about Egypt before and after Gamal Abdel Nasser's revolution.

title: Felix Wankel, Inventor, Is Dead; Creator of Rotary Engine Was 86
description: Felix Wankel, the inventor of the rotary engine for automobiles that bears his name and of other automotive and aeronautical equipment, died Sunday at his home in Lindau, West Germany, on Lake Constance. He was 86 years old.

description: Michael Venezia, a 43-year-old jockey who was planning to retire at the end of this year, died of massive head injuries yesterday when he was kicked by a horse after a spill in the fifth race at Belmont Park.

description: Perhaps like the Claude Rains character in ''Casablanca,'' James A. Baker 3d says he's ''shocked, deeply shocked'' about chicanery under his nose.

description: LEAD: Stock prices rebounded yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 7.12 points, to 2,133.36.

description: In 1984, employees of the Sundstrand Corporation destroyed an internal report and memorandums suggesting that the Illinois aerospace company knew that its billing of the Pentagon for cost overruns was illegal, according to the company's plea agreement with the Government.

description: It doesn't arrange photo opportunities or kiss babies, and it won't debate. Yet to many New York politicians, it is the most significant item that will appear on the ballot next month.

The company also said the Ecusta division contributed $52,743,000 in sales and $4,195,000 of net income for the third quarter of 1987; in the year- ago 9-month the division contributed $84,127,000 in sales and $6,725,000 of net income.

This Team Flattens Opponents
description: Watching the broadcast of the American League Championship Series, I remember hearing Reggie Jackson sum it up pretty well. The Oakland Athletics just got rolling, he said, and whoever got in their way was run over. They were steamrolled.

description: WSNS-TV, Chicago's largest Hispanic station, will defect from the Univision Network when its contract expires at the end of the year and join the Telemundo Network, both parties confirmed yesterday.

description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday offered a $40 million issue of consolidated notes due to mature on Oct. 1, 1990, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

description: Dr Pepper is dropping its iconoclastic image to portray itself as a soft drink for conformists. New commercials by Young & Rubicam, beginning during the World Series Sunday, will keep the two-year-old slogan, ''Just what the Dr. ordered,'' but will feature mainstream characters in mundane situations.

The action means that the right fielder cannot become a free agent, but it does not mean that the Yankees might not attempt to trade him. Winfield would have to approve any trade.

Sunday, at the Katie Murphy Auditorium, Pomerantz Center, Fashion Institute of Technology, 27th Street and Seventh Avenue. Tickets: $20. Information: 704-2100. Information: 355-6100, extension 215. STORIES AND POEMS, a program by Ted Pugh, a storyteller and actor, 2 P.M. tomorrow, at the Rudolf Steiner School, 15 East 79th Street. Sunday, sponsored by the Clark Garden auxiliary of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, at Clark Garden, 193 I. U. Willets Road, Albertson, L.I., adjacent to the railroad station. title: Special-Effects Show
description: Industrial Light and Magic, the visual-effects branch of George Lucas's film company, Lucasfilm, will blow its own horn tomorrow and Sunday with special-effects demonstrations and lectures at Florence Gould Hall, 55 East 59th Street. Technicians will demonstrate the effects used in the transformation scene in the movie ''Willow,'' and the techniques used to merge live action and animation in ''Who Framed Roger Rabbit.'' They will also discuss and demonstrate special effects in television commercials. There will be a question and answer period. The show is at 6 and 8:15 P.M. tomorrow and at 2 P.M. on Sunday. Admission is $20. Information: 355-6105.

title: Forty-Two Catholic Churches Without a Prayer

title: Nicaraguan Faults U.S. but Sees Better Ties

The Museum of Modern Art is the last stop on a tour that has included the Art Institute of Chicago and the Philadelphia Museum of Art - the show's joint organizers - and the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles.

description: A Westchester County contractor who testified last summer for the prosecution in the Wedtech trial pleaded guilty yesterday to state charges that he failed to report more than $8.5 million in personal and corporate income from 1984 to 1986.

title: Sundstrom to Miss Devil Home Opener
description: The Devils will appear before their home fans Friday night for the first time since the euphoria of last spring.

title: Review/Theater; 'Obscurity' Dishes The Dirt
description: At ''A Chorus Line,'' audiences quickly come to hate Zack, the faceless director who must decide the fates of the nice, vulnerable, talented performers begging him for work. At the new play presented by Playwrights Horizons, the audience learns what it's like to be the dread Zack. ''Saved From Obscurity'' is a 90-minute ''Chorus Line''-style confessional monologue in which an obscure New York actor, Tom Mardirosian, tells all about his life and career. Unlike the director in ''A Chorus Line,'' we can't give the performer before us a job, but it is in our power, if we wish, to reward him with enthusiastic approval. ''Saved From Obscurity'' is an unsung player's audition for fame.

title: Chiat/Day and Yamaha End Their 11-Year Tie
description: Chiat/Day Los Angeles and the Yamaha Motor Corporation will end their 11-year relationship at the end of the year.

title: Review/Concert; David Zinman Steps In
description: David Zinman, whose own Baltimore Symphony is on strike, has become the favored substitute of the moment. He stepped in with the New York Chamber Symphony last weekend, and this week he replaced Seiji Ozawa at the Boston Symphony's three concerts in Carnegie Hall.

title: Competition In Fashion Magazines
description: MARYBETH RUSSELL loves fashion publishing. And if she has her way, she will turn Taxi and Model magazines into the same high-fashion successes that she helped create at Elle, where she was publisher during that magazine's first three years.

title: Top Legal Post Filled At American Exchange
description: The American Stock Exchange said yesterday that it had named Gordon L. Nash, a partner in the New York law firm of Lord Day & Lord, Barrett Smith and longtime outside counsel for the exchange, to the post of senior executive vice president for legal and regulatory affairs.

title: Compromise Is Nearer on Tax-Corrections Bill
description: Leaders of the House and Senate tax-writing committees said today that they had made good progress at reaching a compromise on legislation that will make technical corrections and other changes in the 1986 tax law.

description: A four-year, $1 billion campaign to fight cancer began Wednesday night at a gala black-tie concert-dinner-dance in the glittering new space of the Winter Garden. The campaign, Stop Cancer, is the creation of Dr. Armand Hammer, who is chairman of President Reagan's cancer panel.

Dukakis quarreled last night over which of them was responsible for the shrill tone of the Presidential campaign, while trading sharp words on Social Security, abortion, military policy and the basic values that each would bring to the White House.

description: Year-ago 9-month share earnings are not applicable; the company converted to stock onwership form in Jund 1987.

description: Steel imports rose again in August, helping increase total shipments for the first eight months of the year to 14.4 million tons, 12.7 percent above the same period last year, the American Iron and Steel Institute said today. Exports reached 139,000 tons for the highest monthly total since September 1982.

description: The duo of Joanne Brackeen on piano and Cecil McBee on bass is to perform tonight and tomorrow at Bradley's, 70 University Place (228-6440). Music begins at 9:30 P.M.; there is a $5 cover and an $8 minimum.

description: Results of the Apparel division of Sportsotron Inc. are included from its acquisition effective Aug. 1, 1987.

description: ''The Kiss'' is the story of a jet-setting Cosmo cover girl (Joanna Pacula) who is actually the essence of evil incarnate. This distinction, it turns out, is not as sharp as one might think.

description: In a procedural change with far-reaching implications for Italian public finances and Government stability, the lower house of Parliament put an end today to a 140-year tradition that had enabled its members to vote in secrecy on virtually all important matters.

title: Bruno Annoyed
description: Frustrated by a seemingly unending string of postponements of his heavyweight championship bout against Mike Tyson, Frank Bruno said yesterday in London that he was ''getting fed up with all the delays.'' ''Tyson is either breaking his hands, smashing his car or having a divorce and I can tell you it's getting me down a bit,'' said Bruno, 26 years old, the challenger, who has weathered three official postponements because of Tyson's physical and personal problems. ''I know he is champion, but he is not God and it's time he got his affairs in order.'' The fight is scheduled for Dec. 17 at Wembley Stadium in London. The crowd will be limited to 24,000 in a stadium that can accommodate 100,000 people.(AP)
