description: ''The Explorers: A Century of Discovery,'' a National Geographic Society special that was scheduled for broadcast yesterday at 9 P.M. on Channel 13, was pre-empted by the debate between the Presidential candidates. The program has been rescheduled for tomorrow night at 7 o'clock.

title: Thaddeus Dulski, 73, an Ex-Congressman
description: Thaddeus J. Dulski, an accountant and a former eight-term Congressman from the Buffalo area, died of leukemia Tuesday at the Roswell Park Institute in Buffalo. He was 73 years old and lived in Buffalo.

title: Aero Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Solution in Sinai
description: To the Editor:

title: China Fights Corruption
description: China said today that it planned a review of thousands of state companies as part of a campaign against corruption. One trading group said it was the subject of a financial overhaul.

title: Chemical Banking Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After nonrecurring gains of $40.4 million from settlement of a portion of the company's pension obligations and a net gain of $23.3 million relating to the divestment of certain non- strategic businesses. c-Net loss and after a $135 million pre-tax special charge associated with the decision to restructure operations at Chemical Bank and certain other subsidiaries, for the quarter and 9 months; the 9 months also reflected the $1.1 billion special addition to the allowance for loan losses made in June 1987 for loans to countries engaged in debt rescheduling and a related $80 million deferred tax benefit writeoff.

title: Automatic Data Processing Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Southington Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Auctions
description: Americana Rarities

title: Vermont American Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Moscow Names Kabul Envoy
description: The Soviet Union appointed a top Foreign Ministry official as Ambassador to Afghanistan today, apparently signaling a determination to assert more control over developments in Kabul as Soviet troops withdraw.

title: Tokyo-Pretoria Trade
description: Japan's trade with South Africa declined by 5.5 percent in the first nine months of 1988, as Government efforts to curb activity with Pretoria began to have an effect. Finance Ministry data released today showed that exports and imports involving South Africa fell to $3.1 billion in the period.

title: Best Club Didn't Win Pennant
description: With all due respect to the Los Angeles Dodgers, the best team in the National League isn't playing the Oakland Athletics in the World Series.

title: Brenco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Officer's Killing 'a Message to Police'
description: One of four men charged with killing a rookie police officer in Queens said on a videotape played in court yesterday that the order for the execution-style murder came from a jailed drug dealer to ''send a message out'' to the police.

title: Gateway Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Three Bands Whose Rock Is Their Own
description: Some rock bands try to be consistent, forging a group sound and working variations on it as the years pass. But in the 1980's, when everything from fashion to art to television commercials revels in incongruities, some innovative rockers have demanded just as much flexibility for their music. They're not waiting for a single style to gel; their styles depend on sudden change and enigmatic juxtapositions, on asymmetry and sonic whiplash. While the result can be a noisy hodgepodge, more and more bands are piecing together rock like a crazy quilt, unpredictable but somehow coherent. Three of those bands are in town tonight: Antietam and Run Westy Run at CBGB and the Pixies at the World.

title: Lucian C. Warren, Journalist, 75
description: Lucian C. Warren, a Washington journalist, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Issue, Md. He was 75 years old.

title: Klima Reinstated
description: The Detroit Red Wings yesterday reinstated the left wing Petr Klima, who was suspended for disciplinary reasons last month by Coach Jacques Demers. Klima will report to Adirondack in the American Hockey League, General Manager Jimmy Devellano said in a statement. Klima, who defected from Czechoslovakia, was suspended without pay Sept. 23 after he missed practices and team planes, including one that was to have taken him to Adirondack. Last Sunday, Klima was arrested in Royal Oak, Mich., and charged a day later with operating a vehicle under the influence of alcohol. It was his second alcohol-related arrest in 17 months. (AP)

title: Art People
description: Things-in-Themselves

title: Dining Out Guide: Town-House Dining
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Brive

title: Caci International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Badger Paper Mills reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Congress Passes Compromise AIDS Bill
description: Congress, in its first comprehensive effort to combat the AIDS epidemic, passed legislation today sharply increasing both money and personnel for research and providing speedier assessment of new drugs. But the compromise measure deleted a key section assuring confidentiality for patients whose tests for the disease showed they were carriers.

title: Review/Film; Animated Works From All Over
description: Any film that sends vicious M & M's candies skittering up a human foot as if they were African ants and that sets Che Guevara twirling in dance with the Statue of Liberty deserves a livelier title than ''The 21st International Tournee of Animation.'' The latest in this annual series of short animated films is full of wit, sophistication and visual energy - the best way to escape the listlessness and self-importance such anthologies are prone to. These film makers graciously take their technical finesse for granted, and allow the audience to lose itself in the split-second, magical transformations that are the soul of animation.

title: No Progress Reported as Two Koreas Meet
description: South and North Korean delegations met for the first time since the Olympic Games today, but failed to make progress in their efforts to find ways to reunite their divided land.

title: Metro Datelines; 109 Suspects Seized In L.I. Drug Sweep
description: Nassau County police in a pre-dawn raid yesterday arrested 109 people, including a 13-year-old boy, for selling drugs to undercover officers during a four-month investigation in Hempstead, law-enforcement officials announced.

title: Italian Stake By Kidder
description: In an attempt to position itself for the dismantling of trade barriers within the European Community, the Kidder Peabody Group Inc. said yesterday that it had invested in an Italian merchant bank and its investment banking unit.

title: Bank of New York Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Washington Talk: Briefing; Community Growth
description: After doubling its membership to 12 countries, the European Community is again turning expansionist, this time in the United States.

title: For Dancegoers, A Trip Around The World In Three Days Of Performances
description: SOONER or later, the world comes to New York City. Or so it seems this weekend, when a far-flung group of dance and dance-theater companies descends upon the city. Not that there will not be enough home-grown dance to satisfy stalwart hometown boosters. But the accent is on visiting companies, from the itinerant Korean performing troupes at the Asia Society and the National Dance Company of Senegal at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, to the Tulsa Ballet Theater at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College, as well as an act or two that could pass for extraterrestrial at the Danspace Project Benefit '88 at St. Mark's Church.

title: 2d New Hampshire Man Arrested In Series of Arson Fires in 3 Towns
description: The police today charged a teen-age volunteer firefighter with setting one of a series of fires that have frightened his neighbors for months. A former volunteer firefighter was charged in the case Wednesday.

title: Clowns for Children
description: As part of its series of live entertainment for children, the Triplex performing arts center of the Borough of Manhattan Community College, 199 Chambers Street, is to present a program called ''Clowning Around'' tomorrow at 11 A.M. and again at 1 P.M. Two clowns, Olaf and Flipper, will use pantomime, storytelling and the European circus tradition in their act. The show is intended for children ages 4 and up. Subsequent shows will include flamenco, folk songs, giant puppets and African folk tales. Tickets are $5; a 10-show subscription reduces the price by 25 percent. Information: 618-1980.

title: Review/Jazz; Re-examining Rhythm
description: Evan Parker, the English saxophonist and early advocate of free improvisation, came to the Knitting Factory on Tuesday night and turned technical exercises into art. Mr. Parker is a virtuoso; for his first two pieces, he used a circular breathing technique - where an instrumentalist draws in air and expels it at the same time - to keep compositions going, without a break, for up to half an hour.

title: Plant Manager Steps Down
description: The manager of the Savannah River Plant has taken a leave of absence for medical reasons pending his retirement, according to the E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, which operates the nuclear complex. A company spokesman, Jim Felder, said there was no connection between the departure of the plant's general manager, John T. Granaghan, 59 years old, and problems with the plant's reactors. John T. Lowe, director of the Savannah River Laboratory at the plant, will succeed Mr. Granaghan as general manager.

title: Merrill Lynch & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflects an after-tax gain of $100.3 million related to the sale of the company's right to acquire a partnership interest in the south tower of the corporate headquarters at the World Financial Center. The latest third quarter consisted of 14 weeks of operations, compared with 13 weeks for the year-ago period.

title: A Star Replays His Greatest Role
description: At a closed meeting yesterday morning, more than 100 Democratic legislators and aides warmly welcomed Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas to the chamber of the House of Representatives. Since his ''You're no Jack Kennedy'' retort to Dan Quayle in the Vice-Presidential debate, Mr. Bentsen has emerged as a Democratic star.

title: U.S. Will Study Corporate Payments of Taxes to Panama
description: The Treasury Department will investigate American companies that are said to be violating a Presidential directive to pay taxes owed in Panama into special United States escrow accounts, senior Administration officials said today.

title: American Realty Trust Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $62,000 for the quarter and a gain of $172,000 for the 9 months, both on the sale of properties. c-Includes tax benefits of $4,551,000 and $1,802,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9-month also includes a gain of $238,000 on the sale of properties.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
VW of America Chief To Head Autolatina
description: LEAD: Volkswagen of America said yesterday that Noel Phillips, its president and chief executive since 1982, has been named president of Autolatina, the joint venture formed last year in Brazil and Argentina by Volkswagen A.G., which has a 51 percent stake, and the Ford Motor Company.

title: Allied Bankshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included net securities gains of $437,000, or 8 cents a share, for the latest period and $512,000, or 10 cents a share, for the year-ago period.

title: Bank Sets Plan To Help Stock
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation, the Chicago bank rescued from collapse in 1984, announced a series of moves today aimed at increasing its stock price. The company proposed a 1-for-4 reverse stock split and plans to raise its dividend, establish an employee stock ownership plan, broaden its stock option plan and change its name to the Continental Bank Corporation. In a press conference today, Thomas C. Theobald, Continental's chairman, said the dividend increase, to 5 cents a share from 2 cents, could facilitate a public offering of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's 69 percent stake in the company. But he added, ''Independent of who owned the shares, we would have made the same decision.''

title: Penn Central Wins Republic American
description: The Penn Central Corporation will buy the Republic American Corporation for $249 million. Penn Central, a telecommunications company and military supplier, which already owns 14.3 percent of Republic American's common shares, said it would pay $15.75 a share in cash to buy the remainder of its 18.4 million shares outstanding.

title: Ad Official Retires at Time; New Marketing Post Filled
description: Time Inc. yesterday announced the retirement of Richard B. Thomas, the senior vice president of advertising for its magazine group, and the appointment of Donald M. Elliman Jr. to the new post of executive vice president for marketing.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a gain that Merrill Lynch & Company is expected to take because of a change in its company pension plan misstated the timing.

title: Guarantees on Bailouts Stir Fears in Congress
description: As Congress begins examining the recent string of billion-dollar rescues of insolvent savings institutions, some legislators fear that Federal regulators are committing the Government to debts far larger than imagined.

title: Review/Film; Silence, Crime and Complicity
description: ''The Accused,'' written by Tom Topor and directed by Jonathan Kaplan, makes a persuasive case for the proposition that witnesses who encourage a crime are as guilty as the perpetrators. In this case, the crime is a gang rape, committed in the back room of a crowded bar late on a boozy night. The victim is a sexily dressed young woman, not entirely sober and a little high on marijuana, who, as everybody says, ''asked for it.''

title: Dividend at Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would maintain its dividend of 60 cents a share despite analysts' expectations that it would raise it to as much as 75 cents. A Ford spokesman had no comment on when the company might increase its payout. Analysts said the auto maker, which has $10 billion in cash on hand, could easily afford 70 or 75 cents.

title: Owner Will Sell His Nazi Relics
description: Following a public outcry, a hotel owner who has a collection of Nazi memorabilia says he will sell them rather than put them on display.

title: Barry's Jewelers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Church Says Shroud of Turin Isn't Authentic
description: The Roman Catholic Church announced today that the Shroud of Turin, venerated by millions of Christians over the centuries as the burial cloth of Jesus, could not be authentic because new scientific tests show that the linen dates from the Middle Ages.

title: The Law; Federal Court Rules Challenged After 50 Years
description: Dissatisfaction is growing among lawyers, judges and scholars over the 50-year-old rules that make up the foundation of the Federal court system.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Alysheba-Bet Twice, Round 9
description: Alysheba and Bet Twice, Bet Twice and Alysheba. It doesn't have quite the ring of Affirmed and Alydar, and neither does their long rivalry, which will go into its ninth round tonight at the Meadowlands.

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT SURGED IN AUGUST TO $12.2 BILLION
description: The nation's trade deficit climbed sharply in August, to $12.2 billion, as both imports and exports reached record levels, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: S.E.C. Investigates Pillsbury Trading
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating trading in the stock of the Pillsbury Company prior to the announcement that Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. was bidding for the company, Pillsbury said. On Oct. 4, Britain's Grand Met bid $60 a share for the food and restaurant conglomerate in a transaction that values Pillsbury at $5.23 billion, causing a one-day rise of more than $18 in Pillsbury's shares. Pillsbury disclosed in court papers that it had been notified by the S.E.C. of the investigation.

title: Burnham Pacific Properties Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The latest 9-month includes a one- time charge of $221,000 for merger expenses.

title: Congress's Lid on Lobbying
description: Both the Senate and House of Representatives have passed bills limiting their members' lobbying after they leave government. But the measure, which would finally make Congress subject to limits it imposed on the executive branch, requires swift compromise between the weaker House bill and the Senate's stronger version. The close of the session approaches, but failure to complete action on this issue would be unconscionable.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied-Lyons P.L.C., the British brewing conglomerate, announced plans for a joint venture with Japanese whisky maker Suntory Ltd. to increase sales of Allied lines in Japan.

title: Pepsico Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
description: b-Includes a one-time pretax loss of $9.4 million for the quarter on the sale of a winery in Spain; the 9 months include a one-time after-tax reorganization charge in domestic soft drinks of $10.4 million. c-Includes a one-time pretax charge of $8 million for the reorganization of Kentucky Fried Chicken's domestic operations. d-Includes a $1.3 million loss from discontinued operations, an $11.5 million loss on the disposal of discontinued operations, a one-time after-tax gain of $18.5 million, or 7 cents a share, on sales of certain foreign bottling operations, pizza restaurants, and a U.S. cookie plant. Year-ago quarter and 9-month amounts have been reclassified to report under the equity method of accounting certain bottling operations contributed to joint ventures at year- end 1987.

title: Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $31,541,000 and $67,036,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a gain of $44,992,000 on the sale of securities for both periods. c-Includes a tax credit of $10,562,000 and $40,594,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9 months also includes a charge of $149,700,000 from an accounting change. d-Net loss

title: Merrill's Net Slides 66.4% In 3d Quarter
description: Merrill Lynch & Company reported yesterday that third-quarter earnings had fallen 66.4 percent as higher revenue from investment banking failed to offset lower commission revenue.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; McLaughlin Times Two
description: John McLaughlin's PBS television program ''One on One'' will have as a guest this weekend his wife, Labor Secretary Ann Dore McLaughlin. Mr. McLaughlin explained: ''We made a deal. She does 'One on One,' and I have to host a Cabinet spouse tea.''

title: Poll Finds Antipathy Toward Some AIDS Victims
description: The public overwhelmingly expresses general sympathy for people who have AIDS, but for many Americans that sympathy does not extend to AIDS victims who are homosexuals or intravenous drug users, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Crestar Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflects an $8.1 million pre-tax charge for severance and retirement benefits. c-Reflects an $18 million special loan loss provision taken in the second quarter primarily against Latin American debt.

title: Malfunction Seen as Cause of Zia Crash
description: Experts sent to Pakistan to investigate the plane crash that killed President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq have concluded that the crash was caused by a malfunction in the aircraft, and not by a bomb or a missile, Administration officials say.

title: The Law; An Office on Wheels for Lawyers in a Jam
description: What sends documents over a facsimile machine, has cellular telephones, makes copies and honks?

title: A Murder Trial That Shocked England
description: Public television's ''Mystery'' begins a new season this weekend not with a standard whodunit, but with the recounting of a murder trial that scandalized England in 1935. ''Cause Celebre'' was written a decade ago by Terence Rattigan, a playwright long taken with the dark underside of British gentility (''The Deep Blue Sea,'' ''Separate Tables''). His play has been adapted for Anglia Television by Ken Taylor (''The Jewel in the Crown''); the first part of ''Cause Celebre'' will be broadcast tomorrow at 9 P.M. on Channel 13.

title: For Some, Shroud Is Still Inspirational
description: The Shroud of Turin has probably received more widespread and intense attention in the last 90 years than in all of its long history as the reputed burial cloth of Jesus. It was not popular enthusiasm, rumors of visions or reports of miracles that accounted for this modern interest, however. It was science.

title: Tulane Returning To Conference
description: Tulane University, which withdrew from the Metro Conference in 1985 after a point-shaving scandal in its men's basketball program, was reinstated to the conference today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The nation's trade deficit climbed sharply in August, to $12.2 billion, as both imports and exports reached record levels. The Commerce Department's trade report, which was somewhat worse than expected, was the last one to be issued before Election Day. It came on the day of the Presidential debate between Michael S. Dukakis and Vice President Bush and prompted a fresh exchange of charges by Democrats and Republicans over one of their most divisive economic issues. [ Page A1. ] The Treasury Department will investigate U.S. companies that are said to be violating a Presidential directive to pay taxes owed in Panama into special United States escrow accounts, senior Administration officials said. [ D2. ] Congressional leaders decided that the House would not pass broad new legislation this year to give banks expanded powers to underwrite securities. [ D2. ] The House and Senate tax-writing committees made progress at reaching a compromise on legislation that will make technical corrections and other changes in the 1986 tax law. [ D2. ] Sales of new American-made vehicles rose 31.5 percent in the first part of October from a year earlier. [ D3. ] COMPANIES Sundstrand employees destroyed an internal report and memorandums suggesting that the aerospace company knew its billing for cost overruns on military contracts was illegal, according to Sundstrand's plea agreement with the Government. [ D1. ] Hospital Corporation of America received a buyout offer of $51 a share, or roughly $4 billion, from its management. [ D1. ] Merrill Lynch reported a 66.4 percent drop in earnings and said it was terminating its current pension plan in a move that would increase fourth-quarter earnings by about $220 million. [ D1. ] Pepsico's earnings rose 27.2 percent, because of strong beverage and snack-food sales. [ D1. ] Carl C. Icahn met with the unions of T.W.A. and Eastern Airlines this week to explore a takeover of Eastern by the New York financier, people familiar with the talks said. [ D3. ] Major banks reported strong earnings for the third quarter. The Bank of New York, Security Pacific and Continental Illinois all posted healthy gains, while Chemical reversed a loss. [ D3. ] The Cooper Companies agreed to sell Cooper Technicon to Miles Inc. in a deal worth about $500 million. [ D3. ] Continental Illinois proposed a 1-for-4 reverse stock split and said it would raise its dividend. [ D3. ] Time Inc. created the post of executive vice president for marketing and announced the retirement of its senior vice president of advertising for its magazine group. [ D15. ] MARKETS The dollar plunged on the report of a widening trade deficit and some dealers predicted further declines before the election. [ D1. ] Stock prices rebounded from Wednesday's sharp decline and the Dow Jones industrials gained 7.12 points, to 2,133.36. [ D4. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds closed little changed, although the announcement of a larger-than-expected trade deficit pushed them sharply lower early in the session. [ D12. ] Orange juice futures prices surged amid rumors that Brazil, the world's largest orange juice producer, may have problems meeting its delivery commitments. [ D11. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The memory of the stock market crash is still vivid a year later and many investors and securities dealers fear that it could happen again. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] The big investors behind leveraged buyout funds are uneasy about financing hostile takeovers. Market Place. [ D4. ]

title: Treasury Prices Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds closed little changed yesterday, although the announcement of a larger-than-expected merchandise trade deficit in the morning pushed them sharply lower early in the session.

title: Profits Up at 3 Major Banks; Chemical Reverses a Loss
description: Major banks yesterday reported improved earnings that analysts said indicated that the rebuilding from last year's difficult times is continuing.

title: Mets Are Expected To Retain Johnson
description: When it was over, when they had lost the pennant to the Los Angeles Dodgers, the Mets flew home with heavy hearts and apologies to their fans and with one major piece of pending business: Will Dave Johnson be returning as manager next year?

title: Review/Film; Allen Directs Rowlands In 'Another Woman'
description: Woody Allen's ''Another Woman,'' his 17th feature since ''Take the Money and Run'' in 1969, is about the mid-century crisis of Marion (Gena Rowlands), an intelligent, beautiful, esteemed professor of philosophy who, having just passed what a friend describes as ''the big 5-O,'' is re-examining her life.

title: Molex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Law; At the Bar
description: Divorce lawyers are generally an individualistic breed, but the names Marvin Mitchelson and Raoul Lionel Felder are invariably linked. The men are about the same age, had the same impoverished childhoods, and enjoyed the same success. Each is as famous in his own right as many of his celebrity clients. Each appears far more often in the tabloids than in the law reviews.

title: Metro Datelines; Murder Is Charged In Shooting of Baby
description: A 21-year-old Brooklyn man has been charged with murder in the fatal shooting of his 13-month old nephew on Tuesday, the police said yesterday.

title: Square D Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Intergraph Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Security Pacific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After provisions for credit losses of $147.3 million for the quarter and $305.2 million for the 9 months. c-After provisions for credit losses of $89.6 million for the quarter and $849.7 million for the 9 months.

title: Parents Night: Show-and-Tell and a Message
description: Once a year, in two hours, parents suddenly find out what their children do at school all day. At the H. C. Crittenden Middle School here tonight, mothers and fathers squeezed into small desks in classrooms fitted with American flags and fluorescent lights and learned, 10 minutes per teacher, what their sixth, seventh and eighth graders were studying: the War of 1812, Pascal, diphthongs, the electoral college, field hockey and listening skills.

title: Metro Datelines; Landlord Assessed $15 Million for Repairs
description: More than $1 million in repairs will be made at 15 Manhattan apartment buildings owned by a landlord whose tenants compared life in his structures to living in hell, a New York City official said Wednesday.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 451 money market mutual funds increased $305.4 million, to $267.46 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 125 institutional funds were down $490.3 million, to $69.07 billion. Assets of the 223 general-purpose funds were down $80.80 million, to $85.04 billion. The 103 broker-dealer funds rose $876.5 million, to $113.35 billion.

title: Morton Thiokol Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $14.1 million from a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Congress Completes Action On Medical-Waste Measure
description: The House completed Congressional action on legislation to control the kind of infectious medical waste that fouled Atlantic Coast beaches this summer.

title: From 'Balzac of Egypt,' Energy and Nuance
description: Critics sometimes call Naguib Mahfouz the Balzac of Egypt because of the way his works express the pulsating energy of city life and because of their psychologically nuanced characters and broad social concern.

title: Aspen Ribbons Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dollar Plunges on Trade Data
description: The dollar, continuing on its downward course this week, plunged yesterday on the report of a widening United States trade deficit in August. Some traders and economists said they expect further declines before the election and the new year.

title: Potlatch Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Digital Microwave reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: Automatic Data Processing $ 34,400,000 + 13.2 E-Systems Inc. 19,600,000 + 24.1 Gannett Co. 75,100,000 + 6.5 B.F. Goodrich Co. 60,800,000 + 43.4 Great Northern Nekoosa 92,300,000 + 65.7 Humana Inc. 58,200,000 + 22.5 Merrill Lynch & Co. 65,600,000 - 66.4 Miniscribe Corp. 15,000,000 + 78.6 Morton Thiokol 41,300,000 + 55.8 Owens-Corning Fiberglas 51,000,000 + 45.7 Pepsico Inc. 241,600,000 + 27.2 Potlatch Corp. 28,300,000 + 25.2 Raytheon Co. 126,600,000 + 10.5 Service Merchandise Inc. 800,000 * - Sherwin-Williams Co. 37,800,000 + 3.8 Southmark Corp. (138,000,000) - Uniroyal Goodrich Tire Co. 14,300,000 + 138.3 Willamette Industries 39,000,000 + 21.9 See accompanying notes for speical items.(Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Auto Sales Rose 31.5% In Period
description: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks rose 31.5 percent in the first part of October from the comparable period a year earlier, when the market was depressed because the auto makers had dropped their sales incentives.

title: Finances and the Fear of Serious Accident Prompt Rare Openness on Weapon Plants
description: In a remarkable public admission, the Energy Department has acknowledged over the last two weeks that the Government's mismanagement of the nation's nuclear weapon industry has resulted in many industrial mishaps, chronic safety violations and a legacy of environmental contamination.

title: Apple Harvest Time Brings Vision of Profits
description: At first glance, the life of a Yakima Valley apple farmer resembles one of those stylized drawings that used to adorn wooden fruit boxes: all sun and color in an orchard that looks like Eden.

title: Uniroyal Goodrich Tire Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes $1.9 million in extraordinary income for both periods; the 9 months also include a provision of $16.3 million for transaction costs related to the company's recapitalization. In 1988 the company changed its fiscal year-end from Nov. 30 to Dec. 31. The year-earlier periods ended Aug. 31. Uniroyal Goodrich was formed in August 1986 as a joint venture combining the tire businesses of Uniroyal Inc. and B.F. Goodrich. In June 1988 B.F. Goodrich sold its share of the business to a group of investors led by Clayton and Dubilier.

title: Ex-Wayne Mayor Is Arraigned
description: The former Mayor of Wayne pleaded not guilty yesterday to additional corruption charges involving development in the Passaic County township of 50,000 people. In a revised indictment returned earlier this month, the former Mayor, Louis V. Messercola, was accused of conspiring to extort, on behalf of an unidentified co-conspirator, a below-market price for a town house from a developer, Kingsbridge Heights Associates, in 1986 and 1987.

title: British Jobless Rate Off
description: Unemployment in Britain fell to a seasonally adjusted 8 percent of the work force in September, from a revised 8.1 percent in August, the Government said today. It was down from 9.8 percent in September 1987. Total seasonally adjusted unemployment was estimated at 2.26 million people in September, down from a revised 2.27 million in August and 2.77 million in September 1987.

title: Heritage Financial Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Self-Serving Report Defends Animal Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayberry a Coach
description: He left Kansas City on unfriendly terms with management after the playoffs in 1977, but John Mayberry has been brought back as a hitting coach and to bolster morale in the Royals' clubhouse. Mayberry, a power-hitting first baseman who was popular with Royals' fans, was hired after management decided that a black coach would be beneficial because of tension that existed between players last season. General Manager John Schuerholz said the addition of Mayberry should not be construed simply as a move to add a black to the staff. ''He'll not only provide a contribution in the clubhouse but in a variety of ways,'' Schuerholz said. ''He has exceptional knowledge of our organization and has worked for years with hitters. I just like his knowledge of the game in general and in particular his positive approach to the game.''(AP)

title: Universal Health Realty Inome reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gabel Recalls Myerson Aid, Invitations
description: Sukhreet Gabel told a jury yesterday that Bess Myerson befriended her in 1983, helped her write an employment resume and entertained her at several ''casual social occasions.''

title: Brooklyn Needs a Friend at Chase
description: Chase Manhattan Bank must choose whether to move its computer operations to Newport City, on the New Jersey waterfront, or to Metrotech, a promising 16-acre office park taking shape on an urban renewal site in downtown Brooklyn. Brooklyn deserves fair and full consideration.

title: Eastern Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $179,364 for the quarter and $475,935 for the 9 months. Shares earnings figures reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June.

title: Ken Murray, 85, Vaudeville Star Who Later Recorded Hollywood
description: Ken Murray, an actor and comedian who spent more than a quarter century in vaudeville and in films, died Wednesday in Burbank, Calif. He was 85 years old and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: Janet Grice
description: Janet Grice, a bassoonist, will lead a Brazilian jazz group featuring Claudio Roditi on trumpet tonight at 8 at Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street. Admission is $10; information, 206-1050.

title: Chips & Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Andean Music
description: Sukay will play Andean music on Sunday at 3 P.M. at Prospect Park Picnic House, near Third Street and Prospect Park West, in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Admission is $5; information, (718) 788-0055.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, an article yesterday about a debate between Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut and his Democratic challenger, Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman, misidentified Mr. Weicker's campaign manager. He is Jay F. Malcynsky.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Sullivan Leads in Texas: Mike Sullivan shot a seven-under-par 63 that included two chip-ins and took a one-stroke lead yesterday after the first round of the $600,000 Texas Open in San Antonio. Sullivan made seven birdies and an eagle in near-ideal conditions at the Oak Hills Country Club course. Corey Pavin, who scored a hole-in-one, was tied with Bobby Wadkins at 64. Pavin hit a 172-yard 7-iron shot that ran into the cup on the second hole. Tom Watson shot a 66.(AP) Faldo Leads England: Nick Faldo shot a seven-under-par 65 yesterday to open England's defense of the $1 million Dunhill Cup team tournament at St. Andrews in Scotland. Faldo's five-shot victory over Emmanuel Dussart was the most decisive of the day and helped England to a 3-0 victory over France in the first round of the medal match-play tournament. Of the eight seeded teams, all but Ireland went through to today's second round with 3-0 victories. The top-seeded United States team, led by the United States Open champion, Curtis Strange, swept past the Philippines. Strange, who smashed the world's most prestigious course record with a 62 in last year's competition, shot 70 yesterday to beat Eddie Baghtas by five strokes. Beck defeated Rudi Lavares, 68-81, and McCumber beat Frankie Minoza, 72-75. The Americans will meet Ireland in the second round; England and Scotland are matched against each other in a rematch of last year's final. (AP) Victory for Lang: Martha Lang of Geneva, Ill., jumped out to a huge lead yesterday and went on to defeat Mary Hanyak of Boynton Beach, Fla., 4 and 3, to win the United States women's mid-amateur championship at Amelia Island Plantation in Florida. Lang never trailed after taking the lead at the third hole. The title is the first national championship for Lang, who advanced to the semifinals of the 1969 United States girls' junior championship before being eliminated by Hollis Stacy. (AP) TENNIS Svensson Is Upset: Milan Srejber of Czechoslovakia upset fourth-seeded Jonas Svensson of Sweden, 6-3, 6-3, yesterday in the second round of the $290,000 Olympia tournament in Toulouse, France. Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia defeated Guy Forget of France, who won the title in 1986, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4, and also advanced to the quarterfinals.(AP) Evert Advances: Chris Evert beat Catarina Lindquist of Sweden, 6-1, 7-6, yesterday and advanced to the quarterfinals of a $250,000 Virginia Slims tournament in Filderstadt, West Germany. Evert, who is seeded No. 2 and who is the fourth-ranked player in the world, took 1 hour 25 minutes to win. Already in the quarterfinals is Martina Navratilova, the world's second-ranked player behind Steffi Graf. Evert will play Sylvia Hanika of West Germany. Navratilova will play Radka Zrubakova of Czechoslovakia.(AP)

title: Market Place; Buyout Funds And Hostile Bids
description: SOME Wall Street investment bankers have predicted that the giant pool of capital devoted to leveraged buyouts will not only continue to fuel takeovers indefinitely but will also be used in hostile transactions.

title: Comerica Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the 9 months' comparison is affected by the special $36 million provision recorded during the second quarter of 1987 for Latin American loans.

title: Topics of The Times; Beyond Howard Beach
description: Only last month a judge closed the book on the Howard Beach prosecutions by sentencing Robert Riley, the 19-year-old who cooperated with the authorities in return for leniency, to six months in jail and 400 hours of community service. Now there has been another incident, apparently similar to Howard Beach, that points up the persistence of racial violence and the Legislature's failure to enact laws to stem it.

title: Font & Vaamonde Wins a Jell-O Account
description: Font & Vaamonde, one of the largest Hispanic marketing agencies in the United States, has been awarded the $2 million Spanish-language account for Jell-O desserts, a General Foods product.

description: The North Carolina Dance Theater from Winston-Salem has come back to town with its usual complement of strong dancers, and its second program on Wednesday night showed them off to special advantage.

title: U.S. CAPTURES 120 IN GANG ROUNDUP
description: Police and Federal agents in 20 states have arrested more than 120 suspected members of Jamaican gangs that are said to be responsible for more than 1,400 murders and the large-scale distributing of illegal drugs.

description: Share earnings have been restated to reflect a 50-percent stock dividend paid on Nov. 6, 1987. The company also restated fiscal 1987 figures to reflect the acquisition of Craft House Corp. in March 1988.

description: To the Editor:

description: A four-night festival of cabaret songs and singers at Weill Recital Hall began on Wednesday evening with a concert by Adelaide Hall, who established the rich background on which today's cabaret singers can build.

description: A deal last winter involving the Dodgers and the Athletics, as well as the Mets, had a great deal to with helping Oakland and Los Angeles into the World Series. Additional articles, scouting reports by last year's pennant-winning managers and facts and figures on the Series begin on page D17.

Great Northern Nekoosa Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Last year's results include one month's contribution from the company's Nekoosa packaging division, which was acquired Sept. 1, 1987.

description: The Speaker of the House and the chairman of its Banking Committee came to an agreement today that marks the death knell for banking legislation this year.

description: Aid for Jamaica

title: CHINA SEES SUMMIT WITH SOVIETS IN '89
description: Deng Xiaoping, China's foremost leader, said today that China and the Soviet Union are likely to hold a summit meeting next year, diplomats reported. It would be the first such meeting in 30 years.

description: Deadpan Doo-Wops

title: Sang Won Park
description: Sang Won Park will play the Korean kayagum, or zither, on Sunday at 2:30 P.M. at the Uris Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Admission is $10, or $7 for students and the elderly. Information: 206-1050.

title: How Carbon 14 Was Used to Fix Date of Shroud
description: The Shroud of Turin was identified as a medieval forgery using a very sensitive dating technique available to only half a dozen laboratories around the world.

title: Charles Kuralt's Roadshow Continues
description: Despite a slow start and some sputtering along the way, ''Back on the Road'' rolls along into fresh territory tonight. In the course of the hourlong special at 10 on Channel 2, the hearty Charles Kuralt, who has made a career out of being a national tour guide for CBS News, introduces us to several old-timers who helped build the Golden Gate Bridge 50 years ago.

title: Baltimore Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company attributed the loss to a one-time writedown of a preferred stock portfolio taken in the second quarter.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Signed Doug Robbins, catcher, to a minor league contract and assigned him West Palm Beach of the Florida State League. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Released David Palmer, pitcher. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Waived Dave Rucker, pitcher. BASKETBALL DENVER (NBA) - Announced that Freddie Banks, guard, left training camp. PHILADELPHIA (NBA) - Agreed to terms with Hersey Hawkins, guard, to a multiyear contract. HOCKEY DETROIT (NHL) - Reinstated Petr Klima, left wing, and assigned him to Adirondack of the American Hockey League, effective Sunday, Oct. 16. COLLEGE CALDWELL - Named Glenn Carroll and Bruce Bartlett assistant men's basketball coaches.

title: Economic Scene; The Vulnerability Of the Markets
description: DON'T expect a ticker tape parade to celebrate the anniversary of the stock market crash of October 1987. On the contrary, Wall Street would like to forget it, consign it to the history books - but it cannot. The event is still alive, breeding anxieties among investors and securities dealers that it could happen again.

title: Stryker Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hawkins a 76er
description: The Philadelphia 76ers came to terms yesterday on a multiyear contract with Hersey Hawkins, their first-round draft choice. Hawkins led the nation in scoring at Bradley last season with an average of 36 points, the highest in 11 seasons and the 15th-highest ever. Coach Jim Lynam of the 76ers is counting on the 6-foot-3-inch Hawkins to take the pressure off Charles Barkley, the All-Star forward, with his long-distance shooting. Hawkins is still recovering from strained ligaments in his right knee that he suffered during the Seoul Olympics, causing him to miss the semifinal game against the Soviet Union.(AP)

title: Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $4 million and $14 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from affiliate income and an extraordinary loss from early retirement of debt of $6 million and $8 million for the same periods, respectively. c-Includes income from affiliates of $3 million and $8 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and an extraordinary loss of $5 million and $19 million for the same periods, respectively; the 9 months also include a first quarter after-tax gain of $83 million, or $2.01 a share, from the sale of certain assets.

title: Player Paralyzed
description: One of the Islanders' minor league prospects, Peter McGeough was left partly paralyzed after sliding helmet-first into the boards during an American Hockey League game, the team said yesterday. The Springfield defenseman suffered a fractured and dislocated vertebra in his back during a game against Cape Breton Tuesday night, according Mark Aldridge, a trainer for the Islanders. He said McGeough underwent surgery in which steel rods were inserted into the player's vertebra to reinforce his spinal column. ''We're not sure if he'll be able to walk again,'' Aldridge said. McGeough, 23 years old, is paralyzed from the waist down.(AP)

title: Autumn Festival
description: Square dancing, hayrides and pumpkins will be featured in an autumn festival on Sunday, beginning at noon, at the Central Park Band Shell, in the middle of the park near 72d Street. Rides and pumpkins are free for children, and cider and dancing are free for adults. Information: 360-8128.

title: Massachusetts Miracle Is More than a Mirage; Sick Picture
description: To the Editor:

title: Genlyte Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings figures are fully diluted; year-ago share earnings figures for both the quarter and 9-month periods are pro-forma.

title: Upjohn Files Suits
description: The Upjohn Company filed lawsuits accusing two companies, California Pacific Research and Pantron, of making false advertising claims that their products can make hair grow or stop hair loss. Upjohn makes and markets Rogaine, the first prescription medicine cleared by the Food and Drug Administration for treating baldness. It said it expects to sell $100 million worth of Rogaine on world markets this year.

title: Antiques Center Still Expanding As New Dealers Move Into Shops
description: THE scaffolding has been removed from the entrance and escalators transport as many as 500 visitors a day to the Place des Antiquaires, the two-story maze of antiques shops below the street at 125 East 57th Street.

title: Welbilt to Sell Debt Totaling $75 Million
description: The Welbilt Corporation, a manufacturer of cooking equipment and home furnaces, is offering $75 million of 13 3/4 percent senior subordinated notes due in 1998 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Review/Film; The Last of an Empire
description: The film opening today at the Public Theater, titled ''The Last Emperor,'' is a double-decker footnote, to history and to movies, specifically, to Bernardo Bertolucci's Oscar-winning ''Last Emperor.''

title: Talman Home Federal Savings & Loan reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
People
description: * James Forsythe, senior vice president and circulation director at Essence Communications, has been named director of new business development.

title: Foreign Policy Fake, Arms Control Poseur
description: How George Bush maintains his campaign pose as a foreign policy and arms control expert is a bafflement. The fact is, he's more like the marginal baseball player who has a ''cup of coffee'' in the major leagues than the Hall of Famer he'd like voters to think he is.

title: Restaurants
description: When you enter the marble and glass lobby of the building at 18 East Broadway in Chinatown, an official-looking woman, wearing a dark blue uniform and holding a walkie-talkie, trots over and inquires, ''Are you here for dinner?'' ''Well, yes, we are.'' ''Take this elevator,'' she beckons, barking orders in Chinese to a command post upstairs. On the second floor, we enter an expansive sparkling banquet hall of marble and chrome with chocolate-brown rugs, pink curtains, white tablecloths and potted plants. Captains wearing dark suits and little gold name tags usher us to a table. (On subsequent visits, we were dispatched to a similar room on the third floor, featuring a glass-fronted display case holding brandies and Cognacs and two giant shark fins.) The Golden Unicorn, a branch of a Cantonese restaurant by the same name in Hong Kong, is more opulent - and expensive - than the average spot in Chinatown. Some of the food excels, although a tour of the voluminous menu uncovered a fair number of run-of-the-mill offerings that could be found for a lot less money at any of three dozen neighborhood restaurants.

title: Gannett Earnings Rise 6.5%
description: The Gannett Company, which publishes USA Today, said today that its contingency plans helped increase its earnings by 6.5 percent in the third quarter, although advertising linage barely grew.

title: Emhart to Acquire GardenAmerica
description: The Emhart Corporation reached a conditional agreement to acquire the GardenAmerica Corporation for $28.25 a share, or a total of $84 million. GardenAmerica, based in Carson City, Nev., designs and manufactures watering systems for the commercial and home markets. It sells products in the United States, Australia, France, Italy and Spain.

title: Court of Appeals Voids Nassau County's Budget
description: The Nassau County budget for 1988 is illegal because it does not take into account a $90 million county surplus, the State Court of Appeals ruled today.

title: Transcript of the Second Debate Between Bush and Dukakis
description: PARTICIPANTS IN THE DEBATE CANDIDATES: Vice President Bush, Republican, and Michael S. Dukakis, Democrat. MODERATOR: Bernard Shaw, anchor, Cable News Network. PANELISTS: Ann Compton, correspondent, ABC News; Andrea Mitchell, White House correspondent, NBC News; Margaret Garrard Warner, White House correspondent, Newsweek.

title: Princess Picks Lintas: U.S.A.
description: Princess Cruises, the world's largest cruise ship company, has taken its account, worth more than $30 million in advertising and direct marketing billings, from Tracy-Locke's Los Angeles office and delivered it to Lintas: U.S.A., an Interpublic Group subsidiary.

title: Review/Pop; A Balladeer With Quips And Tunes
description: ''Nashville is the only place in the world where you can eat escargots and gravy,'' Paul Williams remarked during Tuesday's opening night show of his weeklong engagement at Michael's Pub (211 East 55th Street). The diminutive singer and songwriter's remarks came by way of introducing a country ballad he had written with Willie Nelson in mind.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: A Nominee For C.F.T.C.
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate William Albrecht, an economics professor and an associate dean of the University of Iowa, to a vacancy on the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: U.S. Consul in Mexican Port Is Said to Be Taken Hostage
description: A gunman complaining of mistreatment by Mexican authorities entered the United States Consulate today and took the consul hostage, officials said.

title: Walking Through Time in Lower Manhattan
description: The loss of a half-trillion dollars and the onset of the Great Depression hardly seem like events to commemorate. But those two dark October days - Oct. 19, 1987, and Oct. 29, 1929 - will be not-so-solemnly noted on Sunday during a walking tour of the multi-trillion-dollar thoroughfare known as Wall Street.

title: Continental Illinois Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The latest third quarter included $28.7 million in net gains from the sale of certain domestic and foreign operations and $6 million from a release of reserves relating to the sales. The company said the gains were largely offset by a $15 million reduction in interest revenue resulting from non-performing Argentine loans and a decrease of almost $10 million in net gains from the venture capital business compared with the year-ago third quarter. The year-ago 9 months included a provision of $500 million for possible losses on loans to less developed countries.

title: A Guide to Weekend Walks
description: Here is a guide to weekend walking tours for outdoor explorers. FRIDAY A.T.&.T. BUILDING. An inside look at Philip Johnson's tower at 56th Street and Madison Avenue, sponsored by the 92d Street Y, at 1 P.M. $10. Reservations: 996-1100. SATURDAY WASHINGTON SQUARE AND GREENWICH VILLAGE. A survey of the square, from potter's field to the park, and environs, with a focus on Village history from the Henry James era to the bohemian 1920's. Led by Howard Goldberg of Adventure on a Shoestring. Meets at 3 and 5 P.M. $5. Reservations: 265-2663. THE ORIGINAL TIN PAN ALLEY. Tour meets at Madison Square Park (near the statue of William Seward, at 23d Street and Fifth Avenue) at 2 P.M., and explores the original home of the music industry, near 28th Street in Chelsea. Led by Ken Falk for Chelsea Visiting Neighbors. $7; $3 for the elderly. Information: 929-0811. GRAMERCY PARK. The park's colorful past, when it was filled with Army encampments and a tavern out of an O. Henry story, is the subject of a 1 P.M. tour led by Richard McDermott, editor of The New York Chronicle, a journal of local history. Meets at 21st Street and Park Avenue. $7. Information: (718) 423-8738. BROOKLYN-QUEENS BOUNDARY WALK. Tour explores the border between the two boroughs, focusing on the Ridgewood, Highland Park and Cypress Hills neighborhoods, with a stop at the 18th-century Van der Ende-Onderdonck Farmhouse. Meets at 1 P.M. at the Cypress Hill subway stop on J line (Jamaica Avenue, between Crescent and Hemlock Streets). Led by Jack Eichenbaum and John Kriskiewicz, for the Brooklyn Historical Society and the Queens Historical Society. $5 (includes admission and refreshments). Information: (718) 624-0890. TRINITY CEMETERY. A look at Manhattan's only active cemetery - the burial place of many rich and famous New Yorkers. Meets at 2 P.M. at Church of the Intercession on Broadway and 155th. Led by Sidewalks of New York. $10. Information: 517-0201. GHOSTS AFTER SUNSET. A tour that ferrets out haunted houses in the Village. Meets at 7 P.M. at Horatio and West Streets. Led by Sidewalks of New York. $10. Information: 517-0201. MORNINGSIDE PARK. Frederick Law Olmsted's landscaping and a history of battles are the focus of this Urban Park Rangers excursion. Meets at 2 P.M. at 110th Street and Morningside Drive. Free. Information: 397-3080. THE LOEWS KINGS. The vintage Brooklyn movie palace and nearby movie-related landmarks are explored with a local movie buff, Charles Sinclair, for the Prospect Park Environmental Center. Meets at 1 P.M. at the Cineplex Kenmore Theater, at Church and Flatbush Avenues. $4; $2 for children and the elderly. Information: (718) 788-8549. PROSPECT PARK MONUMENTS. A tour of statues and monuments in Brooklyn's great park, with the Urban Park Rangers. Meets at 1 P.M. at Grand Army Plaza Arch. Free. Information: (718) 287-3400. PAINTING FALL FOLIAGE IN PELHAM BAY PARK. A workshop with the Urban Park Rangers. Free. Meets at 2 P.M. at Pelham Bay Environmental Center, Orchard Beach, the Bronx. Information: 885-3466 or 589-0096. VAN CORTLANDT MANSION. A guided tour at 1 P.M. of the 250-year-old house in Van Cortlandt Park, near Broadway and 242d Street in the Bronx, with the Urban Park Rangers. Free. Information: 548-7070. BIRD WALK IN QUEENS. A tour of Brookville Park that looks for geese and other migratory shorebirds, with the Urban Park Rangers. Meets at 8:30 A.M. at Brookville Boulevard and 147th Avenue. Free. Information: (718) 699-4204. SUNDAY LOWER MANHATTAN. The early residents of lower Manhattan, from Fulton Street to the South Street Seaport, are the subject of tours offered by a group called New York Walk-About at 11 A.M. and 2 P.M. Meets at Broadway and Fulton Street. $7. Information: 582-2015 or (914) 834-5388. LOWER EAST SIDE. Two tours, focusing on the area's immigrant heritage, will be offered by Herman Storick for New York Walk-About, at 11 A.M. and 2 P.M. Meets at the southwest corner of Chrystie and Grand Streets. $7. Information: 582-2015 or (914) 834-5388. UPPER WEST SIDE. Tour focuses on the area's three types of housing - townhouses, tenements along the old Columbus Avenue elevated train, and luxury buildings on Central Park West and Broadway. Meets at 11 A.M. at the Dakota, 72d Street and Central Park West. Led by M. Christine Boyer and David Melville, for the Museum of the City of New York. $10; $6 for members and the elderly. Information: 534-1672, extension 206. UPPER WEST SIDE. A four-hour foray led by Joyce Mendelsohn, meeting at 11 A.M. at the Lincoln Center fountain, sponsored by the 92d Street Y. $10. Reservations: 996-1105. MORNINGSIDE HEIGHTS. A four-hour tour, led by John Tauranac for the 92d Street Y, meets at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 10 A.M. $10. Reservations: 996-1105. GREENWICH VILLAGE HISTORY WALK. Tour explores the development of the Village as a health retreat for those escaping epidemics around 1800. Conducted by the Village historian Joyce Gold. Meets at noon at Washington Square Park Arch. $8. Information: 242-5762. BAWDY, HISTORIC CHELSEA. Tour focuses on the days of music halls and theaters during the Gilded Age, when Chelsea was the heart of Manhattan night life. Meets at 2 P.M. at the southwest corner of 24th Street and Avenue of the Americas. Led by Maryann McFadden as a benefit for Chelsea Visiting Neighbors. $7; $3 for the elderly. Information: 929-0811. FALL COLORS IN PROSPECT PARK. A free Brooklyn walk with the Urban Park Rangers, meeting at 1 P.M. at Prospect Park West and Third Street. Information: (718) 287-3400. FALL COLORS IN CROCHERON PARK. A free walk in the Queens park with the Urban Park Rangers, meeting at 1 P.M. at 215th Place and 33d Road in Bayside. Information: (718) 699-4204. AUTUMN COLORS ON STATEN ISLAND. Free tours of Clay Pit Ponds State Park Preserve at 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. The park is at the end of Carlin Street, off Sharrotts Road in the Charleston section. Information: (718) 967-1976. AUTUMN BIRD RAMBLE. Sarah Elliot will guide binocular-class birders in Central Park's wooded Ramble. Meets at 10 A.M. at the Loeb Boathouse, near 75th Street and East Drive. Free. Information: 397-3080. FORT WASHINGTON PARK. One of Manhattan's lesser-known parks, beneath the George Washington Bridge, is explored by the Urban Park Rangers. Meets at the west end of 181st Street at 1 P.M. Free. Information: 397-3080. HAWK WATCH IN BRONX. Walkers in Van Cortlandt Park can scan the skies for hawks, turkey vultures and other migratory birds, with the Urban Park Rangers. Meets at 10 A.M. at the visitors' center, 242d Street and Broadway. Free. 548-7070. ALONG THE AQUAHUNG. A stroll through Bronx Park, along the Bronx River (known by the Indians as the Aquahung), with the Urban Park Rangers. Meets at 1 P.M. at Allerton Avenue and Bronx Park East. Free. Information: 548-7070.

title: Cadigan Tries to Toughen Up
description: In a maneuver designed to give Dave Cadigan tougher game-like experience, Mark Gastineau today emulated Bruce Smith, the Buffalo Bills' Pro Bowl pass-rushing end who will be matched against Cadigan on Monday night.

title: TCF Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $2,730,000 for the quarter and $6,671,000 for the 9 months. c-After a gain of $1,245,000 from the reinstatement of tax benefits. d-Net loss and after a penalty of $2,883,000 from the prepayment of Federal Home Loan Bank advances.

title: NCNB Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Art; The Poetic Renderings Of Howard Hodgkin
description: Howard Hodgkin is a poet in paint who deals with places, with people and with their mutual entanglements. He is also, in our time, an incomparable colorist. To walk into his new show at Knoedler & Company is to be wafted high above the grimy, gritty concerns of everyday life in a big city. We enter, instead, a state of bliss in which the subway never breaks down, the right person answers every telephone call on the first ring, it's never too hot or too cold and nobody ever gets a bad deal.

title: Raytheon Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sun Microsystems
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., based in Mountain View, Calif., said it was raising the prices on its computer work station and server products an average of 7 percent because of the increased cost of memory chips. Sun, which had raised prices by about 10 percent earlier in the year, increased prices on newer models by about 6 percent, while older models were raised by 10 to 15 percent. It also raised prices for add-on memory by $100 per megabyte. Sun said the higher prices would allow it to purchase larger volumes of chips, thereby speeding up manufacturing and reducing lead times.

title: Review/Concert; Vivaldi, Debussy
description: For the past 19 seasons the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has made a fetish of rare and unusual repertory. So what better way to begin its 20th year at Alice Tully Hall Wednesday than with ''The Seasons'' by Vivaldi - perhaps the most relentlessly popular piece of music now making the rounds of public-radio stations and better elevators. Debussy's ''Afternoon of a Faun'' - also on Wednesday's program - is equally affixed to the classical-music hit parade. Indeed, the society could have chosen no better way to surprise its audience than with the predictable.

title: Reistertown Federal Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Completions Of Homes Fall
description: Completions of new homes in the nation fell 1.2 percent in August to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.51 million after a slim gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Portsmouth Bank Shares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company converted to stock form of ownership on Feb. 17, 1988.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY NEW FROM JAPAN

title: Thousands in Haiti Protest Reported Transfer of Priest
description: About 6,000 people demonstrated here today against an order reportedly issued by Roman Catholic Church leaders to transfer a popular radical priest out of Haiti.

title: Concerto for Guitar
description: Pepe Romero is to be the guitar soloist in Rodrigo's ''Concierto de Aranjuez'' with the Lausanne Chamber Orchestra tomorrow afternoon at 3 at Carnegie Hall. The program, which is to be led by Lawrence Foster, also includes Haydn's Symphony No. 95 and Honegger's Symphony No. 4 (''Deliciae Basilienses''). Tickets are $19 to $9. Information: 247-7800.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jerry Butler, the third-ranked wide receiver in Buffalo Bills history, announced his retirement yesterday after sitting out all of last year with a leg injury and not playing this season because his leg hadn't recovered sufficiently to withstand the stress of the game. Butler, a former collegiate star at Clemson, finished his pro career with 278 catches for 4,301 yards. . . . Eric Show, a pitcher who is coming off his best season ever, signed a two-year contract yesterday with the San Diego Padres. Show, 32 years old, won a career-high 16 games against 11 losses, and pitched 13 complete games. . . . The Philadelphia Phillies yesterday released David Palmer, a right-hander, who underwent rotator cuff surgery on his pitching arm last month. Palmer (7-9) had a 4.47 earned run average in 22 games last season.

title: Miniscribe Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,510,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $3,732,000 for the 9 months. c-After an extraordinary credit of $617,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $1,638,000 for the 9 months.

title: Lawyer Granted Right to Conceal Client's Identity
description: In a case closely watched in legal circles nationwide, a Florida judge ruled today that a lawyer does not have to disclose the identity of a client who may have killed a man in a hit-and-run accident two years ago. Without the lawyer's cooperation, prosecutors have been unable to identify a suspect and file criminal charges.

title: Seven Metro-North Officers Are Dismissed Over Taunts
description: Seven longtime Metro-North policemen who appeared in a 1985 videotape that showed them taunting homeless people while on duty in Grand Central Terminal have been dismissed, the head of their union said yesterday.

title: Independent Bank Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Poor Results Bring End to Anti-AIDS Drug Study
description: A study of Ampligen, once widely viewed as one of the most promising new anti-AIDS drugs, has been halted because it failed to show benefit, the drug's developers announced yesterday.

title: Nobel Prize in Literature Awarded to an Arabic Writer for First Time
description: Naguib Mahfouz, an Egyptian novelist, playwright and screenwriter, won the Nobel Prize in Literature today, becoming the first Arabic writer to win literature's highest award.

title: Sihanouk Hints at U.S. Military Aid
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk said today that his Cambodian guerrilla forces were receiving new military aid from ''some countries,'' and strongly hinted that he was referring to the United States.

title: Candy in Jersey Didn't Contain Strychnine
description: A New Jersey state police finding that a piece of candy contained strychnine was incorrect, the result of a scientist's mistake, the authorities said today.

title: Prime Computer To Buy G.E. Unit
description: Prime Computer Inc. said it would acquire the General Electric Company's Calma business, which makes computer-aided design and manufacturing systems, for an undisclosed price. The move will increase Prime's share of the computer-aided design market while getting G.E. out of a money-losing business, which it entered with fanfare in 1981.

title: U.S. Chides Soviets on Rights Talks
description: Confronting renewed Soviet demands, the United States repeated today that the Soviets must improve their performance on human rights before the United States will agree to a human rights conference in Moscow.

title: Calton Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said revenue and net income for the latest third quarter decreased from 1987 principally because of a non-recurring land sale in 1987, which increased revenues by $6.1 million and net income by $3.2 million.

title: Southmark Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $20,000,000 from early retirement of debt. c-Net income In the fourth quarter 1988 the company said it added $206,000,000 in reserves to reflect continuing deterioration in some real estate markets and the decline in value of some of its marketable securities.About $120,000,000 of the loss reserve additions were at the San Jacinto unit. The company also said it is in discussions with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board that are likely to result in restrictions on operational relationships between Southmark and San Jacinto. The results reflect consolidation of previously unconsolidated subsidiaries, including San Jacinto Savings Assn. and Southmark Life Group.

title: Bridge
description: The American open team was in top form at the World Team Olympiad here today, scoring 72 victory points out of a possible 75. It beat Sweden, the reigning European champion, 22-8, and then took maximum points against two low-ranked teams, San Marino and Chile.

title: Goodrich ,B F Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $8,000,000 for the quarter and $12,600,000 for the 9 months, and the 9-month also includes a $2,700,000 gain from an accounting change. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $500,000 and $3,700,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and tax credits of $13,600,000 for the quarter and $24,100,000 for the 9 months, and the 9-month also includes a $3,100,000 loss on extinguishment of debt.

title: KEY RATES
Schultz Homes reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $129,000.

title: N.F.L. Matchups; Jackson Is Ready To Pursue 'Hobby'
description: A battle cry often heard among the Los Angeles Raiders this season has been, ''If we can just hold on until Bo Jackson gets back. . . . '' Well, Bo's back. Jackson practiced Wednesday for the first time since ending his baseball season with the Kansas City Royals. He managed a 10-day break before picking up his ''hobby.''

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Slobodan Milosevic; The Serb Who's Giving the Orders
description: Yugoslavia's man of the hour, Slobodan Milosevic, appears to be a bundle of contradictions: He wears banker's pinstripes, smokes cigarillos and drives a Yugo car. But in his rise to absolute power in Serbia, he has also displayed a rough tongue and a ruthless willingness to instigate mobs to achieve his political ends.

title: Sherwin-Williams Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $2,772,000.

title: Lockheed Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $177 million for the quarter and $182 million for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $6 million for the quarter and $7 million for the 9 months. The discontinued operations reflected the sale of Dialog Information Services and a provision for additional costs associated with the disposal of the discontinued shipbuilding operations.

title: Golden West Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After charges for FHLB advance payment benefits of $1,470,000 for the quarter and $4,759,000 for the 9 months.

title: Savings Bonds In Sales Drop
description: Sales of United States Savings Bonds dropped for the fifth time in six months in September, falling 10.8 percent, to $519 million, the Treasury Department said this week.

title: Weaknesses Show In Rangers' Start
description: The room in the basement of Madison Square Garden, overly bright and barely furnished, looked appropriate for an arraignment. Michel Bergeron, emerging from a grim locker room Wednesday night, stepped into the room and read off the long list of charges to the gathered reporters. So broad was his indictment of the Rangers that it appeared to include even himself.

title: Mahfouz's Unflinching View of His Land
description: When your heart achieves its desire, you will have transcended the confines of time and space. But you still feel oppressed in this cottage, in the midst of a grassy lawn surrounded by a fence lined with cypress trees. And you await the day when the cypresses and all they enclose will disappear, the day when the plants will no longer whisper of the night's sorrows, the day when the scuttling of the cockroaches and the croaking of the frogs will fall silent, the day when memory will lose its tyranny and you'll merge into nothingness. Then the chants of India and Persia will no longer echo and the rosy beams of ecstasy will fall directly upon you. That precious, hard-won ecstasy of dawn will draw you with all the force of the unknown into heaven's dome where your heart will awake while the bodily senses sleep. - ''The Beggar'' (1965), translated in 1986 by Kristin Walker Henry and Nariman Khales Naili al-Warraki Once more he breathed the air of freedom. But there was stifling dust in the air, almost unbearable heat, and no one was waiting for him; nothing but his blue suit and gym shoes.

title: Dodgers vs. Athletics: Big Trade Pays Off for Both
description: In the aftermath of the Mets' loss to the Los Angeles Dodgers in the final game of the National League pennant playoff, Joe McIlvaine stood in the Mets' clubhouse and recalled a moment 10 months earlier. ''I was standing between Fred and Sandy thinking this is a great trade for these teams,'' the Met executive related. ''As it turned out, we were the last three teams playing.''

title: Salvador Army Tied to 10 Peasants' Deaths
description: The El Salvador Attorney General's office contradicted the military today and said army troops were responsible for the slayings of 10 peasants last month.

title: Vac-Tec Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Cooper Agrees to Sell Technicon to Miles
description: The Cooper Companies said today that it had agreed to sell Cooper Technicon Inc., its medical-diagnostics business, to Miles Inc., a health care subsidiary of Bayer U.S.A.

title: Thomas Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes $193,000, or 2 cents a share, from the sale of the company's Pouliot Designs subsidiary for the quarter; the 9 months include an $800,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change and $1,576,000, or 15 cents a share, from the sale of the company's minority interests in two companies. c-Includes $373,000, or 4 cents a share, from the sale of an office property for the quarter; the 9 months include $348,000, or 3 cents a share, from the sale of undeveloped land in Ontario.

title: An Invitation From Mr. Gorbachev
description: In at least one arena of Soviet policy, Mikhail Gorbachev has scored a clear victory. For months he has struggled with his former number two, Yegor Ligachev, over the ideological underpinnings of Soviet foreign policy. Mr. Gorbachev has stressed common interests, Mr. Ligachev conflict. Now Mr. Gorbachev has prevailed.

title: Dams vs. Indians: The Battle Calls for War Paint
description: For much of his life as a Kaiapo Indian chief, Totoi has seen his tribesmen struggle with whites, chase out lumbermen, argue with gold diggers and even kill farmers who invaded their lands. But the latest problem is confounding for him and the chiefs of neighboring Amazon villages.

title: Nuclear Weapon Test Shakes Tall Buildings in Las Vegas
description: A nuclear weapon test today shook high-rise hotels and apartment buildings here, 80 miles from the test site.

title: Dynatronics Laser Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $11,600 for the latest quarter and $32,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Pepsico's Earnings Jump 27.2%
description: The cola and snack business, as far as Pepsico Inc. is concerned, has never been better.

title: Nobel Prize in Literature Awarded To an Arabic Writer for First Time
description: Naguib Mahfouz, an Egyptian novelist, playwright and screenwriter, won the Nobel Prize in Literature today, becoming the first Arabic writer to win literature's highest award.

title: Elcor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fifth Third Bancorp (Cincinnati, Ohio) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $7,455,000, or 35 cents a share, from an accounting change. The latest 9 months included $1,955,000, or 9 cents a share, from the settlement of Fifth Third's master retirement plan obligation to current retired employees in the second quarter of this year. All periods have been restated to reflect acquisitions.

title: Computer Task Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Topics of The Times; 'Working Late' Again
description: More families in which both parents work mean more families in which one parent works at home - and that has inspired a new product: a tape of office sounds. Laura Newman, of Kingston, N.Y., made the tape for herself after she began taking calls from business clients at home and felt embarrassed by her children's squalling and other domestic noise.

title: Lockheed Net Rises
description: The Lockheed Corporation said today that its earnings had nearly tripled in its third quarter because of an unusual $176 million gain.

title: Kaydon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Clayton Homes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 5-for-4 split on Sept. 28.

title: GORBACHEV URGES FREEING OF FARMS FROM COLLECTIVES
description: In an urgent effort to increase food production, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has called for farmers throughout the nation to be freed from the current state-run system of collective agriculture, Soviet television reported tonight.

title: Forget Uncle Milty, It's the New Dukakis
description: Forget that Michael S. Dukakis has a reputation as a chilly, humorless politician. The new revised Democratic Presidential candidate is exuding dazzling one-liners - the Henny Youngman of American politics.

title: Nixon-Era Plan for Children Didn't Include Concentration Camps
description: To the Editor:

title: Pilot Seized in Paris Flights
description: The police have arrested a man suspected of being the pilot who evaded them for months while making low-level nighttime flights over the capital, news reports said today. The Air and Border Police arrested Albert Maltret, 53 years old, when he landed Thursday at Saint-Cyr, a private airfield in a Paris suburb, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Maltret was convicted in 1986 of landing a small plane on the Champs-Elysees, which had been closed to traffic for the filming of a movie.

title: Meridian National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income c-After a tax credit of $117,000.

title: Retail Sales Show Decline For Second Straight Month
description: Retail sales in September dropped for the second consecutive month, the Government said today, confirming the view of some economists that the confidence of American consumers is slipping.

title: IMC Fertilizer Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2.4 million from the disposition of assets. The company went public in July.

title: 2,550 in Jersey Program Leave Welfare and Find Jobs
description: Governor Kean presented wristwatches to 10 women today, not to mark their retirement but to mark their entry into the work force after years on welfare.
