title: Correction
description: An article on Wednesday about a study by Contact Center, a nonprofit organization, on furloughs granted to Federal and state prisoners included a misstatement, taken from the study, on South Carolina's program.

title: 90 Co-ops Suffering Through a Strike
description: A strike by a major building maintenance union has left thousands of cooperative apartments in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island without heat or hot water. Deliveries, garbage pickup and other services have also been disrupted.

title: Fairfield-Noble Corp reports earnings for Year to June 30
Keystone Heritage Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pennwalt Sells Unit
description: The Pennwalt Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Sharples-Stokes division to Alfa-Laval A.B .of Stockholm for $119 million. Some analysts had expected the division would fetch only $80 million. Pennwalt stock rose $2 today, to $93 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. Centaur Partners, a New York investment group, holds a 7.6 percent stake in Pennwalt and has said it mayt consider a takeover. Pennwalt plans to restructure to make the company less vulnerable to a takeover.

title: United Investors Management reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After securities gains of $47,000 for the quarter and $174,000 for the 9 months. c-After a securities loss of $20,000 for the quarter and a securities gain of $788,000 for the 9 months.

title: Altera Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bush vs. Bush on the Environment
description: Though you would never know it from the Presidential ''debates'', the environmental question is as significant as any now facing the American voter, and more significant than most. The cumulative destruction and corruption of the earth's resources on the land, in the seas, and throughout the atmosphere present as much of a challenge to the survival of the human race as nuclear war. For the last eight years, Vice President Bush has served as second-in- command of the most viciously anti-environmental Administration in American history. As Candidate Bush, he now presents himself as a card-carrying environmentalist -again as recently as Thursday night.

title: Vehicle Output Rises
description: Domestic auto makers were scheduled to produce 234,027 cars and light trucks this week, up from 233,484 last week, Ward's Automotive Reports said. This week's output is higher than the week a year earlier, in which 231,759 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said.

title: New Help for the Coroner's Office
description: For years under the direction of Dr. Elliot Gross, the New York City Chief Medical Examiner's Office was plagued by doubts about its competence and management. The selection of Dr. Charles Hirsch to replace Dr. Gross can begin to restore the office's reputation.

title: Lockheed Gets Navy Contract
description: In a move that could mean $5 billion in business for the Lockheed Corporation, the Navy today selected the company to develop a successor to the P-3 Orion anti-submarine aircraft.

title: Adaptec Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 23
Polaroid Loses Shamrock Motion
description: Shamrock Holdings Inc.'s hostile takeover bid for the Polaroid Corporation gained ground today when a Delaware court denied the photo products company's motion to halt Shamrock's $2.4 billion offer.

Temple-Inland Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Your Money; No Simple Rules On Deferments
description: Many executives and management-level employees must soon decide whether to defer year-end bonuses, and perhaps some salary, into future years or to take the compensation now in expectation that tax rates will increase.

No Plan Yet on Pullout, Cuba and Angola Say
description: Angolan and Cuban diplomats have denied reports that they have agreed with South Africa on a schedule for the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola.

title: Easy Finish on Fifth Avenue
description: For two dozen world-class runners, the long track-and-field season, which took some of them to the Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, will end today at the intersection of 62nd Street and Fifth Avenue, the finish line of the Mercedes Mile.

title: Bank of San Francisco Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: At Core of Dodgers' Ascent Is Gibson's Intensity
description: The game was over, the pennant was won and the Dodgers' celebration was in full and foamy fury Wednesday night. One of the star players, though, the spiritual and often the batting leader, the man given huge credit for helping lift the team from fifth place last season to the National League championship, was nowhere to be found.

title: Desoto Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $1,500,000 gain from an accounting change. c-Net income Year-ago 9 months include pre-tax restructuring gain of $5,358,000.

title: Democrats, on the Day After, See a Long Hard Road Ahead
description: Democrats tried to put as good a face as possible today on the second Presidential debate. But they didn't seem happy in their work.

title: Suspect Denies Killing Pratt Student
description: A Brooklyn man charged in the shooting death of a Pratt Institute student from Arkansas pleaded not guilty yesterday at his arraignment at State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: Stage II Apparel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Both periods included the results of the apparel division of Sportsotron Inc. since its acquisition effective Aug. 1, 1987. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Special High Schools: Prized Goal for Students
description: Martha Snider said she often couldn't sleep for worry over where she would attend high school next year. Elvia Pazmino, who remembers seniors' crying in the hall of her middle school in Brooklyn last year when they were not accepted at their first choices, is confused and worried now that it is her turn.

title: LaRouche and 6 Aides Charged With Mail Fraud
description: Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the political extremist, and six of his associates were charged today in a Federal conspiracy and mail fraud indictment that accused them of borrowing more than $30 million that Mr. LaRouche apparently had no intention of repaying.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 36.

title: Chile Coalition to Back One Candidate
description: The 16-party coalition that led opponents of Gen. Augusto Pinochet to victory in last week's plebiscite announced today that it would back a single candidate in the presidential elections next year.

title: Smith, A O Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-After a gain of $3 million from a change in accounting.

title: Review/Music; Karen Mason, Cabaret Singer, at Carnegie
description: Although Karen Mason, a cabaret singer with a devoted cult following, moved to New York from her hometown of Chicago many years ago, she still betrays an ingenuous enthusiasm over being caught up in the swirl of Manhattan. ''I'm a white, Catholic suburban girl,'' she announced on Thursday evening at Weill Recital Hall, where she was the second of four performers to appear in the four-evening Cabaret Comes to Carnegie.

description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $310,000 and $1,498,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $306,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: 2 More Palestinian Deaths Tied to Uprising
description: Two Palestinians wounded in clashes with troops in the occupied West Bank died today, Arabs and hospital officials said.

description: b-After tax credits of $253,000 for the quarter and $462,000 for the 6 months.

A Public Phone Aid For Hearing Impaired
description: Ultra Tec Inc., a manufacturer of telecommunication devices for the deaf, known as called TDD's, has invented a product to help people with hearing impairments to use public telephones.

title: Review/Dance; 3 Stages of Young Love, In New Work at the Joyce
description: Rick McCullough's ''By Lamplight'' received its world premiere on Thursday in a performance by the North Carolina Dance Theater at the Joyce Theater. The dance - or ones like it - has been seen before in countless excursions into the gauzy ballet dreamland of young contemporary lovers. But the piece makes that familiar genre seem newly fresh and vivid.

title: Incstar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $30,100 for the quarter and $8,500 for the 6 months.

title: Dover Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in September.

title: Two 'Angels' Arrested in Midtown on Robbery and Drug Charges
description: Two Guardian Angels were arrested yesterday on robbery and drug charges after a man said the Angels punched him and stole $90 from him on a midtown sidewalk.

title: Battle of Algiers, Revisited
description: A week of deadly rioting against austerity measures in Algeria has shaken the complacency of a regime inclined to live on the myths of a revolutionary past. President Chadli Benjedid has responded sensibly with a program of accelerated political and economic reforms. Americans and all others who value stability in this strategically situated country ought to root for the success of his attempts at perestroika, Algerian-style.

title: M.T.A. and Abrams Merge Metro-North Investigations
description: A two-year state investigation into the troubled Metro-North railroad police force has been expanded and merged with an internal inquiry by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the parent of the railroad, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Andover Togs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Craig Raupe, 63, Dies; Aide to House Speaker
description: Craig Raupe, a former top aide to House Speaker Jim Wright, died of a burst aorta today at Washington Hospital Center. He was 63 years old.

title: More Honors for Ritter
description: Louise Ritter shared her Olympic gold medal with the townspeople who stood behind her through years of frustration.

title: Bush-Dukakis Debate: For Workers in Texas, Little to Cheer
description: They had spent the early part of the evening assembling lawn signs for state and local candidates, arguing and joking and drinking beer as they worked, but when the Presidential debate came on the staple guns and the power saws fell silent, and so did the rank-and-file union members gathered on Houston's southeast side Thursday night.

title: Vampire Kingdom's Fate Hangs in the Balance
description: The Queen of the Damned By Anne Rice 448 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Cannon Group Inc., Los Angeles, a film company, said it would build about 30 multiscreen movie theaters in Britain in the next five years.

title: Banks Children Can Call Their Own
description: A bank in a toy store, or in a caboose, may be hard to take seriously. But banks for children seem to be more than a novelty.

title: Senate, in Vote of 87 to 3, Adopts Anti-Drug Measure
description: The Senate today passed legislation that would gradually shift priorities in the fight against illegal drugs from law enforcement to education, rehabilitation and other efforts to reduce demand.

title: U.N. Settles Dispute On Korean Speeches
description: It took weeks of high-level negotiations, but finally a compromise was worked out allowing both South and North Korea to address the General Assembly next week, diplomats say.

title: Operator for Bryant Park Restaurant Named
description: The operators of the Gotham Restaurant & Bar in Greenwich Village were chosen yesterday to build and run at least one of two restaurants in Bryant Park as part of a restoration project.

title: In Czechoslovakia, a Rare Visit With a Political Prisoner
description: LEAD: What does the Federal Government have to hide in its prisons?

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I think Bush can start measuring the curtains in the White House.'' - Gov. Michael Castle of Delaware, a Republican. [ 1:2. ]

title: Evert Plans to Play
description: Chris Evert, who spent last summer in uncertainty about whether 1988 would her last year of competitive tennis, has apparently decided to continue playing. Evert, 33 years old, told The Stuttgarter Nachtrichten, a West German newspaper, that she plans to continue in competition. ''I will play for at lest another year, perhaps not so many tournaments as before, but certainly the important ones,'' she said. Evert is playing in the Virginia Slims tournament in Filderstadt and is seeded second behind Martina Navratilova.(AP)

title: Stephanie Salzman Marries Jean-Louis Carbonnier
description: At the Brooklyn Ethical Culture Society, Stephanie Beatrice Salzman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eric Salzman of Brooklyn Heights and East Quogue, L.I., was married yesterday to Jean-Louis Carbonnier, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Claude Carbonnier of Rheims, France. Lois Kellerman, a leader of the society, officiated.

title: Review/Theater; In a Rameau Opera-Ballet, A French Baroque Challenge
description: In spite of Jean-Philippe Rameau's high repute in music history as a theorist and composer, his operas have proved extremely resistant to revival in modern times. The French Baroque style, with its interweaving of singing and ballet, has not found the wide audience that scholars believe is due it, possibly because too many productions have been hampered by a deadly combination of amateurish singers and ill-trained dancers. The performance of Rameau's comic opera ''Platee'' that the Piccolo Teatro dell'Opera presented on Thursday evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music took a more professional approach that solved some, though hardly all, of the problems inherent in such revivals.

title: Jazz at Cooper Union
description: Cooper Union will have a free jazz concert at 8 P.M. Oct. 26 in the Great Hall, 7 East Seventh Street, at Third Avenue. John Lindberg, a bassist, and his Revolving Ensemble will perform. Information: 353-4195.

title: Dime Savings Bank of NY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $7,550,000 for the quarter and $25,997,000 for the 9 months. c-After extraordinary tax credits of $9,813,000 and $30,631,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; both periods also included a charge of $835,000 for the early extinguishment of debt net of tax benefit. The 1987 data has been restated to reflect the retroactive implementation of SFAS No. 91--accounting for non-refundable loan fees and costs.

title: Third TV Debate Brings Change in Commentary
description: The final Presidential debate produced a significant change in coverage by network television: After deliberately not picking a winner in the two previous debates, the networks declared George Bush the victor Thursday night.

title: C.I.A. Aide Sees Soviet Economy Failing to Gain
description: A senior C.I.A. official said today that Mikhail S. Gorbachev's efforts to transform the Soviet economy did not have a good chance of succeeding.

title: At New Docklands, a Tale of 2 Cities
description: The wall, a brick sentinel that shields one world from another, stands as a symbol of sweeping change and resultant bitter divisions in London's once-derelict dock area.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Ireland Upsets U.S.: Curtis Strange's hopes of following up his United States Open triumph by leading his country to victory in the $1 million Dunhill Cup in St. Andrews, Scotland, were dashed yesterday when his top-seeded team was upset by Ireland. Ronan Rafferty set the eighth-seeded Irish on course for victory when he edged Mark McCumber by one stroke with a one-under-par 71. Then Chip Beck halved his match with Des Smyth as they both scored 71. Strange, who set a course record 62 in the same tournament last year, this time carded a 68 and lost by two strokes to Eamonn Darcy, whose 66 gave Ireland a 2 1/2- 1/2 victory.

title: Bush, Fighting Back Glee, Vows Tough Battle to End
description: Vice President Bush's campaign began a battle against over-confidence today, with the Presidential nominee pledging to run hard over the remaining three weeks and aides publicly predicting a close race.

title: Marshall & Ilsley Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
More Presidential News Conferences Urged
description: The Presidential news conference has fallen into ''a serious state of disarray'' under President Reagan, who has held relatively few such conferences, a Harvard commission says. But a Reagan spokesman said Thursday that the report gave too much emphasis to the number of news conferences.

title: Fairness Was Sought in Vietnam Reports
description: To the Editor:

title: Fifth Oyster Festival Comes to Oyster Bay
description: The town of Oyster Bay, L.I., will dispel any doubt about its name this weekend, when it conducts its fifth annual Oyster Festival from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. today and from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. tomorrow. Some 25,000 oysters are expected to be consumed - on the half shell, in chowder and stewed and in a variety of homemade foods. Among other treats will be hot-air balloon rides, an arts-and-crafts sale, a juried art show and continual musical entertainment.

title: Sports of The Times: THE WORLD SERIES; Howell and the Bash
description: In recent days, J. Canfield Howell of the Los Angeles Dodgers Inc. has worn a cloud over his head like a hat.

title: Senate Approves 11 Federal Court Nominees
description: The Senate today approved 11 of President Reagan's judicial appointments, but at least 15 others have virtually no chance of approval before the chamber adjourns for the year.

title: Campbell Soup
description: The Campbell Soup Company said it had acquired a Belgian seafood processor for an undisclosed amount of cash. Morubel N.V., based in Ostende, Belgium, is a privately held supplier of frozen prawns to major retail chains and food service customers in Belgium, Britain, France, Germany and Italy. It had 1987 sales of $44 million. Morubel is also a major supplier to Campbell's seafood division, which processes cold water prawns, squid, lobster tails and breaded scampi.

title: International Business Mahines Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a cumulative effect of $315,000,000 as of Jan. 1, 1988 of change in accounting principle. Revenue represents total or worldwide gross income.

title: U.S., FOR DECADES, LET URANIUM LEAK AT WEAPON PLANT
description: Government officials overseeing a nuclear weapon plant in Ohio knew for decades that they were releasing thousands of tons of radioactive uranium waste into the environment, exposing thousands of workers and residents in the region, a Congressional panel said today.

title: Bank of Delaware Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest third quarter and 9 months included a pre-tax gain of $1,430,000, or 12 cents a share, after tax, from the sale of its portion of the Local Bank Credit Bureau.

title: Missile Blast Called Deliberate
description: The Air Force has denied an assertion by the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee that a safety officer destroyed a Navy Trident 2 submarine missile by mistake.

title: First Alabama Bancshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. HOLDING BACK PART OF U.N. DUES OVER BUDGET ISSUE
description: The Reagan Administration has told Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar that it plans to keep withholding part of its United Nations dues this year until the organizationapproves a new austerity budget and other administrative changes, American and United Nations officials said today.

title: Seoul Seeks U.N. Help in Rift With North
description: President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea said today that he would ask the United Nations and its member countries to help bring about a reconciliation with North Korea that would ease tensions between the neighbors.

title: Landmark Bank for Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dukakis Returns to Stump As Aides Paint Rosy Picture
description: Michael S. Dukakis returned to the campaign trail today with a barrage of new assaults on Vice President Bush, while his aides fought the notion that the Democratic Presidential nominee had lost a critical opportunity in Thursday night's debate.

title: NBD Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said net income in 1987 was negatively affected by a special $54 million provision for possible credit losses on Latin American loans, which reduced after-tax income by $32.4 million, or 69 cent a share.

title: Robert Gross, 83, Heart Surgeon
description: Dr. Robert E. Gross, a cardiovascular surgeon who did pioneering work in the field of cardiac surgery, died Tuesday at the Newfield House Nursing Home in Plymouth, Mass. He was 83 years old.

title: Review/Pop; Cello With Pots and Pans
description: Tom Cora, a cellist, and Peter Hollinger, a percussionist, presented two short, intense sets at the Knitting Factory on Wednesday night; though the music was freely improvised, the two musicians moved nimbly from groove to groove, from dense noise to spacious melodies.

title: College Football Notebook; Many Points Likely at Army
description: When Army played Lafayette in 1986 and 1987, a total of 27 touchdowns and 190 points were scored, and 1,945 yards were gained. The Cadets won both games, by 56-48 and 49-37. Everyone expects more of the same today at West Point, and Bill Russo, Lafayette's coach, can explain why.

title: Centerre Bancorporation reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a credit of $4,469,000 for an accounting change.

title: Focus on Game 1
description: Dave Stewart The Oakland starter will be making his first World Series appearance. He is the only pitcher to win 20 or more games in each of the last two seasons. Stewart, who once pitched for the Dodgers, started twice in this year's playoff, winning once. Regular Season $ W L IP H SO BB ERA 21 12 275Z 240 192 110 3.23 Playoffs $ W L IP H SO BB ERA 1 0 13Y 9 11 6 1.35 Tim Belcher The Dodgers' starter is also a World Series rookie. He won his two playoff starts against the Mets, striking out 16 in 15Y innings. At one time he was the property of the Athletics, who traded him to Los Angeles as the player to be named later in the Rick Honeycutt deal. Regular Season $ W L IP H SO BB ERA 12 6 179Z 143 152 51 2.91 Playoffs $ W L IP H SO BB ERA 2 0 15Y 12 16 4 4.11

title: L'Oreal Buys Rubinstein in Shrouded Deal
description: L'Oreal, the French cosmetics conglomerate, has bought Helena Rubinstein Inc., the company named for the famed business executive who built an international cosmetics empire that until 1985 was a major force in the United States industry.

title: Brinkmann Instruments Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Lubricant Permits Use of a CFC Substitute
description: Allied-Signal Inc., based in Morris Township, N.J., has developed a lubricant that it says will allow refrigeration systems to use a substitute for chlorofluorocarbons, or CFC's.

title: L.I. Man Sentenced In Wedding Deaths
description: A man convicted for an automobile crash that killed three members of a wedding party on Long Island last year was sentenced yesterday to a maximum of two and one-third to seven years in prison.

title: Another Billion-Dollar Savings Rescue in Texas
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today announced its sixth billion-dollar rescue of insolvent savings institutions in Texas this year.

title: Designcraft Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Superior Industries International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings reflected a 10 percent stock dividend paid in June.

title: Review/Theater; From New Zealand, a Breakfast Fantasy
description: Party talk, snapshots, breakfast -commonplace events - take on new resonances, comic and poignant, in the performance art of the Front Lawn, a superb duo from New Zealand that played its first United States engagement for two nights at Dance Theater Workshop. In the two-part program on Tuesday, ''The Story of Robert'' and ''The Reason for Breakfast,'' Don McGlashan and Harry Sinclair acted, sang, danced, played guitar and made toast, never taking ordinary activities for granted. Behind habits and routines, their pieces suggest, lurks chaos.

title: A Broker Drive to Lure Investors
description: LEAD: A year after a stock market crash that petrified Wall Street, the brokerage industry has begun a marketing blitz designed to lure individual investors back to the fold.

title: Aluminum Co of America (ALCOA) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $9.9 million for a new profit-sharing plan for U.S. salaried employees. c-After a charge of $23,900,000 from early retirement of debt.

title: Tainted Food Is Linked to Northwest Flights
description: Hundreds of Northwest Airlines passengers have been stricken with an illness that state health officials said today might be linked to contaminated food served aboard at least four flights.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Washington Redskins have signed Greg Coleman, 34 years old, a former punter for the Minnesota Vikings and a brother of Vince Coleman, the star base stealer for the St. Louis Cardinals, as a free agent and released Garey Waiters, a rookie punter. . . . The Houston Rockets signed first-round draft pick, Derrick Chievous of Missouri, to a three-year contract. The 6-foot-7-inch, 220-pound forward is the third-leading career scorer in Big Eight history.

title: Hearing Aid Implanted in Middle Ear
description: Many people with hearing problems have found hearing aids to be almost as frustrating as the impairment itself. They complain of irritating feedback and distorted sound.

title: DPL Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the year-ago 9 months includes an unbilled revenue adjustment equivalent to 44 cents a share.

title: About New York; For Old Liberals, Harry's the One, But Mike'll Do
description: Meyer Haspel, 77-year-old youngster and son of the hosiery and underwear king of Orchard Street, has his convictions. As a teen-ager, he organized workers in his father's two stores into a union, nearly provoking filicide.

title: Many Courts Have Upheld Right to Die
description: Courts have long recognized that ''every human being of adult years and sound mind has a right to determine what shall be done with his own body,'' as Judge Benjamin Cardozo wrote in a 1914 New York Court of Appeals decision. This right is based in the common law and, according to some courts, the constitutional right to privacy.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Infotron Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Interspec Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $328,000 for the quarter and $531,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss and after tax credits of $352,000 and $877,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Arizona Instrument Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Pop; Jazz Quintet and Cello Choir
description: The action is in the low register in the Ron Carter Nonet, which is appearing through tomorrow at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street. Mr. Carter, a bassist, has supported some of the best jazz ensembles since the 1960's, turning rhythmic underpinnings into consistently inventive countermelodies. As a leader, he leaves the rhythm to others, and his nonet merges a jazz quintet including two bassists - himself in melodic solos, while Leon Maleson plays within the rhythm section - with the four-member New York Cello Choir. The nonet's music stays hushed and somber, but it luxuriates in the woody, burnt-sienna sound of low strings.

title: INSIDE
description: Genocide Treaty Backed

title: All-California World Series Poses Difficulties for NBC
description: When the New York Mets lost the National League Championship Series Wednesday night, they gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a pennant and the National Broadcasting Company a headache.

title: Teco Energy Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rodney Markley, 75, Ex-Lobbyist for Ford
description: Rodney W. Markley Jr., former vice president for governmental relations at the Ford Motor Company, died of bladder cancer Wednesday at the Sunny Bank Anglo-American Hospital, Cannes, France. He was 75 years old and lived in Theoule sur Mer, France.

title: Management Drops Bid for Wickes
description: The Wickes Companies said a $573.8 million takeover offer from a management group led by its chairman, Sanford C. Sigoloff, had been dropped today because of the company's deteriorating earnings.

title: U.S.-Soviet Grain Talks
description: The latest round of American-Soviet talks on a new long-term grain agreement ended abruptly in London today without an accord, but the American side said a deal was still possible.

title: Atlantic Express reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a $1,027,317 gain from an accounting change.

title: Courtyard of the Louvre Opens With Its Pyramid
description: Thousands of visitors streamed into the refurbished courtyard of the Louvre today for their first close look at a giant glass pyramid destined to be the museum's new entrance.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: And Now Even E.P.A. Backs Waste Reduction
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar in Another Decline; Weeklong Momentum Cited
description: The dollar continued its steady decline yesterday and some traders said it might take central bank intervention to stop the fall.

title: Merchants Bank of NY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share earnings were adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split paid July 20, 1988.

title: Congressional Negotiations On Tax Bill Are Broken Off
description: Congressional negotiations on a compromise tax bill broke off today after Senators and House members could not even approach agreement on how large a tax increase they should approve.

title: Trion Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest 9 months included a one- time gain of $366,000, or 9 cents a share, for a reduction in accumulated deferred income taxes.

title: CXR Telecom Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Alysheba Wins by Neck
description: Alysheba became only the second horse ever to earn $5 million and set his second straight track record tonight when he scored a surprisingly narrow victory over Slew City Slew in the $600,000 Meadowlands Cup at Meadowlands Race Track.

title: Torchmark Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After securities gains of $938,000 for the quarter and $3,440,000 for the 9 months. c-After securities gains of $4,011,000 and $12,767,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; the 9 months also included a $7,903,000 loss from the redemption of debt.

title: All the Comforts In Dress Shoes
description: The crisp autumn weather should bring the walk-to-work brigade back to the streets. But what will it take to get them to give up their athletic shoes?

title: Legislators Leave For West Germany
description: A dozen New York State legislators and several top government officials left yesterday for a weekend trip to West Germany, courtesy of the New York Air National Guard and the Air Force.

title: Excerpts From the Court of Appeals Decision on a Patient's Right to Die
description: Following are excerpts from the New York State Court of Appeals decision on the right of a patient to refuse life-sustaining measures. The majority opinion was written by Chief Judge Sol Wachtler, joined by Associate Judges Judith S. Kaye, Vito J. Titone and Joseph W. Bellacosa. A concurring opinion was written by Associate Judge Stewart F. Hancock Jr. The dissent was written by Judge Richard D. Simons, joined by Associate Judge Fritz W. Alexander 2d. FROM THE OPINION By Chief Judge Wachtler

title: Reservoir Levels Fall After Torrid Summer
description: After a summer and early fall of skimpy rainfall and heavy demand for water, reservoirs throughout the metropolitan region have fallen to below normal levels.

title: Western Micro Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ford Incentives
description: The Ford Motor Company became the latest American auto maker to offer cash incentives on some 1989 models. Ford said it would offer rebates of $300 on 1989 model F-series trucks, with the same amount of cash back still available on 1988 models. The offer will run through Dec. 5. Last week, the Chrysler Corporation began a cash incentive program. Analysts said the incentives were the earliest ever offered in a new model year. The General Motors Corporation followed suit with its rebate program.

title: Aim Telephones reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $221,000, or 5 cents a share, from a change in accounting principle.

title: Rowan Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pharmacontrol Corp reports earnings for Year to June 30
Five Nuns Decline to Speak With Priest Sent to Negotiate
description: Five nuns who have locked themselves in a wing of their monastery's infirmary refused today to meet with a priest that their bishop said was a Vatican representative sent to help resolve the dispute over changes in their style of living.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 58.

title: Charlotte Buzzing Over the Hornets
description: George Shinn is a self-made millionaire and had no trouble putting together $32.5 million for a National Basketball Association expansion team. He also delivers inspirational talks and writes motivational books, and his positive approach helped him just as much as his money in realizing his dream of owning a sports franchise.

title: I.B.M. Net Rises 3.3% In Quarter
description: Reflecting strength in the middle and the top of its product line, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that its third-quarter net income rose 3.3 percent, to $1.25 billion. Analysts predicted that the worst was now behind the computer maker after its struggle to restructure itself and control costs.

title: Networks Shift on Debate
description: In a significant shift in coverage of the Presidential debates, the television networks declared George Bush the victor Thursday night. Page 8.

title: Tyson Files for Divorce
description: Mike Tyson contended in divorce papers filed in Trenton yesterday that his wife, Robin Givens, had no intention of making their marriage successful and married him for his money and fame.

title: Senate Votes to Carry Out Treaty Banning Genocide
description: The Senate gave final legislative approval tonight to a change in American laws that will permit the United States to join 97 other countries in an international treaty outlawing genocide. The treaty was first proposed 40 years ago by President Truman.

title: Producer Prices Up Last Month A Modest 0.4%
description: Prices at the producer level rose a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent in September as higher food prices were offset by a big drop in energy costs, the Labor Department reported today.

title: In Winner's Circle, Jockey Is Mourned
description: The Belmont Park bugler, who calls the horses to the post nine times a day, blew taps yesterday morning as 200 race-trackers gathered in the winner's circle to mourn the death of Michael Venezia, the 43-year-old jockey who was killed in the fifth race Thursday.

title: Man Facing Ouster for War Crimes Flees U.S.
description: A former pro-Nazi Latvian police commander long facing deportation from the United States in connection with World War II atrocities has secretly fled to West Germany, apparently with false documents, Government investigators said yesterday.

title: Health Images Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Biogen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: MELVIN FRANK, PRODUCER, DIRECTOR AND WRITER OF MOVIES, DIES AT 75
description: Melvin Frank, half of a prolific team that wrote, produced and directed some of Hollywood's wittiest romantic comedies, including ''Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House,'' died of complications from open-heart surgery on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 75 years old.

title: Miami News May Be Closed
description: Cox Enterprises Inc. said today that it would close The Miami News at the end of the year if it did not find a buyer for the money-losing afternoon newspaper.

title: Yale Given Letters Written by Gandhi
description: Fifty letters and postcards written by Mahatma Gandhi to a woman he grew to treat like a daughter have been donated to Yale University.

title: Cleveland-Cliffs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $300,000 and $2,700,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $400,000 for the quarter and $17,400,000 for the 9 months. In the year-ago quarter, preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: Iomega Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Sure Loser in the Debate: The Format
description: Overnight polls show, some by nearly 2-to-1 margins, that Vice President Bush got the better of Governor Dukakis in Thursday's Presidential debate. Mr. Dukakis's forces concede nothing. There was, however, one certain loser: the public, which could have learned more about both men in a less rigid format, one offering the chance of spontaneity.

title: Industry Output Fails to Rise For First Time in 7 Months
description: Industrial production in September failed to rise for the first time in seven months, suggesting to economists that the overheated manufacturing sector is cooling a bit.

title: 2 Carolina Indians Acquitted in Hostage Taking
description: Two Tuscarora Indians who took over a newspaper office and held hostages for 10 hours in what they said was a protest against local corruption were found not guilty of all charges today.

title: Companies' Consumer Offices Gain Leverage and Respect
description: One day last summer, 10 consumer advocates entered the offices of the American Express Company in New York on a most unusual mission: to evaluate the work of the company's consumer-affairs office.

title: New York's Highest Court Rejects Family's Plea in Right-to-Die Case
description: New York's highest court ruled yesterday that an elderly woman who has suffered debilitating strokes must be kept alive through artificial feeding, even though her daughters insist that she would prefer to die.

title: National Micronetics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: b-After tax credits of $332,000 for the latest first quarter and $53,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Noland Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A's Come to Los Angeles Relishing Role of Heavy Favorites
description: They are the favorites here, and they seem to like it. The Oakland Athletics, a team still being carried by its sweeping momentum in the American League playoff, rolled into Dodger Stadium today and announced plans to make the 85th World Series a brief one. Meet the heavies. ''Look around,'' said Jose Canseco, the A's right fielder and leading slugger. ''Our game is more well-rounded than the Dodgers', and we're coming into the series with several advantages. Our ace will be able to pitch two or three times if we need him; we've got better hitters; we've more power, more speed. I'd say we're a more qualified team.

title: Drug Charges for Banks
description: Chip Banks, a linebacker with the San Diego Chargers, was arrested last night on charges of possession of cocaine and marijuana, the police said. An Atlanta police spokesman, Sgt. G.E. Smith, said Banks was arrested at a routine police roadblock after a search of his car turned up about half an ounce of marijuana and four packets of crack cocaine. He also had no driver's license, Smith said.

title: A Device to Correct Rhythm of the Heart
description: Todd J. Cohen, a cardiology fellow at the Stanford University Medical Center in Palo Alto, Calif., won a patent this week for a device to correct the rhythm of a malfunctioning heart.

title: Time to Start on High-Speed National Rail
description: To the Editor:

title: Unimpressive Showing
description: Keith Hernandez and Gregg Jefferies of the Mets, who were coached as teen-agers in California youth baseball games by Tony Santora, may not be looking forward to seeing their old coach soon, after the way they performed in the final game of the National League playoff series against the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Kentucky Utilities Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
77 Aliens, in Debt to Smugglers, Found in Captivity in California
description: A three-bedroom house here became a debtors' prison for 77 illegal aliens who could not afford to pay the smugglers who brought them into the United States from Mexico, the authorities said Thursday.

title: Partition of Tiny Burundi Is Not the Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: Lojack Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $12,000 and $38,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: International Minerals & Chemcial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $17.5 million, or 72 cents a share, related to IFL's sale of shares to the public in July 1988 and the subsequent redemption of IFL's exchangeable preferred stock, series A. The company said the adjusted results for the year-ago quarter assume the following fiscal 1988 events or transactions were completed as of June 30, 1987: the IMC Fertilizer initial public offering (IPO), payment of dividends from IMC Fertilizer prior to the IPO, redemption of the company's holdings of IMC Fertilizer preferred stock, and reduction of the company's common equity interest in IMC Fertilizer to approximately 38 percent; and further assume elimination of nonrecurring items and earnings from Mallinckrodt's operations divested in 1988, utilization of the cash proceeds from these transactions for debt repayment and short-term investments; and elimination of the net credit to earnings from an extraordinary item. The company also said IMC Fertilizer Group Inc. (IFL) results were consolidated through Jan. 31, 1988. Subsequent to the IFL initial public offering on Feb. 2, 1988, which reduced IMC common stock ownership in IFL to 47 percent, the equity method of accounting was used. The company's first quarter sales in fiscal 1988 included $226.4 million of IFL sales. In July 1988, IFL concluded a subsequent public offering of 5,000,000 common shares at a price of $40 a share. The sale of these additional shares reduced IMC's common stock ownership in IFL to approximately 38 percent. In September 1988, the proceeds of that offering plus $8 million from IFL general funds were used to redeem for $200 million the outstanding shares of IFL's exchangeable preferred stock, series A, all of which were owned by IMC.

title: Delchamps Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,046,000 from a tax adjustment.

title: Cooper Tire & Rubber Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in August 1988.

title: Grandparents to Keep Baby
description: The paternal grandparents of a baby born and abandoned in an airplane restroom will be allowed to keep the child in their New York home but the court will retain legal custody of the infant, a court ruled today.

title: System Uses Seawater To Make Methanol Fuel
description: John H. Perry Jr., founder of Perry Oceanographics Inc., in Riviera Beach, Fla., won patent approval this week for a system to produce methanol fuel from seawater.

title: FNW Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The bank said the figures have been adjusted where applicable to reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid June 1, 1987.

title: Brothers Come of Age With New Bid
description: Because of their youth, the Rales brothers were known as ''raiders in short pants'' when they came out of nowhere and began to take over a string of manufacturing companies nearly a decade ago. Now, with their $2.6 billion bid for Interco Inc., the brothers have joined the big boys in the front ranks of the hostile takeover game.

title:
CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Coping: With Automobile Alarms
description: LEAD: If you are in the market for an automobile alarm, remember the last time you were awakened by the wail of a primitive one, the kind that started screaming when a car was bumped and howled until the owner arrived to reset it.

title: Ponce Federal Bank FSB reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Theater; This Florence Nightingale Knew How to Fight a War
description: As Lytton Strachey made clear in his book ''Eminent Victorians,'' Florence Nightingale was not the delicate ''Lady With the Lamp'' of Victorian legend but a medical pioneer who was both ''fierce and passionate.'' In the real Florence Nightingale, he said, there was ''more that was interesting'' and also ''less that was agreeable.''

title: Traffic Note
description: Fifth Avenue between 62d and 82d Streets will be closed today from 11 A.M. until 3:30 P.M. for a New York Road Runners Club one-mile race. Second Avenue between 14th and 34th Streets will be closed tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. for the Autumn Jubilee street fair.

title: Tolland Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Drug Arrests Near Schools
description: In a crackdown on drug dealing near schools, police officers have arrested 83 people, seized 10 firearms including an AK-47 assault rifle and confiscated five and a half ounces of rock cocaine, or crack. In the sweep Wednesday 250 police officers posed as drug buyers near elementary and junior high schools.

title: Ross Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Laidlaw Transportation reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Daughter Tells Of Phone Call Over Myerson
description: Sukhreet Gabel provided dramatic testimony yesterday about confronting her parents after learning that her mother was the judge handling the divorce case of Bess Myerson's companion.

title: Two Ways to Prevent Another Crisis in Banks and Thrifts
description: LEAD: As Congress copes with the daunting problems of our savings and loans and the impending insolvency of the F.S.L.I.C., which insures their deposits, it has to guard against the temptation to simply throw money at the problem while failing to address the underlying deficiencies.

title: Estimate Board Votes Second Prison Barge
description: The New York City Board of Estimate voted early yesterday to spend more than $17 million to buy a second floating prison barge, which the Koch administration hopes will help relieve jail overcrowding by housing about 400 inmates starting next spring.

title: James W. Kynes, Executive, 60
description: James W. Kynes, a lawyer, business executive and former Attorney General of Florida, died of stomach cancer Thursday at his home in Tampa. He was 60 years old.

title: Intech Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 16
description: b-Net loss Shares earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in August.

title: Intermagnetics General Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-Includes about $285,000 of non- recurring income associated with the formation of a joint venture.

title: Partition of Tiny Burundi Is Not the Answer; Don't Call Them Tribes
description: To the Editor:

title: Pioneer-Standard Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hyatt Waggoner, 74, Author and Professor
description: Hyatt H. Waggoner, an author and professor emeritus of English at Brown University, died of emphysema Thursday at Hanover Terrace Health Care in New Hampshire. He was 74 years old and lived in Rochester, Vt.

title: Review/Dance; New Graham Work Revisits American Indian
description: The world of Martha Graham is a creative universe and in her wondrous new ''Night Chant'' she has delved into the American Indian experience and produced a work of magic theater.

title: Quayle Says Dukakis Isn't Courteous, Either
description: Senator Dan Quayle complained today that Gov. Michael S. Dukakis did not have ''the common courtesy'' in Thursday night's Presidential debate to say a kind word about Vice President Bush.

title: The A's Revolve Around Canseco's Excellence
description: So much has been spoken and written that it has already begun to sound like legend, as if Jose Canseco is somehow more myth than man. They say he is the strongest player in baseball, that he has the greatest natural gifts, the swiftest and the smoothest swing, the most fearsome arm. Exactly where the truth lies is difficult to tell.

title: Hibernia Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hunt, J B Transport Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,556,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Park Communications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ISC Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 23
Finns Clarify Deng Remarks On a Chinese-Soviet Summit
description: Revising an earlier statement, the Finnish Foreign Minister says Deng Xiaoping told a visiting delegation that a Chinese-Soviet summit meeting is possible, but not necessarily likely, in 1989.

title: Dime Bank Dividend
description: The Dime Savings Bank of New York, which converted to stock ownership from mutual ownership two years ago, declared its first quarterly cash dividend of 15 cents a share. The dividend was declared despite weaker earnings than bank officials expected. Earnings in the third quarter of $18.3 million, or 80 cents a share, were down 29.1 percent from $25.8 million, or $1.13 a share, a year earlier. The 15-cent quarterly dividend, or an annual rate of 60 cents, results in a yield of 3.8 percent based on yesterday's closing stock price of $15.625.

title: The Nixon Prediction: Bush, by a Landslide
description: In a letter to his friends, former President Richard M. Nixon said this week that Vice President Bush would win in a landslide unless he became overconfident or there was ''dramatic improvement'' in Michael S. Dukakis's ''pathetically amateurish campaign.''

title: EX-JACKSON GROUP TO SETTLE CLAIMS
description: The educational program formerly headed by the Rev. Jesse Jackson agreed today to pay $550,000 to the Government to settle long-standing civil claims that the group had not lived up to the terms of several grants and contracts awarded in the late 1970's and early 1980's.

title: 2 Rescued From Fire In Brooklyn Building
description: A man and a pregnant woman were rescued from a burning building early yesterday after they were found unconscious in a smoky room, authorities said.

title: Williams, W W Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Visual Arts Exchange Developed With Soviets
description: An agreement signed by the United States and the Soviet Union this week will enable visual arts specialists from the two countries to share their archives, conservation workshops and museum collections.

title: West Mass Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The bank said the latest quarter reflected the one-time start-up costs of a new computer system.

title: Japan Concern Bankrupt
description: Nippon Tochi, a real estate company noted for stock speculation, filed for bankruptcy Thursday, citing debts equivalent to $1.2 billion, a court official said. Nippon Tochi asked the Osaka District Court for protection from 256 creditors. Nippon Tochi's petition, which declared 156 billion yen in liabilities, was the third-largest bankruptcy filing ever made in Japan.

title: Chicago Crimes Raise Conflicts on Witness's Duty
description: Four times in the last month, riders on Chicago's transit system have witnessed singularly brutal acts of violence: two murders, a rape and a slashing, each of them carried out in full view of horrified onlookers.

title: St. Martin-in-the-Fields
description: The Academy of St. Martin-in-the-Fields, directed by its concertmaster, Iona Brown, is to perform a Purcell Chaconne (Z. 730), Schoenberg's ''Verklarte Nacht,'' Britten's ''Simple'' Symphony and a chamber version of Beethoven's ''Grosse Fuge'' (Op. 133) at 3 P.M. tomorrow at Avery Fisher Hall. Tickets are $20 to $11. Information: 874-6770.

Constitution Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dash Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
STOCKS MIXED AS DOW SLIPS BY 0.18
description: LEAD: Stock prices were mixed in moderate trading yesterday as investors digested a slew of economic news.

title: Giants Hope They Can Feast on Lions
description: Bill Parcells won't admit it, his players won't acknowledge it, and his opponent isn't about to concede it. But after six straight games against playoff-caliber opponents, the Giants are hoping to have a momentum-building game against the struggling Detroit Lions at Giants Stadium on Sunday.

title: Pension Vesting Change

description: b-Includes tax benefits of $18,000 for the quarter and $119,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax benefits of $528,000 and $1,197,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: This Drug Bill Deserves to Die
description: The 100th Congress appears determined not to leave town without serving up a tough-sounding bill on drugs. While the Senate has offered sensible new thinking, any final version now will include an expansion of the death penalty that renders the whole bill unacceptable.

description: b-Net loss

title: KEY RATES
Honeywell Sues Unisys on Units
description: Honeywell Inc. has filed a $350 million lawsuit against the Unisys Corporation, accusing the giant computer maker of artificially inflating the financial strength of four aerospace operations that Honeywell bought for more than $1 billion in 1986. In September, Unisys charged that Honeywell had failed to pay $565,000 it said was due under the sales agreement.

title: Redman Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Reagan Sends Warning To Managua on Rebels
description: President Reagan said today that he ''would not hesitate'' to call a special session of Congress to release $16.5 million in stockpiled United States aid for the Nicaraguan rebels if the Sandinista Government should attack them.

title: Nichols Research Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
First Colonial Bankshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
In Yugoslavia, a Charge of 'Stalinist!'
description: The President of one Yugoslav republic accused the party leader of another today of aspiring to strong leadership based on a Stalinist concept.

title: Bridge; American open team remains in second place after two victories.
description: The American open team held steady in qualifying play today at the World Team Olympiad. It tied 15-15 with Panama and then defeated Turkey 19-11 and Kenya 25-2, retaining second position in its pool behind the Greek team. The leaders were: first, Greece, 366; second, the United States, 358; third, Austria, 351.5; fourth, Norway, 330.7; fifth, Sweden, 323, and sixth, Poland, 318.2.

title: Final Effort by Icahn and Union Seen
description: Carl C. Icahn and the head of the machinists' union at Eastern Airlines plan to meet over the weekend in a final effort to determine whether they can come up with an offer to acquire Eastern, union sources close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Review/Music; Shostakovich, With Boisterous Bernstein
description: If international orchestras have lost their individual voices, the best of them have become wonders of adaptability. The New York Philharmonic spent a good deal of Thursday's program at Avery Fisher Hall dealing with the quiet, dignified manner of Shostakovich's A minor Violin Concerto, yet elsewhere it bashed away convincingly at Leonard Bernstein in his most boisterous mood.

title: National Commerce Bancorporation reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rates Little Changed by Economic Data
description: Interest rates were little changed yesterday as a welter of fresh statistics on inflation, retail sales and industrial production did not clarify the outlook for the economy.

title: To the Tories, Thatcher Stays to Rule
description: Will the Conservative Party rule Britain into the 21st century? If you asked that question here this week during the annual conference of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party, the answer was yes, and why not?

description: b-After a $2,666,000 credit from the repurchase of bonds for the both periods. c-Net income

description: The Federal Trade Commission will not block Brooke Partners, an entity controlled by Bennett S. LeBow, from buying more than $15 million of shares of American Brands or from possibly seeking control. A 30-day waiting period ended yesterday in which the F.T.C. could have requested additional information on the stock purchases.

title: Lemieux Leads Canadiens Past Devils
description: The seventh opener at Byrne Meadowlands Arena will be remembered for two reasons by the Devils and their fans.

title: Lasorda Serves Pasta With Baloney
description: In the hours before the main event, Tommy Lasorda fed a linguine supper to his players and their families to celebrate their victory over the Mets, made an evangelical appearance on the Johnny Carson show, shed crocodile tears in a dozen news conferences and announced that he would pitch his star rookie, Tim Belcher, against Dave Stewart of the favored Oakland Athletics in the opening game of the World Series.
