Boise Cascade Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Koch Nominates Transit Adviser For Taxi Post
description: Mayor Koch yesterday nominated his transportation adviser, Jack S. Lusk, for a seat on the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission, and if the City Council approves that appointment, Mr. Koch said he would then make Mr. Lusk the commission's new chairman.

title: Head of Group At GTE Quits
description: The GTE Corporation has said that James L. Broadhead resigned on Thursday as president of the company's Telephone Operating Group, which last year accounted for about $12 billion of the company's $15.4 billion in sales. Mr. Broadhead had held the post for two years.

title: Review/Pop; Frenetic English Reggae
description: UB40, the English reggae pop group riding the success of its hit ''Red Red Wine,'' played to a sold-out audience at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night.

title: Yankee Companies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $700,000 for the quarter and a loss of $5,899,000 for the year, both from the disposal of discontinued operations, and gains from the restructuring of debt of $736,000 for the quarter and $22,888,000 for the year. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $28,080,000 for the quarter and $29,683,000 for the year, and gains of $8,544,000 for the quarter and $4,883,000 for the year, both on the disposal of discontinued operations; the year also included a charge of $569,000 from the restructuring of debt.

title: Charles J. McCarthy, 94, Aircraft Designer
description: Charles J. McCarthy, an aircraft designer and pioneer in the development of naval aircraft, died of heart failure Thursday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 94 years old.

title: Castle & Cooke Head Offers Allegheny Plan
description: David H. Murdock, the chairman of Castle & Cooke Inc., today joined the list of potential suitors who want to obtain control of Allegheny International Inc., the consumer products company that is in the midst of Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5, 32 Washington will withhold some dues to the United Nations this year until a committee approves a new austerity budget and other administrative changes, the Reagan Administration said. Page 1 Mikhail Gorbachev may not succeed in his efforts to transform the Soviet economy because ''the downward spiral of the Soviet economy'' has not slowed, said Robert M. Gates, Deputy Director of Central Intelligence. 1 The President of South Korea, Roh Tae Woo, said he would ask the United Nations and its member countries to help bring about a reconciliation with North Korea. 1 The United States can join a treaty outlawing genocide now that the Senate approved a change in American laws. The proposal had been blocked by a battle over whether to mandate capital punishment for genocide. 2 A former pro-Nazi officer fled secretly to West Germany, apparently with false documents, Government investigators said. He is Boleslav Maikovskis, an 84-year-old retired carpenter from Mineola, L.I. 4 Name-calling by Yugoslav leaders included an incident in which the President of the Republic of Slovenia, called the Serbian leader, Slobodan Milosevic, a Stalinist. 4 The Chilean opposition is to unite behind a single presidential candidate, avoiding a split between the Christian Democrats and the Socialists, a 16-party coalition announced. 3 Tories may continue to rule Britain well into the next decade, and some have begun seeking a successor to Margaret Thatcher. Meanwhile, the Labor Party remains in disarray. 3 Cuba, Angola deny there is yet a firm troop pullout schedule 32 National 6-9 Officials knew of radioactive leaks at an Ohio nuclear weapon plant for decades but decided not to spend the money to correct the problems, a Congressional committee said. 1 Producer prices rose moderately in September, by four-tenths of 1 percent, representing a 5 percent annual inflation rate, the Labor Department said. A big drop in energy costs offset higher food prices. 1 Purchase of 11 savings institutions with an estimated $1.3 billion in aid over 10 years from the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation was agreed to by a Texas cable entrepreneur, Don A. Adam. 1 The Senate passed a drug bill that emphasizes education and rehabilitation, It includes civil penalties for possession of small amounts of drugs and the death penalty for drug traffickers who commit murder. 6 Lyndon LaRouche was charged, along with six of his associates, in a Federal conspiracy and mail fraud indictment that accused them of borrowing more than $30 million that Mr. LaRouche apparently did not intend to repay. 6 Violence on Chicago's subways has created a public outcry, and the interventions of bystanders have raised questions about how much citizens should do to prevent a crime. 6 Attracting small investors back to Wall Street a year after the stock market plunged more than 500 points is the aim of a marketing blitz by the brokerage industry. 41 California house become aliens' prison 9 Politics 8-9 Democrats conceded that the debate Thursday between the Presidential candidates did not go well for Michael Dukakis. They said that his performance fell short of what was needed to overtake George Bush. 1 George Bush battled over-confidence as he pledged to run hard over the remaining three weeks and as aides publicly predicted a close race. But hiding glee over Thursday's debate was tough. 8 Michael Dukakis began new assaults on George Bush, saying Thursday's debate was ''strike three'' against the Republicans. His aides denied that he had lost a critical opportunity in the debate. 9 The networks said George Bush won Thursday's debate, though they had avoided picking a winner in the two previous debates. The cause, they say, was instant polls and a sense that Mr. Bush was an obvious victor. 8 Richard Nixon predicted that George Bush would win in a landslide unless he became overconfident or there was a change in Michael Dukakis's ''pathetically amateurish campaign.'' 8 Ex-Jackson group to pay civil claims 9 Debate fails to stir union workers in Texas 9 Regional 33-36 An elderly woman must be kept alive through artificial feeding, New York's highest court ruled, even though she has suffered debilitating strokes and her daughters insist that she would prefer to die. 1 Courts have long recognized right to self-determination 36 Thousands on welfare found jobs through a new program in New Jersey that requires able-bodied recipients to seek work, training or education in return for medical benefits, child care and transportation. 33 Testimony in the Myerson trial was provided by Sukhreet Gabel, who described confronting her parents after learning that her mother was the judge handling the divorce case of Bess Myerson's companion. 33 An inquiry into Metro-North's police by the state has merged with a separate investigation by the railroad's parent agency, the Metropolitan Transporation Authority, law-enforcement officials said. 35 The Taxi and Limousine Commission of New York City will likely get Jack Lusk, Mayor Koch's transportation adviser, as its new chairman. The City Council must first act on his appointment. 35 Two Guardian Angels were arrested on robbery and drug charges after a man said the Angels punched him and took money from him on a midtown sidewalk. One Angel had a vial of crack, the police said. 35 High school applicants enjoy menu of choices 33 Minority workers for New York City increase 35

title: Inquiry on Offshore Accounts Disclosed in Pentagon Case
description: Federal investigators looking into fraud and bribery in the Pentagon's procurement of weapons have learned about the existence of ''foreign or offshore accounts.'' Such bank accounts, a Federal law-enforcement official said, are frequently used to hide the source and ownership of money.

title: 2 Premieres
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is to open its 20th season at 5 P.M. tomorrow at Alice Tully Hall with a program that includes premieres of works by Ned Rorem and Leon Kirchner. Mr. Rorem's work, ''Hail and Farewell,'' is scored for two trumpets, two trombones and organ and was composed as a tribute to Charles Wadsworth, who is leaving his post as director of the society after this season. The Kirchner work, ''Music for 12,'' composed in 1984, is being given its New York premiere under the composer's direction. Also on the program is Schubert's ''Trout'' Quintet. Tickets are $20. Information: 874-6770.

title: Helix Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Resumes That Work
description: Autumn is a peak time for job hunting, and a well-prepared resume is the first thing you need. Several formats are now popular. A chronological resume lists experience by dates; a functional resume describes areas of job experience and skill and a targeted resume states a job goal and describes achievements and capabilities. Whatever the format, employment counselors recommend that the resume be no more than two pages, and one page is preferable. It is no longer standard to include age, health, marital status, salary or references. Here is a sample of a functional resume. PERSONAL DATA Name, address and telephone number. List office number only if you can receive calls there. EXPERIENCE In about four paragraphs, each about four sentences long, describe positions held and responsibilities. WORK HISTORY Starting with your most recent position, list dates of employment and names of employers. EDUCATION List most recent degree first, with the date and school where it was earned. Include special licenses or certificates.

title: Two Ways to Prevent Another Crisis in Banks and Thrifts
description: LEAD: A great deal of attention has been focused on the multi-billion dollar deficit in the F.S.L.I.C. insurance fund. Unfortunately, however, the question of how to treat the disease has been lost in an excessive discussion of the symptoms. The cure, however radical, is simple: Government deposit insurance should be replaced by private insurance.

title: No Sale
description: To the Editor:

title: JEREMY RIFKIN JUST SAYS NO
description: LEAD: GIANT KILLER TOMATOES . . .'' WITH A frustrated shake of his head, Jeremy Rifkin says the three words most likely to find a place in his obituary; then he laughs and proceeds to polish off a dish of apple pie and ice cream. Rifkin, 43, the nation's most persistent critic of biotechnology, author of nine books on technology and environmental issues and what he likes to call ''cultural philosophy,'' has dropped in for a late-night snack at a truckstop off Interstate 80 in central Pennsylvania.

title: ; A Pianist Who Does Just As She Likes
description: Mitsuko Uchida is still something of an enigma in the United States. Is she a new competition-winning, 18-year-old technical wizard fresh from Japan? Does she play anything other than Mozart, the composer with whom she is usually associated? Does she speak English?

title: Quilting Convention Becomes an Art Event
description: LEAD: WHAT started out as a simple quilting convention 15 years ago has evolved into an extensive multimedia art event that is expected to draw more than l50 participating artists and at least 5,000 visitors to the Hempstead House in Sands Point Preserve this week.

title: San Francisco's Military Base With Scenery
description: IN June 1776, about the time Benjamin Franklin, John Adams and Thomas Jefferson were discussing the Declaration of Independence in Philadelphia, a young Spanish soldier named Juan Bautista de Anza planted a wooden cross on a windswept hillside above San Francisco Bay and decreed that a presidio would be built on the site. A few weeks later, a small band of soldiers arrived from Monterey and began building a settlement of tule-reed houses surrounded by an adobe wall.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The glazing compound on the windows on the south and west sides of our house deteriorates rapidly, with the compound cracking and curling up. We have tried several types of compound, but none seems to last more than a couple of years on those windows. This is especially noticeable along the bottom of each pane on the windows that get the most sunlight. The compound on the other sides of the house has lasted 25 years. Do you have any suggestions on how we can get a longer-lasting job on these windows?

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: The Bare Facts The Town of Islip's naked man was getting an enthusiastic reception.

title: MIX OF MATERIALS: PATRICK NAGGAR
description: Patrick Naggar carries pictures of vintage airplanes in his sketchbook. ''The composition and the structural complexity of these early flying machines, as well as the metals they were made of, have always been an inspiration to me,'' says the architect.

title: Died-in-the-Wool Yuppie Has a Striking Proposal
description: MY husband and I are young urban professionals. Labled yuppies, we are bombarded with slick enticements for improving our minds (through psychotherapy), our bodies (through health clubs), our career (through power lunches), our homes (through Laura Ashley).

title: A Playwright Takes on Television
description: ''I've got to keep my blood pressure down,'' David Mamet says when asked about his forays as a writer and director into the television and movie executive hierarchy. ''My experience with most movie producers has been that their job is to say, in effect, 'I'll tell you why we can't do that.' Or to say, 'I get it and you get it, but are they going to get it?.' ''

title: Vatican Has a Record Deficit And Asks More Contributions
description: The Vatican today announced a record deficit of $63.8 million in 1987 and appealed to Roman Catholics throughout the world to increase their contributions to the work of the church.

title: Qian Changzhao, Politician, 89
description: Qian Changzhao, a former official in the Nationalist Government and a ranking member of the mainland version of the Nationalist Party, died Friday, the official New China News Agency said. He was 89 years old.

title: Penthouses
description: To the Editor:

title: Geri Lynn Friedlaender Marries Edward A. Band
description: Geri Lynn Friedlaender and Edward Alan Band were married last evening at the Hampshire Country Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y., by Rabbi Ari Fridkis.

title:
Numismatics;
Plans for a New Silver Dollar
description: LEAD: THE United States Mint will issue a commemorative silver dollar in 1990 to honor President Dwight D. Eisenhower on the 100th anniversary of his birth. Both houses of Congress voted to authorize the coin and President Reagan signed the legislation.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: HALF OF MAN IS WOMAN. By Zhang Xianliang. Translated by Martha Avery. (Norton, $17.95.) Zhang Xianliang's novel caused a sensation when it was published in China three years ago, though not so much because of its detailed and powerful indictment of the excesses of the Cultural Revolution or its bitterly ironic references to Chinese leaders.

title: In Pursuit of the 20th Century Express) mm
description: To Jack Cowart, one of the curators of 20th-century art at the National Gallery, it is ''a kind of coming-out party.'' Cobbled together during the last quarter-century, the museum's collection of paintings and sculptures since 1900 has over the years been displayed only sporadically, shunted aside whenever room is needed for blockbuster touring exhibitions. But now the collection forms a major show of its own. Over the last six months the museum has constructed 23 new galleries to display selections from its 20th-century holdings that will remain on view at least through 1990.

title: Thomas F. Power, 72; Led U.N. Development
description: Thomas F. Power Jr., a career diplomat with the United Nations and director of the United Nations Development Program for 26 years, died of lung cancer Thursday at the Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y.. He was 72 years old and lived in Somers, N.Y.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Midwest; Indiana Remains Unbeaten
description: Anthony Thompson rushed for 139 yards and 3 touchdowns and became Indiana's career scoring leader as the Hoosiers beat Minnesota, 33-13, in a Big Ten Conference game today.

title: Mayor's Admission of Infidelity Brings Pain to San Antonio and Questions on Press
description: For eight years, he has been cheerleader, role model, a figure of virtual reverence: not just the Mayor, but the embodiment of what many San Antonians aspire to be.

title: Amsterdam
description: To the Editor: Allow this Sephardic Jewish son of Amsterdam to commend Marylin Bender on her article about Amsterdam (Travel, Aug. 14). However, there are a few assertions that should be corrected. I lived in A'dam at the time in question and was subsequently arrested and sent to Auschwitz so I remember that nobody called de Joodse Raad the Judenrat.

title: Soviets Push for Better Europe Ties
description: With Soviet-American relations temporarily becalmed by the Presidential election, the Soviet Union is making a major push this fall to improve ties with Western Europe.

title:
BODY AND MIND;
Balloon Man
description: LEAD: IN HIS POEM THAT BEGINS ''IN JUST-SPRING,''

title: STATELY STYLE: MARK HAMPTON & MARIO BUATTA
description: Although Mario Buatta and Mark Hampton have distinct decorating styles - Buatta's chintz-filled and cluttered, Hampton's more tailored and classical - the sources of their ideas are surprisingly similar. Both decorators scour the great houses of Europe, studying the details and structure of the buildings and their interiors and even the design of their gardens.

title: CONSUMER RATES
The Bright Side of Hoover
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Winters Married To Roger D. Chiocchi
description: Eileen Frances Winters, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis C. Winters of Newport, R.I., and Roger David Chiocchi, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Chiocchi of Manasquan, N.J., were married yesterday at the Chapel-by-the-Sea in Newport by the Rev. Thomas J. Carnevale, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Reviews/Dance; Martha Graham Reworks Mythology
description: Martha Graham does more than retell old stories in her mythological dances; she also tries to revivify them and set them moving in what she once called ''the dangerous landscape of the mind.'' The Martha Graham Dance Company presented two mythological works last Sunday at the City Center Theater. The first act of ''Clytemnestra'' was performed in the afternoon, and ''Cave of the Heart,'' based on ''Medea,'' was offered in the evening. Both productions featured previously unreviewed dancers in the principal roles.

title: WHAT THEY'RE WEARING - BLACK
description: No matter how vociferously designers, stores and the press promote color for evening, good old black remains a big favorite. Certainly one gala evening last month provided ample evidence. Manhattan's National Academy of Design was awash with women in beautiful black dresses at the preview dinner for the Geoffrey Beene ''First 25 Years'' exhibition. Not unexpectedly, most of these gowns were Geoffrey Beene designs, many from his latest collection. But a surprising number of women turned up in Beenes of seasons past. It is a tribute to the designer's extraordinary ingenuity that none of the older ones looked in any way dated. But perhaps a smidgeon of credit could also go to the fact that most of them were shaped of black fabrics. For one thing, black is always in style. Also, black is a superb medium for spelling out a designer's original techniques of draping, shaping or tucking. And Geoffrey Beene is no slouch at all that. Black is also a shameless flatterer of almost every skin tone. It is a becoming frame for all gradations, from palest cream to deepest ebony. And black is an artful foil for accessories, especially pearls, diamonds or blazing gold. WHAT THEY'RE SAYING

title: Employer Praised on Day Care
description: LEAD: IT is a low-slung building of stucco cinder blocks - hardly, as Isaac Heller puts it, ''an architectural wonder.'' Yet it is a kind of wonder to 84 children, who range in age from 8 1/2 months to 5 years, and their parents.

title: GRAHAM'S ''DEEP SONG': 51 AND STILL PROTESTING
description: The revival of ''Deep Song,'' a solo that Martha Graham created for herself in 1937 during the Spanish Civil War, as well as the re-entry into her dance company's repertory of several pieces from the 1930's and 1940's, illuminates a rarely considered facet of Miss Graham's work.

title: Asbury Park Fined for Beach Pollution
description: The state of New Jersey has fined Asbury Park more than $1 million for causing the ocean pollution that closed a popular stretch of Monmouth County beaches for 19 days this summer.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-17

title: Sunday? It's Time for Brunch
description: LEAD: CHAMPAGNE mimosas, eggs Benedict, smoked salmon and even fettuccine Alfredo all spell Sunday brunch at restaurants around New Jersey. Since most of us, because of workaday schedules or cholesterol concerns, don't indulge in substantial breakfasts during the week, that leisurely cross between breakfast and lunch is a popular weekend treat.

title: Jodie Foster: Tough Hero
description: LEAD: ''People ask me, 'Why do you always play victim parts?' '' says Jodie Foster, who, in her latest movie, ''The Accused,'' portrays a woman who is gang-raped on a pinball machine in a bar as spectators cheer.

title: Anita W. Monteith Weds John Dixon, a Consultant
description: Anita White Monteith and John Charles Dixon were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Judith T. Baumer performed the ceremony.

title: Vic Raschi, Star Yankee Pitcher From 1946 to 1953, Dead at 69
description: Vic Raschi, the big right-hander who joined Allie Reynolds and Eddie Lopat in pitching the Yankees to six World Series championships over eight seasons in the 1940's and the 1950's, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Groveland, N.Y., outside Geneseo. He was 69 years old and had lived in the rural upstate area on the shore of Lake Canesus since he retired from baseball in 1955.

title: Question Of the Week; Once and For All, What About The D.H. in The Series?
description: Let the Nationals and the Americans have their own rules during the regular season, but create equal footing for the World Series. In each game, allow a team a designated hitter as long as its own starting pitcher remains in the game. When the starter is relieved, the designated hitter is out of the lineup. DENNIS JABLONSKI Weehawken, N.J.

title: The World Agrees: No More Khmer Rouge
description: IN recent months, as the diplomatic pace toward a Cambodian settlement has quickened, one issue more than any other has taken on urgency: How can the Communist Khmer Rouge guerrillas be prevented from seizing power after Vietnam withdraws its troops?

title: It's a Corker
description: SOME YEARS AGO, IN A pleasant Stockholm restaurant, I ordered a bottle of Chablis to complement a good Swedish fish. The wine was fine; so was the fish. Still, something was wrong. It was the wine bottle. The Chablis had been imported by the Swedish Government monopoly and bottled with, of all things, a screw cap.

title: Librarians' Salaries In Connecticut
description: In reference to the information presented in the article ''Survey to Examine Librarian Shortage,'' (Sept. 11), two clarifications are important.

title: Tokyo Finance Minister Is Implicated in a Scandal
description: Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa came under fire today after he changed his testimony in a stock trading scandal and disclosed Friday that 10,000 shares of the stock in question were bought in his name.

title: Canada Looks Inward as Johnson's Troubles Grow
description: Just as Canadians started to believe that the Ben Johnson affair was receding, the sprinter was back on their television screens last week. But this time, instead of dodging questions about the positive drug test that caused his disqualification as the 100-meter winner at the Olympic Games, the 26-year-old athlete was pictured coming out of a police station where he had been charged with assault and possession of a dangerous weapon.

title: For Slovenia, Even Protests Are Orderly
description: In this capital of Slovenia, a tranquil and orderly Central European city north of Balkan Yugoslavia, pedestrians wait for the green light before crossing. Graffiti ask existential questions like, ''Now where to?''

title: Game Wtih a Bit of an English Flair
description: ANYONE who does not think the English eccentric, will reconsider when it comes to the shooting season. After Aug. 12 and until Feb. 1, those privileged with large country houses start the round of shooting lunches and house parties, ''walking up'' grouse, ''pegging and unpegging'' dogs, getting out their shooting sticks and cartridge bags and hoping that their guests will not bring back birds that have been ''badly shot.''

title: LAW SCHOOL V. REALITY
description: I agree with Scott Turow's call for serious exploration, in the law schools and out of them, of ''an understanding of the moral issues that govern law.'' But I am also concerned about what seems to me a misunderstanding, by Mr. Turow and much of the profession, of what those moral issues are.

description: To the Editor:

Chief Judge Thomas C. Platt of Federal District Court in Brooklyn officiated.

description: Mr. and Mrs. John Whittemore Stokes Jr. of Memphis have announced the engagement of their daughter Miriam Dean Stokes to Francis Cabell Brown 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Brown Jr. of New York. A December wedding is planned.

title: Capitals Pummel Devils and Sauve
description: The Devils yielded three goals before they took their first shot tonight and never quite recovered from the early shock.

title: Java's Myths Retold in Dance And Puppetry
description: LEAD: IMAGINE a play of shadows cast by leather puppets that had its opening night a millenium ago and that still plays to packed houses, a dance in which the movements are described as waves and frangipani blossoms slip from the folds of the dancer's sarong as she moves slowly across a marble floor, music in which the musician is instructed to run his ring and little fingers up the strings ''like a spider.

title: How a Bush or Dukakis Victory Will Affect Jobs
description: Job CREATION, an equivocal phase once found mostly in economic textbooks, has entered the nation's political vernacular with a vengeance this election year, and both Michael S. Dukakis and George Bush are responsible.

title: Ms. Strauss Wed To Eric Schmidt

Judge Leo Yanoff of New Jersey Superior Court in Newark officiated.

title: U.S. Agent Held by Gunman
description: An American consular agent was held at gunpoint for 14 hours in the Mexican port city of Veracruz, then released unharmed Friday after the gunman surrendered to Mexican officials, the American Embassy and local justice officials said. An embassy statement said the consular agent, Edwin Culp, emerged unharmed from his office after being held by a man demanding justice in an inheritance dispute. The embassy said the gunman, Francisco Delfin Perez, a Mexican citizen, had entered Mr. Culp's office around midday on Thursday armed with a pistol.

title: TWO GENERATIONS: GROWING UP IN JERUSALEM
description: LATE ONE AFTERNOON in March, I was driving to the Hebrew University campus on Mount Scopus. Suddenly, as I was waiting near Damascus Gate for the traffic light to change, I made a decision: Instead of driving directly, as usual, through the Arab section, I turned left, taking ''the Jewish way'' -through the safe Jewish neighborhoods.

title: Correction
description: A Travel Advisory report on Sept. 25 about fall foliage misstated the telephone number for information on Rhode Island. The number is 800-556-2484; it can be used only from East Coast states from Maine through Virginia, plus West Virginia and northern Ohio. Elsewhere, the number is 401-277-2601.

title: Alex Scribner Has Wedding
description: At St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Mount Kisco, N.Y., Alexandra Crowell Scribner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard O. Scribner of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to Colin Mark Carter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Shelby H. Carter Jr. of Dallas. The Rev. Richard S. Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: Lauren Feinsot Weds Robert E. Riordan Jr.
description: At the Lotos Club in New York, Lauren Patricia Feinsot, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Aaron Feinsot of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and Robert Emmet Riordan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Riordan of New York and Miami, were married yesterday by Don Johnson, the senior leader of the Ethical Culture Society of New York.

title: Eurailpass
description: To the Editor: The statement in ''Taking Thrifty Cues From the Swiss'' (Travel, Aug. 14) that for visitors to Switzerland ''Eurailpass ... entitles them to unlimited first-class travel on the rail networks of Switzerland ...'' may be true in a technical sense, but it misleads the average tourist who does not realize that several private lines fail to qualify.

title: THE NATION: The Responsibility Issue; After 40 Years, the Silence Is Broken On a Troubled Nuclear Arms Industry
description: WITH a half-dozen Congressional committees scrambling - sometimes competing with one another - to expose the problems of the nation's nuclear weapons production industry, the Energy Department has provided a candid account of its failings. But some are beginning to wonder, why has the Government operated in virtual silence about its activities for the past 40 years?

title: DATA BANK: October 16, 1988
Easy Goer Wins Champagne
description: Easy Goer continued to look like the most promising 2-year-old in the last five years when he scored an easy victory in the Champagne Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. But his filly counterpart had a much closer call in the $349,200 Frizette.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: GONE THE SUN. By Winston Groom. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Winston Groom's previous fiction has explored the war in Vietnam (''Better Times Than These'') and corruption in a small Southern town (''As Summers Die''), and his fifth novel continues with both of these concerns. ''Gone the Sun'' chronicles the life and death of an Alabama newspaper editor named Beau Gunn, a Vietnam veteran who comes to a fateful crossroads when he covers a story of murder and oil-business fraud in his hometown.

title: Plane to the Game
description: Donald J. Trump has acquired an air carrier that could, among other things, shuttle people back and forth between pieces of Trump-owned real estate. Mr. Trump agreed last week to pay $365 million in cash for the Eastern Airlines shuttle. The highly profitable service now runs between New York City, Washington and Boston, and Mr. Trump said he was considering adding a stop in Atlantic City, where he owns two hotel-casinos. Mr. Trump, who expects to take over the carrier in December, said all current shuttle employees would keep their jobs and get new uniforms, presumably in keeping with his stated intention of providing ''immaculate'' air service. No great suspense surrounded the question of what the real-estate developer would call his new acquisition.

title: Recitals by a Soprano, A Cellist and a Violinist
description: Anne Nispel

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE DUCHESS OF WINDSOR: The Secret Life. By Charles Higham. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.) There is always something more to say about the Duke and Duchess of Windsor - the man who was King Edward VIII of England and the compelling, controversial woman for whom he gave up the throne. A lot of it is not very nice.

title: Zoning the 'Land of Milk and Honey'
description: AS the town of Goshen gets ready to celebrate its 250th birthday, it finds itself beset by development pressures and legal battles over zoning laws. The outcome will determine what will become of this former farming community in the future.

title: Norwalk Symphony Hall is Redone
description: AFTER three and a half years in a temporary auditorium, the Norwalk Symphony wil return to its acoustically refurbished concert hall on Saturday in the renovated Norwalk City Hall. The occasion marks the symphony's 50th season and 300th concert.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Pittsburgh
description: THE largest mixed-use development in this area is rising in Robinson Township, about 15 miles west of downtown and two miles east of the Greater Pittsburgh International Airport.

title: HOW SWEET IT IS
description: A SIMPLE PIECE OF PIE OR A BOWL OF ICE cream barely qualifies as dessert anymore. Instead, diners are scanning the menu for something that's unforgettably rich and intense. That may explain why a number of chefs are presenting more elaborate, more voluptuous and even more desserts on the plate. A few chefs are offering three or four desserts at once, each a variation on a single flavor.

title: 2 Stand Trial for Bribery on Alaska's North Slope
description: One of Alaska's most powerful political lobbyists has gone on trial here on Federal charges of bribery and racketeering, accused with a business associate of corrupting the Eskimo-led North Slope Borough government to reap millions of dollars in illegal gains.

title: U.S. Concludes Accord to Run Philippine Bases
description: The United States and the Philippines reached agreement today on terms for continued operation of American bases in the Philippines through September 1991, Administration officials said.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN PET SUPPLIES;
A FUTON OFR SLEEPING, A CHATEAU FOR SHELTER
description: LEAD: Karen's For People And Pets, the Bergdorf Goodman of pet couture, caters to Park Avenue dogs and Fifth Avenue cats with $140 fur coats, $120 leather jackets with optional snakeskin trim and gem-studded necklaces. Those are a few of the items available in the 450-square-foot specialty store on Lexington Avenue.

title: Miss Moynahan Becomes a Bride
description: At St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake, N.J., Patricia Anne Moynahan, the daughter of Theodore J. Moynahan of New York and the late Rosemary T. Moynahan, was married yesterday to Richard Clarence Rice, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Rice of Marietta, Ga. The Rev. Jeremiah V. McGinley performed the ceremony.

IN SHORT;
FICTION

Dick was best known for his many works of science fiction, including ''The Man in the High Castle,'' a Hugo Award winner, and ''Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?,'' which came to the screen in 1982, the year of Dick's death, as ''Blade Runner.

title: 11 Judges Approved by Senate
description: The Senate approved 11 of President Reagan's judicial appointments on Friday, but at least 15 others have virtually no chance of approval before Congress adjourns for the year.

title: To Dukakis, It's All Too Clear Where George Is
description: AFTER three months and two debates against Vice President Bush, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's challenge remains what it has been since the Democratic convention in July: How to get past two forces that keep leaping into the ring on the side of his rival.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''He did not buy this thing to put Atlantic City on the airline map. '' Timothy Pettee, analyst at Bear, Stearns, on Donald Trump's latest deal.

title: Sex Scenes: Handle With Utmost Care
description: Since the plot of the courtroom drama ''The Accused'' hinges on the facts of a rape case and the manner in which they will be perceived by a jury, there's a lot riding on how the film depicts the crime. Will the rape be presented in an exploitative way? Will its impact be used to anger and upset the audience? Or will the event be handled so that it does not interfere with the viewer's objective judgment of the case? Where the treatment of this all-important and potentially inflammatory episode is concerned, the film itself is, in a sense, on trial.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Washington, D.C.;
Developing The Waterfront
description: LEAD: AN architectural and development firm is trying to get eight acres on Washington's gritty industrial peninsula rezoned for a $200 million project with 1.3 million square feet of office space and 900 housing units proposed by Theodore F. Mariani & Associates.

title: RUNAWAY GLACIER
description: YEAR OF CHANGE More About ''The New Yorker'' & Me. By E. J. Kahn Jr. 295 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: James D. Madigan 3d, Lawyer, 37
description: James D. Madigan 3d, a lawyer who specialized in labor law and taught at the Brooklyn Law School, died of Hodgkin's disease yesterday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 37 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Knoxville, Tenn.;
A Downtown Boon or Bane?
description: LEAD: TO some people, the planned campus-style headquarters of Whittle Communications will be the centerpiece of a rejuvenated downtown; to others, it is another scheme to enrich owners and developers at the expense of taxpayers.

title: Without Electric Power System Expansion, We Face Blackouts
description: To the Editor:

title: Winning Streak Ends for Columbia
description: Cockiness, not normally the byproduct of a single victory in five years of football, nonetheless pervaded football practice at Columbia all week. Coach Larry McElreavy could sense it, and he did what he could to stop it. But by week's end, it was still there: what McElreavy called an air of looseness about the team, an air of confidence among the players.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS OF THE BURGER COURT. By Bernard Schwartz. (Oxford University, $34.50.) As he did in his 1985 volume, ''The Unpublished Opinions of the Warren Court,'' Bernard Schwartz, Webb Professor of Law at New York University, examines the process that led to 10 of the most important decisions of the Warren E. Burger era on the Supreme Court. He embroiders drafts of the decisions with finely detailed commentary on the conferences, the assignment of opinions and the zigzags of consensus. Like most of what is written about the Court's inner workings, ''The Unpublished Opinions of the Burger Court'' has a fascinated tone and scrutinizes incidents of judicial deal-making that may or may not be significant. At the same time, it explains, uncondescendingly, why the politicking matters. For example, Roe v. Wade, the 1973 decision striking down most state restrictions on abortion, would have evaded the core constitutional issue - the right to privacy - had the Court adopted Justice Harry A. Blackmun's initial, narrowly drawn opinion; instead, the Court identified a right to abortion that has changed both social attitudes and constitutional jurisprudence. The assertion of personal rights preoccupied the Court in its 17 years under Mr. Burger from 1969 to 1986, and is a principal theme for Mr. Schwartz. However, his main purpose is not to illuminate the law but to show how it is made. Will writing about the Justices' deliberations inhibit them? Mr. Schwartz naturally disputes the suggestion. Besides, he adds, ''no other governmental institution could be subjected to comparable scrutiny of its internal processes and come out so well.''

title: Gandhi Assassins Get Time to Petition for Mercy
description: Two men convicted of assassinating Prime Minister Indira Gandhi four years ago have been given until next Wednesday to petition for mercy or face execution by hanging.

title: Some Questions On Plans for Islip
description: While no one can argue with the fact that Central Islip will surely benefit from an influx of new industry and commerce, and new homes there are points in your article ''Central Islip Gets New Plans for Revitalization'' [ Aug. 28 ] that need to be questioned.

title: Europe's Failing Effort To Exile Toxic Trash
description: IN the town of Manfredonia on Italy's Adriatic coast, recently, there was a general strike and the city council resigned en masse to protest the Italian Government's efforts to get the port to accept the Deep Sea Carrier, a ship hauling more than 2,000 tons of toxic waste back to Italy from Koko, Nigeria. The week before, the Karin B., carrying 2,100 tons of toxic waste from the same Nigerian landfill, finally received permission to land in Livorno, Italy, ending a nine-week odyssey during which six European countries refused to let it dock.

title: June Cleaver Without Pearls (Annie Leibovitz)
description: ''Good men,'' says the comedienne Roseanne Barr, ''don't just happen. They have to be created by us women.'' Ms. Barr, who crunches on Cheetos during her stand-up routine and delights in dumping on doltish husbands, should know. Self-dubbed ''America's favorite domestic goddess,'' she is the star of ABC's much-talked-about situation comedy, ''Roseanne,'' which has its debut on Tuesday night at 8:30.

description: Reggie Lawrence of Huntingdon, Tenn., has trouble with the name Dukakis. ''It sounds like somebody in Indonesia or Greece or someplace overseas,'' he told some political reporters he'd run into at a local cafe. ''It just doesn't sound American.''

title: DU PONT DISPUTES CHARGES ON SAFETY AT NUCLEAR PLANT
description: In a sharp disagreement with the Department of Energy, the head of the Du Pont company says the Government is playing politics with the Savannah River nuclear weapon plant, which the department has shut down, and is exaggerating the problems to get money to build a new reactor.

title: Mary McClellan, Executive, Weds
description: Mary Katherine McClellan and Patrick Antoine Longmire were married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church on Nantucket, Mass. The Revs. Douglas G. Tompkins and Joyce U. Tompkins performed the ceremony.

title: When Bedfellows Make Strange Politics
description: EVERY marriage has its ups and downs, but back in '84 when my husband told me he was voting for the Presidential candidate who supported every issue I opposed, I knew we were in trouble. How could I live with a man whose values were diametrically opposed to mine? So I told him, ''Go with me for counseling or pack your bags.''

title:
GARDENING;
The Many Glorious Varieties of Apples
description: LEAD: THE apple crop is 23 percent smaller than the record harvest last year, and in addition to higher prices, the inferior quality of the mass-market produce could well lead gardeners to grow their own.

title: Kevin Sjodin Wed To Pamela Akers
description: Pamela Renee Akers and Kevin Andrew Sjodin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton F. Sjodin of Fairfield, Conn., were married on Oct. 1, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John F. Akers of Westport, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass., have announced. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert L. Bast and the Rev. Thomason L. Newcomb at St. Timothy's Episcopal Church in Fairfield.

title: A Girl's Peace Mission to Moscow
description: FROM the beginning, it was a most unusual project for a group of five children: to embark on a three-week international peace mission on behalf of children who had died in wars since 1930.

title: C. Ellis Schiffmacher, 79, Counsel to Towns
description: C. Ellis Schiffmacher, a lawyer who represented many municipalities and government agencies on Long Island, died Thursday at his home in Great Neck. He was 79 years old.

title: Syracuse Rallies To Win a Big One
description: A crowd of 85,916, the second-largest in Beaver Stadium history, turned out expecting to see Penn State avenge a 48-21 loss to Syracuse last year. Instead, it saw Syracuse become only the 11th team in Joe Paterno's 23 years as head coach to score consecutive victories over the Nittany Lions. Syracuse, trailing by a point at halftime, rallied for 18 second-half points to defeat Penn State, 24-10.

title: Leslie M. Ginway Wed To Peter Craig Gambee
description: The wedding of Leslie McDowell Ginway, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Ginway of Lake Forest, Ill., and Mantoloking, N.J., to Peter Craig Gambee, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Craig Gambee of Weston, Conn., took place yesterday at All Saints' Episcopal Church in Bay Head, N.J. The Rev. Hugh McGlashon Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: A Year After the Crash, Climbing Back; Resilient Economy Puts Home Buyers Back into Market
description: A YEAR after Wall Street quaked last Oct. 19, tumbling much of the real estate market with it, most residential properties have sprung back smartly. But those closest to the epicenter - houses and apartments destined for buyers with incomes earned from the financial markets - are still slithering around in a slough of weakness.

title: Baymen Return to the Net Game
description: LEAD: FOR baymen on Long Island, it appears to be a case of giving with one hand and taking with the other.

title: Campaign Worries Goldwater
description: Barry Goldwater, concerned about the tenor of the Presidential campaign, urged Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis on Friday to ''quit calling each other names'' and concentrate on important issues like the national debt and Federal budget deficits.

title: Paris by Bus
description: To the Editor: After dinner in Paris several years ago my wife and I impulsively boarded a No. 72 bus on the Rue de Rivoli and enjoyed a beautiful ride that went on and on with fewer and fewer passengers until we were alone with the young driver and his uniformed female companion. At St. Cloud we were informed that it was the end of the line. We made no move to leave - ready for the return trip.

title: A Breathtaking Bridge Soars High Over Tampa Bay
description: The most surprising thing about the Sunshine Skyway Bridge, the central section of the 8.1-mile causeway across Tampa Bay that opened to traffic last year, is that it isn't ugly. It is, in fact, more than not ugly. It is startlingly beautiful, which makes it unlike almost any other bridge of the last generation. Most new bridges, at least in this country, have been clunky, heavy structures of concrete or steel, with none of the grace of the great suspension bridges of the late 19th and early to mid-20th centuries. But this bridge soars over the water with a lyrical and tensile strength.

title: An 'Attractive' Art Stock

Goldy) Wakefield $190,000 2027 Edenwald Avenue 2-family, semi-attached, brick house; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath, large kitchen in each unit; full basement, attached 1-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,400 (Broker: Cancro Realty) BROOKLYN Flatlands $192,500 5801 Avenue L 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, semiattached, aluminum-sided house; dining room, large kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage, 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $849 (Broker: Fogarty Real Estate) Park Slope $146,500 499 12th Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 900-sq.-ft. co-op in a recently renovated prewar building; windowed dining area, fireplace, remodeled kitchen and bath; maintenance $280, 53% tax-deductible (Broker: Warren Lewis Realty) QUEENS Elmhurst $385,000 3-family, semi-attached, brick house; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath, dining room, large kitchen, terrace in two upper units; studio with large kitchen on first floor; 1-car garage, 23- by 138-ft. lot; taxes $1,867 (Broker: Century 21/Elms Realty) Springfield Gardens $102,000 177-25 130th Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, detached colonial; dining room, large kitchen, full basement, 50- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $650 (Broker: John E. Miller Real Estate) STATEN ISLAND West Brighton $171,300 27 Stebbins Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached colonial; dining room, large kitchen, stained-glass windows, parquet floors, original moldings and details, detached 1-car garage; 35- by 120-ft. lot; taxes $900 (Broker: Rand Properties) Richmond Town $251,000 96 Pinewood Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, single-family, detached high-ranch; dining room, large kitchen, family room, 1-car garage; 40- 110-ft. lot; taxes $1,800 (Broker: Century 21/Papp Realty)

title: Dr. Lee E. Morrone Is Wed To Joseph Fierro, a Banker
description: Dr. Lee Ellen Morrone, the chief resident in obstetrics and gynecology at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, and Joseph Fierro, a vice president of Resource Mortgage Banking in White Plains, were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York. The Rev. John Driscoll performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Reviews/Dance; The Forces of Nature Choreographer Modernizes Traditional African Forms
description: There are performances when everything goes right. And one of those performances occurred on Wednesday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, when the Forces of Nature Dance Company presented works by Abdel R. Salaam, the group's director and a choreographer with an unmistakable and sure voice of his own.

title: Miss McDonald Wed in Baltimore
description: Elizabeth Hinsdale McDonald, a marketing manager for Time Inc. in New York, and Trevor Bowen Peard, an English teacher at the Choate Rosemary Hall school in Wallingford, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Blair Newcomb performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Baltimore.

title:
Photo of the Jericho Meeting House (Benjamin Doughty, 1885);
Quaker Meeting House Marking Bicentennial
description: LEAD: DESPITE the fresh coat of paint that still smells new, the scent that permeates the old Quaker Meeting House in Jericho is one of the past.

title: A Difficult Test
description: MANY deals are like an onion:

title: Israeli and 8 Arabs Wounded
description: Assailants with axes and knives attacked an Israeli businessman in the West Bank after Israeli forces raided three villages today and rounded up 20 Palestinians suspected of making bombs.

title: Negative Ads in Senate Race Are Putting Off Many Voters
description: THE race for United States Senate in New Jersey, as framed by the two candidates, is asking voters to choose between the ''lesser of two evils.''

title: Drawing From a Distant Past
description: Not so long ago, antiques from the Middle Ages and Renaissance were about as welcome in American homes as that other emblem of those eras -the Black Death. ''I hate to think of how many New York butchers are cutting meat on the stuff,'' says Alan Stone, a Manhattan print and drawing dealer and antiques enthusiast who notes that many early European tables, made of heavy slabs of oak or walnut, were chopped up into blocks for just that purpose. Recently, however, furnishings from these periods - which are characterized by an imposing scale, hefty woods and sculptural simplicity - are emerging from the dark ages, becoming a source of inspiration to collectors and decorators alike.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: CAROUSEL EXHIBIT

title: Laura Coleman Marries
description: The marriage of Laura Kimbrough Coleman, a daughter of John T. Coleman 3d of Chase City, Va., and the late Elizabeth Coleman, to Klaus Theodor Said, a son of Mrs. Herman Lang of Bonn, and the late Ahmed Said, took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York. The Rev. Thomas Joyce performed the ceremony. Mrs. Said is a manager and her husband an associate director of J. P. Morgan Securities in London.

title: Which Candidate Understands a Mother's Fear?
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Designers Get Their Ideas
description: They see things ordinary mortals don't: an unusual bed in an old movie, the background color of a faded chintz, the rusty metal of a vintage airplane hangar. These observations, no matter how insignificant they may seem, trigger ideas in the creative mind of the architect or decorator, ideas that shape the direction and look of design styles today.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: FIT TO PRINT: A. M. Rosenthal and His Times. By Joseph C. Goulden. (Lyle Stuart, $21.95.) This is a TV talk-show biography, formatted to titillate rather than to illuminate. So it focuses on Abe Rosenthal's supposedly ''sarcastic'' and ''mercurial'' personality and repeats old stories of newsroom clashes.

title: An Improved Outlook For Manufacturing
description: When William C. Johnson left his job in 1984 to sell cars after 23 years on the assembly line at the Warner & Swasey Company's Cleveland plant, the downturn in the fortunes of the machine tool manufacturer seemed irreversible. While major customers in the auto, defense and energy industries were in a slump, Japanese competitors had grabbed a large share of the market. Total plant employment had fallen below 300, from a high that reached 1,900 in the late 1970's.

title: Hawaii's Short-Sleeve Plumage
description: LIKE fragrant woodroses and ruffled hibiscus, Hawaiian shirts are an integral, cheerful part of the Hawaiian landscape. Hotel receptionists, newspaper vendors and fishermen unloading their catch at the Honolulu fish auction wear them, and so do many of their customers. In Hawaii a business suit is a tucked-in aloha shirt, and there is no shortage of executives hurrying (admittedly in Hawaiian fashion, which is a stroll) along city streets, briefcase in hand and bright, flower-splashed shirt tucked in.

title: Detroit Has Hard Times And One Man In Charge
description: IN his 15 years as Mayor of Detroit, Coleman A. Young has seen the city's industrial base decline and its population shrink. So he didn't seem surprised recently when the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Detroit announced that it, too, would be pulling up some stakes. Mr. Young said the archdiocese plan to close more than one-third of its churches in the city was simply a ''belated recognition'' of the fact that their congregations had long since left. Even so, it was another reminder that Detroit is still in a painful transition from its past as motor capital of America.

title:
MUSIC VIEW;
AT CARNEGIE: THE BEST VS. JUST O.K.
description: LEAD: It is not hard to acquire a taste for less than the best. A soft-headed acceptance of the perfectly O.K. and the routinely blameless usually comes first. From there it is a slippery slope: a grudging tolerance for mediocrity and, when the bottom is reached, an unembarrassed affection for whatever is.

title: Recalling Life on the Old Estates
description: LEAD: WHEN Betty Smith was asked to talk about her life as a kitchen maid at a Locust Valley estate, her reaction was swift and, to Elly Shodel, puzzling at first.

title: Fly Me to the Mall
description: THE PERSONAL AIRCRAFT - it's a little noisy, but it does fit in your garage. The Merlin 200 (above), which has recently been rechristened the Moller 300 (for its inventor, Paul S. Moller), is just about ready for takeoff after nearly $20 million worth of on-again off-again research. Mr. Moller, who is president of Moller International, a research and development company in Davis, Calif., has been experimenting with designs for VTOL (vertical takeoff and landing) aircraft since the early 1960's. ''Eventually,'' Mr. Moller says, ''I think a large part of the population will own a vehicle like this. We're aiming it for consumer use. It was my objective in the beginning and it still is.''

title: Mary C. Tanner Becomes a Bride
description: The wedding of Mary Catherine Tanner, the daughter of Marilyn S. Tanner of Closter, N.J., and the late Donald N. Tanner, to Frederick Frank, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Frank of Salt Lake City and La Quinta, Calif., took place yesterday at the Harvard Club in New York. Justice Betty Weinberg Ellerin of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, First Department, officiated.

title: Rivals for Jersey Senate Seat Promise to Stay Costly Course
description: As the United States Senate fight in New Jersey moves into the final rounds, both the Democratic incumbent, Frank Lautenberg, and his Republican opponent, Pete Dawkins, have enough money to keep swinging hard until Election Day, reports filed with the Federal Election Commission indicate.

title: ENHANCING THE LEGACY
description: ANNA FREUD A Biography. By Elisabeth Young-Bruehl. Illustrated. 527 pp. New York: Summit Books. $24.95.

title: The AIDS Burden
description: 'Our hospitals, clinics and social-service agencies are already strained to the limit, and many HIV-infected persons are not receiving adequate care. How is the system going to manage in the future?' - New York City AIDS Task Force, calling for expanded services to treat an expected deluge of AIDS patients.

title: Camille Duvall to Be Married
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Carole Camille Duvall to Byron A. Hero Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Hero of New York and Southampton, L.I., by the future bride's mother, Dianne Duvall of Windermere, Fla. Miss Duvall also is the daughter of the late Samuel E. Duvall Jr. of Dallas.

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;
PARIS
description: LEAD: If Paris fashion sometimes resembles a limited-choice, prix fixe menu, designers have come up with an a la carte spread in their spring and summer collections to be shown this week. No one is out to impose a length or a single silhouette, although there are still strong points of view, especially about pants.

title: David Frediani Marries Mary Claiborne
description: Mary Taylor Claiborne, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Augustine Claiborne of Richmond, and David Raymond Frediani, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond R. Frediani of Roseville, Calif., were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert Hetherington officiated at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Richmond, assisted by the Rev. Fred Feusahrens, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: New Small Speakers Deliver Big Sound
description: Harvest season. Barns and barrels are filling up, and so are hi-fi shops. With the audio industry clinging to the dubious notion that there must be new models every year, a fresh crop of components is sounding off each fall. The assumption that the new stuff is better than the old is occasionally true, but that may not be a compelling reason to ditch your present rig.

title: MULRONEY LEADING IN CAMPAIGN POLLS
description: Two weeks into a seven-week campaign, Canada's governing Conservative Party appears to have consolidated its lead in opinion polls and to be on course, barring major campaign upsets, for a second term in office.

title: A Mania For Testing Spells Money
description: ITEM: Some 1.7 million high school students will pay $13 each to take the Scholastic Aptitude Test this school year and another million or so will pay $11.50 to take the American College Test, all in hopes of getting into the college of their choice.

title: Drugstore Reborn s a Museum
description: LEAD: NEW CANAAN'S oldest drugstore has been moved lock, stock and apothecary furnishings into a wing of the New Canaan Historical Society.

title: 'Guys And Dolls' Revived In Darien
description: AT the Darien Dinner Theater, there is a musical fable about a gambler for whom the stakes are never too high (he is called Sky); Sarah Brown, the Salvation Army lass he takes to Havana (on a bet), and another gambler (Nathan Detroit) who has been engaged for 14 years to a nightclub singer (Miss Adelaide), who sneezes a lot.

title: Floor Coverings
description: COVERING wood floors with carpeting, asphalt tile or resilient flooring makes sense when restoring the floor is impossible or when the qualities of a particular floor covering are desired. However, simply installing the new covering over the old floor can invite trouble.

title: Capital Subway Entryways Shut to Homeless
description: The Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority is installing barriers to seal the entrances to four of its subway stops after hours, preventing numerous homeless people from using the stations as shelters at night.

title: Paris by Bus
description: To the Editor: Kay Eldredge's article on exploring Paris by bus (Travel, Aug. 14) didn't mention the S.I.T.U. automatic How to Get There From Here machines at many intersections around town.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Zurich
description: Visitors to Zurich will be struck by a new awareness of prosperity's threat to the environment. Posters and newspapers cry for cleaner air and water as well as respect for greenery. The city has started a $50 million program to recover 50 streams that used to run from the hills east and west into the lake that it hugs and the two rivers - the Limmat and the Sihl - that enclose its core. Decades ago the brooks were paved over; now they are being dug up to enliven the cityscape.

title: BUSH AND DUKAKIS BOTH READY SHIFT IN THE CAMPAIGN
description: Vice President Bush's campaign, sensing new opportunities after the Presidential debate Thursday, may now take the fight to the Democratic stronghold of New York and is exploring ways to help Republican senatorial candidates as well.

title: Revaluations Anger Homeowners
description: AS Trenton, Camden and Newark face their first revaluations of property in more than 25 years, the troubled experience of Jersey City offers an example of the confusion that revaluations can cause when they are postponed during years of rapidly rising real-estate values, tax experts and officials say.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: FALSE STARTS. By Terri McFerrin Smith. (Knopf, $17.95.) This spare, carefully controlled first novel captures the disarray of a young woman's life as she floats in and out of an indifferent love affair and a number of pregnancies. Suffering from chronic unhappiness - the legacy of her alcoholic home - Mara Johnson doesn't see anything clearly.

title: Women's Group Libeled Man In Assault Charge, Jury Says
description: A jury has found that the group Women Against Rape libeled a man when it circulated a flier falsely accusing him of assault and attempted rape.

title: A Faulty Date Misled the Detective
description: A censored cover mailed from Italy to Torrington, Conn., led to some detective work, and then humbled the detective when he overlooked the obvious.

title: 'Pull Over,' the Officer Said, So I Went to Court
description: ''PULL over, blue Tercel,'' crackled the loudspeaker of the black and white police cruiser that pulled up behind me.

title: Five Nuns Meet Priest Dispatched by Vatican
description: Five nuns locked in a spiritual battle over the intrusion of the modern world into their cloistered lives met today with a priest dispatched by the Vatican to help resolve the dispute.

title: Supermarket Mergers Will Mean Higher Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: Modest Laureate
description: Just as well that Naguib Mahfouz, an Egyptian writer, never wrote the advertising blurbs for his 40 novels and collections of short stories or his more than 30 screenplays. He once called himself ''a fourth- or fifth-rate writer.'' Last week, the Swedish Academy of Letters took a different view and awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature to the 77-year-old Mr. Mahfouz, the first Arabic writer to win literature's highest award. His writing is popular in Arabic-speaking countries, although he was blacklisted for a time by many Arab countries because of his support for the 1979 peace treaty between Egypt and Israel. As for praise from the academy for ''works rich in nuance - now clear-sightedly realistic, now evocatively ambiguous,'' Mr. Mahfouz said, ''Clarity is valuable, but ambiguity sometimes has its values, too.''

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: WHEN I was young, I dreamed of the myth of infinite. It is part of our heritage, a little bit of the American dream that linked suburban kids to the unbroken greatness of purple mountains' majesty and sea to shining sea.

title: DATA UPDATE: October 16, 1988
Discovering Harriet Wilson
description: To the Editor:

title: THE QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Does Davey Johnson Deserve to Come Back?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Who Are They?
description: The election isn't over. But the second and, Vice President George Bush made clear, final confrontation of Presidential candidates left Governor Michael Dukakis well short of the breakthrough he needs.

title: Distressed By Columnists
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Tennis Courts, Too; Upgrading U.P.S.
description: A large office building, topped by three clay tennis courts for those whose labors include perfecting a backhand, is to be fashioned from the 400,000-square-foot former United Parcel Service distribution center, at 333 East 38th Street.

title: Local's a Dirty Word at Fish Stores
description: AS far as many residents of towns near the Sound are concerned, the farther away a fish was when last it swam, the better. Fish store customers all seem to have the question ''Where did this fish come from?'' in common.

title: Dr. Elisa H. Birnbaum Wed To Dr. Darryl Zuckerman
description: Dr. Elisa Hope Birnbaum, a resident in general surgery at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park, L.I., and Dr. Darryl Adam Zuckerman, the chief resident in radiology at the medical center, were married last evening at Sinai Temple in Champaign, Ill., by Rabbi Brad Bloom.

title: 'Luminous' Drama on Black Woman's Struggle
description: >VEN though Zora Neale Hurston's novel, ''Their Eyes Were Watching God,'' published in 1937, which is generally considered to be the end of the Harlem Renaissance, is a classic, by critical and scholarly acclamation, it has yet to make a necessary universal dent. But it is sinking into popular consciousness, thanks to college courses on Afro-American literature, changing women's roles or just plain great books, and there is something renewing about hearing how students are so taken by Hurston's work that they are passing it on to their parents.

title: TALKING: Day Care; Opening Centers in Apartments
description: SHOULD a member of a condominium, co-op or homeowner association be allowed to operate a home-based day-care center inside her unit? The question is being discussed more and more by residents and association officers as a growing number of owners take in four or five preschoolers each day for a fee, often without the prior knowledge or consent of the association board or the residents of adjoining units.

title: Joleen Jasinski Wed To James A. Marren
description: Joleen Jasinski, the daughter of Chester P. Jasinski of Springfield, Vt., and the late Beverly J. Jasinski, was married yesterday in Springfield to James Anthony Marren, a son of Therese V. Marren of Massapequa Park, L.I., and the late Thaddeus F. Marren. The Rev. James M. Shea performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Blurring the Lines - Dots? - Between Camera and Brush
description: OF ALL THE ARTISTS WHO CAME to be called Photo Realists in the early 1970's, only Chuck Close has successfully maintained a dialogue between the distinct but interlinked representational systems of painting and photography.

title: Dukakis Takes On a Combative Edge
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis assailed Vice President Bush on crime and national security issues today, accusing him of being ineffective in the war against drugs and inattentive to the needs of the nation's armed service members.

title: Question Of the Week; Once and For All, What About The D.H. in The Series?
description: With the advent of the d.h., the Tinkerses and Everses, Stankys and Darks, Rizzutos and Gordons, have been replaced by the left-hand batting what's-his-name batting against the right-hand pitching so-and-so who doesn't even get a time at bat. JACK LEYTON Fresh Meadows, Queens

title: POSTINGS: Prize-Winning House; 'Realms' for All
description: Beginning with the log cabin, wood has been the most popular material for American homes. More than 90 percent of new homes are wood frame, according to the American Wood Council.

title: BENTSEN APPEALS TO UNION MEMBERS
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen assailed the Republican ticket before older citizens in Northeastern Pennsylvania and union leaders in New York yesterday, vowing that he and Michael S. Dukakis ''will never sit idly by and watch America slip.''

title: THE WORLD SERIES: Evangelist vs. a Calm Analyst; LaRussa's Method Is Scholarly
description: There are similarities between the men, between Tony LaRussa and Tom Lasorda, that will not go unnoticed as the World Series unwinds this week on the California shores. They are of Italian descent, for instance, and they are managers who motivate. They believe that players win games, that coaching staffs help, that making moves from the dugout can sometimes be an overrated thing. There are also differences. LaRussa, the handsome 44-year-old manager of the Oakland Athletics, does not necessarily find a plate of pasta irresistible. He can push himself away from the dinner table without problem. He lacks both bravado and the urge to incessantly hug his players after home runs.

title: Sports of The Times; Going Straight
description: Fred Claire had made big decisions before. He used to be one of those dynamic, responsible, bottom-line, big-picture captains of industry known as sportswriters.

title: SONY AND CBS RECORDS
description: I am surprised that even so brief a history of Columbia Records as the one boxed with Peter Boyer's article on the sale of the company could fail to mention Mitch Miller, who became head of the popular division in 1950, when it was No. 4 in the industry, brought it to No. 1 in two years; he left, in 1961, to work in television.

title: Reviews/Music; The Harrington Quartet, From West Texas State U.
description: In 1981, the arts patron Sybil Harrington endowed a resident-artist program at West Texas State University. To fill the residency, the school put together a quartet, which adopted its benefactress's name. The ensemble - Dawn Harms and James Lyon, violinists; Amy Brandfonbrener, violist, and Brian Manker, cellist - made its New York debut on Wednesday at the 92d Street Y. In its opening work, Haydn's Quartet in G (Op. 54, No. 1), the group seemed an earnest young ensemble with some unusual, if underbaked, interpretive notions and a sound that was not particularly sumptuous. The Allegro con moto, for instance, was taken at a clip so brisk that Ms. Harms often slurred the first-violin lines when the passagework grew dense; yet the closing Presto seemed moderately paced by comparison.

title: Wild-Game Time In New England
description: IN churches and American Legion halls, in fire stations and community centers throughout New England, the curious and the carnivorous gather each autumn to partake of a time-honored rite: the wild-game supper.

title: State Urges Precautions on Rabies
description: LEAD: AS what the authorities call a ''rabies epidemic'' spreads through the wildlife population of nearby states, health officials in New Jersey are trying to prevent the disease from entering the state by warning residents to take steps to protect themselves and their pets.

title: Joan Futterman Is Married to Dr. David Bergman
description: Joan Futterman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Futterman of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Dr. David Bergman, a son of Mrs. Bradley D. King of New York and Quogue, L.I., and the late Dr. Arthur Bergman, were married last evening. Rabbi David Lincoln performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: Piano Concert Opens a New Series Caramoor
description: THIS weekend promises to be busy, with a piano recital, a chamber program and an orchestral concert among the opening night events, along with appearances by a major flute-piano duo, a county-based brass quintet and a visiting orchestra from Czechoslovakia.

title: Robinson Leads And Rams Follow
description: John Robinson can tie Chuck Knox's team record of 54 regular-season coaching victories when the Los Angeles Rams (5-1) take on the San Francisco 49ers (4-2) on Sunday in Anaheim Stadium. From the Rams' first coach, Hugo Bezdek, in 1937, when the franchise was in Cleveland, to Sid Gillman in 1955 to George Allen in 1966 and on to Knox in 1973, no one has left more of an imprint than Robinson.

title: 'Little Shop of Horrors' Is Staged
description: TO preserve the purity of ''Little Shop of Horrors,'' a sweet musical spoof about a blood-guzzling plant in a skid row flower shop, the New York producers resisted all offers to move the show to Broadway. After all, it originated in a 98-seat institutional theater and was transferred to a 340-seat commercial Off Broadway house, after becoming a runaway hit.

title: Museums: For the Few or the Many?
description: To have, or not to have, a museum of one's own? The question - a hot one in the art world as more and more wealthy collectors choose private ways of making their holdings public - struck sparks the other evening at a panel at the Guggenheim Museum, with some lively exchanges about feminist politics and public financing for museums.

title: Book Says Hoover Wanted to Tilt the Courts
description: A new biography of J. Edgar Hoover, the longest-serving Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, says Chief Justice Warren E. Burger in 1971 sought the bureau's help in selecting conservative court administrators who, in Mr. Hoover's words, might keep ''some of these stupid appellate opinions from coming out.''

title: Handling Infamy In Dallas
description: FOR years, civic leaders in Dallas wrestled with a painful issue: what to do with what has been called the city's most infamous site - the sixth floor of the building where Lee Harvey Oswald fired the shots that killed President John F. Kennedy.

title: Cuomo's War, Lilco's Deal
description: BACK in the spring of 1986, when it appeared Governor Cuomo was destined to be the 1988 candidate for President, Sam Donaldson observed on the David Brinkley show that the Governor could be especially mean-spirited toward those who opposed him on major issues. Nothing so substantiates Mr. Donaldson's view as the present controversy looming over the Lilco settlement.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 16, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 THE DARK TOWER: The Gunslinger, by Stephen King. (Plume/NAL, $10.95.) Volume One of a series about a young man's pursuit of an evil force. 2 4 MURDER IN THE CIA, by Margaret Truman. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A C.I.A. operative investigates the suspicious death of a literary agent on her way to Budapest. 3 2 HEAVEN AND HELL, by John Jakes. (Dell, $5.95.) Two families in the aftermath of the Civil War. 4 2 HEAVEN CENT, by Piers Anthony. (Avon, $4.50.) A young prince's search for a missing sorcerer. 5 1 THE MAIDEN, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $4.50.) The passion of a warrior princess and a man who would be king. 6 2 A SOUTHERN FAMILY, by Gail Godwin. (Avon, $4.95.) The effect of a violent death on an eccentric North Carolina clan. 7 7 TEAM YANKEE, by Harold Coyle. (Berkley, $4.95.) The exploits of an American tank company in Europe - during World War III. 8 2 HER MOTHER'S DAUGHTER, by Marilyn French. (Ballantine, $5.95.) A chronicle of four generations of women. 9 * 4 LONIGAN, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $3.50.) Six short stories about life on the American frontier. 10 1 MEMORY PRIME, by Gar and Judith Reeves- Stevens. (Pocket, $3.95.) Captain Kirk confronts an assassin in this new ''Star Trek'' novel. 11 14 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 12 11 FALLEN HEARTS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.95.) The scandals and horrors of her past return to haunt a bride in a backwoods town. 13 * 26 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $4.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 14 6 THE FIVE BELLS AND BLADEBONE, by Martha Grimes. (Dell, $4.50.) Two Scotland Yard men track down a murderer. 15 1 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Plume/NAL, $8.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. Weeks This On Week List Nonfiction 1 15 SMALL SACRIFICES, by Ann Rule. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) Murder and incest in an Oregon town. 2 21 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) The importance of a patient's mind and emotions. 3 260 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Spiritual inspiration. 4 18 THE POWER OF MYTH, by Joseph Campbell with Bill Moyers. (Doubleday, $19.95.) How mythology illuminates the stages of life. 5 11 SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright with Paul Greengrass. (Dell, $4.95.) The autobiography of a former member of the British secret service. 6 * 6 VEIL, by Bob Woodward. (Pocket, $4.95.) The inside story of William Casey's years at the C.I.A. 7 4 I'M WITH THE BAND, by Pamela Des Barres. (Jove, $3.95.) The ''confessions of a groupie.'' 8 2 KEEPING SECRETS, by Suzanne Somers. (Warner, $4.95.) The actress recalls her experience as the daughter of an alcoholic. 9 6 IT'S ALL IN THE PLAYING, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $4.95.) Behind the scenes of the television series ''Out on a Limb.'' 10 23 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Touchstone/S&S, $7.95.) A critique of American liberal arts education. 11 * 11 THE HERO WITH A THOUSAND FACES, by Joseph Campbell. (Princeton University, $9.95.) The human race seen through mythology. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 3 THE ESSENTIAL CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $12.95.) Cartoons about a boy, his toy tiger and his parents. 2 5 TALES TOO TICKLISH TO TELL, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) ''Bloom County'' cartoons. 3 10 FEELING GOOD, by David D. Burns. (Signet/ NAL, $4.95.) A physician's treatment for depression without the use of drugs. 4 * 20 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) How to solve your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. 5 12 NIGHT OF THE CRASH-TEST DUMMIES, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $5.95.) The ninth collection of ''Far Side'' cartoons. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Thai Cuisine, Trekking Eastward
description: THAI food is hot on Long Island. Long a Manhattan favorite, this cuisine is slowly proceeding east. Now, with the opening of the Thai Lemongrass Restaurant, the progression has reached Brentwood.

title: Women Writers
description: To the Editor:

title: Nasty People Lend Spice to 'A Perfect Spy'
description: With ''A Perfect Spy,'' public television's Masterpiece Theater gets back on a quality track tonight at 9 on Channel 13. After nearly two months of trying to avoid ''By the Sword Divided,'' fans can venture back to the fold. Based on the John Le Carre novel, ''A Perfect Spy'' may not have Alec Guinness's George Smiley as a drawing card, but this seven-episode production is on a par with ''Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy'' and ''Smiley's People,'' the two previous television adaptations of Le Carre books. Once again we are taken, with knowledge and certainty, into the modern netherworld of spies and intelligence agencies, of treason and personal betrayals. Formerly a minor player in the espionage game himself, Le Carre is a master guide.

title: A Darker Side
description: To the Editor:
