title: Anderson's Works Performed On Tour
description: IF Maxwell Anderson is to be appreciated anew, it is not likely to be as a consequence of the random compilation of the prolific playwright's works that is being produced by Uni/Verse, a Connecticut touring group specializing in what it calls ''literary performances,'' intended to fall somewhere between a staged reading and a complete production.

title: 6 Connecticut Bishops Urge Better Education on AIDS
description: Six Roman Catholic bishops from Connecticut issued their first unified statement on AIDS Friday, releasing a pastoral letter that urges followers to learn about the deadly disease and minister to those afflicted with the virus.

title: Grumbles in the Shower
description: To the Editor:

title: Whither Westwood?
description: VIVIENNE WESTWOOD, the prophet of punk, is still trying to serve as a fashion seer, but her message now is murky. At her show in London last Monday night there were many manic styles, along with a few neat ones, and the show ended the spring and summer opening season with all the exuberance of a high-school pageant.

title: Focus on Game 2
description: Storm Davis will be making his second World Series start. Pitching 5 innings for the Baltimore Orioles in 1983, he earned a victory over the Philadelphia Phillies, despite allowing 6 hits and 3 runs. He pitched well without a decision against Roger Clemens in Game 2 of this year's playoff. Regular Season $ W L IP H SO BB ERA 16 7 201Z 211 127 91 3.70 Playoffs $ W L IP H SO BB ERA 0 0 6Y 2 4 5 0.00 Orel Hershiser Coming off a complete-game shutout in Game 7 of the playoff, he will make his first World Series start with three days of rest. That shouldn't be a problem for the 30-year old from Buffalo, who has been pitching superbly. In his last 83Z innings he has allowed 3 earned runs, for an 0.32 e.r.a. Regular Season $ W L IP H SO BB ERA 23 8 267 208 178 73 2.26 Playoffs $ W L IP H SO BB ERA 1 0 24Z 18 15 7 1.09

title: ACTORS AND MIRACLES
description: WATER INTO WINE By Helen Norris. 152 pp. Chicago: University of Illinois Press.

title: Jane Seymour, Queen of the Mini-Series
description: When journalists describe Jane Seymour as the queen of the mini-series, as they do with increasing frequency these days, her agent gets worried. Doesn't it suggest she's a one-medium performer? Isn't it time she established herself as a power on the big screen, too? But the actress herself defiantly declares that the title makes her proud. And one must agree that if there were such a throne, no one has a better claim to it than Miss Seymour.

title: Let Speakers Speak
description: After a heckler shouted down a controversial speaker last year, Harvard Law School decided it was time to spell out some rules of engagement. Now a student-faculty committee has come up with guidelines aimed at letting speakers speak -and even letting hecklers hoot, if they don't drown out the message.

title: Elizabeth C. Shaw Is Married to Francis C. Record
description: Elizabeth Coolidge Shaw and Francis Crowninshield Record were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington. The Rev. Edward L. Lee officiated.

title: Whose Way on the Economy?; Paying the Bill for Present Prosperity
description: Are you better off than you were in 1980? With George Bush running on the Reagan record and Michael Dukakis running against it, the answers may prove decisive. But there's a more relevant question: Which candidate is better equipped to build on the strengths of the Reagan economy and shore up its weaknesses?

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
DAYS ON THE LIFE
description: LEAD: Eight years after his murder, the memory of John Lennon is everywhere. The most ambitious project yet is ''Imagine: John Lennon,'' a film about the rock star that includes home movies and private footage supplied by his wife, Yoko Ono, as well as film culled from years of television coverage. IMAGINE: JOHN LENNON (Macmillan, $39.95) is the movie's lavish companion coffeetable book of still photographs, edited and annotated by Andrew Solt and Sam Egan, the co-writers of the film.

title: AXIONS, NEUTRINOS AND THOSE ELUSIVE WIMP'S
description: THE DARK SIDE OF THE UNIVERSE A Scientist Explores the Mysteries of the Cosmos. By James Trefil. Illustrated by Judith Peatross. 197 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $17.95.

title:
FOCUS: Rentals;
Building Without the Pre-'86 Tax Breaks
description: LEAD: MALLARD PROPERTIES of Minneapolis is doing three things that more and more apartment developers say they cannot do - building apartments, renting virtually all and making money doing so.

title: Art and Money Go South in California
description: In the larger scheme of things, it seems fitting that the all-California World Series beginning here today bypasses elegant San Francisco, pitting this gritty rival to the south against Oakland.

title: Reviews/Dance; Rabelaisian Korean Folk Art
description: Namsadang is the name of the lusty folk theater from South Korea that the Samul-Nori company and guests performed Friday night at the Asia Society.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: LIBERTY DENIED: The Current Rise of Censorship in America. By Donna A. Demac. Preface by Arthur Miller. Foreword by Walter Karp. (PEN American Center, 568 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10012, Paper, $6.95.) Donna A. Demac asserts in ''Liberty Denied'' that the Reagan Administration has made the most systematic and broad-based attempt to manipulate information and to curb dissent of any peacetime American Government.

title: Army Speed Sends Lafayette to Defeat
description: Army was too quick for Lafayette today, too determined, too tough. The Cadet backs ran for 450 yards and the defense maintained pressure on the Leopards' outstanding passer, Frank Baur, right to the end.

title: BUICKS AND MADMEN
description: HELLO AMERICA By J. G. Ballard. 224 pp. New York: Carroll & Graf Publishers. $17.95.

title: An Old Hospital Moves to Meet The Needs of a New Generation
description: The New York Foundling Hospital, a 119-year-old charity that cares for handicapped, abused and neglected children, has moved to a new $50 million building that reflects both the hospital's evolution and its success in the real-estate market.

title: New Hampshire Man Is Said to Admit Arson
description: Prosecutors here said Friday that a former volunteer firefighter in neighboring Jefferson had admitted setting about 17 of the more than 20 arson fires that have plagued the area since May.

title: Don't Blame Strawberry
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Condo Spoken Here
description: IF your parents are retired and living in a condominium community in Florida, you won't be vacationing in Acapulco or Aruba anymore. You'll be using your vacation time to visit your folks in Florida . . . or else. Before heading south again, you should learn to speak Condo, the official language of Florida retirees. Once you learn your parents' lingo you'll understand the condo customs and rituals they have adopted. After all, as your parents have already reminded you, they are no longer spring chickens. So study the following glossary, then plan another visit - and speak Condo.

title: Small-Company Stocks Out of Favor
description: Earlier this year, investors eagerly bought stocks of smaller companies - those with stock market values of less than $500 million. The prices of the securities of these companies soared in the first quarter.

title:
MUSIC;
Princeton Symphony Heading to Middle East
description: LEAD: THE Chamber Symphony of Princeton, as part of a weeklong Middle Eastern tour at the end of the month, will be the first orchestra to perform at the new opera house in Cairo.

title: County Sets a Day T>o Dispose of Chemicals
description: LEAD: Because Dr. Barbara Silverman, a deputy health commissioner for Westchester, lives in Rockland County, she will not be eligible to participate in Saturday's ''Household Chemical Cleanup Day'' at the Fire Training Center in Valhalla, which she has helped organize.

title: Lifting the Lid From Eastern Europe's Bubbling Caldron of Nationalities
description: THE warmer climate of increased political tolerance that has swept Eastern Europe this year has helped bring a blossoming of ethnic and national feeling in a region burdened heavily by historic rivalries and feuds.

title: Sports of The Times: THE WORLD SERIES; The Dodgers' New Breed of Bulldog
description: His nickname is Bulldog but he looks more like a whippet or a smooth-haired pointer. His name is Orel Hershiser, the Dodgers' starter in the second World Series game tonight, and over the last six weeks, there has never been a pitcher quite like him. In nine starts, he has a 7-0 record with seven shutouts that included 67 consecutive scoreless innings, plus a one-out, 12th-inning relief appearance in the pivotal fourth game of the National League playoff that reflected the nickname Tommy Lasorda once bestowed on him.

title: STREETSCAPES: 45 East 66th Street; For a Jewel on the East Side, A Loving Facade Restoration
description: IN the middle of a three-year, $900,000 restoration and still swathed in scaffolding, the 80-year-old apartment house at 45 East 66th Street has undergone a cleaning that has removed decades of grime that hid its unusual red-and-white French Gothic design.

title: Pentagon Considers a Suspension Of Contract Ties With Sundstrand
description: The Pentagon has begun to consider further steps against the Sundstrand Corporation after the company's settlement of criminal fraud charges with the Government earlier this week, Defense Department officials say.

title: THE WET NURSE OF ALL CREATION
description: PLACEWAYS A Theory of the Human Environment. By Eugene Victor Walter. Illustrated. 253 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $10.95.

title: By Definition
description: To the Editor:

title: THERAPY STUDIED FOR SURVIVAL RATE
description: A study of elderly and gravely ill hospital patients who were revived after the heart had stopped found that none of them lived to leave the hospital, researchers have reported.

title: Question Of the Week; Once and For All, What About The D.H. in The Series?
description: Dump the d.h. In the intense atmosphere of a World Series game, eliminating the strategic moves by a manager relating to the pitcher slot is criminal. TOM VENTRA New York

title: Variations on a Theme
description: Where do architects get their ideas?

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Ivy League; Cornell Defeats Brown in a Romp
description: Aaron Sumida threw three touchdown passes today, two of them set up by the running of Scott Malaga, as Cornell beat Brown, 35-0, handing the Bruins their second straight shutout.

title: Disappearing Without a Trace
description: WHEN the horror of a flash flood that trapped a church bus and van in central Texas was finally over, 10 of 43 young people were dead or missing in the Guadalupe River in Kendall County. All but one body was recovered in July 1987 after the worst flooding of the river in 55 years.

title: RESULTS
description: Horse Racing Winning Colors Finishes Fourth: The long shot Hail a Cab charged down the stretch to overcome a 15-length deficit yesterday and win the $264,000 Grade I Spinster Stakes at Keeneland, Ky. Winning Colors, the winner of the Kentucky Derby, was fourth in a field of five fillies and mares. Hail a Cab won by three lengths over Willa on the Move.

title: An Election's Approach Brings Out the Indian in India
description: THE formation of a new Indian political party last week was a reminder that sometime in the next year -maybe as early as February - the people of India will go to the polls to cast their votes in a national parliamentary election and in so doing make some important decisions about the country's future.

title: SHERIDAN'S RIDE
description: THE GUNS OF CEDAR CREEK By Thomas A. Lewis. Illustrated. 371 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $24.95.

title: Long Island Interview: Victor Shulman; Packaging Glasnost: From Russia With Talent
description: VICTOR SHULMAN is a Russian-born impresario who has produced more than 30 concert tours in the United States for a wide variety of Russian poets, writers, comedians, singers and theater groups.

title: The Difference Between Brooklyn And Here? Sidewalks
description: MY mother-in-law's first reaction to our house in the county was: ''But there are no sidewalks! Where will you walk with a baby carriage?'' At the time, mortgage payments - not baby carriages - were uppermost in our minds.

title: The Puzzling New World of Bank C.D.'s
description: If, like many investors, you put your spare cash into a federally insured 12-month bank certificate of deposit after the stock market crash last October, you may be faced with a decision about how to reinvest that money as the first anniversary of Black Monday approaches. But what used to be a straightforward task - finding the highest rate for the length of time you were willing to tie up your money - has now become dauntingly complex. Deregulation has removed the old strictures on the types of C.D.'s that banks can offer, and diversity now reigns.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Washington, D.C.;
Developing The Waterfront
description: LEAD: AN architectural and development firm is trying to get eight acres on Washington's gritty industrial peninsula rezoned for a $200 million project with 1.3 million square feet of office space and 900 housing units proposed by Theodore F. Mariani & Associates.

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;
Legislators Find Even Fake Guns Difficult to Control
description: LEAD: WHILE little headway has been made toward Federal laws controlling the sale and manufacture of handguns, supporters of gun control might have taken some comfort last week when Congress dealt with a related, if less volatile issue: regulating fake guns that look real.

title: Fire Razes Antebellum House
description: A two-story frame house that withstood damage inflicted by cannon in the Civil War was destroyed Thursday in a fire believed to have been set by vagrants. The vacant house was one of nine antebellum homes remaining in this northern Florida town. ''The Police Department had been running out some vagrants who had been staying there,'' said Capt. John Holley, the town's fire marshal. ''They might have tried to build a fire in the fireplace there.''

title: From Brooklyn, A New Spin on Egypt
description: With ''Cleopatra's Egypt,'' a pioneering survey of the art of Ptolemaic Egypt, the Brooklyn Museum has broken new ground of a kind that has a consistent fascination. The title helps, of course. ''The Egypt of the Ptolemies'' would not be a grabber, but Cleopatra is one of the most charismatic women in history. With Handel's ''Giulio Cesare'' now playing at the Metropolitan Opera, with a newly discovered drawing of Cleopatra by Michelangelo on view at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, with Shakespeare's word pictures of her still quoted and misquoted every hour of the day, and with the current exhibition in Brooklyn to give a solid historical background, Cleopatra is present to us almost as vividly as she was to those who worshiped a gilded image of her 350 years after her death.

title:
The View From: Campaign Headquarters;
The Beep of the Fax Machine, No Matter the Party Label
description: LEAD: Team spirit - the kind one sees on opening night of a school play or in the locker room before a big game - can thrive under any political label.

title: Dubious Celebration Of Insult and Prejudice
description: Any unbiased examination, or simply reading of the ''real'' story of this restricted ''private'' community could never come up with such glowing language that you used to describe this ''idyllic life'' settlement on Fire Island, that includes a 6-foot chain link, topped by a 2-foot barbed wire fence from the bay to the ocean, with locks and gates to keep the two ''worlds'' of Fire Island separated.

title: Tyson's Career Hurt by Gossip
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: A Year After the Crash, Climbing Back; Office Leasing Picking Up Pace in Manhattan
description: IN the last year, downtown Manhattan has been a lonely place for landlords burdened by vacant office space.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Actually they are dead. We were told there was an outbreak of measles and they died in July.'' - Dr. Taban Nelson, of the Sudanese Red Crescent, explaining absence of children at famine center. [ 1:4. ]

title: A Fire Island Enclave For Snobs and Bigots
description: ''Achtung - You are leaving the American Sector,'' to quote a sign posted in the early 50's by three teen-agers in Ocean Bay Park, the Fire Island community adjacent to Point O' Woods (commonly referred to by P.O.W. as ''Fort Apache'').

title: The Looks for Less
description: Creating the looks of America's top interior designers need not be costly. In fact, if you can be content with furnishings that don't bear the pedigree of the established decorating sources, affordable suppliers abound.

title: North Carolina Bridal For Donna Lee Moore
description: Donna Lee Moore, a program administrator at the Department of Education in Washington, and Garrett Raymond McMullin, a senior systems analyst at the Bureau of Labor Statistics in Washington, were married yesterday at the nondenominational Old Church at Tanglewood near Winston-Salem, N.C., by the Rev. Dr. Alan J. Hanson, a United Methodist minister.

title: Debra K. Dorman Is Wed
description: Debra Kristiina Dorman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert O. Dorman of Brooklyn and Lantana, Fla., and David Steven Smith, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. Smith of Manhattan and Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Petti Palonen officiated at the Gloria Dei Evangelical Lutheran Church in Brooklyn. The bride, a sales administrator for the international division of Macmillan Publishing Company in New York, graduated from New York University. Her father, who is retired, was a technical engineer with CBS-TV. Mr. Smith, the vice president of Fairfield Brokerage Agency in Stamford, Conn., and a certified financial planner, graduated from Bryant College. His father is the founder and president of Fairfield Brokerage Agency, a financial service concern in New York.

title: Protestant Militant Is Slain In Raid on East Belfast Bar
description: Gunmen wearing jeans and ski masks burst into a Belfast bar tonight and killed a leader of the biggest Protestant paramilitary group in Northern Ireland, the police said.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Providence, R.I.;
Luring Artists To 'ProHo'
description: LEAD: IMPERIAL PLACE, a $9 million project, is advancing the concept of ''ProHo,'' a SoHo-style artists' district in this city of about 157,000 people.

title: Books Written for Migrants' Children
description: ''The Smallest Cow in the World'' is a special book to Derek Grace. It is the story of a farm much like the one where he lives. And the book's heroes, Marvin and May, look very much like Derek, who is 8 years old, and his 10-year-old sister Sarah.

title: In Defense Of Alysheba
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Q and A
description: Bloomsbury

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Fanwood $176,000 54 Shady Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old expanded Cape Cod; w/w carpeting, patio, remodeled bathrooms; taxes $3,396. Howell Township $200,000 8 Mouse Creek Court 4-bedroom, 3-bath, new contemporary; fireplace, skylights, w/w carpeting; taxes $2,800. Manalapan $210,000 7 Patterson Lane 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 10-year-old colonial; central vacuum, patio, brick fireplace; taxes $3,011. New Providence $330,000 7 Oaks Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 27-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, c/a, deck, family room; taxes $4,243. Wanaque $135,000 41 Haskell Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, porch, partially finished basement; taxes $1,600. Wayne $279,900 17 Winonah Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old split level; formal dining room, 2-car garage, full basement; taxes $2,970. OTHER AREAS West Hempstead, L.I. $250,000 422 Nocella Court 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 18-year-old high ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, c/a, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $3,400. Lincolndale, N.Y. $275,000 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, family room, 2-car garage; taxes $3,768. Manchester, Conn. $130,000 49 South Alton Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 45-year-old Cape Cod; new country kitchen, hardwood floors; taxes $1,100.

title: Slash and Burn
description: DRUMS ALONG THE MOHAWK Starring Henry Fonda (in photo), Claudette Colbert, Edna May Oliver, John Carradine. Directed by John Ford. 1939. Key Video. 103 minutes. $19.98. Closed captioned.

title: De Larrocha Travels To 'Iberia' Once More
description: One has no choice but to call ''Iberia'' excessive. This is not a condemnation, only a description of its essence. Isaac Albeniz's 12 piano pieces are a hymn to overabundance. He was a Catalan who spent much of his incredible childhood in the New World and his later productive years in Paris. But Andalusia was closest to his heart, and the florid vegetation of this music seems to rise up like a mirage out of the hot, dry Spanish landscape.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
On Pine Tar, 'Good Stuff' and Mr. October
description: LEAD: A few random thoughts about the baseball playoffs and the World Series:

title: First-Class Fare Lives, a Puzzle
description: Rumors of the death of first class are premature. If evidence is needed, some people are paying more than is required to sit in first class. And fare-cutting little Virgin Atlantic is increasing the space it allows for its premium-fare seats.

title: Susanna R. Sieglaff Is Wed in Delaware To William Brown 3d, a Sales Manager
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Wilmington, Del., Susanna Read Sieglaff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Maynard Sieglaff of Wilmington, was married yesterday to William Lee Lyons Brown 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Brown Jr. of Louisville, Ky. The Rev. J. Clark Grew 2d, the godfather of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Rutgers' Running Stops B.C. Eagles
description: Scott Erney set a career passing yardage record for Rutgers today. But it was the Scarlet Knights' running game and defense that were primarily responsible for a 17-6 triumph over Boston College.

title: Survey Alerts Youths to Suicide
description: LEAD: A COMPUTERIZED health survey is alerting depressed high school students to find help.

title: Stacey Lynn Glass Married To Anthony Joseph Scarpa
description: The wedding of Stacey Lynn Glass, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Glass of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., to Anthony Joseph Scarpa, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Scarpa of Bay Shore, L.I., took place last evening at the Windows on the World restaurant at the World Trade Center in New York. Rabbi Arthur Schwartz performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Briggs Weds in Rye
description: At Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y., Ashley Catlin Briggs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Briggs Jr. of Rye, was married yesterday to Jason Ruggles Bernhard, a son of Mrs. John Updike of Beverly Farms, Mass., and Alexander H. Bernhard of Boston. The Rev. Perry R. Williams, the Dean of Trinity Episcopal Cathedral in Cleveland, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Edward Johnston, the rector of Christ's Church.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The glazing compound on the windows on the south and west sides of our house deteriorates rapidly, with the compound cracking and curling up. We have tried several types of compound, but none seems to last more than a couple of years on those windows. This is especially noticeable along the bottom of each pane on the windows that get the most sunlight. The compound on the other sides of the house has lasted 25 years. Do you have any suggestions on how we can get a longer-lasting job on these windows?

title: LAW SCHOOL V. REALITY
description: I am now in my third week at Harvard Law School. I have found the school has made a broad pitch to all One L's to become involved in clinical or public-interest work during our three years here. In addition to offering courses in the lawyering process and professional responsibility, our professors engage us routinely in examinations of the tensions between jurisprudence and justice.

title: Port Chester Panel Clears 5 of Ethics Violations
description: LEAD: The Port Chester Board of Ethics, investigating allegations that six public officials, including the Mayor and Village Manager, received preferential treatment when buying condominiums last year, has concluded that only one of the officials is guilty of anything more than an appearance of impropriety.

title: A Conference of Advice on Learning Disabilities
description: LEAD: A conference exploring ways to help learning-disabled children and children with learning differences - including using English as a second language - is expected to draw librarians, teachers and parents to the New Rochelle Public Library on Tuesday.

title: Penthouses
description: To the Editor:

title: LOAN SHARK BLUES
description: CUT NUMBERS By Nick Tosches. 233 pp. New York: Harmony Books. $17.95.

title: No Place Like Home
description: After winning two gold medals at the Olympics an athlete is entititled to one of those luxury vacations in some strange and exotic clime. And when they returned from Seoul, South Korea, Jackie Joyner-Kersee and her husband, Bob Kersee, decided to do just that, picking what Joyner-Kersee regards as the ideal place to be, her hometown of East St. Louis, Ill.

title: It's Bulb Planting Time
description: BULB planting continues. Don't forget to mow the lawn; mowers are set to cut high, but the last cut will be shorter to about one-inch. Rake leaves off lawns and add them to compost, flower borders or vegetable patches. Dig, dry and store tender bulbs, such as caladiums and tuberous begonias, if tops have been weakened by frost. Into the Ground

title: On the Farm, A Disaster That Wasn't
description: The harvest is nearly over in western Missouri and there is no rejoicing. But given the heavy toll that this summer's searing drought took on crops, what seems remarkable is that many farmers are not in deep despair.

title: Personalized Software
description: In the beginning, say about 1977, virtually all users of the then-primal personal computers were, by necessity, hackers: technology buffs who could not only write whatever programs were needed, but could repair or rebuild the hardware as well. Today, most users are less sophistBcated and computers are more powerful, prompting software companies to find new ways to improve the sometimes frustrating relationship between man and machine.

title: Gibson Crashes Athletics' Victory Party
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers, who invoked all kinds of mysterious magic to upset the mighty Mets this week, went to even more dramatic lengths tonight when they defeated the favored Oakland Athletics, 5-4, in the opening game of the World Series on a pinch-hit home run in the ninth inning by the injured Kirk Gibson.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The glazing compound on the windows on the south and west sides of our house deteriorates rapidly, with the compound cracking and curling up. We have tried several types of compound, but none seems to last more than a couple of years on those windows. This is especially noticeable along the bottom of each pane on the windows that get the most sunlight. The compound on the other sides of the house has lasted 25 years. Do you have any suggestions on how we can get a longer-lasting job on these windows?

title: Are Gremlins Causing Those Nasty Spots?
description: SOMETIMES photography seems like an endless chain of things that can go wrong. Your pictures can be too light, too dark or too contrasty. They can be out of focus, or blurred because the subject moved, or fuzzy because the camera moved. They can be too blue or too green.

title: ARTS AND CRAFTS: JED JOHNSON and ALAN WANZENBERG
description: The Arts and Crafts furniture and collectibles that fill this Manhattan apartment speak volumes about the design style of the owners, Jed Johnson, a decorator, and Alan Wanzenberg, an architect. These pieces, all products of a decorative movement that began in England in the 1880's, stemmed from a strong collaboration between architect, designer and craftsman. An identical spirit of teamwork characterizes the practice Johnson and Wanzenberg started seven years ago. So do a love of beautiful woodwork, a subtle use of decoration and a high regard for simplicity, all of which also exemplify the Arts and Crafts period.

title: New York Region Brushes Off Effect Of Oct. 19 Collapse
description: A year after the stock-market collapse sent shock waves through the New York metropolitan region, economists and business executives say most job seekers have little cause for worry -their skills are in high demand.

title:
ART;
Abbott's New York
description: LEAD: BERENICE ABBOTT, who celebrated her 90th birthday in July, is one of photography's American masters.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on page 1 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the comedienne Roseanne Barr misidentifies the co-star of the ABC series ''Roseanne.'' He is John Goodman, not John Parker.

title: Deer in County: Conflicting Perceptions
description: LEAD: In 1983, when Westchester residents were asked to vote for the county's official mammal, they chose the white-tailed deer over the raccoon and the gray squirrel. Today, many are asking if the deer herd has grown too large and needs management.

title: Martin Trounces Adams, 34-0
description: John Adams, the defending Public Schools Athletic League champion, lost a chance for its second consecutive undefeated season when August Martin trounced the Spartans, 34-0, yesterday and moved into first place in the Queens A Division.

title: The Race for Congress; Democrat Covers Rhode Island in an Uphill Race
description: At 6:30 Wednesday morning, long johns beneath his pin-striped suit, Richard A. Licht was at the front door of a textile mill in North Providence, shaking hands with workers and promising to support limits on imported textiles.

title: BEST SELLERS: October 16, 1988
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 11 THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan races to the rescue of an American secret agent. 2 2 4 BREATHING LESSONS, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $18.95.) The many facets of a 28-year marriage are revealed during a drive to a friend's funeral. 3 3 10 TILL WE MEET AGAIN, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $19.95.) The exploits of a woman and her two daughters. 4 4 16 ALASKA, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $22.50.) The history of the 49th state told in fictional form. 5 5 6 SPOCK'S WORLD, by Diane Duane. (Pocket, $16.95.) An emergency meeting of the planet Vulcan's ruling council exposes its secret history. 6 9 3 KOKO, by Peter Straub. (Dutton, $19.95.) Three Vietnam veterans on the trail of a friend who may be responsible for a series of murders. 7 6 6 THE SILENCE OF THE LAMBS, by Thomas Harris. (St. Martin's, $18.95.) A young woman F.B.I. trainee pursues a serial killer. 8 * 8 50 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 9 * 10 26 LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $18.95.) A Colombian poet's perdurable love for a woman is tested. 10 7 35 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 11 1 FINAL FLIGHT, by Stephen Coonts. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Colonel Qazi, an ''international terrorist,'' plots to steal American nuclear weapons. 12 1 SWORD POINT, by Harold Coyle. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The Soviet Union's invasion of Iran brings the world to the brink of nuclear war. 13 8 SHINING THROUGH, by Susan Isaacs. (Harper & Row, $18.95.) The progress of a Queens woman from Wall Street secretary to wife of her boss to spy in Nazi Germany. 14 * 12 2 TRACKS, by Louise Erdrich. (Holt, $18.95.) The mysterious life of Fleur Pillager, a Chippewa woman with the powers of a shaman. 15 * 15 12 DOCTORS, by Erich Segal. (Bantam, $19.95.) The life stories of five members of Harvard Medical School's class of 1962. 16 * 11 2 PRIME TIME, by Joan Collins. (Linden/Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Five actresses compete for a glamorous role in Hollywood. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 26 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A British scientist's review of efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 2 4 8 THE RAGMAN'S SON, by Kirk Douglas. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) The actor recalls his life as poor immigrant's son, waiter, steel mill worker, haberdashery salesman, film star, father and man. 3 2 6 THE LIVES OF JOHN LENNON, by Albert Goldman. (Morrow, $22.95.) The rock-and-roll star as legend and as human being. 4 3 7 THE BOZ, by Brian Bosworth with Rick Reilly. (Doubleday, $17.95.) The autobiography of the Seattle Seahawks football player. 5 1 SURVIVING THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990, by Ravi Batra. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) What Americans and their Government should do in the face of economic disaster. 6 12 10 SENATORIAL PRIVILEGE, by Leo Damore. (Regnery Gateway, $19.95.) A reporter's reassessment of the 1969 accident on Chappaquiddick Island. 7 6 13 THE DUCHESS OF WINDSOR, by Charles Higham. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.) The life of the woman who married King Edward VIII. 8 5 2 LANDSLIDE, by Jane Mayer and Doyle McManus. (Houghton Mifflin, $21.95.) Two Washington reporters on ''the unmaking of the President, 1984- 1988.'' 9 8 14 GENERATION OF SWINE, by Hunter S. Thompson. (Summit, $18.95.) Commentary on the current decade. 10 7 7 TRANSFORMATION, by Whitley Strieber. (Beech Tree/Morrow, $18.95.) The author of ''Communion'' tells of more confrontations with ''intelligent nonhumans.'' 11 9 3 PRESS ON! by Chuck Yeager and Charles Leerhsen. (Bantam, $17.95.) The legendary pilot on flying, the outdoors and his West Virginia roots. 12 11 44 TRUMP, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. 13 10 3 THEY WENT THAT-A-WAY . . ., by Malcolm Forbes with Jeff Bloch. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) How the famous (and the infamous) met their end. 14 1 THE FIRST SALUTE, by Barbara W. Tuchman. (Knopf, $22.95.) A historian's view of the American Revolution. 15 1 BOB KNIGHT, by Joan Mellen. (Fine, $17.95.) A portrait of the controversial Indiana University basketball coach. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 67 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 2 3 28 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 3 * 2 6 ALL YOU CAN DO IS ALL YOU CAN DO, BUT ALL YOU CAN DO IS ENOUGH! by A. L. Williams. (Nelson, $14.95.) The philosophy of a highly successful entrepreneur who deals in life insurance and investments. 4 4 159 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $16.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 5 1 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The Third College Edition of a standard work, updated in 1988. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) THE LIFE OF LANGSTON HUGHES. Volume II: 1941-1967. I Dream a World, by Arnold Rampersad. (Oxford University, $24.95.) The conclusion of Mr. Rampersad's splendid study of the conflicted figure who was our most prominent black poet and the first black American to make a living as a freelance writer. THE PROUD DECADES: America in War and Peace, 1941-1960, by John Patrick Diggins. (Norton, $19.95.) A historian's panoramic survey that tries to see those much-abused, enormously active years as they really were, as much in irony as in celebration. THE LETTER LEFT TO ME, by Joseph McElroy. (Knopf, $16.95.) This short, hypnotic novel revolves about a letter to the narrator, a 15-year-old boy, from his dead father - a letter that becomes a metaphor for intrusion and invasion of privacy. THE SWIMMING-POOL LIBRARY, by Alan Hollinghurst. (Random House, $16.95.) Handsomely wedding the conventions of fiction to a tale of modern transgressions, this novel becomes an ironic history of the homosexual English elite in this century. THE FLOATPLANE NOTEBOOKS, by Clyde Edgerton. (Algonquin of Chapel Hill, $16.95.) A warmly humorous, rich and gossipy novel about a South Carolina family whose affection, nuttiness and well-meant lies engage them in a sort of perpetual reunion. A GATHERING OF SAINTS: A True Story of Money, Murder and Deceit, by Robert Lindsey. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A former Times correspondent captures the religious and social atmosphere in which a really abominable villain hornswoggled officials of the Mormon Church and many, many others. A DEADLY SILENCE. The Ordeal of Cheryl Pierson: A Case of Incest and Murder, by Dena Kleiman. (Atlantic Monthly, $19.95.) How and why a sexually abused 16-year-old suborned her father's murder, ably reconstructed by a Times reporter.

title: LONG DISTANCE ACQUIRER: O. Gene Gabbard; Ganging Up on the Big Boys
description: Ask O. Gene Gabbard, founder and chief executive of Atlanta-based SouthernNet Inc., whether he is satisfied being the nation's fourth-largest long-distance carrier, and he breaks into his most disarming grin. ''We're just local people providing local services,'' he said. ''We're not going to become another U S Sprint.''

title: INSIDE
description: Dodgers Win Game 1

title: PLAIN GEOMETRY: MARIETTE HIMES GOMEZ
description: Listening to Mariette Himes Gomez discuss the design of a room conjures up images from a geometry class. Words like ''solids'' and ''voids,'' ''volumes'' and ''planes'' invariably crop up in her descriptions. Not surprising, then, that geometric shapes can be found in most of her rooms. Take the master bedroom of her Long Island country house. The 18th-century Spanish bed features a round headboard with a painting of a madonna and child in a pastoral setting. A table in one corner displays some painted paper geometric solids, as well as a watercolor with a circular motif. Playing against the circles is a prominent triangle - an off-center pediment of a house-within-a-house, built to enclose a bathroom and closet. For Gomez, ''inspiring designs are those which create tension through contrasting forms and shapes, colors and materials.''

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Limiting Growth on the Lower Palisades
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH high-rise residential buildings, factories and one-family homes have been built on the cliffs of the Lower Palisades during this century, much of the area remains undeveloped, forming a distinct natural landscape in Hudson and Bergen Counties.

title: When Miniature Means Monumental
description: Miniatures with monumental presence are what Edward H. Merrin pursued for an exhibition and sale of mostly ancient amulets, votive figures, tomb objects, vessel decorations, tool handles, weights and a comb.

title: Nancy Marchand Reflects
description: First, there's Nancy Marchand the actress. ''I love theater,'' she says. ''I love to act.'' Then there's Nancy Marchand the person.

title: Question Of the Week; Once and For All, What About The D.H. in The Series?
description: Elimination of the d.h. in the World Series essentially means that: (a) the player who is usually a team's m.v.p. offensively sits out, and (b) pitchers who never hold a bat or run the bases must now learn to read signs, bunt in critical situations and replace the sluggers. The concept is absurd; its implementation is patently unfair.

title: Lush Crops and Profits in California
description: Jack Pandol Sr. can watch the grape harvest on his family's 9,000-acre ranch near Delano in the heart of California's lush San Joaquin Valley this fall and permit himself a smile. ''Barring any unusual weather between now and Dec. 1,'' Mr. Pandol said, ''we're quite optimistic.''

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THIS FAR AND NO MORE: A True Story, by Andrew H. Malcolm. (Signet/New American Library, $4.50.) With Lou Gehrig's disease crippling her muscle by muscle, Emily Bauer decided to exercise her right to die. ''The reader, unabashedly voyeuristic, absorbs detail after detail about the torture of an intelligent mind entrapped in a useless body,'' Gloria Hochman said here in 1987. ''Anger, love, rage, resentment, guilt, fear stalk every page.'' BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) In her Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, Toni Morrison tells the story of Sethe, a young black woman who finds that after emancipation she is still enslaved by memories of an earlier time - and of a daughter, called Beloved, and her haunting death. ''Ms. Morrison's versatility and technical and emotional range appear to know no bounds,'' Margaret Atwood said in The Book Review last year. ''We experience American slavery as it was lived by those who were its objects of exchange.'' AN ADULTERY, by Alexander Theroux. (Collier/Macmillan, $8.95.) When Christian Ford embarks on an affair with a lost soul named Farol Colorado, he sets off a chain of betrayals that, in the end, leaves him among its victims. Last year, our reviewer, Ron Hansen, called the novel ''a bitter, brooding, Jacobean tragedy of being used and getting even. . . . An odd and hypnotic pleasure to read, [ it is ] a book you dislike and can't do without.'' REBECCA WEST: A Life, by Victoria Glendinning. (Fawcett Columbine/Ballantine, $10.95.) This biography of the novelist and journalist Rebecca West shies away from evaluating her as a writer, John Gross said in The Times last year. But the account of her long liason with H. G. Wells and the feud with their son, Anthony West, ''is consistently readable. Her wit is unforced, her narrative glides along easily and compellingly.'' THE PLAYMAKER, by Thomas Keneally. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $8.95.) A naval officer determined to bring a bit of Covent Garden to the British penal colony in Australia puts on a play, struggling to draw art and drama from his all-convict cast. Last year, our reviewer, James Atlas, complained that the novel is chaotic and formulaic, but he said its ''depiction of the bleak Australian landscape . . . has a hallucinatory vividness. . . . One of [ Thomas ] Keneally's great gifts is an ability to imagine the lives of the marginal, the forgotten.'' THE MAYOR OF CASTRO STREET: The Life and Times of Harvey Milk, by Randy Shilts. (St. Martin's, $10.95.) Half a decade before the publication of ''And the Band Played On,'' Randy Shilts's detailed account of the AIDS plague, he chronicled the history of San Francisco's gay Castro community and its most visible political leader, Harvey B. Milk, the city supervisor who was murdered in 1978. In 1982, one reviewer said the book not only succeeds as history and biography but also as ''an investigative piece on the mechanics of big-city government in all of its expedient, back-biting splendor. Shilts pulls off this threefold stunt admirably.'' SENT FOR YOU YESTERDAY, by John Edgar Wideman. (Vintage, $6.95.) The novelist John Edgar Wideman has made the Homewood district of Pittsburgh as memorable a spot in the literary atlas as Sherwood Anderson's Winesburg, Ohio, or William Faulkner's Yoknapatawpha County, Alan Cheuse said here in 1983. '' [ He ] returns to the ghetto where he was raised and transforms it into a magical location infused with poetry and pathos.'' Vintage is also republishing the other two books in the Homewood trilogy: DAMBALLAH and, in November, HIDING PLACE (each $6.95). THE CREATION OF MATTER: The Universe From Beginning to End, by Harald Fritzsch. (Basic, $9.95.) In 1984 our reviewer, Timothy Ferris, said the high point of this account of the big bang, translated from the German by Jean Steinberg, contains ''one of the clearest explanations of the equivalence of matter and energy I've encountered.'' UTAH, by Toby Olson. (Collier/Macmillan, $8.95.) In search of his lost wife, Lorca, a New York masseur known for his erotic touch is drawn to the nether world of Utah. Writing here in 1987, Charles Johnson praised Toby Olson's ''ability to conjure gorgeous prose passages that celebrate the healing powers of friendship, the pleasures of love and lovemaking, and the inborn mystery and beauty of things in this world.'' BAILOUT: An Insider's Account of Bank Failures and Rescues, by Irvine H. Sprague. (Basic, $9.95.) Written by a former chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, this account of the troubled banking system, Michael M. Thomas said here in 1986, is ''an unglossed, authentic inside account.'' Though dry at times, ''the facts he adduces are staggering.'' CIGARETTES, by Harry Mathews. (Collier/Macmillan, $8.95.) Harry Mathews's literary jigsaw about promiscuous art lovers in Greenwich Village ''provides enough plot for a season of mini-series,'' Lisa Zeidner said in The Book Review last year. But in the ''subtly experimental novel, the plot is used as bait to lure us into confronting love's darker side.'' DOMESTIC AFFAIRS: Enduring the Pleasures of Motherhood and Family Life, by Joyce Maynard. (McGraw-Hill, $7.95.) A former New York Times journalist, Joyce Maynard has chosen to cover her own experience raising children. Last year Frances Wells Burck said here that in the collection's best pieces, the author's musings build ''into a complex and subtle metaphor for how we learn to mother.''

title: Darby Mengel Marries
description: Darby Denton Mengel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Denton Mengel of Cincinnati, was married yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York to Eric Robert Van Heyst, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jan Van Heyst of Rochester. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth Jones performed the ceremony. The bride, a graduate of the School of Design and Architecture at the University of Cincinnati, is a merchandise manager for Anne Klein II in New York. Mr. Van Heyst, a vice president in the North America corporate finance sector at the Chase Manhattan Bank, graduated from the College of Wooster, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received an M.B.A. degree from Vanderbilt University.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
A College Dedication
description: LEAD: A ceremony 10 years in the making will take place Wednesday afternoon at Westchester Community College in Valhalla when college officials and County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke dedicate a long-awaited administration building.

title: 'Biblical Scorecard' Chooses Bush, But With Reluctance
description: The Presidential Biblical Scoreboard is a four-color, 48-page publication with a political message for America's evangelistic faithful: come November, hold your nose and vote for George Bush.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: West; U.C.L.A. Reaches 6-0 in 38-21 Victory
description: Troy Aikman threw for two touchdowns and ran for a third score as U.C.L.A. routed California, 38-21, in a Pacific-10 Conference game today.

title: New York as Window
description: To call something a Winter Garden is to give it a wonderful name. One thinks of snow and wind and icy blasts, and of roses and daffodils and hibiscus blooming peacefully under glass. But to see the new Winter Garden at Battery Park City is to think of something else entirely. It's to remember that New York is the City on the Harbor.

title: A World of Wonders in Java
description: ALL the cultures of the East - Hindu, Buddhist, Islamic and animist - have been converging and blending for centuries in Southeast Asia. But nowhere, from Indochina and Thailand south to Australia, have they produced in one place a living museum of such quality and scope as they have within a hundred-mile radius of the Indonesian city of Jogjakarta.

title: Art Museums Abroad Seek U.S. Funds
description: When the Tate Gallery in London decided to raise money last year to buy a painting by Jackson Pollock, it turned not only to its own coffers but also to a source that it believed was ripe for an approach: wealthy Americans.

title: Reviews/Dance; A Partner Pays Tribute To an Artist
description: Hector Tello, a dancer and choreographer who died last October, was celebrated on Tuesday at Japan House in a program of great warmth that was put together by Saeko Ichinohe, with whom Mr. Tello had danced since 1980. Dances, slide projections and reminiscences served to summon up Mr. Tello's life and career, with Miss Ichinohe contributing two new pieces inspired by her young protege.

title: St. Francis Coach Thwarted By Farrell
description: Vinnie O'Connor, the St. Francis Prep football coach, returned to the scene of his 100th victory yesterday and tried to get his 200th, but the Monsignor Farrell team turned him away, 27-14.

title: President Assails Congress On Taxes and Budget Deficit
description: President Reagan, in one of his most partisan radio addresses in months, today accused the Democratic majority in Congress of seeking to elect a ''tax-and-spend'' President.

title: After a Three-Year Fight, Students Can Vote at Local Polls
description: WHEN students at the State University of New York at Purchase, Sarah Lawrence College and Manhattanville College vote at county polling places next month, many may not realize that they are taking part in something that is impossible in many other areas of New York State and very new in Westchester County.

title: Art Meant to Touch and Be Touched
description: LEAD: AT the Lions Gallery of the Senses in the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, art is a matter for more than just the eyes.

title: A Firsthand Look at Secondhand Chic
description: ONE of the liveliest weekend scenes in Manhattan occurs on Sunday mornings at 25th Street and the Avenue of the Americas. That's where a flea market takes place each week, and it has become a boon both to neighborhood treasure hunters and to those who like to keep their finger on the pulse of downtown fashion.

title: The Flag Returns To Tarrytown Library
description: LEAD: A FEW hundred feet from the statue that commemorates the capture of the Revolutionary War spy Maj. John Andre by three Tarrytown-area farmers, a new symbol of patriotism has risen outside the Warner Library here.

title: Two Schools of Thought
description: I have an American friend whose personal style of decorating is so close to that of the French ancien regime that anyone not wearing a pannier or knee breeches seems a tad out of place in his living room. (He calls it ''mon petit salon,'' and the accent is creditable.) Only the lowish ceiling betrays the fact that we are not tucked in an 18th-century hotel particulier on the Place Vendome. His charming mantelpiece (spirited out of a Burgundian chateau) is of rosy marble, and has carved scallop shells and an escutcheon hinting of nobility. His canapes and tabourets are signed by the best of the fine French furniture makers. The fragile antique needlepoint upholstery has been restored to near perfection. And his search for a pair of sublime corner cupboards has given him a decade of happy exploration among the antiquarians of the rue du Bac.

title:
DANCE;
Alumni to Help Troupe Celebrate
description: LEAD: DANCE breeds ''A'' students, both on and off stage, says Alfred Gallman, the founder and director of Gallman's Newark Dance Theater, which will celebrate its 10th anniversary Saturday at Symphony Hall in Newark.

title: For Chicago, Racial Politics Is Becoming A Tradition
description: IN most places, people are members of one ethnic group or another by birth and members of one political party or another by choice. In Chicago, it often works the other way around. Most people here were born Democrats. But ethnic identity, in a broad sense, can effectively be a matter of choice.

title: Ella Yang Married To David A. Hahn
description: At the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York, Ella Yang, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Insuk Yang of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Tokyo, and David Aaron Hahn, a son of Virginia Hahn of Lancaster, Pa., and the late Dr. Irving N. Hahn, were married yesterday. The Rev. Richard D. Leonard officiated.

title: U.N. School Opens Doors for New Soviet Students
description: LEAD: In school this year, Yelena Zoubanovh, 7 years old, said she had learned to count to 1,000 in English (almost), and Katya Zarovsky, 8, is playing ''Mary Had a Little Lamb'' on her flute and now says ''yuk'' and ''yummie.''

title: CHALLENGERS SEEKING TO UNSEAT 4 DEMOCRATIC ASSEMBLYMEN
description: In election campaigns ranging from casual to intense, four incumbent State Assemblymen from the county's southern tier are being challenged this year by candidates seeking to break the Democratic hold on the area.

title: Beyond the Campaign, More Tests Await 'Star Wars'
description: THE fate of ''Star Wars'' will be partly determined when voters choose between two Presidential candidates with sharply differing views of the space-based defense system, but political factors represent only half of the equation that will eventually determine its success or failure.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Designer Home for WNET
description: LEAD: Chieftans, a 96-acre estate on the Rye Brook-Greenwich border, will be open to the public as a designer house Saturday through Nov. 20. The 38-room fieldstone mansion and surrounding stables, barn and gardens have been decorated to benefit WNET/Thirteen, the public television station.

title: Nicaragua's Economic Crisis Is Seen as Worsening
description: Although the machine guns and mortars that echoed across Nicaragua for six years have largely fallen silent, the country is facing a profound social, political and economic crisis that diplomats and political leaders say will probably take years or even decades to resolve.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Saved by a Story

title: 768 Yards by Oklahoma
description: Oklahoma ran for a record 768 yards, including 3 touchdowns by Charles Thompson, in routing Kansas State, 70-24, in a Big Eight Conference game today.

title: SONY AND CBS RECORDS
description: Peter J. Boyer's article on the sale of CBS Records to Sony demonstrates, in a nutshell, what is wrong with the United States economy today (''Sony and CBS Records: What a Romance!'' Sept. 18).

title:
GARDENING;
The Many Glorious Varieties of Apples
description: LEAD: THE apple crop is 23 percent smaller than the record harvest last year, and in addition to higher prices, the inferior quality of the mass-market produce could well lead gardeners to grow their own.

title: Iran Is Said to Close Its Border to Iraqi Kurds
description: Iran has closed its border to Kurdish refugees fleeing Iraq through Turkey, a Turkish official says.

title: Decades of Latin-American Artists In a Contemporary Hispanic Setting
description: ESTABLISHED in 1971, the Bronx Museum of the Arts spent its first 11 years tucked away in the rotunda of the County Courthouse. It was a modest operation, but it seemed to do the job, which was to bring culture to a poor community. One of the shows of that era that lingers was of the originals for science fiction illustrations; another was of contemporary abstractions painted entirely in black. Both were well attended.

title: Stadium in West Haven Held Between 2 Visions
description: ITS stands, built 41 years ago with secondhand lumber, are gone as are the minor league baseball games that made Quigley Stadium West Haven's most famous landmark. But the memories and dreams of the thousands of games played at there are still quite alive among most of the 60,000 town residents.

title: Countdown to Standard Time
description: NEW ENGLANDERS are known for their set ways and obdurateness. Old-timers greet change reluctantly. ''If it don't need fixin', don't fix it,'' they say.

title: SONY AND CBS RECORDS
description: Two billion dollars is an astounding amount; thus, how CBS spends the proceeds from the sale of its records division to Sony is surely significant. I was amazed to learn from your article that ''much of CBS's cash now rests'' in Treasury bills.

title: Jersey Conflict Over a Rail Bed
description: WHAT should be done with an abandoned railroad bed?

title: Writer's Son Given Life Term in Death Of New York Youth
description: Jacob Wideman, the 18-year-old son of a prominent writer, has been sentenced to life in prison for the stabbing death of a teen-age traveling companion from New York two years ago.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
Where Houses Grow Instead of Apples
description: LEAD: PEOPLE are busy picking apples at Outhouse Orchards on Hardscrabble Road in North Salem, just as they have for more than a decade of Octobers, but next year they may be picking houses instead.

title: Kerry T. O'Dwyer To Marry in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. William O'Dwyer of Loudonville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kerry Teresa O'Dwyer to Leon D. Marrano 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marrano Jr. of Rye, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: Review/Music; Thouvenel String Quartet
description: Composers have always used dissonance, in large or small measure, as an expressive tool; and listeners, depending on their orientation, have always found it shocking, surprising or affecting; sometimes all three. In its program at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening, the Thouvenel String Quartet - Eugene Purdue and Janet Chisholm, violinists; Sally Chisholm, violist, and Rebecca Seiver, cellist - offered a compact overview of how the conception and use of dissonance has changed over the last two centuries.

title: Slaney Ends '88 With a Victory
description: A man with a microphone approached Mary Slaney and asked to interview her.

title:
GARDENING;
The Many Glorious Varieties of Apples
description: LEAD: THE apple crop is 23 percent smaller than the record harvest last year, and in addition to higher prices, the inferior quality of the mass-market produce could well lead gardeners to grow their own.

title:
GARDENING;
Cooler Weather, Brighter Colors
description: LEAD: MANY garden flowers go on blooming into late fall and provide bright color. I've noticed subtle changes in the foliage and the wonderful color combinations they produce.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: GOLDEN GIRL: The Story of Jessica Savitch. By Alanna Nash. (Dutton, $18.95.) Jessica Savitch was an attractive, popular child. Desperate to remain that way, she grew into an aggressive, obsessive woman and achieved her goal of becoming an NBC news anchor by age 30. She also managed an accomplishment nearly as deliberate: she was dead by age 36.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Westfield
description: LEAD: THE sun had barely begun to climb above the horizon on a recent Saturday morning, but Westfield's downtown was already crowded.

title: 8 Educators Recognized With Awards of $25,000
description: EIGHT educators are making plans that range from sending youngsters to summer camps to buying a diamond ring with the $25,000 awards each received for their work in the schools.

title: Algeria's Unhappy Revolutionary Example
description: WATCHING images of destruction in downtown Algiers flicker across the television screen, a group of conservative Arab diplomats gathered in a Jordanian businessman's home last week agreed that the explosion of wrath by young Algerians against their Government had swept away the image of a triumphant and progressive Algerian revolution.

title: Allison Giffen, Student, Weds T. E. Houghton
description: Allison Ann Hopkins Giffen and Thomas Edward Houghton were married yesterday at the New York Academy of Art by Judge Dorothy Chin Brandt of the Criminal Court of the City of New York. The bride is the daughter of James H. Giffen of New York and June Hopkins of Los Angeles. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Thomas Houghton of Danville, Calif.

title: Home Design/Magazine Part 2
description: Special reports in this issue include: * Inspirations: Where designers get their ideas. * How Medieval and Rennaisance furnishings are emerging from the dark ages. * Why architects today borrow from the past.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The glazing compound on the windows on the south and west sides of our house deteriorates rapidly, with the compound cracking and curling up. We have tried several types of compound, but none seems to last more than a couple of years on those windows. This is especially noticeable along the bottom of each pane on the windows that get the most sunlight. The compound on the other sides of the house has lasted 25 years. Do you have any suggestions on how we can get a longer-lasting job on these windows?

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Switching Channels Starring Kathleen Turner, Burt Reynolds, Christopher Reeve, Ned Beatty, Henry Gibson, George Newbern, Al Waxman, Ken James, Charles Kimbrough. Directed by Ted Kotcheff. 1988. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 104 minutes. $89.95. Rated PG. Contains strong language.

title: Patrick Jay Brown Marries Delia Anne O'Brien on L.I.
description: At St. Brigid's Roman Catholic Church in Westbury, L.I., Delia Anne O'Brien, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. O'Brien of Westbury, L.I., and Little Apple Bay on Tortola in the British Virgin Islands, was married yesterday to Patrick Jay Brown, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Brown of Wyckoff, N.J., and Naples, Fla. The Rev. Walter O'Brien, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: South; Ga. Tech Stuns S. Carolina
description: Andre Thomas scored on a 51-yard interception return and set up another touchdown with a 10-yard return as Georgia Tech ended a 15-game losing streak against Division I-A opposition by stunning previously unbeaten South Carolina, 34-0, today.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ANTHONY BURNS The Defeat and Triumph of a Fugitive Slave. By Virginia Hamilton. 193 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95. (Ages 10 and up)

title: Colleges Stage a World of Theater
description: LEAD: IF Peter Sander, the new chairman of the department of theater and dance at Hofstra University, is right and the university stage is ''the last bastion of challenging theater in the United States,'' then Long Islanders could have a lot of challenging theater in their present and future.

title: BRING BACK THAT OLD SANDLOT NOVEL
description: LEAD: World Series time, hurrah! The fan of the game who is also a reader of books takes up his position before the television. On a nearby table lies a new novel. The jacket of the novel shows a man in what appears to be a baseball uniform sliding into a white cushion that appears to be a base on a baseball field.

title: How Military Might Robs an Economy
description: The key to revitalizing America's economy lies not in trade, industrial policy, or management style - as important as each of these may be - but in defense policy. Only by reducing the burden of its military expenditures can the United States unshackle its economic potential in the years ahead.

title: Still Sweating, but in Nicer Clothes
description: In the movie ''Pumping Iron,'' Arnold Schwarzenegger's oiled chest earned him the Mr. Olympia crown, and the sweaty gym he used was celebrated as the odoriferous temple of body building.

title: OLD POSSUN'S POSTBAG
description: THE LETTERS OF T. S. ELIOT Volume I, 1898-1922. Edited by Valerie Eliot. Illustrated. 639 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $29.95.

title: Ban on Juror Deals With News Media Weighed
description: LEAD: THE New Jersey State Legislature appears ready to pass a law that would forbid jurors in criminal cases to make any monetary deals with news organizations before a grand jury proceeding or a trial has ended.

title: Question Of the Week; Once and For All, What About The D.H. in The Series?
description: Let the ''real'' teams play.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: THE secret, according to experts in the art of city survival, is to avoid eye contact. This does not mean that one is oblivious to what is going on, where it's going on and, most important of all, who else is around. It merely means that acknowledging the presence of anyone else - friend, acquaintance or stranger - is optional.

title: Irish Upset The No. 1 Hurricanes
description: In another of those magnificent and thrilling victories that have given Notre Dame a special place in sports history, a young and spirited Irish team brought down Miami, the long-reigning champion of college football, 31-30, today.

title: 'Electronic Cottages' Take Root
description: While others commute to offices, millions of workers will stay home this week, toiling in their dens, spare bedrooms, kitchens, converted attics, garages and basements. Link Resources, a research firm, says about 9.5 million people who work at home are self-employed, running their own businesses, while an additional 15.5 million work at home for others.

title: Elizabeth L. Baum Is Wed To William Louis Berman
description: Elizabeth Lee Baum, an associate in the Westwood, Mass., law office of Maureen A. O'Reilly, and William Louis Berman, an assistant district attorney for Middlesex County in Concord, Mass., were married yesterday. Rabbi Ellen Lewis officiated at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Theodore B. Baum, in Englewood, N.J.

title: Democrat Takes On 13-Month Incumbent
description: LEAD: THE Fourth Congressional District race pits a Republican incumbent with a perfect attendance record against a challenger who was only the third Democrat in this century elected First Selectman of Greenwich.

title: GIBSON LIMPS OFF WITH GLORY
description: Before the first game of the World Series tonight, Tommy Lasorda, the usually optimistic manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers, was discussing the physical status of his No. 1 hitter and team leader, Kirk Gibson.

title: NIGHTMARES OF THE POLES AND THE LESNIKS
description: THE KING OF THE FIELDS By Isaac Bashevis Singer. Translated by the author. 244 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: Islanders Get By Canadiens
description: It was an understated home opener, but according to Coach Terry Simpson, that was the only way for his Islanders to approach an evening with the Montreal Canadiens.

title: A Stylish Tribute
description: ALICIA Starring Alicia Alonso (in photo) and dancers of the National Ballet of Cuba. Directed by Victor Cassaus. 1976. Video Artists International 70 minutes. $49.95.

title: Fraternity Row Integrated at Ole Miss
description: Two and a half months after an arson fire that threatened to prevent it, fraternity row here at Ole Miss is integrated today.

title: THE SCHOOL THEY ASKED FOR
description: THE WORLD WE CREATED AT HAMILTON HIGH By Gerald Grant. 285 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $24.95.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: 1976 Decision; Whether to Undo A Rights Ruling: The Justices Hear From All Sides
description: THE lawyers who argued Patterson v. McLean Credit Union before the Supreme Court last week had little to say about the case at hand: a racial harassment suit brought by a black North Carolina woman, Brenda Patterson, against her former employer. Instead, they talked mostly about a 1976 decision that is critical to Mrs. Patterson's suit. Last term, when they presented their cases, neither side questioned the precedent, Runyon v. McCrary. The Court did, however, and in an unexpected move, asked the lawyers to return for argument on whether it should reconsider its earlier holding.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN PET SUPPLIES;
PRODUCTS FOR PAMPERED PETS FROM PARIS TO HONG KONG
description: LEAD: Animal aficionados abroad are the target of several American companies in the pet supply industry, some of which staked out their international turf more than 20 years ago.

title: Brothers Are Foes in Miller's Drama
description: IN all of Arthur Miller's plays, the playwright addresses to what extent humans are willing to take responsibility for the choices they make.

title: A Contra Leader Says the Civil War Is Futile
description: Declaring that the military struggle against the Sandinista Government is futile, a Nicaraguan rebel leader has announced the formation of a new group to push for peaceful change in his country.

title: Executive Is Wed To Pam McGinley
description: The marriage of Patricia Ann McGinley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald H. McGinley of Short Hills, N.J., and Hobe Sound, Fla., to Scott Murray Quackenbush, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hubert G. Quackenbush of Orlando, Fla., took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Rose of Lima in Short Hills. Msgr. Harrold A. Murray performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. William F. Devine.

title: Soviets Try to Return to Psychiatric Fold
description: In an effort to improve the international standing of its long-criticized psychiatric profession, the Soviet Union has said it is reapplying to the World Psychiatric Association, a top official of that organization said today.

title: Vigorous Portugese in Danbury
description: THE robust country cooking of Portugal can be found at its Connecticut best in a modest little storefront restaurant in Danbury called O Faia (named for the owner, Joao Martins Faia).

title: Algeria Riots Said to Bolster Islamic Militants
description: One clear winner in the wave of unrest in Algeria has been the Islamic fundamentalist movement, many officials and diplomats here say.

title: A New Influence in Gardens
description: If James van Sweden and Wolfgang Oehme have their way, the American residential landscape is in for some major changes by the time the 21st century rolls around. Already, their landscape architecture firm, Oehme, van Sweden & Associates, founded in 1975 and based in Washington, has won kudos for its fresh style of garden design. Dramatically unlike anything ever seen in America, theirs is truly a garden for all seasons, marked by lush plantings of decorative grasses and massed bold-colored perennials that blend with the landscape and can be viewed with interest all year long.

title: When Self-Importance Interferes With the Music
description: While U2 was touring stadiums last year, band members told interviewers they had become fascinated with American music, especially the black Southern music at the roots of rock-and-roll - blues, gospel and soul. At the same time, the Irish band's 1987 album, ''The Joshua Tree,'' had brought the band world-beating popularity, rocketing U2 from having a sizable cult following to nearly universal applause.

title: Off-Season Work Pays Off
description: The Boston Red Sox traded Dave Henderson to the San Francisco Giants because they didn't have room for him in their outfield of Mike Greenwell, Ellis Burks and Dwight Evans. The Giants let him become a free agent two months later because they didn't have room for him in their outfield of Jeff Leonard, Brett Butler and Candy Maldonado.

title: 350 Years of History Retraced in Exhibit on State Women
description: FRAMED petition from 1669 which accused Katherine Harrison of witchcraft; the diary of a 16-year-old Irish girl who came to New Haven in the 1880's, and a 1987 photograph of the female graduating class of the police academy in Windsor Locks are all part of the exhibit ''Coming of Age: Connecticut Women and their Choices'' at the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford.

title: London's Crop Of Choice B & B's
description: NOBODY in the travel business seems to care much anymore about the discerning tourist of moderate means. In London, as in most major cities around the world, the hotel chains have programmed their microchips to serve either the expense-account traveler or the packaged vacationer, trapping those who know what they like but can't always afford it between the basic $165-a-night Sheraton Hiltons on the one hand and the truly basic cell blocks of the mass-market travel trade on the other. The current London Tourist Board booklet, London Value Hotels, lists only 120 reasonably central establishments where rooms may be had for around $82 (calculated at $1.65 to the pound) a night, for two, and many of those are, well . . . basic.

title: Student Rights Vs. School Responsibilities
description: Earlier this year you published two letters on the Hazelwood decision of the Supreme Court affirming the right of a principal in St. Louis to delete material from a student newspaper. A former school-board member supported the decison, comparing the principal to a private publisher. A Civil Liberties Union representative opposed the decision and the board member by claiming that a public school principal, unlike a private publisher, is a government official and cannot arbitrarily control student speech and press. There is more to the Hazelwood decision.

title: A River's Beauty In a 2-Part Show
description: THE show ''Landscape Painters of the Delaware River'' is divided between two locations, both in Trenton. One is the Trenton City Museum in Cadwalader Park, the other Artworks, at 19 Everett Alley (off Stockton Street).

title: Overlooking Warts At Point O'Woods
description: As a Point O'Woods neighbor who overlooks the ball field and chain-link fence, please note, There is no barbed wire (for at least 25 years).

title: Maine Driver Is Cited Over Lobster on Plate
description: The police in this small central Maine town have cited a resident for violating a state law that prohibits altering license plates.

title: Traffic Note
description: Second Avenue between 14th and 34th Streets will be closed today from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. for the Autumn Jubilee street fair.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN PET SUPPLIES;
FANCY FOODS TO FEED THE FOUR-FOOTED SET
description: LEAD: Trends in the pet food industry have paralleled changes in human diets. Whole grains, fresh vegetables and choice cuts of meat are replacing ''beef byproducts'' and preservatives with names like ''ethoxyquin'' as common ingredients in dog and cat foods.

LEAD: It was in 1939 that I first met Sasha - which is what all his friends and colleagues call Alexander Schneider. I was 18 years old, and in all the years since then no one has shown me more about the inner quality of music or the need to search endlessly for knowledge and experience. He has been affectionately but deeply critical and unremittingly demanding that one learn one's responsibilities to oneself and to music, and never to be satisfied with what has been achieved, but to realize only what has not yet done.

title: Ants Invade BAM. Puppets in Cahoots
description: ''The fighting should be like a dance - not serious and tragic, but more like a fairy tale.'' Lee Breuer, in rehearsal, is directing the great battle sequence of ''The Warrior Ant,'' his epic-in-progress that opens the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival on Wednesday. ''I want it as if we were making a Kurosawa movie with Walt Disney cartoons,'' he says. ''The samurai is a rabbit, or Porky Pig.''

title: Catcher Without a Job Winds Up in the Series
description: One of the more emotional scenes from the Dodgers' victory last Wednesday in the National League playoff was this one: Fred Claire, the Los Angeles general manager, hugging Rick Dempsey, the veteran catcher who was without a job and apparently at the end of his career last winter.

title: LASORDA'S WEAPON IS EMOTION
description: The manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers was walking, apparently aimlessly, through a clubhouse in St. Louis late one afternoon last July when suddenly, to the happy surprise of one of his players, an unclaimed $20 bill appeared on the floor.

title: CYCLING INTO OBLIVION
description: MAJOR TAYLOR The Extraordinary Career of a Champion Bicycle Racer. By Andrew Ritchie. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: Bicycle Books/Kampmann & Company. $19.95.

title: KIDS IN THE FAST LANE
description: LEAD: I AM SITTING ON THE DUSTY FLOOR OF A karate studio, watching my son, Andrew, take his first class. Andrew is 4 years old, and I fear for him. The instructor, a black belt named Mohamad, barks, ''Push-ups, on your knuckles!'' But Andrew does not know what a knuckle is, let alone a push-up. I expect him to start crying, or just stand there, but he copies the other boys and flounders along as best he can.

title: PAINTER OF THE APOCALYPSE
description: ANSELM KIEFER'S PAINTINGS are big, thickly painted, operatic.

title: County May Reconsider Recycling Exclusion
description: LEAD: A decision to exclude seven northern Westchester towns from a county program to award $250,000 in grants for recycling projects will apparently be reconsidered by the Board of Legislators.

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, a portion of an article on ''Star Wars'' research on page 4 of The Week in Review, section 4, was covered by an advertisement. The passage, in the third column of the article, concerned Congressional testimony last week by Gen. Robert T. Herres of the Air Force, the vice chairman of the Joint Chiefs. It reads:

title:
GARDENING;
The Many Glorious Varieties of Apples
description: LEAD: THE apple crop is 23 percent smaller than the record harvest last year, and in addition to higher prices, the inferior quality of the mass-market produce could well lead gardeners to grow their own.

title: WOMEN AND THE IDEAL FAMILY
description: The thinking woman's and man's reaction to the cautions raised in Jane O'Reilly's essay ''Talking About Women, Not to Them'' (Hers, Sept. 11), should be a loud Brava! I refer, in particular, to her observation that our politicians are presenting their version of the ''ideal'' woman, ever so subtly ensconced in the confines of the ''ideal'' family.

title: Shopping
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's article on the duty-free status of items from developing countries and territories under the Generalized System of Preferences (Practical Traveler, Aug. 14) will undoubtedly benefit the traveling public as well as business people in the areas involved.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: No Town by Any Other Name

title: Question Of the Week; Once and For All, What About The D.H. in The Series?
description: Keep the d.h. out of the Series. If you give in to the A.L. on this, they'll next copy football's platooning and put d.h.'s in every position. Hitters won't field and fielders won't hit. Baseball's unique emphasis on all-round athletes will be replaced by specialized freaks talented in only one area. DONALD J. MORTON Auburn, Mass.

title: New York Moves to Protect Plants
description: New York State is acting to protect 365 rare, native plants that it considers to be in danger.

title: FICTION
description: BORROWED TIME. By Amnon Jackont. Translated by Dorothea Shefer-Vanson. (Hamish Hamilton/David & Charles, $19.95.) Amnon Jackont's compelling first novel is a hybrid, a thriller inhabited by people and ideas that are supposed to be taken seriously.
