As a result, the Rangers were taking their time getting started in a season that they had already claimed they couldn't afford to begin slowly.

title: Randall D. Wheelis Is Wed To Mary Elizabeth Adams
description: Mary Elizabeth Adams and Randall Dana Wheelis were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Larchmont, N.Y., by the Rev. Dorothy Green. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Adams Jr. of Delray Beach, Fla. Her husband is a son of Mrs. Reuben E. Wheelis of Mobile, Ala., and the late Col. Wheelis, U.S.A.

title: Patriots Stop Bengals' Streak
description: The New England Patriots concentrated on running the ball today. They got the passing they needed from Cincinnati's erratic Boomer Esiason.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about minority hiring by New York City municipal hospitals incorrectly stated both the size of the hospitals' black and Hispanic work force and the percentage of workers with annual salaries of more than $43,000 who are black and Hispanic. In all, 65.5 percent of the total work force is black and Hispanic, while 22.3 percent of the highest-paid workers are.

title: NBC Proposes Standard For a Better TV Picture
description: The National Broadcasting Company announced Saturday that it was proposing a new high-definition television standard intended to accelerate the development of a higher-quality television picture in the United States by the mid-1990's.

title: Hampers, Not Pampers
description: Just as it's desirable to limit carriage horses to Central Park, it's sensible to limit what the horses leave behind. Yet the usual reaction to horse manure in the park is a resigned giggle. No one loves the sight, smell or residue in the tread of bikes or running shoes, but what, shrug, is to be done? The very idea of horse diapers provokes incredulous snickers. ''Just think,'' someone is sure to say, ''of what big safety pins you'd have to use!''

title: B-1's Long-Running Battle Just Goes On and On
description: Over the last 20 years, few weapons in the United States arsenal have been blown about by political crosswinds as often as the B-1 bomber. Even though it has been built and paid for, the aircraft continues to be the subject of partisan contention.

title: Boeing Order By British Seen
description: British Airways is ordering more than 35 new aircraft from the Boeing Company in a $1 billion deal, The Times of London reported today.

title: For the Athletics, the Dream Dies Hard
description: The team that talked about winning the World Series in five games talked tonight about returning home and returning to normal. Suddenly, the Oakland Athletics are no longer strutting.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council

title: Memorial for Dougherty
description: A memorial service for Philip H. Dougherty, the advertising columnist for The New York Times, who died on Sept. 27, will be held on Wednesday at 5:30 P.M. in the downstairs auditorium of the Equitable Center, at 787 Seventh Avenue, between 51st and 52d Streets.

title: Big Banking Merger in Spain Is Approved
description: Shareholders of Banco Espanol de Credito and Banco Central approved a plan on Saturday to merge the banks and create Spain's biggest commercial bank.

title: Campaign Trail; Soviets Have Vicarious Campaign
description: Far from the campaign trail, the Bush-Dukakis match escalates too.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Theme Park Account Awarded to DMB&B
description: Six Flags Great America in Gurnee, Ill., has awarded its advertising to DMB&B/Chicago. The budget is $3 million.

title: Botha, Pressing Drive by Pretoria, Meets With Ivory Coast President
description: President P. W. Botha of South Africa and President Felix Houphouet-Boigny of the Ivory Coast, black Africa's longest-serving President, met this weekend in a publicity coup for the Pretoria Government.

title: Bills' Bennett Says He's Best
description: Cornelius Bennett isn't bragging. It's just that he's, well, Cornelius Bennett and he must speak the truth.

title: Kansas Man Sows Seeds of Dream
description: From an unusual base, Balbir Mathur, an unusual Kansan, will set off for India Monday to continue his pursuit of a goal that seems to him altogether reasonable. He wants to help reforest the world and help feed its hungry.

title: Larrocha to Play 'Iberia'
description: The pianist Alicia de Larrocha is to play the complete Albeniz ''Iberia'' on Nov. 22 at Carnegi Hall. Tickets, at $35, $25, $23, $20 and $14, are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.

title: Tennis; Navratilova Tops Evert in 75 Minutes
description: Martina Navratilova defeated Chris Evert, 6-2, 6-3, to win a Virginia Slims tournament.

title: The President, Under Glass
description: Few modern Presidents have shielded themselves from reporters as successfully as Ronald Reagan. News conferences have virtually disappeared; discourse between press and President consists mainly of shouted questions on the White House lawn, the answers muffled by the noise of a waiting helicopter.

title: Afghan Radio Reports Death of 2 Americans
description: The official Afghan radio reported today that two Americans helping Afghan rebels and two Pakistani officers were killed Saturday in fighting in Afghanistan. [ In Washington, an Administration official familiar with the region said he had heard no reports of Americans being killed. The official said no United States personnel are authorized to accompany the guerrillas, although private citizens are known to have spent time with rebel groups.

title: Review/Opera; Cast Changes for 'Boheme'
description: Virtually all of Saturday night's principals were new to the New York City Opera's current run of ''La Boheme.'' Ruth Golden and Jon Garrison were Mimi and Rodolfo; Kenneth Shaw, Stanley Wexler and Michael Willson sang Marcello, Colline and Schaunard; the Musetta was Michele McBride.

title: Outdistance Age on the Golf Course
description: YOU never get too old for golf. It is Willard Scott's kind of sport. A 99-year-old man recently made a hole-in-one in Switzerland and a 95-year-old woman made one in Florida. As a matter of fact, the rarest feat in golf is for someone to actually give up the game. The last known person to have done it was Cary Middlecoff, the two-time United States Open champion. ''I just got tired of watching myself play,'' he said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Eastern Airlines to Lintas: Worldwide for advertising in Canada, Europe and Puerto Rico.

title: Six Are Hurt in Violence at a Minnesota Campus
description: Hundreds of university students clashed with the police and burned furniture in two nights of violence that resulted in at least 50 arrests, the police said today.

title: Trade Paperbacks Gaining In Role of a Happy Medium
description: WHEN inflation and declining sales forced book publishers against the financial wall in the early 1980's, many of them sought refuge in trade paperback books. Bigger than the rack-sized mass-market paperbacks and only about half the price of hardcovers, they seemed a perfect solution because of their portability and affordability.

title: U.S. Studies Health Problems Near Weapon Plant
description: More than four decades after the vast energy of the atom was unleashed on Japan, Federal health investigators are preparing to search the high plains of eastern Washington State for American victims of the atomic bomb.

title: Dr. Deborah H. Elkind Marries Gregory S. Shatan
description: The wedding of Dr. Deborah Helen Elkind to Gregory Samuel Shatan took place yesterday at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman officiated.

title: New York Is Building Schools To Reverse Years of Neglect
description: After more than a decade during which its public schools have grown ever more dilapidated and overcrowded, New York City is beginning to build schools once again.

title: Reviews/Dance; 'On a Verge,' Works by 4 Young Chroreographrs
description: Four young choreographers and dancers presented new dance that was sure but superficial in ''On a Verge,'' presented on Saturday night at the Nikolais-Louis Choreospace. A new dance by Ann Burros was less ambitious than the others on the program, but Ms. Burros worked her restricted area of concern - the ritual of psychotherapy - with humor and sensitivity. The first half of the dance, ''Sessions,'' had her three performers sitting restlessly and falling, one by one, into moments of stretching release to Manhattan Transfer's ''Twilight Zone.'' ''Same Time Next Week,'' danced to music by Tracy Chapman adapted by Georg Brandl, offered a look into the psyches of the three women, in a dance that suggested a degree of revelation and retreat, though no great individuality. Curiously the dance ended before its music. The persuasive cast included Lisa Marielle Bleyer, Amy Leshner and Maria Naidu.

title: INSIDE
description: Dodgers Take 2-0 Lead Orel Hershiser pitched Los Angeles to a 6-0 World Series victory that gave the Dodgers a two-game lead over Oakland. SportsMonday, page C1. Minding the Robots Robot automation in factories has been disappointing; managers have found that the machines require smarter workers. Page D1.

title: Where Carriage Horses Belong
description: Last August, a carriage horse named Whitey collapsed on Second Avenue, a victim of heat exhaustion. In December 1985, another carriage horse had to be destroyed after a speeding limousine caused it to bolt into an intersection. And every day carriage horses, plodding at their own pace, add to New York's legendary midtown traffic congestion.

title: No Accord For Icahn On Eastern
description: Carl C. Icahn met with leaders of the three major unions of Eastern Airlines over the weekend, but the groups were not able to agree on a plan to make an offer for the embattled carrier.

title: Apartheid Haunts Gold Giants' Fight
description: Opposition to apartheid is giving a takeover contest between the non-Communist world's two largest gold mining groups heavy political overtones internationally, with voices raised in countries as diverse as the United States and Papua New Guinea.

title: Pakistan Points to Sabotage in Zia Crash
description: A report issued today by a Pakistani investigation team said sabotage or another criminal act probably caused the plane crash that killed President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, the American Ambassador and 28 others. But the report did not specify what criminal act was involved.

title: A Quick Cure for Anemic Democracy
description: LEAD: Soon the quadrennial dirge for American democracy will begin again.

title: 2 Politburo Members Resign in Yugoslavia
description: Two Politburo members resigned today on the eve of a Central Committee meeting widely expected to produce a purge of party members, the Tanyug press agency said.

title: Review/Television; When News Becomes Happy Talk
description: The scene is a morning television show that is in transition from being a serious news program to becoming a lighter breakfast confection called ''Sunny Side Up.'' We are moving from the ''CBS Morning News'' right past ''Today'' and on to ''Good Morning America.'' Len, the young hotshot newcomer, is worried about the impression he made on the first telecast. Gil, the staid veteran, assures him: ''Looked fine.'' Len: ''I wasn't too . . . uh?'' Gil: ''No, not at all.'' Earlier, Len has this line: ''Who knows? Y'know. I don't know.''

title: 84 Arrested in Protest At the Seabrook Plant
description: Eighty-four demonstrators, including at least two children under the age of 10, were arrested today in a protest against the long-delayed Seabrook nuclear power plant.

title: Making Fragrance From 3,000 Odors
description: ''We must have a lot of imagination; we must be dreamers sometimes,'' mused Elie G. Roger, master perfumer and vice president at Firmenich Inc.

title: Rig Count Up in Week
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs jumped by 11 last week, to a total of 925, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago, the count was 1,134. The rig count is a widely watched industry index of drilling activity and reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil as of last Friday.

title: Campaign Trail; Full-Court Press For Letters on Press
description: Among the list of messages on Susy Elfving's desk the other day was one to call the Bush-Quayle headquarters about ''grass-roots support'' for the Republican candidates. Since Ms. Elfving is a Democrat, an administrative assistant to Representative Norman Y. Mineta, Democrat of California, the message left her puzzled. She returned the call. ''Where are you calling from?'' asked the person who picked up the telephone. 'Mineta's.'' ''Is Mineta a proper name or place?'' ''Mineta is a member of Congress.'' ''Did you get the August 9 memo?'' ''No.'' ''Well, look, what we are in is a list of 30 names of people willing to have their names signed to predrafted letters to the editor. Will it be a problem to give us 30 names?''

title: It's Gorbachev and Soviet Masses vs. Old Guard
description: To the Editor:

title: Kelly and Bills Bury Jets
description: Suddenly, it seems like winter again for the Jets.

title: Indian Head Banks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lilco Assures N.R.C. of Its Shoreham Nuclear Plant's Readiness
description: The Long Island Lighting Company sought today to convince the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission that it was ready to begin full-power operations at its Shoreham nuclear-power plant.

title: India Reports Arrival of Burmese Refugees
description: Students fleeing Burma have begun to arrive in India's northeastern states, according to reports from the area.

title: Philip Morris Companies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Latest quarter results reflect a pre- tax charge of $117 million related to the restructuring at General Foods Corp., partially offset by a pre-tax gain of $46 million from the sale of the Open Pit barbecue sauce retail business. These items reduced net earnings and earnings per share by $22 million and 9 cents, respectively.

title: Review/Opera; 'Cosi' in Los Angeles, With Debut and Supertitles
description: An excellent rendition of Mozart's ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' - strongly cast in most roles, beautifully conducted, manifestly prepared with care for detail -concluded the opera's four-performance run at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion here Sunday afternoon.

title: Teamsters Back Bush, Only
description: Vice President Bush won the Presidential endorsement of the Teamsters executive board today after a poll of the nation's largest union gave him a small margin over his Democratic opponent, Michael S. Dukakis. The union president, William J. McCarthy, said the endorsement applied only to Mr. Bush personally and not to his running mate, Dan Quayle, or the Republican Party. Only 21,207 of the 1.7 million members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters voted, giving Mr. Bush a margin of 50.2 percent to 46.4 percent.

title: Soviets Say U.N. Peacekeeping Effort Should Emphasize Prevention
description: A senior Soviet official said today that the United Nations should shift the focus of its peacekeeping operations, putting greater emphasis on preventing conflicts instead of seeking to stop them after they have started.

title: When Leaking Becomes Spying
description: Only one American has been convicted of espionage for leaking classified information to a publication. He is Samuel Loring Morison, a naval intelligence worker who sold a photograph taken by satellite to the British publisher of a military-affairs magazine. Now the Supreme Court refuses to review that conviction, leaving in force a dangerously broad definition of espionage.

title: Our Towns; 'Liberal' Is Not A Dirty Word To This Coalition
description: Sometimes it seems as if the only guy in America saying the word ''liberal'' out loud is George Bush, and he says it about every two minutes in a tone that makes it sound like a synonym for ''extremely painful root canal.''

title: Business and Health; The Controversy On Benefit Rules
description: EMPLOYER-SUBSIDIZED health benefit plans that cover millions of Americans are likely to be revised as a result of new requirements that Congress is reviewing this week. The measures, which have attracted criticism, are intended to insure that a company's lower-paid employees get the same type and value of medical benefits as managers and other higher-paid personnel. Some executives are likely to have to pay income taxes on a portion of their health benefits.

title: Krueger, W A Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $4.4 million from an accounting change.

title: Mr. Bush Sinks the Truth in Boston Harbor
description: As the court-appointed Special Master in the Massachusetts Superior Court litigation over the pollution of Boston harbor, I find myself compelled to speak out on what I believe is a damaging distortion by Vice President George Bush of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's environmental record.

title: Egyptians Agree to Postpone Enforcement of Taba Ruling
description: Egypt has agreed to delay enforcement of an international ruling on the Taba border dispute with Israel until after Israel's general elections, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Saudis Call For Cut in Oil Output
description: A powerful alliance of Arab oil producers inside the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, led by Saudi Arabia, called today for a steep cut of as much as 3 million barrels a day in OPEC's current oil production.

title: Glaxo Appointment
description: Thomas W. D'Alonzo has been named president of Glaxo Inc., the United States subsidiary of Glaxo Holdings P.L.C., a leading pharmaceutical company. Mr. D'Alonzo, 45 years old, fills a position vacated this summer when Ernest Mario, 50, was named chairman and chief executive. Mr. D'Alonzo joined Glaxo, of Research Triangle Park, N.C., in 1983 as general counsel and was named executive vice president last year.

title: New Terms for Bird
description: Larry Bird and the Boston Celtics agreed yesterday on a two-year contract extension worth a reported $4.2 million per year. The Celtics announced an agreement in principle to extend Bird's current five-year contract. The pact, which had two seasons left, pays Bird $1.8 million per year, said to Bob Woolf, his attorney. ''I'm real happy with everything,'' Bird said. ''The Celtics were very fair with me and now I'm going to work hard to help bring another championship to Boston.'' Woolf said Bird, 31 years old, plans to retire when his contract expires after the 1991-92 season. He said Bird will live up to existing contract terms for the next two years. Woolf said the new deal would make the 6-foot-9-inch forward one of the five highest-paid players in the league. Bird reportedly will receive $8.4 million for the 1990 and 1991 seasons. Woolf said the extension is ''well in excess of $4 million'' for each of the final two years of the contract. Bird had set a deadline for Nov. 4, when the Celtics open their regular season, for conclusion of negotiations. He indicated that if they weren't completed by then, he would finish the two years on his contract, then retire or become a free agent.(AP)

title: National Westminster Banorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $7.8 million for the quarter and $18.1 million for the 9 months from the partial recognition of previously unrecorded tax benefits related to the special loan loss provision recorded in 1987. c-Net loss and included a $220 million addition to the reserve against loans to certain countries with severe debt servicing problems.

title: Campaign Trail; Spirits Are High At White House
description: Despite Mr. Atwater's admonition, White House officials were virtually popping the champagne corks on Monday, mindful that their jobs may remain intact if Mr. Bush moves into the Oval Office.

title: Puzzle on Solar Heat
description: Scientists have detected gigantic whirlpools on the surface of the Sun and speculate that this turbulence could be responsible for the extremely high temperatures of the outer solar atmosphere, which is one of the most puzzling features of the Sun and other stars.

title: Utah Power & Light Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
By Design; Going to Any Length
description: Everyone thought - or hoped - the hemline controversy was over. But here it comes again.

title: First Lady Expresses 'Regrets' on Wardrobe
description: The White House acknowledged today that Nancy Reagan has borrowed designer clothes and jewelry from American fashion houses in recent years, even though she promised to end the practice in 1982.

title: The Reality: A 2-Game Lead
description: There is, Joe McIlvaine, a Mets masochist, said today, ''a superior force at work here.'' He meant superior as in supernatural. The Mets executive knows whereof he speaks because he watched the Los Angeles Dodgers do it to the Mets and now he is watching them do it to the Oakland Athletics.

title: A.I.D. Embezzler Sentenced
description: A former financial adviser to the Agency for International Development who admitted embezzling $1.37 million was sentenced Friday to five years in prison.

title: PATTERNS
description: Tahari Branches Out

title: The Athlete on the Mound
description: OREL HERSHISER used to be a hockey defenseman. You could almost see that from the way he swept around second base on Sunday night, leaning forward, long legs slightly bowed, looking to fire a slap shot or slide into third base. He slid, and was safe.

title: People in the News: George Herbert Hitchings; A Research Collaboration Spanning Four Decades
description: GEORGE H. HITCHINGS is described by his colleagues as a man so dedicated and so brilliant that his ideas have shaped drug development for more than 40 years. Yet he had all but given up the idea of ever winning the Nobel Prize.

title: DESPONDENT BOYS IN DOUBLE SUICIDE
description: Two 15-year-old boys despondent at being separated when one of their families moved away took their lives together in a weekend reunion, sharing a hunting rifle that each fired at his own head, the police said today.

title: Northern Trust Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Graco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 23
For Dodgers, A Miracle?
description: The World Series switched to northern California today with the Los Angeles Dodgers holding a two-game lead over the Oakland Athletics, who were placing their hopes for survival on the home turf, the designated hitter and two games of freedom from Orel Hershiser.

title: Foothill Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $4,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $359,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes extraordinary gains of $149,000 and $239,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Pulitzer Publishing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
British Brewer Gets Elders Bid
description: The Australian brewing group Elders IXL today began a takeover bid of $:1.6 billion, or about $2.8 billion, for the British company Scottish & Newcastle Breweries P.L.C.

title: National City Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dale Pon's Milestone For Cool Jazz on WQCD
description: Dale Pon, who left Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/GGK on Labor Day to form Dale Pon Advertising Inc., yesterday displayed for public view his first television commercials for his charter client, the radio station WQCD-FM in New York City, which features contemporary jazz and jazz alone.

title: Republicbank in Dispute Over Tax Bill Provision
description: The First Republicbank Corporation and its creditors stand to lose as much as $200 million of the holding company's last remaining assets should Congress pass a pension law provision included in the proposed tax amendment act.

title: 'Jammy Man' Actor's Plight
description: ROBBY RAMSEL, the most mysterious figure in print advertising since the man in the Hathaway shirt, desperately wants work.

title: Delchamps Spurns Proposal by A.&P.
description: Delchamps Inc., a supermarket chain based in Mobile, Ala., said that its board had rejected a $30-a-share offer from the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company and that Delchamps had filed a lawsuit against A.&P. and related parties in Federal District Court in Mobile. The suit contends that A.&P. failed to disclose potential antitrust violations and neglected to disclose a plan to cripple Delchamps financially if it failed to buy the company.

title: Commerce Bancshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bush Assails Dukakis on the Military
description: Vice President Bush said today that his military spending goals were consistent with those that had restored the nation's ''diplomatic credibility.''

title: Bid for London Papers
description: Daily Mail and General Trust P.L.C., a British investment concern, said today that it had agreed to acquire the 50.5 percent of Associated Newspapers Holdings P.L.C. that it does not already own. The offer of $13.46 a share for the remaining 66.9 million shares outstanding puts a value of $2.1 billion on the printing and publishing company. It publishes the London newspapers The Daily Mail, The Mail on Sunday and The Evening Standard.

title: A Man Called Lemkin
description: The story in the paper reported that after 40 years of consideration the U.S. Senate voted last Friday to make it a Federal offense to commit genocide. That is the crime of acting with intent to destroy a national, ethnic, racial or religious group.

title: Comdial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Amity Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Angelo Carmine Ferrara, 57, Pediatrician
description: Dr. Angelo Carmine Ferrara, a pediatrician and neonatologist, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 57 years old.

title: Dow Ends Up by 7.29 in a Seesaw Session
description: Stocks bounced back and forth yesterday, but by the closing bell prices were moderately higher, buoyed by some program buying and a token show of strength in the dollar.

title: Mercantile Bancorporation Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included a special provision of $75 million added to the reserve for possible loan losses for Latin American loans.

title: Here and There
description: Frank Bruno flew to New York yesterday and said that he did not want to change the site of his mandatory challenge of Mike Tyson from London to the United States. Tyson, who signed an agreement in August to fight Bruno in London, apparently changed his mind earlier this month. ''In England I've got all the advantages,'' said Bruno. ''Mike Tyson, with all his confusion, this is the right time for him to be beaten.'' Bruno and his promoters, Jarvis Astaire and Mickey Duff, were to meet with Tyson's manager, Bill Cayton, to continue discussions that began last Thursday. Sept. 3 was the original target date for the bout. After last week's announcement that Tyson's hand injury had not healed properly, a date of Jan. 14 was set.

title: 10 Students Win Churchill Awards
description: Ten American students have been awarded the 1988 Winston Churchill scholarships for graduate work in engineering, mathematics and the sciences at Cambridge University in England.

title: Myers Suspended
description: Angel Myers, dropped from the United States Olympic swimming team after testing positive for steroid use, has been suspended from competition through 1989, according to a board of review for United States Swimming, the sport's governing body in this country. The three-member board, meeting to decide a penalty against the swimmer following her failure to have the test findings overturned in appeal, also invalidated Myers's records and recalled medals she won during the national long course championships, the meet used to select the Olympic team. The board also ordered Myers to undergo ''not less than three'' random drug tests a year through 1992.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amax Inc. said its Amax Oil and Gas unit had completed its acquisition of SPG Exploration Corp. from Quantum Chemical Corp. for $118 million.

title: United Technologies Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $33.3 million, or 15 cents a share, from the previously announced sale of certain leasing subsidiaries for both periods. The 9 months include first-quarter pretax gains of $155,995,000 from the sale of the company's Essex unit and certain leasing subsidiaries, a second- quarter pretax gain of $41,435,000 from the sale of the company's share of Telefunken Electronic GMBH, a German semiconductor joint venture, and a third-quarter pretax gain of $33,335,000 from the sale of additional leasing subsidiaries. The latest 9-month results are after first-quarter charges to cost of goods and services sold totaling $148,781,000 for restructuring actions at certain operating entities. The restructuring charges include provisions to re-baseline major radar contracts at Norden Systems, charges to write off capital equipment which is expected soon to become excess to Norden's needs and, at several operating units, costs of relocation of some operations and of personnel reductions beyond those announced in December 1986. The company said that year-ago third quarter and 9-month amounts have been restated to reflect the adoption of Financial Accounting Standard No. 94, which requires the consolidation of the corporation's previously unconsolidated finance subsidiaries. The consolidation had no effect on net income.

title: INSIDE
description: Fashion and the First Lady Nancy Reagan issued regrets at not reporting that she had borrowed designer outfits. She promised in 1982 not to borrow any more. Page A26. Trump Sells St. Moritz Donald J. Trump is selling the elegant hotel to an Australian billionaire for $150 million more than he paid for it in 1985. Page B1. The Global Office Arrives Advances in telecommunications and computers are enabling more companies to move white-collar jobs abroad to low-cost locations. Page D1.

title: TRW Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $63 million from the sale of TRW REDA Pump and TRW Oilwell Cable operations and a charge of $43 million to resolve claims from dealers and truck owners stemming from the recall of certain truck steering gears.

title: A's Pitcher Looks to Recapture Triumph
description: Like Kirk Gibson with his home run in Game 1, Bob Welch has embraced his own moment of personal triumph in the World Series. But the 10 years that have passed since Welch, then a 21-year-old rookie for the Dodgers, struck out Reggie Jackson have seemed to pass too quickly.

title: 36 New Goldman Partners Symbolize a Global Outlook
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company, the last major Wall Street firm organized as a partnership, yesterday announced the results of its naming of partners, bringing 36 new professionals into the fold.

title: Chase, Morgan and First Chicago Profits Up
description: Three major bank holding companies yesterday reported higher third-quarter earnings although they were unable to report profits from a large part of their Argentine loans.

title: United Jersey Banks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago figures have been restated to reflect the acquisition of First Valley Corp. on Jan. 29, 1988, accounted for on a pooling of interests basis.

title: Huntington Bancshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Union National Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $800,000 after-tax loss on the sale of a Pittsburgh office building and an after-tax expense of $1.8 million for an early retirement program.

title: The A.C.L.U. That Thornburgh Forsook
description: To the Editor:

title: Archer-Daniels-Midland Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A 'Free Market' at Work in Feeding Kids
description: Here is a tale of free enterprise at work that will gladden the heart of every capitalist who manages to avoid paying taxes:

title: Profits Scoreboard
Escape From Cabaret: Peter Allen to Put 'Legs' on Broadway
description: So why is Peter Allen making the leap from cabaret to Broadway?

title: Bard, C R Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed on Sept. 30.

title: Crawford & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Badger Meter Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Friends of Louise Nevelson Gather In a Memorial for the Late Artist
description: When asked, after a trip to Egypt, how she liked the pyramids, the sculptor Louise Nevelson replied, ''Too small.'' The response, said the art dealer Arnold Glimcher, typified her sense of ''grandeur,'' her ''great expectations'' for herself and everyone around her.

title: Morgan, J P & Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Provision for credit losses of $20 million for the latest third quarter was unchanged from the year-ago period, and the latest 9 months totaled $100 million, compared with $930 million, in the year-ago period.

title: Topics of The Times; Bone in the Throat
description: Consumers are entitled to accurate information about food. Yet the U.S. Department of Agriculture now proposes to let manufacturers put ground bone in hot dogs, bologna and other processed meats without revealing it on the label.

title: First Pennsylvania Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included gains of $3.2 million on sales of investment securities and $1.5 million from the sale of lease financing residual values. c-Net loss and included investment securities gains of $600,000 and a special $100 million reserve addition.

title: August Rise In Inventories Is Put at 0.8%
description: Business inventories, a closely watched indicator of a developing recession, rose by a strong eight-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. It was the 20th consecutive monthly increase.

title: New York Mounts Campaign Against Wall St. Tax Cheats
description: As part of a major drive against income-tax evasion by Wall Street brokers and investment house employees, the state tax department announced today that it would withhold taxes from bonuses and commissions at the state's highest rate starting Jan. 1.

title: Houston Responds
description: The University of Houston said yesterday it had filed its response to the National Collegiate Athletic Association regarding allegations of recruiting violations in its football program. Yesterday was the deadline for a response. The program is accused of 250 rules infractions said to have taken place during the coaching tenure of Bill Yeoman, now a fund-raiser for the school. (AP)

title: Gundle Environmental Sysems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Market Place; Takeover Targets In Bank Industry
description: THE Bank of New York's protracted, expensive and ultimately successful takeover of the Irving Bank Corporation is more than an isolated event, according to some industry analysts.

title: O'Neill Lauded in His Own Words . . .
description: ''Come on now, everybody, with a Happy Birthday . . .'' - Theodore Hickman (Hickey) in ''The Iceman Cometh''

title: Brothers Put The Pressure On Interco
description: The Cardinal Acquisition Corporation yesterday intensified its battle to acquire Interco Inc. by raising its bid by $4 a share, to $74. The new offer totals about $2.67 billion, up from $2.53 billion, for Interco, a St. Louis-based furniture and apparel company whose products include Ethan Allen furniture, London Fog raincoats and Florsheim shoes.

title: New Soviet Credit Line Is Expected
description: The Soviet Union is expected this week to wrap up what is likely to be the largest credit line ever with the West. The deal with London banks would come just days after the Soviets signed two major credit agreements with West German and Italian banks.

title: Steinberg Trial Is Told Evidence May Be Painful
description: The prosecution in the trial of Joel B. Steinberg said yesterday that its evidence would be gruesome and that ''there are no eyewitnesses'' to the crime.

title: ...And in San Francisco, They Also Have a Cake
description: In the six years Eugene O'Neill lived in his California home, Tao House, nearly an hour's drive from here, he wrote some of his greatest plays, including ''A Moon For the Misbegotten'' and ''The Iceman Cometh.''

title: Albany Imperium? Is That Near the Civic Center?
description: Nassau County has its Coliseum and Manhattan has its Garden. In Albany, how about the Sportacular, or the Spectraplex, or perhaps the Stockade?

title: Review/Music; At Radio City, Dylan Sings Dylan With All the Old Fire
description: Bob Dylan has always taken liberties with his songs - changing the tempos and arrangements, altering or jettisoning melodies, turning venom to sarcasm to enigmatic croon.

title: Dukakis Rolls Up Sleeves and Steps Up His Attack
description: Michael S. Dukakis brought his campaign to the industrial heartland today, to Shorty's Delux Diner and the Varsity Bowling alley, with the kind of person-to-person politicking that marked the early days of his drive for the White House.

title: Panel Backs Libel Law Shift
description: A panel of experts on libel and free expression yesterday recommended new Federal rules on libel claims to help settle disputes more quickly.

title: Makings of Genius
description: ''Genius,'' Thomas Alva Edison once remarked, ''is 1 percent inspiration and 99 percent perspiration.''

title: New Law Is Directed Against Fan Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Tishman Sets Aoki Venture
description: The Tishman Realty and Construction Company of New York and the Aoki Corporation of Japan have formed a joint real estate investment fund to sponsor some $2 billion of Tishman construction projects in the next five years.

title: People in the News: Sir James Whyte Black; A Pharmacology Pioneer Who Avoids the Spotlight
description: SCIENTISTS who know him describe Sir James Black as tenacious and driven by obsessive curiosity, but also as a modest man who shuns publicity.

title: A.T&T. to Cut Long Distance By About 3.8%
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would cut long-distance rates an average of 3.8 percent, a move that would save residential and business customers about $700 million a year.

title: Jersey City Schools Return $3 Million in Aid From U.S.
description: Jersey City was forced to return more than $3 million in Federal and state school aid over three years because it could not document enrollment figures or prove the money had been correctly spent, a state auditor said today.

title: Coca-Cola Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the year-ago third quarter includes $40 million gain from the sale of stock in TCC Beverages Ltd.

title: The Growth of the Global Office
description: For the New York Life Insurance Company, the office of the future is in this rural Irish market village, where high technology has usually meant a new tractor.

title: For Iguanas, Place in Sun May Be Too Bright
description: CONSERVATIONISTS breeding green iguanas in captivity to replenish the dwindling population of the species in Central America face a quandary: is it better to turn loose the bullies or the more submissive iguanas?

title: Rules Aimed at Gangs Produce Unexpected Result: Marriages
description: Faced with moving toward the altar or moving out, half a dozen men chose to get married rather than be ejected from their women friends' apartments at a West Side housing project.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Sneaking a Snicker
description: Robert Gates, the nation's No. 2 intelligence official, doesn't mind joking about his experience in 1987 Senate confirmation hearings. Mr. Gates withdrew his nomination to be Director of Central Intelligence after legislators said they would vote against him to send the White House a message about the Iran-contra affair.

title: British Retail Sales Slip
description: Retail sales in Britain fell by 1 percent in September, the Government said today, raising expectations that some of the heat may be going out of a consumer boom that has fueled inflation and deepened the trade deficit. Base lending rates have been raised to 12 percent from 7 1/2 percent since June.

title: Georgia Congressman Charged With Perjury
description: Representative Pat Swindall of Georgia was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on 10 counts of perjuring himself in his grand jury testimony earlier this year in a Federal money-laundering investigation.

title: Crown Cork & Seal Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings results reflect a 3-for-1 stock split distributed Sept. 12.

title: Workers Evacuated at A-Plant
description: An exhaust fan failed in a plutonium-processing area of the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant complex today, causing the evacuation of about 100 workers. But officials said there was no contamination. The fan pulls fresh air through the building and out through filters that trap any radioactive material. A backup fan was out of service for routine maintenance, said a plant spokesman, Cliff Webb.

title: Grace, W R & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net loss of $90,000 for the quarter and net of $5,700,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations, and the 9-month also includes a credit of $4,854,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $474,000 and $27,471,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9-month also includes a tax loss carryforward of $6,882,000.

title: India Shifting Carbide Judge
description: An Indian court has ordered the replacement of the judge trying the compensation case against the Union Carbide Corporation, saying there were grounds for the company's concern that it might not get a fair trial at Bhopal.

title: Net Up at Unisys and NCR, But Both See '89 Slowdown
description: Unisys and NCR announced higher third-quarter earnings yesterday, but both companies said they expected an industry slowdown in 1989 and were already seeing slower orders.

title: Runner Returning
description: Antoni Niemczak of Poland, the second-place finisher in the 1986 New York City Marathon, who later was disqualified after testing positive for an anabolic steroid, will return to compete in this year's race after having served a two-year suspension. The announcement of his eligibility was made yesterday by the race director, Fred Lebow. Niemczak's suspension, levied by the International Amateur Athletic Federation, will end Nov. 2, four days before the race. Although Niemczak, the Polish record-holder in the marathon, proved that the banned substance was administered without his knowledge, by a doctor in his hometown of Wroclaw, Niemczak's suspension was not lifted.(AP)

title: Koch, in Miami, Tempers Tough Talk
description: One moment speaking Yiddish and the next posing in a boat that is used to chase drug traffickers, Mayor Koch of New York campaigned here today for Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic Presidential candidate.

title: Bridge
description: One American team qualified for quarter-final matches in the World Team Olympiad here tonight, and the other is virtually certain to do so.

title: What's Burning in Brazil
description: The Amazon rain forest, the greatest natural wonder of the planet, is rapidly disappearing. Spurred by misguided Government incentives, an army of settlers is torching the trees to convert the forest to cattle ranches. Brazil's President, Jose Sarney, last week decried the ''predatory development.'' But that's scant assurance that action will follow.

title: Andersen Unit Is Renamed
description: Arthur Andersen & Company said today that it had changed the name of its United States Information Consulting practice to Andersen Consulting.

title: Hospital Corp of America reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes about $6.9 million, or 10 cents a share, from the favorable settlement of prior years' medicare cost reports. c-Net loss d-Includes about $2.2 million, or 3 cents a share, from the favorable settlement of prior years' medicare cost reports; and the 9-month includes about $140 million in income taxes resulting from the divestiture of 104 hospitals, a $73 million pre-tax increase in allowance for doubtful accounts, and $126 million in pretax charges incurred mainly to write down certain investment properties and other assets. The company restated its year-ago figures in February to defer a gain on the sale of the 104 hospitals.

title: Franklin Computer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Upjohn Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. DOESN'T DOUBT PAKISTAN ON CRASH
description: American officials expressed confidence today in Pakistan's investigation of a plane crash that killed President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan, but they would not rule out a further inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Survival Test for Simms
description: In a pro football season in which quarterbacks have been knocked out of action week after week, Phil Simms of the Giants has survived. On a Sunday in which John Elway of the Denver Broncos, Mark Rypien of the Washington Redskins and Steve Pelluer and Danny White of the Dallas Cowboys were knocked out of games, Simms was sacked five times and hit several times more, but he and the Giants won.

title: Avemco Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment losses of $378,000 for the quarter and $73,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes realized investment gains of $623,000 and $1,148,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Joyner-Kersee Fights Steroid Rumors
description: She received another award yesterday. The Women's Sports Foundation selected Jackie Joyner-Kersee the amateur athlete of the year for the second successive year, and only if someone else had won would it have been a surprise.

title: Pentair Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CRACKS ARE FOUND ON AGING JETLINER
description: A 30-inch-long series of cracks has been discovered on a 19-year-old Continental Airlines Boeing 737, a top Government safety official said yesterday in a speech about the hazards of aging airliners.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why are heavenly bodies round? A. ''They are not, of course,'' said Leroy Doggett, an astronomer with the nautical almanac office of the United States Naval Observatory. ''They only seem spherical, or they are almost spherical.''

title: McKesson to Sell Liquor Businesses
description: The McKesson Corporation agreed to sell its remaining alcoholic beverage businesses to a unit of Remy Martin et Cie, the French cognac house. The sale, for an undisclosed amount of cash, includes all of the capital stock of ''21'' Brands Inc. of New York and Distillerie Riunite di Liquori S.p.A. of Italy, and a majority interest in Mt. Gay Distilleries Ltd. of Barbados. The combined annual sales of the units total about $100 million.

title: Oregon Is Granted Custody Of 55 Children in Abuse Case
description: Oregon officials today were granted custody of 55 hungry children taken from a farmhouse where an 8-year-old girl was reported to have been beaten to death by staff members of a California religious center.

title: Review/Music; Chamber Works Old and New at Tully
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is celebrating its 20th anniversary this season, and the planned festivities include performances of the 20 works voted most popular by the society's audience. At the opening concert of the series, on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, two of those works were played -Bach's ''Brandenburg'' Concerto No. 5 and the chart-topper, Schubert's ''Trout'' Quintet. And two new works paid homage to the society's role in the expansion of the contemporary chamber literature.

title: NCR Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Campaign Trail; Atwater's Order: 'Keep the Heat On'
description: Lee Atwater should be delighted, but he's nervous. Forget all the talk about George Bush being ahead in the polls, about the Vice President outperforming Michael S. Dukakis in the Presidential debate, he says. Lee Atwater doesn't want to hear a word about it.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Rule Whether Burning the Flag Is Legal
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether burning the American flag as a political protest is the kind of symbolic or political speech protected from criminal prosecution by the First Amendment.

title: Campaign Trail; A Matter of Import To the President
description: It was a White House political strategy luncheon with President Reagan, and the President's schedule over the final weeks of the campaign. A White House aide began discussing Senate races around the nation.

title: Nacco Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nicor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Myers Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The earnings were adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid September 1988. The latest periods' results restated to reflect the acquisition of Plastic Parts Inc., which was accounted for as a pooling of interest. Prior year results have not been restated as the effect would be immaterial.

title: Keys to Israeli Vote: The Orthodox and the Arabs
description: As he stepped to the microphone, Shimon Glick, a medical doctor, admitted that he had never given a political speech before. But he stood before a packed hotel conference room in Tel Aviv, adjusted his skullcap and promised to ''try my best.''

title: APPEAL REBUFFED IN RARE SPY CASE
description: The Supreme Court today refused to hear an appeal by a former Navy intelligence analyst who was convicted of espionage for giving classified satellite photographs to a British military journal.

title: Gertrude Baltimore, Educator, 79
description: Gertrude Baltimore, a former psychology instructor at Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville, N.Y., died of cancer yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 79 years old.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M.

title: Review/Theater; Rodgers and Hart, 48 Different Ways
description: Listening to two hours of Rodgers and Hart is not one of life's ordeals, and you can do it for the next couple of weeks at the York Theater, where six singers and two pianos are offering, in whole or part, 48 songs from the team that gave Broadway 26 musicals between the mid-1920's and the early 1940's, when Lorenz Hart died.

title: Addendum
description: * M magazine, a men's life style publication, will be raising its rate base 7 percent, to 160,000 from 150,000, with ad rates increasing 10 percent, with the January issue.

title: Judge in Drexel Fraud Case Refuses to Remove Himself
description: A Federal judge yesterday refused to remove himself from the Drexel Burnham Lambert securities fraud case and denied charges made by some of the defendants that by presiding in the case, he was violating conflict of interest rules.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: Mounting a stunning takeover bid that would create the biggest producer of consumer goods in the world, Philip Morris Companies Inc. late yesterday offered to buy Kraft Inc. for nearly $11.5 billion in cash.

title: Why Bennington Is the Most Expensive College
description: Among the reasons Bennington College is the nation's most expensive school is the way it has handled Ada Vlachoutsikou and her imperiled monk seals.

title: Joseph E. Sokal, Researcher, 71
description: Dr. Joseph E. Sokal, a researcher in cancer treatment, died Thursday at Duke Hospital in Durham, N.C., after a short illness. He was 71 years old and lived in Durham.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about an American airlift of food to the southern Sudan, and its headline in some copies, misstated the cost of the airlift. It is $1.5 million, not $100 million.

title: Goetz Seeks Reversal On Gun Conviction
description: A lawyer for Bernhard H. Goetz asked the state's highest court yesterday to give some weight to ''little words'' and overturn a gun possession conviction stemming from his shooting of four men in New York City in 1984.

title: Corrections
description: The TV Notes column yesterday misidentified the New York station that broadcasts reruns of ''Cheers'' and has been losing viewers. It is Channel 11, not Channel 9.

title: Bavarian Party Moves to Fill Posts Once Held by Strauss
description: Bavaria's right-wing Christian Social Union today gave two men the task of filling the roles held by Franz Josef Strauss, who died early this month.

title: Student Dies After Fall
description: A 16-year-old girl who fell through a skylight while taking yearbook pictures on the roof of her high school has died after two days in a coma, the authorities said. Rabsary Gutierrez, a junior at Hialeah-Miami Lakes High School, fell 30 feet on Friday when she apparently misjudged her step and plunged through the glass skylight.

title: Strain on Industrial Capacity Eases
description: The strain on industrial capacity in the United States eased in September for the first time in seven months as utilities scaled back after the summer heat wave, the Government said today.

title: Manville Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a net charge of $13.9 million related to restructuring costs. c-Included gains primarily from the sale of assets of $3.5 million for the quarter and $12.5 million for the 9 months.

title: Justin Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,054,000 for the quarter and $2,261,000 for the 9 months.

title: Children Find Body While Playing Ball
description: A group of youngsters playing ball in a grassy area near the Interboro Parkway in Brooklyn on Sunday found a body in a plastic bag that was hidden in bushes, the police said.

title: Morrow To Publish Spy Book
description: A book to be published next week says the British Government shielded a top-ranking British traitor because he had access to intelligence information about the purported Nazi sympathies of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor.

title: Court Drops Charges On Mafia Informant
description: Heroin-smuggling charges were dropped in Federal court in Brooklyn yesterday against Tommaso Buscetta, a Mafia defector who gave law-enforcement officials valuable information in major organized-crime trials in Italy and the United States.

title: Source Capital Inc reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Net income represents net assets.

title: Sallie Mae Yield Tied to Yen
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association yesterday priced a $60 million offering of reverse principal exchange-related securities through a syndicate led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Roosevelt Savings Yield Put at 9.71%
description: The Roosevelt Federal Savings and Loan Association yesterday priced a $100 million offering of 10-year mortgage-backed securities through an underwriting syndicate led by Drexel Burnham Lambert.

title: Trump to Sell The St. Moritz At Big Profit
description: Donald J. Trump said yesterday that he was selling the St. Moritz Hotel on Central Park South for $150 million more than he paid for it in 1985.

title: 3 Drug Pioneers Win Nobel in Medicine
description: Two Americans and a Briton won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine yesterday for discoveries of what the Nobel committee in Stockholm said were ''important principles for drug treatment.'' The researchers developed a series of drugs that have become essential in the treatment of heart disease, peptic ulcers, gout, leukemia and other ailments.

title: Grainger, W W Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Reynolds Metals Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,300,000 and $4,100,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Champion International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ashton-Tate Names PC Division Officer
description: The last career decision that William P. Lyons made was in 1969 when he was promoted to captain in the United States Army. He dropped out of the Army and joined the International Business Machines Corporation instead.

title: United Cable Television Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Aramco Wins Overseas Discrimination Suit
description: American companies operating abroad do not have to comply with the civil rights law forbidding discrimination on the job, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: MEXICO TO RECEIVE UP TO $3.5 BILLION AS LOAN FROM U.S.
description: In its largest loan ever made to a debt-pressed nation, the United States said today that it would grant Mexico up to $3.5 billion to help it cope with reduced revenues resulting from the plunge in oil prices.

title: Trivandrum Journal; An Education in Politics For Girls at Holy Angels
description: In India's gentle deep south, where mosques and churches share the beach-front coconut groves with Hindu temples, two perenially wary adversaries - a Marxist government and a Roman Catholic education system - are squared off again in tense confrontation.

title: On Horse Racing; A Death Intensifies Jockeys' Solidarity
description: The bitter labor strife that has enveloped New York racing lifted briefly yesterday, long enough for the funeral and burial of Michael Joseph Venezia.

title: Woman's Right to Die Upheld
description: In a case that gained attention from the involvement of a Roman Catholic bishop, a Federal judge ruled today that a comatose woman has a constitutional right to have her feeding tubes removed, despite objections by a state attorney that she would starve to death.

title: Louisiana-Pacific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The figures for all periods exclude the earnings and sales for Fibreboard Corp., a former Louisiana-Pacific subsidiary, which was spun off in June 1988. The company said the figures also excluded a nonrecurring gain on the final settlement of Redwood National Park condemnation in the first quarter of 1988.

title: The A.C.L.U. That Thornburgh Forsook; His Long Silence
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Idle Retirees Drag Down the Economy
description: LEAD: A retired American today is probably the freest human being ever to walk the earth. Assuming that basic needs are met by a pension, Social Security, Medicare and investment income, the retiree lives in a perpetual paradise of leisure and recreation. If the retiree stays healthy, this special status can be enjoyed for 15 to 20 years.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Acme Electric Corp., Olean, N.Y., a maker of power conversion equipment for electronic and electrical systems, elected as a director Robert T. Brady, president and chief executive of Moog Inc.

title: Give Manhattan Chauvinism a Bronx Cheer
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Signal Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Storm in Chicago Area Leads To Hundreds of Flight Delays
description: A storm raked central and northern Illinois with hail and high winds today, delaying hundreds of flights at Chicago airports. Five people were reported to have been struck by lightning.

title: Simpson Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Books of The Times; One Man as an American Metaphor in Vietnam
description: A Bright Shining Lie John Paul Vann and America in Vietnam By Neil Sheehan Illustrated. 861 pages. Random House. $24.95

title: Lin Broadcasting Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $862,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $31,125,000 on the sale of radio stations.

title: Birmingham Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bush Gains in a New Poll of Voters
description: Vice President Bush has opened a large lead over Michael S. Dukakis among likely voters, according to the first major survey of opinion since Thursday's final debate.

title: Ewing Practices
description: Patrick Ewing, the Knicks' center, who has missed all three of the team's preseason games with a bruise above his right knee, returned to practice yesterday at the team's training camp at SUNY-Purchase. During Ewing's absence, the Knicks lost their last two exhibition games, to the Cleveland Cavaliers and the Charlotte Hornets. The 126-113 loss to the Hornets, an expansion team, on Sunday night was particularly upsetting for Coach Rick Pitino. ''We are not playing very well right now and that has bothered me, but all that changed today when Patrick came back,'' Pitino said. ''He makes everyone so much better.''

title: Late and Loudly, Jackson Rejoins Fray
description: Jesse Jackson was not sulking or skulking. He was not dispirited or dyspeptic. He was, on the contrary, ready to fire and inspire.

title: LaRouche Enters Not Guilty Plea in a Fraud Case
description: Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the political extremist, and six co-defendants pleaded not guilty today to Federal charges of fraud and conspiracy in connection with what the authorities said was a scheme to raise money.

title: United Technologies' Profit Up 15%
description: The United Technologies Corporation today reported a 15 percent increase in its third-quarter profit, including a gain from the sale of assets.

title: U.S. and Philippines Sign Pact on Bases
description: The United States and the Philippines signed an agreement today that will give the Philippines $962 million in military and economic aid in 1990 and 1991 in exchange for the continued operation of two American military bases there.

title: D.F. King Fills Dual Post Of President and Chief
description: D.F. King & Company, one of the Wall Street proxy-solicitation firms that have thrived in the era of mergers and acquisitions, has named John J. Gavin president and chief executive.

title: First of America Bank Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Witness Tells Of Warnings By Myerson
description: Sukhreet Gabel testified yesterday that Bess Myerson told her in the midst of a grand jury investigation that ''you could be dangerous'' and that she should ''keep your mouth shut.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17

title: People
description: * Donna Campanella has joined Lintas: USA as senior vice president, group media planning director.

title: Green Names Coaching Staff
description: Dallas Green, the new manager of the Yankees, yesterday announced his coaching staff for the coming season, selecting four men who have had managerial experience in the major leagues.

title: Chase to Aid Harlem Dance Tour
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that it would sponsor the Dance Theater of Harlem's 1989-90 national tour, which will celebrate the ballet troupe's 20th anniversary. The troupe is to receive a $120,000 grant, with an additional amount estimated by a bank representative as at least $120,000 given for such services as tour publicity and receptions.

title: Old Kent Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Commercial Credit Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a $52,800,000 loss from discontinued operations.

title: Review/Music; Taste for the Fastidious
description: American conductors in important posts have become somewhat of a trend in European musical life. Many have done better abroad than at home. New York, for example, hears Lawrence Foster less than it hears about him, but this conductor from Los Angeles has a number of interesting conducting jobs on the Continent. One is as music director of the Lausanne Chamber Orchestra, which he brought to Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon in a program of Haydn, Rodrigo and Honegger.

title: Leslie Fay Companies reports earnings for 13wk to Oct 1
Corning Glass Works reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 9
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $700,000 and $2,000,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and both the quarter and 9 months include one- time gains of $59.9 million, or $1.32 a share, from several previously announced transactions in Japan. c-Includes a tax loss of $400,000 for the quarter and a tax benefit of $1,800,000 for the 9 months.

description: Debt

title: Why Small Businesses Need Health Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Electronic Shipments Up
description: American factory shipments of electronic equipment and components in the first nine months of 1988 rose 10.3 percent, to $183 billion, from $166 billion a year earlier, the Electronic Industries Association reported today.

title: People in the News: Gertrude Belle Elion; A Research Collaboration Spanning Four Decades
description: GERTRUDE B. ELION is known for her precise, careful work, her intellectual brilliance and her ability to work with others, her colleagues said.

title: Icahn Ending Attempt To Buy Eastern Airlines
description: Carl C. Icahn, the investor and chairman of Trans World Airlines, told officials of the Texas Air Corporation yesterday that he was ending his effort to make a bid for Eastern Airlines.

title: 200 Arrested Near Pentagon In Protest of Salvador Policy
description: The Federal and local police arrested more than 200 demonstrators outside the Pentagon today during a protest against United States military involvement in El Salvador.

title: Binks Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $375,000 from an accounting change.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about American reaction to recent demonstrations in Yugoslavia, and a correction in this space yesterday, misidentified a New York Representative who received a letter from Vice President Bush expressing concern about the situation of ethnic Albanians. He is Joseph J. DioGuardi, Republican of Westchester County.

title: 6 IN CHICAGO PLAN TO RUN FOR MAYOR
description: The field of Democrats planning to run in next year's Chicago mayoral election grew to six today, when Edward M. Burke, one of the city's best-known political names, declared himself a candidate.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Congress; CONTRA AID BATTLE IS STYMIED, BUT DISPUTES LINGER
description: While the Congressional battle over aid to the Nicaraguan rebels has been suspended, a dispute persists over whether the Administration's public relations campaign to promote the program in earlier years amounted to an illegal domestic propaganda operation.

title: Standard Products Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
Baseball Survives Translation
description: LEAD: Except for the fact that they were the first baseball team from the Soviet Union to visit the United States, the men of the D. I. Mendeleyev Institute of Chemical Technology in Moscow might have been any other tourists in New York during a stretch of balmy autumn days.

title: Judge Picks Final Site For Yonkers
description: The Federal judge in the Yonkers housing-desegregation case yesterday designated the last of seven sites for low-income public housing and ordered the city to act to acquire the property.

title: Bronx Official Seeks Hair From Relative Of Missing Woman
description: A Bronx prosecutor asked a judge yesterday for permission to take hair samples from the former brother-in-law of a Bronx woman whose headless body, the police say, was found in the Hudson River last spring, nearly two years after she disappeared.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Maple Leafs 6, Canadiens 2: The center Vincent Damphousse scored three goals for the first time in his career as Toronto (4-3) beat Montreal (2-4) last night. The Maple Leafs took a 3-0 lead in the first 15 minutes, as Derek Laxdal and Damphousse each scored his fourth goal of the season and Dan Daoust had his first. (AP) North Stars 3, Oilers 3: Dave Gagner banged in his own rebound early in the third period to give Minnesota (1-4-1) the tie in Edmonton. Gagner knocked down a pass by the defenseman Reed Larson near center ice seven minutes into the final period and skated in alone on Grant Fuhr, who made the initial save, but was unable to stop the rebound. The Oilers are 2-2-2. (AP) Flames 11, Kings 4: Jiri Hrdina had three goals to lead Calgary at home. The Flames (3-1-1), who led 4-3 after two periods, scored three times in the first 2:01 of the third period. The Kings are 4-2-0. (AP)

title: Office Depot reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $161,000 and $546,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; 9 months also include $2 million, or 28 cents a share, of life insurance proceeds. c-Net loss

title: Town & Country Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31

THE ENVIRONMENT;
IN WISCONSIN, A DEBATE OVER WAYS TO MANAGE NATIONAL FOREST GROWTH
description: LEAD: THE United States Forest Service is expected to rule in the next few months on a controversial proposal by a team of Wisconsin botanists that could profoundly change the way a national forest is managed.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Good to the Corps
description: One of the tasks of the Peace Corps is to help developing countries become more self-sufficient in food supplies.

title: Terms Revised in Deal for Lorimar
description: In response to the delay in closing the merger deal between the Lorimar Telepictures Corporation and Warner Communications Inc. as well as the weakening condition of Lorimar, the companies have renegotiated the terms of their merger agreement.

title: Macmillan and Kohlberg Win Round in Takeover
description: In an important victory for Macmillan Inc. in its struggle to evade a takeover by the Maxwell Communications Corporation, a Delaware judge upheld a provision fashioned by Macmillan to help carry out a leveraged buyout of the company by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

title: KEY RATES
Man Is Sentenced In L.I. Killing
description: A man who admitted killing a drug dealer's girlfriend after the dealer offered to forgive a $7,000 debt in exchange for the murder was sentenced today to 18 years to life in prison.

title: Alma Cunningham, 78, Clothing Executive
description: Alma Cunningham, retired vice president of fashion design for the Simplicity Pattern Company, one of the world's leading manufacturers of paper patterns for clothing, died of breast cancer on Oct. 10 at a hospital in Dallas. She was 78 years old and lived in Dallas.

title: Barris Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest first quarter results were negatively impacted by unrealized losses on equity securities of $3,865,000 and losses on the sale of investments of $523,000 with no associated tax benefits.

title: First Union Real Estate Investments reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $852,000 and $4,390,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $751,000 for the quarter and $5,881,000 for the 9 months.

title: Sun and Seiko In Licensing Pact
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., based in Mountain View, Calif., signed a licensing agreement with Seiko Instruments Inc. of Tokyo for Sun's scalable processor architecture, or Sparc. Seiko plans to use Sparc, a fast microprocessor based on reduced instruction set computing, a technology used to speed processing, in its high-end computer work stations and file servers.

title: IRAN SAID TO WORK ON U.S. EMBASSY
description: Iranian travelers here report that Revolutionary Guards have been withdrawn from the United States Embassy in Teheran and that the complex is being refurbished, Western diplomats said today.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Sweet Deal
description: Having established a bastion on Capitol Hill, there was still another Federal fortress - the White House - to be stormed with M & M's, the hard-shelled chocolate candy that comes in a variety of colors. Now that has happened, and jellybeans are history.

title: Arabs Giving Millions To Fund for Palestinians
description: Arab donors have contributed about $18 million to a special United Nations effort to aid Palestinian refugees in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, officials here said today.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Art Is Also in Her Blood
description: The name on the abstract graphics and metal sculptures in a Washington gallery is Gabriela von Habsburg, which sounds like royalty. And it is.

title: Findings Shed Light on Asbestos and Cancer
description: DOCTORS have known for more than 20 years that asbestos can cause cancer, but just how the mineral does this has been a mystery.

title: Leaders of 3 U.S. Jewish Groups Take Issue With Pro-Israel Lobby
description: Leaders of three of the nation's most important Jewish organizations have asserted that the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, the chief lobby for Israel on Capitol Hill, is out of step with ''the consensus of the organized Jewish community'' on some key Middle East issues.

title: L.I.R.R. Details Plan to Revamp Penn Station
description: A new, ''more distinguished'' look and about 17,000 square feet will be added to Penn Station under the Long Island Rail Road's $73-million renovation plan, which the railroad described in detail for the first time yesterday.

title: Yonkers Razes a Blighted 'Parthenon'
description: When they were erected here a decade ago, the Colonnades held out all the hope of a heart transplant for Getty Square, the shabby and shunned downtown area of this Westchester city.

title: Careers; Expertise Needed for Cogeneration
description: USING a process called cogeneration, a growing number of industrial and commercial plants are cutting millions of dollars from their utility bills. Under the process, the plants produce their own electric power and thermal energy from waste heat - and add to the employment possibilities for technical experts in such widely varying fields as engineering, law, marketing and finance.

title: An Ad Woman For Bank Post
description: Becoming part of the 17-member New York State Banking Board had never occurred to Caroline R. Jones.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Rodney W. Markley Jr., a former executive of the Ford Motor Company, misidentified his widow. She is the former Annabel Pugh Dolan.

title: Advisory Facts and Fantasy Figures
description: It's official! The Administration has issued its formal estimate that the Federal deficit in fiscal 1989, which began Oct. 1, will be less than the $146 billion ceiling set by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law. Not much less, says the Office of Management and Budget - only $545 million. But that's enough to forestall the chaotic across-the-board spending cuts that would otherwise be required. That makes Washington happy; Democrats and Republicans alike are made to look responsible. But anyone familiar with Federal bookkeeping knows the numbers are fantasy.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a visual-arts exchange between the United States and the Soviet Union misidentified the site of an exhibition of works by students from the I. E. Repin Institute of Painting, Sculpture and Architecture in Leningrad. The exhibition will be at the New York Academy of Art, 419 Lafayette Street, tomorrow through Nov. 27; it is not at the New School.

title: Fairchild Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $2,033,000 for the quarter and $7,459,000 for the 9 months, and the 9-month also includes net from discontinued operations of $2,459,000. c-After a loss of $3,261,000 for the quarter and net of $2,475,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations and tax credits of $2,772,000 and $12,687,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a charge due to an accounting change of $193,000 for the quarter and a gain from an accounting change of $2,601,000 for the 9 months. Year-ago sales are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: U.N. Official Criticizes Focus Of Third World Development
description: The director general of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization criticized third-world governments today, saying they spent too much money and energy on ''showcase'' projects in their big cities while neglecting food production and the needs of the rural poor.

title: First Chicago Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: HOUSE REPORT FAULTS F.D.A. APPROVAL OF SEDATIVE
description: A Congressional investigation into how the Food and Drug Administration approved a sedative linked to deaths and serious side effects shows that the agency has failed to get all available data before clearing this and other drugs, a House subcommittee reported today.

title: Sobol Backs Course On AIDS in Sayville
description: State Education Commissioner Thomas Sobol ruled yesterday that a curriculum intended to teach about AIDS was proper, despite assertions by some parents that the courses were nothing more than sex education under a different guise.

title: Worries Persist On Towers Plan At Coliseum Site
description: A proposed skyscraper complex on Columbus Circle, which was scaled down after objections to its size, would still increase traffic congestion, cast shadows over Central Park and place new burdens on the area's sewerage system, a draft environmental impact statement filed yesterday said.

title: Autodie Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain fo $758,187, or 15 cents a share.

title: Mirages in the Sky May Not Be So Rare
description: NEW evidence indicates that giant arcs of light, mirages produced by the gravity of distant galaxies, are more abundant in the universe than had been supposed.

title: Weyerhaeuser Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Keycorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pirate Radio Station Goes On and Off Air From a Ship Off L.I.
description: An unlicensed rock radio station forced off the air 14 months ago by the F.C.C. resumed broadcasting for about an hour last night from a ship four miles off Long Island until ordered to stop by a Federal judge.

title: Unlikely Allies Rush to Free 3 Whales
description: Three young whales, battered and bloodied by jagged ice that has trapped them near Point Barrow, Alaska, have become the focus of a huge rescue effort by uncommon allies.

title: Andrew Cuomo to Shift to Full-Time Housing Work
description: Andrew Cuomo announced yesterday that he would leave his job with a Manhattan law firm to devote full time to building housing for homeless families now in welfare hotels.

title: Court Eases Securities Firm's Bond
description: In a ruling sharply limiting the impact of a racketeering indictment against five executives of a New Jersey securities firm, a Federal Judge yesterday restricted the amount of money that the firm would have to post as a bond to insure assets that might be forfeitable to the Government.

title: French Government Is Criticized For Failing to Condemn Algeria
