description: The French Government has come under sharp domestic attack for failing to criticize Algeria for repression in quelling riots and protests there last week. Some 250 people were reported killed in the clashes.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Philip Morris offered $11.5 billion for Kraft in a bid that would create the world's biggest producer of consumer goods, with an empire ranging from its many cigarette brands to Miller beer and a huge line of General Foods products. The $90-a-share deal would, if completed, displace Unilever, the big British-Dutch company, as the world's largest producer of consumer goods. It would be the second-largest takeover in history, following the 1984 Chevron-Gulf merger. Kraft shares closed at $60.125 before the offer was announced. Kraft has not yet responded to the bid. [ Page A1. ] A.T.& T. plans to cut long-distance rates 3.8 percent, or about 29 cents on a typical monthly residential bill of about $8.60. But the reduction would take effect Dec. 1, the day customers start paying 60 cents more a month in local access charges. [ A1. ] New York State will withhold taxes from bonuses and commissions as part of a major crackdown on income-tax evasion by Wall Street brokers and investment house employees. [ A1. ] The Nobel Prize in Medicine was awarded to researchers for Burroughs Wellcome, SmithKline and Imperial Chemical. [ A1. ] A Federal judge refused to remove himself from the Drexel Burnham Lambert securities fraud case. [ D1. ] Carl Icahn gave up attempts to make a bid for Eastern Airlines, a source close to the talks said. [ D2. ] Higher profits were reported by three banking companies -Chase, J.P. Morgan and First Chicago. [ D1. ] The Rales brothers raised their bid for Interco by $4 a share, to $74. [ D5. ] Donald J. Trump is selling the St. Moritz Hotel in New York to Alan Bond, the Australian billionaire, for $180 million. [ B1. ] Unisys and NCR reported higher earnings, but both expect an industry slowdown in 1989. Lotus said profit fell. [ D10. ] First Republicbank's creditors stand to lose as much as $200 million of the company's assets under a new proposal. [ D17. ] Goldman, Sachs named 36 new partners, giving each access to millions of dollars in capital. [ D2. ] A judge limited the bond amount to be posted by five executives of Princeton/Newport L.P. in a racketeering case. [ D9. ] A judge upheld Macmillan's measure to help carry out a leveraged buyout of the company. [ D27. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT The U.S. will grant Mexico up to $3.5 billion, its largest loan to a debt-troubled nation, to help its neighbor deal in the short term with the revenue loss from falling oil prices. [ A1. ] The Soviet Union is likely to wrap up its largest-ever credit line with the West - with London banks for up to $2.62 billion - this week. The Soviets are restructuring their economy. [ D1. ] Sharp cuts in OPEC oil output were proposed by an alliance of Arab oil producers, led by Saudi Arabia. [ D1. ] THE ECONOMY Business inventories rose by eight-tenths of 1 percent in August, the 20th consecutive monthly increase. But sales also rose, by a brisk 1.1 percent, keeping the ratio of sales to stockpiled goods at a manageable 1.5. [ D1. ] The U.S. factory operating rate fell to 83.6 percent of capacity last month, from 83.8 percent in August, the first decline in seven months. [ D6. ] MARKETS Stocks rose moderately, helped by strength in the dollar. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 7.29 points, to 2,140.47. [ D10. ] Platinum futures rose sharply. [ D22. ] The dollar rose after reports of intervention by the Bank of Japan. Gold prices rose on the Comex to $412.20, up $3.10. [ D22. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher in thin trading. [ D21. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Requirements intended to insure that a company's lower-paid employees get the same type and value of medical benefits as managers are under scrutiny this week. Business and Health. [ D2. ] Bank of New York's struggle to gain control of Irving should send a clear message to banking executives that they must maximize shareholder value, analysts say. Market Place. [ D10. ]

title: Horizon Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Campus Buildings Are Decaying, Survey Says
description: By constantly deferring expenses for maintenance, the nation's colleges and universities now face an estimated $20 billion in urgently needed work to repair and update buildings, equipment and utilities, a survey contends.

title: Ziegler Company reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hubbell Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sorg Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $87,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Pope & Talbot Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
It's Gorbachev and Soviet Masses vs. Old Guard; Forget Plot Fantasies
description: To the Editor:

title: Diebold Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $4,484,000 from the cumulative effective of an accounting change. The company said year-ago 9-month sales were restated in the fourth quarter of 1987 due to a change in accounting for a majority-owned subsidiary.

title: Flexible Address Book
description: IT has always seemed like a good idea: automating an address book.

title: Haiti Says It Foiled Coup Attempt
description: The military Government said today that it had thwarted an attempted coup against Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril by two military officers.

title: US Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $8,834,000 from the cumulative effect of accounting changes. The earnings in the latest periods included the results from U.S. Bank of Washington, which was formed by the merger earlier this year of Peoples Bank and Old National Bank, acquired in 1987. The year-ago results have been restated to include Peoples but because of accounting rules, only include the results from Old National since the completion of that cash acquisition on July 1, 1987.

title: Baybanks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $4,820,000 from an accounting change.

title: Studies Link AIDS Virus Directly to Cancer and Dementia
description: SCIENTISTS have found surprising effects of the AIDS virus that may help explain how it contributes to cancer and dementia in many of its victims.

title: Loring Journal; Rallying Round an Air Base in Northern Maine
description: Several times a day, the tranquillity of this Northern Maine potato-farming town is broken by shrieking jet engines.

title: Hewlett-Packard's Stake in Conductus
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said that it had made a 15 percent equity investment in Conductus Inc., a start-up company based in Palo Alto, Calif., that is pursuing high-temperature superconductor technology. The companies agreed to perform joint research and development for five years.

title: Burlington Northern Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter includes about $8,000,000, or 10 cents a share after-tax loss related to the disposition of trucking operations. The latest 9-month includes after- tax charge of $143,000,000, or $1.91 a share related to natural gas take-or- pay claims; also included is an after- tax charge of $12,000,000 related to the disposition of trucking operations. Share earnings and shares outstanding provision for income taxes have been restated for the implementation of statement of FAS No. 96, accounting for income taxes.

title: Compaq Introduces Laptop
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation, a pioneer maker of transportable computers that got off to a late start in the growing laptop machines market, yesterday introduced its smallest computer yet.

title: German Oil Trader Held
description: The chief oil trader at Kloeckner & Company was dismissed from his job and arrested today on suspicion of embezzlement in connection with a multimillion-dollar oil trading loss, the company said.

title: Burlington Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest 9-month includes an after-tax charge of $143,000,000 relating to natural gas take-or-pay claims. Share earnings and shares outstanding are pro fomra.

title: Palestinians to Meet This Month on Declaring State
description: After several postponements, the Palestine National Council is scheduled to meet on Oct. 31 to adopt a declaration of an independent Palestinian state, Palestinian officials said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Nobel Prize is fine, but the drugs I've developed are rewards in themselves.'' - Gertrude B. Elion, who shares Nobel Prizein Medicine. [ C16:2. ]

title: Coca-Cola's Net Up 8.9%
description: The Coca-Cola Company today reported an 8.9 percent rise in third-quarter net profit and said its performance for the year was on target.

title: Why Next Is Promising A Revolution
description: LAST week was Next week. Next Inc. of Palo Alto, Calif., briefly diverted the nation's attention from the Presidential elections by announcing a new computer that makes more promises than any candidate.

title: Great Lakes Chemical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Southtrust Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Issues Overcome Early Dip
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher in very thin trading yesterday despite some weakness in the dollar and a further slight rise in the price of oil.

title: FMC Gold Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
It Began With Dolley Madison
description: Nancy Reagan is not the first President's wife whose appetite for high-fashion clothes has come under scrutiny. In the 19th century Dolley Madison, Mary Todd Lincoln and Julia Grant were known to spend lavishly on clothes. When Jacqueline Kennedy was criticized early in her husband's Administration for wearing French designer clothes, she dealt with the problem by installing Oleg Cassini as her official couturier.

title: Chess
description: Bent Larsen, the greatest player in Denmark's history, has neither played nor lived in his native country in recent years. But he made an exception to enter and share first prize in the Naestved Open International Tournament, which ended July 31, with Ferdinand Hellers of Sweden. Both the famous grandmaster and the rising international master scored 7 points in the nine-round Swiss-system competition to top a field of 323 participants.

title: Maurice Moore-Betty, 77, a Chef
description: Maurice Moore-Betty, a cooking teacher and author, died of a heart attack Wednesday at a friend's home in Manhattan. He was 77 years old and lived in Shelter Island, L.I.

title: New Plans for Space Reactors Raise Fears of Nuclear Debris
description: THE United States and the Soviet Union are drawing up elaborate plans for the use of nuclear power in space, reigniting fears that radioactive debris from an accident will sooner or later come raining down on the Earth.

title: Chubb Unit Pays Claims to Farmers
description: The Chubb Corporation said its Federal Insurance Company unit had paid out $20 million in claims on rain insurance to farmers in seven Midwestern states. It also paid $11 million to farmers who applied for the insurance but received no coverage.

title: Uganda Airliner Crash In Italy Leaves 31 Dead
description: A Uganda Airlines passenger jet crashed near Leonardo da Vinci Airport outside Rome early today, killing 31 of the 52 people aboard, police officials said.

title: On California's North Coast, Oil Is the Only Issue
description: On the last day of voter registration here, Rachel Binah signed up two out-of-town visitors: a television anchor who was in town for a feature on opposition to offshore oil drilling and a guest in the bed-and-breakfast inn that she owns on a bluff overlooking the Pacific.

title: Federal Suit Accuses Burger King Of Discrimination Against Blacks
description: The Burger King Corporation was accused in a lawsuit today of relegating black owners of its fast-food franchises to unprofitable locations in poor, urban neighborhoods and reserving more profitable outlets for whites.

title: Manville Net Rises by 10%
description: The Manville Corporation yesterday reported a record third-quarter net income of $53.5 million, or $1.96 a share, up by 10 percent from the corresponding period last year, when the Denver-based company had a profit of $48.6 million, or $1.76 a share.

title: Gregory Henderson; Korea Expert Was 66
description: Gregory Henderson, a former Foreign Service Officer and a specialist on Korea, died at Lawrence Memorial Hospital in Medford, Mass., on Sunday as a result of injuries suffered in a fall. He was 66 years old and lived in Medford.

title: Topics of The Times; Andrew Cuomo's Example
description: For nearly three years, Andrew Cuomo, the son of New York's Governor, has been the driving force behind Help, an innovative nonprofit enterprise that provides decent transitional housing for the homeless. Yesterday the younger Mr. Cuomo set a worthy example: He announced he was giving up his lucrative legal practice to work for the homeless organization full time.

title: Chemistry of Sexual Desire Yields Its Elusive Secrets
description: The sex hormone testosterone is a genuine aphrodisiac, with higher levels stimulating sexual desire in men and perhaps in women as well, recent research has shown. But the level of testosterone coursing through a person's body has little direct impact on sexual performance, according to the studies, which have discovered a sharp distinction between the chemistry of desire and that of the sexual act itself.

title: New Certificate May Ease Criticism of Death Data
description: IN an ironic twist, probably no document has as much impact on the health of a population as does the death certificate. Data collected from the certificates have become the most widely used statistical tools to monitor serious diseases. Thus the documents play an integral role in helping shape health policy.

title: Pro Football Notebook; Elway Is Added to Toll of Quarterbacks
description: When John Elway lay on the Mile High Stadium grass on Sunday clutching his right knee while his right ankle also throbbed with pain, Coach Dan Reeves realized that the Broncos, too, had been bitten by the nagging bug that has plagued the National Football League this season.

title: Equimark Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Officials Plan Meeting on Foster-Care Issue
description: Aides to the City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, and Deputy Mayor Stanley Brezenoff will meet at City Hall today, following an incident yesterday in which investigators for the Comptroller were denied access to a city center in the South Bronx where foster children are supposed to be cared for.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Utah's Intermountain Power Agency yesterday offered approximately $500 million of power supply revenue refunding bonds through a syndicate led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Abitibi-Price Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: EAST GERMAN SEES JEWISH SPOKESMAN
description: The East German leader, Erich Honecker, met today with the president of the World Jewish Congress, Edgar M. Bronfman, to discuss the possibility of East German reparations to Jewish victims of Nazism.

title: Chase Manhattan Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The latest third quarter earnings included an after-tax gain of about $103 million from modification of its pension plan and the purchase of annuity contracts substantially in settlement of its pension plan obligation. The company said the latest quarter reflected a decline in net interest income due in part to placing about $538 million of credit on extension to borrowers in Argentina into nonaccrual status. This action reduced income for the quarter and 9 months by $18 million. The year-ago third quarter included an $88 million after-tax pension plan settlement gain, utilization of about $50 million in federal income tax benefits and a network restructuring charge of $26 million after taxes. The latest 9 months also included $69 million in after-tax income resulting from the sale by Chase's equity capital subsidiary, Chase Manhattan Investment Holdings Inc., of its equity interest in Cain Chemical Inc. The latest 9 months also included a $61 million after-tax gain from the sale of Interactive Data Corp., a $59 million after-tax gain from the sale of a Paris branch office building, $155 million in income tax credits and the previously mentioned $103 million after-tax gain on a pension plan modification. The year-ago 9 months included a $1.6 billion addition to the reserve for possible credit losses related to lesser developed countries, $150 million in tax credits, an $88 million after-tax pension plan settlement gain, a $9 million after-tax gain from the sales of a Dutch factoring subsidiary and the minority interest of a Belgian affiliate, and a $26 million after-tax special network restructuring charge.

title: Review/Television; Roseanne Smirks Through the Trials of Life
description: Turning to his passengers on a Manhattan bus the other day, the driver asked if anybody wanted the 23d Street crosstown. ''Why?'' said a smirking enormous woman sitting opposite me, ''Ya selling one?'' Having just watched the pilot for ''Roseanne'' - which can be seen at 8:30 tonight on ABC - I was freshly familiar with the type.

title: Florida Progress Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenue for the year-ago period have been restated to include certain previously unconsolidated operations.

title: Knoll International Inc. Picks a Top Executive
description: Alfred S. Crimmins, former chief executive of the Collins & Aikman Corporation, the big textile maker, has been named president and chief operating officer of Knoll International Holdings Inc., a privately held company that has enterprises ranging from commercial furniture to do-it-yourself tile stores to the venerable ''21'' Club restaurant in New York.

title: Unisys Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lotus Development Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Yugoslav Party Opens Pivotal Session
description: The Communist Party Central Committee today opened a meeting that had been billed as crucial to solving Yugoslavia's urgent economic, ethnic and political problems. But it failed to produce any concrete initiatives to deal with those problems.

title: South Africans Try to End Segregated Rugby
description: In open defiance of the Pretoria Government, white rugby officials have reached an agreement with black guerrilla leaders and black sports administrators to desegregate rugby, the national sport of Afrikaners.

title: Modular Clothes: Count the Ways
description: In a time of escalating clothing costs and fashion ennui, ''modular dressing'' is catching on across the nation. Sold in department and specialty stores by clerks trained as stylists, collections like those from Singles, Multiples and Units promise freedom from the ironing board as well as from the dictates of fashion.

title: John Ball Dies at 77; A Critic and Novelist Know for Mysteries
description: John Ball, a music critic turned mystery writer, died of colon cancer Saturday in Encino (Calif.) Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: Jordan's West Bank Move Upsetting Daily Life
description: King Hussein's decision in July to give up all ties to the Israeli-occupied West Bank of the Jordan River in favor of the Palestinians is having real consequences on the lives of the 2.8 million people of Jordan, about 40 percent of whom consider themselves Palestinians.

title: Accounts
description: * CBS to Beber Silverstein & Partners, Miami, for a TV station, WCIX, Channel 6, in Miami, that it proposes to own and operate, pending F.C.C. approval.

title: Bush Heads for New York City
description: Switching his schedule in an effort to win a state he had written off, George Bush will visit a Roman Catholic school in Queens. Page B6.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; It's Raining Money
description: Lawmakers representing urban areas have found the Reagan Administration a hard sell when it comes to approving money for mass transit programs. But they are gleeful at the moment over an unexpected and absolutely unintended windfall in the 1989 transportation spending bill President Reagan signed on Sept. 30.

title: Islanders Outlast Canucks
description: It was a case of vintage performances by both teams at Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: Reading Between the Lines
description: THE moral to the Mickey Hatcher story is: Never go a day without checking out a newspaper or two. The ink might come off on your hands, but you never know what information might stick to you as well.

title: Late Rally Pushes Dow to Post-Crash High
description: A rally late in the afternoon yesterday pushed the Dow Jones industrial average to its highest point since the market crashed a year ago today.

title: Criminal Inquiry On Drexel
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has been notified in writing by prosecutors in the United States Attorney's office that it is under investigation for a broad range of possible criminal violations including racketeering, people who have seen the letter said yesterday.

title: Down Byways in Search of Man Ray
description: Man Ray American Artist By Neil Baldwin 449 pages. Clarkson N. Potter. $25.

title: American Cyanamid Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $11.6 million for both the quarter and 9 months. Year-ago 9-month net from continuing operations includes a gain of about 13 cents a share from the sale of the Jacqueline Cochran Fine Fragrance and Skin Care business.

title: Indian Jet Carrying 135 Crashes; Some Aboard Are Said to Survive
description: An Air-India jetliner with 135 people on board crashed and exploded today in central India, the airline said.

title: White House Is Pressed on Nuclear Plant Safety
description: The White House faced growing pressure today over safety and health problems in the nation's nuclear weapon industry. The chairmen of five Congressional committees, and the Governor of Ohio, urged the Reagan Administration to resolve the safety issues before reopening two key weapon plants.

title: Olin Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Head of Philip Morris Talks Strategy
description: Hamish Maxwell, chief executive of the Philip Morris Companies, is known as an unassuming man who shuns publicity.

title: Court Orders New York State to Speed Prisoner Transfers
description: New York's highest court ordered the state prison system yesterday to take custody of prisoners within 10 days after their sentencing, a decision which the State Corrections Commissioner said will have ''massive implications'' for a system already stretched beyond capacity.

title: Boxing Notebook; Patterson Guides Protege
description: Tracy Harris Patterson will be making his Felt Forum debut on Oct. 27, and when he climbs into the ring, a familiar figure, Floyd Patterson, the former heavyweight champion, will be working his corner.

title: A U.S. PROP FOR MEXICO;
description: For the second time in six years, the United States has initiated a multibillion-dollar rescue for debt-ridden Mexico. But this time, Washington is also propping up a political system that many here believe is itself foundering.

title: Gym Star Retires
description: The University of Oklahoma gymnast Kelly Garrison-Steves, a two-time N.C.A.A. champion and a member of the United States Olympic team, announced her retirement from the sport yesterday. Garrison-Steves, 21 years old, who has been in the sport for 14 years, said: ''I feel it's time to relax. I have achieved all the goals I've set for myself.'' Garrison-Steves has perfected two moves, known as the Garrison roll and the Garrison mount.(AP)

title: Richard L. Frey, Leading Figure In Contract Bridge, Is Dead at 83
description: Richard Lincoln Frey, one of the great figures in contract bridge, died of cancer Monday night at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: America's Vogue for Things Russian
description: IT was a ball that would have made the Czar proud. Gathered recently in the Phipps mansion in Old Westbury, L.I., 658 guests, including a few descendants of Russian nobility, donned their finest heirlooms to celebrate the splendor of old St. Petersburg.

title: Black Colleges Turn To Marketing Methods
description: Faced with increasing competition from larger and better known colleges for a shrinking number of black college-bound students, the nation's black colleges and universities have discovered that how they market themselves is as vital as the size of their libraries or the prowess of their athletic teams.

title: A Cake Wizard Brings Out a Book of Magic
description: RARELY does a book on baking attract widespread attention in the food world. Rose Levy Beranbaum's ''Cake Bible'' is different. Even before its official publication date, Sept. 20, bakers and nonbakers alike were telling each other that it was one of the very few books that, like Paula Peck's ''Art of Fine Baking'' and Flo Braker's ''Simple Art of Perfect Baking,'' would serve as textbook and inspiration for a generation of dessert makers. Nearly 100,000 copies of ''The Cake Bible'' have already been printed, and the publisher is shipping 2,000 copies a week to bookstores.

title: KEY RATES
Warsaw Delays Talks With the Opposition
description: The Government said today that talks with the opposition have been delayed until after Oct. 24, and it urged its partners in the dialogue to disavow ''extreme elements'' before the talks begin.

title: WINE TALK
description: SOME years ago Baron Elie de Rothschild, then managing partner of Chateau Lafite-Rothschild, was given a very old Lafite to taste. ''Well,'' he said, after a pause, ''it's wine.''

title: Familiar Pattern as Jets Falter
description: For the often-traumatized Jets fans and the team's beleaguered coach, it seems to be happening again: the quick start, the slow but sure fade, the sudden and growing injury list.

title: Plans for Single UNIX Standard Set Back
description: Efforts to unite the computer industry behind a single standard version of the UNIX operating system appeared stymied today when 18 computer companies announced that they would form an alliance supporting American Telephone and Telegraph's UNIX System V, Release 4.0 as the basis for the next generation of software. The alliance, known as the Archer Group, includes A.T.&T., Sun Microsystems Inc., Unisys, Amdahl and NCR.

title: Cigars and Pipe Tobacco To Get Warning Labels
description: Most cigars sold in the United States, and possibly some pipe and loose cigarette tobacco, will soon carry cancer warning labels as a result of an agreement reached today by manufacturers to settle a lawsuit filed by the California Attorney General.

title: Moscow Calls for Naval Cuts
description: At the United Nations, a senior Soviet official stressed the need for reductions in naval strength, where NATO forces have an edge. Page A12.

title: 7 Officers Killed On Duty in '88
description: Feb. 27 - Officer Edward Byrne, 22 years old, a rookie, was shot and killed execution-style while he was guarding the home of a witness in a drug case in South Jamaica, Queens. Four suspects are awaiting trial in the case.

title: From the Very Busy Sendak, A Book of a Rare Grimm Tale
description: ''When you hit 60,'' says Maurice Sendak, ''you get so maniacal. You want to do everything, in case you don't hit 61.''

title: Metro Datelines; Goldin Staff Allowed Into Welfare Centers
description: The Koch administration agreed yesterday to give investigators for Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin access to child-welfare centers, a day after Mr. Goldin's aides had been barred from a Bronx center by workers who cited confidentiality rules.

title: BRIDGE
description: Qualifying play in the World Team Olympiad ended here this afternoon, setting up quarter-final playoffs beginning Wednesday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Government was lying to us, and they lied and lied. It's just a terrible thing they've done.'' - Doris Clawson, who lives next to the Fernald nuclear plant in Ohio. [ A1:4. ]

title: A JEWISH OFFICIAL LAUDS BERLIN TALK
description: Edgar M. Bronfman, the president of the World Jewish Congress, said today that his meetings with East German leaders had left him ''totally satisfied'' with East Germany's attitude toward the mass killing of Jews under the Nazis and its readiness to pay at least symbolic compensation.

title: Jersey Tells Town to Plan Housing Despite Lack of Open Land
description: A state agency has told this densely developed suburb that it cannot be excused from an obligation to provide low- and moderate-income housing simply because it has no vacant land.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Living Section last Wednesday with an article about vegetables in unusual colors identified a vegetable incorrectly.

title: THORNBURGH BACKS WIDER DEATH RULE
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh says he would support legislative efforts to expand the use of the death penalty for Federal crimes, including the assassination of senior Government officials.

title: Molson Picks Outsider To Fill Top Positions
description: The Molson Companies, Canada's second-largest brewing operation after John Labatt Ltd., went outside the industry yesterday to name a new president and chief executive.

title: 2 Wall St. Brokerages Subpoenaed in Ellis Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission recently subpoenaed at least two Wall Street brokerage firms for information in one of the longest and largest insider trading investigations in history.

title: India Bans a Book For Its Own Good
description: Dear Rajiv Gandhi:

title: How It Happened; One Pitch Spoils Howell Comeback
description: Between the playoff game from which Jay Howell was ejected for having pine tar on his glove and his appearance in the ninth inning of the third game of the World Series tonight, the Los Angeles Dodgers' relief corps allowed only two runs in 27Y innings.

title: American Electric Power Co reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-Includes a reduction in net earnings and share earnings of $68,863,000 and 36 cents a share, respectively, due to Columbus Southern Power Company's write-off, after taxes and related adjustments, of a second portion of its investment in the Zimmer Plant.

title: Dukakis Gets A Needed Boost For Campaign
description: Michael S. Dukakis was just a few minutes into his speech when it happened, a sudden outbreak of what the Democratic Presidential campaign so badly needs these days: enthusiasm.

title: Lackluster Defense Worries the Devils
description: The Devils have lost their last two games by not playing like the Devils of last spring and they have reasons to be concerned.

title: Paris Raises Rates to Bolster Franc
description: The Bank of France today raised its interest rates to help bolster the franc after the French currency fell in recent days in response to a wave of strikes and a widening trade deficit.

title: American Home Products Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Norwest Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included a $204 million provision for loans to less developed countries. The latest third quarter included tax benefits of $10.2 million related to the 1987 special provision for international credits, which were offset by charges related to the relocation to new corporate headquarters, and investment security losses. The year-ago periods were restated for adoption of FAS 96.

title: Real Estate; L.I. County's Office Space: Old vs. New
description: DURING the 1960's and 1970's most builders of speculative office space in Nassau County found no shortage of tenants. Back then, new construction lagged behind demand as the Long Island economy rapidly moved from manufacturing toward office-based services.

title: U.S. Savings Bonds for College: Easy, Sound
description: To the Editor:

title: Manufacturers Hanover Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included for the quarter an after- tax gain of $98 million from the sale of a London office building, $9.9 million, after taxes, from the sale of previously unissued stock in Banco Manufacturers Hanover (Portugal) S.A., and $9.4 million, after taxes, from the sale of the corporation's interest in Eastern States, a bank credit card processor; the 9 months included net gains of $159.5 million from the sale of Manufacturers Hanover Consumer Services Inc., $16.2 million from the sale of two branch buildings, and $12 million from the sale of Manufacturers Hanover Investment Corp. c-Included a gain of $29.4 million, after taxes, realized by recognizing a portion of the excess value in the corporation's pension fund. d-Net loss and reflected the decision to increase the reserve for possible credit losses by $1.7 billion, and included a net gain of $12.8 million from the sale of two residences in Japan. The provision for credit losses for the latest 9 months was $388.6 million, compared with $2,097,900,000 for year- ago period. The 1988 net included the recognition of an extraordinary tax benefit of $17.6 million in the third quarter and $200.4 million for the 9 months, relating to the $1.7 billion addition to the reserve in the second quarter of 1987. In 1987, the results included the recognition of a tax benefit of $35.1 million in the third quarter and $273.8 million for the 9 months.

title: 'Soft Landing' for New York City
description: Dotty Feinberg finally bought a new fur coat yesterday. A year ago, when the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 508 points in a single day, she put off the purchase.

title: Mr. Dukakis's Modest Housing Plan
description: Governor Dukakis chose Levittown, L.I., to announce a new housing plan, and the site evoked memories of successful housing policies that turned hundreds of thousands of Americans into homeowners. Unfortunately, Mr. Dukakis can't promise nearly that much.

title: A New York Race Moves to the South
description: Although the feud between Mayor Koch of New York and Mr. Jackson is supposedly history, the Mayor could barely contain his annoyance with Mr. Jackson here on Monday while campaigning for Mr. Dukakis. Underscoring it all seems to be Mr. Koch's concern that Mr. Jackson will campaign to unseat the Mayor next year.

title: Jockeys Strike at Aqueduct Over Pay; Substitutes Are Hired
description: The 26 jockeys who had been named to ride at Aqueduct today plan instead to picket the track while at least 18 replacement jockeys ride in the nine opening-day races.

title: Citicorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $139 million reflecting a ''reserve related'' tax benefit and $163 million net gain from recognition of pension fund over-funding. c-Net loss The latest third quarter's net included an after-tax gain of $55 million from the sale of part of Citicorp's domestic investment management business and an after-tax reduction in earnings of $22 million resulting from the decision to put $566 million of the company's $1.4 billion exposure to Argentina on a cash basis--reflecting the non-payment of interest for 90 days or more on these loans. The provision for possible credit losses for the latest periods totaled $302 million for the quarter and $906 million for the 9 months, compared with $320 million and $4,197,000,000 for the same year-ago periods, respectively. The ''normalized'' figures for the year-ago periods were: Quarter revenue, $2.9 billion; net income, $226 million, and per share earnings, 71 cents; 9-month revenue, $8.5 billion; net income, $778 million, and per share earnings, $2.51. The year-ago normalized figures excluded the impact of the $3 billion addition to the reserve for possible credit losses, recognized tax benefits, and other related transactions. The year-ago periods have been restated to reflect the adoption of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 91.

title: Tribune Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $8.8 million and $9.7 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, for employee severance at the New York Daily News.

title: California Court Backs Suit of Moon's Church
description: Two former members of the Unification Church can sue it on charges of deception and brainwashing because freedom of religion does not protect fraudulent recruiting, the State Supreme Court has ruled.

title: Warner Communications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax net gain on investments of $33,200,000, or 21 cents a share, compared with 39,600,000, or 28 cents a share, in 1987.

title: Union Picks Up Check for Green's Luncheon
description: New York City Schools Chancellor Richard R. Green was unable to get enough corporate donors to pay for a luncheon he sponsored last month to mark the beginning of the school year, officials involved say.

title: Of Sudan's Woes, War Is the Worst
description: In a country that has been besieged this year by plagues of almost biblical proportions - famine, flood, drought and locusts - a protracted civil war is proving the most debilitating of all.

title: Corrections
description: A map in some copies on Monday with an article about Jonas Savimbi, the Angolan guerrilla leader, misplaced the town of Jamba, where his rebels have their headquarters. Angola has two towns named Jamba; the rebel headquarters are about 50 miles north of the Angolan-Namibian border and 50 miles west of the Angolan-Zambian border.

title: Waiting for the Japanese
description: After five weeks of vacation it was dismaying to get home and find the election was still going on. I'd gone away hoping they might come to their senses, call the thing off for a year or 18 months, then start all over again with some new candidates.

title: Washington Talk: The Senate; As Adjournment Nears, Cutting a Judicial Deal
description: As the 100th Congress nears adjournment, one of the more anxious observers is James R. McGregor, a state trial court judge in Pittsburgh. He has been nominated as a Federal district judge by President Reagan, and has the strong backing of Senator Arlen Specter, a Republican from his home state.

title: 50 Are Dead or Missing In Colombian Flooding
description: Officials said today that 50 people were dead or missing in flooding in northern Colombia caused by a powerful hurricane.

title: Ford Estate Proposal Backed
description: A retired judge appointed to look after the financial interests of minor and unborn heirs to Henry Ford 2d's $350 million estate supports a proposed settlement to a lawsuit blocking investment of the family trust. The retired judge, Robert Hewitt, told Judge Vaughn Rudnick of Palm Beach County Circuit Court that the proposal protects the financial interests of minor heirs. The specifics are unknown, but the plan could settle a dispute between Mr. Ford's widow, Kathleen, and Edsel Ford 2d, Henry Ford 2d's son by a previous marriage, over how the trust should be invested and who should manage it.

title: Philip Krumm, 82, A Former President Of Olympic Group
description: Philip O. Krumm, a former president of the United States Olympic Committee, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Divide. He was 82 years old.

title: G.E. Engine Order
description: The General Electric Company landed a $150 million order from All Nippon Airways of Japan to provide G.E. engines for six Boeing 747-400 jet planes. Officials at G.E.'s jet engine plant in this Cincinnati suburb said the order was for the company's CF6-80C2 engine. They said it is the best-selling engine worldwide for the 747-700 wide-body jets. Three jets will be delivered to All Nippon in both 1990 and 1991.

title: Albert J. Rosen, Executive, 86
description: Albert J. Rosen, a retired shirt manufacturer, died of heart failure Monday at his home in Hewlett Bay Park, L.I. He was 86 years old.

title: IC Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $32.5 million for the quarter and $45.3 million for the 9 months; the 9 months also included a gain of $23.7 million from a change in accounting. c-After income from discontinued operations of $16.2 million for the quarter and $52.9 million for the 9 months.

title: Review/Television; Comedies From Sports And Canada
description: No doubt about it. Home Box Office is making the most of comedy, encompassing everything from straightforward stand-up routines to elaborate sketches. Tonight, HBO cable-channel subscribers can jump from a pack of troglodytic football players, unabashedly vulgar and uproarious, to five delightfully inventive young men from Toronto who, in the Monty Python tradition, spend a good deal of their comedy time in drag. In between the two shows, incidentally, at 11 P.M., can be found the Robert Townsend film ''Hollywood Shuffle.''

title: Congress Approves Making V.A. a Cabinet Department
description: Congress completed action tonight on legislation that will transform the Veterans Administration into the 14th Cabinet department of the Federal Government, giving the nation's millions of veterans a voice in policy making at the White House.

title: Trading Halts to Begin
description: A plan to use coordinated market halts, or circuit breakers, will be implemented by the major American stock and commodity exchanges at the end of business today.

title: Review/Pop; A Subdued Elton John Gives Songs Center Stage
description: Elton John the flashy showman was replaced by Elton John the seasoned singer, tunesmith and keyboardist when he opened five sold-out nights at Madison Square Garden on Monday.

title: San Pablo Journal; New Indoor War Game Makes Splash in the Fog
description: Laird Cummings did not see the man coming at him through the smoky haze in the dimly lit warehouse here. He did not see the gun pointed at him. But he heard the shot that nailed him squarely in the back. ''I'm hit, I'm hit,'' he shouted. Then lowering his own custom 300-shot ''sniper'' pistol, Mr. Cummings shook his head and wiped a splatter of yellow paint off his black flak jacket. ''I'm getting my tail kicked in there,'' he said.

title: U.S.-Soviet Trade Concern
description: An American company and a Soviet agriculture board today said they had formed a United States-based concern that would trade agricultural goods between the Soviet Union and North America. The new company, called

title: Fedders Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $887,000 for the quarter and $4,403,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $1,105,000 and $4,189,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Restaurant Account Goes to Bayer Bess
description: Grisanti Inc. has called on Bayer Bess Vanderwarker, Chicago, to promote its chain of Italian and Mexican restaurants. The budget is in the area of $3 million.

title: Senate Passes a Lobbying Bill
description: The Senate approved a compromise bill today that would bolster lobbying restrictions against former Federal officials and for the first time would apply to former members of Congress.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority offered $400 million worth of bonds yesterday.

title: Fans Unruly at Jets Game
description: There were many incidents of bottle-throwing, drunken behavior, and fighting in the crowd of 70,218 at the Jets' game Monday at Giants Stadium. While conceding that there were even more incidents than normal for a Monday night game, the Jets' president, Steve Gutman, said he was not sure what, if any, measures he was prepared to recommend to curtail them.

title: Environment Will Expire if We Don't Act Now; Politics Is Missing
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethyl Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 9 months both include a gain of 7 cents a share from the settlement of a lawsuit and gains realized by First Colony Life Insurance Co. of 2 cents a share for the quarter and 7 cents a share for the 9 months. Year-ago quarter and 9 months includes gains from First Colony Life Insurance Co. of 3 cents a share and 10 cents a share, respectively.

title: Morgan Stanley Profit Off
description: The Morgan Stanley Group's profits fell 28 percent in the third quarter, the company said yesterday, pointing to a falloff in underwriting and commission income that was only partly offset by strong mergers and acquisition activity.

title: Hartville, Ohio
description: UNTIL he started the 1880 Buffalo Ranch eight years ago, William Tocci had never even tasted buffalo meat. But then neither had anyone else in this northern Ohio town of 1,800. It seems, however, that everyone was waiting to try it. Before long, Mr. Tocci, a former truck driver, was selling fresh cuts from his freezer and promoting his product in restaurants.

title: Home Loan Bank Offering
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board priced a $4.235 billion note offering in five separate issues yesterday.

title: Analysts Suggest Targets in Food
description: THE startling bid Monday of $90 for each share of Kraft Inc. stock sent the stock of other food companies soaring yesterday. Led by Kraft, which shot up $28.125, to $88.25, Gerber Products rose $4.375, to $57.75; CPC International $2.25, to $55.50, and General Mills $2.125, to $54.50. Borden Inc and Quaker Oats also gained.

title: Irving Bank Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The latest third quarter results were affected adversely by the placing of $72 million in Argentine term loans on non-accrual status, reducing net income by $2.8 million. The special and nonrecurring items reflected in net income for the latest quarter included the recognition of $3.4 million in tax benefits related to the special LDC provisions for credit losses taken in 1987. This benefit was more than offset by $16.5 million ($9.3 million on an after-tax basis) in takeover defense expenses. The third quarter results for 1987 included an $86.7 million pre-tax gain ($42.4 million after taxes) on the settlement of certain pension plan obligations, a $17.3 million pre-tax gain ($9.5 million after taxes) on the sale of an equity security, and $19.7 million in tax benefits related to the special LDC provision for credit losses taken in the second quarter of that year. The special and non-recurring items reflected in net for the latest 9 months included a pre-tax gain of $139.7 million on the sale of the corporation's 39 percent interest in Banca Della Svizzera Italiana, which enabled the corporation to recognize an after-tax gain of $119.9 million. In addition, the corporation recognized a further $24.8 million in tax benefits related to the 1987 special LDC provisions. Takeover defense expenses of $30 million ($17 million after taxes) partially offset these gains. Special and nonrecurring items reflected in earnings for the year-ago 9 months were the $225 million ($168.2 million after taxes) special provision for credit losses related to LDC debt taken during the second quarter of that year, as well as the items previously noted for the third quarter of 1987.

title: U.S. Gets Taste of Managua Embargo
description: Shrimp and lobster fleets from this Caribbean port have been helping Nicaragua evade the economic embargo imposed by the United States.

title: Trisha Brown Honored
description: Trisha Brown was inducted into the Order of Arts and Letters by the French Government yesterday in a ceremony at the Office of Cultural Services for the French Consulate in New York. Ms. Brown, a noted post-modernist choreographer who is based in New York, has frequently performed with her company in France. Most recently, she was jointly commissioned by the festivals at Aix-en-Provence and Montpellier to create new work that received its premiere this summer and will be performed during the company's season at City Center from March 14 through 19.

title: Profits Down For Citicorp, 3 Other Banks
description: Major banks reported conflicting results yesterday.

title: McAllen, Tex.
description: THE first major harvest of a redder breed of grapefruit began last week in the Rio Grande Valley orchards that cluster here. This means that the Rio Red, a sweet and ruddier variety, will be available for the first time in markets in many parts of the United States.

title: Hearing Set in North Case
description: The judge in the Iran-contra case today ordered a hearing on Oliver L. North's assertion that the National Security Council, where he worked, was exempt from a Congressional ban on helping arm the Nicaraguan rebels. The hearing, scheduled for Nov. 3 by Judge Gerhard A. Gesell of Federal District Court, will focus on defense assertions that Mr. North cannot be prosecuted for conspiring with three co-defendants to illegally divert proceeds from the sale of United States arms to Iran to the contras.

title: Emulex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
Merck & Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the share earnings reflected a 3-for-1 stock split effective in May 1988.

title: Bush, in a Change, Sets Queens Campaign Stop
description: Sensing an opportunity to win a state he had written off, Vice President Bush has picked a Roman Catholic high school in a blue-collar, conservative Democratic area of Queens for his first campaign appearance in New York City tomorrow.

title: Bausch & Lomb Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: The company said revenue comparisons for the latest quarter and 9 months exclude 1987 sales for the microscope and opthalmic instrument product lines which were divested in December 1987.

title: Afghan Leadership Reported at Odds
description: A factional power struggle appears to have broken out in Afghanistan's Communist leadership, delaying a meeting of the ruling party and complicating Soviet efforts to resume a troop withdrawal, Western diplomats and Afghan rebels here say.

title: Banc One Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago 9 months per share earnings restated to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in the first quarter. The company said its year-ago 9 months earnings included a 33 cents a share charge reflecting the establishment of special reserves in the 1987 second quarter, principally for problem loans to Third World countries.

title: Queen Elizabeth in Madrid
description: Queen Elizabeth II, on the first state visit to Spain by a British sovereign, visited Parliament today and paid tribute to Spain's peaceful transition to democracy after the death of Franco in 1975. ''The democratic Parliament before me, and the manner in which it was achieved, will stand out as one of the brightest pages in your nation's long and proud history,'' she said in a speech that drew enthusiastic applause from legislators.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Angela Abelow has been named senior vice president at Ketchum Advertising, New York.

title: A Town Celebrates the Lowly Lima Bean
description: IN the seashore resort of Cape May, N.J., which is surrounded by the Atlantic Ocean and Delaware Bay, mid-October is synonymous with Victorian Week tours of grand homes, tulip-bulb planting, migrating birds and the last days to sit on porches in still-warm but waning sunlight. Separated from Cape May by Wilbraham Park is West Cape May, landlocked and noted for its lima-bean farms.

title: The Pop Life
description: Coping With a Bad Year

title: Review/Theater; Next Wave's Formula For Nurturing of Artists
description: ''Arm in arm with the artists in the trenches,'' is how Joseph Melillo, the producer of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival, describes the academy's role in producing more of the work that occupies its stages. This effort will be on display during the nine-week festival of experimental dance, performance and music that opens its sixth season tonight with ''The Warrior Ant,'' the Lee Breuer-Bob Telson spectacle combining Japanese puppetry, Latin American music and West African mythology.

title: OPEC's Present Output
description: Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, the oil minister of the United Arab Emirates, said in remarks published today by the Saudi newspaper Asharq al Awsat that OPEC was now producing 21 million to 22 million barrels of oil a day.

title: Testing 'Smart' Roads To Avoid Traffic Jams
description: Americans are now spending more than 1.6 billion hours a year waiting in traffic jams, a number that the Federal Highway Administration expects to grow to 8.1 billion hours by the year 2005. Most traffic experts think it is unlikely that enough new highways can be built to alleviate the problem.

title: Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MCI Communications' Net Increases Nearly Sixfold
description: Continuing a string of sharp earnings gains, the MCI Communications Corporation said yesterday that its net income in the third quarter of this year rose almost sixfold on a 40.8 percent increase in revenues, compared with the corresponding period last year.

title: Prices of U.S. Securities Inch Up
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes inched a bit higher yesterday in another session of thin, listless trading.

title: Crossland Savings FSB reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest 9-month per share earnings reflected quarterly dividend payments on Crossland's 2.5 million shares of $12.75 cumulative preferred stock, series B. Year-ago per share earnings reflected dividends paid in the third quarter only, as the series B preferred was issued in August 1987.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M.

title: PENTAGON IS URGED TO BE MORE ACTIVE IN ECONOMIC POLICY
description: An independent advisory panel has urged the Secretary of Defense to take a more assertive role in setting economic policy to head off ''an increasing loss of technological leadership to both our allies and adversaries.''

title: OUSTER OF ISRAEL FAILS AGAIN AT U.N.
description: Ninety-five countries, 15 more than last year, voted today to block an Arab-sponsored measure that would have expelled Israel from the United Nations General Assembly.

title: Review/Music; An East-West Message
description: Kazuko Inoue, a pianist, is interested not only in new music but also in a social agenda that includes pointing up connections between East and West and emphasizing the importance of surmounting the terrors of the nuclear age. Thus the program she and her Inoue Chamber Ensemble played at Weill Recital Hall on Monday evening was devoted mostly to new works by American, Chinese and South Korean composers.

title: Choose:
description: Land-based nuclear missiles are a critical part of America's deterrent, but neither Presidential candidate has presented a plausible plan for keeping them that way. The present force of Minuteman missiles was deployed more than 15 years ago and needs upgrading. Michael Dukakis says he favors modernization, yet he opposes both available new missiles, the Midgetman and the MX. As for George Bush, his Administration came into office screaming for new missiles to close the famous window of vulnerability, and then spent eight years doing almost nothing.

title: Tax Sleight of Hand Made 'Reform' Possible Teaneck, N.J., Oct. 9, 1988  The writer, a tax lawyer, is professor of taxation at Fairleigh Dickinson U.
description: To the Editor:

title: Tough Wine Course Has New Students
description: THE English wine trade's equivalent of the Ph.D. is coming to the United States.

title: Cuomo Takes to the Road for Dukakis, Stressing the Need for Vision
description: Mario Cuomo, who last year refused to rule out a Presidential bid of his own and early this year declined to endorse a candidate in the Presidential primary, has shed his reluctance recently and has spent the last few weeks campaigning vigorously for Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts.

title: John F. Finn Jr., Lawyer, 83
description: John F. Finn Jr., a retired lawyer and former judge, died of leukemia Monday at Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 83 years old and lived in Sea Cliff, L.I.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avon Products Inc., a worldwide beauty company, promoted Paul B. Markovits, Stuart A. Ochiltree and Robert W. Pratt to executive vice presidents.

title: Roman Kozak, Writer About Rock, Dies at 40
description: Roman Kozak, a former rock editor at Billboard magazine and the author of a book about the New York rock club CBGB, died of cardiac arrest last Thursday in Las Vegas, Nev. He was 40 years old and lived in New York City.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Colt and Union to Hold Talks For First Time in 17 Months
description: Officials of the Colt Firearms Divison and the striking United Automobile Workers union are to meet Wednesday in their first bargaining session in almost 17 months.

title: Alabamian Admits Role in '63 Bombing of Church in Birmingham
description: A retired bus driver in Alabama has told investigators that he participated in one of the most infamous incidents of racial violence during the civil rights movement, the 1963 bombing of a Birmingham church that killed four black girls, Federal investigators said tonight.

title: Panel Chooses A Former Hotel As a Landmark
description: The former Knickerbocker Hotel, at Broadway and 42d Street, whose exuberant turn-of-the-century design still conjures the time of John Jacob Astor and Enrico Caruso and George M. Cohan, was made a New York City landmark yesterday.

title: Dep Corp reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split effective April 29. The company said year-ago sales included $4,052,000 related to divesting subsidiaries.

title: Coleman Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bust the Nuclear Pork Barrel
description: LEAD: Washington is moving toward a consensus on a dubious proposal to spend tens of billions of dollars building new facilities or repairing old ones to produce materials for nuclear weapons.

title: Commonwealth Edison Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Vote 'Yes' for Charter Revision
description: With the Supreme Court poised to rule next spring on the constitutionality of New York City's Board of Estimate, the city's Charter Revision Commission, led by Richard Ravitch, wisely deferred any change in the board's present structure. Instead, five less momentous but still important charter amendments will appear on the Nov. 8 ballot. All five, listed as Proposals 2 through 6, merit support. (Proposal 1 concerns the state's Transportation Bond Issue.)

title: Alcan Aluminium Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in U.S. dollars. Year-ago revenue figures are restated.

title: Diamond Shamrock R&M Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an $800,000 extraordinary charge for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss and after a $9,300,000 extraordinary charge for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Peru, in Disarray, Directs Its Fury at the President
description: With Peru in its worst economic crisis this century, the country's fragile democracy has been battered in recent weeks by rumors that President Alan Garcia had decided to resign and that the armed forces were planning to topple him.

title: Yugoslavia's President Says Crisis Harms the Country's Reputation
description: President Raif Dizdarevic warned the Communist Party's Central Committee today that the ''passion, vengefulness and aggressiveness'' that marks Yugoslavia's present politics was harming the country's position before the world.

title: ISRAELI COURT BARS PARTY OF KAHANE
description: Israel's highest court ruled today that the Kach party of Rabbi Meir Kahane is not eligible to run in the national elections on Nov. 1.

title: Frederic Ewen, 89, Ex-Professor of English
description: Dr. Frederic Ewen, an author, lecturer and former English professor at Brooklyn College, died of a heart attack yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Hearx, a hearing-care chain in West Palm Beach, Fla., to Barbara Gordon Associates, Lake Worth, Fla.

title: A French Economist Wins Nobel
description: Maurice Allais, a 77-year-old French economist, won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science today for his pioneering development of theories to better understand market behavior and the efficient use of resources.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Rosenfeld, Sirowitz
description: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz, Humphrey & Strauss has bought, for an undisclosed combination of cash and stocks, a $17 million Southwest shop called Patchen Brownfeld. The decade-old Phoenix agency, whose name will be changed to RSH&S/Patchen Brownfeld, will be bringing on board clients such as America West Airlines and Sun State Savings and Loan Association.

title: For the President, It's Back on the Trail
description: The Bush campaign hardly needs help, given the latest polls. But the Vice President is unloading his major weapon in the campaign Wednesday, the Gipper.

title: 2 Policemen Are Shot and Killed In Separate Manhattan Incidents
description: Two police officers - one an undercover officer negotiating a routine drug deal, the other in uniform and coming from the scene of a medical emergency - were shot and killed in upper Manhattan last night, the police said.

title: Southwestern Bell Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest third quarter net was increased by 5 cents a share by out-of- period adjustments, primarily related to other taxes, covering the years 1984 through 1987.

title: No Buyer for Big Ruby
description: A 48-carat ruby, the largest ever presented at auction, did not sell yesterday at Sotheby's. The auction house had estimated that the jewel, which is called the Mandalay Ruby and was being auctioned for an unidentified owner, would sell for $15 million. That would be a record for a jewel. ''I imagine we put a value on it that was just too high,'' said John D. Block, who heads Sotheby's jewelry sales.

title: Heroics in 9th Inning Again, This Time by McGwire
description: Two games had come and gone, but the Oakland Athletics were still waiting for someone to step forward, to give them the lift that Kirk Gibson had given the Los Angeles Dodgers in the opener of the 85th World Series last Saturday. Tonight, after 26 innings of drowsy offense from the A's, Mark McGwire finally did it.

title: Surgery for 2 Yanks
description: Two Yankee infielders underwent relatively minor surgery in the last five days. Willie Randolph, the second baseman, had an arthroscopic procedure to repair torn cartilage in his right knee on Monday at New York University Medical Center. Last Friday at the Medical Center, Mike Pagliarulo, the third baseman, had surgery to relocate the ulnar nerve in his right elbow. He is expected to undergo a four-week period of recovery and should be completely fit for spring training. While the Yankees were announcing Monday the hiring of six coaches to serve under incoming Manager Dallas Green and the reassignment of four coaches who had worked on the final staff of Lou Piniella, no mention was made of Chris Chambliss and Mike Ferraro. Those two coaches were not retained.

title: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 9 months figures include the results of Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of Memphis, Tenn., the Florida operations of Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of Miami, and all of the Maryland and a portion of the Delaware operations of Delaware Coca-Cola Bottling co. These operations were acquired on Jan. 29, 1988, and consolidated as of Jan. 1, 1988.

title: Payment Protest
description: Greg Norman of Australia, the world's No. 1-ranked golfer, defended appearance payments for players yesterday in the face of controversy over a proposed levy on Australian club golfers.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Miami Dolphins have agreed to contract terms with the kicker Tony Franklin, a nine-year veteran released by the New England Patriots during preseason. Franklin made a club record 32 of 41 field goals in 1986 but only 15 of 26 last year. ''I'm looking forward to playing in Miami,'' the barefooted kicker said. ''I always wanted to play here because of the great weather. . . . Roberto Duran of Panama, a former world lightweight and welterweight champion, was charged with a felony in Miami for threatening ''to beat up all American police officers,'' George Law, a police spokesman said yesterday. Duran became irate after the car in which he was riding was pulled over for a traffic violation, Law said, and the former boxer was charged with making threats against a police officer, a felony, and disorderly conduct. . . . Charles Thompson, who rushed for 123 yards and three touchdowns against Kansas State last Saturday, will start at quarterback against Colorado this week, Coach Barry Switzer of Oklahoma said. ''Jamelle's not well,'' Switzer said of Jamelle Holieway, who sprained an ankle against Texas two games ago, then reinjured the ankle against Kansas State.(AP)

title: INSIDE
description: 131 May Be Dead in Crash

title: SHIFT ON MEDICARE EXPECTED TO HURT HOSPITALS IN CITIES
description: The Department of Health and Human Services will begin a Medicare reimbursement policy on Nov. 1 that will hurt large metropolitan teaching hospitals that serve the inner-city poor.

title: Wells Fargo & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The year-ago third quarter earnings included a tax benefit from the second quarter 1987 special addition to the loss allowance made in connection with loans to developing countries. Wells Fargo said that excluding the tax benefit, the latest third quarter net per share would represent a 30 percent increase in earnings per share from year-ago period.

title: Demystifying the Elements Of Asian and Thai Cooking
description: TWO newly published books are musts, the first for those who are struggling to learn about Asian ingredients and have run into language barriers in the tiny shops where many of the more exotic ones can be found, and the second for those who wonder whether the Thai food in their local restaurants is authentic or Americanized. ''Bruce Cost's Asian Ingredients'' (Morrow, $22.95) and ''The Taste of Thailand'' by Vatcharin Bhumichitr (Atheneum, $29.95) will take the mystery out of Asian cooking.

title: The Word Wore Out
description: It isn't easy to grasp why ''liberal'' has become such a bad word in the United States. But the reasons seemed more evident when a group of Europeans gathered at Harvard with some Americans last weekend to look back over 20 years at ''May '68: The Vision and the Reality.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Anheuser-Busch Cos., St. Louis, withdrew a letter of intent under which it would have bought a malt plant in Pocatello, Idaho, from Penwest Ltd. of Bellevue, Wash.

title: Flexsteel Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Environment Will Expire if We Don't Act Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Apollo Computer Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Experts Say Treatments Affect Recall
description: Sukhreet Gabel's psychiatric treatments, mental illness and the stress she has been under, in part because of the Bess Myerson trial, could have distorted her recollection of events, experts say. But, they add, it is impossible to determine whether the factors affected the accuracy of her testimony against her mother and Ms. Myerson, or, if so, how.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: October 19, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Review/Theater; Private Vision of an Anxiety the Audience May Share
description: When an artist builds a wall between himself and his audience, there can be no doubt he is sending a strong message. But the message transmitted by Richard Foreman in ''What Did He See?'' at the Public Theater could hardly be more mixed. The wall is huge - it rises from floor to ceiling before the first row of spectators -yet, being made of plexiglass, it is transparent. Mr. Foreman, who has spent over 15 years pursuing the obsessions of what he calls the Ontological-Hysteric Theater, appears to be offering audiences a large window into his soul and, at the same time, shutting us out.

title: Occidental Is Told To Sell a Company
description: The Occidental Petroleum Company was ordered to sell Tenneco Polymers Inc., after an administrative law judge ruled that the 1986 acquisition of the company reduced competition in the production of materials needed to make plastics.

title: Difference of Opinion Among Dukakises
description: Something Mrs. Dukakis did not enjoy - and is still angry about -was the first question of last week's Presidential debate. Bernard Shaw, the anchor at the Cable News Network who was moderator of the event, asked Gov. Michael S. Dukakis if he would still oppose the death penalty if Mrs. Dukakis were raped and murdered. Mr. Dukakis, who upset some of his supporters by the emotionless manner in which he replied that he would not change his view, later said it was a fair question.

title: South Korean Chief, at U.N., Calls For World Talks and Unification
description: The President of South Korea, the only country over which the United Nations has formally gone to war, addressed the General Assembly for the first time today. He called for an international conference to end the division of the Korean peninsula.

title: Amalgam of Agony and Anger Downwind From Uranium Site
description: The farming, laboring, shopkeeping families around here seem just as conservative and just as patriotic as the small-town stereotype would have it. But the uranium processing plant down the road, and what the Federal Government has told them about its safety, has them sounding like something else entirely.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Penguins 4, Flyers 2: Mario Lemieux scored three times and set up a goal by Bob Errey as Pittsburgh beat the Flyers in Philadelphia last night, ending the Flyers' four-game season-opening winning streak. Lemieux's points raised his league-leading total to 19. He has had at least 1 point in each of Pittsburgh's five games and has 12 in the last two games. He completed his 14th career hat trick with a goal into an empty net with five seconds left in the game as the National Hockey League's last undefeated team was beaten.(AP) Red Wings 4, Blackhawks 3: Steve Yzerman scored his sixth goal of the season a split second before the overtime buzzer sounded last night, lifting Detroit to victory over Chicago. Yzerman picked up a puck from a scramble and lifted a shot over the rookie goaltender, Ed Belfour, as time expired. Chicago protested the goal, but it was allowed to stand.(AP) SOCCER L.I.U. 2, Columbia 1: Emmett Trinity and Carlos Agusto DaSilva scored first-half goals to lead Long Island University to victory over Columbia in men's competition yesterday at the L.I.U. Athletic Field in Brooklyn. The Blackbirds (10-4-1) played the last 47 minutes of the game a man short. Columbia (4-6) got its score on Chris Ziadie's free kick in the 57th minute.

title: Harassing Letters Upset Students at Dartmouth
description: A series of letters delivered last week to black, gay and female Darmouth College students demanding that they get off the campus has left students here angry and frightened.

title: Maurice Richter, Pathologist, 91
description: Maurice Richter, a former chairman of the pathology department at New York University Medical Center, died of bladder cancer Saturday at Friendship Village, a retirement center in Tempe, Ariz. He was 91 years old.

title: Byron Janis Recital
description: The pianist Byron Janis will perform an all-Chopin recital at 8 P.M. Nov. 29 at Alice Tully Hall. The program will consist of five nocturnes, three mazurkas, ''Valse Brillante'' in A flat and the Sonata No. 3 in B minor. Tickets are $25 and $17.50. Information: 874-6770.

title: Metro Datelines; Insurance Official Remains Suspended
description: The Joint Underwriting Association suspended its general manager yesterday for another nine days, this time without pay, after hearing allegations that he misused association cars and drove without insurance. He had been suspended with pay on Sept. 22 The general manager, Nelson D. Ealey, has held the post since the association's inception in mid-1983.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addendum
description: * People magazine will be increasing its rate base 1.7 percent, to 3 million from 2.95 million, and raising ad rates 7.8 percent, with the Jan, 9, 1989, issue.

title: Loral Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Survey Shows Senate Battle Is a Dead Heat
description: Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman is running even with the incumbent, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., in the Senate race in Connecticut after trailing by a large margin a month ago, according to a statewide poll released yesterday by the University of Connecticut's Institute for Social Inquiry and published in The Hartford Courant.

title: Champion Spark Plug Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2.9 million for the quarter and $6.4 million for the 9 months.

title: Off-Duty Officer Shot In a Struggle in Bronx
description: An off-duty police officer was shot in the hand, apparently by a bullet from her own gun, during a struggle with an assailant in a passageway outside her apartment building in the Parkchester housing complex in the Bronx, the police reported.

title: Delta Air Selling Trust Certificates
description: Delta Air Lines offered $253.4 million worth of equipment trust certificates through a syndicate led by Salomon Brothers. The certficates will finance leases on seven Boeing 757 and 767 planes in Delta's fleet.

title: Secondhand Clothes
description: Nancy Reagan stole the show six years ago at Washington's annual Gridiron dinner when she sang ''Secondhand Clothes,'' to the tune of Barbra Streisand's popular ''Secondhand Rose.'' It was a graceful response to those who criticized her practice of accepting expensive designer dresses as loans and gifts. Beyond the self-deprecating humor, though, Mrs. Reagan was sufficiently upset by her critics to promise that she would ''no longer accept designer-loaned clothing.''

title: Judge's Daughter Concedes Giving Differing Testimony
description: A defense lawyer hammered away at Sukhreet Gabel in cross-examination yesterday as she acknowledged giving conflicting testimony in the Bess Myerson case.

title: Kansas Judge Bars Doctors' Release of Positive Test for AIDS Virus
description: A Kansas judge issued a permanent injunction yesterday barring a man's doctors from informing his former wife that he had tested positive for the AIDS virus.

title: McLain Pleads Guilty
description: Denny McLain, the former Detroit Tiger pitcher who was baseball's last 30-game winner, pleaded guilty to Federal racketeering and cocaine charges yesterday, 14 months after an appeals court overturned his conviction stemming from a 1984 indictment alleging he engaged in loan-sharking, gambling and drug dealing.

title: Day 744 of Fight to Open Bronx Shelter
description: Winter is coming and in the north Bronx, at the House of the Holy Comforter on the Grand Concourse, the number posted above the entrance grows bigger every day.

title: EATING OUT: With Luciano Pavarotti; For Pavarotti, the Proof's in the Pasta
description: ''I HAVE eaten only one piece of fennel all day,'' said Luciano Pavarotti as he maneuvered his diminished yet still heroic frame into a banquette at San Domenico, the Italian restaurant at 240 Central Park South. Mr. Pavarotti, the celebrated tenor blessed with perfect musical pitch and a soaring vocal range, concedes that there is only one scale he struggles to conquer - the one in his bathroom.

title: EATING WELL
description: THE following conversation, overheard in an Italian restaurant on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, crystallizes the image problem that plagues pasta.

title: Time and Tribune Gain; Media General Is Flat
description: Two large media companies, Time Inc. and the Tribune Company, reported higher third-quarter income yesterday, while Media General Inc. said that its earnings for the period were flat.

title: Private Incentives As Pollution Curb
description: IN this year of needle-strewn beaches and radon-poisoned parlors, every candidate who reads the polls is a self-proclaimed environmentalist. George Bush and Michael Dukakis are not exceptions: Both favor tougher enforcement of air and water quality standards and a moratorium on oil drilling off the coast of vote-rich California.

title: U.S. Schools Abroad: Issues Beyond Learning
description: As superintendent of the Colegio Americano here, Floyd J. Travis deals with curriculum, teacher recruitment and all the other issues that confront school principals in the United States. But unlike his counterparts back home, Dr. Travis must also worry about exchange rates, visas for his staff and complying with the separate school certification requirements of two countries.

title: Fame Is Fleeting In Hollywood
description: Hollywood and Washington collided the other night, and the results were a little bruising and a little funny.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for speical items.(Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Atlanta
description: LEAD: ''WE fit three people and 600 dogs in there and people don't know how we do it,'' said Glenn Robins, 32 years old, owner of Barkers Hotdogs. He was describing the 4- by 8-foot stainless-steel trailer he parks at Bobby Dodd Stadium of the Georgia Institute of Technology on football Saturdays and, Monday through Friday, at Woodruff Park in the heart of

title: Strike in Peru Lifts Copper; Oil Glut Depresses Prices
description: Prices of copper soared to new life-of-contract highs yesterday as renewed labor unrest in Peru, a significant supplier, prompted scare buying by domestic and foreign industrial users as well as speculators.

title: 60-MIUNTE GOURMET
description: ONE recent evening some friends dropped in unexpectedly, presenting me with the challenge of extending a casual dinner to make enough for company.

title: Zia Crash: Two Views
description: In the weeks after Pakistan's President, Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, and the United States Ambassador to that country were killed in a plane crash there in August, it seemed as if the United States and Pakistan were destined to reach different conclusions about the cause of the crash.

title: Warner-Lambert Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of approximately $29 million in connection with the company's deconsolidation of its operations in Argentina, reflect the impairment of its investment due to business and economic conditions in that country.

title: New Inquiry On Air Route To Tokyo Set
