description: The Department of Transportation yesterday ordered yet another reconsideration of an award of a contested route between Seattle and Tokyo, taking the route away from Continental Airlines Inc. and appointing a career officer in the agency to take a new look at the convoluted proceeding.

title: Warner-Lambert Falls After Vote by Panel
description: Scientific reservations about Lopid, the Warner-Lambert Company's largest-selling drug, sent Warner-Lambert shares plummeting yesterday, but a company spokesman said the market's concerns about the anti-cholesterol drug were unfounded.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Ruling In Agency Breakup
description: A NEW YORK State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that Lord, Einstein, O'Neill & Partners is temporarily free to recruit and accept employees from Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, the advertising agency that has been suffering since six top executives left last March to form the new shop.

title: Bush Asserts 'Iron Curtain' Remains, but It's 'Rusting'
description: Vice President Bush today came to the place where Winston Churchill warned of an ''Iron Curtain'' descending across the European continent and declared that, 70 years after the Russian Revolution, Marxism ''is losing its luster.''

title: Maytag Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,679,000 for the quarter and $3,559,000 for the 9 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $1,650,000 for the quarter and $3,817,000 for the 9 months.

title: Holly Farms Rejects Tyson Bid
description: The Holly Farms Corporation's board rejected Tyson Foods Inc.'s $920 million takeover offer, which was made one week ago. As expected by industry analysts, the Memphis-based chicken supplier called the Tyson offer, valued originally at $45 in cash and $4.50 in common stock per share, inadequate and not in the best interests of its shareholders.

title: Environment Will Expire if We Don't Act Now; Clean Air in '89?
description: To the Editor:

title: Consolidated Freightways Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BOOK NOTES
description: The Assassination

title: Aristech Chemical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $23,700,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: U.S. Warns Europeans To Cut Farm Subsidies
description: The United States warned today of escalating trade wars with the European Community if the Europeans do not agree to a timetable this year for long-term elimination of agricultural export subsidies.

title: Court Hearing On Macmillan
description: The Delaware Supreme Court yesterday agreed to hear an appeal by Maxwell Communications challenging a lockup provision and various other facets of a buyout proposal by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company for Macmillan Inc. At the same time, Judge

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
New Haven
description: LEAD: AROUND the turn of the century, Peter DeRose, newly arrived in New York City from Naples, quit his $10-a-week factory job when he found he could make $10 a day peddling apples. After moving to New Haven, he sold fruits and vegetables from a pushcart before opening a store. In 1980, his grandson, also named Peter D

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New AIDS Ads Are Displayed
description: The Federal Government's Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta has displayed a new set of powerful commercials in its two-year-old ''America Responds to AIDS'' campaign, several of which address, for the first time, the uncomfortable subject of marital infidelity. One spot, entitled ''Married

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report on Monday in the Campaign Trail column about the views of a professor, William C. Adams, on how the second Presidential debate was perceived by a radio listener misstated his affiliation. He teaches at George Washington University.

title: Pfizer Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said that in September 1988 the company acquired the remaining interest in Oral Research Laboratories Inc. Oral Research will operate as part of the company's consumer products segment. The acquisition was accounted for as a purchase, and its results of operations are included from the date of acquisition.

title: Lagerfeld: Fashion's Statesman
description: Karl Lagerfeld, one of the world's most prolific fashion designers, is perched on a gilt chair sipping orange juice in his 18th-century house on the Left Bank. His signature ponytail is now steel gray, and instead of a custom-tailored frock coat, he is wearing a loose black suit by Comme des Garcons with a black shirt by Matsuda. Japanese clothes are easier to work in, he explained. The made-to-measure suits are in storage. Mr. Lagerfeld has two important entries in the spring and summer fashion openings here this week: KL, the only collection to bear his name, or at least his initials, and Chanel, the venerable house he has catapulted into the forefront of fashion. Two weeks ago, he showed his ready-to-wear for Fendi in Milan, Italy.

title: Tandy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sundstrand Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an increase in the provision for resolution of pending government contract disputes amounting to $48.6 million, or $2.63 a share.

title: PHILIPPINE CRITICS ASSAIL U.S. ACCORD
description: President Corazon C. Aquino today welcomed the signing of a compensation agreement for American bases here, but a growing clamor of editorials and political statements denounced it as a poor deal.

title: PPG Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Freymiller Trucking reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $155,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Report of Gunfire Closes Brooklyn Bridge
description: The police sealed off the Brooklyn Bridge and part of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive for an hour late yesterday morning after a painter on the bridge's promenade reported being shot at while he took a coffee break.

title: CPC Sets Appointments For Orderly Succession
description: CPC International Inc., a major food company with annual sales of $4.9 billion and several top brands, named a new vice chairman and a president at a board meeting yesterday.

title: Bangkok Journal; There She Is: Valley Girl Wins the Hearts of Siam
description: Anyone who regards beauty contests as a pre-feminist frivolity might consider the events of Saturday night at the Rama Gardens Hotel. Angry contestants passed over earlier that evening in the 1988 Miss Thailand World competition reportedly ransacked the room of the winner, Papasara Chutanupong, and deposited her cape and scepter in the toilet.

title: Israelis Kill Two Arab Youths And Hurt U.S. Photographer
description: Israeli soldiers shot and killed two Palestinian boys, one of them 5 years old, and wounded an American news photographer today when they opened fire with plastic bullets in a West Bank riot, Arabs and the army said.

title: Lessons
description: This was supposed to be the year that education became, in the words of Governor Kean, a ''prime focus'' of the Presidential campaign. George Bush started out promising to be the ''education President,'' and Michael S. Dukakis quickly vowed to be ''our nation's No. 1 advocate for good schools and good teaching.''

title: College Football Notebook; Unbeaten Ithaca at Top in Poll
description: Ithaca College, unbeaten after six games, again led the poll of the East's Division III teams this week. Wagner, after its 30-24 victory over Hofstra, went from fifth to third behind Fordham, also 6-0.

title: Driver Goes on a Rampage; Rams 17 Cars With Tow Truck
description: A Police Department driver was jailed awaiting arraignment today on charges of going on a rampage with his tow truck, ramming 17 cars, pushing them into row houses and injuring at least five people.

title: Lebanese Fail to Elect Speaker
description: Lebanon's Parliament failed to elect a Speaker today when Christian legislators boycotted the session, preventing a quorum. Only 26 legislators, all pro-Syrian, attended the session. Thirty-nine are needed for a quorum. The post of Speaker is reserved for a Shiite Moslem under a national covenant.

title: Frustration Ends With One Swing
description: Tony LaRussa had grown tired of all these fly balls. The warm afternoon had become a cool evening, and balls hit to the power alleys or to center field at the Oakland Coliseum were becoming harmless outs.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: First Bank System Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $160 million addition to reserve for loan losses to reflect exposure to less developed countries.

title: Kohlberg Seen as Contender for Kraft
description: The nation's wealthiest buyout firm, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, may join in the bidding for Kraft Inc., people familiar with Kohlberg disclosed yesterday.

title: Morgan Stanley Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The shares outstanding include common stock equivalents. Revenue represents total revenues.

title: Bentsen Assails G.O.P. Charges as 'Nonsense'
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen, in one of the strongest counterattacks of his Vice-Presidential campaign, today accused the Republican candidates of turning ''a great national election into a carnival sideshow of nonsense and negativism.''

title: Symbol Is Winner In MSI Data Fight
description: A heated takeover battle in the lucrative portable computer industry came to a close as Symbol Technologies Inc. and the Telxon Corporation announced that they had forged a settlement in their quest for control of MSI Data Corporation. The deal allows Symbol to acquire MSI, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., in a $23-a-share friendly merger. Symbol, based in Bohemia, had made its offer, which values MSI at a total of $135.2 million, to counter Telxon's sweetened $20-a-share offer last month.

title: Ford Plant in Wales
description: The Ford Motor Company announced plans to open a $:725 million, or $1.27 billion, car engine plant in Wales that will create at least 3,000 jobs in the economically depressed area. The investment, Ford's biggest yet in Britain and the largest ever in a motor engine plant, was announced at Britain's International Motor Show in this industrial city.

title: Dukakis Ads: Blurred Signs, Uncertain Path
description: One major reason for Michael S. Dukakis's campaign difficulties has been an inability to produce timely, effective and consistent television advertising, judging by the laments of Democrats and the gloating of Republicans, As seen through the eye of his own advertising, the Democratic Presidential candidate was an economic manager. Then he was a successful debater. Now, he is a concerned father.

title: Oregon Court Finds Peyote Use Is Legal In Indian Ceremony
description: The use of a hallucinogenic drug derived from peyote in Indian religious ceremonies is protected by the Constitution's guarantee of religious freedom, the Oregon Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Esprit Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 2
description: b-Net income

title: Where One Policeman Fell: A Drug Trade's New Center
description: The shifting tide of narcotics dealing that has for several years engulfed much of the Upper West Side has most recently focused on a few blocks that include the street where a police officer was slain last night during a narcotics arrest.

title: Protest Against Elders IXL Bid
description: Scottish & Newcastle Breweries P.L.C., the British brewer, said today that it was printing ''hands off'' on millions of its beer bottle labels in protest against a hostile takeover bid by the Australian brewing giant Elders IXL Ltd.

title: Corestates Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pillsbury, Rejecting Offer, Says It Will Study Options
description: The board of directors of the Pillsbury Company unanimously rejected Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.'s $5.23 billion takeover bid today, calling it ''inadequate and not in the best interests of the company and its shareholders.''

title: California Dropping Dick and Jane
description: In their reading textbooks, elementary school students in California will seldom see Dick and Jane run. Instead, as early as next year, they will learn to read by using such classic tales as Aesop's Fables and stories by Mark Twain and other modern writers.

title: Marine Midland Banks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax benefits of $12,008,000 for the quarter and $29,884,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss Marine Midland is a member of the HongKongBank Group.

Memories of DeMille Go on Auction Block
description: Lester Binger wanted a money clip that had belonged to Cecil B. DeMille, but the retired Federal employee never even raised his bidding paddle.

title: Soviet Official Says Talks on Arms Should Emphasize Cuts in Navies
description: A senior Soviet official said today that more emphasis should be put on cutting naval strength in current disarmament negotiations.

title: Dukes Up, Mike!
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Fallon McElligott Wins Weyerhaeuser Paper
description: The Weyerhaeuser Paper Company has named Fallon McElligott of Minneapolis, a unit of the Ogilvy Group, as its agency of record for an account worth more than $3 million in annual billings.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Taking No Chances
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh seems determined to avoid the sorts of allegations that bedeviled his predecessor, Edwin Meese 3d, who was repeatedly accused of accepting valuable gifts and other favors from friends seeking influence in the Reagan Administration.

title: An Anniversary the Press Didn't Miss
description: It began as a trickle and grew into a flood. The New York Stock Exchange's press office has been inundated with requests for interviews, briefings and photo opportunities, as the nation's news organizations prepared for the first anniversary of the stock market crash.

title: Lilly, Eli & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $6.5 million for the quarter and $8.1 million for the 9 months.

description: b-Includes a gain of $2,299,000 from an accounting change. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $523,000 and $6,778,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; gains from the disposal of discontinued operations of $38,967,000 for the quarter and $30,913,000 for the 9 months, and a reversal of a tax credit of $9,267,000 and a tax credit of $8,334,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: 5 Big Drug Companies Report Increases in Profits
description: Five major drug companies yesterday reported double-digit increases in their earnings for the third quarter, but analysts said a weakening dollar might slow the trend at the end of the year.

title: American Television & Comunications Corp reports earnings for
description: b-Includes a one-time pretax charge of $19.9 million.

title: Marshall and Tudor Join Ailing Gibson
description: The merry mystique of the Los Angeles Dodgers finally took some bashing tonight from the leading bashers in the American League. But the emotional damage seemed a lot less punishing than the physical damage the Dodgers suffered while losing to the Oakland Athletics for the first time in the 85th World Series.

title: Northrop Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Transactions
description: BASKETBALL MIAMI (NBA) - Waived Connor Henry and Tony Fairley, guards. Signed Jamie Waller, guard. FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Released Leander Knight, defensive back, and Reggie Camp, defensive end. Signed Evan Cooper, safety. GREEN BAY (NFC) - Placed Walter Stanley, wide receiver, on injured reserve. Signed J. R. Ambrose, wide receiver. KANSAS CITY (AFC) - Waived Larry Moriarty, fullback. MIAMI (AFC) - Signed Tony Franklin, kicker. HOCKEY HARTFORD (NHL) - Assigned Sean Evoy, goaltender, to Vinton of the Atlantic Coast Hockey League. Loaned Ross McKay, goaltender, to Indianapolis of the International Hockey League. PITTSBURGH (NHL) - Sent Perry Ganchar, right wing, to Muskegon of the I.H.L. QUEBEC (NHL) - Recalled Gord Donnelly, right wing, from Halifax of the American Hockey League. Sent Mario Gosselin, goaltender, and Joel Baillargeon, left wing, to Halifax. SOCCER BALTIMORE - Signed Slobo Ilijevski, goalkeeper, to a one-year contract. COLLEGE CHICAGO STATE - Named Aubrey Volious assistant basketball coach. PRATT - Named Eugene Marshall athletic director; Wanda Bacon women's volleyball coach; Michael Blake men's soccer coach, and Michael Green assistant men's basketball coach. RUTGERS - Named Peter Kowalski director of sports media relations.

title: Time Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $19,900,000, or 17 cents a share, pretax charge for American Television & Communications Corp.'s reorganization and the relocation of its executive offices. c-Includes pretax gains of $15,300,000, or 14 cents a share, from the sale of Discover Magazine.

title: Oregon Officials Investigate Brutal Child Beatings at Farm
description: Children at a farm described as an athletic camp for ghetto youngsters were ritualistically beaten, left to go hungry and forced to watch as an 8-year-old girl was flogged to death, Oregon authorities said today.

title: P.B.A. Lawyer Quits After Investigation
description: A Lawyer who was under investigation for his management of the escrow funds of the New York City Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, has given up his law practice, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, said yesterday.

title: Frozen Food Express Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Citizens & Southern Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Washington Talk: Briefing; Soviet-U.S. Harmony
description: Call it the Hot Capitals, or something like that.

title: Taiwan Push Overseas
description: Businessmen from Taiwan, facing rising wages and tough antipollution laws at home, are expected to double their overseas investments this year, to about $200 million (United States funds), the Government's Investment Commission said today.

title: Court Overturns Gag Order in Steinberg Case as Unconstitutional
description: A gag order forbidding lawyers in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg from discussing the case with reporters was overturned yesterday by a New York State appeals court on the ground that it went too far.

title: Kraft Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: b-After a gain from discontinued operations of $658.4 million. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $10 million for the quarter and $14 million for the 9 months; the 9 months also included a gain from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting of $45.2 million.

title: About New York; Keeping Faith: A Loyal Porter And a Synagogue
description: Four decades ago Ansche Chesed was one of the grand synagogues of the Upper West Side. More than 1,000 families came to worship in its orange brick temple, including the lords of the building and rag trades. Limousines were parked out front. Top hats, striped pants and cutaway coats were de rigueur.

title: Pipeline Company Prices Note Issue
description: The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company priced an offering of $250 million eight-year notes.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Paris on the Potomac
description: Ever since the Kennedy Administration there has been nothing nouvelle about French chefs in Washington. They are all over the place, and in neighboring suburbs of Virginia and Maryland.

title: State by State; Where Political Humor Is Still Alive
description: Jim Hightower came up with two of the better lines of the 1988 Presidential campaign - two of the few that seem likely to survive from a contest more notable for faux pas than bons mots.

title: Harold O. N. Frankel, Retired Lawyer, 84
description: Harold O. N. Frankel, a retired Manhattan criminal lawyer, died Tuesday at his son's home in Tucson, Ariz. He was 84 years old and moved to Tucson from Manhattan last year.

title: Bristol-Myers Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bolster Gorbachev, Italian Says
description: Europe can reap ''unimaginable commercial advantages'' by giving Mikhail S. Gorbachev economic aid to carry out his program of restructuring the Soviet economy, Prime Minister Ciriaco De Mita said today.

title: Draft Report on Global Warming Foresees Environmental Havoc in U.S.
description: Global warming caused by industrial pollutants in the atmosphere is likely to shrink forests, destroy most coastal wetlands, reduce water quality and quantity in many areas and otherwise cause extensive environmental disruption in the United States over the next century, according to a draft report by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: A FOE OF PINOCHET GOES FREE IN CHILE
description: A former Foreign Minister has been freed after spending more than a year in jail as an ''apologist for terrorism.''

title: Noxell Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Vanbiesbrouck Meets the Test
description: John Vanbiesbrouck, a long, very visible scar on his left wrist, admits he is not fully recovered from the frightening accident he suffered last June. He insists, though, that he is 100 percent capable as a goaltender. It is a subtle, but significant distinction, and it is one he had to convince his coach and teammates of before the season began.

title: A Matter of Money
description: Following is a comparison of minimum jockey fees based on the $87,300 Ashley T. Cole Stakes, the feature race yesterday at Aqueduct. The central issue in the dispute between the jockeys and the horse owners is the fee paid for second- and third-place finishes. The jockeys want 5 percent of the owner's share of the total purse. They currently get a flat rate based on a sliding scale with a maximum of $450 when the total purse of a race is $500,000 or more.

title: Sundstrand Suspended by Pentagon
description: The Pentagon today suspended the Sundstrand Corporation as a Government contractor, temporarily cutting the company off from new contracts because of its admission last week of procurement fraud.

title: Kraft Director In a Dual Role
description: The chairman of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, John F. McGillicuddy, has found himself in a dual role in the $11.5 billion bid for Kraft Inc. by the Philip Morris Companies.

title: Young Rembrandt
description: To The Home Section:

title: Foremost Corp of America reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $666,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes income of $3,231,000 for the quarter and a gain of $8,186,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. The company said the latest quarter and 9 months both include a special one-time charge of $9,900,000 for an addition to insurance portfolio loss reserves.

title: Inside-Trade Inquiry Is Set By the British
description: The British Government said today that it would investigate the possibility of insider trading in the stock of Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. just before the British mining giant received a hostile takeover offer by a company with South African interests.

title: Sports People; Waiting for Robinson
description: Larry Brown, the San Antonio Spurs' coach, said in a conference call yesterday with National Basketball Association writers that he was optimistic that David Robinson would be released from the Navy soon, perhaps in time to play this season, which opens Nov. 4. Robinson's two-year tour of duty is scheduled to end in mid-May. Brown said the 7-foot Robinson, who signed a $26 million contract with the Spurs, has complied with the wishes of the Secretary of the Navy in that he has applied for the release personally in writing. Earlier, Lee Fentress, Robinson's agent, had made the request in a letter. In his request, according to Brown, Robinson has offered to extend his service in the Naval Reserve. Brown, who coached Kansas to the national collegiate championship last season, also disclosed that he was undergoing tests to determine the origin of ear and head pains he has had for the last four months.

title: Police Officer, 29, Is Arrested Seized on Drug Charge
description: A 29-year-old police officer who was appointed to the force two years ago was arrested yesterday and charged with criminal possession of drug paraphernalia, the police said.

title: Guilty Plea in Lottery Scheme
description: A man accused of masterminding a scheme to claim a $15.2 million lottery jackpot with a fake ticket pleaded guilty today in Dauphin County Court.

title: Newhall Land & Farming Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes $9 million, or 45 cents a unit, from the sale of a 32-acre parcel. Share earnings are in units.

title: Bearings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,151,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

description: The year-ago 9 months' results reflect the effect of a special provision for losses associated with the company's Latin American debt.

title: Yugoslavia Party Meeting Ends Without New Policies to Solve Crisis
description: The Yugoslav Communist Central Committee ended a three-day emergency session today without proposing new policies to pull this country out of its deep economic, political and ethnic crisis.

description: b-After a loss of $3,907,000 from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $580,000 and $1,276,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Gene-Implant Tests With Humans Are Put Off to Resolve Questions
description: In a letter mailed today, Dr. James B. Wyngaarden, the director of the National Institutes of Health, said he was delaying final approval of the first Government-endorsed experiments to transplant genes into human patients because of ''unresolved questions.''

title: 'Don't Just Write About Us. Know Us.'
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Living Section yesterday with an article about Karl Lagerfeld described a sketch by him incorrectly. It was a design for the Karl Lagerfeld 1989 summer collection, not for Chanel.

title: Review/Jazz; Harper Brothers' Debut
description: The Harper Brothers' debut concert at Birdland on Monday night was as much a coming-out party as it was a show. The five-piece band, led by Winard Harper on drums and his brother, Philip Harper, a trumpeter, has a handful of musicians who are too young to vote; family members were in the audience, as was a solid group of people involved in jazz.

title: Associated Banc-Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Health; Cholesterol Lower In California Eggs
description: Hens fed a secret diet have produced the first eggs certified by the state of California as lower in cholesterol than regular eggs.

description: b-Includes $7.8 million and $25.6 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, in non-operating income from asset sales and a Canadian tax adjustment offset by a writedown of oil and gas assets. c-Includes gains on asset sales of $1.9 million for the quarter and $3.7 million for the 9 months.

title: INSIDE
description: Herrington on A-Plants The Energy Secretary acknowledged vast problems with the nuclear weapon industry and told of his efforts to address them. Page A16. Delay for Gene Therapy The head of the National Institutes of Health, citing ''unresolved questions,'' said he was delaying experiments to transplant genes into human patients, a major step toward long-awaited gene therapy. Page B9. North Korea Answers South Ignoring the South's proposal, a North Korean official called for a confederation in which the current rival systems would coexist. Page A6. Dodgers Take 3-1 Lead Los Angeles, the cinderella team helped by three early errors by the A's, turned back Oakland by 4-3 and took a World Series lead of three games to one. Page D25.

title: Senate Backs Childrens' TV Regulation
description: The Senate gave final legislative approval today to a bill that would reimpose regulations on children's television, but President Reagan has expressed dislike for the bill and a veto seems likely.

The year-ago 9-month includes a pretax charge of $15,206,000 for relocation of the company's insurance operations.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Foreign Service to End
description: Allan E. Gotlieb, Canada's Ambassador to the United States since 1982, who is being replaced on Jan. 1, is leaving his Government's service. Mr. Gotlieb, widely regarded as an effective ambassador who pressed his government's interests in meetings at both the White House and on Capitol Hill, also was a popular host who, with his wife, aggressively entertained Washington's elites. He had held the highest career position in Canada's Foreign Ministry before Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau appointed him to the Washington post in December 1981.

title: Health: Immunization; Medicare to Offer Free Flu Shots To Test Merit of Preventive Program
description: A little-noticed Federal project is ready to provide free influenza shots to millions of elderly Americans this winter in the beginning of what health officials view as a landmark preventive health effort that could save thousands of lives and billions of dollars.

title: Campaign Finance; PAC's Discard Ideology and Bet on Incumbency
description: Until she quit early this year to run for Congress, Patricia L. Williams was the executive director of the board of realtors here.

description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $21.3 million and $36 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: 164 Killed in 2 Plane Crashes in India; 5 Survive
description: At least 164 people were killed today in the crashes of a Boeing 737 and a smaller turboprop aircraft on domestic flights. The two planes went down near airports, one in western India and the other in the northeast.

title: Wang Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
6 Scientists Win Nobel Prizes
description: Three Americans were awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics yesterday for research that improved the understanding of elementary particles and forces, while three West Germans won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry for unraveling the structure of proteins that play a crucial role in photosynthesis.

description: b-Includes gains of $5.3 million, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $18.5 million, or 19 cents a share, for the 9 months on the sale of loans and mortgage-backed securities. c-Includes gains of $13.2 million, or 13 cents a share, for the quarter and $72.1 million, or 73 cents a share, for the 9 months on sale of loans and mortgage-backed securities. Year-ago third quarter and 9-month net were increased by $3.1 million, or 3 cents a share, and $12.1 million, or 12 cents a share, respectively, by an accounting restatement.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the crash of a Ugandan airliner near Rome misidentified Uganda's capital in some editions. It is Kampala.

title: 3 West Germans Wins Nobel Prize in Chemistry
description: Three West German scientists were awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry yesterday for research revealing the three-dimensional structure of closely linked proteins that are essential to photosynthesis, the chemical reaction on which all higher forms of life depend.

title:
CURRENTS;
Architects Predict The Future
description: LEAD: IT often takes years for architects to accumulate a substantial body of built work. Budgets are cut, commissions are canceled, clients turn elsewhere.

Rebel Attacks on the Rise in Salvador
description: In a surge of guerrilla violence, leftist rebels briefly seized a southeastern town on Tuesday night and detonated two powerful car bombs in one of the capital's wealthiest neighborhoods. At least 3 people were killed and 15 were wounded, three seriously.

title: Southern Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $229 million after-tax write-off related to costs that could not be recovered through rates for the company's Georgia Power subsidiary's Vogtle nuclear plant.

title: Kennametal Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Festive Evening for the Folk Art Museum
description: WHILE other New York charities are talking about curtailing the lavishness of their benefit parties, the Museum of American Folk Art has gone the other way.

title: JUDGE DENIES PLEA IN PACEMAKER SUIT
description: A Federal district judge today rejected a plea agreement reached by prosecutors and the Cordis Corporation, which is accused of 23 counts of selling defective cardiac pacemakers from 1980 to 1985.

title: Serbian Nationalism Could Rip Yugoslav Fabric; The Montenegrins
description: To the Editor:

title: Put a Song in Your Portfolio: 'Happy Birthday' Is for Sale
description: ''Happy Birthday to You'' may seem as if it belongs to everyone, but the song is actually under copyright, and that copyright will soon have a new owner.

title: American Savings Bank of New York reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest periods included an additional $3.5 million to the bank's loan loss provision for a loan to a Connecticut-based real estate syndication and management company.

title: Kaman Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Alberto-Culver Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain of $2,269,000, or 16 cents a share, from the sale of Lamaur Inc. common stock which was acquired prusuant to a merger proposal.

title: Health; Personal Health
description: One of my most beautiful friends is hardly what our society would call a classic beauty. At 5 feet, 4 inches tall and 120 to 125 pounds, she is absolutely average, statistically speaking. Clearly, she is not centerfold material: her belly protrudes a bit, her waist and neck are somewhat foreshortened, her thighs are slightly flabby and her face is round but lacks the delicacy of a cherub.

title: Rival Prods Moynihan, But in Vain
description: Robert R. McMillan's slogan for his low-budget challenge of Senator Daniel P. Moynihan is: ''He won't just talk - he'll get results for New York State.''

title: Ward Orders Officers to Use Protective Vest
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward, stunned by the shooting deaths of two young policemen Tuesday night in separate incidents, yesterday ordered all uniformed police officers on patrol duty to begin wearing bulletproof vests at all times.

title: Microsoft Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Chain of City Weeklies Sold
description: American City Business Journals Inc., a chain of weekly publications, ageed Tuesday to be acquired by TA Associates Communications, a Boston-based group that invests in media holdings, for $124.7 million in cash and debt.

title: Emporia Journal; Where Eloquence Seems a Birthright
description: On the slender shoulders of Barbara White Walker has fallen the right and obligation to take command of a country newspaper that once made a little Kansas town a household word and that, nearly a century ago, gave America the Sage of Emporia.

title: Park Ave. High School Pays $35,500 in Taxes and Reopens
description: More than two weeks after it was closed for failing to pay back taxes, a Russian high school in Manhattan reopened yesterday when officials paid the Government $35,500 in a jubilant transaction at the front gate.

title:
CURRENTS;
Country Houses Are in Ireland, Too
description: LEAD: BY now there cannot be much more published on the architecture, decoration, arts and social life of the English country house. Fortunately for the fans of such manors and manners, Ireland also provides ample material.

title: Ameritech Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the sale of Applied Data Research lowered its latest third quarter net per share by about 6 cents. Year-ago third quarter results are restated to reflect accounting changes.

title: Sweden's Police Chief Quits Over Unsolved Palme Case
description: Sweden's police chief, Niels Erik Ahmansson, resigned today after the country's Attorney General criticized him for incompetence in the unsolved killing of Prime Minister Olof Palme.

title: Pain and Prejudice
description: To The Home Section:

title: General Dynamics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jefferson Bankshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Buffalo Hospital Revenue Bonds
description: The New York State Medical Care Facilities Finance Agency yesterday offered $170 million worth of revenue bonds for Buffalo General Hospital.

title: Government Has Failed to Bolster Guard Against Spies, Report Says
description: A succession of damaging spy cases has largely failed to bring about improvements in the Government's procedures for protecting its secrets, a Congressional report concluded today.

title: Thornburgh Is Said To Plan a Reversal Of Order by Meese
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has decided to overrule or severely restrict an order signed by his predecessor, Edwin Meese 3d, to appoint special prosecutors when members of Congress face charges of major wrongdoing, according to Justice Department officials.

title: Air Products & Chemicals Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $4,081,000 from the early retirement of debt.

title: A Hunt Deal Is Reported
description: A lawyer for Minpeco S.A., a commodities company owned by the Government of Peru, said today that Lamar Hunt had agreed to settle his portion of $132 million in damages awarded to Minpeco last August by a Federal jury in New York for $17 million.

title: Campaign Trail; The Dukakis Plan: Take to Airwaves
description: As if in response to Mr. Mondale - and other Democrats - the Dukakis campaign is not only sending hundreds of volunteers and staff workers from Boston and Washington to key states, but also putting into action a strategy for the final weeks in which the Governor will focus on television, radio and newspaper interviews and nationally televised speeches.

title: Stocks Fall Sharply a Year After the Crash
description: LEAD: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday, a year to the day when they fell unbelievably.

title: Whittle Seen In Time Deal
description: Whittle Communications, the magazine publishing partnership based in Knoxville, Tenn., is expected to announce today that it will sell a half-interest in the company to Time Inc.

title: Market Place; Willcox & Gibbs Called Underrated
description: EVEN though Willcox & Gibbs is soon likely to report its 23d consecutive quarter of increased sales and earnings, it does not get the investor appreciation it deserves, analysts say. The stumbling block is that, like many conglomerates, investors are not sure what kind of company it is.

title: Continental Sells Two Subsidiaries
description: The New York-based Continental Corporation announced agreements to sell two life insurance subsidiaries in separate transactions that are expected to yield a total of $185 million in cash. One unit, Loyalty Life, based in Michigan, will be sold to the NFU Acquisition Company. The other subsidiary, Commercial Life, will be sold to two separate buyers: the UNUM Corporation and the Sun Life Insurance Company of America, a unit of Kaufman & Broad Inc.

title: 50 Years of Jazz, in the Hands of Gerald Wilson
description: Gerald Wilson, the 70-year-old dean of California big band jazz, is standing before the American Jazz Orchestra in a dingy rehearsal hall near Times Square. He counts off the time, the orchestra starts together, and immediately he waves on the brass section as if he were a third base coach urging a runner home.

title: Students in a Moscow School Debate the Once-Undebatable
description: For years the study of Soviet history at Secondary School 831 in Moscow was less an exercise in understanding the country's heritage than in denying it.

title: Problems at Weapon Plants Conceded
description: Energy Secretary John S. Herrington acknowledged yesterday that severe problems with safety, equipment and management are wracking the nuclear weapon industry in the United States. And he conceded that despite efforts to improve the safety of the system, he still does not feel that he has total control of the Government bureaucracy and private companies that operate it.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: THE girl was the youngest in her kindergarten class, having passed the age cutoff by just two weeks. Although her reading level was well above those of the other children in the room, her teachers felt that her social skills were not up to par because she was so young. Last spring they recommended that the girl spend another year in kindergarten.

title: Scorsese's Passion Now: Dostoyevsky
description: As the crew of Martin Scorsese's new film heads off to lunch, Nestor Almendros stays behind on the set and says, ''He reminds me of Truffaut a lot.'' Mr. Almendros, the renowned cinematographer who worked on many of Francois Truffaut's films, hadn't even been asked any questions yet, but he knows an intriguing line when he drops one. So how is Martin Scorsese like Truffaut?

title: Drug Center Applauds Nixon as Fighter
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon walked into the dining room of the Daytop Village Swan Lake center here today, and more than 400 teen-agers and young adults rose to give him an ovation.

title: Dukakis Makes Strong Response To G.O.P.'s Ads
description: Michael S. Dukakis took his case to Main Street today, waving two Republican leaflets that attack his record and telling a cheering, flag-waving crowd: ''Friends, this is garbage.''

title: Review/Music; At Tully, Mostly Other Bachs
description: Lincoln Center discovered the drawing power of period-instrument ensembles a few seasons ago and now offers an annual early music subseries on its Great Performers schedule. The first of this season's presentations was a concert by Musica Antiqua Koln and the Rheinische Kantorei on Sunday evening at Alice Tully Hall.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: FINE hand-knotted rugs are often works of art, yet many owners choose to use them every day. Handmade antique and silk rugs, which are both precious and fragile, should be used daily only with great caution and should be cared for professionally. But most fine hand-knotted wool rugs, those less than 50 years old, can withstand normal household use, and as long as they are in good condition, they can be cleaned and cared for by amateurs.

description: A new Cabinet was formed in this turbulent Central African nation today, headed by a Prime Minister from the country's oppressed Hutu tribe, Burundi's Ambassador to Kenya, Marc Nteturuye, said.

But Federated, a unit of the Campeau Corporation, said the results were largely offset by lower expenses because of a cost-cutting program.

description: In addition to voting Nov. 8 for a President, a United States Senator and Representative and local officials, New Jersey voters will also be asked to approve $350 million in capital spending for education.

description: The Food and Drug Administration today announced new procedures for approving drugs, saying they would make new treatments available more quickly to people with such life-threatening diseases as AIDS or cancer.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Our house has a septic tank for sewage disposal, and every time there is heavy rain we get a sewage odor in one of the bathrooms. There is no such problem with the bathroom at the other end of the house, and all appliances flush and drain properly. The problem disappears within an hour or two after the rain stops; there is no sign of a leak under the house or in the ground near the septic tank. What could be causing this? A. The problem may be in the vent stack or pipe that services the toilet. This vent goes up through the roof and is supposed to let sewer gases escape. The vent may be partly blocked, so that in a heavy rain, water accumulates inside and traps odors. (The other toilet would have a separate vent, so it is not affected.) After a few hours the water probably drains away and the odors dissipate. Cleaning the vent pipe might solve the problem. Q. The paint on the outside of my house is peeling and flaking. I have taken samples to dealers, who say the original primer has broken down and is no longer bonding. They say the only remedy is to remove all the old paint down to the bare wood. The house was repainted about two years ago, and where the paint was applied to bare wood it seems to be adhering. The painter at that time said he had used a self-priming paint. Should this paint also be stripped? A. When you remove the old paint, whether by sanding or with a chemical remover, remove all of it. After the wood is stripped, apply a good-grade primer as a first coat. No house paint should be used on bare wood without priming first. Q. Last winter we moved into an eight-year-old house that was heated by a wood stove in the cellar. This past summer some of the floors and several of the stairs leading from the cellar started creaking when walked upon. We invested in a dehumidifier, but this has not helped. What do you think causes this? A. It is possible that the heat from the wood stove dried out and shrunk or warped some of the floorboards or the supporting beams and joists. If so, a dehumidifier would not help. If the creaking persists, you will have to find the loose floorboards and fasten them securely with nails or screws.

title: Winners of Nobel Prizes for Unlocking Secrets in Physics and Chemistry
description: PHYSICS Leon Max Lederman

title: 3 American Physicists Get Nobel for Landmark Work
description: The Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded yesterday to three Americans for their landmark experiment a quarter century ago using the first laboratory-made beam of neutrinos, elusive particles that play a fundamental role in the structure of matter.

description: The Devils suffered their third consecutive loss in the young season tonight, but this one may have been the most painful because they were shut out by a goaltender they traded away last season.

title: Review/Theater; 650 Years Between Parallel Lives
description: There are entertaining moments in ''The Green Death'' by Peter Mattaliano, and a few laughs, but those are small satisfactions in a play billed as a black comedy that drags its way through more than two hours of confusion. The most memorable incident in the production at the Actor's Outlet Theater is the change of scenery in the first act. Charles E. McCarry has devised a set that is transformed in an instant from a dark medieval inn to a gleaming neo-classical Connecticut mansion. It deserves the applause it gets.

title: Now, Neighbors Recall Doubts on Youth Farm
description: When members of the Ecclesia Athletic Association first moved to a farmhouse near here in the summer of 1987, a neighbor, Kenneth Teuscher, did what he could to assist them in setting up their retreat for ghetto youngsters. He helped them plant a garden and build a fence, even letting them use some of the land on his cattle ranch for tents.

description: When Congress voted Tuesday to create a needless new Department of Veterans Affairs it also created three problems.

No doubt the road for a Dukakis victory is long, winding and steeply uphill, and the time remaining is very short. Yet a third of all likely voters remain swingable -that is, show a willingness to switch candidates, perhaps more than once, between now and Nov.

Results Plus
description: N.H.L. Maple Leafs 4, Sabres 2: Gary Leeman scored a short-handed goal and assisted on Ed Olczyk's tie-breaking power-play goal late in the second period last night as Toronto got 37 saves from Ken Wregget to beat Buffalo. Olczyk scored his second goal of the game and sixth of the season into an empty Buffalo net with 8 seconds remaining to account for the final margin. Craig Laughlin also scored for the Maple Leafs. Dave Andreychuk and Christian Ruuttu scored for Buffalo. Buffalo outshot Toronto, 39-22, but Wregget was equal to the challenge. (AP) Canadiens 5, Whalers 4: Mike Lalor converted a pass by Claude Lemieux into his first goal of the season with 1:40 to play as Montreal defeated Hartford at home. Lemieux skated along the boards, and when pressed by the defenseman Ulf Samuelsson, he passed to Lalor, who found the corner of the net past the goaltender, Mike Liut. The Canadiens, who won for the first time in five games against Adams Division competition, had moved ahead, 4-3, on a power-play goal by Chris Chelios. But Ray Ferraro, who had set up two earlier goals, put a slap shot beyond the goaltender, Patrick Roy, to get the Whalers even. (AP) Tennis Edberg Gains in Tokyo: Top-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden defeated Todd Nelson of San Diego, 6-2, 6-2, yesterday in the first round of the Seiko Super tournament in Tokyo. In other matches, John Fitzgerald of Australia, ranked 32d in the world, easily defeated an American, Ken Flach, 6-4, 6-0, in 55 minutes. Richard Matuszewski of the United States beat a countryman, Jay Berger, 7-6, 6-3, and Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia beat Toshihisa Tsuchihashi of Japan, 7-5, 6-3.(AP) Shriver Wins in Zurich: Top-seeded Pam Shriver eliminated Judith Wiesner of Austria, 4-6, 7-5, 6-0, in the opening round of the women's European indoors championship in Zurich. Fifth-seeded Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria defeated Isabelle Demongeot of France, 6-4, 6-2, to advance to the quarterfinals. In a first-round match, eighth-seeded Raffaella Reggi of Italy eliminated Cathy Caversazio of Switzerland, 6-3, 6-3. (AP)

title: Review/Television; Helping People to Read

A little good news is most welcome about a condition that is keeping millions of Americans from breaking out of poverty and costing the nation heavily in the forms of crime, welfare and an unskilled work force.

title: A WAR CRIMES CASE STIRS FRANCE ANEW

title: Edmonton Warms Up as Fans Welcome Gretzky's Return

Allegations of betrayal filled the prairie air, and even Gretzky's father, Walter, suggested that his son's giving up of his homeland for the United States was bad for Canada, and possibly bad for the National Hockey League's most famous player.

title: Review/Theater; Diderot's Dialogue, With Contemporary Parallels
description: As a protean man of ideas during the Enlightenment, Denis Diderot was a philosopher, encyclopedist, critic and playwright - and an influence on generations of thinkers and artists in each of his various fields. One of his most consequential works is ''Rameau's Nephew,'' an apparently fictive dialogue that was unpublished in Diderot's lifetime.

description: The number of AIDS cases has reached alarming proportions in Central America, health officials in the region say, and the virus is continuing to spread rapidly throughout the area.

title: Baseball Notebook; Rumors About Mattingly Trade Won't Go Away
description: Bob Quinn, the Yankees' general manager, is not at the World Series, but he heard about the Don Mattingly report long distance.

title: Australian Trade Deficit
description: Australia is well on the way to an economic recovery with all signs showing continued improvement in its trade situation, Paul Keating, the country's Treasurer, said today. Mr. Keating made the statement after the release of official statistics showing the nation's current account deficit had narrowed to $990 million (Australian), or $804 million (United States), in September. The current account, measuring trade in both goods and services, showed a shortfall of more than $1.3 billion (Australian) in August and about $1.5 billion in July.

title: Recipe for a Trilogy: Mix Carefully

Even Robert Greenhut, the film's producer, said of anthologies, ''The track record hasn't been wonderful.'' For every classic like the Italian ''Boccaccio '70,'' there are clunkers like ''Twilight Zone - The Movie.''

Dukakis does, they abandon the brave midsummer talk about making inroads in the Deep South and end up right here, in the Midwest, hoping that the three big states of Illinois, Ohio and Michigan will all go their way and push them toward the White House.

Maligned as a Southern sympathizer, and suffering mental strain that ultimately led to her institutionalization, she infuriated her husband by her obsession with finery acquired at public expense. ''Flub-dubs!'' President Lincoln once shouted when presented with a list of expenses for mansion furnishings and dresses. ''For flub-dubs!''

title: GANG CHIEF GUILTY IN RIVAL'S SLAYING
description: The leader of El Rukn, a street gang, who is already serving a long sentence for conspiring to commit terrorist acts, faces up to 80 years in prison for ordering the slaying of a rival gang leader.

title: Middle South Utilities Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results for the year-ago periods are restated to reflect the writeoff of the cost of the Waterford 3 nuclear unit disallowed for rate recovery.

title: Campaign Trail; A Little Help From the Other Side
description: Virtually every power broker in Washington turned out for a party the other night honoring Robert S. Strauss, a prime power broker, on his 70th birthday. Mr. Strauss, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, told the group that on the way to the party his wife, Helen, had said he had better think of something to say to all those heavyweights.

title: A Cocaine Addict Confesses To at Least 600 Burglaries
description: A man the police call ''a one man crime wave,'' has admitted to committing 600 to 700 burglaries in the city over the last two years, the authorities said.

title: Slices of Life in a 'Five Year Diary'
description: You may have been to a few movies that seemed 40 hours long. Now you can see one that really is. It's called ''Five Year Diary,'' and it took seven years to make. It takes eight days to show. And it has its premiere Friday at the American Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens.

title: Campaign Trail; A Little Advice From an Old Warrior
description: In the final weeks of the 1984 Presidential campaign, Walter F. Mondale knew that President Reagan would overwhelmingly defeat him. But Mr. Mondale, instead of yielding, decided to campaign with an intensity that startled his advisers and, he acknowledges, himself. Mr. Dukakis, he says, should do the same because he has a far better chance of beating Vice President Bush than he had of defeating Mr. Reagan.

title: Pittway Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Stanley Works reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $6,735,000 and $9,698,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Masters of Disguise
description: HALLOWEEN season is soon upon us. If you're undecided about appropriate dress for the occasion, don't despair. Robert Gordon's 65-year-old Gordon Novelty Company sells every costume and mask imaginable. The store also carries accessories of every sort - bushy black eyebrows, medieval swords, tiaras, Captain Cook eye patches, fangs, feather boas, Roman shields, hula skirts, inflatable barbells, gun and holster sets, rhinestone eyelashes, tomahawks and hundreds more items.

title: Judge Fatally Shot in Court; Estranged Husband Is Held
description: A county judge was fatally shot in her chambers today by her estranged husband, an off-duty police officer, who fired at other officers before surrendering, the police said.

title: Workman Publishing Set To Buy Algonquin Books
description: In a reversal of the usual takeover pattern in book publishing, where big houses gobble up smaller ones, the Workman Publishing Company of New York has reached an agreement in principle to acquire Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill, N.C. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: Scecorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Europe Offers Assurance Of 'Free and Open' Trade
description: As it prepares to create one market among its own member nations by 1992, the European Commission today declared that it had a ''fundamental stake in the existence of free and open international trade'' and dismissed fears of looming European protectionism as ''senseless and groundless.''

title: Construction Of Housing Up by 1.5%
description: A rebound in apartment construction offset a decline in single-family home building last month as overall housing activity rose a modest 1.5 percent.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My children have often asked me why I never received a Nobel Prize. I used to tell them it was because the Nobel committee couldn't make up its mind which of my projects to recognize.'' - Leon M. Lederman. [ B12:6. ]

title: Campaign Trail; Lampooning Paper Makes Quayle News
description: ''Quayle Becomes President.'' '' 'Uh-Oh,' Says Worried Nation.'' That headline appears on a free, single-page broadsheet, The Washington Possible, that lampoons Dan Quayle and was circulated yesterday in Washington, New York and Los Angeles. Nearly 20,000 copies of the ''newspaper,'' whose appearance vaguely resembles that of The Wasington Post, are scheduled for distribution in about a half-dozen cities, as are 20,000 posters that duplicate it.

title: Outfitting An AIDS Agency's New Space
description: AS the first voluntary organization in New York to address the AIDS epidemic, the Gay Men's Health Crisis has been accustomed to facing seemingly insurmountable odds.

title: A Student Is Charged With Stealing a Skull
description: Syracuse University art student has been accused of taking a skull from a mausoleum and boiling it in his dormitory to prepare it for a sculpting class. The skull possibly was that of a man who served as the Mayor of Syracuse more than 100 years ago.

title: Prosecutor Cites Drexel Role in Princeton/Newport Case
description: A Federal prosecutor in court proceedings yesterday charged that Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. had engaged in a criminal conspiracy with officials from a New Jersey investment firm to manipulate stock prices and defraud customers.

title: TRAINING IS CITED AT ATOMIC AGENCY
description: A group that monitors nuclear safety said yesterday that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission had failed to issue regulations on worker training at nuclear reactors as required by law and that better training would reduce the number of mishaps.

title: A Space Big Enough for Two, Barely
description: LEAD: BEDTIME is an awkward situation for Chuck Shorter, who calls a living room his home. ''I feel uncomfortable asking my roommate and her friends to leave because I have to go to bed at 11 P.M.,'' he said. ''It's kind of embarrassing for a 24-year-old to sound like a 40-year-old.''

title: A Plant as Changeable as Autumn Itself
description: AUTUMN, from almost any point of view, is a season of many great excellences in the lives of gardeners. The weather is pleasant in its variations. A day that is a reminder of summer may be followed by one that is a foretaste of winter.

title: 4 Publishers List Results For Quarter
description: Three leading publishing companies - McGraw-Hill Inc., the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation and Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. - yesterday reported moderately higher earnings for the third quarter. A fourth company, Multimedia Inc., reported that its earnings fell slightly in the period. McGraw-Hill
