(Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Cincinnati Gas & Electric Co reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $16,847,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The latest 12 months period includes a $91 million net charge from the writedown of an investment in the Zimmer generating plant.

title: Koch Attacks Goldin on Foster-Care Issue
description: Mayor Koch yesterday accused his longtime rival, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, of ''using kids for politics'' by taking reporters and photographers into a city child-welfare office on Monday after Mr. Goldin's investigators were denied access because of confidentiality rules.

title: Transactions
description: Basketball

title: Puget Sound Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago third quarter earnings were sharply reduced by a $15 million pre-tax charge related to certain real estate loans in Alaska and Texas.

title: Trans-Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos have been held in contempt of court for failing to obey a grand jury's subpoenas that require them to provide their fingerprints and other material for the investigation, a Federal appeals court said. Page A1

title: Serbian Nationalism Could Rip Yugoslav Fabric
description: To the Editor:

title: Consolidated Rail Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $32 million tax credit. The company said its 9-month net is compared with the prior year's on a pro forma basis because net income through the first quarter 1987 was enhanced by the existence of net operating loss and investment tax credit carryforwards which sheltered the company from federal income taxes. These carryforwards were cancelled by the legislation authorizing the company's transfer to the private sector in the March 26, 1987, public stock offering.

title: Northeast Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFS
description: Common Stock

title: Yacht Navigates a Mystery
description: The mystery of why Cuba detained an American vessel carrying the 1988 America's Cup challenger New Zealand was cleared up yesterday when the vessel, the Tampa Seahorse, arrived in New York Harbor with its piggyback cargo.

title: Independent Bank Corp (Mass) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sports People; N.B.A. Willing to Talk
description: The National Basketball Association is willing to discuss sending its players to the Olympics if the International Basketball Federation decides that admitting N.B.A. professionals to Olympic competition would benefit the sport worldwide, Commissioner David Stern said yesterday in Madrid. Stern said N.B.A. officials had yet to take up the subject of how American professional basketball players, considered the world's best, could be incorporated into Olympic play, but he said the international federation could adopt rules in April to open the way for N.B.A. participation.(AP)

title: U.S. Court Holds Marcos and Wife In Contempt for Defying Subpoena
description: Former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and his wife, Imelda, have been held in contempt of court for failing to obey a grand jury's subpoenas in Manhattan, a Federal appeals court said yesterday in upholding the contempt citations.

title: American Electric Power Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: TV Notes
description: Support for Rather

title: Surely Lincoln-Douglas Roll in Their Graves
description: To the Editor:

title: Substitutes Replace Striking Jockeys at Aqueduct's Opener; Regulars Picket In Pay Dispute
description: The regular jockeys picketed yesterday outside the Aqueduct gate and, when it was race time, clambered up onto a flatbed truck to make themselves tall enough to watch what was happening on the other side of the fence.

title: LAWSUIT IS SETTLED OVER FORD ESTATE
description: Kathleen DuRoss Ford, third wife and widow of the automobile magnate Henry Ford 2d, has reached a settlement with Ford family members that will guarantee her at least $10.5 million a year for life from his $350 million estate, her attorney announced today.

title: Life Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sports People; Inquest to Be Ordered
description: An inquest will be ordered before the end of the week into the cocaine death of the football player David Croudip, Gwinnett County Coroner Randolph D. Simpson said yesterday. Croudip, a defensive player and captain of the special teams for the Atlanta Falcons, died Oct. 10. Although there is no dispute that Croudip died as a result of taking cocaine, Simpson said, questions about the circumstances of his death have been raised by conflicting stories told by Croudip's wife, Holly. She said she was the only person present when her husband had a seizure after taking cocaine in a fruit drink. In one television interview, she said that her husband never used drugs. But she has reportedly told the Gwinnett police that Croudip had been in drug treatment in California. Croudip's mother, Josephine Thornton, sent a letter to Simpson Tuesday asking him to hold an inquest.

title: Helen O'Bannon, 49, Pennsylvania Official
description: Helen B. O'Bannon, senior vice president of the University of Pennsylvania and a former Secretary of Welfare in Pennsylania, died of cancer yesterday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. She was 49 years old and lived in Bala Cynwyd, Pa.

title: Sports People; Givens Seeks No Money
description: Robin Givens will not seek a settlement from Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, her New York-based attorney, Raoul Felder, said. ''Robin is waiving all claims,'' Felder said. ''She will not be asking for nor will she take any money.'' Felder said that on Tuesday, while awaiting a settlement offer from Tyson's attorney, Howard Weitzman, Givens called to tell him she wanted nothing from Tyson in settlement of their divorce. ''I told her to sleep on it,'' Felder said. ''But she said it wasn't necessary. When I checked again 10 minutes before I spoke to the press, she hadn't changed her mind.'' In a prepared statement, Givens said: ''Michael can have his divorce. I never married Michael for his money. Therefore this represents no loss for me.'' Felder said he believed that Givens, in withdrawing any claims on Tyson, had given up a $10 million settlement.

title: Ben Johnson, World's Fastest Scapegoat
description: LEAD: From newspaper reports of the past month, you might conclude that the most contemptible human on the planet was Ben Johnson, the Canadian sprinter who tested positive for steroid use. He was sent home in disgrace, stripped of his gold medal, hounded by the press and became the subject of an official inquiry.

title: Rohm & Haas Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Georgia Gulf Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ailing Dodgers Succeed
description: This is success: You take the lead in the World Series, three games to one, with Orel Hershiser ready to pitch the clincher.

title: West Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 2
description: b-Includes a net charge of 6 cents a share from a retirement program.

title: Oakland's Stars in the Front Office
description: The success of the Oakland Athletics this year is usually attributed to the slugging of Jose Canseco, the pitching of Dennis Eckersley and the fielding of Walt Weiss.

title: Hasbro Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said its latest third- quarter pretax earnings were affected by a provision related to the discontinuance of its efforts to develop an interactive video entertainment system. The total impact of this development is about $12.6 million and $16.4 million for the latest third quarter and 9 months, compared with $1.9 million for the year-ago quarter and $4.4 million for the 9 months.

title: House Approves Credit Bill
description: The House today approved a bill requiring issuers of credit cards to give consumers more and earlier details about interest rates and other costs.

title: Kaisertech Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $200,000 for the quarter and $7.8 million for the 9 months, and tax credits of $19.1 million and $36.9 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-After net of $1.5 million for the quarter and a loss of $26.1 million for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. d-Net loss The year-ago 9 months' loss included loss provisions of $400 million that resulted primarily from restructuring operations. The year-ago periods are restated to reflect accounting changes.

title: US Surgical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: The New York Times college football rankings on the sports statistics page in some editions on Tuesday gave an incorrect record for Notre Dame. The university has a 6-0 won-lost record. The other information about the team, including its No. 3 position in the ranking, was based on the correct record.

title: Last Gasps in Congress; Cleaning Up Its Own Lobbies
description: Is it too much to ask that House committee staff members wait a year after leaving Congressional employment to lobby their old colleagues? Apparently so, in the view of some staff members and a few powerful House chairmen. Their last-ditch special pleading is the only major obstacle to a bill to extend landmark ethical reforms to Congress.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. DECOLONIZATION COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Battle for a Treaty
description: Over the last 19 years Senator William Proxmire, the Wisconsin Democrat, gave 3,000 speeches on the Senate floor in an often lonely battle to win United States approval of the international treaty outlawing genocide. He finally achieved that goal in a Senate vote last Friday in the last days of his political career. Today, some people who appreciate those efforts are going to make a few speeches to him.

title: Man Convicted of Rape on DNA Evidence
description: In the first trial in New York State in which a defendant was linked to a crime through an analysis of his own genetic material, a 46-year-old man was convicted yesterday of sexual attacks on three women in Queens last year.

title: Carl Low Is Dead at 71; Stage and Screen Actor
description: Carl Low, an actor who appeared widely on stage and in films and television, died of cancer yesterday at Nyack (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Nyack.

title: Dukakis Does A Little Better In 2 New Polls
description: Two surveys released yesterday paint a somewhat better view of the Presidential race for Gov. Michael S. Dukakis than was presented in a poll earlier this week, which showed an overwhelming lead for Vice President Bush.

title: Substitutes Replace Striking Jockeys at Aqueduct's Opener
description: New York's regular jockeys picketed Aqueduct Race Track on opening day yesterday as a sometimes ragged crew of 24 replacement riders rode in the afternoon's nine races before a small and sometimes angry crowd of horseplayers.

title: Mellon and First Interstate Report Losses
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation and First Interstate Bancorp yesterday announced large losses in the third quarter as they made preparations for new companies to be spun off from the parent concerns.

title: Stone & Webster Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from the sale of investment securities of $2,823,000, or 37 cents a share, and $8,577,000, or $1.13 a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Revenue represents gross earnings. Latest-year 9 month gross earnings include $12,585,000 from the sale of securities.

title: Hirohito's Condition Worsens
description: The condition of Emperor Hirohito worsened today as he coughed up blood for the first time since his intestinal hemorrhaging began a month ago, Imperial Household officials said. Doctors gave the 87-year-old Emperor nearly two pints of blood that stablilized his condition, they said. The Emperor's daughter, Atsuko Ikeda, said he was awake but hardly responded to her when she visited him, Kyodo News Service said.

title: Kodak Buys I.B.M. Copier Agreements
description: The Eastman Kodak Company has agreed to buy the International Business Machine Corporation's existing copier service, sales and lease agreements in 16 countries. The deal follows a similar one in April that transferred I.B.M.'s United States copier service and sales agreements to Kodak, as of July 1, said a Kodak spokesman, Ron Roberts. Terms were not disclosed in either deal.

title: A Car Bomb in Southern Lebanon Kills 7 Israeli Soldiers and Hurts 8
description: Seven Israeli soldiers were killed and at least eight were wounded today in a car-bombing attack on an Israeli military convoy in southern Lebanon.

title: Broadcasters Shouldn't Quake Before Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: U.P.I. Offers New Services
description: Following through on its plan to expand into new areas, United Press International today announced a package of regional business news and stock indexes that the financially troubled company hopes will attract corporate customers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Walter F. Guarino has joined Albert Frank-Guenther Law as executive vice president and general manager.

title: Official Denies Anti-Semitism
description: An Education Department official denied today that she was motivated by anti-Semitism when she recommended withholding money from a Holocaust program that did not present Nazi views.

title: Bush, in Michigan, Travels Two Roads on the Campaign Trail
description: Vice President Bush traveled two distinct roads on the campaign trail today, proposing an early summit meeting to bolster the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and using the slaying of two Detroit police officers to question Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's opposition to the death penalty.

title: Hexcel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mercantile Bankshares Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Family Dollar Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Judge's Daughter Is 'Smiling Through Tears'
description: Sukhreet Gabel, a key prosecution witness in the Bess Myerson trial, described herself on a television show yesterday as ''smiling through tears.''

title: Southwestern Bell Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest third quarter net was increased by 5 cents a share by out-of- period adjustments, primarily related to other taxes, covering the years 1984 through 1987.

title: Bonn Plans Card Phone
description: West Germany will replace half its coin-operated public telephone booths with card phones by 1995, Post Minister Christian Schwarz-Schilling said today.

title: 2 in Politburo Ousted in Rift On Security in Afghan Capital
description: The Afghan Communist Party dismissed two Politburo members today as rebels showered rockets on Kabul, killing at least nine people.

title: MCI Communications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest third quarter included a pre-tax gain of $11 million from an antitrust settlement and a pre-tax charge of $8 million for contract settlements. The year-ago figures are restated to reflect accounting changes.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Addenda
description: LEAD: * McCall's will be increasing its ad rates by 7 percent, effective with the February 1989 issue.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: I HAVE a recipe suggesting that you fill half a pumpkin with Gruyere cheese, cream and chicken broth and bake it in the oven until the whole thing turns into soup-in-the-shell. Call me unimaginative, but I can't see myself serving this to one grown man who came late to basil and two little boys who once trashed an entire pot of meatballs because they found a bay leaf in the tomato sauce, and having everyone go, ''Wow! Gruyere cheese, cream, chicken broth and pumpkin soup! Let's chow down!''

title: McGraw-Hill Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Reforestation Money Spent on Firefighting
description: The Forest Service has raided a key reforestation trust fund to cover more than $500 million in firefighting expenses over the last two years, and the agency's budget director said today that he was not sure where money would come from next summer.

title: Allied Irish Offer To First Maryland
description: A special advisory committee to the board of First Maryland Bancorp said the company should reject a $327.6 million offer from Allied Irish Banks P.L.C. to buy the 50.3 percent of stock in the bank it does not already own. But the committee also recommended that the bank should continue discussions with Allied to seek a larger offer.

title: Pitney Bowes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Brawley Aftermath: Less Black Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Tom Lasorda's Emotional Edge
description: IN the minutes before last night's World Series game, the Dodgers were in their clubhouse at the Oakland Coliseum, watching NBC's pre-game show.

title: Yields Rise In Week
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose in the week ended yesterday.

title: Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the decline in third-quarter and year-to-date earnings reflect a drop in investor participation in financial markets and non- recurring merger-related expenses regarding the E.F. Hutton acquisition. The share earnings assume full conversion of the cumulative convertible preferred stock and certain options into common stock when dilutive. In the 1988 periods, the assumed conversion of the preferred stock was not dilutive and therefore not included. Prior-year results have been restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, named Brian E. Scott president of its new standard markets department in its Commercial Insurance division.

title: Health: Gynecology; New Tests Can Detect Viruses That Signal Risk of Cervical Cancer
description: Amid frightening reports that certain viruses that cause genital warts may play a role in cervical cancer, researchers are developing new tests that can detect the viruses soon after they enter the body. A woman who tests positive for one of the viruses should be monitored by her doctor so that any early abnormalities found in her cervix could be treated, removing the threat of cancer.

title: CONGRESS STRIVES FOR DRUG ACCORD AS MEMBERS LEAVE
description: House and Senate leaders struggled today to speed up a compromise on the final version of drug legislation as some frustrated lawmakers, particularly on the Senate side, abandoned the capital to campaign in their home states.

title: Beverly Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $657,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. The latest quarter includes pretax charges of about $6.2 million and $3.3 million relating to net loss in connection with the disposition of nursing home facilities as part of the company's debt restructuring program, and discounts, fees and expenses related to the sale of notes receivable to a real estate mortgage investment conduit, respectively.

title: Review/Dance; Phaedra's Tragedy in 2 Retellings
description: For the final week of its season, which concludes Sunday night, the Martha Graham Dance Company has introduced two more works by Miss Graham. ''Celebration,'' the 1934 stunner revived last year, is very much a plus. ''Phaedra's Dream,'' created in 1983, is something of a minus.

title: Sports People; New Hearns Opponent
description: James Kinchen will replace Fulgencio Obelmejias as the opponent for Thomas Hearns on a Nov. 4 boxing card in Las Vegas, Nev. Hearns was seeking his fifth world title against Obelmejias, the World Boxing Association supermiddleweight champion (168-pound limit). But Obelmejias said he had suffered an injury to his ribs when he announced Tuesday that he was pulling out of the bout. Kinchen has a 45-4-2 record with 32 knockouts and is the North America Boxing Federation supermiddleweight champion. Hearns, who lost his World Boxing Council middleweight title in June when Iran Barkley knocked him out, could be edged out of the distinction of winning five world titles by Ray Leonard, who will fight Donny Lalonde on Nov. 7 for Lalonde's W.B.C. light-heavyweight title and the new W.B.C. supermiddleweight title. . . . Angelo Dundee will not work Leonard's coming fight against Lalonde because of a dispute over negotiations for his pay, said Mike Trainer, Leonard's attorney. Dundee, who has been in Leonard's corner for every fight since Leonard became a professional nearly 12 years ago, will not work because he insists that his payment be negotiated by his attorney, Trainer said. (AP)

title: Federal Drug Agent Is Wounded And Dealer Is Killed in Shootout
description: A Federal drug agent was wounded last night during a shootout in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn in which one of four drug dealers was killed, the police said.

title: Hercules Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $5.4 million due to disposal of businesses for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes a gain of $533.8 million for both the quarter and 9 months from the sale of an affiliate, and the 9-month also includes a gain of $90.5 million from a stock offering.

title: Restoring Pieces Made Of Paper
description: LEAD: PAPIER-MACHE, which originated in Persia, eventually found its way to England, where a patent was issued in the 1770's. But it was not until the mid-19th century that it was at its most splendid. For a while, it was used to make just about every type of furniture and accessory. Papier-mache quickly caught on in the United

title: Washington Talk/Working Profile: Lauro F. Cavazos; In Search of a National Commitment to Education
description: When young Lauro F. Cavazos was ready to enter the third grade, his family moved from a house on the 800,000-acre King ranch, where his father was a cattle foreman, to the nearby town of Kingsville, Tex. The boy had attended the ranch's two-room, Hispanic elementary school. Now, his father said, Lauro would be the first Hispanic child to attend the town's Anglo school.

title: AMR Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Area in Queens Awaiting Bush, Many Indecisive
description: Pondering what George Bush means to him and what he means to George Bush, Thomas J. Macaluso, 37 years old, a real-estate broker in Middle Village, Queens, and the father of two boys, rolled back in his chair and, with his feet propped up, moved some papers away on the oak-top desk he had bought when the business grew.

title: Snap-On Tools Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mariner Offer to Piniella
description: Lou Piniella, dismissed 12 days ago as manager of the Yankees, received an offer this week to manage the Seattle Mariners and said today that he would make a decision by the weekend.

title: First Interstate Bancorporation reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter included a provision for the spinoff of about $400 million in non-performing assets and the addition of $180 million for loan and foreclosed property reserves of its Texas subsidiary.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Marine Memorial
description: Sunday, which is the fifth anniversary of the terrorist bombing at the Marine barracks in Beirut, will be marked by ceremonies at Camp Lejeune, N.C., and at Arlington Cemetery, according to Paul L. Corby, the chairman of the newly established Beirut Veterans of America.

title: 3 Apartheid Foes Leave U.S. Consulate
description: Three anti-apartheid leaders who escaped from detention and took refuge in the American Consulate 37 days ago walked out today, apparently on the advice of Nelson R. Mandela.

title: Review/Dance; The Ballet Hispanico Evokes Dance Halls Of 1930's Argentina
description: Ballet Hispanico opened a two-week season Tuesday night with a mixed bill enhanced by a vibrantly theatrical series of tango vignettes by Graciela Daniele, a choreographer better known on Broadway than in concert dance.

title: Trademark Bill Passed By House
description: Reflecting the growth in comparative advertising, the House today passed and sent to the Senate a sweeping rewrite of American trademark law. The bill would expand the right of a business to sue competitors that attack it in advertisements.

title: 407.48-Carat Diamond Fails to Sell at Christie's
description: The largest diamond ever to go up for auction - a 407.48-carat stone the size of a large strawberry - did not sell yesterday at Christie's.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Tuesday about the Rev. Jesse Jackson's efforts on behalf of the Dukakis campaign characterized their extent incorrectly. He has been campaigning steadily since Labor Day; his effort was not ''late.''

title: Lima Journal; Miguel Dukakis for President! 'Mom' Is So Proud
description: When Gov. Michael S. Dukakis traces his fluent Spanish and his interest in Latin America to his time as an exchange student here, an elderly Peruvian woman with strong political views visibly swells with pride over how well her ''North American son'' has done.

title: Dun & Bradstreet Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Excludes a gain taken by IMS from the disposal of discontinued operations of $15,093,000, or 80 cents a share in the first quarter of 1987. The company said year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of IMS International, which was accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Chesapeake Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes restructuring charges of $3,172,000 and $3,676,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Digital Equipment
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation has introduced the new Microvax 3300 and 3400 minicomputers, which will offer greater performance than its entry-level Microvax II systems and will replace older models in that line. Prices for the new models start at $40,950. The new systems will upgrade an industry favorite. Digital has sold more than 100,000 Microvax II systems in the last three and a half years, said Domenic La Clava, group vice president.

title: Mueller, Paul Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss of $190,000 for the quarter and a net of $998,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $4,979,000 for the quarter and $5,410,000 for the 9 months.

title: Revitalized Cabarets Seek a National Audience
description: WITHIN Manhattan's fiercely competitive cabaret world, this is the triple crown weekend. Simultaneously, Barbara Cook, Maureen McGovern and Andrea Marcovicci - three of cabaret's brightest stars - have arrived for extended engagements at, respectively, the Ballroom, Michael's Pub and the Oak Room at the Algonquin Hotel.

title: Auctions
description: 'War of the Worlds'

description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Official Praises Eastern-Bloc Changes
description: The American Deputy Secretary of State said today that he had found ''major institutional change'' taking place on his latest trip through Eastern Europe. But he acknowledged that some Bulgarian human-rights campaigners might have been arrested Wednesday because they tried to meet with him.

title: Protesters for Homeless Enter Quayle's Office
description: Police today arrested 19 demonstrators from Minnesota who crowded into Senator Dan Quayle's office on Capitol Hill to demand more aid to the homeless.

title: CONGRESS PASSES FRAUD CRACKDOWN AND HOMELESS AID
description: In a burst of energy created by its impending adjournment, Congress today approved in rapid succession bills to ban plastic weapons, assist the homeless, rewrite American trademark law and crack down on procurement fraud against the Government.

title: Britain Moves to Limit Right of Silence for Ulster Terrorist Suspects
description: The British Government moved today to limit the right to remain silent for suspects accused of terrorist crimes in Northern Ireland's courts. The move would allow judges to draw negative inferences against defendants who refuse to talk to the police or to the courts.

title: Hawkeye Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $7,446,000 from the extinguishment of debt.

title: Senator Proxmire's Monument
description: At last, at long last, after 40 years, the United States has joined 97 other countries in a treaty outlawing genocide. Approval should have come long ago when, with the horror of the Holocaust fresh, Harry Truman first sent the treaty to the Senate. That approval now comes at all testifies to the tenacity of Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, who retires this session.

title: Caterpillar Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Charles Schwab Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Latest third-quarter results include a $1.3 million pre-tax writeoff of deferred financing costs resulting from the prepayment of $47.3 million of LBP debt during the quarter, a full three years ahead of schedule. Results for 1987 are pro forma and give effect to the management-led leveraged buyout in March 1987, the sale of 8,000,000 common shares in the company's initial public offering in September 1987, and the application of the offering's net proceeds as if these events had occurred on Jan. 1, 1987.

title: Pittston Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $4,030,000 and $8,357,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the 9 months also include a gain of $9 million recognized in the first quarter from the subleasing of certain excess coal reserves. c-Includes tax benefits of $1,462,000 and $2,958,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and for both periods includes a charge of $1,596,000 from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Glenfed Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $9,475,000. The company said effective July 1, it changed its method of accounting for non-refundable fees and costs associated with originating loans to comply with the FASB statement No. 91, issued in December 1986. Financial statements and related information for prior years have been restated to apply the new method retroactively. The effect of the restatement on prior year figures due to an accounting change on the year-ago first quarter was a decrease of $5.6 million in earnings before extraordinary items, and an increase of $4.3 million in tax loss carryforwards; for a net decrease of $1.3 million in net earnings. The restatement also resulted in a net deferred credit of $126.2 million and a $79,755,000 reduction in stockholders' equity as of June 30, 1988.

title: Behind the Wave of Leveraged Buyouts, Huge Profit Potential
description: It is one of the amazing facts of financial life, circa 1988. Leveraged buyouts, once a minor factor in the takeover game, are now possible at the largest of companies, and investors are clamoring to finance such deals. If yesterday's proposal for a $17 billion leveraged buyout of RJR Nabisco is successful, it will rank not just as the largest leveraged buyout ever, but also as the largest takeover of any kind.

title: Dispute on Wastes Poses Threat To Operations at Weapon Plant
description: A political impasse over where to ship its radioactive wastes threatens continued operation of the Government's Rocky Flats nuclear weapon plant, already partly shut because of safety problems, officials said today.

title: BankAmerica Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $45 million for the quarter and $107 million for the 9 months. c-Net loss and included a $1.1 billion addition to reserves for credit losses. BankAmerica said that during the latest third quarter it placed $394 million of its $492 million portfolio of Argentine debt on a nonaccrual status. As a result, previous net income accrued but not received was reversed, reducing net income by $14 million. Also in latest quarter, as result of recent court ruling, non-interest expenses were reduced as reserves previously established for those legal matters became unnecessary and were reversed, increasing net by $17 million.

title: Bell Atlantic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Union Pacific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a special credit of $23 million resulting from an adjustment of the loss from a discontinued operation in 1986. Year-ago figures are restated to reflect full consolidation of Overnite Transportation Co.

title: Indiana, Michigan In Title Rivalry
description: Beware the road!

title: The Road From Racism
description: How far have race relations progressed in America?

title: Institutional Investor Post
description: Peter A. Derow, a former president of the CBS Publishing Group, has been named president of Institutional Investor Inc., succeeding Gilbert E. Kaplan, the company's founder, who has been chairman and president.

title: Dishonest Election Ad
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; Mamet's Unwiseguys
description: The gofer at the Tahoe airport pumps mob-soldier Jerry (Joe Mantegna) about the identity of Jerry's elderly, aloof traveling companion. Says Jerry with offhand cool, his eyebrow lifted a significant millimeter, ''He's the guy behind the guy behind the guy.'' The go-fer is impressed.

title: Sports of The Times; Lasorda's the Man With Everything
description: The scene of this fantasy is Tom Lasorda's office long after the Dodgers clinched the World Series last night. Outside, the fans are driving off into the night, wondering how the brawny hometown heroes could lose to these Dodgers in five games. In the office, everybody is sitting around eating linguine con vongole and listening to Lasorda talk about the Great Pasta Machine in the Sky. The phone rings.

title: Dukakis Aide Resigns Over Remark on Bush
description: Donna Brazile, deputy national field director of the Dukakis campaign, resigned last night after telling reporters covering the campaign that they should pursue rumors, which she did not document, about Vice President Bush's personal life. In resigning, she said: ''Today I made certain comments which I deeply regret. I believe too strongly in the importance of electing Mike Dukakis and Lloyd Bentsen to allow myself to become an issue in the campaign. Because the time is short, and the issues are so important, I have decided to leave the campaign. I wish Mike Dukakis and Lloyd Bentsen the best in the final weeks of the campaign.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Grand Bay Hotels Ads To Robinson, Yesawich
description: The Grand Bay Hotels of New York and Miami, operated by the Continental Companies, based in Miami, has named Robinson, Yesawich & Pepperdine of Orlando, Fla., to handle its advertising. The total budget exceeds $1 million. Warren/Kremer Advertising, in New York, was the former agency.

title: Review/Art; Kenji Fujita's Marriage Of Sense and Nonsense
description: Kenji Fujita's new wall sculptures, on view at Luhring, Augustine & Hodes gallery, combine a Minimalist love of material and physical fact with a taste for the Baroque. They brim over with gesture and the implied movement that the Minimalists consider anathema, but they insist upon a completely legible, self-evident structure that is the opposite of Baroque. This is the fourth one-man show for the artist, whose work was included in the Aperto section of last summer's Venice Biennale, and it may be his best.

title: First Florida Banks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Horse Racing Notebook; Jockeys Staying Away From Rich N.Y.R.A. Mile
description: The inaugural running of the first stakes race that the New York Racing Association named after itself will be run tomorrow amid one of the greatest crises in the association's history.

title: Pennbancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bid for RJR Nabisco Jolts Bonds
description: The corporate bond market was jolted yesterday by the $17 billion leveraged buyout offer for RJR Nabisco.

title: Review/Art; An Unwavering Vision: Donald Judd at Whitney
description: As welcome as it is, the Donald Judd retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art tries to do too much. In just three relatively small galleries and one barn of a space, and with only 30 works, it sets out to argue both for the continuity and consistency of the work and for its ultimate resistance to systematic analysis. It suggests Mr. Judd's gift and ambition as a designer and argues for his ability to move between sculpture, architecture and furniture and influence all three. Its weight is less on the Judd who will probably always be considered the high priest of Minimalism than on work in which generalizations about him are challenged.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 President P. W. Botha shelved a law that would have increased financial penalties on blacks and other nonwhite South Africans living in residential areas that are legally reserved for whites. Page A1

title: Clorox Company reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sheila Scott, 61, British Aviator
description: Sheila Scott, a British aviator who in 1971 became the first woman to pilot a flight circling the world by way of the North Pole in a light aircraft, died today of lung cancer, her literary agent said. She was 61 years old. Miss Scott, a former actress, flew her way into aviation history with more than 100 flying records, trophies and awards. She made three solo flights around the world and set records for single-handed London-Cape Town and Cape Town-London flights.

title: RJR Nabisco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $80 million from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Reviews/Theater; Light Banter and Dark Feelings in Gurney's 'Cocktail Hour'
description: ''Nobody goes to the theater anymore,'' says Bradley, the well-off 75-year-old WASP father who presides over ''The Cocktail Hour,'' the new A. R. Gurney comedy at the Promenade. As far as Bradley (Keene Curtis) and his wife, Ann (Nancy Marchand), are concerned, modern plays contain too much screaming and disrobing to lure them to Manhattan from their home in upstate New York. But this couple can still remember a distant time when ''wonderful plays'' regularly visited their local Erlanger Theater. A wonderful play was one featuring an attractive, ''very sophisticated'' couple - invariably the Lunts - a ''minor indiscretion'' and a happy ending. A wonderful play gave the audience something ''to celebrate at the end of the day.''

description: General Assembly POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. DECOLONIZATION COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. COUNCIL FOR NAMIBIA - 3 P.M.

title: Americans Win Paris With a Cancan
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov and American Ballet Theater were the toast of Paris Wednesday after they bowled over a high society audience with an effervescent cancan in a production of ''Gaite Parisienne.''

description: A look at the roots of Shakespeare's ''Comedy of Errors'' will highlight a ''Bard-a-thon,'' sponsored by the Riverside Shakespeare Company that begins today at the Shakespeare Center, 165 West 86th Street.

title: TV Weekend; 'Jack the Ripper' Promises Solution to Mystery
description: Beginning this evening and continuing on Sunday, both nights at 9, CBS is devoting four hours to a drama called ''Jack the Ripper.'' It seems we have reached the 100th anniversary of the notorious Ripper murders that took place in the East End of London from August to November 1888. The identity of the murderer has remained secret. The related Scotland Yard files were locked for years by royal decree.

title: Sundstrand Suspended by Pentagon
description: The Pentagon Wednesday suspended the Sundstrand Corporation as a Government contractor, temporarily cutting off the company from new contracts because of its admission last week of procurement fraud.

title: Reception Cool in Sale Of Nippon Phone Stock
description: The Japanese Government sold its third huge stake in the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation today, but found that the offering created none of the frenzy of buying that resulted when it first began selling off shares of the telecommunications giant.

title: All That Glitters Is Not Rolls
description: The City of Beverly Hills declared a $200,000 Rolls-Royce a public nuisance Wednesday and barred its owner from parking it in the same spot on Rodeo Drive for more than an hour at a time. Judge Edward Kakita of Superior Court issued an injunction against an art gallery owner, David Spellerberg, who parked his chauffeur-driven 1954 Rolls in the one-hour spot in front of his gallery for the last seven months.

title: New TV Spots Asssail Dukakis on Furloughs
description: An independent political committee today unveiled stark television advertisements showing a victim and the sister of a victim of crimes by a prisoner who was let out on furlough under a program supported by the Democratic Presidential nominee, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts.

title: 2D SUSPECT LINKED TO 1963 BOMBING
description: Law-enforcement officials here and in Alabama said today that they were interviewing a second potential suspect in the racially inspired 1963 bombing of a Birmingham church in which four black children died.

title: Still No Daylight For Giant Runners
description: If you wonder why the Giants are struggling with a 4-3 record, playing fairly well one game and not so well the next, look no farther than the running game. And if you wonder why the running game has been so erratic, look no farther than the health of the offensive linemen who block for the runners.

''Manon Lescaut'' was probably not the right choice for Pilar Lorengar, who has sung 13 roles in San Francisco over the last quarter-century.

description: There is political satire, there is political diatribe - and then there is Larry Kramer's ''Just Say No,'' a churlish assault on just about everybody in the governmental line of fire, and others the author might accuse of being guilty by reason of relationship. Combine beanball pitching and below-the-belt in-fighting and one might begin to have an idea of the show's aim.

description: Federal authorities said yesterday that they would look into whether there had been any civil rights violation in the death earlier this month of a black youth who was killed by a car on Staten Island. The youth was killed shortly after he and some friends had argued with a group of white men.

description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that, largely because of a slump in advertising volume, its third-quarter earnings declined 18.1 percent, to $26.7 million, or 33 cents a share, on consolidated revenues of $404.1 million.

title: WASHINGTON TALK:Briefing; Moving Day
description: Americans have long been a mobile people, but not until 1984 did the Government officially recognize that its own employees were part of that eternal and internal migration. In that year Congress passed a bill increasing relocation assistance to Government employees facing transfer, who now number 40,000 a year. For help in relocating employees, the Government turned to the private sector, namely the Employee Relocation Council, an association of corporations that routinely transfer employees.

title: Lounge Lizard
description: The Lounge Lizard, a jazz group, are to perform tonight and tomorrow at 8:30 and 11:30 at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880). Tickets are $12.50.

Digital Profits Are Off by 17%
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said today that its profits fell 17 percent, to $223.4 million, for the quarter ended Oct. 1 because of lower-than-expected sales of its high-end computer systems.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Are Up 3.2% on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest on the Big Board rose by 3.2 percent in the four-week period that ended last Friday.

title: Indian Point 3 Is Shut Down
description: The New York Power Authority shut down its Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant early today after a small amount of radioactive water mixed with water that turns the turbine generator. There was no public health threat, the authority said in a statement. The release of radioactive gas into the atmosphere was less than 0.1 percent of the level permitted by the Federal Government in normal plant operations. Plant officials termed it an ''unusual event,'' the lowest of four classifications for occurrences at nuclear power plants, the statement said.

title: When Prayers Are Questioned, Not Answered
description: When May Dooley was 5, her parents joined the Hendrickson Avenue Bible Church in Lynnbrook, a strict fundamentalist church. No drinking, no dancing and lots of churching, four times weekly. May carried a Bible to Lynnbrook High and, in her free time, passed out religious pamphlets. If classmates found her weird, she didn't care, for she was saved and destined for the Big H. She went upstate to Houghton College, a fundamentalist school. Vietnam was turning America upside down, but at Houghton, girls still wore gym shorts to their knees. Senior year, she broke the rules and for the first time snuck off to a movie, to see ''South Pacific.'' She returned home to teach science and English at Hicksville Junior High. After school, she ran Bible classes. Summers she was a missionary for Send the Light Inc.

title: Merger Is Set By Lloyds Unit
description: Lloyds Bank P.L.C., Britain's third-largest commercial bank, said today that it had agreed to merge its financial services arm with Abbey Life Group P.L.C. in return for a majority stake in the British life insurance company.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; CEBA Gives Awards for '88
description: CEBA, Communications Excellence to Black Audiences, presented its 1988 awards for the best advertising aimed at blacks, at a dinner last night at the New York Hilton.

title: A's Left to Puzzle Over Series That Didn't Add Up
description: By every measurement on the field and in the stands at the Oakland Coliseum, this has been a special baseball season. A franchise that once seemed headed to another town attracted nearly 2.3 million fans. A team that had established the goal of a championship as far ago as spring training was chasing greatness less than a week ago.

title: THE LAW: At the Bar
description: Sometimes it seems that for every lawyer happy with his or her lot, there are five others wishing they were somewhere else, like off writing novels or Broadway musicals. The fictional counterpart of these unhappy lawyers isn't Perry Mason; it's Walter Mitty.

title: The Long Arm of a Lawsuit Arrests History
description: In Robert Redford's movie, ''The Milagro Beanfield War,'' there is a wonderful symbol of how the dissemination of a free press sustains a civilized society. A bunch of tough guys sets out to burn every copy of a township's news sheet because it has an item that a local Mr. Big does not want Hispanic farmers to read. A magical breeze catches the flimsy sheets, floats them across a pure blue sky and down into the hands of everyone in the community.
