description: An electrical fire in the control tower at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport briefly halted flights there yesterday, causing delays, diversions and cancellations.

title: Stake in Pennwalt
description: Centaur Partners, a New York general partnership, said it had increased its stake in the Pennwalt Corporation to one million common shares, or 8.6 percent of the company. The group, led by Melvyn J. Estrin and Abbey J. Butler, had raised its stake last week to 8.5 percent. Pennwalt, a chemical company based in Philadelphia, earlier this month completed the sale of its worldwide pharmaceutical business.

title: Campaign Trail; Is It in His Eyes? No, It's in His Kiss
description: Unlike Mr. Kerrey, crowds in Missouri welcomed the Democratic standard-bearer with exuberance as the Dukakis bus entourage glided through Mark Twain country. Mr. Dukakis seemed buoyed by the reception, relaxed and - just as Kitty Dukakis and Iva Turner insist - a far more warm and cuddly fellow than he frequently appears. Iva Turner? Mrs. Turner, a sweet-faced, white-haired Missourian who could be Huck Finn's grandma, was in the midst of a large crowd at an elementary school, holding a hand-lettered sign that said: ''Tomorrow Is My Birthday. I'd Like a Kiss, but a Handshake Will Do.''

title: Angolan Rebel Town Tries to Mend the Maimed
description: Jonathan Muco, a sad young man in a faded campaign hat, waved a small red-and-green paper flag of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola. His wooden crutch was propped beside him, and the empty right trouser of his green military fatigues flapped as he joined with other maimed guerrillas in the rhythmical praise-singing of their leader, Jonas Savimbi.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Van Dorn Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Film; Six Hours of Dickens, With 'Little Dorrit'
description: Television's mini-series have given us a taste for literary adaptations that approximate the entire content of a long work. They've also evolved into what is virtually a new dramatic form. They helped prepare Broadway audiences for the Royal Shakespeare Company's eight-and-a-half-hour version of Charles Dickens's ''Nicholas Nickleby'' (1981), and they prompt one to anticipate - with a good deal of excitement - Christine Edzard's six-hour adaptation of ''Little Dorrit.''

title: Soft Money? No - Sewer Money
description: First, let's stop calling it ''soft money.'' That's the benign-sounding term politicians give to the tens of millions of dollars flooding into the campaigns of George Bush and Michael Dukakis from fat cat donors - violating the spirit, if not the letter, of Federal contribution and spending limits.

title: Restaurants
description: The Water Club

title: Alexander's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net income The loss in the latest year included a gain of $1,741,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: KEY RATES
Founder of U.S. Health Sells Out for $28 Million
description: When Frank Bond was a young man managing a finance company in Baltimore, he exercised at a Y.M.C.A. After he joined a private gym that was easier to get to than the Y.M.C.A., the gym offered him $10,000 a year as an instructor-salesman. ''It seemed kind of strange that you could earn money in a gym,'' Mr. Bond said yesterday.

title: Dining Out Guide: Pizza
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. (Full menus are offered at all the restaurants mentioned here.) Mezzogiorno

title: Piero Fornasetti, 74, Artist, Dies; Created Bold Furniture and China
description: Piero Fornasetti, an Italian artist and designer, died in Milan on Oct. 9. He was 74 years old. His son, Barnaba, said in a telephone interview yesterday that Mr. Fornasetti had had ''heart problems.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It has been a family business for 700 years. That is quite a long time.'' - Prince Rainier of Monaco. [ A4:3. ]

title: Yugoslav Session Deflates Even the Optimists
description: The three-day emergency meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee, which ended Wednesday, has disappointed Yugoslavs in general. But for many Serbians, anger is even greater than disappointment.

title: The New York Times Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included equity in earnings of forest products group of $6,302,000 for the quarter and $20,817,000 for the 9 months. c-Included equity in earnings of forest products group of $4,391,000 for the quarter and $10,936,000 for the 9 months.

title: Tragic Night: Top Detective Looks Back
description: Like most of his superiors and the 100 or so detectives in the hastily assembled task force he was supervising, Deputy Chief John V. Menken did not sleep Tuesday night - or much of Wednesday, for that matter. He laughs wearily when asked to recall what he was doing during those awful hours.

title: Exchange Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $736,000. c-Included tax credits of $1,689,000 for the quarter and $2,771,000 for the 9 months.

title: New Prize Announced In the Humanities
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities announced the Charles Frankel Prize today. It is to honor up to five individuals each year for bringing history, literature, philosophy and other humanities disciplines to general audiences.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Vampiring 101

title: Campaign Trail; Plenty of Questions, Too Little Help
description: With the free-spirited zaniness that one often associates with San Francisco politics, the city's voters are facing the election in some turmoil. The acting registrar of voters has decided to quit, declaring she is not in the mood to do her job anymore.

title: Time and Whittle Form Alliance
description: Time Inc. has agreed to pay $185 million for a half-interest in Whittle Communications, in a striking alliance between the country's most established magazine company and an independent entrepreneurial operation based in Knoxville, Tenn.

title: Nabisco Executives Offer $17 Billion for Company
description: Proposing the most expensive takeover in history, an investment group led by top executives of RJR Nabisco Inc. said yesterday that it wanted to buy the tobacco and food giant for $17 billion. The deal, which would be done in partnership with the Wall Street firm of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., would rely almost entirely on borrowed money.

title: American Express Net Falls Despite Gains in Key Areas
description: The American Express Company yesterday announced record third-quarter earnings for its travel and charge-card businesses and for its IDS Financial Services but weaker results at the American Express Bank.

title: As Israeli Parties Denounce Bombing, Effect on Vote Worries Some
description: Leaders of both major Israeli political parties today denounced the car-bomb attack that killed seven Israeli soldiers in southern Lebanon on Wednesday. Some Labor Party officials worried that the incident might affect the national elections 10 days from now by pushing some voters to the right.

title: Talks Resume On Tax Law
description: Negotiations that broke off earlier this week on legislation to make technical corrections in the 1986 tax law were on again today, reviving prospects for final action before Congress's expected adjournment on Friday.

title: CBS Records Unit to Move
description: CBS Records Inc., in the first significant management shift directed by its new corporate parent, the Sony Corporation, plans to move its classical music division from New York to Hamburg, West Germany.

title: Next President's Difficult Choices
description: HOW much does the outlook for the American economy depend on whether George Bush or Michael S. Dukakis is the next President? The stock market thinks it matters a great deal. On Wednesday, the first anniversary of the market's crash, stocks fell sharply on rumors that The Washington Post would publish an article damaging to Mr. Bush's electoral prospects; when The Post denied the rumors, the market began to recover.

title: Review/Art; The Letters of Artists: Some Belles, Some Not
description: ''Show and Tell: Artists' Illustrated Letters,'' at the Grey Art Gallery, is a large, subtly detailed and often amusing and revealing collection initiated and organized by Prof. Colin Eisler. ''Illustrated letter,'' in this context, means a letter from an artist in which image takes precedence, from time to time, over text.

title: Hit-and-Run Case Envelops Several in Florida
description: Thwarted by a judge's ruling that they cannot force a lawyer to name a client involved in a hit-and-run death, prosecutors ordered that sworn statements be taken today from nine people with cars similar to the one in the accident.

title: Ex-Officer Linked to Attacks
description: A former New York City police officer, serving a burglary sentence in an upstate prison, admitted today to a spree of sex attacks on women in Suffolk County, a Suffolk police spokesman said. The former officer, David Wood, 29 years old, of Babylon, was linked to the sex offenses by a recently installed police computer.

title: Review/Film; The Autumn Before Womanhood
description: It would be easy to think ill of a film that equates life's great mysteries with a secret formula for tomato sauce, but in the case of ''Mystic Pizza,'' it would also be a mistake. Though in essence this is little more than a girls' romance novel brought to life, it has been filled with heart and humor. The place, the people and even the largely predictable situations in which they find themselves are presented in an entirely winning way. ''Mystic Pizza'' offers warm, inviting and funny glimpses into the lives and loves of three appealing young women, who are just on the threshold of leaving the carefree years of their girlhood behind.

title: Dun & Bradstreet Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Excludes a gain taken by IMS from the disposal of discontinued operations of $15,093,000, or 8 cents a share in the first quarter of 1987. The company said year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of IMS International, which was accounted for as a pooling of interests. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Burlington Northern Names 2 Executives
description: Burlington Northern Inc., the large railroad company, announced yesterday that it would distribute its shares in its new resources unit to holders on Dec. 31 and named new chief executives for itself and the unit.

title: Devils to Take On Penguins' Lemieux
description: Now that Wayne Gretzky's first visit back to Edmonton as member of the Los Angeles Kings is done with, Mario Lemieux may start receiving the headlines he deserves.

title: Uneasy Mingling: When Small Talk at Parties Tackles Large Racial Issues
description: When Dr. Alvin Poussaint, associate professor of psychiatry at Harvard University, goes to certain kinds of parties, he tends to be on his guard.

title: Pretoria Retreats on Measure To Enforce Segregation Law
description: President P. W. Botha has shelved legislation that would have increased financial penalties on blacks and other nonwhite South Africans living in residential areas that are legally reserved for whites.

title: November Palestinian Parley
description: An often-postponed special session of the Palestine National Council has been pushed back yet again and is now scheduled to be held in Algiers on Nov. 8 or Nov. 10, Palestinian officials said this week. The officials had set the meeting for Oct. 31 but rescheduled the session so as not to interfere with a Nov. 3 referendum in which Algerians are to vote on revisions to their Constitution.

title: Books of The Times; Blunt's Treason: How, How Much, How Long?
description: Mask of Treachery By John Costello Illustrated. 765 pages. William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

title: Alleghany Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net gains on securities transactions of 15 cents and 16 cents a share for the latest quarter and 9-months, compared with securities gains of $1.62 for the year-ago quarter and $1.72 for the 9 months period. c-After a $5.1 million loss from discontinued operations. Year-ago quarter includes a fresh start tax benefit of 84 cents a share.

title: Boatmen's Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Negotiators for House and Senate In a Virtual Accord on Drug Bill
description: The House Appropriations Committee today called for $500 million in new spending for the fight against drugs as the House and Senate struggled to complete details of new drug legislation.

title: Discipline and Silence for a 'New Age' Priest
description: An obscure Roman Catholic priest, popular on the New Age lecture circuit but about to be silenced by the Vatican, today cast himself in the mold of Galileo, St. Thomas Aquinas and other Catholics who have been disciplined over the centuries by the church hierarchy.

title: American Express Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago third quarter results are restated to include deferred income tax benefits recorded to comply with FASB rules implemented in December 1987. The benefit for the 1987 9-month was $196 million, or 45 cents a share.

title: Amoco Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: Because of a production error, parts of two articles in some editions in Business Day on Thursday dealing with the Sundstrand Corporation were omitted. Both stories are reprinted today on page D4.

title: Cambodia Peace Plan Eludes Asian Nations
description: Officials from Southeast Asian nations failed today to agree on a plan to end the 10-year-old Cambodian conflict, but the participants pledged to meet in December to try again.

title: Appeals Court to Study Drexel Claim
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday blocked Federal Judge Milton Pollack from issuing any rulings in the Drexel Burnham Lambert securities fraud case while it evaluates charges by the investment firm that the judge has violated conflict of interest laws.

title: Final 3 People Picked for Jury For Steinberg
description: The final three members of the jury for the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg were chosen late yesterday, and opening statements are to start Tuesday.

title: To the Victors, $108,664.77
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers and the Oakland Athletics set records for winning and losing shares for World Series teams, with the winning share exceeding $100,000 for the first time.

title: The Slow Bear
description: In the morning, Soviet delegates talked at the United Nations with warm intensity and thoughtful detail of their vision of the organization - stronger, more active in peace, better prepared to prevent war, a place where all problems from disarmament through the poisoning of the air could find decent solution.

title: GAF Backs $1.47 Billion Heyman Proposal
description: After a year of on-again, off-again negotiations, the GAF Corporation said yesterday that a special committee of independent directors had accepted a $1.47 billion offer from a management group led by its chairman, Samuel J. Heyman.

title: Nashua Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Japan's U.S. Property Investment Has Only Begun
description: To the Editor:

title: Bringing Musicals To Young Audiences
description: They laugh uninhibitedly and they're not ashamed to cry. They are given to frenzied applause and intermittent cheering, and on occasion they'll even talk back to the actors, so compelled are they by the drama before them.

title: Equifax Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MCA Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Revco Will Sell Odd Lot to Riklis
description: Revco D.S. Inc., which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in July, agreed to sell its Odd Lot close-out subsidiary to the Riklis Family Corporation of New York. Revco said in a statement that it had signed a contract to sell Odd Lot Trading Inc. to two Riklis subsidiaries, OLT-I and OLT-W, for about $37.1 million.

title: Great Lakes Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
James J. McGuire, 82, Retired Police Inspector
description: James J. McGuire, a retired deputy chief inspector of the New York City Police Department and the former head of its Emergency Service Division, died of complications of kidney disease yesterday at his home in the Bronx. He was 82 years old.

title: Stone Container Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pacific Telesis Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results were restated to reflect consolidation of subsidiaries.

title: Citytrust Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago figures have been restated to reflect accounting changes.

title: Great Western Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Candidates Try Their Hand at Humor
description: The two men who have been calling each other terrible names sat down together tonight to eat an elegant dinner, separated only by John Cardinal O'Connor.

title: Discovery Engine's Cooling System Had Small Leak, NASA Reports
description: One of the engines that powered the space shuttle Discovery into orbit last month developed a small cooling-system leak and will be replaced for the ship's next scheduled flight in February, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title: Review/Opera; Revival of Haydn's 'Armida'
description: In instrumental music, Haydn was a pathbreaker, especially in his pioneering treatment of the string quartet as a conversation among four equal voices. In opera, he was far less adventurous, hewing fairly faithfully to the formalities of the opera-seria genre that in his lifetime was gasping its last. ''Armida,'' his second-to-last opera, is characteristic of the high Baroque style, with its legendary heroes and strings of wildly ornate arias. With the proper, technically proficient singers, it would deserve revival today, if only because Haydn is said to have considered it his finest dramatic work.

title: State Street Boston reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TW Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Race for Congress; Surging Republican Threatens to Cement Two-Party System in Mississippi
description: It was an old-fashioned Democratic fund-raising event - a ''beans and greens'' dinner in the local armory, where former Gov. Bill Allain dished out the turnip greens, black-eyed peas and ham, and the white-haired women of the Young at Heart Washboard Band serenaded the 150 diners with a version of ''Happy Days Are Here Again.''

title: Applied Magnetics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said figures were restated to reflect accounting change.

title: Baxter International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Edward A. Terres, Steamship Executive, 78
description: Edward A. Terres, a retired vice president of States Marine Isthmian Lines, a steamship company, died of liver cancer last Saturday at Alta Bates Hospital in Berkeley, Calif. He was 78 years old and lived in Oakland, Calif.

title: Campaign Trail; Meat and Potatoes Of Election '88
description: So Michael Dukakis and George Bush have some ideological differences. That's the least of it. There's the culinary gap, too. On the campaign trail, the Vice President treats room service like an Iran-contra question: with total avoidance. Instead, he consumes inordinate quantities of pork rinds, taco salads and tuna sandwiches on Air Force Two during the day, then almost invariably eats dinner at a restaurant selected by local politicians or people on his staff, where he mingles with patrons in some impromptu campaigning. (Even when at his official residence in Washington, Mr. Bush is known to have slipped out with his son George Jr. and tried a Chinese restaurant in nearby Arlington, Va.) Mr. Dukakis, on the other hand, rarely eats out, dining on room service food or, at times, delicacies offered by local Greek restaurants.

title: Marsh & McLennan Companies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
N.F.L. Matchups; No Love Lost in Philadelphia When Cowboys Meet Eagles
description: When the Dallas Cowboys played here last season, Buddy Ryan smacked them squarely in the face until they saw stars.

title: Lions Player in Crash
description: Three teen-age boys were killed and Reggie Rogers, a defensive end for the Detroit Lions, was injured seriously early yesterday in a two-vehicle crash in Pontiac, Mich. The police said the accident occurred at an intersection when a Jeep driven by Rogers struck a car carrying the driver, Kenneth J. Willet, 19 years old, of Drayton Plains, Mich., and his cousins from Versailles, Mo., Kelly Ess, 18, and Dale R. Ess, 17. Oakland County Prosecutor L. Brooks Patterson said he would decide today whether he would bring criminal charges against Rogers, who he said had run a red light. Rogers, 24, who was alone in his vehicle, was in guarded condition after being treated at Pontiac Osteopathic Hospital for a fractured neck, a partly severed right thumb, an injured right ear and multiple cuts and bruises. Dr. Robert Aranosian said Rogers would remain hospitalized for at least a week. He is the brother of Don Rogers, the former defensive back for U.C.L.A. and the Cleveland Browns who died in 1986 of a cocaine overdose. (AP)

title: Leader of Camp Denies Children Were Abused
description: The leader of a religious group whose daughter was killed at a camp in Oregon denied today on a television show that children were beaten or abused at the camp.

title: American Medical Internaional Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a $33,900,000 charge from the repurchase of debt and a $50,700,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Includes a $5,897,000 charge from the repurchase of debt. d-After a $5,897,000 charge from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Pinnacle West Capital reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes the establishment of a $46 million after-tax accounting reserve relating to certain real estate originally acquired by Suncor Development Partners in 1986. Latest quarter was also affected by a $9 million after-tax adjustment of Malapai Resources Co. uranium inventory balances to reflect current market values. c-Includes a $16,110,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Review/Film; A Nice Guy Shot Down in Vietnam
description: Gene Hackman, as Lieut. Col. Iceal Hambleton in ''Bat 21,'' radiates something not usually seen on the faces of war heroes: worry. Hambleton, whose real story is the basis for the film, is seen as a 53-year-old Air Force strategist who was quite literally pulled off the golf course to help out with a reconnaissance mission, during which he was unexpectedly shot down in Vietnam. The film, which details the elaborate Air Force effort to rescue Hambleton, is more the story of an ordinary man in extraordinary cirumstances than it is a familiar story of war.

title: Crompton & Knowles Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about third-quarter bank earnings misstated the timing of Marine Midland Bank Inc.'s tax-loss carryforward, which affected its latest earnings. The bank took the carryforward in the third quarter this year.

title: Campaign Trail; Loyalty, of Sorts, To the Ticket
description: With friends like Bob Kerrey, does Michael Dukakis need George Bush?

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for speical items.(Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Lafarge Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Wednesday about a ruling in the trial of Joel B. Steinberg misattributed the Constitutional guarantee of press freedom. It is embodied in the First Amendment.

title: Lomas Sets Price On 7-Year Notes
description: The Lomas & Nettleton Financial Corporation, the big mortgage banking company, yesterday offered $175 million of seven-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Estimate Panel Votes Funds for Drug Teams
description: The New York City Board of Estimate voted unanimously yesterday to transfer $32.9 million from a variety of city programs to pay for a widening effort to attack the drug trade in specific neighborhoods.

title: Icons of the Wild West At Pier Antiques Show
description: WESTWARD HO - the theme of this year's Fall Antiques Show at the Pier - is heralded at the entrance to the fair with a late 19th-century American icon: a covered wagon.

title: Beatrice Braude, 75; Challenged Blacklist
description: Dr. Beatrice Braude, a retired professor of French and former radio producer, died Sunday of brain cancer at the Hebrew Home of Greater Washington in Rockville, Md. She was 75 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Michigan National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Disciplined Black Lawyer Posthumously Reinstated to Florida Bar
description: A black man who fought for almost 30 years for the right to practice law in Florida was posthumously reinstated today to the Florida bar by a unanimous State Supreme Court.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Washington in D.C.
description: A favored pastime of tourists visiting the capital has been to pose for a sidewalk photo with cardboard cutout figures of such political celebrities as President Reagan, Vice President Bush, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: Sun Microsystems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Colgate-Palmolive Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $13,087,000 for the quarter and $40,134,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $14,718,000 and $42,820,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said that, for purposes of comparison, the 1987 income and earnings per share exclude a net restructuring charge of $150 million, or $2.20 a share and $2.18 a share for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The final net income for the 1987 quarter and 9 months periods reflects a net charge of $150,000 for the implementation of a restructuring program. Discontinued operations include the results of the Kendall Health Care business, which is in the process of being divested. The company also said two Kendall operations were sold at the end of 1987.

title: Shawmut National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $24.9 million from the settlement of certain pension plan obligations and the revision of acturial pension plan assumptions.

title: Hazel Hertzberg, 70, Professor and Author
description: Hazel W. Hertzberg, who taught history and education at Teachers College of Columbia University and was an authority on American Indian history, died Wednesday while attending a conference in Rome. She was 70 years old and lived in Palisades, N.Y.

title: No Pretoria Trip for Zairian
description: In an apparent setback to Pretoria's diplomatic offensive in Africa, a visit to South Africa by Zaire's Foreign Minister, Nguza Karl-i-Bond, that had been scheduled for today was suddenly postponed. Only hours after the South African Foreign Ministry announced the visit Wednesday night, Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said the planned three-day visit had been postponed due to ''unforeseen circumstances.''

title: Gerber Products Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $2,000,000 from discontinued operations for both the quarter and 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $10,871,000 and $10,325,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Calfed Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect accounting changes.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Sine of Impatience
description: Members of Congress, ever more impatient to go home, replaced their FREE THE 100th CONGRESS buttons yesterday with new ones bearing the legend ''Sign or Die,'' a variant on Sine Die, the Latin phrase for adjourning indefinitely.

title: Foes Save Funds for Final TV Blitz, Reports Show
description: Both Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts entered the final five weeks of the Presidential campaign with more than half of their $46.1 million in Federal funds.

title: Tyson May Box in U.S.
description: Mike Tyson's title defense against Frank Bruno, which has shifted dates several times, appears to be heading for a change of sites.

title: Harris Bankcorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The year-ago periods reflected a $50 million special provision for possible credit losses.

title: Wind Is Buoying Hope For 3 Trapped Whales
description: An easterly wind that was breaking pathways in Artic ice buoyed hopes today for three whales trapped in Artic ice off the coast here.

title: U.S. Customs Officers Seize Imported Uniform Patches
description: United States Customs inspectors today seized as illegal an order of 5,000 imported patches that were to have been worn by Customs inspectors commemorating the agency's 200th anniversary in 1989, the head of their union said.

title: Owens & Minor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Garbage Man
description: A charge by one Stuart Piper, the executive director of the Illinois Republican State Central Committee, is a measure of the depths to which the Bush ''Presidential'' campaign has sunk.

title: Western Digital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $160,000.

title: A Push for Peace in Korea
description: Another piece of cold war orthodoxy yielded Tuesday when President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea took the podium at the United Nations. It marked the first time that the leader of South Korea, the only country the U.N. ever went to war to protect, has ever addressed that body. And Mr. Roh used the occasion to launch a courageous and creative diplomatic proposal to bring peace to his peninsula, an effort worthy of the strides he has made toward democracy at home.

title: CSX Sets $32 Price In Stock Buyback
description: The CSX Corporation set a price of $32 on 40 million shares of stock it offered to buy back last month. The offer was oversubscribed when it expired at midnight Tuesday, the company said.

title: Poll Lifts Lieberman From the 'Can't Win' Depths
description: Since announcing as a candidate for the Senate in February, Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman has been considered an underdog at best.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: A.&P. raised its bid by $2, to $32 in cash, for each common share of Delchamps Inc., the supermarket chain, which is based in Mobile, Ala. Delchamps, which last week rejected the previous offer, has seven million common shares outstanding, so the total takeover offer now stands at $224 million.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: F. Ross Johnson; A Chief Willing to Gamble
description: In the world of corporate takeovers, many chief executives resist having their company acquired. Not F. Ross Johnson, chief executive of RJR Nabisco.

title: General Signal Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest quarter was due to special charges, resulting from the writeoff of operating problems associated with the company's ongoing businesses. It said these charges, which included provisions for inventories, receivables, legal and environmental exposures, as well as termination and severance costs, amounted to approximately $36 million before taxes.

title: Figgie International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Perles's Reward
description: Last January, Coach George Perles of Michigan State rejected a $2.2 million offer to coach the Green Bay Packers. Yesterday, a report by the university indicated that Perles was rewarded for his loyalty to the Spartans. In a 10-year contract, Perles has an annual salary of $105,000, plus the use of two automobiles and a country-club membership. If Perles, 54 years old, remains at Michigan State as a coach or teacher beyond Jan. 1, 1993, he will receive for the rest of his life $45,000 a year in monthly payments of $3,750 beginning in December 1997. (AP)

title: MARCOS MAY FACE INDICTMENT TODAY
description: A Federal prosecutor is expected to seek an indictment of Ferdinand E. Marcos as early as Friday on charges that he fraudulently acquired Manhattan real estate valued at hundreds of millions of dollars, a Reagan Administration official said today.

title: Russians in Marathon
description: For the second time in the 19-year history of the event, runners from the Soviet Union will take part in the New York City Marathon on Nov. 6. In 1982, four Soviet runners took part. This year's runners will include Tatyana Polovinskaya, who finished fourth in the women's Olympic Marathon in Seoul, South Korea, with a Soviet record of 2 hours 27 minutes 5 seconds; Raisa Smekhnova, Alevtina Chasova and Irina Petrova. The men competing will be Nikolai Tabak, whose career best of 2:10:19 is only 15 seconds off the Soviet record; Yuri Porotov and Rustam Shaviev.

title: Paper Says Frenchmen Flew Iraqi Missions
description: French pilots flew combat missions with the Iraqi Air Force against Iran for several months in 1983 and 1984 and may have taken part in planning attacks against Iranian targets during the eight-year gulf war, a French weekly has reported.

title: Dauphin Deposit Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lonrho Shares Up On Stake Rumors
description: Shares in Lonrho P.L.C., the big British conglomerate, rose in heavy trading today, spurred by persistent rumors that the Bond Corporation of Australia or some other big interest was building a stake. More than 29 million shares changed hands on the London Stock Exchange.

title: Squibb Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WASHINGTON TALK: The Senate; Chiles to Continue Fight Very Close to His Heart
description: The legislative agendas of members of Congress are normally dominated by obligations to the interest of their party, state and constituents. Only rarely do matters of the heart intrude on lawmakers' calendars, although that has been case of Senator Lawton Chiles of Florida in his efforts to try to reduce the number of infant deaths in America.

title: McDonald's Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $47.4 million from an accounting change.

title: How It Happened; Reversal Of Roles At Plate
description: The Athletics did not try to make excuses for their unproductive swinging, but Lefebvre did mention one possible reason for it.

title: Spritz Your Bic
description: It was the handiness of it all that bound the Bic Cricket to the heart. No more flints, no more spilling lighter fluid, no more futile presses from a feeble thumb. It was the chic of it, too. One former smoker still cherishes the memory of the Bic she wore slung on a leather thong around her neck.

title: Lincoln Journal; Nebraska's First Man Enjoys the Last Laughs
description: Bill Orr, who is married to Gov. Kay A. Orr, went to cash a check the other day at a local bank.

title: New York Plan to Dredge Hudson for PCB's Draws Fire
description: After more than a decade of planning, state officials have developed a $40 million proposal to remove PCB's from a portion of the Hudson River near here - almost 200 miles north of New York City - and bury them on what is now a dairy farm.

title: Gastineau Tells the Jets He Is Quitting
description: Mark Gastineau of the Jets, one of the National Football League's top pass rushers, suddenly quit football today, apparently distraught because his fiancee has cancer.

title: T.W.A. Deal For Planes Is Expected
description: Trans World Airlines Inc. will soon lease or buy as many as 60 new airplanes worth up to $1.5 billion to help revamp its aging fleet, a person close to the company said yesterday.

title: Asarco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $88,499,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. The third quarter and 9-month 1987 earnings included pre-tax profits of $222 million from the sale of shares of M.I.M. Holdings Ltd., an associated company in Australia, and shares of Asarco Australia Ltd., a gold mining company. They also included an extraordinary tax credit of $88 million resulting from utilization of all of Asarco's net operating loss carryforwards. The company said that after deducting all non-recurring nature, Asarco's 1987 9-month earnings were $10,140,000, or a loss of 18 cents a share after allowance for preferred stock dividends.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Quartet With 'Lion'

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Wednesday about the disqualification of Rabbi Meir Kahane's party from the Israeli elections translated the party's name incorrectly. The name, Kach, means ''thus'' or ''this way.''

title: Bush and Dukakis Trade Accusations Over Crime
description: Vice President Bush and Michael S. Dukakis traded charges of poor records on crime as they campaigned through the New York area yesterday on their way to a shared stage at the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Dinner of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese.

title: Legal Briefs
description: Unofficial Official I

title: Review/Film; The Forked Tongue of Ken Russell
description: Not a worm is left unturned in Ken Russell's buoyant, mischievous and predictably overwrought new film, loosely based on the last novel by the author of ''Dracula,'' Bram Stoker. ''The Lair of the White Worm'' (from Stoker's 1911 novel, published in America under the title ''The Garden of Evil'') incorporates every imaginable worm and serpent double-entendre. Though no film of Mr. Russell's would be anywhere without an overabundance of phallic symbolism, that barely scratches the surface of the imagery to be found in this one.

title: Sotheby's to Auction von Bulow Collection
description: SOTHEBY'S lips are sealed, but mention its Oct. 28 and 29 sale entitled ''Property From a Private Collection'' to any serious dealer or collector and the reaction will immediately be nods or winks. Word is out in the art and antiques world that the sale's handsome hardback catalogue shows the furniture, paintings, silver and objects belonging to Claus and Martha (Sunny) von Bulow.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Monday about Gladys Lopez Espinoza's preparation of medicines in Matamoros, Mexico, misidentifed the shop in which she was working. It was an herberia, or herb shop, where folk remedies are sold. Many people cross the border to buy medicines that are not readily available in the United States.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Burmah Oil P.L.C., Swindon, England, will spend $46 million to purchase Chem-Trend Inc., a supplier of metalworking fluids and lubricants based near Detroit.

title: Warsaw Eases Its Grip on the Press
description: When two journalists from The Reporter, a quiet monthly, interviewed Lech Walesa in Gdansk last month, the censors refused to allow publication, and the paper's editors declined to get pushy about it.

title: Senate Approves Joining Copyright Convention
description: After more than 100 years, the Senate approved American participation in the Bern copyright treaty today in an action that will help Americans protect their copyrighted material abroad.

title: Interco Raises Payouts And Rejects Higher Bid
description: Interco Inc. today rejected as inadequate the Cardinal Acquisition Corporation's sweetened buyout offer and increased dividend payouts under a restructuring program.

title: Seamen's Prices $200 Million Offer
description: The Seamen's Capital Corporation yesterday priced a $200 million offering of mortgage-backed securities.

title: Gillette Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FMC Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a $10,700,000 extraordinary loss from the writeoff of deferred recapitalization costs.

title: QUAYLE PARALLEL DRAWS OBJECTIONS
description: NBC has stopped broadcasting a promotional spot for a sex-and-politics mini-series, ''Favorite Son,'' after Republican officials complained that the ads seemed to be referring to Senator Dan Quayle.

title: Bowater Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dominion Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Court Upholds Resident Rule For the Police
description: New York State's highest court upheld a rule yesterday requiring New York City firefighters, police officers and jail guards to live in the city or one of six nearby New York counties.

title: Di Giorgio Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-Includes income of $862,000 for the quarter and a loss of $16,070,000 for the 9 months both from discontinued operations, and the 9-month also includes a $1,117,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: About Real Estate; A Surge of Housing on Staten Island
description: New Lane, in the Rosebank section of Staten Island, is already about a hundred years old, despite its name. This short, scruffy road becomes a dead end at the rocky beach on the island's north shore amid a hodgepodge of worn Victorian houses and graffiti-covered industrial buildings.

title: Review/Film; The Case Of an Identity Crisis
description: ''Without a Clue,'' opening today at the Guild and other theaters, is an appallingly witless sendup of the Sherlock Holmes-Dr. Watson stories, based on an idea that wouldn't support a five-minute revue sketch, much less a feature film for Michael Caine and Ben Kingsley.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker; Science Can Tag Along On North Shore Holiday
description: For more than a century, this tiny village on the North Shore of Long Island has swung with the times, readapting itself as a center of the whaling industry, as a summer community that attracted the cream of New York society and, most recently, as a tranquil district of boutiques, antiques shops and art galleries.

title: Yellow Freight System Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Behind the Surge For Alexander's
description: WITH department store sales lackluster, something else must be responsible for the rise in Alexander's Inc. stock by $12.125 a share since Oct. 7. It closed yesterday at $75.125, up $3.875, after rising $3 on Wednesday.

title: Boeing Jet Orders
description: Three foreign airlines have ordered a total of five jets, worth about $520 million, from the Boeing Company. Qantas, Australia's international carrier, ordered two 747-400's costing an estimated $320 million. Qantas now has eight of the latest 747's on order, with options on 17 more. Icelandair ordered two 757-200's worth $100 million and took an option on a third. Malaysia Airlines ordered one 747-400, valued at more than $120 million.

title: Bear Stearns Companies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the quarter reflect the change in Bear Stearns' fiscal year to June 30 from April 30. The company said year-ago figures were restated to conform to current fiscal year presentation.

title: Lilibet of London Visits Cousin Juanito, the King
description: He calls her Lilibet. She addresses him as Juanito.

title: Nynex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Loctite Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Horizon Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Times Mirror Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of 14 cents a share from the sale of Timberlands for the quarter; the 9 months include a gain of 30 cents a share from the sale of Timberlands and the January sale of Times Mirror Press. c-Includes a gain of 3 cents and 8 cents a share for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from the Timberland sales.

title: Antonie Stolper, Author, 97
description: Antonie Stolper, an author who was active in refugee affairs during World War II, died Tuesday at her home in Alexandria, Va. She was 97 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Art Directors Putting 3 in Hall of Fame
description: MICHAEL TESCH sat in his too-small, too-cluttered office at Ally & Gargano yesterday morning and screened a 1980 commercial that reflected his art director's eye. From the opening shot, the ad evoked autumnal France - gray and brown hues, grainy film, romantic music with a mere hint of discord. A young man asks his sultry female companion where her beautiful coat came from. Her coquettish reply humorously breaks the Gallic mood. ''Barneys,'' she says, referring to the New York clothing store.

title: F.A.A. Orders Test of Takeoff Alarms
description: The takeoff warning systems on almost 2,000 jetliners were ordered yesterday to be subjected to repeated tests after a survey prompted by a Boeing 727 crash in Texas last August showed that ''a significant number'' of the systems on 727's were not working properly.

title: Textron Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from early redemption of debt of $9,700,000 and a loss from arbitration concerning a former line of business of $20 million. c-Includes a gain on sales of discontinued operations of $24,300,000 and a loss from early redemption of debt of $25,900,000 for both periods; quarter also includes a loss from discontinued operations of $900,000, and the 9 months also include a gain from discontinued operations of $2,100,000. The company said a 7-week strike at its Lycoming turbine engine division, settled in July, adversely affected the results in both the second and third quarters.

title: Israel Seizes Dozens in Effort To Curb a Moslem Movement
description: Trying to neutralize a powerful Moslem fundamentalist group based here, Israeli officials have imprisoned dozens of Palestinian scholars, preachers and others thought to make up its middle and lower ranks.

title: Review/Television; Peanuts Become Pilgrims
description: ''This is America, Charlie Brown!'' plops down the Peanuts characters on the gangplank of the Mayflower. We never know how they came to be among the Pilgrims, but that storybook conceit is nothing next to the program's most unusual feature. ''The Voyage of the Mayflower,'' the first episode in this eight-part series, is an animated history lesson for very young children, but a lesson with a surprisingly somber and realistic layer beneath its candy coating. ''The Voyage of the Mayflower'' will be shown tonight at 8 on CBS.

title: Auditor Says Contractor Tried to Impede Search
description: The procurement scheme by the Sundstrand Corporation, the Illinois military contractor that agreed last week to plead guilty to the largest military fraud in history, was designed by upper- and middle-management Sundstrand executives, the Government auditor who led Federal prosecutors to the case said.

title: In Paris, Fashion Takes On a Jaunty Air
description: In the first days of the spring and summer ready-to-wear showings, several designers made their mark. Christian Lacroix proved he was a sparkling fashion original, even without the pouf that catapulted him to fame just two years ago. Patrick Kelly got a rousing reception on Wednesday at his first presentation here in the courtyard of the Louvre.

title: Mattingly Draws Interest of 4 Teams
description: Don Mattingly, the subject of trade rumors since he criticized Yankee management in August, is continuing to attract attention from at least two teams in each league, according to General Manager Bob Quinn. And the Yankees are listening.

title: Shearson Cuts Research Staff
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. has laid off about 13 percent of the investment bank's equity research staff, a spokesman for the company said yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Coca-Cola Co., Atlanta, said John W. Georgas would succeed Claus M. Halle, who plans to retire as president of the company's international soft-drink business as of May 31.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Edberg and Becker Advance: Top-seeded Stefan Edberg won easily, but second-seeded Boris Becker struggled yesterday as both advanced to the quarterfinals of the Seiko Super tournament in Tokyo. Edberg, the defending champion, won the first set against Chris Pridham easily, then used a strong service game to fight off the Canadian, who is ranked 119th in the world, 6-1, 7-5. ''I lost my concentration because the next court was so loud,'' Edberg said of the second set, referring to the noise generated by Shuzo Matsuoka's 7-5, 7-6, defeat of Marty Davis before 6,800 fans at the Yoyogi National Stadium.

title: Soviets Promote Ex-Envoy Cool to U.S.
description: A former Ambassador whose policy views include a conspicuous coolness toward the United States has been appointed head of an important Soviet foreign-policy panel, the Government said today.

title: REAGAN ENVISIONS KOREA TROOP CUT
description: President Reagan said today that there was a possibility that the United States would reduce its military forces in South Korea if, at some future date, they were ''no longer needed'' because of a reduction in tensions in the region.

title: Nuns' Protest Illuminates a Cloistered Order
description: The Carmelite monastery on Route 24 here was built as a sanctuary from the turmoil of daily life, a sylvan setting where nuns could spend cloistered lives in prayer, silence and solitude.

title: Lasorda's Darlings
description: They were the Foreign Legion of baseball, the refugees and expatriates, the irregular army that limped and conquered, and they were led by an uncommon pitcher who sat on the bench with his eyes closed between innings and sang hymns to himself.

title: Review/Music; Prague Symphony's Sounds of Home
description: Visiting orchestras have one of two mandates - either to bring us music we know less of and should know more, or else something that is indissolubly their own. Much of the Prague Symphony's program at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night was all too familiar, but such pieces as Smetana's ''Moldau'' and the Dvorak Eighth Symphony become suddenly more interesting when we know that the composers and their interpreters spring from a single national source.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 452 money market mutual funds increased by $1.18 billion, to $268.76 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 127 institutional funds were up by $348.10 million, to $69.55 billion. Those of the 223 general purpose funds were up by $325.7 million, to $85.36 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds rose by $508.90 million, to $113.85 billion, the institute said.

title: First Wisconsin Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $57.2 million, or $2.68 per share, from the sale of the company's headquarters real estate and from income tax benefits resulting from provisions made during 1987 for less developed countries loan losses. c-Net loss and attributable to the $96 million loan loss provision made for loans to less developed countries.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Andiamo!

title: Southern New England Teleommunications reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Northern Trust
description: The Northern Trust Corporation of Chicago, which now operates in Florida, Arizona and California as well as Illinois, will expand into Texas with the acquisition of the Concorde Bank of Dallas, a $70 million institution specializing in private banking services for the wealthy. Northern Trust, which has $9.4 billion in assets, paid $11.8 million for Concorde, which was founded with $10 million in capital three years ago. The Dallas bank will keep its managers and will be renamed Northern Trust Bank/Dallas, a Northern spokesman said.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY CHEAP READS

title: Irony in Endive: Republicans Endorsed It First
description: To the Editor:

title: Rise in Allies' Lending to Soviets Divides U.S.
description: A surge of foreign bank lending to the Soviet Union is causing sharp divisions within the Reagan Administration and deep disquiet in Congress, where the Senate has already called on the President to study the impact of the credits on national security.

title: A.T.&T. Net Rises 16.2% In Quarter
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that its net income rose 16.2 percent in the third quarter on a 3.2 percent increase in revenues compared with the corresponding period last year.

title: Review/Theater; Out of the Ibsen Closet Comes a New 'Ghosts'
description: The Roundabout Theater earns credit for turning out a production of ''Ghosts'' that, for most of the way, does not tickle the audience into unwanted laughs. A small tribute, perhaps, but how much better can a company do today with Ibsen's sins-of-the-father drama? Plays that arouse indignation at first sight, as ''Ghosts'' resoundingly did in 1881, have a way after a while of inviting parody.

title: Monaco Journal; He's the Man Who Runs the Bank at Monte Carlo
description: The chief executive officer of Monaco Inc. was urbanely pushing the merits of his ancient enterprise, which occupies a choice piece of Mediterranean seaside property about the size of Central Park.

title: Robert Moberly, 49, Stage and TV Actor
description: Robert Moberly, a stage and television actor who appeared on Broadway and in regional theater, died of AIDS Monday in Los Angeles. He was 49 years old.

title: CCB Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $1.6 million from a change in accounting.

title: On Stage
description: Next for Epstein: 'Robbers'

title: Campaign Trail; Live, From D.C., It's Michael Dukakis
description: Michael S. Dukakis has agreed to a 90-minute interview with Ted Koppel on ABC next Tuesday night, part of an ambitious strategy by the Democratic Presidential nominee to step up his appearances over national television in the campaign's final weeks.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Coach Rick Pitino has appointed Mark Jackson, last season's National Basketball Association rookie of the year, and Patrick Ewing, the 7-foot center, as co-captains of the Knicks. After missing the first three preseason games with a bruise over his right knee, Ewing scored 27 points Wednesday night in a 95-94 exhibition game loss to the Indiana Pacers. . . . The Soviet Union has granted approval for Aleksandr Volkov, a 6-8 forward on the Soviet Olympic basketball team, to negotiate with N.B.A. teams, the Cleveland-based sports agency International Management Group said yesterday. Volkov was a sixth-round draft pick of the Atlanta Hawks in 1986, but the agency said he was a free agent. . . . Michael Fennessey, an attorney for Angel Myers, said the swimmer would appeal sanctions imposed by United States Swimming Inc. stemming from a drug test that found anabolic steroids in her system at the Olympic trials last August. She was disqualified from the American team. Myers has blamed birth-control pills for the positive test.

title: Zenith Back In the Black
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation, which has come under sharp criticism from Brookhurst Partners L.P., a dissident shareholder group, today reported third-quarter net income of $3 million, in contrast to a loss of $25.1 million for the comparable period a year ago.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Soviets Are Reported Likely To Let Sakharov Visit U.S.
description: A senior Soviet scientist has told American colleagues that Andrei D. Sakharov will probably be permitted to travel to the United States next month. It would be the first visit to the West by the physicist and human rights campaigner.

title: 5% Perpetual Stake Is Bought by Haft
description: Robert H. Haft, who with his father has attempted takeovers of several leading retail companies, has acquired a minority interest in the Perpetual Financial Corporation, based in Washington. Mr. Haft, who purchased 5 percent of Perpetual's stock, said, ''I believe the enterprise has a bright future.'' Perpetual Financial is the holding company for the Perpetual Savings Bank, the largest savings institution in the Washington area.

title: No Insurers' Windfall
description: To the Editor:

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums STORY HOUR IN FRENCH, a program for ages 6 to 8, including picture books and old and new tales, 4 P.M. today, at the French Institute-Alliance Franc,aise, 22 East 60th Street. Admission: $1. Information: 355-6100, extension 215. ''GHOSTS AND GOBLINS,'' a Lolli-Pops Concert for children by the Little Orchestra Society, directed by Dino Anagnost, with music by Saint-Saens, Ives, Prokofiev and others, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. tomorrow, at Avery Fisher Hall. Tickets: $20. Information: 704-2100. SATURDAY AT STEINER, TALES OF MANY LANDS, a program of stories and humorous poems, 2 P.M. tomorrow, at the Rudolf Steiner School, 15 East 79th Street. Children, $3; adults, $5. Information: 535-2130. ''THE MAGIC FISHBONE,'' a musical based on a Charles Dickens story, performed by On Stage, Children, directed by Alice Elliott, 1 and 3:30 P.M. tomorrow, at Hartley House Theater, 413 West 46th Street. Tickets: $5. Information: 666-1716. ''BUGS AND BALLOONS,'' a show with Allynn Gooen and audience participation, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Puppet Playhouse, the Murphy Center at Asphalt Green, 555 East 90th Street. Admission: $3. Reservations recommended. Information: 369-8890. ''PETER AND THE WOLF'' AND ''THE FROG PRINCE,'' two shows presented by Puppetworks, 1 and 3 P.M. Sunday, at 287 Third Avenue at Carroll Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn. Tickets: children, $3.75; adults, $4. Reservations: (718) 834-1828. STORY HOUR, a 45-minute program for ages 3 to 6, with refreshments, 11 A.M. Sunday at Eeyore's Books for Children, 2212 Broadway, at 79th Street (362-0634) and at 12:30 P.M. Sunday, at Eeyore's, 25 East 83d Street (988-3404). Free. ''THE FUNZAPOPPIN MAGIC SHOW,'' a program of comedy and magic, presented by Michael Taubenslag Productions, 1:30 P.M. Sunday, at the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street. Tickets: $4.50. Reservations: 772-9180. ''PINOCCHIO,'' a musical version of the Collodi story, performed by the Theater Workshop, 1 and 3:30 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, at the Fantasy Playhouse, 317 Merrick Road, Lynbrook, L.I. Tickets: $5. Reservations: (516) 599-1982. OLD MERCHANTS HOUSE, the 1832 Seabury Tredwell House, which the Tredwell family occupied for almost 100 years, containing original furniture and family memorabilia, with three floors on view. The house is open from 1 to 4 P.M. Sundays. Children under 12, free; students and the elderly, $1; others, $2. At 29 East Fourth Street. Information: 777-1089. ''THE ROSE THAT REFUSED TO BLOOM,'' a musical with audience participation, 1 and 3 P.M. Saturdays, and ''The Snow White Show,'' a musical, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays, at the 13th Street Repertory Company, 50 West 13th Street. Tickets: $4. Information: 675-6677. MYSTIC (CONN.) SEAPORT, a 17-acre outdoor maritime museum with historic ships, exhibition buildings and two restaurants. Open 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily. Admission: adults, $11; children, $5.50; under 4, free. Information: (203) 572-0711.

title: The Dodgers' Improbable Dream Comes True
description: The last pitch of the season sailed through the strike zone and seemed to freeze in time. Orel Hershiser, his work finally done, took several steps off the mound, tilted his head back and looked into the darkened sky. Then, suddenly, he was hoisted into the air. He allowed himself a smile. The night belonged to Hershiser but also to the Los Angeles Dodgers. It had been a struggle, but when the final out was made - when Tony Phillips swung and missed - the Dodgers could finally celebrate. With Hershiser and heart, they had won the 85th World Series.

title: Drug Makers' Profits Rise
description: Two more large drug companies reported double-digit increases in net income in the third quarter. The Squibb Corporation, based in Princeton, N.J., said net income had risen 12.6 percent from a year earlier. Earnings at the Schering-Plough Corporation, based in Madison, N.J., increased 27.9 percent.

title: American Petrofina Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter and 9-month results include a $32 million writedown of certain facilities at the company's Port Arthur, Texas, refinery.

title: No Profitable Ventures for Perot
description: A judge in Virginia ruled today that H. Ross Perot could compete with Electronic Data Systems Inc., his former company, in ventures that make no profits but barred any profit-making ventures until after Dec. 1, 1989.

title: Ryder System Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes two unusual charges totalling $51.4 million relating to the restructuring of certain businesses and a downward reevaluation of goodwill, an extraordinary loss of $18,581,000 relating to the company's repurchase of $157.8 million of its unsecured notes plus, and an extraordinary gain of $81,096,000 from an accounting change.

title: Man Wired to Explosive Killed in Subway Blast
description: A man with an explosive mechanism concealed under his shirt was killed yesterday afternoon when the device detonated in a Harlem subway station.

title: Navy Stands Firm
description: Navy Secretary William L. Ball 3d has rejected a request from Ens. David Robinson to be released from active duty to start his professional basketball career this season. Robinson, a 7-foot-1-inch all-American at the United States Naval Academy who played with the United States Olympic team this summer, had petitioned the Secretary to be released before completing a two-year commitment to the service in return for increasing the length of his commitment to the Naval Reserve. Robinson has signed an eight-year, $26 million contract with the San Antonio Spurs. His commitment to the Navy will not expire until May 17, well after the regular season ends. Ball, however, decided he was not going to tamper with Navy policies regarding active-duty service personnel and professional-sports endeavors by providing Robinson with a special exemption, said a source who requested anonymity. The Navy declined to discuss the Secretary's decision beyond acknowledging that he had spoken with Robinson by telephone. Robinson is assigned to the Navy's Trident submarine base at Kings Bay, Ga., as a civil-engineering officer. Robinson said in a statement, ''I respect the Secretary's decision and appreciate their time and consideration.'' (AP)

title: Jazz Film Festival Opening
description: This year's Greenwich Village Jazz Festival didn't include a film series, but the idea was only hibernating. Bruce Ricker, the film maker who has put together the Greenwich Village film series since 1981, has assembled a more ambitious three-week program that begins this weekend at Film Forum 2, 57 Watts Street (431-1590). Jazz and blues documentaries, feature films, animated films, television specials, rare performance footage and films with jazz soundtracks are to be shown.

title: Soviets Remove Restrictions On Number of Subscriptions
description: After months of public outcry, the Council of Ministers has lifted restrictions on subscriptions to popular newspapers and magazines, Pravda reported today.

title: Trustcorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Two Held in Rock-Throwing From I-78 Overpasses
description: A volunteer firefighter and a member of a volunteer rescue squad in New Jersey have been charged with six counts of attempted murder in connection with a series of incidents in which, the authorities say, they deliberately dropped rocks and cinder blocks onto passing cars and then rushed to the aid of the stricken motorists.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; A Hostage's Birthday
description: Terry Anderson, the Associated Press bureau chief in Beirut who wastaken hostage by terrorists more than three years ago, will be 41 years old on Oct. 27. To mark the day, a humanitarian organization called No Greater Love is circulating a birthday card, designed by the ''Doonesbury'' cartoonist, Garry Trudeau, for signatures from fellow journalists here. The organization plans to send a photograph of the card to news agencies in Beirut and to save the original for delivery to Mr. Anderson when he is freed.

title: Meredith Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $10,801,000 from an accounting change.

title: Thomas & Betts Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Restoring A Polish Jewish Soul
description: LEAD: When in 1957, at the age of 24, I left Poland for America, it was a suffocating year for me and my generation. The brief period of cultural freedom of expression ended on a sour note of neo-Stalinist repression. And as if this was not bad enough for Poles already surrounded by the Soviets, Mother Russia had just encircled with her two Sputniks the entire Mother

title: First Tennessee National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the 1987 results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Peoples and Union Bank in Lewisburg, Tenn. The transaction was completed in March 1988 and was accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Democrats in the House Urged to Aid Dukakis
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson has urged House Democrats to campaign vigorously for Michael S. Dukakis when Congress adjourns.

title: Home & City Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
O'Connor Has Breast Surgery To Stop Cancer
description: Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor of the Supreme Court underwent surgery here today for breast cancer. According to a statement from the Justice, which was released this afternoon by the Court's press office, the cancer was in a ''very early form'' and the prognosis is for ''total recovery.''

title: Nigerian Vows to End Military Rule
description: A tank stood parked by the lawn of the presidential office complex, Dodan Barracks. At his desk, the President wore the five stars and the crisp olive green uniform of an army general.

title: Rangers 4, Capitals 1
description: Dr. Jim McGee, a psychologist who has worked extensively with the Baltimore Orioles, clearly has experience counseling teams with chronic performance problems. So it is less than astonishing to learn that he has taken on the Washington Capitals as his latest clients.

title: Seymour R. Askin, Retailer, 90
description: Seymour R. Askin, a former president of Askin Stores Inc., a 65-unit chain of clothing stores, mostly in the South and Southwest, died of heart failure Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90 years old. Mr. Askin, whose hometown was Rochester, had been a vice president of the Central Synagogue, on Lexington Avenue at 55th Street.

title: Duke Power Co reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Merrill Lynch Unit Seeks Moran, Stahl
description: Merrill Lynch Realty of Stamford, Conn., signed a letter of intent to acquire Moran, Stahl & Boyer Inc., a management consulting firm specializing in business relocation. Moran, which has offices in New York City and Boulder, Colo., will operate as an independent subsidiary of Merrill Lynch Realty. The price of the acquisition was not disclosed.

title: Alliant Computer Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Youths, many of them unemployed, took to the streets to protest Government austerity policies.

description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reopened the bidding today for two troubled Texas banks that were to be acquired by Carl R. Pohlad, the Minnesota investor.

title: COPING: With a Tax Audit
description: Audit. The word makes taxpayers nervous, and with good reason. At best, an audit means corresponding with the Internal Revenue Service, searching through files, producing records. At worst, it can mean paying additional taxes, the interest on those taxes and, should the I.R.S. conclude that the taxpayer deliberately filed an erroneous return, a penalty.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 22, 1988
description: The Economy

title: LSB Bancshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lions' Rogers Charged
description: An arrest warrant was filed yesterday in Pontiac, Mich., charging the Detroit Lions defensive end, Reggie Rogers, with involuntary manslaughter in connection with a car crash in which three teen-agers were killed Thursday. Rogers was intoxicated when he sped through a red light and slammed into the teen-agers' car early Thursday, the Oakland County Prosecutor L. Brooks Patterson said. The 24-year-old Rogers faces up to 15 years in prison if convicted of three counts of the felony charges. Patterson said Rogers would not be served the arrest warrant until he leaves Pontiac Osteopathic Hospital, where he is being treated for a fractured neck, a partially amputated thumb and other injuries he suffered in the crash in downtown Pontiac. The Lions refused to comment on the charges yesterday.(AP)

title: Consolidated Oil & Gas Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31

title: OPEC Cut In Output Expected
description: Driven by the realization that none of its members can live with low oil revenues, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is approaching an agreement to limit oil prodution next year to a ceiling of 18.5 million barrels a day, which represents a cut of at least 2.5 million barrels a day from the present level.

title: MGM/UA Offer
description: A $1 billion bid for MGM/UA Communications by a Monaco-based company was rejected by Kirk Kerkorian, who owns about 80 percent of the movie company, a published report Thursday said. Elizabeth Dickenson Industries recently made the offer, the company's lawyer, Howard Weitzman, said.

title: Mexicans in Opposition Finding Unity Elusive
description: In the Mexican presidential election in July, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas brought together a divided assortment of political groups and won 31.1 percent of the officially recorded vote. But as he and his supporters settle in for the longer struggle against the political system in place in Mexico for the last 60 years, they are finding it more difficult to forge formal and lasting unity.

Cult Member Guilty In Theft of Loans
description: A woman in the Circle of Friends group faces 20 years in prison and $220,000 in fines after pleading guilty Thursday to stealing thousands of dollars in student loans, a court official said.

title: Pennwalt Plans Stock Repurchase
description: The Pennwalt Corporation approved a plan to buy back more than a third of its shares in a long-expected recapitalization plan that will pay shareholders more than $400 million. The company embarked on the restructuring plan as a way of fending off a takeover by Centaur Partners, an investment group that owns 8.6 percent of the company.

title: Patents; Curbing Nicotine Desire
description: Gerald K. Ebbesen of South Newfane, Vt., won patent approval this week for a new method of relieving nicotine cravings in people trying to quit smoking. The method is a precise mix of sugar, potassium and caffeine. According to the patent, the mixture briefly increases a person's metabolic rate, stimulating the adrenaline-like jolt of nicotine.

title: Candidates in Westchester Sting Each Other in a Heated Campaign
description: The 20th Congressional District race heated up this week with charges and countercharges of illegal campaign contributions and indictments.

title: U.N. Calls on Deposed Afghan King
description: The United Nations official assigned to promote a political settlement in Afghanistan has appealed to the exiled Afghan King to help form a government of national reconciliation before the Soviets complete their military withdrawal.

title: Barnes Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a pretax charge of $2.9 million to cover transition costs related to the company's engine valve spring project.

description: The British international trading group Lonrho P.L.C., target of heavy share trading in London this week, said that Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. of Australia and its associates had built up a stake of nearly 15 percent in it.

description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and human rights campaigner, announced today that he would travel to the United States next month. The announcement means that the Soviet authorities have ended their longstanding ban on Dr. Sakharov's travel to the West.

title: Rooney Found Guilty
description: Kevin Rooney, the trainer for Mike Tyson, was found guilty Thursday in Catskill, N.Y., of third-degree assault for the beating of his estranged wife's friend, James Karkheck, on Dec. 12, 1987. Rooney, who said he would appeal the decision, could spend a maximum of one year in the Greene County Jail.

description: Potatoes may be the biggest business in this part of Maine, but the french fries served at local McDonald's and Burger Kings are most likely to be from Idaho or somewhere else in the West.

description: British Airways ordered 31 Boeing airliners today, handing the United States manufacturer a prize contract worth about $1.8 billion in the face of intense competition from the European Airbus consortium.

title: Westcorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nicaragua and Costa Rica Brace As Edge of Hurricane Slaps Coast
description: Hurricane Joan haltingly approached Central America's Caribbean coast today, threatening to unleash a torrent of flash floods and mud slides.

title: Bannister Let Go
description: The Knicks got down to the required 12-player roster yesterday by releasing Ken Bannister, a 6-foot-9-inch center; Sean Couch, a 6-1 guard from Columbia, and Bill Jones, a 6-7 forward from Iowa. Bannister was a sometime starter with the Knicks for two seasons from 1984-86, but played last season in the Continental Basketball Association. Included among the 12 players left on the roster are Rick Carlisle, a 6-5 guard who has missed most of the training camp with a sore shoulder, and Greg Butler, a 6-11 center from Stanford who was the No. 2 draft choice.

title: Duriron Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Wagner's Best Wants More
description: Terry Underwood was sitting in the bleachers, resting his sore muscles while the rest of his Wagner College teammates were doing situps and pushups. Wind sprints had already been taken care of, and soon the Monday ritual every football player dreads, the viewing of game films, would begin.

title: Mack Trucks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

The latest quarter also included a $2.2 million gain on the condemnation sale of a branch sales and servie facility. Start-up costs for the Winnsboro plant amounted to $4.2 million in the year-ago quarter. The year-ago quarter was also hurt by about $6.1 million related to the financial restructuring of Mack Financial Corp. and costs incurred to prepare for a possible disruption of production by Mack's U.A.W. employees.

title: William Campbell, 83; A U.S. Judge 48 Years
description: William J. Campbell, a former chief judge of the Federal District Court in Chicago whose tenure encompassed a turbulent period in the city's law-enforcement history, died Wednesday of complications following surgery at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 83 years old and lived in Lantana, Fla.

title: Citizens First Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 6-for-5 stock split paid in 1987.

title: LIGHTEST TURNOUT IN 40 YEARS IS SEEN
description: Several political analysts predicted today that despite simplified registration procedures and aggressive drives to encourage voting, the rate of turnout in the election Nov. 8 would be the lowest in at least 40 years.

title: 2 Die as Greek Cruise Ship Sinks in Collision
description: A Greek cruise ship carrying 475 British students and teachers collided with a freighter and sank near shore today, officials said. Two Greek seamen were killed and some students were feared trapped underwater, though nearly all of the passengers were reported safe.

title: Manufacturers National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago 9 months included a net charge of $27.4 million from a reserve for less developed country risk.

ISRAELI JETS BOMB REBELS IN LEBANON
description: Israeli Air Force jets bombed Palestinian and pro-Iranian guerrilla positions in southern Lebanon and the Bekaa region today, two days after a car-bomb attack killed seven Israeli soldiers on the Lebanese border.

title: Earnings Rise 26.5% at Texas Instruments
description: Despite a mild easing in demand for semiconductors, Texas Instruments Inc. said today that its profits rose 26.5 percent in the third quarter, to $93.7 million, or $1.03 a share, from $74.1 million, or 85 cents a share, in the same period a year ago.

title: Two Dodgers For Any Era
description: They'll soon be measured for World Series rings, but many of these Dodgers wouldn't have survived spring training with the Boys of Summer teams in Brooklyn. Or with the Koufax-Drysdale team that swept the Yankees in the World Series a quarter of a century ago. Or maybe even with Tom Lasorda's other Series champions in 1981, who stunned the Yankees in six games.

title: 4 Die as Small Plane Crashes
description: All four people aboard a single-engine airplane were killed Thursday night when it crashed 100 yards from the runway of Wings Airport in suburban Montgomery County, where it had been trying to land. The plane, on a flight from Rochester, N.Y., went down in the front yard of a house, but no one on the ground was injured.

title: Cobe Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Some Seat Belts Found Inferior (or Lethal)
description: Automobile seat belts save lives. But Government safety experts and consumer organizations say American manufacturers are using belts that are technologically obsolete, prone to improper use and outlawed in most other nations. A result, they say, is that front seat belts give inadequate protection and that belts in rear seats actually cause deaths and injuries.

title: Shearson Risks, Rewards on RJR Nabisco
description: As the advisers to RJR Nabisco's board yesterday began to weigh the fairness and viability of a proposed $17 billion buyout bid for the company, other Wall Street professionals assessed what would be the largest and most complex transaction of its kind.
