description: Damian Johnson, who started the first six games of the season for the Giants at offensive right guard until back problems sidelined him last Sunday, will miss the game Sunday against the Falcons in Atlanta.

title: Dodgers Head Home for a Party
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers took their trophy and their legend home today. But not, as the baseball snipers were suggesting, to start the awesome job of rebuilding the team that won the World Series.

title: Cape Cod Bank & Trust Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Welfare Cash Machines
description: State welfare recipients participating in a demonstration project will be able to collect their benefits through cash machines starting next summer. Plastic debit cards will be issued to recipients in Pierce County, who will use them to draw cash against their accounts from any of 140 machines. Frank Mendizabal, a spokesman for the state's Department of Social and Health Services, called the project ''an effort to make it a more efficient system for us and the recipients.''

title: Suede, George! Suede!
description: Keeping ahead of the news means never sleeping. That is what this column does: never sleeps. That is why we can bring you up to date on President Bush's White House disaster while other press, television and polling swamis keep repeating last week's news like stuck records.

title: Kalman Apfel, Physician, 81
description: Dr. Kalman Apfel, a retired physician and winner of several national contract bridge titles, including the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup in 1954, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 81 years old.

title: United Carolina Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bridge; Denmark wins women's title, and U.S. team leads in open final.
description: Denmark won one world title at the World Team Olympiad here tonight, and the United States seemed headed for the other.

title: DS Bancor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Patents; Imaging Systems Cover Heart and Blood Vessels
description: Since the early 1980's, magnetic resonance imaging, or M.R.I., has become a widely used method for producing vivid images of a brain or spinal cord.

title: Review/Theater; Waging War on Family and Time
description: The title character in Cassandra Medley's ''Ma Rose'' is an aged matriarch who finds her mind and her life are slowly slipping away. Stubbornly she wants to hold on to her independence, but she is surrounded by relatives determined to give her a final push. The play is the story of Ma Rose's battle, and it is also about the conflicts among three generations of women who seem destined to repeat one another's mistakes.

title: Vulcan Materials Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $1,105,000 for the quarter and $2,827,000 for the 9 months.

description: The Surgeon General of the United States, C. Everett Koop, said today that RJR Nabisco Inc.'s new ''smokeless'' cigarette was a ''drug-delivery system'' that should be regulated by the Federal Government.

title: New York Region's Costs Up 1.4% as Apparel Surges
description: A stronger-than-usual seasonal surge in apparel costs helped push September consumer prices up a sharp 1.4 percent in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area, the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Super Food Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
F.B.I. Agent Is Held On Charge of Selling Cocaine in Chicago
description: An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was arrested in Chicago today on charges that he sold cocaine to an undercover F.B.I. agent at a Chicago nightclub.

title: Ex-Official in Vice Plea Bargain
description: Roger Boas, former chief administrative officer of this city, pleaded guilty Thursday to seven counts of statutory rape, charges that stemmed from his having had sexual relations with teen-age girls at a brothel. Twelve other counts were dropped in return for the guilty plea, which reportedly allows Mr. Boas, 67 years old, to avoid prison. Judge Timothy Reardon of Superior Court set sentencing for Nov. 17.

title: Ashton-Digital Software Pact
description: The Ashton-Tate Corporation and the Digital Equipment Corporation are expected to announce Monday that Ashton, the software publisher, will make its popular Dbase management program available on Digital's computer line, analysts and sources close to the company said. The companies have scheduled a news conference Monday in Boston, but Digital and Ashton-Tate officials would not comment on the reports.

description: b-After charges from the early extinguishment of debt of $1,000 for the quarter and $772,000 for the 9 months.

description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $2,709,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

description: Philips N.V., the giant Dutch electronics company, has traded $5 million in Brazilian debt to buy the contract of a soccer star who will play on a Dutch soccer team that Philips controls.

Tickets are $10; students and the elderly, $7. Information: 666-0675.

description: The year-ago results restated to reflect a 20 percent stock dividend declared as of July 29, 1988.

title: PS Enterprise Group reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Sidney Reitman, Lawyer, 73
description: Sidney Reitman, a labor lawyer who was active in the civil rights movement in the 1960's, died of thyroid cancer at St. Peter's Medical Center in New Brunswick, N.J., on Wednesday. He was 73 years old and lived in West Orange, N.J.

title: National Banc of Commerce Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Music; Beethoven and a Domesticated Strauss
description: The newsworthy aspect of the current New York Philharmonic subscription program at Avery Fisher Hall, heard Thursday night, is the Philharmonic debut of the Mozart specialist Mitsuko Uchida, playing Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 3. But at least as interesting was the impact of the other work on the program, Richard Strauss's ''Symphonia Domestica.''

title: James Aronson, Journalism Critic, Editor and Teacher, Is Dead at 73
description: James Aronson, an editor, teacher and journalism critic for five decades, died of cancer of the prostate yesterday at the Cabrini Hospice in Manhattan. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Innocents in Town
description: Until last week, it had been many years since a New York City woman had seen an old-fashioned teen-ager.

title: Old National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Soccer Race Remains Tight
description: With less than three weeks left in the regular college soccer season, the contest for the two automatic playoff berths in the New York Region is a three-team race among Adelphi, Brooklyn College and Long Island University.

title: Review/Dance; Ballet Theater Overcoming Paris Critics' Reserve
description: It is never easy for American ballet companies to win over Paris, a city that often acts as if any ballet troupe that comes from outside France is a group of upstarts. Nevertheless, American Ballet Theater, making its first appearance in Paris in 11 years, has been slowly winning over some hard-to-please Parisian critics.

title: Honeywell Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Includes $108 million in pretax charges from writeoffs in the company's defense avionics systems division for both the quarter and 9 months; extraordinary credits of $10.3 million and $16.8 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, one-time gains from the sale of real estate of $12.3 million for the quarter and $27.2 million for the 9 months. c-Net income The company said the extraordinary credits of $10.3 million and $16.8 million in its third quarter and 9 months, respectively, were after taxes, and the gains of $12.3 million and $27.2 million from the sale of real estate in the third quarter and 9 months, respectively, are pretax gains. The company noted, however, that tax on the gains was offset by a $4 million tax credit in the third quarter.

title: American Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest periods included an additional $3.5 million to the bank's loan loss provision for a loan to a Connecticut-based real estate syndication and management company. Corrected from Thursday, Oct. 20, editions.

title: Women in the Theater and in Music Pause to Assess Their Status; At Juilliard, Gains Are Recounted
description: ''We've come together at a moment of supreme optimism, I believe, in the history of women in music,'' the flutist Eugenia Zukerman said from the stage of the Juilliard School's Paul Recital Hall at the start of a symposium on the opportunities available to women in classical music.

title: Quiet Jersey Town Braces for New Housing After Ruling
description: Ask people in Fanwood what living here is like, and they talk about the quiet streets, the annual Easter egg hunt in the park, the volunteer fire department, the small-town feeling.

title: PRESIDENT URGES WIDE G.O.P. VICTORY
description: President Reagan returned to the South today with a broad message of support for Republican Congressional and gubernatorial candidates that reflected White House elation with Vice President Bush's campaign for the Presidency.

title: Cup Sailoff Is Proposed

Women in the Theater and in Music Pause to Assess Their Status; Playwrights See Little Progress
description: Susan Croft, the director of the New Playwrights Trust in London, was recalling a survey made in 1982 and 1983 on the status of women in the British theater. ''Out of about 600 plays put on by all the national and regional theaters surveyed,'' she said, ''42 were by women. And 22 of those were by Agatha Christie.''

title: Quaker Oats Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: A Company Briefs listing in Business Day on Thursday incorrectly described the sale of Ektelon, a manufacturer of racquetball equipment. Ektelon is being sold by Browning of Morgan, Utah, to Prince Manufacturing Inc. of Princeton, N.J.

title: Commerce Clearing House Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5 Ferdinand Marcos was indicted in a racketeering case that includes charges that he, his wife and eight associates embezzled more than $100 million from the Philippine Government and used the money to buy three buildings in New York City. Page 1 The Marcoses will surrender in New York by Oct. 31 and plead not guilty to the indictments against them, a lawyer for the couple said. 4 Officials defended the indictment of Mr. Marcos by arguing that the former friend of Washington had continued to violate American laws after he arrived in the United States. 4 Israel bombed southern Lebanon and the Bekaa region, the site of Palestinian and pro-Iranian guerrilla positions. The action came two days after a car-bomb attack killed Israeli soldiers on the Lebanese border. 1 The Afghan King's help was requsted by a United Nations official in forming a government of national reconciliation before the Soviets complete their military withdrawal. The King is in exile. 5 Soviet constitutional amendments to reorganize the nation's top governmental bodies were proposed by the Government. They would carry out most of the political changes sought by Mikhail Gorbachev. 3 The Mexican alliance forged from four political parties and dozens of political organizations by Cuauhtemoc Cardenas in the Presidenital election is having trouble saying together. 2 Japan agreed to end restrictions that limit foreign companies from establishing private, multimillion-dollar computer networks between Japan and other nations. The agreement appeared to benefit I.B.M. in particular. 35 A troubled Israeli conglomerate, Koor Industries, is seeking a Government bailout. It was thrown into financial crisis by a suit over its failure to pay $20 million loan. 33 President Botha clashed with the only prominent black figure in the country who has been willing to work within its white-controlled political system, the leader of South Africa's Zulus. 3 Central American countries braced as storm touches coast 2 Nigerian leader vows a return to civilian rule 3 National 6-9, 28, 50 Food and clothing prices rose in September, pushing up the Consumer Price Index by three-tenths of 1 percent. Economists said the increase posed little inflationary threat. 1 A regional surge in apparel costs helped push up consumer prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area in September by a sharp 1.4 percent, the Labor Department reported. Food prices and college tuition also rose. 35 Lawmakers have left Washington, eager to campaign and frustrated by a delay in adjournment. Two lone Senators and the House approved restrictions on lobbying by former executive branch members. 1 Social Security benefits will increase by 4 percent starting next January, raising the average retired worker's pension by $21 a month, the Government announced. 35 Two men were acquitted of arson after admitting in court to setting fire to a Detroit crack house. The case dramatized the frustrations of inner cities and tested the line between self-protection and vigilantism. 1 Sandra Day O'Connor had surgery for breast cancer. The cancer was in a ''very early form'' and the prognosis is for ''total recovery,'' a statement by Justice O'Connor said. 6 An attack on ''smokeless'' cigarettes was made by the U.S. Surgeon General, who called RJR Nabisco Inc.'s new product a ''drug-delivery system'' that should be regulated by the federal government. 28 A man who confessed to bombing a black church in Birmingham, Ala., in 1963 fabricated the story, investigators said. 6 Maine potatoes may go fast food now that a major producer in the state, McCain Foods Ltd. of Canada, has been designated a french-fry supplier by the Burger King Corporation. A shift to Maine would bring major economic benefits. 33 Yellowstone fire damage less than thought 6 Politics 8-9 An election turnout at a 40-year low was predicted by several political analysts, despite simplified registration procedures and aggressive drives. 1 Michael Dukakis traveled to Harlem with polls showing his support among blacks weakening and as George Bush aims at New York for possible victory. ''I'm on your side,'' he said. ''And that's why I'm here.'' 8 George Bush backed a weapons ban for deadly chemicals, saying barriers against them ''must be repaired and raised even higher,'' and vowed to make nations that use such weapons ''pay a price.'' 9 State by State: In West Texas, Bush's message comes across 8 Reagan urges wide support for G.O.P. candidates 9 Regional 29-32 New York has two school systems, one in affluent areas and the other in poor areas, a state task force said. Racism ''clearly underlies much of the problem,'' it said. 1 Police Headquarters is in disrepair in New York City 15 years after it was opened as the nation's largest and most advanced. Parts of the roof leak and the 300-foot-long plaza is crumbling. 29 The comatose body of Lisa Steinberg was handed to Hedda Nussbaum by Joel Steinberg shortly before he left to have dinner with a friend, she has told Manhattan prosecutors, law-enforcement officials said. 29 Senator Moynihan's campaign began full-time with 17 days left before Election Day. He told high school students not to use drugs and ''to tell on'' those who do. 29 A license for Shoreham to operate at 25 percent of capacity was sought by the Long Island Lighting Company, one week after a report said there is no reason why the nuclear power plant should not be allowed to operate at that power level. 31 Fraternity and sorority leaders promised New Jersey's Board of Higher Education to promote responsibility and not to tolerate hazing, alcohol and drug abuse, sexism or discrimination. 30

title: Texaco Canada Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago revenue figures restated. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Bruno's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,577,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said the latest quarter earnings includes 12 weeks of results from Piggly Wiggly operations, compared with 16 weeks in the year- earlier period.

title: Tyson's New Promoter?
description: Bill Cayton, manager of the heavyweight champion, Mike Tyson, said yesterday that the promoter Don King told him Thursday that King had signed Tyson to an exclusive four-year promotional contract and had gotten a limited power of attorney from Tyson. Both Cayton and his attorney, Irving Gruber, said that only Cayton, and not Tyson, had the contractual right to sign a promotional agreement. ''I am conferring with Bill,'' Gruber said, ''about the appropriate course of action.'' Charles Lomax, King's attorney, declined to comment on King's contractual relationship with Tyson and said that King was on his way from Cleveland to Chicago last night.

title: Ramada Is Planning to Sell Its Hotels and Restaurants
description: Ramada Inc., in a move to thwart the takeover attempts of the Pritzker family of Chicago, plans a restructuring that would include the sale of its hotel and restaurant businesses.

title: Gleason Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-After a gain of $2,951,000 from the cumulative effect of an inventory change. Year-ago third quarter figures were restated to reflect a $485,000 reduction from a change in accounting for inventories. The year-ago 9-month net includes an after-tax restructuring and disposal charge of $952,000 and an accounting change for inventories decreased previously reported net by $598,000.

title: Curtiss-Wright Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $1,021,000 and $1,460,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes extraordinary gains of $2,300,000 for the quarter and $3,782,000 for the 9 months. The company said results in the latest quarter and 9 months included real estate gains of about $1,973,000 for both the quarter and 9 months, and the 9-month also includes tax benefits of $1,470,000. Results in the year-ago quarter and 9 months both included real estate gains of $4,091,000; tax benefits of $2,108,000 and $3,782,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9-month also includes a gainof $2,282,000 from a modification of the payment schedule from the sale of Curtiss-Wright's rotary engine business.

title: Botha, in Speech, Sets Off Feud With Zulu Leader
description: President P. W. Botha found himself embroiled today in a bitter personal feud with the leader of South Africa's Zulus, the only prominent black figure in the country who has been willing to work within its white-controlled politics.

title: Holly Will Consider New Tyson Foods Bid
description: Holly Farms, the Memphis-based chicken company that spurned a $920 million buyout plan from its rival Tyson Foods Inc. earlier this week, said today that it would consider Tyson's increased offer of $941 million in cash.

title: Holiday Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $4,773,000 and $29,589,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-After extraordinary charges of $2,000 for the quarter and $3,458,000 for the 9 months.

title: Jim Wright, Unlikely Sparkplug
description: Though the Democrats controlled both houses in the 100th Congress for the first time since 1980, they still confronted a popular Republican President. Jim Wright, newly elected Speaker of the House, refused to settle for a stalemate. His personal conduct attracted wide, sometimes harsh, attention. But his boldness as a leader prompted more useful legislation than anyone expected.

title: Greater New York Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest 9 months included a $9.7 million net loss on the sale of First Republicbank notes. The bank converted to stock ownership on June 24, 1987.

title: Israeli Concern Seeks State Bailout
description: Executives of Koor Industries, Israel's largest industrial conglomerate, and officials of its creditor banks are increasing efforts to obtain a Government bailout to keep the heavily indebted company from foundering. But Israeli officials have not publicly said they would engage in a bailout.

title: Central Fidelity Banks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Clip the Wings of the Mega-Airlines
description: Ten years after the airlines were deregulated, much of what we worked to achieve is threatened by the emergence of large areas of monopoly power in serving some classes of customers on some routes. The answer is not to re-regulate, but to curtail the practices that have enabled a few megacarriers to dominate the industry.

title: Cyclops Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter includes results of Eastern Stainless, acquired July 29, and an income tax provision of $1,200,000 for Eastern Stainless' earnings. Year-ago quarter is restated to exclude discontinued operations of Cytemp Specialty Steel and Detroit Strip. Comparable year-ago figures are not applicable; the company began operations in July 1987. The company said the year-ago quarter included one-time tax benefits which raised the earnings. It also said higher interest charges contributed to lower net.

title: Former Colonel and Unisys Are Accused in Billing Case
description: A former Air Force colonel who once supervised the modernization of the service's computer network has been indicted along with the computer company that is doing the work, Federal prosecutors said today.

title: Chris-Craft Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes pretax gains on sale of marketable securities of $3,115,000 for the quarter and $6,451,000 for the 9 months.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''President and Mrs. Marcos are obviously deeply disappointed at President Reagan's failure to prevent this treatment of a longstanding ally.'' - John J. Tigue Jr., a New York lawyer for the Marcoses. [ 1:6. ]

title: Flowers Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: b-Includes a $1,757,000 tax credit.

title: North Fork Bancorporation reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Marcoses to Surrender in New York, Lawyer Says
description: A lawyer for Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos said today that the couple would surrender in New York by Oct. 31 and plead not guilty to the indictments against them.

title: Marion Isbell, 83, Founder of Chain Of Ramada Motels
description: Marion W. Isbell, who founded Ramada Inc. and built it into a 500-motel chain, has died at the age of 83.

title: Laurels for CUNY
description: Announcements of this year's Nobel Prize winners held special significance for New Yorkers. The selection of Gertrude Elion in medicine and Dr. Leon Lederman in physics brings to 11 the total of Nobel laureates who have received undergraduate degrees from the City University of New York. That's more than any other public university in the nation.

title: Schmidt a Free Agent
description: For the first time in his 16-year career, Mike Schmidt is a free agent. Schmidt, the Philadelphia third baseman with 552 home runs, filed for free agency yesterday, the first day eligible players could do so.

title: Jefferson Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mike Bell Suspended
description: Mike Bell, a defensive end for the Kansas City Chiefs who served a four-month prison term in 1986 on a cocaine conviction, was placed on the team's 30-day non-football illness list yesterday for violating the National Football League's substance-abuse policy. Bell, the second player taken in the 1979 draft after playing at Colorado State, has been a starter for Kansas City for most of his pro career. Although the Chiefs' announcement provided no details, it is believed that Bell's violation will be considered his second by the N.F.L., meaning that a third would lead to a lifetime ban from the league. ''We are saddened by the news'' said Jim Schaaf, the Chiefs' general manager. ''We are in full support of the league's substance-abuse policy and its actions in this matter.''(AP)

title: Lie Tests Are Sharply Curbed
description: The Labor Department issued regulations today forbidding most private employers to use lie detectors to screen job applicants and greatly restricting the use of the devices to test present employees.

title: I.B.M. Halts Some Japan Chip Orders
description: In a move that may eventually help ease the shortage of personal computer memory chips in the United States, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had canceled several memory chip orders from Japanese suppliers.

title: Northern Telecom Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: All figures are in U.S. funds.

title: Threat on Bush Reported
description: A man accused of threatening the life of Vice President Bush was ordered held without bond Thursday by a Federal magistrate. Magistrate Stewart Elliott ruled after a hearing in United States District Court that David Allen Russell, 21 years old, was a threat to himself and others. He is charged with sending a threatening letter through the mail after a Bush rally in Owensboro.

title: Soviets Draft Plans for Government Change
description: The Soviet Government has issued detailed proposals for constitutional amendments to reorganize the country's top governmental bodies and carry out most of the political changes sought by the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Taylor Settles Suit
description: A Morristown, N.J., man and Lawrence Taylor have reached an out-of-court settlement in connection with an altercation during the summer, a prosecutor said yesterday. Lawrence Gross, 19, told Morristown Municipal Court Judge Michael J. Noonan that he was satisfied with restitution the Giants linebacker agreed to pay for allegedly kicking Gross's car Aug. 17, said the prosecutor, Michael Murphy. Terms of the settlement were not released. Calls to the Giants seeking comment yesterday were unanswered.(AP)

title: Patents; Bill Barring Royalties on Animals Dies
description: As Congress prepared to adjourn this week, lawmakers decided to duck the hottest patent issue of the session: Should farmers have to pay royalties on genetically engineered animals that have been patented?

title: Honoring Agnes de Mille
description: The choreographer Agnes de Mille is to receive the 1988 Mr. Abbott Award, given by the Stage Directors and Choreographers Foundation, at a ceremony on Nov. 14 at the Astor Ballroom of the Marriott Marquis Hotel. The award is given for accomplishment in the theater. Previous winners include Bob Fosse, Harold Prince and Mike Nichols. Tickets to the event, which begins at 7 P.M. with a cocktail reception followed by dinner and a tribute, are $200 and are tax-deductible. Information: 865-1812.

description: b-Net income

title: Confusion About Gastineau
description: Controversy followed Mark Gastineau, the Jets defensive end, today, one day after he suddenly retired from football because his fiancee has cancer.

title: Interim Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest periods include amounts for acquisitions completed subsequent to Sept. 30, 1987. Pretax income for the year-ago periods includes interest income received from the company's former parent, Kidde Inc., of $315,000 for the quarter and $863,000 for the 9 months.

title: Company Blamed for Blasts
description: Serious and willful safety violations were responsible for the two explosions that killed five people and injured three at a grain elevator complex in Illinois last spring, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration has concluded.

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $5,000,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $150,000 and $545,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

description: Per share earnings not available for other periods because the bank converted to stock ownership on July 6.

title: Your Money; The Right Way To Make a Will
description: If there are ambiguities in a will, it may well wind up in Surrogate's Court. And the decision there may not be what the deceased wished.

description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $712,000 reflecting the premium paid on the early redemption of subordinated capital notes. c-Included a one-time after-tax writedown of $478,000 relating to the elimination of the FSLIC secondary reserve.

title: STATE BY STATE In 'the Loneliest Country There Is,' Only Bush's Message Is Getting Across
description: The old-time cowboys used to call the high plains that stretch for hundreds of miles from San Antonio to El Paso ''the loneliest country there is.''

title: New England Electric System reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest 9 months included an after-tax writedown of $179 million from a previously announced rate settlement. The year-ago figures are restated.

title: North Side Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $1,814,000.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: Backwardness and Birth Control
description: Which of the following apply to the women who opt to end their pregnancies? Rich. Poor. Black. White. Single. Married. Catholic. Protestant. Jewish. Evangelical. Very young. Verging on middle age. Careless about contraception.

title: Confident Moynihan Starts A Full-Time Campaign
description: With 17 days remaining before the election in which he is an overwhelming favorite, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan began full-time campaigning yesterday with an impassioned plea to high school students not to use drugs and ''to tell on'' those who do.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Edberg and Becker Gain: Top-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden struggled to defeat Paul Chamberlin of Manhattan Beach, Calif., and second-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany played a near-perfect game in beating a countryman, Eric Jelen, in quarterfinal matches yesterday in the Seiko Super tournament in Toyko. Edberg, ranked third in the world and the tournament's defending champion, scored a 7-5, 6-2 triumph over Chamberlin, the world's 264th-ranked player, in 73 minutes. Becker used booming serves and passing shots in beating Jelen, 6-2, 6-1, in 55 minutes.(AP) Shriver Gains: Top-seeded Pam Shriver will face fourth-seeded Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany in the semifinals of the $200,000 European Indoors tournament after both posted straight-set victories yesterday in Zurich. In today's other semifinal, 16-year-old Conchita Martinez of Spain will face Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria, seeded No. 3. Shriver beat unseeded Brenda Schultz of the Netherlands, 6-3, 6-3. Kohde-Kilsch defeated eighth-seeded Raffaella Reggi of Italy, 6-1, 7-5. Maleeva defeated her sister, Katerina, 6-2, 6-2. The unseeded Martinez defeated 18-year-old Jana Pospisilova, a qualifier from Czechoslovakia, 6-0, 5-7, 6-4.(AP) Cross-Country Iona Runner Wins: Sean McGuirk of Iona, who covered the five-mile course in 24 minutes 44.03 seconds, won the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference cross-country championship yesterday in a steady rain at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. Pat Lavery of Fordham was 25 yards off the pace in 24:49.35. Iona won the team title with 26 points. Cheryl Simoni of Manhattan was first in the women's 3.1-mile race in 18:08.09. Fordham took team honors with 26 points. Paralympics Wins Third Gold Medal: Dennis Oehler of Brookville, L.I., who swept the men's 100-meter and 200-meter dashes, added another gold medal yesterday, winning the 400-meter race at the Paralympics in Seoul, South Korea. Oehler, 28 years old, won the 400 in a world-record 56.25 seconds. His time bettered the previous mark of 1:01.09. Oehler, who lost his right leg below the knee in a 1984 traffic accident, became the world's fastest amputee athlete Tuesday, winning the 100 in 11.73. Oehler also won the 200 in a world record 24.37. The previous mark was 28.23. (AP) Golf Three-Way Tie: Mark Hayes, Scott Hoch and John Cook tied for the second-round lead at nine-under-par 135 yesterday in the $400,000 Pensacola Open in Florida. One stroke behind the leaders were Lance Ten Broeck, Ken Green and brothers Curt and Tom Byrum, the latter shooting a 64, the lowest score of the tournament and the lowest of his career on the PGA Tour.(AP) Basketball Celtics 113, Yugoslavia 85: Larry Bird scored 17 of his game-high 27 points in the second half and Kevin McHale sparked an early third-quarter surge to lead Boston to a victory over the Yugoslav national team yesterday in the first round of the McDonald's Open in Madrid. The Celtics will face the host of the tournament, Real Madrid, in the championship tomorrow. Real Madrid defeated the Italian league champion, Scavolini Pesaro, 108-96. (AP) Hockey Maple Leafs 4, Red Wings 2: Darren Veitch and Daniel Marios scored 51 seconds apart in the second period to help Toronto to its four straight road victory for the first time since 1977-78. Detroit's Steve Yzerman failed to score for the first time in the Red Wings seven games this season.(AP) Sabres 5, Canadiens 3: Dave Andreychuk and Mike Foligno scored two goals as Buffalo took a 5-0 lead. Montreal outshot Buffalo, 15-1, in the third period. Daren Puppa of the Sabres made 39 saves. Buffalo took only 18 shots in the game.(AP)

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 32.

title: 2 Teen-Agers Charged In Robbery and Killing
description: Two teen-agers from the Bronx were accused last night of being part of a gang that robbed and killed a limousine driver and then broke into his house and raped his wife and daughter, the police reported.

title: Why Test Homes for Radon? The Risks Are Real
description: To the Editor:

title: Mt. Vernon Shelter: Ready, but Forgotten
description: For the last four decades or so, the Governors of New York State have had no luck rousing anyone at City Hall here on their special hotline. Not that some people haven't tried.

title: Pernod Advances Bid in Ireland
description: An Irish judge ruled in favor of Pernod Ricard, the French liquor concern, in its long takeover battle for the whiskey maker Irish Distillers Group P.L.C. The court ruled that Pernod, competing with the British giant Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. for Irish Distillers, had won an irrevocable promise of a 20 percent stake in Irish Distillers held by the Irish fruit importers FII Fyffes P.L.C.

title: Patents; Floss Has Toothpaste
description: Leonard Lorch, an entrepreneur in Stanford, Calif., has invented a dental floss that has toothpaste encased between two thin ribbons of Teflon fiber. The floss offers a way to get toothpaste between teeth. In addition, the Teflon coating is smoother and less likely to cut gums, the inventor said.

title: Pros Likely at Games
description: The International Basketball Federation will probably vote next April to allow United States professional basketball players to compete in the 1992 Olympic Summer Games in Barcelona, Spain, the secretary general of the federation said yesterday in Madrid. ''I am quite sure the congress will vote in favor of the change,'' the official, Borislav Stankovic of Yugoslavia, said at a joint news conference with Commissioner David Stern of the National Basketball Association. The conference was held before an exhibition game between the Boston Celtics and the Yugoslav national team. Stern said he would encourage N.B.A. players to compete in the Games.(AP)

title: Mending the Leaking, Crumbling Police Headquarters
description: Only 15 years after the Lindsay administration opened the nation's largest and most advanced police headquarters, parts of the 3.5-acre complex in lower Manhattan have fallen into serious disrepair.

title: Review/Dance; The San Francisco Ballet Explores Ancient Egypt
description: The San Francisco Ballet is appearing at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts for the first time since Helgi Tomasson became the company's artistic director in 1985, and the mixed bills on view this week here are obviously intended as showcases for the entire company.

title: Knight-Ridder Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $2,199,000 for the quarter and $5,990,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,619,000 and $4,500,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the discontinued operations are results for the eight television stations it intends to sell.

title: Lilco Asks U.S. Panel for a License to Operate Shoreham at 25% of Power
description: The Long Island Lighting Company today requested Federal approval to operate its Shoreham nuclear power plant at 25 percent of full power.

title: Lincoln Telecommunications Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Knitting Factory
description: Cassandra Wilson, a singer, is to lead a group and Greg Osby, a saxophonist, is to lead his ensemble Sound Theater at 9 and 11 P.M. tonight at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Tickets are $8.

title: William Regan Jr., 62, Retinal Disease Expert
description: Dr. William F. Regan Jr., co-founder of the retina service at Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, died of colon cancer Wednesday at his home in Pelham Manor, N.Y. He was 62 years old.

title: Feeding Winter Birds
description: If you're going to feed the birds, start doing it now, before the really cold weather sets in. Chickadees, white-throated sparrows, juncos, woodpeckers, nuthatches and grosbeaks are among the birds who don't mind the cold and don't fly South.

title: Buffets Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Datum Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Briggs & Stratton Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
High Farm Income Seen
description: Despite drought, the net cash income of farmers in 1988 is expected to nearly match or exceed last year's record $57.1 billion, unchanged from the outlook a month ago, the Agriculture Department said Thursday.

title: Ira L. Cahn, Publisher, 69
description: Ira L. Cahn, a newspaper publisher and former officer of the New York Press Association, died of complications of diabetes Oct. 15 at Martin Memorial Hospital in Stuart, Fla. He was 69 years old and lived in Palm City, Fla.

title: Minnesota Power reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Columbus's First Voyage Still Led the Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; A Slasher Goes Back To Work
description: It seems too strange to be true, but Halloween and Friday the 13th and prom nights were not always celebrated with slasher films; those quaint seasonal customs began a mere 10 years ago. Before Jason put on his hockey mask and began strewing bodies around, before Freddy started haunting the dreams of teen-agers on Elm Street, in 1978 there was Michael Myers, the killer in John Carpenter's stylish and still scary ''Halloween.''

title: U.S. Bonds Drop as Dollar's Fall Continues
description: Treasury bond prices fell modestly yesterday as a decline in the dollar to its lowest levels since late June revived concerns about inflation and foreign demand for American Government bonds.

title: National Bancorp of Alaska Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said it made $8,550,000 in loan loss provisions for the latest third quarter and $14,050,000 for the 9 months, compared with $975,000 and $2,920,000 for the year- ago quarter and 9 months, respectively.

Park Is Less Burned Than Thought
description: Damage from the summer wildfires that swept through Yellowstone National Park was not as severe in some respects as first believed, park officials asserted today. They said the park was expected to recover without reforestation or reseeding.

title: A Door Opens Dreams
description: LEAD: Underneath Times Square, at the east end of the Track 1 platform for the crosstown shuttle, lies a gateway to my dreams: a dark brown door with a portal in the middle that no longer contains any glass. Above this door, carved in stone and in big letters, it says: ''Knickerbocker.'' It's a remnant from a vanished time providing a glimpse into

title: Old Stone Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included a $16,177,000 charge from a change in accounting.

title: Japan Shifts on Computer Networks
description: Taking steps to resolve an increasingly bitter high-technology dispute, Japan said today that it would rescind rules that sharply limit the ability of foreign companies, particularly I.B.M., to establish private, multimillion-dollar computer networks between Japan and other nations.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Caring for Leather
description: Leather garments and furniture have become increasingly popular, but they need special care. When making a purchase, ask the seller for care instructions. Before sending a costly item to a dry cleaner, ask to see results on similar garments. If local establishments do not provide leather care, garments may be mailed to companies that specialize in such work. A mail-order cleaner will send a written appraisal of the work needed and the cost. When cleaning furniture, handbags or shoes yourself, test for discoloration on an inconspicuous area. Leather items last longer and are easier to clean if they are first treated with a water repellent.

title: Dukakis, in TV Ads, Strikes Back in Kind
description: After taking weeks of pounding from negative advertising by the campaign of Vice President Bush, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts finally fought back yesterday in commercials of his own that accuse Mr. Bush of ''dragging the truth into the gutter'' and showing ads ''full of lies.''

title: Social Security To Pay 4% More
description: The nation's 38.4 million Social Security recipients and 4.5 million recipients of Supplemental Security Income will receive an increase of 4 percent a month, starting in January, the Government announced yesterday.

title: About New York; Up From Havoc: Repairing Minds And Buildings
description: Imagine yourself unloved and unable to love, incapable of communicating across the immense canyon dividing you from others, and forever disappointed in your rare strivings to achieve. Imagine yourself as a despicable piece of rubbish. Then imagine yourself as a drug fiend - because if you are an addict, that is likely the way you feel.

title: Charity Picks New President
description: The Baron De Hirsch Fund, a Manhattan-based charitable organization, yesterday announced the election of Francis F. Rosenbaum Jr. as its president. He is the third generation of his family to hold that position. Mr. Rosenbaum, a 1948 graduate of Princeton University, is a partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Lawrence, O'Donnell, Marcus & Company. The fund, established in 1890, assists Jewish immigrants to the United States and Israel and now helps those arriving from the Soviet Union and Iran integrate into American society.

title: 'Legs Diamond' Delayed
description: The first preview of the Broadway musical ''Legs Diamond,'' starring Peter Allen, has been postponed again, this time until Tuesday night, at the Mark Hellinger Theater. The first preview had been planned for last Tuesday but was rescheduled for last night, then was delayed again. The problem, the producers say, is difficulty installing the sets in the theater. The official opening date remains Dec. 1.

title: South Carolina National reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Keystone Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
American Income Life Insurance Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After capital losses of $555,000 for the quarter and $2,011,000 for the 9 months. c-After a capital loss of $139,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $164,000 for the 9 months.

title: 6-Year-Old Killed in Hit-and-Run Accident
description: A 6-year-old Bronx girl was struck and killed yesterday evening by a hit-and-run driver as she and her father tried to cross a Bronx street, the police said.

title: Carlisle Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $915,000, or 11 cents a share, from the sale of certain assets and International Wire Products Co.

title: Republicans Set Sights on Montana, a Democratic Bastion
description: This state has not elected a Republican to the United States Senate in more than 40 years, or to the Governor's office in more than 20 years.

title: Gentex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Little Movement In Jockeys' Strike
description: Negotiators for horse owners and for jockeys on strike at Aqueduct Race Track since Wednesday were described by a mediator as being ''substantially apart'' after meeting for two hours at the track last night.

title: Marilyn Hirsh, Writer, 44
description: Marilyn Hirsh, a teacher, author and illustrator of children's books, died of cancer Tuesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. She was 44 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Chicago Pacific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $1,901,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $421,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $3,539,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary loss of $609,000 for the 9 months. The latest quarter net from operations includes a pre-tax gain of $64.9 million from the sale of the company's Rowenta group.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about a protest by cloistered nuns at a New Jersey monastery misidentified a visiting prioress in some editions. She is Mother Maria Brinkman, who traveled from Texas to support the monastery's prioress, Mother Teresa Hewitt.

title: Second Suspect Held in Slaying Of a Patrolman
description: A Bronx resident who is believed to have fired the shots that killed Police Officer Michael J. Buczek was charged with murder last night after a two-day manhunt in which scores of detectives scoured the city.

title: York Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid Aug. 15, 1988.

title: Fastenal Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Progressive Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After capital gains of $200,000 for the quarter and $1.1 million for the 9 months. c-After capital gains of $5.1 million for the quarter and $15.4 million for the 9 months.

title: United Banks of Colorado reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Nussbaum Tells of Being Handed Comatose Body of Lisa Steinberg
description: Hedda Nussbaum has told Manhattan prosecutors that Joel B. Steinberg handed her the comatose body of Lisa Steinberg shortly before he left their Greenwich Village apartment on Nov. 1, 1987, to have dinner with a friend, top law-enforcement officials said last night.

title: Leo P. Reckford, Laryngologist, 85
description: Dr. Leo P. Reckford, a laryngologist, died of heart failure Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85 years old.

title: Landmark Bancshares Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ex-Scoutmaster Gets 5 Years in Sex Case
description: A former Southington Boy Scout leader has been sentenced to five years in prison for sexually molesting members of his troop.

title: Corrections
description: A chart about the World Series in Sports Pages on Oct. 14 misidentified the single game that holds the attendance record. It was Game 5 of the 1959 Series, not Game 1.

title: Health Care Property Investrs reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Panel Again Backs Research With Tissue of Aborted Fetuses
description: An expert panel convened by the Federal Government to look at the ethical, legal and scientific issues of using human fetal tissue from induced abortions for research and therapy today reaffirmed its earlier conclusion that these uses would be acceptable.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP 0.3% AS FOOD AND CLOTHING RISE
description: The Consumer Price Index rose by three-tenths of 1 percent in September as higher costs for food and clothing were largely offset by a sharp downturn in the cost of gasoline, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Biweekly Mortgages: A Way to Build Equity
description: More homeowners around the nation are taking advantage of mortgages that require payments every two weeks instead of once a month.

title: Dukakis, at Harlem Church, Says, 'I'm on Your Side'
description: With polls suggesting his black support may be a bit soft, and his Republican rival targeting his political base in New York, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis traveled yesterday to Harlem, where he clapped and swayed to gospel rhythms and made a pitch to black voters.

title: First Bancorp of Ohio reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bush Assails Use of Chemical Weapons
description: Campaigning for the vital 23 electoral votes of Ohio, Vice President Bush said today that the United States must take the lead in making sure that nations using chemical and biological weapons are punished.

title: Test Cuts Fare Cheats To 3% From 30%
description: Thirty percent of the people entering three East Side IRT stations were fare evaders, the Transit Authority said yesterday in releasing results of a five-day experiment studying the $60 million-a-year loss from fare beaters.

title: No Refuge From American Law
description: Indicting a deposed head of state granted asylum in the United States may seem a poor way to treat a guest. But according to a Federal grand jury in New York, Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos have treated their hosts shabbily, operating a racketeering enterprise out of their safe haven from the Philippine revolution.

title: Mass for Charles Raffa
description: A funeral Mass for Charles Raffa, Governor Cuomo's father-in-law, will be celebrated Monday at 10 A.M. at St. Anastasia's Roman Catholic Church, 45-14 245th Street, Douglaston, Queens. Viewing hours at the New Hyde Park Funeral Home, New Hyde Park, L.I., are 2 to 4:30 P.M. and 7 to 9:30 P.M. today and tomorrow. Mr. Raffa, a manufacturer of supermarket equipment, died Wednesday. He was 84 years old.

title: Texas Instruments Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago figures are restated to reflect change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Dekalb Genetics reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The latest quarter includes a $1,200,000 after-tax charge from the distribution of Dekalb Genetics stock to shareholders of Dekalb Energy Co.

title: Confession in '63 Bombing Of Church Is Called a Fake
description: State and Federal officials said today that they have disproved the confession of a man who asserted that he and a friend had taken part in the bombing of a black church here in 1963.

title: MARCOS AND WIFE, 8 OTHERS CHARGED BY U.S. WITH FRAUD
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos was indicted yesterday in a racketeering case that includes charges that he embezzled more than $100 million from the Philippine Government and used the money to buy three buildings in New York City.

title: Social Security Checks Will Rise 4%
description: The nation's 38.4 million Social Security recipients will see their benefits increase by 4 percent starting next January, raising the average retired worker's pension by $21 a month, the Government announced today.

title: Hard-Pressed Teachers Don't Have a Choice on Multiple Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CRADLE OF CIVILIZATION?
description: A DREAM OF MAYA Augustus and Alice Le Plongeon in Nineteenth-Century Yucatan. By Lawrence Gustave Desmond and Phyllis Mauch Messenger. Illustrated. 147 pp. Albuquerque: University of New Mexico Press. Paper, $19.95.

title: At History's Side, Along the Wall
description: NAMES like Wall Street and Rampart Street in our own cities remind us that walls remained important for urban defense until relatively recent times. It comes as a surprise to many to learn that the fortification wall of ancient Rome survives along a considerable part of its length. This is because through all the centuries of the Middle Ages and well into the modern era, while other ancient structures were recycled or permitted to fall into ruins, the wall was kept in repair for defense purposes.

title:
Hers;
Three Cheers For My Daughter
description: LEAD: I SCREAMED WHEN MY daughter told me at 16 that she was trying out to be a cheerleader; I remember the moment precisely. My daughter - strong-willed and strong-armed, critical and deep and smart - approached me with a trace of hesitation in her step. Mom, she said, I have something to tell you, and

title: U.S. Assails Khmer Rouge Over Refugee Treatment
description: United States officials have for the first time expressed alarm about what they say is the violation of human rights in refugee camps run by the Khmer Rouge near the Thai-Cambodian border.

title: The Realty Game Turns On the Utilities
description: Daniel Feld believed that New York City deserved its own potato chip and that his company, Saratoga Potato Chips, just starting up, deserved to save some money on the millions of cubic feet of gas it would take to cook them.

title: ALL WE SURVEYED
description: A WRITER'S AMERICA Landscape in Literature. By Alfred Kazin. Illustrated. 240 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: Gallaudet University Installs Deaf President
description: Gallaudet University has officially installed Dr. I. King Jordan as the first deaf president in the history of the nation's only university for the hearing-impaired.

title: Works by 2 Pottery Legends
description: ''I WRITE our names; Otto prints them,'' Vivika Heino explained. She had been asked how one could distinguish her pots from those of her husband; both names go on every piece made in their studio.

title:
FOCUS: PARADISE VALLEY, PA.;
Poconos Now More Than a Honeymooners' Haven
description: LEAD: Nestled in the Pocono Mountains on a wooded site as peaceful as this little village's name stands Cranberry Creek Estates, part of a development surge transforming this area from a vacation refuge to an exurban residential community.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: A Day in the Death of Joe Egg Starring Alan Bates, Janet Suzman, Peter Bowles, Sheila Gish, Joan Hickson, Elizabeth Robillard, Murray Melvin, Fanny Carby, Constance Chapman, Elizabeth Tyrell. Directed by Peter Medak. 1972. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 106 minutes. $69.95. Rated R.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: A LONG LONG SONG Written and illustrated By Etienne Delessert. Unpaged. New York: Michael Di Capua Books/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $13.95. (All ages)

title: Squatter Touches Off Homeless Battle
description: When Dorothy King decided in August that she would illegally occupy a boarded-up, vacant house in the shabby northeast section of Denver, the aim was to ignite government interest in helping the city's growing homeless population. That she and her cause might be consumed in the ensuing blaze was not a concern.

title:
GARDENING;
For Mice and Men, a Common Treat
description: LEAD: MANY plants produce nuts that mature in the fall. Hickory nuts, walnuts and chestnuts are prized by both humans and the squirrels, chipmunks, mice and other rodents that store them for the winter by. In fact, humans may have to beat out the rodents to get their fair share.

title: Restoring the Enola Gay And a Point in History
description: Aircraft restorers are working to recreate a B-29 heavy bomber exactly as it was when it changed the face of warfare in 1945.

title: Dukakis, in South, Fights G.O.P. Labels
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis campaigned in the politically troublesome South today trying to erase what is perceived as his negative images. He bought five minutes of national television time to ask voters to ignore the campaign ''of fear and smear'' that he said Vice President Bush was running.

title: Role Models Examine Values
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Local Colleges; Fordham Is Upset By Stony Brook, 3-0
description: Bob Burden's 31-yard field goal at 9 minutes 22 seconds of the first quarter gave Stony Brook a 3-0 upset over previously undefeated Fordham in a Liberty Conference game yesterday at Patriots Field in Stony Brook, L.I.

title:
GARDENING;
Pick Your Favorite Squash for Halloween
description: LEAD: PUMPKINS come in all sizes these days from tiny to small to large to huge. Seedsmen have divided them into four.

title: BLOOD, SWEAT AND 9.2 MILLION WORDS
description: WINSTON S. CHURCHILL Volume VIII: ''Never Despair,'' 1945-1965. By Martin Gilbert. Illustrated. 1,438 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin. $40. CHURCHILL A Photographic Portrait. By Martin Gilbert. Illustrated. 374 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin. $24.95.

title: Fending Off the Mr. Fixit Cult
description: CONTRARY to public opinion, wives don't always want their husbands to fix things around the house. I am aware of the ''List of Jobs to Do'' that women hand spouses, but most of this list hearsay is myth, invented, no doubt, by men who crave sympathy. Trust me when I tell you that most women dread the thought of their husbands' tackling home repairs.

title: Vermont
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed the article on the glass blower Simon Pearce and Quechee, Vt., (Travel, Aug. 21) so much that five of us rushed there the very next day. Unfortunately, Alberta Eiseman failed to mention that the prices for everything, except the glassware, are extraordinarily high (even by Manhattan standards) and that the restaurant staff and manager were extraordinarily rude (also even by Manhattan standards).

title: 3 Youths Now Held in Killing of Man and Rape of Wife and Daughter
description: A third teen-ager from the Bronx was arrested yesterday and charged with being part of a gang that robbed and killed a former employer and then broke into his house and raped his wife and daughter, the police said.

title: Interior Dept. Weighing Proposal to Reduce Jobs
description: The Interior Department is trying once again to reduce its staff and transfer many duties to private industry.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: IMAGES SINCE '74

title: Correction
description: An article on page 27 of the Arts and Leisure section today about Jonathan Miller's version of ''The Mikado'' gives an incorrect time for the broadcast Friday on Channel 13 in the New York area. It begins at 9 P.M.

title: Byram Hills Stops Hackley on Strong Running and Defense
description: WESTCHESTER

title: Zoning Challenged in North Salem By TESSA MELVIN
description: A DEVELOPER has gone to court in an effort to overturn North Salem's new zoning ordinance and increase residential density in the town.

title: Baseball Notebook
description: Raines Will Pass Up New-Look Free Agency for Expos Pact

title: The Fate of Baby Amy
description: Not many years ago, physicians could offer little more than sympathy to parents of newborns with hypoplastic left-heart syndrome. Now, parents must decide, under great duress and with limited and often conflicting information, whether to allow such infants to die peacefully and relatively quickly or to stake all their hopes on risky and experimental, but possibly life-saving, surgery.

title: Schools Split on 'Open Campus'
description: FOR Jennifer White, a senior at North Shore High School in Glen Head, an open campus has meant the freedom to leave school at lunch time, as well as during other free periods, to work on independent research projects. This, Ms. White says, is a privilege she cannot afford to lose. However, if the School District decides, by its targeted deadline of mid-November, to close the high school campus, students no longer will be permitted to leave school during the time when they are not in scheduled classes.

title: Review/Music; The Six-String Be-Bop of Mundell Lowe
description: About halfway through his first set at Bradley's on Wednesday night, Mundell Lowe, the guitarist, started in on ''Stomping at the Savoy.'' When he finished the melody, but before he started his improvisation, he sprayed out chiming harmonics, which Ron Carter, the bassist, immediatly played back to him. The audience, silent and enraptured, of all different ages, took it in; jazz seemed like the local music of the neigborhood.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ON BORROWED TIME: How the Growth in Entitlement Spending Threatens America's Future. By Peter G. Peterson and Neil Howe. (ICS/Kampmann, $24.95.) Government entitlements can destroy the economy unless we change our collective minds about what should be done with them, argue Peter G. Peterson and Neil Howe.

title: Susan Lundergan Weds R. J. Gentile
description: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Susan Teresa Lundergan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. Lundergan of Bradenton, Fla., to Richard Joseph Gentile 2d, a son of Mrs. Richard J. Gentile of Kansas City, Mo., and the late Mr. Gentile. The Rev. Michael Marchlewski performed the ceremony.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 23, 1988
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 5 THE DARK TOWER: The Gunslinger, by Stephen King. (Plume/NAL, $10.95.) Volume One of a series about a young man's pursuit of an evil force. 2 3 HEAVEN AND HELL, by John Jakes. (Dell, $5.95.) Two families in the aftermath of the Civil War. 3 5 MURDER IN THE CIA, by Margaret Truman. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A C.I.A. operative investigates the suspicious death of a literary agent on her way to Budapest. 4 3 A SOUTHERN FAMILY, by Gail Godwin. (Avon, $4.95.) The effect of a violent death on an eccentric North Carolina clan. 5 3 HEAVEN CENT, by Piers Anthony. (Avon, $4.50.) A young prince's search for a missing sorcerer. 6 3 HER MOTHER'S DAUGHTER, by Marilyn French. (Ballantine, $5.95.) A chronicle of four generations of women. 7 2 THE MAIDEN, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $4.50.) The passion of a warrior princess and a man who would be king. 8 * 15 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 9 5 LONIGAN, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $3.50.) Six short stories about life on the American frontier. 10 8 TEAM YANKEE, by Harold Coyle. (Berkley, $4.95.) The exploits of an American tank company in Europe - during World War III. 11 * 12 FALLEN HEARTS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.95.) The scandals and horrors of her past return to haunt a bride in a backwoods town. 12 27 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $4.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 13 2 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Plume/NAL, $8.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 14 7 THE FIVE BELLS AND BLADEBONE, by Martha Grimes. (Dell, $4.50.) Two Scotland Yard men track down a murderer. 15 2 MEMORY PRIME, by Gar and Judith Reeves-Stevens. (Pocket, $3.95.) Captain Kirk confronts an assassin in this new ''Star Trek'' novel. Weeks This On Week List Nonfiction 1 16 SMALL SACRIFICES, by Ann Rule. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) A police-procedural account of a case involving murder and incest in an Oregon town. 2 22 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions in treating serious illness. 3 19 THE POWER OF MYTH, by Joseph Campbell with Bill Moyers. (Doubleday, $19.95.) How mythology illuminates life's stages, from birth to coming-of-age to marriage to aging and death. 4 261 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 5 3 KEEPING SECRETS, by Suzanne Somers. (Warner, $4.95.) The actress recalls her experience as the daughter of an alcoholic. 6 12 SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright with Paul Greengrass. (Dell, $4.95.) The autobiography of a former member of the British secret service. 7 7 VEIL, by Bob Woodward. (Pocket, $4.95.) The inside story of William Casey's years at the helm of the C.I.A., 1981 to 1987. 8 5 I'M WITH THE BAND, by Pamela Des Barres. (Jove, $3.95.) The ''confessions of a groupie'' known as the Sweetheart of Rock. 9 24 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Touchstone/S&S, $7.95.) A critique of American liberal arts education during the past 25 years. 10 7 ALL IN THE PLAYING, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $4.95.) Behind the scenes of the television series ''Out on a Limb.'' 11 * 12 THE HERO WITH A THOUSAND FACES, by Joseph Campbell. (Princeton University, $9.95.) The human race's struggle for identity, seen through many centuries of mythology. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 4 THE ESSENTIAL CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $12.95.) Cartoons about a boy, his toy tiger and his parents. 2 6 TALES TOO TICKLISH TO TELL, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) ''Bloom County'' cartoons. 3 21 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) How to solve your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. 4 11 FEELING GOOD, by David D. Burns. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) A physician's treatment for depression without the use of drugs. 5 13 NIGHT OF THE CRASH-TEST DUMMIES, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $5.95.) The ninth collection of ''Far Side'' cartoons. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Ex-Hostage Recalls A Victory Over Death
description: LEAD: ''WHEN you confront the possibility of your own death many times in the span of three weeks, it puts your life into perspective. Even though I was only 17 at the time, it certainly helped me to evaluate what's important and what's not.''

title: No Headline
description: I would like to respond to the article ''Brand-New Degree and No Place to Go'' [ Opinion, Aug. 28 ] .

title: A Mother's Lament
description: I WOULD wash his mouth out with shaving cream, if I could catch him. I would give him a good kick if he didn't move like a gazelle, his arms and legs too long, flying as he runs. Amazingly large feet ''almost'' housed in red bleached, blotched sneakers hit the floor with a force unworthy of his bony body. I would kill him one day, I swear as the door slams so hard that it causes the hurricane lamps to rattle.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: East; West Virginia (7-0) Scores a 59-19 Rout
description: Major Harris passed for three touchdowns and ran for two, and a reserve tailback, Undra Johnson, rushed for 111 yards and scored twice to lead West Virginia to a 59-19 rout of Boston College today.

title: The Rivera Was an Edsel
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Of the Week; Does Davey Johnson Deserve to Come Back?
description: Absolutely not. He doesn't communicate with his players except through remarks to the press. He appears more afraid to offend certain players than to do what the team needs. He shows little confidence in other, younger players. He sacrifices defense in the hope of the homer. Bring on McCarver. ROBERT FREDERICKS Garden City, L.I.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 9 about campaign tactics of Israeli political parties misstated the views of a communications analyst. The analyst, Dr. Yehudit Elitzor of Hebrew University, said commercials by the two leading parties suggested an attitude of ''I'll bet voters aren't going to use their heads.'' She did not express that sentiment as her own.

title: Justice O'Connor Seen As in Good Condition
description: Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor of the Supreme Court was described today as being in good condition and resting comfortably at a Washington hospital after surgery for breast cancer.

title: Behind the Facade: World of the Sea Re-Created on Land
description: THE Pacific kelp bed at Mystic Marinelife Aquarium is a popular exhibit that evokes visions of the sunny California coast. It might surprise exhibit visitors, however, to learn that it is not really Pacific kelp in there. In fact, it is not kelp at all, but a plastic rendering.

title: A Radically Rethought Magical Kingdom
description: Probably no music pulls so many generations of Americans into the same imaginative world as Walt Disney's movie songs. Since the 1937 release of ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs,'' Hollywood's first full-length animated feature, every generation has had an opportunity to enter this magical kingdom at an impressionable age, as the film has been systematically reissued. That's one reason why its most famous tunes, ''Heigh Ho,'' ''Whistle While You Work'' and ''Some Day My Prince Will Come,'' created by the Disney staff writers Frank Churchill and Larry Morey, seem as ageless as Christmas carols and campfire songs.

title: CONGRESS ADOPTS TAX CODE CHANGES
description: The tax bill that Congress approved early today increases a variety of business taxes, especially those of military contractors, and cuts some taxes on individuals, notably farmers. The tax increases and reductions, at about $4.1 billion each, will roughly balance each other.

title: THE WORLD: Two Views on Occupied Territories; Israeli Election Is Partly a Referendum on Borders
description: Israel's national elections only eight days away, public opinion polls show the public evenly divided on the campaign's crucial issue: how the region can make progress toward peace. Voters to the left want to give up parts of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, while those to the right want to keep control over the territories, where 1.7 million Arabs live and where an uprising against Israel is in its 11th month. The race appears deadlocked, with neither the left-wing Labor Party nor right-wing Likud likely to be able to form a governing coalition.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption with an article about Venice on Oct. 2 in The Sophisticated Traveler, part 2 of The Times Magazine, misidentified the church visible across the Grand Canal from the Piazzetta di San Marco. It is San Giorgio Maggiore.

title: How 'Cotillon' Was Reborn
description: When George Balanchine was named the first ballet master and choreographer of the Ballets Russes de Monte Carlo - the company formed to fill the void left by the collapse of Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes in 1929 - he immediately set about recruiting new dancers. For the troupe's 1932 debut season, he engaged Tamara Toumanova and Irina Baronova, both 13 years old, and the 14-year-old Tatiana Riabouchinska, all of them children of Russian emigres in Paris; their virtuosic precocity prompted the indelible sobriquet: ''the baby ballerinas.''

title: 'Children Have to Have Role Models'
description: THE waiting lists at Connecticut's mental health clinics for children grow longer every day. Among the reasons seen by Patrick Bologna, a psychiatric social worker who has been the director of the Child Guidance Center of Greater Bridgeport for 14 years, are a shortage of money and therapists. The result, he said, is that more children who need therapy are going without help.

title: Boston Appointee Felt Racism's Pain
description: Twelve years after a beating turned Theodore C. Landsmark into a symbol of this city's racial tensions, the black lawyer and educator has been appointed to direct a municipal social service agency.

title: Prospects; Toward a 'Pentagon Inc.'
description: A study panel of the Defense Science Board last week urged the Pentagon to take the lead in the battle to keep American industry competitive. The panel, which will release its report next month, called for linking the nation's economic policies with its military strategies, particularly in research and technological development. Will the Pentagon prove the solution for making American industry more competitive? Charles Wolf Jr. Director of international economic studies at the Rand Corporation.

title: Compaq Finally Makes a Laptop
description: A battery-powered laptop computer was finally introduced last week by the Compaq Computer Corporation. For several years, while other companies were reaping millions of dollars in the emerging market, Compaq steadfastly refused to bring out a laptop, saying it would not be content with the compromises that existing technology would require. Only when a laptop could equal the performance of a desktop model, Compaq said, would it produce a laptop.

title: Emily Schmidt, A Banker, Weds
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill, Mass., Emily Schmidt, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Kurt F. Schmidt of Brookline, Mass., was married yesterday to Mark Clay Andrews, the son of Mrs. Hugh H. Andrews of Cummaquid, Mass., and the late Mr. Andrews. The Revs. Stephen V. Smith and Suzanne Hiatt performed the ceremony.

title: Sit on My Laptop
description: TIME WAS, THE SEX-ist male boss dreamed of inveigling his female secretary to sit on his lap. Today, male and female executives dream of using their laps as launching pads for brainy little machines called >laptops.

title: Other People's Dresses
description: Even after she promised six years ago to quit borrowing designer gowns and jewelry, Nancy Reagan apparently did not say ''no'' to such loans. After Time magazine reported last week that the First Lady had in recent years worn numerous borrowed outfits ranging in value from $1,500 to more than $20,000, a White House spokesman acknowledged that Mrs. Reagan had gone back on her word. ''She broke her little promise because she just didn't feel she had to do it,'' said Elaine Crispen, Mrs. Reagan's press secretary. When news articles first questioned the practice in 1982 and Mrs. Reagan promised to stop it, the Office of Government Ethics said she had done nothing improper. Although the White House nevertheless agreed to disclose such loans, the disclosures ceased after 1982.

title: Polish Those Manners, Newark Tells Cabbies
description: Mayor Sharpe James said he was outraged one night when a Newark resident called to complain that a taxicab driver at Newark International Airport refused to take her to Market and Broad Streets in downtown Newark.

title: Drug Money is Fighting Crime
description: LAW enforcement officials are turning crime against itself. Millions of dollars from drug dealing have been put to use against crime in Connecticut under a four-year-old Federal law allowing assets seized in drug raids to be returned to the state and local police.

title: Capt. A. J. Williamson Has a Wedding
description: Capt. Annesley Jeanne Williamson and Maj. Jonathan Hunter Jaffin, both surgeons in the Army Medical Corps, were married yesterday at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn., by the Rev. Roland E. Jones.

title: Westport Residents Join to Save a Doomed Tree
description: LEAD: ON Washington Avenue in Westport, neighbors know one another and hold an annual clambake. Recently they banded together to save a tree.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''It would be a tragic mistake if Western capital enables the U.S.S.R. to put off the hard choice between guns and butter.'' Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, on the new bank loans being arranged for the Soviet Unions.

title: Abigail Goldberg Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. L. John Goldberg of London and Saratoga Springs, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter Abigail Shira Goldberg to Adam Garett Speigel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Spiegel of Van Nuys, Calif. A December wedding is planned. The bride, a graduate of the Shipley School and Mount Holyoke College, is an account administrator at the Washington office of Johnson & Higgins, insurance brokers. Her father is a senior vice president in the London office of Johnson & Higgins. The future bridegroom, a graduate of the University of California at Los Angeles, is a third-year student at the Georgetown University Law Center. His father is an accountant in Tarzana, Calif.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Less than a week after being named the Green Bay Packers' starting quarterback, Don Majkowski, has signed a two-year contract, which will reportedly bring him $550,000 a year. . . . Lawrence Taylor has reached an out-of-court settlement with the 19-year-old man who said the Giant linebacker had caused $300 in damages to his car when he kicked a door in a traffic dispute in August. No terms of the settlement were announced. . . . Lori McNeil and Claudia Kohde-Kilsch have qualified for the Virginia Slims tennis championships at Madison Square Garden Nov. 14-20. . . . Penny Fendick has replaced Mary Jo Fernandez on the United States Wightman Cup tennis team, which will play Britain in London next week. Fernandez withdrew with a back ailment.

title: MOUTH, EAR, NOSE
description: UNDER THE JAGUAR SUN By Italo Calvino. Translated by William Weaver. 86 pp. New York: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95.

title: JADED GENTLEMEN OF VERONA
description: HOME THOUGHTS By Tim Parks. 208 pp. New York: Grove Press. $16.95.
