title: The Fate of Baby Amy
description: There is no single right answer when you are asked if risky heart surgery should be performed on your newborn child (''The Fate of Baby Amy,'' by Lynne Vuillemot, Sept. 25). With full respect for Lynne Vuillemot's decision, I feel a need to present another side to this story. I share Lynne's intense grief - from the moment I learned my baby daughter, Anna, was born with hypoplastic left-heart syndrome to the pain and numbness of her death a month ago.

title: GHOSTS AND GOBLINS BY MAIL
description: Because it culminates in Christmas, fall is the biggest selling season for mail-order catalogue companies. And thanks to Halloween, the fall shop-by-mail season, which once began at Thanksgiving, is extended by almost a month.

title: ISRAEL'S OTHER WAR
description: FOR THE LAND AND THE LORD Jewish Fundamentalism in Israel. By Ian S. Lustick. 244 pp. New York: Council on Foreign Relations/Kampmann & Company.

title:
Focus: The Poconos;
Resort Draws Long-Distance Commuters
description: LEAD: Nestled in the Pocono Mountains on a wooded site as peaceful as this little village's name stands Cranberry Creek Estates, part of a development surge transforming this area from a vacation refuge to an exurban residential community.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
A 25th Anniversary
description: LEAD: Tarrytown House, believed to be the first executive conference center with overnight accommodations in the United States, is marking its 25th year this season.

title: A De-Japanned 'Mikado' Frisks Onto the Small Screen
description: This Friday evening at 9, local Savoyards should be prepared to shout hurrah or to shake in their shoes as PBS broadcasts Jonathan Miller's radically reinterpreted, de-Japanned version of ''The Mikado,'' staged originally for the English National Opera in 1986. (In the New York City area, Channel 13 will broadcast the show at 10 P.M.) Opening the 16th season of the Great Performances series, this two-hour production of the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta stars the Monty Python alumnus Eric Idle as Ko-Ko, the cheap tailor-cum-executioner. It was produced last year by Britain's Thames Television, which taped Mr. Miller's popular version directly off the stage of the London Coliseum during performances before an audience.

title: DRUG BILL PASSES, FINISHING BUSINESS OF 100TH CONGRESS
description: In a self-congratulatory mood, Congress early today passed comprehensive legislation aimed at curbing the supply of illicit drugs and the public's demand for them, approving the measure as its final act before adjournment.

title: A Rising Challenge to the Reagan Policy on World Debt
description: SIX years ago, when Miguel de la Madrid was approaching inauguration as President of Mexico, the United States rallied behind him with a $1.8 billion loan to shore up his economy. Now Mr. de la Madrid is leaving and another President-elect, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, will take office Dec. 1. Again, the United States is preparing an emergency short-term loan - this time, of $3.5 billion.

title: What to Pack
description: To the Editor: Having read and saved Betsy Wade's article ''Packing Without the Angst: Making a Priority List'' (Practical Traveler, Sept. 4), I decided to let world in on two secrets that keep my husband happy.

title: Michael Steers Plans To Wed Ann M. Lyons
description: Prof. and Mrs. John L. Lyons of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ann Martha Lyons to Michael Steers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Coster Steers of Greenwich. A Nov. 12 wedding is planned.

title: Students Find an Electoral Voice
description: LEAD: WHEN 1,100 students at the State University of New York at Stony Brook registered to vote in the local election, they did more than take advantage of a recent agreement allowing them to do so. They were making a statement of their intentions to have a voice in the community.

title: INNOVATIONS IN FANGS, BROOMSTICKS AND CANDY CORN
description: Halloween is the nation's eighth most popular occasion for sending greeting cards, says the Greeting Card Association, a trade group. And the use of Halloween cards is growing.

title: Weed-Covered Pillars Preserved in Pound Ridge
description: LEAD: FOUR classical columns that for years have intrigued motorists on Long Ridge Road near the Connecticut border here are being preserved as a landmark honoring the memory of an American heroine of World War I.

title: Katharine du Pont Sanger Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. George T. Weymouth of Wilmington, Del., and Fishers Island, N.Y., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Weymouth's daughter Katharine du Pont Sanger of Sanibel Island, Fla., to Lewis Polk Rutherfurd of New York and Hong Kong. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: Ceiling Fixtures
description: CEILING fixtures for overhead lights, chandeliers or electric fans often must be removed during interior painting or redecorating, or to check a malfunction. Although the means by which these items are attached to the ceiling is usually hidden from view, fixture mountings are seldom as mysterious as they may seem.

title: Q and A
description: The Azores

title: Dogs May Be Banned by Maine Island
description: Percival Baxter, a former Governor of Maine, loved dogs. He lowered the flag on the State Capitol when one of his Irish setters died, and he gave a 100-acre island to the state so that his dogs' graves would be cared for after he was gone. Now, almost 20 years after his death, dogs may be banned from the island.

title: For Mexicans, A Lame Duck Isn't So Lame
description: Back in early July, before political parties in the United States had even picked their candidates, Mexican voters went to the polls and chose Carlos Salinas de Gortari as their next President. Nearly four months later, Mexico's President-elect is still patiently counting the days until his inaugural on Dec. 1.

title: THE CHARGE OF THE LITTLE PLATOONS
description: IN PURSUIT Of Happiness and Good Government. By Charles Murray. 341 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: In Hewlett, Italian and Aiming to Please
description: VITO'S of Hewlett is a restaurant with an identity crisis. Is it Italian, yuppie, contemporary, traditional, economy or luxury? A case can be made for any of the above. The exterior and name are Italian. The interior is modern and trendy: etched glass, gray spare walls, black lacquer chairs and ephemeral art.

title: In 'Hot' Suffolk Race, G.O.P. Tries to Retake Seat
description: One of the nation's most sharply contested Congressional races is shaping up here in eastern Suffolk County, where the Republican Party sees the possibility of reclaiming a House seat that was lost in 1986.

title: Women Must Lead Their Own Lives, Make Their Own Choices
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Milwaukee;
Downtown Is Looking Up
description: LEAD: NEW apartment buildings with above-average rents are making this city's downtown commercial and industrial center a fashionable address. In the last year, three buildings with a total of 628 apartments have been completed and are more than 80 percent leased, ending two decades of little residential construction.

title: NEVER A BLACK SHEEP BARING
description: THE SIXTH GREAT POWER A History of One of the Greatest of All Banking Families, the House of Barings, 1762-1929. By Philip Ziegler. Illustrated. 430 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $29.95.

title: Both Bentsen and Quayle, Stumping on Home Turf, Display a Sense of Ease; Democrat Reveling in Role as Monitor of the G.O.P.'s Ads
description: Seventeen days before what may be the first general election defeat of his 40-year political career, Senator Lloyd Bentsen is as cheerfully undaunted as if the polls still showed the Democratic ticket with its midsummer lead.

title: When the Speed of Rockets Delivered the Mail
description: FOR hobbyists who collect stamps by topic, one of the most popular areas is space exploration.

title: 2 in Arctic Go Where Few Will Venture
description: If helicopter pilots have a particular nightmare, it is one that features flying low, in fog, over mountainous terrain. But for Linh Ho, a 45-year-old veteran of the South Vietnamese Air Force, such perils are to be taken in stride, whether they are encountered here in the Canadian Arctic or in the Pleiku Highlands of Vietnam.

title: THEIR BRILLIANT CAREERS
description: THE WAY IT WAS An Oral History of Finance: 1967-1987. By the Editors of Institutional Investor. 815 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $24.95.

title: SAVING FOR ARMAGEDDON
description: SURVIVING THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990 Protect Your Assets and Invesments - And Come Out on Top. By Ravi Batra. Tables. Charts. 367 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95. HOW TO PROFIT FROM THE NEXT GREAT DEPRESSION By John L. King. Tables. Charts. 208 pp. New York:. New American Library. $17.95.

title: Marcos Indictment Will Aid Manila, Aquino Says
description: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that the indictment in a New York court of her predecessor, Ferdinand E. Marcos, would serve as a deterrent to leaders who believe themselves to be above the law.

title: Getting Real
description: To the Editor:

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Alan Sagner;
National Security as a Business
description: LEAD: WHEN Alan Sagner, 68 years old, was chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, he learned about Business Executives for National Security, a group that is trying to ''redefine national security.'' According to the group, national security consists of more than weapons and armed forces.

title: Davis's Sister to Testify on Night of Police Raid
description: The sister of Larry Davis who answered the door when the police burst into her Bronx apartment with guns drawn almost two years ago is expected to testify in his defense tomorrow.

title: Stiffer Penalties on Insider Trades And Rewards for Informers Voted
description: Capping a two-year struggle to address Wall Street's insider trading scandal, the Senate early this morning approved legislation that greatly increases the monetary penalties and jail terms for the crime.

title: Matching Images With Words
description: LEAD: WITH few exceptions, the 20 artists now on exhibit at the Sabbeth Gallery of the Wunsch Arts Center in Glen Cove are unknown to the general public; even the gallery and museum-going public.

title: The Fate of Baby Amy
description: Amy's story touched me deeply, especially for the compassion with which she was allowed to live, and die.

title: Village Embroiled in Historic District Dispute
description: BECAUSE of a long-simmering dispute in its historic district, the village of Tarrytown is involved in separate suits filed by two property owners in the neighborhood.

title: About Cars; A BMW That Meets All Requirements
description: I am soliciting sympathy. Here I am in a bright red example of Bayerische Motoren Werke's handicraft and I have to give it back because the test is over.

title:
MUSIC;
Australians Are Finding Their Own Musical Path
description: LEAD: Australians with an interest in musical history are fond of pointing out that the first white settlement, in 1788 on the shores of what is now their country's most populous city, Sydney, was established when Mozart was at the height of his creative powers and Haydn on the eve of unparalleled celebrity.

title: What to Pack
description: To the Editor: An effective aid in reclaiming lost luggage is to add the name of the hotel where you will be staying upon arrival to the name tags (one inside and one outside) on your luggage.

title: UNION REBEL: Jerry Tucker; The Man Who Is Fighting the U.A.W. From Inside
description: When the governing body of the United Auto Workers union meets on Dec. 5, an unusual tension is likely to pervade the session. For the first time in at least 30 years, union leaders will be confronting a genuine rebel in their midst.

title: What to Pack
description: To the Editor: The first consideration is security. I had zippers sewn to fasten the inside pockets of my sport jackets. One pocket was deepened to hold airline tickets, vouchers and traveler's checks. The other pocket was for passports and money. All valuables are now virtually pickpocket proof.

title: Matchmaking as a Retirement Career
description: IT'S never too late,'' says Hyalie Hurwitz, a Manchester woman who specializes in bringing together mature Jewish singles in Connecticut, Rhode Island and western Massachusetts.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE WORLD OF ''MESTRE'' TAMODA. By Uanhenga Xitu. Translated by Annella McDermott. (Readers International, Cloth, $16.95; Paper, $8.95.) Blessed is he who can laugh at the preposterous irony that punctuates the lives of Angola's people, colonized and colonizers alike. Doubly blessed is Uanhenga Xitu, the Angolan author and revolutionary who cleverly constructed ''The World of 'Mestre' Tamoda'' while imprisoned by the Portuguese authorities between 1959 and 1970.

title: Next Best Thing To Walking on Air
description: OPEN backs and curved medium-high heels give shoes being shown with the Paris ready-to-wear collections a comfortable, airy look. This front-laced style, a favorite of Christian Lacroix in leather or straw, is almost prim from the front, but light at the sides and back. It is paired with his more formal spring daytime clothes. His summer play clothes skim along on flat thong sandals in cotton prints inspired by his native Provence. All the Lacroix shoes are made by Diego Della Valle. (In Manhattan, the shop is located at 462 West Broadway, near Prince Street.)

title: Khrushchev Son's Tale: 'No Struggle for Father'
description: Following are excerpts from the fourth installment of Sergei N. Khrushchev's diaries, published today by the weekly magazine Ogonyok and translated by The New York Times. The narrative deals with the 1964 ouster of the author's father as Soviet leader and begins with Nikita S. Khrushchev and the Soviet President, Anastas I. Mikoyan, seated in the rear of the leader's plane after being summoned urgently back to Moscow from his Black Sea retreat.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: South; N.C. State Beats Clemson by 10-3
description: The tailback Chris Williams ran for a 5-yard touchdown with 10 minutes 4 seconds to play to give North Carolina State a 10-3 upset of Clemson today in an Atlantic Coast Conference game.

title: Follow-Up: All Bets Off at Raceway
description: THE likelihood of Roosevelt Raceway operating again as a standardbred race track appears remote.

title: Bush Edge Is Holding In Survey
description: A Gallup Poll for Newsweek magazine gives Vice President Bush a 50 percent to 41 percent lead over Michael S. Dukakis, a margin basically unchanged from the last Gallup Poll.

title: Julie Muir Weds James D. Kenny
description: The wedding of Julia Louise Muir, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Muir 2d of Larchmont, N.Y., to James Douglas Kenny, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis J. Kenny of Larchmont, took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Augustine in Larchmont. Msgr. Walter F. Kenny performed the ceremony.

title: 'Wasserella' in Expansion Mode
description: All in all, last week was a pretty good week over at Wasserstein, Perella & Company.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International/3-19

title: Role Models Are Needed
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Split on Turf at Laurel
description: Capades won the Selima Stakes and Luge II won the Laurel Futurity today as American and foreign horses split the first two races of the International Turf Festival at Laurel Race Course.

title: FICTION
description: SPEAKING IN TONGUES. By Linda Ashour. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Lucy Lerner, the American narrator of Linda Ashour's promising first novel, has moved to Provence, where she shares a renovated country house with her husband, a French photographer, and their young son. In ''Speaking in Tongues,'' Ms. Ashour comically exploits the clash of cultures in Lucy's life as she shuttles back and forth between France and the Bible Belt of Oklahoma, where her family still lives. Along the way, we meet a poet who is arrested for publicly posting an ode to body hair; a young Frenchwoman with a voracious, and possibly dangerous, appetite for American jeans; Lucy's son, Sam, who alarms his nursery school teacher with fantasies of himself as a fish; Lucy's mother, Agnes, whose evangelical leanings lead her on a pilgrimage to a born-again faith healer; Lucy's cousin, Ella, who sends her letters from the state mental hospital doused in vanilla extract; and Lucy's brother, Cody, who marries and then deserts Tulsa's former Tractor Queen. Ms. Ashour, who was born in Oklahoma and has lived in France, reveals the turmoil in Lucy's life in a comic novel that is often rich and lyrical. However, it begins to lose focus toward the end; while there's a final family reconciliation, we're never sure just why it is that Lucy has gone to such extremes to keep her two lives separate. Still, Ms. Ashour portrays her characters with depth and wry humor. This is an auspicious debut by a talented writer.

title: SMALL FARMERS: AN ENDANGERED SPECIES
description: RAISING LESS CORN AND MORE HELL Midwestern Farmers Speak Out. By Jim Schwab. Illustrated. 301 pp. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. $24.95. FAMILY FARMING A New Economic Vision. By Marty Strange. Tables. Charts. 311 pp. Lincoln: Institute for Food and Development Policy/ University of Nebraska Press. $18.95.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It made everybody think about this job again and that dying is a part of it. When this happens to two in one day, you can't ignore that dying is a part of the job.'' - Thomas Barnes, a New York police officer. [ 1:4. ]

title: The Race for Congress; Florida Senate Contest Turns on Performance
description: The candidates in the Senate race in Florida, one of the tightest in the country, use different labels to describe each other but agree that the contest turns on their competing ideologies as expressed in their voting records.

title: Old Money, New Power
description: ED BRADLEY, THE ''60 MINUTES'' CORRESPONDENT, was on the podium. He was speaking on an afternoon last May at the national convention of the American Association of Retired Persons, the subject of a famous expose by ''60 Minutes'' that accused the group of being little more than a front for an insurance company. But that was long ago - back in 1978, when the A.A.R.P. had only 10 million members or so. Since then, it has reorganized and nearly tripled in size, to more than 28 million.

title: Why Older Horses Run Into Our Hearts
description: Two weeks after Waquoit, named for a small town on Cape Cod, won the $1 million Jockey Club Gold Cup at Belmont Park on Oct. 8 he was paraded around his home track at Suffolk Downs in East Boston, Mass. More than 6,000 posters of the gray 5-year-old were given to a crowd some 25 percent larger than would normally be at Suffolk on a fall Sunday afternoon. Three cheers. No, let's make that 100.

title: Ann Fogarty Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Ann Elizabeth Fogarty to Mark Kevin Stanton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Stanton of Greenwich, Conn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Michael Joseph Fogarty of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., the parents of the future bride.

title: PHYLLIS WAS NEVER ANY FUN
description: THE COMPANION By Chaim Bermant. 176 pp. New York: St. Martin's. $14.95.

title: Nathan Levin, 84, Investment Consultant
description: Nathan W. Levin, an investment consultant who was a financial aide in the philanthropic work of the Julius Rosenwald Fund, died of congestive heart failure Friday at his home in Mt. Kisco, N.Y. He was 84 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

title: Pepper Has Minor Surgery
description: Representative Claude Pepper, Democrat of Florida, said today that doctors had discovered a ''small knot'' on a hernia scar in routine tests at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center after the close of the 100th Congress. Mr. Pepper, the chairman of the House Rules Committee and who, at 88 years of age, is the oldest member of Congress, said in the statement that the knot was removed in a minor surgical procedure Friday and that he expected to resume campaigning on Monday.

title: Hurricane Hits Nicaragua; Toll for Week Is Now 65
description: With powerful winds and torrential rains, Hurricane Joan smashed across Nicaragua's Caribbean coast today, splintering houses and unleashing floods and mud slides across a wide swath of Central America.

title:
DINING OUT;
Eclectic Newcomer in West Caldwell
description: LEAD: IT'S not often that an instructor gets to practice what he preaches, but William Decker is doing just that. The former director of the culinary program at Essex County Community College is now executive chef at an ambitious four-month-old restaurant in West Caldwell.

title: THE REGION: Debts by Any Other Name; The Most Public City Resumes Public Building - With a Lot Less Splendor
description: For one golden century, from the Civil War to the 1960's, New York stood out among American cities for the magnificence of its public works: subways and aqueducts, parkways, bridges and tunnels, libraries, parks and schools.

title: PRIMERS FOR PRESIDENTS
description: The literature of economics influences Presidents, even those who aren't notable readers. The 20th century is bracketed by two periods when books on economic questions mattered enormously - the progressive era of Theodore Roosevelt and Woodrow Wilson and the Reagan Presidency. Beneath today's slick campaign symbolism, the submerged economic issues of 1988 echo earlier debates. Does taxation kill incentive? Has the pendulum of deregulation swung too far? Should the Government or the marketplace provide health insurance? Does America need a national competitiveness strategy?

title: Exploring The Heart of Old Tokyo
description: IN the year 628, so the legend goes, two brothers named Hinokuma were fishing in the Sumida River, which ran through the little village of Edo - now called Tokyo - when they dragged up a statue of Kannon, the Goddess of Mercy.

title: Clothes Don't Make The Opera
description: The practice of updating classic operas or otherwise displacing them in time and place is not automatically to be despised. It is a device to be used cautiously, however, if at all. Any genuinely great work is delicately balanced, a structure built on subtleties of history, culture and artistic convention that may slip away and bring down the whole building if a single block is nudged out of place. An opera director who put ''Otello,'' say, in 20th-century dress would have to face the issue of race more squarely than one who left the action in 15th-century Cyprus. To the extent that a modernized ''Otello'' succeeded in throwing new light on the old tragedy, it would almost certainly have to twist Verdi's original out of shape.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; What Will Happen in The N.B.A. In '88-89?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title:
WINE;
Wine and Indian Fare: Some Bottles Do Work
description: LEAD: RECENT outings to the Bengal Tiger restaurant in White Plains and the chic dining spot Dawat in Manhattan (a branch of which just opened in White Plains), provided an opportunity to test the contention of many connoisseurs that Indian cuisine defies a successful marriage with wine.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
NO LIFE FOR CHILDREN
description: LEAD: When, in 1983, the photographer Mary Ellen Mark and Cheryl McCall, a reporter, set out to write about runaway children for Life magazine, they headed not for such hotbeds of social disorder as New York and Detroit, but for ''America's most livable city,'' Ms. Mark writes in STREETWISE (University of Pennsylvania, Paper, $24.95).

title: Reaching the Student Who Needs Special Help
description: LEAD: WHILE a relatively small percentage of students in the county drop out of school, there are many who ''drop out'' while continuing to attend school. ''I found a large group here who go to school, but have dropped out academically and socially,'' said Dr. Barbara Mason, a retired educator. ''These are the kids who keep getting negative messages.

title: For Children, a Lobby Old Enough to Vote
description: LEAD: CHILDREN'S interests in the election campaign are the focus of a new group.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: COMPARED TO WHAT? On Writing and the Writer's Life. By Thomas Farber. (Norton, $14.95.) Thomas Farber, a fiction writer now in his 40's, has written an amiable and lively account of himself at mid-journey. Allusive, anecdotal, ''Compared to What?'' is also admirably unsententious, particularly given the fact that it is his life as a writer with which Mr.

title: Cauliflower Fading As an Island Crop
description: LEAD: WHAT had been a Long Island harvest ritual for 71 years has passed into history, a victim of suburban sprawl, high labor costs and, in the current year, a bad growing season.

title: Temples Hewn From Rock in India
description: ''INDIA is the country, fields, fields, then hills, jungle, hills and more fields.'' E. M. Forster described it in 1924. The great cave temples of Ajanta and Ellora, elaborate structures that plunge into the basalt earth, lie sequestered in such Indian hills.

title: CD Players With a Light Touch
description: Advanced audio design is forever straining at the outer limits of technical possibility. Such heroic striving is essential to progress in the long run. In the short run, however, it sometimes inspires twisty refinements that accomplish very little aside from showing off the designer's technical bravura. This may account for some rather exotic innovations in several recent stereo components.

title: Outdoors; A Calendar for Small-Game Hunters
description: Most of New York State's small-game seasons are under way, and with few exceptions, they are similar to those of recent years.

title: ARE WE DOING ALL RIGHT SO FAR?
description: DAY OF RECKONING The Consequences of American Economic Policy Under Reagan and After. By Benjamin Friedman. 323 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: MINES STILL A PERIL TO GULF SHIPPING
description: Despite the cease-fire in the Iran-Iraq war, United States and Arab officials in the region of the Persian Gulf say shipping in the waterway still faces a threat from mines sown during the conflict.

title: When the Jailed Sue the Jailers
description: CHARGING that their constitutional rights had been violated in prison, 15 inmates sued the New York State Commissioner of Correctional Services and the prison superintendent - and won.

title: THE WORLD: Relief for Salinas; Buying Time in Mexico
description: IN offering to lend Mexico $3.5 billion, the United States last week gave President-elect Carlos Salinas de Gortari breathing room to relieve pressures that are as much political and psychological as financial.

title: EGGS, FRIENDS AND ECONOMICS
description: MEMOIRS OF AN UNREGULATED ECONOMIST By George J. Stigler. Illustrated. 228 pp. New York: Sloan Foundation Science Series/ Basic Books. $17.95.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additinal titles of interest:

title: 'Take 2 Candidates and Call Me in the Morning'
description: The slow-motion pictures are fuzzy in a warm way; the music is soft, the words airy. Is it a commercial for a men's cologne? Not exactly. It is a commercial for George Bush. With the debates over, the Presidential campaign has become a spattering of 30-second television commercials. A few years ago candidates were being sold like detergents; then it was breakfast cereals. This season the spots are more like those for pain relievers, which, by Nov. 8, viewers may need.

title: Idaho Firm on Barring Atomic Waste
description: Cecil D. Andrus, who has blocked a railroad car filled with radioactive wastes from entering a Federal storage site near here, acknowledged today that his move may lack legal justification.

title: Mad Ride to Nikko and Beyond
description: ''IF you will kindly accept the offer, I should like to show you a famous tourist site: the Slorp,'' said my host.

title: U.S. Court Says Feeding of Ill Woman May Stop
description: In the first decision of its kind at the Federal court level, a judge has ruled that a state hospital must remove a feeding tube from a comatose woman or transfer her to an institution that will comply with her family's request that the feeding be stopped. The state has agreed to try to find such an institution.

title: Energy Battle Looms Over Gas Pipelines
description: AS Governor Cuomo and state legislators lock horns over the Shoreham nuclear-power plant, a related energy battle is heating up over natural-gas pipelines, a battle that could have broad repercussions for Long Island.

title:
the anser iz faniks 
[
the answer is phonics
]
description: LEAD: William Bennett, the former Secretary of Education, was right on target when he pointed the way to closing the literacy gap between minorities and the middle class by teaching phonics. In fact, by using phonics - the relationship between letters and speech sounds and meaning - as a first step to teaching reading, Israel, Cuba and the Soviet Union solved widespread illiteracy problems in a single generation.

title: Q and A
description: One-Time Exemption

title: 'SPOOKTACULAR' VIDEOS WITH DRACULA AND FREDDY
description: Next weekend, employees of the National Video franchise in Appleton, Wis., will dress up in costume - for fun, but also to remind customers to buy or rent horror videotapes for Halloween. According to the assistant manager, Linda Gregorius, the 8,000-square-foot store stocks 7,500 titles. Twenty percent are in the horror or science fiction categories.

title: Lost in Translation
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Taipei
description: Unlike Rome, Taipei looks as if it were built in a day. In parts of the city, where straight roads swirl or zag into circular intersections, small alleyways or dead ends, the sense of urgency seems overwhelming: Cars spill onto sidewalks and up to a family's doorstep as if to shorten the distance to the dinner table; motorcycles scoot on sidewalks to skirt traffic; pedestrians hug street curbs to avoid sidewalk vendors; new stores display wares in boxes while workmen still paint the walls.

title: Protesters Must Honor Rights of Others
description: Richard Galligan disingenuously ignores the objective of the anti-hunter protestors, which is to prevent hunting, rather than merely register disapproval (''State Curtails Freedom of Speech,'' Opinion page, Sept. 25). His argument in favor of their unfettered ''free speech'' is really just the usual one propounded by the assorted zealots of our day who use their right of protest to interrupt and prevent the exercise of other citizen's legal rights.

title: Ms. Delano Wed To Photographer
description: At St. Mark's Church in-the-Bowery in New York, Laura Delano, a daughter Mr. and Mrs. William A. Delano of New York, was married yesterday to Benjamin Dimmitt, a son of Lawrence H. Dimmitt of Clearwater, Fla., and the late Betty Jane Roth Dimmitt. The Rev. David A. Garcia performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Hospitals: Strategies For Survival
description: LEAD: ON the way to the employee cafeteria, doctors and nurses at St. Barnabas Medical Center here can pick up a copy of the movie ''Rambo III,'' deposit their paycheck at the bank or stop by the travel agency to plan a vacation. Or they can pass up the cafeteria and head for the McDonald's just off the lobby.

title: Reading: Joy to Some, Battle to Others
description: This letter is to address the parents and teachers of Christine Meding (''Reading My Way to Success,'' Sept. 4) and to Christine herself. As an avid reader, I certainly can identify with Christine's love of the written word. Though not a reader at such an early age, I quickly learned the pleasures of being immersed in a great novel, a mystery story or a newspaper article.

title: Just a Prelude
description: THREE decades ago one of the rubber bridge strongholds in Manhattan was the Bridge House, where the high-stake game had a simple rule: No women. The players made an exception one day and admitted to their sanctum a young woman expert from the nearby Cavendish Club. For the first rubber she sat North, facing the late Fred Dossenbach, an experienced and skillful player.

title: In Health Care Policy, the Latest Word Is Fiscal
description: AMONG the changes wrought during the Reagan years, few may turn out to be so profound and irreversible as the reshaping of health care. Partly because of the Administration's initiatives and partly because of other social and financial forces, the roles of those who provide care and pay for it and the expectations of those who need it have been thrown into turmoil.

title: Hoya Runner Captures Title
description: John Trautman of Georgetown won the Big East Conference cross-country title in 24 minutes 48.8 seconds over five miles at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx yesterday. Providence, led by the third-place finish of Frank Conway in 25:05.6, won the team crown with 37 points. Georgetown, the defender, was second with 69. Tina Moloney of Providence won the women's 5,000-meter race in 17:28.6. Georgetown prevailed in the women's team competition with 37 points.

title: Politics Catches Up To 'The Candidate'
description: LEAD: In 1972, I wrote a movie for Robert Redford and director Michael Ritchie in which an idealistic young liberal reluctantly runs for Senator in California and, in the process, gets so pressured that he starts speaking the very nonsense that made him hesitate to run in the first place. At the end, when he is elected in an upset victory, he takes his campaign manager aside and asks: ''What do we do now?

title: Xiang-Dong Kong, Chinese Pianist
description: Xiang-Dong Kong

title: It's a 'King of Hearts' With a 'Nice' Touch
description: WITH ''King of Hearts,'' the Forum Theater Group can reclaim its identity as a second stage for the failed or so-called ''unsung musical.''

title: Hospital Workers Complain of Discrimination
description: A group of workers at a city-run hospital on Roosevelt Island has charged that senior black employees have been harassed and systematically removed from top positions since the hospital changed administrators three years ago.

title:
DINING OUT;
Salads, Pasta, Pizza in Eastchester
description: LEAD: WESTCHESTER has long been ready for an eating spot like Ciao's. The place offers excellent, stunningly arranged salads, about two dozen pasta dishes, individual and large-sized pizzas and a moderately priced wine list. That is it - the preferred food of today, fresh, light, delicious, healthful. The restaurant has been discovered.

title: Lord's Prayer Isn't His, Panel of Scholars Says
description: The Lord's Prayer - which begins ''Our Father who art in Heaven'' - is one of the most famous utterances of Jesus in the New Testament. A national group of biblical scholars concluded last week, however, that the prayer was really the work of early Christians who wrote it based on various ''ideas'' of what Jesus had said.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Little Compton, R.I.; Beach Option, Good to Dec. 15
description: THE Nature Conservancy, a national nonprofit conservation organization, has won an option to buy a beach of remarkable beauty even for Rhode Island - a state celebrated for its shoreline - and has until Dec. 15 to put together enough money to exercise the option.

title: The Case Against Japanese A.D.R.'s
description: Investors checking the lists of the largest point gainers or losers on the New York Stock Exchange could be forgiven for occasionally thinking that they must have opened to the Tokyo Stock Exchange page by mistake. On any given day, the Big Board's top-10 lists are likely to contain names like Matsushita, Honda and Sony. Although some of these issues were temporarily pushed out of the top 10 last week when bids for Kraft and RJR Nabisco sent food company stocks soaring, their absence was seen as temporary.

title: What to Pack
description: To the Editor: Maps are my No. 1 item. Another desirable inclusion is an eyeglass screwdriver kit for side pieces that come loose. Such a kit is small and available at any optometrist.

title: Debate on Islamic Law Further Strains Sudan
description: When Sadiq al-Mahdi was chosen as the Sudan's Prime Minister more than two years ago, there was hope in the West that the country might start to repair the worst of its political and religious problems.

title: Leslie Berger Marries Paul J. Kiernan
description: In Washington yesterday, Leslie M. Berger, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Berger of Harrington Park, N.J., was married to Paul J. Kiernan, a son of Richard R. Kiernan of New York and Greta S. Kiernan of Hackensack, N.J. The Rev. Michael J. O'Sullivan performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE LAST PORTRAIT OF THE DUCHESS OF ALBA. By Antonio Larreta. Translated by Pamela Carmell. (Adler & Adler, $17.95.) In 1802, the Duchess of Alba, sometime mistress of Francisco Goya and subject of his great painting ''The Naked Maja,'' was murdered. Who was her assassin? Antonio Larreta's first novel, the 1980 winner of Spain's Editorial Planeta Prize, provides an intriguing answer.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: SARAH SCHULTE'S little secret actually isn't. A while ago she realized that she had better tell it to her son and daughter (who live elsewhere) because, she said, ''If I was found dead looking like that, they might think it strange.'' And in fact, and to put it mildly, they most certainly would have.

title: Social Events; From SoHo to Harlem
description: Benefit for the Aged

title: How Defense Became Respectable
description: THE first man to revel in defense was Wilhelm Steinitz, who ruled the chess world from 1866 to 1894. He has disciples everywhere.

title: 2 'Rights' Are Wrong
description: ''Who is college football's winningest coach?'' That was the question posed by John McLain, a public relations consultant for Susquehanna University, in a series of letters sent to sports editors and writers this fall.

title: 5 Years Later, Grenada Is Tranquil and Thriving
description: They remember hearing the drone of airplanes over the island in the early morning darkness. As the sky began turning gray, a plane roared low over the new airfield the Cubans were building and antiaircraft guns opened up, spewing red tracer bullets. Another plane flew in even lower, and parachutes began blossoming behind it.

title: Laura Siegel, a Lawyer, Weds Stephen D. Stern
description: Laura Jane Siegel, an associate in the New York law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, was married yesterday evening at the Park Avenue Synagogue to Stephen David Stern, the director of sales planning and analysis at BMG Direct Marketing in New York. Rabbis Kenneth Berger and Barry Schaefer performed the ceremony.

title: No Republican 'Lock' on Electoral Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Perils of Owning Too Many Books
description: LAST summer, I encountered my mortality in some boxes of books -not by reading them but by counting them. I discovered that I own more books than I can read in the traditional life-span left to me.

title: NONFICTION
description: FALL FROM GRACE: Sex, Scandal, and Corruption in American Politics From 1702 to the Present. By Shelley Ross. (Ballantine, Paper, $9.95.) If you worry that politicians are mucking about more and reporters are happily raking up more of that muck, ''Fall From Grace'' offers reassurance. Sex, hypocrisy and corruption have been common and chronicled since New York was a backwash of a British colony. Indeed, before there was Gary Hart, there was Lord Cornbury, the British governor-general of Manhattan who opened the New York assembly of 1702 dressed in drag in the style of Queen Anne. Before there was Imelda Marcos, there was Mary Todd Lincoln, who bought 300 pairs of kid gloves while Yankee soldiers were shivering without blankets. Before there was Paula Parkinson, the blond lobbyist who was less than popular with Washington wives, there was Peggy Eaton, the daughter of a Washington tavern owner and the wife of Andrew Jackson's secretary of war, whose low-cut dresses and vivacious ways caused such a furor among the wives of Administration officials that President Jackson had to dissolve his entire Cabinet to end the ''petticoat war.'' Would you ever have guessed that the feeble President who brought you the Teapot Dome Scandal, Warren G. Harding, was capable of this sort of prose to his mistress: ''There is one engulfing, enthralling rule of love, the song of your whole being which is a bit sweeter - Oh, Warren! Oh, Warren! - when your body quivers with divine paroxysms and your soul hovers for flight with mine.'' And, in a more prosaic style, there was the wonderful seduction line uttered by Lyndon Johnson in the middle of the night to a female aide staying in a guest room at the Texas ranch: ''Move over, this is your President.''

title: Louise Dube Wed To Donald Cram
description: Marie Jennifer Louise Dube, a planning analyst with the Legal Aid Society in New York, was married yesterday in Ottawa to Donald Peter Cram, a budget analyst at the New York City Office of Management and Budget. The ceremony at St. Brigid's Roman Catholic Church was performed by the Rev. William Ashley.

title: What to Pack
description: To the Editor: An important item to leave at home is the set of stubs that record the checks you have already written. These are irreplaceable. Mine were stolen once, and it was four or five months before I knew how much money I had. DORA P. CROUCH Troy, N.Y.

title: When Race and Sex Don't Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I installed a device on my bathroom sink that attaches to the hot-and cold- water faucets to mix them so that the water comes out of a single spout. Very hot water came out and cracked the enamel in the sink, and I now have a rust patch under this spout. Can this be covered up or repaired in some way?

title: Nicola A. Belzer, an Editor, Is Married to Scott Richter
description: Nicola Alys Belzer and Scott Mark Richter were married yesterday evening at the Fresh Meadows Jewish Center in Queens by Rabbi Abraham Neustein and Cantor Hertzl Pinelis.

title: GOOD GUYS IN WHITE COATS
description: LEAD: DOCTORS The Biography of Medicine. By Sherwin B. Nuland. Illustrated. 519 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: More Guidebooks for the Shelf
description: MOVE the Mobil Guides and the A.A.A. Tour Books over; space needs to be made for the Zagat Hotel Survey of the United States, which is published in two volumes, and the TravelVision U.S.A. Sightseeing Guides, which is published in four. Zagat, creator of pocket-width city-by-city restaurant guides with citizen ratings, enters the hotel-resort-spa rating stakes next month. TravelVision put its new project out last summer; it does not evaluate, but provides copious names and phone numbers for lodgings, and will be helpful to people on the road who make up their plans as they go along.

title: Smith Helps Islanders Extend Unbeaten Streak
description: The game was unruly, but it was ruled by the Islanders, and they extended their unbeaten stretch to four games with a 7-3 victory tonight over the Nordiques.

title: Five-Alarm Fire in Brooklyn
description: A five-alarm fire at a Brooklyn warehouse sent flames high into the evening sky along the East River yesterday, but the authorities said the building was apparently unoccupied and no injuries were reported. A fire department spokesman, said the fire at 55 Kent Avenue in the Greenpoint section was reported at 6:49 P.M. By 7:20 P.M. it had reached five alarms, bringing about 150 firefighters and 60 fire trucks to the scene. The fire was declared under control at 8:54 P.M., he said.

title: Second-Half Surge Sends Michigan to Top in Big Ten
description: Michigan, leading by a point at halftime, broke open a close game with a razzle-dazzle touchdown in the third quarter and surged to the lead of the Big Ten Conference today with a 31-6 victory over Indiana.

title: Ozone 'Solutions' Won't Work
description: Recently, Dr. Paul S. Cohen urged New Jerseyans: ''Let's Take Action to Reduce the Ozone on Route 1'' (Opinion page, Sept. 11). His solution: more highways and more cars - the very sources of ozone and congestion.

title: DATABANK: October 23, 1988

MUSIC;
3 Libraries Offering Matinees
description: LEAD: HE county's libraries, schools and musical clubs will be centers of musical activity this week, starting today with three intriguing free library matinees. One features a lecture and film, another offers works by seven female composers and the third presents the Sleepy Hollow Chamber Players, an ensemble otherwise to be found in residence at Tarrytown's Hackley School.

title: The Growing Fear of Fortress Europe
description: There is a magnificently simple vision behind the European Community's plans to remove internal trade barriers in 1992: help the 12-nation community grow faster by encouraging more competition and efficiency.

title: WHILE GOD WAITS US OUT
description: MARGARET OF THE IMPERFECTIONS By Lynda Sexson. 211 pp. New York: Persea Books. $16.95.

title: CUOMO ULTIMATUM OVER SHOREHAM
description: Governor Cuomo has asked the leaders of the State Legislature to call their members back to Albany to approve the closing of the Shoreham nuclear power plant or, he said, he will call a special session himself.

title: Question Of the Week; Does Davey Johnson Deserve to Come Back?
description: If you believe that baseball is solely a matter of sitting back and waiting for the long ball to put the game on ice, relegating to oblivion the contributions of defense, base running and such offensive minutiae as bunting, squeeze plays and manufactured runs, then Davey Johnson is your manager for the future and deserves to come back. LARRY and TOBY DEUTSCH City Island

title: Defense Sustains Penn (6-0)
description: Penn kept both its unbeaten record and its hold on first place in the Ivy League intact today with a 10-3 victory over Yale in the cold wind at Franklin Field.

title: A Bach Organ Mass
description: The organist Anthony Newman is to play Johann Sebastian Bach's German Organ Mass at Holy Trinity Church, 316 East 88th Street, today at 5 P.M. The concert is the first of two programs devoted to all the surviving organ music Bach wrote during his years of service in Leipzig, from 1723 until his death in 1750. The second installment is to take place on Nov. 6. Tickets are $8. Information: 289-4100.

title: In Suffolk, Wider Role For Airport
description: LEAD: BESIDES being used by weekend commuters, flight schools, private pilots and the Air National Guard, Suffolk County Airport in Westhampton Beach is home for some 64 tenants in its industrial park.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: San Francisco; Housing Built Over a Store
description: WHAT is believed to be the first donation in the country of air rights over a privately owned commercial facility to build low-income housing has been made by Standard Brands Paint Company to the Bernal Heights Community Foundation in San Francisco.

title: In Disasters, a U.N. Agency Produces Order
description: When hurricane Gilbert struck Jamaica last month, knocking out communications on the island, amateur radio operators were organized to carry information on the extent of damage. In Bangladesh, when the country was hit last month by the worst floods in memory, there were large stocks of food on hand to face the immediate crisis. Before the rains came to Sudan last August, causing widespread destruction, plans had been prepared for coping with floods.

title: Perspectives: Greenpoint's Historic District; Store Owners Bristle at Review Process
description: Banks can be patient. In the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, the East New York Savings bank has been operating a new branch for a year and a half in a former lingerie shop without putting in a new storefront. Business has been less than booming.

title: Nevada Supreme Court Upholds Bar on Gay Rodeo
description: A state judge on Friday barred the Gay Rodeo National Championship from holding the event in this northern Nevada town, and the state Supreme Court upheld the decision.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Desserts Can't Be Too Thin; or Too Rich
description: LEAD: LONG ISLANDERS are dedicating themselves to fitness, exercise and nutrition. That's six days a week. Then, in two hours in a restaurant on Saturday night, they engage in a gastronomic practice known as ''Vive le deluge,'' which makes hedonists look positively Spartan.

title: DANCING WITH THE OPPRESSORI
description: LADY MORGAN The Life and Times of Sydney Owenson. By Mary Campbell. Illustrated. 250 pp. Winchester, Mass.: Pandora Press/Unwin Hyman. Cloth, $34.95. Paper, $14.95.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: AT HALLOCKVILLE With a special emphasis on crafts popular during the decades between 1890 and 1910, Hallockville, the 19th-century museum farm in Northville, holds its annual Fall Festival today from noon to 5 P.M.

description: To the Editor:

description: THE CAPTAIN AND THE ENEMY By Graham Greene. 189 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: With Shore Ailing, Ads on Tourism Turn Inland
description: ALTHOUGH the state's new tourism advertising was planned before pollution problems in Long Island Sound became major news, the focus on inland attractions could bear fruit next summer, if the coastal problems persist.

description: To the Editor:

title: THE UNTRUSTWORTHY MADE SIMPLE
description: UNDERSTANDING THE NEW ECONOMY By Alfred L. Malabre Jr. 174 pp. Homewood, Ill.: Dow Jones-Irwin. $19.95.

Marinan Jr., is hoping for such a favor from his party's Presidential candidate, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis. ''I'm no fool,'' Mr.

title: Would-Be 'Rescuers' Create Emergencies to Display Heroics
description: What prompts a person whose job entails rescuing people to create the very emergency - to set a fire, say - that allows him or her to be the rescuer?

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: The Diamond District; New Facet for an Area That's Bursting at the Seams
description: EARLIER this year, Michael and Geri Bondanza moved their jewelry company into an oddity in Manhattan's diamond district: a building specifically designed for it.

title: Miss Kaplan, Lawyer, Wed to Michael Kupin
description: Rhonda Kaplan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Kaplan of Plainview, L.I., and Michael Barry Kupin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Kupin of Yonkers and New York, were married last evening at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn, L.I., by Rabbi Joseph Sternstein.

title: A Church Heps Pupils Dream of College
description: THIS promises to be a busy year for Demetria Davis. In addition to her usual seventh-grade classes at Thomas J. Quirk Middle School in Hartford, she plans to spend a lot of time voluntarily in study hall.

title: A.T.&T.'s Competition Is Looking More Real
description: A YEAR and a half ago, the future looked bleak for the MCI Communications Corporation and the U S Sprint Communications Corporation, the two principal competitors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in the long-distance telephone market.

title: Teatro del Sur's Wild Odyssey To the Next Wave

Argentines, it seems, prefer their theater big, star-studded and unequivocal, and so Teatro del Sur, which is anything but brassy, quietly carried out its intricate explorations of sound and light and movement without the undue distractions of recognition and income.

A Federal grand jury last week indicted Mr. Marcos, his wife, Imelda, and several other people on charges of participating in a scheme in which the Marcoses used more than $100 million in embezzled cash to purchase real estate and other personal property in New York City. The Marcoses were also charged with defrauding two American banks of more than $165 million.

Patrick is too modest to add that it is a balance aided immeasurably by the simple fact that he is finally back on his skates.

His bid for a second term in a Presidential election year is likely to attract a larger

title: Question Of the Week; Does Davey Johnson Deserve to Come Back?
description: The Mets are a collection of considerable individual talents without an apparent sense of team drive. Johnson will probably not change that condition and the outcome will be the same. ROBERT REGGIO New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I installed a device on my bathroom sink that attaches to the hot-and cold- water faucets to mix them so that the water comes out of a single spout. Very hot water came out and cracked the enamel in the sink, and I now have a rust patch under this spout. Can this be covered up or repaired in some way?

title: Whalers Win
description: Carey Wilson, the center, had two goals and an assist tonight as the Hartford Whalers beat the Philadelphia Flyers, 8-6, in the National Hockey League. Penguins 7, Blackhawks 4

title: From Uruguay, Woolens in Style
description: ROLLING grasslands, English pedigree sheep and a climate similar to that of New Zealand have long made Uruguay a leading exporter of fine wool. And for the last 20 years, this small South American nation has also been the source of richly colored handknits, the creation of a knitting cooperative called Manos del Uruguay.

title: Infected But Not Sick: An AIDS Story
description: EVERY Tuesday and Friday morning I meet a nurse who tries to save my life. We tell jokes and talk about family and friends as I sit for a half hour being infused with Ampligen, an experimental drug that is believed to arrest the AIDS virus.

title: ISLIP, A YEAR AFTER THE BARGE
description: Last year, when officials in Islip, L.I., realized the town landfill was filling up, they banned commercial trash to save space for household refuse.

title: Deficit Double Talk From Candidate Bush
description: To the Editor:

title: FICTION
description: HAZARD AND THE FIVE DELIGHTS. By Christopher Noel. (Knopf, $16.95.) The title of Christopher Noel's first novel refers to his high-spirited heroine, 20-year-old Hazard MacIntyre, and her pronouncement of ''the five things that make life worth living.'' Hazard and Baker Samuels, formerly childhood playmates, now close friends and tentative lovers, inhabit a summery Vermont landscape where they're perpetually in flight from the pedestrian and prosaic. Baker, a starry-eyed innocent, witnesses and experiences miracles. Hazard expresses her exuberance mainly through ''quickmotion'' - the first of the Five Delights. Baker's muse and mentor, she inspires their adventures, including a playful jaunt that transports them into a tall pine tree. There, atop a branch 15 feet off the ground, they engage in tender lovemaking. But despite the coming-of-age theme and Baker's sexual initiation with Hazard, this novel often reads like a children's storybook. Baker, for example, assigns fanciful names to his escapades (''the Miracle of the Chestnut Pine Tree'') as well as to his haunts (''the Scoop-Out''). Two dogs, Everet and Nutmeg, and an assortment of other animals crowd the story and often guide the characters in their search for secret knowledge. In a childlike voice almost choked with hope and wonder, Mr. Noel's narration advances his fable and mirrors Baker's poetic sensibility: ''The sun was close to rising. There was a solid goldness filling Baker up. . . . His arms felt like they could lift anything, no, everything.'' There's a distinctive imagination at work in ''Hazard and the Five Delights,'' albeit one that is occasionally prodigal in its expression. Readers tolerant of Mr. Noel's penchant for whimsy will find a sweet wisdom and quirky charm in his storytelling.

title: Trouble and Strife
description: THE BAKER'S WIFE Starring Raimu and Ginetta Ledex (in photo). Directed by Marcel Pagnol. 1938. Interama Video Classics. 124 minutes. $59.95.

title: NUCLEAR ARMS PLANTS: Where the Chain Has Broken
description: SAFETY problems permeate the far-flung plants that make atomic bombs, hydrogen bombs and the fuel for warship reactors. All the sites are old; Oak Ridge, Tenn., and Hanford Reservation in Washington date to the early 1940's, the dawn of the nuclear age. For many years, their managers say, the Government provided little money for maintenance, let alone improvements. Now, even as it considers spending more than $170 billion to modernize the system and clean up tons of toxic wastes, the Department of Energy has decided that two plants pose so severe a threat to workers and people who live nearby that they must be closed. A third has been closed by the workers themselves, who are striking over pay and safety concerns. ROCKY FLATS: Energy Department halted processing Oct. 8 after three people were exposed to plutonium for lack of a warning sign . . . Built in 1952 . . . Has had dozens of fires, which sometimes spread plutonium-laden smoke over Denver area, yet inspectors found fire suppression measures ''antiquated'' . . . Leads Environmental Protection Agency list of Federally owned hazardous waste sites. FERNALD: Workers have been on strike two weeks . . . Built in 1951, 20 miles from Cincinnati . . . Report in April found ''pervasive'' management problems and worker exposure to radiation . . . For decades, tons of uranium and other radioactive wastes were stored in leaky pits and cracked tanks, contaminating area water supplies . . . Filters on ventilation stacks broke about once a month for years, allowing ''relatively large amounts'' of uranium dust to escape . . . Ohio residents sued contractor that used to run plant; Energy Department filed a motion saying that it was Federal officials, not the contractor, who repeatedly decided to let pollution continue. SAVANNAH RIVER: Energy Department forbade restarting reactors at South Carolina plant in August pending retraining of operators who pushed ahead with procedures even though the reactor was not responding according to plan, as long as the unexplained response was not considered dangerous . . . Metal reactor vessels show markings that might indicate cracks . . . Built in 1954, it has five reactors, two of them permanently disabled . . . Improperly buried wastes have contaminated groundwater . . . Scores of tanks hold highly radioactive liquids.

title: Question Of the Week; Does Davey Johnson Deserve to Come Back?
description: Davey has admirable qualities as a manager - his gift for nurturing young pitchers may be the most important - but I'm sure many Met fans share my fear that this very talented group will never play up to its potential with Davey's relaxed approach to the basics. ANN STEINBERG New York

title: On the Adoption Of Black Children
description: As an adoptive parent, I cheer the state's effort to find permanent homes for hard-to-place black children (''State Offers New Program on Adoption of Blacks,'' Sept. 11). However, I continue to be outraged at the Division of Youth and Family Services' reluctance to place black children with white families.

title: The Fate of Baby Amy
description: ''The Fate of Baby Amy'' was a powerful story.

title:
ART;
Works by Boccioni On View at Yale

title: Army Pins Down Rutgers
description: Army gained respect and plaudits today with a well-earned 34-24 triumph at Giants Stadium over a Rutgers team that had been favored by as much as 10 points.

description: ONCE upon a time, way back when Harry S. Truman was in the White House, John Cameron Swayze was on television and Studebakers were on the highways, stylish women carried Samsonite cosmetic cases when they went on trips.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Trees for the Digging
description: LEAD: Visitors to the Marshlands Conservancy, the county-owned wildlife sanctuary and environmental education center in Rye, can come away with more than pleasant memories Saturday. If they come with a pick and a spade, they can take home oaks and maples, as well as other varieties of trees and shrubs.

title: Plan for Rail Line Sets Suburb Against City in Los Angeles
description: To Jeffrey L. Levine, a businessman in the San Fernando Valley, the Valley is ''Leave It to Beaver'' land, all suburban families, manicured lawns and station wagons. To Rabbi Marvin Sugarman the Valley is an ''island of tranquility'' for his Orthodox flock. And to Robert C. Bonner, the United States Attorney here, it is the pornography distribution capital of America.

title: Talking: Bridge Loans; Slow Sales Enhancing Importance
description: The slowdown in home sales in the Northeast and other areas is reviving the need among buyers for bridge loans. A bridge loan is short-term financing that provides a buyer with the funds necessary to close on a newly purchased home before his present home is sold.

title: Block Printing at the Zimmerli
description: WOODBLOCK printing appeared in the West about the same time that paper-making and type were introduced - in the early 1400's. Since then, the medium has had its ups and downs and, according to Nicholas Carpasso, the guest curator of the current show at Rutgers's Zimmerli Museum, it has been enjoying an ''up'' since the beginning of the decade. Mr. Carpasso has selected more than 65 prints and blocks from the Rutgers Archives for Printmaking Studios for a show entitled, ''Relief Printing in the 1980's.''

title: A Loving Treatment for Mental Illness
description: SHE screamed at me, her face red with anger and puffy from the medication: ''What are you doing here? I don't know you!''

title: You Can Have a Jack-o'-Lantern and Eat It, Too
description: AS autumn deepens, country markets glow with seasonal pumpkins. From tiny to giant, they beckon. But purchase a pumpkin and then what?

title: On Plant Survival
description: KEEP after leaves; rake or blow them off the lawn and add them to compost; run the mower over grass to break up leaves into pieces so they will decompose faster. Bulb and evergreen planting continues. Last call to dig and divide perennials. Watering

title: 'The Nerd' Who Came To Dinner and Stayed
description: THE best and perhaps only reason for seeing ''The Nerd'' at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale is Jared Roy's side-splitting performance in the title role. Other than that, there's not much here. The minimal plot of this play by Larry Shue revolves around the fact that Willum Cubbert (all but the title character have unusual names) had his life saved by a man named Rick Steadman when they served in Vietnam.

title: Under Wraps
description: IN HER LIFETIME, IT TURNS out, she was important enough, the daughter of a dignitary. But now, 2,500 years or so later, Wenu-hotep, an Egyptian mummy who has resided at the Children's Museum in Indianapolis since 1959, has staked a claim as a scientific pioneer. Aided by the new technology of three-dimensional CT (computerized tomography) scans, science is recreating her face.

title: Photography Center to Move in Spring
description: The International Center of Photography is to move its midtown gallery next spring into expanded quarters at 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43d Street, the center's founder and director, Cornell Capa, has said. The new two-floor museum will provide four times as much exhibition space as the center's current gallery at 77 West 45th Street.

title: Badgers on the Moor
description: MY adventures never resemble those first-person narratives in gorgeous travel magazines: ''Shivering uncontrollably, watching my last supplies tumble down the chasm, I noticed the brilliant moon shining on the Himalayas.'' Just thinking about high altitudes I feel the beginning throb of a migraine. ''Burning sand swirled around our camels, blinding me, and I wondered if we would ever reach the oasis.'' I'm uncomfortable in Minnesota during a hot, dry summer. ''At the end of 30 miles with 40 pounds on my back, I was pleased to see the cliffside youth hostel.'' Even with no pounds on my back, I am pleased to log five or six miles on a level footpath.

title: The Menace of Trade Blocs
description: A watershed in world trade lies not far ahead. Decisions during the next Administration can determine long-term health of the U.S. and world economies, affecting politics and defense.

title: Andrew L. Hogan Wed to Dorothe di Bonaventura
description: Dorothe Cristina Allegra di Bonaventura, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mario di Bonaventura of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Andrew Lally Hogan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Anthony Hogan Jr. of Greenwich. The ceremony was performed at the nondenominational First Church of Round Hill by the Rev. Avery Manchester.

title: Horace Mann Reviving Football
description: With grand heritage and a commitment to athletics, Horace Mann High School could be a model football environment. Its expansive campus in the Riverdale section of the Bronx begs for the bulky shoulder pads and bulky sweaters of brisk Saturdays in the fall.

title: Memorial for Dorothy Parker
description: Before her death in 1967, Dorothy Parker, the Jazz Age writer and critic reknowned for her caustic wit, suggested her own epitaph: ''Excuse my dust.''

title: Political Memo; Just Talking of Landslide Has Rival Camps Uneasy
description: Two weeks ago, the 1988 Presidential campaign between George Bush and Michael S. Dukakis was widely regarded as a close race in which the Vice President had a small advantage. Now, after the second debate between them, politicians have begun to talk about a Bush landslide.
