description: The future of daily newspaper competition will be at stake next Friday. That is when a Federal appeals court in Washington hears arguments concerning a plan to create the nation's biggest business combination of newspapers in the same city.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: The Big Day For the Next President

title:
GARDENING;
A Natural Pesticide With Promise
description: LEAD: A garlicky-smelling natural oil derived from a common shade tree in India may soon become an important weapon against insects. The oil, extracted from seeds of the neem tree (Azadirachata indica), contains a complex molecule, azadirachtin, that protects plants against nearly 200 different insects.

title: A New Booklet for the Disabled
description: LEAD: A COMMUNITY'S concern about needs for the disabled has led to a new booklet, ''Access Guide,'' recently issued by the Eastchester Committee for the Disabled.

title: Lisa Broida, a Lawyer, Wed to M. S. Josephson
description: At the Harmonie Club in New York, Lisa Ann Broida, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin S. Broida of Ridgewood, N.J., was married last evening to Michael Steven Josephson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Josephson of Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Alex J. Goldman performed the ceremony.

title:
GARDENING;
For Mice and Men, a Common Treat
description: LEAD: MANY plants produce nuts that mature in the fall. Hickory nuts, walnuts and chestnuts are prized by both humans and the squirrels, chipmunks, mice and other rodents that store them for the winter by. In fact, humans may have to beat out the rodents to get their fair share.

title: What's Old in . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Of the Week; Does Davey Johnson Deserve to Come Back?
description: The Mets have invented a new statistic: plays not made (p.n.m). When anything but a strikeout will advance a runner, they strike out. Why doesn't a runner tag up from first on a fly to the outfield? How come the captain didn't make trips when he was hurt? Why can't guys bunt? Why can't pitchers hold runners at first? Obviously, some teaching still needs to be done. I doubt Tommy Lasorda or Whitey Herzog would sit cross legged while p.n.m.'s pile up. Bye, Davey. ROBERT STEVENS New York

title: INSIDE
description: Hurricane Hits Nicaragua

title: The Fate of Baby Amy
description: As the mother of a 5-month-old baby girl, I remember vividly how my body felt following her birth. My breasts ached as they filled with milk; after 24 hours of hard labor, every muscle from my neck to my calves was so sore I could stand for only a few minutes. I cried and laughed, cried and laughed, from joy, exhaustion and hormonal chaos for days.

title: Try, Try Again
description: He has tried and failed twice, but Jackie Nicklaus is not one to give up. The 27-year-old son of Jack Nicklaus is making his third attempt in three years to qualify for the PGA Tour.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Making Jersey City a Center for Offices
description: LEAD: ONCE a desolate tract of worn-out factories and dilapidated piers, Jersey City's waterfront has undergone substantial commercial revitalization over the last five years in tandem with mammoth, predominantly residental projects such as Newport and Port Liberte.

title: Portrait of Poussin as a Young Artist
description: When the time comes to call the honor roll of international exhibitions in the 1980's, a place will be kept warm and ready for ''Poussin: The Early Years in Rome'' at the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth. In the way of sustained intellectual stimulation it has had few rivals. It deals with a vital, much disputed and hitherto enigmatic period in the career of one of the greatest of all European painters (and one who has never before been the subject of a large-scale exhibition in the United States).

title: STREETSCAPES: Readers' Questions; Letters on Life, a Wilde House and a Hospital That Died
description: This is another in a series of columns that appear from time to time to answer readers' questions about New York's changing streetscapes.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: South Portland, Me.; Another Coup For a Suburb
description: WHEN the Guy Gannett Company, which publishes Portland's two daily newspapers and The Maine Sunday Telegram, decided to build its printing plant and distribution center here, some residents thought it was a real coup for the Portland suburb.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Greenwich
description: TWENTY years ago the image that Greenwich projected - New England charm, exquisite homes, fine schools, freedom from crime, many recreational and cultural facilities and low taxes - earned it the nickname Camelot.

title: Boy Faces Drug Charges
description: A 10-year-old boy has been arrested and charged with juvenile delinquency for possession of heroin and cocaine with intent to sell, the state police said. The boy, not identified because of his age, was carrying $190 and what the police suspect was 10 packets of heroin and three packets of cocaine, the police said. He pleaded not guilty in Brockton Juvenile Court and was released on bail in the custody of his parents.

title: Jane Eyre Fergus Marries
description: Jane Eyre Fergus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Fergus of New York, and Joseph Berritto Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Berritto of Howard Beach, Queens, were married yesterday at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in New York by the Rev. Peter Colapietro. The bride, a graduate of St. John's University, is a transportation coordinator for the ABC-TV program ''Good Morning America.'' The bridegroom is a project manager at Lincoln Scenic Studios, builders of theatrical sets in New York.

title: Playing Mozart On Mozart's Own Terms
description: Like Ferruccio Busoni, the legendary piano virtuoso of the early 19th century, Vladimir Horowitz, another supervirtuoso, has turned to Mozart in his old age. Busoni, who had been identified with Bach, Beethoven and Liszt, with the colossal works of the repertory, started to give Mozart concerto series in the last two decades of his life. In the early years of this century, it was unprecedented. Only two Mozart concertos were played those days - the D minor (No. 20, K. 466) and the A major (No. 23, K. 488). Busoni let the world know that there were many more than those two, all equally wonderful. But despite his considerable authority, Busoni never succeeded in starting a Mozart revival. That remained for the period after World War II, when Mozart was rediscovered with a vengeance.

title: Patricia Chamberlin Wed to E. F. Keyes
description: Patricia Ann Chamberlin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Chamberlin of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Edward Frank Keyes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Keyes of Barrington, R.I. The Rev. Paul T. Keyes, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at St. Paul Roman Catholic Church in Princeton.

title: The Writer of 'Daisy' Repairs 'Pizza'
description: LEAD: WHEN the Off Broadway play ''Driving Miss Daisy'' was well on its way to winning the 1988 Pulitzer Prize for drama last year, its author, Alfred Uhry of Morris, was working in the Hilton Hotel in Mystic, serving as a doctor for the ailing dialogue in the Sam Goldwyn film ''Mystic Pizza.''

title: Annals of American Poetry: Pound and the Bollingen Prize of '49
description: To the Editor:

title: HANDICAPPING
description: For any cuisine to survive through the centuries, it has to be closely associated with health. Throughout its history, great cuisine -from Chinese to French to Indian - follows that code. Yet when people speak about diet food, it brings to mind tasteless, boring concoctions and tiny portions. The current euphemism ''spa cuisine'' is not much better. It puts so much emphasis on decoration that the minuscule pieces of permitted food are usually buried under a mound of beautiful flowers and other inedible paraphernalia.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The All-Purpose Animal

title: Greeks Seize Captain Of Freighter in Crash
description: The Greek authorities detained the captain of an Italian freighter and accused him of ramming a Greek cruise ship on Friday, but Italian officials said today that the freighter was at a standstill before the fatal crash.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: NO-FRILLS GUERNEY Patrons of the Long Wharf Theater are in for a unique experience when they see ''Love Letters,'' the new production opening Friday for a week of previews before its regular run from Nov. 4 to Dec. 11. Written as a tour de force for two actors by A. R. Gurney Jr., it has been staged only once, before an invited audience at a benefit for the New York Public Library.

title: Victoria
description: To the Editor: It saddens but does not surprise me that Moira Farrow's ''What's Doing in Victoria'' (Travel, Aug. 28) did not mention the museum devoted to the city's most famous and marvelously eccentric native daughter. When last we visited, even the taxi driver had never heard of the Emily Carr Gallery of the Provincial Archives of British Columbia at 1107 Wharf Street in downtown Victoria. The gallery celebrates, in a modest but enthusiastic fashion, the writings and paintings of this typically Victorian child, who studied art in Paris but then returned to British Columbia because she was convinced that its native American art, and landscape, was nearing its end. She captured both, in her seven books and her art, and through them earned for the Indian tribes a new respect throughout Canada and the world.

title: Center on 47th St. Helps The Mentally Ill Adjust
description: The front door is never locked, and there are no guards. The carpeted entrance hall has a curved staircase, chandeliers and papered walls with paintings. In the mornings, there is always coffee waiting.

title: >Museum: 3 Sites In Running
description: THE first major step in developing a railroad museum for the state will be taken Friday when the New Jersey Railroad and Transportation Study Commission is expected to pick a site.

title: Hits That Make A Heart Sink
description: Dutifully, with a sense of dread, I slapped Bon Jovi's ''New Jersey'' on the turntable the day it arrived. The new album was all I expected and worse. By the time I played it again, it had probably sold a million copies, maybe two. By now, according to Polygram Records, ''New Jersey'' has sold three million copies, a third of the total sales of its predecessor, ''Slippery When Wet.'' ''New Jersey'' zoomed immediately to No. 1 on the album charts and will likely stay there awhile. I may have to boycott commercial rock radio stations well into 1989.

title: Women Must Lead Their Own Lives, Make Their Own Choices; Is Father Criminal?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Better the Colleges, The Better for Us All
description: THOUGH the election of a President will dominate the ballot in November's election, there are many other important choices that New Jerseyans will be asked to make. Besides choosing a United States Senator, members of Congress and countless municipal officials, voters will be asked to decide on a number of public questions.

title: THE NATION: Debate on Quality; Efficiency Marches On, And Some Patients Are Left Behind
description: WHILE the dispute continues over health-care financing, the debate over health-care quality is just beginning.

title: Speaking of Rehabilitation
description: Not everybody thinks of Watergate when Richard M. Nixon shows up these days. At the Daytop Village drug treatment center in Bethel, N.Y., last week, Mr. Nixon was praised as one President who offered more than slogans in his war on drugs. ''Under his Administration we had expansion of treatment programs and introduction of preventive efforts,'' said the Daytop president, Msgr. William B. O'Brien. In an address to 400 teen-agers and young adults, Mr. Nixon cited the experiences of people who had overcome drug addiction and other obstacles. Seeming to recall some tough times of his own as well, he said, ''Suffering a shattering defeat is not the end.'' But when asked if he was speaking from experience, the former President responded, ''Absolutely not.''

title: Way Out in the Outback
description: YOU know you are approaching the Australian outback when the sheep in the fields are no longer as white as they were along the coast; they're a dusty ocher, instead, colored by the red clay soil. You also know you're in the outback when a giant truck has an elaborate network of steel bars - 'roo bars - bolted across the front of the tractor to protect the driver and vehicle from wandering kangaroos, which have no road sense.

title: EPIC! HEROIC! AMERICAN!
description: LEAD: AN EMPIRE OF THEIR OWN How the Jews Invented Hollywood. By Neal Gabler. Illustrated. 502 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $24.95.

title: Bucknell Gets Help From Columbia
description: Columbia made enough mistakes yesterday to help Bucknell achieve its first victory of the season after six setbacks.

title: A Father Sees the End of the Line
description: Y wife and I held moist hands as we sat in a small office on Yale-New Haven Hospital's seventh floor, the wing for infant care.

title: Forty Niner Is The Real Thing
description: Forty Niner illustrated yesterday that a very good horse can overcome a very ordinary rider by scoring a brilliant victory in the inaugural $500,000 N.Y.R.A. Mile as New York's regular jockeys continued their strike at Aqueduct Race Track.

title: Nuclear Arms Plants: A Bill Long Overdue
description: LIKE O-rings on a shuttle booster or rusting bolts on a highway bridge, weaknesses long overlooked in the nuclear weapons industry are now being recognized as precursors to a potential disaster. Recent plant shutdowns have broken fragile links in the production chain, impairing the country's ability to maintain its nuclear stockpile and raising far-ranging concerns about human health and safety.

title: Islamic Nations Seek to Improve Food Output
description: Leaders of Islamic nations met here this week to discuss a question crucial to all their development efforts: Why can't the Moslem world feed itself?

title: Review/Music; Stuttgart Symphony Plays Russian Works
description: Carnegie Hall has offered us a week of European orchestras with nationalistic bents. Last Sunday, the Lausanne Chamber Orchestra brought us music by Honegger; the Prague Symphony followed on Wednesday with a program that was Czechoslovak from beginning to end.

title: Elway Sidelined
description: After watching his star quarterback limp through some test drills on a sprained ankle Friday, Coach Dan Reeves of the Denver Broncos knew that John Elway would not be playing against the Steelers in Pittsburgh today. ''He's tender, and knowing John, he would try to do things he normally does, from a reaction standpoint,'' Reeves said. ''And then he could aggravate it.''

title: The Soviet Challenge, Unanswered
description: Which Presidential candidate offers more promise in foreign relations? On the most important relationship, this campaign remains, for both candidates, a campaign of missed opportunity.

title: The Economics of the Waste Crisis
description: Even as disposal costs are skyrocketing, the United States now throws away more trash than any nation in the world, fostering a problem that is both economic and environmental.

title: DATA UPDATE: October 23, 1988
Innovations From Munich's Masters Of Art Nouveau
description: Scores of exhibitions over 30 years have reviewed the development of the Art Nouveau style, focusing on its materials, its designers or the cities where it flourished. Now, the Philadelphia Museum of Art has organized another such survey, presenting many little-known works of German innovators in ''Art Nouveau in Munich: Masters of the Jugendstil, 1895-1910.''

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Brookline, Mass.;
A View From The Summit
description: LEAD: SUMMIT HILL, a $7.5 million, 20-unit condominium project being built atop Corey Hill in this Boston suburb, has a view of wooded conservation lands now ablaze in fall colors.

title: On an 8-Mile Jog, a Question Answered
description: FLUSHED with the sweat and surety of an eight-mile jog along the Belmar boardwalk, my running companion exulted in the moment: ''Someone should write about this!''

title: THE RISE AND FALL OF THE AMERICAN ECONOMY
description: THE GREAT U-TURN Corporate Restructuring and the Polarizing of America. By Bennett Harrison and Barry Bluestone. Tables. Charts. 242 pp. New York: Basic Books.

title: Flood aters Anger a Southampton Community
description: LEAD: EVELYN HEINSSEN'S children used to play volleyball on the hard-packed sandy yard behind her summer house in Rose's Grove, a tiny community of several dozen homes on Little Peconic Bay in Southampton. Now, flood waters mark the game poles up to the bottom hole for the net.

title: Lawyers at Odds: News as Court Tactic
description: THE battle to get the ear of reporters covering a news event - and ultimately the attention of the public - has become an expensive public relations tug of war, with courtrooms among the battlegrounds.

title: Tricks and Treats for Grown-Up Children
description: Whether it is greeting cards, candy or costumes, Halloween continues to grow in popularity as an adult celebration. Not that children are excluded from the festivities. Rather, marketers say, the baby boom generation, with its tremendous buying power, has appropriated the occasion as its own, and businesses are picking up on this trend.

title: Genevieve Cook Weds Accountant
description: At the Cosmopolitan Club in New York, Genevieve Hogan Cook, a daughter of Mrs. Philip C. Jessup Jr. of Washington and Michael J. Cook of Canberra, Australia, was married yesterday to Mohamed Moustafa, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mahmoud H. Moustafa of Alexandria, Egypt. Judge Richard M. Palmer of Family Court in Manhattan officated.

title: Richard J. Ilchert Wed To Catherine Stewart
description: Catherine Ann Stewart and Richard John Ilchert were married yesterday at St. Monica's Roman Catholic Church in New York by the Rev. John O'Leary. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Stewart of Middletown, N.J., and the bridegroom is a son of Frederick A. Ilchert and Elizabeth A. Sutton, both of New York.

title: >Commuters Who Want To Fight Back
description: I read with great interest the article on Sept. 11 concerning Martin Hacker, a commuter on New Jersey Transit who wants to fight back (''Irked by Delays, Commuter Fights Back'').

title: Jefferson Continues Comeback
description: The Thomas Jefferson football team, 0-8 in 1987 and threatened with demotion to the Public Schools Athletic League B division, continues to put in a bid for comeback team of the year. The Orange Wave rallied to overwhelm Sheepshead Bay, 26-12, at the winner's field to capture their fourth game in six outings this season.

title:
Paramus Journal;
Touch of Manhattan Glitter Across the Hudson?
description: LEAD: ONCE it was rich farmland, where wild turkeys roamed and streams were filled with fish. The Lenni Lenape Indians named it ''terampsus,'' meaning ''a fertile land where corn is grown.'' Later, it became a headquarters of General Washington's during the Revolutionary War.

title: Breaking Up India Connection
description: HE WAS described as a veteran airline pilot who flew between New York City and Bombay, India. As he stepped off his jetliner at Kennedy International Airport on July 1, 1987, agents of the United States Customs Service and the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration closed in.

title: For Jessica Lange, Life Is a Mother's Role
description: On a frigid fall night in a suburb called Towson, a cadre of bejeweled partygoers sweeps through a sumptuous Colonial-style manor. But while a few are chatting and sipping their cocktails, most of the sophisticates are staring through the glass-paneled doors at an ingenuous trio seated outside.

title: WHERE BUSH APPEARS AS SOLID AS THE ROCKIES
description: One night in 1958, Lyndon B. Johnson, a diligent student of voting patterns, told one of his aides, Horace W. Busby, that he was worried about the future of the Democratic Party.

title: CAVEAT DIRECTOR
description: BOARD GAMES The Changing Shape of Corporate Power. By Arthur Fleischer Jr., Geoffrey C. Hazard Jr. and Miriam Z. Klipper. 236 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

title: A Sculpture Is Created With the Blind in Mind
description: IN museums and galleries, art is presented as something precious. Objects of art are protected from visitors, who might be asked to keep their distance.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I installed a device on my bathroom sink that attaches to the hot-and cold- water faucets to mix them so that the water comes out of a single spout. Very hot water came out and cracked the enamel in the sink, and I now have a rust patch under this spout. Can this be covered up or repaired in some way?

title: Elizabeth Griffin Is Married in Rye
description: Elizabeth Anne Griffin and Edward Anthony Matthews were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y., by Raymond Daur, deacon of the church. Mrs. Matthews is the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Joseph Griffin of Rye. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Matthews of Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Picnicking Atop the City's Seven Hills
description: FROM our picnic spot on the Janiculum, the only hill on the west side of the Tiber, all of Rome spread before us in a panorama of warm red roofs and bright yellow walls, undulating in the soft curves of the hills and punctuated by domes of various sizes. Beyond the cliffside parapet, we could make out the gentle outlines of the other six hills of Rome: the green expanses of the Pincio, the palaces on the Quirinale, the campanile on the Esquiline, the slope of the Celio, the graceful pines of the Palatine and the blush of roses in the gardens of the Aventine.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: GUITAR TRIO

title: Cold War Vestiges
description: 'The world of confrontation and conflict is giving way to a world of detente, a trend that is taking place right here at the United Nations. Serious efforts are also commencing to bring peace and the relaxation of tension to the Korean peninsula, one of the last vestiges of the cold war.' - Roh Tae Woo, President of South Korea, calling for an international conference to end the division of the Korean peninsula.

title: Susan G. Pender Weds S. E. Obus
description: Susan G. Pender and Steven Edward Obus were married yesterday at Estherwood in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., by Judge Michael J. Obus of the Criminal Court of the City of New York. Judge Obus, the bridegroom's twin, also served as best man.

title: Holtz Causes Orderly Success
description: It was at the final team meeting before the 1986 season opener against Michigan that Notre Dame's new head coach, Lou Holtz, learned there was still confusion where there should have been order and discipline. Repeating a question he and all other detail-conscious coaches ask just before a football game, Holtz yelled out, ''Who's on the first punt team?''

title: Marjorie Goodstein to Wed Russell Newman in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. Steven Goodstein of Kings Point, L.I., and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Pamela Goodstein, to Russell Newman, a son of Mickey Newman of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Sanford Newman.

title: Tatyana Doughty Becomes a Bride
description: Tatyana Doughty was married yesterday to David Olyphant at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. David H. C. Read. The bride is a daughter of Nina Sorokoff Doughty of New Vernon, N.J., and Selden Emerson Doughty of Nanticoke, Md. Her husband is a son of Adele Olyphant Emery of New Vernon and the late John K. Olyphant of New York.

title: Megan M. Quinn Is Wed To an Account Executive
description: Megan Marie Quinn, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Quinn of Lancaster, Pa., was married yesterday to James P. DeLess, the son of Roberta A. DeLess of Wallingford, Pa., and Donald J. DeLess of Devon, Pa. The Rev. Arthur A. Anderson officiated at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Lancaster.

title: Sports of The Times Dodgers' Dugout Continuity
description: In winning the World Series, the Dodgers were rewarded for continuity in the dugout. Of all the current clubowners, the O'Malley family has been in baseball the longest, 38 years, while hiring the fewest managers: 3. Tommy Lasorda has been ensconced in the Dodger dugout the last 12 years, Walter Alston was there the previous 23 years, Chuck Dressen the first 3 years.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: TWENTIETH-CENTURY CULTURE: Modernism to Deconstruction. By Norman F. Cantor. (Peter Lang, $39.95.) ''We are still spending the intellectual capital of Modernism,'' Norman Cantor asserts in his tome on the intellectual, artistic and ideological facets of the 1900's. A professor of history, sociology and comparative literature at New York University, Mr.

title: Molly Hood To Be a Bride In November
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Hood Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Molly Ann Hood to George Augustine O'Brien 3d, a son of Dorothy Thompson Fisher of White Plains, and the late George A. O'Brien Jr. A November wedding is planned.

title: Suffolk Propane Tank Site Opposed
description: LEAD: A PROPOSAL to install a 30,000-gallon propane storage tank on Old Riverhead Road across from Suffolk County Airport is being opposed not only by neighbors adjacent to the site, but also the fire chief of Westhampton Beach, who says the tank is too close to three schools in the area.

title: No Place for Radicals in This Campaign
description: THE Congressional race in the Sixth District is a battle of moderates: Nancy L. Johnson, a three-term incumbent who calls herself a moderate Republican, and James L. Griffin, a political newcomer who says he is a moderate Democrat. Part of the battle is that they disagree on what moderate means.

title: Revue Recreates Music Hall
description: THE dining room at the Spinning Wheel Inn in Redding Ridge has but a single tier and a mini-stage, but to the four performers in ''British Music Hall,'' the customers at the tables might as well be in the gallery, the circle or the stalls - and the pianist is a one-man pit band.

title: The Vintage Jukebox: Our Memories are Made of This
description: NOSTALGIA lovers, antiques fanciers and popular-music buffs all share a fascination with the jukebox. The earliest models, from the ''golden age'' of jukeboxes in the 1930's and 40's, were gorgeously crafted sound machines that ''bubbled,'' radiating light and color and bringing joy to the dancing feet of millions.

title: The Fate of Baby Amy
description: As a parent, I was moved by Lynne Vuillemot's description of her dilemma in choosing among Amy's treatment options. It is clear that her husband, John, and she made a decision based on their love for Amy and fears for her future.

title: Holland Idleman, 82, Ex-Moody's Executive
description: Holland B. Idleman, a former president of Moody's Investors Service, died of cardiac arrest Friday at his home in Chatham, N.J. He was 82 years old.

title: Yonkers Ends a Phase Of Crackdown on Drugs
description: Police officers working under cover since April concluded the first phase of a crackdown on drug sales this week with the arrest of 52 people, bringing to 120 the number apprehended since April.

title: Leaving a Home for a Condo Brings Seesawing Indecisiion
description: ''SELLING our home and buying a condo had to be one of the hardest things my husband and I ever did,'' my friend Muriel said as we had lunch together one August day. ''I wonder where it ranks on that list of stressful conditions?'' ''Pretty high, I bet,'' I said. ''Where would you want to live if you sold your house?'' Muriel asked. ''Have you thought about that?'' ''Facing the Hudson River,'' I answered. ''Oh, the Hudson is too expensive to face,'' Muriel said. ''How far up are you willing to go?''

title: The World's Richest Museum
description: JOHN WALSH TURNED HIS station wagon north along the San Diego Freeway, pointing out the window at a cliff that rose abruptly near Sunset Boulevard. ''We start here,'' he said, ''and run as far as the eye can see.'' His hand swept forward, toward a mountain on the distant north horizon. The enormous stretch of untouched property paralleled the freeway, cutting a wide, rough path through the affluent, well-populated neighborhood of West Los Angeles known as Brentwood.

title: At P.S. 1: A Failure and a Triumph All in One
description: The retrospective of the Italian artist Michelangelo Pistoletto currently on view at P.S. 1 in Long Island City is an odd creature: a clear-cut triumph and a palpable failure rolled into one. As with the large display of paintings by Robert Ryman currently on view at the Dia Art Foundation on West 22 Street in Manhattan, the Pistoletto exhibition reflects an alternative space assuming the function of a conventional museum. A 30-year retrospective accompanied by a hefty catalogue, this show defines a new potential for P.S. 1 and also suggests how such a redefinition, however intermittent, could lighten the pressures on this city's overextended museums as far as contemporary art is concerned.

title: Slot Machines Without Casinos
description: LEAD: When Jackpot Enterprises was listed on the New York Stock Exchange last year, few people noticed.

title: Ellen Archer Wed To Jeffrey Gracer
description: Ellen Lee Archer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joel S. Archer of New York and Nantucket, Mass., and Jeffrey Bruce Gracer, a son of Jane Blumenfeld of New York and Englewood, N.J., and the late David Gracer, were married last evening at the Westbury Hotel in New York. Rabbi Judith Shanks, the bridegroom's cousin, officiated.

title:
ART;
Human Body as Metaphor
description: LEAD: THE 10 artists featured in ''The Plight of the Figure,'' the current exhibition at the Islip Art Museum, treat the human body as a multifaceted metaphor, an allusive entity, a symbol.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I installed a device on my bathroom sink that attaches to the hot-and cold- water faucets to mix them so that the water comes out of a single spout. Very hot water came out and cracked the enamel in the sink, and I now have a rust patch under this spout. Can this be covered up or repaired in some way?

title: Leslie A. Brownridge Wed to Jordan Mayer
description: At the Great Neck Synagogue in Great Neck, L.I., Leslie Ann Brownridge, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Brownridge of Roslyn, L.I., was married last evening to Jordan Mark Mayer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford J. Mayer of Jericho, L.I. Rabbi Dale Polakoff officiated. The bride graduated from the University of Wisconsin and received a master's degree in advertising at Northwestern University. She is a vice president and the director of marketing at the Fidelcor Business Credit Corporation in New York.

title: Susan Huffman Weds J. H. Boal
description: Susan Parker Huffman and Jeffrey Hazen Boal were married yesterday at the nondenominational First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Avery C. Manchester performed the ceremony.

title: Trapped Whale Presumed Dead; 2 Others Aided
description: One of three California gray whales trapped for more than two weeks in unseasonably heavy ice was presumed dead today.

title: Women Must Lead Their Own Lives, Make Their Own Choices; Never the Mother
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Of the Week; Does Davey Johnson Deserve to Come Back?
description: I think it is more apt to ask if New York and the Mets deserve Davey Johnson. His record is enhanced by his refreshingly even-handed and calm style and what appears to be substantial affection, respect and regard for his players, his team and the sport. DIANE P. BARTO Brooklyn

title: Mt. Vernon Unveils Effort for 21st Century
description: IN 1858, some New York City merchants stepped over the Bronx border and laid out a series of 50-by-100-foot lots for themselves in a pastoral setting bordering the Eastchester Creek. They called their suburban dream ''the city of homes'' and named it Mount Vernon. The lots they laid out between First and 14th Avenues composed the first planned community in the state.

title: MADISON AVENUE PUTSCH
description: EMPERORS OF ADLAND Inside the Advertising Revolution. By Nancy Millman. Illustrated. 225 pp. New York: Warner Books. $18.95.

title: 100-Year-Old Engine is Restored
description: THE century-old Derby locomotive, the first electric freight engine, traveled a quarter-mile last weekend at the Shoreline Trolley Museum in East Haven. Moving at a speed considered extraordinary for its time and with sunlight flashing off its ''Broadway colors'' of cadmium yellow and orange, the engine resembles a giant toy.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: ECONOMICS IN PERSPECTIVE: A Critical History, by John Kenneth Galbraith. (Houghton Mifflin, $8.95.) Condemning those who treat economics as a Platonic system of mathematical abstraction, John Kenneth Galbraith demonstrates how power politics and ideology shape what is perhaps the most subjective of sciences. ''Like virtually all of his work, [ this book ] will amuse and instruct the general reader and give a pain in the neck to the professional economics establishment,'' Leonard Silk said in The Book Review last year. KRAZY KAT: A Novel in Five Panels, by Jay Cantor. (Collier/Macmillan, $7.95.) With her competitors Felix, Fritz and Garfield enjoying continued celebrity, Krazy Kat, created in 1910 by the cartoonist George Herriman, has lapsed into obscurity and a deep depression. But Ignatz, an intellectual mouse who is a disciple of Freud, is determined to cure Krazy, helping her come to terms with sex and death. Earlier this year, our reviewer, Thomas M. Disch, called Jay Cantor's novel ''sprightly, delightful and insightful. . . . As [ his ] comedy becomes bawdier and bolder . . . his cartoon characters become rounder, richer, more densely packed.'' THE MASK OF COMMAND, by John Keegan. (Penguin, $7.95.) To examine the changing style of military leadership, John Keegan profiles Alexander the Great, the Duke of Wellington, Ulysses S. Grant and Adolf Hitler. The result is a ''fascinating and enlightening'' book, John Gross said in The Times last year. It is ''marked by great intellectual liveliness.'' GET HOME FREE, by John Clellon Holmes. (Thunder's Mouth, $8.95.) When Dan and May, two New York bohemians, decide to break up, one heads north, the other south in their separate attempts to go home again. In 1964, our reviewer, Haskel Frankel, called the novel ''a neatly wrapped package of futility that [ is ] both depressing and impressive. . . . What is impressive is the author's ability to create so much life in so barren an atmosphere.'' The same publisher has reissued two more of the author's novels of the beat generation, each priced at $9.95. THE HORN, which is about Edgar Pool, a black saxophonist who finally meets his match, is ''the most successful novel of jazz that has ever been published,'' one reviewer said in 1958. When it was published in 1952, five years before Jack Kerouac's ''On the Road,'' Mr. Holmes's first novel, GO, was not especially well received, but it has come to be recognized as a classic of a genre, beat literature, that he did much to help create. CONSPIRACY OF SILENCE: The Secret Life of Anthony Blunt, by Barrie Penrose and Simon Freeman. (Vintage, $10.95.) When Guy Burgess, Donald Maclean and Kim Philby defected to the Soviet Union from Britain, the spy they left behind was Anthony Blunt, who lived quietly for years as an art historian. Prime Minister Thatcher exposed him to a shocked nation in 1979. Last year, our reviewer, Stephen Koch, said this biography is ''a valuable book, to be read by anyone under the scandal's spell.'' FIRST LIGHT, by Charles Baxter. (Penguin, $6.95.) In a novel whose plot moves backward in time, Charles Baxter traces the lives of Hugh Welch, a car salesman, and his sister, Dorsey, an astrophysicist, showing how they became estranged. Writing in The Times, Michiko Kakutani called the book ''a remarkably supple novel that gleams with the smoky chiaroscuro of familial love recalled through time.'' ''GROWN-UPS'': A Generation in Search of Adulthood, by Cheryl Merser. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) Why is it, the author wonders, that so many of her fellow baby boomers feel like oversized children, forever awaiting the moment when they will magically become adults? ''There is something touching and sad in this depiction of a generation reared as one of the most pampered and prosperous in history still trying to grow up,'' Francine Klagsbrun said here last year.'' YEARS FROM NOW, by Gary Glickman. (Plume/New American Library, $7.95.) A Jewish family in New Jersey is confronted with the fact that a son, David, is homosexual and living in New York with his friend Beth, a lesbian. Gary Glickman's ''sense of the rhythms, the beauty, the absurdity, the poignancy of the family as it participates in its rituals is delightful and true,'' Robert Houston said in The Book Review in 1987. THE FUTURE 500: Creating Tomorrow's Organizations Today, by Craig R. Hickman and Michael A. Silva. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) In the coming decades, executives will have to search for more than excellence if they want their corporations to survive, the authors argue; they will need to learn new ways to manage overwhelming complexity. Last year, our reviewer, Elizabeth Bailey, said the book provides ''a valuable history of American business and management theory.'' PSYCHOTIC REACTIONS AND CARBURETOR DUNG, by Lester Bangs. Edited by Greil Marcus. (Vintage, $9.95.) This collection of essays by the rock critic Lester Bangs, who died six years ago, ''rescues from oblivion one of the most distinctive voices in modern popular criticism,'' Ken Tucker said here in 1987. ''He created a rude yet earnest persona in his writing, one that believed passionately in rock music as the most vital and innovative of the popular arts even as he decried its crassest excesses. Rather than simply babble on about this or that favorite rock group, Bangs attempted to place rock within a cultural framework, pointing out its similarities to everything from Dada to Jack Kerouac.''

title: A Botanist Sounds the Alert: Kudzu Is Spotted in Scarsdale
description: RECENTLY, I had a frantic telephone call from a friend telling me that she saw a kudzu vine colony while cycling along the Bronx River in Scarsdale. ''Exactly where,'' I asked in great excitement. ''On a path on the east side of the river directly behind the Scarsdale railroad station,'' she replied.

title: Solidarity Blames New Premier for Delay in Talks
description: The Polish Government is delaying the start of wide-ranging talks with the opposition grouped around the illegal Solidarity trade union, and Solidarity leaders say they believe one of the major obstacles is the new Prime Minister, Mieczyslaw Rakowski.

title: Review/Dance; A Puzzle Set In the Realm Of a Fantasy
description: Little dances gave way to dramatic vignettes. Then came other little dances, a few more vignettes and a film. ''A Starer,'' which was presented Wednesday night at the Washington Square United Methodist Church, resembled a jigsaw puzzle, and its dances, dramatic scenes and cinematic interlude resembled pieces of a puzzle that were gradually fitted together. But once all the parts of this dance-theater work were put into place, no big picture ever came clear.

title: For Israeli Labor Party, Vote Rides on Land-for-Peace Idea
description: The meeting room was filled with undecided voters, hoping to speak with Foreign Minister Shimon Peres. And the very first question exposed the Labor Party candidate's greatest area of political vulnerability.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE BEAVER CONFERENCE FARM;
For Those in Spiritual Need, a Retreat Dedicated to Peace
description: LEAD: THERE is no mistaking the Beaver Conference Farm for an ordinary dwelling.

title: Carolyn Maida O'Donnell Weds David T. Gurney
description: Carolyn Maida O'Donnell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence G. O'Donnell of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to David Taylor Gurney, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank I. Gurney of Washington Township, N.J. The Rev. Peter C. O'Donnell, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Nativity in Midland Park, N.J. He was assisted by the Rev. Dr. David O. Dungan, an uncle of the bridegroom and a Presbyterian minister.

title: Takeshita's Scorecard After a Year: Less Is More
description: When Noboru Takeshita was chosen to be Japan's Prime Minister last year, his critics forecast a bleak future.

title: The Music Of Fountains Is Everywhere
description: BY day the din of traffic often drowns out the murmur of the fountains, but early in the morning or late at night you don't have to walk far to hear it.

title: Art and Identity in Glen Cove
description: LEAD: FROM a decayed industrial hub, where tattered laundry once slapped against its downtown backside, Glen Cove has been transformed during more than 20 years of urban renewal into a modern suburban satellite.

title: Miss Robinson Is Wed To Thomas E. Bitnar
description: The wedding of Agnes Randle Robinson, a daughter of Mrs. Hamilton Robinson of Washington and the late Mr. Robinson, to Thomas Edward Bitnar, the son of the late Joseph Bitnar and the late Sona Bitnarova of Prague, took place yesterday at Epiphany Roman Catholic Church in Washington. The Rev. Gabriel Duffy performed the ceremony.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Pies Contested In Massachusetts

title: >WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: NOT SO SLEEPY HOLLOW The spirit of Halloween, incipient year round in the land of the Headless Horseman, will emerge full-blown from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Saturday and Sunday, when ''The Legend of Sleepy Hollow'' will be invoked in stories, films, tours and puppetry at Sunnyside in Tarrytown and at Philipsburg Manor in North Tarrytown.

title: BIAS WAS HIS BUSINESS
description: SQUARE ONE A Memoir. By Arnold Forster. Foreword by Elie Wiesel. Illustrated. 423 pp. New York: Donald I. Fine. $21.95.

title: Survival Odds
description: THE NEONATAL INTENSIVE-CARE UNIT houses the tiniest patients in the hospital. All the medical devices - the intravenous needles, the endotracheal catheters, the nasogastric tubes - are the smallest sizes available. The biggest patients in the unit weigh but seven or eight pounds - full-term newborns. They look gigantic next to some of their neighbors. A nurse here can see veins that are invisible to other eyes. She can draw blood from a vein no bigger than a hair, and, even more amazing, she can thread an IV into such a vein, to give a tiny, premature baby the fluids, the antibiotics, the calories it needs.

title: Nasta's Cartoons of American Politics on View in Hartford
description: LEAD: JUST in time to lend perspective to the electoral season comes an exhibit of vintage political cartoons that were once thought to be so powerful they could influence voting patterns and topple corrupt leaders.

title: In the Storage Closet Was a Lost Treasure
description: I was rooting around in my storage closet last week and spied a leather camera case I hadn't seen in years. Inside, perfectly preserved was the first camera I ever owned. I bought it for 170 hard-earned dollars exactly 20 years ago.

title: THE NATION: Election '88; Final Pitches to an Electorate Grown Cold
description: ONE goal of any Presidential candidate is to tap into the discontents of the American voter. But this year one of those discontents is with the candidates themselves and the campaigns they have been running.

title: Cognac
description: To the Editor: In her article on Cognac, the brandy town on the Charente River (Travel, Aug. 21), Jeannette Ferrary names illustrious Frenchmen who were born or who died in Cognac. She did not, however, name Jean Monnet, the son of a brandy merchant, born in a little house in the heart of the old town 100 years ago.

title: For the Nobelists of Another Year, Some Big Mysteries of Science
description: LAST week, Nobel Prizes were awarded for discoveries in the categories of medicine or physiology, chemistry, physics and economics. To mark the occasion, George Johnson, an editor of The Week in Review, asked eight scientists to describe some of the most perplexing unresolved problems in their fields. Here are excerpts from their replies. Life's Immensity

title: Elizabeth Brown and M. E. Roberts Jr., Lawyers, Are Married in Washington
description: Christ Episcopal Church in Washington was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Elizabeth Merrill Brown and Martin Earl Roberts Jr., who are both lawyers. The Rev. Sanford Garner performed the ceremony.

title: Trial Under Way in Murder of Bride
description: FOR some, the memories are fading. ''I remember something about a girl going for a walk, and then she was found murdered, and later her husband was arrested,'' one prospective juror said.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: ADVICE FOR A PRESIDENT-ELECT;
Tax the Rich, They Consume Too Much
description: LEAD: Congratulations. The American people have awarded you their highest honor. They have also placed in you their most sacred trust. I would like to offer you some suggestions on the most serious economic problems you will face in discharging your new responsibilities.

title: Lauren Trownsell And J. R. Watkins To Marry Dec. 10
description: Lauren Lee Trownsell and James R. Watkins plan to be married on Dec. 10, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Trownsell of Madison, Conn., and Hilton Head Island, S.C., have announced. Mr. Watkins is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Watkins of Cincinnati.

title: Show of Collages Opens New Exhibit Hall in New Rochelle
description: THERE have been a couple of changes at the College of New Rochelle, ones that mark a lot of progress on the campus.

title: The Embattled Professional Corporation
description: Ten years ago, Monte Venis completed his training as a chiropractor and opened an office in Clearwater, Fla. Last month, Dr. Venis met with an accountant to discuss incorporating his practice, because ''I've finally gotten to the point where I'm making some money, so I started thinking about where to put my money and how to protect what I've got.''

title: On Bedrock in Bergen Beach: Bucking That Sinking Feeling
description: The problem with southeast Brooklyn's Bergen Beach, said the developer of a 184-unit condominium there, is that the land is being bought up even as it is slipping away. Land prices in Bergen Beach have quadrupled in the last five years, said George Massaua and other area developers. Mr. Massaua and his partners, the brothers Murray and Edward Gallin, are putting up the six-building Bergen Cove condominium on a four-acre parcel, one of the last large lots.

title: A Canalside Promenade In Utrecht
description: SHOULD you mention Amsterdam or The Hague to an Utrechter, he will say with just an iota of condescension, ''They are new cities.'' Utrecht is indeed the oldest city in the Netherlands, dating to around A.D. 48, when the Romans built a fort on what is today the epicenter of the city, Dom Square. Traditionally, Utrecht has been known as the City of Churches: there are 17 medieval churches, all restored, within the city limits, and much of the country's religious history was forged here. Since 1636, the year that what is today its largest university was founded, the city has been an intellectual and cultural center.

title: Finding Sanctuary and Serenity as the Family Chauffeur
description: I HAVE four children; one of them can drive. The rest are driving my husband crazy.

title: Massachusetts to Vote on Nuclear Plants
description: Massachusetts voters will have a chance to shut down the state's two nuclear power plants. An affirmative vote Nov. 8 for one question on the ballot would ban generating of electricity by commercial nuclear power plants ''by means which result in the production of nuclear waste'' after July 4, 1989.

title: More Killers
description: To the Editor:

title: How Many Petunias?
description: To the Editor:

title: New Consortium to Help in Training of Exporters
description: LEAD: WHEN Japanese businessmen carrying briefcases stuffed with cash arrived on the docks of Montauk three years ago to buy giant tuna directly from American fishermen, it came as no surprise to a young exporter named Paul J. Flagg.

title: Pamela Briggs Weds Philippe Besnard
description: Pamela Briggs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Taylor R. Briggs of New York and Williamstown, Mass., was married yesterday to Philippe Jean-Louis Besnard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jean-Louis Besnard of Lyons, France. The bride's sister, the Rev. Cynthia Briggs Kittredge, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: The Corn Is Green, Is It?
description: WHERE is this smallest corn crop in Essex County? It is on a small triangular property, bounded on two sides by the juncture of Walnut and McKinley Streets in Nutley, and backed by a large, conglomerate boulder that was dug up from underneath the Hoffmann-La Roche visitors' parking lot a few years ago, when Mayra Scarborough was No. 6215 on the work force. The corn field measures 26 inches by 32 inches by 43 inches.

title: 130 Held in Protest Outside Abortion Clinic
description: About 130 anti-abortion protesters were arrested today after they blocked an abortion clinic in what they described as a ''rescue operation'' of unborn babies, the police said.

title: AWARDS FOR VIDEO GER
description: The familiar proverb notwithstanding, the recognition of better mousetraps is by no means automatic. It is difficult for the more casual customers to spot superior designs in the competitive whirl. Somebody has to point them out. That is the intended purpose of the newly instituted Grand Prix for outstanding designs in video equipment. Recently awarded for the first time by Audio-Video International, a prominent trade publication, the honorific prize represents the choice of an independent committee of technical experts. A previous column reported on the winners among television sets.

title: Scary Stories Appeal To Adults, as Well
description: LEAD: CHILDREN are not the only ones to love a good, scary story, especially on Halloween. Many adults enjoy a tale well told.

title: Beacon Hill
description: To the Editor: Otherwise uplifting, the article ''Living the Life of a Bostonian on Beacon Hill'' (Travel, Sept. 11) has a problem.

title: Village to Impose Halloween Curfew
description: LEAD: PORT WASHINGTON NORTH has sent a stern message to youths under the age of 19: Do not come out after 7 P.M. between Oct. 30 and Nov. 1 each year.

title: Long-Lived Conductors
description: To the Editor:

title: Growing Temple Stirs Complaints
description: LEAD: FIVE years ago, Young Israel of Lawrence-Cedarhurst bought two adjoining houses on Spruce Street in Cedarhurst, a residential neighborhood, to accommodate its growing congregation.

title: Lori Vitallano Marries
description: Lori Ann Vitallano, a senior editor at ABC News in New York, and William George Bores, a videotape editor for broadcast operations and engineering at ABC, were married yesterday at Windows on the World. Judge Micki Scherer of Criminal Court officiated. Mrs. Bores, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Vitallano of Mount Vernon, N.Y., is a graduate of the State University of New York at Binghamton, as is her husband. Mr. Bores is a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Bores of Williston Park, L.I.

title: L.I. Association Doesn't Speak for All
description: Whoa! Wait a minute! We love you, Grumman, oh yes we do. And I personally agree with everything that Grumman's chairman, John O'Brien, proposed for Long Island in the front page article the Long Island Weekly [ Sept. 18 ] , and in the excerpts from his address to the Long Island Association. Except one gigantic detail: that the Long Island Association become the one unifying spokesperson for the region.

title: The Fate of Baby Amy
description: I am entering medical school next fall. Lynne Vuillemot's story has given me insight into the dilemma faced by parents of seriously ill infants. I hope that, thanks to her, I will be able to discuss honestly and with compassion all the alternatives available in such a situation, including the difficult one of doing nothing and letting nature take its course. ADAM J. GOODFARB Narberth, Pa.

title: REPORT FROM NEW YORK
description: Forget about provocative new silhouettes, dramatic hemline shifts or startling colorations. This is not the moment. The spring 1989 American collections, beginning this week, make it clear that this country's fashion creators are concentrating on the cautious route. After a lackluster year of sales, no one is about to go out on any chancy limbs. As always, certain general trends are emerging. These include classic clothes with slightly softer lines for day and the use of fluid fabrics, such as chiffon, for evening. But in the main, designers are presenting clothing that enhances their already-established looks. As Bill Blass says: ''I'm paying no attention to 'outside' [ read European ] influences. I'm convinced you must stay with your own viewpoint.'' The trend toward staying on course does not imply that there will be a dearth of desirable clothes. By now, America has developed a healthy number of ''signatures'' that are instantly recognizable by fashion-knowledgeable shoppers. They are the women who can spot a Calvin Klein, Ralph Lauren, Donna Karan, Anne Klein, Geoffrey Beene, to name a few, before even getting off the escalator. Even in the area of late-day and evening clothes, where many designers' offerings blur, there is still that undefinable something that sends out a Carolina Herrera, Oscar de la Renta or Scaasi signal.

title: Carmen Maura: Good Times for a 'Bad Woman'
description: For years, Carmen Maura was considered a ''bad woman'' because she wanted to be an actress. Her conservative upper-middle-class Madrid family and friends shut her out of their lives, and she lost custody of her son and daughter during a bitter 12-year battle to win a papalannulment of her marriage.

title: THE NATION: 'Scorpions in a Bottle'; Congress and the President Part At the Height of Misunderstanding
description: THE 100th Congress and President Reagan part company in a paradoxical state, accomplishing more than either dared hope yet torn by animosities that threaten to leave the legislative and executive branches estranged.

title: Rabbi David Aronson, 96, Religious Author
description: Rabbi David Aronson, former president of the Rabbinical Assembly of America, has died after a short illness. He was 96 years old. ''He was one of the leading rabbis, nationally, in the last 60 years,'' said Rabbi Kassel Abelson, Rabbi Aronson's successor at Beth El Synagogue in the Minneapolis suburb of St. Louis Park.

title: More Killers
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Of the Week; Does Davey Johnson Deserve to Come Back?
description: Johnson is the first manager in history to win 90 games in each of his first five seasons. And under Johnson, the Mets have never finished lower than second place and have finished in first place twice in three years.

title: Unbeaten Notre Dame Posts 7th Victory
description: There were all sorts of pitfalls that could have tripped up Notre Dame today, enough that Coach Lou Holtz admitted he was fitful and scared all week.

title: New Menu at a Bridgeport Hotel
description: REPORTS that the restaurant, Parc 1070, in the Bridgeport Hilton, had a new menu led us to Bridgeport to find out. With the upsurge in recent years of high-quality dining rooms in chain hotels, another culinary coup was expected.

title: FICTION
description: PRIVATE WOODS. By Sandra Crockett Moore. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $18.95.) For a novel set in an isolated hunting lodge in the Appalachian Mountains, ''Private Woods'' is filled with homely, almost suburban details of meals served and dishes scrubbed. A strict division of labor applies, with the women preparing food and waiting on their menfolk, who exchange macho challenges when not tracking deer with bows and arrows. It is in this atmosphere, charged with both blood and cooking smells, that Sarah Lannom encounters a surprise guest - her first love, Sonny Woods. Seventeen years have passed since their last, tense meeting, following Sonny's return from Vietnam. Sarah has since become a successful artist and the devoted wife of a computer executive, while Sonny, still tortured by memories of the war, has married a woman raised in the country and earns his living by hiring out as a guide to city slickers. In her debut novel, Sandra Crockett Moore uses direct, unadorned prose to describe the rekindling of old emotions and the consequences of Sarah and Sonny's reunion. And Ms. Moore's spare style suits many of the traditional ideas that are expressed in the course of her narrative - that Sonny is the 1980's version of a natural man; that shooting animals with a bow is more sporting than using a gun. One of the wives even argues, in defense of the male urge to hunt, that ''killing is part of a man's nature, any man's.'' Not all readers will agree with these opinions, but many will be drawn in by Ms. Moore's narrative skills and by the conviction with which she tells her story.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: IMPERIAL CITY: New York. By Geoffrey Moorhouse. (Henry Holt, $21.95.) ''The most sensational city walk in the world begins unpromisingly, on a concrete path, surrounded by graffiti, with traffic howling by on either side,'' writes the British traveler Geoffrey Moorhouse, commencing a journey across the Brooklyn Bridge to Manhattan.

title: Political Notes Giuliani Regime Nears End as a Top Protege Resigns
description: The beginning of the end of the Rudolph W. Giuliani regime in Foley Square was signaled last week with the resignation of Howard Wilson, who was chief of the criminal division in the United States Attorney's office and was Mr. Giuliani's choice to succeed him until he was vetoed by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: ALONE IN QUEENS, AN UNLIKELY TOWER SCRAPES THE SKY
description: There is nearly complete in New York City a skyscraper that is having an impact on the skyline as profound, in its own way, as the World Trade Center. It is not 110 stories tall, or even half that, and it is but a single tower, not a pair, but it is rapidly becoming one of the most conspicuous structures in the entire city. The building is the new office center of Citicorp, a tower of blue-green glass, and the reason its 42 floors add up to so prominent a presence on the skyline is that the tower is being built in Long Island City, in Queens, in a neighborhood in which the tallest things until now have been factories, row houses and the elevated IRT tracks.

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;
A Fight for Fragments of Indian Culture
description: LEAD: ALMOST a century after they were stolen from their reservation in northern Montana, the skeletal remains of 16 Blackfeet Indians have been returned from a Smithsonian Institution storeroom to their home beneath the Sawtooth range of the Rocky Mountains.

title: The Military Consensus, Undone
description: At the cost of almost $2 trillion, President Reagan has generally improved the quality of American military forces. But he has built a fortress on sand. The economy has been undermined by the Reagan deficits; the incoherence and waste of his defense programs have eroded the national consensus for substantial military spending.

title: RICH LITTLE POOR GIRL
description: EVA LUNA By Isabel Allende. Translated by Margaret Sayers Peden. 272 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: The Other Election
description: Israel's political campaign, which ends just a week before ours, has similarly featured more invective than attention to the country's real problems. But through the clouds of rhetoric one can detect something that matters. More of the public is coming to see that Israel must deal politically with the Palestinians.

title: Aikman's Passes Lead U.C.L.A., 24-3
description: Troy Aikman passed for 283 yards and 3 touchdowns today, leading U.C.L.A. to a 24-3 victory over Arizona that earned the Bruins (7-0,4-0) a tie with Southern Cal for the Pacific-10 Conference lead and their best start in 22 years.

title: 12,000 Form Ranks to Mourn 2 Slain Policemen
description: As a frigid wind whipped down the avenue, swirling over the bell towers of the church and cutting through the crowd, 12,000 uniformed police officers gathered yesterday in tribute to two of their comrades, shot to death on the same night.

title: Diane Siesel to Marry S. D. Muratore in May
description: A May 28 wedding is planned by Diane Elizabeth Siesel and Stephen Dominick Muratore, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Siesel of Mamaroneck, N.Y., have announced. Mr. Muratore is the son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Raymond Muratore of Brooklyn.

title: Laura Jinishian and Richard W. Davis Jr. Marry
description: Laura Elizabeth Jinishian, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Jinishian of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Richard Warren Davis Jr., the son of Mrs. Herbert L. Buckman of Prides Crossing, Mass., and Mr. Davis of Essex, Mass., were married yesterday at the Dingletown Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Joel Baehr, a Unitarian minister.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Will a Record Be Set At Norweb Auction?
description: LEAD: THE third and final auction of United States coins from the Norweb Collection will take place Nov. 14 and 15 at the St. Moritz Hotel, 50 Central Park South, New York City.

title: AIDS and the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Midwest; Iowa's Big Plays Rout Purdue, 31-7
description: Mike Saunders went 72 yards for a touchdown and Tony Stewart raced 65 yards to set up another score as Iowa routed Purdue, 31-7, in a Big Ten Conference game today.

title: New York Farmers Report Record Profits for 1987
description: New York farmers made record profits last year, said a report issued this week by the State Agricultural Statistics Service here.

description: This week, by many measures, was the best thus far on the 1988 campaign trail for Senator Dan Quayle.

title: JESSE GROWS UP IN PIECES
description: LEAD: THE MAN WHO KNEW CARY GRANT By Jonathan Schwartz. 249 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: Mary Tyler Moore Tosses Her Hat Up Again
description: Mary Tyler Moore plants her feet on the ground like a traffic cop and with an outstretched hand diverts the galumphing of her golden retriever aptly named Dash. The bold reach exposes some of her jewels. Diamonds encircle her wrist, hug the face of her wristwatch and surround the tremendous emerald ring, an anniversary present from her third husband. Two even pinch her ears.

title: What to Pack
description: To the Editor: I consider a flat sink stopper indispensable. Also: sleeping mask, small notebook, pocket calculator, phrase book, washcloth in plastic case and plastic bag for swimsuit and anything else damp.

title: Family History
description: IF it has lasted in a box for the last 100 years, why shouldn't it last another century? Because of the ruins they find when they next peek into that box, said Kathleen Brennan, a professional archivist, growing numbers of amateur archivists are appealing to the Westchester Historical Society for help in preserving family memorabilia.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Little Compton, R.I.; Beach Option, Good to Dec. 15
description: THE Nature Conservancy, a national nonprofit conservation organization, has won an option to buy a beach of remarkable beauty even for Rhode Island - a state celebrated for its shoreline - and has until Dec. 15 to put together enough money to exercise the option.

title: Jets Begin New Era Without Gastineau
description: A Jets team angered and weakened by Mark Gastineau's decision to quit football starts its new era today against the Dolphins in Miami.

title: Not Even Kindling
description: To the Editor:

title: NO ISLAND IS AN ISLAND ANYMORE
description: THE PREDICAMENT OF CULTURE Twentieth-Century Ethnography, Literature, and Art. By James Clifford. Illustrated. 381 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. Cloth, $30. Paper, $15.95.

title: Big Bids Reshape Takeover Game
description: Two enormous bids left many on Wall Street convinced that no company is too big for a takeover attempt. In the biggest bid ever, the top executives of RJR Nabisco teamed up with Shearson Lehman Hutton to propose a $17 billion leveraged buyout of the tobacco and food giant. The company was formed just three years ago when R.J. Reynolds, whose brands include Winston, Salem and Camel cigarettes, merged with Nabisco, a consumer products powerhouse that produces Oreo cookies, Ritz crackers, Planters peanuts and Del Monte fruits and vegetables. F. Ross Johnson, chief executive of RJR Nabisco, is a leader of the buyout effort. It must be approved by the board, which appointed outside directors to study it. Wall Street seemed to think a higher offer might emerge. On the day of the announcement, RJR Nabisco shares, which had been in the mid-$50's, soared a couple of dollars above the $75-a-share bid price.

title:
BOOKS & BUSINESS;
MEET THE WINNERS
description: LEAD: YEN! Japan's New Financial Empire and Its Threat to America. By Daniel Burstein. Tables. Charts. 335 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: BAD MONEY. By A. M. Kabal. (Dutton, $18.95.) Four assassinations in four countries. A colonel in Panama, a correspondent in Italy, a banker in London and a priest in Poland. No one suspects the global connection among these murders except a lush of a has-been journalist who hails from the Virginia of power brokers and aristocrats.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Local Talent Dominates Concerts
description: APPEARANCES by local musicians head the list of concert performances across the state this week, starting at the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford, home to workshops and recitals that add up to an ambitious season for the Connecticut Classical Guitar Society.

title: Film Dissects Murder and Justice
description: FOR Errol Morris, a film maker from Hewlett, ''The Thin Blue Line'' is as much a mission as a motion picture.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Hare-Raising Day Anne Rodriquez wanted her bunny, and she wasn't going to let anyone get in the way. The Calverton mother had come to the bunny auction at the Suffolk County Farm Pumpkin Festival in Yaphank along with her husband and two children, red-headed Jillian, 4, and brown-haired Jason, 10.

title: False Reports Laid to T.V.A.
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has concluded that the head of the Tennessee Valley Authority's nuclear power program repeatedly made false statements to the commission about a plant under construction near Spring City, Tenn.

title: Leslie Greenberg Marries Stuart Jeffrey Ochs on L.I.
description: The wedding of Leslie Jana Greenberg, a daughter of Bernard Greenberg of Oceanside, L.I., and the late Frances Katz Greenberg, to Stuart Jeffrey Ochs, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Ochs of Oceanside, took place last evening at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I. Rabbi Gilbert S. Rosenthal officiated.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Choosing to Buy a Lot Now, Build Later
description: LEAD: IT is unusual for any house to be built in six weeks, and even more unusual when the owner acts as his own general contractor. But Robert Mecca, a heating and air-conditioning wholesaler, did just that recently, moving into a four-bedroom, 3,500-square-foot contemporary in an East Patchogue waterfront development called Skyhaven

title: A Colonial Condo: The Monroe Mix
description: A 115-acre, single-family home project in Monroe, Conn., will combine Colonial- and condominium-style property arrangements, with 138 Early American reproduction houses built around commons ranging in size from a half acre to three acres. Because the project on Cutlers Farm Road is a condominium and not a subdivision, the greens will be jointly owned by community members.

title: Promotion of New Book Revives Italians' Anger Over Nazi Occupation
description: It was a daring jailbreak, one that might have ignited the Italian imagination had it not also scraped a painful patch of the national soul.

title: Motto Was Selected For State in 1959
description: In ''Celebrating the Bland but Influential People of Connecticut'' (Opinion page, Sept. 4), Christopher Hoffman makes the point that Connecticut's official designation, ''The Constitution State,'' honors the role of Connecticut delegates to the Constitutional Convention in mediating the differences between large and small states over the nature of representation in a national legislature. I agree with Mr. Hoffman that the designation looks good on our license plates, but he is wrong about its inspiration.

title: One Dies in Chile as Rebels Attack Two Police Stations
description: Leftist guerrillas attacked two small police stations in the south with machine guns and anti-tank rockets, killing a corporal and wounding a local farmer, the police said today.

title: Tennis
description: Edberg Upset by Australian: John Fitzgerald of Australia upset top-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden yesterday and will meet Boris Becker in the final of the $627,500 Seiko Super tournament in Tokyo. Fitzgerald, seeded sixth, eliminated Edberg, 7-6, 6-0, winning the tie breaker, 7-2. Becker, seeded second, also went to a tie breaker before beating Richard Matuszewski of the United States, 7-6, 6-1, in the other semifinal.(AP) Shriver and Maleeva in Final; Top-seeded Pam Shriver and third-seeded Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria gained the final of the $200,000 European Indoors women's tournament yesterday in Zurich. Shriver, ranked fifth worldwide, methodically defeated Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany, seeded No. 4, 6-4, 6-4. Maleeva outlasted unseeded Conchita Martinez, 16 years old, of Spain, in a 4-6, 6-4, 6-4 match that lasted almost two hours. (AP) Austrians Advance: Thomas Muster and Horst Skoff of Austria won their semifinal matches yesterday in the $205,000 Grand Prix tournament in Vienna. The top-seeded Muster defeated fourth-seeded Kevin Curren of the United States, 6-4, 6-4. Skoff beat third-seeded Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 7-5, 4-6.(AP) McNeil Is Upset: Susan Sloane of Lexington, Ky., upset second-seeded Lori McNeil, 6-7, 6-2, 6-1, yesterday in the Virginia Slims of Nashville tournament. In the final today, Sloane will face Beverly Bowes, who beat Leila Meskhi of the Soviet Union, 6-1, 6-1. (AP) Auto Racing Gant Is First: Harry Gant won the AC-Delco 200 Busch Grand National race by three-tenths of a second over Dale Earnhardt yesterday at North Carolina Motor Speedway in Rockingham, N.C., but it was also a victory for Tommy Ellis, who won the circuit's driving championship. Ellis, 41, of Richmond, Va., clinched the title with a ninth-place finish, eight spots ahead of Mike Alexander. With one race left, Ellis has 4,145 points while Alexander has 3,956.(AP) Baseball Lions Take Series Opener: Kazuhiro Kiyohara and Hiromichi Ishige each hit home runs to lead the Seibu Lions to a 5-1 victory over the Chunichi Dragons in the opener of the Japan Series yesterday. The seven-game series continues in Nagoya today. (AP) Paralympics Australian, 68, Gains Bowling Medal: A 68-year-old man from Australia won a gold medal in lawn bowling yesterday in Seoul, South Korea, to become what may be the most decorated man in Paralympic Games history. He now holds 76 Paralympic medals, won in every games since the Paralympics began in 1960. Roy Fowler of Ipswich, Queensland, won his 35th gold yesterday, his first in the 1988 games. Fowler, a wheelchair athlete, has won medals in swimming, archery and table tennis.(AP) Soccer Norwich Beats Tottenham: Norwich City strengthened its hold on first place in the First Division of the English League by beating Tottenham Hotspur, 3-1, yesterday. Millwall played to a 2-2 tie with Nottingham Forest and stayed in second place.(AP) Golf Norman Pulls Ahead: Greg Norman of Australia took a two-stroke lead yesterday in the $165,000 New South Wales Open in Sydney, Australia. Norman finished the third round with a two-under 69 for a 54-hole total of nine-under 204. The defending champion, Craig Parry, carded a 72 for 206.(AP) Aoki Holds On: Isao Aoki fired a three-under-par 69 and held a two-stroke lead over Masashi Ozaki after the third round of the $630,000 Bridgestone Tournament in Chiba, Japan. Aoki had five birdies and two bogeys, finishing three rounds in 14-under 202. The defending champion, David Ishii of the United States, fired a 71 to tie for 38th at 217.(AP) Byrum Leads by 4: Tom Byrum shot a seven-under-par 65 yesterday for a third-round score of 201 and a four-stroke lead over four other golfers in the $400,000 Pensacola Open. Trailing Byrum were Bruce Lietzke, Andrew Magee, Ray Stewart and Ken Green.(AP) Track and Field South African Meets: Two Americans and a Brazilian based in the United States, competing on a team that faces suspension when it goes home, won their events for the third straight meet yesterday in Germiston, South Africa. The Athletics Congress, the national governing body for the sport in the United States, announced Thursday that 14 athletes, including Tom Hintnaus of Brazil, were to appear at a National Athletics Board of Review hearing Nov. 18 in Chicago for violating an international ban on competing in South Africa. Milan Stewart won the 110-meter high hurdles in 13.79 seconds, his third victory in the three-meet series. Hintnaus won the pole vault for the third time, at 17 feet 3/4 inch. Carol Cady, the American record-holder in the women's discus, won for the third time, with a throw of 197-4.(AP) Triathlon Molina Back on Top: Scott Molina, who dominated the sport from 1982-86, made a successful comeback yesterday by winning the Ironman world championship in Kailua-Kona, Hawaii. Molina, 28, of Boulder, Colo., finished the 2.4-mile swim, the 112-mile bicycle ride and the 26.2-mile run in 8 hours 31 minutes.(AP)

title: Mary Lindemann Is Wed To Alan G. Spear in Maine
description: Mary Allen Lindemann and Alan George Spear were married yesterday at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin in Falmouth, Me. The Rev. Stephen W. Foote, Archdeacon of the Episcopal Diocese of Maine, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Jeffrey M. Kirk.

title: Anne Fender is Wed
description: The wedding of Anne Elizabeth Fender, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Fender of Basking Ridge, N.J., to Erich Ryder Salzman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Salzman of Ridgefield, N.J., took place yesterday at St. Lawrence O'Toole Roman Catholic Church in Brewster, N.Y. The Rev. Gerard P. Travers performed the ceremony. The bride, a graduate of Simmons College, is a certified public accountant and was until recently with Price Waterhouse in Stamford, Conn. The bridegroom, a graduate of Ithaca College, is the controller at Advance Stone, a construction company in New Milford, Conn.

title: Steppenwolf Plays Together, Stays Together
description: It's the sort of story that, written by any of a score of modern dramatists, would end ironically. Those glitteringprizes would turn out to be gilded lead. Conspicuous success would actually be moral defeat.

title: YUGOSLAVIA VOTES ECONOMIC CHANGES
description: Parliament today approved constitutional amendments designed to make the economy more market-oriented and to ease the worst economic crisis since World War II.

title: Jennifer Petino Engaged
description: The engagement of Jennifer Lynn Petino and John Joseph McNaught has been announced by the future bride's mother, Gloria M. Petino of Brooklyn. Mr. McNaught is the son of Audrey McNaught of Jersey City and the late John F. McNaught. The future bride, also a daughter of the late George J. Petino, graduated from Pace University and is a traffic coordinator with McCann-Ericson, an advertising agency in New York. Mr. McNaught, president of Chipps Personnel Inc., an employment agency in New York, attended the Fashion Institute of Technology.

title: Dead Reckoning
description: DA Starring Barnard Hughes and Martin Sheen (in photo), William Hickey, Karl Hayden, Doreen Hepburn, Hugh O'Conor, Ingrid Craigie, Joan O'Hara, Peter Hanly. Directed by Matt Clark. 1988. Virgin Vision. 102 minutes. $79.95. Closed captioned. Rated PG. Includes some strong language.

title: Truth in Lending: Making It Readable
description: Anyone who takes a chance on an adjustable-rate mortgage knows that his bills can rise or fall with marketplace whims. But Federal regulations put in place this month take some of the suspense out of the ride. The new rules for banks were added to the Truth-in-Lending Law and represent a decision by the Federal Reserve Board that disclosure should include explanation and at least a bit of plain language. The amendment also standardizes the form that banks use to pass along information to help in comparison shopping.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Centereach $160,000 17 Walnut Street 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 33- year-old splanch; sunken living room, partial basement, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,000. East Patchogue $119,750 95 Miramar Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 18-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement, deck, above-ground pool; taxes $2,000. Glen Cove $395,000 14 Edwards Lane 3-bedroom, 2$-bath, 29-year-old ranch; new kitchen, fireplace, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $5,500. Lattingtown $325,000 26 Egypt Lane 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 70-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, oak floors, plaster walls; taxes $1,530. Ronkonkoma $147,000 73 Plainview Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 16-year-old ranch; new eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,700. Uniondale $195,000 332 Leslie Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 32- year-old split level; finished basement, dining room, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $3,100. OTHER AREAS Old Saybrook, Conn. $200,000 14 Cinnamon Ridge 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old Cape Cod; screened porch, 1 acre; taxes $1,819. Chappaqua, N.Y. $534,000 8 Deborah Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 8-year-old ranch; skylights, fireplace, playroom, deck, 1-acre; taxes $7,755. Chatham Borough, N.J. $193,000 31 King's Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old split level; deck, fireplace, new driveway; taxes $3,358.

title: UPRIGHT AMONG THE SWINE
description: BLACKWATER By Paulette Jiles. 239 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: Correction
description: A caption today in the highlights section on page 15 of the Television section refers to Mark Gastineau's scheduled performance in a football game this afternoon between the New York Jets and the Miami Dolphins.

title: CASE STUDY: The Philip Morris-Kraft Merger; Why Bigness May Not Matter
description: The case study method of teaching business requires students to study a corporation and suggest ways to solve its problems. This article takes the same approach, but with a twist: The subject is the proposed Philip Morris-Kraft merger, and the ''students'' - in this case, professors, executives, analysts and consultants - were asked to predict the results.

title: Italy Seizes Lebanese Who May Have Hostage Role
