description: The police in Milan said today that they had arrested a Lebanese woman who arrived from Beirut carrying three letters reportedly written by Americans held hostage in Lebanon. The woman also reportedly had at least two photographs of the American hostages.

title: A Mother's Fury
description: SHORTLY AFTER my retirement from a career in surgery, I was invited to teach at a school for naturalists at Yellowstone National Park. Let it be said that I know nothing of the wilderness, that my feet have rarely left pavement, that I am afraid of snakes. Nevertheless, at the appointed date, there I was in Mammoth Hot Springs, Wyo., to ''reinterpret'' the wilderness as though it were a human body. It is just another piece of cheer to which surgeons are prone.

title: Rogers Is Charged
description: He has a neck injury that could affect his football career, but Reggie Rogers has more serious matters on his mind these days. The Detroit Lion defensive end, who was involved in an automobile crash in which three teen-agers were killed in downtown Pontiac, Mich., early Friday morning, has been charged with three counts of involuntary manslaughter. In an interview with The Detroit Free Press, Rogers, who suffered a neck fracture that could jeopardize his career, said he was scared about his future, with or without football. According to prosecutors Rogers caused the accident by running a red light at high speed while driving drunk. (AP)

title: A Modest Proposal
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
For Mice and Men, a Common Treat
description: LEAD: MANY plants produce nuts that mature in the fall. Hickory nuts, walnuts and chestnuts are prized by both humans and the squirrels, chipmunks, mice and other rodents that store them for the winter by. In fact, humans may have to beat out the rodents to get their fair share.

title: 'The Captain and the Enemy'
description: The opening paragraph at once and magisterially upends us into Graham Greene's universe: ''I am now in my twenty-second year and yet the only birthday which I can clearly distinguish among all the rest is my twelfth, for it was on that damp and misty day in September I met the Captain for the first time. I can still remember the wetness of the gravel under my gym shoes in the school quad and how the blown leaves made the cloisters by the chapel slippery as I ran recklessly to escape from my enemies between one class and the next. I slithered and came to an abrupt halt while my pursuers went whistling away, because there in the middle of the quad stood our formidable headmaster talking to a tall man in a bowler hat, a rare sight already at that date, so that he looked a little like an actor in costume - an impression not so far wrong, for I never saw him in a bowler hat again. He carried a walking-stick over his shoulder at the slope like a soldier with a rifle. I had no idea who he might be, nor, of course, did I know how he had won me the previous night, or so he was to claim, in a backgammon game with my father.''

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
The T-Shirt Campaign: One Runner's Revenge
description: LEAD: My wife and I like to run. One would think that the pastime would be simple, the mere placing of one foot in front of the other until it is too late to call the whole thing off, return home and hide behind several sections of the newspaper.

title: Son Tells of Khrushchev's Last Days in Power
description: Nikita S. Khrushchev, the burly, boisterous peasant-turned-politician who became Stalin's successor in the Kremlin, at first refused to believe a reliable warning of his colleagues' plot to oust him and, when forced to believe it, refused to fight.

title:
GARDENING;
For Mice and Men, a Common Treat
description: LEAD: MANY plants produce nuts that mature in the fall. Hickory nuts, walnuts and chestnuts are prized by both humans and the squirrels, chipmunks, mice and other rodents that store them for the winter by. In fact, humans may have to beat out the rodents to get their fair share.

title: Sports of The Times; Repeal the Mike Andrews Rule
description: One of the nice things about the World Series was seeing Charles O. Finley being ''rehabilitated,'' in the Kremlin sense of the word. Even though Finley stubbornly ran the Athletics into chaos in the late 1970's and finally sold out, he had given Oakland a glorious tradition, and was graciously mentioned by Manager Tony LaRussa and others in the past week.

title: THE IRREPRESSIBLE NARCISSIST
description: LEAD: DIARY OF AN UNKNOWN By Jean Cocteau. Translated by Jesse Browner. 234 pp. New York: Paragon House Publishers.
LEAD: THE promise of the first major cultural-planning study in nearly 15 years is bringing a sense of optimism to the county's arts community.

title: Claire McIlhenny Is Married in D.C.
description: Claire Brooke McIlhenny, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. McIlhenny of Great Falls, Va., and John Joseph Dempsey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dempsey of Cleveland, were married yesterday at the Presbyterian Church of the Pilgrims in Washington by the Rev. Sidney D. Skirvin, who was assisted by the Rev. George M. Anderson, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Bush Wins the Endorsement Of Two Chicago Newspapers
description: The Chicago Tribune and The Chicago Sun-Times today endorsed George Bush, the Republican Presidential nominee, calling him one of the most qualified and experienced candidates ever, although the Tribune complained about the quality of the campaign and Mr. Bush's choice of a running mate.

title: At the Joffrey, the Curtain Rises on Act 2
description: For the first time in its 32-year history, the Joffrey Ballet will open a New York season at the City Center, on Wednesday, without Robert Joffrey. Yet, unlike so many other ballet troupes in transition, the Joffrey is still headed by a co-founder and by the resident choreographer whose ballets have molded the company's signature style.

title: Lisa B. Zalkin to Marry William Glenn in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Isadore Zalkin of Martinsville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Beth Zalkin, to William Henry Glenn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira S. Glenn of New York. The couple plan to wed on April 15.

title:
ART;
Soreff's Adventures in Abstraction
description: LEAD: HELEN SOREFF has a reputation for demonstrating the evocative powers of abstraction, using primarily pared-down, simplified forms in paintings or subtle divisions of black and white gradations in drawings.

title: Diane E. Hall Wed To H. W. Juan 3d, A Bank Executive
description: Diane Elizabeth Hall, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon B. Hall Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Henry Walter Juan 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry W. Juan Jr. of Greenwich. Rocco Benvenuto, a Town Justice in Greenwich, officiated.

title: France
description: To the Editor: There are three restaurants that might be of interest to your readers in addition to those suggested in the two insightful articles about Lyons and Colmar (Travel, Aug. 7).

title: Medical-Van Benefit: Helping the Homeless
description: About 800 of New York City's real estate brokers will get together tomorrow at a black-tie dinner in the Grand Hyatt Hotel to roast themselves and help light a fire under a particularly appropriate charity. Money raised by the $175-a-plate benefit will go to the New York Children's Health Project, which was started by Paul Simon, the composer and singer, to dispatch medical vans to homeless children.

title: Difficult Week for French Premier
description: Prime Minister Michel Rocard has endured his most embattled week in office, with more than 50,000 Government workers taking to the streets of Paris to demand pay increases.

title: What to Pack
description: To the Editor: Instead of taking your address book, pack preprinted gummed labels. These are great for postcards since you can keep track of who has been sent a card, and you don't run the risk of losing the address book. Other addresses or phone numbers you might need should be carried separately on a piece of paper (with copies distributed among your baggage or traveling party). DARRYL D. McEWEN Washington

title:
MUSIC;
Piano and Violin Duo Take On Sonata Limits
description: LEAD: THE pianist Peter Serkin and the violinist Young Uck Kim, in performing as a duo, have challenged the notion promoted by many publicists and concert managers that sonatas for violin and piano were intended as vehicles for a solo violinist with piano accompaniment.

title: After 28 Years, a Return to a Changed Moscow
description: ''Audiences here are different than audiences anywhere else in the world,'' Byron Janis, the pianist, said the other night. ''People here react, palpably, to one musical phrase. Playing here is a very personal experience between you and your audience.''

title: Review/Opera; 'Gotterdammerung' Completes Met's 'Ring' Cycle
description: The Metropolitan Opera's new ''Ring'' may or may not coalesce successfully when it finally appears in proper sequence later this season, but optimism could only grow after Friday evening's premiere of ''Gotterdammerung.'' The final work in Wagner's ever-astonishing tetralogy flamed into life early in the opening-night performance and scarcely cooled down for a moment. Wagnerian skeptics are hereby advised that they may leave their No-Doz at home this time.

title: Slate by Slate, a Steeple is Repaired
description: LEAD: TO hear Laura Price tell it, she will soon be a little bit closer to heaven. That is because her name will have a special place nearly 200 feet above the historic Bedford Village Green, a memento clinging to the larger of two spires of the old Bedford Presbyterian Church.

title: New York, Under Construction for Three Centuries
description: 1653. A wall is built, where Wall Street now runs, to protect New Amsterdam from Indian raids. 1699. The city, in English hands and renamed New York, builds a City Hall at Wall and Nassau Streets. 1735. The first city almshouse opens in what is now City Hall Park. 1759. A three-story jail is built next to the almshouse. 1788. City Hall is refurbished and renamed Federal Hall for the use of the first Congress. (Two years later, it moved to Philadelphia.) 1811. Present City Hall is completed. 1828. Gas street lights illuminate Broadway. 1830's. First real sewers, made of brick, are installed in Manhattan. Some are still in use. 1832. The horse-drawn cars of the New York and Harlem Railroad, the city's first, begin carrying passengers. Steam engines are introduced two years later, but not below 14th Street; the city thought them too dangerous for heavily populated areas. The ban was later extended to 42d Street, thus dictating the site of Grand Central Terminal. 1842. Croton Aqueduct System, supplying water from Westchester County, is finished at a cost of $12.5 million. The work was prompted by a fire that destroyed more than 600 buildings because firefighters, some of whom had ferried their pumpers from Jersey City and Brooklyn, lacked water. 1843. First school built by the new Board of Education opens. 1856-63. Central Park is acquired and laid out. 1878. Elevated railways are built on Third and Sixth Avenues. 1880. Electric street lights are installed on Broadway between 14th and 26th Streets. 1883. Brooklyn Bridge is opened; the City of Brooklyn, then independent and a commercial rival of Manhattan, paid much of the $16 million bill. 1898. The first public high schools open. 1903. Williamsburg Bridge opens. 1904. The Interborough Rapid Transit Company, with city help, builds an electric subway on the West Side, from City Hall to 145th Street. 1909. Queensborough and Manhattan Bridges are finished. 1917. Huge new water tunnels begin drawing from reservoirs in the Catskills. 1927. The Holland Tunnel opens. 1928. Goethals Bridge and Outerbridge Crossing open; they link Staten Island and New Jersey. 1930. The West Side Highway opens. 1931. George Washington Bridge and Bayonne Bridge open. 1932. City-built subway, now the IND line, is completed. 1936. Triborough Bridge opens; construction starts on Queens-Midtown Tunnel, Sixth Avenue Subway and a project to draw water from the Delaware River, completed in 1955. 1937. Henry Hudson Parkway, part of East River Drive and Lincoln Tunnel's first two tubes open. 1939. Bronx-Whitestone Bridge opens. 1940's. City and private developers work more and more closely on housing projects like Stuyvesant Town. 1940. City buys the subway lines operated by the IRT and the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Company. 1941. Work starts on mammoth air terminal in Idlewild, Queens, later to be called Kennedy Airport. 1949. Brooklyn Battery Tunnel opens. 1954. Columbus Circle redevelopment, including construction of Coliseum, starts; it is one of a series of ''slum clearance'' projects. 1961. Throgs Neck Bridge opens; with the Clearview Expressway, it cost $125.5 million. 1963. Lincoln Center complex is begun. 1964. Verrazano-Narrows Bridge opens; it is the city's last. 1968. Construction of World Trade Center begins. 1970. Third Water Tunnel, from Bronx reservoir to Manhattan, is begun. It is still not in service. 1972-73. $774 million worth of contracts are assigned for sewage treatment plants. 1973. West Side Highway collapses. 1975-76. Fiscal crisis means drastic cuts in capital budget, except in transit. Already-committed Federal aid means that $460 million in contracts are let for expansion of the subway system, including the still-incomplete Second Avenue Subway. 1982. City begins $6.3 billion program to rehabilitate the subways; most of the financing comes from a state bond issue. 1985. After more than a decade of debate, city gives up on Westway, which was to have been a combination of redevelopment along the Hudson and a new road to replace the West Side Highway. 1986. Facing severe shortage of low- and middle-income housing, city announces $2.4 billion, 10-year plan to rehabilitate apartment buildings it owns.

title: KILLING OFF THE SOUL
description: THE USE OF MAN By Aleksandar Tisma. Translated by Bernard Johnson. 342 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich.

title: For Burt of Giants, Too Much Too Soon Is the Right Medicine
description: Jim Burt has never taken adversity lying down.

title: A Quickening Congressional Race
description: WITH a little more than two weeks to go before Election Day, Nita M. Lowey, who came from behind last month to win a three-way Democatic primary for the 20th Congressional District race, is seeking a similar upset in an even tougher contest, against the two-term Republican incumbent, Joseph J. DioGuardi.

title: DIVING WITHTHE DOW
description: BLACK MONDAY The Catastrophe of October 19, 1987 . . . and Beyond. By Tim Metz. 264 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title: Arafat, Hussein And Mubarak Seek New Unity
description: After more than two years of estrangement between the Palestine Liberation Organization and Jordan, the P.L.O. Chairman, Yasir Arafat, and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt met with King Hussein today in the Jordanian port of Aqaba.

title: WHAT ASIAN THREAT?
description: THE THIRD CENTURY America's Resurgence in the Asian Era. By Joel Kotkin and Yoriko Kishimoto. 286 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $19.95.

title: Cayton's Complaint
description: Now that Mike Tyson and his wife, Robin Givens, have broken up, he seems to have shifted his allegiance to Don King. And like the marriage, the arrangement with the flamboyant promoter seems to be headed for court.

title: Society of Architects Picks Award Winners
description: LEAD: SMALL projects of the post-modern style captured the attention of the New Jersey Society of Architects at the annual awards presentation in Atlantic City earlier this month.

title: John Hamish Gardner 2d Is Married To Elizabeth Finkle, Sales Assistant
description: At the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York, Elizabeth Hamilton Finkle, the daughter of Mrs. Richard B. Smith of New York and S. Marcus Finkle of Aspen, Colo., was married yesterday to John Hamish Gardner 2d, a son of Mrs. Edward P. Gardner of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Gardner.

title: 'Taking the Worry Out of Growing Older'
description: I would like to comment on a recent article, ''Interest Grows in Continuing-Care Communities for the Elderly.'' I am a resident of Monroe Village in Monroe Township, and I could never have made a greater decision than coming here.

title: An America's Cup Reunion
description: It was a day in mid-September, one of those fine sailing afternoons that only autumn in the Northeast can bring. The sun was shining, and a fresh sea breeze kicked in on Narragansett Bay in Rhode Island.

title: Lifting the Ice Curtain
description: ABOUT 30 YARDS TO the west, across the snow and ice hummocks of the Bering Strait, lies the international date line. Beyond the random paths of polar bears and the scattered holes cut through the ice by Eskimos to snare king crab, no signs or even snow cairns mark one's approach to the divide. Crossing it is only a matter of steps, but this global seam separates today from tomorrow, the Americas from Eurasia, and the territory of the United States from that of the Soviet Union. Here, offshore between the barren islands of Soviet Big Diomede and American Little Diomede, 52 miles below the Arctic Circle, the two great continental powers reach out across the map and all but touch, like the outstretched figures in Michelangelo's ''The Creation of Adam.''

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Sales of Small Airports Are Taking Off
description: THE quest for land in Connecticut has made small, privately owned airports, particularly those that are unprofitable, prime targets for redevelopment. At least three of 16 such facilities have been sold or leased, and two more are on the block.

title: Stephen Ohler Married To Silvia R. McCarthy
description: Silvia Rosa McCarthy, an account supervisor, and Stephen Hardenbergh Ohler, a vice president and associate creative director, both at the New York advertising agency of McCann-Erickson, were married yesterday at St. Charles Borromeo Roman Catholic Church in Albuquerque, N.M. The Rev. Jose Blanch performed the ceremony.

title: Why Some Movies Don't Travel Well
description: It's not fashionable to look at movies as social artifacts. Movies are supposed to be art, to stand alone to speak to whomever wants to look and listen. Since most films are not art, however, there's no other easy way to respond to them except, occasionally, as psyche-revealing inkblot tests.

title: A Day for Entrepreneurs at College
description: ''WHOM do we expect? Victims of corporate down-sizing, women trying to make it on their own, minority entrepreneurs and small-business owners, and just about anyone else who is looking for an alternate way of earning a living.''

title: UNDER DIKE BRIDGE
description: SENATORIAL PRIVILEGE The Chappaquiddick Cover-Up. By Leo Damore. Illustrated. 496 pp. Washington: Regnery Gateway. $21.95.

title: PARLEY IN JORDAN IS SAID TO NARROW SPLIT WITH ARAFAT
description: The leaders of Egypt and Jordan reported significant progress today in healing a two-year rift between Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization after unexpected negotiations Saturday with Yasir Arafat, chairman of the P.L.O.

title: Rome Suspects Arms Dealer Has Role in Efforts on Hostages
description: Police officials said today that they were investigating a suspected arms dealer who has links to Italian and Swiss intelligence agencies to determine his role in possible efforts to free American hostages being held in Lebanon.

title: Tie Breakers Made Simpler
description: TIE BREAKERS in Davis Cup? Heresay, you say. But it's true. Beginning in 1989, Davis Cup matches, the last bastion of such outrageous set scores as 10-8, 13-11, 17-15, will end all but the final sets of individual matches with tie breakers once a set reaches 6-6.

title: Farley Bids $1.3 Billion For Pepperell
description: After five months of intense speculation, heavy trading of its stock and a $14 jump in the price of its shares since May, West Point-Pepperell Inc., a big Georgia-based producer of sheets and towels, is coming under takeover attack today.

title: South African Family Mourns Son Who 'Disappeared'
description: A gentle man wearing his best Sunday suit and the look of personal tragedy, Matome Bopape wondered today about the whereabouts of his oldest son, Stanza.

title: Why Johnny Can't Think
description: It occurred to me the other day that this year's rather mindless Presidential campaign might be further evidence of the decline of American education. Maybe the candidates are giving us such a thin diet because our schools never taught us how to deal with anything more substantial.

title: Willoughby's Is Sold for $1 Million
description: Willoughby's, a Manhattan retailer that calls itself the world's largest camera store, has been acquired by Queen Street Camera Inc. of Toronto for $1 million. The Canadian company plans to inject $5 million into the store immediately for new inventory, physical improvements and marketing, its chairman and founder, Erik Olesen, said.

title: Reading Bush's Mind
description: Mustn't get overconfident. That Sasso fella will stop at nothing, and is pumping the rumors of me being a civil libertine. And I hear Lloyd Bentsen has something more respectable up his sleeve.

title: Why Social Security Shouldn't Be Voluntary
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Durable Goods Sept. Wednesday G.N.P. 3d Qtr. Thursday Personal Income Sept. Friday None

title: OPEC's Plan to Cut Production Collapses
description: An ambitious attempt by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to limit its rampant oil production collapsed over the weekend as Iraq and Iran failed to bridge their political schism.

title: ITT Plans Guilty Plea In U.S. Contract Case
description: The ITT Corporation said today that it would plead guilty Monday to a charge of conspiring to defraud the Government. The Government had charged that the company treated an Air Force employee to meals and golf greens fees to obtain information on two Air Force contracts worth $180 million. The company could be fined as much as $500,000. ITT was indicted in June 1987, several months before an investigation began into the use of consultants by corporations to get information for use in bidding for contracts. Company Is 'Distressed'

title: Other Sides of Skiing
description: There is life after ski racing. In fact, there is another life during a ski racer's career. That's what 50 racers and coaches from the United States Ski Team are discovering today in a kind of executive training program. They are learning about the business side of skiing as well as how to move into the real world after their racing days are over. The event is the United States Ski Team Academy held in Park City, Utah.

title: Reviews/Television; An Amish Farmer and a Prosecutor
description: A promising beginning and an inspirational ending, but no middle; that is the average made-for-television movie. Tonight's specimen, on NBC at 9, is ''A Stoning in Fulham County.''

title: A Stray Bullet Kills a Woman In Queens Home
description: A woman standing in the foyer of her house in Queens was killed yesterday when a bullet from a high-powered rifle smashed through the front door, striking her in the abdomen, the police said.

title: What's Wrong With Public School Uniforms?; 'A Cover-Up'
description: To the Editor:

title: Group Plans Overhaul Of the Pulitzer Fountain
description: A privately financed renovation of Grand Army Plaza, on Fifth Avenue, is to begin today with the removal of the goddess Pomona from atop the Fountain of Abundance. By the end of 1989, the fountain may do something it hasn't in six years - function.

title: Bush Flier Features Convict
description: A Republican Party campaign flier mailed last week in support of Vice President Bush's campaign prominently features a photograph of Willie Horton, the murderer who escaped while on prison furlough in Massachusetts and then raped a woman in Maryland.

title: Foes Accuse Bush Campaign Of Inflaming Racial Tension
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and other Democrats accused the Presidential campaign of Vice President Bush yesterday of inflaming the nation's racial fears with a relentless emphasis on the case of a black prisoner who raped a white woman while he was on leave from a Massachusetts prison. The Bush campaign immediately ridiculed the accusations.

title: Thomson McKinnon Stake
description: Employees of Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc. have been told that the firm is seeking a buyer of a 23 percent stake in the brokerage held by the Hartford Insurance Group, people close to the firm said yesterday.

title: Bridge
description: For the first time in the 28-year history of the World Team Olympiad, an American open team collected the title. Presented with the trophies Saturday night, marking their success in the two-week competition, were Bob Wolff, Bob Hamman and Jim Jacoby of Dallas; Seymon Deutsch of Laredo, Tex.; Jeff Meckstroth of Columbus, Ohio, and Eric Rodwell of West Lafayette, Ind.

title: Dr. Jennifer Madans Wed to Immunologist
description: Dr. Jennifer Holly Madans, an official at the National Center for Health Statistics in Hyattsville, Md., and Dr. Terence Martyn Phillips, an immunologist, were married yesterday at the One Washington Circle Hotel in Washington by Rabbi Harold White.

title: The Men Behind the Campaign Myth
description: As recent weeks have confirmed, a Presidential campaign is not designed to reveal character. Each candidate is presented as tough and gentle, thoughtful and decisive, a family man and a man of the world, along with whatever else suits the audience of the moment. So with about two weeks to go until Election Day, the questions with which the campaign started - Who is George Bush? Who is Michael S. Dukakis? - remain matters of interest.

title: Legends of Soccer
description: Hilarious soccer joke:

title: Soap Opera Magazines Fight For Fans' Hearts and Dollars
description: Psst! Skye will try to kill Barbara on ''All My Children.'' Mason will develop a third personality on ''Santa Barbara.'' And David will turn out to be the father of Nina's baby on ''The Young and the Restless.''

title: Review/Theater; Seeking Truth in an Age of Considerable Boredom
description: If the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival is a serious portent of cultural things to come, the term avant-garde can finally be retired from New York's vocabulary. The festival's opening attraction for 1988, ''The Warrior Ant,'' is nothing if not a throwback to the smorgasbord esthetics of that totemic artistic happening of the 1950's, the Ed Sullivan show.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article yesterday about a Bach organ Mass to be played by the organist Anthony Newman at the Holy Trinity Church, 316 East 88th Street, misstated the day of the performance. It is to be this Sunday.

title: POLITICS: Campaign Finance; Democrats Turn Tables on G.O.P. Outraising It in Races for the Senate
description: Many Republican Senate candidates this year are finding themselves in the unusual and uncomfortable position of being outspent or matched financially by their Democratic rivals.

title: Algo Henderson, 91, Ex-President Of Antioch College and an Author
description: Algo D. Henderson, a former president of Antioch College and one of the principal planners of the State University of New York, died of cancer Thursday at Kaiser Hospital in San Francisco. He was 91 years old and lived in Orinda, Calif.

title: Another Bicentennial
description: George Washington is customarily associated with the city that bears his name and with his native Virginia. Yet, in the case of New York, Washington not only slept there, but was also inaugurated there as the country's first President in 1789. In fact, New York was the capital of the United States from then until 1790.

title: Julie Herzig Is Married To Dr. Robert Desnick
description: The wedding of Julie Esther Herzig, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip R. Herzig of Great Neck. L.I., to Dr. Robert John Desnick, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore D. Desnick of Minneapolis, took place yesterday at the North Shore Country Club in Glen Head, L.I. Rabbi Jerome Davidson performed the ceremony.

title: HDM New York Gets Lea & Perrins Account
description: Less than two years after introducing White Wine Worcestershire Sauce to a public acquainted only with the deep brown original, Lea & Perrins Inc. on Tuesday gave its $5 million account to HDM New York.

title: Hope and Infighting Mix In Pakistani Campaign
description: The cement was still wet on the front stairs when Tikka Khan, a retired general and former head of the Pakistani Army, moved into his new election office this week. Seated under a portrait of the late Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, the former general opened his first civilian political campaign.

title: A Hero Emerges At West Virginia
description: Representatives of eight bowl games were in the press box at Morgantown, W. Va., Saturday when the Mountaineers handed Boston College a 59-19 defeat.

title: Eagles' Rally Stuns Cowboys
description: Randall Cunningham threw a 1-yard touchdown pass to Anthony Toney with four seconds left today as the Philadelphia Eagles rallied from a 20-0 first-half deficit to beat the Dallas Cowboys, 24-23.

title: Client Group Confronting Fiery Topics
description: THE Association of National Advertisers is accustomed to opening its annual meetings during times of turmoil. Last year the stock market crash disturbed day one. This year the association's 79th annual convention comes to New York amid proposals for the largest mergers and buyouts of consumer-products companies in history.

title: The Squeeze on Peru's Businesses
description: For Hans Traver, the perils of making plastic goods in Peru have included the hostility of a leftist military regime, a flood of cheap products from foreign competitors and a .38-caliber terrorist bullet that is lodged in his jaw.

title: Bringing Warmth To Winter Sportsmen
description: Several years ago, a California-based construction supply firm came across a product that seemed well suited to its buyers. The item was a hand warmer activated by air.

title: Cosby at Carnegie
description: The comedian Bill Cosby is to give a benefit performance at Carnegie Hall on Nov. 29 at 9 P.M. to benefit the hall. Ticket prices range from $35 to $2,500. Information: 247-7800.

title: Devils Tie After a 2-0 Lead Slips Away
description: The Devils took a two-goal lead before the game was nine minutes old tonight, but had to settle for a 3-3 deadlock with the Red Wings.

title:
MARKET PLACE;
Brokers Covet Maturing C.D.'s
description: LEAD: WITH individual investors still avoiding the stock market, the brokerage industry is looking for any glimmer of hope. Now, coming over the financial horizon, is more than a glimmer: billions in maturing certificates of deposit into which worried investors rushed after last October's stock market collapse.

title: Sprouse Out Of Business
description: Stephen Sprouse, the American designer who shook up the fashion world in 1983 with his neon colors and graffiti-scrawled 1960's shapes, will go out of business again, said CSI Associates, the company that runs his retail and wholesale operations.

title: A Fallen Leader Is Now Talking Of Loftier Things
description: He sounded like the quintessential political reformer, passionately espousing the virtues of public campaign financing and the stronger ethics provisions proposed by commissions on city charter revision and government integrity. Only the special relevance of those proposals to his present circumstances, and his cigar, gave him away.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 24, 1988: MONDAY Atlantic Richfield Lubrizol Corp Baker Hughes Phila Elec Co Brown & Sharpe Mfg Union Camp Corp Howell Corp Wells Fargo Mtge & Equity Interstate Securities Zurn Industries Johnson & Johnson TUESDAY Ahmanson (H.F.) & Co Kennametal Inc Amax Gold Inc McDonald & Co Instmts American Brands NUI Corp Amoco Corp Newmont Mining Corp Ball Corp Norwest Corp Black Hills Corp Public Serv Co New Mex Borden Inc Rockaway Corp Cilcorp Inc Rollins Inc Duke Power Rubbermaid Inc Edison Bros Stores Southwestern Pub Serv Enserch Corp Standex Intl Fedders Corp Tambrands Inc Fleming Cos UGI Corp Gannett Co USX Corp Glenfed Inc USLife Corp Great Western Financial Warner-Lambert Indiana Energy Wicor Inc WEDNESDAY Alltel Corp Inland Steel Indus AMP Inc Kentucky Utilities Amer Electric Pwr Lukena Inc Anheuser-Busch McGraw-Hill Belo (A.H.) Corp NCNB Corp Cigna Corp Natl Medical Enterprises Cameron Iron Works Oakwood Homes Corp Chevron Corp Panhandle Eastern Corp Coast Svgs & Ln Assoc Parker Hannifin Columbia Svgs & Ln Russell Corp Downey Svgs & Ln Scana Corp DuPont Shaw Indus Eaton Corp Squibb Corp Energen Corp TRW Inc Exxon Corp TW Services Inc Hercules Inc Textron Inc Home Group Inc Union Carbide Houghton Mifflin Wrigley THURSDAY Affiliated Publications Lawter Intl Amer Genl Corp Morton-Thiokol Inc Amer Home Prdts Nalco Chemical Anadarko Pete Olin Corp Avemco Corp Owens & Minor Avery International Pfizer Inc Bemis Co Inc Potomac Elec Pwr CRS Sirrine Inc Questar Corp Delta Air Lines RLC Corp Eastern Gas & Fuel Assn Republic Gypsum Empire District Elec Sara Lee Corp Ethyl Corp Sonat Inc Imperial Corp Amer Texaco Inc Iowa-Ill G&E UST Inc Jostens Inc FRIDAY Dexter Corp Mobil Corp Equifax Inc Monsanto Co Equitable Resources Norton Co First Wachovia Corp Rollins Environmental Svcs Georgia Pacific Ryder Systems Harland (John H) Co Sizeler Property Invstrs Harris Corp Del Snap-On Tools Kaufman & Broad Home Vulcan Materials Kysor Industrial West Point Pepperell McDonnell Douglas Wisconsin Energy SATURDAY Mead Corp Wackenhut Corp

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel section yesterday about hotel reservations in Washington for the Presidential inaugural weekend misstated the cost of a package plan at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. It costs $15,000.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Miss Duke Wed To John S. Cluett
description: Maria-Luisa Biddle Duke and John Stockton Cluett were married yesterday at their home in Big Sur, Calif. Judge Mark C. Rowland of Alaska Superior Court in Anchorage officiated.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-9 Progress in Jordanian-P.L.O. ties was reported by the leaders of Egypt and Jordan after unexpected negotiations Saturday with Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization. A1

title: INSIDE
description: Fighting Nature, for Whales As the small war being waged to save two whales increased in Alaska, some biologists began to question the wisdom of the efforts. Page A15. Jets and Giants Win The Jets beat the Dolphins, 44-30, despite spectacular passing by Miami's Dan Marino. The Giants topped Atlanta, 23-16. SportsMonday, page C1.

title: David Abrams Marries Amy Levine in Boston
description: Correction Appended

title: Conservationists Laud Efforts For the Hudson
description: They began with a passion for a mountain, a band of volunteers determined to stop Consolidated Edison from building a power plant on the slopes of Storm King Mountain overlooking the Hudson River Gorge.

title: Villahermosa Journal; Recipe for Mexico? Politics With Pepper Added
description: Politicians have switched parties, accusations of electoral treachery are flying and both candidates are attempting to forge unity in their own fractious parties. Here in Tabasco these days, the politics are even hotter than the state's famed chili peppers.

title: Recognition Officials Depart
description: The president and marketing director of Recognition Equipment Inc., both indicted two weeks ago on charges of conspiracy to defraud the United States Postal Service in the procurement of $250 million in Government contracts, have taken leaves of absence, the company said Thursday. The two executives, William

title: As Alaska Whale Rescue Is Pressed, Biologists Question Effort's Wisdom
description: As the small war being waged to save a pair of whales escalated today, some biologists began to question the wisdom of the effort.

title: Couch Potato Vote Receives an Appeal
description: Like the three performers who sang Stephen Sondheim's ''You Gotta Have A Gimmick,'' Anna Eshoo has a gimmick. California-style.

title: Reviews/Music; Sketches of Beethoven Heard at Carnegie Hall
description: Beethoven's sketchbooks were his musical diaries and idea books, carried always on his person and containing not only notated music but also verbal scenarios. One thing they describe is a composer's obsession with often trivial musical themes. Their appearance and reappearance in gradual transformations make the sketchbooks road maps to his creative process.

title: Common Heritage Isn't Always Enough
description: One of the bits of conventional wisdom of the 1988 Presidential is that the Greek-American vote will go overwhelmingly for the first Greek-American to run for President.

title: Britons Deny Reports Of a Bell Buyout Effort
description: Principals of Lowe Howard-Spink & Bell, the British ad agency holding company partly owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, have denied reports that its deputy chairman, Tim Bell, tried to organize a management buyout of part of the company.

title: Dr. Minna Cagan Marries Dr. Steven E. Selub on L.I.
description: Dr. Minna Ruth Cagan, a fellow in reproductive endocrinology at the Duke University Medical Center in Durham, N.C., and Dr. Steven Elie Selub, a fellow in gastroenterology at the University of North Carolina School of Medicine at Chapel Hill, were married yesterday at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, L.I. Rabbi Earl Kideckel performed the ceremony.

title: Fountain Bet Ends in Death
description: Christopher Paulsen, 26 years old, bet a man a dollar last Saturday that he could swim through a narrow conduit connecting two pools on the upper tier of the outdoor Ira's Fountain, near Portland's Civic Auditorium. He became trapped under a concrete slab, had to be rescued, and died in a hospital this Saturday, the authorities said.

title: CONGRESS REGAINS ITS VOICE ON POLICY IN 1987-88 SESSIONS
description: Overshadowed for six years by a popular and aggressive President, Congress regained its voice in the 1987-88 sessions, enacting ground-breaking legislation in areas as diverse as trade policy and welfare, civil rights and arms control.

title: The Emerging Trade Threat
description: LEAD: While Bush and Dukakis out-Rambo one another on national defense and trade, real foreign policy pressures are building. The United States, Europe and Japan risk being pulled apart by three super-regional blocks of nations now forming in our own hemisphere, across the Atlantic and in East Asia. The results could be a more protectionist world economy, more trouble in handling Moscow and less clout for

title: Curbside Pickup and Sludge Forests: Some Cities Make Recycling Work
description: When the people who manage the 100,000 tons of sewage sludge produced annually by this city are asked what they do with it, they point to a forest of unusually large conifers.

title: 2,800 Residents, 2 Papers, and a Matter of Pride
description: A war of weekly newspapers has broken out in this secluded former whaling village in eastern Suffolk County, challenging loyalties to a local institution.

title: POLITICS: The Basic Speech; 'When I Talk About a Kinder and Gentler Nation, I Mean It'
description: Candidates for President make dozens of speeches in their campaigns. Some address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. But more often the candidate uses a ''basic speech.'' It summarizes, with little variation from one occasion to the next except for an obligatory local reference at the beginning, how the candidate wants to present himself to the voters.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Kraft's board rejected a takeover by Philip Morris. Moving to preserve its independence, the directors offered stockholders a dividend package they valued at $110 a share, or $14 billion. Philip Morris, which had offered about $11.5 billion, is likely to raise its bid for the nation's fourth-largest consumer goods producer. [ Page A1. ] Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts will offer $20 billion for RJR Nabisco, people with knowledge of the firm's plans said. Nabisco's top management and Shearson Lehman Hutton have offered $75 a share, or $17 billion. The $90-a-share bid would dwarf the $11.5 billion that Philip Morris has offered for Kraft and the $6.2 billion paid for Beatrice in 1985. RJR Nabisco stock closed at $76.75 on Friday. [ D1. ] Farley is attempting to take over West Point-Pepperell, offering $48 a share, or about $1.3 billion, for the 90.2 percent of the company it does not own. The move comes just six months after Pepperell acquired J. P. Stevens, another producer of sheets and towels, in a move to fend off hostile suitors. [ D1. ] Shearson Lehman Hutton plans to cut its work force by about 1,000 people before the end of the year, sources said. [ D3. ] Queen Street Camera has bought Willoughby's for $1 million. The Canadian chain plans to inject $5 million into the camera store immediately for new inventory and physical improvements. [ D3. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT An OPEC effort to limit oil production collapsed amid continuing friction between Iraq and Iran. The plan would have integrated Iraq into a production quota system and eliminated about three million barrels of excess OPEC oil a day from world markets. [ D1. ] The London police say they questioned a man who penetrated military, corporate and university computer systems in Europe and the United States. Officials said the investigation began after reports that the man offered to tell a computer maker, in exchange for money, how he broke into its computer network. [ D1. ] Greece has begun an ambitious export program. Consortiums in the United States will seek a tenfold increase in shipments of products in seven categories, including food and apparel. [ D6. ] Harsh economic measures have created havoc for businesses in Peru. A plastics maker says the situation is the worst he has seen in 25 years of business. [ D6. ] THE ECONOMY ITT said it would plead guilty today to a charge of defrauding the Government. A Federal indictment had accused the company of treating an Air Force employee to meals and golf greens fees to obtain information about two contracts. [ D2. ] The S.E.C. is cracking down on fraud and manipulation in penny stocks, its chairman said at a regulators' meeting in Denver. [ D2. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS A weekly newspaper war has broken out in Sag Harbor, L.I., challenging small-town loyalties to a local institution. [ D10. ] Magazines about daytime television are thriving, and publishers say the increased competition is good for business. [ D10. ] NBC has taken several actions to win friends in Washington, part of Robert C. Wright's strategy aimed at loosening Government restrictions on the networks. Television. [ D10. ] A big advertising trade group has taken steps to fight what it sees as Government encroachment. The Association of National Advertisers is meeting in New York. Advertising. [ D9. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS People with sizable sums in retirement plans must make an important decision involving an excise tax. Tax Watch. [ D2. ] Long-term interest rates are likely to remain stable for a while. Analysts note that, despite predictions of volatility, rates have remained in a tight trading range for a year. Credit Markets. [ D5. ] Securities brokers are hoping for a huge windfall as C.D.'s worth billions of dollars reach maturity. Market Place. [ D4. ]

title: Soviets Plan Price Index
description: The Soviet Union, which has long maintained that it has no inflation, plans to develop an index to measure rising prices, a senior Government statistician said Thursday.

title: Witnessing the Birth Of an Interest Group
description: ''Average Students for Quayle.''

title: Outdoors: Angling in Preserves
description: THE Constitution makes no mention of trout or bass, deer or grouse, duck, goose, dove or quail. But there is, nonetheless, a bedrock American tradition of free public land and the freedom to hunt and fish thereon.

title: Review/Music; The Prokofiev Sonatas
description: This season we have already had a complete Bartok quartet cycle, and the start of a Beethoven piano sonata cycle, and there are other cycles in the offing. But valuable as these traversals may be, they tend to focus on works we hear all the time, or even, as in the case of the Beethoven, entire cycles we hear at least annually.

title: Senate Rejects Aid for U.N. Troops
description: As it rushed toward adjournment, the Senate on Saturday rejected an Administration request for $150 million for United Nations peacekeeping operations in several regions, including southern Africa, despite White House assurances that it would continue to support the Angolan rebels.

title: Chevron to Cut 400 Jobs
description: Chevron U.S.A. announced plans Friday to cut 400 jobs from the work force of 2,200 at its largest refinery because of increased competition and reduced profit. The Port Arthur refinery has an operating capacity of 407,000 barrels of crude per day. After streamlining, capacity will be about 329,000 barrels per day. A marketing strategy calls for the refinery to place a greater emphasis on the production of petrochemicals, premium unleaded gasoline and lubricating base oils.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Magee Wins in Florida: Andrew Magee earned his first victory on the PGA Tour, shooting a six-under-par 66 yesterday to win the $400,000 Pensacola Open tournament by one stroke over Bruce Lietzke, Tom Byrum and Ken Green. Magee, 26, who entered the tournament in 64th place on the money list, won $72,000. The University of Oklahoma graduate's previous best finish was a tie for third earlier this year at the Hertz Bay Hill Classic. Magee, from Scottsdale, Ariz., finished with a 271 on the 7,033-yard, par-72 course at Tiger Point Golf and Country Club in Gulf Breeze, Fla. He sank eight birdies, offset by two bogies on the final round.(AP) AUTO RACING Wallace Is First: Rusty Wallace kept alive his chance of winning the Winston Cup championship by coming from two laps down to win the AC-Delco 500 Nascar race at North Carolina Motor Speedway in Rockingham, N.C., yesterday. Wallace, in a Pontiac, beat Ricky Rudd, driving a Ford, by 12.3 seconds. Terry Labonte, in a Chevrolet, was third, followed by Bill Elliott, the Winston Cup points leader, in a Ford and Dale Earnhardt in a Chevrolet. The victory, combined with Elliott's fourth-place finish, allowed Wallace to move to within 79 points of the lead in the Winston Cup competition. Elliott has 4,198 points to Wallace's 4,119 with two races remaining.(AP) TENNIS Shriver Wins in Switzerland: Top-seeded Pam Shriver overpowered third-seeded Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria, 6-3, 6-4, yesterday to win the $200,000 European Indoor tournament in Zurich. The American, ranked fifth in the world, used an aggressive serve-and-volley game to clinch her first tournament title since winning the Pan-Pacific Open in Tokyo in May. It was the seventh loss for the 21-year-old Maleeva in eight career encounters with Shriver. Maleeva took her opponent to break point four times in the first set. She broke Shriver once in the second set to tie at 4-4, but faltered on her serve and lost the next game without winning a point. (AP) Mayotte Edges Mexican: Top-seeded Tim Mayotte defeated Leonardo Lavalle of Mexico, 4-6, 6-4, 6-3, to win the Frankfurt Cup. Mayotte, who also won the tournament last year, needed 2 hours 20 minutes to overcome the left-handed player. In the decisive set, Mayotte broke Lavalle's serve for a 4-2 lead and wasted 3 match points before scoring his fourth tournament victory this year. Mayotte earned $28,000 for his victory.(AP) McEnroe Defeats Krickstein: John McEnroe served and volleyed his way past a fellow American, Aaron Krickstein, 6-3, 6-1, to win a four-man tennis exhibition in Turin, Italy, Saturday night. McEnroe served 12 aces and controlled the net with sharp volleys to dispose of Krickstein in 58 minutes indoors at the Turin Sports Palace.(AP) HORSE RACING Upset at Aqueduct: The Phipps Stable and its trainer, Shug McGaughey, the leading stakes-winning outfit in New York this year, added an improbable winner to their record when Dancing All Night scored an eight-length upset victory in the $187,200 Long Island Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct. The winner was ridden by the replacement jockey Julian Vazquez as the jockeys' strike continued for a fifth day. Casey, an English import, was second by a length over Gaily Gaily. Anka Germania finished fifth as the 7-5 favorite in a field of 10 fillies and mares. Dancing All Night, a 4-year-old daughter of Nijinsky and Blitey, ran the mile and a half on a yielding grass course in 2:34 1/5. She paid $27.60 for $2 to win and was coupled in the betting with Dutchess Best, who finished ninth.

title: Turn That Dial Back in Time: Superman & Co. Return!
description: Look! Up in front of the Holiday Inn! It's a bird! It's a plane! It's Bob Hastings! Yes, it's Bob Hastings, who can change the course of mighty rivers, bend steel in his bare hands and fight the never-ending battle for truth, justice and the American way -all while standing calmly at an ordinary-looking microphone, wearing his everyday corduroy jacket and his dark, open-necked sport shirt. No red cape, blue tights or telephone booths for Bob Hastings.

title: The K.G.B.'s Lofty Humanist
description: LEAD: With Moscow mounting a new effort to rejoin the World Psychiatric Association, a hitherto unnoticed passage in a Pravda interview on Sept. 2d with Victor M. Chebrikov, then the head of the K.G.B., deserves close attention.

title: Banks Sparks Giants
description: The Giants have made a habit this season of winning or losing games in the last seconds, but they almost outdid themselves today.

title: Steelers Increase Creativity and Win
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers played as if they had nothing to lose today, and ended their longest losing streak in 20 seasons.

title: Letting Smokers Pay for Child Care
description: John J. Day of Indianapolis is a parent, a teacher and a state legislator and, logically enough, the creator of Indiana's program of paying for child care for school-age children by raising the state cigarette tax.

title: Milestone Events
description: On Friday, at the State Department, Carol Adelman was sworn in as the Agency for International Development's Assistant Administrator of the Asia and Near East Bureau. In brief remarks attended by her husband and friends, Mrs. Adelman said that her induction into office might be a candidate for the Guinness Book of World Records as the last swearing-in of the Reagan Administration. But, she added, she was not an entry for the category of ''most controversial confirmation'' by the Senate.

title: Coaches in Overtime
description: When George Butcher retired in 1981 after 34 years of coaching high school football, he planned to play a lot of golf and spend the winters in South Carolina and Florida with his wife, playing more golf and relaxing.

title: Streaking Rangers Roll Into First Place
description: They are almost tragicomic, what with their hands of stone and limitless spirit. They create havoc and thus innumerable chances, if also precious few goals. As a result, they have a tendency to exasperate in the same shift as they delight. One thing Lucien DeBlois, Don Maloney and Jan Erixon never do, though, is stop working. It's an ethic that has been admired but in the past only occasionally imitated by their teammates.

title: An Apprentice Drug Czar
description: Czar Dan: Vice President Bush said he would give his running mate the huge task of coordinating Federal anti-drug efforts.

title: Anti-Nuclear Group Marks a 5-Year Vigil
description: About 70 people assembled on a small triangle of land near the White Hart Inn this weekend to mark the fifth anniversary of what has become the state's oldest anti-nuclear war vigil.

title: Review/Art; After the Crosshatch: Johns in Philadelphia
description: Acclaimed in June as the crown and centerpiece of this year's Venice Biennale, the exhibition of ''Jasper Johns: Work Since 1974'' opens Sunday at the Philadelphia Museum of Art and can be seen there through Jan. 8. Composed almost entirely of large new paintings in which mastery is everywhere evident, it makes a tremendous impact in a museum whose plain grandeur sets it off to perfection.

title: The Talk of Mystic; Pizza Brings New Fame To a Seaport
description: Something happened here last week, something that could affect the delicate balance between the tony and the touristy, the patrician and the prosaic, that this salt-sprayed former whaling port has tried to maintain. It was a movie, ''Mystic

title: What's Wrong With Public School Uniforms?; Mayor's Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: A Stretcher for the Dodgers
description: MAYBE most of all this winter I'll miss Mickey Hatcher, who runs as if he's being chased by a dog.

title: For Hockey Enthusiasts, Holiday on Ice
description: DAVE SPRINGETT manages a grain company in Winnipeg, Manitoba. For two weeks each winter, he is a manager of a different sort, a playing manager of an international hockey team.

title: In the Middle of It, Filled With Wonder
description: Shortly before Gov.

title: Review/Dance; Abridged 'Swan Lake' Breaks With Tradition
description: The East Coast had its first look at the San Francisco Ballet's lavishly designed and hugely popular new ''Swan Lake'' when the production by Helgi Tomasson came to the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts this weekend.

title: Vicki Nightingale Becomes a Bride
description: Vicki Lynn Nightingale, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Nightingale of Rye Brook, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Anderson Hettich, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Hettich of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Longboat Key, Fla. Judge Peter C. Dorsey of Federal District Court in Hartford performed the ceremony at the Belle Haven Club in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Barry Campbell Good, Executive, 56
description: Barry Campbell Good, a managing director and energy industry analyst at the brokerage house of Morgan Stanley & Company Inc., died of lung cancer Saturday at his Manhattan home. He was 56 years old and also lived in Watermill, L.I.

title: Greece Plans More Exports to U.S.
description: The Greek Government, with the assistance of American marketing experts, has begun an ambitious export program designed to make ''Made in Greece'' a household label in the United States.

title: Kodak-Mitsubishi Deal
description: An Eastman Kodak Company subsidiary that sells an innovative snowmaking aid announced an agreement with the Mitsubishi Corporation that gives the Japanese company all rights to sell the product in Japan. The snowmaking aid, called Snomax, is a protein that, when dissolved in water, allows snowflakes to form in water that is 8 to 10 degrees Fahrenheit warmer than freezing. It is in use by more than 150 ski resorts around the country and in Canada and was used at the Winter Olympic Games in Calgary, Alberta, earlier this year. Snowmax Technologies, the Kodak subsidiary, has also started marketing it in various European countries as well as in Australia. Financial terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: Airline Deregulation's Middle Age
description: Remember when it was fun to fly? There was just one fare in coach, the center seat was always empty and the plane usually landed on time. What you may not remember on this 10th anniversary of airline deregulation is that fares were 20 percent higher in 1978 and that far fewer cities enjoyed the benefits of frequent air service.

title: Japanese Visitors
description: The Japanese are coming this week with more than 500 works of art representing the great Daimyo culture of feudal lords who ruled Japan under the shoguns. They will go on view at the National Gallery of Art on Sunday. A festival of Japanese art forms will accompany the show, including the daily performance of a traditional tea ceremony.

title: Books of The Times; Reagan's Fiscal Policies Come Home to Roost
description: Day of Reckoning The Consequences of American Economic Policy Under Reagan and After By Benjamin Friedman 323 pages. Random House. $19.95.

title: Affordable Housing in Jersey Is Still an Elusive Goal
description: Thirteen years after New Jersey's Supreme Court outlawed exclusionary housing zones with its Mount Laurel doctrine, problems continue to block broad availability of affordable housing for poor and moderate-income residents.

title: Sunshine Forever Rallies
description: Sunshine Forever, the heavy favorite from the United States, rallied after losing the lead in the deep stretch to win by a neck today in the $750,000 Budweiser International at Laurel.

title: William H. Borden, Executive, 73
description: William H. Borden, the president of Monmouth-Evergreen Records and a longtime chairman of the board of trustees of the Manhattan School of Music, died of cancer Friday night at his home in Rumson, N.J. He was 73 years old.

title: Fire Strikes Theater in Paris Showing Film on Jesus' Life
description: Ten people were injured in a fire at a Parisian theater where ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' was being shown, the police said today. A police spokesman said the cause of the fire was unknown.

title: Jockeys Are Beating the Odds
description: If a betting window at Aqueduct Race Track had been taking action on the length of the jockeys' strike that began last Wednesday, all the smart money would have been snapping up tickets that said no more than two or three days.

title: Amoco Profit Rises by 34%
description: The Amoco Corporation reported Thursday that third-quarter earnings rose 34 percent on a 1.7 percent increase in revenue.

title: Jets Beat Dolphins' Air Attack
description: Under intense, dramatic circumstances, the Jets surged to a 20-point lead over the Dolphins today, then staggered to a 44-30 victory.

title: TV Notes
description: Public Broadcasting Act

title: The Promotion NBC Killed: A Lesson in Back Scratching
description: TO the promotion department at NBC in Burbank, the temptation was irresistible: in real life, the Republicans had nominated for Vice President a handsome young Senator, Dan Quayle, who looked good on television but whose past was in question. As it happened, that came tantalizingly close to one of the story lines in NBC's upcoming miniseries, ''Favorite Son,'' a steamy political soap opera. So NBC quickly devised a promotional pitch for its fictional miniseries that played off the news stories about Senator Quayle. ''From out of today's headlines,'' the narrator in the spot declared, ''comes the most provocative miniseries of the year....''

title: Shearson Expected To Cut Staff
description: As part of a broad cost-reduction effort, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. is planning to cut its work force by about 1,000 people before the end of the year, people close to the securities firm said yesterday.

title: Detroit Bets on a Safer Brake System
description: The 1989 model year is the first in which computer-controlled anti-lock brake systems are available on many cars and light trucks. Experts regard the brakes as a major advance in reducing accidents, and Detroit is ignoring the conventional wisdom that safety does not sell and betting that buyers will pay close to $1,000 for the technology.

title: Tamils Kill 9 Indian Troops
description: At least nine Indian peacekeeping soldiers were killed in two attacks by Tamil guerrillas in Sri Lanka's northern and eastern regions today, Indian officials said. A Indian spokeswoman here said seven soldiers were killed when their vehicle was blown up by a land mine at Omanthai in the north. At Batticaloa in the east, two soldiers and a former Tamil rebel were killed in an ambush, she said.

title: Amid High Hopes, Kohl Leaves Today For Talks in Moscow
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl flies to Moscow on Monday with a grand entourage and high hopes that West Germany can finally find the place it seeks at the forefront of East-West detente.

title: Tokiko Kato's Songs Reach for Intimacy With Her Audience
description: In the sea of sentimental warblers and prepubescent teen-age idols that engulfs Japan's pop culture, Tokiko Kato stands out.

title: Treasury to Offer 2-Year Notes This Week
description: This week's Treasury calendar is highlighted by an offering of $9 billion in two-year notes on Wednesday. As usual, the weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills will be held this afternoon.

title: Savings Unit Failures Seen
description: Up to 50 United States savings and loan institutions will fail between now and year-end, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board chairman, M. Danny Wall, told a business conference Friday.

title: Renamed Shansby Fund To Cut Montgomery Tie
description: Just a year after forming a consumer-oriented investment fund with Montgomery Securities, J. Gary Shansby is severing ties with the San Francisco investment banking company and renaming the fund. In a friendly buyout, an investor bought Montgomery's limited partnership interest in the fund, which will change its name from the Montgomery Consumer Fund to the Shansby Group.

title: The Busiest Day
description: Why does it occur in October?

title: Leonard H. Sandler Is Dead at 62; New York Appellate Court Justice
description: Justice Leonard H. Sandler of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, who administered the oath of office to Mayor Koch for each of his three terms, died last night at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Shelter to Aid Homeless Men Who Have TB
description: In an attempt to stem a surge in tuberculosis cases among New York City's homeless, health officials are planning a separate homeless shelter ward for men receiving treatment for the disease.

title: Proxmire Savors a Victory as He Bids a Farewell
description: ''This is my last speech in the Senate,'' said the austere and contentious William Proxmire on the closing day of the 100th Congress, 31 years after he delivered his first. There were thousands in between.

title: Ayer's Car Role In Spain Grows
description: SEAT, the biggest Spanish car maker, which was bought by Volkswagen two years ago, has chosen Tapsa Ayer, the Madrid arm of N. W. Ayer, to become its European agency of record. The budget is $90 million, which will more than double the shop's billings from last year and make it the largest agency in Spain, up from No. 6, an agency spokeswoman said. The incumbent was TBWA. Tapsa Ayer, which formerly handled only SEAT's Spanish advertising, faces conflicts now that it is expanding its reach throughout the Continent. N. W. Ayer offices in Europe also handle Renault cars in Italy and Toyota in France.

title: BOMBING SUSPECTS SEIZED BY ISRAELIS
description: The Israeli Army said today that it had arrested several residents of southern Lebanon accused of helping to plan a car-bomb attack that killed eight Israeli soldiers on Wednesday.

title: Dangers on the Playground: Better Safeguards Are Urged
description: Few regulations exist to guard preschool children against dangers in the playground, even though many such hazards could be avoided, Federal health officials say.

title: Review/Dance; Graham, Old and New
description: One of the greatest influences upon Martha Graham from the 1920's to the 1940's was Louis Horst, a theorist of dance composition who also composed spare, rhythmically crisp, melodically clear and pungently dissonant scores. Two Graham works with music by Mr. Horst were offered by the Martha Graham Dance Company Friday night at the City Center Theater, 131 West 55th Street.

title: What Congress Has Wrought
description: From economics to the environment to ethics, the Congress that adjourned this weekend passed a host of major legislation. Table, page B7.

title: Taking the Hits, Paying the Price
description: IT figures. In a season in which quarterbacks have fallen like bowling pins, Jim McMahon has remained sturdy. For the first time in his seven-year career, McMahon made his seventh straight start last week.

title: Pro Basketball; Celtics Victorious As Toast of Madrid
description: K. C. Jones was optimistic: ''We'll get to him,'' the Boston Celtics' former coach and current vice president said of Stojan Vrankovic, a 7-foot-2-inch Yugoslav coveted by the Celtics.

title: More B-1 Problems Reported
description: Maintenance problems are hampering the Air Force in readying its new fleet of 99 B-1 bombers for wartime missions, the General Accounting Office asserted in a report today.

title: Colorado Rejects a Request To Store More Nuclear Waste
description: Gov. Roy Romer today denied a Federal request to expand low-level radioactive waste storage at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant.

title: Review/Opera; Older Singers Bring a New Life to 'Cosi' and Others
description: A remarkable group of Italian basses and baritones is spreading disproportionate amounts of good cheer in opera these days. It is the prerogative of these singers, at the age when higher-paid tenors and sopranos must retire, to shift into the basso-buffo repertory and go on more or less indefinitely. At the moment, Rolando Panerai (64 years old), Giuseppe Taddei (72), Italo Tajo (73), Sesto Bruscantini (69) and Renato Capecchi (65 next month) are giving audiences around the world a little reminder of the flavor of Italian opera 30 or 40 years ago.

title: Arab Intrusion in Israeli Politics Dominates an Election Debate
description: Israel's candidates for Prime Minister struck out at each other today in a campaign debate dominated by questions about King Hussein's apparent endorsement of Foreign Minister Shimon Peres and his plans for Middle East peace.

title: Bush Is Sticking With a Safe Game Plan
description: Vice President Bush enters the final stretch of the Presidential campaign seeking to keep his candidacy in a protective bubble that minimizes the possibility of last-minute mistakes and to continue to rely on carefully scripted events and commercials to keep Michael S. Dukakis on the defensive.

title: Julie Fraenkel Is Married to Joshua Jacob Mamis
description: Julie Fraenkel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Levy Fraenkel of Rye, N.Y., and Joshua Jacob Mamis, a son of Mrs. John Edward King of Glen Ridge, N.J., and Justin Mamis of Watchung, N.J., were married yesterday. Rabbi Robert A. Rothman performed the ceremony at the Stouffer Westchester Hotel in White Plains.

title: The Work of the 100th Congress
description: THE ECONOMY Omnibus Trade Act Extends Presidential authority to negotiate trade agreements, increases Presidential authority to retaliate against certain unfair trade practices, provides relief to United States industries hurt by imports if they improve competitiveness, authorizes $1 billion for worker retraining and streamlines rules controlling exports to Soviet bloc. Canada Free Trade Agreement Implements pact that eliminates virtually all trade barriers affecting goods and services exchanged by United States and Canada by Jan. 1, 1999. Deficit Reduction Changes in 1985 balanced budget law make procedures for automatic spending cuts constitutional and sets new deficit reduction levels through 1993. Insider Trading Greatly increases financial penalties and jail terms for insider stock trading and provides for bounty payments to informers. Tax Corrections Corrects drafting errors in 1986 tax law and extends expiring tax breaks for a variety of groups, repeals limits on Treasury issuing of long-term bonds. F.S.L.I.C. Assistance Gives Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation authority to borrow $10.8 billion over three years to shut down or merge insolvent thrifts. Farm Credit Bailout Restructures farm credit system and permits borrowing of $4 billion over two years to rescue failing Federal land banks. SOCIAL POLICY Welfare First major overhaul of welfare laws in half a century would require states to set up education, training and work programs to help move welfare recipients into private jobs. Omnibus Drug Bill Increases education, treatment and drug interception efforts, permits death penalty for drug related killings and imposes new penalties for casual drug users. Civil Rights Restoration Act Overturns 1984 Supreme Court decision that restricted application of Federal anti-discrimination laws to individual programs or activities receiving Federal aid. Enacted over a veto, it prohibits discrimination in entire agency or institution receiving Federal money. Fair Housing Gives Federal Government new authority to crack down on discrimination in sale or rental of housing and extends protection to the handicapped and families with children. Plant Closings Requires employers of 100 or more workers to give 60-days' notice of plant closings or layoffs lasting more than six months. Enacted without the President's signature. McKinney Homeless Assistance Act Authorizes grants for shelter, food, job training, physical and mental health care and counseling for the homeless. Japanese-American Reparations Authorizes $1.25 billion for payments to people of Japanese ancestry who were interred or relocated during World War II. MILITARY AND FOREIGN POLICY INF Treaty The first major arms control agreement approved by Senate in more than 15 years eliminates medium- and shorter-range missiles based on land and includes a provision aimed at prohibiting the President's reinterpretation of treaties without advice and consent of Senate. Arms Control Legislation Provisions in fiscal 1988 and fiscal 1989 military program bills bind the Administration to a restrictive interpretation of 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile treaty and prevent further breaches of unratified 1979 Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty. Contra Aid Provides $27 million for food, clothing, shelter and medical supplies through March 31, 1989. Base Closings Establishes special Pentagon-appointed commission to recommend list of outmoded military bases to be closed over next five years. U.N. Financing Fiscal 1988 foreign aid bill revokes previously imposed Congressional restrictions on payment of dues to the United Nations and authorizes full payment subject to certification of reforms by President. Genocide Treaty Paves way for United States participation in international treaty outlawing genocide. HEALTH Catastrophic Health Insurance xhrrExpands Medicare coverage to provide unlimited free hospital and physician care, as well as eventual coverage of up to 80 percent of costs for prescription drugs, after certain deductibles are reached. Financed by higher premiums and income tax surcharge for beneficiaries. AIDS Financing Authorizes increase in staff for Federal AIDS research efforts and $400 million over two years for grants to provide home health care to AIDS patients and to pay for anonymous blood testing and counseling for high risk groups. THE ENVIRONMENT Clean Water Act Authorizes nearly $18 billion for loans and grants to construct sewage treatment plants; provides greater controls on toxic pollutants and establishes programs to monitor and control pollution in the Great Lakes and other lakes and estuaries. Enacted over President's veto. Pesticides Amends Federal Insecticides, Fungicides and Rodenticides Act of 1972 to speed up testing of old, unregulated pesticides currently on the market. Ocean Dumping Sets deadline of Dec. 31, 1991, for end to ocean dumping of sewage sludge and establishes system of fees and fines for violators aimed at making land-based disposal more economically attractive. MISCELLANEOUS Ethics in Government Tightens restrictions on lobbying by former senior Government officials and extends the limits for the first time to former members of Congress and their top aides. Independent Counsel Five-year extension of existing law that provides for appointment of an independent counsel to investigate alleged criminal violations by certain high- level executive branch officials. Airline Smoking Ban Bans smoking on scheduled commercial airline flights of two hours or less. V.A. Cabinet Department Creates new Cabinet department to handle veterans' affairs. Drought Relief Provides approximately $5.1 billion to assist farmers and ranchers affected by severe summer drought. Polygraph Protection Prohibits use of lie-detector tests by most private employers. Such tests would be permitted by Federal, state or local governments, some private security businesses and by drug companies if done in connection with a criminal drug investigation. Surface Transportation Act $70.3 billion over five years for Federal highway programs and $17.6 billion over four years for mass transit programs. Allows states to increase speed limit on rural sections of interstate highways to 65 miles per hour. Enacted over Presidential veto.

title: 2 Mexican Police Officials Seized In New York on Narcotics Charge
description: Two Mexican police officials were arrested in New York City late Saturday night and charged with conspiring to import large shipments of Mexican heroin into the United States, the authorities said.

title: Lithuanians Move to Limit Moscow Ties
description: The inaugural congress of a grass-roots political movement in the Soviet republic of Lithuania today approved a founding platform dedicated to curtailing, but not totally eliminating, Soviet rule in Lithuania.

title: Exxon's Japan Affiliate Shifting to Thompson
description: Esso Sekiyu K.K., the Exxon Corporation's Japanese affiliate, has moved its advertising to J. Walter Thompson Japan after a four-way competition that included the incumbent, Tokyu. The annual budget is $16 million.

title: School of Visual Arts' Chairman Is Honored
description: Silas Rhodes, founder and chairman of the School of Visual Arts in New York, was applauded heartily by hundreds of art directors - many of them graduates of the school - as he received the Art Directors Club's Special Hall of Fame Award at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Friday night.

title: Jennifer S. Orkin, a Stylist, Wed to Kenneth A. Lewis
description: At the Lotos Club in New York, Jennifer Sara Orkin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Orkin of New York, was married yesterday to Kenneth Adam Lewis, a son of Barbara Lewis of Merion, Pa., and Stanley Lewis of Yardley, Pa. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony.

title: Jersey Woman and Cousin Charged in Killing of Father and an Aunt
description: A college freshman and her cousin were charged yesterday with killing her father and her aunt, who were found bludgeoned to death Saturday in Upper Saddle River, N.J.

title: Los Angeles Ad Agencies Struggle
description: When it opened an office here three years ago, Scali, McCabe, Sloves was not alone among New York-based advertising agencies in regarding this as a most promising city for expansion - a vibrant, trend-setting market that styles itself as the hub of the Pacific Rim.

title: Vote No on Highway Bonds
description: On Election Day, New York State voters will be asked to approve borrowing $3 billion for repairs to highways, roads and bridges. By voting no, they would send a necessary message to the Legislature.

title: What's Wrong With Public School Uniforms?
description: To the Editor:

title: What's Wrong With Public School Uniforms?; Dress Code for Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: An Effort to Smile Through the Gloom
description: There are some moments when a day on the campaign trail is like a day at summer camp, with the candidate's entourage behaving like carefree children. There are other days when the campaign turns glamorous and tense with drama. But then, there are days like the recent one in McKeesport, a steel mill town that has come on hard times.

title: Halftime Score: League Is Ahead
description: A year after the strike, the National Football League at midseason boasts booming attendance, strong competition and unlikely leaders in each conference while continuing a fight against drug abuse.

title: French Wine Promoted In Cable TV Campaign
description: The French Food and Wine Society, a trade group also known as Sopexa, is starting an American advertising campaign on cable television today promoting its ''affordable'' line of wines. A total of 33 wines from 11 importers affiliated with its division called food and wine from France will be featured.

title: Bicyclists Leave Diets Behind
description: HOWARD SCHERZER mounted the steps of the Maine Monument at the southwest corner of Central Park and called the group of bicyclists to order. ''This is our most gluttonous tour,'' he warned, ''so be ready.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''After 50 years of repression, our nation is seeking to regain its liberty.'' - Jurgis Oksas, to the Lithuanian Reform Movement's congress. [ A1:4. ]

title: Brunswick Up Slightly
description: The Brunswick Corporation Friday reported marginally higher profits for the third quarter, saying that a lower tax rate had increased net income. Earnings rose to $43.2 million, from $42.8 million in the 1987 quarter. The company said revenues rose to $767.9 million in the third quarter from $766.5 million in the comparable 1987 period. But Brunswick, which makes bowling equipment, fishing tackle and camouflage as well as power boats, said it had a 19 percent decline in operating earnings.

title: Director at Sackler and Freer Named
description: Dr. Milo C. Beach, an expert on Indian painting, has been named director of the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery and the Freer Gallery of Art, two museums of the Smithsonian Institution devoted to Asian arts.

title: Retirement-Plan Accumulations
description: INDIVIDUALS who have accumulated sizable sums in retirement plans face an important decision, and, tax professionals warn, the paperwork needed to make the decision is so complex that they ought to start getting the necessary records together right now.

title: A Blustery Day for Head of the Charles
description: The 24th annual Head of the Charles Regatta became the battle of the Boston wind today as more than 3,500 rowers battled a howling wind over the first two and a half miles of this three-mile course.

title: For Bush and Dukakis, Three Capital Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * West Germany's growth rate next year could reach 2 percent to 2.5 percent, up from earlier official forecasts of 1.5 percent to 2 percent, the Economics Ministry said today. In a statement, the ministry said it was still reviewing the economy and that an official projection would be made in the Government's annual economic report in January. The statement repeated earlier forecasts by West German ministers predicting 1988 growth of about 3.5 percent in real terms, after 1.7 percent growth in 1987.

title: Steven George Eftimiades Is Married to Miss Marudis
description: At the Orthodox Church of Our Lady of Kazan in Sea Cliff, L.I., Eleni Marudis was married yesterday to Steven George Eftimiades by the Rev. Emmanuel Gratsias, assisted by the Rev. Leonid Kishkovsky.

title: Question Box
