title: Hispanic Influx Spurs 3 Ballots on Language
description: With 300,000 Hispanic immigrants a year pouring into the South and the West, Spanish has supplanted English in some areas, and many Americans who say they feel like aliens in their own country are stepping up a battle to reaffirm English as the language of public life.

title: Auction Rates Up At Citicorp
description: Interest rates rose modestly at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. It was the second straight week that rates have increased.

title: Washington Federal Savings Bank (Hillsboro, Ore) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a one-time writeoff of $143,500.

title: Ecolab Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $97,000,000 for the quarter and $100,063,000 for the 9 months. Year-ago quarter and 9-month include a one-time restructuring charge equal to 89 cents a share. The company's figures include the results of Chemlawn, acquired in April 1987.

title: Pumpkin Doughnut: An Autumn Glory
description: AROUND 2600 B.C., the Egyptians figured out how to make leavened bread. Making a great leap forward, the Dutch in the 16th century developed the ''olykoek,'' or oily cake, a doughnut without a hole. Moving closer to home, a Maine sea captain named Hanson Gregory, in 1847, punched a hole in his mother's dough to create the modern doughnut.

title: Grove Bank for Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Freeport-McMoran Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Xerox Profit Rises by 9%
description: The Xerox Corporation's earnings rose 9 percent, to $146 million, in the third quarter, with a strong showing from its financial services division, the company said today.

title: Friedman Again Guilty In Graft Case
description: Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader who was convicted of Federal racketeering charges in 1986, was found guilty yesterday of state charges that he bribed a former New York National Guard general in an effort to sell a hand-held computer to the state militia.

title: Buyouts Devastating Bondholders
description: While many stockholders are rejoicing at the flurry of huge corporate takeover attempts, bondholders are wincing at the damage inflicted on their holdings.

title: Call to Arms To Oppose Ad Curbs
description: A SERIES of speakers yesterday lambasted public officials who would tax, restrict or ban advertising and urged members of the Association of National Advertisers to be unyielding in the fight for unfettered ads.

title: Periodic Inspections Check for Permits
description: New York City requires that building permits be clearly displayed at every construction site. Teams of building inspectors conduct periodic, block-by-block surveys in an attempt to insure compliance, but can only make scores of such surveys each year, officials say.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Popeye's Founder Aims To Lessen Competition
description: LEAD: Alvin C. Copeland, the Louisiana entrepreneur who is seeking to acquire a rival fast-food chain, Church's Fried Chicken Inc., in a $295.7 million tender offer, has made a fortune purveying his own brand of spicy chicken.

title: Borden Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
First Recipient Of Award Named
description: The Association of National Advertisers yesterday named Robert Haynes, the recently retired director of creative services for the General Foods Corporation, the first recipient of its Robert V. Goldstein Award for distinguished service as an Advertising Council campaign director.

title: Inquiry on Fraternity 'Slave Auction'
description: A student disciplinary committee at the University of Wisconsin began an investigation today into a fraternity's sponsorship of a mock slave auction held last week as part of a fund-raising event.

title: San Francisco Journal; A Collision Of Grime, Glamour
description: At a new Nordstrom department store here, customers can order tea from the dressing room or relax with an herbal body treatment after shopping. They can buy custom-blended face powder, dine in a restaurant that serves Louis XIII cognac for $500 a bottle or be entertained by a musician playing the largest piano Steinway makes.

title: Review/Television; 3 New Series Are Having Premieres
description: Don't despair. There will indeed be a new television season, giving all television watchers their annual opportunity to moan about how everything is even more dreadful than expected. Postponed by the writers' strike, the new series are slowly surfacing. This evening, three are on tap: ''The Van Dyke Show'' at 8 o'clock and Mary Tyler Moore's ''Annie McGuire'' at 8:30, both on CBS, and ''Tattingers'' at 10 o'clock on NBC. ''Annie McGuire'' was not available for review. Make of that what you will.

title: Kraft Sets Terms for Philip Morris
description: In a letter from one chairman to another, Kraft Inc. yesterday told the Philip Morris Companies that it was prepared to negotiate if the tobacco and foods giant, which bid $90 a share for Kraft last week, would be willing to pay more than $110 a share.

title: For Moscow and Bonn, A Range of Agreements
description: The Soviet Union and West Germany reached agreements or partial agreements on a diverse range of political, economic and scientific issues today, as the second day of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's visit continued with a tone of cautious optimism.

title: Campaign Trail; A Case of No News Being Good News
description: Marilyn Quayle phoned her husband, Senator Dan Quayle, the other day. ''You must be making great speeches, drawing tremendous crowds, really getting them on their feet and saying all the right things because I haven't heard one thing about you this week,'' she said.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Letters by Anne Frank Auctioned for $165,000
description: Pen-pal letters sent by Anne Frank and her sister to two girls in Iowa in April 1940 were purchased for an unidentified buyer for $165,000 last night, and are to be given to the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles.

title: BRIEFS
description: * C-Tec Corp., Wilkes-Barre, Pa., said it had received a $43-a-share bid from AWSC Acquisition Corp., a group formed by members of the company's management, and one partner.

title: Economic Scene; Deficit Bang or Deficit Whimper?
description: ''READ my lips,'' repeats George Bush: ''No new taxes.'' But professional campaign watchers prefer to read his eyes, and many discern hints of the Big Wink.

title: NEW POLL SHOWS ATTACKS BY BUSH ARE BUILDING LEAD
description: Voters are giving Vice President Bush a widening lead over Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, but they say they dislike the choice they have been offered and regard the Presidential campaign as negative, uninteresting and insubstantial.

title: Prosecution Says Steinberg Beat Lisa and Left Her to Die
description: The prosecution in Joel B. Steinberg's murder trial charged yesterday in its opening statement that he ''brutally beat 6-year-old Lisa Steinberg'' and that with ''depraved indifference'' left her to die in his apartment while he went to dinner with a friend.

title: Fruehauf Layoffs At Trailer Unit
description: The Fruehauf Corporation is restructuring its slumping trailer operations, a move that will result in an unspecified number of layoffs and early retirements at its headquarters here, the company said. The truck-trailer and auto-parts maker began layoffs last week in its engineering department, said David Hladik, a spokesman. About 40 percent of the department's 78 engineers were laid off, and others will be transferred, he said.

title: Coins of the Realm
description: On Monday the very day the Treasury Department accused Taiwan and South Korea of manipulating their national currencies to stimulate sales of their goods in the United States by linking them to the dollar, the mail brought a kind of pre-emptive strike of Asian gentility to a number of Washington offices: an expensively bound hardcover book.

title: Man Is on Trial in Wife's Slaying One Year to Day After Wedding
description: Today would have been the first wedding anniversary for Lisa and Matthew Solomon. Instead, Mr. Solomon, a 23-year-old sheet metal worker, entered a courtroom here to stand trial in the murder of his 22-year-old wife last December.

title: Packers Waive Kicker
description: The Green Bay Packers waived their erratic place-kicker, Max Zendejas, and brought in four other kickers for tryouts yesterday. Zendejas made only 9 of 16 field-goal attempts this season and missed a 24-yarder Sunday with 11 seconds left in a 20-17 loss to Washington.(AP)

title: Shell Canada Ltd reports earnings for
description: Figures are in Canadian funds. Listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. The company said share earnings were higher in the latest quarter because of reduced preferred dividend requirements.

title: Enserch Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $2,702,000 and $1,350,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a provision for the loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $224,911,000 for both the quarter and 9 months, and the 9-month also includes gains of $50,000,000 from accounting changes. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $8,354,000 for the quarter and $17,408,000 for the 9 months, and the 9-month also includes a loss of $3,786,000 on reacquisition of debentures.

title: Valley National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included pre-tax gains on the sale of securities of $57,776 for the quarter and $920,732 for the 9 months. c-Included pre-tax gains of $312,635 for the quarter and $762,999 for the 9 months on the sale of securities.

title: New Process Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Solidarity Rejects New Move by Warsaw
description: The Government called today for further preliminary talks to remove what it said were obstacles to full-scale discussions with Solidarity, the outlawed labor federation. The union rejected the call, leaving the prospect of any talks uncertain.

title: FICO Offering Bonds at 9.65%
description: The Financing Corporation, also known as FICO, a mixed-ownership Government corporation chartered by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, is offering $700 million of 9.65 percent bonds due in 2018 at a price of par through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Washington Post Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring after-tax gain of $115.7 million, or $8.99 a share, primarily from the sale of the company's Florida cellular telephone interests. c-Includes non-recurring after-tax gains of $30.2 million, or $2.35 a share, and $115.7 million, or $8.99 a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, primarily from the sale of the company's cellular telephone interests.

title: Repurchase Of Stock Set By Tenneco
description: Two weeks after announcing that it expected to receive more than $7.3 billion by selling its oil company, Tenneco Inc. said today that it would spend $900 million to $990 million to repurchase 18 million of its common shares.

title: Campaign Trail; Bentsen's Long Trip To Find His Roots
description: How far will Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas go to dispel the image that he's a chilly patrician? How far will the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate go for a chance to have his photograph taken?

title: Fort Howard Financing Priced by Morgan Stanley
description: Morgan Stanley & Company yesterday priced the Fort Howard Corporation's $1.7 billion debt issue, one of the largest high-yield deals to come to market this year.

title: Panel Criticizes Elections Board On Ethics Case
description: The New York State Board of Elections, in a 15-month investigation of allegations of political corruption in Poughkeepsie, failed to uncover almost $600,000 in secret campaign contributions and expenditures and did not interview important figures in the case, investigators told the State Government Integrity Commission yesterday.

title: Taiwan and South Korea Stress Trade Cooperation Efforts
description: Taiwan and South Korea, responding to Administration accusations of currency manipulation, said today that they had been given insufficient credit for their efforts to cooperate.

title: First Amarillo Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After gains of $38,085 for the quarter and $1,194,570 for the 9 months from the extinguishment of debt.

title: Book Notes
description: McInerney Rights

title: Chrysler Introduces New Line of Sedans
description: The Chrysler Corporation introduced the Dodge Spirit and Plymouth Acclaim and priced them at less than $10,000, but analysts said the sedans faced stiff competition. The two models technically replace Chrysler's K-cars, the Plymouth Reliant and Dodge Aries, which will be phased out next year. But the new models are larger, plusher and more advanced than their predecessors.

title: Interpublic Group of Companies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from exchange and translation of foreign currencies of $1,735,000 for the quarter and $4,712,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses of $571,000 for the quarter and $1,694,000 for the 9 months from exchange and translation of foreign currencies. Revenue represents total gross income.

title: Comfed Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after a $3,232,000 tax benefit. The results for the latest quarter reflected a decline in loan origination fees of about $6.7 million due to a change in accounting methods. Comfed said that if the accounting change had not occurred, net income for the latest quarter and 6 months would have been about $1.3 million and $2.9 million, respectively.

title: Review/Pop; McGovern's 3 Voices in One
description: Maureen McGovern is a singer of such formidable technique that she seems to harbor three different voices in the same body. One is a big belting alto whose nasality strongly echoes Barbra Streisand. Dipping into a contralto mode, the voice darkens, somewhat like Cleo Laine's. Her most difficult feats are accomplished in a piccolo-like coloratura high soprano over which she exerts an iron discipline that enables her to sing intricate, perfectly pitched duets with other instruments for minutes on end without making a slip.

title: Amerada Hess Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Suit Against the Klan Brings Verdict of Nearly $1 Million
description: In a verdict unsealed today, a Federal jury found two white supremacist groups and 11 people responsible for the violent disruption of a 1987 civil rights march in Forsyth County, Ga., and awarded nearly $1 million in damages to demonstrators who filed the suit.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is often easier to make strong speeches about foreign drug lords or drug smugglers than to arrest a pair of Wall Street investment bankers buying cocaine on their lunch break.'' - Nancy Reagan. [ A1:5. ]

title: Greyhound Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $768,000 representing Greyhound's equity in GLI Holding Co.'s extraordinary loss on the early extinguishment of debt, and a gain of $10,750,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Includes net of $10,215,000 from discontinued insurance and U.S. bus operations, including a $33,099,000 net gain on the sale of U.S. bus operations and an extraordinary charge of $6,211,000 representing Greyhound's equity in GLI Holding Co.'s extraordinary loss on the early extinguishment of debt. The company said the year-earlier third quarter net consists of income from continuing operations of $24,195,000, or 60 cents a share, a net loss of $8,674,000 from discontinued insurance and U.S. bus operations and a loss of $475,000 from early extinguishment of debt. The latest 9-month net from operations includes gains on sale of real estate formerly used in U.S. bus operations of $1,529,000, or 4 cents a share. Year-ago 9-month net from continuing operations includes gains on the sale of real estate formerly used in U.S. bus operations of $2,109,000, or 5 cents a share. Year-ago results are restated to show insurance operations, primarily Verex Corp. and Greyhound Lines Inc. U.S. bus operations as discontinued operations.

title: Sumner W. White 3d, Stockbroker, 58
description: Sumner W. White 3d, a retired Manhattan stockbroker, died of lung cancer Monday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 58 years old and lived in Summit.

title: Alfred J. Marston, Economist, 64
description: Alfred J. Marston, president of the Manhattan Downtown Community Council and a former chairman of Community Board 3 on the Lower East Side, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 64 years old.

title: Gold Fields Takeover Is Blocked
description: The British Government today blocked a $4.9 billion takeover bid by the overseas investment arm of South Africa's Anglo-American Corporation and DeBeers gold and diamond group for Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C., the mining company based in London.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 3 P.M.

title: Teaching the Basic Skills Is Still Principals' Top Goal
description: Teaching the basics of reading, writing and arithmetic remains the most important goal for high school educators who responded to a survey.

title: LaRussa Wins Poll
description: Tony LaRussa, a lawyer who piloted the Oakland Athletics to a club-record 104 victories and the pennant, was named American League Manager of the Year yesterday by the Baseball Writers Association of America. It was the second time LaRussa won the award. He was also honored in 1983, when he led the Chicago White Sox to the West title. The 44-year-old LaRussa edged Joe Morgan of the Boston Red Sox by 14 points in balloting by a committee made up of two writers from each American League city. LaRussa received 103 points, compared with 89 for Morgan and 37 for Sparky Anderson of the Detroit Tigers. LaRussa got 15 first-place votes, 6 more than Morgan, who took over the struggling Red Sox at midseason and led the club to the East title. Each first-place vote was worth 5 points. Second-place votes were worth 3 points each, while a third-place vote counted as 1 point. The A's improved by 23 victories in 1988 and won the division by 13 games over the defending World Series champion Minnesota Twins. LaRussa graduated from the Florida State University School of Law in 1978 and passed the bar examination in December 1979.(AP)

title: Optimism at Aqueduct
description: Gerard S. McKeon, president of the New York Racing Association, said last night that he was ''somewhere between hopeful and optimistic'' that Aqueduct's striking jockeys would be riding again by Saturday. ''I don't really see any insurmountable problems,'' McKeon said after meeting with leaders of the jockeys and the horse owners.

title: Stock Buyback Set by Digital
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation announced plans today to buy back shares with a current market value of more than $900 million. Its stock rose amid sketchy takeover rumors.

title: USX Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $71 million. c-Includes a favorable $47 million adjustment to the 1986 asset restructuring charge. Latest third-quarter results include a $61 million pretax gain from asset sales, partially offset by the effect of an unfavorable LIFO liquidation and costs associated with a fire at a Gary, Ind., steel facility, totalling $30 million. Year-ago third-quarter results include a $22 million pretax gain from asset sales.

title: Banks Ask Fed for Power To Underwrite Securities
description: Although Congress failed to pass legislation giving banks new powers to underwrite securities, at least three New York City banks and a large West Coast bank have asked the Federal Reserve Board to grant them the authority.

title: Flagler Bank Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jones Intercable Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income The year-ago first quarter revenue included $1,739,000 received as a fee and distribution upon the sale of all the cable television properties owned by a managed limited partnership.

title: Stratus Computer Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Regional Federal Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bush Holds Lead in Gallup Poll
description: Vice President Bush continues to hold a strong lead over Gov. Michael S. Dukakis in the latest survey of public opinion by The Gallup Organization, which released its findings yesterday.

title: 3 May Have Been Sent to Kill Koch, Officials Say
description: Three Colombians were arrested in Manhattan last week, and Mayor Koch and New York law-enforcement officials said they may have been hired by Colombian drug traffickers to kill the Mayor or the top Federal drug agent in New York.

title: Real Estate; Seaport Link For a Tower In Manhattan
description: EARLY in this decade, strong demand for expansion space from financial service companies riding a wave of prosperity sent developers of commercial buildings stampeding toward Wall Street.

title: Rail Foreman Falls And Is Killed by Train
description: A Metro-North Commuter Railroad foreman was killed yesterday in a tunnel near Grand Central Terminal when he fell off a platform and under a slow-moving train, a spokesman for Metro-North said yesterday.

title: C.I.A. Chief Says Libya Develops A Huge Chemical Weapons Plant
description: William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, said tonight that Libya is developing ''the largest chemical plant I know of for chemical warfare.''

title: Eating Well
description: SQUASH has been around for a long time, but except for zucchini, which has made it big, it is seldom at the top of anyone's list as a favorite vegetable. This prejudice appears to go back to the Pilgrims. Although the Indians told the Pilgrims about squash, not many recipes for its use survive, with the exception of pumpkin pie.

title: BMR Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PNC Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Irving Elias, Executive, 88
description: Irving Elias, a businessman and philanthropist, died of pneumonia Saturday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: East-West Accord In Chilly Waters
description: IGNORING numbed fingers and cold feet as they assiduously cast through much of a nasty day of mixed snow and rain, two six-person fly-fishing teams, one from the United States and one from the Soviet Union, were able to coax 22 trout from the Beaverkill and Willowemoc rivers yesterday.

title: RJR Nabisco Bidders Said to Talk
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton and Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the two Wall Street titans competing over a record buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc., held talks yesterday morning to discuss the possibility of a combined bid, according to Wall Street professionals with knowledge of the discussions.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Oct. 19 about the New York City landmark designation of the former Knickerbocker Hotel at Broadway and 42d Street gave an incorrect location in some editions for the nearby Bush Tower, which also received landmark status.

title: Quick Appearance
description: Ben Johnson, the sprinter, made a quick appearance yesterday in Provincial Court in Toronto, the city where he will return next April 24 to plead on charges of common assault and possession of a weapon dangerous to the public peace. Johnson was charged earlier this month after an unidentified motorist said a man in a black Porsche pointed a gun at him on the Trans-Canada Highway near Toronto. The police later said they seized a starter's pistol from Johnson's Porsche at his home.(AP)

title: National Mercantile Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share earnings were adjusted to reflect 10 percent stock dividends declared in February 1987 and June 1988. The provision for loan losses in the latest periods were $250,000 for the quarter and $802,000 for the 9 months. The provision for loan losses for the year-ago periods were $925,000 for the quarter and $1,306,000 for the 9 months.

title: Gradac Journal; Englishwoman Seeks and Finds Serenity in Serbia
description: ''This reminds me of my riding country,'' said the tall, stern Englishwoman, looking from a hillside over the verdant mountains and dales of this remote corner of southern Serbia, miles from the nearest paved road. ''I grew up among horses.''

title: Tambrands Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago third quarter and 9-month results are restated to reflect a change in accounting for certain promotional allowances.

title: Comings and Goings
description: After playing with one arm almost useless in recent games, the linebacker Brian Bosworth will be out two or three weeks following arthroscopic surgery on his left shoulder, Seattle Seahawks officials said. The operation was described as a success by a Seahawks spokesman, Gary Wright, who said the surgery on the second-year linebacker ''revealed some wear and tear on the shoulder, and a small piece of loose cartilage was removed.'' . . . Karl Mecklenburg, the Denver Broncos' inside linebacker, will be out six weeks after undergoing surgery on his right thumb to repair a pin. . . . Alabama's star running back, Bobby Humphrey, probably won't return to the playing field this season, team officials said after viewing X-rays which showed very minimal healing in his broken left foot.(AP)

title: Freeport-McMoran Reources Partners LP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding represent units.

title: Surgery for 3 Dodgers
description: Three members of the Los Angeles Dodgers - John Tudor, the left-handed pitcher, and Mike Scioscia and Rick Dempsey, catchers - are scheduled to undergo surgery tomorrow by Dr. Frank Jobe. Tudor, who left Game 2 of the World Series with a sore elbow, will undergo ligament reconstruction surgery on his pitching arm. He will also have arthroscopic surgery on his left shoulder and have bone screws from a 1987 operation on his left knee removed. Scioscia, who suffered a right knee injury in Game 4 of the Series, will undergo an arthroscopic procedure to remove torn cartilage. Dempsey is scheduled for an arthroscopic examination and removal of torn tissue in his left shoulder.(AP)

title: Defend Us From Any Sicilian Expeditions
description: To the Editor:

title: A Plane Crash in Peru Kills 12 in the Andes
description: A state-owned airliner carrying 65 passengers and a crew of 4 crashed today high in the Andes, killing 12 people, including one American, and injuring 56, airline officials said. One person was missing.

title: Xerox Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Activity in Bonds Remains Light
description: The corporate bond market, rattled by the implications of the huge takeover bids for Kraft Inc. and RJR Nabisco, struggled through another difficult session yesterday as few issues changed hands. But market participants said that buyers for selected investment-grade industrial issues were beginning to emerge in contrast to recent days.

title: BRIEFS
description: Common Stock

title: Lawrence Brown Service
description: A memorial service with music for Lawrence Brown, a trombonist, will be held Friday at 5 P.M. at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, 619 Lexington Avenue, at 54th Street. Mr. Brown, who played with the Duke Ellington Orchestra, died last month at the age of 81. Those performing at the tribute, which is open to the public, will be Vince Giordano and the Nighthawks; the Bobby Short Trio; Geanie Faulkner, a soprano; Bobby Pring and Al Grey, trombonists, and Loren Schoenberg, a conductor.

title: Critic's Notebook; Dancing in the Dark, or, Learning to Love Ambiguity
description: They could have been lost in the desert, or on some tundra, or out on the steppes. Or were they symbolically journeying through the dark night of the soul? It was impossible to say where the dancers in David Dorfman's ''Silent Station'' were supposed to be. It was also impossible to say precisely who they were supposed to represent.

title: Carter-Wallace Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
People
description: * Harvey W. Greisman has been appointed vice president, corporate public affairs at GTE, Stamford, Conn., a telecommunications, lighting and precision materials company.

title: Veterans' Agency Rises To Departmental Rank
description: At ceremonies today marking the fifth anniversary of the American invasion of Grenada, President Reagan signed legislation creating the Department of Veterans Affairs and took the opportunity to stress the differences between the Presidential candidates on defense policy.

title: Jets Fill Spot on Roster
description: The Jets yesterday claimed on waivers Mark Garalczyk, a second-year defensive tackle with the Phoenix Cardinals. He will take the place on the Jet roster that was occupied by Mark Gastineau, the defensive end who announced his retirement last week.

title: Falconbridge Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes special gains of $2 million and $43 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: A Matter of State
description: Unofficial personal travel by Secretary of State George P. Shultz cost the Federal Government $1,892,214 in the last three years, according to a new audit by the General Accounting Office.

title: Michael Ffolkes, 63, Cartoonist for Punch
description: Michael Ffolkes, a cartoonist whose work appeared for decades in Punch and major American publications, died Oct. 18 in a London hospital. He had acute pancreatitis and cirrhosis of the liver.

title: First Security (Utah) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cynthia Freeman Is Dead at 73; Writer of Best-Selling Romances
description: Beatrice Cynthia Freeman Feinberg, who became a best-selling author of romance novels under the name Cynthia Freeman after beginning her writing career at the age of 50, died of cancer last Saturday at the University of California Medical Center in San Francisco. She was 73 years old.

title: Cuomo Says He Gave Dukakis Bad Advice Cuomo Admits Giving Bad Advice to Dukakis
description: Governor Cuomo of New York acknowledged today that he gave Michael S. Dukakis bad advice on ignoring attacks by Vice President Bush and said he now believes the Massachusetts Governor should capitalize on the underdog's role.

title: Shell Oil Company reports earnings for
description: Shell Oil is a unit of Royal Dutch- Shell Group.

title: Boxing Notebook; Lalonde-Leonard: It's Same Old Hype
description: When the Nov. 7 match between Donny Lalonde, the World Boxing Council light heavyweight champion, and Sugar Ray Leonard was announced to the public in August, the two fighters acted more like corporate executives than combatants in a 12-round bout.

title: Mt. Holyoke Dedicates Vance Professorship
description: Mount Holyoke College dedicated its new Cyrus R. Vance Professorship in International Relations last night in an effort to draw more women into that field. The women's college in South Hadley, Mass., plans to name prominent practitioners to the position and share their experience with associated colleges in the region.

title: Topics of The Times; At Last, a Warning on Alcohol
description: Prodded by health and consumer groups, Congress finally acted last week to inform consumers better about the most abused drug: alcohol. A provision tucked in the new omnibus drug bill requires that all liquor, beer, wine and wine coolers carry labels warning of the risks of drinking during pregnancy and of drinking and driving.

title: Booby Clark, Football Player, 37
description: Booby Clark, a fullback who led the Cincinnati Bengals in rushing yardage in the 1975 and 1976 seasons during an eight-year National Football League career, died from an apparent blood clot in his lung today. He was 37 years old.

title: Stotler Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Household Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $8,300,000 for the quarter and $209,400,000 for the 9 months. Year-ago quarter includes unusual after-tax gains of $50,600,000 primarily from the installment sale of Arizona Properties for the quarter, and the 9-month includes a net gain of $64,200,000 primarily from asset sales.

title: History Is Hazy on Cocktails' Origins
description: YEARS ago, maybe 20 or 30, two of my aunts decided that they would like to see how many drinks they would need to become giddy. Not having been brought up in the imbibing tradition - wine was used for sacramental purposes only, and shots of brandy were just for men - they came late to cocktails.

title: 500 IN PHILIPPINES LOST AS SHIP SINKS
description: An inter-island ferry carrying more than 500 people sank Monday in a typhoon, and officials said this morning that they feared that most had drowned.

title: S.E.C. Subpoenas Third Wall St. Brokerage in Ellis Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has subpoenaed Brown Brothers Harriman & Company for information relating to one of the largest and longest insider trading cases in history, people familiar with the case said yesterday.

title: Salomon Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Honda Accepts European Demand
description: The chairman of the Honda Motor Company said that Honda's new British-built Concerto would have at least 80 percent local content, thus conforming with European car makers' demands. ''Screwdriver factories are not good; we want to install real industrial units,'' Satoshi Okuba said at a seminar here. The powerful European car makers' committee has demanded that Japanese cars built in Europe have at least 80 percent of their components built in Europe.

title: Phillips Petroleum Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Profits Fall at Washington Post
description: The Washington Post Company said yesterday that its third-quarter net income dropped 37.8 percent, to $38.1 million, or $2.96 a share, compared with $61.3 million, or $4.77 a share, a year earlier.

title: From Vine to Dinner

title: Reviews/Dance; Ways of the Yugoslavs
description: Balkan folk-dancing as a recreational activity on the American college circuit is as popular as square dances once were. Even experimental choreographers like Mark Morris now list Balkan folk-dancing on their resumes.

title: Chevron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter included a $48 million benefit from the enactment of lower income tax rates in Canada and Australia. Offsetting this benefit were charges of $48 million relating to provisions for environmental programs, reorganization costs and write-off of a chemical plant. Earnings for the latest 9-month included net gains of $360 million on asset dispositions and $114 million for various tax adjustments. These gains were partially offset by charges of $115 million relating to environmental programs and $16 million for reorganization costs. The year-ago third quarter and 9 months included net gains of $51 million and $293 million, respectively, from asset sales and other items.

title: Edward Uhlan, 76, Founder and Leader Of Vanity Publisher
description: Edward Uhlan, the founder and longtime president of Exposition Press, died of prostate cancer on Sunday at his home in Coconut Creek, Fla. He was 76 years old.

title: Jersey's Top Court Limits the Death Penalty to Intentional Murders
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that the death penalty could be imposed only on those who intentionally commit murder.

title: U.S. Egg Output Slips
description: An estimated 5.55 billion eggs were produced commercially in the United States last month, down 2 percent from September 1987, the Agriculture Department said on Monday. The number of laying hens was down 3 percent in September, compared with last year, the department said in its monthly report. Thus, 100 hens averaged 2,037 eggs, up from 2,024 in September 1987, the report said.

description: Three days after he threatened to call a special session to force New York State lawmakers to consider the Shoreham settlement by the Nov. 18 deadline, Governor Cuomo said today that it was possible the deadline could be extended.

title: Reviews/Dance; Salute to Hispanic Arts
description: Dance Theater Workshop's ambitious ''Tour de Fuerza'' festival, a 10-day salute to the new Latin American movement in dance, performance and music, has gotten off to a provocative start. Seen on Saturday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, the opening program of dance by Viveca Vazquez and the team of Merian Soto and Pepon Osorio explored the life of the transplanted Puerto Rican with poignancy and humor.

title: Reviews/Dance; Japanese Folk Dances
description: The Odori Festival of Japan - the program that the Japan Folkloric Art Dance Troupe offered Sunday afternoon at Lehman Center for the Performing Arts in the Bronx - included folk dances from many regions of Japan. Appropriately, therefore, the presentation, directed by Hideo Kimura, resembled a communal enterprise. Musicians sat on stage beside the dancers, as if to suggest that music and dance were equals, and the dancers often made music as they moved.

title: Reactor Storage Plan Opposed
description: A panel of citizens and scientists objected today to a plan for mothballing a reactor disabled in the accident at Three Mile Island in Pennsylvania nearly 10 years ago. The panel members said they were afraid that if the reactor was sealed up, as planned, it would never be decontaminated.

title: Salvador Rebels, on Latin Tour, Meet With Costa Rica's President
description: In a diplomatic offensive that underscores the divisions facing the Salvadoran left, the senior commanders of the Salvadoran guerrilla army met here Monday with President Oscar Arias Sanchez.

title: Vallone Proposes Sweeping Package of Drug Laws
description: The New York City Council majority leader, in an effort to disrupt and deter drug trafficking, introduced a legislative package yesterday intended to attack the assets of those who either sell or use illicit substances.

title: Checking Out A Bee's Day
description: Entomologists studying the behavior of honey bees have adapted bar code scanning technology from the supermarket checkout counter to keep track of bees as they come and go from the hive. They want to know how often and at what time bees leave on pollen-gathering trips, and when they return. Since a honey bee lives for only four weeks, the entomologists have long sought a means of monitoring a bee's lifetime of comings and goings.

title: Ungaro and Valentino: Firm Footing

title: As Values in U.S. Shift, So Does Spending
description: BY focusing on month-to-month changes in consumer spending habits, it is easy to get a distorted view of how people are spending their money. While much attention has been paid to the sluggishness in apparel sales, for instance, Americans seem to be spending about the same percentage of their incomes on clothing.

title: DEVILS ALSO LOSE; Maple Leafs 4, Islanders 3
description: With three minutes left in the game and the Islanders a goal behind, Brent Sutter found himself just in front of the Toronto goaltender, Ken Wregget, in position to tip in a tying goal. Alan Kerr blasted a shot that obediently skidded right onto Sutter's stick for the deflection, but instead of passing Wregget, the puck jumped right into his arms, and he smothered it harmlessly to his stomach.

description: Nancy Reagan told the United Nations today that the United States must do more to solve its drug problem itself through stricter law enforcement and education. She said the United States should stop blaming developing countries that produce most of the illegal drugs consumed by Americans.

title: Over-the-Counter Short Sales Rose 8.4% in Month
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported an 8.4 percent monthly increase in the short interest for the most active over-the-counter securities in its national market system.

title: Boston Paper Endorses Bush
description: The Boston Herald endorsed Vice President Bush for President in Wednesday's editions, saying it had erred in backing Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, the Democratic nominee, beginning with the New Hampshire primary. The Herald cited the leadership of Mr. Bush, the Republican nominee.

title: Sun Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $62,000,000 from windfall profit tax adjustments. c-Net income Results for the latest 9 months include a $297,000,000 after-tax charge for the writedown of assets in a restructuring.

title: EATING OUT With Stephen King; Writer Eats Steak Before It Eats Him
description: HALLOWEEN is a busy time for the novelist Stephen King, what with all those vampires, witches, zombies, cuddly pets-turned-bloodthirsty killers, possessed teen-agers and other socially maladjusted types rattling around his house in Maine. Nonetheless, he managed to squeeze in a business trip to New York last week and took time out one evening to share a monstrous steak with me at the Peter Luger restaurant in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

title: A Toast to Spirits Blithe and Drinkable
description: GLASSES - mostly long-stemmed and frequently fluted - were raised high in the Rainbow Pavillion on the 65th floor of the RCA Building the other evening, all to toast ''Blithe Spirits,'' a lavishly illustrated $50 cocktail-table book. It celebrates what Jill Spalding, the author, calls the revival of ''Hollywood-type cocktails and dressy cocktail parties.''

title: Reining In Unfettered Development
description: To jaded metropolitan eyes, the city of Santa Rosa, Calif., an hour's drive up Highway 101 from San Francisco, looks like a friendly, easygoing town out of the 50's. At high noon, businessmen in shirt sleeves, their coats over their backs, stroll through the low-slung downtown. In accord with local style, even the Kentucky Fried Chicken store is tastefully low-key and bereft of the customary red and white striped bucket rotating overhead. The hills in the distance add a bucolic grace note. But do not be fooled. This small, countrified city of 120,000, founded in 1868 in the heart of Sonoma County, just might become the next uninterrupted urban sprawl in Northern California. Impressions gathered on a drive around the area confirm that Santa Rosa is a city bleeding out of its pastoral perimeters in all directions.

title: Books of The Times; Dialectics of Vacuuming, Love and Other Trivia
description: Two Against One By Frederick Barthelme 264 pages. Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $17.95.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: IT is fascinating to me how flavors, like fashions in clothes and automobiles, peak and ebb in popularity. For example, two years ago it seemed that you could not get a restaurant meal without coriander. This year, on a trip to Paris, I repeatedly found chervil in places ranging from the simplest brasserie to the famed Taillevent. Sure enough, chervil is the herb of choice now in New York.

title: Drug Testing Upheld for Police in Elite Corps
description: Upholding an order by Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward, New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that an elite corps of undercover New York City police officers could be required to submit to periodic random drug testing.

Yesterday, Rooney pleaded guilty in Catskill, N.Y., only to charges of harassing her, and surrendered to the police. He was released by Justice Frank McDonald on $5,000 bond, ordered to pay a $250 fine and given a conditional discharge on a 15-day sentence.(AP)

title: Justice O'Connor Goes Home
description: Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor of the Supreme Court was released from Georgetown University hospital today, five days after undergoing surgery for breast cancer, a Court spokeswoman said. The spokeswoman, Kathy Arberg, said Justice O'Connor, 58 years old, returned home after being discharged. The Justice, who underwent surgery on Friday, plans to be on the bench on Oct. 31 when the Court reconvenes after a two-week recess, the spokeswoman said. A statement Friday said the prognosis for Justice O'Connor was for ''total recovery.''

title: In Reversal, 3 Endorse Pact On Shoreham
description: Three major opponents of the Shoreham nuclear power plant reversed themselves today and endorsed Governor Cuomo's plan to close Shoreham. The move appeared to be the opening round of a series of compromises that will most likely lead to legislative approval of the accord.

Health: Treatments; Breast Cancer Patients Face Daunting Array Of Options on Therapy
description: While experts now agree that almost all women who have breast cancer should undergo some form of chemotherapy or hormonal therapy after surgery, women and their doctors are confronted with a bewildering array of treatments and the fear that a wrong choice could be deadly.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Red Wings 4, Canadiens 2: Paul MacLean scored with 6 minutes 50 seconds remaining in the third period to snap a 2-2 tie last night and Detroit beat Montreal, 4-2, in Detroit. After the Canadiens tied the score on Claude Lemieux's goal 3:30 into the final period, MacLean scored the game-winner after a muffed clearing pass by Patrick Roy, Montreal's goalie. Steve Yzerman's pass into the slot glanced off MacLean's stick and slid toward Roy, who attempted to poke the puck away. The clearing pass hit MacLean's skates and bounced past Roy into the Montreal net.(AP) Whalers 7, Sabres 1: Kevin Dineen, the right wing, scored two goals and Dave Babych, a defenseman, had four assists to lead Hartford over Buffalo last night. The loss was the worst the Sabres had suffered on home ice since Dec. 13, 1987, when the Calgary Flames beat them, 7-1. The Whalers, who have scored 23 goals in the last four games, were never behind, leading by 1-0 after the first period and by 2-1 entering the third.(AP) Maple Leafs 3, North Stars 2: Ed Olczyk scored with 25 seconds left in the second period to snap a tie as surprising Toronto defeated Minnesota for its sixth straight road victory. The Maple Leafs won only seven road games all last season, when they finished with the league's second-worst record, behind Minnesota. Toronto, 5-0-1 in its last six games, leads the Norris Division so far with the league's best record: 8-3-1 for 17 points. The North Stars, 1-7-1, are again at the bottom of the Norris Division and have the worst record in the N.H.L. Only 6,895 fans showed up at Met Center in Bloomington, Minn.(AP) Tennis Graf and Shriver Advance: Steffi Graf and Pam Shriver advanced to the third round of the Midland Group women's championships at Brighton, England. Graf, a West German and the world's No. 1 player, downed Hester Witvoet of the Netherlands, 6-1, 6-1. Shriver needed just 35 minutes to defeat Laura Garrone of Italy, 6-0, 6-0. In a first-round match, Lori McNeil of the United States recovered from a shaky start to overcome Silke Meier of West Germany, 4-6, 6-0, 6-1. Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria overcame a Swedish qualifier, Maria Strandlund, 6-4, 6-1.(AP) Golf Lohr Takes Lead: Bob Lohr, a four-year PGA Tour veteran looking for his first victory, shot a 10-under-par 62 yesterday for a two-shot lead after the first round of the Walt Disney World Classic at Lake Buena Vista, Fla. The event is being played over three courses. Lohr had 10 birdies and missed by a stroke both the low round this year and Mark Lye's Palm course record. The Palm is one of three courses used in the 72-hole tournament. Fuzzy Zoeller shot a 64, his best score this year, for second place. Zoeller, seeking his first victory since 1986, was eight-under-par at the Lake Buena Vista course, the shortest and easiest of the three layouts. Mark Calcavecchia, Jay Don Blake and Mark McCumber all shot 65 at the same course and were tied for third.(AP) Horse Racing Prospector's Halo Wins: Prospector's Halo, ridden by Dean Sarvis, came from off the pace to score a three-quarter-length victory in the $41,000 Dance Bid Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct. Faster Than Sound, ridden by Jose Romero, was the runner-up in the field of seven, a neck in front of Hittias. Prospector's Halo covered seven furlongs on the fast track in 1:23 1/5 to record his fifth victory in 13 starts this year. He earned $24,600 for his owner, Vernon H. Heath, and returned $8.60 for $2 to win. Soccer Adelphi 1, Columbia 0: Ronan Wiseman scored the game's only goal with less than five minutes left in the second overtime at the Columbia Soccer Stadium. Adelphi (13-3-1), the top-ranked team in New York State, assured itself a bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament in two weeks with the victory. Columbia (4-8) will have its first losing season since 1975.

Edward Triwush, whose law license was suspended by the Illinois Supreme Court earlier this year, was ordered Monday by Circuit Judge Anthony Scotillo to pay a total of $395,568 in damages to 417 aliens and 11 employers.

Revenues were $303.2 million, up 34.1 percent from $226.1 million in the period last year. Seagate said on Tuesday that the loss resulted in part from significantly lower production and sales.

title: Sports People; Workout Barred
description: Marty Denkin, a state boxing official, said yesterday that Sugar Ray Leonard, who was not allowed to spar on Tuesday because he did not hold a boxing license in California, had been told previously that he could not engage an opponent in the ring. Leonard arrived on the West Coast Tuesday for a public workout to promote his Nov. 7 bout against the World Boxing Council light-heavyweight champion, Donny Lalonde, in Las Vegas, Nev. Just as Leonard was about to put on a sparring show for 3,000 spectators at the ABC Entertainment Center in Century City, Frank Adair, the state athletic commission inspector, blocked the display. Leonard cannot be licensed to fight in California because the state prohibits issuing a license to any fighter who has had retinal damage repaired. Denkin, who is in Mexico City, said that Leonard had been informed a month ago, when he planned to stage an exhibition before a card at the Los Angeles Sports Arena, that he could not get into the ring because he could not be licensed. (AP)

description: Earlier ages, secure in their faith, once produced works like ''The Divine Comedy,'' ''Paradise Lost'' and ''The Oresteia'' - works of religious artists who used their talent not to annotate the ways of men, but to ratify man's relationship to the everlasting. With the dawning of more secular times, it seemed, art began to focus more insistently on the machinery of society, the world of love, money and work.

The latest 9 months included a net gain of $10.6 million, or 20 cents a share, on the sale of Primerica's remaining timberlands; and a net loss of $1.5 million from the restatement for a change in accounting for interest-sensitive insurance products. The year-ago quarter included a gain of $3.7 million, or 7 cents a shre, from a change in accounting for income taxes adopted in 1987; and a reduction of $2.1 million from the restatement for a change in accounting for interest-sensitive insurance products. The year-ago 9 months included a net gain of $37 million, or 69 cents a share, from the sale of certain timberlands; a net gain of $15.2 million, or 28 cents a share, from the public offering of common stock by Primerica's former Musicland Group Inc. subsidiary; a net gain of $4.7 million, or 9 cents a share, from a change in accounting for income taxes adopted in 1987; a reserve of $23.1 million after- tax, or 43 cents a share, related to the participation of one of Primerica's former subsidiaries in a real estate joint venture; and a net loss of $6.9 million from the restatement for a change in accounting for interest- sensitive insurance products.

title: When Paint Is Not Just A Cover-Up
description: TO celebrate the current profusion of painted finishes in decorating, the New York School of Interior Design is opening an exhibition, ''Painted Surfaces,'' on Nov. 1, to run through Dec. 16. Included are rare examples of trompe l'oeil, false marble and wood finishes, and stenciling from many leading practitioners. ''The time was right for this kind of show,'' said Sally Forbes, the assistant curator. ''The art of the painted interior has become such an important decorative trend.'' Ms. Forbes, together with David Garrard Lowe, the curator of the school's gallery, have selected the work of 17 artists. Also included will be work from such sources as the Finishing School, the Isabel O'Neil Foundation and John Stubbs Rare Books and Prints.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I recently learned that the roofing shingles on my 58-year-old house are made of asbestos and that roofers are reluctant to work on this type of roof because they are afraid of the toxic effects of asbestos. Is this true, and if so, what recourse do I have when roof repairs are needed? A. Your shingles are most likely made of asphalt, not asbestos. While some older asphalt shingles do have a small amount of asbestos in them, I doubt if this would be a cause for concern for any experienced roofer, particularly since roofing work is all done outdoors. Roofs like yours are constantly being repaired or replaced without posing any asbestos hazard. Q. During cold weather we have a lot of condensation on the inside of our windows, even though we have storm windows outside. This moisture is not between the window and the storm window. In very cold weather we even have ice on the inside. We turned off our furnace humidifier, as this only made it worse. Any idea what we can do to cure this problem? A. There is obviously too much humidity inside. Install exhaust fans in the bathrooms and in the kitchen and make sure that they are turned on when those rooms are in use. If you have lots of house plants, get rid of most of them, as they produce moisture. Also, check the fit of the outside storm windows. They may be leaking a lot of cold air around the edges due to poor or missing caulking.

description: David Jacobs, who created ''Dallas'' and ''Knots Landing,'' is now bringing his clearly marketable, if somewhat askew, sense of family and community values to what is called an ''authentic'' western format, set in 1890. ''Paradise,'' having its premiere on CBS at 9 o'clock this evening, is about as authentic as a Gene Autry movie, and not nearly as entertaining.

title: Nerco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $9,100,000 extraordinary charge.

title: Hard-Up Oxford Opens Fund-Raising Drive
description: Prompted by cuts in Government spending for education, England's oldest university began a private fund-raising drive today to raise nearly $375 million for teaching positions, laboratories and endowment by 1993.

title: HWC Distribution reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Intermec Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago figures are restated to conform to current year classifications and to reflect the acquisition of Intermec-Southwest, accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: 2 Partnerships In Joint Deal For Wickes
description: Investment partnerships controlled by two of Manhattan's leading investment boutiques have reached agreement to acquire the Wickes Companies of Santa Monica, Calif., for $539 million in cash and stock, the diversified manufacturing and retailing company said today. The assumption of Wickes's debt will raise the purchase price to $2.7 billion, it added.

title: In a Welfare Hotel, an Earnest Teacher and a Willing Class
description: EVERY Friday afternoon at the Prince George Hotel, in a room that smells of apple juice and diapers, the women and their children sit on folding chairs and strain to hear.

title: The Plant-Closing Law Reaches Into Wall St.
description: When the political battle raged last summer over a plant-closing bill that required 60 days' notice of shutdowns and large layoffs, much of the debate centered on blue-collar jobs. Few participants would have guessed that Wall Street bankers and brokers might be among the first people affected after the bill passed.

title: Queens Housing Plan Combines Market-Rate and Cheaper Units
description: The Koch administration yesterday unveiled a multimillion-dollar plan to build market-rate housing for as many as 10,000 families on long vacant city-owned land along the Rockaway peninsula in Queens.

title: Peru Official Assails Airline After a Crash That Killed 12
description: The state airline, Aeroperu, should be reorganized, Peru's Vice President said today, the day after 12 people died in a jetliner crash.

title: Metro Datelines; Blue Cross Contract Is Delayed by Board
description: The New York City Board of Estimate moved yesterday in an executive session to delay approval of a municipal contract providing health care insurance for city workers by Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield.

title: Ford Motor Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid last December.

title: Shelton Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Let F.D.A. Examine Smokeless Cigarette
description: To the Editor:

title: Ward's 5 Years at the Helm: Higher Goals Remain Elusive
description: In his nearly five years as New York City Police Commissioner, Benjamin Ward has shaken up the department with a score of new programs, overcome deep resistance and suspicion and gained much respect from his 27,000-member force.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Maize-Products Co., Stamford, Conn., said it had received several offers from parties interested in buying its building materials business.

title: Sports People; Simmons Rejoins Cards
description: Ted Simmons, a former All-Star catcher who set a St. Louis Cardinal record by catching 1,440 games for the club, has returned to the team as director of player development. The 39-year-old Simmons was hired yesterday to fill the vacancy created when Jim Riggleman was named the team's first-base coach. Riggleman had been hired as director of player development this summer when Lee Thomas became general manager of the Philadelphia Phillies, and he moved to the coaching box when Nick Leyva was hired as manager by Philadelphia. Simmons, an eight-time All-Star in his 19 seasons, had a .286 career batting average with 248 home runs and 1,389 runs batted in.(AP)

title: Block Drug Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Wm Wrigley Jr Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dollar Drops on G.N.P. Data; Traders See a Further Slide
description: The dollar declined sharply yesterday, falling against the yen to a level below where it stood before last summer's rally. The dollar also fell against the mark and other currencies, as the downward trend of the last three weeks continued.

title: Town Decides Fate Of Historic House
description: LEAD: THE decision to reveal the original Georgian style of the 1810 Ralph Hascall House in Essex, N.Y., was not a radical one, but the decision-making process was. The town's 880 residents, as well as preservationists and restoration architects, were invited to help determine the future appearance of the building.

title: ESI Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a credit of $326,000 representing cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net income

title: X-Rite Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $406,810 from the sale of a building.

title: Review/Concert; All-Brahms Program At Carnegie
description: First-rate recitals by violin and piano duos probably have never been commonplace. Even in a past generation when the fiddle fancier could pick and choose favorites from such big names as Heifetz, Elman, Milstein, Oistrakh, Menuhin, Grumiaux, Francescatti and Rabin, there was seldom any question about which partner dominated the performance. Pianists have generally been valued by star violinists for their ability to stay discreetly in the background.

title: Review/Dance; Kathy Gatto Presents Works for Nondancers
description: Choreographers occasionally cast dances with nondancers: people with little or no dance training or experience. Two dances of this sort were on the program offered by Kathy Gatto and Friends on Monday night at the Mulberry Street Theater.

title: Hydraulic Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Metal Resources Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: A Giant Receiver Adds Some Muscle
description: Last spring and summer, Stephen Baker went on a weight-training program and gained a pound, all the way up to 158. He is 5 feet 8 inches and skinny, and people refuse to believe he plays pro football for the Giants.

title: Arab Hints and Israel's Election
description: Have Arab leaders overstepped proper bounds by endorsing Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader, in Israel's Nov. 1 election? Yitzhak Shamir and his Likud backers charge that, but they are either being hilariously naive or just plain cynical.

title: Joint Deal For Nabisco Is Rejected
description: The competition grew more intense yesterday in the battle for RJR Nabisco, as F. Ross Johnson, the company's chief executive, announced that he and his financial partner, Shearson Lehman Hutton, would not work with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company on a combined buyout bid.

title: Panhandle Eastern Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $243,956,000 from the resolution of take-or-pay and gas supply disputes for both periods; the 9 months also included a gain of $64.3 million from the sale of Quantum Chemical Corp. stock. c-Net income and the 9 months included a loss of $1,461,000 from discontinued operations.

title: For Sari Designer, Tradition and Daring
description: To the outsider's eye, an Indian sari is six yards of exquisitely woven cotton or silk. To the Indian woman, it is a proud national symbol that has never been seriously challenged or undermined by Western dress.

title: Howell Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and 9 months losses were after pretax charges of $16,607,000 from writedowns of oil, gas and coal assets; the losses reflect the settlement of litigation.

title: Sports People; An Eye Toward Japan
description: Orel Hershiser, the most valuable player of the World Series, said yesterday that during an exhibition tour of Japan next month he will explore the possibility of playing a season there. ''I'll be a free agent in a year, and you never know what's going to happen,'' the Los Angeles Dodgers pitcher told reporters during his team's visit to the White House to received congratulations for winning the Series from President Reagan. Hershiser has been saying he is interested not only in learning about Japa-nese culture, but also in seeing if he might like to play there in the event of a long players' strike against major league owners in 1990. (AP)

title: LAURA STEIN, AUTHOR, WED TO E. V. WOLSK, PRODUCER
description: Laura Stein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Stein of Milford, Conn., and Eugene V. Wolsk, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Wolsk of New York, were married yesterday at their home in New York by Judge Franklin R. Weissberg of the New York State Court of Claims.

title: Bethlehem Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains from the early retirement of debt of $3.8 million for the quarter and $11.4 million for the 9 months. The latest quarter and 9-month includes charges of $58 million related to the proposed sale of certain operations, and a $30 million charge related to navy contract adjustments.

title: Reviews/Theater; John Kelly, Alone, as Anyone Else
description: Sitting at his dressing table on stage, John Kelly bears a fleeting resemblance to Jean-Louis Barrault. One would certainly not want to carry the comparison too far - for one thing, Mr. Kelly is primarily a comic performer - but there is something in his gaunt look that suggests the French master. In his new one-man show, ''Ode to a Cube'' (at La Mama), he is playing an actor, an American enfant du SoHo, lost in his own illusionary world.

title: Fixing Broken Zippers
description: ''ANYTHING that zips, our motto is that we fix it,'' said Marvin Rosen, co-owner of Superior Leather Restorers. The 58-year-old firm repairs zippers on dresses, leather jackets, duffle bags, trousers, ski parkas, handbags, coats, backpacks, briefcases, luggage, wallets, cosmetic cases - you name it; they even fix tent zippers.

title: U.S. Farm Credit Agency Sets $2.47 Billion Offering
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation is offering $2.47 billion of consolidated systemwide bonds through various securities dealers.

title: French Fashion Leaders Join AIDS Fight
description: It was billed as a sober evening, but it turned into a brilliant one.

title: Scana Corp reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Catholic Church Is Said to Settle Molestation Suit
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Washington made a secret out-of-court settlement with a 20-year-old man who sued the church for negligence after he was molested by a Catholic priest in the early 1980's, The Washington Post reported today.

title: Campaign Trail; Democrats Line Up For a Party Fight
description: Some Democratic insiders believe that the best reason to elect Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts as President is to avoid the bloodbath that might engulf the party if he loses. The first post-election fight will be over who should succeed Paul G. Kirk Jr. as chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

title: Talking Deals; Burger King Role In Pillsbury Fight
description: IT is hard enough for a company to decide what to do when an unsolicited takeover offer lands on its doorstep. But, in the case of the Pillsbury Company, finding a workable alternative is being made more difficult by the intervention of an unlikely group - its Burger King franchisees.

title: A.&P. Withdraws Bid for Delchamps
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company withdrew its merger and tender offers for Delchamps Inc., concluding the third attempt by A.&P. to take over the supermarket chain, which is based in Mobile, Ala. On Tuesday, the Delchamps board rejected A.&P.'s offer of $32 a share, or $224 million. The bid was sweetened from A.&P.'s earlier tender offer of $30 a share.

title: Review/Opera; New Principals in 'Tosca'
description: There were two new principals in the New York City Opera's production of Puccini's ''Tosca'' on Sunday evening at the New York State Theater: Elizabeth Holleque in the title role, and Roger Roloff as Scarpia.

title: Cambrex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $401,800 loss from discontinued operations and a $2,461,700 gain on the sale of discontinued operations.

title: On Stage
description: Pop to Stage

title: Reports of Illegal Construction Have Doubled
description: Reports of illegal construction have doubled in the three days since a building in midtown Manhattan collapsed in a hail of concrete and glass, the New York City Buildings Commissioner said yesterday.

title: Dionex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
In Sharpeville Vote, The Underdog Wins
description: With a voter turnout of less than 20 percent, the underdog won an overwhelming victory Wednesday in the black township of Sharpeville in the nationwide municipal elections.

title: Topics of The Times; Citizens, Too, Have Eyes
description: Working without a permit from the Department of Buildings, a contractor fatally weakened a load-bearing wall in a six-story building on 31st Street in Manhattan last Monday. All six floors collapsed, killing the owner and grievously injuring a courageous woman who lay unseen beneath the debris for hours.

title: Prices of Imports Decline by 1.1%
description: Prices of imported goods dropped by 1.1 percent in the third quarter, the first decline in more than two years, the Government said today.

title: Jets Take a Course From an Ex-Steeler
description: The Jets' long-winded professor, Robin Cole, was teaching today, not only giving classes in X's and O's, but also lecturing on how to avoid the Pittsburgh Steelers' trap plays.

title: Economic Scene; Debt in Buyouts Causing Anxiety
description: THE multibillion-dollar bids to take over RJR Nabisco, Kraft, Pillsbury and other companies have raised anxieties that the heavily debt-financed takeover wave could endanger the solvency of American corporations and the stability of the economy. ''The whole business and financial system is highly leveraged,'' said James J. O'Leary, economic consultant to the United States Trust Company.

title:
About Real Estate;
New Building Tied to YMCA Next Door
description: LEAD: The Club at Turtle Bay, a 40-story, mixed-use condominium nearing completion at 236 East 47th Street, has only one major amenity for the residents' exclusive use: a roof lounge and garden.

title: Nalco Chemical Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Theater; Comedy With a Subversive Punch
description: In ''Eastern Standard,'' his new play at the Manhattan Theater Club, Richard Greenberg captures the romantic sophistication of the most sublime comedies ever made in this country: those produced by Hollywood from the middle of the Depression until the waning days of World War II.

title: At the Bar
description: There has been a brisk trade in Finley Kumble desks and chairs, although Finley Kumble matchbooks and Finley Kumble neckties aren't in such demand. As for the Finley Kumble art collection, the results are mixed. The bucolic English sporting scenes have sold well; not so the portraits of Hugh L. Carey, Robert F. Wagner and other former partners that once graced its halls.

title: Bronx Leukemia Complaints Are Described as Unfounded
description: Health Commissioner Stephen C. Joseph said yesterday that a study had failed to find an unusual incidence of childhood leukemia in the northeastern Bronx, despite the concerns of a group of residents.

title: Maker Says Pressures Could Revive Abortion Pill
description: Officials from the French company that suspended distribution of a new drug that induces abortion early in pregnancy said today that they might reverse that decision if the pressures against the drug die down.

title: Market Place; A Price Mystery In Manville Stock
description: THE world of $2 stocks does not often get much attention on Wall Street, where it is assumed that respectable companies trade for much more. But there is growing attention, and incredulity, being focused on one such stock: the Manville Corporation's.

title: The Brands With Billion-Dollar Names
description: In the supermarket, everyday products like Velveeta and Oreos sell for a few dollars or less. In the frantic market where companies are bought and sold, those products are worth billions.

title: Bonn Arrests 13 Palestinians
description: The authorities have arrested 13 Palestinians suspected of preparing a terrorist attack, a prosecutor said today.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 453 money market mutual funds increased $1.73 billion, to $270.52 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 128 institutional funds grew $909 million, to $70.51 billion. The 223 general purpose funds grew $296.70 million, to $85.63 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds grew $519.90 million, to $114.38 billion.

title: Abortion, Intimidation and Death
description: By capitulating to activists who regard abortion as immoral, a French company called Groupe Roussel Uclaf may be committing a larger immorality, ordaining the death of tens of thousands of women around the world. That's the judgment of people who should know - doctors attending the current World Congress of Gynecology and Obstetrics in Rio de Janeiro.

title: Former Nixon Aide Serving As Bush Campaign Adviser
description: Dwight L. Chapin, a former White House aide under President Nixon who was imprisoned in the Watergate scandals, is serving as an unpaid staff adviser to George Bush's Presidential campaign, The San Jose Mercury News reported today.

title: Campaign Trail; TV as the Wheel Of Dukakis Fortunes
description: H-e-e-e-e-e-r-e's . . . Michael.

description: b-Net loss

title: China Explains Policy Shift Retightening Economic Grip
description: Zhao Ziyang, China's Communist Party chief, has issued a long and vigorous explanation of the Government's economic retrenchment policy, revealing the alarm with which China's leaders view the country's apparent economic disorder.

title: TV Weekend; Drug Runner's Mother
description: This week's television mystery: What does CBS think it is accomplishing with ''Dadah Is Death,'' a four-hour mini-series being broadcast at 9 P.M. Sunday and Monday? Based on a true story, the film revolves around the efforts of an Australian woman to save her drug-smuggling son from a mandatory death penalty in Malayasia. With drugs currently a priority issue among American voters, this would hardly seem the most propitious time to elicit sympathy for dealers. Even at the time of the case, several years ago, a poll revealed that 60 percent of the Australian public supported the death penalty in this instance.

title: Dukakis's Great Denial
description: Many failings have contributed to Michael Dukakis's lagging campaign for President but one seems to be at the heart of the problem - the candidate's long, lame and basically unbelievable effort to deny that he and his party represent the great liberal tradition of the last half-century.

title: People
description: * Edward S. Littleford and Colleen Butler Gowl have been promoted to senior executive vice president, executive creative director, and executive vice president, group management director, respectively, at FCB/Leber Katz Partners, New York.

title: Dukakis Favors Weapons Policies That Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Soccer; 14 Players Sign With U.S. Federation
description: The United States Soccer Federation, the national governing body for the sport, took the first step yesterday toward getting the best players in the country to make the United States national team their first priority.

title: Man Arrested in Drug Officer's Death
description: The man suspected of firing the shots that killed an undercover New York City narcotics officer last week was arrested yesterday in a shopping mall in San Juan, P. R., after a nine-day manhunt, the police and the F.B.I. announced.

title: Reagan Calls Vote Against Democrats Good Negative Campaigning
description: President Reagan, using a final swing through the Midwest and the Far West to implore voters to turn out on Election Day, asserted today that ''the right kind of negative campaigning'' is a vote cast against the Democratic ticket.

title: Gorbachev Associate Rejects Baltic Independence Moves
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's closest Kremlin associate says the Soviet republics of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania will not be allowed to print their own currency, conduct their own diplomacy or expect to take any other major steps toward independence.

title: Angry Farmers Camp in New Delhi's Stately Core
description: They began arriving Monday on tractors and hay wagons and buses garlanded with marigolds and flags: thousands, then tens of thousands, and finally several hundred thousand protesting farmers from breadbasket states close enough to the capital to feel the urban-rural gap widening.

title: DOCTORS PROTEST COMPANY'S ACTION ON ABORTION PILL
description: A French company's decision to suspend distribution of an abortion-inducing drug caused a furor here today at a congress of the main international body of gynecologists and obstetricians.

title: Sports People; Muncie Pleads Innocent
description: Chuck Muncie, a former San Diego Chargers running back, pleaded innocent yesterday to three counts of selling cocaine and one count of intent to sell cocaine to undercover drug agents. United States Magistrate Roger C. McKee allowed Muncie, 35, to remain free on $20,000 bond and set a hearing for Monday.(AP)

title: Eldon Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Chrysler Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Creating a Brand Image For Eggs
description: IN advertising, there's no question that the chicken came before the egg.
