BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Indiana Utility Names A Chairman and Chief
description: LEAD: James E. Rogers, a lawyer who specialized in the natural gas business, was named today as chairman and chief executive of the Public Service Company of Indiana, an electric utility powered largely by coal.

title: Betz Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Our Towns; What Next? Linus Hauled Off In Handcuffs?
description: Now hear this. Now hear this, all juveniles 18 years old and younger in this pleasant North Shore village. On Halloween eve and Halloween, Oct. 30th and Oct. 31st, between the hours of 7 P.M. and 6 A.M., you will be outlawed from all public places and private property in the village, except your own house or a friend's, unless you are accompanied by your mom or dad, or have a permission slip signed by your mom or dad. The police will strictly enforce the curfew. Violators will be subject to arrest and may be fined or jailed. That is all.

title: Health Care Is Lacking in New York Schools That Need It Most
description: To the Editor:

title: WASTEFUL SUBSIDIES BLAMED
description: The Soviet Finance Minister said today that the Soviet Union has been running large budget deficits for years and predicted that this year the deficit would amount to the official equivalent of $58 billion. It was the first time that the Government had made public this indicator of its economic distress.

title: Reluctant Whales Coaxed Closer to Sea
description: Like two houseguests who would not leave, two whales who have been shown the door to the open sea today showed little inclination to go.

title: Watching Weicker, Ever Confident, on the Stump
description: The rock-and-roll radio station marked the eighth stop of a nine-stop day. Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. taped an interview and chatted his way around the studios. Advance men wrapped up a touch football game on the pavement behind the building. The campaign bus, a long white Winnebago-like beast nicknamed Grapefruit II, panted in the parking lot.

title: Dukakis Attacks Bush on Worker Safety, Taxes and Campaign Ads
description: Michael S. Dukakis, scornfully described by the Republicans as ''the iceman,'' is turning up the heat.

title: Auctions
description: Cameraless Photos

title: Fischer & Porter Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said share earnings results have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividends paid in April 1988 to common and class B shareholders.

title: Halloween Revels for Grown-Ups
description: Halloween in New York is, for better or worse, predominantly a grown-up affair, with parties that bring out a latent looniness in all but the most buttoned-down reveler.

title: Review/Art; Carol Hepper, in Wood: A Supple Synthesis
description: Sculptors, curators and critics have been aware of Carol Hepper for a while. Her taut and supple wood constructions, drawn with branches and holding the memory of the South Dakota Indian reservation on which she was raised, have been appearing in New York group shows for several years. The works were intelligent and distinct, but they also seemed unfinished, and there was a question whether this sculptor was actually going to emerge.

title: For Senators Weicker and Lautenberg; Behind All That Heat in Connecticut
description: Connecticut has two well-qualified candidates in a hot contest for U.S. senator. Lowell Weicker, the unconventional Republican incumbent, is challenged by Joseph Lieberman, the popular Democratic Attorney General. Each would be an asset in Washington. Mr. Weicker, with his strong record, has our support for a fourth term.

title: Campaign Trail; The Way We Were Is The Way It Is
description: Is the Bush campaign afraid of Barbra Streisand?

description: b-After a tax credit of $10.8 million for the both periods. The company said year-ago sales figures were restated to recalculate adjustments needed for the amalgamation which formed Placer Dome in August 1987. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Art; The Real World and Edward Hopper
description: Natural light and architecture are two of the leading characters in the drama of Edward Hopper's art, and they currently hold center stage at the Hirschl & Adler Galleries. The exhibition on view there, ''Edward Hopper: Light Years,'' downplays the artist's involvement with the figure and virtually ignores his broad range of urban subjects to concentrate on Hopper in more natural settings, usually on or around Cape Cod, where he spent more than 40 summers of his life.

title: Review/Art; Edgar Franceschi, in Many Media
description: The eight-year retrospective of paintings, sculptures, mixed-media objects and a complete stage set by Edgar Franceschi at the Museo del Barrio, 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street, is an event that honors both the artist and the museum. More than one museum to the south of 104th Street could learn from the lucid, calm and spacious installation. And the work, though uneven, has high ambitions in the areas of wit, fancy and sophistication.

title: How Race Destroyed the Democrats' Coalition
description: LEAD: After Walter Mondale's defeat in 1984, the scholar Samuel Popkin pointed out that the Democratic nominees had lost the majority of white votes in every election since the death of Franklin D. Roosevelt, save for Lyndon B. Johnson's victory in 1964 and, that after Mr. Johnson, only Jimmy Carter had won as much as 40 percent of the white vote.

Bid by Banner Unit
description: Rexnord Holdings U.K. P.L.C., a British unit of Banner Industries Inc., has offered to buy Avdel P.L.C., which makes assembly-line systems, for $:102 million, or about $178.5 million. Banner, based in Cleveland, supplies components to the aviation and aerospace markets. A merger would create a leading force in the industry, with combined sales exceeding $250 million, Rexnord said. Banner holds an option on 27.56 percent of Avdel, bringing its stake, along with that of associates, to about 29.61 percent of its common stock.

title: Lacrosse Club Shifting to L.I.
description: The Major Indoor Lacrosse League announced yesterday that the New York Saints, a team that played its league games during the 1987 and 1988 seasons at Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., would move to Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I., for the 1989 season. Two expansion teams, the

title: Chemical Issue Yields 10.235%
description: The Chemical Banking Corporation is offering $150 million of 10 1/8 percent subordinated notes due in 2000 at a price of 99.25 to yield 10.235 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Eugene Rosenfeld, Administrator, 71
description: Dr. Eugene D. Rosenfeld, a former executive director of Long Island Jewish Hospital, died of a heart attack Tuesday at the University of Arizona Medical Center in Tucson. He was 71 years old and had lived in Manhattan and Montauk, L.I., before retiring to Green Valley, Ariz., in 1985.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES G.M. reported a 5.8 percent rise in profits for the third quarter, from the comparable period a year earlier, while Chrysler reported a 54 percent drop in earnings for the period. G.M.'s gain is far more striking than it appears, because last year's figure was inflated by an accounting change. [ Page D1. ] Mcorp has a ''high probability'' of entering bankruptcy next month, its chief executive said. The remark is seen as a daring challenge to bank regulators. [ D1. ] Fears about bank lending for leveraged buyouts are overblown, banking experts said. Lenders have not only built recession assumptions into their loan decisions but also have avoided overconcentration by distributing their loans widely, they maintained. [ D1. ] Stocks of companies subject to takeover bids fell sharply on the day after the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, advised Congress to consider limits on the borrowing needed to complete corporate takeovers. [ D1. ] UAL and Delta Air Lines reported sharply higher earnings for the third quarter, mainly because of higher traffic and the higher fares that have been put into effect in the past year. [ D4. ] Dean Witter Reynolds is expected to announce large layoffs soon in its fixed-income department. [ D12. ] Salomon will join Shearson in making a bid for RJR Nabisco, RJR's chief executive said. [ D20. ] A $1.15 billion financing for Federated is being restructured, the Campeau Corporation and First Boston acknowledged. [ D20. ] Coniston Partners said it would begin an offer for TW Services, valuing the food-services operator at $1.4 billion. [ D4. ] Grand Metropolitan extended its offer for Pillsbury by a week, to Nov. 8. Pillsbury has rejected the $5.23 billion bid. [ D4. ] THE ECONOMY Personal incomes rose a moderate five-tenths of 1 percent in September while consumer spending turned in its weakest performance in almost a year, the Commerce Department said. The reports offered fresh evidence that economic growth is slowing. [ D2. ] INTERNATIONAL The Soviet Union has been running large budget deficits for years, the Soviet Finance Minister said, and he predicted that this year the deficit would amount to the official equivalent of $58 billion. He also said that the Government, eager to lure more Western investment, has agreed for the first time to let foreign companies own controlling interests in Soviet joint ventures. [ A1. ] MARKETS The Dow dropped 24.35 points, to close at 2,140.83, pulled down in part by takeover stocks that were sold off amid concerns about buyout financing. The selloff was broad. [ D6. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds posted strong gains in fairly light trading, as investors were hit with a barrage of developments that made Treasury issues appear more attractive. [ D12. ] The dollar ended mostly higher after a seesaw session, influenced largely by rumors of central bank support. Gold prices fell 70 cents on the Comex, to $407.60 an ounce. [ D16. ] Copper futures prices hit the lows of the week before rallying on the New York Commodity Exchange, where the major concerns continued to be a strike in Peru and tight demand. [ D16. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The heavily debt-financed takeover wave is raising anxieties that it could endanger the solvency of American corporations and the stability of the economy. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Officials at Manville say they are baffled by the discrepancy between the price of its old common stock and that of its new common stock, now trading on a when-issued basis. Market Place. [ D6. ]

The strong alternative was wide ankle-length trousers, endorsed by pace-setting designers like Christian Lacroix, Karl Lagerfeld, both in his KL collection and in his clothes for Chanel, and by Claude Montana, whose light, supple designs made the longer look totally acceptable.

description: Naguib Mahfouz, winner of the 1988 Nobel Prize in Literature, said today that he was not well enough to travel to Stockholm to receive his $390,000 award on Dec. 10.

title: Sports People; Canseco Weds
description: Jose Canseco of the Oakland Athletics, who had an uncharacteristically quiet World Series offensively, was wed quietly in Coral Gables, Fla., Tuesday afternoon. Canseco and Esther Haddad of Miami were married in a brief civil ceremony on the second floor of the Coral Gables police station, said Louis Tomeo, the clerk who performed the ceremony. ''I read the basic ceremony,'' Tomeo said. ''They were giggling. Two minutes later it was finished.'' The Cansecos told the clerk that they were planning a formal ceremony and reception in November. If the reception is inordinately lavish, it may be because Canseco won a hefty bet from Dave Stewart, a pitcher for the Athletics. Stewart had bet $10,000 to Canseco's $5,000 that the outfielder would not be wed by Nov. 5. Stewart

title: N.F.L. Matchups; Saints Bracing for Showdown As Rams Invade Superdome
description: No need to tell Jim Mora the importance of the game Sunday in the Louisiana Superdome between the New Orleans Saints and the Los Angeles Rams.

title: College Football Notebook; Garrett Signs Guide Princeton
description: When Princeton lines up for its first offensive play at Palmer Stadium tomorrow, the destiny of the game and the Ivy League championship will seem to be in the hands of No. 17, Jason Garrett, quarterback and captain.

description: Jazz Abstraction

title: 4 Film Series With an International Flavor
description: A month of subtitled cinema offerings begins this weekend, covering international movie making from 1930's Italy to present-day Japan.

title: Jury Is Told Joel Steinberg 'Acted Cold and Uncaring'
description: Joel B. Steinberg, on trial in the murder of Lisa Steinberg, seemed remarkably remote and unconcerned when told that the child he had raised was near death, prosecution witnesses testified yesterday.

title: Mets Reward Johnson With a 3-Year Deal
description: The Mets ended a year of suspense and speculation yesterday by announcing they had signed Dave Johnson as manager for three more years with an option for a fourth year, and saying, ''His record speaks for itself.''

title: Campaign Trail; Mrs. Quayle Charges Bias by the Press
description: Dan Quayle has called a detente with the press - ''The more I get to know you, the more I really like you'' - but his wife, Marilyn, is not quite endorsing any rapprochement. She says he has been treated roughly by the press because there is an East Coast and West Coast bias against Midwesterners.

title: Utility Default Trial
description: Attorneys in the Washington Public Power Supply System securities fraud trial are negotiating a possible settlement of $200 million or more that could involve the 15 remaining utility defendants, several people in the case said today. United States District Court District Judge William Browning recessed the trial in Tucson, Ariz., until next Wednesday, saying lawyers who had requested the break ''may be productive in shortening the trial.'' Several utilities confirmed meetings were scheduled next week to discuss a settlement offer from plaintiff attorneys in the giant case. The case stemmed from the system's default in 1983 on $2.25 billion in bonds intended to finance two nuclear power plants that were never completed.

title: U.S. May Yield Health Data On Nuclear Weapon Workers
description: The Department of Energy said today that it was reconsidering a policy that bars independent researchers from reviewing the health records of the 300,000 workers who have been exposed to at least some radiation at American nuclear weapon plants since the early 1940's.

title: Tonka Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Sports People; Piniella's Choices
description: Lou Piniella was at home in Allendale, N.J., yesterday pondering his managerial future but saying his situation would be ''cleared up within a week.'' ''I've talked to both Houston and Seattle and I'll have to make a decision,'' he said. ''I just don't know what that decision's going to be at this point. The biggest decision I have to make is if I want to uproot.'' Piniella can work for the Yankees for the next three years and earn $1.2 million. Or he can take the Seattle job, which has been offered to him, or the Astros' job, if it is offered. But he has been reluctant to leave the area, especially because his daughter, Kristi, has only one year left in high school after this year.

title: Review/Film; Tea and Tragedy In Japan
description: Don't be put off by the title. ''Gonza the Spearman'' is not an Eastern western. Masahiro Shinoda's stately work, which opens the Public Theater's Autumn in Japan series today, has few duels and only a gout or two of blood. Instead, it is filled with historical imagination, social comment and restrained passion, along with scene after elegantly composed scene of a culture that seems to have been paralyzed in a spare beauty.

title: Bankers Defend Buyout Loans but Investors Fret; Lenders Calculate Chance of Recession
description: Banking experts said yesterday that fears about excessive bank lending to companies undertaking leveraged buyouts were overblown. Lenders have not only built recession assumptions into their loan decisions but have also avoided over-concentration by distributing their loans widely through the industry, the bankers and industry analysts maintained.

title: Australian Group Lifts Lonrho Stake
description: The Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. of Australia said it had acquired 24 million more shares of the London-based Lonrho P.L.C., raising its stake to 90.8 million shares, or about 20 percent. A statement issued through the London Stock Exchange did not elaborate on the stake, which had stood at 14.9 percent. Lonrho officials were unavailable for comment.

description: b-After extraordinary charges of $3.2 million for the quarter and $18.5 million for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $102.4 million for the quarter and $85 million for the 9 months. d-Net loss All 1987 figures were restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: S.B. Fuller, Door-to-Door Entrepreneur, Dies at 83
description: S. B. Fuller, an entrepreneur who became the first black member of the National Association of Manufacturers, died of kidney failure Monday at St. Francis Hospital in Blue Island, a suburb of Chicago. He was 83 years old.

title: Salomon to Join Shearson in Nabisco Battle
description: In a sign that the largest corporate bidding battle in history is about to start, F. Ross Johnson, chief executive of RJR Nabisco Inc., said yesterday that Salomon Brothers would join Shearson Lehman Hutton in making an offer for the huge food and tobacco company.

title: Teachers' Exam, Often Criticized, To Be Replaced
description: In a move that will substantially alter the way new teachers are certified, the Educational Testing Service said yesterday that it would replace its much-criticized National Teachers Examinations with more sophisticated tests.

title: Pepperell Creates A Severance Plan
description: West Point-Pepperell Inc., the textile giant resisting a $1.3 billion tender offer by Farley Inc., has created a cushion for more than 14 percent of its employees who might lose their jobs under a new owner. But Pepperell, based in West Point, Ga., said the severance package did not result from the Farley bid. A Pepperell official said the plan was adopted by its board last week.

title: Iraq, to Spur Talks, Says It May Develop New Port
description: A senior Iraqi official says his Government will develop a new port on the Persian Gulf if Iran continues to reject its proposals for reopening a blocked waterway when gulf peace talks resume in Geneva next week.

title: Botha's Party Loses Ground In Segregated Local Voting
description: The governing National Party retained control of most of South Africa's major cities Wednesday but lost heavily to the far right in rural and industrial areas in nationwide local elections, the first to be held simultaneously for all races. The elections were shunned by the majority of blacks.

title: Washington Talk: Administration Policy; As the Election Nears, Talk About Noriega Fades
description: Last spring, in the aftermath of the Federal indictments accusing Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of drug trafficking, the Reagan Administration vowed that the Panamanian military leader had to go. But the American effort to topple him by applying intense diplomatic and economic pressures didn't work.

description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British conglomerate that is offering $5.23 billion for the Pillsbury Company, today extended its offer by a week, to Nov. 8.

description: Jeffrey Leonard of Milwaukee filed for free agency yesterday. This year Leonard, an outfielder, had 10 home runs and a batting average of .242. He just completed a four-year contract that brought him $3,775,000. Other players filing yesterday were Cecilio Guante of Texas, Tim Laudner of Minnesota, Willie Upshaw and Terry Francona of Cleveland, Ron Oester of Cincinnati and Jim Acker of Atlanta. The free-agent list totals 33.

description: The General Motors Corporation reported a surprisingly strong performance in its third-quarter earnings today.

title: Leakage Closes Nuclear Plant
description: The Rancho Seco nuclear reactor plant, which supplies power for nearly a million people, shut down Tuesday because contaminated water was leaking from its cooling system. No radioactive material was leaking to the outside, and the leakage was not dangerous, said Ron Scott, a spokesman for the Sacramento Municipal Utility District. Contaminated water from the cooling system at the plant, 40 miles southeast of Sacramento, began leaking into a containment building Tuesday at a rate of a gallon a minute, Mr. Scott said.

description: NBC gave two prime time hours Tuesday night to what purported to be a serious exploration of Satanism by the talk show host Geraldo Rivera. In fact, the program was a piece of pornography masquerading as journalism.

The trade balance rebounded from a deficit of 9 billion francs, or $1.48 billion, in August to a surplus of 400 million francs, or $66 million, in September, the Government said. Earlier this week, the Government reported the biggest monthly drop in French unemployment in a decade.

title: Woman Is Among Eight Elected to Ayer Board
description: N. W. Ayer on Wednesday elected eight executives from its New York office to its board and promoted all of them to the position of executive vice president. One of them, Marcella Rosen, 54 years old, is the first woman to become a board member in the agency's 119-year history.

title: Dukakis Nearly Cuts Lead in Half in Poll By NBC and Journal
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts has gained ground on Vice President Bush, according to the latest NBC News/Wall Street Journal Poll, but Mr. Bush still leads his Democratic rival for the Presidency by 51 percent to 42 percent.

title: Income Up At Delta And UAL
description: The parent companies of United Airlines and Delta Air Lines reported sharply higher third-quarter earnings yesterday, mainly because of higher traffic and the higher fares that the industry has been able to put into effect in the past year.

description: President Reagan said today that the United States had no option but to raze the new American Embassy office building in Moscow, which has been riddled with Soviet eavesdropping devices, and to put up a new building in its place.

description: In a far-reaching action resulting from the ripping away of a large section of a Boeing 737's fuselage in April over Hawaii, the Federal Aviation Administration yesterday proposed a rule that would require extensive strengthening of the structure of the older 737's.

title: At Least 12 Deaths In Hospital in Bronx Linked to Poor Care
description: The New York State Health Department charged yesterday that mismanagement, overcrowding and crucial staff shortages - all symptoms of a widening health crisis in New York City - contributed to the deaths of at least 12 people this year at Lincoln Hospital, a city-run hospital in the Bronx.

title: Morrell Fine Is Expected
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration is expected to impose a substantial fine today on John Morrell & Company, the Cincinnati-based meatpacking concern.

title: International Flavors & Frarances Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sports People; Deputy Commissioner
description: When A. Bartlett Giamatti officially becomes the commissioner of baseball next April 1, a former Hollywood executive will join him as deputy commissioner and chief operating officer. Francis T. (Fay) Vincent Jr., the former chairman and chief executive officer of Columbia Pictures Industries, will take office the same day that Giamatti, now the president of the National League, replaces Peter Ueberroth as commissioner. Vincent, 50 years old, lives in Greenwich, Conn. He joined Columbia Pictures in 1978. When Coca-Cola bought Columbia in 1983, Vincent continued as head of the motion picture studio and was made an executive vice president of Coca-Cola. He left that position in July after he was assigned to areas other than entertainment.

title: Dukakis Staff Faulted as Too Insular
description: Every campaign has a personality, and it often reflects the candidate's in one way or another. So the Presidential campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, like the man, has tended to be lawyerly, organization-minded, policy-oriented and very much a creature of Boston.

title: Lagos Journal; A Gleeful David Faces the Goliath That Is Nigeria
description: ''Read this,'' Gani Fawehinmi commanded a visitor to his law chambers recently, waving a newspaper clipping as if it were evidence in a private court of corruption.

description: b-Includes a gain of $125,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Comics and a 50's Hop in the Wee Hours
description: One of the last sounds to disappear in the wee hours of the morning on a New York weekend is the sound of laughter. Here is a list of some of the late-night comedy shows, and one post-show participatory event, that are scheduled this weekend. Political Jokes Randy Credico, Brett Butler and Noo Yawk Talk, Top of the Village Gate (160 Bleecker Street). ''Quayle will help the Republican ticket out in the South - Paraguay, Chile, South Africa, and Pakistan,'' remarks Randy Credico, one of New York's most outspoken political comics. With spiky, angry humor, Mr. Credico follows in the progressive-liberal-left footsteps of Lenny Bruce. A Dukakis supporter, he has journeyed to Nicaragua several times and raised money to aid Nicaraguan children. He will be master of ceremonies of a show featuring Brett Butler, who discusses current affairs, and the nine-member improvisational troupe Noo Yawk Talk. Shows will be at midnight tonight and tomorrow. Tickets are $8. Reservations: 982-9292. Computer Antics Bill Coronel and Patty Rosborough, Stand-Up New York (236 West 78th Street). A dedicated disciple of late 80's high-tech culture, Bill Coronel bills himself as ''the computer comic.'' A computer expert who publishes his own magazine, he knows as much as any young humorist about the funny ways in which machines are taking over the world. Patty Rosborough, a comedian who uses props, employs paraphernalia that sometimes turns against her. One of her most popular routines involves adhesive tape that comes strangely and dangerously to life as she winds it around her body. The weekend's one late show is tomorrow at 12:30 A.M. There is a $12 cover charge and a two-drink minimum. Reservations: 595-0850. Urban Humor Rick Aviles, Caroline's at the Seaport, 89 South Street, at Pier 17 (233-9400). A former street performer, the raspy-voiced New York comedian Rick Aviles mines a rich vein of urban humor out of his experience of growing up Hispanic in New York. For the weekend's one late show, which starts promptly at midnight tomorrow, there is a $15 cover charge and a two-drink minimum. Modern Angst Ray Romano, Linda Hill and Liz White, the Comedy Elite, 2 Bond Street (260-1213). A warm observational humorist, Ray Romano was voted best comedy newcomer in Atlantic City last year, and much of his humor deals with the intricacies of modern relationships. Linda Hill, who made her name in San Francisco before moving to New York recently, has a rag-doll face and the manner of an ingenuous Martha Raye or Carol Burnett as she dissects contemporary life and love. Liz White is a waittress and comedian. Show time is 12:30 A.M. this evening, and there is a $10 cover charge. Halloween Sock Hop ''The Taffetas - A Musical Journey Through the Fabulous 50's,'' Cherry Lane Theater, 38 Commerce Street (989-2020). Patrons who attend tomorrow's 10 P.M. performance of this charming Off Broadway production wearing 50's period attire will be given a 25 percent discount off the regular ticket price and invited to a post-performance Halloween sock hop in the lobby. The party will be attended by the Taffetas, a fictional female quartet from Muncie, Ind., modeled after the Lennon Sisters, the McGuire Sisters and the Chordettes. Along with 50's music, there will be candied apples, cider and the dancing of the bunny hop. Pre-discount tickets are $32.50.

title: U.S. RELIEF EFFORT BLOCKED IN SUDAN
description: After two weeks of trying, the United States has been blocked from delivering food to a famine-stricken town in the southern Sudan where more than 8,000 people are reported to have died of starvation.

title: Boston Edison Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $10,965,000.

title: Cache Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said its 1987 results were adversely affected by its emergence from bankruptcy proceedings on Dec. 30, 1986.

title: Review/Ballet; The Joffrey, In a 'Lost' Balanchine
description: The Joffrey Ballet opened a three-week repertory season Wednesday night on a new note and with a revival of ''Cotillon,'' a so-called lost ballet by George Balanchine.

title: Benjamin Felson, 75, Interpreter of X-Rays
description: Dr. Benjamin Felson, an expert in interpreting X-rays who also taught and wrote about the use of radiology in diagnosing and treating diseases, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Cincinnati. He was 75 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is not a problem that has cropped up all of a sudden. It is a result of an unbalanced economy, of excessive subsidies, of huge losses caused by extensive management methods, parasitic attitudes and passive financial policy.'' - Finance Minister Boris I. Gostev on the Soviet budget deficit. [ A11:3. ]

title: Courts Expand the Rights of Unmarried Fathers
description: The courts, which have been granting more parental rights to fathers, are expanding their definition of paternity to include unmarried fathers who have traditionally been locked out of their children's upbringing.

title: CVN Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income c-Net loss Year-ago quarter and year results include an investment gain of $1.3 million, or 7 cents a share. Year-ago results are restated to the company's new fiscal reporting period. The company's annual financial reporting period was changed from a Dec. 31 calendar year to an Aug. 31 fiscal year, effective Aug. 31, 1987. The company said figures from 1988 include the full operating results of Cable Value Network, which became a wholly owned unit of CVN Co. on Aug. 31, 1987; prior to full ownership, financial results included only CVN's 50 percent equity interest in the joint venture.

title: Czechs Seize 5 Fleeing Poles
description: Five Poles who hid in a makeshift shelter beneath a foot-thick layer of coal dust on a freight train were discovered by Czechoslovak border guards before the train crossed the border into Austria, the official press reported today. Thursday. The men were detained at the Breclav train station, near the Austrian border, where the train's 25 carloads of coal were inspected before crossing into Austria, the agency said, providing no other details.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about New York City Police Department statistics on murder and manslaughter misstated the total for cases reported in July. The combined total of murders and cases of non-negligent manslaughter was 189. The combined monthly total last year was 148.

title: Banta, George Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter and 9-month sales include $55,000,000 and $100,000,000, respectively, from the acquisition of Beddor Cos., which was accounted for as a purchase effective April 1, 1988.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Signs of Settlement In Jockeys' Strike
description: You can't help feeling that a labor dispute is nearing its end when the strikers start passing around their picket signs like high school yearbooks, asking one another for autographs.

title: Layoffs Seen at Dean Witter
description: Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. is expected to announce large layoffs soon in its fixed-income department, people inside the firm said yesterday.

title: General Motors Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said its 1987 third quarter earnings benefited from depreciation and amortization accounting changes that were retroactive to the beginning of the year but recognized in the third quarter on a cumulative basis. Without those gains for the first two quarters, GM's 1987 third quarter net income would have been $1.05 a share.

title: Raychem Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Raychem said its Raynet subsidiary had a pre-tax loss in the latest first quarter of $10.7 million assuming Raychem's effective tax rate, compared with Raynet's pre-tax income of $4.4 million, or 9 cents a share, for the year-ago period.

title: Air Force Contract To McDonnell Unit
description: A unit of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation has been awarded a $421 million Air Force contract to train air crews for its new C-17 plane. The 15-year contract was awarded to McDonnell Douglas Training Systems Inc. of Bedford, Tex.

title: Officer Resigns At Bank Leu
description: Seven months after a management shake-up that followed two insider trading scandals, Switzerland's oldest bank, Bank Leu, has again lost its chief executive - this time over a personality clash.

title: Executive Succession Completed at Crossland
description: Maurice L. Reissman started his banking career in the subway and worked his way up to become president and chief executive of Crossland Savings, the nation's 11th-largest savings institution, and yesterday, he was named to the additional post of chairman.

title: Review/Theater; Dark Tale in Few Words
description: In Alberto Felix Alberto's dark, fantastic and virtually wordless play, ''Tango Varsoviano'' (Warsaw Tango), illusion and reality become so indistinguishable that every move its four characters make takes on the shadow of menace. The performance of this piece of intrigue - by the Teatro del Sur of Buenos Aires - at the Brooklyn Academy of Music as part of the Next Wave festival is as stylish as the tango itself.

title: Judith Epstein, Hadassah Official, 92
description: Judith Epstein, a former national president of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, died of a heart attack yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. She was 92 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Noah C. Barnhart Jr., Executive, 80
description: Noah Chisholm Barnhart Jr., a retired business executive, died Wednesday at the Winchester (Va.) Medical Center. He was 80 years old and lived in Winchester.

title: Aaron Rents Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter and 6 months revenues include $5.7 million and $11.1 million, respectively, from Ball Stalker Co. which was acquired on Oct. 1, 1987.

title: Review/Film; How a Star Was Born And What Produced Her
description: The moment of triumph depicted at the end of Kon Ichikawa's ''Film Actress,'' which opens today at the Carnegie Screening Room, isn't the sort of pinnacle Western audiences might expect. Though the film outlines the career of a legendary screen star, it involves no joyous acceptance speechs, no paper-thin displays of humility and no tributes from adoring fans.

title: Interface Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding results are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in September 1987.

description: The year-ago periods included a $852,000 charge for early extinguishment of debt.

title: Israelis Appear Immune To Comments by Arabs
description: No single event could better illustrate the polarized nature of Israeli society today than the extraordinary near-endorsements that Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader, has been getting from leaders of the Arab world, including Yasir Arafat of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: A Justice Holds Hearing on Issue Of Jews on Jury
description: In an unusual proceeding, a Queens prosecutor accused by a judge of excluding prospective jurors with Jewish surnames was called back to court yesterday by the judge to explain himself.

title: Bridge
description: The funniest deal in the World Team Olympiad, which ended Oct. 22 in Venice, was perhaps the one shown in the accompanying diagram. It was played in the quarterfinal match between India and Greece, and everyone was amused except the Greeks.

title: 50 Held in Prague Crackdown
description: Czechoslovakia's Communist authorities cracked down on dissent today, detaining more than 50 people and rejecting dialogue with dissidents on the 70th anniversary of national independence.

title: Bankers Defend Buyout Loans but Investors Fret; Merger Stocks Drop As Gains Are Taken
description: The stocks of companies subject to takeover bids fell sharply yesterday after the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, advised Congress to consider action that would limit the borrowing needed to complete the corporate takeovers.

title: Consolidated Edison Co of NY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a report by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith on neo-Nazi youths misstated the length of a conference the league held on hate crimes. It was one day, not five days.

title: 2 Islanders Are Injured in a Costly Loss
description: The Islanders didn't want to share the blame tonight after suffering through a 5-2 browbeating by the Flyers; each wanted to claim it for his own.

title: Campaign Trail; The No. 2 Man Gets A Great Big Hand
description: The normally taciturn Lloyd Bentsen grinned with delight and spoke with exuberance. The Secret Service was nervous. The Bentsen entourage was amazed.

title: TW Services Holders To Get Coniston Bid
description: Coniston Partners L.P., eager to repair its image as a serious contender for takeovers, said yesterday that it would take a $29-a-share offer to the shareholders of TW Services Inc.

title: Indictment Is Elusive in a 1986 Slaying
description: One afternoon last April, a headless body turned up on the banks of the Hudson River at the northern tip of Manhattan. Four months later, medical examiners identified it as that of Rita Fioretti, a 35-year-old mother of two who mysteriously disappeared in the summer of 1986 from her home on City Island.

title: 2 Arts Groups to Use Old Ferry House
description: Two experimental arts groups were named yesterday as the future occupants of a mini-cultural center to be created in a landmark turn-of-the-century ferry dock in Battery Park. The cultural center, to be called the South Ferry Arts Center, is to be part of the $400 million South Ferry Plaza redevelopment project.

title: Westinghouse Agrees to a Sale
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation signed an agreement to sell its elevator and escalator business to Schindler Holding A.G. of Switzerland. The deal, for which terms were not disclosed, must be approved by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Giants Are Aiming To Tighten Defense
description: For years, the Giants have been known for their defense. Two seasons ago, defense was largely responsible for getting them to the Super Bowl and for winning there. But this season, it has been struggling.

title: Sonat Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $13,130,000 from an accounting change. c-After net from discontinued operations of $301,000 for the quarter and $25,625,000 for the 9 months.

title: Aide to Reagan Praises Peace Moves by Soviet
description: President Reagan's national security adviser praised the Soviet Union today for playing a ''constructive role'' recently in settling regional conflicts. But he said the United States could encourage the trend only if it exerted continuing pressure in areas like Central America where military conflicts continue.

title: Circle Journal; Farm Town Uproar: The Doctor Vanishes
description: The townspeople knew it would not be easy to attract a doctor to a remote community of 600 people in the high plains of eastern Montana.

title: G.M. Recalling 750,000 Cars
description: The General Motors Corporation has begun recalling nearly 750,000 1984-model cars and trucks bearing Chevrolet, Pontiac and G.M.C. nameplates to replace a defective switch in the pollution control system, the Environmental Protection Agency said today. A defective switch can cause excessive emissions of carbon monoxide and unburned gasoline. The models affected are the Chevrolet Impala, Caprice Classic, Camaro, Monte Carlo and El Camino; the Pontiac Firebird, Bonneville, Grand Prix and Parisienne and the G.M.C. Caballero.

Washington Talk: Briefing; Temporary Help Wanted
description: In a departure from longstanding practice, the Office of Personnel Management wants to revise Federal hiring regulations so that Government agencies may call in temporary help in peak periods and emergencies.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Exports: 'No Exceptions'
description: Despite recent improvements in East-West relations, senior Reagan Administration officials say they are not about to ease controls on strategic exports to the Soviet Union.

description: Following are excerpts from an interview on Wednesday with Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, Mikhail S. Gorbachev's closest Kremlin associate, as translated by The New York Times. The interviewer's questions are included in some instances. Stalinism

title: Review/Opera; 'Barbiere di Siviglia'
description: Rossini's ''Barbiere di Siviglia'' is one of a handful of nearly perfect operas. Not that it is surefire or indestructible. Anything but. Few operas are easier to destroy with slapstick comedy, for instance. Rossini's wittiest effects grow directly out of his score and need to be treated as musical jokes in the best sense, not vaudeville turns applied to the surface of the work. Still, the results in this most effervescent of operatic comedies should be - how to put it? - comic.

title: Dining Before Dawn: Bistro Fare and Pasta
description: The city that never sleeps is also the city that never stops munching. Yet finding a good place to dine - not just to snack - after midnight takes some research. Most restaurant kitchens close between 11 and midnight. To my mind, nothing ruins a meal more than seeing waiters flip chairs onto tables and cleaning crews mopping up. Here are some suggestions for those times when midnight and hunger strike simultaneously. Brasserie This sprawling, utilitarian-looking spot in the Seagram Building is one of the few restaurants in the city open 24 hours. The food is not exceptional, but much of it is satisfying: the best options are the steak with french fries, the chicken paillard with herb butter (insist that they don't overcook it), soups and salads. A three-course meal runs anywhere from $20 and up. If you are in a rush, sit at the counter. (At 100 East 53d Street, 751-4840. Serves 24 hours daily.) Cafe Luxembourg A stylish and reliable spot, Cafe Luxembourg is the place to go in the Lincoln Center area. The scene around midnight is much more colorful than the early-evening crowd of straitlaced opera and symphonygoers. American bistro food is the specialty here, and you can rely on the roasted leg of lamb, grilled seafood and roast duck: daily specials are usually good, too. Pastas are risky. A three-course dinner runs between $35 and $45. (At 200 West 70th Street, 873-7411. Dinner served 5:30 P.M. to 12:30 A.M. weekdays, until 1:30 A.M. Friday and Saturday.) Carnegie Deli If you are the type who can sleep soundly after consuming a sandwich the size of a softball, head over to the Carnegie Deli for a pastrami or corned beef on rye, with sour pickles, of course. After midnight seems to be about the only time there are not lines outside this renowned New York institution. Sandwiches run about $8 to $9. Many of the waiters are gruff old-timers who may crack a smile if you manage to clean your plate, then ask, ''What's for dessert?'' (At 854 Seventh Avenue, at 55th Street, 757-2245. Serves from 6 A.M. to 4 A.M. daily.) Corner Bistro This is a good little spot to recuperate with a bowl of chili or a fat hamburger on the way home: and it's possible to eat for as little as $10, including a few beers. It is a cozy spot with high-backed wooden booths and a long mahogany bar where a neighborhood crowd hangs out. The brick-walled back room has a bohemian charm. I usually go for the fist-thick bistro burger, which is wrapped in bacon and topped with tomato and lettuce. It comes with a stack of terrific steak fries ($4.75). (At 331 West Fourth Street, 242-9502. Serves 11:30 A.M. to 4 A.M. daily except Sunday when service begins at noon.) Mezzogiorno This playful Italian trattoria is related to Mezzaluna, and the pastas and brick-oven pizzas are just as good. The setting, though, is considerably larger here, with a long marble-topped bar and cafe tables running along white-paned windows. The pizza oven cranks up at 10 P.M. Before that, you can get such well-made specialties as orecchiette with sausage and fennel; tagliolini with shrimp, arugula and tomato; gnocchi with shredded basil; homemade ravioli with changing fillings, and whole-wheat pasta with tomato (entrees are about $12 to $14).

title: G.O.P. Already Speculating About Top Positions in a Bush Administration
description: With the final days before the Presidential election ticking away, the confident campaign of Vice President Bush is busy with jockeying and guessing over who will fill the top slots in the Bush Administration.

Federated Offering Is Being Revised
description: Faced with disgruntled potential investors, the Campeau Corporation and its main investment banker, the First Boston Corporation, acknowledged that a $1.15 billion high-yield bond financing for Federated Department Stores, a Campeau subsidiary, is being restructured.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Daimler-Benz A.G., Stuttgart, West Germany, has abandoned plans to produce light commercial vehicles with the Mitsubishi Motors Corp., Tokyo, in Europe.

title: Saga of a Waste Cleanup: 12 Years and Counting
description: For 12 years, the Environmental Protection Agency tried first to persuade and then to force the owners to clean up a chemical production plant that the agency rates as one of the most dangerous hazardous waste sites in the country.

title: On the Jersey City Docks, Wall St. West
description: Around Wall Street, Bankers Trust seemed more like a bunch of gamblers than a band of conservative financiers when officials decided three years ago to start moving parts of the bank's operations to the desolate Jersey City docks.

description: b-After a loss of $42 million for the quarter and income of $48 million for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and after a loss of $101 million for the quarter; the 9 months was after a loss of $124 million from discontinued operations.

description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect 1988 pooling of interests acquisitions.

title: AMCA International Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the year-ago quarter and in both the latest 9-month and year-ago periods.

title: McDonnell Douglas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said disposition of its interest in a health maintenance organization contributed a pre-tax gain of $26 million to the latest third quarter results. However, that gain was fully offset by costs of a restructuring program. The results for the year-ago quarter included a pre-tax gain of $15 million from the sale of holdings in a computer services company.

title: Riding Shotgun on Gorbachev's Glasnost Express: Aleksandr N. Yakovlev
description: One day in 1959 a Russian exchange student named Aleksandr N. Yakovlev popped into a store on lower Broadway in New York to buy a briefcase.

title: Holder Sues Lotus On Product Delay
description: The Lotus Development Corporation is being sued on charges of securities fraud involving delays in an upgraded version of its Lotus 1-2-3 speadsheet program. The suit contends that Lotus and two directors ''disseminated false and misleading information'' about the delivery of the Release 3 product. The suit was filed in Federal District Court here last week by a shareholder, Matthew J. Berliner, on behalf of those who bought Lotus stock between Feb. 25 and Oct. 7.

title: Jewish Book Festival at 7th Regiment Armory
description: Soft covers, hard covers and undercovers will pop up in profusion as the Jewish Heritage Book Festival speaks volumes Sunday and Monday at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 67th Street.

title: Metro-North Police Captain Charged in Tapping of Phone
description: A Metro-North police captain, a central figure in a sweeping state investigation of corruption in the railroad's police operations, was charged yesterday with illegally monitoring and recording a phone call by a subordinate.

title: Under All That Mud in New Jersey
description: The race between Frank Lautenberg and Pete Dawkins has frequently looked more like mud-wrestling than a contest for the U.S. Senate from New Jersey. Wipe away the mud and neither candidate is as hideous as his opponent suggests. Mr. Dawkins is a man of charm and impressive accomplishments - almost a Jack Armstrong come to life. But his promise does not justify replacing Senator Lautenberg, who exemplifies another American ideal - the self-made man. The incumbent has compiled a solid, if unspectacular, record in his first term. He deserves another.

title: Shirley Temple: Celebrity or Generic Term?
description: For more than 50 years the sweet pink Shirley Temple ''cocktail'' of lemon-lime soda and grenadine syrup topped with a maraschino cherry has been served in restaurants as a nonalcoholic treat for children. It was invented in the 1930's at the Brown Derby restaurant in Hollywood and named in honor of the child star.

title: Cuomo Presses For Bond Issue On Long Island
description: Governor Cuomo, campaigning for a $3.1 billion transportation bond issue, warned today that the New York budget deficit next year might be worse than the $1.8 billion shortfall he inherited from Gov. Hugh L. Carey in 1983.

title: Andover Controls Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 18
Review/Film; Art Blakey's Pep Talk, With Music
description: ''The bandstand is the only place I got to go in this world,'' says the drummer Art Blakey. ''If I don't get there, I'm dead.'' He's giving a new band of Jazz Messengers a pep talk, alternately fatherly and hard-nosed, in one of the most telling sequences of ''Art Blakey: The Jazz Messenger,'' a documentary that has its New York premiere tonight and tomorrow at Film Forum 2 as part of its Jazz Film Festival.

title: Dining Guide: Neighborhood
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Anatolia

title: Japan's Sensitivity on Rice Issue
description: When Emperor Hirohito awoke from his sickbed one morning a few weeks ago and asked whether this year's rice harvest was good, the Japanese rice lobby seized on the comments to buttress its argument that rice still carries mystical significance to the Japanese people.

title: Backers of Whistleblower Bill Upset
description: Congressional leaders of both parties sharply attacked President Reagan and the Justice Department today over the President's decision to pocket veto legislation to protect Federal workers who expose fraud and corruption in Government.

title: 10 Are Rescued As Boat Capsizes
description: All 10 crew members of the racing yacht Blue Arrow, owned by Peter de Savery of England, were rescued today after the boat capsized, authorities said.

title: After-Midnight Excursions for Night Owls
description: FOR New York night owls, the hours after midnight are not a somnolent period between dusk and daybreak. Instead, this borderline between days represents the gateway to an exotic landscape filled with smoky jazz clubs and brash discotheques, stylish restaurants and quirky all-night haunts.

title: Sports People; Shoemaker to Retire
description: Bill Shoemaker, thoroughbred racing's most successful jockey, says he will retire at the end of 1989. ''It's time,'' said Shoemaker, who is 57 years old and in his 40th year of riding. ''One more year is enough. I don't want to be a hanger-on.'' Shoemaker told the Los Angeles Daily News on Wednesday that he was laying the groundwork for a series of appearances at tracks around the world in his final year. He has won 8,781 races and his mounts have won more than $121 million. Laffit Pincay Jr. is second in career victories, with 6,989. He has won the Kentucky Derby four times, including in 1986 aboard Ferdinand, which made him the oldest jockey to win the event. He has won the Belmont Stakes five times and the Preakness twice.(AP)

title: Cornelius Vanderbilt 3d Is Stabbed to Death
description: Cornelius Vanderbilt 3d, a descendant of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt, was found stabbed to death in his home on Staten Island yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Thompson Will Handle Account for 7-Eleven
description: The Southland Corporation's 7-Eleven Stores yesterday awarded its account, reportedly worth more than $12 million in annual billings, to J. Walter Thompson, Chicago. Hill Holliday Connors Cosmopulos, New York, had been the agency of record until late July.

title: Even the East Reflects The Western Heritage
description: To the Editor:

title: TGI Friday's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Results Plus
description: Golf Lohr Sets Mark: Bob Lohr shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday for a 36-hole tournament record of 129 and a three-shot lead at the halfway point in the $700,000 Walt Disney World Classic in Lake Buena Vista, Fla. Robert Wrenn missed three birdie putts of 6 feet or less but still shot his second 66 and was alone in second. Fuzzy Zoeller overcame a drive into the water that resulted in a double bogey but shot 69 and was third another stroke back. Lohr, looking for his first PGA victory, bettered Chip Beck's 1984 36-hole total by one stroke. The defending champion Larry Nelson had the day's low round, 63, and was at 135.(AP) Pair Tied for Lead: The U.S. Masters champion Sandy Lyle of Scotland and the British Open winner Seve Ballesteros of Spain each had seven birdies en route to 4-under-par 68s yesterday and shared the opening round lead in the $963,00 Volvo Masters tournament in Sotogrande, Spain.(AP) Tennis McEnroe Advances: John McEnroe advanced to the quarterfinals of the Paris Open yesterday by defeating Paul Annacone, 6-3, 6-2.

title: Board Backs Prison Barge Near Pier 40
description: The Board of Estimate early today approved a plan to moor a 386-bed prison barge in the Hudson River at Pier 40 in Greenwich Village, overriding the strong objections of community groups and elected officials who called the barge idea ludicrous and dangerous.

title: Dart Drug Account To Earle Palmer Brown
description: The Earle Palmer Brown Companies, Bethesda, Md., has won the account of Dart Drug Stores Inc. over three agencies. The budget is $7.5 million.

title: For Children
description: Halloween Activities HALLOWEEN AT OLD WESTBURY GARDENS, with hayrides, pumpkin painting and shows by Magic Al, noon to 5 P.M. Sunday. Children must be dressed in Halloween costumes and accompanied by an adult. At the gardens, Old Westbury Road, between the Long Island Expressway and Jericho Turnpike. Admission: $10 per adult and child, which includes the hayride, one show performance and one pumpkin per child. Reservations and information: (516) 333-0048. HALLOWEEN COSTUME PARTY, a program with Madeline the Magician, games and other entertainment and a bake sale, 2 P.M. tomorrow, at the Jack and Jill School, St. George's Church, 209 East 16th Street. Admission: $3. Information: 475-0855. PACKER PUMPKIN PATCH COUNTY FAIR, with a parade featuring children from the Packer Collegiate Institute of Brooklyn, down Montague Street, noon today. From 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. tomorrow, a fair will offer games and other entertainment, including a new six-foot inflatable pumpkin character, at the institute, 170 Joralemon Street. Information: (718) 875-6644. NEW YORK GHOSTS, an hourlong drama, featuring witch and ghost tales from earlier times by three actors from Stories Inc., will be presented for ages 5 to 15, who may wear costumes, 3:30 P.M. Monday, at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West. Admission: children, $3; adults, $5; includes refreshments. Reservations required: 873-3400.

title: A Gala Tribute Amid the Sweaters
description: There are, among others, the roses of Picardy, the rose that's a rose that's a rose and the last rose of summer. But for the past dozen years, when autumn rolls around and there is a nip in the New York air and tweedy clothes in shop windows, the VIP of roses has been Lord & Taylor's Rose Award. Actually not a real rose, the award is a crystal prism etched with the flower and presented by the store to a celebrity deemed worthy of the honor.

title: NATO Prepares for a Debate On Nuclear Arms in Europe
description: Sidestepping anti-missile concerns in member countries, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's nuclear planners prepared the ground today for a long-delayed debate on the future of nuclear weapons in Europe. The debate could be in the spring. The Nuclear Planning Group of the alliance, which meets every six months, ended its fall session with a noncommittal communique reaffirming the strategy of nuclear deterrence coupled with negotiations with the Soviet bloc on arms control. The next session will be held in Brussels.

title: 5 1/2 Tons of Cocaine Seized
description: Army troops on a training mission discovered nearly five and a half tons of cocaine in a cave in the Sierra Madre, a military official said today. The official said the troops found the cocaine on Thursday near Buenaventura, 120 miles north of Chihuahua, the capital of this northern state, which borders on the United States. The seizure was called the largest in Mexico.

title: Along the Elbe With the Soviet Army
description: The river at Sandau is eight feet deep, with a moderate current. Soviet armored units practiced crossing the river under simulated fire from an imaginary enemy in Warsaw Pact military maneuvers here the other day.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article yesterday reported on results of Wednesday's local elections in South Africa and on their implications for the ruling party. The article noted that the elections were open to all races. It also said President P. W. Botha and his National Party might be forced to seek the support of mixed-race and Indian voters in a future general election to compensate for the ruling party's loss of support among Afrikaner voters.

Tennis
description: Hlasek Upsets McEnroe: John McEnroe was upset by Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland, 7-6, 2-6, 7-6, last night in the quarterfinals of the $1.1 million Paris Open. McEnroe set off an uproar in the decisive third set, arguing that a serve by Hlasek tipped the net and persuading the tournament supervisor to overrule the chair umpire. The controversial play came on break point, with the score tied at 2-2. In other quarterfinal matches, Amos Mansdorf of Israel defeated Aaron Krickstein of the United States, 6-3, 7-6, and Tim Mayotte and Brad Gilbert of the United States advanced to the semifinals with straight-set victories.(AP) Shriver Reaches Semifinals: Pam Shriver advanced to the semifinals of the Midland Group championships yesterday in Brighton, England, Shriver beat Sylvia Hanika of West Germany, 7-5, 6-2. In the semifinals, she will meet Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria, who beat Sandra Cecchini of Italy, 6-3, 6-2. Steffi Graf of West Germany defeated Natalie Tauziat of France, 6-3, 6-2, for her 42d consecutive victory.(AP) Cross-Country Dartmouth Triumphs: Greg Whiteley of Brown, who was ninth last year, won the Heptagonal Games Association championship in 24 minutes 50.6 seconds yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. Whiteley, a senior, finished 60 yards ahead of Michael Donoghu, who crossed the finish line in 25:04.3 to lead Dartmouth to a second straight team title with 26 points. Dartmouth placed its five runners among the top nine finishers to outdistance the field of 10 schools. Brown was second with 75 points. Sarah P. Smith, the runner-up last year, was the winner in the women's 5,000-meter run in 17:26.9 to help Yale defend its team title with 39 points. Horse Show Victory for Monte Carlo: Monte Carlo, owned by Lancer Farms and Mary Tyng of Beverly Hills, Calif., won the $3,500 Intermediate Jumper Stake yesterday in the Washington International Horse Show at the Capital Centre in Landover, Md. Monte Carlo, ridden by Tyng, was among six horses jumping clearly to advance from the original field of 26. The jump-off was over eight fences, after the course had been shortened from 10. The winner was the only horse to go without faults and was clocked in 39.786 seconds. Ashley and Courtney Kennedy, sisters from Orlando, Fla., shared honors as owner and rider in two classes. Courtney rode Lyrik, owned by Ashley, to victory in a Large Working Hunter class. Ashely showed Mind Games, owned by her sister, in the next Large Working Hunter class and won the event. The United States leads in the team standing with 52 points. France is second with 24 points.(AP) Golf Lohr Takes Lead: Bob Lohr shot a six-under-par 66 yesterday at the Walt Disney World Classic in Lake Buena Vista, Fla., to take a two-stroke lead after three rounds. Lohr, with a 21-under-par 196 after 54 holes, needs a 65 in the final round today to break the PGA Tour record for most shots under par. The record for a 72-hole tournament, 27 under, was set by Ben Hogan in the 1945 Portland Invitational and tied by Mike Souchak in the 1955 Texas Open.(AP) N.H.L. Red Wings 4, North Stars 1: Steve Chiasson and Miroslav Frycer scored 49 seconds apart early in the second period last night as Detroit, playing at home, extended Minnesota's losing streak to four games. Also scoring for the Red Wings were Gerard Gallant and John Chabot. Dave Gagner scored for the North Stars.(AP) N.B.A. Bulls 117, Nets 87: Michael Jordan scored 20 points to lead the Bulls to the exhibition victory. Chicago jumped to a 23-6 lead. The Nets trailed by 20 after one quarter and by 68-33 at the half. Chris Morris, a rookie from Auburn, was the Nets' top scorer with 15 points. The first N.B.A. exhibition game in Lincoln, Neb., since 1974 was played before a sellout crowd of 14,846 at the Bob Devaney Sports Center.(AP)

description: Martin Wattenberg wasn't surprised when Vice President Bush surged ahead of his Democratic rival, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, immediately after the Republican convention, opening a sizable lead that he has maintained ever since, Mr. Wattenberg had been expecting something like that all along.

title: Bush Distorts Economic Facts. . .
description: ''Practical politics'' wrote the historian Henry Adams some 80 years ago ''consists in ignoring the facts.'' George Bush is some practical politician. When he's not railing about flags and furloughs he's playing fast and loose with the facts. He unabashedly informs us that the national economy has prospered almost miraculously under the Reagan-Bush Administration while Massachusetts has stagnated under Gov. Michael S. Dukakis. The truth is quite the opposite. Our economic future has been mortgaged over the last eight years to create a present that is much grimmer than George Bush allows. He crows that family incomes have risen but omits the primary reason why -the entrance into the labor force of millions of second earners who are forced to work to support their families.

title: POSTAL YULETIDE
description: It's not a moment too soon to start thinking about airmailing Christmas gifts and cards abroad. For packages, fill out customs forms and make sure the contents, however innocent they seem, are legally acceptable at the destination. Insure gifts only for what they are worth. Keep the receipt; the Postal Service does not. Maximum mailing weight varies, but for most countries it is 44 pounds. Check before you wrap. Boxes should be strudy. The Post Office sells avariety of sizes. Department store give boxes should be packed in stronger cartons. Put the recipient's name and address inside the box on a separate piece of paper. Seal with heavy-duty tape. Do not wrap in paper or use maksing tape or Scotch tape; all of these can tear in automatic processing machines. Address the package clarly on one side only. The sender's name and address should be in the upper lefthand corner - that is a Postal Service requirement. For surfac mail, Nov. 4 is the deadline for gifts and cards to reach Europe, Central and south America, and the Caribbean in time for Christmas. For airmail, here is a guide to the last dates for Christmas presents: Destination Deadline Deadline Letters, Parcel s Cards Southeast Asia Nov. 21 Nov. 21 Australia Nov. 21 Nov. 24 Middle East Nov. 21 Nov. 24 Africa Nov. 21 Dec. 1 Europe Dec. 2 Dec. 2 Far East Dec. 2 Dec. 2 Central and South America Dec. 5 Dec. 5 Caribbean Dec. 9 Dec. 9 Source: United States Postal Service

CSX had initially planned to buy back 40 million common shares, or about 26 percent of shares outstanding. The offer expired on Oct. 18. CSX said it would pay stockholders $32 for each of the 43.1 million shares.

title: Bonn's Useful Business in Moscow
description: Western leaders never feel comfortable about a West German leader visiting Moscow. They fear the Soviet Union's embrace will lure Bonn from its anchor in the West. But Chancellor Helmut Kohl can claim success in his four-day stay: he demonstrated support for Mikhail Gorbachev's moving his country along more moderate and hopeful lines, and he did so without breaking faith with the Western alliance.

title: Noranda Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $36 million gain on the sale of its stake in Polysar Energy & Chemical Corp. Figures are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Reviews/Film; Plot Twists, Into a Lake
description: ''I saw Jimmy,'' says Wade, the cute young handyman at snowy Wolf Lodge. ''He's in the lake. He's frozen and dead.'' Yes, he's frozen and dead, says the none-too-bright Wade, with all the excitement of someone who has just found his misplaced car keys instead of the previous cute young handyman. ''Into the Fire'' tries to heat up ''The Postman Always Rings Twice'' - a truly perverse idea -with quadruple plot twists about who's murdering whom for the insurance money. It adds bloody deaths and prophetic nightmares, so that everything seems too blunt, almost baroque, except for the listless acting.

title: Police Attack Protesters at Prague Demonstration
description: About 5,000 people defied the authorities by rallying in Wenceslas Square today to demand political change and greater freedom on the 70th anniversary of Czechoslovak independence. They shouted ''Shame!'' and ''Gestapo!'' at police officers who dispersed them with clubs and water cannons.

description: J. R. Reid, the all-America junior forward at the University of North Carolina, had a pin inserted in his left foot yesterday as part of surgery to repair a stress fracture of the fifth metatarsal bone that he aggravated during the Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea. He is expected to be sidelined for about eight weeks, said Dr. Timothy Taft, who performed the operation.(AP)

Hewlett-Packard's instrumentation group remained unchanged as well.

title: American Held in Drug Case Will Be Sent Home by Spain
description: An American freelance photographer who was convicted earlier this year in Spain on drug-trafficking charges will be returned to the United States in a prisoner exchange, the Justice Department said today. The plight of the photographer, Conan Owen of Annandale, Va., had received extensive publicity in the United States, especially after former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d made a plea on Mr. Owen's behalf.

title: CoastAmerica Tie To American Hoist
description: The CoastAmerica Corporation, a hardware retailer, agreed to be acquired by the American Hoist and Derrick Company in a $110 million deal. The merger will create the fifth-largest United States hardware distribution business, with more than over $800 million in annual sales.

title: George Wallace's Mother
description: Mozelle Wallace, mother of former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, died at her home in Montgomery Thursday after an extended illness. She was 90 years old. Mrs. Wallace, a former county health worker, is survived by the former Governor and three other children, Gerald Wallace, Jack Wallace and Mary Ann Dauphin.

title: Jersey Focuses On Tight Race For Congress
description: The race between two experienced officeholders to succeed the late James J. Howard as representative from the 3d Congressional District along New Jersey's northern shore is shaping up as the closest of the state's 14 House contests.

title: Dukakis, in Fiery Michigan Rally, Demands Atom Plant Safeguards
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis today assailed safety lapses at the Department of Energy's nuclear production plants, and aides asserted that his new aggressiveness was building momentum for his underdog campaign.

But consumption of light beers and wine-juice coolers has surged.

''It's a very tough market,'' he said, adding that he had been selling about 8,000 copies a month. Mr. Himoff founded the tabloid-size magazine in February 1986 with Andrew Kaskel, the associate publisher.

title: Drawing Time, Setting Back and Marching On
description: At the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, in Manhattan, there is a giant clock with a milk-glass face set high on the south wall. Twice a day its sugar pine hands sweep a circle of Roman numerals, moved by an elegant mechanism on display on the school's top floor. In the evenings the landmark tower is lighted from within and the timepiece, which dates from 1859, glows like a great autumn moon, visible as far as the Brooklyn Bridge.

description: As roads have become increasingly clogged with commuters driving to work, car pools have become a fact of life. According to the Census Bureau, 22 percent of all commuters, some 18 million people, share rides to work.

The Islanders learned that Dean Chynoweth, whose left eye was gouged in a fight with Rick Tocchet, had suffered bleeding within the eye and bruises above, beside and below it.

Few Americans dispute the importance of a common tongue; an open society thrives on open communication, and economic opportunity in America depends on knowing English. But to require it smacks of discrimination.

Schroeder has five years in the major leagues and can make that demand. If he doesn't withdraw it and isn't traded by March 15, he becomes a free agent. But if he doesn't withdraw the demand, he would not be eligible for free agency for three more years.

Reagan Signs Radon Bill
description: President Reagan signed legislation today calling for a three-year, $15.5 million program to deal with radon contamination in schools and Federal buildings. The bill provides for $10 million for grants to state and local governments, $3 million for seminars and information activities, $1.5 million for rating the proficiency of radon abatement programs and $1 million for development of eradication centers. An additional $1.5 million is provided for a study of contamination in schools.

title: 3 Retailing Chains Expect Strong Holiday Sales
description: The heads of three of American retailing's largest chains, the K Mart Corporation, the Dayton Hudson Corporation and Toys 'R' Us Inc., said yesterday that they expected strong sales this Christmas season and a healthy gain in fourth-quarter profits over 1987.

title: Article 615288 -- No Title
description: A West German trading group, Kloeckner & Company, which announced up to $380 million in oil trading losses earlier this month, said today that the country's largest bank would give it 400 million West German marks ($225 million) to help it recover.

title: Hussein Bows Out
description: Ibrahim Hussein, winner of the New York City Marathon last year, will not be able to defend his title in the race Nov. 6. Fred Lebow, the race director, said that Hussein decided he was not in shape to compete after dropping out of the Olympic marathon Oct. 2 in Seoul, South Korea. Also withdrawing was Pat Petersen, who has been the top American finisher three times.

Judge Rebuffs Ex-Governor
description: A Superior Court judge has rejected former Gov. Edward J. King's request for a new trial in his unsuccessful libel suit against The Boston Globe. The judge, James P. Lynch Jr., said he denied the motion Monday.

title: FRANCE ORDERING COMPANY TO SELL ITS ABORTION DRUG
description: Saying it was acting in the interests of public health, the French Government today ordered a French company to resume distribution of a new abortion-inducing drug two days after the company took it off the market because of pressure from anti-abortion groups.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''From the moment Government approval for the drug was granted, RU 486 became the moral property of women, not just the property of the drug company.'' - Claude Evin,France's Minister of Health. [ 1:6. ]

title: Review/Music; The Philharmonic, With Leppard as Guest
description: The latest in this season's guest conductors at the New York Philharmonic is Raymond Leppard, the British conductor who has moved much of his activity to this country and who is now music director at the Indianapolis Symphony.

The opera is Jack Beeson's ''My Heart's in the Highlands,'' receiving its first full-length, staged performances during this run.

title: Terrell Traded
description: The Detroit Tigers traded the pitcher Walt Terrell to the San Diego Padres for the infielders Chris Brown and Keith Moreland yesterday and announced that they would not offer a contract to Darrell Evans for next season.

title: Army Contract
description: The Army has selected a contractor team to develop the engine that will power its next generation of helicopters. The service said it was awarding the engine contract to the Light Helicopter Turbine Engine Company, a partnership formed by the Allison gas turbine division of the General Motors Corporation and the Garrett engine division of the Allied-Signal Aerospace Company. That partnership was selected over another competing team, known as APW, formed by the Pratt & Whitney division of the United Technologies Corporation and Lycoming of Textron Inc.

Florida City Settles Rights Suit
description: A couple accepted a $220,000 settlement Wednesday, ending a four-year, $7 million suit charging that New Port Richey officials harassed them and tried to run them out of town.

title: Polaroid Battle With Shamrock
description: Polaroid, which is fighting a $2.4 billion takeover offer from Shamrock Holdings, contended in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission that Shamrock had failed to advise investors adequately of its plans. The camera company cited memorandums prepared in January 1988 by Wertheim Schroder & Company, one of Shamrock's financial advisers. The memorandums describe various options for Shamrock, including the possible sale of Polaroid's camera manufacturing business.

He argues that the economy -which has been going gangbusters on almost every front - is not doing well at all. William Diaz, 34 years old, was sentenced to finish two years on an old robbery sentence and then to serve at least six more before he reapplies for parole.

He could not be more grateful to the Giants for hiring him or to the Philadelphia Eagles for keeping him for four years before they discarded him.

title: Sharpton and 15 Others Arrested in Court Scuffle
description: Sixteen people, including the Rev. Al Sharpton and the lawyers William M. Kunstler and C. Vernon Mason, were arrested Friday after a confrontation between demonstrators who refused to clear a Brooklyn courtroom and court officers, the police said yesterday.

description: New York State will distribute food stamps in supermarkets beginning later this week as part of a pilot program intended to make redeeming the coupons easier.

title: Night Games
