title: NEW ENGLANDERS UNDERSTAND THE IMPORTANCE OF TREES
description: YOU do not have to live in Connecticut to love trees. I loved them long before I moved here as a child. Even then I had certain trees that were special to me.

title: Oz for the Space Age  E.T. THE EXTRA-TERRESTRIAL  Starring Dee Wallace, Henry Thomas (in photo), Peter Coyote, Robert Macnaughton, Drew Barrymore. Directed by Steven Spielberg. 1982.  MCA Home Video.  115 minutes. $24.95. Closed captioned. Rated PG. Contains occasional rude language.
description: E.T. has taken much longer to get to home video than to get home. But the alien, marooned on a strange planet, is still civilized and learned, patient and gentle, as he is befriended by 10-year-old Elliott.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our 63-year-old house was reshingled 11 years ago. The shingles were coated with a good brand of gray shingle stain. Two sides of the house have now started to mildew (south and west). We have been told that this condition will not clear up even when the humid weather ends. Can you advise us as to what we can do?

title: MR. NICE GUY
description: BOB KNIGHT His Own Man. By Joan Mellen. Illustrated. 286 pp. New York: Donald I. Fine. $17.95.

title: New Road in Delaware Collides With a Cemetery
description: Perusing the legal notices in the local newspaper recently, Edward W. Heite, an archeologist from Camden, Del., made a discovery that excited him. The state of Delaware was looking for the descendants of Robert Graham, believed to have been buried in 1813 in a cemetery of unmarked graves.

title: In England, Beat the Clock
description: BONG! It usually takes the clock in the Great Court of Trinity College at Cambridge University in England about 46 seconds to strike all 24 chimes that mark high noon.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE BREAKTHROUGH: The Race for the Superconductor. By Robert M. Hazen. (Summit, $18.95.) Early 1987 was a time of excitement in science labs around the world. With the discovery of superconductors - electrical conductors that could operate free of resistance at temperatures warm enough to make practical applications conceivable - the world of physics snapped to attention. Robert M. Hazen, a physicist who collaborated with another physicist, Paul Chu, explains both the methods and ramifications of obtaining superconductors in ''The Breakthrough.'' However, the most fascinating aspect of the book relates to the cloak-and-dagger aspects of the research. The discoveries were scientifically important - Nobel prizes were virtually guaranteed, but to whom? - and scientists and institutions that patented practical superconductors would certainly become wealthy. The race to be first engendered jealousies, Mr. Hazen says, discussing widespread suspicions of industrial and academic spying. Most fascinating of all are his accounts of Mr. Chu's obsessiveness. He modestly insisted that his name appear as the last author on some work, yet Mr. Hazen shows that at a critical time Mr. Chu almost certainly doctored up his own formula in drafts of an article, so that his results could not be duplicated and exploited. Mr. Hazen's account comes strictly from personal experience; he was not even sure at the time which other laboratories were doing comparable research. A more annoying weakness is the author's holier-than-other-scientists attitude. Pledged to silence by Mr. Chu, Mr. Hazen wrings his hands over the unaccustomed secrecy and is naively appalled by scientists who demonstrate human failings.

title: Seasonal Pointers
description: LAST call to plant peonies; be sure to select a sunny location where the soil drains well. Finish bulb planting; daffodils should be in the ground as well as crocus and hyacinths. Move plants of questionable winter hardiness into coldframes. It is still too early to apply winter mulches; wait until at least after Thanksgiving. Bulb Feeding

title: From China, Remembrances of Great Minds Lost
description: Over the last 10 years, China's intellectuals have visibly if slowly shaken off the effects of decades of re-education and imprisonment, public humiliation and private despair.

title: Blind Seating
description: To the Editor:

title: West Va. Routs Penn State
description: Years of frustration against archrival Penn State were forgotten by exuberant West Virginia players and fans today when the undefeated Mountaineers trounced the Nittany Lions, 51-30, with a record-high score before a record Mountaineer Field crowd of 66,811. And it was all witnessed by a national television audience.

title: Richard Broomer Weds Miss Kelly
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Joseph Kelly of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathleen Anne Kelly to Richard Jeffrey Broomer, a son of Fay Broomer of Ossining, N.Y., and the late Cyril J. Broomer. A January wedding is planned.

title: A Farmer's Obsession: Reviving Jersey Breed
description: LEAD: DALE, Bonnie, Glitter and Beatrice all immediately recognize him. Even in a shirt and tie, Max Spann clearly is at home in his dairy barn, showing a visitor his Jersey herd.

title: Letting Computers Lend a High-Tech Helping Hand
description: COMPUTERS are now helping with the dirty work of the job hunt, from addressing letters and tracking contacts to rewriting resumes.

title: Man Is Found Hanging in a Subway Station
description: A man believed to be a psychiatric patient was found hanged in a Manhattan subway station yesterday, a transit police spokesman said.

title: REMEMBERING DROUANT
description: It has been more than half a century since I first set foot inside the legendary Drouant, a sumptuous Parisian restaurant where, as a 14-year-old country boy from Burgundy, I spent five years as an apprentice and cook.

title: Mount Sinai Vote Due On High School Plan
description: LEAD: IN the face of continued declining enrollment, why would any Long Island school district be on the verge of building a new high school, especially if that district had been sharing the high school facilities of a nearby village for nearly 50 years?

title: 'A Thousand Clowns': Offbeat Happy Home
description: ''A THOUSAND CLOWNS,'' the production at the Broad Hollow Theater in Farmingdale, had its Broadway premiere in 1962.

title: Minnie Mouse's Favorite Soup
description: Most of the Disney gang are vegetarians,'' said Minnie Mouse. ''I'm not quite sure why, but I suspect cartoon carnivores just weren't endearing enough for Mr. Disney.''

title: Crash Course
description: To the Editor:

title: OUT AT SEA WITH GIANTS OF JAZZ
description: The only thing better than jazz on dry land is jazz afloat. For star-struck jazz buffs, cruises offer a chance to hear and even meet favorite musicians in congenial surroundings. The barriers between audience and artist that exist at Madison Square Garden or Carnegie Hall fade in the average smoke-filled dive. On a ship they disappear. There's also no cover, no minimum, no reservations, no maitre d's and no cabs home.

title: TV's Role in '88: The Medium Is the Election
description: The next President will have been chosen in a campaign dominated as never before by television.

title: Chicago
description: Not so long ago, a fledgling airport named after a local war hero stood amid the corn and beanfields northwest of Chicago, a quiet stretch of prairie where night life could mean a tractor plowing in the moonlight. But the field named for Butch O'Hare would become the busiest airport in the world, and corporate towers began to sprout prodigously from the soil, giving rise to a gleaming, sprawling suburbanopolis that today competes for visitors with its big-shouldered progenitor along Lake Michigan. (A recent survey shows that more people work in the suburbs than commute, now that so many major corporations are based outside the city.) Just as train travel early in this century made Chicago the locus of business meetings and trade conventions, the growth of O'Hare (nearly 60 million passengers passed through in 1987) has combined with suburban expansion to spawn the kinds of hotels, restaurants and bistros that once required a trip to the city.) The city itself, of course, remains a vibrant, cosmopolitan feast for the senses - from the restaurants in Greek Town to the glittering shopping district on Michigan Avenue. But the Land Beyond O'Hare, as it is called, is also worth exploration, especially since the trek downtown may demand more energy than a weary traveler can summon. The area, in a 30-minute radius of the airport, is dotted with glass and steel corporate towers and crisscrossed with expressways that bend through the old towns and newer settlements.

title: Presidential Candidates Gain Endorsements
description: Newspapers in Kansas City, Mo., Denver and New York City endorsed Presidential candidates this weekend in editorials that also criticized the campaign as superficial and negative.

title: FISH STEWS WITH A MEDITERRANEAN HERITAGE
description: MEDITERRANEAN seafood stews are particularly good for informal entertaining. They are easy to assemble (the stock and sauces can be made in advance) and take only a short time to cook. If you serve salad and cheese afterward, followed by a simple fruit dessert (something made with apples would be good), you have a dinner party menu that can be put together without a lot of fuss.

title: Colombia Reportedly Regains Vital Banana-Growing Region
description: The Interior Minister, Cesar Gaviria, said today that troops were regaining control in Uraba, a vital banana-growing region in the north, after a major rebel offensive. Mr. Gaviria said two battalions had been sent to Uraba, 250 miles northwest of Bogota.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: 'CLASSICS FOR KIDS'

title: Reviews/Dance; The Joffrey, in Tribute To Its Namesake
description: The Joffrey Ballet presented the first of several performances of its rather solemnly-named Founders Program on Friday at the City Center Theater, 131 West 55th Street, where the company performs through Dec. 4. The program of works by the late Robert Joffrey and Gerald Arpino, co-founders of the Joffrey, was well chosen, for it included a revealing excerpt from a ballet by Mr. Joffrey and two Arpino classics.

title: Wait for a Club Tee Gets Longer
description: PATIENCE is not only a virtue but a necessity for anyone hoping to join many country clubs. This year, for example, S8 families were accepted into the Country Club of New Canaan after waiting about seven years to join the town's only golf club, which is also one of the oldest country clubs in the nation.

title: Margery M. Trimble Wed in Maryland To R. B. Kennelly Jr., a Silver Medalist
description: The wedding of Margery Mills Trimble, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Trimble Jr. of Owings Mills, Md., to Richard Bayard Kennelly Jr., the son of Mr. Kennelly of Claremont, Calif., and Mrs. Tevita Puloka of Nukualofa, Tonga, and Arlington, Mass., took place yesterday at St. Thomas's Episcopal Church in Garrison, Md. The Rev. William Warwick Rich performed the ceremony.

title: MOTHER TAKES ENVIOUS LOOK AT CHAPERONING OF 18-YEAR-OLDS
description: I USED to be 18 years old. I remember clearly how I felt that the most important relationship I wanted with my parents was one in which I was away from them. It was crucial for me then to have privacy and the independence to make my own decisions about friends, job choices and, most important of all, dating.

title: POLICE INVESTIGATE CHARGES OF RACISM
description: The New York City Police Department is investigating allegations that black police officers in the 113th Precinct in Queens have been subjected to racial slurs and harasssment by white officers over the last six months, a high-ranking police official said yesterday.

title: Contra Chief Faults Reagan Statements
description: The chief representative of the Nicaraguan rebels in the United States said President Reagan had hurt their cause by using ''excessive rhetoric'' and comparing them to the Founding Fathers, and he said the next President should cooperate more closely with Congress in formulating policy toward Nicaragua.

title: Reviews/Music; Populists' Common-Sense Voices
description: During the evolution of the modern folk-music movement, one quality that has remained in scant supply is an plainspoken unpretentious sincerity. From Bob Dylan and Joan Baez to John Denver and Jackson Browne, even the most talented and well-meaning performers, in delivering political messages, have tended to treat the concert stage as pulpit.

title: A Civil War Cemetery Is Now a Battleground
description: Of the 18 cemeteries in the Cypress Hills section of Brooklyn, none is more prominent than the Cypress Hills National Cemetery, one of 12 burial sites established for Civil War dead by President Abraham Lincoln and the only national cemetery in the city.

title: Proposals for Peace
description: I LEARNED EVERYTHING I needed to know about how to make peace in the Middle East while grocery shopping in Jerusalem. And even now, as the world awaits what may be momentous events - an Israeli election Tuesday that could determine whether Israel withdraws from the occupied territories, and an anticipated meeting of the P.L.O. that could determine whether it recognizes Israel - my mind keeps returning to a supermarket on Jaffa Road where I shopped for fruits and vegetables almost every day.

title: Return of the 60's: Rock, Romance and Rebellion
description: I ASKED my husband the other night if we were baby boomers. Of course, he laughed heartily; anyone born in the 50's was considered a baby boomer. We lived through the 60's, didn't we? We experienced firsthand Haight-Ashbury, Woodstock, love beads, Nehru jackets, Jim Morrison, Vietnam, yippies; all the good stuff, the media would have us believe.

title: Unanimous Decision for Chavez in 11th
description: Julio Cesar Chavez, the World Boxing Association lightweight champion, defeated Jose Luis Ramirez, the World Boxing Council lightweight champion, tonight on a unanimous technical decision at the Hilton Center here.

title: Hospital Patient Arrested in Nurse's Murder
description: A 33-year-old Connecticut man was arrested yesterday and charged with the murder of a Metropolitan Hospital nurse in her East Side apartment on Oct. 19, the police said.

title: A Modern-Art Museum To Rise in a Textile Mill
description: A collaborative team of architects - including the firms of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill; Frank O. Gehry & Associates; Venturi, Rauch and Scott Brown Inc., and Bruner/Cott & Associates - has been chosen to produce a plan for the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, a complex of cultural and commercial buildings for North Adams, Mass.

title: EXPERT CHOICES
description: Having company used to be an occasion for bringing out the ''good stuff'' and setting the same table the same way every time. But now that entertaining tends to be more casual, an eclectic supply of tableware and accessories is what is needed. The selection here includes some of this season's best, ranging from a high-tech wire-mesh casserole holder and bread basket to elegant French porcelain dessert plates, crystal champagne flutes and a mahogany and pewter salad set. For whimsy, what about porcelain demitasse cups that imitate crumpled paper, or a crystal candy dish on a pedestal that inverts to become a vase? And no savvy host will ignore the practical, whether it is as simple as colorful paper napkins or as striking as a handsome stainless-steel percolator that makes up to 55 cups of coffee. NOT QUITE WHAT THEY SEEM

title: Planning Ahead; Wines for Now and Later
description: Everyone can buy a bottle of wine, but not everyone knows how to make a suitable yet economical choice.

title: 'Orthodoxy' Is Open to Wide Interpretation
description: WHAT makes chess such an adventure is the enormous range of possibilities that appear even in the openings.

title: GLITTERING FINALES
description: A truly festive dessert table deserves a touch of pure gold - or silver. But in the setting pictured here, the sumptuous luster of precious metal isn't due just to polished platters and servers. These desserts have been touched, as if by Midas, with decorations ranging from powdered gilt to golden sugar and silver dragees. Not only are the offerings as delectable as they are gorgeous, but the metallic embellishments are either edible or easily removed before serving.

title: Accord Allows Trips to Japan Without a Visa
description: The United States and Japan have agreed to allow their citizens to travel between the two countries without a visa, beginning Dec. 15. The two countries exchanged diplomatic notes earlier this month dropping the visa requirement for those traveling for business or pleasure for 90 days or fewer.

Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 69 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 2 2 30 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) AN EMPIRE OF THEIR OWN: How the Jews Invented Hollywood, by Neal Gabler. (Crown, $24.95.) A rich and prodigiously researched chronicle of the men, most of them immigrants, who created a fantasy America that was cleverer, more glamorous, more adventurous and often much nicer than the real thing. WINSTON S. CHURCHILL. Volume VIII: ''Never Despair,'' 1945-1965, by Martin Gilbert. (Houghton Mifflin, $40.) This 1,438-page whopper marks the end of 20 years of skilled and arduous labor, narrating the daily life of a dominating figure of our century. UNDER THE JAGUAR SUN, by Italo Calvino. (Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $12.95.) Before his death in 1985, the daring Italian post-modernist undertook to write a story on each of the five senses; this nervous, narrow, penetrating volume contains the three he finished, on taste, hearing and smell. A WRITER'S AMERICA: Landscape in Literature, by Alfred Kazin. (Knopf, $24.95.) The distinguished critic evokes the simultaneous exhilaration and guilt provoked in American writers by the existence of a virgin world and the potential for its exploitation. THE CAPTAIN AND THE ENEMY, by Graham Greene. (Viking, $17.95.) A meditation on the ways of love in the shabby, unpromising England of the 1950's that plunges midway into a dangerous world of political intrigue in Central America. BLACKWATER, by Paulette Jiles. (Knopf, $17.95.) A representative miscellany by an elegant American writer living in Canada, including a short novel, a number of poems and an unsettling, eccentric cycle about Frank and Jesse James. ELIOT'S NEW LIFE, by Lyndall Gordon. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) This successor volume to ''Eliot's Early Years'' aims at elucidating a deliberately imposed spiritual pilgrimage from T. S. Eliot's life and work after his conversion to Christianity.

title: Some Second Attempts Make First-Rate Music
description: Brahms composed two string sextets, Schubert two piano trios and Smetana two string quartets. In each case, the first of each pair is performed (and recorded) far more often than the second. There seems an obvious reason for their popularity: all three are outstanding examples of gloriously melodic 19th-century chamber music. But the second members of each set, given their relative obscurity, have surprisingly much to offer.

title: Carol Sundheim Engaged
description: The engagement of Carol Sue Sundheim to Gary Scott Cozen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Cozen of Wyncote, Pa., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David J. Sundheim of Elkins Park, Pa. A December wedding is planned. Ms. Sundheim is a vice president in the investment-banking group at Cores States Corporation in Philadelphia. She is a summa cum laude graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, and received an M.B.A. degree at its Wharton School. Mr. Cozen, a graduate of George Washington University, is a vice president of Warner Brothers Television Distribution in Philadelphia.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Shoreline Construction Limits Challenged
description: LEAD: An emergency regulation issued by Governor Kean earlier this month to control the pace of development along New Jersey's coastline has halted construction on 1,600 housing units and led to protests and a suit by six developers.

title: Renita M. Esayian Is Wed in London
description: At the American Church in London, Renita Margaret Esayian, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Esayian of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., was married yesterday to Richard Dennis O'Connell, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. O'Connell of Wellfleet, Mass. The Rev. Ron Allison, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: SPINNING THE GOLDEN THREAD
description: LEAD: IT WASN'T ALL VELVET By Mel Torme. Illustrated. 384 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: Lisa Ostergard, Executive, Weds
description: Lisa Ann Ostergard, a daughter of Marie F. Ostergard of Moreland Hills, Ohio, and Ellsworth H. Ostergard of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, was married yesterday to Ted Allan Gardner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Gardner of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. The Rev. D. Larry Kline officiated at the Garfield Memorial Methodist Church in Pepper Pike, Ohio.

title: SISTERHOOD IN THE SMALL ZONE
description: GREY IS THE COLOR OF HOPE By Irina Ratushinskaya. Translated by Alyona Kojevnikov. 357 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Business Behavior
description: To the Editor:

title: For Salem, a Reminder of a Dark Past
description: It is the witching season again in Salem, when residents and tourists don black costumes and attractions like the Witch Museum draw more than the usual number of visitors. But there are few reminders in this Boston suburb of the 1692 witch trials, whose dark events gave birth to this fascination.

title: LOVE UNDER THE DOOMSDAY CLOCK
description: LEAD: BINDING SPELL By Elizabeth Arthur. 372 pp. New York: Doubleday. $17.95.

title: FICTION
description: HOSPITAL OF THE TRANSFIGURATION. By Stanislaw Lem. Translated by William Brand. (Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $17.95.) An insane asylum as refuge from the madness of Nazi-occupied Poland in World War II - at first glance, the metaphor seems hopelessly trite. Yet this skillful, semiautobiographical first novel just skirts the edge of allegory, and its author's artistry steers it gracefully away from the dangers of cliche. But then it's no ordinary first novel. The Polish author Stanislaw Lem wrote it in 1948, long before he achieved fame as one of the world's leading contemporary science fiction writers. Now published in English for the first time in a solid translation by William Brand,, ''Hospital of the Transfiguration'' is the pensive story of Stefan Trzyniecki, a directionless, despairing young doctor who takes a job at a provincial Polish mental hospital at the outset of the war. There he confronts the absurdity of life through events that occur both inside and outside the asylum walls. Many of the hallmarks of Mr. Lem's mature science fiction style are present in this melancholy work of realism - the penchant for metaphysical discourse, the command of technical details, the flashes of humor. If it suffers from some of the common weaknesses of a first novel - occasionally excessive bursts of passion, a certain disjointedness - it is nevertheless strong testimony to the profound understanding of people and life that underlies even the lasers and spaceships of Mr. Lem's better-known oeuvre.

title: Jasper Johns: Toward a Fuller Disclosure
description: Jasper Johns is not yet 60, but he has been considered a great and important artist for a long time - more than half his life - and he is probably the closest thing American art has to a living national treasure. Beyond question this status is deserved. Johns is on, and may be at the top of, the short list of American and European artists who in the 1950's set the stage for the art of the second half of the modern century. His by now iconic flag and target paintings emphatically reintroduced legible sign, symbol and literary meaning into the territory of abstract art.

title: YONKERS CHARTER FACES THE VOTERS
description: LEAD: FOUR years ago, Yonkers voters narrowly defeated a proposal to change the city's government by strengthening the mayor's powers. In November, voters will once again be deciding whether the city government should undergo some sweeping changes.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEDBOOK;
Philadelphia : Reviving A Ghost Town
description: LEAD: A vandalized, ghost-town-like cluster of 27 abandoned low-rise apartment buildings in northeast Philadelphia is about to be revived as a 518-unit rental development.

title: Standards For Helmets
description: When purchasing a bicycle helmet, make sure it has a sticker stating that it has been approved by the American National Standards Institute or the Snell Memorial Foundation. An approved helmet has the following chracteristics:

title: Dr. Bonnie Blackman Is Wed to Dr. Ira Siegel
description: Dr. Bonnie Eve Blackman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Blackman of Nanuet, N.Y., and Narragansett, R.I., was married last evening to Dr. Ira Siegel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Siegel of New City, N.Y. Rabbi Chaim Shapiro performed the ceremony at the Touro Synagogue in Newport, R.I.

title: Joan Morrow Marries
description: Joan Marya Morrow, the daughter of Canon and Mrs. John T. Morrow of Gladstone, N.J., was married there yesterday to Clyde William Seigle Jr., the son of Mrs. Richard Ackerman of Northampton, Pa., and Mr. Seigle of Roanoke, Va. The ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, of which the bride's father is rector, was performed by Bishop Albert W. VanDuzer of the Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey, who is retired, assisted by the Rev. Charles F. Sutton Jr.

title: Conference to Focus on Issues of Children
description: TO businesses they are the next work force. To politicians they are future voters. To educators they are today's responsibilities and tomorrow's teachers. They are children, and many are not getting a good enough start in life to take over society, say organizers of ''Our Children, Our Future,'' a monthlong event in New Haven, to begin on Tuesday.

title: Charlotte Murphy To Wed Nov. 26
description: The engagement of Charlotte Tommins Murphy to Joseph E. Cox, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Cox of Grundy Center, Iowa, has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Murphy of Oldwick, N.J., and Groton Long Point, Conn. A Nov. 26 wedding is planned.

title: Griffith Films
description: A double bill of silent films by D. W. Griffith will be shown today at the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences, 75 Stuyvesant Place, in St. George. The screening begins at 1:30 P.M. with the short film ''The Rocky Road'' (1910), followed by ''Isn't Life Wonderful?'' (1924). This is the first in a three-part series of screenings of Griffith films; others will be shown on Nov. 6 and 13. Admission is $2. Information: (718) 727-1135.

title: Fairest 'Lady' Issued On CD
description: Lest anyone still doubt the vitality of the American musical in this age of imported blockbusters, the recent hit recording of ''Show Boat'' with an operatic cast - not to mention best-selling recordings of the recent past like the similarly cast ''West Side Story'' - should confirm the enduring popularity of the native form.

title: Banks Using Personal Touch to Lure the Wealthy
description: FOR people in Connecticut with an annual income of at least $100,000, a minimum net worth of a quarter of a million dollars and a checking account with a balance of $10,000 or more, going to the bank is becoming a thing of the past.

title: WHITE HOUSE RACE NEARS END MARKED BY MORE ATTACKS
description: With just over a week to go before the election, the Presidential race is largely focusing on issues of economic class, with Gov. Michael S. Dukakis accusing Vice President Bush of favoring the rich and Mr. Bush asserting that his rival is dividing the country.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
EXHIBITION OFFERS PERSPECTIVE ON HISTORY
description: LEAD: ROMAN coins are featured in a new exhibition at the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American History in Washington, D.C. The exhibition opened Oct. 22 and will continue through June 1989. There is no admission charge. The exhibition ''Rome at War as Seen Through Coins'' was organized by curators of the Smithsonian's National Numismatic Collection in cooperation with the Staatliche Munzsammlung in Munich, West Germany, and Emory University in Atlanta,

title: WHY MORE MONEY IS FLOWING TO THE DEMOCRATS
description: In the competitive world of money and politics, some most unlikely alliances form.

title: Bush Is Maintaining Lead Over His Rival, A New Survey Finds
description: The Republican ticket of Vice President Bush and Senator Dan Quayle has maintained a steady lead over the Democrats since last month, according to the latest Time/Yankelovich Clancy Shulman poll, to be published by Time magazine tomorrow.

title: Indictments in Pentagon Case Are Expected After Election
description: Federal prosecutors expect to bring the first indictments in the Pentagon fraud and bribery investigation shortly after the Presidential election, according to the Federal prosecutor in charge of the inquiry.

title: Political Notes; A Democratic Tradition Ends in New York City
description: A three-decade tradition in New York City will end Thursday when Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts campaigns in some other state rather than at a Garment Center rally that has whooped it up in past Presidential elections for Adlai E. Stevenson, John F. Kennedy, Lyndon B. Johnson, George McGovern, Jimmy Carter and Walter Mondale.

title: Letters on Travel; Cruises
description: To the Editor: There ought to be some way that prospective cruise passengers could inspect a ship before committing their money and time.

title: DEMOCRAT AND DEBT: U.S. POLICY ON LATIN AMERICA IS WELL RECEIVED - IN WASHINGTON
description: In proclaiming the success of its policy toward Latin America, the Reagan Administration has identified ''the greatest expansion of democracy in Latin history'' as its central achievement. Yet not for the first time, the perspective from Washington is not the view south of the border.

title: Prospects
description: Bond Market Jitters

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Cheerleaders 1, Football 0

title: Pushing the Stakes To New Heights
description: THE nation was rocked this month by the spectacle of takeover fights for some of America's largest and best-known companies. Even in this day and age when the multibillion-dollar acquisitions of household-name companies have become commonplace, the sheer size of the offers was astounding: $20.3 billion for RJR Nabisco, $11.5 billion for Kraft and $5.23 billion for Pillsbury.

title: QUIET ROADS ACROSS THE PRAIRIE
description: You can drive on an Interstate across the most endlessly enchanting of countrysides and encounter only an unrelieved monotony. The expressway exists in its own world, an unwalled tunnel, and moves at its own urgent pace. It has a rhythm and a rigidly regular time quite distinct from the landscape it crosses. It would not serve its purposes in any other way.

title: Farmers Seek Pesticide Alternatives
description: LEAD: PROMPTED by changing Federal guidelines and public concern over pesticide residues in food, Long Island farmers are seeking cost-effective alternatives to systematic spraying of plants and crops.

title: Carlucci Meets With Hussein To Discuss Peace in Mideast
description: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci met King Hussein of Jordan today for talks on Middle East peace prospects and military cooperation, a palace official said.

title: NEW CHIEF: Ralph S. Larsen; Taking the Reins From a Legend
description: FOLLOWING in the sootsteps of a legend can be intimidating - or comforting. It depends on your point of view.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
An Honoring Mission
description: LEAD: Forty years after he was the county's welterweight amateur boxing champion, Albert (Scoop) Gallello of New Rochelle is again putting on his gloves. This time he's fighting City Hall.

title: William H. Catto Exchanges Vows With Ms. Kent
description: At St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York, Kristina Kent, a daughter of Elizabeth Kent Adler of New York and Erik A. Kent of Plandome, L.I., was married yesterday to William Haskel Catto, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry E. Catto of McLean, Va. The Rev. Thomas Dix Bowers performed the ceremony.

title: Belfast Amid the Strife: Wrenched but Not Ruined
description: The war correspondent visiting this torn province for the first time would think parts of it are like Beirut: the bomb-charred barricades dividing sectarian communities, the taxis that will go to some neighborhoods and not others, the armed men patrolling sullen, hostile blocks of houses, the fear.

title: Fraud Charged in Jersey Condo Plan
description: Bosses and associates of the Genovese organized-crime family held hidden interests in a $25 million condominium project in Edgewater, N.J., and paid the borough's Mayor $500 a week to help push it along, a Federal indictment has charged.

title: 7 Latin Chiefs Discuss Writing Off Some Debt
description: Seven South American Presidents pledged today to devise a strategy to persuade creditors to write off part of their $339 billion debt.

title: The Reagan Years In the Region
description: The Caribbean: President Reagan, seeking to diminish what he calls Cuban and Soviet influence in Central America and the Caribbean, meets with the new conservative Prime Minister of Jamaica, Edward P. G. Seaga, in 1981 and promises economic aid. In 1983, the region's English-speaking islands support the American invasion of Grenada. Nicaragua: The Central Intelligence Agency begins clandestinely supporting anti-Sandinista guerrillas in 1981. The contras will become the focus of debate over whether, to what extent and how openly the United States Government should support their efforts to topple the Government in Nicaragua. One element in the debate is whether more emphasis should be placed on supporting the Latin Americans' own peace initiatives. Argentina: The Falkland War in 1982 pits Argentina against Britain, increasing American disillusionment with Argentina's military Government. After efforts to mediate the dispute, the Administration sides with Britain, alienating many Latin Americans who sympathize with Argentina's claim to the islands they call the Malvinas. El Salvador: United States-backed elections are held in El Salvador in 1982 amid civil war, to choose an assembly that will oversee a transition to democracy after rule by a civilian-military junta. In 1984, another election is held, for the office of President; the winner is Jose Napoleon Duarte, a centrist whom the United States supports. Mexico: President Reagan holds several meetings with Mexico's leaders, first Jose Lopez Portillo and then Miguel de la Madrid. In 1982 and 1988, the United States is instrumental in extending loans to Mexico to bolster its economy. Chile: Earlier this month, voters in Chile reject Gen. Augusto Pinochet's bid to be confirmed in power through a plebiscite, setting the stage for a possible transition to democracy that the Administration hails as another foreign policy victory. During the Reagan years, transitions to civilian rule have taken place in El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Argentina, Peru, Ecuador and Uruguay.

title: Bentsen Casts Two Ballots for Himself, Legally
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen voted for himself twice today in the Starr County Courthouse here, once for Vice President and once for Senator, and hopes fellow Texans will follow his example.

title: Ada Gates, Art Dealer and Farrier, Wed
description: Ada Gwendolyn Gates, a daughter of Mrs. John M. Gates of New York and the late Mr. Gates, was married in Pasadena, Calif., yesterday to Harry Holiday Patton, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Carl A. Patton of Long Beach, Calif.

title: Current PINS Law: Everybody Loses
description: As a clinical social worker in private practice in Suffolk County, I am very concerned about this issue. I had no idea of the scope of the problem. I feel that the age of emancipation should be raised to 18.

title: Harvard Blacks Make Unusual Plea on Hiring
description: A group of black professors who routinely criticize Harvard University's record on affirmative action have taken an unusual tack in their latest appeal to school administrators to begin immediately hiring more black and Hispanic faculty members.

title: WANTED: GOOD THROWAWAY HOUSING
description: I LONG for the era of the disposable house. When a leak develops in the basement, the roof shows signs of deterioration and the kitchen has become obsolete, you simply press a button and the whole thing self-destructs leaving a small pile of ash which can be spread around the azaleas. Until that time arrives, however, one must endure the endless struggle to keep the thing hanging together.

title: Noll Still Setting the Traps
description: A long time ago someone told Chuck Noll, ''Do what you know.''

title: DATA BANK: October 30, 1988
description: THE ECONOMY

title:
A View From: St. Gabriel's Performing Arts Center;
FORMER SCHOOL NOW HOUSES NEW LIFE AMONG MEMORIES
description: LEAD: THE halls of St. Gabriel's School once reverberated with the sound of young people's feet, but now one is more likely to hear the strains of singing or the music that accompanies a dance.

title: Wilmington, Del.: Luring Tenants In an Office Glut
description: With the office vacancy rate at a record 23 percent in the central business district here, landlords are beginning to offer special incentives to attract tenants. So far, they have been cautious about giveaways.

title: MISSION IMPOSSIBLE
description: As one who is old enough to remember when mail was delivered twice a day, I am always baffled by the many articles which argue that the Postal Service needs to break even financially. Why can't the Government subsidize mail delivery? It's one of the few services the Government provides that is not only harmless but even quite pleasant. Consider, by way of comparison, Government subsidies paid out to tobacco growers.

title: Why Labor Is at Odds With theN.L.R.B.
description: LEAD: IN April 1979, Kenneth Prill started driving a truck for Meyers Industries, but from the outset his rig was plagued by steering and brake trouble. He complained to superiors, but little was done. On one trip, he narrowly escaped serious injury when his brakes failed in Chicago traffic.

title: Miss McPhilliamy Is Wed in Queens
description: Anne Marie McPhilliamy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick McPhilliamy of Little Neck, Queens, and William Irving Cote Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cote of Tillson, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Anastasia in Douglaston, Queens. Msgr. Nicholas W. Sivillo performed the ceremony.

title: Letters on Travel; Belleville
description: To the Editor: Regarding Julian More's article on Belleville (Travel, Aug. 28), I must point out that the Simone Signoret film that was shot there was not ''Casque d'Or'' but ''Madame Rosa.'' DON KOLL New York, N.Y.

title: Current PINS Law: Everybody Loses
description: I am responding to the article ''Emancipation Age: Should It Rise to 18?'' [ Oct. 2 ] . As a member of the lobbying group Parents on the Move that will meet with Assemblyman Albert Vann in the near future for discussion on this issue, it is rewarding to see that The New York Times has taken the initiative in opening the eyes of the public to the sad state of New York's current PINS [ Persons in Need of Supervision ] laws.

title: Cecelia McEvoy, a Nurse, Is Married to Tony Walter
description: Cecelia Ellen McEvoy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. McEvoy of Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday to Winston John Walter Jr., a son of Mrs. Anthony J. Sposato of Pelham, N.Y., and the late Mr. Walter. Msgr. George T. Deas performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in Bayside.

title: THEURGY AND ECSTASY
description: KABBALAH New Perspectives. By Moshe Idel. 419 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $40.

title: U.S.C. Goes 7-0 By 41-20
description: Rodney Peete threw for three touchdowns to Erik Affholter as Southern Cal took sole possession of first place in the Pacific-10 Conference with a 41-20 victory over Oregon State today.

title: Entering Elmsford: The Condo Creep
description: It exists, but not for long: a community in the metropolitan area without condominiums. Elmsford, N.Y., only one square mile between Tarrytown and White Plains, has remained a community of single-family homes - some, now, holding two families - and just a few rental apartment houses. It has been, in fact, Elmsford's small size and central location that have prevented things from changing. ''It's surrounded by golf courses and developed properties, and there haven't been many opportunities,'' said Henry Reiter, a developer who finally found a spot and is building a 31-unit condominium there.

title: East Hartford Considering Drug-Testing in Schools
description: LEAD: THE schools in East Hartford are considering a voluntary drug-testing program for high school students involved in extracurricular activities, including athletics. If the program is adopted, it is believed that it would be the first in Connecticut, and one of a very few in the country. The chairman of the Board of Education, Donald Currey, who proposed the idea in

title: Marathoner Ailing
description: WHEN he sent word last week that he would not be defending his title in the 1988 New York City Marathon next Sunday, Ibrahim Hussein, the Kenyan runner who lives in New Mexico, did not explain why. Now his wife, Zainab, has cleared up the mystery.

title: Review/Theater; Humanity of Ordinary New Yorkers
description: Ira Levin's ''Cantorial,'' which made its New York debut Thursday night at the Jewish Repertory Theater, may be the most melodic nonmusical in town. What's more, it strikes the right note theatrically almost to the very end: good staging, attractive casting, inventive idea and crisp dialogue.

title: A Small Ring Leaves a Large Hole
description: MY hand feels strange, different, off balance. For a brief moment I think I have forgotten something; I look down, and then I remember.

title: Headliners; Parental Dispute
description: Robert W. Mays denies that he and his late wife took the wrong baby home from the hospital in 1978, but he said last week that even if they did, he will not give up the child, Kimberly Michelle Mays. Regina and Ernest Twigg of Pennsylvania, whose child was born about the same time in the same Florida hospital, say that tests showed that the little girl they took home, who died of a heart defect last summer, could not have been their biological daughter. Since Kimberly was the only other white infant in the hospital at the time, the Twiggs maintain, she must be their daughter. Mr. Mays, whose wife died six years ago, has said he would not agree to genetic tests on Kimberly to establish her parentage ''just because some people have made some unsubstantiated alllegations.'' A Florida judge is to consider this week whether Kimberly should be tested.

title: NONFICTION
description: THEY WENT THAT-A-WAY . . . By Malcolm Forbes with Jeff Bloch. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The unspoken and perhaps unintended message of this collection of ''death stories'' is that you should avoid being ''famous, infamous [ or ] great,'' since you will surely die young, unhappy or both. Among the 178 notables whose final days are recounted in ''They Went That-a-Way . . .,'' there are 44 homicides, 29 accidental deaths, 25 deaths in which liquor or drugs were factors, 16 suicides, 6 mysterious disappearances, 5 natural deaths rife with irony (the runner Jim Fixx's heart attack and the dietitian Adele Davis's cancer) and one death from syphilis. On the plus side, there are no deaths resulting from the victim being crushed by a horse being lowered on her for purposes of romance: Catherine the Great, for once and for all, is absolved of this vicious canard by the authors, Malcolm Forbes, editor and chairman of Forbes magazine, and Jeff Bloch, a New York City writer. Some deaths are weirdly funny: shortly after extolling the virtues of bone meal during a taping of ''The Dick Cavett Show,'' the health-food buff J. I. Rodale collapsed from a heart attack. Some deaths are fitting - the Tammany boss William Marcy Tweed died in jail - and some aren't - Ivan the Terrible died in bed. Despite occasional infelicities of language ('' [ Edmund ] Kean survived an attempt to send him to jail, but he was almost scandalized off the stage for good''), the book is fascinating in a way that only a book on death can be.

title: Having Third Thoughts On Yellowstone's Fires
description: NOW that the smoke has cleared, Park Service officials are stating that the forest fires that swept through Yellowstone last summer will have no long-range ill effects on the park's environment and wildlife. While it was undoubtedly a crisis, they say, the fire will actually enhance the park's ecology.

title: BOARD TO WEIGH VETERANS MEASURE
description: LEAD: THE Westchester County Board of Legislators appears ready to grant veterans a property-tax exemption that it rejected four years ago. The measure would particularly benefit those in the armed services during the Vietnam and Korean Wars.

title: Any Sale in U.S. Of Abortion Pill Still Years Away
description: Although the abortion-inducing drug RU 486 is back on the market in France, experts say it will be years before the drug could be sold in the United States, even if a company decides to try to market it here.

title: Utility Cuts Bid to Raise Rates
description: AFTER nearly five years without an increase, the Connecticut Light and Power Company is seeking to raise its rates, but the State Attorney General and the Consumer Counsel contend that even a modest rise is unwarranted.

title: The Economic Pace Slows Down a Bit
description: The economy's pace slackened to an annual growth rate of 2.2 percent in the third quarter. The gain in gross national product was the smallest in nearly two years and came after growth of 3 percent and 3.4 percent in the immediately preceding quarters. The blame for the decline fell on the summer drought and a weaker trade performance. . . . Another sign of easing growth was a 4.2 percent drop in orders for durable goods in September. The military and transportation sectors had steep declines . . . Personal incomes grew five-tenths of 1 percent in September and personal spending was unchanged. *A record-settng bid was topped, as Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts offered $20.3 billion for RJR Nabisco. The previous week the top management of RJR Nabisco, working with Shearson Lehman Hutton, had proposed a $17 billion buyout of the food and tobacco giant. The rival groups held talks but could not reach a deal for a cooperative effort. The management- Shearson group said Salomon Brothers would join it as a ''financial partner.'' A bidding battle is expected.

title: Special Today: Entertaining/Magazine Part 2
description: Expert advice on the ins and outs of a great party. Gold and silver give desserts a special luster. A wine collection for today's diverse needs. Party-planning professionals. ''White-tablecloth'' restaurant fare at home. Small apartment, big party. Classic French cuisine, in a microwave. Some of the season's best table accessories.

title: In Secular France, Stirrings By an Angry Religious Right
description: REVIVING old enmities, church and state have stumbled, almost reluctantly, into a clash over the emotional issue of abortion in France. Although this is a highly secularized nation, a series of controversies this month has demonstrated the power and passion of committed Roman Catholics and has provoked an angry debate about both freedom of expression and a revolutionary new abortion pill.

title: Sandra D. Yearley To Have a Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Douglas C. Yearley of Westfield, N.J., and Scottsdale, Ariz., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sandra Dunbar Yearley, to Mark Christopher Durgin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Durgin of Middleton, Mass. The wedding is planned for December.

title: STUDENTS LEARNING ABOUT CHILD'S PLAY
description: HOW do you make a worm garden? Fill an acquarium with layers of soil and plant some earthworms in it. Then water the soil and watch the worms come up.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEDBOOK;
Boothbay Harbor, Me.: New Score for An Opera House
description: LEAD: A boat-builder has converted the landmark 1894 Opera House, long an eyesore in this coastal resort town, into a 10-room inn and restaurant, its shabby clapboard now brightened with a coat of subdued yellow paint.

title: Ms. Wright Is Married To David Mark Eldred
description: At the Episcopal Church of St. Joseph of Arimathea in Elmsford, N.Y., Elizabeth Fullerton Wright, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Wright Jr. of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and David Mark Eldred, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Linn Eldred of Mohawk, N.Y., were married yesterday by the Rev. Donald R. Cutler.

title: Martha Brody, a Violinist, To Marry Frederic Grevin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan E. Brody of Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Ann Brody, to Frederic Jean Grevin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques Grevin of Orinda, Calif.

title: MISSION IMPOSSIBLE
description: In my 28 years as a letter carrier, I have seen nothing like the bizarre episodes described by John Judis.

title: BROTHERS IN FRAUD
description: LEAD: THE PLAGUE-SOWER By Gesualdo Bufalino. Translated by Stephen Sartarelli. 186 pp. Hygiene, Colo.: Eridanos Press. Cloth, $22. Paper, $13.

title: Court Ruling Challenges Gulotta on Budget
description: LEAD: NOVEMBER may be remembered in Nassau County this year as double budget month.

title: Jersey Nannies Organize for Status and Friendship
description: Tracy Hughes is no baby sitter.

title: Trial Drains Grenada's Coffers and Emotions
description: Nearly two years ago, 17 leftists were convicted of killing the head of Grenada's People's Revolutionary Government and 10 others in a spectacular outburst of violence that prompted an invasion by American troops in 1983.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our 63-year-old house was reshingled 11 years ago. The shingles were coated with a good brand of gray shingle stain. Two sides of the house have now started to mildew (south and west). We have been told that this condition will not clear up even when the humid weather ends. Can you advise us as to what we can do?

title: Hannah Tillich, 92, Christian Theologian's Widow
description: Hannah Tillich, whose vivid but unblinking remembrance of four decades as the wife of Paul Tillich scandalized some of his fellow theologians in 1973, died Thursday at Southampton Hospital after suffering a heart attack. Aged 92, she had lived in East Hampton, L.I., since her husband's death.

title: I'm a Liberal And Proud Of It
description: LEAD: I have just returned from two months in Europe, where I followed the election news assidulously. I've been appalled at the passivity of the electorate, at the lack of even the most elementary principles of democratic thought and action, at the degeneration of our language, at the lulling, the brainwashing, the disinformation.

title: Angolan Rebels Look to Life After South Africans
description: As mortar shells thudded softly in the distance, Lieut. Col. Juliao Vilinga reported that his guerrillas were skirmishing with Government troops probing the savanna around what remains of the besieged town of Cuito Cuanavale.

title: DOS SANTOS REPORTED IN MOSCOW TO DISCUSS PACTS WITH GORBACHEV
description: President Jose Eduardo dos Santos of Angola has been in Moscow meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, to discuss the terms of a possible settlement of the conflicts in Angola and Namibia, American officials said today.

title: Correction
description: A picture last Sunday with an article about the Senate campaign in Florida was published in error. It showed Representative Pat Swindall of Georgia, not Representative Connie Mack of Florida.

title: Juli Bookstein Married
description: Juli Bookstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Bookstein of Albany, was married last evening to Daniel E. Karson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Karson of West Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Martin Silverman officiated at the Colonie Country Club in Voorheesville, N.Y. The bride is a lawyer specializing in commercial real estate. Mr. Karson is general counsel and the managing director of Kroll Associates, a New York-based management consulting concern.

title: Reagan Signs Radon Bill
description: President Reagan signed legislation Friday calling for a three-year, $15.5 million program to deal with radon contamination in schools and Federal buildings. The bill provides for $10 million in grants to state and local governments, $3 million for seminars and information activities, $1.5 million for rating the proficiency of radon abatement programs and $1 million for development of eradication centers. An additional $1.5 million is provided for a study of contamination in schools.

title: Vietnam and Laos Finally Join Talks on Refugees
description: Vietnam and Laos took part this week in international talks on the problems of Indochinese refugees, whose number has grown this year as more Vietnamese flee by boat to neighboring Southeast Asian countries.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: The Adventures of Picasso Starring Gosta Ekman, Hans Alfredson, Margaretha Krook, Bernard Cribbins, Wilfrid Brambell, Per Oscarsson, Lennart Nyman, Lena Nyman, Birgitta Andersson. Directed by Tage Danielsson. 1980. New Star Video. 88 minutes. $59.95. Not rated.

title: LA PAZ TO COCHABAMBA BY BUS
description: The flight from La Paz to Sao Paulo takes little more than three hours, and anyone in a hurry to get from the largest city in Bolivia to the largest in Brazil has no choice but to fly. Bolivian buses and trains are not exactly the last word in comfort or convenience, yet crossing the Andes by land is vastly more rewarding than gazing down at the mountains from a plane.

title: The Two Faces of Space
description: For architects and city planners, space may be a shape; for city dwellers, it's a container. This is from ''Placeways: A Theory of the Human Environment'' by Eugene Victor Walter (University of North Carolina).

title: HOWARD'S WAY
description: In Richard Bernstein's article ''Howard's Way'' (Sept. 25), on translating Proust, three different translations are offered of the famous opening sentence of ''Swann's Way'': Longtemps, je me suis couche de bonne heure. The three versions are: ''For a long time I used to go to bed early.'' ''Time was when I always went to bed early.'' ''Time and again, I have gone to bed early.''

title: In Paris, Necklines Plunge
description: LOW necklines are back in the news for spring and summer. Teardrops and asymmetric cutouts have turned up at various fashion houses in Paris, but the sexiest necklines are on Emanuel Ungaro's clingy draped blouses with old-fashioned sweetheart cuts, shown above. They are not meant just for evening; Ungaro's flowered daytime suits are frequently accompanied by low-cut blouses. Suit jackets at a number of houses often have scooped necklines and are worn without blouses. Hemlines are dropping, and necklines are following along.

title: Let's Not Reject Compulsory Voting Too Hastily; Widen the Options
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; British Ondine Group Interprets French Music
description: The flute and harp constitute an understated repertory by composers seeking an obliqueness of speech, a sense of deflected passion, or else a pervasive, smoothing calm. The Ondine Ensemble from Britain offers these instruments together with a violin, viola and cello. It made its first New York appearance at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday night, and not surprisingly three-fifths of the program was French.

title: Images of Dickens in a Historic Setting
description: SECRET ROAD INN. The name conjures up a myriad of images. It could easily be the setting for a tale told by Dumas, Dickens or Robert Louis Stevenson. The Long Island reality is a picturesque and historic restaurant in Miller Place.

title: RYE VOTERS TO DECIDE ON GARBAGE OPERATION
description: LEAD: RYE City voters will decide on Election Day whether to authorize the city to spend up to $1.1 million for a new central maintenance garage, allowing it to assume sole responsibility for garbage collection.

title: Baseball Notebook; Steinbrenner Silent on Mattingly Trade Status
description: GIVEN an opportunity one day last week to dispel the idea that the Yankees are trying to trade Don Mattingly, George Steinbrenner declined. He refused to answer questions and brushed past reporters who only wanted to try to understand what was going on in the inner sanctum of the owner's mind.

title: The Run-Up in Sharon Bonds
description: LEAD: THE steady rise in the price of some Sharon Steel Corporation bonds has caught Wall Street's eye. Since Jan. 1, the bonds (the 13 1/2 percent issue due in 2000 and the 14 1/4 percent issue due in 1999) have gone to a price of 44, or $440 per $1,000 bond, from 18, or $180 per bond.

title: Q. ''How can I give a big party in my minuscule apartment?''  A. ''Rearrange your space.''
description: New York City forces people to do many strange things, and so it is true in entertaining. In a city where apartments can be tiny, it is not uncommon to encounter desperate measures, particularly among people with big ideas and little space.

title: U.S. Shuttle Is Readied For November Liftoff
description: The space shuttle Atlantis will be moved to its launching pad on Wednesday in preparation for a late November flight in which it will carry a secret military satellite.

title: DESK SET
description: BECOMING THE ENEMY By Brenda Peterson. 276 pp. St. Paul: Graywolf Press.

title: Catherine Miles Becomes a Bride
description: At St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., Catherine Rita Miles was married yesterday to Daniel Francis Crowther 3d by Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan.

title: MODERN SOOTHSAYERS PROPHESY THE PRESIDENCY
description: THROUGHOUT history, predicting the future has been a preoccupation of a great many people. The ancient Greek and Roman soothsayers and oracles read the entrails of animals or birds. More recently, gypsy fortune-tellers gazed into a crystal ball, mediums consulted the departed, and astrologers followed the courses of the stars and planets. Now we have election polls.

title: The Reluctant Voters
description: George Bush has run a brilliant campaign in one vital respect:

title: Lisa Tenney Hearst Is Wed To Thomas Espy, Executive
description: The marriage of Lisa Tenney Hearst and Thomas Pierson Espy took place yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Frederick Hill performed the ceremony.

title: Correction
description: A caption on page 38 of The Times Magazine today with an article about television for children misidentifies the woman in a studio photograph for the ''Lassie'' series (1954-71). She is Bonita Granville Wrather, a producer of the series, not June Lockhart. Mrs. Wrather died this month.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Sharon Gail Fass Wed in Scarsdale
description: The marriage of Sharon Gail Fass, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Fass of Great Neck, L.I., to Perry Pruzan Jacobson, the son of Liane Pruzan of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Richard Jacobson, took place last evening at the Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale. Rabbi Robert Rothman officiated.

title: Elizabeth Tobin Is Wed To Jeff Brown, a Writer
description: Elizabeth Ann Tobin and Jeff Brown were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Osborn Elliott in Stonington, Conn. E. Sims Casey, a justice of the peace, officiated.

title:
A SPECIAL GUIDE TO CRUISES WORLDWIDE;
FOR THE ADVENTUROUS, ANTARCTICA
description: LEAD: Antarctica is a remarkable frontier, accessible to a limited number of tourists during only 12 temperate weeks. A far cry from overrun tropical resorts and overcrowded ski runs, Antarctica combines some of the best features of both - an unpolluted expanse of the out-of-doors, sea, snow and sun, and lots of it.

title: Lake George Condos: A Victorian Evocation
description: The Antlers resort has passed through phases that mirror those traveled by the Lake George area itself. In 1880, Jerome Burton began building the Antlers Hotel on logging land he had been farming. It was designed and run like the Adirondack camps then attracting wealthy New Yorkers whose doctors prescribed mountain air. Later, the carriage trade was supplanted by the station wagon trade and the camps by motels. When the Antlers Hotel burned in 1968, its family-sized cottages stayed open.

title: Let's Not Reject Compulsory Voting Too Hastily; Doing a Better Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners; Historic Race
description: Of the contestants in the Presidential race, only Lenora B. Fulani has already secured a place in history. As the New Alliance Party's candidate, Dr. Fulani, a

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last week about Halloween marketing misstated the number of catalogues issued annually by Lillian Vernon Inc. It is 103 million.

title: NORTHERN PART OF COUNTY IS IN CONCERT SPOTLIGHT
description: THE county's concert activity tends to be centered in its middle and southern parts, but this week the northern communities are in the spotlight, starting tonight with the season opening of the Mount Kisco Concert Association.

title: Marjorie Lyn Howard To Wed D. M. Evans
description: Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Howard of Westport, Conn., and Longboat Key, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Lyn Howard, to Douglas Mark Evans, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald L. Evans of Sudbury, Mass.

title:
ART;
Modern Romance, Via Computer
description: LEAD: LAURENCE M. GARTEL'S ''Cybernetic Romance,'' the title of his current exhibition of computer-generated art at the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island in Hempstead, is a love affair between man and machine.

title: Begonias Without Tears for Hobbyists
description: IF you are among those gardeners who have tried and failed with begonias, give them one more chance. But this time, be selective. Do not fall for the first pretty leaf and stay away from finicky species and difficult, thin-leaved, mildew-prone hybrids.

title: Visit Bolsters West German's Gorbachev Ties
description: As Chancellor Helmut Kohl moved through the carefully plotted paces of his Moscow summit meeting, nobody seemed better pleased than the stocky, dour Foreign Minister ever hovering near.

title: Commercial Property: The Grand Central Area; Landlords Set Up a Special Tax to Upgrade District
description: A firm believer in the convenience of working near Grand Central Terminal, Todd Selbert refused to stray far last month when he moved out of cramped offices in the Graybar Building on Lexington Avenue, adjacent to the train station.

title: Mailbox; Horse Show Memories
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: AMBIVALENCE IN THREE-QUARTER TIME
description: THE VIENNESE Splendor, Twilight, and Exile. By Paul Hofmann. Illustrated. 346 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday. $22.50.

title: Whalers and Liut Shut Out Devils
description: The Devils played a listless game for the most part here tonight and suffered their second shutout in the last six games.

title: GUIDE
description: BRITISH ENSEMBLE

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: A SCARSDALE HALLOWEEN For three years the Church of Saint James the Less in Scarsdale has held a Halloween Walk through its graveyard - which, according to church officials, is the only churchyard burying ground in town. The tour guides, who dress as Scarsdale residents of times past, relate a history of the people buried there and some of the village's lore. The tours proved to be so popular as a Halloween event for parishioners, particularly children, that this year the church is inviting the general public.

title: Both Candidates Say U.S. Should Increase United Nations Role
description: The two major Presidential candidates, in their first formal statements of the policies they would adopt toward the United Nations if elected, say the United States should play a more active role in solving global problems through the world organization.

title: Disturbing Prospect Of a Tax Increase
description: It is most disturbing to read [ ''Property Tax Vs. Sales Tax: Debate Is On,'' Oct. 9 ] that Nassau County officials are considering a property tax hike for 1989, fresh upon the heels of last year's hefty increase.

title: FUGITIVE EX-NAZI GIVEN GERMAN VISA
description: The strange case of a former Latvian Nazi police chief who escaped deportation from the United States by quietly fleeing to West Germany, only to be arrested there on war crimes charges, has taken another unusual turn.

title: INDEXES OF HOUSING COSTS/N.Y.-Northeast N.J. area*
description: % change from % change from Sep. Aug. Sep. 87 Rents 143.7 0.9 7.6 Homeowner's costs 147.3 0.8 8.9 Fuel and utilities 95.0 0.1 -1.5 Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics *Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic. Indexes: 1982-84-100 MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES(Averages) Last Week Previous Week Year Ago New York Conventional (30-yr) 10.57 10.62 11.59 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.18 8.18 8.36 New Jersey Conventional (30-yr) 10.39 10.45 11.37 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.10 8.11 8.41 Connecticut Conventional (30-yr) 10.56 10.60 11.67 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.51 8.42 8.51 Co-ops (N.Y.) Conventional (30-yr) 11.13 11.07 12.24 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.43 8.42 8.48 *2*Indexes for Adjustable-Rate Mortgages* 1-yr. Treasury security 8.12 8.07 7.22 National Mortgage 8.98 8.98 8.91 Contract Rate Source: HSH Associates *Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: Hints for Picking Out a User-Friendly CD Player
description: Back in the beginning of the digital age, picking a CD player was simple, all you needed was $1,000 - the price of most players at the time. It didn't matter much which one you chose. They all sounded very much alike, which is not suprising, since they all used almost identical circuitry.

title: TV Mirrors a New Generation
description: When the baby-boom generation was young, it saw the world through the eyes of Beaver Cleaver. Now that huge population, born in the years following World War II, is 30-something, and prime-time television is beginning to see the world through their eyes. As this strike-and-sports-delayed television season finally gets under way, programs for that postwar generation and, more notably, about it, are prominent in the network schedules.

title: AFTER-DINNER DRINKS
description: Planning a dinner party is a delicate enterprise: The appropriate guests, food and wine are just the beginning. Offer the right after-dinner drinks, however, and the evening is guaranteed to prosper. There are, after all, so many possibilities, from the simplest - real and decaffeinated coffee, fruit juices and water - to the grandest and most fanciful - a rare old Cognac, a goldwasser or a clear, fragrant fruit eau de vie.

title: Expert Advice: What Makes a Party Go?
description: If we took all the advice offered by experts we'd be perfect - and unbearable - people. If we took all the advice offered by party experts, we'd have perfect - and unbearable - parties. Still, there's no denying that some party-givers know a lot about what makes an enjoyable evening. And certainly some party-goers are more schooled than others in the niceties of being a guest. Those who go to, and give, more parties in a month than many do in a year are bound to develop certain skills. Here, some top people who have mastered the art of entertaining and being entertained - and are known for giving parties that work - share a few of their thoughts. WHAT TO WEAR WHEN: GEOFFREY BEENE

title: Wide Receiver to Go
description: HE retired after last season and was running a delicatessen in Camden, N.J., 15 minutes from Veterans Stadium in Philadelphia, when the call came from the Eagles for an experienced wide receiver to go. So yesterday, Kenny Jackson signed a one-year contract to return to the team that made him the fourth draft choice in 1984 after he set 27 school records at Penn State.

title: Carolyn A. Rubin and Robert Kelly Have a Wedding
description: The marriage of Carolyn Ann Rubin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ger Mrs. William Edward Kelly of Spring Lake, N.J., took place yesterday at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Paul S. Tipton officiated.

title: Next Week; What Do You Think About the Jockeys' Strike?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: BACKPACK FEAST
description: LEAD: Planning a lunch that can be stowed in a couple of backpacks and taken on a cross-country trek is a distinctive, appealing way to entertain, especially on one of those winter days when the wind is kind and the sun reflects brilliantly off the snow. Two experts on hearty yet sophisticated dishes appropriate for cold-weather picnics are Mary Thorwarth and Claude Pottier, a husband-and-wife team who runs Cakes and Catering, a cafe with takeout service in Stockton, N.J.

title: WELLS, WELLES AND THE MARTIANS
description: LEAD: ''When the Martians started coming north from Trenton we got really scared. They would soon be in our town.''

title: HOWARD'S WAY
description: There are more reasons than its familiarity in the English language to keep the title ''Remembrance of Things Past.'' The sonnet from which this title comes is a perfect capsulization of precisely what Proust achieved in his monumental work - the recapture of lost time through art. The Scott Moncrieff title has a redolence to anyone acquainted with the Shakespearean sonnet that is lost in the banal ''In Search of Lost Time.'' The phrase belies the sort of recherche that Proust was doing. It suggests the narrator is an Olympian Euell Gibbons stalking a wild madeleine across an obstacle course. DORIE BRODIE North Haven, Conn.

title: DEE-FENSE!
description: TOUGH STUFF The Man in the Middle. By Sam Huff with Leonard Shapiro. Introduction by Tom Landry. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $18.95.

title: THE SLIVER OF ANCIENT CARTHAGE
description: In 1553 Dragut the Corsair descended on Gozo in a fleet of galleys, overwhelmed its hilltop citadel and carried off into captivity 7,000 survivors of the siege. Fewer than 300 Gozitans managed to escape by slithering down ropes in the darkness before the final assault and hiding in a legendary tunnel near Il-Harrax hill. Nothing much has happened on the island since. A sliver of ancient Carthage, its limestone cliffs golden in the Mediterranean sun, the rocky island of Gozo juts out of the poet's wine dark sea 60 miles south of Sicily and 180 miles north of Libya, bypassed by the modern world. Technically the northern dependency of Malta, Gozo is a piece of antiquity preserved in amber. Its 5-by-10-mile expanse is dotted with ancient fortified medieval towns.

title: Time for a More Equitable System at Oxford and Cambridge
description: To the Editor:

title: 'X-Day,' the Day Japan Will Decide to Stand Still
description: In the back corners of coffee shops near Government offices, and in whispered conversations across the bureaucracy's rows of battleship-gray desks, it is known simply as ''X-day.''

title: Temple Breaks Losing Streak
description: Rutgers, a team that surprised many people early this season by beating teams it was not supposed to beat, today surprised some more people by losing to a team it was not supposed to lose to.

title: Fish Pollution In Florida
description: FLORIDA, which has had more than its share of walking catfish, three-pound poisonous toads and other exotic creatures not endemic to the state, has found one way to control the encroachment on its native wildlife: fighting fire with fire.

title: Q and A; Study Abroad
description: Question: Many colleges and universities offer organized travel with academic credit during the summer. How can I find out what courses will be offered next summer by the various instituions of higher learning in this country? - P. R., Pacific Palisades, Calif. Answer: There is a comprehensive reference book on this subject, called ''Vacation Study Abroad,'' a guide that describes 1,300 programs, about 80 percent of them in Europe. Two-thirds of them are sponsored by colleges and universities in the United States; the remainder are sponsored by foreign universities and language schools. The guide gives dates and prices, details of opportunities for academic credit, and lists whom to contact for further information. It also indicates those programs that include travel as well as study. The length of the courses varies from 3 or 4 to 12 weeks and in a few cases 16 weeks.

title: Body and Mind; The Cheapskates Ploy
description: MONEY, MONEY. WHAT AN all-purpose container, what a dump. Upon this dumping ground we play out the mortal combats of marriage, the rages of divorce, the lusts of power and vengeance, the lifelong grievances of childhood, all those fevered games, and we insist that the currency is dollars and cents. Sometimes we even believe it; we don't like to see ourselves in metaphors. Yet nothing else is so rarely about what it is ostensibly about as anything that is ostensibly about money.

title: OUTDOOR SCULPTURE WITH CRITICAL NOTE
description: ''DESIRE PATHS'' is a show of outdoor sculpture that criticizes shows of outdoor sculpture. The idea comes from Helen Horowitz, a curator at the International Sculpture Center in Washington, and it is played out by the 13 sculptors she has chosen in the grounds of the Schulman Realty Group, at 707 Westchester Avenue here.

title: 'WE CAN PROTECT BIOLOGICAL DIVERSITY'
description: LESLIE J. MEHRHOFF is one of the state's foremost champions of endangered species. For more than 13 years Mr. Mehroff, a biologist, has compiled and maintained the State Department of Environmental Protection's lists of locations of endangered and threatened species and of species of concern.

title: Capital's Homicide Rate Is at a Record
description: With two months left in the year, Washington has already matched the record of 287 homicides set in 1969, and the police say increased use of drugs, particularly crack, is more and more a cause.

title:
'Base Isolation';
Taking the Shock Out of Quakes
description: LEAD: When an earthquake strikes, emergency officials prepare to respond even as they feel the ground begin to shake.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Budd Lake $179,000 5 Budd Lake Heights Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 17-year-old contemporary; full basement, eat-in kitchen, fireplace; taxes $3,056. Hanover Township $234,500 271 Whippany Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old ranch; c/a, patio, fireplace in living room; taxes $3,500. Kendall Park $175,000 26 Stillwell Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 26-year-old colonial; family room, fireplace, c/a, Jacuzzi in master bath; taxes $2,022. Manalapan $200,000 31 Clinton Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; enclosed porch, eat-in kitchen, c/a; taxes $2,800. Short Hills $750,000 2 Roland Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, year-old colonial; finished basement, central vacuum, w/w carpeting; taxes $9,248. South Orange $442,000 60 North Wyoming Avenue 6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 22-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, den, fireplace, formal dining room; taxes $8,046. OTHER AREAS Pound Ridge, N.Y. $410,000 522 Indian Hill Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 11-year-old colonial; fireplace, in-law apartment, 2.5 acres; taxes $5,379. Old Lyme, Conn. $525,000 Wolcott Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; wooded lot, 3-car garage, 2.1 acres; taxes not yet available. Lindenhurst, L.I. $135,700 320 South Broadway 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 75-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $2,600.

title: NO MIDDLE GROUND
description: EL INFIERNO By Carlos Martinez Moreno. Translated by Ann Wright. 266 pp. St. Paul: Readers International/Consortium Book Sales. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $8.95.

title: Police Training Overhaul Sought in Massachusetts
description: State Attorney General James M. Shannon has called for a ''radical, major overhaul of police training in Massachusetts'' after investigating a training center at which 47 cadets became ill.

title: IT MAY LOOK LIKE A HOE, BUT IT'S REALLY MONEY
description: What are these African metal objects that look like miniature iron banners, copper croquet wickets, a bronze spiral from a giant's bedspring or iron spearheads too thin to penetrate more than air? Money, more or less, said Michael Ward. The Manhattan dealer has assembled 49 such items in ''Symbols of Value: Abstractions in African Metalwork,'' an exhibition at the Michael Ward gallery, 9 E. 93d Street, through Dec. 17. The examples chosen served as currency, jewelry or both from the 12th through the 20th centuries in various tribal societies of central Africa.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: OPEN DOOR. By Luisa Valenzuela. Translated by Hortense Carpentier, J. Jorge Castello, Helen Lane, Christopher Leland, Margaret Sayers Peden and David Unger. (North Point, Paper, $12.95.) Luisa Valenzuela's affecting short stories - parables, really - are cryptic and poetic. Like many Latin American writers, she produces work that verges on the surreal.

title: Editors' Note
description: A political article in the ''State by State'' series last Sunday reported criticisms of Bill Wasserman, who was dismissed as state director of the Dukakis campaign in New Mexico.

title: Let's Not Reject Compulsory Voting Too Hastily; Quorum Spells Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: MISSION IMPOSSIBLE
description: While pay scales, productivity, poor union relations and management incompetence may all play a part, I believe the key to the dilemma is to be found in the very last sentence of your article, where you mention junk mail. A privatized mail system would quickly decide that junk mail does not pay its way.

title: Oh, Oscar, You're Just an Old Softy
