description: Anyone who sees Shirley MacLaine in ''Madame Sousatzka'' is sure to feel sorry for her, because Ms. MacLaine looks a fright. Heavy makeup accentuates every line in her face, and the age spots on her hands look conspicuous and real. She walks with a slight limp, weighed down by clattering jewelry, and her costumes give her a thick, ungainly silhouette. However, there's a limit to the sympathy this ought to generate, because next spring Ms. MacLaine is liable to be laughing all the way to the Academy Awards.

title:
SETTING THE SCENE;
BRACING WINTER PICNICS
description: LEAD: Once Thanksgiving is over and the holiday season gains momentum, most people's thoughts of entertaining turn to the indoors. But to James Biddle, the Sunday after Thanksgiving was a good choice for his winter picnic, a casual but well-organized party that has marked the cusp between fall and winter for the past few years.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
The Bard in New Rochelle
description: LEAD: ''There's always something new in Shakespeare,'' said Alice Knubel, a New Rochelle resident, past president and present member of the Avon Bard Club. ''The circumstances in your life affect your understanding of the work; meanings change. When I was younger, I liked the comedies. Now, I feel closer to the tragedies.

title: Adam Smelin Married to Nora Plesent
description: Nora Elizabeth Plesent, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Plesent of Larchmont, N.Y., and New York, and Adam Paul Smelin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Raanan Smelin of New York and Quogue, L.I., were married last evening. Rabbi Emily Korzenik performed the ceremony at the Century Association in New York.

title: About Men; Lost Among the Girls
description: WHEN I WAS 13, my parents sent me to a girls' school. Their intention was not to torture me. They just weren't happy with the local public and parochial schools, and the only alternative in our town was a small, private day school then accepting boys for the first time in its 100-year history.

title: For Senate Rivals, a Harsher Tone
description: FOR months, Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman, the Democrat challenging Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., had attacked his rival. Mr. Weicker is detached, he said, and regularly missed votes on bills. The Senator's reputation as a maverick who is good for the state is a myth, he said, calling him ''an outsider in Washington.'' Mr. Weicker, in turn, simply charged that Mr. Lieberman was not addressing the issues.

title: No-Frills Play from Guerney
description: FOR an actor or actress who wants to act with minimal constraints and commitments, and for theater managers who need to put on a show frugally and fast, A. R. Gurney has written what may well be the ultimate no-frills play. ''Love Letters,'' which began previews last Friday at Stage II of the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, requires literate male and female characters - one of each - and that's that. There are no lines to memorize, no sets (just a table and two chairs), no contracts to negotiate and no rehearsals, except perhaps a run-through or two .

title: EMELIN'S 'GLASS MENAGERIE' HAS MAGIC MOMENTS
description: PERHAPS ''The Glass Menagerie,'' like a fluttering bird, has to be let go before long. With its gossamer texture and inimitable lyrical grace, one is set up for an ethereal tale. But here's one about a family's all-too-tangible fears and domestic pressures, framed by the turbulence of the 30's - what the narrator, Tom, calls the play's ''social background.''

title: Births Among Teen-Agers Down a Bit
description: A FIVE-YEAR decline in the birthrate among teen-age mothers in Connecticut has health planners optimistic that education efforts are meeting with some success.

title: New Tales of the Clown and the Juggler
description: Wait - stop the election. There happens to be a late entrant in the Presidential race: a clown, an authentic pratfalling professional. He'll be tossing himself into the ring at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday night, only a week before Election Day. His name is Bob Berky and he has a red ball for a nose and a duck call for a voice and there is a certain beat-up elegance to the tilt of his squashed top hat.

title: More Aid for Firefighters' Families
description: TUCKED deep in the 400-page anti-drug bill that was recently passed by Congress is a little help for the families of five firefighters killed in a July 1 blaze at an automobile dealership in Hackensack.

title: CRIME
description: Any theatergoer who has ever felt the urge to murder an actor for an execrable performance should get a kick out of two backstage mysteries that do the deed with a nice theatrical flourish. In Herbert Resnicow's novel THE GOLD GAMBLE (Kahn/St. Martin's, $15.95), a Broadway producer's chippy girlfriend is smothered in her own cold cream when her backstabbing threatens to wreck a revival of ''Guys and Dolls.'' Another revival, of Shaw's ''Major Barbara,'' gets a last-minute cast change in Jane Dentinger's DEATH MASK (Scribners, $16.95) when an insufferable artiste has a diabolically induced ''heart attack'' onstage.

title: Reviews/Dance; Tour de Fuerza Explores Latin Diversities
description: Two works presented Thursday night in the second program of the Tour de Fuerza series of events by Latin American choreographers at the Bessie Schonberg Theater were elaborate multimedia creations. Another was a solo. All three testified to the diversity of Latin American dance and performance art, but only the solo was truly compelling.

title: ISRAEL FACES CRUCIAL ELECTION AND APATHETIC PUBLIC
description: Three days before Israel's parliamentary elections, by all accounts the most important of recent times, the Israeli public seems to have lost interest, depressed by the likelihood that the balloting will result in another stalemate.

title: Bar Examinations For Practicing Lawyers
description: In the article ''Debate Renewed on Barriers to Lawyers'' (Oct. 2), Dr. Saul Wolfe comments that New Jersey's requirement that out-of-state lawyers take the state's bar examination is justified by a need to insure that lawyers practicing in the state have knowledge of local law.

title: 100,000 Sq. Ft. of Offices: Biggest in Bahamas
description: The Bahamian economy runs on sunshine, palm trees and Eurobonds.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our 63-year-old house was reshingled 11 years ago. The shingles were coated with a good brand of gray shingle stain. Two sides of the house have now started to mildew (south and west). We have been told that this condition will not clear up even when the humid weather ends. Can you advise us as to what we can do?

title: Variety in an Old Opera House
description: REMEMBER those old movies in which an eager group of aspiring thespians gathers and someone says, ''Hey gang, let's put on our own show''? That is the feeling one gets when visiting Greenwoods in Bethel, a restaurant that combines a youthful, inexperienced staff with some creative ideas, pleasing flair and a hefty helping of unbridled enthusiasm.

title: Warsaw Pact Seeks a Summit
description: Foreign Ministers of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact today ended two days of talks after calling for a 35-nation European summit meeting on reducing conventional weapons, official reports said. Most of the proposals made at the meeting were contained in previous documents issued by the military alliance, but the summit call was new.

title: Huntington Divided Over Plan to Raze Old House
description: LEAD: HUNTINGTON'S Village Green, the site of many festivals and art shows, stretches along the north and south sides of Main Street, offering stark contrast to the bustling intersection of Route 25-A and Park Avenue at its easternmost periphery.

title: Q. ''How can I serve classic French cuisine when it takes so much time?''  A. ''Use your microwave.''
description: What, you use a microwave for cooking?'' Almost with a sense of alarm, friends wander into my kitchen and wonder what a microwave has in common with classic French cuisine. Actually, quite a bit, I've learned. Last year, I added a microwave oven to my kitchen in Paris, where I put it to daily use making rich poultry stock and trying out a seemingly endless number of recipes I enjoy creating on my own, inspired by French cookbooks and magazines. I later installed one in my country house in Provence. Like many French housewives, I have taken to the microwave with a passion.

title: It's the Year's No. 2 Night to Howl
description: At Abracadabra, a Manhattan store offering one-stop shopping for all your Halloween needs, including coffins for rent or sale, a suburban couple, Annette and Skip Marino, were laying in supplies for the holiday weekend. ''How about blood, hon?'' said Mr. Marino, holding up a packet of fake blood.

title: ABOUT THE ARTS: Film; 'Little Dorrit': Fine Performances, Vivid Faces - Gaunt Cheek by Comfortable Jowl
description: The new film of ''Little Dorrit,'' written and directed by Christine Edzard, must be the most ambitious movie adaptation of a Dickens novel ever made, and, setting aside David Lean's superlative 1946 version of ''Great Expectations,'' the most successful. Moreover, in ''Great Expectations'' David Lean was working with a relatively compact story, while ''Little Dorrit'' is a great urban sprawl of book, Dickens at his most profuse.

title: Theatricality Bedecks a Festival in Lyons
description: Festival is a devalued word in the performing arts nowadays. But if there is any event, in its scope and celebration of an art form that restored full meaning to the term, it was this autumn's International Dance Biennale in Lyons, France.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Lohr Wins Playoff for First Victory: Bob Lohr, who birdied the 18th hole to force a playoff, won his first PGA Tour title by sinking a 5-foot par putt on the fifth extra hole yesterday to beat Chip Beck in the $700,000 Walt Disney World Classic in Lake Buena Vista, Fla. Beck three-putted the final hole, missing an 8-footer for par before Lohr dropped his putt. The playoff was the 13th and longest on the Tour this year and the first ever for Beck or Lohr. Beck shot a 66 yesterday to complete 72 holes at 25-under-par 263. Lohr put his approach shot on 18 within 3 feet of the cup and sank the birdie putt to complete a round of 68. Bruce Lietzke and Fuzzy Zoeller tied for third at 269, 19 shots under and 6 off the pace. Lietzke shot a final-round 68; Zoeller had a 70.(AP) TENNIS Shriver Withdraws and Graf Gains: Pam Shriver's hopes of a rematch with Steffi Graf were dashed by a stomach virus yesterday when she withdrew during the semifinals of the $250,000 Midland Group championships in Brighton, England. After the top-seeded Graf struggled to beat Lori McNeil, 6-2, 5-7, 6-4, in the first semifinal, Shriver was forced to retire when she was trailing, 6-7, 1-2 to Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria. The 19-year-old Graf beat Shriver in the semifinals at Wimbledon. Graf posted her 43d consecutive victory and the 69th in 71 matches this year. The fifth-seeded American stayed with Graf until, 4-4, in the final set. But Graf gained a crucial break and then served out the match to move into today's final against Maleeva.(AP) Gilbert-Mansdorf Final in Paris: Brad Gilbert reversed a defeat at the Paris Indoor Open last year by beating the second-seeded player, Tim Mayotte, 7-5, 6-3, yesterday in the semifinals of the $1.1 tournament. In today's final, Gilbert will meet Amos Mansdorf of Israel, who beat Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland, 7-6, 7-6, winning the tie breakers. Hlasek upset John McEnroe in the quarterfinals, 7-6, 2-6, 7-6. The tournament winner gets $262,000.

title: On the Broadening of Contacts and Knowledge
description: ''DON'T join too many gangs. Join few if any.''

title: Unbeaten U.C.L.A. Is Upset
description: The brief reign of U.C.L.A. as the No. 1 college team in the nation came to an end here today as the Washington State University Cougars upset the pass-happy Bruins, 34-30.

title: Carlo Tresca's Enemies
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about jukeboxes misidentified a Rock-ola machine. The jukebox, wholly visible at the center of the page, was a 1422 model from 1946.

title: 156 Arrested in Los Angeles
description: The police arrested 156 people, including 98 suspected of being gang members, and impounded 21 vehicles and seized four guns in a nine-hour sweep through a gang-infested area Friday night, the authorities said today. The charges against those arrested ranged from curfew violations to narcotics trafficking.

title: The Timeless Appeal of Chanel
description: What was it about her? Gabrielle Chanel reached the height of her creativity in the late 1920's and the 30's. She died in 1971. Yet today, her fashion philosophy is as potent as ever - suits with jackets that fit like sweaters, women's clothing based on gentlemanly elements, masses of bogus bijoux replacing the demure real stuff. Chanel's influence does ebb and flow with the tides of fashion, receding in times when eccentricity and exaggeration are in. But this fall, her impact is apparent everywhere.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: A VICTIM MUST BE FOUND. By Howard Engel. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) It takes a lot to make some private investigators feel fully alive: a gangland kingpin muttering threats, bullets through the windshield, a smoky-voiced chanteuse with come-hither eyes. Then there's Benny Cooperman: ''I ordered a chopped egg salad sandwich on untoasted white bread.

title: What Will Happen in The N.B.A. In '88-'89
description: The Boston Celtics, bouncing the ball with their heads if necessary (that may be the only part of their anatomy not ailing by the playoffs), will be battling the Detroit Pistons for the opportunity to face the Los Angeles Lakers in the finals. SHELLY CHIN New York The Lakers will send the Big Fella out in style by successfully answering the latest battle cry: ''THREE-PEAT!'' JULIUS CHANG Morganville, N.J. The Celtics and the Atlanta Hawks will prevail in the playoffs and meet in the Eastern Conference finals, where Atlanta will dispose of Boston in six games.

title: U.N. Backers Urge Full U.S. Dues Payment
description: A suggested blueprint for the next United States Administration's political agenda at the United Nations has been set out in a study by the United Nations Association of the United States of America, based on a nationwide survey of the group's 20,000 members and other interested organizations.

title: Canceling a Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop From the Black Sea, Cloaked in Mystery
description: The most unlikely contender on the 1987 British pop charts was an album of female voices, usually unaccompanied, singing in Bulgarian. ''Le Mystere des Voix Bulgares'' (''The Mystery of Bulgarian Voices''). The album, originally released on the French label Disques Cellier, caught the restless ears of trend-happy British tastemakers, who had never heard anything like its ethereal and pungent harmonies or the quavers and yips and microtonal nuances of the soloists.

title: Leonard Nimoy at the Controls
description: Leonard Nimoy tries to suffocate his joy, to stuff his happiness back into his chest as if it were a quilt being crammed into a bag too small to hold it. It is unseemly that at the age of 57 he should be so happy. And this exotic feeling, coming as it does after years of being dutiful and earnest and, above all, serious, is built on pain.

title: Alice Jeppe Dabezies Wed to Peter Madsen
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in New Orleans was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Alice Jeppe Dabezies, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Jean Dabezies of New Orleans, to Peter Bo Madsen, a son of Niels Bo Madsen of London and Janecke Naess Madsen of New Canaan, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Hill C. Riddle.

title: Behind the Preference for 'Junk' Bonds
description: THE relatively high returns of ''junk'' bonds have convinced many investors that these bonds are one of the most attractive investments of the post-crash market. Lured by yields of more than 12 percent, individual investors too frightened to own common stocks are pouring billions of dollars into mutual funds investing in these bonds of low-rated and sometimes highly leveraged companies.

title: Backstage at the Biggest Deal of All
description: F. ROSS JOHNSON, the chief executive of RJR Nabisco Inc., began his morning Oct. 20 with a laugh. An article about his company was prominently featured that day in the business section of The Atlanta Journal & Constitution, his hometown newspaper. The article, an analysis of the impact on the food industry of the recently announced bid by the Philip Morris Companies for Kraft Inc., carried the headline, ''Analysts Say RJR Isn't Likely to Be Involved in Any Merger.'' ''Well,'' Mr. Ross said to a business associate, ''they sure have figured us out again.'' By early morning, the press finally had figured out RJR Nabisco and Ross Johnson. It was then that the company's board announced that a management group led by Mr. Johnson was considering a $17 billion leveraged buyout of the tobacco and food giant. The proposal eclipsed the $11.5 billion offer for Kraft that had made history just three days earlier as the largest takeover bid ever for a consumer products company.

title: Manalapan Journal; A Good Neighbor, Flea Market Offers Bargains, Too
description: THE only thing that's not for sale at the Englishtown Flea Market is the market itself, and that makes just about everybody happy.

title:
DINING OUT;
Khan's Mongolian Garden
description: LEAD: ON Saturday evening, when the Tappan Zee Bridge is spared a rush hour, this place is worth the short and easy ride. Remember it at other times, too, if traffic is at a standstill and a little dinner is all that's required to raise the blood sugar of testy passengers. Consider taking a break over a few dim sum, a bowl of soup and a plate of freshly cooked victuals.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANT BULBS EARLY TO ENCOURAGE ROOTS
description: LEAD: IF we are to enjoy the bloom of tulips and daffodils in the spring, attention must be paid in the fall. A few hours of planting bulbs now will result in many hours of enjoyment later.

title: Greta Weil Is Married
description: At the Dingletown Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., Greta Weil, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David M. Weil of Chicago and Oslo, was married yesterday to Richard Francis Conway, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Francis Conway of Greenwich. The Rev. Paul Beavers, a minister of the Christian Missionary Alliance, performed the ceremony.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: New Rochelle, N.Y. $397,000 16 Tulip Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 31-year-old split level; fireplace, paneled den, playroom, 2-car garage; taxes $5,622. Pound Ridge, N.Y. $410,000 522 Indian Hill Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 11-year-old colonial; fireplace, in-law apartment, 2.5 acres; taxes $5,379. Waccabuc, N.Y. $414,500 Post Office Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 1850 farmhouse; fireplace, sun porch, den, barn, lake rights, 2.6 acres; taxes $4,059. Lebanon, Conn. $248,500 3 Levita Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, year-old Cape Cod; interior balconies, cathedral ceilings, 2.1 acres; taxes not available. Old Lyme, Conn. $525,000 Wolcott Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; wooded lot, 3-car garage, 2.1 acres; taxes not yet available. Old Saybrook, Conn. $114,000 19 Soundview Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 70-year-old summer cottage; walk to beach, unfinished attic; taxes $556. OTHER AREAS Coram, L.I. $172,000 18 Baron Court 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, new colonial; family room, c/a, 2-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,500. Garden City, L.I. $302,000 63 Grove Street 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 21-year-old split level; center hall, dining room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,800. Hanover Township, N.J. $234,500 271 Whippany Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old ranch; c/a, patio, fireplace in living room; taxes $3,500.

title: Wage Worries
description: To the Editor:

title: GIVING BUSINESSES AN OLYMPIC SPIRIT
description: WHAT can a motivational specialist who once served the Soviet Olympic Team teach American businessmen? Plenty, said Dr. Grigori Raiport, a former Soviet psychologist who demonstrated his mental training techniques to the Advertising Club of Westchester at its October meeting.

title: Done In By Automatic Dial
description: To the Editor:

title: Current PINS Law: Everybody Loses
description: Responding to the article, Dorothy Holmgren of Parents on The Move notified us because we are members of a statewide coalition working to change the PINS age to 18.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: PRIME TIME. By Joan Collins. (Linden/Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) You might not expect Joan Collins, the actress who has achieved considerable celebrity playing the ultimate vixen on television's ''Dynasty,'' to be a dazzling prose stylist or even a great storyteller. You might hope, however, that she'd be capable of putting together a juicy, insider's look at the television industry.

title: Of Men and Women (Cont'd)
description: Members of the Chilton Club, which was organized 78 years ago for women, have voted to accept men as members. Without making the change Thursday, the club could have lost its food and liquor licenses as discriminatory. The club had said it might seek an exemption from the rule. On Tuesday, the all-male Tavern Club, which also had said it planned to seek exemption, announced it would begin accepting women as members.

title: Sophie Nash Wed To G. R. Ours 3d
description: Sophie Nash and George Ralph Ours 3d were married yesterday at St. Thomas' Parish Church in Upper Marlboro, Md. The Rev. Edward Raffetto performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: THE PENSIONS PROBLEM;
Let Pension Funds Help Companies, Too
description: LEAD: WHEN a pension plan is overfinanced, can an employer tap the surplus and put it to other uses? That hotly debated question came one step closer to being decided by a little-reported provision in the new tax bill that attempts to discourage pension ''reversions,'' as the practice is called. This provision, sponsored by Senator Howard M.

title: Bush, in Illinois, Keeps Up Tough Talk
description: Vice President Bush, making appearances today in the counties outside the Democratic stronghold of Chicago, decided to do just a little bit more negative campaigning, at least in key states like this one where the race is considered by many strategists too close to call.

title: Credit Squeeze
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Launching Delayed
description: Moscow postponed launching its first shuttle when a platform failed to separate from the rocket. Page 14. New Phase in Angola War Having lost direct South African aid, Angolan guerrillas still hope to win a voice in a peace agreement. Page 10. China's Scarred Literati China's intellectuals have slowly overcome past persecution, but retribution is a constant threat. Page 12.

title: How to Get a Better Deal on Trade
description: THE candidates have ignored it, but the trade deficit has not gone away. Leaving aside the 30 percent increase in the trade gap in August and the 28 percent drop in July, the long-term trend is not encouraging. Based on the first eight months of the year, the trade deficit for 1988 will probably approach $140 billion, a long way from being in balance. And the deficit is not expected to dip to $100 billion until well into the 1990's.

title: Correction
description: Because of a transmission error, an article last Sunday about a debate over Islamic law in the Sudan reversed the relationship between that issue and the country's civil war.

title: Sri Lanka Peace Talks Break Down Yet Again
description: Talks among the Government and opposition groups on ending political violence and holding elections appear to have reached a stalemate.

title: Notre Dame (8-0) Gets By Navy, 22-7
description: Although unbeaten Notre Dame, rated second in the Associated Press writers' and broadcasters' poll and third in The New York Times's computer ranking, posted its 25th consecutive victory over Navy today, Coach Lou Holtz was not happy.

title: Playing Ball Downwind of Rocky Flats
description: To the Editor:

title: Pietro Annigoni, 78, Dies in Italy; Noted for Portrait of Elizabeth II
description: Pietro Annigoni, the Italian artist whose 1955 portrait of Queen Elizabeth II brought him international acclaim, died Friday in Florence, Italy. He was 78 years old.

title: Prince Attacks Modern Architects Once More
description: Prince Charles attacked modern British architecture again Friday night with a television documentary of his own that left no one in any doubt about what he didn't like.

title: Kathleen A. Hadley Is Wed To James Alan Connors Jr.
description: Kathleen Ann Hadley and James Alan Connors Jr. were married yesterday in the Holy Family Chapel at the College of St. Elizabeth in Convent Station, N.J. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by the Rev. Giles P. Hayes.

title: The Race for Congress; In Westchester, Harsh Exchanges Narrow Gap
description: The race for the 20th Congressional District in Westchester County, one of the most expensive contests in the nation, has taken on a harsh tone, with sharply negative radio advertisements dominating the debate over issues.

title: NONFICTION
description: MONDAY NIGHT MAYHEM: The Inside Story of ABC's Monday Night Football. By Marc Gunther and Bill Carter. (Illustrated. Beech Tree/Morrow, $18.95.) Red Smith once calculated that in a football game the ball was actually in motion only 25 percent of the official playing time; the other 75 percent was used to pick up the ball and get set for the next play. How to fill in the dead time was always a problem for broadcasters. On Sept. 21, 1970, Roone Arledge, president of ABC Sports, solved the problem with ''Monday Night Football.'' His broadcast team would fill in the dead spots: a former star quarterback, Don Meredith, and an abrasive lawyer turned radio sports reporter, Howard Cosell. The show hit pay dirt, and for most of the next 15 years watchers of ''Monday Night Football'' cheered Mr. Meredith and his put-downs of Mr. Cosell. One of the few notable dissenters was Henry Ford II, whose company sponsored the first season. ''I listened to that gab between Don Meredith and Howard Cosell,'' the book quotes him. ''I couldn't concentrate on the football. Take that guy Cosell off.'' ''Monday Night Mayhem,'' by Marc Gunther and Bill Carter, two journalists who cover television, is a fast-moving, evenhanded account of how the show began, hit the top and eventually sank low, in ratings and revenue, amid disputes among Mr. Cosell and his colleagues. The book is straight; there is no fan adulation. It describes what it was like inside the ABC broadcasting booth, control truck, executive office. By 1987, the original stars had left, and the authors say the production ''was not 'Monday Night Football' anymore. It was football on Monday nights.'' The thrill of victory, Henry Ford might have thought.

title: Mailbox; Give More Credit To Alysheba
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Courts Altering Criteria
description: Landlords and tenants in New York City have long been aware that rent-regulated status for a tenant is based on the assumption that the tenant really lives in the apartment as a primary residence.

title: A GOLDEN BOY NO MORE
description: LEAD: THE TIME IS RIPE The 1940 Journal of Clifford Odets. Introduction by William Gibson. Illustrated. 369 pp. New York: Grove Press. $22.50.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: No Escaping A Craving

title: CONNECTIUT GUIDE
description: PARISIAN HAUTE COUTURE Original gowns from the houses of Paquin, Poiret and Worth, will be among 50 examples of early 20th-century Parisian haute couture in an exhibition opening today at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford.

title: FARMERS REMOVED FROM PARK IN INDIA
description: Policemen wielding batons began rounding up thousands of defiant farmers who have been camped in a park and escorting them out of town on Saturday night.

title: Sports of The Times; Halloween Party at Yankee Stadium
description: THE invitation for the Halloween party at Yankee Stadium read that a costume was required. The invitation was signed, ''King Kong.''

title:
MUSIC;
An Opera Company
description: LEAD: FOR the New York tenor Ira Siff - known onstage as the soprano Mme. Vera Galupe-Borszkh - La Gran Scena Opera Company, which he formed in 1981, was a true labor of love.

title: Prague Police Seal Off Site of Friday Rally
description: The police sealed off much of Prague's Wenceslas Square today as water cannon and military trucks stood ready to stop demonstrators from returning to the site of a police attack on a peaceful rally the night before.

title: League Is Changing, but Lakers Are Still on Top
description: THE Los Angeles Lakers are stronger, the Boston Celtics older and the Detroit Pistons deeper. But perhaps the most intriguing aspect of the 43d National Basketball Association season, which begins Friday night, is whether the Atlanta Hawks can prove that Dominique Wilkins, Moses Malone and Reggie Theus, with a combined salary of $4 million, can play with one $75 basketball.

title: Islanders Beaten In Overtime, 3-2
description: Tommy Albelin scored from the blue line 2 minutes 33 seconds into overtime tonight to give the Quebec Nordiques a 3-2 victory over the Islanders.

title: Employees Deserve Their Money
description: IN the final hours of this Congressional session, I was able to press the Administration to adopt a new policy that will give Congress time to protect the pension security of millions of Americans. The six-month Internal Revenue Service plan should deter companies from terminating healthy pension plans to strip them of so-called ''excess'' funds.

title: CHILDHOOD: THE NAMES STILL HURT
description: THEY said I was chubby, ''pleasingly plump.'' But I knew I was fat. I could ride a two-wheeler, skate, catch a ball with either hand, but I couldn't run bases like my skinny tomboy friends. You know you're fat when you're always the last one chosen for the softball team.

title: BUSY AS AN APIS MELLIFERA
description: A BOOK OF BEES . . . And How to Keep Them. By Sue Hubbell. Illustrated by Sam Potthoff. 193 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: On Language; Like Ugly on an Ape
description: I KNEW THE MINUTE I said 'card-carrying member of the A.C.L.U.,' '' George Bush told Maureen Dowd of The New York Times, ''a couple of your best columnists would jump all over me like ugly on an ape.''

title: Killer of a Drug Agent Gets Long Prison Term
description: A former Mexican policeman was sentenced Friday to 240 years plus life in prison for the 1985 torture-murder of a United States drug agent and his pilot.

title: MISSION IMPOSSIBLE
description: Want to guarantee that your mail is delivered - and promptly? Camouflage your envelopes as bills and payments. For decades I have received every invoice due and the vendor has received every check I've mailed. JEROME AGEL New York, N.Y.

title: The Race for Congress; Nevada Senator's Hope Is Revived
description: Gamblers, of which there are several in this vast and arid state, might have thought they had a sure thing betting that the popular Democratic Governor, Richard H. Bryan, would push the state's hapless Republican Senator, Chic Hecht, out of office.

title: CANADA'S NATIONAL REFERENDUM ON ALL THINGS AMERICAN
description: Living atop the 49th parallel has never been easy for Canadians. When Robert Campeau won his takeover battle for Bloomingdale's and other parts of the United States-based Federated Stores chain earlier this year, the Canadian entrepreneur's victory was saluted across his homeland. When Wayne Gretzky took his ice hockey talent south a few months later, from the Edmonton Oilers to the Los Angeles Kings, the whole country was plunged into gloom.

title:
DINING OUT;
Surprising Italian Dishes in Clinton
description: LEAD: A LITTLE over a year ago, Ann Chamberlain, a science teacher, joined forces with a Hungarian-born chef, Louis Szabo, to open Prego, an Italian restaurant in Clinton, Hunterdon County.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE PROSECUTORS: Inside the Offices of the Government's Most Powerful Lawyers, by James B. Stewart. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) Charges of insider trading at Morgan Stanley and bribery at McDonnell Douglas are among the cases portrayed in James B. Stewart's book about government prosecutors. ''Each of the stories unfolds with the suspense of a terrific detective novel, but the book is even better than that because the stories are true,'' Seymour Wishman said in The Book Review last year. THE WORLD AS I FOUND IT, by Bruce Duffy. (Ticknor & Fields, $8.95.) During his early days at Cambridge, arguing logic with Bertrand Russell, it seemed that Ludwig Wittgenstein was the ultimate system builder, attempting in his book ''Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus'' to delineate the geometries of language and life. But somewhere along the way, the philosopher had a change of heart. The ''sweeping arrangement of fact and fancy'' in Bruce Duffy's novel about this enigmatic man ''is vivid, passionate and funny,'' Perry Meisel said here last year. ''Mr. Duffy's is an achievement in both fiction and historiography which deepens Wittgenstein's mythology and should attract a wider audience to it.'' THE TOXIC CLOUD, by Michael H. Brown. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $9.95.) With dioxins, heavy metals, sulfur dioxide and other chemicals filling the air, environmentalists fear that the atmosphere itself is becoming a toxic cloud. Last year, our reviewer, Philip Shabecoff, said this book is ''so compelling it may prod the public to demand that serious attention be paid to this national scandal.'' MURDER IN THE CIA, by Margaret Truman. (Fawcett, $4.95.) President Truman may have been responsible for the creation of the Central Intelligence Agency, Newgate Callendar said here last year, but his daughter, Margaret, takes a dim view of how the organization has changed. Miss Truman, who has also written novels about murder in the White House, the Supreme Court, Georgetown and other Washington locales, ''has become a real pro who can juggle false leads with the best of them.'' THE PHILOSOPHICAL DISENFRANCHISEMENT OF ART, by Arthur C. Danto. (Columbia University, $13.) ''Without theories of art,'' writes the philosopher and art critic Arthur C. Danto, ''black paint is just black paint.'' ''The magnitude of the issues Mr. Danto's books raise is a mark of the books' importance,'' Paul Guyer said in The Book Review in 1987. FELICITY, by Coral Lansbury. (Ivy, $3.95.) Felicity, a beautiful if slovenly art historian, becomes involved with a gang of adulterous academics in a search for a campus murderer. Last year, our reviewer, Fay Weldon, complimented Coral Lansbury for ''the sheer pleasure she takes in her own intelligence, her own ingenuity, her own wonderfully informed mind.'' THE LOBBY: Jewish Political Power and American Foreign Policy, by Edward Tivnan. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) Edward Tivnan's argument that the American pro-Israel lobby has encouraged the suppression of dissent among American Jews may be overstated, Walter Goodman said in The Times last year. But ''in treating that delicate subject in a not-so-delicate way, 'The Lobby' is in keeping with the scrappy spirit of open controversy found in both America and Israel.'' GREAT SKY RIVER, by Gregory Benford. (Bantam, $4.50.) When artificial intelligence takes over a planet, the dominated human inhabitants are nearly reduced to a breed of biological machines. ''The mutual incomprehension between adversaries gives rise to crisply rendered scenes of suspense and horror as well as some surprising moments of gallows humor,'' Gerald Jonas said here this year. MANY MASKS: A Life of Frank Lloyd Wright, by Brendan Gill. (Ballantine, $12.95.) Frank Lloyd Wright was as inventive a self-promoter as he was an architect, Brendan Gill writes, ''a virtuoso at bearing false witness.'' ''In giving us a vivid picture of Wright the man, Mr. Gill also succeeds in giving us a practical appreciation of his work,'' Michiko Kakutani said in The Times last year. ''As with the play 'Amadeus,' we end by contemplating the frequent disjunction between temperament and talent, character and genius.'' TENDING TO VIRGINIA, by Jill McCorkle. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A shocking revelation from her husband sends a pregnant young Southern woman fleeing home to Saxapaw, N.C., for a therapeutic conversational marathon with three generations of family. Last year, Alice McDermott said in The Book Review that she admired ''the tremendous exuberance'' of Jill McCorkle's characters. TOWARDS THE MOUNTAIN: An Autobiography, by Alan Paton. (Scribners, $9.95.) Born in South Africa just after the Boer War, Alan Paton, the author of the novel ''Cry, the Beloved Country,'' spent his life fighting apartheid. ''No one . . . has done more to interpret black and white South Africa to the world outside,'' Thomas Pakenham said here in 1980, ''its terrible wealth and beauty, its frustration and anguish and hope.'' EARLY GRAVES, by Joseph Hansen. (Mysterious Press, $3.95.) When Dave Brandstetter, a homosexual insurance investigator, returns home to Los Angeles and finds a dead man on his patio, he is drawn into a mystery involving a serial killer whose victims are young men suffering from AIDS. Last year, our reviewer, Newgate Callendar, said this ''well plotted and well written'' novel is ''about AIDS and the fear, even hysteria, it creates among otherwise rational people. . . . 'Early Graves' takes a long, sad look at the problem.''

title: Protecting History Under Water
description: WHEN the Confederate ironclad Georgia was added to the National Register of Historic Places in April 1987, some people wondered why. She is under 30 feet of water in Savannah, Ga.

title: From Lassie to Pee-Wee
description: I LOVED WATCHING television as a child. In the early morning, I would turn on the set, sit on the floor and watch the odd assortment of farm reports, documentaries and public service announcements that came on before the cartoons. None of this material was created or shown with children in mind, and that, certainly, was a large part of its appeal. The haphazard jumble had a force, a meaning - it was a world of chance, a world in which anything could happen.

title: New Dean's Proposals Raise Concerns in a School at Yale
description: Yale University last week named a new dean for its School of Organization and Management and announced a series of changes in the curriculum there, setting off concern that the school may be moving away from its experimental approach to graduate business education.

title: Dukakis Said to Ignore Black Vote
description: THE Democratic Party has shown a talent for getting specific groups of supporters to the voting booth in close elections in recent years, but the State Assembly minority leader and other Democrats say that they are worried about the widening lead that George Bush appears to be taking in Presidential election polls and that they fear Michael Dukakis will not remain close enough to allow even the best street operation to give him the state's 16 electoral votes.

title: Is Envy at the Root Of Anti-Blonde Bias?
description: ''There Are Redeeming Qualities'' [ Opinion, Sept. 11 ] evidently wasn't written by someone subscribing to the adage ''Gentlemen prefer blondes.'' Early on, he complains: ''Bubble-head blondes in red Firebirds cut you off at intersections.''

title: Indiana Eludes Iowa's 558 Passing Yards
description: Anthony Thompson rushed for 168 yards and three touchdowns today as Indiana, surviving a devastating passing attack by Iowa's Chuck Hartlieb, held off a second-half rally and beat the Hawkeyes, 45-34, in a Big Ten Conference game.

title: I'm Looking Forward to More Visits From My Silent, Sloe-Eyed Guests
description: I NEVER knew how the woods would work on me; I had loved the city so. Growing up I never had longings for a house; apartments suited me just fine: nosey neighbors, noisy kids, radios blaring, cars screeching, people dropping by - people everywhere - I liked it. But, because my husband worked in the suburbs I agreed to move to a house and adjust.

title: The 'Lost Art' of Railbird Hunting
description: LEAD: STANDING at the back of the skiff, Ken Camp looked like a gondolier as he pushed forward with a pole through the tall marshy grasses lining the Maurice River.

title: Crew Teams in Simsbury Steal Thunder from Football
description: AS a middle-school student, Paul DiGiacomo dreamed of playing football at Simsbury High School. ''I like the game and I used to think about all of the glamour - the cheerleaders, the band, the crowds and so on,'' he said.

title: ALL THE SHIPS AT SEA, A WINTER DIRECTORY
description: LEAD: The following directory of cruise ships is arranged by destination and basically covers sailings from Nov. 1 to Feb. 28. Information for the directory was supplied by individual cruise companies, but dates, ports of call and fares are all subject to change. Unless otherwise noted, fares are for one person in double occupancy, exclusive of port taxes; some fares may be subject to currency fluctuations.

title: IN FLAMES ON ASH WEDNESDAY
description: FIRESTORM By William Coyle. 336 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $18.95.

title: EROTICISM IS WATCHING ONESELF
description: LEAD: THE STANDARD LIFE OF A TEMPORARY PANTYHOSE SALESMAN By Aldo Busi. Translated by Raymond Rosenthal. 430 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.

title: NONFICTION
description: LOVING RACHEL: A Family's Journey From Grief. By Jane Bernstein. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) When Jane Bernstein and her husband, Paul Glynn, discovered that their 2-month-old daughter, Rachel, was blind, the result of an incompletely developed optic nerve, they were stunned. Blind? Their pretty, cherished baby? It was inconceivable. Over the months, as additional symptoms cropped up and they were presented with the frightening possibility that Rachel might be brain damaged as well, the bleakness the couple felt was almost overwhelming. Their marriage was bruised by the emotional upheaval, and their 4-year-old, Charlotte, stood in doorways ''wide-eyed and silent,'' watching her mother cry. Their anguish and fear seemed insurmountable. Fortunately, the family found a source of strength - their love for Rachel. They loved her not in spite of or because of her disability, but simply for who she was. Ultimately, this is a story of courageous love that rises above misfortune; of parental love, immeasurably patient, hopeful, buoyant; of marital love that is tested, stretched and strengthened through adversity. Ms. Bernstein is a writer of considerable skill (she wrote the novel ''Departures''), and in ''Loving Rachel,'' which reads almost like a diary, her prose is incisive and vivid; it rings with truth and flashes of humor. Parents of disabled children, or any parents for that matter, will find this an inspiring tale.

title: Headliners; Today, the Barnyard
description: Revolution is afoot on the animal farms of Sweden, fomented largely by Astrid Lindgren. Mrs. Lindgren, the widely read author who is perhaps best known as the creator of the character ''Pippi Longstocking,'' lobbied tirelessly for the passage of an animal-welfare law that is now being implemented. Under the new law, Swedish cattle and pigs must have ''access to straw and litter,'' chickens must be let out of cramped cages, and no drugs or hormones can be administered except to treat disease.

title: Correction
description: A Travel Advisory report on Oct. 9 misstated the United States telephone number for reservations at the Hotel Regina in Grindelwald, Switzerland. It is (800) 223-6800; in New York State, the number is (212) 838-3110.

title: 'They' Were Right About Pollution
description: RECENTLY, we have become acutely aware of an incipient problem that has been with us for years, but until now has only been the concern of the proverbial ''they.''

title: A Temple To the Dreams of Flight
description: The history of flight is a story of characters, most of them eccentric, who spent too much time in the garage, too little time on such necessities as sleep and usually died young in the air because of it. Fortunately, many of the creations left behind by these pioneers are still intact, or have been lovingly restored, and have found a permanent home at Seattle's new Museum of Flight.

title: Erich Mendelsohn's Lyrical Vision
description: Erich Mendelsohn is one of those architects whose name everyone knows - well, let's say everyone who follows the world of architecture knows - but about whom no one ever seems to know very much. He hovers around the edges of modern architecture, a contemporary of such great figures as Mies van der Rohe, Walter Gropius and Le Corbusier, but never quite their equal. History has relegated him to what can best be thought of as a supporting role in the great drama of 20th-century modernism. Mendelsohn, who was born in East Prussia in 1887 and died in San Francisco in 1953, never led a school; he never founded a style, and with one notable exception he never designed a building that the average lover of architecture would be likely to recognize today, half a century after he and his contemporaries did their most important work.

title: Lights! Camera! Action! Acting Tips for Interviews
description: AFTER the job hunter's foot is in the door, what then? Presenting a positive image - what used to be called making a good impression - has become so important that these days executives at even the highest level may seek out career coaching or enlist the aid of actors to help them play their roles better at an interview.

title: American Opera Singers Can Look Homeward
description: Every year, 30 or so singers make debuts at the New York City Opera. They may stay on and become regulars, or be picked up (''stolen,'' as Beverly Sills sometimes puts it) by the Metropolitan, Chicago, San Francisco and the big European houses, or disappear from New York. But the City Opera is by no means the first step in a performing career for most singers.

title: VIEWS OF THE TURN-OF-THE CENTURY AT THE STAMFORD MUSEUM
description: IN anticipation of this century's end, the Stamford Museum and Nature Center is celebrating the end of the last one. ''American Artists at the Turn of the Century,'' as it is called, focuses on the period 1880 to 1910 (give or take a few years) and it comes with a catalogue written by Dorothy Mayhall, the museum's director of art and the organizer of the show.

title: Condensation Can Cause Problems
description: FROST appeared on the windowpanes of my house last week, reminding me that the storm windows need to come out of the basement. It's also the season to start thinking about protecting cameras from the cold.

title: New Beer Makes a Pitch For the Upscale Market
description: ''IT'S here,'' the bulletin board at trendy Dalt's restaurant and bar announced. ''Jersey Premium Lager Beer.'' The message is repeated in stand-up placards at each table: ''Now Available Here, Jersey Premium Lager Beer. Jersey's Own.''

title: Practical Traveler; When Teens Go Overboard
description: Cruise lines' vigorous sales work promoting short cruises, especially to younger people, backfired last spring and summer. An overpopulation of students on several cruises created conditions that one passenger, himself a parent of teen-agers, described as Fort Lauderdale at sea. A passenger on another vessel, also a parent and therefore not out of touch, compared life on deck to life on the grounds of the Woodstock music festival.

title: Straight Talk in Africa
description: Olusegun Obasanjo, former President and still a powerful personality of Nigeria, says it straight out. ''The bold fact is that Africa is a continent in dereliction and decay. We are moving backward as the rest of the world is forging ahead.''

title: Waiting for Godot Tickets
description: To the Editor:

title: Carlo Tresca's Enemies
description: To the Editor:To the Editor:

title: Former Mental Patients Upset Coastal Community
description: LEAD: THIS seaside community is less than one mile square, has a business district that is only two blocks long and a year-round population of 4,600. Its Victorian buildings and narrow streets evoke memories of a gentler era, and its tranquil atmosphere gives no hint of the controversy prompted by the large number of deinstitutionalized mentally ill people that have been placed in the town's boarding homes and rooming houses.

title: For Some in Maine Town, a Boom Was No Boom
description: Dennis Daniel feels like a prisoner in his own home.

title: Westchester Residents, Citing Deceit, Oppose Group Home Plan
description: Some residents of this Westchester village of 6,100 oppose plans of a private agency and New York State to place 12 severely retarded adults in a new group home, but they say it is not that they do not want the home placed in their backyard. Rather, they say, they simply do not want it placed behind their backs.

title: Some Familiar Faces in the Buyout Crowd
description: WHENEVER one corporation dangles big money in front of another, a tight circle of seasoned bankers, lawyers and buyout artists bursts into action. These are the people who are instrumental in formulating battle tactics, offering advice or actually mounting buyout offers of their own.

title: The Voters' Race
description: With the general election less than two weeks away, beleaguered employees of the Board of Elections were worried last week that their 14-hour days would not be enough to insure that all would-be voters in the county would have their registration applications approved by Nov. 8.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 30, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Weel List Fiction 1 4 HEAVEN AND HELL, by John Jakes. (Dell, $5.95.) Two families in the aftermath of the Civil War. 2 4 HER MOTHER'S DAUGHTER, by Marilyn French. (Ballantine, $5.95.) A chronicle of four generations of women. 3 6 MURDER IN THE CIA, by Margaret Truman. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A C.I.A. operative investigates the suspicious death of a literary agent on her way to Budapest. 4 6 THE DARK TOWER: The Gunslinger, by Stephen King. (Plume/NAL, $10.95.) Volume One of a series about a young man's pursuit of an evil force. 5 4 A SOUTHERN FAMILY, by Gail Godwin. (Avon, $4.95.) The effect of a violent death on an eccentric North Carolina clan. 6 3 THE MAIDEN, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $4.50.) The passion of a warrior princess and a man who would be king. 7 3 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Plume/NAL, $8.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 8 1 FAVORITE SON, by Steve Sohmer. (Bantam, $4.95.) The phantasmagoria that follows a televised attempted assassination of a senator. 9 6 LONIGAN, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $3.50.) Six short stories about life on the American frontier. 10 * 4 HEAVEN CENT, by Piers Anthony. (Avon, $4.50.) A young prince's search for a missing sorcerer. 11 1 WASHINGTON WIVES, by Maureen Dean. Sex, love, self-analysis, forgiveness and reverence in English clerical circles. 15 28 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $4.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions in treating serious illness. 2 17 SMALL SACRIFICES, by Ann Rule. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) A police-procedural account of a case involving murder and incest in an Oregon town. 3 1 THE CAT WHO CAME FOR CHRISTMAS, by Cleveland Amory. (Penguin, $6.95.) A self-styled curmudgeon's memoir of a cat that adopted and soon owned him. 4 262 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 5 20 THE POWER OF MYTH, by Joseph Campbell with Bill Moyers. (Doubleday, $19.95.) How mythology illuminates the stages of life. 6 4 KEEPING SECRETS, by Suzanne Somers. (Warner, $4.95.) The actress recalls her experience as the daughter of an alcoholic. 7 * 6 I'M WITH THE BAND, by Pamela Des Barres. (Jove, $3.95.) The ''confessions of a groupie.'' 8 13 SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright with Paul Greengrass. (Dell, $4.95.) A critique of American liberal arts education. 10 8 VEIL, by Bob Woodward. (Pocket, $4.95.) The inside story of William Casey's years at the helm of the C.I.A., 1981 to 1987.
