Cartoons about a boy, his toy tiger and his parents. 2 7 TALES TOO TICKLISH TO TELL, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) ''Bloom County'' cartoons. 3 22 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) How to solve your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. 4 1 THE FAR SIDE GALLERY 3, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $10.95.) A selection of cartoons from three previously published collections. 5 14 NIGHT OF THE CRASH-TEST DUMMIES, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $5.95.) The ninth collection of ''Far Side'' cartoons. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: A Case of ''the Slows'
description: GEORGE B. McCLELLAN The Young Napoleon. By Stephen W. Sears. Illustrated. 482 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $24.95.

title: HANDLE WITH CARE
description: As the wife of a hemophiliac who recently died of complications of AIDS, I was moved by Cecilia Worth's article, ''Handle With Care'' (Body and Mind, Sept. 25).

title: Parade Tomorrow
description: The Halloween parade will begin at 7 P.M. tomorrow on West Street between Houston and Christopher Streets, travel east on Houston Street to the Avenue of the Americas, north to 14th Street and east to Union Square.

title: What It Takes to Dress Like a First Lady
description: To the Editor:

title: For Sean O'Casey, Acceptance at Last As a Modern Master
description: To his consternation, Sean O'Casey saw his theatrical reputation fluctuate widely during his lifetime. When he died in 1964 at the age of 84 he was generally regarded as a playwright who had not measured up to his early potential. Even those plays that were acknowledged as his finest - his Dublin trilogy, ''The Shadow of a Gunman,'' ''Juno and the Paycock'' and ''The Plough and the Stars'' - were not in the active international repertory. The feeling among some critics and academics was that he was a man mired in his time who suffered in comparison with modernists like Samuel Beckett.

title: Karen Stone of ABC Wed
description: Karen Lee Stone, a correspondent in Washington for ABC News, and Bruce Edward Yannett, an associate counsel in the Office of the Independent Counsel: Iran-Contra in Washington, were married yesterday at Georgetown Lutheran Church in Washington by the Rev. Robert R. Behnke. The bride, a daughter of Leanore J. Stone of Dillon, Colo., and Elmer O. Stone of Seneca Falls, N.Y., will keep her name professionally. The bridegrom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter W. Yannett of Seaford, L.I.

title: Westchester Opinion; SPEAKING PERSONALLY: JUST AS RETIREMENT WAS GETTING COZY, A NEW GRANDCHILD
description: LOOK what's happening to me, two and a half years after my retirement, when I'm finally making peace with myself about the change.

title: 'WE'RE ALL SHOCKPROOF THESE DAYS'
description: THE COMING TRIUMPH OF THE FREE WORLD By Rick DeMarinis. 177 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE TURNAROUND WIND Written and illustrated by Arnold Lobel. 32 pp. New York: Harper & Row.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THE great holiday is almost upon us. Mind you, I'm not talking about Election Day or Allhallows Eve (or even its commercialized replica, Halloween). So if this leaves your calendar apparently one holiday short, don't be puzzled. It's a made-up holiday. In fact, I'm declaring it, right now.

title: Comings and Goings
description: THE Boston Red Sox, saying they had younger players in the farm system they wanted to promote, have released Larry Parrish, the 34-year-old first baseman-designated hitter who joined the team in July and helped power the Red Sox to the division title with a .259 batting average, 7 home runs and 26 runs batted in. . . . Howard Johnson of the Mets underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right shoulder at Roosevelt Hospital to repair torn cartilage. The one-hour operation was performed by Dr. James Parkes, the Mets' team physician. . . . Boris Becker has become the fourth player to qualify for the $750,000 Nabisco Masters that begins Nov. 30 at Madison Square Garden.

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;
White Plains, a Coming Attraction
description: LEAD: When WP Centre Associates went shopping in downtown White Plains recently, it literally bought out the store, paying $16.3 million for Alexander's, a retail fixture in the city since 1956.

title: Social Events; History, Horses and Crafts
description: Historical Benefit Oct. 31 - For the first time in its 184-year history, the New-York Historical Society will hold a fund-raising evening in its galleries on Central Park West at 77th Street. Paul Volcker, former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, will be honored, and the more than 700 guests are expected to include Mayor Koch, former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and the philanthropist Laurence S. Rockefeller. The black-tie event starts with cocktails at 6:30 to the accompaniment of four ensembles throughout the museum. Dinner and dancing follow. Tickets, $500, from 212-873-3400. Hunt Ball at the Plaza Oct. 31 - On the eve of the weeklong 105th National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden, the equestrian set from around the nation will gather for the Hunt Ball at the Plaza. Cocktails at 7:30 will start the evening for the benefit of the National Horse Show Foundation, which supports numerous equestrian programs. White tie preferred. Tickets, $200 or $125 for those 30 and under, from 212-757-0222. Briefly Noted Oct. 31 - The American Craft Museum will hold its annual benefit auction at the museum, at 40 West 53d Street, starting with cocktails and a buffet at 5:30. Fifty pieces by leading American craft artists will be auctioned in the range of $1,500 to $14,000. Entertainment follows. Tickets, $175, from 212-956-3535. Oct. 31 - The Junior Committee of the Manhattan Friends of Thirteen will hold a masquerade ball at the Explorers Club, 46 East 70th Street, at 9. Tickets, $80, from 212-560-2800. Nov. 1 - The 95-year-old Visiting Nurse Service of New York will hold its annual dinner-dance at the Plaza starting with cocktails at 7:30. Tickets for formal event, $250, from 212-794-9200. Nov. 1 - The Annual Fall Gala of the American Ballet Theater will be at the Palladium, 126 East 14th Street, starting at 7. Dress is black tie. Tickets, $75, $125 and $250, from 212-477-3030, extension 246 or 247. Nov. 2 - The Big Apple Circus is back in town with the added attraction of the 23-member Nanjing Acrobatic Troupe from China. The Institute for Asian Studies has the best seats in the house for a benefit. Show time is 7:30 and will be followed by a champagne and Chinese hors d'oeuvres party at Shun Lee West around the corner from Lincoln Center and the circus tent. Tickets, $100, $125 or $150 for show and party or $50 for the show alone, from 212-535-7496. Nov. 2 - The Count Basie Orchestra, a drill team, dancers, an auction, cocktails, dinner and dancing will mark the New York City Mission Society benefit at the Waldorf-Astoria. Black tie for evening starting at 6:30. Tickets, $350, from 212-997-0100. Nov. 3 - The Archives of American Art, part of the Smithsonian Institution, is opening a permanent exhibition space in New York at the Paine Webber Building of the Equitable Center, 1285 Avenue of the Americas near 52d Street. A preview of the inaugural exhibition, ''The Armory Show of 1913: A Documentary View,'' will be shown from 6 to 7 followed by cocktails, dinner, dancing and entertainment by the Capitol Steps, a group of Congressional aides who perform political satire. Black tie. Tickets, $250, from 212-399-5030. Nov. 3 - The New Israel Fund, a philanthropic partnership of Israelis and North Americans devoted to strengthening democracy and social justice in Israel, is holding a theater benefit at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street. A 6:30 cocktail buffet precedes the performance at 8 of ''Soul of a Jew.'' Tickets, $100 and $250, or $50 for the show alone, from 212-302-0066. Nov. 4 - The Big Apple Circus, said to be the nation's only nonprofit circus, and its auxiliary programs including the New York School for Circus Arts, will benefit from a full evening for the whole family under the big tent at Lincoln Center. A Chinese buffet dinner at 6 opens the evening, followed by a 7:30 performance featuring the Nanjing Acrobatic Troupe from China. Dessert and dancing in the ring follows. Tickets for adults, $450, $250 and $150 and for children 12 and under, $100 and $50, from 212-391-0760. Nov. 6 - The New York Chapter of Hadassah will hold its annual dinner-dance at the Plaza starting with cocktails at 5:30 to benefit the Hadassah Medical Organization in Jerusalem. Tickets, $250 or $75 for those under 40, from 212-765-7050. Benefit for Hearing Nov. 6 - During its 30-year history, the Deafness Research Foundation has awarded 11,095 grants totaling nearly $10 million for research into hearing loss affecting an estimated 22 million Americans. One of those affected is Dr. C. Everett Koop, Surgeon General of the United States, who will be honored at a dinner-dance benefit at the Waldorf-Astoria. Cocktails at 5, Victor Borge at 6 and dinner at 7. Tickets, $400, from 212-684-6556. Night of Laughs Nov. 7 - The New York downstate affiliate of the American Diabetes Association will benefit from an evening of dining and comedy. The benefit starts with dinner at 6 at Caroline's at the Seaport, Pier 17 and Fulton Street, after which guests will board buses for a ride to the Joyce Theater on Eighth Avenue at 18th Street. Ten stand-up comics will present their acts, which will be followed by a cast party in the theater's lobby. Tickets, $100 for dinner, show and party, or $50 for show and party, or $25 for the show alone, from 212-947-9707.

title: Reviews/Music; With a 60's Sensibility
description: It's a common idea in music criticism that musical eras end abruptly, replaced by something new. Zussan Kali Fasteau's show at the Knitting Factory on Tuesday night, dripping with 1960's sentimentality and esthetics, was proof that intellectual movement isn't always that orderly.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title: Dukakis Assails Administration's Rural Policies
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, clearly fired by a sense that his underdog campaign was on the move again, told a roaring rally here today, ''We're closing that gap.''

title: Resumes That Talk and Tell the Truth, Too
description: A RESUME is no more than a marketing tool to get your foot in the door, career experts agree. But with so many resumes flooding the market, how can a job hunter convince a potential employer to let his foot in the door, and not somebody else's?

title: Boy Admits Causing a Death
description: A boy has confessed releasing the brakes on a freight car that ran over and killed a railroad worker Oct. 17, the police said Friday. The authorities said the boy was under 10 years old and would not be charged. The freight car rolled about a mile before it struck a Burlington Northern work truck, then killed the worker, Kevin Evenstad, 35 years old.

title: Repairing Ceramic Floor Tiles
description: CERAMIC floor tiles offer superior durability and appearance, but are brittle. A powerful blow from a sharp object can crack even the most expertly laid tile, but often foot pressure alone is sufficient to crack tile that is improperly set or inadequately supported.

title: 'Favorite Son': Cynicism Spices Political Intrigue
description: With little more than a week remaining before Election Day, NBC is presenting the country with a six-hour mini-series in which the hero, an embittered F.B.I. agent looking in disgust at the American political process, concedes that he ''hasn't voted since Truman went back to Independence.'' We can argue for years as to whether television shapes popular culture and ideas or merely reflects them. What cannot be denied is that ''Favorite Son'' - to be broadcast tonight, tomorrow and Tuesday at 9 o'clock - offers a portrait of contemporary values and governmental machinations that sets new high-water marks for cynicism. Making the exercise all the more startling, most of the scenario, cleverly echoing headlines of recent years, is thoroughly believable and, as American mini-series go, entertaining.

title: Dazzle Remains For Former Stars
description: Seldom is a 2-2 game described as satisfying, but for 20,731 soccer-hungry spectators at Giants Stadium, that word fit the Legends game, an exhibition featuring two dozen or so of the world's best players.

title: Correction
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Pillsbury Company incorrectly described a disclosure by the company. Pillsbury, which has rejected a takeover offer from Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., disclosed that other parties had expressed varying degrees of interest in buying the company, but it did not report that it had received another formal offer.

title: Fairy Tale Fringes
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Tyson, Rooney, Trump and King
description: WHEN last seen in his black trunks and his black shoes, Mike Tyson was standing over Michael Spinks with the cruel dignity befitting a world heavyeight champion. More than four months since then, it's as if Mike Tyson has been an actor playing himself in several strange roles unbefitting a world heavyweight champion. In order of appearance, he has been:

title: Reviews/Music; Life's Cycle, to Mozart
description: Manuel Alum's ''Monte'' is a visionary dance about life. It is not the most dramatic of pieces, at least as performed by Ballet Hispanico. But it represents a change of pace for the company, which presented the piece for the first time on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater. And the Ballet Hispanico dancers gave ''Monte'' a hauntingly lyrical performance.

title: Furniture Fit For the Kings of France
description: Today's big money goes into paintings, but in France in the 17th and 18th centuries it was decorative arts that commanded high prices. The ebenistes, or cabinetmakers, and menuisiers, or chair makers, in the reigns of Louis XIV, XV and XVI produced furniture of richness and superb quality. The word masterpiece can properly be applied to many, as its origin was the piece a journeyman had to submit to a guild in order to qualify as a master.

title: A La Carte: Hearty Fare for Autumn Diners
description: AUTUMN'S chilly blasts have driven the crowds from the East End. This might be an ideal time to try the hardy Tuscan specialties on the fall menu of Sapore di Mare (Montauk Highway, Wainscott, 537-2704), one of this summer's hottest Hampton restaurants.

title: An All-Out Evening
description: When Renee gives a party,'' said Victor McTeer, ''I go.'' All the way from Greenville, Miss.? ''All the way from Greenville to Chicago, Ill. Her parties are famous,'' he said with a laugh.

title: CHASING THAT HOT NEW ACCOUNT IN MOSCOW
description: Anyone watching Chancellor Helmut Kohl lumbering into Moscow last week with 50 businessmen and $1.6 billion worth of credits in tow could hardly be blamed for assuming that change has its rich rewards. That, no doubt, was how Mr. Kohl hoped his gifts would be understood as he joined the long caravan of Western politicians and capitalists drawn by a new star to the East.

title: No Headline
description: IT IS TWO DAYS AFTER THE MOST DRAMATIC moment in Lloyd Bentsen's political career, his Vice Presidential debate with Senator Dan Quayle in Omaha. But in the more mundane realm of day-to-day politics, Bentsen has hit a snag. He is sitting in a Houston television studio, from where he is to be linked by satellite to stations in such places as Amarillo, Wichita Falls, Harlingen, Midland and Sherman. This is to be the electronic equivalent of a one-man blitz of rural Texas. But one by one, most of the interviews fall through because of technical difficulties or scheduling foul-ups.

title: Directional Illiteracy: Lost on the Island
description: I'M in trouble on Long Island. An architectural trend is interfering with my meager orienteering skills. More and more strip malls are being built around parking lots. Sometimes they're in straight rows, other times they're L-shaped. They usually have a unifying roof or cornice. they all have delis, pizza places, stationery stores and dress shops. They all look alike. My optometrist is in one. Fabric and specialty food stores I frequent are in others. I have trouble locating them.

title: Auburn Stops Florida By 16-0
description: Stacy Danley rushed for 131 yards and a touchdown, and Auburn limited Florida to 116 yards today for a 16-0 victory and a share of first place in the Southeastern Conference.

title: What Will Mrs. Grundy Say?
description: To the Editor:

title: These Days, Composing Can Be Fun
description: The art of composing music gets easier all the time. A week hardly goes by without the announcement of a new electronic device that promises to speed up the dreary business of putting one note after another on score paper. Presumably the composer, burning with inspiration but overburdened by mundane details, will now be able to churn out more and better work. If this isn't progress, what is?

title: Hope P. Geier Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip H. Geier Jr. of New York and New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Hope Philippa Geier to Theodore Briell Smith 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith Jr. of Mill Neck, L.I., and Point O'Woods, Fire Island, L.I.

title: SOVIET TEST DATA REKINDLE DISPUTE
description: The data gathered from a recent underground nuclear explosion at a Soviet test site have reinvigorated a debate over the Reagan Administration's stance in talks on nuclear testing. The experiment was the second conducted under a verification agreement signed by the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Trenton State Edges Montclair State
description: Steve Ware, who had 32 carries for 259 yards, scored on a 44-yard run as Trenton State edged Montclair State, 23-21, tonight in a New Jersey State Conference game at Sprague Field.

title: YOU CAN'T BEAT THE CABAL
description: LIBERTY UNDER SIEGE American Politics, 1976-1988. By Walter Karp. 255 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $19.95.

title: CANADA VOTE RACE SEEMS TO TIGHTEN
description: Despite widespread expectations that the governing Progressive Conservatives would be easily returned to power in Canada, the general election campaign appears to have suddenly tightened because of voter anxieties over the free-trade pact with the United States.

title: HAPPY TO SING THE BLUES
description: OF SUCH SMALL DIFFERENCES By Joanne Greenberg. 262 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $18.95.

title: A Remark Enrages The Indian Community
description: A RECENT comment by former Mayor Jed Colicchio has raised the ire of New Jersey's Indian community. Mr. Colicchio said his remarks were misinterpreted and he has apologized.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Affordable Housing for the Empty-Nester
description: LEAD: Thanks to far-sighted zoning adopted by some towns as long as two decades ago, some of the most affordable housing being built on Long Island can be found in developments restricted to older purchasers.

title: The Campaign Has Real Issues In Spite of Itself
description: The 1988 Presidential campaign seemed to reach its logical conclusion when the candidates started airing television commercials attacking the opposition's television commercials as being filled with falsehoods. To the voters, America's continuing experiment in self-government, a heroic idea, suddenly seemed empty of content. What is supposed to be a quadrennial national debate over the issues looked more and more like a spectator sport in which the fans were starting to leave long before the game was over.

title: Q. ''How Can I give a really nice dinner at home when I'm a terrible cook.''  A. ''Let a restaurant chef do the cooking.''
description: Carryout has gone haute. No longer does takeout necessarily mean little white cartons of Chinese food or big flat boxes of pizza, or even the elaborate pastas and salads that are now available. Today's host can entertain at home in style, with meals from fine restaurants and possibly even a chef and waiter in attendance.

title: Platform Problem Aborts Launching of First Soviet Shuttle Mission
description: The first launching of the Soviet space shuttle was aborted today, 51 seconds before the scheduled liftoff, when an emergency evacuation platform failed to separate from the rocket body and computer sensors shut down the launching, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported.

title: High, Low and No Roads: Three Strategies For Holding Onto A Senate Seat
description: Until the last few weeks, the campaigns for the United States Senate in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey had one thing in common: They all seemed like sideshow skirmishes that could not compete for the attention of a public preoccupied with the Presidential race, summer heat, ocean pollution and the Olympics.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: THROUGH A LENS

title: Mailbox; A Tribute To Venezia
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: VOTERS TO CHOOSE SEVEN JUDGES AT THREE JUDICIAL LEVELS
description: WESTCHESTER voters will elect seven judges from a field of 16 candidates to fill vacancies at three judicial levels this year.

title: LAW SCHOOL V. REALITY
description: As a graduate of Yale Law School and the recipient of an honorary Doctor of Laws degree at Harvard, I read Scott Turow's article, ''Law School v. Reality,'' (Sept. 18) with interest. He sees a wide gap between the teaching of law in law schools and the rough-and-tumble practice of law in later life. I disagree with him.

title: EMPLOYEES LEARN TIPS ON PATRONS' DRINKING
description: LEAD: ALCOHOL and gasoline don't mix, went the famous warning. Alcohol and gasoline do mix, but they taste something awful, went the dissenting opinion.

title: East German Official Rejects Copying Changes by Moscow
description: East Germany's chief ideologist today rejected the idea that East Germany should follow Moscow's restructuring programs, saying they were not transferable to other Communist countries.

title: HALLOWEEN: TIME FOR CUSTOM AND FAMILY
description: IN medieval times, Halloween was a Christian occasion observed on the eve of All Saints' Day, Nov. 1. Eventually, it became a secular event, influenced by Celtic and Anglo-Saxon festivals to ward off evil spirits, protect the return journey of livestock from summer pastures and welcome the souls of the dead who were believed to revisit their homes in autumn.

title: Nightingale-Bamford: Growth Awaits Grading
description: After three years of bruised feelings on the Upper East Side, the conflict caused by the Nightingale-Bamford School's desire to build atop its present structure will go before the Board of Standards and Appeals on Tuesday.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''It's an amazingly resilient business. How many products can you buy for $1.20 that is an appetite suppressant, a stimulant or a relaxant, depending on the conditions - and is a legal product?'' Diana K. Temple, analyst at Salomon Brothers, on the tobacco business.

title: Can Museums Learn From Mickey and Friends?
description: LEAD: Can museums learn anything from Mickey Mouse and his pals? When 300 museum trustees flew to Florida last week for a meeting of the Museum Trustee Committee for Research and Development at Walt Disney World, that question was very much on their minds. In addition to their normal agenda, concerned with collections, marketing, publicity, development and legislation, they discussed ''Creating Museum Magic Through Quality Service Disney Style.

title: Commemorating a Night of Horror
description: LEAD: ''IT'S very disturbing to realize that the words you're singing, trying to be children who played games and were sometimes happy even if they knew they were going to die, are words written by kids who never got to grow up to be as old as you are. Who never saw another dog or butterfly or mousie, the things they wrote about and the things we sing about.

title: Debuts; A Pianist Counters the Stereotypes
description: Timothy Ehlen

title: Suffer the Little Children?
description: To the Editor:

title: They Bleed RAdiators, Don't They?
description: I USED TO BE A HYPOCHONDRIAC OF SORTS. I even wrote a book about it, giving medical advice to other worriers. Myself, I don't think I was that bad. I admit that I had a certain fondness for revealing, over lunch, the amount of carcinogenic aflatoxin in the average peanut butter sandwich. And there were nights when my heart was skipping beats (this was a medical, not a romantic phenomenon) and I kept watch into the early morning, unwilling to leave my fate in the hands of my autonomic nervous system. But I was never unreasonable. These days, I don't worry so much about my heart. I did get a blood test recently for Lyme disease, but this was after visiting my parents, who live in Lyme (well, Old Lyme, right next door), on a wooded lot no less, thick with deer and presumably with larval deer ticks carrying Lyme disease spirochetes ready to scuttle up to my brain and cause permanent neurological damage unless I stayed alert to warning symptoms, such as the pains I was experiencing in my knees and elbows. It only made sense to get the test - even if it did turn out negative. There's a difference between hypochondria and prudence.

title: Suddenly, the Race Is Close in Canada
description: Despite widespread expectations that Canada's governing Progressive Conservatives would be easily returned to power in the Nov. 21 elections, the campaign appears to have tightened because of anxieties over the accord to promote freer trade between Canada and the United States.

title: Missed Signs?
description: To the Editor:

title: YO, BAUDELAIRE
description: VANNA KARENINA By Frank Gannon. Illustrated. 152 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: Camille Duvall, Champion Water Skier, Marries Byron Hero Jr. in the Bahamas
description: At the Church of the Annunciation in Nassau, the Bahamas, Carole Camille Duvall, the daughter of Dianne Duvall of Windermere, Fla., and the late Samuel E. Duvall Jr., was married yesterday to Byron A. Hero Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Hero of New York and Southampton, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Milton B. Efthimiou of the Greek Archidiocese of North and South America performed the ceremony.

title: What Makes a Great Party?
description: The elements usually include lively guests, good food and drink, and a genial ambiance. Simple to set up if you have the know-how, tricky if you don't. This issue is packed with expert entertaining advice, and our brief quiz will start you off. You've invited 30 people for cocktails in your slightly- smaller-than-a-Fotomat-booth apartment. Where do you park some of your stuff temporarily? a) With your neighbors (invite them) b) With your mother in New Jersey c) In your bathtub An experienced host will never be caught: a) Last-minute shopping in a liquor store b) With a case of wine he's never tasted c) Both of the above If you have several tables of guests, how do you make sure each table has fun? a) Be prepared to table-hop b) Have a guest host each table c) Spike the salad dressing Everybody, including you, has a bad case of winter pallor. What dinner-table lighting will help improve that? a) Votive candles b) Tall tapered candles c) Miner's helmets painted to match your china You want extravagant-looking party flowers, but your floral budget is down to a shoestring. Solution? a) Borrow Aunt Eunice's orchid collection (don't invite her) b) Mix fresh flowers with dried grasses c) Unobtrusively move your flower arrangements mid-party Turn this page upside down for the answers, and score 10 points for every correct one. If you scored 40 or above, you agree with our experts and your parties should be memorable. Less than 40? Don't worry, there are plenty of score-boosting suggestions on the following pages. Answers: 1)C (see page 50) 2)C (see page 64) 3)B (see page 25) 4)A (see page 24) 5)B (see page 38).

title: Reviews/Music; Sounds of Puerto Rico
description: Los Pleneros de la 21, who performed Monday night at Dance Theater Workshop, reminded the audience that the music of Puerto Rico was once made for a local community and that its aspirations and its references were intentionally small. It dealt with familial, personal things often overlooked in popular music.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in:; Flatiron District
description: Lou Jawitz can remember when few people wanted to live in the area known as the Flatiron District. ''When I moved here in 1967, they were giving lofts away,'' he said. ''All I had to do to get my first loft was to get my hair cut and pay $275 a month.'' Without the haircut, he said, the landlord would have charged him $300.

title: Stalemate in Strike Threatens Quality of New York Racing
description: The central question surrounding the strike by Aqueduct Race Track's jockeys is no longer who will be riding the horses each day, but whether the quality of New York racing is in serious jeopardy.

title: Two Good Men
description: What a sour, superficial, misleading campaign: George Bush is not the nasty propagandist that his harsh attacks have made him seem. Michael Dukakis is not the unfocused incompetent that his late and lame responses have made him seem. Both are better men, and better potential Presidents, than the images they project on television.

title: Lehman Upsets DeWitt Clinton, 20-15
description: In a major upset in the Public Schools Athletic League, Lehman defeated DeWitt Clinton, 20-15, in a Bronx Division game at Clinton.

title: SOME WAYS TO PUT THE SPORT BACK INTO HUNTING
description: HUNTING season is here again, and along with it all the tired old cliches, reasons and excuses hunters use to defend their sport. That is if you can call hunting a sport. There is something about the act of blowing an unarmed animal out of a tree with a high-powered semi-automatic rifle that somehow stretches the definition of the word sport to its broadest limits.

title: School Board Acts to Preserve Land
description: LEAD: IN an unusual move designed to keep a large parcel of farm property out of the hands of developers, the Three Village School District in Setauket has offered to exchange property it already owns for the land.

title: Update on Nielsen
description: BRIGITTE NIELSEN, the fiancee of Mark Gastineau, has had a recurrence of a pre-cancerous condition, her publicist said yesterday.

title:
FILM;
Cameras Return to the East End
description: LEAD: MOVIE making has returned to the Hamptons, which had been a popular shooting location until a writers' strike shut down productions nationwide.

title: In Vermont, Alternative Candidates Find a Forum and Encouragement
description: LEAD: By the standards of most political campaigns. Morris Earle, a candidate for Vermont's only seat in the House of Representatives, was having a light day. He began it with an interview at 10 A.M. moved on to a luncheon with two friends and then, after some handshaking, went home to work around the house.

title:
Fare of the Country;
A World of Food Beyond San Francisco
description: LEAD: Around San Francisco and in other parts of Northern California, numerous farmers' markets, held in plazas, parking lots, parks or fairgrounds, invite strolling and tasting. Relaxed supermarkets carry superb local and imported goods.

title: Letters on Travel; Carry-Ons
description: To the Editor: In reference to ''Computer as a Carry-On Bag'' by L. R. Shannon (Practical Traveler, Aug. 21), I found it quite distressing as to the inconvenience to other passengers and the adverse effect it can have on the aircraft.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANT BULBS EARLY TO ENCOURAGE ROOTS
description: LEAD: IF we are to enjoy the bloom of tulips and daffodils in the spring, attention must be paid in the fall. A few hours of planting bulbs now will result in many hours of enjoyment later.

title: Mailbox; Mets Need More Dedication
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: FICTION
description: THE BLESSING & THE CURSE. By Linda Bayer. (Jewish Publication Society, $16.95.) Ida Morgan-Weiss, the heroine of Linda Bayer's first novel, faces a dilemma that is rapidly becoming a 1980's stereotype: approaching 40, successful and recently separated from her husband, she wonders whether she should beat the biological clock by having a child on her own. Ms. Bayer, however, has added a few twists to this familiar situation. Because Ida is Jewish, she feels all the more compelled to perpetuate her people's heritage; because she was adopted and is troubled by feelings of rootlessness, she worries about whether she should bring into the world a child whose biological father may have no more identity than a test tube. Months of soul-searching ensue as Ida takes on a new university teaching position and begins a love affair with a congenial - but married - colleague. Finally, she decides that she will know whether it is important for any child to have a sense of ancestry only if she seeks her own biological mother in Israel. At this point, logic disappears from the plot of ''The Blessing & the Curse,'' since Ida's very need to make the trip has already answered her question. Her ultimate choice regarding childbearing seems just as anticlimactic, possibly because Ms. Bayer has foreshadowed it all along. Also predictable is the cast of supporting characters. Because their personalities are not developed throughout the novel, sudden switches in points of view - a chapter told from Ida's lover's perspective and one from that of her birth mother - seem like tantalizing distractions. Ms. Bayer's heroine, however, is a strong and sympathetic creation, testifying to a talent that deserves as much nurturing as Ida's hopes.

title: Battle for Hispanic Voters in Texas Intensifies
description: The battle for Texas' critical Hispanic vote has been given new urgency in a weeklong barrage of charges and countercharges between Republicans and Democrats.

title: A House With a Past
description: ''YOU'LL love this house, in fact there was once a wedding here,'' the agent told my mother, a woman with two young single daughters.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our 63-year-old house was reshingled 11 years ago. The shingles were coated with a good brand of gray shingle stain. Two sides of the house have now started to mildew (south and west). We have been told that this condition will not clear up even when the humid weather ends. Can you advise us as to what we can do?

title: WESTCHESTER Q&A;: For County Historian, a Once Musty World is Changing
description: LEAD: SUSAN SWANSON has been the County Historian since 1984. A former Pelham town historian, high school social-studies teacher and real-estate saleswoman, she now acts as the liaison between the county and 34 municipal historians working in Westchester. In that capacity she coordinates historical projects, collects historical information about the county, writes historical texts and works with schools on special historical projects.

title: Singer's Intense, Edgy Music Fuels Dance Clubs
description: LEAD: 'Don't rush me,' sings Taylor Dayne on her forthcoming single. yet, in only slightly more than a year since she signed with Arista Records, the 25-year-old South Shore native has achieved the kind of commercial success and garnerred the extensive radio air play that eludes many of her more seasoned contemporaries.

title: Youth Service Ignored
description: To the Editor:

title: Perspectives: Investing in Rentals; A Slower Pace for Housing Improvement
description: ''Chemical, Citibank - they are all sitting back and wondering,'' said David Diamond. He is wondering, too.

title: Janet Meyers Wed To Mark A. Pollak
description: Janet M. Meyers, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Meyers of Richmond, was married there last evening to Mark A. Pollak, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Pollak of Lakehurst, N.J. Rabbi Jack Spiro performed the ceremony at Congregation Beth Ahabah.

title: Let's Not Reject Compulsory Voting Too Hastily
description: To the Editor:

title: THE VISIONARY OF BROHOBYCZ
description: LETTERS AND DRAWINGS OF BRUNO SCHULZ With Selected Prose. Edited by Jerzy Ficowski. Translated by Walter Arndt with Victoria Nelson. Preface by Adam Zagajewski. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $25.

title: Going After That First Charge Card
description: WHEN Penny Kaganoff graduated from college, her low-paying editorial position did not qualify her for a credit card. After she married, she used her husband's American Express and Visa cards, deciding not to apply again for credit of her own even when she got a better-paying job.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE ERRAND OF THE EYE. By Hope Norman Coulter. (August House, $15.95.) The members of the family depicted in this unusual first novel are a rare breed, progressives of a sort almost too good to be believed. Frank McCain wills his inherited land in southern Louisiana to a cooperative run by blacks, his wife, Lillian, champions a slew of liberal causes, and their 17-year-old daughter Allie throws herself into the arms and bed of Paul Kalunge, a 38-year-old black art teacher at her local high school who is divorced and the father of two children.

title:
THEATER;
The Education Of a Playwright Turned Director
description: LEAD: A trio of potted plants sits on the table in Manhattan Theater Club's rehearsal hall during the first read-through of ''Italian American Reconciliation,'' a yearning exploration of divorce by John Patrick Shanley. Mr. Shanley courts the cast (his new wife, Jayne Haynes, among them) with these small pots of green, with gentle gibes and self-revealing comments.

title: The View From: DEEP RIVER
description: SCHOLARS say they study history to avoid repeating the mistakes of the past, but the Deep River Historical Society apparently needs another lesson.

title: Outdoors; An Angling Classic Returns to Print
description: WHEN Mary Orvis Marbury died in 1914, the English Fishing Gazette acclaimed her as ''the most famous but one female angling author.'' (The other was Dame Juliana Berners, an Englishwoman who wrote ''A Treatyse of Fysshying Wyth an Angle'' in 1496.) Marbury's ''Favorite Flies and Their Histories,'' which became a best seller among anglers after it appeared in 1892 and went through nine printings by 1896, has recently been reprinted by the Wellfleet Press.

title: Letters on Travel; Car Sharing
description: To the Editor: A word of warning regarding the Aug. 14 Travel Advisory mention of ''Car Sharing in Europe'' - the growing network of linking drivers with riders in major European cities.

title: Minnesota Settles Drought Insurance Claims
description: A $5.25 million settlement has been reached with the Chubb Corporation and its subsidiary, the Federal Insurance Company, in a dispute over drought insurance sold to Minnesota farmers last spring, state officials announced today.

title: MISSION IMPOSSIBLE
description: I must apologize for many unkind thoughts I've directed toward postal workers for the inferiority of service (''Mission Impossible,'' by John B. Judis, Sept. 25). I now realize it is not labor that is at fault. Management seems to have caused the majority of difficulties by virtually mandating no thinking on the job. It is ridiculous not to allow postal deliverers to reroute a letter when they know it has been ''missed'' by machines.

title: Signs of Intelligent Life in Music Television
description: One evening this month as I was riffling through television by remote control, I happened to spot the stern, cherubic face of Wynton Marsalis. The young jazz trumpeter was the guest on a program called ''New Visions,'' a weekly two-hour series that airs on Sundays at 10 P.M. on the 24-hour cable music channel, VH-1. The program is one of many welcome signs that music-oriented television, which arrived with a splash in 1981 with MTV, has discovered that there is life beyond the flashy video clip.

title: Correction
description: An article on Oct. 16 about two Indians awaiting execution for the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi misidentified one. The defendant, Kehar Singh, was a Government clerk not directly involved in the assassination but convicted of conspiracy; he was not a bodyguard.

title: Jules Labarthe Is Married To Sarah Rogers Marmor
description: Sarah Rogers Marmor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Marmor of New Haven, was married yesterday in Princeton, N.J., to Jules Judd Labarthe, the son of Dr. Darwin R. Labarthe of Houston and Anne R. Carew of Deering, N.H. Marvin Reed, Acting Mayor of Princeton Borough, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title:
A SPECIAL GUIDE TO CRUISES WORLDWIDE;
WHAT'S ON DECK THIS SEASON
description: LEAD: The number of new ships coming into service this year and in the immediate future has been a major factor in keeping prices low for cruises, which in general continue to offer good value. While not all cruises are inexpensive, when compared with the soaring prices of hotels, restaurants and entertainment, most cruises will prove to be a better buy.

title: Touches of Wit and Whimsy
description: PERHAPS it's the mood that Halloween brings. Maybe it's something in the water supply. Whatever the reason, a lot of fall outfits seem to have been taken over lately by a wonderful sense of whimsy.

title: TEACHER'S TALES ARE A GHOSTLY LOT
description: TOMORROW night, anyone near the old Norwichtown Cemetery in Norwich may see a strange figure at the tomb of Hannah Arnold, the mother of Benedict Arnold. For it is said that on Halloween, Benedict Arnold's ghost visits his mother's grave.

title: Woman Who Hid Anne Frank To Speak
description: MIEP GIES, the woman who hid Anne Frank and gave her diary to the world, will speak on Thursday at Temple Judea of Manhasset to conclude its monthlong ''Children of the Holocaust'' program.

title: Greenport Reconsiders Waterfront
description: LEAD: TWO years after it voted to ban condominiums on the waterfront, part of a program designed to revitalize a rather shabby downtown section, the Greenport Board of Trustees is being urged to reverse itself.

title: AIRPORT'S OLD CONTROL TOWER IS HOME OF AVIATION MUSEUM
description: LEAD: IN 1942, Herbert C. Gerlach, Westchester's second County Executive, gave a command to James C. Harding, the young consulting engineer he had just hired to head his Public Works Department. Mr. Harding, now 88 years old, doesn't recall the exact words, but he said he would never forget their essence: ''Build me an airport.

title: Mack Lobell Retiring
description: WHEN a Swedish breeder paid Lou Guida $6 million for a three-quarters interest in Guida's 4-year-old trotter, Mack Lobell, in May, the deal called for Guida to continue managing Mack Lobell's racing career in the United States through his 5-year-old racing season next year. Then the Swedish breeder, John Erik Magnusson, would take control and Mack Lobell would be placed at stud.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANT BULBS EARLY TO ENCOURAGE ROOTS
description: LEAD: IF we are to enjoy the bloom of tulips and daffodils in the spring, attention must be paid in the fall. A few hours of planting bulbs now will result in many hours of enjoyment later.

title: Officers Kill Suspect In Bronx Cab Robbery
description: A 28-year-old man who the police said was robbing a gypsy cab in the Bronx died yesterday after he was shot in the head by officers. A second gunman was arrested.

title: Sandra Rogowski Is Wed to Charles Lizza, Lawyer
description: At the Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington, Sandra Lynn Rogowski, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Rogowski of Alexandria, Va., and Charles M. Lizza, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Lizza of Jersey City, were married yesterday. The Rev. Charles F. X. Dolan performed the ceremony.

title: Reduction Seen in Political Violence at U.N.
description: It is the largest diplomatic community in the world in one of the most maligned cities when it comes to violent crime. Yet the diplomats' principal security problems in New York City are automobile thefts and vandalism, stolen wallets and false bomb threats.

title: A Playwright Holds a Light To Israel's Soul
description: ''The tragic situation of Israel and Israelis today,'' says the Israeli playwright Joshua Sobol, ''is that we are starting to resemble certain of our own oppressors.''

title: Bar Examinations For Practicing Lawyers
description: Re: ''Debate Renewed on Barriers to Lawyers'':

title: HOW BADOIT TOOK ON PERRIER
description: WHETHER Americans visiting France dine in humble bistros or resplendent three-star restaurants, they are often surprised to see so many of the French drinking a sparkling water named Badoit. Perrier is often nowhere to be seen.

title: Celebrating the Memory and Art of Paul Robeson
description: They're throwing a 90th birthday party on Broadway tonight to celebrate the memory of Paul Robeson, the actor, concert singer, all-American football player and controversial political figure, who died in 1976 at the age of 77.

title: Born on the Baseline
description: ANDRE AGASSI'S WORKOUT IS more like batting practice than a long rally. Augusto Solano, a young Colombian player employed by the Nick Bollettieri Tennis Academy in Bradenton, Fla., hits the ball to the 18-year-old tennis player, and Agassi whales on it. Solano feeds him one more, and Agassi takes another vicious cut. Backhand or forehand, he swings at every ball as hard as he can, and whether the screaming line drives that jump off his racquet land inches inside the baseline or crash into the back fence on the fly, the rally is quickly over. Solano reaches back into a grocery cart full of balls and serves up another.

title: Soviets Understate Deficit, U.S. Specialists Say
description: American specialists on the Soviet economy say that Soviet officials probably understated the size of their budget deficit and the resulting problems when they announced this week that they expect to have a deficit of $58 billion next year.

title: Streetscapes: London Terrace; Time Erodes Unity of a 1,665-Unit City Within a City
description: London Terrace, the huge apartment development on the block bounded by 23d and 24th Streets and Ninth and 10th Avenues, was built as a self-contained urban community in 1929-1931 with an elaborate array of services. Time and other elements have gradually compromised the special unity of London Terrace and now a partial co-op conversion is testing even further the cohesion of the venerable complex.

title: The Unseasoned Palate
description: Hold that jalapeno, chef. Take it easy on the chili habanero. And don't try to curry favor with me. Some like it hot, but I do not. To clear my nostrils, I prefer an inhalator, and I would rather burn my tongue on boiling coffee.

title: Transformed by Diamond Dust
description: To the Editor:

title: Kate Lynch Is the Bride Of Donald M. Grossinger
description: Kate Lynch, a daughter of Mr. and William F. Lynch of Stuart, Fla., was married yesterday to Donald Michael Grossinger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Grossinger of Oceanside, L.I. The Rev. Eric Carpine, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Joseph Gelberman performed the ceremony at the Montverde mansion in Peekskill, N.Y.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANT BULBS EARLY TO ENCOURAGE ROOTS
description: LEAD: IF we are to enjoy the bloom of tulips and daffodils in the spring, attention must be paid in the fall. A few hours of planting bulbs now will result in many hours of enjoyment later.

title: Anderson's Aides to Receive A Pay Increase of 25 Percent
description: Warren Anderson, with only a few weeks left as leader of the state Senate's Republican majority, has rewarded many of his top legal advisers with hefty pay raises.

title: Prize Winner, Accused Of Bias, Collects Award
description: The Templeton Prize, the world's largest award in the field of religion, was finally presented in a quiet ceremony last month, after a four-month delay to investigate charges that the winner had promoted anti-Semitism.

title: Halpin to Press Bill On Bicycle Helmets
description: LEAD: AS part of his 1989 legislative program, Suffolk County Executive Patrick G. Halpin will ask state lawmakers to enact a law requiring bicyclists to wear helmets.

title: Jean Gibney Marries Peter Owen Scannell
description: The wedding of Jean Marie Gibney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard X. Gibney of River Edge, N.J., to Peter Owen Scannell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond F. Scannell of Richmond and Virginia Beach, Va., took place yesterday at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Henry A. Boyle performed the ceremony.

title: AMONG TH MILLENNIUMS
description: What a pleasure it is to deal with a man who loves his work. And T. G. H. James, until his retirement earlier this year the Keeper of Egyptian Antiquities at the British Museum, clearly loves Egypt. Starting with the proposition that ''in almost every respect the nineteenth-century traveler to Egypt was at an advantage compared with today's two-week visitor,'' Mr. James starts the armchair archeologist on his journey not in Cairo, where the air traveler commonly disembarks, but in the delta, on a meander up the Nile and through time and history that ends in Nubia. Traveling companions in ANCIENT EGYPT: The Land and Its Legacy (University of Texas, $29.95) include wonderful color plates, liberal quotations from the letters and memoirs of earlier visitors, selected anecdotes of excavation, discovery and thievery and that soothing British diction that, when ornamented with a sense of dry humor and a quick turn of phrase, settles you happily in the lap of an expert. What emerges from the expert's view is a landscape and a culture that was constantly in process. Living places and lesser civil and religious edifices, made of mud brick, when decaying were used by farmers for fertilizer; grander stone monuments and tombs celebrating one Pharaoh or another were used by successor monarchs as fill for still more ambitious structures. But what remains on site, combined with what the Europeans took to their museums, constitutes enough of a record to capture the country - and, in Mr. James's hands, ''the essential humanity of the ancient Egyptians,'' whose comfortable conviction about the afterlife left us that record to read.

title: EXHIBIT REVEALS A PASSION FOR PAISLEY
description: LEAD: ACOMMON denominator runs through the fashion retrospective now at the Fairfield Historical Society: the paisley design.

title: A Late Burst by Yale Overcomes Dartmouth
description: Scott Walton's third field goal of the game and a 57-yard touchdown run by Buddy Zachery, both in a 1-minute-13-second span of the final quarter, lifted Yale to a 22-13 comeback victory over Dartmouth today.

title: In Yonkers, Voters Reconsider the System
description: Obscured by the lingering furor over housing desegregation is an Election Day proposition that might have averted last month's crisis.

title: An American Triumph
description: THE World Team Olympiad that ended in Venice a week ago was full of surprises. One surprise was the early elimination of the favored United States women's team, which went down in the quarter-final round to an unheralded Bulgarian team. Another was the victory in that series of the Danish team, giving Scandinavia its first triumph in a world championship.

title: Frances Truscott Wed in England
description: Frances Jill Truscott, the daughter of Gloria Truscott of Selsdon, Surrey, England, and Alan Truscott of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Charles Hewett Collins, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Hewett Collins of Royal Tunbridge Wells, Kent, England. The Rev. Norman Norgate performed the ceremony at St. James' Anglican Church in Turnbridge Wells, Kent, England.

title: The Poetic Art of a Japanese Warrior Elite
description: The exhibition of Japanese art opening today at the National Gallery of Art in Washington is unprecedented in the scope, quality and numbers of treasures (close to 500 works of art) gathered from more than 100 collections all over Japan. ''Japan: The Shaping of Daimyo Culture 1185-1868'' represents the outcome of years of collaborative effort among Japanese and American officials and scholars following a meeting of the minds at the Tokyo Summit in 1983.

title: Inside the Jocks' Room: A Rider's Life
description: BEING a jockey is not just a glamorous life in the limelight. In fact, 90 percent of the riders in this country are relatively unknown to the public. Only a few get recognition while there are thousands of struggling riders all over the country working long hours just to keep their heads above water in a very competitive sport.

title: Rough Cut
description: ''A ROSE BOWL IS A ROSE BOWL,'' Jim O'Leary says. Perhaps that is so, but O'Leary, who is the master designer at Waterford Crystal, is a self-effacing man. At least, so he seems during a telephone interview from County Waterford, Ireland, as he explains his recent creation: the crystal bowl that is to commemorate the centennial of the Tournament of Roses parade on Jan. 2, 1989, in Pasadena, Calif. ''The nicest ones are generally globular,'' O'Leary says. ''Then it was just a question of whether to put a foot on it or not.'' That's it? ''Then the actual size of the piece,'' he adds. ''How magnificent should we have it?''

title: In Search of the Right Place to Work
description: NO one enjoys job hunting, a task that can be a full-time job in itself. But every year, about 40 million Americans undergo a job or career change. In the course of a typical career, people will either change jobs or change their assignments within the same company an average of 10 times, according to estimates by the outplacement firm of Drake Beam Morin.

title: Struggle to Create U.S. Peace Garden
description: THE five-year race to build a National Peace Garden in Washington enters its second year facing a formidable problem: money.

title: Lehigh Routs Columbia
description: The quarterback, Jim Harris, threw for 340 yards and four touchdowns and ran for another score as Lehigh beat Columbia, 56-27, today.

title: Review/Theater; The Lives and Times Of Real Stand-Up Guys
description: In the brutal vocabulary of professional comedians, ''killing'' is reducing an audience to helpless laughter and ''dying'' is being met with stone-faced indifference. ''Flop sweat'' is a symptom of dying, and ''toilets'' are the grubby out-of-the-way cellars in which young comics toil while elbowing some room in a cutthroat field.

title: New Jersey Q & A: Riley W. Regan
description: AS the director of the state's Division of Alcoholism, an arm of the Department of Health, Riley W. Regan of Imlaystown oversees a staff of 70 and a $17 million annual budget. In 1976, he moved from Maryland, where he was alcoholism director for Montgomery County, to become the first director of New Jersey's Division of Alcoholism.

title: Ms. Samuels Weds
description: At St. Luke's Episcopal Church in the Bronx, Donna-Marie Samuels and Michael Anthony Artis, both graduates of the Howard University School of Law, were married yesterday by the Rev. Wendell C. Roberts, assisted by the Rev. Lorenzo Parker. The bride, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald E. Samuels of the Bronx, will retain her name. She is an associate in the Bronx office of the law firm of Rodman & Campbell. Mr. Artis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Wadsworth Artis of Teaneck, N.J., is a lawyer for Essex-Newark Legal Services in Newark.

title: Migratory Birds of Prey Find Fire Island a Welcome Haven
description: LEAD: PEREGRINE and merlin falcons have been flying low over Fire Island this month, en route on their fitful journey from Greenland and the vast north country of Canada to winter hunting grounds in Central and South America.

title: An Homage to O'Neill at Drew
description: HOW curious that in the midst of a nationwide celebration of the Eugene O'Neill centennary, only one of the state's major professional theater companies is mounting a full-scale production of a full-length O'Neill play.

title: Discovery Channel Finds Gold in Documentaries
description: It was to be another breathtaking first from the Discovery Channel: the first underwater expedition ever to be broadcast live. As it happened, the diver at the bottom of the Red Sea last May was breathless, too; because her helmet fit badly; ''every time she took a breath, it filled up with water,'' John Hendricks, the channel's founder and chairman, recalled recently. By the second day of the three-part series, however, the helmet had been tightened, and ''Reef Watch - Live From the Red Sea,'' a Discovery Channel co-production with the British Broadcasting Corporation, presented viewers with a spectacular display, live, of coral polyps and parrotfish.

title: Rangers Chase Down the Flyers
description: The tighter the game got, the more tempted Ranger Coach Michel Bergeron was to put his checking line on the ice and leave it there. Not only to check the Flyers into submission, but perhaps to sneak in a go-ahead goal of their own, which was precisely what they did.

title: BEARING THE CROSS IN INGLENOOK, MINN.
description: WHEAT THAT SPRINGETH GREEN By J. F. Powers. 335 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Ruling Upholds 'Moving' Radar
description: ''Moving'' radar can be as reliable as stationary radar, and the evidence it produces against motorists can be used without expert testimony, New York State's top court ruled this week.

title: Patent Cure
description: To the Editor:

title: Eilish Leene Married To Stewart Perry Neff
description: Elizabeth Harris Leene, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Leene of Newark, N.Y., and Stewart Perry Neff, the son of Patricia A. Neff of Rockville, Md., and W. Perry Neff of Weston, Vt., were married yesterday in Biddeford, Me. The Rev. Richard C. Malo performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Reviews Yes, Censorship No
description: Even though I am a ''card-carrying'' feminist, I take strong exception to the directive of art reviewer Helen A. Harrison that ''male and female viewers alike should view its (the paintings of Tony Ingoglia) message with distaste'' [ ''Dissidents on Exhibition,'' Oct. 9 ] .

title: OCEANS, TOO, HAVE AREA CODES
description: Everyone is familiar with telephone area codes, but you might not realize that oceans have area codes. When you know their numbers, it becomes almost as easy to dial someone aboard a ship as it is on land. It is also as easy to dial from a ship to someone at home as it is across town.

title: HOWARD'S WAY
description: If Richard Howard felt the novel's inner logic required that it begin with the word ''time,'' he should have translated longtemps not as ''time and again,'' but as ''time was'' - the phrase James Grieve favored (and which Mr. Howard himself described as a brilliant stroke).

title: Reviews/Music; Husband and Wife Duo In a Cello-Piano Debut
description: Norman Fischer was the cellist of the Concord Quartet until it disbanded last year, but since 1971 he has also been giving concerts as half of the Fischer Duo, with his wife, Jeanne Kierman Fischer, a pianist. The Fischers, who are on the faculty of Oberlin College, were presented by that conservatory in their New York debut recital on Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Verbatim: 'That Hellish Poison'
description: ' During World War II, even during the most desperate battles, both sides refrained from using chemical weapons, weapons that Winston Churchill referred to as ''that hellish poison.'' The Iran-Iraq war ended that restraint and set a dangerous precedent for future wars. These weapons are thought to offer a cheap and readily obtainable means of redressing the military balance against more powerful foes. ' William H. Webster Director of Central Intelligence

title: Hempstead Wins Coaching Rivalry
description: Not a lot was at stake when the Farmingdale High School football team took the field against Hempstead at the Tigers' homecoming game today.

title: Teen-Age Equestrians Hone Skills
description: LEAD: THEY have given up many of the things most teen-agers take for granted to pursue rigorous training that leaves little time for other activities. Though their manner is relaxed and friendly, their faces mirror the precision that has become a way of life.

title: Hitler's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Mulroney vs. Turner: Prosperity, Independence
description: In a heated debate in Ottawa last week, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and John Turner, the Liberal Party leader, clashed over the free-trade pact between Canada and the United States. Mr. Mulroney is an architect of the agreement. Mr. Turner opposes it. Here are excerpts from the exchange. John Turner. I happen to believe you've sold us out. Prime Minister Mulroney. Just one second, Mr. Turner. You do not have a monopoly on patriotism, and I resent the fact that you imply that only you are a Canadian. I want to tell you that I come from a Canadian family, and I love Canada, and that is why I did it, to promote prosperity. Mr. Turner. We have built a country, east and west and north, on an infrastructure that resisted the continental pressure of the United States. For 120 years we've done it, and with one stroke of the pen you've reversed that, thrown us into the north-south pull of the United States. And that will reduce us, I'm sure, to an economic colony of the United States, because when the economic levers go, the political independence is sure to follow. Mr. Mulroney. With a document that's cancelable on six months' notice? Be serious.

title: EXPERTS QUESTION DRUG BILL'S IMPACT
description: Law-enforcement officials say the drug bill passed by Congress last week provides them with new tools to curb illicit drugs but leaves unclear how some provisions, like civil penalties for occasional use, will work in practice.

title: Marines Believe a Collision Caused Fatal Copter Crash
description: Two Marine helicopters that crashed Tuesday night, killing nine marines and an Air Force officer, apparently collided less than 200 feet above the Arizona desert, officials said Friday.

title: WARMING UP TO FUR COATS
description: Men who wear fur fall into two distinct classes: those who flaunt their passion for lambskin, mink or possum, and those who pay a premium to keep it under wraps. Michael M. Connery, a New York City lawyer and the owner of a cloth coat smartly trimmed in beaver, ranks himself with the former. ''Lining a coat with fur misses the point,'' Connery says emphatically. ''If you're going to wear it, people may as well see it.''

title: Education Bond Issue: Questions on Competition
description: LEAD: A BOND issue on the November ballot to raise $350 million for New Jersey's higher education institutions and technology centers has raised questions about the most effective way for the state to achieve competitiveness in an increasingly technological era.

title: Susan Sprague Wed to T. R. MacGregor
description: St. Bernard's Episcopal Church in Bernardsville, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Susan Hickock Sprague, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Hayes Sprague of Maplewood, N.J., and Benson, Vt., to Tracy Reel MacGregor, a son of Lieut. Comdr. Norman Kenneth MacGregor, U.S.N., retired, and Barbard Reel MacGregor, both of Broomall, Pa. The Rev. Frederick Baldwin performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. William Burns, a Methodist minister.

title: SAFETY ISSUES FOR BUILDINGS ANS BUILDERS
description: A six-story building in midtown Manhattan collapsed in an avalanche of concrete and glass last week, killing the owner and injuring at least 20 people. City officials said the cause was illegal construction. Workers attempted to strengthen a wall by replacing loose bricks, one by one, and weakened it instead. The contractor had not obtained the permit that the city requires for any structural work. James Barron, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The New York Times, asked four experts how much construction is done without permits and how often safety is compromised as a result. Excerpts follow. 'Not Wild West'

title: A 'Painterly' Show in Jersey City
description: LEAD: THE term ''painterly'' is one of the most enigmatic in the art lexicon. It should be straightforward, meaning involving primarily the manipulation of paint. But such a focus on the movement of the artist's hand does not necessarily yield information critical to an understanding of a body of work or a philosophy.

title: The Race For Congress; Without Incumbents, 3 Upstate Contests Heat Up
description: Out here in Jack Kemp country, right for 18 years has meant might. But Mr. Kemp, who made an unsuccessful bid for the Republican Presidential nomination this year, is not seeking re-election in November, and his decision has set off an ideologically charged race that is perhaps the most heated Congressional contest in the state.

title:
THE NATION;
'NO COUNTRY ON EARTH HAS MIUSED WATER AS EXTRAVAGANTLY AS WE HAVE'
description: LEAD: The rains began to fail in 1888, and 1889 was drier.

title: MEMORIAL TO MAN WHO BROUGHT THE BARD TO LIFE
description: FOR 28 years here, children and their parents have sat around the dinner table discussing Ophelia's madness, Goneril's cruelty and the magic of fairies on a summer night.

title: In Math, the Language of Science, Americans Grow Even Weaker
description: IN ''A Study in Scarlet,'' the first of the Sherlock Holmes stories, Watson is appalled to find his eccentric fellow lodger unaware that the earth orbits the sun.

title: Donna Ann D'Onofrio, a Banker, Wed To Norman M. Beretta in Connecticut
description: At Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church in Wilton, Conn., Donna Ann D'Onofrio, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony A. D'Onofrio of Wilton, was married yesterday to Norman Morse Beretta, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Beretta Jr. of Jamestown, R.I., by the Rev. Michael C. Palmer.

title: The Conservatives Have Better Ideas
description: LEAD: Why is George Bush ahead in the polls? The answer of choice for most of the media runs like this explanation from Newsweek: ''George benefits from the Republicans' well-honed marketing skills, taste for hardball tactics and willingness to exploit 'hot button' issues.'' It is also an answer that reveals an extraordinary contempt for the political intelligence of the public.

title: Cup Maneuvers in Library
description: The library at the New York Yacht Club on West 44th Street is a quiet enclave with more than a century of yacht-racing history on its shelves. But the courthouse battles engulfing the America's Cup have turned it into something else, a kind of end zone for the legal teams looking for material to bolster their cases. If researchers wore uniforms, there would be different-colored jerseys at every table.

title: Weekend Features Chamber Orchestras
description: IN between the intimacy of chamber music and the full sonic spectrum of the symphony, lies the delectable middle ground of compositions for chamber orchestra. Most of the great composers have contributed to this enticing repertory, but certainly compared to string quartets and symphony orchestras, there are all too few organizations dedicated to its care and cultural feeding. Three that are will be performing next weekend (and pay attention because their similar titles can confuse anyone): the Chamber Orchestra of Connecticut opens its season on Thursday, while the Connecticut Chamber Orchestra and the Fairfield Chamber Orchestra perform Saturday evening.

title: Perrier's New American Assault
description: GUSTAVE Leven, the white-haired chairman of the Perrier Group, often sounds like an Old Testament prophet when he rails against the evils of tap water and hails the beneficial aspects of mineral water.

title: For Prosperity and Employment, Don't Forgo International Trade
description: IN a recent poll of my constituents, I asked them to rank the 10 greatest concerns facing our nation. A healthy economy was at the top of their list, while international trade was near the bottom. What concerns me about the results is that so few Americans, comparatively speaking, realize the great impact international trade has on maintaining a healthy economy.

title: TOW VIEWS OF WHAT ONE EUROPE SHOULD BE
description: From the very beginning of the Common Market in 1957, two very different visions of Europe have inspired its leaders and institutions. Shimmering in the distance was the dream of a federal European union, with a common currency, a common social and economic structure, and a common defense. But looming more closely, was a practical framework of loose cooperation between the old, familiar nation-states of Europe.

title: Did Gide Read Proust?
description: To the Editor:

title: State by State; In Swing Precinct in Modesto, Calif., The Presidency Is Still Up For Grabs
description: Vice President Bush has struck pay dirt in Precinct 14 here.

title: Beverly Johnston Wed To Richard Lee Ford
description: Beverly Johnston, a daughter of Mrs. John Gladstone Johnston of Boynton Beach, Fla., and North Hills, L.I., and the late Mr. Johnston, was married yesterday to Richard Lee Ford, a son of Mrs. William Lee Ford of Arlington, Va., and the late Mr. Ford. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: THE WORLD
description: In the three Baltic republics, where nationalist movements are gaining momentum, the Soviet Union is facing the consequences of its raw use of power at the outbreak of World War II and a bold attempt to tamper with the historical record.

title: Reviews/Music; Ned Rorem Harmonies With a Choral Backdrop
description: Ned Rorem, whose 65th birthday celebrations continued with a program of (mostly) choral music at St. Thomas Church on Tuesday evening, is a composer who has remained faithful to many facets of traditional harmony without asserting the traditional power of harmony very boldly. Like certain other basically lyrical and conservative composers in the postwar decades, he has tended to decorate his chords with added or altered tones that cloud their identity without adding any great sense of movement or direction, and that lends a certain feeling of sameness to the harmonies even when, underneath, they are indeed going somewhere.

title: Show and Tell, With Visual Aids
description: OF the thousands of meetings that your bosses, colleagues and casual acquaintances have invited you to attend so far this year, no doubt a few failed to quicken your pulse. It is no cause for shame. We've all had fleeting moments of ennui during meetings, especially when the person who has called the gathering - ostensibly to enlighten everyone on the statistical fluctuations in the third-quarter exchange rate of the zloty, for example - pauses, pulls out a foot-thick sheaf of overhead transparencies and says, ''I've brought along a few visual aids, which I created all by myself using desktop presentation software.''

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Oct. 15 MANHATTAN Chelsea $385,000 315 West 23d Street 1,050-sq.-ft. open loft with bath in a former prewar warehouse; 24-hr. doorman, skylights, wrapped terrace, four exposures, Jacuzzi; maintenance $1,100, 60% tax-deductible (Broker: Debra Kameros Co.) East Midtown $135,000 350 East 54th Street 550-sq.-ft. prewar studio condo; separate dressing area, high ceilings, north exposure; common charge $240, taxes $1,200 (Broker: Buchbinder & Warren) Morningside Heights $242,500 245 West 107th Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, parquet floors; maintenance $572, 51% tax-deductible (Broker: Klara Madlin Real Estate) Murray Hill $450,000 28 West 38th Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 2,000-sq.-ft. prewar loft co-op; dining area, high-ceilings, hardwood floors; maintenance $861, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Molk Associates) West Village $505,000 288 West Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 2,000-sq.-ft. prewar loft co-op; dining room, 2 fireplaces, Hudson River view; maintenance $683, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Kingman Associates) BRONX Marble Hill $155,000 52 Marble Hill Avenue 2-family attached, aluminum-sided house; 3 bedrooms in primary unit; 2 bedrooms in other; 1 bath, dining area, large kitchen in each; finished basement, 29- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,000 (Broker: Marilyn & Morris B.
