Walsh)

title: Officials Realize 'Inmate' Was Never Jailed
description: Corrections officials in Mississippi did not realize Shelly Teague had not served a day of his four-year prison sentence until they could not find him to let him out on parole.

title: WHERE A ZUNI'S SOUL DIES
description: PAINTED TURTLE Woman With Guitar. By Clarence Major. 159 pp. Los Angeles: Sun & Moon Press. $14.95.

title: Franchise Brokers Making Their Mark
description: For years, people thought that picking a real estate broker was a little like choosing a new car: You asked friends and watched the ads.

title: What Rivera Saw
description: To the Editor:

title: Lincoln H. Clark; Co-Founder of CARE, 77
description: Lincoln H. Clark, co-founder of the relief organization CARE and a professor of marketing at several colleges during his career, died of cancer Friday in his home Falmouth, Me. He was 77 years old.

title: Trying to Disagree, Opponent Tags Moynihan a 'Dukakis Democrat'
description: Robert R. McMillan described Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan as ''a Dukakis Democrat'' and ''a liberal Democrat'' last night in the last debate of their campaigns for the United States Senate, although the two men often agreed on issues during the evening.

title: Correction
description: An article on page 5 of the Arts and Leisure section today incompletely describes the production of ''Soul of a Jew,'' by the Haifa Municipal Theater of Israel, which opens on Wednesday at Symphony Space. It will be performed in Hebrew, with simultaneous English translation available on headphones.

title: CHUGGING AWAY
description: Sometimes it's too much oak in the chardonnay; sometimes it's too much alcohol in the zinfandel. California is a land of abundance, and the state's wine growers have often been troubled by too much of a good thing. More and more, it's getting to be too many tourists in the valley.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: M.D.: Doctors Talk About Themselves. By John Pekkanen. (Delacorte, $18.95.) ''I admitted a cute little 11-year-old for a tonsillectomy when. . . .'' The sophisticated reader immediately recognizes the traditional overture to the medical disaster story. A lucky heroine of such a tale leaves the hospital with nothing worse than paraplegia, but in today's overheated market for medical horrors she probably remains on a respirator to this day.

title: Penn Continues on Unbeaten Path
description: Penn was penalized 21 times today, an Ivy League single-game record. Nevertheless, the Red and Blue managed beat Princeton, 31-23, while curbing the Garrett brothers' flashy show, so much a part of Tiger football, before a crowd of 24,500 at Palmer Stadium.

title: Sunday Buffet, Brazilian-Style
description: For Alfred and Suzana Monacella, a Manhattan-based film maker and a Brazilian-born fashion designer, staging a party is as pleasurable as the party itself. ''We entertain so much because we enjoy the whole process,'' explained Mr. Monacella, who, with his wife, especially likes giving Sunday afternoon buffets. ''Suzana likes it because doing this sort of thing is part of her culture in Brazil. And I enjoy it, I think, partly because I was an only child. I like having people around.''

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: TURNING THE WHEEL: American Women Creating the New Buddhism. By Sandy Boucher. (Harper & Row, $22.95.) In the 1960's, many young Americans embraced not only Buddhist philosophy but its Asian cultural trappings - shaved heads, robes, Japanese clogs and paper umbrellas and a ponderous respect for religious rank.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In most physics experiments the answer used to be just one number or a string of numbers.

title: Integration Proves Elusive in an Ohio Suburb
description: Eight years after a Federal judge ruled that this working-class suburb of Cleveland had actively excluded blacks for at least two decades, the city is building public housing, holding seminars on racial relations and spending $75,000 on an advertising campaign urging blacks to move in.

title: Supercomputer Pictures Solve the Once Insoluble
description: Describing how a tornado forms in a thunderstorm racing across a prairie is a most complex scientific problem, requiring dozens of separate mathematical equations. Solving the equations would create an answer requiring millions or billions of numbers. Today, researchers are using pictures and movies to dramatically simplify their answers and to give new insights into the formation of tornadoes.

title: Amid Plenty, Many in Peru Face Hunger
description: Wandering around a street market near her home with the equivalent of just 60 cents in her pocket, Sara Chaverry seemed almost in a daze as she tried to imagine how she would provide the next three meals for the 10 members of her household.

title: THE MAKING OF A 'DUBLIN SMARTIE'
description: BERNARD SHAW Volume One, 1856-1898: The Search for Love. By Michael Holroyd. Illustrated. 486 pp. New York: Random House. $24.95.

title: MOST HOMELESS STUDENTS NOT IN NEARBY SCHOOLS
description: LEAD: SCHOOL officials in the county say their earlier fears that homeless children would overcrowd the school districts near their motels this fall have not proved well-founded.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Account
description: * Clarke Goward Fitts of Boston was retained by the Towle Manufacturing Company for its $2 million cutlery and housewares account.

title: 4 ISRAELIS KILLED IN ATTACK ON BUS
description: Four Israeli civilians were killed and eight were wounded Sunday evening when a passenger bus was attacked with firebombs during an ambush just outside the West Bank city of Jericho, the Israeli Army said early today.

title: Imelda Marcos in New York For Her Arraignment Today
description: Imelda Marcos, wife of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines, arrived here yesterday from Honolulu to be arraigned today on embezzlement and racketeering charges at Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Reviews/Dance; On the Ice, Olympians And Their Technique
description: How satisfying it can be to watch a skater glide across the ice. The sheer ease of the act can create a glow of well-being in any spectator. One felt such a glow Saturday night at the very start of ''Benson & Hedges on Ice'' when Scott Hamilton, a 1984 Olympic gold medalist, not only glided across the vast rink at Madison Square Garden, but also effortlessly punctuated the movements with especially graceful spins.

title: 11% Korea Growth Seen
description: South Korea's gross national product is expected to grow 11 percent this year, instead of the 10 percent previously projected, the Bank of Korea said Friday. The central bank attributed the revised projection to strong export earnings, high domestic demand for products and the continued expansion of capital investment.

title: Campaign Tactics Provoke New Charges
description: Supporters of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis complained today about a flier from the Maryland Republican Party that suggested that violent criminals would invade American homes if Mr. Dukakis becomes President.

title: Net Down 7% At Aetna Life
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company said Friday that its third-quarter net income fell 7 percent because of declining results from personal, commercial property and group insurance.

title: Work on AIDS and Fatherhood Still Theoretical; A Venereal Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Candidates on the Issues
description: The United States Senate race in New Jersey has been among the most hard-fought and bitter in the country. Yet when addressing specific issues, the Democratic incumbent, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, and his Republican challenger, Pete Dawkins, do not differ dramatically. For example, both want the Federal Government to spend more on the environment, on anti-drug programs and on day care. Both are concerned about the size of the deficit. Neither favors increased taxes to pay for new government programs or to offset the deficit, although Mr. Dawkins alone pledges not to vote for tax hikes. On some issues, abortion for example, Mr. Dawkins takes a moderate rather than a conservative position. Similarly, on such issues as gun control, Mr. Lautenberg takes a moderate rather than a liberal position. The two men were interviewed by Clifford D. May of The New York Times. What follows is a distillation of their positions on issues facing New Jersey and the nation. Frank R. Lautenberg: Federal deficit - Sees the deficit as a problem of ''major magnitude.'' Opposes the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit reduction law because ''we don't need to go on automatic pilot.''

title: Giants Top Lions in Overtime
description: The Giants' offense was hardly pretty today, and most of the time it found a way to thwart a drive. But the defense was efficient and fired up, and in overtime it made the big play that set up a 13-10 victory over the Detroit Lions.

title: Work on AIDS and Fatherhood Still Theoretical; California's Prop. 102
description: To the Editor:

title: Hearing for Drexel Judge
description: A Federal Appeals Court will hear arguments today on whether a Federal judge violated conflict-of-interest rules and demonstrated bias against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., a defendant in a securities fraud case brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission last month.

title: Market Place; Breadth Indicator Shows Weakness
description: IT takes more than takeover stocks to make a strong stock market, and some analysts are starting to worry that this market has little else to offer.

title: Looking to History
description: Imagine the United States this way in the year 2010: It has lost its competitive edge in all major industries; its allies have fallen away or turned elsewhere; the dollar is weak and Washington cannot borrow abroad; its schools turn out future lawyers, dentists and real estate agents, but not scientists, engineers and skilled craftsmen. Then a ''major South Asian power'' begins seeking a dominant world role, grabbing territory of smaller neighbors.

title: ON YOUR OWN: Fitness; Orlon Socks Go Toe to Toe With Cotton
description: ONE day last summer, Timothy Graham decided to perform a test in a tennis match with some of his cronies at the Hempstead Country Club on Long Island.

title: Cuomo Son Plans Units for Homeless
description: Andrew Cuomo, the Governor's son, announced plans yesterday to build transitional housing in the South Bronx for 300 homeless families.

title: We're All Accomplices In the No-Issue Campaign
description: LEAD: Who is to blame for this extraordinarily unsatisfying Presidential campaign?

title: Soviets Said to Offer Afghan Premier as a Conciliator
description: Prime Minister Hassan Sharq of Afghanistan will address the United Nations this week as part of a Soviet-inspired campaign to promote him as the potential head of a national reconciliation government in Afghanistan, State Department and Pakistani officials said this weekend.

title: Outdoors: Unusual Encounter
description: OVER the years, I have grown accustomed to being bested by my cherished fishing companion, Vic Pomiecko. And on a recent trip he not only caught more trout than I but also captured a ruffed grouse with his bare hands.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday on life in Belfast incorrectly described the population of Northern Ireland in some copies. The British Government estimates that 61 percent of the population is Protestant and 39 percent Roman Catholic.

title: Campaign Finance; Contributors Help Dukakis By Avoiding Limits He Set
description: Although Gov. Michael S. Dukakis pledged that the Democratic National Committee would refuse contributions from corporations and labor unions this year, those sources are giving state party organizations millions of dollars that can help his Presidential campaign.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Honoring Women in Baseball
description: LEAD: THE teams wore short-skirt uniforms, and had names like the Peaches and the Chicks, and they crisscrossed America playing regulation baseball in the only professional women's baseball league in the history of the United States.

title: Pat Moynihan's Salad Days
description: A word of praise, first, for Robert R. McMillan. He's the Republican who volunteered for the suicide mission of running against Daniel Patrick Moynihan for the United States Senate. Mr. McMillan, who's been stumping the state in his own car, has waged a creditable campaign, making sensible suggestions on issues like lower-income housing and cleaning up New York's fetid coastal waters.

title: 11 Progresso Unions Gain In Battling Publisher
description: The National Labor Relations Board has accused the publisher of Il Progresso Italo-Americano of negotiating in bad faith with two unions and subsequently moving its business in order to publish with nonunion employees. At the same time, 24 former Il Progresso journalists and typographers have distributed a prototype of America Oggi, which would compete with Il Progresso, the nation's only Italian-language daily newspaper.

title: Traffic Notes
description: The Halloween parade will begin at 7 o'clock tonight on West Street between Houston and Christopher Streets, travel east on Houston Street to the Avenue of the Americas, north to 14th Street and east to Union Square. Because of All Saints Day, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Reviews/Theater; Perils of Dalejean in 'Good Black'
description: Dalejean is a middle-aged single mother of three teen-age children, each of whom is going through a period of adolescent crisis. But Dalejean doesn't have a lot of time to worry about them. She is usually running late to her job as a waitress in Jake's soul food diner. Jake drinks too much, keeps a gun under the counter and is constantly trying to seduce Dalejean. But Dalejean is having a secret affair with Rip, a ''live and let live'' kind of guy who is at least 10 years her junior and who wants to marry her.

title: Seamen Institute Finds a Haven On Water Street
description: Almost as nomadic in recent decades as the seafarers it serves, the Seamen's Church Institute of New York and New Jersey plans to anchor at last in the South Street Seaport Historic District of lower Manhattan.

title: Arafat Restates His Interest In International Conference
description: The chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasir Arafat, reiterated in an interview released today that he was prepared to participate in an international peace conference with the Israelis.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm a liberal in the tradition of Franklin Roosevelt and Harry Truman and John Kennedy.'' - Michael S. Dukakis. [ A1:4. ]

title: Fans Behave Better
description: Three hours before the 1 P.M. kickoff of the Jets' game against the Pittsburgh Steelers today, sunshine, footballs, hamburgers and beer, the staples of a tailgate party, were as abundant as cars in the parking lots at Giants Stadium.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Some Ads The Public Never Saw
description: HARD by an ersatz cemetery with cardboard tombstones bearing the inscriptions ''Herb - R.I.P.'' and ''Nissan Engineers -R.I.P.'' several dozen creative people gravely contemplated advertisements that died too soon.

title: Dragging of Woman by Train Prompts New Transit Inquiry
description: A Brooklyn woman was dragged 15 feet by a subway train Saturday, prompting a Transit Authority investigation of the train's crew and whether the doors were functioning properly.

title: The Two German Nations Prepare To Recall Kristallnacht's Brutality
description: The night of Nov. 9-10, 1938, has always stood out as a fateful turning point in the annals of the Nazi terror, and with the approach of the 50th anniversary of what has come to be known as Kristallnacht, both Germanys have announced plans for a broad range of nationwide ceremonies, conferences and other commemorative acts.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Orel Hershiser's 6-0 victories over the Mets and the Oakland Athletics during the postseason made him the first pitcher in the 20-year history of the league championship series to throw shutouts in both the playoffs and the World Series in the same year. How many pitchers had two shutouts in the same World Series?

title: Ivy League Race Is On Again
description: The Ivy League race is not quite a runaway and Saturday's results gave promise of the usual turbulent November in a conference famous for the unexpected.

title: Koch Picks 8 Sites in 3 Boroughs To House Homeless AIDS Patients
description: The Koch administration, anticipating an acute need for housing for homeless people with AIDS, has decided on at least eight such sites, city officials said yesterday.

title: Population Size Can't Be Overlooked as an Environmental Danger
description: To the Editor:

title: Literary Guild Post Filled
description: Maureen Mahon Egan, the editorial director of the Literary Guild, was named to the additional post of editor in chief on Thursday. The Literary Guild is the flagship of Doubleday Book and Music Clubs Inc. Mrs. Egan thus reassumes the post she held until 1985, when Genevieve Young became editor in chief. Ms. Young is now editorial director of Bantam Books. Juliet Rubenstein, formerly senior editor of the Literary Guild, was named executive editor of the guild.

title: Sports World Specials; Back in the Right Lane
description: At the age of 30 and after six years of steady progress on the talent-packed Professional Bowlers Association tour, Brian Voss has enjoyed solid success in the last 10 months.

title: KRAFT BEING SOLD TO PHILIP MORRIS FOR $13.1 BILLION
description: In one of the biggest takeovers to date, two of the nation's best-known makers of consumer goods, Philip Morris Companies and Kraft Inc., yesterday agreed to merge in a deal valued at $13.1 billion in cash.

title: Review/Theater; Love in Little Italy, as Told by John Patrick Shanley
description: When the moon hits your eye like a big pizza pie, that's amore. But these days it may also be a new script by John Patrick Shanley, who has followed his Oscar-winning screenplay for ''Moonstruck'' with another slice of sometimes gooey, sometimes piquant, always moonlit romanticism, Italian-American-style. Mr. Shanley's new work, a play set in Little Italy, is baldly titled ''Italian American Reconciliation.'' It can be found at the Manhattan Theater Club Stage 2, a few steps and several cultural eons away from Richard Greenberg's ''Eastern Standard,'' which brought a younger, designer-pizza generation's love stories to the company's main stage only last week.

title: Dr. James Lerrick Wed To Wendy Ann Munoz
description: Wendy Ann Munoz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Munoz of Freehold, N.J., and Dr. James Andrew Lerrick, a son of Dovia Lerrick of Chappaqua, N.Y., and the late Dr. Robert B. Lerrick, were married yesterday at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Scarborough, N.Y. Rabbi Chaim Stern officiated.

title: BUSH FIGHTS BACK ON ISSUE OF ELITISM
description: Fighting back against Democratic charges that he is an elitist whose policies favor the rich, Vice President Bush flew up from Washington today to have lunch with the owners of an automobile body repair shop in a working-class suburb of Philadelphia.

title: A Murder in Texas: 12 Years Later, Questions Linger About Justice System
description: Despite widening assertions that an innocent man may have been convicted of killing a Dallas police officer 12 years ago, local and state officials are contesting efforts to win a new trial in a case that is raising troubling questions.

title: Vogue Tries a More Relaxed Look
description: The jeweled Christian Lacroix T-shirt on the cover of the new issue of Vogue costs at least $10,000. That may not be so surprising; Vogue has always gone gaga over expensive French couture. What is unusual is that a $50 pair of blue jeans accompanies the T-shirt. It may well be the first time blue jeans have appeared on a Vogue cover -without a belt and with the model's tummy showing, no less.

title: Ercil Howard Is Wed To Capt. Mark Wroth
description: Ercil C. Howard and Capt. Mark B. Wroth, U.S.A., were married yesterday at the Cadet Chapel at the United States Military Academy in West Point, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Richard Camp Jr., a Baptist minister and a chaplain at the academy, performed the ceremony.

title: Savings Units: A Fairer Way
description: Well-heeled thrift institutions long ago stopped loving their indigent insurer, the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. Now, the Great Western Financial Corporation, of Beverly Hills, Calif., one of the richest, is trying to leave it.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Reviews/Dance; The World's Last Act Has A Latin Beat
description: JoAnn Fregalette-Jansen is a choreographer with an original voice. It is a very dark voice. But Ms. Jansen's gifts, so clearly evident in a performance by her company last Thursday at the Whitney Museum of American Art at the Equitable Center, make her apocalyptic vision almost exhilarating.

title: Land Dealer Is Acquitted
description: Thomas Gaubert, a Texas land developer, was found not guilty Saturday in a fraud case involving a $32 million loan made in a condominium project.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Thompson Media Buyer For a Canadian Brewer
description: J. Walter Thompson, Toronto, went into the weekend with a $20 million media-buying assignment, awarded by Carling O'Keefe, the Canadian brewer, for all English-language buys in Canada. Just last month the agency won the $10 million advertising account for three of Carling's major brands - OV, Foster's Quebec and Miller, which markets in Canada through Carling.

title: Hopes Rise For Finding 8 Lost Planes
description: For more than a quarter of a century, engineers and pilots searched in vain for the Lost Squadron, two B-17 Flying Fortresses and six P-38 Lightnings that went down on the Greenland icecap while flying to Britain in the summer of 1942.

title: Image Crisis for Savings League
description: It is hard not to be relaxed at the lavish resorts on the beach of Waikiki, but the 2,300 executives gathering here for the annual convention of the United States League of Savings Institutions will be wringing their hands nonetheless.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; WRG Resigns From Pan Am
description: Wells, Rich, Greene resigned from the Pan American World Airways account Friday morning and declined to participate in the airline's agency review.

title: Bhutan Lifts the Royal Wedding Veil
description: The Kingdom of Bhutan, locked in its Himalayan fastness, had an important announcement to make today.

title: 16 New Israeli Parties Have Little Chance but May Bar Clear Election Victor
description: ''They're all corrupt, and so will we be if we get elected,'' Yaakov Gross flatly tells potential voters in a brief campaign commercial on television.

title: 4 Black Youths Held in Attack
description: Four black youths were charged yesterday with beating and robbing a white youth on a city bus in Queens in what the police have classified as a bias incident, a police spokesman said.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Southwestern Phone Names New President
description: LEAD: Twenty-six years after joining Southwestern Bell Telephone as a computer supervisor on the night shift, James R. Adams will return to St. Louis for the third time in his career, this time as president and chief executive officer of the company.

title: A Connecticut Wedding For Dr. Carole Lengyel
description: Dr. Carole Lengyel, a pediatric resident at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, and Dr. Satori Iwamoto, a fourth-year medical student at Harvard University, were married yesterday. Town Justice Barbara Amatruda officiated at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Peter Lengyel, in Woodbridge, Conn.

title: Congress Cleans Up After Itself
description: For too long Congress has been open to the charge that it legislates ethics for the other branches and nondiscrimination for everyone but not for itself. In its final days, the 100th Congress finally gave two presentable responses.

title: Rangers Win 7th in a Row
description: The Rangers trounced the Penguins, 9-2, for their seventh consecutive victory last night in an ugly hockey game marked by 272 minutes in penalties.

title: Business and the Law; Retiree Benefits And Bankruptcies
description: WITH the surge in leveraged buyouts, restructuring of companies and foreign takeovers, many retired employees have had to struggle in Congress and the courts to protect their expensive medical benefits from the sharp knives of cost cutters.

title: A Tribute to Paul Robeson on Boards He Trod
description: What Lena Horne called the ''unbearably majestic beauty'' of Paul Robeson's voice returned to the Shubert Theater last night, 12 years after his death and 45 years after he first gave a legendary performance on the Shubert stage as Othello.

title: Key West Journal; Homosexuals Unmask On Night of Costumes
description: With his broad shoulders, rose-red lipstick, white chiffon dress and runs in his stockings, William Shultz looked like Joan Crawford on a bad night.

title: California Dreaming: At Least Three to Share Record Lottery Prize
description: Three winning tickets were sold for California's $60.8 million lottery jackpot, perhaps the largest lottery jackpot in the world, state officials said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Seminar for Volunteers
description: Agency people with souls for more than selling are invited to a free seminar on options for volunteer work in New York, to be held Wednesday from 6 P.M. to 7:30 P.M. at the J. Walter Thompson auditorium, 466 Lexington Avenue, between 45th Street and 46th Street, on the second floor. Representatives from organizations that help homeless people, children, the elderly and AIDS patients will speak. The seminar is sponsored by Advertising Age.

title: George Carey, a Professor, Is Wed to Janet Lipschultz
description: >The International Center for B'nai B'rith in New York was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Janet Lipschultz, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harry Lipschultz of Brooklyn, to Dr. George W. Carey, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George A. Carey of the Bronx. Rabbi Richard Jacobs and Cantor Janece Erman Cohen officiated.

title: Shirley in Person
description: The other afternoon, the former owner of a Shirley Temple doll walked over to a Fifth Avenue bookstore to peer at its prototype autographing her book, ''Child Star.'' Judging by the line that curlicued through B. Dalton, every other former owner of a Shirley Temple doll within hailing distance of midtown had the same idea.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Oct. 30, 1988: MONDAY Airborne Freight Armstrong World Ind Boeing Consol Freight Foster Wheeler TUESDAY Carlisle Cos Emerson Electric General Housewares Hershey Foods Liberty Corp Mickelberry Corp Monarch Machine Phila Suburban Polaroid Corp Smucker Co Source Capital US Surgical Zero Corp WEDNESDAY Capital Holding Eagle-Pitcher Indus Great Northern Nekoosa M A Hannah Corp IE Industries Ingersoll-Rand Lincoln Natl Corp McKesson Corp Phelps Dodge Corp Premark Intl Betts Corp Utilicorp United Inc Wendy's Intl XTRA Corp THURSDAY Alexander & Alexander Auto Data Processing Avon Products Coastal Corp Contel Corp Dover Corp GTE Corp Humana Inc Kimberly-Clark Landmarc Bancshares Paine Webber Pennzoil Co Prdcts Rsrch & Chem Corp Reece Corp Trans Technology Corp Wyle Laboratories FRIDAY ASA Ltd Chemed Corp Raychem Corp Reebok Intl Ltd Scotty's Inc State Mutual Securities Stride Rite Corp Temple Inland Timken Co Washington Water Pwr SATURDAY Eldon Indus

title: TV Notes
description: Kennedy Assassination

title: Bio-Gas and Sun Energy Make Life Better in India
description: Twenty-four-year-old Ponnulingham, like most of India's 800 million people, will never be part of the new middle class that frequents the coffee shops and health clubs of five-star hotels. Chances are he will never live in a house with electricity or running water.

title: Books of The Times; To the Fringe and Back: Burroughs's Life's Circle
description: Literary Outlaw The Life and Times of William S. Burroughs By Ted Morgan Illustrated. 659 pages. Henry Holt & Company. $27.50.

title: Results Plus
description: Auto Racing Senna Clinches Drivers' Title: Ayrton Senna of Brazil, driving a turbo-charged McLaren Honda, overcame a stall from his pole position start yesterday and won the Japan Grand Prix, along with the 1988 drivers' title. Senna, 28 years old, clinched his first world drivers' championship with one race remaining in the Formula One championship series, at Adelaide, Australia, Nov. 13. Senna completed 51 laps of the 3.641-mile Suzuka circuit in 1 hour 33 minutes 26.173 seconds.(AP) Road Racing Cruz and Weidenbach Win Marathon: Alejandro Cruz of Mexico and Lisa Weidenbach, who finished fourth in the 1984 and 1988 United States Olympic trials, raced to easy victories in the Chicago Marathon yesterday. Weidenbach, a former Boston Marathon champion, was timed in 2 hours 29 minutes 18 seconds and Cruz in 2:08:57, both personal bests.(AP) Tennis Mansdorf Takes Paris Open: Amos Mansdorf of Israel won the world's richest indoor tennis tournament, beating Brad Gilbert, 6-3, 6-2, 6-3, yesterday in the final of the $1.1 million Paris Open. For his fourth career title, Mansdorf earned $262,000, more than 10 times his best previous tournament paycheck. Gilbert won $131,000, his best payday.(AP) Graf Victor in Straight Sets: Steffi Graf trounced Manuela Maleeva, 6-2, 6-0, yesterday to win the Midland Group championship in Brighton, England, for her 11th title of the season. The $50,000 first prize increased Graf's 1988 earnings past the $1.3 million mark as she extended her winning streak to 44 matches.(AP) Cross-Country Ludwikowski First in 10,000 Meters: Marty Ludwikowski, a former all-American at Manhattan College, was the winner in a time of 32 minutes 27 seconds for 10,000 meters as he led the New York Athletic Club to a successful defense of the team title with 23 points in the Metropolitan Athletic Congress Cross-Country championship at Van Cortlandt Park. Marian Irwin of St. John's University was the women's 5,000-meter winner in 18:44. Dog Show Chihuahua Takes Top Honors: A 4-pound red fawn smooth Chihuahua, Ch. Adams Joy Sundance Kid, owned by Rey and Viola Burgos of Woodside, Queens, was gaited yesterday by Terence Childs to the top honors at the 56th All-Toy Show of the Progressive Dog Club at Loew's Summit Hotel. N.H.L. Sabres 3, Bruins 3: Glen Wesley scored with less than four minutes remaining last night to lift visiting Boston into a tie with Buffalo. The tie enabled the Bruins to extend their unbeaten streak to seven games, four of them victories.(AP) Jets 8, Kings 4: Randy Gilhen's goal snapped a third-period tie as Winnipeg scored six goals in the final period to beat visiting Los Angeles last night. After the game, John Ferguson, general manager and vice-president of the Jets for the last 10 years, was dismissed, said Barry Shenkarow, president of the team. The Jets (3-4-2) are last in the Smythe Division.(AP) Canucks 2, Flames 1: Jim Sandlak's power-play goal with 13:08 to play last night in Vancouver, British Columbia, gave the Canucks their first victory over Calgary since the 1986-87 season.(AP) Blackhawks 5, Oilers 2: Doug Wilson and Dirk Graham scored short-handed goals 34 seconds apart early in the second period last night as visiting Chicago beat Edmonton. (AP)

title: Learning Disabilities and Crime: Struggle to Snap the Link
description: The 40 New York City probation officers, learning about the relationship between juvenile delinquency and learning disabilities, began to shift uncomfortably in their seats. Richard Lavoie, playing the role of stern teacher, began to ask questions so quickly that few had time to think and answer.

title: Political Memo; G.O.P. Makes Reagan Lure Of Young a Long-Term Asset
description: It is said that the future belongs to the young, which gives the Republican Party a lot to look forward to.

title: London Journal; Watch Out, Lager Louts! Here's Sobering News
description: On busy streets, in the subways below and amid the tight, after-work squeeze on commuter trains, a menacing, befuddled and reeling regiment is on the attack.

title: Rams Win, 12-10; End Saints' Streak
description: Jim Everett passed for 243 yards and Mike Lansford kicked four field goals today to give the Los Angeles Rams a 12-10 victory over the New Orleans Saints, snapping the league's longest winning streak.

title: College Football; List of Heisman Candidates May Include a Mountaineer
description: The top of the national rankings underwent a major realignment Saturday with Washington State's 34-30 upset of U.C.L.A. (7-1), which was ranked No. 1 in the news agency polls and No. 2 by The New York Times in its computer ranking.

title: Gibbons, Green To Buy Stake
description: Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen, a merchant banking firm, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $21 a share, or a total of $65 million, for 27 percent of Robert Half International Inc., a large personnel-service organization.

title: Truck Driver Goes on Rampage, Killing One
description: The driver of a tractor-trailer ran at least nine vehicles off the road today, killing one driver, and shot and wounded an officer in a violent spree along 70 miles of Interstate 10, the police said.

title: Von Bulow Furnishings Set Records at Auction
description: A two-day auction of English furniture and paintings, porcelains and silver belonging to Claus and Martha (Sunny) von Bulow ended at Sotheby's on Saturday evening with sales of $11,562,980, $3.5 million above the auction house's high estimate.

title: Dukakis Asserts He Is a 'Liberal,' But in Old Tradition of His Party
description: Michael S. Dukakis dropped his resistance today and accepted the label that Republicans have been trying to pin on him for months. But he defined it in his own terms, declaring, ''I'm a liberal in the tradition of Franklin Roosevelt and Harry Truman and John Kennedy.''

title: Reviews/Theater; Strutting Those 'Fiorello' Tunes
description: As long as those Jerry Bock-Sheldon Harnick songs occupy stage center at the Equity Library Theater, its production of ''Fiorello!'' is a vote-getter. Who can resist ''Politics and Poker'' or ''Little Tin Box,'' as belted by the card players in the clubhouse, not one of whom looks like a song-and-dance man. Along with the rest of the large cast that often covers the oddly gloomy set, however, they have plainly been chosen for their voices; there are enough bad actors on hand to staff Jimmy Walker's City Hall.

title: Marathan; At Starting Line, More Open Lanes
description: When there is fine fall weather the call of the road can be strong. But rain or shine, come next Sunday, if you decide to take a spin through Staten Island you'd better get an early start or wait until afternoon.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addenda
description: * Newsweek will raise its ad rates 4.1 percent with the Jan. 2 issue. Its circulation remains at 3.1 million.

title: New Zealand Inquiry
description: New Zealand's Justice Minister, Geoffrey Palmer, said Friday that he had appointed a panel to investigate whether there were sufficient controls on the New Zealand stock market. Mr. Palmer has expressed worries about the market's practices for some time.

title: The Ghost Maker: A Halloween Tale
description: I live my days in silence, behind the barred windows of this asylum, in a cell of shadows.

title: Review/Chamber Music; New Australian Works
description: ''Terra Australis,'' a local chamber ensemble with links to the Australian musical scene from which some of its members hail, presented six works new to New York at the Asia Society Saturday evening. All six were composed within the past four years, and they suggest that composers Down Under are finding Minimalism and popular music invigorating influences just now. Nothing heard here fit directly into those categories, but peppy, regular rhythms and simple harmonies had a prominence that I don't think one would have found on a similar program 10 years ago.

title: Boxing; Welterweight Class in Chavez's Plans
description: Julio Cesar Chavez has an agenda. That's the word his promoter, Don King, used when he spoke of the boxing future of Chavez after the fighter from Culiacan, Mexico, beat his countryman Jose Luis Ramirez on a technical decision Saturday night at the Hilton Center here.

title: End May Be Drawing Near In Suit on '83 Bond Default
description: The expected $200 million settlement on Monday by 13 utility defendants in the securities-fraud lawsuit involving the Washington Public Power Supply System could mean that the remaining four defendants will also settle quickly. It would halt a trial that began nearly two months ago and end a five-year legal battle over the nation's largest municipal-bond default in history.

title: Algerian Revolution Inspires Freedom Struggles
description: To the Editor:

title: Chile Promotes Forestry Industry
description: Chile has begun to reap the benefits of a forestry planting program that was started in the mid-1970's and is expected to make the country a major exporter of wood and wood products by the mid-1990's.

title: Boston Fed's New Head An 'Eclectic Pragmatic'
description: For Richard F. Syron, it all started in ''Money and Banking'' at Boston College in 1963.

title: Slight Fall in Rates Is Forecast
description: Interest rates on Treasury notes and bonds could move a bit lower, credit market analysts predict, even without the assistance of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: This Week's Election
description: The election in Israel this week has this startling similarity to our own election: swing voters believe what their candidates are saying about each other.

title: Reviews/Dance; Harlem Troupe Celebrates Itself on the Stage
description: Dance Theater of Harlem had two reasons to celebrate on Friday night. Its performance opened its Fourth Community Concert Series, which runs through Nov. 12 at Davis Hall, City College, West 134th Street and Convent Avenue. More important, it began the company's 20th anniversary season. The program offered a sample of the kinds of productions that Dance Theater of Harlem has specialized in for the last two decades.

title: State By State; California Realist Assesses Dukakis
description: No city in America gives its politicians more leeway to do and say what they please than this one, and no politician takes better advantage of his constituents' forbearance than Willie Brown, the Speaker of the California Assembly, who is from San Francisco.

title: A Good Rule Preserved
description: One of the best features of new Federal drug legislation is that in the end it does not water down the exclusionary rule any more. This was unexpected because the Senate and House had each voted for exceptions to the rule, under which courts refuse to admit illegally seized evidence. Somewhere during the reconciliation meetings, both sides called a truce and struck both provisions.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Around New York, They're Singing And Playing the Blues
description: The blues will be all over Manhattan this week, from Greenwich Village to Harlem. Benson & Hedges Blues will present all-star blues and soul concerts this weekend at the Beacon and Apollo Theaters - with such performers as B. B. King, John Lee Hooker, Koko Taylor, Etta James, Albert King and Albert Collins - and Tuesday through Sunday there will be blues shows at the Lone Star Cafe and afternoon and evening performances, workshops and discussions uptown and in midtown.

title: Prejudice on Campuses Is Feared to Be Rising
description: Racist, sexist and anti-Semitic incidents on and near college campuses from Dartmouth to Wisconsin to Stanford this fall have provoked worries by education and civil rights leaders that such acts are on the increase.

title: For Running Mates, Differing Final Roles
description: In the final week of the Presidential election, the Bush and Dukakis campaigns are planning different roles for their running mates.

title: Limon Group Names 2 To Administrative Posts
description: The Limon Dance Foundation has announced the appointment of Rick Reynolds as managing director of the foundation and of Norton Owen as director of the Limon Institute. Mr. Owen has also been named development director for the foundation.

title: Breeders' Cup; Three Stars Will Be Racing For More Than Just a Victory
description: At least nine horses will go to the post for each of the seven Breeders' Cup contests at Churchill Downs Saturday, but three of the races seem to be contests between a horse and a different kind of opponent, the judgment of history.

title: Burmese Leaders Take Steps To Help Private Enterprises
description: Burma's military rulers announced new steps over the weekend to encourage private enterprise in the midst of dismantling the country's 26-year-old socialist system.

title: Browns Stymie Bengals, 23-16
description: As usual, dog biscuits littered Cleveland Stadium today, and several of the 79,147 who kept tossing the real ones wore paper ones on their heads. Others waved placards celebrating their dog defense. And afterward, those in the east end zone nearly fell out of the stands leaping and cheering joyously as a few Browns jogged past them barking, offering thanks for the ruckus.

title: Review/Music; Firkusny Plays Dvorak
description: Rudolf Firkusny has not pursued his career in such a way as to build cult followings or be called a legend in his own time, but it is hard to think of a pianist whose name one would be gladder to find on an evening's program. He played Dvorak's G-minor Concerto, with which he has long been identified, at the Metropolitan Museum on Friday evening, accompanied by the Orchestra of St. Luke's under Karel Husa. The pianist was not in top form technically, and encountered a bit of heavy weather in the finale, but he played with the natural ease of expression that belongs only to performers who have fully absorbed the material they treat.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied-Signal Aerospace Co., Morris Township, N.J., a unit of Allied-Signal Inc., announced that William C. Purple, president of its Defense Systems Co. and an executive vice president of the parent company, will retire at the end of the year.

title: Review/Art; The Flowering of Japan's Daimyo Culture
description: ''Japan: The Shaping of Daimyo Culture 1185-1868'' is one of the most ambitious exhibitions of Japanese art ever held in the United States. It spans 700 years and includes more than 400 works, some of them national treasures that have never before been out of Japan. The exhibition is quiet and discreet, encouraging sustained contact with the objects.

title: Taverns Making Effort to Discourage The Big Drinkers, Through Service
description: The 27-ounce margarita cocktail in a glass resembling a frosted fishbowl is no longer served here at the restaurant-bar where it won fame. Double scotches are out, too. Instead, patrons are politely offered a new nonalcoholic beverage menu.

title: For the Malaysian Chinese, A Year of Disenchantment
description: A year after the leader of his party and six other members of Parliament were detained without trial, Lee Lam Thye is trying to sustain interest in the travails of his political group, the Democratic Action Party, and in the difficulties of the Chinese minority.

title: Bullet-Riddled Bodies Found Dumped in Queens Driveway
description: The bullet-punctured bodies of three men were discovered in the driveway of a Queens apartment building Saturday night, and police investigators were trying to figure out who had dumped them there.

title: U.S. Pact With Abu Dhabi
description: The United States Government-owned Overseas Private Investment Corporation has signed an accord with the United Arab Emirates for protecting overseas investments by Americans from political risks, officials said today.

title: Don't Call the Shroud of Turin a Forgery
description: To the Editor:

title: One More Obstacle Confronts Lalonde
description: NOT long ago, Sugar Ray Leonard, seated ringside at his training camp in Scotrun, Pa., got to his feet to show a visitor his impression of Donny Lalonde, the World Boxing Council light-heavyweight champion.

title: Foreign Writers, Even Nobel Winners, Find Few Outlets
description: MORE books are being translated into English than ever before, but American bookstores, unlike some automobile showrooms, are not likely to become dominated by imports. Indeed, the real problem now is finding bookstores that sell the translations.

title: Strong Quake Shakes Alaska
description: A strong earthquake awakened residents early today, but no damage or injuries were reported, the Alaska Tsunami Warning Center reported. Paul Whitmore, a geophysicist at the center, said the earthquake measured 5.1 on the Richter scale of ground motion and struck at 1:33 A.M., about 60 miles northwest of Homer, in the south central part of the state.

title: Massachusetts Voters Will Decide the Fate of a 1914 Labor Law
description: Unions and contractors in Massachusetts are entangled in a high-stakes fight over a referendum that asks voters to repeal a 74-year-old state law requiring communities to pay union wage rates on public building and maintenance projects.

title: Bridge
description: Four decades ago, the idea of presenting bridge deals through a consistent cast of characters was popularized by S. J. (Skid) Simon in England. He was followed by another Englishman, Victor Mollo, whose death last year brought an end to the series of tales about the Hog, the Rabbit and other denizens of the Griffins Club.

title: 2 Men, 2 Women and 2 Deaths
description: Two men died within a half-hour on Saturday in separate accidents in which they fell from apartment buildings while trying to climb in to see their girlfriends, the police said today.

title: Several Giant Pension Funds Investing in Offer for Nabisco
description: The $2 billion down payment on the $20.3 billion buyout offer for RJR Nabisco Inc. will be provided by the retirement funds of Coca-Cola, Georgia-Pacific and United Technologies; the endowment funds of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Harvard, and the pension funds for state employees of New York, Iowa and Michigan, among others.

title: An Intricate Deal Saves M.T.A. Dollars
description: Rube Goldberg would have loved it: An intricate deal in which the Japanese buy 190 new subway cars from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, lease them back and somehow, some way, everyone comes out ahead.

title: 'Leak' Is an Issue in Aid Scandal
description: The chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee asked the Reagan Administration today to investigate whether Administration officials had leaked classified papers to the authors of a newspaper article describing corruption in a secret United States program to aid Cambodian rebels.

title: Utilities Worried by Decision on Older Coal Plant
description: In a decision dismaying to power companies throughout the country, the Government has told a Wisconsin utility that plans to repair its coal-burning power plant will subject it to the strict air pollution standards that apply to new plants.

title: Sports World Specials; Hurdle of Obscurity
description: Quickly: Name the Olympic champion in the men's 400-meter hurdles?

title: September Tool Orders Fell by 3.4%
description: After a sharp surge in August, orders for American-made machine tools slipped 3.4 percent in September, according to a report scheduled to be released today by the industry's trade association.

title: Metro Matters; Another Detour In Troubled Life: Back to Prison
description: What is to be done with Dwayne Gosso?

title: Finding Dual Causes For an Upbeat Mood
description: Upbeat as Gov. Michael S. Dukakis seems, the reason is not simply the fact that some polls show that Vice President Bush's lead is narrowing. In recent days Mr. Dukakis's wife, Kitty, joined the campaign. Aides say that whenever Mrs. Dukakis joins the candidate, he turns more buoyant.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * China's cabinet, the State Council, has ordered a wide-ranging investigation of market prices and has threatened tough penalties for price gouging, The People's Daily reported yesterday. The newspaper said the main aims would be to insure stable prices for rationed items like grain and cooking oil and steady supplies of vegetables, meat and eggs. The prices of products used by the nation's farmers, like fertilizer and plastic sheeting for protecting crops, will also be monitored. The newspaper did not give details of penalties to be imposed for price gouging but said local mayors would be responsible for insuring stable supplies of goods in local markets.

title: A Sure Sign of Halloween: An Eggy Deluge
description: It's Halloween. It's egg time.

title: Compromise on Jockeys' Pay Could End Strike
description: Officials of Aqueduct Race Track and a jockeys' group confirmed last night that a new two-tiered system of riding fees could be approved today, bringing an end to the 12-day-old strike by more than 30 of New York's regular jockeys.

title: Horse Show; Horse and Rider A Lucky Match
description: The last time Greg Best received a stinging critique of his horsemanship was 10 years ago, the first time Frank Chapot, coach of the United States Olympic jumping team, watched him ride.

title: Bears Fall Victim To Flutie's Passes
description: Doug Flutie threw four touchdown passes, including an 80-yard connection with Irving Fryar on the first play from scrimmage, as the New England Patriots stunned the National Football League's top defense with a 30-7 victory over the Chicago Bears today.

title: Dying Nuclear Plants Give Birth to New Problems
description: An expanding program to decontaminate and decommission radioactive nuclear weapon factories is emerging as another of the enormous costs of producing history's deadliest weapons.

title: Airline Guide Being Sold To Maxwell
description: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation has agreed to sell its Official Airline Guide for $750 million in cash to the British publisher Robert Maxwell, the two parties announced yesterday.

title: Linda M. Ecksmith Is Wed To Peter Charles Farranto
description: Linda Mary Ecksmith, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gene R. Ecksmith of Canton, Ohio, and Peter Charles Farranto, the son of Helen Farranto of Mew Dorp, S.I., and Charles C. Farranto of Willowbrook, S.I., were married yesterday at the Plumbush Inn in Cold Spring, N.Y. Carmine Ricci, a Town Justice of Cold Spring, officiated.

title: Review/Music; John Adams Conducts New and Old Works
description: According to one school of thought, composition is a form of game playing, the object being the discovery of the right balance of sounds and durations for the circumstances at hand. A variant of the game adds the challenge of overcoming, but not abandoning, sets of stylistic strictures.

title: The Race for Congress; Choice in Wisconsin: Rich Is (A)Evil or (B)Good
description: In a state that prides itself on progressive politics and clean government, Herbert Kohl, one of the wealthiest men in Wisconsin, is spending millions of his own dollars to win a seat in the United States Senate.

title: Look Out, Harvard: Here's DePauw
description: Goodbye Harvard.

title: Fore! 18 Holes in Dubai, Then a Day at the Races
description: With grass seed from Georgia and around $10.5 million, the rulers of this emirate on the Persian Gulf have turned the desert green to create what is said to be the only all-grass, 18-hole championship golf course in the Arab Middle East.

title: When Big Salaries Prove Embarrassing
description: Making a populist pitch before blue-collar and farm audiences can prove a little delicate for Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, especially if his supporters are well-paid entertainers.

title: Confusing the Polls And Being Proud of It
description: Tired of polls? And pollsters? And pundits telling us who is going to win before anyone votes?

title: Sports World Specials; Auerbach's Structure
description: Red Auerbach has been the architect behind the raising of 16 National Basketball Association championship banners in the Boston Garden. In another part of Massachusetts today, Auerbach, who has devised the Celtics' blueprint for success, will have his name on a real set of blueprints. He is not the architect, however. Auerbach's name will be on the building.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-11 Four Israeli civilians were killed and eight wounded when a passenger bus was ambushed and attacked with five firebombs in the West Bank city of Jericho, Israelis close to the military said. A1

title: The Race for Congress; In Connecticut, Politics Of Apples and Omelets
description: A Sunday morning late in the campaign found the State Attorney General, Joseph I. Lieberman, at the New Colony Diner in Bridgeport where Eli Rosa was just sitting down to his usual Sunday breakfast: a three-egg omelet with hash browns. The two men had never met.

title: INSIDE
description: Fresh Face in Afghanistan An Afghan official with an independent streak is being promoted by the Soviet Union as a candidate to lead a national unity government. Page A3. New Approach by Jockeys Striking jockeys and Aqueduct officials have agreed on a two-tiered fee system that could bring back regular riders. SportsMonday, page C1. Von Bulow Furnishings Sold Record prices were brought at the auction of furniture, paintings, porcelains and silver of Claus and Martha (Sunny) von Bulow. Page C14. Guilty or Innocent? Did Randall Adams kill a police officer? Despite wide assertions of his innocence, Texas officials are contesting efforts for a new trial. Page A13. Making It Official in Bhutan Because the private ceremony was judged unfit for a king, Bhutan's ruler is marrying his four wives again, this time in public. Page A3.

title: Mary E. Tippett, 83, Thoroughbred Breeder
description: Mary Elizabeth Tippett, an owner and breeder of such racing thoroughbreds as Mr. Gus, Tumbleweed, Pretense and Racing Room, died late Saturday after a long illness at Llangollen Farm, her 4,000-acre estate at Upperville, Va. She was 83 years old.

title: Catholics in Illinois Offering Loans to Farmers
description: Roman Catholics in central Illinois are sending financially troubled farmers a little cash along with their prayers this year.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M.

title: Review/Television; Politics and Pledges,
description: Once again, we have a national election campaign so uninspiring that, at best, only half of the eligible voters will bother to participate. And once again, television is being perceived as the culprit, the machine that reduces everything to simplistic images. The ads with the most emotional clout, evidently, determine the future of our country. But that's only half the truth about television, and it is limited to those areas that can be manipulated by campaign managers - namely, the expensive commercials and the deadening formats of the so-called ''debates.'' These are areas that should have been regulated by law long before now.

title: Sports of The Times; The Jets' Instant Leader
description: HE had joined the Jets only the week before, claimed on waivers after the Pittsburgh Steelers had cut him. He was a stranger in their midst, but sometimes a stranger can see what's wrong quicker than those accustomed to the problems. And the day after the Jets were routed, 28-3, by the New England Patriots in their season opener, Robin Cole, a 33-year-old linebacker with two Super Bowl rings, stood up in the locker room at the weekly ''players only'' meeting.

title: Mary Jo Gallo Is Wed To Bruce Fox on L.I.
description: Mary Jo Gallo, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sullivan A. Gallo of Patchogue, L.I., and Bruce Evan Fox, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Fox of Great Neck, L.I., were married yesterday at the Interfaith Chapel at the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University in Brookville, L.I. The Rev. Edward Roberts, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, assisted by Rabbi Irwin Lowenheim.

title: Battle for Nabisco Is Called Unlikely
description: The prospect of a bidding battle for RJR Nabisco Inc. appeared to diminish over the weekend as the company's financial advisers decided that they were unlikely to match the $20.3 billion that has been offered by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, people close to the situation said.

title: Heavy Schedule of Municipal Financings
description: For investors seeking new tax-exempt issues, the calendar shows an abundance of municipal financings that are tentatively scheduled for this week. A modest amount of corporate debt issues are also ready to come to market this week should market conditions dictate.

title: Friends of Forests
description: Jungle fever is sweeping the nation's capital.

title: Julie Cooper Wed To Donald Spero
description: Julie Cooper, a program analyst in Mayor Koch's office of operations, and Donald Spero, the director of capital budget for the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, were married yesterday at James House in North Tarrytown, N.Y. Dr. Robert L. Berson, the leader of the Ethical Society of Northern Westchester, officiated.

title: The 29-Year Ordeal to Tear Down One Building
description: In 1960, it took five months and $1 million to build a modest one-story building here to process plutonium for the military.

title: Poll Indicates Smaller Lead By Lautenberg
description: As the United States Senate campaign in New Jersey moves into its final phase, Pete Dawkins, the Republican challenger, has reduced the lead held by his opponent, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, according to a poll released yesterday by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University.

title: A Jungle Gym for Adults
description: The idea of a gyroscope large enough for a person to climb inside has taken shape as a new fitness tool. National Survival Games, a company based in New London, N.H., has developed a 9-by-9-foot gyroscope made of tubular steel. Three concentric rings rotate round each other on a stationary frame. The rider fastens his feet into bindings on a base plate at the center of the inner loop. Hand grips are secured to a padded waistband and to the bar overhead. The base plate adjusts to accommodate people of different heights.

title: Your Marathon Countdown
description: TWO days before the 1981 New York City Marathon, Alberto Salazar had lunch at the Carnegie Deli. He ate a mile-high pastrami sandwich, hardly a staple of a runner's diet, and few crumbs were left on his plate. The result? Salazar won the marathon that year, setting a world record.

title: Patient Held in Nurse Slaying
description: A 33-year-old Connecticut man was arrested Saturday and charged with the murder of a Metropolitan Hospital nurse in her East Side apartment on Oct. 19, the police said.

title: Lincoln H. Clark, CARE's Co-Founder, 77
description: Lincoln H. Clark, co-founder of the Cooperative for American Relief Everywhere, died of cancer Friday in his home in Falmouth, Me. He was 77 years old.

title: Not So Exotic, the Jews of Samarkand
description: There were a dozen people, nearly twice as many chickens, a few roosters and a pair of doves waiting for Rabbi Bakhor Kuyenov when he came to work one recent day.

title: Ad-Heavy Giants Fight for Los Angeles Suburbs
description: Twenty years ago, the radically libertarian Orange County Register was demanding an end to taxpayer support for institutions as deeply rooted as public schools, the post office and police departments. Its publisher, R. C. Hoiles, helped make this Southern California county well known for conservative thinking.

title: Wiesenthal Center Honors Reagan for Humanitarianism
description: President Reagan, declaring that ''we must not, we cannot, and we will not'' forget the Holocaust, received the annual Humanitarian Award of the Simon Wiesenthal here tonight in recognition of his ''historic contribution to the cause of world peace.''

title: Claudia Grossman Wed to Aaron Jaffe
description: The wedding of Claudia Leigh Grossman, a lawyer in New York, to Aaron David Jaffe, a civil engineer in New York, took place yesterday at Temple Beth Israel in Niagara Falls, N.Y. Rabbi Samuel Porrath and Cantor Herbert Strauss officiated.

title: Jets Use Turnovers to Top Steelers
description: The Jets today called on their oldest defensive player, one of their youngest, a trick play and some surprises by the special teams to continue their unexpected march toward respectability.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 2 New Print Gimmicks Ready for Consumers
description: Advertising's silly season is upon us, judging from a couple of new gimmicks intended to draw readers' attention to the printed page.

title: Ad About Turmoil in Mexico Seeds a Mystery in Washington
description: A mysterious committee predicts an immiment Communist-inspired insurrection in Mexico, masterminded by a defeated candidate for president of that country. The group is well bankrolled. The warning appears in full-page ads, all paid for in advance, in several of this country's major newspapers.

title: Doron Resheff Is Wed To Karen Joy Lehrman
description: The marriage of Karen Joy Lehrman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert O. Lehrman of New York and Edgewater, N.J., to Doron Resheff, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arie Resheff of Nahariya, Israel, took place yesterday at the Carriage House in Englewood, N.J. Rabbis Daniel S. Wolk and Mark Schneier officiated.

title: Pressure Is on Brazil to Cut Deficit
description: Under attack from labor groups and business organizations, the Brazilian Government is scrambling to find new ways of controlling its huge budget deficit to prevent the economy from being consumed by hyperinflation.

title: Nuclear Reactor Shuts Down
description: The one operating reactor at Three Mile Island automatically shut itself down today for reasons believed to be linked to the plant's non-nuclear turbine system, said Gordon Tomb, a spokesman for the plant operator, GPU Nuclear Corporation. He said no emergency condition existed and said the reactor would remain out of service until an investigation was completed. The plant's other reactor, damaged in an accident in 1979, has never been restarted.

title: N.C.A.A. Panel Checks Sooners
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association Infractions Committee spent much of today reviewing its case against the Oklahoma football program, sources told The Associated Press.

title: Quick Crash Response Praised
description: A Pentagon study has praised the quick and professional response by military medical teams to the air show disaster in August at Ramstein Air Base in West Germany.

title: Paul S. Graziano, 70, a Retired Professor
description: Paul S. Graziano, a retired professor at St. John's University Law School, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Flushing, Queens. He was 70 years old.

title: Builder of People Express Links Failure to Technology
description: In the ''where are they now'' department, Donald C. Burr, the executive who built People Express, is working on a book about his ill-fated airline and also riding the lecture circuit.

title: Work on AIDS and Fatherhood Still Theoretical
description: To the Editor:

title: Bank Board to Alter Its Evaluation Method
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board, beset by criticism that it is the weakest of the agencies regulating financial institutions, has overhauled its system for examining savings and loan institutions.
